column2: Even rabid critics of hightransfer fees were forced to admit today that the [Pound]8,000 ($38,400) paid by Aston Villa to Blackpool for Frank O'Donnell was money well spent.

Sumner Burritt Stiles of 420 Wes 119th Street, New York, a member of the law firm of Dunn Stiles 70 Pine Street, died here today a the home of his son, Russell Stiles from the effects of a stroke suf fered a week ago. He was 87 years old. In addition to his son, daughter, Mrs. Pierre A. Banker also survives.

Major Arthur J. Dalton, ordered deposed as manager of the Veterans Hospital here, where an unmarried nurse has been accused of killing her infant child, asked opportunity today to reply to his critics. Dr.

William E. Hudson, a member of the Chicago Board of Trade since 1895 and a director of the Exchange for nine years during that time, died today in Evanston Hospital at the age of 75. His home was in Wilmette, a suburb.

Disclosure yesterday that the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company had completed arrangements with life insurance companies-for the sale to them of $40,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds and with banks for a $10,000,000 five-year credit struck what was said to be a new high' record for private financing this year.
The Titans of the University of Detroit came from behind with fury today to swamp Tulsa, 39 to 14, in an intersectional football battle played on a gridiron drenched by an allnight rain.

Gains in the first week, compared with last year's opening week, were made by half of the forty-four divisions conducting New York Chapter's Red Cross roll-call, Mrs. David Challinor, roll-call director, reported yesterday to Edward R. Stettinius Jr.,

Despite the fact that the government has refused to admit Jewish refugees before the examination of their cases by the Minister of Justice, frontier police have been authorized to admit the most urgent cases prior to such examination-in the cases of homeless children, for instance.

THE development of public taste where music is concerned is demonstrated impressively by the evolution of the Metropolitan repertory in recent years. Twenty years ago there were usually unpurchased seats for Wagnerian opera and a pair of tickets for a performance of "Tristan und Isolde" could easily go begging.

The kitchen is the "miracle room" of the modern American home. It seems so particularly to those women who remember the days of drudgery when a heavy and cumbersome old coal or wood stove was the main source of heat for cooking;
VISITORS at automobile plants marvel at the precision with which workers on the assembly lines put together the component parts which make a complete automobile.

After five years of observing the system of freshmen under preceptors and of sophomores under tutors, Colgate University officials have found now that the student malcontent who is unable to adjust himself to his environment has been virtually eliminated.

Harry W. Baals, Mayor of Fort Wayne, Ind., which claims to have one of the lowest per capital debt rates in the country, warned Mayors of other cities against a tendency to apply for PWA grants to build useless "doodads" which become financial burdens after their construction, in an Interview yesterday
The Silvermine Music Festival, which was inaugurated in 1937 and held a second time last August at Silvermine, Conn., is to be perpetuated.

WITH the recently issued "Seven Overtures of Beethoven in Score," Books and Music, Inc., of this city inaugurated its International Music Edition, which should prove an estimable addition among American music publications.
Arnold College of New Haven, Conn., scored on a safety in the early min- , utes of play to gain a 2-0 decision over the Bergen County Junior College football team today at Riverview Field.

The crisis in world affairs has greatly increased attendance at those lecture centers in New York that deal with social problems. Disjointed lectures and debates are being discarded in favor of lecture courses covering many aspects of a subject over a period of several months.

Brooks Mendell, chairman of the American Business and Professional Committee for Tolerance, presented yesterday to Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of staff of the Cuban Army, a silver tea set in appreciation of the Cuban leader's pledge of a haven for refugees from Germany.
" Look here, Red," Frank Case said to Sinclair Lewis, "in the space of ten minutes I can set down on paper suggestions enough to keep two men busy for days.

Robert T. Bowman, president of the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce, announced today that the chamber would undertake a survey which "will seek to analyze the effect upon New Jersey's diversified industries" of the new trade agreements with Great Britain and Canada.

Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Beverley of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Nevin Beverley, to E. Frantz Hershey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Frantz Hershey of Hershey, Pa.
Gross valuation of New York State's public school buildings, land and equipment reached an all-time peak of $1,038,826,367 during 1936-37, the Education Department has revealed.

FOR the third time the Nobel Prize for literature has come to America. Eight years ago the committee awarded the honor to Sinclair Lewis. six years later to Eugene O'Neill. Now it comes to the woman who made China a living reality for novel readers.

Charles Berkell, veteran of more than a half century on the stage, died today of a heart ailment at his home here at the age of 70. He was born in Boston and joined a theatrical troupe at the age of 12, performing as a boy magician.
The engagement of Miss Gertrude Lober, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Lober of Castle Point Terrace, Hoboken, N. J., to Saul Sperling of this city has been announced by her parents.

THE season of early dusks and frequent storms will soon be driving the amateur photographer indoors. But there, unless he is sadly lacking in imagination, he will not find it necessary to abandon his hobby.

CHRISTMAS is rapidly appreaching, and this department wants, before it is too late, to urge shoppers to look over the new assortment of greeting cards issued by the American Artists Group, Inc. It is announced that twenty-five additional names have been added to the roster of a group that for several years now has successfully published Christmas cards reproducing American works of art.

Playing before a rain-soaked crowd of 4,000 on muddy Patterson Field, the Drexel Dragons swamped the Ursinus Bears today, 25-0. The defeat sent the Bears into last place in the Eastern Pennsylvania conference race and gave the Dragons their first Conference victory.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor announced today that they would attend the Thanksgiving Day service in the American Church in Paris Thursday.

The majority of parterre boxes have been taken for the benefit matinee performance of "Tristan und Isolde" on Dec. 2 at the Metropolitan Opera House. The matinee has been taken over to raise funds for the Manhattan School of Music, which for many years was the Neighborhood Music School.
Herbert T. Wade, retired editor and author, has been elected president of the Society of Older Graduates of Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.

The Flushing High School football team defeated its time-honored rival, Jamaica, 6-0, yesterday at Memorial Field in Flushing before 4,500. Late in the first quarterback Donald Welch recovered a Jamaica fumble on its 30-yard stripe and this paved the way for the only touchdown.
SWINGING over the trails of the Palisades Interstate Park at Bear Mountain, hikers may stumble upon huge rock piles, rusted rails, water-filled shafts and drill-pocked caverns.
A determined Florida eleven found Grant Field's mud to its liking today and fought a favored Georgia Tech football team to a 0-0 tie.

Poking fun at some of Manhattan's foibles, including the "big broadcast" industry, and taking a slap at the "big three" European dictators, "All Around the Town," fifty-first annual production of the Mask and Wig Club. University of Pennsylvania, played before nearly 6,500 persons at matinee and evening performances here yesterday.
After attacking many things in the United States the Voelkischer Beobachter today launched an attack on the "American girl cult," which it contends makes the American man ridiculous.
" How Social-Minded Is the Social Fraternity?" will be the theme of the thirtieth national interfraternity conference on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday at the Hotel Commodore.
Baltimore's first team lost one of the closest games In the Southeastern field hockey tournament today when it dropped a 3-to-1 decision to the Philadelphia second squad.

ONE of the more promising items in recent cinema news was the report that Leslie Howard will soon be forming his own individual producing unit in association with Walter Futter to make his own pictures in England with American financial backing.
Toward the end of the World War a Democratic political machine known as the "clan O'Connell" began to emerge in Albany, busy river port,
Miss Jane Leiper, daughter of George Neville Leiper of Westleigh, Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Robertson F. Smith of Mount Airy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence R. Smith of Boston.

Illumination, both by day and by night, at a minimum level of "sixfoot candles for ordinary work and ten-foot candles for fine work such as reading," should be provided as a minimum standard in low-cost homes, a survey prepared by the United States Public Health Service declares, according to Science Service.
ROME. THE Ministry for Popular Culture has announced the coordinated bills for the Winter seasons in Italy's leading opera houses. The outstanding works are as follows:
Carrying out the plan for the organization of a cooperative to run the Greenbelt stores, residents of the government project in Maryland have placed subscriptions for 217 shares of stock at $10 each,

The refugee organization operated here since April by Mr. van Gildemeester, Netherland philanthropist, and Arthur Kuffler, a baptized Jew well known in British and American cotton circles, is resuming its work after temporary control of its funds by the government and cessation of the delivery of emigration permits.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday over a range of 5 points to end unchanged to a loss of 4 points. Under steady covering by trade interests, holders of December contracts were able to liquidate at a premium of better than 55 points above the July and about 85 points over the October position.

THE long headache that the Philippines turned out to be was for several years accompanied by shooting and knifing pains. These are described at some length by Mr. Hurley in his informal history of the Philippixie Constabulary, and in it there is many a story of shooting and knifing.

The marriage of Miss Corinne M. MacLennan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Duncan MacLennan of Durham, N. C., to Frank T. Kennedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Kennedy of Upper Montclair, N. J., took place here yesterday morning in the rectory of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle.
King Carol and Crown Prince Michael of Rumania were cheered by a crowd tonight when they arrived here from Brussels on an official visit.

A recent study by the division of research and statistics of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board revealed that life insurance companies invested 3.27 times as much money in new mortgage loans upon non-farm homes in 1937 as in 1935.

Philip A. Benson, new president of the American Bankers Association and president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, is to be entertained at a "homecoming luncheon" by the Brooklyn Trust Company in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn on Nov. 29.
A sixteen-game schedule has been arranged for Susquehanna University's basketball' team this season with twelve of the contests to take place in the new Alumni Gymnasium.

Buck Miller, one of nineteen men indicted in connection with racial disorders at Smyrna a month ago today was sentenced to a year in prison for "chasing Negroes and leading others -in the chase." Superior Judge J. H. Hawkins imposed the sentence.

Andrew Bachmann, who has been with the Kresge Department Store, Newark, for the last ten years, has been appointed advertising manager of the store, it was announced yesterday by Hugh E. Barnes, president.

In delaying deportation proceedings against Harry Bridges, West Coast C. I. O. leader, the Labor Department is following the customary legal procedure in cases where a similar case is moot in the courts, Secretary Perkins informed Stephen F. Chadwick, National Commander of the American Legion, in a letter made public today.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

MEMBERS of the National Book Council assembled in cheerful mood for their annual meeting. The Poet Laureate has consented to become their president; the sales of book tokens have passed the million mark,

President Roosevelt called on the Amerlean people today to celebrate Thursday the fact that this country is living in peace and understanding with its neighbors and has seen the world escape from the horrors of a general war. The text of the Proclamation was as follows:
" Judgment Day," by Elmer Rice, a play dealing with fascist justice, will be presented at Swarthmore College, the evening of Dec. 3, by the Little Theatre Club.
DITHERS AND JITTERS" is another one-woman show, a successor to "Excuse It, Please," by Cornelia Otis Skinner. As in her acting,
Six convicts escaped from State prison tonight after overpowering a trusty, sawing through a prison window bar and climbing over the prison wall with the help of two large beams.

The Pine Mountain Settlement School of Harlan County, Ky., which will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary tomorrow evening at the Town Hall, presents an example of progressive educational methods projected against a background of remote hill farms and coal mining villages.

Dr. Bayard Dodge, president of the American 'Jniversity at Beirut, Syria, arrived Friday on the Hamburg American liner Hansa for a four-month stay accompanied by Mrs. Dodge. He will stop at his mother's home, Mrs. Cleveland Dodge at Riverdale.
The Wheeling Lake Erie Railroad is seeking bids for the construction of 400 hopper cars, according to Railway Age. The Cornwall Railroad has ordered twenty ore cars from the Bethlehem Steel Company.

A major problem of the makers of modern central heating and airconditioning systems is to shift some of the burden of the care of machinery to the householder by teaching him to manage his equipment himself, L. R. Taylor,

The annual convention of the American Bankers Association, by bringing together some 3,000 or more bankers from every section of the country, affords each year an opportunity for a broad sampling of the temper and opinions of the country's financiers.

A "rising tide of anti-Semitism" in the United States was blamed in part today before the House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities on the large number of organizations in this country which agitate such sentiments and in part on the effects of "the situation in Europe."

A campaign to urge consumers to buy American-made goods was started today at the annual meeting of members of the Woolen Textile Overseers Association. The overseers adopted resolutions pledging members to solicit the support of the estimated 200,000 persons in New England dependent upon the woolen industry.

In 250 telegrams sent to branch chairmen of the Committee on Human Relations of the National Council of Women, he reaction of women as individuals and as organized units to the recent persecution in Germany, is being canvassed. Hundreds of replies have been received at the national office in Rockefeller Center. Many of them indicate that messages in still greater number have been forwarded to the Department of State.

The Republit can sweep in New England is subject to certain discounts, in the view of general observers. Republicans will now hold all six Governor ships, eight instead of six Senatorships, and twenty-two instead of fourteen of the twenty-nine seats in the Lower House.

Twenty-one indictments returned ten weeks ago against Mayor S. Davis Wilson, charging him with misbehavior in office, failure to suppress gambling and unlawful demotion of policemen and firemen, were quashed today by Judge Harry S. McDevitt in Common Pleas Court.
Aboard S. S. QUIRPGUA. WHEN all the color has disappeared from the trees in Central Park, and mince pie makes its gloomy bow upon the menu of our favorite restaurant,
Staunton Military Academy defeated Bordentown Military Institute, 12-8, today in a North-South football game played in Temple Stadium. Staunton thus finished two consecutive seasons undefeated.

On the Westport-Wilton Road opposite the curving lane which leads motorists to the new Merritt Parkway, a Connecticut dwelling remindful in many ways of the old Pennsylvania country homes hag just been completed and will be occupied by a real estate man as a combined residence and office.

A series of luncheons, to be held in the Caprice Room of the Hotel Weylin, is now being arranged to aid the work of the Hospital Occupation Committee of the New York City Visiting Committee. The first of these events will be held Dec. 12, under the chairmanship nf Mrs. Charles Manton Richter.
What is in debate these days in France is, broadly speaking, whether the individual citizen should serve the community or the community in the form of the State should maintain the citizenry.

The foreign exchange market continued to weaken in yesterday's short period of trading. The pound sterling fell 3-16 cent to $4.70 1-16, making a drop of 2 15-16 cents in the week, and the franc went down 1/3 point to 2.63 cents, a loss of 1 5/8 points in the week.

A recent proposal discussed in Administration quarters to divert some of the Works Progress Administration program to the field of national defense raises a series of important problems which must be overcome before such a program can go Into effect, as well as numerous questions as to how the WPA can be employed in many of the most important activities.
Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corportion, the principal holding company affected by TVA competition with the private power business in the Tennessee Valley,

Hundreds of racegoers rushed to the rainswept rail today to get closer to one of the bitterest stretch duels in Bowie history, a race that ended in a dead heat and in time which menaced the record for the Prince George Autumn Handicap.

The Brooklyn Dodgers, still clinging to a hope of winning the Eastern championship of the National Football League, will have that hope either blasted or strengthened today when the Chicago Bears visit Ebbets Field for a game that should come close to attracting a capacity crowd.

Santa Clauses are waiting in the wings of the department store toy shows, ready to tie on their whiskers and emerge to amuse the children. In the last few days the toys have been assembled and the excitement is about to begin.

The fast-skating New York Rovers will take on the Hershey (Pa.) Cubs at Madison Square Garden in an Eastern Hockey League clash, the feature of an amateur doubleheader, this afternoon. In the opening contest on the program the Stock Exchange Brokers will meet the Sands Point Tigers in a Metropolitan League engagement.
Mrs. Jane Adelaide Hitchcock Hotaling, the widow of George Hotaling, lawyer, died Friday night in her home at 640 Park Avenue after an illness of several months.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Jackson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George G. Jackson of this city, to Robert Brodhead Litch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Litch of Montclair, took place this evening at the Jackson home.
Captain Jules Chabot, veteran shipping master of the French Line and captain of the liner Ile de France, took his ship out of New York-Harbor for the last time yesterday.

Robert H. Armstrong, New York realty man, yesterday issued his annual list of suggested reading matter on realty topics. His citation of the "ten best" volumes of the year in this field embraced the following books:

Italy's new "racial" laws, expected to reduce most of Italy's Jewish breadwinners to the position of small tradesmen, are said to have resulted in the discharge of 15,000 Jews from government and private jobs in the past few days.
The renting department of the Franklin E. Tyrrell organization in Forest Hills reports that renting has been very active since Oct. 1 for all types of apartments.

Rural newspaper women will compete with women in the city field in the first contest sponsored by the two-year-old National Federation of Press Women of which Mrs. Joseph E. Goodbar of New York City is president.
A special issue of The Montclarion, student newspaper of the Montclair State Teachers College, will be published on Wednesday to mark the publication's tenth anniversary.

Mr. and Mrs. William Marshall Bullitt of Louisville, Ky., and Stockbridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nora Iasigi Bullitt, to Eugene Walter Leake Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Walter Leake of 21 East Sixty-sixth Street, formerly of Montclair N. J.

Johnny Broaca, the pitcher who two years ago became the first ball player on record to walk out on an almost certain world series cut, was sold yesterday on waivers by the Yankees to the Indians, Business Manager Ed Barrow announced.

Manuscripts of Professor Albert Einstein and Dr. Thomas Mann will be auctioned at a book auction dinner for the benefit of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the Committee for Christian German Refugees on Thursday evening, Dec. 8. at the Hotel Plaza.

The police still were without clues last night in the murder of John F. O'Hara, 26-year-old investigator in the municipal department of Dun and Bradstreet, who was shot to death Friday evening at the entrance to his Queens home.
The Farm Colony on Staten Island, a city home for the aged, will receive a WPA Federal Art Project mural on Tuesday, it was announced yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Roy Augustus Barnard of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Elizabeth Barnard, to George Day Blakeslee, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Hubbard Blakeslee, also of Worcester.

An agreement providing for arbitration of all disputes, with strikes outlawed except for violation of the impartial chairman's decisions, was made public yesterday by the Fur Merchants Employers Council and the Fur Merchants Employes Union, Local 64, of the International Fur Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate.

A warning that November and December, with their numerous holidays, long hours of darkness and bad driving conditions, have become an annual bugaboo to drivers and those interested in promoting highway safety was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council in an effort to continue the good safety record set so far this year.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Nelva M. Weber of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Weber of Arrowsmith, Ill., to Joseph M. Sammataro, also of New York. The wedding will take place on Dec. 24.
With less than two minutes before the final gun, University of Delaware made 2 points on a safety for the only score in its football game today against Washington College.
A foreman in a silk mill, Luis Jacome, today killed his employer, a Swiss engineer, Walter Kagi. This is the third killing of an employer by a workman in Mexico City recently.

PHILADELPHIA. MAPPED in 1934 and opened experimentally about sixteen months later, the Horse-Shoe Trail, winding between Manada Gap and Valley Forge, Pa., was completed recently and now is undergoing practical tests by riders and hikers.

Three building plots, averaging about 17,000 square feet, in the Round Hill Road section, known as Berkley Hills, adjoining Scarsdale, Westchester County, have been purchased by the Taunton Construction Company of Scarsdale from the Berkley Hills Corporation.
In a thrilling battle today the Haverford College soccer team defeated their traditional rivals, Swarthmore, 4 to 3, for their first victory in four years.

Moses Shapiro, an attorney, took office yesterday as impartial chairman for labor relations in the scrapiron and steel industry of this city. Under an agreement between the New York chapter of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel and the Waste Material Workers Union, Local 1,120. an A. F. of L. affiliate,
IT takes unusual courage to discuss the puzzling character of the passage of time. It matters not whether the discussion is ponderous or light, scholarly or popular.

Istanbul paid its last tribute to Kemal Ataturk today at a religious service. The body was then placed aboard a battleship, whence it started its journey to Angora, where the funeral services will be held Monday.
The seven-room English-style cottage at 108-25 Sixty-seventh Avenue in the Sussex Homes development at Forest Hills, L. I., has been purchased by Joseph P. Frank of Philadelphia.

Substantiation of allegations by Brock Pemberton, theatrical producer, that "crooked people" in the theatre are working against the success of the ticket code, was requested yesterday by Gustave A. Gerber, general counsel

On the ground that the right of minorities to free speech must be defended, "however objectionable their views," the American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it had offered aid to German-American Nazis in two suburban cases.
The national tournament of the United States Field Hockey Association will start this week at the Merion Cricket Club, Haverford, Pa. PIF will begin on Thanksgiving Day and end on Sunday.
Muhlenberg scored its fifth straight triumph today by turning back the MIoravian College Greyhounds, 8 to 0, in a rain-drenched football game before a slim crowd.

The National Association of Better Business Bureaus, through H. J. Kenner, chairman of its committee on cooperation with official and voluntary agencies, yesterday issued a statement approved by its board of governors condemning
Burns P. Hodgman, banker, lawyer and president of The Rumford Press, died tonight in a hospital after an appendectomy. He was 63 years old.
The lower house of the Czechoslovak Parliament voted autonomy for Slovakia and Carpatho-Ukraine [Ruthenia] today amid foreign reports of a revolt in the latter province.
In the seventy-second game of the traditional series that goes back for more than half a century, Lafayette turned back Lehigh on the muddy turf of Fisher Field today by 6 to 0.

William Randolph Hearst's historical blue Staffordshire ware and early American furniture realized $80,947, it was announced yesterday at the close of the three-session auction which was held Thursday, Friday and yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.
Coach Pit Lepine, seeking to bolster a rookie club which has won but a single game in six starts, announced tonight he had acquired two more National League veterans for the New Haven Eagles

Cheaper gasoline with higher efficiency will soon be produced for motorists by means of the Houdry catalytic process for refining crude oil, the American Petroleum Institute was told this week at its annual meeting here.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has set Jan. 4 for public hearings on a plan of reorganization for the Erie Railroad Company. The proposals were filed by a committee representing institutional holders of refunding and improvement mortgage bonds of the railroad.

THERE are breeding farms in the West where only pedigreed, pure - blooded Herefords are raised to grade up the lean, long-horned wild cattle of Texas to make great herds with all the Hereford virtues of size, stamina, gentleness and quality.

Four hundred costumed marchers, six bands, fifteen floats and five helium-filled comic balloons will make up the annual Thanksgiving Day Parade of R. H. Macy Co., it was announced yesterday. The procession will start from 106th Street and Central Park West at 1 P. M. on Thursday, go south to Columbus Circle and then down Broadway to the store at Thirty-fourth Street.
Rain and mud meant nothing to Bucknell's Bisons today as they trampled George Washington under a 16-to-0 score to end their season with a record of five victories against two defeats.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bachrach of 155 Riverside Drive of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Bachrach, to Dr. Stanley Jay Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Coodman of Jersey City.

Plans for a new group of twentynine dwellings in the State Homes development on Seventeenth Avenue, between Sixty-sixth and Sixtyseventh Streets, Brooklyn, were filed last week by the State Construction Company, Paul Futterman, president.
Mrs. Frank O'Brien of Woodbridge has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Teresa B. O'Brien, to Anthony S. Gadek Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony S. Gadek of this place.

Work is progressing rapidly on the construction of the first twenty-seven units in the Delano Park development under construction on the site of the former Belmont estate at Hempstead, L. I., and excavation on the second unit is under way.
The government began construction today on a $10,000,000 airport here intended to be the equal of any in the world.
A shot fired a fortnight ago-in Paris set up reverberations that last week were felt around the world. That shot had been the signal for the worst antiSemitic disorders known in the Nazi Third Reich.
THE Yonkers Symphony Orchestra, under J. Leonard Bauer, will give the first of its three annual concerts Dec. 1 in Yonkers, N. Y., with Georgia Graves, contralto, as soloist.

One of the first of the major items in repairing the September hurricane damage on the south shore of Long Island and realigning the popular inland waterway west of the Shinnecock Canal will have a public hearing Tuesday morning at 11:30 o'clock in the Community House at Quogue. Major J. F. C.

More officers and more enlisted men, a continuation of the navy's expansion and replacement program for combatant ships, new auxiliaries, more aircraft tenders, adequate shore base facilities for patrol planes and a modern merchant marine were asked in the annual report today of Secretary of the Navy Swanson.

The gridiron forces of the University of Buffalo closed a poor season with a victory today at Rotary Field, pounding Rensselaer Tech on soggy turf for a 26-to-7 triumph with one of the best displays of power shown by the Bulls this season. The victory was Buffalo's second of the season.

The Suffolk County Republican organization held a dinner tonight at the Timber Point clubhouse of the Suffolk County Republican Club in celebration of its victories in the recent election, with more than 500 persons attending.
BOOKMAN: The Canadian Association for Adult Education listened last week to the Dominion's Governor General, Lord Tweedsmuir. He had a confession to make.

The Japanese military spokesman said last night that the possibility that foreign merchant ships would trade with Chinese guerrillas was one of the deterrents to reopening the Yangtze River to third party vessels.
The Supreme Court considered today whether to review a test of the right of an employer to discharge sit-down strikers.

WHEN Samuel Goldwyn first drafted production plans for "The Cowboy and the Lady," he plotted a light drawing-room drama. It was to have sidelights of Western action--and a slight dash of the wide-open ranges.

Miss Mary Jane Pelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jeremiah Pelley, was married tonight to Willem Dirkse-van-Schalkwyk, formerly an attache of the legation in Washington of the Union of South Africa, and now of the office in Ottawa, Ont., of its accredited representative in Canada.

Transparent, flexfore, moisture resistant sheets and films that look like cellophane and are usable for the same purposes can be made from starch, beans and seaweed, according to four patents (Nos. 2,137,168 to 2,137,171, inclusive) granted here to Harold A. Levey of New Orleans, La.

President Roosevelt in his Thanksgiving Day proclamation yesterday asked the nation's prayers for "unfortunate people in other lands who are in dire distress" and there was indication that he considered this problem the major issue in the world.

Because the German Lloyd passenger-freight ship Weser failed to hoist the United States flag when she docked here, sixty longshoremen walked off the job of unloading in a five-minute protest strike today.
The wildfowlers on Barnegat Bay seem to have made up for lost time during the past few days, for ,many reports have come In on limit bags.

Large American funds are still tied up in Germany. Since Austria and economically important parts of Czechoslovakia have been added to the Reich the volume of these blocked funds has increased considerably. The question how to liquidate or utilize these holdings is a difficult problem for the owners.

The university administration and the student governing body of Temple University joined forces today to clear the way for a "talent tournament," regarded as one of the most important student activities of the school year.

Adolf Vogel, the Metropolitan bass-baritone, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. In his native city, Munich, Mr. Vogel, who began his musical career as a violinist, was for some time the concertmaster of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, so that when he subsequently took up singing it was but natural that his vocal efforts should display the sound musicianship that marked them yesterday evening.
THERE used to be a man in Marlboro, Conn., named Jonathan Kilbourne, and he was something of an inventor, not unlike a good many of his fellows in the "land of steady habits."

Indiana University has gained its, sixth successive cross-country running championship of the Big Ten Conference. The Hoosier team was first in a four-mile meet at Purdue University yesterday with 30 points. Mel Trutt of Indiana finished in 20 minutes 11.8 seconds for individual honors.

South Carolina's invasion of the North in an attempt to spoil Fordham's perfect record against Southern teams came to naught yesterday as the Gamecocks were set back, 13--0, in the mud and mire of a dismal day at the Polo Grounds.
Mrs. Thomas F. Casey gave a luncheon yesterday at Hampshire House for Miss Elizabeth Joan Petri, debutante daughter of Mrs. James Graham Petri of Brooklyn.

With all the scoring confined to the second half, the Thomas Jefferson High School soccer team vanquished Stuyvesant, 2-1, for the City P. S. A. L. championship yesterday at Crotona Park in the Bronx. Outplayed during most of the game, the Brooklyn forces struck twice within five minutes to overcome the 1-0 lead Stuyvesant had gained early in the half.

Recent events in Palestine and Central Europe, and a program for preserving democratic rights in America will form the centers of discussion at the annual convention of the Junior Hadassah, opening Thursday in the Hotel William Penn, Pittsburgh, Pa.

With a few small companies leading the way, it now appears that an important proportion of the steel industry will file briefs in opposition to the minimum wage standards decreed on Nov. 5 by the Department of Labor for companies bidding for government contracts, as provided in the Walsh-Healey act.

Columbia's luck kept pace with the weather yesterday. Both were pretty bad. The ill-starred Lions had another typical Light Blue day against Syracuse before 20,000rainsoaked and bedraggled spectators at Baker Field and wound up on the short end of a 13-to-12 score.
The U. S. S. Phoenix, newest of American light cruisers, was anchored in the Hudson River yesterday off Fifty-ninth Street for a week-end visit.

With the price of prime United States grade A turkey set yesterday by a leading chain store at 33 cents a pound for Thanksgiving buying and with most vegetables, fruits and butter cheaper than they were a year ago, housewives are not going to have to strain their budgets heavily to provide Thursday's feast.

The United States and Russia remained the only two great world powers not recognizing the conquest of Ethiopia when Andre FrancoisPoncet, the new French Ambassador, presented his credentials to Victor Emmanuel as King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia today.

THE most important collection of United States stamps ever to be sold outside of this country will be auctioned in London on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, and the fact that these postal treasures, estimated to be worth more than $100,000, are being disposed of abroad is deplored by numerous American collectors on the theory that the large majority of the wealthier philatelists interested especially in United States issues are Americans.

The Eastern and Western divisional leaders of the National Football League will meet at the Polo Grounds this afternoon when the New York Giants oppose the Green Bay Packers before an expected crowd of more than 50,000 in the most important professional engagement of the season to date.

In the former Austrian city of Vienna, Fabian Greif was a prosperous wholesale grocer with two robust sons, aged 10 and 5. With the recent turn of events Mr. Greif decided to send his children to the United States, even though he and his wife could not accompany them.
Philanthropy is the keynote of national sorority activity, according to a recent survey of the sororities affiliated with the Pan-Hellenic Association at Hunter College.

Everett E. Worrell, superintendent of elementary education, Virginia Department of Education, died today at his home here at the age of 71. Mr. Morrell was a native of Carroll County, Va., a graduate of the College of William and Mary, and had been associated with the State Education Department for twenty-nine years.

Amid the approval of many, the disapproval of others and the indifference of most, Finance Minister Paul Reynaud has ruled that from the end of next year the French national lottery will be suppressed.

ON Thursday, Dec. 8, a Book Auction Dinner will be held at the Hotel Plaza, New York City, for the benefit of the Joint Distribution Committee and the American Committee for Christian German Refugees, of which Thomas Mann is honorary chairman.

ARMED with a case of samples and at least fifteen pounds of scrapbook telling all about himself, Willys De Mond ("Willys of Hollywood"), who says he is the most important stocking stylist in the film industry, left New York for the Coast a few days ago after weeks of intense concentration on the stocking requirements of Ginger Rogers for RKO's forthcoming production.

HISTORIANS of the Constitution and its interpreters commonly divide into two schools of thought. First, there is the group which sees judges acting as automatons of justice in a vacuum, swayed by no breezes of passion, personal background and prejudice, or pressures of popular will.
President Anastasio Somoza, in a statement to the foreign press regarding newspaper reports that he plans to go to Washington, says:

Three retail committees which will begin an immediate investigation of the possibilities of increasing cotton consumption through the normal channels of business and trade as an aid to the Department of Agriculture in solving the cotton surplus problem were appointed yesterday by Saul Cohn,

-Centenary, led by its stellar back, Weenie Bynum, crushed Depaul of Chicago, 48 to 0, today before 6,000 fans. Whitehurst, fullback, started the touchdown parade near the end of the first quarter, when he plunged over.

Army carried its objective today in its first invasion of Palmer Stadium as the cadets overpowered their foe in rain and the mud to register their initial victory over the Tiger in nine meetings. The score was 19--7.

The Finance and War Ministries, it is unofficially announced, have decided to invoke the much-disputed Article 11 of the National Mobilization Law, which authorizes the government to limit the dividends and profits of all Japanese businesses.
The names of presidents elected by five societies of Georgian Court College and the council members of a sixth campus club were made public today by school officials.
Canada and the twenty LatinAmerican republics could contribute more than a million trained naval craft, to the mutual defense of the Western Hemisphere, which President Roosevelt has envisaged.

More than $11,000,000 was paid during the last fiscal year from the pension and relief funds of twentyfour of the principal Protestant denominations in the United States and Canada, the Y. M. C. A. and the Y. W. C. A. to beneficiaries including retired ministers and their widows and orphans, according to a report made to the twenty-fourth annual Church Pensions Conference, meeting last week in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Members of the Connecticut Farms, N. J., Chapter of the Colonial Daughters of the Seventeenth Century will unveil a tablet in honor of the pioneers who settled the town at ceremonies this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock in the Old First Presbyterian Church. Mrs. John Foster McMillan is president of the chapter.

On their way to a city clinic for their weekly treatment, seven crippled children and the driver of the automobile in which they were riding were drowned today when the road gave way beneath the car and it plunged into a mine cave hole, filled with water, in Wilkes-Barre township.

Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, warned the broadcasting industry tonight that it must operate in the public interest if it wished to maintain its favored position.
Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran ordered Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday to double immediately the number of summonses served for overtime parking in the city streets.

LAKELAND, Fla. A SCHOOL for Florida's Semi nole Indians, recently opened at Brighton at their request, is a significant monument marking a new attitude of confidence on the part of these natives, who, for more than a century, have been driven farther and farther into the Everglades swamp.
The Postoffice Department suggested bigger, even if not better, Christmas greeting cards today.

Oklahoma's football powerhouse, short circuited on the ground by the brilliant defense play of Iowa State eleven, took to the air today and scored a 10-0 victory which gave the Sooners their first Big Six championship.

Applications for insurance of mortgages under the FHA plan have been coming into the New Jersey office in such volume since the passage of the amendments last February that the amount of cases handled during the year 1938

In a speech in which she stressed the need for courage and determination to know facts "before being swept one way or another," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday defended the World Youth Congress against charges that it was communistic. She spoke at the annual luncheon of the New York branch of the American Association of University Women at the Hotel Astor.
Local traction issues were the only ones to emerge from a narrow price range and featured an otherwise dull and colorless session yesterday of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange.

With the filing of a medical examiner's verdict that Elizabeth Dorr, 23-year-old Smith College graduate, was a "suicide by carbon monoxide gas poisoning," police Captain Danel F. McCarthy tonight announced that the case was closed. While expressing "surprise," Dr.

A recrudescence of Soviet-Japanese friction is being brought about by the Soviet's cancellation, effective Jan. 1, of three fishing grounds in the Sea of Okhota managed by the Nichiro Fishery Company and a reported Soviet border crossing in the Hunchun district.
Interest in herbs and herb gardening has increased tremendously in the past decade, and today there are few real garden lovers who can resist the lure.
A new organization, the Jacobus Club, has been formed at Stevens Institute of Technology and will hold its first general meeting Wednesday at 11:30 A. M.

More than 500 undergraduates, faculty and guests attended the second annual concert and dance of the Barnard College and Columbia University glee clubs last night in the Hotel Biltmore. Willard Rhodes of the Department of Music at Columbia led the two groups in a program of classical and modern songs.

Despite C. I. O. victories in 76.9 per cent of its contests with the American Federation of Labor under the National Labor Relations Board, the board's policy has favored the A. F. of L. rather than discriminated against it, according to the Columbia Law Review.

LAKELAND, Fla. A HINDU temple, brought in 239 pieces from Benares, India, holy city of Hinduism, has just been erected in the midst of the sixty-acre citrus grove campus of Florida Southern College, overlooking Lake Hollingsworth.

Little Sal Di Yeso, plunging quarterback of the White Plains high school football team, may grow up to become one of Uncle Sam's finest mail carriers, for today he most assuredly lived up to that famous motto chiseled on the facade of the New York Postoffice.

A colony of devout German refugees, whose communal life recalls Brook Farm and other experimental American settlements in the days before the Civil War, has recently been rediscoveredleading a frugal and hard-working existence in the Cotswolds.

Science playing the role of a modern Joshua has devised a method whereby life can be commanded to stand still in a latent state in which no change can take place for tens of thousands of years, it was reported here today before the closing sessions of the annual general Autumn meeting of the American Philosophical Society, founded by Benjamin Franklin in 1727.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced that foreclosures on city and town property during September were 21.7 per cent less than for the corresponding month of last year.

The Centre Club, 120 Central Park South, will be the sponsor of a . piano concert by Carol Moorland of New Orleans at the club at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon for the benefit of the annual Christmas party for the children of the Madonna Settlement House on Cherry Street.

Effective solution of many problems affecting both retailers and manufacturers was seen here yesterday as likely to result from the formation last week of the new ready-to-wear group for buyers within the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Word received by the American Committee for Relief in Czechoslovakia from American observers in Prague indicates that the Czechs are concentrating on problems of reconstruction and are not "crushed or dispirited," it was announced yesterday by the committee.

Almost 400 persons perished in explosions and a resulting fire in a munitions plant in a Barcelona suburb yesterday, according to travelers entering France today. No word of the disaster has been allowed by the Loyalist authorities to come over the news wires from Spain.
Mr. and Mrs. John Lewis Montgomery and Miss Florence Wardwell have returned from Oyster Bay and are at 108 East Eighty-second Street for the Winter.

Gradually, but very completely, the flower borders have driven the old-fashioned vegetable patch from the home plot. This, it has seemed to me, is greatly to be regretted. Only on the very smallest of places is it actually true that there is "no room for vegetables."
To maintain the services offered to members of the Art Workers Club for Women, a benefit bazaar and fashion show will be held on Dec. 1 at the Pierre.

ONE of the diverting and interesting shows that opened last week was that of oils and gouaches by C. Louis Guglielmi at the Downtown Gallery (until Dec. 3). This artist, who has been styled an American surrealist, has indeed a somewhat surrealist approach in his work but is rather, it seems to me, an imaginative realist.

The campus-wide community chest drive at Smith College, just concluded, netted $7,100, according to Miss Janet Stockbridge of Baltimore, general chairman.. Additional contributions, including an estimated $1,000 from the Charity Ball in December, will bring this year's calculated amount to more than $8,200, and the grand total since 1925 to more than $147,000.

The Westchester County Park Commission does not intend to cut down the row of trees and shrubs, planted six years ago on a "safety" island separating Bronx River Parkway Extension and Broadway, Valhalla's business street, despite complaints of Valhalla business men that the foliage creates a traffic hazard and hides Broadway's stores from potential trade, a commission spokesman revealed at the close of the board's weekly meeting today.

With numbers of women's clubs already on record as endorsing the principle of government meat grading, consumer sentiment is being solidified in preparation for- hearings on the new ordinance now before the City Council. While few of the committees have completed their studies of the newly drafted bill, plans are already being laid to form a joint committee for action.

Three centuries were included in the touring Marylebone Cricket Club's total of 569 for six wickets at the end of the first day's play in a match with Griqualand West today. The fixture continues until Tuesday.

The marriage of Miss Eileen Sullivan, daughter of Judge Mark A. Sullivan of 23 Duncan Avenue, Jersey City, and the late Mrs. Sullivan, to James A. Cotter, son of Mrs. James A. Cotter of Brookline, Mass., and the late Mr. Cotter, took place yesterday mcrning in the Catholic Church of St. Aedan, Jersev City.

A party of 175 Austrian Jews, including dentists, physicians, architects and other professional men, arrived in Quebec today en route to Australia and New Zealand, where they will found new homes for themselves.
A birthday gift for King George will be a feature of his visit to Canada. The King's birthday will fall on June 9 the day before he sails from Halifax on his return journey.

Thirty-two gunners took part in a shoot for thirty turkeys over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. J. J. Van Gonsic took the high-over-all scratch honors by breaking 99 of 100 targets.

A resolution denouncing the German Government for its anti-Jewish acts was adopted today by the American Legion's executive committee. Copies were sent to President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

PINEHURST, N. C.-Golf will -continue to hold the center of attention here for the rest of the month, although field trials, equestrian activity and tennis also will occupy a place on the sports program.

G. Isaaos of George Washington, D. Mayers of Townsend Harris, H. Redisch of Townsend Harris, P. Wolf of Boys High and P. Wolk of Monroe are setting the pace in the high school championship chess tournament,
The Stevens varsity soccer team lost its last game of the season to Delaware, 1--0, at the Castle Point Field today. Playing on a muddy field,

Metropolitan Opera boxholders for the Philadelphia season of ten performances, which opens at the Academy of Music next Tuesday with the Strauss opera "Der Rosenkavalier," were announced today. They include:

Many men and women of society are cooperating as patrons and patronesses in plans for the annual Allaverdy Ball to be given on Dec. 9 at the Plaza under the auspices of the Caucasian Society Allaverdy.

The University of Arizona Wildcats mingled an aerial offensive with a relentless ground attack to score an upset 20-12 victory tonight over Marquette's Golden Avalanche before a homecoming crowd of 10,000.

The voluntary auction sale of three Bronx properties for account of the Estate of Mary A. Langbein, Bank of Manhattan Company, executor, held last week, attracted a number of bidders, Jere J. Reid, auctioneer, reports.

Confident that the mass-buying system of obtaining promotion goods for drug stores is the most effective method of improving sales in a difficult period, the Read Drug and Chemical Company of Baltimore, which originated the idea,

Mr. and Mrs. J. Bryant Heard of Danville, Va., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Alberta Heard, to Dr. David Eugene Warden of Montclair, N. J., and this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David Todd Warden of Montclair.

Chinese Communists have obtained control over several areas northwest of Tsitsihar and north of Harbin, according to foreign missionaries and Japanese news agencies. These Communist strongholds are regarded as a serious menace to Japan because they are between central Manchukuo and the Siberian frontier.

Sman employers anu, in -some cases, employers not so small are remanding in increasing number that the protection available to their employes under the Social Security program be extended to themselves, it was disclosed yesterday by Mrs. Lillian L. Poses, regional attorney for the Social Security Board.
The sum of $9,387 was realized yesterday afternoon at an auction of English and American furniture and decorations at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
WITH the approach of the tropical dry season, the season of flowers and of flowering trees, hundreds of tourists will visit the Isthmus of Panama and cross the Panama Canal.

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome R. Lavigne of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Carolyn LaVigne, to William Stuart Walcott 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Stuart Walcott Jr. of Litchfield and Daytona Beach, Fla.

Musicians, educators and authors comprise a sponsors' committee for the program of English and American folk dancing and music which will be given tomorrow night at the Town Hall to mark the twentyfifth anniversary of the Pine Mountain Settlement School in Harlan County, Ky.
GILBERT DU MOTIER DE LAFAYETTE was an eighteenth-century French nobleman who to the man on the street in twentieth-century America is a wholly familiar legend and an almost totally unknown man.

Applications have been mailed to more than one hundred young singers of New York State, who will participate in a contest sponsored by the New York Federation of Music Clubs with a view to introducing an outstanding young soprano on National Day at the New York World's Fair, 1939.

HOLLYWOOD and the keepers of its ledgers are engaged in a milliondollar publicity, advertising and exploitation campaign designed to convince skeptics that "Motion Pictures Are Your Greatest Entertainment." Before that slogan was adopted the campaign committee virtually had decided upon another: "Movies Are Your Best Entertainment."

At Lake Mohawk, Sussex County, N. J., construction is under way on a year-round home on North Shore Road for Harry C. Stoddard of Kew Gardens, an executive of the Colonial Trust Company of New York City. Edwin'R. Close is the architect.

Policemen and detectives ordered more than twenty tenants from a three-story brick building in Brooklyn yesterday morning to trap an armed man, who they charged had waylaid a laundry executive, stolen a payroll bag containing $2,600 and sought refuge in the building.

THE statistics of the Com posers' Forum-Laboratory, one of the Federal Music Project's units, are always impressive. The latest computation shows that 968 compositions by 158 composers have been performed by the Forum-Laboratory since its start in October, 1935.

Mr. and Mrs. Chester Blaine Mallory of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucia Blaine Mallory, to Frederick Bray Korsmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Korsmeyer, also of Scarsdale.

A thunderstrom, unusual in November, visited New York at 4:36 P. M. yesterday, the United States Weather Bureau reported. Similar storms, attributed in part to changing temperatures, were reported along a line running roughly from Block Island to Richmond, Va. Yesterday continued unseasonably warm,

The Montclair State Teachers College eleven brought its season to a close with a 6-0 victory over the Trenton Teachers on Sprague Field today. Taking a Trenton kick on the enemy 25 and racing back to the 15, Don Seldomridge set up the only score of.the game.

A substantail upturn in lithography sales has set in, with the Eastern coast feeling the improvement first, W. Floyd Maxwell, secretary of the Lithographers National Association, reported last week after a one month's tour through the country.

Men will appear on the Wilson College stage for the first time in the history of undergraduate dramatics when Wilson's Kittochtinny Players present "Stage Door" as the climax of the Thanksgiving Day program Thursday night.

The Polish Day Nursery will be aided by a supper dance to be held by members of the Helios Club on Friday at Sherry's. Mrs. Joseph Baluta, president of the nursery, heads the entertainment committee for the benefit; and Mrs. Henry D.

According to usual newspaper standards, action makes news and inaction does not. Yet last Thursday a notable case of inaction was worthy of large type on Page 1. The headline recorded that Adolf Hitler had remained silent, except for private remarks he may-have made, at the funeral of the slain Ernst vom Rath at Duesseldorf.

THIS is not a book for children. It is a delightful collection of folk tales-legends, myths, jokes, anecdotes and fairy stories--and it has the realism and the wisdom, along with the fancy'-and superstition, of ancient earth-born things.

Despite a decrease in the revenue from student employment projects at Princeton University during the past year, a larger number of undergraduates have been kept on the rolls of the Bureau of Appointments and student employment than in 1936-37, according to the annual report today by Richard W. Warfield, director of the bureau.

COLONIZERS: The famous prison ship La Martiniere sails tomorrow for the French penal colony in Guiana, carrying convicts for the first trip since June, 1936. Under Premier Blum transportation of convicts was abandoned. Now the "dry guillotine" is to have new victims, and last week hundreds of convicts were being assembled in France for the sea voyage.

Church members here of all denominations will join in a union service at 10:30 A. M. on Thanksgiving Day and offer prayers for the Jews in Germany, it was announced today by the Rev. James Harry Price, rector of the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less, where the service will be held.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Oldford Brown of Newtonville of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Guinevere G. Brown, to John Bradley Leypoldt, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Leypoldt of Maplewood, N. J.

Production of gold bullion in Ontario for the first nine months of 1938 was valued at $73,228,132, an increase of 12.4 per cent over production for the same period in 1937, according to official reports. Production in September was $8,412,863, a decrease of $416,618 from that in August.
Miss Eweretta Kernochan will give a luncheon at Sherry's on Friday, when final arrangements will be made for the benefit matinee on Dec. 16 of "Falstaff" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Swarthmore vanquished the Earlham Quakers of Richmond, Ind., today, 15-0, in a sea of mud. The game, played in pouring rain and in thick fog during part of the second half, was marked by many fumbles and incompleted passes.

Replies to the three most common objections against permissive incorporation of New York Stock Exchange firms are contained in the second preliminary report of the special committee appointed to study the subject. The report will be distributed to members tomorrow.

A loan exhibition of folk arts from the Hawaiian Islands will be opened today at the Folk Arts Center, 673 Fifth Avenue. It will be under the sponsorship of the National Committee on Folk Arts of the United States, which has held six previous folk art exhibitions.

Calling attention to the fact that there is an abundance of mortgage money and marked advances in the Improvements and refinements in the mortgage procedure of private institutions, Morton Bodfish, executive vice president of the United States Building and Loan League, points out the need of more rapid retirement of government from the ??ending business.

The latest moves against the Jews in Germany have amazed and dumfounded the British and destroyed-at least for the present-such faint hopes as existed of an early rapprochement with Germany. They dealt a severe blow to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy,

There has been an increase in the number of inquiries for business properties, store locations and offices since the election, according to Harold C. Samuels, head of the brokerage firm bearing his name.

Along with the official United States delegation, a number of women representing various movements and organizations will be passengers on the Santa Clara when she sails Friday, all bound for the Pan American congress at Lima, Peru. Motivated by diverse

To the Drama Editor: Why have we never had a good anti-Nazi or anti-Fascist play? We have not had a good anti-Nazi play, not because, as you say, we are "too close to the events," or because the problem is of vast political or social significance,

Joint Congressional Executive Monopoly Committee will begin public hearingss Dec. 1, starting with a generall picture from government expertss on the national economic scene, which will be followed by two weeks or more of testimony on the use, distribution and poolng of patents in the automobile and glass industries.

Mnnesota's mighty men, with a devastating running attack that produced three touchdowns and a second straight Big Ten championship, exploded Wisconsin's long-cherished dream of a football empire today.

The new development known as Gateway Homes at 224th Street and 11,h Avenue, St. Albans, L. I., is rapidly assuming definite form. At present thirty homes are under construction and four are expected to be ready for inspection next week.
A dinner dance, entitled "Alexander's Ragtime Band," will be held next Saturday night at the Glen Island Casino, New Rochelle, to aid the philanthropic fund of the Bronxville League for Service.

Laughton Lupin, a blue male Persian, was judged yesterday both the best cat and the best champion, in the cat show that was held Friday and yesterday in Commerce Hall of the Port Authority Building under the sponsorship of the Empire Cat Club of New York and the Siamese Cat Society of America.

Many reservations have been received for a luncheon and card party in behalf of the charitable activities of the Almoners, to be held Tuesday at Sherry's. Proceeds will be donated to several philanthropies for distribution among the destitute and needy at the Christmas season.

Closer cooperation between the trade unions and the cooperative movement was urged yesterday by speakers at a conference called by the Social Democratic Federation at People's House, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

CHICAGO. ALFRED LUNT and Lynn Foncanne, with what amounts to an "original company," original inasmuch as they'll be rehearsed in five plays, are devoting every spare moment while touring toward Chicago to the preparation of "Idiot's Delight."

The School of Tropical Medicine, maintained jointly in San Juan by the University of Puerto Rico and Columbia University, made progress in research last year, completing twenty-five projects out of fiftyeight undertaken, Dr. George W. Bachman, director, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday at Columbia.

The question of the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority's power program now awaits determination of the Supreme Court of the United States. On the court's forthcoming decisions hangs also the problem of competition between government agencies and private utilities in the sale of electric power in the TVA area.

Connecticut College students will assume responsibility for the daily chapel service during the eight weeks following Thanksgiving in an experiment suggested to President Katharine Blunt by the student government cabinet and the student religious council.

A NEW committee of the American Standards Association to coordinate work on highway traffic standards held its organization meeting last week in New York. This committee brings together all groups interested in motor, highway or traffic safety problems.

Captain Andrew Trzeciak carried the ball six successive times on a 25-yard drive opening the third period of the V. M. I.-Roanoke game today and scored from the 1-yard line to give the cadets a 6-to-O victory.

Captain Andrew Trzeciak carried the ball six successive times on a 25-yard drive opening the third period of the V. M. I.-Roanoke game today and scored from the 1-yard line to give the cadets a 6-to-O victory.

Signs worn by two pickets in front of the London Clothes Shop, a haberdashery at 10 Journal Square, were torn from their shoulders today by Captain Peter Quail of the Jersey City police after the pickets had refused to remove them.

A study of the more than 100 species of birds we have obtained during our five months in the New Guinea wilderness has revealed one type so rare that only a single specimen is known in the museums of the world, and another that we believe has never before been seen by a scientist.

Walter R. H. Hardingham who at the time of his retirement fifteen years ago had been associated with the New York law firm of Shipman, Laroque Choate for more than fifty years, died last night at his horse, 715 Ravine Road, this city.

President and Mrs. , Charles Seymour of Yale University gave a buffet luncheon today in honor of President and Mrs. James Conant of Harvard University. Dr. and Mrs. Conant and Mr. and Mrs. Roger Shepard of New York were the house guests of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour during the week-end of the Yale-Harvard game.

Mr. and Mrs. George G. Hewlett of Flushihg, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Kathryn Hewlett, to William A. Michel, son of Mrs. William Rasquin of Flushing and the late William C. Michel of New York.

Of the entire cultural heritage handed down to us by the ancient Greeks, athletics is the only subject that is taught correctly in the schools today, Dr. John Erskine, author and educator, declared yesterday before the fifth annual Foreign Language Conference sponsored by the New York University School of Education.

This season's series of Musical Mornings, conducted by Albert Morris Bagby will be inaugurated tomorrow in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The concerts for many years have been features of the Winter musical season in this city and always have received a large patronage from men and women of prominence in society.

The first of three Coffee Dances for this season will take place Dec. 12 in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club. The dances which have been given for many years, are named from the custom of subscribers giving dinner parties and taking their guests afterward to the club for coffee and dancing.

A number of improvements to meet the demand for modern living quarters in the heavily populated East 116th Street section have been completed recently or are now under way, points out Leon S. Altmayer, agent for several properties in that vicinity.

David Lasser, national president of the Workers Alliance of America, urged President Roosevelt today not to lay off 450,000 WPA workers. This number was in danger of being discharged, he said in a telegram to the White House,

Despite the driving rain, a field of twenty-one took part in the turkey shoot over the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club. R. Helsel and J. K. Voorhees each broke fifty straight. Third was C. Schad, who had forty-nine.

Dr. and Mrs. James Philip Gibbs of Huntsville, Texas, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Virginia Sandford Gibbs, to Joseph Smyth Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Smyth of Sayville, L. I.

Harvard's extra-curricular study of American history and civilization is going forward this year with the appointment of seven Fellows in American History, each assigned to one of the seven upper-class residential Houses as an unofficial tutor to guide students in the informal work.

Battered down in a terrific rainstorm, a big army bomber smashed up in a West Georgia forest last night, killing seven fliers in one of the worst tragedies in the history of military aviation. An eighth member of the crew was gravely injured.

IN the English tavern which is the back room of their clubhouse, the Lambs and Lamb kins aroused themselves from their thoughts of yesterday's great parts and the greater parts to come. While the Buddha over the fireplace smiled down understandingly, their eyes turned lingeringly from the yellowed programs on the wall and rested on the door.

With Puerto Rico observing-today as a holiday to mark its discovery in 1493 by Columbus, the question of where he actually landed remained disputed with great rivalry between the adjoining towns of Aguada and Aguadilla.
Creation of a New York State Bureau of Commerce to determine whether industries are leaving the State because of taxes, labor and operating costs, was proposed today by Ernest V. Hoit,

Announcement has been made by Professor Stephen P. Mizwa, executive director of the Kosciuszko Foundation, that the sixth "Night in Poland Ball," an annual entertainment given under the foundation's auspices, will take place on Jan. 20 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Miss Helen K. Charmley, daughter of Mrs. Helen Charmley of Millburn, N. J., and the late John T. Charmley, was married here yesterday in St. Vincent Ferrer's Church to John L. McNamara, son of Mr. and Mrs. John, B. McNamara of Summit, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John D. Walsh.

LINCOLN'S Gettysburg speech has been quoted and repeated so many thousands of times and has become so much a part of our language that it is hard to realize that there ever was a time when it was not to be found in the school readers or among the world's supreme orations. But it was new once.

The Pantepec Oil Company of Venezuela has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 292,878 shares of one-bolivar-par common stock. The aggregate amount of the proposed cash offering is estimated at $2,466,280.

Georgetown University ended its season undefeated today, with a hard-fought 14-to-7 victory over hapless Maryland. About 10,000 spectators, soaked by a steady drizzle of rain, turned out for the hard-played game,

Sweeping changes in the national farm program to make "parity income for the American farmer a reality " were urged this week by the national convention of the Farmers Union in Madison, Wis. outrightt repeal of the Agricultural Adjustment Act was not recomnended, but amendments were proposed to eliminate "many obvious weaknesses."

As a result of increased interest in debating during the past year, Williams College has appointed Rev. Dr. Raymond Blakeney, local pastor, to the position of debating coach, the first in the history of the college.

The congregational societies of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, will hold a supper dance next Saturday at the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds to aid the Sisterhood of the synagogue in its educational work among the underprivileged children of the lower East Side.

In the James Memorial Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary yesterday afternoon Miss Ruth Pierpont Stephens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ward-Stephens of 132 East Nineteenth Street, was married to John Martin Lyden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Lyden of Youngstown, Ohio.

No higher compliment could have been earned by Secretary Hull's reciprocal trade agreement policy than its denunciation by the press in Germany as "a great fiasco against which all sensible nations valuing their independence must protect themselves."

With the present buildings now 95 per cent rented, plans are under way for the erection of a third structure in the Colonial Village at Fleetwood, Westchester County, according to Gaspar Morrell, manager.

Means of avoiding a repetition of the damage caused to trees by the recent hurricane will be discussed at an Eastern Shade Tree Conference on Dec. 8 and 9 at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park, it was announced yesterday. Dr. William J. Robbins, director of the garden, is summoning a large group of tree experts to the meeting.

Grinnell College closed its 1938 football season today-and its last season in the Mississippi Valley Conference-with a'21-to-7 triumph over Colorado College. It was the first game between the two colleges.

TO his rogues gallery of America--"The Gangs of New York," "The Barbary Coast," 'The French Quarter" (and perhaps "Hatrack" could also be included)-Mr. Asbury now adds a special section devoted to gamblers.

SPENDING Christmas in the Old Country (whatever that country may be) is more and more becoming a Winter holiday habit. Thousands of American citizens, recalling the festivities in family homes across the sea, choose this season for a foreign tour.

The modern hot-water heating plant, points out the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau, is equipped with an air-tight cbmpression tank and relief valve, thus closing the system to the atmosphere. The result is to raise the boiling point of the water, permitting higher water temperatures to be used.

The Geneva College eleven defeated Westminster, 6 to 0, today. A small crowd braved a cold drizzling rain to witness the final game of the year and to pay tribute to Captain Dominic Rosselli, quarterback for the Covenanters for the last four years.
The present state of affairs in Palestine was briefly mentioned in King Farouk's speech from the throne in opening the new session of Parliament this morning.

With the New York district in the lead, large-scale multi-family rental housing projects conceived under the amended National Housing Act extending FHA mortgage insurance to this type of construction have been increasing rapidly.

Demands for lower utility rates will be curbed only when the public is made to like and respect the utilities and the men who operate them, Lorenzo Semple, assistant vice president of the American Water Works and Electric Company, New York, said today at the closing session of the twenty-third annual convention of the New Jersey Utilities Association in the Hotel Traymore.

Charles M. Wurthman, known to thousands of New York State College for Teachers students, died today after a year's illness. He was 75 years old. Mr. Wurthman retired in 1929 after serving thirty-eight years as janitor of the college.

Edward Hall Chapin, retired vice president of the National Car Wheel Company of Rochester, died today at his home here at the age of 71. He was born in Rochester and was the son of Charles Hall Chapin and the grandson of William E. Kidd, both prominent in early Rochester banking history.

THE big pleasure fleet of boats, small and large, heading southward via the Intra Coastal Waterway to spend the Winter in more tropical waters is well on the way. Many of them take the quickest, most direct route, but for the more leisurely traveler there are a number of side trips to be explored.

SAN SALVADOR. NOTWITHSTANDING an agreement between Nicaragua and Honduras to withdraw temporarily from circulation their air mail postal paper involved in the "stamp war" resulting from the boundary dispute between the two republics, mail reaching El Salvador continues to be franked with the two controversial stamps.

Announcement of a settlement by the United States and Mexico regarding the agricultural lands expropriated by Mexico suggests that this particular dispute s drawing toward a close. Under the announced agreement each Government has appointed a commissioner to value the lands of Americans taken over by Mexico since 1927.

The swimmers of Textile virtually made sure yesterday of successfully defending their Manhattan-Bronx senior high title in the P. S. A. L. competition. They maintained a clean slate by defeating Stuyvesant, 47-24, at the fifth series of dual meets for the divisional laurels in the De Witt Clinton pool.

THE new season begins tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House, which, now venerable com pared with most of New York's theatres, had its original opening fiftyfive years ago. Details of each first night have varied with the years, but the spirit of the occasion remains essentially the same.

Miss Marjorie Miles, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter R. Miles of this city, was married to Roswell Dunlop McClelland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross St. John McClelland of Los Angeles, this morning in the Marquand Chapel of Yale Divinity School. The Rev. Alexander C.

Bob Zuppke's University of Illinois eleyen blasted Chicago's last chance to win a Western Conference football game this season by routing the hapless Maroons, 34 to 0, in the season's finale today for both schools.

Sociology students of Marymount College here have extended their program of activities and charitable projects, the college announced today. Enrollment of freshmen in the sociology survey class has increased 35 per cent this year.

Demand of two Duchy of Lichtenstein investment firms for payment of their claim against the Cotton Belt Railroad in Dutch gold guilders, under optional clause in one of the barrier's bond issues, was taken under advisement yesterday by a special master of the Federal court.

A further recovery in residential construction may be expected, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday, provided there are no "untoward incidents such as a sudden increase in building costs."

Nebraska's Cornhuskers, none too successful themselves this Fall, put a drab finish on an already dismal football season for Iowa today by handing the Hawkeyes a 14-to-0 defeat before approximately 14,000 fans.

Albert Mayer, architect and chairman of the borough planning advisory board, speaking before the apartment house group of the management division, Real Estate Board of New York, last week, declared that congested building had overreached its aims, with the result that land is now available at prices inviting a reversal of previous trends.
Michigan's prowling Wolverines, impotent against Ohio State for four years, turned at long last today to beat the Buckeyes, 18 to 0, in the season's finale before a crowd of 67,554.

Men and women in their native Ukrainian costumes led a parade of 15,000 persons up Eighth Avenue from Abingdon Square to the Manhattan Center at Thirty-fourth Street yesterday morning to protest Polish "barbarism" against their people abroad.

Delegates to the annual meeting of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church, comprising Bishops, ministers and laymen from various parts of the country, condemned in a resolution last week "the excesses and outrages that have marked the Japanese invasion of China."
WHILE appreciating the nation-wide scope of the National Automobile Show, which closed last week at Grand Central Palace, the local aspect is not to be overlooked.

TheUniversityof California's Golden Bears, making a last-ditch stand for a chance at the Pacific Coast Conference football championship and the Rose Bowl bid, scored a fourth period touchdown and a 6-to-O victory today over their oldest football rivals, the Stanford Indians.
The Alumni Association of St. Peter's College will hold its annual dance Wednesday evening at the Forest Hill Field Club in Bloomfield. Arthur C. Bromirski and Robert M. Doherty are co-chairmen.
