Erasmus Hall High School's football team finished its season yesterday unbeaten and untied. With 20,000 looking on, the Buff and Blue gained the distinction of being the only New York City eleven to win all its games for the year as it repulsed its time-honored foe, Boys High, 7-0, in the star contest of a schoolboy double-header MANUJ at Ebbets Field.

The gridiron rivalry that exists between the local army elevens, Fort Jay and Fort Hamilton, will be renewed this afternoon at Morris Memorial Field on Governors Island. Both combinations point for this contest each year.

An All-Mexican Night will be held at the World Cinema on Dec. 1 for the benefit of the Manhattan Council of the Camp Fire Girls. Various committee members are now engrossed in arrangements for the details.

Spruille Braden, United States Ambassador to Colombia, who represented President Roosevelt during the Chaco conference in Buenos Aires, declared yesterday that the signing of the peace pact between Bolivia and Paraguay last July was "a distinctly American accomplishment."

When Governor Earle requested the House Investigating Committee at Harrisburg this week to give, him and other State officials opportunity to reply to graft and corruption charges against them, he prompted this question among many persons, Democrats and Republicans alike:
Lieutenant F. F. Wing of the United States Army team, riding the veteran Dakota, tonight won the international individual military jumping event at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.
A thousand dollars in currency was found under wall paper in the home of Joseph Johnson after his death. Now the State wants back $512 paid to Johnson and his widow for old age assistance.

With the greatest naval-expansion program in the history of the nation definitely under way, the Navy Department is rushing a program to increase navy-yard-facilities, which is necessary if the yards are to perform efficiently the tremendous job immediately ahead.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ashley Day Jr. of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Gardner Day, to Bruce Scott Old.

WITH the opening of the Metropolitan Opera season this week, a new bal let ensemble will make its appearance in the field. As was announced at the close of last season, the opera company will maintain its own corps of dancers from now on instead of engaging a unit from outside, as was done for the three seasons just past with the American Ballet.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens. who was elected national commander of the Army and Navy Legion of Valor at its convention in Pittsburgh, said that July 7 would be set aside for the organization's 1939 convention delegates at the World's Fair.

To the Art Editor: THE government has been generous in aiding the farmer and the garment worker by buying their excess stock. The suggestion has many times been made that it also buy the work of artists. Food and clothing are both needed by the destitute, but objection is made that the public does not need paintings.

The committee for the Yorkville dinner dances anticipates one of the largest and most successful parties in the history of these events when the first dance in this season's series is given on the night of Dec. 6 at the Ritz-Carlton.
Washington and Jefferson and Wooster College fought to a scoreless draw on a mud-soaked field today in the final game of the year for both schools.

Congressmen who voted to revoke the restoration of Colonel Luis Larrea Alba to active service were attacked in the street by Larrea partisans yesterday. They were rescued by soldiers who are now guarding their houses due to the high feeling on the part of the Larrea followers.

EMPORIA, Kan. CLOSE to the middle of this pleasant small town planted at or about the middle of the United States is the modest office of The Emporia Gazette, and in the middle room of that office, between the countingroom, where the money comes in, and the news room, the composing room and the press room,

MR. SAROYAN, the flip. the casual and the spectacular, may one day come to be considered a moralist, for in this new volume of short stories he seems to be aware for the first time of the vast, inarticulate striving of humanity toward something called civilization.

Java exported 1,095,092 metric tons of sugar in the season ended on Aug. 31, against 1,125,656 in the 1936-37 year, a decline of 30,564 tons, or 2.7 per cent, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange reports.

A percentage of the advance sale of tickets for the matinee on Dec. 26 at the Metropolitan Opera House of the operas "Hansel and Gretel" and "Pagliacci" will be used for the benefit of the Children's Health Service of Greenwich House. Funds raised in this way will further the work of the clinics maintained at the settlement.

The McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will be the beneficiary of a card party to be held the afternoon of Nov. 29 at the home of Mrs. John D. Ryan, 3 East Seventy-eighth Street. A feature of the event will be a Christmas booth where seals, wrappings, cards and ribbons will be offered for sale.

Louisiana State swarmed over Southwestern Louisiana Institute today, 32-0. The Bayou Tigers scored two touchdowns in the first period, one in the second and two more in the fourth. The L. S. U. first eleven played only in the first period.

More than 3,000 guests are expected to attend the annual benefit dinner and dance to be given by the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind and its Junior League on Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria. During the evening there will be a revue by professional entertainers.
The palatial Tower Road estate of John Barrymore in Beverly Hills will be sold at auction Dec. 10, it was announced today by David Fisher, personal business manager for the actor.

William Randolph Hearst urged last night in a nation-wide broadcast originating in his home at San Simeon, Calif., that the former German colonies in Africa be converted into a permanent homeland for the Jewish victims of Nazi and Fascist persecution.
Special prayer services "for the victims of racial and religious oppression" were held in most synagogues yesterday. Churches will hold similar services today.
The Pan-Arab movement, one phase of which is the continuing armed conflict between Arabs and British in Palestine, appears to be gaining momentum.
Gino (Red) Vagnone, San Francisco heavyweight, last night threw Bibber McCoy of Cambridge, Mass., in 27:30 of their finish wrestling match at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn.

Becausee or Interest in tne first competitive hobby show for employes of the New York Stock Exchange, the show will be extended a week. It is sponsored by the Camera Club, the Model Engineering Club and the Philatelic Society, all organizations of employes.
Kirsten Flagstad made her first operatic appearance of the Chicago season tonight before an ardent audience in the Civic Opera House.

Arts and Crafts. Deiphic Studios. 44 West Fifty-sixth Street, until Dec. 3. Work of the New York Society of Craftsmen. Hawaiian Coverlets. Folk Art Center Galleries, 673 Fifth Avenue. Antique examples of a native interpretation of the early American folk craft.

IT is a surprise-which soon turns into a delight-to find Clemenceau biographed by Leon Daudet. Does not the author of "Ka Vie Orageuse de Cldmenceau" (Albin Michel, 315 pp., 18 fr.) profess opinions at the antipodes of his hero's?

With a bridal party of twenty-one members, Miss Virginia Peyton Broun and Robert William Lawson Jr. were married here tonight in St. John's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by Bishop William Loyall Gravatt of Charleston and the Rev. Benjamin R. Roller of White Sulphur Springs.
The Navy gave new impetus to the Administration's rearmament program today with orders for the construction of three 35,000-ton battleships at an expected cost of $150,000,000.

WHATEVER tenderness and affection the pedantic, the witty or the worldly may possess generally reveals itself to children, and these are the qualities, naturally enough. which set the dominant note in this collection of letters.

The tenth anniversary of the opening of aviation and pilot training courses in the curriculum of the New York University School of Education will be observed tomorrow night at 8 o'clock in the Education auditorium, 41 West Fourth Street, it was announced yesterday.
Malcolm Holmes, director of the Wellesley College orchestra, will present his players in a program of early instrumental music on the evening of Nov. 28.

Raymond V. Parsons, research engineer of the Johns-Manville Corporation and chairman of the new housing committee of the Citizens Housing Council, will talk on methods of reducing housing costs tomorrow evening in the housing forum being conducted by New York University in cooperation with the council.
The British military authorities have been extremely successful in this weekend in wiping out Arab terrorism in Palestine.

The domestic packer stands to gain little new business as the result of the new trade treaty with Great Britain. Lard, after Jan. 1, will be admitted free of duty into England, but the United Kingdom already draws about 80 per cent of its requirements from the United States.

The new Normandie Theatre, a 600-seat motion picture louse under construction at Park Avenue and Fifty-third Street, has been sold by Philip Smith, theatre operator of Boston. It was bought by the Norman Theatre Corporation, headed by David Weinstock and Harry Brandt, through David Berk and J. Krumgold, brokers.

Seventy-five passengers aboard a southbound. train of the Harlem division of the New York Central Railroad were shaken, but uninjured, when the locomotive was derailed at 10:45 o'clock tonight by a collision with an unoccupied automobile at Roaring. Brook crossing, a mile north of here.

Industrial activity in Great Britain, based on the quarterly average for the year 1930 as 100, for the third quarter of 1938 was 4.3 per cent less than that of the preceding quarter and 10.5 per cent less than that of the third quarter of 1937, the index number of 116.5 comparing with the previous quarter's 121.7 and with the 130.1 of last year.

Assumption by the national government of one-third of the cost of the Federal old-age insurance program, now financed exclusively through contributions from employers and employes, is being studied by the Social Security Advisory Council for inclusion in its forthcoming report to the Senate Finance Committee and the Social Security Board.
From all the frontier areas of Czechoslovakia have come stories of discontent over the surrender of territory to other powers. Polish terrorists continue to disturb Carpatho-Ukraine [Ruthenia].

The German wholesale price index on Nov. 15 stood at 106, unchanged from a week before. In the first ten months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 106.1, in the weeks ended on Aug. 3, 10 and 17. The lowest was 105.3, in the first two weeks of June.

The twenty-eighth anniversary of the Mexican revolution was celebrated today with a huge athletic parade. Thirty thousand participated and the parade required six hours to pass in front of the Presidential balcony.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent editorial in THE TIMES, "Victory for Housing," draws attention to the hindrance to slum clearance created by the limit of $1.50 a foot for land costs imposed by Mr. Straus.

President Charles Seymour of Yale University discussed in his annual report, which was given out today, a criticism of the Yale Law School faculty, which, he said, labels it as radical and implies that its teachings are corrupting youth.

The colors of twenty-seven patriotic societies were carried in procession yesterday afternoon from the Old Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine into the cathedral for the Thanksgiving service which has been held annually for the last sixteen years.

A first-mortgage loan of $300,000 for ten years has been obtained by the Bocar Realty Corporation on the new six-story apartment house on the south side of Clarkson Avenue, 229 feet east of Flatburh Avenue, Brooklyn. Louis M. Rogovin, broker, arranged the financing of the building, which occupies a plot 143 by 200 feet.

Queen Maud of Norway, sister of the late King George V and only surviving child of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra, died in her sleep early today from heart failure. She underwent an operation last Wednesday for the removal of an abdominal obstruction. She was 68 years old.

Neville Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, has accepted an invitation to act as chairman of the radio council of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's birthday, it was announced yesterday.

Well over a score of new exhibitions await the gallery-goer in the week ahead, with the usual variety and including several of outstanding interest. Among them is the loan exhibition of work by Gros, Gericault and Delacroix, which opens today at the Knoedler Galleries, where it may be seen until Dec. 10, after which it is to be taken to other cities.

Cotton prices were generally lower last week in trading on the New York Exchange. The near-by December and January deliveries registered declines of only 3 points in the period, while the distant July declined 18 points and the distant October 23 points.

Radio Station WMCA broadcast yesterday afternoon, after an address by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Royal Oak, Mich., a charge that "unfortunately Father Coughlin has uttered certain mistakes of fact."

Magazine linage, which has not registered the improvement this Fall originally expected for it, is finally beginning to cut down its losses from a year ago, figures for November monthly issues have revealed. Whereas in October the loss under 1937 was 24 per cent,

Mrs. Jennie L. Matthews, widow of Porter H. Matthews, paint company owner, and principal of Los Angeles' first junior high school and a leader in church and charitable activities for many years, died today of a heart ailment at her home at the age of 78.

If we are to be saved, we must believe, and in order to believe, we need the help of the Holy Ghost, the Rev. Dr. John W. Bradbury said yesterday in his sermon at the North Baptist Church, 232 West Eleventh Street.
A Briton's attempt to fly to his Russian wife here and take her out of the country by airplane has ended in his arrest and the seizure of his plane 100 miles from Moscow.

Germany's latest extremes found their most vivid reflection in the pound sterling, which immediately collapsed in a relatively firm market, with a prospect of a further fair recovery in a manner reminiscent of tie September crisis.

Stocks unsettled, due to foreign situation, and registered widest decline since the week ended on Aug. 13; turnover 7,760,010 shares. All groups of bonds except the traction issues were generally lower; transactions, $38,005,350.
Last week's fall of [pound]4,102,000 in the note circunation of the Bank of England is normal for this time of the year and Is almost the same as the decline in the corresponding week last year.

Thirty boys in a psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital were carefully watched yesterday after they had been foiled in an attempt at a mass escape from their fifth-floor quarters by means of a rope made of sheets.

One of many constructive things accomplished by the National Automobile Show which closed last week was its poll of opinion on a number of important matters affecting driving and the hazards of the streets and roads.

Mrs. Ida Franklin Hedges, widow of Job E. Hedges, lawyer and former receiver of the New York Railways Company, died yesterday, after an illness of several weeks, at her residence, 530 East Eighty-sixth Street.

The Grace Line steamship Santa Clara is due today from Chile, Peru, Ecuador, Colombia and Cuba. Among her passengers are: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Clarkson, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph T. Reed and Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. White.

A parkway link between the present east end of the Northern State Parkway near Westbury and the Wantagh State Parkway leading directly to Jones Beach will be completed within one month, it was announced today by Robert Moses, Come president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

In a summary of its activities during the first nine months of this year the Bureau of Social Hygiene of the Department of Health announced yesterday that 38,250 reports of new cases of social diseases were received during the period, as compared with 12,791 in the entire year of 1937.

German secret police have searched homes of foreigners in their hunt for Jews, foreigners said in Berlin yesterday. At the same time Nazi leaders were reported to have agreed to let Jewish exporters continue in business lest the Reich's foreign trade be injured. [Page 1.]

Nations cannot ignore God and expect government to be effective, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, told the members of his congregation yesterday morning.

In an exciting game, marked by frequent scoring, the Fort Jay football team defeated Fort Hamilton before 3,000 fans at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday to win the First Infantry Brigade championship and the Seventy-eighth Division Veterans' Trophy. The final count was 30 to 25.

Call money closed here last week at 21/8 to 23/8 per cent. The money market con- t tinued exceedingly liquid, and, consequently, the Reich announced a new consolidation loan issue of 1,500,000,000 marks, even though the last issue which produced record results was made only in October.

Seven organizations opposed to war joined today in a statement which described as "hysteria" the current activities designed to strengthen the military and naval forces of the United States to a degree that would enable them to defend the Western Hemisphere.

Miss Ruth Adler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Adler, and Herman N. Liberman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Liberman of 1,010 Fifth Avenue, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 211 Central Park West. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-El.

In 1937 rate reductions in one-or more typical residential electric power bills were made in 227, or 82.5 per cent, of the 250 Connecticut communities having 250 or more population covered by reports of eleven of the nineteen utilities serving these places, the Federal Power Commission announced today.
Because of Europe's troubles, foreigners living in Canada are hastening to become naturalized. It is estimated that 11,000 have done so since Jan. 1.

The recital given by Daniel Erlcourt, French pianist, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall found that gifted artist far less emotionally inhibited than heretofore. As a consequence his highly perfected performances boasted a new eloquence and became keenly communicative.

A 1937 increase of 11 per cent in juvenile delinquency cases was reported today by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor. The report was based on data from areas served by twenty-eight courts in seventeen States and the District of Columbia, each serving an area of 160,000 population or more.

Miss Eleanor M. Bartels, niece of James P. Boland and Miss Helen F. Boland of this place, was married to Joseph A. Kenna, son of Mrs. Katherine Kenna, also of this city, in St. Mary's Catholic Church here yesterday.

The National Lawyers Guild urged President Roosevelt yesterday to call a special session of Congress "to make any appropriation and take any action necessary to prevent the dismissal of any WPA worker and the hardship and suffering which would be entailed thereby."

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins said tonight that no one should resent organization of labor because "whenever an orderly system of collective bargaining by intelligent persons of good-will exists a picture of stable working conditions is obtained."
The Los Angeles Bulldogs defeated another National Football League invader today, scoring a 28-to-7 victory over the Cleveland Rams before 17,000 fans.

After having heard Governor Frank Murphy voice the opinion that the persection of Jews in Germany was not "the will of the people" a mass meeting today adopted a resolution calling for the. United States to place an embargo on all trade with that country.
The Venerable Mother Maria Domenica Mazzarello, co-founder of the Daughters of Mary Help of Christians, was beatified today in St. Peter's Cathedral.

An embargo against all "aggressor and intolerant governments" was urged in a telegram sent yesterday to President Roosevelt by representatives of educational, patriotic, civic and religious organizations who met at the Manhattan Opera House to protest against the persecution of Jews in Italy and Germany.

Presi dent Roosevelt was urged today by the Eastern seaboard memberships of the United Palestine Appeal, the only authorized American Jewish agency for reconstruction and resettlement in Palestine, to make representations to the British Government with a view toward opening the doors of Palestine to refugees Jews from Germany.
The fourteenth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine will open on Friday at the Hotel Pennsylvania and will continue through Saturday and Sunday.

Despite the wretched playing conditions in the East and South, marring the perfect record of cooperation from the Weather Man for the season, football offered little in the way of genuine surprises on Saturday as the campaign ended for the Big Ten, the Big Three and other teams.
Keen competition marked the ope ing today of the two-day field ?? meeting of, the Long Island ?? triever Trial Club, Inc., at the ?? o' Missing Men estate of the la Colonel Henry H. Rogers.

After five years' absence from the screen Ina Claire has signed a term contract with Metro and will appear in "I Take This Woman" with Spencer Tracy and Hedy Lamarr. She will arrive on the Coast tomorrow, and the picture resumes production after two weeks' idleness caused by the replacement of Josef von Sternbers as director by Frank Borzage.

The Nazi regime in Germany was denounced last night by Senator Robert F. Wagner, who is of German birth, as "a deadly and determined force, directed not only against the Jewish people, but against every manifestation of the democratic ideal."
Jan Bata, head of the Bata shoe factory in Czechoslovakia was arrested by mistake several days ago at Leitmeritz, former Czechoslovak city now in Germany, while he was on route to the Netherlands.

George Beatty, 35 years old, of 161 Linden Road, Mineola, a clerk employed in the Nassau County Motor Vehicle Bureau at Mineola, was arraigned here today before District Court Judge Albert C. Moore on a charge of misappropriation of public funds. He waived examination and was held for the grand jury.

Delegates from the Northern New York and Eastern Canada district of the American-Jewish Joint Distribution Committee received instructions at a meeting here today for the funds drive to be held Dec. 11.
Dr. Edwin Herbert Hall, Professor Emeritus of Physics at Harvard University and a recognized world authority in his field, died at his home here today in his eighty-third year.

Signing of the Anglo-American trade treaty has removed that factor as a market influence. Trade sentiment is still strongly divided as to the ultimate effect of the agreement as a price-making factor.

Nazi Germany's theories of "racism, antiSemitism and paganism" represent "intellectualism gone mad," Cardinal O'Connell today told 400 college students in the chapel of the Cathedral of the Holy Cross.
The nations of the New World are united in their determination that this shall be a "continent of peace," Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, said in a radio broadcast today.
Government forces have been holding on to their Segre River positions, with only slight variations in the lines, according to neutral observers who visited the sector today.

In a magnificent game of teethrattling line play and backfield brilliance, the New York Giants toppled the Green Bay Packers, 15 to 3, at the Polo Grounds yesterday before the enraptured gaze of 48,279 spectators.

Out of $924,000,000 made available by Congress for allotment in 1938 by the Public Works Administration to Federal and non-Federal projects, all but $105,319.09 has been allotted, Secretary Ickes announced today.

Helium hissed and squealed through the necks of countless blue, white and orange balloons at the Central Park Zoo yesterday as genial John J. Kelly, who got the idea for his new rocket-like balloonfiller from a toothpowder can, reported glowingly on its first eight weeks.

Two five-story tenements on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 131 and 133 West Sixtieth Street have been sold by the Central Savings Bank to the 131-133 West Sixtieth Street Corporation, A. Schusselberg, president. The latter intends to renovate the property, which is valued at $36,000. Flaherty Associates, Inc., negotiated the sale.

The second week of the 1938 merged campaign for funds to. be expended in Greater New York by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities opened last night.
Extra forces of Mobile Guards were rushed today to the Island of Saint-Martin-de-Re to quell a "general rebellion" among 738 convicts awaiting transfer to France's prison colony off South America.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,974,218,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes an noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Funeral services for Harold R. Warner, a son of the late Ezra J. Warner Sr., one of the founders of Sprague, Warner Co., will be held Tuesday. He died Thursday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif., at the age of 58.
This municlpality is negotiating to buy the telephone system from the Automatic Telephone Company, of. Chicago, which is asking $200,000, according to reliable reports.
Supply contracts valued at $7,120,921 were awarded during the week ended Nov. 12 by ten Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

An unusual feature of the annual Harvest Home Festival today at historic St. Paul's Episcopal Church, East Chester, where George Washington once worshiped, was the presence of two rabbis, who took an active part in the devotional service in protest against the persecution of Jews by German officials. They were Rabbi Henry E.
Speaking at memorial services of the annual convention of the National Grange, National Master Louis J. Taber tonight likened the activities of nazism and fascism. to those of "the Neros of Rome."

The best-in-show award at the seventeenth annual specialty event of the Boston Terrier Club of this city went to Kid Boots' Scarlett O'Hara, owned by Mrs. Jesse Thorton of Towson. The exhibition today, held at the Broadwood Hotel, drew a large gathering of fanciers.

A new fifth floor, added to the Home of the Daughters of Jacob at 167th Street and Findlay Avenue, the Bronx, at a cost of $180,000, was dedicated yesterday with ceremonies at which Borough President Lyons was a speaker.

The present naval expansion program, when completed, should provide a fleet able to give us a "reasonably adequate defense against attack on our shores by the now known future naval force of any one of the foreign nations whose naval expansion is already well under way," Admiral William H. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, declares in his report for the last fiscal year, published today.

Dress market activity last week favored formal and dinner apparel at all price levels. Attendance was smaller than expected at openings of cruise and resort lines, and only Southern accounts started to buy in any quantities.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Haggerty will give a dinner in the Persian Room of the Plaza on Wednesday for Miss Mary Jane Cuddihy, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy. Mr. and Mrs. Hermon D. Smith of Lake Forest, Ill., are at the Commodore.

The children in the National Home for Jewish Children at Denver are taught both patriotism snd love of Jewish tradition, Edwin J. Wittelshofer of its national board of trustees reported yesterday afternoon to the delegates at the thirty-first anniversary convention of the home at the Hotel Commodore.

The report of the New England Power Association and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net profit after taxes and charges of $4,207,897, equal after full provision for preferred stock to 24 cents a common share. This compares with $6,524,543, or $2.73 a common share, earned in the preceding twelve months.

Ably meeting the heaviest charges of their victory-starved rivals, the New York Rangers added to their unbroken string of triumphs by defeating the Canadiens of Montreal, 2 to 1, in a National League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Relief without repentance, social service without spiritual challenge and ministering to human bodies without thinking of the human spirit are tendencies that have become a national menace, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of the Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said in a sermon yesterday.
President Sills of Bowdoin College today suggested "a movement for the reception of political and religious refugees into our own State."
On the foreignexchange market here last week the tendency was in the same direction as on the Bourse, but fluctuations were far from being so wide.

A goal in the last fifteen seconds by Julian Sawchuk, right defense, snapped a 3-all tie and enabled the league-leading New York Rovers to halt the Hershey (Pa.) Cubs, 4 to 8, in an Eastern Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
The resources of Columbia University and its affiliated institutions were estimated yesterday at $158,868,638, an increase of less than 3 per cent over last year's figures.

A nation-wide system of health insurance, "comprehensive and flexible in character," is urged by Dr. John A. Kingsbury, former director of the Milbank Memorial Fund, in a pamphlet to be published today under the auspices of the League for Industrial Democracy.

" Room Service" is this week's attraction at Maplewood, N. J., and "The Children's Hour" will be at Woodcliff, N. J. "The Kingdom of God" plays its second and final week at the Paper Mill Playhouse, Short Hills, N.J. "Created Equal," a WPA Living Newspaper offering, opens Saturday at the Opera House in Newark., N. J.

A new school building for the parish of Our Lady Help of Christians Roman Catholic Church was blessed and dedicated yesterday afternoon at East Twenty-ninth Street and Avenue M, Brooklyn, by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.
A $1,000,000 memorial chapel, gift of the H. J. Heinz family to the University of Pittsburgh, was dedicated today as a place where students may "worship in accord with their own beliefs."

The persecution of the Jews, Catholics and other racial and religious groups in Germany was denounced yesterday by religious leaders in nearly all leading denominations in churches and synagogues throughout the city.

One long reign was continued while another came to an abrupt end yesterday as Joseph P. McCluskey, veteran distance star of the New York Athletic Club, won the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior crosscountry championship in Forest Park, Woodhaven, and led the Winged Foot team to victory over the Millrose Athletic Association.

Hugh Miller Harmer, a member of the law firm of Sproull, Harmer Sproull, 1 Madison-Avenue, and a former Corporation Counsel of New Rochelle, died of a heart attack during his sleep early yesterday morning in his apartment in Butler Hall, 88 Morningside Drive. He was born in New Rochelle sixtynine years ago.

The number of persons usefully employed in F Germany at the end of October was st 20,800,000, according to the latest w report of the Reich Labor Institute. Of these, 6,600,000 were women-an increase of 48,000 over September. A total of 103,000 men and one of 1,400 women wer workless.

An increase of twenty-two junior fellowships among the 274 graduate students at Princeton University last year was noted today by Dr. Luther P. Eisenhart, dean of the graduate school, in his annual report. Sixty-five fellowships in all were awarded.

Speaking at Colmar, Alsace, Camille Chautemps, Vice Premier who is in charge of the affairs of Alsace and Lorraine, declared that French democracy, which was intensely patriotic, was determined to preserve the integrity of its soil against both open and underhand attacks.
Houston Gas Securities Company will redeem by lot on Dec. 31, at par, $100,000 of its 5 per cent collateral trust bonds. The bonds will be paid at the Chase National Bank.

L. F. Sanman gained the honors at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, taking the high-over-all scratch cup with a run of 100. E. J. Zeiner defeated J. J. Cook for the Class A handicap trophy and L. F. Sanman Jr. scored in a shoot-off with R. B. Sloan for the Class C award. W. Black led in Class B.

Mrs. Mary L. Lord of 34-31 Eightysecond Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, a linotype operator on THE NEW YORK TIMES since 1925, died yesterday in the New York PostGraduate Hospital, after an illness of two months. She was born in Maine sixty-two years ago.

W. Earle Andrews, engineer expert on park and recreational projects and consulting engineer for the World's Fair, will direct a survey designed to increase the outdoor facilities available for New York City boys, it was announced yesterday by the Boy Scout Federation of Greater New York.

Wilbert Layton, 34, and his 10-year-old son, John Wilbert, died tonight from eating ice cream which relatives said the father admitted poisoning. Another child, William Frederick, 7, was saved by quick action of a policeman.

The Ministry of the Interior recently dissolved all temperance organizations, which reportedly had some 50,000 members. The reason given was the alleged presence in the organizations of many Communists, who used them for the dissemination of propaganda.

The November issue of The Wilson Bulletin for Librarians reports that A. J. Cronin's "The Citadel" (Little, Brown) is currently heading the list of popular fiction in libraries in twenty-four cities. The children's book most in demand is "Sue Barton, Senior Nurse" by Helen Dore Boylston.

Two thousand Chinese died in the five-day fire that almost completely razed Changsha, Hunan Province cultural and commercial center that formerly had a population of 500,000, according to semi-official reports from Chungking, the temporary capital.

The "appalling" lack of simple, ordinary gratitude in human life was decried by the Rev. Leon Merle Flanders in a sermon at the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street, yesterday morning.

Three youths who went duck hunting in Long Island Sound yesterday are believed to have been swept to sea and lost. They were: Edward Onsrud, 19 years old, son of E. A. Onsrud, Farm Supervisor at the State Hospital here: Robert Brown, 18, son of Mrs. Mae Brown.

Greenwich House Music School will be aided by a concert to be given by Josef and Rosina Lhevinne, pianists, and the members of the Juilliard Orchestra under the direction of Albert Stoessel on the afternoon of Jan. 14 at Carnegie Hall. The occasion will mark the fortieth anniversary of the first joint concert appearance of Mr. and Mrs. Lhevinne at a benefit in Tiflis, Russia, Jan. 14, 1898.

The report of like the Bank of France on Nov. 10 shows a further improvement in the general fiscal situation. Bills discounted decreased 1,273,000,000 francs; and loans against securities and government bills fell 110,000,000. Moreover, amounts thus repaid to the bank through the market were more than offset by the return of deposits to banks.
Niagara University won the Western New York Little Three football crown today by defeating Canisius College, 12 to 0, before about 15,000 fans.

Action taken by the first constitutional convention of the C. I. O. in Pittsburgh last week has intensified the concern already felt by the La Guardia administration over the labor problems eonnected with rapid transit unification, it was disclosed yesterday.

Synthetic resins and their raw materials are covered by a survey made public today by the Tariff Commission in which it is shown that domestic output of the synthetic product increased from less than 2,000,000 pounds in 1921 to 162,000,000 last year, and the value of their sales from $1,400,000 to $25,800,000.
The award of forty-five baccalaureate and 135 advanced degrees at Cornell University, as of Sept. 28, was announced today by President Edmund Ezra Day. Those upon whom degrees were conferred are.

261st St (13-3423M), s s. 34 ft e of Fieldston Rd, 33x93; Herbert Loewenthal, guardian, to George R. Bunting, 4,611 Spuyten Duyvil Pkway. University Ave (11-3217), w s, 609 ft a of 183d St, 37x100; Charles B. McLaughlin Jr., referee, to City Bank Falmere Trust Co, trustee, 22 William St. 150th St, 143 E (9-2348); Harlem Savings Bank to Adrian P. Snoeren, 806 Grand Concourse.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, congratulated the New York Stereotypers Union, Local 1, an A. F. of L. affiliate, on its peaceful and progressive history as more than 1,500 members and guests of the union celebrated the organization's seventy-fifth anniversary yesterday with a dinner and entertainment at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
Howard. McMichael, with his Class B dinghy Ordeal, scored 135 points in seven races today in the Larchmont Yacht Club regatta. He.finished five ahead of Frank Campbell in his craft Felix.

The combined efforts of Dave Smukler, Bill Hewitt and Dick Riffle outweighed the individual brilliance of Whizzer White today and the Philadelphia Eagles downed the Pittsburgh Pirates,. 14 to 7, in a National Football League game.

The Department of Commerce released today a new publication, "Store Arrangement Principles,' the first in a series of reports designed to be of assistance to the small business man in the retail field.

For some time we have been receiving requests for information concerning the upland game shooting on Long Island, especially in the western and central areas. Inquiries addressed to several of the State game protectors brought somewhat vague answers, so we decided to make a check-up of the possibilities in these areas.

John Barrymore's Tower Road estate in Beverly Hills, Calif., representing an investment of almost half a million dollars, will be sold at auction as one parcel on Dec. 10 in the reception room of the main house, according to Arthur C. Sheridan of 18 East Forty-eighth Street, who will conduct the sale.

The campaign for funds for the support of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service is running behind the pace set last year, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the campaign committee, revealed last night.

More than 200 representatives of the cotton industry in fourteen producing States will convene here tomorrow morning to form a permanent National Cotton Council and endeavor to solve problems in the industry.

Authorities investigating the ambush murder Friday evening of John F. O'Hara, 26-year-old investigator for Dun Bradstreet, concentrated yesterday on a search for the car in which the gunmen drove away. Every patrolman on post in Queens was ordered to check up in all public and private garages.

Joseph K. Weitzenkorn, financier and philanthropist, died suddenly at his home here last night following a heart attack. He was 71. His son, Louis Weitzenkorn, the playwright, and a daughter, Mrs. Mortimer Schwager of Brooklyn, N. Y., arrived here today to attend funeral services tomorrow afternoon.
An 18month-old baby girl was found asleep in a hanging basket in a stolen automobile that was wrecked in a collision with a truck early this morning in front of 324 Nepperhan Avenue here.

The British and Canadian trade treaties, and the enthusiastic reception that has greeted their appearance on both sides of the water, have obviously encouraged the whole effort to reduce international trade barriers.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 63 per cent of capacity, up 2 points in the week and more than 34 points from the average in June, which was the low month since last December.

Frank Kniskern, chief electrician for Madison Square Garden, died in his sleep yesterday afternoon at his home in the Majestic Apartments at 373 Ninety-second Street, Brooklyn. There had been no previous illness. His age was 39.

Creation of a Federal Department of Transportation with a Secretary of Transportation of Cabinet rank has been recommended to the Transportation Conference of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which reconvenes here tomorrow.
The most "youthful" Western Conference honor team in recent years, the 1938 All-Big Ten football eleven, was chosen by conference coaches today for The Associated Press.

Protestant, Catholic and Jewish speakers at a meeting in His Majesty's Theatre held to arouse interest in the plight of Jews in Germany united today in a suggestion to the Canadian Government to assist in efforts to find a home for the refugees.

The sponsoring committee of the Conference on Pan-American Democracy, to be held in Washington Dec. 10 and 11, said today it intended to present "documentary evidence showing how the German, Italian and Japanese Governments are planning together to seize control of and partition Latin America."
The executive council of the New York State Conference of Polish Clubs adopted here today resolutions decrying the persecution of Jews and Catholics by the Nazis.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick disclosed yesterday that inspectors of his department had rejected in the last six weeks more than 500,000 .apples, 125,000 bananas and other foods intended for distribution to needy pupils by the school relief committee of the Board of Education.

Irving Barach, formerly in charge of rayon sales for Taylor, Clapp Beall, has joined the sales staff of the rayon women's wear division of Pacific Mills. Philip Schlossburg has been appointed national field sales manager of Keen Dry Shaver, Inc.
Paced by Ken Strong, the Jersey City Giants clinched the American Professional Football Association championship today by vanquishing the Union City Rams, 16-0, before a crowd of 11,000.

Ralph Bruno, 29 years old of 6,121 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot near the heart during a quarrel with two unidentified men in the hallway at 2,816 West Twentyfourth Street, in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, last night.

Herbert E. Plishker has been appointed advertising and sales promotion manager of the lamp division of Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, the company announced for publication today. Mr. Plishker has been on the lamp division advertising staff for eleven years and has served as assistant advertising and sales promotion manager for six years.
John W. Whiteley of Yonkers, a wholesale coal merchant, died today of a heart attack in the clubhouse of the Dunwoodie Country Club here, of which he was a member. His age was 57.

Foreigners are experiencing increasing difficulties in Manchukuo. When a Korean woman patient of a British doctor died after an operation, two Japanese lawyers induced the family to swear out a complaint, and the doctor was arrested on a charge of manslaughter.

The busiest week of the season, with a premiere every evening, is launched tonight by "Good Hunting" at the Hudson. It is a play which spoofs the general staffs of the World War armies and was written by Nathanael West and Joseph Schrank, the latter having been co-author of "Page Miss Glory" of 1934.
Isador S. Worth of Riverside, N. J., national commander of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, urged all Americans today to exercise a "rigid boycott" on all German goods and services.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Nancy Harlan Work, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Work Jr. of Ingleside, Lawrence, L. I., to A. Severin Bourne Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred S. Bourne of Washington, Conn., and Augusta, Ga.

COUNT BELISARIUS, by Robert Graves. (Random House, $3.) A historical novel. INCOME TAX SIMPLFIER, by Frank H. Shevit. (Forbes, $1.) A handbook. LAFAYETTE, by W. E. Woodward. (Farrar Rinehart, $3.50.) A biography.

The "World Woman's party" was created here today, "dedicated to the belief that men and women equally are entitled to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness in their own way under conditions hampering neither to the advantage of the other."

Queen Maud of Norway, a wisp of a woman who scarcely reached her tall husband's shoulder, was a symbol of that comfortable fusion of royalty and democracy which the Scandinavian countries, above all others, have managed to achieve.
Brisk activity in Queens realty was marked over the week-end by the sale of a site in the business section of Elmhurst for improvement with an apartment house.

Miss Anne McCall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner T. McCall of Greenwich, will be married to Dudley H. Dommerich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander L. Dommerlch, also of Greenwich on Dec. 10 at the Round Hill Community Church here. The Rev. Harold E. Wilson, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Henry E. Cobb, retired clergyman of Bronxville, will officiate.

Industrial labor peace through some form of profit-sharing received emphasis today as the goal of a special Senate committee which is scheduled to question a trio of industrial leaders at its first hearings tomorrow.

Bill Swan, veteran New Rochelle skipper, showed the way to the fleet in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's open frostbite regatta for Class D dinghies today. Winning but one race, but close up throughout the series of seven contests, Swan finished with 77 points to 65 for W. J. H. Dyer of Providence and 64 for E. L. Raymond of Stamford.
The Japanese have now conquered the railroad map of China and dispatches telling of the great fire in Changsha have brought

A new note will be introduced tonight at the Fordham College freshman dinner on the campus when for the first time an alumnus who is the father of one of the class members will address the 420 freshmen as guest sneaker.

Leaders In the business, industrial, religious and amusement fields are collaborating with the World's Fair on plans for a nationwide New Year's Eve celebration linked with the fair's theme, "Building the World of Tomorrow," and designed to direct the thoughts of Americans toward "The Dawn of a New Day" of peace and progress, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

A tea this afternoon, at which members of the board of directors of the Young Women's Christian Association will be the guests of honor, will formally open the exhibition of Christmas gifts at the Craft Students League of the Y. W. C. A., 745 Tenth Avenue.

Foreign trade returns of the Reich for October, Including the Sudetenland for the first time, showed total imports of 475,000,000 marks against 485,000,000 a year before, while exports amounted to 467,000,000 marks, against 544,000,000 last year, so both imports and exports, particUlarly the latter, declined.

Warner S. Shelly, newly elected vice president of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., has been placed in charge of service in the New York office, according to announcement for publication today. Mr. Shelly joined the Philadelphia office of N. W. Ayer in 1923 and was transferred to the New York office in 1925, remaining there until 1937, when he was returned to the Philadelphia office in an executive capacity.

The technique of successful living requires that man come to grips directly with the business of living and that he fall under the spell of life's regenerating influences, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, said in his sermon yesterday.
With Christians among those thronging the draped Temple Mishkan Tefila, the combined Jewry of Greater Boston today opened a three-day period of mourning for the Jews of Germany.
The newspaper Le Matin said today that the French Government had decided to establish concentration camps for undesirable foreigners convicted of crime in France.
The Philadelphia women's field hockey team defeated the Southeastern Reserves, 5 to 1, today in the closing game of the Southeastern women's. tournament.
Two miners were rescued alive today from a shaft in which collapsing timbers had imprisoned them for forty hours fifty feet below the surface.

While searching for a parole violator, detectives and New York State Parole Board officers arrested two men yesterday and charged them with participation in a $2,100 payroll robbery at 121 Norfolk Street several months ago.
Five persons were forced to take refuge in a dinghy in Great South Bay this afternoon when the motor cruiser in which they were riding exploded and sank.

Mr. and Mrs. Matthew White Galbraith of this place announced today at a tea the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Galbraith, to Charles A. Ruberl Jr., son of Charles A. Ruberl of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Ruberl.
Sir Arthur Levy, diamond expert, who supervised the cutting and polishing of the Cullinan diamond in Amsterdam before its presentation to Edward VII, died today at the age of 83.

Annual luncheon, American Waldensian Aid Society, Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, 1 P. M. Address by the Rev. George Stewart. Annual meeting, Society of Mayflower Descendants, Hotel Ambassador, 3 P. M. Pelham St. George Bissell, Henry H. Curran.

Major Gen. Karl Bodenschatz, a leading official of the German Air Ministry, arrived in London today on a secret mission almost on the eve of the departure of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, for important consultations in France.

Halifax citizens crowded a theatre today to hear addresses criticizing treatment of Jews by the German Government and passed a resolution condemning the Nazi regime for that treatment. R. A. Kanigsberg, president of the Halifax Jewish Congress, moved the resolution.
A longshoreman was killed and several narrowly escaped todays when two twelve-ton booms crashed to the decks of the German motorship Weser after steel lift cables had snapped.

AYRES-Mrs. Milan Church, In New York City, Nov. 20, after a brief illness; wife of the late Rev. Milan Church Ayres. Funeral private. Interment Fairview Cemetery, Middletown, N. J. BARSKY-Dr. Caroline Whitney, wife of George Barsky, daughter of Josepha Whitney and the late Edward B. Whitney. Funeral Riverside Memorial Chapel. 76th St., Amsterdam Ave., 10 A. M., Tuesday, Nov. 22. New Haven papers please copy.
Charges of murder against three youths were dismissed by Magistrate Matthew J. Troy in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday, but the accused men were rearrested on charges of robbery.

Brookhattan avenged last week's defeat by beating the Kearny Irish Americans at Starlight Park in the Bronx, 3 to 2, yesterday. A crowd of 5,000 saw the American Soccer League fixture. The Irish had a 1-0 lead at the half.

School bells will ring for the city's 34,000 pupils tomorrow as a threw weeks holiday caused by a depleted treasury ends. The Board of Education embarked on a "pay-as-you-go basis" with S430 228 available for operation.

Wrecked by the fury of a powerhouse line and a wild-running backfield that just would not be denied, the championship hopes of the Brooklyn Dodgers vanished yesterday at Ebbets Field as the Chicago Bears romped to a 24-to-6 triumph before a disappointed crowd of 26,416 persons.

With the United States an interested onlooker in the sweeping changes that have taken place in Europe in recent months, a nationwide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director, shows how American sympathies for different European countries have been affected.

Two one-gallon cans of benzine were found in a public locker in the Canal Street station of the Eighth Avenue subway by detectives who trailed an arson suspect to it after arresting his alleged accomplice Saturday evening.
Police announced today discovery of "largescale embezzlements" through which they charged Archduke Otto received 20,000 schillings monthly from the government of former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg.

Plans for two new housing projects in separate "slum areas" of the city were announced yesterday at the office of Mayor La Guardia at City Hall. The announcement did not specify the exact location of the projects.

Detroit kept alive its chances of tying Green Bay for the Western division championship of the National Football League by defeating the Cardinals, 7 to 3, today as the Packers bowed to New York. 15 to 3.
Three touchdowns in the final eight minutes gave the University of Scranton a 25-to-3 football victory over Mount St. Mary's College before 5,800 spectators today.

Michael McMahon, 43 years old, of 48 West Sixty-fourth Street, died in Bellevue Hospital last night after he had been taken there about 6:45 o'clock from the Hudson River between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets.

Prayers for the relief of German Jews were said in many Anglican churches throughout Britain today and a petition signed by 30,000 Catholics headed by Cardinal Hinsley protested against what was described as Nazi terrorism toward German Catholics.
If there is any other way of stopping the Nazi party's methods of undeclared war than by fighting the German people once more, European statesmen will be glad to hear about it.
Referring to President Roosevelt's plans for continental defense, Minister of Foreign Relations Luis Arteaga declared yesterday that national opinion here had revealed its general approval.

To illustrate the limited opportunities in German universities, the student council of Hunter College has called a one-day halt of all extra-curricular activities in the four college buildings for today. All student activities will be closed, including publications. club meetings.

Japan broadened today her monopoly of interior waterways in China by notifying United States and other consular officials at Hankow that the Han River, Yangtze River tributary traversing Hupeh Province west of Hankow, had been closed to navigation except on "special permission of the Japanese Army."

Dwight Marshall. in 65 E 96th St: Walter L. Dessauer, in 350 E 52d St; Mrs. Nina Cover. in 136 E 36th St; H. Warren Billings, in 149 E 45th St: Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers. J. Friedenberg, in 230 Central Park W; I Rich, in 393 West End Ave; M. J. Henderson. in 395 Riverside Dr: Joseph Sugar, in 245 W 75th St; Apartment Renting Co. broker.

A suggestion that the city should institute at once a moratorium on new projects charged against the city's borrowing power was offered to Mayor La Guardia in a letter made public yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York.

Perhaps the most favorable feature of Great Britain's foreign trade in October was the further decline in the adverse balance from the [Pound]43,284,000 of a year ago to [Pound]31,029,000, which makes the total for the first ten months of this year [Pound]328,687,000, against [Pound]340,439,000 a year before.

Protests against the "horrors" of the Nazi persecution of Jews in Germany were voiced last night by Charles A. Poletti, Lieutenant Governor-elect; Richard W. Lawrence, president of the New York City Y. M. C. A.; James J. Lyons, Bronx Borough President, and other speakers at a testimonial dinner for Rabbi Henry A. Schorr of Temple Adath Israel, the Bronx.

Today's events: "Otello," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M.: Catherine Reiner, soprano, Town Hall, 3; Pine Mountain Settlement School concert, Town Hall, 8:30; W. C. Handy birthday concert, Carnegie Hall, 8.

While the Canadian import duty on corn from the United States was reduced 50 per cent by the new treaty between the two countries, the cut has failed so far to increase the demand there for that grain.

Local problems in the retail industry will be discussed here tomorrow and on Tuesday by representatives of twenty-four State-wide retail organizations and seven national trade associations at the third annual association executives conference of the American Retail Association.
Catholic University overpowered Loyola of the South today, 14 to 0. The Cardinals marched deep into Loyola territory five times in the first half, but did not score until the third period.

The New York State Parole Board announced today 1,746 prisoners with minimum and maximum limits to their sentences were released in 1937, bringing the State's average parole population to about 8,000.

The violence of Germany's anti-Jewish campaign has exerted a widespread influence in the financial markets here, although the effects of the latest racial excesses have been almost wholly psychological except as reflected in a further recession in the pound and in increased exports of gold.
In Washington today a subcommittee of the Senate begins hearings on profitsharing in American industry. It is acting under a resolution introduced by Senator Vandenberg.

Dr. and Mrs. Francis Lawrence Tooley gave a tea yesterday at their home, 124 East Seventy-ninth Street, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothea Frances Tooley, to Francis I. Howley, son of Mrs. William E. Howley, also of New York, and the late Dr. Howley.

The Russian Communist party has for all practical purposes abandoned one of the most important fundamental tenets of Communist doctrine, namely, that with the coming of communism the State, in Karl Marx's phrase, will "wither away" and socity will become an orderly, anarchistic Utopia.

" The Spreading of the Gospel," a single fresco panel that is believed to be one of the largest works of its kind in this country, was dedicated yesterday morning at the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventythird Street, west of Broadway. The Rev. Dr. Daniel Russell, the pastor, officiated.

Art is the visual expression of the soul of a people. In periods of chaos or stagnation it either dies or rots. In a time of intellectual or emotional ferment it finds a new birth and flourishes with a vigorous life of its own.

While Reuben Fine of New York, leader in the A. V. R. O. international chess tournament, adjourned his game with Jose R. Capablanca of Havana in an even position, Paul Keres of Estonia, the runner-up, drew with Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia in the tenth round tonight.
Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., one of Mayor La Guardia's secretaries, frustrated today the plans of two youths to have Thanksgiving dinner at his expense.

The Catholic Church is the only power capable of demanding and maintaining the democratic formula, Mgr. Joseph M. Corrigan, rector of Catholic University, Washington, said in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

Samuel Wilson Jr., 18 years old, or 731 Bayview Avenue, Inwood, was killed this afternoon when the auto- t mobile in which he was riding crashed into a concrete buttress of a small bridge on Doughty Boulevard here.

Details of two German-Czech agreements providing for a great motor highway and canal waterways to connect upper Germany with Austria through the center of Czechoslovakia were revealed Saturday and yesterday in official radio broadcasts from Berlin.

Another sharp reduction was made in the fast-thinning ranks of scholastic football teams during the past week-end, for many more squads joined those which had concluded the 1938 campaign more than a week ago.
Although it is too early to make forecasts, there is a general feeling that the Christmas of 1938 is going to be a better one than Chicago had in 1937 so far as business is concerned.

The committee for the 8 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation notified yesterday holders that D. A. Schulte, president of the company, would finance the plans of reorganization under certain terms and conditions.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the Pathe Film Corporation has been called for Dec. 12 instead of Dec. 6 to vote on a plan of liquidation. The principal asset of the company consists of its 85 per cent interest in the du Pont Film Manufacturing Corporation, the other 65 per cent being held by the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

The Duke Power Company soon will start building the first of several steam power plants to meet the demands of industrial growth in this section, according to C. I. Burkholder, vice president and chief engineer.

New York is the center of communistic activity in the country, and the Mayor of that city is the head of that movement, George U. Harvey, President of the Borough of Queens, declared in a brief address at the George Breeman Memorial services in Memorial Park this afternoon.

Prices on the Boerse here were depressed all last week, because, on the one hand, despite official restrictions on the sale of Jewish-owned securities, a considerable volume was offered under the 1,000-mark exemption rule; and, on the other hand, because "Aryans" also were sellers to raise cash to obtain Jewish businesses that are being liquidated at knock-down prices.
Mayor La Guardia tonight accepted an invitation to unveil a memorial to Amelia Earhart at the Miami Municipal Airport on Jan. 6, in connection with the annual all-American air manoeuvres here.

It is gratifying to have the assurance both of Chairman Donahey and of the counsel, Francis Biddle, that the Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority did not ask for and does not intend to use the broad authority conferred by the President's executive order authorizing it to investigate the income and excess profits tax returns both of utility companies and their executives.

Dr. and Mrs. Norborne Page Cocke of University, Va., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cocke's daughter, Miss Constance Ann Collier, to William Saunders Buttfield, son of Mrs. John E. Lancaster of New York. The announcement was made this afternoon at a tea given at the Farmington Country Club here.

Toronto's Maple Leafs, playing their second game in two nights, held Chicago's National Hockey League leaders to a 1-to-1 overtime tie tonight before a Stadium crowd of 17,302, the largest of the season.

How the fine imposed by the government on the Jews is to be collected is now the subject of serious deliberation both by the German authorities and the Jews themselves. When ultimately it has been definitely decided what each individual must pay, the demand is to be presented individually by the taxation authorities in the usual way.
Mgr. Peter M. Cauley, vicar general of the Erie Catholic Diocese and pastor of St. Patrick's Church for a forty-six years, died tonight. He was 83 years old.

While importations of cotton piece goods into the Union of South Africa were decreasing in the first six months of this year compared with the similar period of 1937, the United States' portion of the total trade increased from 950,000 yards
The Danbury Trojans continued their winning pace in the American Professional Football Association today, downing the Newark Tornadoes, 22 to 0.
Announcement of a series of four public lectures by Dr. Thomas Mann, the writer, was made today by Alexander Leitch, secretary of the university committee on public lectures.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and the rest of the Republican State ticket were defeated at the recent election because Republican leaders in New York City "licked the boots of radicalism," Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, said yesterday in a letter to council members.

A young lady in Hollywood has been in difficulties because she insisted on wearing slacks when appearing as a witness before a municipal judge. However, an Appellate Court has decided, while mildly reprimanding her, that the costume was in good-taste.

TWICE the Yale team had thrown back a highTly favored Harvard team in the mud and ooze of a rain-drenched Bowl, and, with the gloom of a sodden night sinking over the weird scene of dim, mud-coated figures struggling in a spattering rain and a drifting mist, Old Eli had the Crimson horde in jeopardy. It was Yale's ball on the Harvard 20-yard line! And first down!

With a declaration that the nations of the Western Hemisphere must "stand together," Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of the Constitutional Army of Cuba, departed at 10 o'clock last night on the Havana Special from the Pennsylvania Station.

A card party and tea for the benefit of the building and scholarship fund of Marymount College will be held Nov. 29 in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis under the auspices of the mothers auxiliary of the college. Mrs. Harry A.

The international reaction to the anti-Jewish measures in Germany and the German response to it reveal a shift in Germany's foreign policy that amounts to a revision of the international strategy laid down in Adolf Hitler's book, "Mein.Kampf," and consistently followed up to the peace of Munich.
Fourteen hundred persons attended last night the first annual entertainment and dance of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union at the Hotel Astor.

Another move was made last week toward the achievement of a full National Soclalist commercial German economy With the issue of a decree requiring all principals In commercial, industrial and trade organizations in the 91 Reich to be approved by the party.

Sumner P. Hunt, outstanding civic leader and architect here, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in his home last night, at the age of 73, after being ill two days. His daughter, Miss Louise Hunt, and his physician were at his bedside when death came.

Knocked from his horse by a slab of concrete tossed from the roof of a five-story tenement at 83 West 132d Street, Mounted Patrolman Thomas Hamilton, 34 years old, of 2,028 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, was taken to Harlem Hospital at about 6 o'clock last night.
Yesterday an Englishman and an American were discussing the curious ups and downs, the attractions and repulsions, in the relations between their respective countries.

Employers were warned today by Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Law, that provisions of the law cannot be disregarded merely because an employe consents to the evasion. Those who did so were subject to the law's penalties, he asserted.

William Rottger, unattached, was first to finish in a field of fiftyseven in the third annual five-mile A. A. U. handicap road run conducted by the Boys of Yesteryear through the streets of Harlem yesterday.

Add to the middleweight championship muddle the name of Ceferino Garcia. The sturdy Filipino, who is to fight Henry Armstrong for the welterweight title in Madison Square Garden Friday night, announced yesterday through his manager, George Parnassus, that if he wins he will seek a match against Fred Apostoli of San Francisco, recognized as the world middleweight titleholder in New York as a consequence of his eight-round knockout of Young Corbett 3d last week.

Large space on the concourse level of The Associated Press Building in Rockefeller Center has been leased by the Union News Company for a restaurant, oyster bar and cocktail lounge. The oyster bar will be fifty feet long and similar to the company's bar in Grand Central Station.

The third annual merchandising industries dinner was held last night at the Hotel Astor to raise funds for the maintenance of New York tuberculosis patients at the Los Angeles Sanatorium, a national free and nonsectarian institution.

Condemnation of Hitler as a "shrewd, cruel and shifty" maniac, anxious to rule the world by terrorism, was voiced last night by Robert E. Sherwood and Maxwell Anderson, both Pulitzer Prize winners in playwrighting, in curtain speeches at special performances of their respective plays, "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" and "Knickerbocker Holiday," for the benefit of German refugees. Mr. Sherwood spoke at the Plymouth Theatre and Mr. Anderson at the Ethel Barrymore.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.4, which compared with 80.5 the week before, 80.4 two weeks before, 80.4 three weeks before and 79.9 four weeks before (reached also on Aug. 20).

Mrs. Milan Church Ayres, who had attained the age of 94, died yesterday after a brief illness in her home at 333 Central Park West. Mrs. Ayres, the former Miss Georgiana Gall, was a descendant of Franz Joseph Gall, the anatomist and physiologist.

The Nazi outrages against the Jews and other minority groups in Germany are not a sudden fury, but are the product of Nineteenth Century German philosophy, the Very Rev. Dr. James F. Kelley, president of Seton Hall College, declared today at the monthly meeting of the National Federation of

Unconvincingly, the German authorities maintain that the new Anglo-American trade treaty will have no deleterious effects on German commerce with the United Kingdom, since, under the Anglo-German trade agreement, the Reich enjoys the most-favorednation treatment, and, as a result, will derive benefit from any fiscal concessions Great Britain makes to the United States.

The Mount Vernon Realty Board, through President Edward F. Hallahan and Major Leslie Thompson of Larchmont, representing groups of taxpayers, today sent out 5,000 petitions for taxpayers to sign in protest to the Westchester County Board of Supervisors against an $3,783,514 increase in the 1939 county budget.

Mordecai Konowitz was re-elected president of the Long Island Zionist Region at its convention yesterday in the Astoria Center of Israel. Others named were Sol Cohen, Harry K. Moskowitz and Irving Schatzberg, vice presidents; Ben M. Friedman, secretary, and Bernard Davidson, treasurer.

A Jewish rabbi, the Rev. Dr. Sidney Tedeche, and members of the Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, attended the regular morning service of the Duryea Presbyterian Church, Sterling Place and Underhill Avenue, yesterday and were welcomed by the Rev. Dr. William G. Clark-Duff, pastor of the church.

Mrs. Walter Watson Patrick of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Mills Patrick, to Henry Richard Wilsey, son of Willard Warren Wilsey, also of Upper Montclair, and the late Mrs. Wilsey.

A prayer for the oppressor as well as the oppressed was offered last night in a broadcast by the National Conference of Jews and Christians on which spoke a Protestant educator, a Catholic editor and a Jewish philanthropist.

The Coast Guard cutter Sebago planted a mine in the wreckage of the barge Pacific early tonight and partly destroyed it. The barge began to founder in bad weather last night as it was being towed by the tug Goliath about forty-five miles northeast of Cape Henry.

Commerce St, 27, n e cor Bedford St. to Barrow St, 65; Josephine Agolia to Barford Realty Corp, 18 E 41st St; mtg $75.000 and purchase money mtg $10,000 ($20). Pike St, 27; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Maxton Contracting Corp. 282 W 114th St; purchase money mtg $16,626 and building loan mtg $7.420 ($17). Suffolk St, 14; Mitaked, Inc, to Reconstruction Building Corp. 1,819 B'way (50).

A concerted move to make possible the immigration of 5,000 Jewish children from Germany by means of a widespread system of adoption was announced today by the Vaad Leumi, the General Council of Jews in Palestine, in cooperation with the Jewish community councils in Jerusalem and Haifa.
Bronx properties under new con- City or on trol include a forty-two-family apartment house that was bought by an investor from the builders.

British gold imports in October amounted to [pound]29,446,660, against [pounds]12,729,690 eorrespondingly last year, putting the ten-month total in 1938 at [pound]228,196,213, against [pound]270,862,855 similarly in 1937.
Sid Luckman, Columbia's triplethreat ace, suffered a broken nose in the second play of the third quarter in the Syracuse game at Baker Field last Saturday, it was learned yesterday.

THE useful thing about Robert Graves's "Count Belisarius"* is that it teaches a painless lesson in ancient history. The interesting thing is that it is a novel, another of Mr. Graves's quasifictional narratives on the order of "I, Claudius" and "Claudius the God."
Flame spitting from a borrowed pistol, the Rev. William Worth Williams, pastor of Mabel White Baptist Church here, chased four would-be car thieves into a ditch at the end of a blind street tonight.

Propper-McCallum Hosiery Company, Inc., has signed a three-year contract with Branch 12, American Federation of Hosiery Workers, affiliated with the C. I. O., according to announcement for publication
Seventeen members of the faculty of New York University have been promoted to higher academic rank or to new administrative posts, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

The demand for personal counsel bnd guidance put upon the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, by his congregation and others has become so great, he announced yesterday, that he has selected six volunteer members of the church to assist him in this special work after they have received training from him.

The German people were dissociated from the Nazi regime and held to be out of sympathy with persecution of Jews there by City Court Justice Vincent S. Lippe, the Rev. Christian F. Reisner and Ione Robinson, an Americanistudent recently returned from Germany, speaking last night at the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:

The Sanitation Benevolent Association held a meeting yesterday afternoon for sanitation employes in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, to develop along benevolent lines a single employes' association similar to that of the Police and Fire Department units, and to initiate a welfare program for the 11,000 members of the uniformed force.

The Metropolitan opera season will open tonight with Verdi's "Otello." The cast will be headed by Maria Caniglia, who makes her debut as Desdemona; Giovanni Martinelli in the title role and Lawrence Tibbett as Iago. Lesser roles will be sung by Thelma Votipka, Nicholas Massue, George Cehanovsky, Wilfred Engelman and Giordano Paltrinieri. Ettore Panizza will conduct.
Blood taken from the veins of Clarion Weltha, 45, while he was unconscious resulted early today in his conviction on charges of manslaughter.

Joint religious services will be held in the future by the congregations of Union Temple and Temple Beth Elohim, two of the largest Hebrew congregations in Brooklyn, it was disclosed last night at a dinner sponsored by the Sisterhood and Men's Club of Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway. Brooklyn.
Jewelry, clothing and household goods valued at more than $15,000 were stolen in two burglaries in homes here late yesterday afternoon or last evening, . it was discovered early today.

An American Institute of Public Opinion survey of the influences behind the political shift shown in this year's elections indicates that the greatest rate of shift away from President Roosevelt is taking place among voters who have the most income, while the smallest shift is occurring with those of least income, Dr. George Gallup, director of the institute, announced yesterday.

Dr. Caroline Whitney of 333 East Forty-first Street, chairman of the Milk Consumers Protective Committee and a member of the committee recently appointed by Mayor La Guardia to investigate the milk industry in New York, died suddenly Saturday night in the Presbyterian Hospital of a pulmonary embolism. She was 37 years old.

Mrs. Charlotte S. French, 59, of Winchester, mother of Art French, former Harvard football star, died today of injuries received last night. when she was returning from the Harvard-Yale game at New Haven. Her automobile was in collision with another.

The French wholesale price index on Nov. 12 was 653, compared with 652 and 654 one and two weeks before. The weekly trend of French wholesale prices by groups, based on the average of 1914 as 100, is shown in the following table, giving figures for the last three weeks and for Sept. 12, before devaluation of the franc in that year:
James McNeil, 54 years old, of 535 East Sixth Street, a WPA plumber, was stabbed in the left arm late last night during a quarrel outside his apartment.

The creation by Congress of an agricultural and industrial credit corporation in an attempt to meet conditions in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, widely differing from those on the mainland, has been approved in principle by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, according to Miles H. Fairbank, Assistant Administrator, under Secretary Ickes, of the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration.
King Leopold will go to The Netherlands tomorrow with Premier PaulHenri Spaak on a State visit. Belgian and Netherland newspapers consider the trip of considerable political importance.
John R. Livezey, head of an insulation contracting business, died yesterday at his home in Elkins Park at the age of 71.

A new cargo carrier that went to sea without the formality of a launching will be inspected by shipping men in New York late this week when the Dolomite 4, owned and operated by the Dolomite Marine Corporation., arrives from Lake ports with a cargo of 2,000 tons of caustic soda.

Second Lieut. John D. Madre, sole survivor of an army bombing plane plunge, showed some improvement today while investigators continued study of the Friday night tragedy which cost the lives of four officers and three enlisted men.
A convoy of 150 automobiles headed by the President of the Republic left this morning for Huaras, officially inaugurating a 100-mile addition to the Peruvian section of the Pan-American Highway.

An appeal to the Jews to turn to the Book instead of the sword and not return hatred for hatred was made last night by Abraham Brill, Brooklyn attorney, in making his tenth annual report as president of Temple Shaari Zedek, Kingston Avenue and Park Place, Brooklyn, one of the largest Jewish congregations in the city.

The level of full-time employment in Philadelphia was slightly higher last Summer than in the Spring of 1936 although lower than in 1937, according to the annual survey of employment taken by the Industrial Research Department of the University of Pennsylvania in cooperation with the Works Progress Administration.
The New York Athletic Club displayed a powerful attack as it crushed the New York Sporting Club, 8 to 1, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association test at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

The interests of the public must not be sacrificed in attaining peace in disputes between management and labor, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declares in his monthly review of business sent to the association's 20,000 banking, manufacturing and wholesaling credit executives and made public yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Van Sinderen Lindsley of this city and Lawrence, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabel Fanshawe Lindsley, to Henry Joseph Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph of Montreal.
