The Paterson Panthers defeated the Brooklyn Eagles in an American Professional Football Association game today, 16-7. before 8,000 fans.

The temporary White House moved southward tonight as President Roosevelt, aboard his special train, headed for Warm Springs, Ga., for two weeks of relaxation in preparation for the new Congressional session which begins the first week in January.

Three months to Sept. 30: Net profit, $435,685, equal to 98 cents a share on 441,354 common shares, compared With a net profit of $511,333, or $1.15 a common share, for the three months to Sept. 30, 1937.

The St. Vincent College Bearcats found a soggy gridiron to their liking today and chalked up their eighth victory of the season at the expense of St. Bonaventure of Olean, N. Y., 21-7, before a crowd of 4,000.

The first im-, pression caused. by the decree laws was good. The Bourse bounded up while the equalization fund was forced to buy about 1,000,000,000 francs worth of foreign currency to satisfy the demand for francs that the market could not meet.

A modern church has "three definite contributions" to make to the life of the community around it, the Rev. Quentin T. Lightner of the Baptist Church of the Redeemer, Ocean Avenue and Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn, declared yesterday at the dedication of the new edifice of Kenilworth Baptist Church, Farragut Road and Kenilworth Place, Brooklyn.

Prejudice, hatred and acting without knowledge were named today as among the greatest obstacles to spiritual growth by the Rev. Herbert J. Glover, vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, in his morning sermon.

The Charity Organization Society announced yesterday that Porter R. Lee, director for the last twentyone years of the New York School of Social Work, an affiliate of the society, had resigned because of ill health.
The City Council has promulgated regulations, approved early this year, for the creation of a "first-class. shopping zone." The district involved is thirty square blocks in the middle of the capital.

Everett Elkins of Marshall College has just about clinched individual scoring honors for the Eastern football season of 1938. Elkins scored one touchdown, his fifteenth of the season, against Ohio University Saturday. After nine games, Elkins has scored 90 points and has one more game to play.

The atmosphere of friendliness surrounding Anglo-American relations "should be a source of general rejoicing at this particular time," Prime Minister Mackenzie King said today on his return from Washington.

Textbooks for college students are rapidly going out of fashion, Theodore W. Koch, Northwestern University librarian, said today. "Formerly classes used textbooks which they were expected to study from cover to cover," he said.
Young Joseph Donnelly Jr. struck a sharp blow for masculine dominance in the horse show ring today and left the Ramapo Valley Riding and Polo Club loaded down with silverware and ribbons.

Thanks to a Jersey City policeman, Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Joseph will eat turkey after all this Thanksgiving. It will be one of the most expensive dinners they ever had, however, for the turkey alone will cost them something like $56.24.

Chairman Dies of the House Committee on un-American Activities said today that David J. Saposs, economist for the Labor Relations Board, wrote an article in 1931 advising workers to use force if political action failed to establish socialism.

Plans for fighting inroads of chain shoe stores on the business of independent retailers were discussed last night at a meeting of the Retail Shoe Merchants Association of New York, Inc., an organization of about 300 Bronx independent dealers. at 792 East Tremont Avenue. Jobbers attending

Undismayed by sin straight setbacks in as many skirmishes since the hockey season opened, the Montreal Canadiens tonight will seek to break into the victory column of the National Hockey League standing when they tackle Red Dutton's Americans in Madison Square Garden.

AMONG those present were Lou Little, Dr. Mal Stevens, stout Steve Owen, Benny Friedman, Herb Kopf, Cliff Battles, Dan Topping, Shipwreck Kelly, Bo Molenda and the usual sprinkling of sideline experts and merry villagers. Somebody said to Benny Friedman that he was all for a strong defense because, if you can keep the other team from scoring, they never can beat you.

The State Athletic Commission at its meeting today is scheduled to dispose of the situation which finds Solly Krieger of Brooklyn and Fred Apostoli, Pacific Coast fighter, disputing possession of the world middleweight championship.

Under the German-Brazilian barter trade pact negotiated in 1935 the Bank of Brazil allowed today the immediate shipment of 200,000 bags of coffee "to complete the coffee quota allowed to Germany by treaty," maintaining that after this
Five newly accredited diplomats, two of them Ambassadors and three Ministers, presented their credentials today to Chancellor Adolf Hitler in the Berghof, near Berchtesgaden.

The United States Government today indicted the Mexican rebel General Saturnino Cedillo, cutting off an avenue of escape from Mexico. Cedillo, three other Mexicans and two American aviators were accaused of conspiracy and violation of the American Neutrality Act of 1937.

Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today that it was "fairly obvious" that final developments in drafting national defense plans were holding up the tax program to be submitted to Congress at the coming session.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Cogswell of Jamaica, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bertha Wheatley Cogswell, to Hadley Brinsmead Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Brinsmead Williams of Phoenix. Ariz.

Testifying before the Congressional investigating committee today, representatives of the American Farm Bureau Federation, saying they spoke for;1,500,000 farm people, approved the TVA program for production of cheap, highly concentrated phosphate fertilizers.
The Milwaukee Journal announced today that employes had received an opportunity to buy an additional block of 15 per cent of the newspaDer's stock.

Automobile dealers and factory representatives will attend a preview dinner tonight in the Administration Building on the World's Fair grounds on the eve of the opening of the Auto Show at the World's Fair in the Motor Transportation Building under the sponsorship of the Brooklyn-Long Island Automobile Dealers Association. D. G. Campbell, president

A bitter attack on the "wholesale-retail racket" tonight marked an address by William J. Cheyney, vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, delivered at a banquet of the third annual Association Executives' Conference of the- American Retail Federation, meeting here at the Hay-Adams House:
The Constitutional Congress began its active sessions today after its inauguration yesterday by President Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez with the diplomatic corps present.

Distributors of electrical appliances predicted yesterday that holiday sales of small table and plug-in appliances would exceed those of last year. The package idea, promoted so successfully here, has been adapted in other major markets, with the result that unit sales are rising sharply.

Buyers were poultry-minded for the Thanksgiving holiday and trading in meats was generally only fair to slow in the local wholesale markets yesterday. Lamb and fresh pork prices were steady to lower; veal and calf showed weakness; other classes were mostly unchanged.

John Holliday, Civil War veteran who was an Odd Fellow for sixtythree years and a Mason sixty-one years, died Friday night in his home here at the age of 90. He was for years employed as pilot and in other capacities on freight vessels on the Hudson River and passenger steamers on Long Island Sound.

The American Mutual Liability Insurance Company--has placed a group insurance program through the Equitable Life Assurance Socity, under which all of the 1,900 employes of American Mutual and associated companies automatically receive group life and group accident and health coverage without cost to themselves as soon as they have been employed for one year.

A net shortage of $16,823 in the accounts of William F. Blauvelt, cashier in the office of the Receiver of Taxes in the Town of Oyster Bay, who committed suicide on July 26, was reported to Edward J. Neary, District Attorney of Nassau County, tonight by County Executive J. Russel Sprague.
The National Grange urged in a resolution tonight adequate armament for national defense but an embargo upon war materials to nations in conflict.

John R. Mohr, a vice president of the Brooklyn Trust Company, 177 Montague Street, died Sunday in the Brooklyn Hospital after a short illness. He was 47 years old and lived at 110-41 198th Street, Hollis, Queens.

Another step toward realization of the city's plan to rid the streets of pushcart markets and concentrate such enterprises under roofs in central locations was taken yesterday when plans were filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings for four new buildings on the lower East Side.

James Houghteling, Immigration Commissioner, said tonight that Paul List, held at Ellis Island as a stowaway from a French Line ship, would not be sent back to his native Germany, but would be allowed to go to some other country and return to the United States under the German quota.

Employers may not withhold part of their employes' minimum wages pending an exemption for learners under the Wages and Hours Law, it was announced today at the office of Administrator Elmer F. Andrews.
Several Westchester and Connecticut properties figured in deals reported yesterday by the High Ridge (Conn.) office of Butler Baldwin, Inc., broker. At Poundridge, N. Y.,
Gales sweeping the French coasts today delayed the departure of 673 convicts for the island penal settlements of French Guiana.

Once again the golden horseshoe at the Metropolitan Opera gleamed, living up to its tradition for resplendence, as the curtain majestically drew aside to reveal the season's opening performance, "Otello." The house was aglow with color, for women, young and old, elected to follow the season's endorsement of rich tones.

Governor Nelson G. Kraschel tonight ordered the immediate withdrawal of National Guardsmen from the scene of the Swift Co. packing plant strike at Sioux City. "There seems to be no further need for the guard at the strike scene," the Governor said.

The Pine Mountain Settlement School of Harlan County, Kentucky, celebrated its silver jubilee with a gala evening of American and English folksong and folkdance last night at Town Hall. The proceeds will be directed to the school's new Hospitality House, a recreation center.

Fred J. Werner, 35 years old, of 1,333 East Twenty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, a former public school teacher and church organist, who pleaded guilty recently in Kings County Court to a charge of grand larceny, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Peter J. Brancato to serve two and one-half to five years in Sing Sing Prison.

Harold L. Rutledge, 39 years old, of Packanack Lake, N. J., who in fifteen years stole $130,915 from his employers, Hemphill, Noyes Co., investment dealers at 15 Broad Street, so that he and his family "could keep up with the Joneses," was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions.

While searching for a snug corner in which to sleep, a month-old cocker spaniel crawled under a gas refrigerator in the kitchen of William Hughes' second-floor apartment at 87 Elwood Street early yesterday and became wedged so tightly between the refrigerator and the floor that a police emergency squad had to be called to extricate the puppy.

The reaction of Britons and Americans to Nazi treatment of Jews is "one more instance of instinctive expression of a common outlook," former Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden declared tonight in an address before the League of Nations Union at Leicester.

Accused of attempted arson in an alleged plot to burn a general merchandise store at 378 Canal Street for the insurance money, Albert Danzig, 34 years old, a former fire adjuster, of 113 West Eighty-fourth Street, admitted in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday that he had set a "number of fires" in other places.

The body or Queen Maud of Norway will lie in state in the chapel of Marlborough House, where she spent her childhood, it was decided today. The general public will not be admitted, but it is possible that some members of the Norwegian colony in London, as well as her British royal relations and English friends will view the body.

Although President Leon Cortes Castro had declared that he would not call Congress to a special session after the failure of the Panama-Costa Rica boundary treaty, he has now issued a call for a special session on Dec. 1.

The annual report of the Chief of Naval Operations, published yesterday, does little to clarify the two fundamentally important naval problems which Secretary of the Navy Swanson failed to consider in his annual report.

Essex St, 80, 1-story public market, 252.7x 71.4; cost, $120,000; Essex St, 100; same, 402.1x70.4; cost, $155,000; Essex St, 130E1, same, 225.3x69.11: cost, $85,000; Essex St, 156. same, 150x69.10; cost. $60,000; Department of Public Works, N. Y. C., owner; Lewis Churchill, architects.

The latest amended plan for merging the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company and its underliers into a single corporation capitalized at $85,000,000 was approved today by the Pennsylvania Public Utility Corporation.

Acquisition of a strip of land running about a mile through Bellerose and Elmont, which is to become part of the cross island section of the Circumferential Highway, was authorized by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors here today.

Three young men lost their lives early today when the automobile in which they were riding crashed into a steam roller on the edge of the new traffic circle on Route 25. They were Percy Anderson, 21 years old, of Morgan, N. J.; Ralph Rippin, 20, of Cliffwood, and John J. Juchnowicz, 20, of South River.

1,320 yards, 3m.3-10s., Wayne Rideout, North Texas State Teachers College at Princeton, N. J, June 18. 1938 3 miles. 14m.27s.. Donald R. Lash, Indiana Univ., at East Lansing, Mich., Nov. 22, 1937. 4 miles, 19m.17.3s., Donald R. Lash, Indiana Univ., at East Lansing, Mich., Nov. 22, 1937. 2 mile steeplechase, 9m.59.4s., Floyd Lochner, Univ. of Okla., at Princeton, N. J., June 19, 1937.

More active covering of near month obligations before notices on Friday, together with smaller ginning figures than had been anticipated, advanced prices 6 to 9 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The December went into

Robert Irwin, 30 years old, who is to be sentenced by Judge Wallace next Monday for the Gedeon slayings, created a stir yesterday in the psychiatric clinic of General Sessions by ramming his left elbow through a frosted partition window when he objected to a question.

A lengthy examination of J. I. Mange, president of the Associated Gas and Electric Company since 1922, was a feature in today's session of the Public Service Commission's investigation into the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, a subsidiary of associated gas.

Before a glittering throng, with Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, in attendance, Major Eduardo Yanez of the Chilean Army tonight won the international military handy course event at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

Careful public study and full discussion of the recommendations recently submitted to the Board of Regents for changes in the State's school system were urged last night by Owen D. Young, a member of the board, and Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education. They spoke at the annual dinner of the House of Delegates of the New York State Teachers Association at the Commodore Hotel.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today its adoption of a rule which permits holding companies to omit details, of tentative plans for economic and geographic integration of their systems which have been submitted informally to the commission- from registration statements, provided they make a reference to the fact that such application has been presented under Section 11 (b) of the Holding Company Act.

Representatives of private clubs in Boston testified today that consumption of liquor had decreased so much since prohibition that the clubs would have to close if their liquor license fees were raised, as proposed, from $600 to $1,200 a year.

The German Reichbank has raised the taxes on registered marks for traveling purposes and has levied a tax on registered marks for gift and support purposes, according to advices reaching Zimmermann Forshay, Inc., here. The new

C. O. Wellington of the Harvard Club reached the final of the metropolitan squash racquets veterans championship tourney last night at the Squash Club by vanquishing J. T. Terry Jr. of the Racquet and Tennis Club in four games.
Germans--Jews and non-Jews-were amazed tonight at the British plan for Jewish refugees to settle on former German colonial soil-a project to which Germany is strongly opposed.

The California-Arizona citrus industry marketed 107,330 cars of oranges, lemons and grapefruit for consumption as fresh fruit during the 1937-38 season, ended on Oct. 31, Paul S. Armstrong, general manager of the California Fruit Growers Exchange, said yesterday in -his annual report.

Herbert Hoover will arrive here by train tomorrow for a oneday visit. He will address the York Bible Class tomorrow night, when representatives of the Canadian Senate, the House of Commons, the Ontario government, church bodies, youth organizations and business leaders will honor him.

In Dr. Seymour's first annual report as president of Yale his defense of free academic opinion is perhaps most notable. Some members of the Law School faculty have horrified some critics with different opinions.

Society drove up in limousines to the south door of the Metropolitan Opera House around curtain time last night-some arriving too late for Lawrence Tibbett's first solo-but the rank-and-file music lovers had preceded them by hours, many waiting since early morning for the privilege of buying standing room tickets for the opening.

John Rochford's field goal in the last two minutes enabled the St. Francis Prep five to conquer Tolentine High, 31-29, on the latter's floor yesterday. The contest was hard-fought all the way, with the losers leading at the intermission, 15-13. High scorer was Peter O'Connor of St. Francis with 13 points.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bruere of 925 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Treat Bruere, to George Carnahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Carnahan of New York, and Tprreon, Mexico.

Seven steps which can be taken to improve merchandise and to aid consumers in choosing goods were outlined in a Harvard Business School research study prepared by Mrs. Mabel Taylor Gragg in collaboration with Neil H. Borden, professor of advertising, and issued here today.

The theory that John F. O'Hara, 26-year-old credit analyst, who was shot and killed in front of his home at 48-19 Forty-fourth Street, Woodside, Queens, last Friday, was the victim of mistaken identity gained weight yesterday when investigators found that a prisoner released from Auburn prison only a few hours previously had returned to his home in the same apartment building just before the murder.

Brooklyn Tech's basketball team flashed a powerful attack in crushing Manual Training, 52-23, yesterday at Tech. The winners, who used thirteen players in the game, held a big advantage at half-time, 21-6. George Roach, with 13 points, starred for the victors.

The New York University football sqcad devoted most of a spirited three-hour session yesterday to polishing its complete repertoire of plays for the twentieth meeting with Fordham at the Yankee Stadium in a rivalry that dates back to 1889.

Mrs. W. Lee Ward will give a luncheon on Friday at Sherry's for her granddaughter, Miss Marie Louise Ward, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Lee Ward. Viscount and Viscountess Knollys of London will leave the Ambassador today for Arizona. Later they will go to Boca Grande, Fla.

Turpentine firm, 22c; sales 92 barrels; receipts 393 barrels, shipments 36 barrels, stock 51,537 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 362: receipts 1,274; shipments 100; stock 298,975 Quote: B. D. $4.05; E, $4.25; F $4.80; G, H. I, K, M, $4.85; N, $5.50; WG, $6; WW and X, $6.65.

Elmer F. Layden, director of athletics, announced today Notre Dame's nine-game football schedule for 1939. Purdue, Southern Methodist and Iowa have been added to the card in addition to the traditional contests with Army, Navy, Northwestern, Southern California, Georgia Tech and Carnegie Tech.

The request of the Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Civil Liberties Union for the Supreme Court to act upon the Mayor Frank Hague injunction case in advance of the Third Circuit Court was denied by the high court today, but the justices granted the organizations permission to file a Future plea in another form.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Interior Design: Furniture and Floors," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; European Decorative Arts (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Interior Design: Dining Rooms," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.

In a test case affecting many cities the State today asked the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, to review its suit challenging the right of cities to keep fines imposed in drunken driving cases.
A large number of Jews have, after imprisonment, been brought by Germans to the frontier near the Czech village of Babylon, which is one of those to be occupied by Germany by Nov. 24.
Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges.

Ninety members of Cleaners and Dyers Union, Local 239, of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America picketed the German consulate at 17 Battery Place yesterday, carrying placards denouncing Germany's persecution of racial and religious minorities and shouting: "Send Hitler to the Cleaners!"
The German Evangelical Church's statistical survey for the years 1934 to 1936, inclusive, indicates that church membership increased during this period.

Mield Trial Champion Blind of Arden, a Labrador owned by William A. Harriman and handled by G. Jasper Briggs, today won the limited open all-age stake at the meeting of the Long Island Retriever Trial Club held at the Port o' Missing Men, estate of the late Colonel Henry H. Rogers. The stake, started yesterday, provided two full days of work, with two land and two water tests.
The Roosevelt Savings Bank in Manhattan and the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh, Brooklyn, announced yesterday that they were making the largest Christmas Club payments in their histories.

In an effort to combat a growing wave of banditry, the Ministry of Justice, in collaboration with the Ministry of the Interior, today created special summary courts composed of three judges each to deal with "gangsters within twenty-four hours." The decisions of these

By a vote of five to two the Supreme Court rejected again today the plea of the General Talking Pictures Corporation in a patent case which has attracted wide attention because of its bearing on the coming monopoly investigation by the government.

Remigio Renzi, since 1883 first organist at St. Peter's Basilica, Vatican City, died Saturday in Rome. His age was 81. This information was received yesterday by his son, Paul Renzi, solo oboeist with several radio symphony orchestras, at his home in Rosedale, L. I.

Steel operations are scheduled at 61.9 per cent of capacity this week, as compared to, 62.6 per cent last week, a decline of 0.7 point, or 1.1 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. One month ago the rate was 53.7 per cent, a gain of 4.3 points, or 8.7 per cent.

The United States Government is still trying to get a satisfactory reply from Germany in regard to Austria's financial obligations, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today. Since the absorption of Austria two notes have been sent to Berlin emphasizing the contention that Germany necessarily assumed Ausrian obligations.

Funeral services were held yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of the Ascension, 107th Street near Broadway, for Eugene Cumisky, veteran Tammany Democrat, who died Friday in Miami at the age of 75.

Charles V. Bob, the mining enginever and investment broker, who stood trial three times for alleged mail fraud growing out of the sale of stock in Metal and Mining Shares, Inc., only to win a disagreement each time, will be placed on trial next month on a new charge of mail fraud.

The City Planning Commission's action in zoning the Fieldstone area of Upper Manhattan as a one-family community was commended yesterday by Frank O'Hara of Jackson Heights, L. I., president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

In New York on a holiday, a Stamford, Conn., policeman got his man and as a result John Westley, 31 years old, a Negro, of 68 West 138th Street, was sentenced yesterday by Magistrate Lindau in Harlem Court to six months in the workhouse for stealing the overcoat of an army captain from his automobile.

Peiping Lily Lee, glamorous wartime party girl who is suspected of being an oriental Mata Hari, is being detained by Chinese authorities today "for observation." Peiping Lily once associated frequently with Foreign Office and military officials of this provisional capital of China.

Army's football squad practiced in its new field house today, as Coach Wood started practice before the Navy game. There were no injuries as a result of Saturday's game with Princeton and the entire squad was on hand today. Tom Davis's cheek cut is only a superficial wound, and not enough to keep him out of uniform.

Columbia's Lou Little, a bit more chipper now that the end of the season is in sight, analyzed next Thursday's Columbia-Brown game for the Football Writers Association at its last open weekly luncheon at Jack Dempsey's restaurant yesterday.

On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight. Nov. 20: SERGEANT-John J. Dilworth, 110th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed Nov. 20, 1913. Temporary Assignments SERGEANT-Francis M. Schuchman, from 75th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Queens County, for 1 day, from 8 A. M. Nov. 17.
BACK WHERE I CAME FROM, by A. J. Liebling. (Sheridan House, $2.50.) A defense of New York's culture.

The teams that have gone this far through the football season with unmarred records are proving very tough. One small college outfit was removed from the list of undefeated and untied teams over the past week-end. That was St. Anselm of

The annual retreat for members of the freshman, sophomore and junior classes of Manhattan College began yesterday morning with a mass in La Salle Chapel on the campus. The retreat for the seniors will be held in June prior to the Commencement Week exercises.

A 30year-old "graduate" of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who left the commission to write and obtain enactment of the new Ohio Securities Act, has been appointed administrator of a new regional office of/the SEC at Cleveland. He is Dan Tyler Moore Jr.

Decision was reserved today by the White Plains Planning Board on an application by the Wyte West Building Corporation for permission to build 114 houses on the North Street estate of the late Daniel Maloney. Neighboring estate owners renewed their protests, contending the "small" houses of eight or nine rooms would harm the section.
King Leopold of the Belgians arrived in The Netherlands today on his first official visit to this country as King. After being

Three former officers of the defunct State Title and Mortgage Company, who were convicted last January of conspiracy to use the mails fraudulently in the sale to the public of $70,000,000. worth of mortgages and mortgage certificates, must serve terms in prison unless they win an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.
175th St (11-2958), n e cor of Vineyard PI, 98x68; Rames Construction Corp to Garden Towers Construction Corp, 765 E 175th St; mtg $90,000.

George E.- Price, former musical comedy star, who is the head of the Stock Exchange firm of George E. Price Co., attended a rehearsal last night of the Financial Follies of 1938, the satirical revue which will be presented on Dec. 16 by the New York Financial Writers Associtation. Participation in the revue

A 12-year-old boy, Ray W. Conover, of Oakland, Calif., became today the millionth person to file his fingerprints voluntarily with the Justice Department. The civil identification section was begun Nov. 10, 1933, to facilitate the identification

Mrs. Spencer Jennings gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests included Mrs. Charles Armstrong, Mrs. Robert Mallory, Mrs. Edward Lawrence Rossiter, Mrs. Walter Gibb and Mrs. Rumson Leach.

John C. Traphagen, president of the Bank of New York, and J. Hamilton Cheston, vice president of the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society, yesterday were elected directors of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company at the annual meeting of the stockholders at Baltimore. They succeed to places left

The results of the election on Nov. 8 indicated "an awakening" of civic responsibility and "foreshadowed" Republican victories in the next municipal, State and national elections, Joseph Clark Baldwin, member of the City Council, told the Women's National Republican Club yesterday.

Plans to include exhibits of textiles as well as women's apparel and accessories within the Hall of Fashion at the World's Fair assures the most comprehensive and glamorous presentation of Americancreated fashions ever 'made in this country, according to a statement issued yesterday by Joseph Love, president of the Apparel and Accesi series Associates, Inc.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 18: LIEUTENANTS Adams, C. R., Washington, D. C., about March 1 to Asiatic Station. Chitwood, J. S., Chicago, Ill., about Jan. 6 to Asiatic Station.

The stage show "Tobacco Road" opened here tonight under the protection of a temporary court injunction that restrained the Mayor, Police Department and the city's board of censorship from interfering.

Forty basketball games and twentyseven hockey engagements for Princeton University teams this Winter were announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, graduate manager of athletics. The freshman hockey program has not been completed.

Dr. Edward P. Whitney, dental surgeon, died today at his home here at the age of 65. Born in Stamford, he attended Stamford public schools and Godard School, Barre, Vt., from which he was graduated in 1894. He was graduated from New

As the Thanksgiving holiday approaches, charitable and philanthropic agencies throughout th city are making preparations t distribute baskets and serve dinner so none in the city may, through misfortune, be deprived of a holi day dinner. The Children's Aid Sc city expects to entertain mor than 1,000 children this week a parties and dinners.

For what seemed to this newspaper excellent reasons, the voters rejected the judiciary amendment to the State Constitution, two weeks ago, by a vote of more than two to one. It was suggested prior to the election that much that was good in this amendment could be salvaged.
The Labor Front of Germany was described by Matthew Woll, a vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in a radio address last night as "a company union on a grand scale." The laboring man

The Wyatt Earp with her decks and rails molded heavily with ice and her rigging encrusted to more than double its normal size with frozen spray is once more and for the fourth expedition under my command forcing her way through the Antarctic pack ice.

More than 20,000 persons paid 25 and 40 cents each last night to pack Madison Square Garden at a mass meeting that united a varied group of organizations and speakers in a "protest against Nazi outrages."

The directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday a year-end dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock payable on Dec. 14 to stock of record of Nov. 29, bringing total dividends payable in 1938 to $3.25 a share. In 1937 dividends amounted to $6.25 a share.

John MeAdams, a former sergeant of patrol in the customs service, who was arrested last December when agents seized a trunk filled with opium just a few minutes before it was to have been removed from a local pier, received a prison sentence of seven years when he pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Henry W.

Frank Shufelt, who was among those to take the first Federal Civil Service examination for railway mail clerk in September, 1889, died today. He had lived here twenty-three years and was a native of Copake, N. Y.

Because he shot at a wild duck when his watch was ten minutes fast, Charles P. Wehrheim, a forester in the United States Department of Agriculture, was fined $5 yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn Federal Court for violating the Federal Migratory Bird Law. Mr. Wehrheim was accused

UTILITY EARNINGS Louisville Gas and Electric Company--Year ended Oct. 31: Net income, $2,637,635 against $2,853,851. A preceding like period; gross 10,856,091 against $10,329,760. Asouri Gas and Electric Service Company--Three months ended Sept. 30: Net income $19,044.

Francis J. Sinnott, Postmaster of Brooklyn, issued a statement yesterday urging prompt posting of Christmas mail for Hawaii. "The steamship Monterey leaves San Francisco on Dec. 6, San Pedro, Dec. 7 and arrives at Honolulu on Dec. 12," he said.

The vacant plot 135 by 100 feet on the west side of Cottenet Street, 250 feet south of Main Street, Irvington - on - the - Hudson, Westchester County, has been purchased by the Deegan Construction Corporation, Florida and Nw York builders.

Miss Margaret Knox, daughter of Dr. Alice Ingram of London and the late Dr. Robert Knox of London, was married to Dr. Lewis Libman Engel, son of Mrs. Adolph Engel of this city and the late Mr. Engel, yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building by Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines.
Former Premier Earl Baldwin has promised to go on the air in a nationwide broadcast, it was learned tonight, to open a non-denominational appeal for funds for refuees from Germany.

Football heads into the last big week of intercollegiate play with an unusual amount of unfinished business to clear up before turning the stage over to the glorifiers of the rose, sugar, cotton and the sun. The double-barreled program for Thanksgiving Day and Saturday is loaded for big hunting, and the boys will be out for something more than turkey. National rankings,

Johnny Gottselig, veteran forward of the champion Chicago Black Hawks, leads thee parade of the National Hockey League pointgetters in the first official scoring statistics issued by the league tonight.

Two clothing stores in the same block on Stanton Street were held up yesterday morning within a half hour. At 9 A. M. Arthur Aronwitz and Hyman Karber, waiting in their store at 100 Stanton Street for a police escort to take their receipts to the bank, were forced into a rear room and robbed of $1,137 by two young gunmen.
The Caxton Press, Caldwell, Idaho, will publish on Dec. 1 "A Bibliography of William Sydney Porter (0. Henry)," by Paul S. Clarkson, a Baltimore attorney.

Ralph DeSola of New York told the House committee investigating unAmerican activities today that many persons employed with him on a WPA writers' project had been, like himself, members of the Communist party..

Exhibitors have already taken more than half of the space provided at the merchandise exposition to be held concurrently witr the twelfth annual convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at the Hotel Commodore Jan. 17, 18 and 19, it was announced yesterday. Included in the list

Plans for additional State and city legislation to reinforce the new theatre ticket code were discussed yesterday by representatives of theatrical organizations with Paul Moss, License Commissioner, and Councilman Howard H. Spellman at the Twenty-one Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street.
28th St, 229-39 W, 124.2x88.8x irreg; John J. Radley Realty Corp, formerly Leerad Realty Corp, to Radley 28th St Corp, 551 5th Ave; mtg $250,000 ($165).

Daytime and evening costumes will be modeled by a group of young women at the luncheon and fashion show to be held today at the Versailles for the benefit of the BideA-Wee Home for Animals. The beneficiary cares for and finds homes for homeless animals. It has headquarters at 410 East Thirtyeighth Street and a country home at Wantagh L.I.

Mrs. Charles Isham, granddaughter of Abraham Lincoln, died yesterday after a long illness. She observed her sixty-ninth birthday on Oct. 15. Mrs. Isham, a widow, was the former Miss Mary Lincoln. She was the daughter of Robert Todd Lincoln, son of the President, who died in 1926 at the age of 82, and Mrs. Mary Harlan Lincoln, who died in March, 1937, at the age of 90.

Cardinal Hayes was eulogized as "priest and patriot" in a memorial read by former Governor Alfred E. Smith last night at a meeting of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. The meeting, held at the Hotel Astor, was attended by more than 800 members.

The fastest mile man ever has run, Glenn Cunningham's 4:04.4 clocking indoors, is hidden away in the list of 144 records that were made by American athletes this year and will be submitted for ap proval to the golden anniversary convention of the Amateur Athletic Union at Washington on Dec. 2, 3 and 4.

Describing the National Labor Relations Act as "one-sided," officials of Endicott Johnson Corporation today outlined the terms under which they would consent to a vote by 20,000 employes on unionization.

By a vote of 21 to 16 the Westchester County Board of Supervisors refused today to "order" the Westchester County Park Commission to remove a barrier at the McLean Avenue entrance of the Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers and install a traffic light in its place.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens began yesterday to question police officers and others who were at the German-American Bund meeting in Turn Hall, Astoria, last Friday Light, to determine whether speakers at the meeting should be prosecuted on charges of inciting to riot.

1st Lt. Sidney J. Guran, Inf.-Res., 35-63 88th St., Jackson Heights, L. I., N. Y., 306th Infantry, is ordered to active duty with the CCC for a period of six months, effective Dec. 17, at headquarters, Trenton District, CCC, North Olden and Breunig Aves., Trenton, N. J., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Date of rank, Dec. 17. He will revert to an inactive status June 16, 1939.

Federal Judge Colin Neblett today overruled all attacks on the validity of the indictment of seventy-three persons charged with WPA fraud and conspiracy and ordered the defendants to trial in January.

Captain William H. Schoemaker, whose career as a law enforcer was one of the most colorful in Chicago police history, died today of a heart attack at his home, 6,237 North Oak Park Avenue. He was 70 years old.

Burnerd D. Arnstein, 20, Stanford University student and son of the late Dr. Henry Arnstein of New York, internationally known chemist, was found crushed to death near his wrecked automobile today. The car had plunged over a 300-foot cliff.

Tonight's events: Philadelphia Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock; Edvard Moritz Chamber Orchestra, Town Hall, 8:30; Composers' Forum-Laboratory, Carnegie Chamber Hall; Candle-Light Musicale, Waldorf-Astoria, 9.
Victor Ridder's talk last night brings to the front a subject which no New Yorker and no American can ignore. We must not permit events in Europe to stir up antagonisms among Ameri-: cans.
The British Government today offered new homelands in distant colonies and temporary havens of refuge in this country for many thousands who are now suffering persecution in Nazi Germany.

Outclassing his rival throughout, Maxie Farber, 1351/2 pounds, East Side, beat Johnny Bonito, 1361/2, Bronx, in the feature bout of eight rounds last night at St. Nicholas Palace. A crowd of 3,500 saw the victor take seven rounds, losing only the fifth on a foul. Farber staggered his foe in the second and seventh.

Elmer L. Eckhouse, president of the Kemico Manufacturing Company of Irvington, died suddenly here today of a heart attack at his home, 61 Osborne Terrace. Born in Washington, Ind., fifty-seven years ago, he had lived here since childhood.

Oskar Maria Graf, a German author, told a meeting sponsored by the German-American League for Culture tonight that throughout Germany small groups of citizens opposed to the rule of Adolf Hitler had formed units and were waiting an opportune time to rise against the Nazi Government.

Frank J. Knell, president of the New York Cotton Exchange, appointed yesterday a committee representing the interests involved to consider the question of present cotton futures contract requirements. This group was appointed

A supplementary summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders in September issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that Alvan Macauley sold 1,900 shares of common stock of the Packard Motor Car Company; Harold S. Vance 1,397 shares of common of Studebaker Corporation; that Walter J. Curley had acquired 1,000 common Hayes Body Corporation, and that R. E. Maxwell had disposed of 1,000 common of the Greyhound Corporation.
Some delay in the signing of the Franco-German pact of non-aggression is reported to be likely as a consequence of the strong disapproval felt here over the treatment of Jews in Germany.

The domestic price of zinc was reduced yesterday 30 points by leading producers to 4.75 cents a pound at East St. Louis. The reduction was a direct result of the new Anglo-American trade treaty which reduced the duty on zinc into the

Leon G. Turrou, the former special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who gathered the evidence that resulted in the indictment of eighteen members of a Nazi espionage ring, three of whom are on trial before Federal Judge John C. Knox, was under fire again yesterday as the trial entered its sixth week.
The Bureau of Mines estimated today a daily average supply of 3,305,800 barrels of domestic crude oil would be needed to meet the nation's market demand in December.
Eight Manhattan properties changed hands via auction sales in the Vesey Street Salesrooms yesterday. Among the parcels involved
The state funeral of Kemal Ataturk, founder and first President of the Turkish Republic, took place here this morning in a steady drizzle.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will conduct a hearing at its offices here on Dec. 3 on the application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the 6A per cent external sinking-fund gold bonds of 1930 of the Province of Buenos Aires which are stamped as assenting to the loan adjustment plan of 1933.
A series of letters exchanged by the poet Robert Browning and son Julia Wedgwood, novelist and critic, were sold for $1,150 last night at auction the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

The State Supreme Court today left the way open for the special October (1937) grand jury to continue its investigation of vice and gambling in Philadelphia even after Dec. 31, the original "deadline," should there arise "exigencies of great public importance."

The other day, when Borough President George U. Harvey made the journey from Queens to Passaic, N. J., he must have recited in a voice choked with emotion, as he approached the end of his trip, the well-known lines from the Fifth Reader:

Gregory Rice, stocky Notre Dame runner, put on a driving sprint to the tape today to win the first National Collegiate Athletic Association cross-country chaminpionship, but Indiana University took the team crown and that of the Central Intercollegiate Conference.

Two Paterson men were found dead of asphyxiation here this afternoon in a bungalow at 29 William Street. Two pet dogs were asphyxiated with them but five cats, also part of the household, recovered after being taken into the fresh air.

A few days ago, soon after the seventh birthday of the George Washington Bridge, the Holland Tunnel marked its eleventh anniversary. The transit cousins ought to exchange felicitations, for both have been a success in the world.

In furtherance of the plan to consolidate all trotting horse activities in the United States and merge the five governing bodies as they now exist, the Trotting Horse Club of America and the American Trotting Register Association held their annual meetings yesterday at the Prince George Hotel and voted to dissolve by the first of the year.
The Civil Aeronautics Authority said today that airlines in the United 21 States set an all-time high in September for both revenue passengers and express poundage carried.

Pennsylvania linemen engaged in their last scrimmage of the season today for their meeting with Cornell in the,annual Thanksgiving Day game on Franklin Field. The backs were not permitted to do any tackling. Team C was on the offense all the time,. using the Ithacans' running and pass plays.

The adoption of Freddie Bartholomew, boy actor, by his aunt, Myllicent Bartholomew, is entirely legal, the District Court of Appeals held today in a decision denying the attempt of the boy's parents to have a Superior Court adoption set aside. Myllicent Bartholomew, who

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Nov. 17 numbered .203, compared with 213 in the same week a year ago and 208 a week ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Resolutions condemning "the recent outrages and injustices perpetrated upon human beings in Germany" and supporting President Roosevelt's recent protest were adopted last night at a meeting of the faculty of Hunter College.

Harold Jacobi, chairman of the Greater New York campaign of the United Palestine Appeal, presiding at an emergency session of 400 leaders of that organization in the Hotel Astor last night, discussed the many proposals made for Jewish colonization in unsettled areas of Africa, and warned against a "diversion of Jewish interest at a crucial time."

Dr. James A. Tufts, Professor Emeritus of English at Phillips Exeter Academy, whose remarkable memory enabled him to call most alumni of the school by their first names, died today at his home here. His age was 83.

The Teachers Alliance of New York City announced yesterday that it was circulating teachers and other employes of the city's school system in an attempt "to follow up with a factual analysis the highly significant statement of Commissioner Johanna M. Lindlof (member of the Board of Education) that 'there is an insidious propaganda spreading in our public schools.'"

The statement for the eleven months ended on Oct. 31 of the Canadian Bank of Commerce shows a net profit of $2,648,975 after taxes of $919,677 and appropriations to the contingent reserve fund, out of which fund full provision for bad and doubtful debts has been made.

G. T, Ohrstrom Co., Inc., New York, was "the real party at interest" in the transactions which started early in 1937 when one J. F. A., Comstedt went to Williamsport, Pa., and obtained options on a controlling interest in Sweet's Steel

Reorder volume in the wholesale markets here yesterday was quite heavy, in line with the improvement in retail trade in most areas last week. Resident buyers reported the demand was broad, covering ready-to-wear, staples and holiday merchandise. Thus far, they added, no delivery difficulties have arisen.

The first annual New York Newspaper Artists Exhibition was opened last night at the Delphic Studios, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. It will be open to the public from today through Dec. 4. Some twenty-five

Traffic accidents and injuries rose sharply last week and week-end in the city as compared with figures covering the corresponding periods last year, the tabulated report of the safety bureau of the Police Department showed yesterday. There was a drop in the number of fatalities, however, although one more person was killed last week-end than in the corresponding week-end of 1937.

The engagement of Miss Helen Gertrude O'Brien, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Joseph O'Brien of this city and the late Mr. O'Brien, to A. Paul Levack of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Joseph Levack of Belmont, Mass., has been announced by her mother.

Senator Edward R. Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, accused the National Labor Relations Board today of making forced settlements in most of its cases. The Wagner Act, he said, was largely a "punitive statute. In an address to the Economic Club, Senator Burke said revision of the Wagner Act to encourage cooperation between labor and

Former City Court Justice Frank A. Carlin, setting forth that he had been appointed counsel to the New York County Clerk on March 31, but that city officials had refused to certify his appointment or pay him his salary, entered suit in Supreme Court yesterday to enforce his claims. The action is directed

Federal Judge R. M. Gibson in the United States District Court at Pittsburgh yesterday ordered a general continuance of the plan of reorganization of Follansbee Brothers Company until Dec. 19 to allow the company time to complete negotiations for the new financing required by the plan.

FLOOD, NED ARDEN (Nov. 8). Estate, more than $1,000. To Anna Davis Flood, widow, executrix, 970 Park Ave. GUNNING, BERNARD (Nov. 13). Estate, more than $10,000. To Annie K. Casey, niece, Clonmore, Killashee. County Longford, Ireland, residue; ten specific bequests; John Drummy, executor, 25-26 41st St., Long Island City, specific bequest.

The personnel and partial schedule of the Princeton University Glee Club for its 1938-39 concert season were announced today by William A. Paddock, '39, of Katonah, N. Y., president of the club. Thirty-eight new members have been added to the ranks.

Japan is rejecting alleged British peace proposals, the press asserts. Although nothing official is known, the press claims that Sir Robert L. Craigie, the British Ambassador, on Nov. 1 tendered Great Britain's good offices in negotiating a ChinoJapanese peace on these terms:

The Bank of the Manhattan Company headed yesterday the successful group, which included C. J. Devine Co. and Ladenburg, Thalman Co., in the purchase of a new issue of $25,000,000 of State of Connecticut building and funding bonds. The issue was awarded to

The Federal District Court dismissed today a suit challenging the right of Joaquin M. Elizalde to be resident commissioner from the Philippines. The court held the suit, brought by Porfirio U. Sevilla, publisher of

The city has made an offer to buy the Brooklyn street car and bus system, largest surface transit facility here, it became known yesterday. The city's move to negotiate the purchase was made within the last few days and constitutes part of the negotiations for transit unification.

Opening night of the Metropolitan Opera, evoking the traditional glamour and general excitement this occasion has inspired among all walks of life for more than half a century, drew to the historic Metropolitan Opera House last night a capacity audience in which were leaders of society and distinguished representatives of the fields of artistic, diplomatic and civic endeavor.

A special novena of Sunday evening services with prayers for increased employment and improvement in economic conditions will be held for the next nine weeks through Jan. 8 at the Most Holy Redeemer Roman Catholic Church, 172 East Third Street, on the lower East Side, near Avenue A, according to an announcement yesterday.

The Metropolitan Opera opened its season last night with Verdi's "Otello." America's oldest and foremost repertory theatre thus continued the practice, restored two seasons ago, of ringing in its own new year with one of the towering masterpieces of operatic history.

The official Japanese reply to the American note of Oct. 6, dealing with Japanese interference with American trade and other legitimate activities of Americans in China, combined with inspired comment of the Tokyo press, constitutes "unmistakable nullification" of the principles of the Nine-Power Treaty, according to a statement issued today by the American Association of Shanghai. It voices the opinion of local Americans regarding the recent Japanese declaration.

Liquidation by holders of December wheat contracts dominated the action of the wheat market on the Board of Trade here again today and prices dropped about 3/4 cent a bushel at the extreme to a new low on the current downturn and came within 1 cent of the seasonal low.

At the same moment when Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain was speaking in the House of Commons on the possibility of finding homes in the British Empire for Jews fleeing Germany, Virginio Gayda in the Giornale d'Italia was asking why no country In the world was eager to throw open its doors to Jewish immigration.
Swen A. Malm bought for occupancy from the New Jersey Realty Company of Newark the one-family dwelling at 100 South Martine Avenue, Fanwood, N. J. Arthur De Vencentis represented the buyer.

Although the Adirondack deer season is now with the past, a number of hunters who tramped those hills are looking back with considerable pleasure on the sport they had. Several who wrote letters dropped in to discuss the hunting. They failed to get their deer, but they all reported seeing plenty of game.

OTELLO-Lyric drama in four acts, in Italian, based on the tragedy by Shakespeare. Book by Arrigo Boito, music by Giuseppe Verdi. Opening of fifty-fourth season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, at the Metropolitan Opera House. Conductor, Ettore Panizza; stage director, Herbert Graf; chorus master, Fausto Cleva.

Fifteen men and five women were indicted today by a Federal grand jury which has been investigating a ring of counterfeiters charged with passing hundreds of bogus $5 and $10 bills. The defendants were arrested in a raid on a Boston apartment last October on conspiracy charges.
A number of properties in various sections of Connecticut were reported yesterday as having changed hands through Mrs. Howard A. Barker, broker. Among the
Oak St, 50, 19.9x50; Gaetano Mistretta to Ignazio Giandalia, 6 Dickerson Ct, Far Rockaway, L. I.; all rt int; 3 years, 6%, $1,500.

Charles E. Johnston, president of the Kansas City Southern Railway Company, Kansas City, Mo., has accepted chairmanship of the Western Association of Railway Executives. Henry A. Scandrett, president of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad and a director of the Western Association, made the announcement today.

Elwood Thomas Baker, retired auditor and accountant, died yesterday at the Grand Central Parkway Rest Home, Jamaica, Queens, after a short illness. He was 85 years old and had lived at Huntington, L. I.
Edwin McArthur, accompanist for Kirsten Flagstad, made his debut as an operatic conductor tonight and won applause and commendation from the audience and critics.

QUEENS DENKER, FRITZ H. (Aug. 7). Gross assets, $16,249: net, $14,651. To the widow, Augusta Denker. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $7,482. William Brunner, attorney, 220 Broadway, Manhattan. MARTENS, FRIEDA C. (May 9). Gross assets, $5,830; net, $2,912. To nephew-Tnlaw, George C. Martens. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $1,683. Greene Greene, attorneys, 61 Broadway, Manhattan.

Renewed weakness which carried sterling and the franc down to their lowest prices since Sept. 28 came into the foreign exchange market yesterday and additional heavy engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were reported.

The Italian Consul has protested against the arrest and harsh treatment by the Japanese of Father Bi Belli, an Italian Catholic priest, who was charged by certain Chinese with bribing natives with sums of $5 to $15 (Mex.) to set fire to buildings here.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 19 unless specified: At San Pedro, Nov. 18: Astoria, Chester, Indianapolis, Louisville, Minneapolis, New Orleans, Northampton, Pensacola, Portland, Pinola, Quincy, San Francisco, Salt Lake City, Tuscaloosa, Vincennes.

Mr. and Mrs. Luman Reed Fuller of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of Mr. Fuller's daughter, Miss Anna Pendleton Fuller, to Andrew Steidinger, son of Christian Steidinger of East Williston, L. I., and the late Mrs. Steidinger.
James Huntington Burnside, retired insurance executive, died on Sunday in his apartment at the Hotel Ansonia, 2,107 Broadway, after a long illness.

I speak as a convinced believer in the possibility of Anglo-German friendship and as a stanch supporter of the Munich agreement. It is because I am so anxious to see a complete and permanent settlement of the questions dividing the two countries that I am speaking frankly, and unreservedly.

Insurgent planes dropped wreaths Saturday on Alicante Cemetery and prison, where Jose Antonio Primo de Rivera, leader of the Spanish Falangist [Fascist] party, was reported killed when a mob broke into the jail on Nov. 19, 1936.

Edward C. Hunter, a twice-elected City Councilman here, who declined, a Mayoralty nomination while in Council, died today. His age was 69. He served twenty-three years as a distillery gauger before entering Democratic city politics, and as national delegate helped to nominate Alfred E. Smith for the Presidency.

Mrs. Marie Burckhalter, 44 years old, a slight, comely housewife of Hastings-on-Hudson, was held here tonight on a charge of first-degree manslaughter, accused of having helped her husband end his life Saturday afternoon in a fantastic suicide plot.

Miss Susanna Jones, 21-year-old college graduate, was injured at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning when she fell or jumped from a bedroom of the third-floor apartment of her uncle, James F. Latimer, a Wall Street executive, at 40 Fifth Avenue.
The long-delayed grand jury investigation of graft and corruption to charges against Governor Earle and thirteen associates was ordered begun on Dec. 5 by Judge Paul N. Schaeffer here today.

One of the main arguments being used by those who oppose the spreading movement for exemption or preferential tax treatment for homesteads, already in effect in more than a dozen States, is that in most communities private dwellings are already being favored by the tax assessors.

Leopold Godowsky, world-famous composer, pianist and teacher, died at 7 A. M. yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital, 111 East Seventy-sixth Street, where he was operated upon for an intestinal ailment last Thursday. Mr. Godowsky, who was taken to the hospital several days ago, was 68 years old.

Prince Paul, Regent of Yugoslavia, arrived today in London, the fourth Balkan ruler to visit this capital in recent weeks for important discussions with British Government leaders. He was accompanied by his wife, Princess Olga.

In conformity with the recommendations of the Evian meeting of July last, His Majesty's Government have under constant examination the contribution it could make with respect to the United Kingdom and the colonial empire to the international effort to facilitate the admission and settlement of involuntary emigrants from Germany.

One of the first tangible results of the recent Anglo-American trade treaty was the reduction yesterday of $6 a ton in the domestic price of zinc. The new treaty provides that the duty on zinc into the United States be reduced by $7 a ton.
West Side and Harlem residential parcels figured in the bulk of the city realty activity made known yesterday.
Retailers of textiles and of wearing apparel of various types figured prominently in yesterday's business rental reports.

Concessions granted by the United States in its trade agreement with the United Kingdom "will most certainly seriously cripple and may even destroy" the fine quality woolens branch of the woolen manufacturing business in this country, Sylvan I. Stroock, president of S. Stroock Co., Inc., predicted in a protest mailed yesterday to Secretary Hull. Mr. Stroock urged the
The new account on the Stock Exchange was ushered in quietly today although the undertone generally was firm.
Bonds drifted moderately lower yesterday on diminished trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange. The $5,597,300 turnover was the smallest since Sept. 27 and compared with $6,923,075 last Friday.

The first of a series of campaign meetings in the drive of the Child Study Association for $200,000 to operate the organization for three years -was held yesterday in the home of Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, book collector, at 15 East Fiftyfirst Street. Dr. Rosenbach is a member of the children's book committee of the association.

Mayor La Guardia returned early yesterday morning from a threeday trip to Havana, where he made a plea for stronger Pan-American relations before the First Annual Congress of Pan-American Cities last Saturday night.

Having lost in the State courts, the Federal District Court and the United States Circuit Court of Appeals their fight against payment in full of taxes levied by New Jersey during the last eight years, railroads moved tonight to effect a compromise that would make further litigation unnecessary.

Because he had "messed things up too much," Frederick Titzell, 26 years old, well known in Westport, Conn., attempted suicide yesterday in an apartment he shared with friends at 224 East Forty-ninth Street.

Dr. Vito Luigi Raia, eye specialist, died today in Jane Brown Memorial Hospital following an operation at the age of 81. Born in Viggiano, Italy, Dr. Raia was the son of Luigi Raia and Mrs. Maria Giuseppa De Santis Raia. In 1872-75 he attended the Collegio Silvio Pellico at Viggiano and in 1875-78 he was a student at the Liceo Cirillo at Naples.

Two of four men under indictment in the so-called Ukrainian Hall kidnapping will be called for trial in General Sessions within the next ten days in the first case under the new amendment of the State kidnapping law.
The new Irvin Works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, largest steel company in the world and principal subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, will be formally opened on Dec. 15.

The rector, church wardens and vestrymen of Trinity Church have brought suit in Supreme Court against Sussman Estates, Inc., asking an accounting of gross revenues of more than $7,000,000 collected by the real estate concern on sixteen lower Manhattan properties which it managed for Trinity during a four-and-a-half-year period, it was disclosed when papers were filed in court yesterday.

Charles P. Livingston, old-time newspaper publisher here, died today in the veterans' hospital at Dwight at the age of 97. He was the last Civil War veteran in Kankakee County and had been a resident here for eight-four years.

The touring Marylebone Cricket Club today tallied 676 runs against Griqualand West in the. second day's play of a three-day contest. In reply the South Africans scored 114 and following on had obtained 116 for three wickets at the adjournment.

Whether an employer may discharge workmen who participate in a sitdown strike will be decided by the Supreme Court, because the justices today granted a review of the Fansteel case Involving that issue.

LAWRANCE THOMPSON has written the most interesting book* on Longfellow that I have ever read, and it so happens that at one time or another I have read a good many. It is a study of the poet's youth and young manhood-that is, of the period from his birth to his belated second marriage in 1843. It gives a picture quite

Vincent de Moro-Giafferi, noted criminal lawyer engaged to defend 17-year-old Herschel Grynszpan, met defeat in court today when he tried to obtain the release on bail of the youth's aunt and uncle, jailed for complicity in the slaying of Ernst vom Rath, German diplomat.
Forty-one silk hand-made garments for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will reach the White House this week, Cooperative Handcrafts, Inc., a governmentsponsored needlework enterprise, announced today.
Champion Rambler of Diamond Rock, red and white cocker spaniel who has been knocking at the door all season, finally scored today.

Three New York A. C. players gained places In the semi-final round of the annual Princeton Club squash tennis tournament yesterday. Harry F. Wolf, the national champion; Frank Iannicelli, brother of the world's open titleholder, and Joseph J. Lordi were the Winged Foot winners.

Manhattan emerged from last Saturday's struggle with West Virginia without an injury. Whatever ill effects the Jaspers suffered were well taken care of by an abundance of soap and water and by the time the squad reported for practice yesterday practically all the mud and dirt accumulated in the course of

" Ringside Seats," Leonard Ide's melodrama about chronic spectators at murder trials, has its deferred premiere this evening at the Guild Theatre under the sponsorship of Rufus Phillips. Grant Mitchell, who appeared last--season in "Tide Rising," heads the cast and is supported by G. Pat Collins, Roy Roberts, Lovise Larabee, Mary Rolfe, Lucia Seger, John Adair and Frank Rothe. Mr. Phillips did the staging. An 8:40 curtain.
As a result of inability to agree on the duration of the events, Chicago faces a three-week market in the women's apparel lines late in January and early in February of next year.

On the eve of the meeting in Paris between Prime Minister. Neville Chamberlain of Britain and Premier Edouard Daladier of France, every Loyalist political party and syndical organization signed a message today refusing in advance to accept any solution of the Spanish conflict that might be reached behind the government's back.

The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association continued upward last week. The index, based on the 1926-28 average was 73.2 for the week ended Nov. 19, compared with 73.1 last week, 72.3 a month ago and 79.8 a year ago. Small gains in farm products

Catherine Reiner, the soprano, no stranger hereabouts, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Before the intermission she sang a group of Brahms lieder and several works by Strauss, Grieg, Berg and Marx. The Liebestod from Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" and Hungarian folksongs by Bartok, Kodaly and Szabados concluded an interesting program selection. The accompanist was Celius Dougherty.

October retail furniture sales gained 10 per cent over September, but were 9 per cent under October, 1937, the National Retail Furniture Association announced here today. Sales for the first ten months of 1938 showed a decrease of 18 per cent.
SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against HARRY TROPIN, Jewelry, 36 W. 47th St.By Harry A. Waldman, for more than $200; Harris 'Stern, more than $200; Jacques Mandelbaum, Inc., more than $200.

The Class I railroads had 5,153 freight cars on order or building on Nov. 1, against 18,305 a year previously and 14,068 two years before. Seven steam locomotives were on order or building on Nov. 1, against 181 correspondingly in 1937 and sixty-seven two years previously.

Archibald Campbell Foss, 68 years old, a New York real estate broker, was found dead last evening on the kitchen floor of his second-story apartment in Oak Crest Road, Darien, by Aime Bernier, occupant of the first floor. Mr. Foss had rented the apartment a month ago.
Italy banned as "un-Fascist" today the use of the "pony" or "trot" that has helped schoolboys throughout the world to wrestle with the Latin of Caesar's "Commentaries" and Virgil's "Aeneid."

The Republican National Committee has no authority to pass on the eligibility of Kenneth F. Simpson to succeed Charles D. Hilles as national committeeman from New York. John M. Hamilton, national chairman, issued this interpretation of the rules, today in reply to the proposal yesterday by the Committee for Republican Integrity that the national committee, when it meets Nov. 29, refuse to seat Mr. Simpson.

Louis E. Cromwell of 25-40 Thirtyfirst Street, Astoria, Queens; a mail carrier in the midtown area, was notified yesterday by Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service, that he is the millionth subscriber to the non-profit three-cents-a-day plan.

Comedy Casualty GOOD HUNTING, a comedy in three acts, by Nathanael West and Joseph Schrank. Staged by Jerome Mayer; setting by Norris Houghton; produced by Mr. Mayer and Leonard Field. At the Hudson Theatre.

In the views of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin on current political and economic questions we are not interested. But we do find interest in the fact that shortly after he completed a radio address on Sunday afternoon Station WMCA broadcast the statement that he had "unfortunately uttered certain mistakes of fact."

" Liquidation" of Jews and hectic propaganda campaigns against the democracies generally and Great Britain and the United States particularly, along the lines of the new German foreign policy, continued in full swing today.
Beersheba, after having been in the hands of Arab rebels since it was abandoned by the government civil authorities six weeks ago. was occupied by British troops today.

Reuben Fine of New York, who has been setting the pace from the start in the A. V. R. 0. international chess masters' tournament, was tied at the top tonight by Paul Keres of Estonia when the American lost his adjourned game from the ninth round to Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion.

Steel went to the farm today when the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, shipped the first of twelve units of prefabricated metal farm buildings to sites selected by theFarm Security Administration in Alabama, Georgia and South Carolina.

CHICAGO--For the third time in five years normal operations in Chicago's stock yards, the world's largest livestock market, were tied up today by a strike. No livestock was sold and no official quotations were issued.

Willy Bernath, one of the three skiers sent by the Swiss Government to compete in the International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show at Madison Square Garden from Dec. 6 to 10- arrived last night aboard the Cunard White Star liner Britannic. Hans Schlunegger

Mexicans whose lands have been expropriated under the government's agrarian program received an appeal today from President Lazaro Cardenas to fulfill a "high moral duty" by sacrificing claims for indemnification. The appeal was in connection with yesterday's twentyeighth anniversary of the revolution that overthrew the dictatorial government of the late Porfirio Diaz.

Approximately 500 macaques completed a 14,000-mile journey from the jungles of India today destined for Santiago Island. There the first free-range primate colony in the Americas is being established off the coast of Puerto Rico jointly by the School of Tropical Medicine and Harvard and Columbia Universities.

A "walking court trial," which attorneys said was unprecedented in New Jersey, was started today when Judge Thomas H. Brown of Special Sessions temporarily transferred a criminal trial session from the Hudson County Court House here to the scene of the alleged crime-Bayonne Police Headquarters.

Mal Stevens does not care what the Governor of North Carolina said to the Governor of South Carolina, but the N. Y. U. coach saw Fordham play the two Carolina universities on successive Saturdays and twice had to change his impressions of the Ram eleven.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Joseph J. Ziger of New York City was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 20-J. O. Stoll, petr., v. William Gottlieb. On writ of cert. to the Supreme Court of Ill. Judgment reversed and cause remanded. Opinion by Justice Reed. Justice

Jacob P. Nathanson, a lawyer and former Assemblyman from Brooklyn, and two co-defendants, Louis Kassman, a bondsman, and his wife, Rose Kassman, owner of several beauty shops, all pleaded guilty in Kings County Court yesterday to perjury charges arising from one of two separate investigations currently being conducted into irregular bail bond practices in Brooklyn.
After coming close but failing in a trio of Narragansett Park efforts, Herman Philips's Scrooge found the right spot in the Milestown Class C Handicap today. Backed into $4.90

Three Illinois officials were notified today of their selection by President Roosevelt for Federal appointments, two to judgeships and the other as United States Attorney. The appointments, which lacked only the formal Presidential announcement, would be as follows:

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, declared last night that he saw an "encouraging improvement in the relations between government and business," with business executives and public officials working together as co-trustees with statesmanship and "neatly balanced judgment and discretion."

Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter refused yesterday to grant a temporary injunction restraining work on concrete piles for hangars at the new North Beach airport, but set down for Friday the trial of a taxpayer's suit which charges that the contract for the work was awarded improperly to the Raymond Concrete Pile Company.

The Cafe Louis XIV will serve as headquarters tonight for one of the more novel of the many benefit events of interest to society. A Photo Finish Story Contest will begin and end there, the interim to be spent in search of a photographic finish to an incomplete story donated by Fannie Hurst.

Albert Morris Bagby's 405th musical morning, the first of this season, was held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Lotte Lehmann, soprano; Lauritz Melchior, tenor, and Erika Morini, violinist.

William J. Knowles, business man who had been associated with various Canadian and United States firms, died here yesterday of a heart ailment at the age of 84. Born in Elora, Ont., he started in a hardware store in Brantford.

Following the directors' meeting of the Pittsburgh Coal Company, Alan M. Scaife, chairman of the board, announced these changes in personnel: J. B. Morrow, formerly coal preparation manager, has been appointed vice president in charge of production, replacing L. E. Young, who becomes vice president in charge of engineering, a new position. Harry Miller, formerly

A concise reiteration was given tonight by Texas Christian University athletic authorities that they have not committed their football team to play in any of the "bowl games" New Year's Day. "Reports we will play in the Cotton Bowl," said Howard Grubbs, director of athletics, "are pure fiction." He was commenting

Twoscore spokesmen for railroads and other transportation agencies and shippers today unanimously approved proposals that distressed roads be permitted to reorganize under the Interstate Commerce Commission without goings through the expensive technicalities of bankruptcy proceedings.
Automobile production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 95.8 from 89.8. The figure for the week ended Nov. 20, 1937, was 96.0

A new magnetic metal that can "shiver" and turn on the heat was announced today at the Battelle Memorial Institute. The shivering of this metal consists in losing its magnetism. It can be made to do this at any temperature from 150 below zero to 1100 above.
The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation reported today that had made contracts with twentynine milling companies, under which it will buy 440,900 barrels of corn meal for relief distribution.

Secretary of the Interior Ickes issued today new regulations governing the assignment of royalty interests in oil and gas prospecting permits and leases designed to furnish additional safeguards for "innocent investors from unscrupulous oil speculators."

The Anti-Nazi Intercollegiate Committee tonight called on the colleges of the nation to support the United States and Great Britain in attempting to find a homeland for the "persecuted minorities" in Germany.

With most of the local wholesalers closing a fairly unsatisfactory season in Fall and Winter goods, retailers are wondering whether their sales are to be disturbed by an outbreak of "job lot" and "wholesale outlet" sales during late November and December.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your issue of Nov. 12 contained an editorial dealing with the problems of slum clearance. You approve the idea frequently expressed by many of those interested and now confirmed by the City Planning Commission, that the best way to clear slums is to replace bad housing with good housing in the same area.
Erich Bodach, 26, of Geyersdorf in the Fraustadt district, and Alfred Kofer, 37, were guillotined here today for espionage. Bodach was convicted

Henry Cotton, generally rated as England's No. 1 golfer, will go to the United States next Spring to play Sam Snead "or anybody else." In a letter to The Associated Press Cotton said he had made arrangements to get away for the trip and was "quite prepared to play anybody, provided the terms make my trip worth while." The former British.

Mrs. Emma Fredericka Grimm Gaebelin of 229 East Sidney Avenue, this city, the wife of the Rev. Dr. Arno Clemens Gaebelin, editor of Our Hope, a Bible study magazine, author and lecturer, died today at the Mount Vernon Hospital after a three-week illness. They were married in 1885.

An appeal to American citizens, particularly Jews and GermanAmericans, to prevent the spread of racial prejudice and animosity in the United States, was made last night by Victor F. Ridder, secretary of the German-language newspaper, the New Yorker Staats-Zeitung und Herold.
The Privy Council, meeting in the presence of Emperor Hirohito, today approved a cultural pact with Germany providing for mutual recognition of their respective racial principles.

BAILEY--Ledyard Marlborough, aged 76, Saturday, Nov. 19, after a short illness, at the home of his daughter, Mrs. T. T. Hazlewood, Ridgewood, N. J. Funeral at Anaheim, Calif. BAKER--Elwood Thomas, peacefully, on Nov. 21, 1938, beloved father of Elwood W., Charles Graham, Tacey Hackstaff, Donald M. and Leslie S. Baker. Funeral services at Dupont Funeral Home, 82-29 Lefferts Boulevard, Kew Gardens, 10:30 A. M., Wednesday, Nov. 23. Interment private.

Defensive and offensive dummy scrimmaging against Brown formations occupied Columbia's varsity yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the Lions' final game of the 1938 season at Providence on Thanksgiving Day.

Henry Goodwin Vaughan, Boston lawyer and yachtsman, who was a national authority on fox-hunting, died today on a train while going to his home in South Berwick Me., from the funeral in Cambridge of his former law partner, Arthur Hendricks Brooks. His age was 70.

After a four-hour session last night the State Executive Committee of the American Labor party was deadlocked on the question of selecting a successor to the late B. Charney Vladeck as Labor member of the City Council from Manhattan and as leader of the Labor party delegation in the Council.
