The entertaining paper on Lincoln's Gettysburg speech, by Emanuel Hertz in Sunday's TIMES, expressed doubt over the idea that the phrase "government of the people, by the people, for the people," was suggested to Lincoln in 1863 by Theodore Parker's "government of all the people, by all the people, for all the people," in his address of 1850 to the New England Anti-Slavery Convention at Boston.

On a high parapet overlooking the Chickamauga Dam of the Tennessee River and the turbulent waters of the unruly stream it was created to harness, President Roosevelt paused today on his way to Warm Springs, Ga., to thank an assembled 2,000 workmen on the project "for a contribution that you are making to our American civilization."

The Green Bay Packers, who were defeated by the Giants in the last game of their campaign last Sunday, set a new scoring record for an eleven-game schedule, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Football League. The Western Division leaders scored 223 points, three more than last season, when they also set the loop mark.

German Jewish refugees, if they seek to settle in British Guiana and Tanganyika Territory, will face the problem of existence in jungle lands--rich in resources, but sparsely populated by whites, equatorial in climate and with scant communications and almost no urban settlements.

Fire in a show window in the furniture store of Michaels Brothers, 163-40 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, yesterday afternoon, caused considerable damage and injuries to two firemen. The fire, believed caused by a short circuit, was confined to the two show-windows at the front of the store.

The United States Maritime Commission awarded today a contract to the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Kearny, N. J., for the construction of six cargo ships for the American merchant marine at a cost of $14,658,000, or $2,443,000 each. The program of the

Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Shiland of this city and East Hampton, L. I., will give a reception at their home here, 120 East Sixty-fifth Street, on Dec. 20 to introduce their daughter, Miss Leonore McAlpin Shiland, to older friends of the family.

The boards of directors of Dow Chemical Company and the Great Western Electro Chemical Company have approved unanimously a plan of merger which will be submitted to shareholders of the respective companies at meetings to be held on Dec. 22.

Rex, a white and black fox terrier, may furnish the only clue to the shooting tonight of his master, William Dobitz, 55-year-old builder, who was mortally wounded while summoning his pet at the rear of his bungalow in Farmingville, near here.

" King Cotton is the nation's economic problem No. 1," Oscar Johnston of Scott, Miss., "father" of the National Cotton Council and former manager of the United States Cotton Pool, asserted at a meeting of five primary groups of the industry to perfect organization of the new council here today.

There will be wide sympathy in this country for Alexander Kosarev, leader of the Russian Komsomols, or Young Communist League, who finds himself in an embarrassing predicament. Denounced by his own paper, the Komsomol Pravda, he is about to become the first sacrifice to a new Soviet crime, officially described as "gaping about."

The Harvard Club's Class B squash tennis team conquered the Columbia University Club by 4 to 1 in a metropolitan league match last night. The other victors were the New York A. C. and the Crescent A. C. The Winged Foot team defeated the City A. C., 4 to 1, and the Crescents turned back the Yale Club, 4-1. As a result of its victory

Robert Jefferson Carter. Bryant J. Tyler, Alfred Seaman, Henry H. Royce, Leonie Langevin. Loren S. Wells, Mark A. Hammond, Francis M. Winikus, Fred A. Hill, Albertus A.. Moore, Maurice C. Hill, William R. Deemer Jr., Will Osborne, Frank Dumond, Anna L. and Cecilia Mallon, in London Terrace, 435 W. 23d St.; Wm. A. White Sons. broker.

R. B. Bennett, former Prime Minister and Conservative leader, announced today that he would retire completely from public life in Canada and spend the rest of his days at a home which he has bought in Surrey. England. Mr.-Bennett said he

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey has filed three petitions with the Federal Power Commission asking reinstatement of applications for appropal of. a merger into it of the Newark Consolidated Gas Company, the Essex and Hudson Gas Company and the Hudson County Gas Company.

Announcement has been made by Foster S. Naething of this city and Tucson, Ariz., of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Katherine Foster Naething, to Norris Dresser Hoyt, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Brewster Hoyt of New Haven, Conn.

Senator Van Nuys, re-elected in the closest off-year contest in a decade of Hoosier politics, asked State Supreme Court writs of prohibition today to halt recount proceedings instituted in seven counties by his Republican opponent, Raymond E. Willis.

Alleging that evidence before the National Labor Relations Board disclosed that fifty employes had been discharged because of membership in and aid of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, a C. I. O.

Sasha Siemel, who says he is the only white man living who hunts and kills South American jaguars with bow and arrow and spear, arrived in New York yesterday after six months in the Brazilian jungle, where he is known as "Tiger Man." He had a question on his mind. He was wondering, he said,

Mrs. Edwards Spencer will entertain at luncheon and dinner at Shipton Court, Lenox, on Thanksgiving Day. She will have as house guests her nieces, the Misses Pernette, Julie M. and Roselyne de Viry of Savoie, France; Miss Marie Delphine Campbell of New York, Mrs. Harmon Pumpelly Read of Albany and Major Ross Rede, U. S. A., now stationed at New Bedford.

A pocketbook containing $1,590 was recovered and a man accused of having snatched it from Miss Louise Albrecht, cashier for the Hamburg-Bremen Shipping Agency of 1,522 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, was captured yesterday after a chase through the crowded Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

James M. Lewis, well known New York billiard player who won honors as an amateur before turning professional eight years ago, died yesterday morning of pneumonia at his home, 446 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. He was about 38 years old.

Whisky production in the United States in the year ended on June 30, 1938, was the smallest since the year following repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and was less than half the quantity produced in the preceding fiscal year, the alcohol tax unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today.

A hundred men in the advertising and publishing fields honored Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, president of the New York Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, at a dinner last night at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

The attempt of Hitler to revise the Old Testament must remind Americans of the blessings of religious liberty, Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran told the Society of Mayflower Descendants at its annual business meeting in the Ambassador Hotel yesterday. Mr. Curran

Leroy Fry, Texas A. and I. halfback, rose to within four points of the nation's scoring leadership by tallying 13 points Saturday on two touchdowns and a conversion, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Gaylon Smith of Southwestern (Tenn.) still leads with 97.
Dave Spittal, professional golfer, died yesterday of a heart ailment while visiting friends here. His age was 56. For the last three years Mr. Spittal was pro at the Idlewyld Club in Sudbury.

Last week Professor Alexander Goetz of the University of California rose before the American Philosophical Socity in Philadelphia to discuss once more his success in keeping microorganisms in a state of apparently indefinite suspended animation by plunging them into liquid gases at a temperature only a little above absolute zero.
The government swung its police forces into action today against a spreading series of strikes in protest against the financial and economic decrees of the Daladier Cabinet.

Officials of three of the nation's most successful business concerns appeared before a Senate Finance subcommittee today to recommend profit-sharing as the most equitable and most businesslike method of establishing and guaranteeing continuity of friendly relations between employers and employes.

Joseph Layman, clothing manufacurer and philanthopist, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday morning in his home, 211 Central Park West. His age was 65. Born in Nashville, Tenn., Mr. Layman was the son of Louis and Anna Layman, who were members of early pioneer families.

A mass meeting of nearly 10,000 persons yesterday to protest anti-Jewish activities in Germany voted to ask the Chilean Government to close immediately Nazi schools in Southern Chile, where the German colony is powerful.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, seeking to place freight rates for fruit-vegetable hampers and baskets on a more uniform basis, ruled today that they should go on a classification basis paralleling the rates on lumber and on box and crate material.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Pederal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 16: increases for the week of $164,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $171,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $23,000,000 in holdings of "other securities."

As his daughter tried frantically to stop an oncoming subway train by waving a tiny handkerchief, Charles Abbott, 84-year-old old-age pensioner, of 474 East 142d Street, the Bronx, was struck and killed yesterday while trying to climb off the tracks, where he had fallen.
Official Soviet disapproval of moral laxity is reflected in an article in the Komsomolskaya Pravda, condemning both "easy young women" and vulgar young men for promiscuity.

Both RKO and United Artists are negotiating with Herbert Wilcox, British producer of "Victoria the Great" and "Sixty Glorious Years," to bring Anna Neagle to the American screen in a modern AngloAmerican film. Wilcox and Miss

The Treasury's weekly bill offering was sold today at an average in. terest rate of 0.026 per- cent, com pared with 0.027 per cent for the issue sold a week ago, Secretary; Morgenthau announced tonight, There -was at least one bid at 100.

Wilder McGowan, 24-year-old Negro, was lynched today by a mob of about 200 white men who had trailed him several hours with bloodhounds after a 74-year-old white woman allegedly was criminally attacked and robbed.

Nine contests have been arranged for the -St. John's University fencing team this season, according to an announcement by the athletic office yesterday. It is one of the most extensive and difficult schedules ever arranged for the Redmen. Coach Marcel Pasche's fencers will open their season against the Army on-Jan. 21.

A pair of rapid-fire goals early in the final period turned a see-saw game into an easy 4-1 victory for the Crescent A. C. skaters over the Imperial Victorias as both teams opened their New York amateur hockey association season at the Imperial Arena tonight.

In line with the frequently expressed hopes of Mayor La Guardia and other officials of the city administration, the Board of Higher Education voted last night to set up a civil service training school in City College next year. In a resolution adopted at a meeting at the City College School of

The second tier of boxes at Carnegie Hall for the recital of John Charles Thomas tonight has been taken over by the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association to raise funds for the organization's welfare projects.

Fear that teachers in New York State may have to pay retroactive income taxes to the Federal Government for the last twelve years, amounting at a moderate estimate to $88,000,000, was expressed yesterday by school leaders at the conference of the New York State Teachers Association at the Hotel Commodore.

Contributions of $10,000 from Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney and of $5,000 from William Nelson Cromwell were among the 640 additional gifts to the United Hospital Campaign reported last night at campaign headquarters, 370 Lexington Avenue, by C. M. Chester. chairman.

The Seaboard Air Line Railway will incur a deficit of about $7,457,808 this year, according to esti- lows fc mates furnished the Interstate Commerce Commission. The actual defi- No. Am cit for the first nine months of the year was $6,150,053.

Modern youth, faced by the transformation of the United States from a "young, pioneer nation" to a "static social order" with more people than opportunities, "must be satisfied with less," Mrs, Jean Shepherd, director of executive personnel at Lord Taylor, declared yesterday in a talk at a campaign luncheon of the Young Women's Christian Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

The Department of Justice purposes to build up a number of consent decrees, ratified by Federal Courts, so that business men will know what they can and cannot do under the anti-trust laws, Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, said today.

Attorney General R. G. Menzies, speaking in the budget debate in the House of Representatives today, announced that the government had decided to adopt the suggestion by former Prime Minister J. H. Scullin for a special session of Parlia ment to formulate amendments to the Commonwealth's Constitution.
The New York Court of Appeals held today that strikers canont picket the homes of workers who do not join a strike.

Leonard St, 55, 25.4x100; George F. Sutherland to 55 Leonard St Corp, 55 Leonard St (50 cents). Suffolk St, 134, 25x99.10; Clara Neuman, individual and as extrx, et al as execrs and trustees Moritz Neuman, to Bowery Savings Bank, mtg $10,000 not to merge in fee ($10.50).

Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems, daughter of Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff of New York and Southampton, L. I., and the late Chester P. Siems, has completed plans for her marriage to James Abercrombie de Peyster, son of the Countess Bohdan de Castellane of New York and Menton, France, and of Frederic Ashton de Peyster of this city, which will take place here the afternoon of Dec. 2 in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

The seventh annual veterans' squash racquets tournament ended on the Squash Club courts last night in a victory for Ralph A. Powers of the Harvard Club over his clubmate and a former champion, Charles O. Wellington.

The government has forbidden all notaries public until further notice to attest the sale of land or houses belonging to Jews. A recent decree limited real estate holdings, and now owners are prevented from disposing of the surplus and must await government instructions as to what to do with the property they are no longer permitted to own.
Stout Steve Owen's face was a mile long early yesterday morning at the Polo Grounds as the Giants assembled to drill for tomorrow's struggle at Ebbets Field against the Brooklyn Dodgers.
Tom Lieb, for nine years head. football coach at Loyola University, resigned today amid mounting criticism by alumni over the team's poor season.

Contracts between ten important manufacturers of higher price dresses and the Association of Exclusive Specialty Shops whereby these manufacturers confined exclusive styles to members of the association have been cancelled, it was announced yesterday by Joseph P. Mandelbaum of Polly's Gown, Inc., and president of the association.

In line with the national policy of reducing WPA payrolls, it was announced here today by Robert W. Allan, acting State WPA administrator, that the New Jersey personnel would be reduced by about 4,000 by Feb. 1. The total employment now on State WPA projects is about 105,000.

Owners of more than a majority of outstanding bonds having agreed to a plan to reduce taxes of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey by disposing of unused lands, a petition seeking permission to effect such disposal will be made to the court soon, it was announced today.

Pearl Buck, author of "The Good Earth" and other novels, who will sail for Sweden soon to receive the Nobel Prize for Literature was guest of honor at a dinner of the American Pen Club last night at the Hotel Algonquin.

The receivers of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company, which owes the government $14,440,500, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to obtain the assistance of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the sale of $640,000 of 3 per cent equipment trust certificates to buy a streamlined Diesel-electric passenger train from the Electro-motive Corporation to be delivered by Feb. 1 next.

Students attending the Eastview Avenue school in this city have been stricken during the past week with a peculiar illness that compelled 400 of the 1,500 youths to remain home a day or longer, according to the Westchester County Department of Health today.

Stephen G. Williams, a lawyer, with offices at 110 East Forty-second Street, who had been a trustee of Columbia University since 1923, died last night at his residence, 1,172 Park Avenue. He was born in this city seventy-eight years ago.

The first death from diphtheria in New York City in the last six weeks occurred during the week ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records. The single death occurred in Brooklyn.

In the most brilliant opera inaugural this city has seen in years, the Metropolitan Opera Association opened its Philadelphia season of ten performances tonight with a sumptuous presentation of Richard Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier" before a capacity audience in the Academy of Music.

Although "Ringside Seat" has an enticingly pugilistic sound, it is a killer of another color. It is Grant Mitchell devoting his plump and fussy comedy to gaping at a murder trial. Leonard Ide, sometime author of "These Few Ashes" and "Peacock," wrote it in appreciation of the dim-wits who take their murder vicariously on the spectators' bench in the court room, and it was put on at the Guild Theatre last evening.

Registering its third straight victory in South Africa, the touring Marylebone Cricket Club today defeated Griqualand West by an innings and 289 runs. In reply to tbe visiting eleven's total of 676 runs, the home players were dismissed for 114 and 273.

Aubrey Williams, deputy administrator of the WPA, was attacked today by Chairman Dies of the House committee investigating un-American activities, for a speech at Birmingham in which Mr. Williams was reported to have endorsed "class warfare."
The six-room dwelling at 115 Sumpter Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Gotham Equities Corporation to a client of A. Froemhoffer, broker.
Taking the stand tonight before the House investigating committee, Governor George H. Earle vigorously denied the charges of graft and misconduct brought against his administration.

Operations of the Plymouth Oil Company in the first ten months of this year resulted in a consolidated net profit of $2,189,148 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges, it was announced yesterday. This is equivalent to $2.17 each on 1,008,200 shares of capital stock outstanding on Oct. 31 last, excluding shares held in the treasury.

Forty-three additional names for members of the New York Stock Exchange's nominating committee for 1939 were submitted yesterday at a meeting of the present nominating committee, whereas four candidates suggested at the previous meeting requested that their names be withdrawn.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 19: COMMANDER Miller, C. C., Battle Force, Destroyers, to Naval Operations, Navy Department In May or June.

Prices of rayon yarn made on continuous-process machines at the new Painesville (Ohio) plant of the Industrial Rayon Corporation, Cleveland, will be held at the same levels as those for yarn made by methods now in use, it was learned yesterday at the New York offices of the corporation.
Fred Apostoli, San Francisco, yesterday was officially recognized as world middleweight champion by the New-York State Athletic Commission.
The body of Queen Maud of Norway was taken tonight to her girlhood home, Marlborough House, for funeral services tomorrow morning before the body is carried to Norway.

Sales of specialty stores in the Loop shopping district are moving upward steadily, a check of sales trends of the last six weeks showed today. The sole exception to the trend is in shoes which have declined from their Sepmember highs because of seasonal influences.

Under an agreement dated Aug. 29, executed in October, an option to purchase a maximum of 20,000 shares of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company at $8 a share from a group of large stockholders was granted to Robert V. White. on condition that he become president of the company before Nov. 1.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered well below the preceding week. However, the total was slightly above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
ADVENTURES OF AMERICA, 1857-1900, edited by John A. Kouwenhoven. (Harper, $3.50.) A pictorial record from Harper's Weekly.

Eric Robinson, British Airways pilot who flew Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain on his visits to Chancellor Adolf Hitler at Godesberg and Munich during the Czechoslovak crisis, was killed today in an air crash.
A "vast increase" within the last year in the number of closed and boarded-up buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn was reported yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement.

Dr. Claudius T. Murchison of New York, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, said today consequences of the recently signed Anglo-American-Canadian trade agreement might be "serious" to the American textile industry.

Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, said today he believed that the Ford and Chrysler motor companies would divorce themselves entirely from any connection with automobile-purchase financing companies.

Professor James Arthur Tufts, part of the tradition of Phillips Exeter Academy since 1878, was known and loved by all his boys as "Tuffy," just as old Chipping, in James Hilton's story, was known and loved as Mr. Chips. The gentle kindliness and dry humor which could freeze to sudden iron in Mr. Chips were wedded, too, in "Tuffy."

Yale University will receive immediately one-half of the residuary estate of Lawrence Darr, who died in France on Aug. 20, and the other half on the termination of a trust, under the terms of his will, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. The estate was formally valued at "more than $20,000."

There will be no doubt in the minds of most lawyers that the Supreme Court was merely following the settled interpretation of the law when it decided the other day that a patentee may restrict the use to which his patent vacuum tube may be put.
Ireland won the international army officers' team challenge trophy at the Royal Winter Fair horse show tonight with a total of nine faults, against eleven for the United States.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $11,997,414, after all operating expenses and charges.

Dr. Alexander MacAlister, who was Walt Whitman's physician and friend, died in his home here today after a long illness at the age of 77. Born in Paterson, he received his medical degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1885.

A wizard of the prohibition era who could make denatured alcohol taste right and easily counterfeit any liquor label was trapped yesterday morning by Treasury Department agents in his four-story headauarters in the Bronx.
Postmaster General Farley authorized today the issuance of four new postage stamps in 1939.

The Most Rev. Luis Chavez y Gonzalez was designated Sunday as Archbishop of El Salvador in an impressive ceremony conducted by two Bishops in the presence of the President, the Papal Nuncio, diplomats and high government officials.

George R. Allhands, a telegrapher for more than fifty years, died in the Kingsland Hospital, Brooklyn, on Sunday at the age of 82. Mr. Allhands was a native of Marshall, Ill., and began his career as a telegrapher at the age of 13.

CASTRIES, St. Lucia, British West Indies, Nov. 22--Steep mountainsides of St. Lucia, among the most beautiful in the West Indies, cracked open today in a series of avalanches that buried perhaps hundreds of persons. [A map showing the position of St. Lucia appears on Page 15.]

Four men who were arrested last Spring in Mayor La Guardia's drive against misleading advertising by small storekeepers were convicted yesterday in Special Sessions by Justices Hackenburg, Doyle and Walling. They paid fines rather than serve alternative jail terms.

Colonel Carlos Sanchez, recently appointed military attache of the Venezuelan Legation in Washington, arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Paula, accompanied by his wife. He is the first military attace ever accredited by Venezuela to the United States Government.

Jack Jacoby, through Chelsea Management Co, in 29 5th Ave; Jerry Barclay, in 253 E 22d St; Marland Stone, in 14 W 10th St; Edward P. Dimond, in 45 5th Ave; Heinz Schultz, in 25 W 18th St; Wm. A. White Sons brokers.

Plans for the alteration of one of the oldest apartment buildings on lower Madison Avenue, involving an expenditure of about $150,000, were filed yesterday. The house concerned is the thirteen-story building at 121 Madison Avenue,
A longsmoldering controversy over football at Pitt broke wide open today, with Chancellor John G. Bowman assailing interference "from unofficial managers who want to sit in the press box."

Leonard Warren, young American baritone, one of the winners in the Metropolitan Opera radio auditionsof-the-air, will make his debut at next Sunday night's concert at the opera house, it was announced yesterday.

From the pine-paneled living room of his "other home" on Pine Mountain, President Roosevelt today charged bad faith to the Legislature and politicians of his adopted State of Georgia, said it was the only State in the country that had refused to cooperate with the Public Works Administration and declared it would not get another cent from the government for public works until it changed its tactics.

Striking C. I. O. union employes made the shutdown of the Chicago stock yards complete at 5 o'clock this afternoon after a day in which "white collar" commission men and company executives stepped into the breach to clear the market of a two-day supply of livestock.

John Sullivan, 54 years old, known as the "czar" of the Wallabout Market in Brooklyn, where he operated as an unofficial watchman with an income said to be sufficiently lucrative to move the Federal Government to prosecute him for income tax evasion, and three associates pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, to charges of violating the State business and insurance laws.

All interests participated in cleaning the yards today pending settlement of the strike. Fed steers and yearlings sold strong to 25 cents higher, according to the United States Department of Agriculture report, several loads of medium weight and heavy steers topping at $13.50.

The organization of government makes it unfit for economic planning, while the "free market" constitutes the most efficient coordinator of economic activities, Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, New 41 45 York City, said here tonight in an 54 address at Johns Hopkins Univer- 1073 sity.
We heard a story yesterday, from a friend who had recently returned from a deer hunt in the Adirondacks, that would make the blood of any real sportsman boil.

The possibility that another $70,000,000 battleship will be allotted to the Navy Yard in Brooklyn for construction was seen yesterday after a visit to the yard by Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

Long Island University will be represented on the gridiron next year, Dean Tristram W. Metcalfe announced yesterday. This action was taken following an overwhelming vote by the student body for the return of football.

Under the combined pressure of a persistent flight of capital from London and short selling, the British pound sterling yesterday again fell heavily in the foreign exchange market and further amounts of gold were engaged in England for shipment here.
Mrs. Theodore M. Edison of West Orange, daughter-in-law of the late Thomas A. Edison, is serving a clerkship in a local pharmacy, it was learned today.

Jackie (Kid) Berg, 146 1/2, of London scored a decisive victory over Frankie Cavanna, 146 1/2, East Side, in an exciting eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena last night before a crowd of 5,000.

John Hudson Bennett, vice president of the Wellington Sears Company, 65 Worth Street, cotton goods commission merchants, and a collector of rare stringed instruments, died on Monday at his home, 9 Washington Square North, after a two-year illness. His age was 65.

Staging a scoring spree in the first and second periods, the St. Nicks team of the New York Amateur Hockey Association last night skated to a 9-3 victory over the New York Sporting Club at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

As Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador, made his farewell call on Secretary of State Cordell Hull at the State Department this afternoon, the State Department announced that Prentiss Gilbert, counselor of the United States Embassy in Berlin, yesterday delivered a note to the German Foreign Office requesting formal assurances that a decree aimed at Jewish business men would not apply to American citizens.

Special Thanksgiving Day services will be held in most of the churches of the city tomorrow, some of them combining in union services. In many of the churches harvest fruits and Autumn leaves and flowers will decorate the altars.

The distinction between the German people and their present leadership was emphasized last night by two German-American leaders and a member of Congress in a broadcast on the current persecutions entitled "The German-American Answer to Hitler."

George M. Verity, chairman of the board of the American Rolling Mill Company at Middletown, Ohio, said today that any profit-sharing on the part of industry should be voluntary and not done under the compulsion or incentive of law.

The transportation conference of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States voiced today its opposition to compulsory consolidation of railroads and to any further railroad regulatory agencies in the Federal Government and urged the government to dispose of its bauge lines to private interests.
Spanish Government advices from the Segre River front said tonight that the Insurgents, after several days of costly counter-attacks,had failed to crack the government line.

Harold B. Scott, president of the Denver Chemical Company in New York and a founder and the chairman of the board of the Washington Irving Trust Company here, died today at his home in Wilson Park after a heart attack. His age was 55.

Other events in Europe have overshadowed what is happening to Czechoslovakia. Yet the developments on the western and eastern frontiers of that shrunken state are of capital importance. Not only do they throw light on the aims of Germany; they strain the ten-year truce between Poland and the Reich and test the power of Berlin and Rome to arbitrate in Central Europe.

Pajamas for Park Avenue's pedigreed pooches is the latest decree of Dame Fashion; not only that, but the pampered pet that really wants to be de rigueur must never, never cavort about the streets on rainy days without his rubbers.

Phil Ross of Montreal carded 39, 37-76 to annex medal honors in the twenty-third annual Carolina golf tournament today. Match play will start tomorrow in flights of eight and the finals will be contested Friday.

Persons active in social service joined with residents of the tenement districts at the funeral of Dr. Caroline Whitney, chairman of the Milk Consumers Protective Committee, yesterday. Dr. Whitney died on Saturday.

Leopold Godowsky was a unique figure among all his contemporaries: a phenomenal pianist and a musician of the most exceptional attributes. Early he had mastered practically the whole of the modern repertory.
A permanent injunction preventing municipal authorities from Interfering with the presentation of the stage play, "Tobacco Road," was granted in Superior Court here late today.

The final wool auctions of the year opened today with a large attendance. Offerings amounted to 9,441 bales, of which 7,515 were sold. The market generally was in accordance with expectations, and although competition was not always brisk, prices were not affected owing to the firmness of sellers' rates.
Thanksgiving festivities, ranging from those emphasizing the original purpose of giving thanks to God to those treating the day as a holiday from routine, start today and continue through tomorrow.

Tne hope that economic recovery can be stimulated by concerted action among the nations following the averting of a general war in Europe was expressed by Thomas J. Watson of New York, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, in a letter today to the governments of all countries belonging to the chamber.
Many leases calling for additional which office space or for retail stores were among the contracts for commercial quarters reported by brokers yesterday.
James Lucas Snyder, who conducted the American Baptist mission in Rangoon, Burma, for twenty-six years until his retirement in 1926, died here yesterday at his home after a lingering illness.

Total deposits of all active national banks on Sept. 28, the recent call date, were $27,103,881,000, an increase of $287,987,000 from June 30, the previous call date, and $563,187,000 from last December, the office of the Controller of the Currency announced today.
Tony Canzoneri, former world welterweight and lightweight champion, made a triumphant return to local boxing last night at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx after eighteen months in retirement.
Three New Jersey debutantes of the holiday season in the Oranges will be presented to society at a supper dance to be given by their parents on Dec. 26 at the Essex County Country Club.

Liquidation of December contracts carried prices on the Cotton Exchange into new high territory were again yesterday and left the list mere with net changes ranging from a gain of 4 points to a loss of 1.

Walter Dumala, 32 years old, also known as Walter Samsky, formerly of Bay Shore, L. I., pleaded not guilty today before County Judge L. Barron Hill, here, to a charge of second degree murder which has been pending against him for the last. fourteen years.

Failure of American industry to recognize that it must not resist unionization is virtually the only barrier to the development of a mature method of establishing workable industrial relations such as now exist in Great Britain and Sweden, two members of the President's commission on industrial relations in those countries agreed last night.

Mrs. Marie Burckhalter of Hastings-on-Hudson was held in $10,00 bail by County Judge Frank H. Coyne here today on an information charging manslaughter, first degree. She is to plead to the charge on Nov. 29;
The Court of Appeals has halted an attempt to evict from a New York City apartment a tenant who relied on the Minkoff tenement rent law in refusing to pay a $5-a-month increase in his rent.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, will leave for Paris tomorrow on a visit intended to encourage the French and remind the world again of the solidity of the Anglo-French alliance.

Approaching the climax of its season, Army's football squad worked this afternoon in the comparative quiet of its new practice field near its huge field house after having listened all day to the annual chant of "Beat Navy!" augmented this year by cries of "Crush Navy,"

A list of gifts of $100,000 or more made by John D. Rockefeller Sr. between 1855 and 1934 was given yesterday by John D. Rookefeller Jr. in a statement made public by Ivy Lee T. J. Ross. The list follows:
City Censor John J. Spencer today ordered deletion of five expressions in Elmer Rice's new play, "American Landscape," on the ground that they were profane.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Nov. 15, issued today, shows that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation rose from 125.29 per cent on Oct. 31 to 126.29 per cent.

MANHATTAN BARTON, JESSIE CLUETT (Sept. 22). Estate, more than $100,000. To Cornelius Vanderbilt Barton, husband, executor, Hotel Plaza, household furnishings, specific jewelry, one-half residue outright and one-half in trust for life; Dorothy Varian, cousin, Woodstock, N. Y., $5,000; Childs Hospital, Albany. N. Y., $600;
Japanese air raids have been resumed on an extensive scale in the vicinity of Shanghai as part of a renewed drive on Chinese guerrillas in Southern Kiangsu.

As Christmas falls this year on Sunday, and the holiday will be officially observed on Monday, Postmaster General Farley wants all postal employes who can be spared to have the opportunity of spending those days with their families.

The report of the Berlin Boersen Zeitung, which frequently speaks for the German Foreign Office, that President Roosevelt was the only statesman to congratulate Joseph Stalin on the twentieth anniversary of the Russian Revolution, Nov. 7, 1937, was denied yesterday by Soviet authorities.

The Continental Oil Company has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $21,071,600 of tenyear convertible debentures due on Dec. 15, 1948. The debentures are first to be offered to holders of capital stock.

The original autograph manuscript of Edwin Markham's famous poem "The Man With the Hoe" brought $700 last night at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The manuscript, consisting of 49 lines and about 480 words, bears the poet's own attestation that it is the genuine one.

About 80 per cent of the labor turnover in most companies is due to lack of faith by employes either in themselves or in their company, Ellis C. Baum, vice president of the Continental Baking Company, said yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Numbering ranking teams from the East, Middle West and South among its eight victims, Notre Dame's all-conquering football team retains its top ranking among the leading gridiron powers in the latest Associated Press poll of the country's sports writers.

Pleas for stimulated efforts against war and for greater aid for refugees were made by speakers yesterday afternoon at a tea given by the Manhattan Division of the Women's International League for Peace arid Freedom in honor of Miss Devereux Blake, a member of the refugee committee of the league.

KINGS ASTOR, ABRAHAM M. (April 11, 1937). Gross assets, $66,517; net, $55,541. To wife, Gertrude R. Astor; daughter, Phoebe J. Astor, and son, Stuart L. Astor, one-third of residuary estate each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $48,701; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $11,450; miscellaneous property, $6,366. Matt Goldstein, attorney, 225 W,. 34th St., Manhattan.

A suggestion that proposed regulations of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act be changed so that the principal panels of package labels carry a line, referring buyers to complete data on the reverse of the package was contained yesterday in a brief filed by the Association of National Advertisers with the Secretary of Agriculture.
The Court of Appeals upheld today the firstdegree murder convictions of Salvatore Gati and Charles Sberna of New York City for the fatal shooting of John Wilson, a New York City policeman.

There has been no rush of Mexican landowners to relinquish their legal rights to indemnity for lands nationalized since President Lazaro Cardenas's speech Sunday requesting Mexicans voluntarily to relinquish such rights.
Protests against German oppression of Jews, Catholics and other minorities continued here yesterday in resolutions of labor, civic, religious, political and other bodies.

Anti-Semitic disturbances in Europe are due principally to economic conditions, Louis S. Posner, Manhattan chairman of the New York campaign of the American ORT Federation, said yesterday at the annual membership tea of the Women's American ORT in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Torbert H. Macdonald, '40, was elected captain of Harvard's 1939 football team today at a meeting of the lettermen at the locker building on Soldiers Field. John M. Atherton 2d, '40, of Glenview, Ky., was appointed manager for next season, and R. G. Page Jr. of Weston, Mass., was named assistant manager.

At the first report luncheon of the women's division in the campaign to raise $250,000 for the construction of a World's Fair Temple of Religion, held in the Hotel Astor yesterday, gifts amounting to $16,348 were announced. Added to the $67,000 already collected, the total received since the campaign began amounts to $83,348.

Trading in wheat futures today on the Board Zin of Trade was at a minimum, and most of the business was in spreading operations between the December and May. Holders of the December liquidated and replaced with purchases of May. Cash Wo houses did the reverse, buying the December and selling the May around 23/4. cents a bushel discount for the former, changing over hedges into the distant month.
Unless the democracies evacuate the German Jews at once and at their own expense, they will be starved into crime and then exterminated with "fire and sword."

Music of Morris Mamorsky and Henry Holden Huss was performed on the Composers Forum-Laboratory program at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night. Mr. Mamorsky, who has written music for the dance, was represented by a Dance Conatine for piano and a suite for violin and piano. Mr.
Craig Wood yesterday was appointed professional at the Winged Foot Golf Club, succeeding the veteran Mike Brady, who served from 1922, when the club was founded, until recently.

William B. Bankhead of Alabama will seek re-election as Speaker of the House, it was announced today. He will not be opposed, according to Representative Sam Rayburn, majority floor leader, who aspired to the Speakership two years ago.

The Securities and Elxchange Commission suspended today until further order the registrations of J. Albert Haines, 10 Broadway, and Herman Lucas, 38 Park Row, both of New York City, as over-the-counter brokers or dealers.

Annual National Interfraternity Conference will open at the Hotel Commodore at 9:30 A. M. Other sessions Friday and Saturday. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Decorative Arts of the Near East," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.;
Abraham Lincoln Bernstein, former Assistant Chief Deputy Tax Assessor of New York, died in his home here this afternoon of a heart ailment at the age of 57. He had retired In February, 1937.

Charles G. Edwards, William E. Russell, P. Walker Morrison and Richard M. Hurd, reorganization managers for the Lawyers Mortgage Company, announced yesterday that holders of more than two-thirds of the outstanding mortgages and mortgage certificates guaranteed by the company had filed assents to the proposed plan of reorganization.

Moving swiftly, John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor appointed a month ago by Governor Lehman to investigate corruption in law enforcement agencies in Brooklyn, officially opened his inquiry yesterday by calling two witnesses before the extraordinary grand jury in connection with the case of Police Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan and the theft of 7,200 police arrest records from a Brooklyn police station.

Unless the United States calls an abrupt halt to the Mexican policy of appropriating American and other foreign-owned property without payment, there is distinct danger that the rest of Latin America, where $6,000,000,000 of American capital is invested, will follow suit.

With merchants revising upward their expectations on Christmas trade, there is every likelihood that dollar sales in the department and specialty stores of the country will amount to a total of at least $1,200,000,000 during the four weeks preceding Christmas, an amount equal in dollars to that- of trade in the same period of 1937, according to an analysis issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Mrs. Audrey James Field, former wife of Marshall Field 3d of Chicago, has announced her engagement today to Peter Pleydell-Bouverie, youngest brother of the Earl of Radnor.

The executive committee of the General Confederation of Labor met Premier Edouard Daladier's stern measures to halt spreading labor troubles with an announcement tonight that the committee had decided to carry out instructions for a nation-wide strike involving 5,000,000 French workers.

General Hugh S. Johnson will be general chairman for the Greater New York area in this year's campaign against infantile paralysis, it was announced today by Keith Morgan, chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday.

A consistent stream of small orders for medium-price and better millinery has arrived in the New York market since Nov. 1, enabling producers in these ranges to equal or surpass their 1937 Fall figures, producers here said yesterday.

Owner P. K. Wrigley of the Chicago Cubs, National League baseball team, said today he would offer Dizzy Dean, the pitcher obtained from the St. Louis Cardinals for $185,000, a salary contract for 1939 calling for the same amount of money he received this past season.

Directors of the United States Rubber Company declared yesterday at a special meeting a dividend of $4 a share on the outstanding 8 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value. This dividend, payable on Dec. 23 to holders of record of Dec. 9, will be the first one paid on this stock since Feb. 15, 1928, almost eleven years.

A military funeral was held at Arlington National Cemetery today for Second Lieutenant Robert Kirkland Black, one of those killed in a crash of an army plane near La Grange, Ga., last Friday. Services were conducted by Chaplain Ora J. Cohee.

James Henry Foley of 1,964 Fendale Avenue, Washington, D. C., committed suicide early yesterday in room in the Hotel New Yorker. He was a civilian employee of the Marine Corps paymaster's office in Washington.

The opening exhibition of the season at the Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, is devoted to "two colorists"-Pierre-Auguste Renoir and Raoul Dufy. Six canvases by the great Renoir range in point of time from the comparatively early landscape, "Route Ensoliellee," dated 1895, to "Reverie," belonging to the last year of the artist's life (Renoir died in 1919).

For their season's third Carnegie Hall concert, Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra last night brought with them the tenor Richard Crooks, the University of Pennsylvania Choral Society and its director, Harl McDonald, and engaged them in a program that jumped centuries in as much time as it takes to open the cover of the next score.

UNITED STATES PRINCIPAL CHEMIST, PRINCIPAL CHEMICAL ENGINEER, $5,800 a year, Department of Agriculture. A four-year course, leading to a bachelor's degree, in a recognized college or university, with major study in chemisry or chemical engineering, is required Applicants must not have passed their fifty-third birthday.

What orange growers did for their industry with advertising, the National Cotton Council, formed here today, hopes to do for cotton. This supplemented by a campaign for lower freight rates and research for new uses of cotton, will constitute the keystone of the council's program for increased use of cotton.

Emmet R. Blake, assistant curator of birds of the Field Museum in Chicago, today reached Georgetown to tell of spending ten days facing starvation on an island of the Corentyne River after his boat was swamped in the river's dangerous rapids on Nov. 1.

Miss Margery Sharp of London, author of "The Nutmeg Tree" and other novels, was married here yesterday afternoon to Geoffrey Lloyd Castle, also of London, in the Central Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers.
Negotiations for the purchase of "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" having reached an impasse, Samuel Goldwyn has started to dicker for "The Raven" by Marquis James as a vehicle for Gary Cooper.
THE football campaign has now reached the stage where nominations are in order. The nominating committees have to pick partners for the bowling parties here and there about the country.

The appearance of distinguished soloists and the performance of several novelties will mark the programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra during December, it was announced yesterday. The highlights for the month follow:
Mrs. F. Tyrell Godman of Sussex, England, was honored at a dinner given tonight by Mrs. Lucy Wadhams Dodge at Guestwick, Pittsfield.

" No doubt" now exists that John F. O'Hara, 26-year-old credit investigator who was slain by gunmen at the entrance of his home, 48-19 Forty-fourth Street, Woodside, Queens, last Friday evening, was the victim of mistaken identity, according to Deputy Police Inspector John J. O'Ryan, in charge of Manhattan detectives.
The Actors Equity Association's council authorized yesterday the appointment of five members of Chorus Equity, subsidiary organization, to serve on the parent body's council.

An alarming diaper shortage in Soviet Russia was revealed today by the newspaper Izvestia. Inefficient organization was blamed by the government organ for the losing race diaper factories are running with the increasing Russian birthrate.

Twice yesterday Floyd Bennett Field was used as a haven by scheduled airliners when a total of nine airplanes landed there under good conditions when Newark Airport, their regular landing point, proved unfavorable for landings.
Today's major events: "Die Walkuere," evening, Metropolitan Opera House; Arnold MacLeod, pianist, afternoon, Town Hall; John Charles Thomas, baritone, evening, Carnegie Hall;

A joint committee made up of representatives of the employers and employes in the painting and interior decorating industry launched a novel campaign last night to raise $100,000 in four weeks for the relief of sufferers in the Jewish persecutions abroad.

Employment in cotton garments increased slightly in September, compared with August, and the gains were shown in all major divisions except the classification for cotton slacks, men's and boys' wash suits and semi-dress pants, according to data issued by the International Association of Garment Manufacturers from figures compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Ruby Helder, woman tenor, star of British Broadcasting Company concerts and wife of Chesley Bonestell, died last night at her home here. She was 48 years old, Miss Helder achieved her greatest fame in London, where she gave command performances.

Mal Stevens, N. Y. U.'s head coach, was complaining about not being able to sleep these nights. The fact that his team was to play Fordham at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday wouldn't have anything to do with it, would it? "It might," said Mal.

L. B. Day, Associate Justice of the Nebraska Supreme Court and chairman of the American Bar Association's resolutions committee, died late today of complications arising from pneumonia. He was 49 years old.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 21: COLONELS Atkins, J. A., Inf., Jefferson Barracks, Mo. to headquarters, Ft. Sam Houston, Texas, about Feb. 10.

It is likely that within the next few weeks 1,500 men and women on the New York City public school eligible lists will receive chest X-ray examinations for tuberculosis, Dr. Louis Marks, chairman of the Board of Examiners, disclosed yesterday.

Without finishing his game in tonight's eleventh round of the A. V. R. O. international tournament, Paul Keres of Estonia, the youngest of the eight competitors, broke away from a tie with Reuben Fine of New York and took undisputed possession of the lead.

In view of the continued softness of prices for refined copper abroad, there is a belief in the trade here that some steps may be taken soon to restore restrictions on foreign production. All restrictions were lifted on Oct. 15 to prevent a runaway market.
Dartmouth football players, here to meet Stanford in one of the big intersectional games of the week, ran through an easy workout today.
The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on two lots of textiles totaling 223,300 yards. The first lot, 36,500 yards,

A trend to slimmer lines in daytime clothes arid to even more generous skirts and more exaggerated sleeves for evening was apparent in the midseason collection of Paris imports, shown at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday.

Four hundred employes of the Conmar Products Corporation, manufacturers of slide fasteners, went on strike here today, charging that the management was attempting to foster a company-dominated union and avoid collective bargaining with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, Local 421, C. I. O.

Four inspectors and four other employes in the Queens division of buildings of the Department of Housing and Buildings have been suspended and will be tried on departmental charges, John P. Riley, Queens superintendent of the department, announced yesterday.

American exporters have obtained approximately 1,500 concessions on their exports to Crown colonies as a result of the Anglo-American trade agreement, Francis T. Cole of the National Foreign Trade Council informed members of the Export Managers Club of New York,

Steel ingot output expanded morel than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 94.8, its highest point since the week ended Oct. 2, 1937. The figure was 92.9 for the preceding week and 55.4 for the week ended Nov. 20. 1937.

Nine German citizens living in Denmark and three Danes were arrested today on charges of having established an information service for supplying news about the movements of ships in Danish waters and other information of value to a foreign country in case of war.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. received yesterday the award of $2,042,000 of city of Boston, Mass., various purpose bonds, on a bid of par for $1,292,000, maturing from 1939 to 1953, as 4s; $650,000, due in 1983, as 2'As, and $100,000, due 1939 to 1948, as 2Ys, or at a net interest cost to the city of 2.587 per cent.
King George VI, when he arrives in this country next May, will -find his great-grandmother, Queen Victoria, enjoying

The Governors of thirty States pledged their cooperation in making the New York World's Fair an unprecedented success and an influence for greater business and economic prosperity, in messages placed yesterday in the cornerstone of the Fair's National Advisory Committees Building.

Every effort will be exerted by the Canadian Federal authorities to see that no hardship is imposed upon Jewish refugees who by various means have gained entry to Canada during the last few weeks, Prime Minister Mackenzie King said tonight.
Four of 109 Hudson County election district board officers, indicted on charges of violating the election laws, were acquitted here tonight by a jury before Judge Thomas Meany in Common Pleas Court.

Baron Stefan Czarnecki of Poland has arrived here with agricultural, highway, hydraulic, electrical and mining engineers to confer with President Anastasio Somoza on establishment of a Polish colony, principally of farmers.

C. W. Kellogg, president of the Edison Electric Institute and chairman of the board of the Engineers Public Service Company, told the Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority today that TVA yardstick rates for electric power were unfair because they did not make proper allocation of the costs of the TVA dams among power, navigation and flood control,
Three Kansas State Penitentiary convicts died today, a fourth is critically ill and twenty others are confined to beds after drinking a soap compound containing methyl alcohol.

Former Mayor James J. Walker and Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy were guest speakers last night at a charity bazaar and entertainment of the New York Infants Welfare League on the roof garden of the Astor Hotel. Twentyfive hundred persons attended the entertainment, which had an African jungle setting.
The New York Americans showed no pity to the hapless Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

An immediate modification of the immigration laws to permit the entry into the United States of Jewish and Christian refugees from Germany is demanded in a leading editorial to appear today in The Commonweal, national weekly edited by Catholic laymen.

By H. LOUIS HOLLANDER Tremont Ave. 1,800 E; 79.7x111.2 irreg; Muldoon et al, trustees, against Tauban Realty Co, Inc; due, $46,900 to plaintiff for $1,000. Prospect Ave. 2,339; 4-story tenement, 50x 95; East River Savings Bank against Emilio Marzullo; due, $39,086; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Barnard College students saw themselves in their roles as undergraduates in a color film of college life shown for the first time yesterday afternoon in Barnard Hall under the sponsorship of the Undergraduate Land and Building Fund. A thousand students,

Permanent meteorological stations in the Arctic to "reduce weather from a philosophy to a science" will be recommended by Clifford J. MacGregor, commander of the MacGregor Arctic Expedition, on the basis of data collected during his long stay in the North, he revealed yesterday.

Pre-Thanksgiving business was centered on poultry in local markets yesterday. Wholesalers were anxious to reduce meat stocks for the Thanksgiving holiday and trading in meats was slow. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to higher; other classes weak to lower.

The Rev. Louis L. Herman of Congregation Rein Ahuvin, 1,819 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 1,682 Prospect Place. His age was 79. Previously he had been associated with the Adath Jeshurin, East Side communal congregational organization.

Properties purchased for investment along the West Side, from midtown to Inwood, were involved in a majority of the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday. Several large business parcels, as well as tenements, changed hands.

Henry Anderson Guiler of 3,750 Broadway, former assistant United States attorney and former special assistant to the Attorney General, died Monday night at the Harkness Pavilion, Presbyterian Hospital, after a short illness. He was 61 years old.

The Edvard Moritz Chamber Orchestra, which made its first appearance on the local scene last May, gave the first of a series of four programs at the Town Hall last night. Edvard Moritz, Swedishborn conductor and composer, who is responsible for the ensemble's name, is its founder and director.

The address of Chairman Douglas of the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday evening was a sincerely conciliatory speech, plainly intended to help create an era of better feeling between Government and business. Mr.

The marriage of Mrs. Gertrude Wright Johnstone of New York to Frank W. Taylor of St. Louis took place here yesterday afternoon at the Savoy-Plaza. The Rev. Emmet Fox performed the ceremony in the presence of relatives and a few close friends.

11th St, 626 E, 25x94.9; Nordank Realty Corp to Louis Kraman, 172 E 4th St; pr mtg, $7,250; install, 6 %; $3,000. 10th Ave, 773, 25.5x60; 773 Tenth Ave Realty Corp to Barnett Kessler, 128 Central Park S; pr mtg, $7,000; demand, 6%; $3,500.

He is a ragged wind who walks The dusty road when Summer ends. He lets a richer harvest lie. And like a lonely peddler bends Beneath his burden. He must go Bearing before the year grows older The secret and amazing weight Of ghostly things upon his shoulder:

The Indiana Supreme Court granted a temporary writ of prohibition today barring recounts sought in seven counties by Raymond E. Willis, Republican candidate for Senator, who was defeated in the Nov. 8 election by the Democratic incumbent, Frederick Van Nuys.

Encouraged by a cordially approving letter from President Roosevelt and the personal participation of Mrs. Roosevelt, the first Southern Conference for Human Welfare, which opened here yesterday, continued today a determined attack on the difficulties and misfortunes which recently have led to the designation of this region as the nation's No. 1 problem.

Poland's and Lithuania's close political and economic cooperation will stave off threatened German expansion in the eastern Baltic region, Warsaw political circles asserted in explaining the press nonaggression pact signed last night.
The Kansas City Southern Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to acquire stock control of the Louisiana Arkansas Railway.
The building at 301 East Fifty-. third Street, containing twenty-five apartments, is now fully rented, according to William A. White Sons, agents.

Chiefly because of the shorter show period and the publication by morning newspapers of only one Sunday section as against two last year, new passenger car linage in New York and Brooklyn newspapers during the auto show period, Nov. 9 to 18, dropped about 31 per cent under last year's figures, according to Media Records.

The Princeton Club annual invitation squash tennis tournament became an all-New York Athletic Club affair last night when Harry F. Wolf and Joseph J. Lordi became the finalists as a result of triumphs over Frank Iannicelli and Frank A. Sieverman 3d, respectively.

Speaking in the Kroll Opera House before 2,000 National Socialist "propagandists" of the Berlin district in the first of 1,500 demonstrations scheduled to explain to the German people the reason for the drastic measures against Jews, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, tonight reiterated the Government's contention that what Germany does with her Jews is wholly Germany's business.
Sixty New Jersey State troopers think they may be "sergeants" in the Swedish Navy, but they are not sure.

The Finnish Fascist party known as the Patriotic National Movement was dissolved by the Minister of the Interior today. The party had continued the anti-democratic activities of the previously dissolved, notorious Lapua Movement.

Moral rearmament, "something far more than inhibitions, prohibitions and laws," has become the world's vital need, Herbert Hoover declared tonight in an address at the annual dinner of the York Bible Class. Yet this need could be met, he said, by nations whose leaders "stand solid."

The Boston Bruins found two holes in the New York Rangers' streamlined hockey attack tonight and stopped the winning streak of the hitherto allconquering Blue Shirts at four straight before a thrilled crowd of 12,000 at the Boston Garden.

Clarenton Kelley, secretary to a vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York, which he had served for thirty-three years, died of a heart attack last night in his home here after returning from work. His age was 55.

Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson brought today to an abrupt conclusion hearings on the long receiverships of Chicago's surface and elevated transit systems. He will write his decision on the case by the middle of December, he told the attorneys.

The German Government issued today a statement on the final German-Czechoslovak border, which is represented as an 'ethnographic adjustment on the lines of Oct. 5, permitting the inclusion of fellow-German communities left outside of that line." Contradicting foreign assertions, the statement insists as many .Czechs are returned to Czechoslovakia as are newly included in Germany by the border adjustment.

Joseph Buffington, retired judge of the Third Circuit Court in Philadelphia, whom Presiding Judge J. Warren Davis recently summoned back to the bench to hear an appeal from an injunction ordering Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City not to curtail civil liberties, had "completely disqualified himself" by publicly discussing the case outside the court room, Morris Ernst, counsel for the C. I. 0. and American Civil Liberties Union, which jointly obtained the injunction, said yesterday.

Paulding Ave (15-4128), n e cor of Morris Park Ave, 100xlO0; Max Nisnewitz to William P. Thomas, trustee, 2,721 Arlington Ave; installments, 4 percent; $45,500. 187th St, 764 E (11-3114); B F E Realty Corp to Yonkers General Hospital; extends mtg to Sept. 1, 1948, at 3 to 4 per cent; $14,800.

Turpentine firm 22c: sales, 94 barrels receipts. 675 barrels; shipments, 25 barrels; stock, 52,187 barrels. Rosin, steady; no sales. Receipts, 2,709; shipments, 127; stock. 301,557. Quote: B, D, $4.05; E, $4.25; F, $4.80; G, H. I, K, M. $4.85; N, $5.50; WG, $6; WW and X, $6.65.
Major Gen. Hugh H. McLean, Lieutenant Governor of New Brunswick from 1928 to 1935, died here late today. He was 84 years old.
The department of stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday receipt from the White Sewing Machine Corporation of a plan to, reduce capital from $5,750,000 to $2,380,000.
Miss Mary E. Dudley of this city has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Virginia Franklin Dudley, to Henry Clyde Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis O. Johnson of Niagara Falls, N. Y.

Johanna Hofmann, the German hairdresser on trial with Erich Glaser and Otto Herman Voss for espionage, testified through an interpreter in Federal Court a week ago because she knew no English but yesterday when she was recalled as a witness before Judge John C. Knox she answered questions in English and even took issue with her grand jury interpreter on the finer nuances of translation.

Eleven young adventurers today shaped a course for Tahiti in the cumbersome little brigantine Florence C. Robinson. Oldest of the ship's company is 30-year-old Lawrence O'Toole, Boston and New York artist, and the youngest, their skipper, Captain Sterling Hayden, who has jut turned 22.

The tentative Chilean delegation to the Pan-American Conference, opening in Lima, Peru, Dec. 9, is reported to have agreed to support President Roosevelt's proposal for joint defense of the Americas against aggressors.

The six-story apartment house at 1 Leighton Avenue, corner of Valentine Avenue, in Yonkers, has been purchased by David S. Meister. The house, on a plot 125 by 100 feet, accommodates thirty-six families and is reported to have an annual rent roll of about $27,000.

A jewelry fashion show, valued at $1,000,000, was paraded through the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel at luncheon yesterday In a demonstration of the theory that gowns should be designed as a background for precious gems.

A second accounting suit against Sussman Estates, Inc., which managed Trinity Church properties for four and a half years, was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court, in addition to the action brought by the rector, church wardens and vestrymen of Trinity Church for an accounting of $7,000,000 allegedly collected in gross revenues by the real estate firm in the management of sixteen lower Manhattan properties.

As France prepared yesterday to receive British Prime Minister Chamberlain and Foreign Secretary Halifax today, she welcomed a statement by Chancellor Hitler envisaging good-neighbor relations between France and Germany. Paris believed Mr.

A fashion show of original designs for cruise and Southern resort wear was held yesterday afternoon at Milgrim's. 6 West Fiftyseventh Street. A collection of seventy-five costumes was modeled before a large audience.

Miss Cora Stanton Jahncke, daughter of Commodore and Mrs. Ernest Lee Jahncke, was married to William Henry Seemann Jr. today at the home of her parents here. Owing to the sudden death of the bridegroom's father last Saturday, invitations to the ceremony, which was to have taken place in Christ Church Cathedral, were recalled.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the recommendation of the committee on stock list that application be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to remove from listing and registration the preferred and common shares and 4 per cent leasedline stock certificates . of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Saulte Ste. Marie Railway Company.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway's directors, after reading the report for October, which showed an increase over September, voted today a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a common share payable on Jan. 1 to stock of record of Dec. 6. The regular quarterly dividend of $1 a share was voted on Series A stock.

The three hours of George Bernard Shaw's "Geneva," which had its London debut at the Saville Theatre tonight, are held to be worth while only for the last act, which has been rewritten since its Malvern premiere last Summer.

Offering will be made today by prospectus only, and subject to prior sale through the exercise of subscription warrants issued to stockholders, of $24,500,000 of Commonwealth Edison Company convertible debentures, 31/2 per cent series, dated July 1, 1938, and due on July 1, 1958.

Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Muir will give a tea dance on Dec. 30 at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Eleanor Warfield Muir. Mr. and Mrs. George W. van Siclen and Miss Elise van Siclen are at the Blackstone.
The Brooklyn College basketball team will engage sixteen opponents in its 1938-39 season, according to the schedule, released by Lou Oshins, director of athletics, yesterday.
The University, Harvard and Yale Clubs each scored its second victory in two starts last night to remain in a first-place tie in Group I, Class B squash racquets of the Metropolitan League.

Manhattan's football team, enjoying the confidence that comes from a three-game winning streak, devoted most of yesterday afternoon's two-hour dummy scrimmage to a study of Villanova's unorthodox and intricate formations as illustrated by the first freshman eleven.

President Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia joined yesterday in backing the annual Christmas seal drive of the Tuberculosis and Health Association after the Mayor had formally opened the drive at a City Hall ceremony.

An initial three-year housing and recreation program under the new housing amendment to the State Constitution, involving an outlay of $245,000,000, was submitted by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to representatives of interested business and civic groups at a meeting last night in the Roosevelt Wing of the American Museum of Natural History.

An agreement has been signed between Hearn's Newark store and Department Store Local Union 1,115-A, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, to run for two years, it was announced yesterday. Increases in wages obtained by the employes will amount to S100.000 for the period.
Four horses bobbed their heads in almost perfect unison in a thrilling photo finish in the Nanticoke Class C Handicap, six-furlong feature for 3-year-olds today.

The first major undertaking of its kind became successful yesterday when the Lehigh Valley Railroad announced that holders of more than 80 per cent of the bonds affected by a readjustment plan announced on Aug. 25 had assented to it. Under the terms of the plan, the deposits received are sufficient to make it effective.

Charles A. Mulligan Jr., who in his ten years as a practicing attorney. on Staten Island -has won. the reputation of being one of Richmond's leading lawyers, was indicted yesterday for practicing law without having been admitted to the bar and for perjury.

BAKRER-Elwood Thomas, peacefully, on Nov. 21, 1938, beloved father of Elwood W., Charles Graham, Tacey Hackstaff, Donald M. and Leslle S. Baker. Funeral services at Dupont Funeral Home, 82-29 Lefferts Boulevard, Kew Gardens, 10:30 A. M., Wednesday, Nov. 23.

Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. T. Smith have a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. T. Suffern Tailer, Mr. and Mrs Winston Guest, Mr. and Mrs. Barclay K., Douglas, Mr. and Mrs. Ford Johnson, Mr. and Mrs. William Fiske and--Mrs. Howard F. Whitney Jr.
King Carol of Rumania arrived at Freiburg-imBreisgau this morning from Paris to hunt as a guest of Prince Friedrich von Hohenzollern.

John D. Rockefeller Sr., who at the height of his career was known as America's first "billionaire," left a net estate of $26,410,837, two-thirds of which was in United States Treasury notes maturing from 1938 to 1941.
Vice President Garner, 70 years old today, wants a deer for a birthday present, and he is not asking it as a gift. He took his gun and left for the brakes and upland to bag it himself.

The State Tax Commission reserved decision today after hearing the plea of the Tax Commission of the City of New York for an increase in the equalization rate of assessments in the city's five boroughs.

Gifts amounting to $320,011 in cash and securities were received by Princeton University from May 1 to Aug. 31 of this year, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university. During the same period the president's $7,750,000 drive reached $2,124,454.

Miss Edith Elsie Rau, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. C. Fred Rau, was married this evening to Robert Farnham Jr., son of Robert Farnham of Mount Airy. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles A. Eder in Grace Episcopal Church, Germantown.

Pennsylvania's eleven, in its last home practice, today went through the entire repertoire of plays to be used against Cornell and then left for the Seaview Country Club, where the squad will remain until Thursday morning.

With all signs pointing to a heavier volume of construction work for 1938 as compared with the total for 1937, prognosticators already are sounding out the prospects in this field for the coming year.

Philip Plant said today that he would marry Miss Marjorie King, former New York show girl, on Dec. 15. They will go to Africa, where he will collect rare species of birds and game, on their wedding trip.
President Ignaz Moscicki today appointed thirty-two Senators to complete the newly elected Upper House. His appointees include five Cabinet members, two Ukrainians, two Jews and two Germans.

Suggesting that the Anti-Chain Bill, which Representative Patman plans to introduce at the opening of Congress, may not be pushed very far, but might prove merely a preparatory step for other measures, Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price variety Stores Association, warned yesterday that many others besides the chains may be affected by the Patman "philosophy" of prevention of "multiple ownership of any kind."

London Boston Securities, Ltd., a new investment trust affiliated cares with one in England, announced yesterday the signing of an agreement with Massachusetts Distributors, Inc., whereby the former will undertake the sole distribution in excee Great Britain of shares of Supervised Shares, Inc. Other agreements provide for similar disribution in the future of other Bostontype funds Sponsored by Massachusetts Distributors.

Leroy Fry, flying halfback of the Texas College of Arts and Industries, recaptured the national collegiate football scoring leadership tonight by ringing up forty points as his team smashed Mexico City, 53 to 7.

Additional employment of 248,000 nonagricultural workers in October was reported today by Secretary Perkins, who said 900,000 workers in this category had returned to work in the last four months. These figures exclude workers on WPA projects and employes of other Federal emergency agencies.
Pensioned On his own application-To take effect 12 midnight, Nov. 22: PATROLMAN-John J. McLaughlin, 28th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 11, 1912.
A slender blonde today convinced Joseph E. Daily, Circuit Court judge, that she was Miss Jessie Barker and was awarded a $1,500,000 fortune.

Republican successes in the recent election have brought about a striking increase in the number of voters who think the party will win the Presidency in 1940, according to the results of a survey made public yesterday by Dr. George Gallup's American Institute of Public Opinion.

Heavy buying was reported yesterday at the liquidation sale conducted by Charles Co., 48 East Forty-third Street, which is winding up its affairs after ninety years of service as one of the largest retailers of fancy groceries in the city.
Columbia's football squad heads for Providence this morning and Coach Lou Little hopes that the Lions will enjoy their Thanksgiving dinner.
The Railway Express Agency, Inc., filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission its brief in behalf of the revised express rate structure for which it recently petitioned the commission.

Mrs. T. L. Nightingale, 60-yearold housewife, of 2,420 F Street, Sacramento, Calif., was named- national crochet champion yesterday in the judging of 1800 entries from all States in a national contest at the Crochet Bureau, 522 Fifth Avenue.

The police undertook an unannounced census of Jewish business in Buenos Aires today in an effort to learn the origin of a movement yesterday that resulted in the closing of shops as a protest against the Nazi treatment of Jews in Germany.

Phillip J. Dwight is with Evans, Stillman Co. Carl M. Trotte will manage the new trading department of the William J. Stelmack Corporation. John G. Kaiser, H. E. Opshal and Arthur Wieners are in the sales department of Amott, Baker Co., Inc.

Huxley Ave (13-3423m). n w cor of 260th St, 75x100: also Huxley Ave, w s. 100 It n of 260th St, 25x105; George W. Simmons to Wilbur Derrick, 256 Fieldston Terrace. Gildersleeve Ave, 1.961 (14-3458); Railroad Federal Savings Loan Assn to Joshua Scaglia, 601 Beach Ave.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the East Tennessee Light and Power Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Power and Light Company, had filed a plan of reorganization under the Holding Company Act to simplify its system through the elimination of its subsidiaries, the Tennessee Eastern Electric Com-. pany and the Tennessee Realty Company.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In view of the importance of the pending controversy between Japan and the United States concerning the "Open Door" in China, I wish to mention the real' origin, meaning, legal status and possible outcome of it.

Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. in Long Island City, Queens, directed yesterday a jury to return a verdict of $22,273 in favor of William F. Heller of 85-31 124th Street, Richmond Hill, against the Pepsi-Cola Company of Long Island City.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh was seen today walking in Paris wearing horn-rimmed spectacles. That they were not colored led to the belief that he wore them not to elude reporters but because of impaired sight.

In a game which went into two overtime periods, the La Salle Academy basketball team defeated Loughlin, 24 to 22, yesterday on the Loughlin court in Brooklyn. The score was 22-22 at the end of the regulation time,

While intensive work went on today in the British Home Office and the headquarters of refugee organizations in London, the British Government watched carefully to see whether its proposals for admitting refugees would find a practical response in other 'countries.
