Secretary of State Cordell Hull has begun informal, preliminary discussions with Peru and Argentina looking to the possibility of the negotiation of reciprocal trade agreements.

Three armed men, running quietly and quickly through a hold-up as though it had been rehearsed, escaped yesterday afternoon with a $1,102 Thanksgiving week payroll intended for the employes of Gunther Sharpman, Inc., underwear manufacturers of 588 Broadway.
Jonathan Bartley, a leader in the crucible and graphite industry until his retirement ten years ago, died yesterday in his home here after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

An invader from, the Middle West who had competed only once before in the East.today captured the Open All-Age Stake for English springer spaniels as the Valley Forge Field Trial Association meeting closed. on Pheasant Run Farm.

A meeting of the Republican State Executive Committee has been called by State Chairman William S. Murray for Monday at the Hotel Ten Eyck in Albany. It will be the committee's first session since the State Republican Convention and one of the principal items on the agenda will be its reorganization.

" The Boys From Syracuse" will arrive tonight at the Alvin Theatre to the tune of a $6.60 top for the premiere. This, of course, is the George Abbott-Richard RodgersLorenz Hart musical, which was put together with a "slight bow" to Shakespeare's "The Comedy of Errors."
Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Atkinson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Clare Atkinson, to Russell Haynes Broadhead of Larchmont, N. Y.

W. Paxton Little, one of the pioneers in New York State electric power service, was the guest of honor at a dinner last night given by a group of his associates of the Niagara Hudson Power system at the Union Club.
Miss Elisabeth Cobb of Santa Monica, Calif., daughter of Irvin S. Cobb, and Robert Cameron Rogers of Santa Barbara, Calif., were married here last night bya municipal judge.

With 185 head catalogued to go under the hammer, the forty-fourth annual Old Glory auction sale of light harness horses will get under way at 11 o'clock this morning in the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue at Ninety-fourth Street, to continue through tomorrow afternoon.
Lack of trading interest rather than any broad selling movement resulted yesterday in a drift of bonds to moderately lower levels on the New York Stock Exchange.

New York's Public Service Commission moved today to learn why Harry Reed, president of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, gets the $57,400 salary that it alleges he collects from the Utility Management Corporation.

Term deliveries on the New York Stock- Exchange will be abandoned on Dec. 1 after a three-month trial. Tabulated returns to a questionnaire yesterday convinced the board of governors of the institution that the change made on Sept. 1 had been unpopular. Accordingly, they voted to return to the old 'skip-a-day" method of settlements.

The government crisis expected since four Ministers were dropped from the Cabinet a fortnight ago broke tonight when sixty-eight members of the Party of National Unity announced that they would no longer support Premier Bela Imredy.

Term deliveries on the New York Stock- Exchange will be abandoned on Dec. 1 after a three-month trial. Tabulated returns to a questionnaire yesterday convinced the board of governors of the institution that the change made on Sept. 1 had been unpopular. Accordingly, they voted to return to the old 'skip-a-day" method of settlements.

The government crisis expected since four Ministers were dropped from the Cabinet a fortnight ago broke tonight when sixty-eight members of the Party of National Unity announced that they would no longer support Premier Bela Imredy.

James P. Selvage, director of public relations for the National Association of Manufacturers, has resigned effective Jan. 1, to open his own public relations organization, Walter B. Weisenburger, executive vice president of the association announced yesterday. No announcement was made as to a successor for Mr. Selvage.
Albert Whitman of Chicago has contracted to publish "Reptiles and Amphibians," third in the natural history series produced by the Federal Writers Project.
The Red Star liner Westernland arrived yesterday in Hoboken with eighty-eight passengers, including seventy-three Jewish refugees from Vienna, Berlin and Hamburg who had boarded the ship at Antwerp.
Cecil Isbell, Green Bay Packer halfback, has gained the top position among the ground-gainers in the National Football League, according to statistics released yesterday.

Should Fordham University's football team be invited to play in the Sugar Bowl on New Year's Day, it will accept, Graduate Manager Jack Coffey announced yesterday in reply to a question put by Herb Benson, chairman of the Sugar Bowl committee.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull made clear at his press conference today that Japan's reply last Friday to his note of Oct. 6 protesting various phases of Japan's activities in China was highly unsatisfactory.

The Italian Government today ordered the expulsion of Frank Smothers, who has been Rome correspondent of The Chicago Daily News for fourteen months. He was requested to leave the country by the end of the month.
Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Law said today that employers who reduced wages to the 25-cent hourly minimum as a result of the act were acting in a "most illegal manner."
Undefeated and untied for the first time in sixty-four years of football, Georgetown University celebrated by electing not one captain, but nine, today.

The National Broadcasting Company has an exclusive arrangement with the German Government whereby it has "first refusal" on all programs originating in Germany or in Austria, according to testimony given today before the Federal Communications Commission by John F. Royal, vice president of NBC in charge of production.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,255,800 barrels, compared with 3,243,250 in the previous week, an increase of 12,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Representative James M. Mead, Senatorelect from New York, stated today that he favored a permanent publicworks agency to provide employment for the jobless.
A technical history of radio development since 1920, the "Year One," when Station KDKA began regular broadcasting, went into the record of the Federal Communications Commission today.

The usual year-end caution of steel buyers seemingly is beginning to manifest itself, according to Iron Age. The publication says new orders are holding up fairly well but that November "will not show imnortant mains" over October.

A banking group neaded by Lehman Brothers and including Phelps, Fenn Co., F. S. Moseley Co., Eastman, Dillon Co., Kean, Taylor Co., Prescott, Wright, Snider Co., Stern Brothers Co. and Wheelock Cummins, Inc., received yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,200,000 of Kansas City, Mo., water refunding bonds.

The Rome-Berlin axis, which has recently repeatedly shown political efficiency, today invaded the spiritual field when Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, and Hans-Georg Viktor von Mackensen, the German Ambassador, signed an agreement regulating scientific, cultural and artistic relations between Italy and Germany.
Mrs. Marie Burckhalter, Hastings-on-Hudson matron, was questioned further here today by Elbert T. Gallagher, chief assistant district attorney, and then was returned to the county jail.

The Rev. Francis P. Nolan, pastor of St. Justin's Church in this city and a leader in Hartford civic activities, especially work in connection with public parks, died last night at the age of 59, shortly before the death was announced of the Rev. John J. Downey of St. Peter's.

The prosecution introduced three New York City policemen today in its effort to prove that George W. Rogers sent a home-made bomb to Lieutenant Vincent J. Doyle of the Bayonne Police Department with the intention of maiming or killing his former superior officer so that he could get his job.
Miss Fernanda Wanamaker Munn was introduced to society here last night at a supper dance given by her mother, Mrs. Wanamaker Munn, in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. It was the largest

High up in the skyscraper at 2 Park Avenue thousands of miles removed from the scene in his thoughts, a genial, silver-haired man who is the chief executive for more than 1,000,000 American boys and men engaged in scouting spoke a few quiet words yesterday that will mean salvation for a number of refugee Boy Scouts from across the sea.

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, urged the Congressional committee investigating the TVA today to call on the Securities and Exchange Commission to fix a fair price for the sale of the Tennessee Electric Power Company, one of the four C. and S. operating companies in the Tennessee Valley, to the TVA.
Refusing to play minor league hockey, Normie Smith, goalie of the Detroit Red Wings when they won two Stanley Cups, announced his retirement today.

John A. MacDonald, former State Highway Commissioner, testified in Superior Court today that G. Leroy Kemp of Mount Vernon, former State land agent for the Merritt Parkway, hid from him the alleged splitting of fees with Thomas N. Cooke, Greenwich real estate

Lamb carcasses were in demand and salemen advanced prices sharply. Fresh pork cuts were active and well cleaned up. Demand for other classes was slow. Steer hinds and ribs were stronger; pork loins were sharply higher; other classes and cuts steady.

Dr. Carl Fromm of this city, who as a pilot in the German Army during the World War bombed Paris and London from a Super-Gotha plane, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Orange, which he entered two weeks ago for an abdominal operation. He was 45 years old.

A revival campaign, intended "to give a hearing to Americanism," began tonight under the auspices of the United States Flag Association, being opened by Colonel James A. Moss, president general of the organization, in a nation-wide broadcast over NBC.

The dumping of ashes and rubbish on Rikers Island is proving detrimental to the best use of the city's new penitentiary on the island as a means to rehabilitate prisoners, the executive committee of the Prison Association of New York, 135 East Fifteenth Street declared in a protest made public yesterday.

After being trained under the theory that musi chas the power to bring contentment and at least mental release to men languishing in jail, fourteen soldier prisoners on Governors Island made their debut as an orchestra last night in a room of Castle William, the army prison almost directly across the harbor channel from the Statue of Liberty.

Alabama's Crimson Tide faces Vanderbilt in an annual Thanksgiving Day football game tomorrow. Coach Frank Thomas of Alabama said today that Carey Cox, regular center, and Charley Holm, mainstay at fullback, would watch the game in civilian clothes because of injuries.

The November grand jury returned bills of indictment today against M. L. Annenberg, publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirere; E. Z. Dimitman, city editor, and Daniel J. Murphy, an attorney, charging libel. Mr.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday that it expected more than 30.000 young men to take the new test for patrolman, which will offer greater advantages to offset the stiff physical and mental requirements it will impose.
Final liquidation of December obligations prior to notices tomorrow created more pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended with losses of 5 to 7 points.

Mayor La Guardia expressed his disagreement yesterday with the proposals for providing new housing put forward Tuesday evening by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who urged a three-year program involving a $245,000,000 outlay.
Thanksgiving will probably bring to the metropolitan area its first taste of Winter weather. The weather forecast was for cold and probably light snow.- Snow fell yesterday in many up-State cities.

Alfred M. Landon, 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, yesterday pictured Governor Lehman as the "outstanding candidate for the Democratic nomination for President in 1940." He also said that the recent election "took the Republican party out of the dog-house."
Forty-six of 78 defendants charged with WPA fraud and conspiracy today were ordered to trial in Albuquerque Jan. 23 by Federal Judge Colin Neblett.

France and Germany agreed on a nonaggression pact today as Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain and Viscount Halifax, his Foreign Seeretary, arrived here, to the accompaniment of boos and cheers, for talks with Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet.

The Stork Club, at 3 East Fiftythird Street, one of the favorite rendezvous of so-called cafe society, must offer reinstatement to nine waiters and pay them about $20,000 in wages lost since their discharge, including the tips they would normally have received. Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel ruled yesterday.

Electric power production last week showed a larger increase than anticipated on the basis of normal trends, and the adjusted index rose to 98.0 from 96.6. The figure for the week ended Nov. 20, 1937, was 100.2.
Mrs. John W. Whiteley, whose husband died of a heart attack at the Dunwoodie Country Club Sunday afternoon, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning at 5:20 this morning.

Justice Hugo L. Black accepted tonight the Thomas Jefferson Medal of the Southern Conference for Human Welfare "as a symbol confided to me for the many Southerners who stand with Jefferson in the belief that good government must give first importance to promoting the welfare and happiness of all human beings by assuring equal justice to all and special consideration to none."
Paul Keres, 22-year-old chess expert from Parnu, Estonia, was still in the lead tonight after completion of eleven rounds of the A. V. R. 0. international chess masters tournament.
The 126th dinner of the Economic Club of New York will be held on Dec. 12 in the Hotel Astor instead of Dec. 14 as previously announced, Robert E. Ely, executive director, stated yesterday.

News reports from Chungking, the temporary capital, quote the Chinese military spokesman as saying that the Japanese plans for the occupation of the entire Canton-Hankow Railway and for control of the Siang River by the occupation of Siangyin had been frustrated by the Chinese counter-offensive north of Changsha in Hunan Province.

The Blackstone Valley Gas and Electric Company, a subsidiary of Eastern Utilities Associates, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $4,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent mortgage and collateral trust bonds, Series D, due on Dec. 1, 1968. It gave the names of underwriters and the amounts underwritten as follows:

Max D. Steuer, noted trial counsel, in a hearing before Surrogate James A. Foley on an application for a fee allowance of $50,000 for legal services rendered in the estate of the late Irving I. Bloomingdale, New York merchant, disclosed that' his net income from professional services during the last four years was better than $500,000 a year.

Anton Myslivec, 53-year-old ex-convict, of 202 West Seventy-eighth Street, New York, was arraigned here tonight before Justice of the Peace Harold Sorenson on a charge of first-degree murder in the fatal shooting Monday night of William Dobitz, 55, a builder, of Farmingville, near here.

The British Government acknowledged today for the first time that it had asked Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy to help in suppressing parts of a newsreel that had been critical of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy during the crisis in September.

After a three-day conference between heads of the aviation industry and officials of the War Department an agreement was reached today in which the aviation industry declared its willingness "to cooperate immediately in any government defense program."

Sister Superior Lina Brechlin, head of the deaconesses at the Norwegian Lutheran Deaconesses Home and Hospital in Brooklyn, which she had served for thirty-two years, died in the hospital yesterday morning.

The first day's sale of the collection of nineteenth-century American stamps formed by the late William H. Crocker of San Francisco realized a total of [Pound]4,215 today, the prices in many cases exceeding those prevailing in the United States.

A settlement has been reached out of court in the $1,000,000 damage suit of Joseph F. Shadgen of 35-45 Ninety-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, consulting engineer, against the World's Fair, and the pending trial will be marked off the Supreme Court calendar, it was disclosed last night.

Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes said today that it might be well to consider Alaska as a possible refuge for German Jews along the lines pursued by this country in its Matanuska Valley project to give homes to American families who had been unable to find adequate means of livelihood within the States.

Willis Maxwell Goodhue of the Hotel Imperial, writer for the stage and screen, died Tuesday in the City Hospital on Welfare Island of uremic poisoning after a week's illness. He was born in Akron, Ohio, sixty-five years ago.
The stock market made a better than average pre-holiday showing yesterday. Leading issues were up fractions to more than 1 point. The tone throughout was firm.

Edwin F. Jaeckle, Erie County Republican leader who fought against New York City control of his party for more than two years, will be a candidate for election as chairman of the new Republican State Executive Committle when it meets Monday in Albany, it was learned last night. Party leaders expect him to win without any opposition.

At least twelve persons were killed in the Winter's first gale, which at one time today reached a velocity of 108 miles an hour. It tore down the English Channel, tossing like a cork the sturdy ship that conveyed Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to France and held in Portsmouth Harbor the huge battleship Royal Oak, which was to have conveyed the body of Queen Maud to Norway.

The housing plan which Commissioner Moses has put forward must have seemed, to those who have long been laboring in this difficult field, a bolt from the blue. At one stroke, if Mr. Moses had his way, we should see our public housing policy drastically changed.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 21: COMMANDERS Blandy, W. H. P., Washington, D. C., in December, to command the Utah. Ryan, F. W., Med. Corps, Philadelphia, Pa., to Navy Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The program follows:

For the first time since the sixteenth century, the Pope will have a personal representative in Great Britain. Mgr. William Godfrey, at present rector of the Venerable English College in Rome, is to be the Apostolic Delegate.
At the November meeting of the Poetry Society of America the society's yearly award of $100 was presented to Helen Morrow of 11 West Eighty-first Street for her poem "Two Deers in a Glade."

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange took yesterday the first step toward adoption of a new constitution. They passed and sent to the membership both the constitution submitted last week and the interim amendment that will cover the period of transition.

Puerto Rico's Thanksgiving Day dinner will be largely boiled and more nearly home grown than at any other time since the combined prayer and feast day was instituted with the American regime forty years ago.

Special Notice Due to scaffolding being erected over roadway in front of the Firestone Building, facing Grand Central Parkway, in the Fair Grounds, which scaffolding permits of only 11 feet headroom, hook and ladder companies entering the Fair Grounds through Corona Avenue Gate, shall detour to the left before approaching the Firestone Building, and go around such building, using the Court of Ships. This condition will exist for a period of three or four weeks.
Dartmouth's football team, preparing for its intersectional game with Stanford here Saturday, scrimmaged briskly today with the results not exactly pleasing to Coach Earl Blaik.

The official German News Bureau today retracts as false on every point reports published in the German press Monday that the Czech shoe magnate Jan Bata had been arrested at Leitmeritz for endeavoring to smuggle [Pound]164,000 into Czechoslovakia. M.

Captain John L. Hoffman, superintendent of the Napanoch State Institution for Defective Male Delinquents, died in his home here last night. He was 59 years old. Captain Hoffman, who served as warden of Auburn prison for a short time in 1930, had been suffering from a heart ailment.

Twenty-five young women, debutantes of this season, received with members of the dance committee at the fifteenth annual Debutante Ball held last night at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the board of governors of the club. The event was founded
Sections of the Congress of Industrial Organizations are seeking to establish relations with Mexican workers in the United States and with affiliates of the Mexican Federation of Labor in Mexico.
A Cabinet member, a member of Congress and plenty of others participated today in the liveliest bout of namecalling that Washington has heard in months.

A vacant plot 72 by 117 feet on the southwest corner of Calamus and Lane Avenues, Winfield, Queens, has been sold by Mary Hala, who had held the property for twenty-six years, to the Trilon Building Corporation.
The Department of Commerce reported today a sharp increase in exports of petroleum and gasoline-attributable in part to world armament needs.

Miss Margaret Louise Terhune, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott Terhune of this community, was married this evening in the West Milford Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Lewis G. Leary, to Thomas Beach Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Miller, also of this place.

Most persons were probably surprised at the comparative moderateness of John D. Rockefeller's estate. The wealth of the "world's richest man" was estimated at one time between $1,000,000,000 and $2,500,000,000. The net value of his, estate at the time of his death is now officially appraised at just a little more than $26,000,000.

A statement outlining the plan of liquidation of the Pathe Film Corporation, addressed to holders of its preferred and common stocks and asking for their proxies, shows an operating loss of $71,319 for the company and subsidiaries for the first nine months of 1938,
Charles A. Brown, a Chicago patent attorney for half a century, died today atb the age of 80 at his home in Redlands, Calif.
Mrs. Julia Glus, 28 years old, an Austrian Catholic who came here from Salzburg eleven years ago, committed suicide yesterday by inhaling gas in her home at 27 Cedar Street Brooklyn.

Miss Rita Amanda Earl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Earl of this city, was married this afternoon to Carl Paul Vogt, son of Frederick A. Vogt of Ardmore. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Lutheran Church at Ardmore by the rector, the Rev. Albert C. Kansinger.

About 750 bankers are expected to attend the bankers forum dinner of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking next Thursday in the Hotel Astor. Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, will be the guest speaker of the evening.

An urgent plea to aid the children of Loyalist Spain, addressed to the women of America by forty-seven Spanish women, including Senora Dona Azana, the wife of the President of the Spanish Republic, was received yesterday by the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, 381 Fourth Avenue.
Joseph E. Brill of New York has been put in charge of a new wages and hours unit in the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Barker gave a small dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for their debutante daughter, Miss Elizabeth Barker. Mr. and Mrs. W. Hamilton Busk have come from Purchase, N. Y., to the Ambassador.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 2d Lt. Daniel Loewenthal, Inf.-Res., 636 S. 10th St., Newark, N. J., 1st Div., is ordered to active duty Nov. 20 at Fort Jay, N. Y., for training with the 16th Infantry. Date of rank: Nov. 20, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status Dec. 3.
Robert Grant 3d, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, has been admitted to general partnership in G. M.-P. Murphy Co.

Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General here, presided yesterday at the 1937-38 distribution of academic prizes at the Lycee Francais, 3 East Ninety-fifth Street, the only French high school in New York, at which Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College and Professor Albert Feullerat of Yale University spoke.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Nov. 22: BRIGADIER GENERALS Richardson, R. C. Jr., Ft. Bliss, Texas, to command the Cavalry School, Ft. Riley, Kan., Feb. 1.

John Nance Garner born. We slipped up on the date under the impression that he was born, as he should have been, on a Thanksgiving Thursday, seventy Years ago. He celebrated the anniversary Tuesday byplunging into the canebrake after deer.
The Brooklyn Dodgers of the National League and George Jacobs, manager of the Easton club, were barred today from operating a baseball club in the Eastern Shore League for three years.

Charles Co., the L-shaped fancygrocery store which fronts on both Vanderbilt Avenue and East Fortythird Street, was obliged to close its doors during store hours yesterday for the first time in the ninety years of its existence.
A strike of 350 employes of the United States Electric Manufacturing Company, maker of radios and electrical goods, forced the company to close its plant at 222 West Fourteenth Street yesterday.
Carnegie Tech and North Carolina State will square off in Riddick Stadium tomorrow in an intersectional football game. About 15,000 spectators are expected.

At the request of the receivers for the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line (Mokan) Company, the directors of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company have amended their resolution fixing the notice date with respect to the exercise of Mokan's warrant for 80,000 shares of Panhandle common stock. The new notice date is Dec. 30, instead of Nov. 30.

Mrs. Beatrice Josephi Sulzberger, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel A. Josephi and widow of Leo Sulzberger, was married yesterday afternoon at her home, 1,045 Park Avenue, to Ely Jacques Kahn, noted architect, who is the son of Mrs. Jacques Kahn of this city and the late Mr. Kahn. The Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise performed the ceremony.

Gerald Connell, 22, whose powerful physique had won him renown in Canadian hockey circles, died here today on the threshold of a promising career. Apparently fit after playing with the Syracuse Stars last evening, he was found unconscious in his bed in a downtown hotel just before noon. He died an hour later.

Three Kings with other royalty attended funeral rites for the English-born Queen Maud of Norway today before the body was placed aboard a purple and black draped train to begin the journey to Oslo, Norway.

Directors of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation deferred action yesterday on the quarterly dividends due at this time on the company's 4 1/2 per cent cumulative prior preferred and 4 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible prior preferred stocks.

Five devastating bombings of Barcelona and a continuing Insurgent push on the front west of that city gave evidence tonight of a mounting campaign against Catalonia. Some government advices said the first two raids, by eight Insurgent planes, killed at least fifty and wounded 120 persons.

BROWN vs. Columbia--The wild turkey is not only a truly North American bird but was signally honored by John James Audubon. The picture of the wild turkey is Plate 1 of the famous Audubon portrait gallery of North American birds. To be really tasty at the table, of course, a turkey should be done brown, which may be a hint about this football game. But Lou Little said: "Be very careful in your choice

The Federal Power Commission has presented to William V. King, its chief accountant from 1920 until his voluntary retirement on Aug. 16, an illuminated copy of a resolution setting forth the commission's appreciation of his long public service. Claude L. Draper, acting chairman, and Commissioner John W. Scott made the presentation at a gathering attended by many of Mr. King's former associates.
Mayor La Guardia explained yesterday that a misunderstanding was responsible for the cancellation of the broadcast by WNYC of Park Commissioner Robert Moses's housing conference Tuesday evening.

Federal conciliators, who began efforts today to end the strike that has tied up the Chicago stockyards three days, announced tonight that leaders of the striking members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Union Stockyard and Transit Company had agreed to a conference to be held on Saturday morning.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, proposed today that collective bargaining be extended as rapidly as possible into the field of giving labor a share in the profits of business over and above its regular wages.

Angered by the Boston City Censor's deletion of "three trivial" blasphemies from the script of his new play, Elmer Rice, Pulitzer prize winner in 1928, said tonight he felt disposed never to bring another play to this city.

An appeal for support of the thirty-second annual Christmas seal sale, which begins today throughout the nation, was made yesterday by Dr. I. Ogden Woodruff, president of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.
A dinner dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Christmas Gignoux of Great Neck, L. I., last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to present to society their daughter, Miss Annette Gignoux.

A suggestion that Governor-elect Arthur H. James of Pennsylvania might some day be President of the United States was made last night by Carl Estes of Longview, publisher and friend of Mr. James, as he introduced him at a dinner given in his honor in Nuevo Laredo by officials and business men of the two Laredos.

The total of highway funds diverted by all States declined $9.000,000 in 1937, for the first time reversing a trend that had risen each year for a decade, it was reported yesterday by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York.

Army's soccer team defeated Navy today, 2 to 1, in the first game of an annual series. A hard downpour made the field a sea of mud and the going was hard for both teams. Army scored early in the first period when Farrell, right half, drove in a long shot from just outside the goal area. The remainder

Lieut. General Sir Basil Burnett-Hitchcock, who as director general of mobilization and recruiting was responsible for the demobilization of 5,000,000 men after the World War and subsequently the creation of a new peace-time army, died today at the age of 61.

For twelve years a victim of a speech impediment that seemed incurable, Joseph Havelka Jr., 32 years old, of Kenilworth, N. J., recovered his normal speech last Monday when he was struck by an automobile and hurled to the pavement on his head, it was learned today.

Cadet James T. L. Schwenk, who will be identified as No. 75 by most of the 102,000 spectators who will attend Army and Navy's thirtyninth game in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium Saturday, today arose from his downy cot at reveille which, to all you civilians, is 6 A. M.

The directors of the Pittsburgh Steel Company have decided to change the fiscal year of the company from the period ending on June 30 to coincide with the calendar year, subject to the approval of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

Leo F. Tierney, Special Assistant Attorney General in charge of the milk monopoly prosecutions, said today that the forty-three individuals and fourteen corporations charged with conspiracy in the Chicago milk industry would be arraigned on Dec. 8 before District Judge Charles E. Woodward. Twenty individuals and

Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for her daughter, Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems, whose marriage to James Abercrombie de Peyster, son of the Countess Bohdan de Castellane of New York and Menton, France, and of Frederic Ashton de Peyster of this city, will take place Dec. 2.

In the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis last night Mr. and Mrs. Robert Crockett Rand of 125 East Sixtyfirst Street gave a dinner dance to introduce Mrs. Rand's daughter, Miss Jeanne Elizabeth Monroe, whose father was the late Colonel Robert Grier Monroe.

To hasten the financial and economic recovery of France and to avert a threatened economic crisis, the Daladier government issued last week fifty-eight decrees, contemplating a three-year recovery plan. Among the laws, which partly
That is not a turkey upon which our readers will be bending their fond gaze within the next few hours.
Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean's Thanksgiving breakfast-traditional in the capital for forty years-will be missing from the holiday calendar tomorrow.
David'H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the- United Hospital Fund, has been elected chairman of the Hospital Council of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday.

Lord Nuffield, millionaire automobile manufacturer and a special benefactor of hospitals, is turning over part of his huge factory at Cowley to build iron lungs free for every hospital and institution in the British Empire.
The executive offices of the Twenty-third Street Association, Inc., have been moved to the Flatiron Building, Twenty-third Street and Fifth Avenue.

ADLER-Johanna. beloved wife of Louis, dear mother of Arthur, Sidney, Howard, Molly Metzger, Sadie Meyer and Alma London. Funeral services Friday at 2 P. M. at Riverside Chapel, 78th St. and Amsterdam Ave. ALLEN-Edward. Services at Walter B. Cooke, Inc., Funeral Home, 117 West 72d St., Saturday, 12 noon. Auspices the Actors Fund.
A late rally under the leadership of gilt-edge stocks slightly relieved the dullness of the stock markets today. The dullness, however, was due more to slackness of trading than to selling pressure.
The movement started only a' week ago by Palestine Jewry to adopt children from- Germany is spreading with amazing rapidity.

After being defeated, 115 to 94, in the lower House of Parliament, Premier Bela Imredy and his Cabinet resigned this afternoon. Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent, refused at first to accept the resignation, but when the Premier had a second audience at 10 o'clock tonight, the Regent deferred his decision until tomorrow morning. It was learned late tonight that

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Everett Grant of 994 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Bernardsville, N. J., gave the first in a series of three dinners last night at their home here for their debutante daughter, Miss Nancibelle Grant, and for Miss Ruth E. Robinson, debutante daughter of Sanford Robinson.

Plans for altering a dwelling on the East Side for business occupancy were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the four-story brownstone house at 141 Lexington Avenue, near Twentyninth Street.

Miss Dorothy Aylesworth of 812 Park Avenue and David G. Knott of 43 Fifth Avenue, whose marriage will take place on Jan. 4 in St. Bartholomew's Church, obtained a license yesterday at the Municipal Building.

MANHATTAN KING, FANNIE (June 1, 1938). Gross assets, $89,934; net. $84,254. To David Francis King, brother, $500; Donald W. Smith, nephew, Edna N. Smith, grandniece, one-half residue each; Junietta Jones, $1,000; two contingent bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $87,657.

The newspaper Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung applied the phrase, "a traitor to German-Americandom," today to Victor F. Ridder in connection with an account of an address in New York Monday in which the New York publisher appealed for racial tolerance.

The University of Pittsburgh's faculty committee on athletics stepped into the "tempest over tuition" today by offering to cancel tuition fees charged to freshman football players for 1937-38 if they entered school under a "misunderstanding."

With an advance sale which had surpassed the $12,000 mark early yesterday, today's Turkey Day gridiron struggle between the Giants and Dodgers at Ebbets Field is likely to attract a near-capacity crowd. If favored with good weather conditions a turnout of 30,000 is anticipated to view the proceedings between the interborough rivals.
Thirty thousand grocery, drug and other neighborhood retail stores throughout the city closed for one to three hours yesterday in protest against racial and religious persecution in Germany.

The British and American Labor parties are "anti-democratic" because they are based on class distinctions, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, charged yesterday in discussing politics in his weekly article for The Columbia Daily Spectator, undergraduate newspaper.

Two of the youngest and most aggressive teams in the National Hockey League, representing clubs which have been keen rivals for years, clash tonight in Madison Square Garden when Lester Patrick's blue-shirted Rangers skate into battle against the Toronto Maple Leafs.

A majority of the heavily backed choices performed as if influenced by the drab weather today. Most of the races were decided through a drizzling rain and a fog hung over the track. A touch of Winter also was in the air.
An appeal for prompt completion of the $325,000 fund needed to carry on the yearly work of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, was made yesterday by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., rollcall chairman.
Alexander Archipenko, internationally known sculptor, disclosed today a plan to erect a statue of Moses to symbolize justice and wisdom for all the oppressed peoples of the world.
Reports that $500,000 was sent from Mexico to Chile for election purposes are generally regarded as at least somewhat exaggerated.
Secretary Perkins will soon call a conference of employers to discuss improvements in State legislation and a model State Wages and Hours Law.

James A. T. Gribbin, chief of the State Labor Department's Bureau of Statistics and Records, said in the 1938 revision of the "Industrial Directory of New Jersey," published today, that New Jersey leads all other "distinctively manufacturing States" in the proportionate increase of industrial activity.

The influence of modern communications on international relations in making isolation and self-sufficiency "illusions" was emphasized by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a radio address tonight. More than ever, he said, interdependence and cooperation among nations were fundamental.

Praise for Park Commissioner Robert Moses's suggested $245,000,000 housing project, because it ineludes plans for schools and playgrounds, was voiced yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.
Lieutenant E. W. H. Berwick, riding Eureka, gave the Canadian Army its only victory in the military jumping events as the week-long Royal Winter Fair Horse Show ended tonight.
A football rivalry, started more than forty years ago, will be continued this afternoon on the turf of the Polo Grounds, when undefeated Villanova tangles with a dangerous Manhattan eleven.
It was said at the Foreign Ministry today that nothing definite had been decided regarding President Roosevelt's plan for joint defense of the Americas.

The decline in the pound sterling slowed down a little yesterday and, although the currency lost further ground and more gold was taken in England for shipment here, the official control did not have to intervene as strongly as on recent days.

Philadelphia cricketers carried off most of the honors in the championship competition of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association for the season of 1938, the official figures for which have been compiled by F. Fitzmaurice Kelly, veteran secretary of the association.
After an ownership of two weeks the five-and-a-half-story walk-up apartment house at 1,350 Grand Concourse, northeast corner of Marcy Place, the Bronx, has been resold by Charles Walzer, operator.

Brown and Columbia, two teams that have had their full share of ups and downs this season, will meet tomorrow on Brown Field with the Bruins established as slight favorites. A crowd of 18,000 is expected, but a forecast of snow tonight may hold down the attendance. It is the closing game for both teams.
Two policemen died yesterday when their radio car crashed into a milk truck parked at the side of Farmers Boulevard near 114th Avenue, St. Albans, Queens.

" May the example of Pierre and Marie Curie show the way to true happiness and turn the people from disputes that lead to social disasters," exclaimed President Albert Lebrun of France in a speech at the Sorbonne tonight.

The Misses Helen Macdonald and Audrey Bibby were introduced to society yesterday at a tea dance in the Embassy suite of the Ambassador. The event was given by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Madison Macdonald of 2 East Eightysixth Street, this city and Old Lyme, Conn., and Mr. and Mrs.

The proposed revision of express rates, by virtually removing the differential between cost of shipping large and small packages, would throw 850 union workers in New York City on "the industrial scrap leap,"

Candy and jewelry, with increases of 17.2 and 14.2 per cent, respectively, led in the sales gains scored by departments of large stores in this district during October in comparison with the same month a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Dr. E. L. Hendricks, president emeritus of Central Missouri Teachers College and president of the National Association of Teachers Colleges in 1930, died last midnight. Dr. Eldo Lewis Hendricks was born in Rossville, Ind., on Oct. 2, 1866, the son of Samuel and Henrietta Stinehouse Hendricks.

Federal Judge Dickinson today approved the plan by which the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company would dispose of 123,000 acres of "barren and unprofitable coal lands in Schuylkill County." The company has said it would save $1,000,000 in taxes.

Charging that the Philadelphia Police Bureau was demoralized and incompetent, the special grand jury, which has been investigating vice and crime in this city, laid blame for the conditions directly upon Mayor Wilson.

After a courtship of 40 years, Joseph F. Hickey, 80-year-old Salem bachelor, and Miss Carrie B. Pyne, 72, of Beverly filed marriage intentions today. Asked why the marriage, the first for both. had been so long delayed,

The Group Theatre's eighth season begins tonight at the Belasco with "Rocket to the Moon," the sixth play (not all full-length) which Clifford Odets has written for the organization, his most recent being the Group's success of last season, "Golden Boy."

Trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today was somewhat larger than on recent days. Holders of December contracts were again persistent sellers, and the near-by month went to about 3 cents a bushel discount compared with the May, the widest difference so far.

William J. Carney, New Jersey regional director for the C. I. O., said here today the C. O. would oppose the proposed reduction of 4,000 in the New Jersey WPA personnel. The reduction, expected to be completed by Feb. 1, was announced yesterday by Robert W. Allan, acting State WPA administrator.

Robert D. Johnston has been elected a vice president of James Talcott, Inc., in charge of the Johnston Factors Division. Mr. Johnston for seventeen years was the active head of Johnston Factors Corporation, which specialized in "drop-shipment" factoring.

It is a commonplace to observe that the Metropolitan Opera season has opened brilliantly. Ostensibly, at least, all Metropolitan seasons open brilliantly. They would open brilliantly in the audience if they did not open brilliantly on the stage, since the inaugural performance of the Metropolitan season is a recognized social event, participated in by those who come to see and to be seen.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Rutherford Lane of Hendersonville, N. C., formerly of Short Hills, have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Alice Rutherford Lane, to Robert Knight Morgan of Asheville, N. C., which took place secretly on Aug. 14 in Greenville, N. C.

The Temple of Religion at the World's Fair has begun its change from a dream into a reality. Ground was broken yesterday for the erection of the building, and sufficient funds are in hand to see that construction starts at once. The campaign to assure the establishment of this haven of faith in the midst of progress has been under way only a short time, but already more than $80,000 has been collected.
The International Copper Cartel announced today that present unrestricted production of the red metal would be reduced on Jan. 1 to bring it to 110 per cent of the basic quotas set some years ago.

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, whose independent investigation into irregular bail bond practices rivals a similar inquiry being conducted by John Harlan Amen, Special Prosecutor recently appointed to supersede Geoghan, expressed vexation yesterday over the action of William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, in ordering the seizure of various documents from the offices of four professional bondsmen in Brooklyn.

President W. H. Cowley of Hamilton signed six contracts today for the building of the new college gymnasium. The contracts total $335,000 in cost. The building will be ready for occupancy in the Spring of 1940.

The Louisiana Jockey Club will inaugurate the racing season at the Fair Grounds tomorrow with a $2,000 added Thanksgiving handicap. As the long local season prepared to open, New Orleans handbooks closed. Since the close of the Fair

Financial difficulties led Rabbi Albert Ruskin, 60 years old, to hang himself yesterday in a furnished room he had occupied for six weeks at 39 West Eighty-third Street. His body was found in the closet of his room by Mrs. Elizabeth Hull, the landlady, when she went in to clean at 2 P. M.

The entire plant of underwearmanufacturing machinery and equipment formerly owned by J. C. Roulette Sons, Inc., at Hagerstown, Md., has been bought by Arthur Albert, liquidators and appraisers, from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Today's major events: "La Bo heme," Metropolitan Opera, evening; Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, afternoon.
Police Chief E. V. Warren said today that a man listed as Charles Dowling, alias Arthur Bentz, arrested here yesterday, would be returned to New York to face possible charges of grand larceny.

A large plot of vacant land in Greenwich Village was sold at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday to the Guaranty Trust Company, plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against Margaret Colgan, on a bid of $100,000.
Paul A. Clark, 15-year-old son of Mrs. Rose A. Clark of 200 Main Street, died at his home today of nephritis, a kidney ailment which he had suffered since January.

Merchants of this hamlet, engineers ow the Westchester County Park Commission and members of the Mount Pleasant Town Board made an inspection in the rain this afternoon of trees and shrubs that partly hide the stores on Broadway from motorists using the Bronx River

The Police Department will undertake soon its first experiment in enforcing traffic regulations for pedestrians under the rights granted by the new city charter that became effective last New Year, it was learned yesterday.

The government's weekly report of crop conditions was issued yesterday as follows: Fall seeded grains continued to make satisfactory advance in the Middle Atlantic area, while generous rains during the week in the Southeastern States improved the outlook there materially;

Three students were shot and slightly wounded this afternoon in rioting at a high school opposite Central Park. The wounded-Rene de la Masa, Lydia Lopez and Iris Caris-were taken to an emergency hospital.

W. Alton Jones, first vice president of the Cities Service Company, presented yesterday to William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a plan of integration for the utility properties held by the Cities Service Power and Light Company, main utility holding unit in the $1,000,000,000 Cities Service system.

The Navy eleven's preparations for the Army game were about completed with a long practice today, while the rest of the regiment rehearsed the marching formations that will be used in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium on Saturday.

Louis H. Egan, president of the Union Electric Company of Missouri, testified today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company had no agreement to pay underwriters of its new stock issue anything more than commissions and legitimate expenses enumerated in a contract filed with the SEC.

In closing his testimony before the house committee investigating graft and corruption charges brought against the State administration, Governor Earle explained today the $26,500 in loans which he obtained from Matthew H. McCloskey,
The South Side Community Center will name its gymnasium "Brud Holland Memorial Gymnasium" in honor of Jerome H. Holland of Auburn, N. Y., Cornell senior and All-America football end.
Governor Davey appealed to the Social Security Board today, "in the spirit of Thanksgiving," to release to Ohio its share of Federal funds for old-age pensions.

Preparations were completed tonight for commemorating the first Thanksgiving Day in an unusual setting. Tomorrow in the Church of the Pilgrimage Rabbi Samuel A. Friedman will sound the keynote of thanksgiving during a union service reminiscent of the meetings of the men and women of the Mayflower.

Mrs. Sophie Hinckell announced here tonight that her granddaughter, Mrs. Pauline Mark Thurston of North Adams and Rochester, N. Y., widow of Howard Thurston, the magician, was married last night to Charles K. Collins of Rochester.

With a wide investigation of bail bonds and other matters under way in Brooklyn, Magistrate Overton Harris conducted a miniature ball inquiry of his own yesterday in Yorkville Court when he suddenly grew suspicious of the security furnished by Albert Goodman of 1,924 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, who was charged with bookmaking.

A number of additional sales of land in various communities in the town of Greenburgh, Westchester County, have been made by the Fred Berger Company. N. J. Fox, who purchased a number of properties in the auction held last Spring by the town of Greenburgh,

Miss Carol M. Forrest, debutante daughter of Mrs. Thomas Edwin Forrest of 25 East Eighty-third Street and the late Mr. Forrest, was the guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon given by her mother in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton.

The question whether the American Federation of Labor or the Congress of Industrial Organizations, through affiliates, is to represent the employes of the Postal Telegraph-Cable Company will be determined by an election to be held as soon as possible, according to an order issued today by the National Labor Relations Board.

George V. Smith, attorney and lifelong resident of Lakewood, died this morning at his home after a short illness. Mr. Smith, who was the son of the late State Senator G. G. Smith of Ocean County, was 62 years old.

George H. Found, '40, of Schenectady, N. Y., has been elected captain of the 1939 Princeton crosscountry team, it was announced today by Arthur G. Gilkes, '39, of Kew Gardens, L. I., retiring leader. Edward Burrows Jr., '42, of McEwensville, Pa., has been chosen freshman captain.

The Macy parade, which has become a Thanksgiving Day tradition in New York City, will start at 1 o'clock today at Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street, rain or shine. The procession is expected to break up at Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway, in front of the R. H. Macy Co. store, at 3 o'clock.

Rough or "humiliating" treatment of pledges as part of college "Hell Week" was denounced yesterday in a report adopted by the College Fraternity Secretaries Association at its thirtieth annual meeting held at the Hotel Commodore. The association opposed this policy.

The Social Security Board announced today that it would make no grants to Oklahoma in November and December for old-age assistance and aid to dependent children because of payments to ineligible persons.

Taking a swift glance at Shakespeare's "The Comedy of Errors," George Abbott, who is the jack-ofall-trades in the theatre, has written and staged an exuberant musical comedy, "The Boys From Syracuse," which was put on at the Alvin last evening.

Mr. and Mrs. Victor Harris of this city and East Hampton, L. I., gave a dance last night at Sherry's for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Grace Harris. An afternoon reception will be given for the debutante by her parents today at their home, 405 Park Avenue.

The Nuremberg laws today were officially adopted in every particular by the Free City for application to all Jews whether Danzigers or Poles. The Nazi organ Vorposten, commenting on the action, ironically hopes that the Poles will be grateful to the Danzig government for its efforts to secure "racial purity" for the Free City's inhabitants.

Prime Minister Eamon de Valera, facing a convention of his Fianna Fail party at the Mansion House tonight attended by 700 delegates from all parts of Ireland, told them that the main objectives before the party now were ending partition, the creation of an Irish-speaking people and the advancement of the social principles set out in the Constitution.
" Abstract Art in Prints" is the title of the current exhibition in the Print Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum. It will continue until Jan. 2. In addition to prints from

Tanganyika offers more hopeful possibilities for colonization than many of the territories mentioned as places of settlement for German refugees. The colonists are few and the administration and the leading business men are ready to welcome settlers and cooperate with them in a scheme for largescale development of the land.

Jacob Schloss, who had made camera portraits of many famous persons before he retired ten years ago, died on Tuesday night at the Lynwood Nursing Home after a long illness. His home was at 251 West Ninety-second Street. He was 82 years old.

The observance of Thanksgiving today will find business generally at a standstill throughout the United States, with all financial and commodity markets closed. Canadian and European markets, however, will be open as usual. Exchanges in this country will resume operations tomorrow.

Except for a few games listed to be played in New Jersey early next month and one local test Saturday, the curtain will be rung down on scholastic football in the metropolitan area today when more than sixty games are staged on gridirons in New York City, Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey.
Stocks closed Irregularly higher with steel and copper shares leading; turnover, 1,003,370 shares. All classes of bonds closed steady; transactions, $6,941,500.
David M. Collins has transferred his New York Stock Exchange seat to Fisher A. Buell. The seat of William P. T. Preston has. been transferred to Robert Grant 3d of G. M.P. Murphy Co.

Mrs. Elizabeth Jefferson Vaughan of Louisville, Ky., has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Phyllis Vaughan, to Robert Mallory 3d of Rye, N. Y., and Philadelphia, son of Mrs. George Dillard Harber of Macon, Ga., and the late Robert Mallory Jr.

The marriage of Miss Jane Frankenthaler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Frankenthaler of 101 Central Park West, to John Edwin Riesenfeld, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Riesenfeld of New York and Beverly Hills, Calif., took place last night in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, German Ambassador- to the United States, who was summoned back to Germany to explain the "singular" attitude of the United States toward the anti-Semitic demonstrations in

Several of the C-3 type steamships to be built by the Maritime Commission will be assigned to American President Lines, company officials indicated today. Six vessels of this type are to be constructed at the Federal shipyards at Kearny, N. J. The contract was awarded Monday.

As Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Viscount Halifax, his Foreign Secretary, were already crossing the English Channel today for their meeting in Paris, the French Government officially announced the forthcoming publication of its agreement with Germany.

An addition to the proposed. revised State insurance code drawn by the State Insurance Department would permit reciprocal fire and casualty insurance companies, which have been forbidden to do business in this State, to enter the field under certain safeguards and restrictions.

Mr. and Mrs. Noah MacDowell gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 4 East Seventysecond Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Annetta MacDowell, to many of the older friends of the family. A tea dance will be given for the debutante and her young friends by Mr. and Mrs. MacDowell on Dec. 20 at their home.

Secretary Roper predicted today that national income would reach .$65,000,000,000 this year, the highest since 1930 with the exception of 1937, when it was $69,000,000,000. Income payments to individuals, he said, had increased in October.

Bonds showed yesterday a firmer undertone in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Although the market again lacked a general feature, some groups responded to a better demand with scattered gains, including local tractions and a few railroad liens. Transactions on the Exchange amounted to $6,941,500, compared with $6,270,000 on Tuesday.

The Rev. John J. Downey, for the last twelve years pastor of St. Peter's Church in this city, one of the better known Catholic priests in Connecticut, and who as a Fordham undergraduate scored the first touchdown ever made by the university in a football game, died last night. He was 77 years old.

Cornell's high-powered team and Pennsylvania will meet in the forty-fifth game of their traditional series on Franklin Field tomorrow before an estimated crowd of more than 70,000. The kick-off has been moved up to 1:30 P. M. for the first time in history.

Officers of the Anchor liner Cameronia, which sailed yesterday for Glasgow, said there would be a boom for shipyards next month, as the British Government had ordered the building of another battleship at Brown's yard at Clydebank.

Preliminary to the opening tomorrow of the annual convention of Junior Hadassah, the young women's Zionist organization of America, the delegates tonight sent a Thanksgiving declaration and pledge to President Roosevelt in which thankfulness was voiced for a "government and a nation that condemn by word and act the terror and vandalism that certain other lands wreak upon their own citizens."
Miss Mary Elizabeth Fahnestock of Newport, R. I., was married in Holy Trinity Church, Brompton, London, today to Esme Tatton Brinton of Belbroughton, Worcestershire.

A 20-year-old State law was invoked here for the first time today when Jersey City authorities filed with the Hudson County Board of Taxation complaints charging six corporations with failure to list personal property for 1937 and 1938. Several other corporations may be affected.

Max Tachna, president of the Allied Civic League of the Rockaways and for many years a supporter of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, announced yesterday that he had broken all political relations with Mr. Harvey.

After deliberating a little more than an hour, a jury in Common Pleas Court here today acquitted four members of the election board of the Sixth District in Jersey City's Fifth Ward of violation of the election laws in the 1937 primary election. Judge James R. Erwin presided at the trial.
Samel P. Weston, expert consultant on circulation and other business probems of newspapers throughout the country, died today in his La Jolla ome after a short illness. He was 5 years old.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported yesterday in a statement covering the first ten months of this year, a net profit of $2,421,496 after expenses, depreciation, interest and provision for Federal income taxes.

New Brunswick's Director of Public Safety, fire chief and City Attorney were enjoined here today by Federal Judge Phillip Forman from enforcing suspension of a fire captain for failure to pay debts. The captain, Kohler Dunn, was ordered reinstated.
Senator Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, described Secretary Wallace's proposed two-price farm program today as "cock-eyed." He urged, instead, an increase in agricultural exports.

A Communist manifesto, published in Chungking today, revealed the Communists had requested permission to join the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] and the Kuomintang-created Youth Corps. The manifesto was the outcome of the recent Communist party executive committee meeting in Yenan, which voted for "cooperation between the Kuomintang and the Communist party."

Forest fires, the worst in the history of Southern California, blazed out of control on widely separated fronts in three counties tonight, leaving heavy damage in the Topanga Canyon region north of Santa Monica and in the San Bernardino Mountains.

Augustine S. Janeway, chief of the Pennsylvania State Works Authority, has promised Secretary Ickes that he will discharge all project inspectors found to have been engaged upon the recommendation of contractors.

In any other city but New York the performance of "Die Walkuere," given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, would have been deemed of exceptional excellence. This would have been the case, in the first place, because of the cast of singers, which, today, could not be equaled in another lyric theatre.
More than 200 persons yesterday morning attended a funeral service for Leopold Godowsky, composer, pianist and teacher, who died here on Monday at the age of 68.

The German Government announced today a new bilateral agreement with Czechoslovakia regarding the transfer of citizenship necessitated by the annexation of the Sudetenland that in this instance gives Germany everything she wanted but was not able to put through an international commission.

Two women, believed to be from Bernardsville, N. J., were killed tonight in an automobile collision on an icy highway at Daleville, near here. State motor police said a handbag, found near by, gave the name of Miss Elizabeth Miller of Bernardsville, N. J. No clue to the identify of the other woman was found.

Adrienne Marden, stage and screen actress, who was seen here recently in "The Women," was married' to Whitner Bissell, actor, yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. John Haynes Holmes in his study at 10 Park Avenue.

In a pep rally for the traditional football game with Fordham on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium, some 1,800 New York University students jammed the auditorium of the Gould Memorial Library on University Heights last night to hear Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, the rival coaches and team captains comment on the appreaching tussle, and indicate a feeling of optimism on both sides.

Warners has placed a second pirate story on its schedule with the purchase of "The Mutineer," by Allan Vaughan Elston, as a vehicle for George Brent. It will follow "The Sea Hawk," which is being prepared for Errol Flynn. The studio

French labor's protests against changes in the forty-hour week were confined today to strikes in the metal trades in Northern France while the executive committee of the General Confederation of Labor was preparing for a session tomorrow to take action on a move for a 24-hour general strike.
The striped bass catches at Montauk are gradually falling off, according to late reports, but the cod and pollack are present in numbers and seem to lure a number of the cold-water anglers.
Myer Brenner and Leo Bochner, Toronto stockbrokers, were arrested today on a theft charge involving $48,000 at the request of Thomas E. Dewey, New York District Attorney.

Because the power policy of the New Deal is, in many respects, the core of its socialeconomic program and the fabric of one of the most utopian of its bright visions, the appearance of Wendell L. Willkie before the TVA inquiry committee today operis a chapter that

In the first four months of the current fiscal year, in which the New Deal's pump-priming expenditures were expanding sharply, the Federal Government's income from internal revenue dropped $24,694,679 behind that of the same months a year earlier, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today.

Following is the text of the formal statement by Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, before the joint Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority:

J. Carlton Ward Jr. has been elected vice president and a director of the United Aircraft Corporation and has been appointed general manager of the Pratt Whitney aircraft division, Donald L. Brown, president, announced yesterday.

Sports from the seventeenth century to the present are illustrated in an exhibition of nearly 100 prints which was opened yesterday by A. G. Spalding Bros, 518 Fifth Avenue. Lithographs, wood cuts, line
Mayor La Guardia has protested to President Roosevelt and Harry L. Hopkins, National Works Progress Administrator, against threatened cuts in the WPA rolls in this city, it became known yesterday.

The Erie Railroad reported a profit and loss deficit of $10,652,318 on Sept. 30. This contrasted with a surplus of $2,168,388 reported for a year previously. Although the company has been in bankruptcy since early this year, this was the first time that it had reported a deficit of this kind.

The breakdown of civilization in the twentieth century was deplored by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College at a Thanksgiving Day assembly held yesterday in celebration of the annual Alumnae Day of Hunter College at the Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska, here today to inspect the Tennessee Valley Authority's Chickamauga dam on the Tennessee River, asserted that "the private utilities are bluffing and we have them licked."
A white-haired Welsh mother, Mrs. Minnie James, 72, opened the door of the new $300,000 Temple of Peace and Health today with a golden key.
The Commodity Credit Corporation announced today that $100,000,000 had been allocated for loans on corn in accordance with the provisions of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938.
Harry Harkness Flagler of Millbrook, N. Y., asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to review the government's claim that he owed $20,687.23 on income taxes for 1934 and 1936. The petitioner said that

Brooklyn Tech, St. Nicholas of Tolentine and Franklin K. Lane scored victories in non-league scholastic basketball games yesterday. Tech scored its second straight success by beating a Brooklyn rival, Samuel J. Tilden, 33-28, at Tech;

James H.Crowley, head coach of the Fordham football team, signed a new five-year contract yesterday. The Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S. J., president of the university; the Rev. John W. Tynan, S. J., faculty moderator of athletics; John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics, and Crowley went into

The two-way tie for the Class A squash tennis lead in the Metropolitan League persisted last night, as both the New York Athletic and Bayside Tennis Clubs swept along to a fourth triumph each in as many starts. The Columbia players also are undefeated, but have played only three matches.

The beginning of the fifty-first year of theatrical production by the City College Dramatic Society will be marked tonight by the presentation of "Idiot's Delight," Robert Sherwood's Pulitzer Prize-winning play of two years ago, in the auditorium of the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
Two leaders of a high school students' group here defied authorities tonight to disband their "C?C" club, whose purpose they described as a "bloodless revolution" for more liberal government.

Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, New York University football coach, yesterday consented to serve in an advisory capacity to Benny Friedman, City College mentor, who will be field coach of the metropolitan college all-star eleven that will face the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field, Dec. 3, in a game for the benefit of German, Austrian and Czechoslovak refugees.

As an effect of the Munich pact Germany's growing economic bloc will soon virtually control trade in Central and Eastern Europe unless the United States and other democratic countries adopt the German Austria and parts of Czechoslovakia, is now cementing her political and economic bonds with Hungary,
Two appointments to the Federal judiciary calculated to restore harmony between the Democratic factions in Illinois were announced by President Roosevelt today.

The opinions of Lewis Morris, a Grimes (Iowa) farmer, on farm and factory problems will be heard at a session of the Congress of American industry, which meets under the auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Dec. 7, 8 and 9.

Alfred M. Cormack of New York and Daniel Bartlett of St. Louis, as attorneys for the Ford Motor Company, filed a brief today asking the National Labor Relations Board to reverse the report of Tilford E.

A brief challenging the legality of the five-man court that heard the appeal for a stay in the civil liberties suit against Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, and questioning the right.of one of the five judges to continue in the case, was filed here today in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals by counsel for the C. I. O. and the American Civil Liberties Union.

The exalted title of Governor of the State of New Jersey is no restraining factor when friends of A. Harry Moore desire to greet him. The Governor relates that while commuting to the State House here from his cabin at Mount Airy in the Hunterdon County hills he passed a group of WPA workers along the road.

Charles A. Mulligan Jr., indicted Tuesday on charges of perjury and of practicing law without a license, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Dodd at St. George, S. I., and was held in $2,500 bail for trial in Richmnond County Court.

Haverford defeated Cornell, 2-1, today and thereby won its first Middle Atlantic intercollegiate soccer championship. Haverford's first goal was scored by Allinson in the initial quarter on a relay from Atkinson. Mears accounted for the second goal with a hard shot in the third period.

Officials of the South Carolina Public Service Authority said today that a base bid of $1,982,505, submitted by the General Electric Company apparently was low for furnishing all generating machinery for the $37,500,000 Santee-Cooper Power and Navigation Project.

Government and defense both rested their cases yesterday in the trial of Johanna Hofmann, Erich Glaser and Otto Hermann Voss for espionage after a stormy court session at which it was revealed that Dr. Ignatz Griebl, a fugitive, admitted to a Federal agent in Berlin that statements he made in a deposition taken in Germany were false.

The Capitol Limited, newest of the Baltimore Ohio's fast trains, was "dedicated" here today. The Diesel-powered streamliner was christened in brief ceremonies in the Grand Central Station. It then started on its first run to Washington and the East.

As a result of the crusade against tuberculosis 200,000 American lives will be saved this year that would have been lost if the tuberculosis death rate of 1900 had prevailed, according to a report yesterday by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

A report issued today by the Department of Mines of Ontario showed that the value of the Province's metal production for the first nine months of this year amounted to $149,749,182, compared with $152,001,543 in the corresponding period

John Charles Thomas gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall as the second event in the Hurok Carnegie Hall series. The popular baritone, as usual, attracted a large host of his fervent admirers to the auditorium, who welcomed him with a. warmth that left no room for doubt regarding their enjoyment of a program which veered sharply from the beaten track, both in its material and arrangement.
The Sunray Oil Corporation will issue soon a new type of security when $4,000,000 of 5 per cent interest-bearing convertible sinking fund debenture shares, Series A, is released on the market.

Tennessee's Volunteers, standing at the threshold of their first conference football championship, ruled a prohibitive favorite tonight to continue along the victory trail by turning back an "old jinx foe," the Kentucky Wildcats, here tomorrow.

The third annual New York University. Frolic tomorrow will be attended by 2,000 students, university administrators, members of the faculty and alumni in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday.
Assurance that no devaluation of the German mark is impending was sent-out to Americanforeign traders yesterday by the Board of Trade for GermanAmerican Commerce.

A few items in yesterday's news may serve to make the realty man's Thanksgiving turkey today a little more enjoyable. One of these was the announcement by the City and Suburban Homes Company that a semi-annual dividend of 2 per cent had been declared on its common stock, payable Dec. 5 to holders of record Dec. 1.
A Jewish native of Czechoslovakia, in the United States illegally, was saved from deportation today by Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan. Judge Sullivan granted a writ of habeas corpus to the alien,

Mr. and Mrs. George C. Hollis of Eagle Pass, Texas, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Florence Adele Hollis, to Lieutenant Christian H. Clarke Jr., U. S. A.

The summary removal of the five principal executives of the Young Communist League, ranging down from Alexander V. Kosaryeff, the leader, was announced today following recent severe criticism of allegedly scandalous and anti-Soviet conditions in the league's leadership.

King Carol of Rumania prepared tonight to talk with Chancellor Hitler at Berchtesgaden tomorrow on the political and economic situation in Southeastern Europe. Oswald Pirow, Defense Minister of the Union of South Africa, British dominion, also was scheduled to be a guest of Herr Hitler tomorrow.
The candidacy of Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines, for the Democratic nomination for President in 1940 was formally announced today by Frank McHale, his campaign manager.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today that Greece had awarded gold marine medals to two officers who participated in the rescue of the crew of the Greek steamship Tzenny Chandris, which foundered on Nov. 13, 1937, off Cape Hatteras.
Federal improvements to the State barge canal at an estimated cost of $27,000,000 will be completed in 1943, the board of army engineers announced today.

Thirty-eight graduate and undergraduate students of City College were elected members of Gamma Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national scholastic honorary fraternity, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Morton Gottschall, dean of the College of Literal Arts and Science.

Mr. and Mrs. Stanhope Scott Goddard of Collender's Point, Noroton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Quinby Goddard, to Manning Barrett Brown, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Blanchard Brown of New York and Darien, Conn.

The world production of tin in the third quarter of this yearamounted to 32,300 tons, against 39,200 in the second quarter and a quarterly average of 52,100 for all of 1937, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.

Dr. Eddie Anderson, football coach at Holy Cross College, today contemplated an offer to coach at the University of Iowa and The Boston Globe quoted him as saying that as much as he liked it at Holy Cross; "it would be difficult to refuse" the Western university's bid.

Miss Doris Masters, daughter of Mrs. George La Rue Masters of this place and the late Mr. Masters, was married today in her home to Frederick Orvis Church, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Orvis Church of South Orange. The Rev. Dr.

Twenty-nine policemen here will have a real cause for Thanksgiving tomorrow, as they had a total today of $45,700 in back salary. The checks represented unpaid salaries from April 1, the date when a pay dispute with the town began, to Nov. 30. In the interim they have had to borrow and obtain credit from sympathetic merchants.

The first pile in the foundation of the Temple of Religion at the World's Fair was driven yesterday afternoon. Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, and William Church Osborn, president of the board of directors of the Temple, participated in the ceremony.

Dr. Rexford Guy Tugwell, chairman of the City Planning Commission and former member of President Roosevelt's "brain trust," and Miss Grace Falke, 30-year-old director of the arts projects -of the National Youth Administration, were married yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall. Mr. and Mrs.

The United States Government proceeded today to make it easier for Mexico to pay her agrarian debt to United States landowners, on which about $10,300,000 is claimed, when the Embassy, in recapitulating the claims, eliminated the largest single item, one of $990,000 for the Tlaljualilo property in the State of Durango.

Two quack doctors, one a second offender, pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to practicing medicine without licenses. The evidence against them was gathered by two women detectives of the State Education Department.
The National Bureau for Blind Artists opened yesterday at 32 East Fifty-second Street its gallery for the display and sale of work by its talented though sightless members.

Thanksgiving Day is older than the day which, as President Roosevelt said in his proclamation, "our fathers aside as they hewed a nation from the primeval forest." It is older than the Puritans and the Pilgrims.

Secretary Ickes twitted his Cabinet colleague, Secretary Wallace, today over the latter's implied rebuke to Mr. Ickes for having sent up a Roosevelt third-term "trial balloon." Asked at his press conference whether he believed that Paul McNutt was a "middle-of-the-road" Presidential candidate, Mr. Ickes replied:

Confidence regarding the outlook for retail trade in 1939 was expressed at the recent meeting of heads of stores which are members of the Specialty Stores Association; according to a statement issued yesterday by Arthur J. McGrail of the Richard Healy Company, president of the buying organization.
