AS a holiday special, three books this morning, one the work of A. J. Liebling, the second a novel by Edwin Corle, the third something called a novel, by Kenneth Horan. All are brisk and pleasant and American.*

Are the Germans trying to undermine the Maginot Line? Subterranean noises heard by a grave digger when filling the grave after the funeral of a young girl have given rise to the theory that the Germans are digging strategic tunnels under and past the Maginot Line for use in the event of war.

Headquarters for the Royal Swedish World's Fair Commission will be set up in Rockefeller Center, where offices on the eighth floor of the International Building have been leased to Count Hugo Hamilton, Assistant Commissioner General of the Swedish section of the exhibition.
James A. Johnson, a pioneer of Shelby and a promoter of the heavyweight championship fight between Jack Dempsey and Tommy-Gibbons here in 1923, died today. He was 73 years old.

Arrival here next week of the first shipments of goods sent out from the Sudeten areas now a part of Germany will touch off a series of court battles to keep the government from imposing German "blacklist" duties on the products and from forcing "made in Germany" markings to be placed on the goods, importers predicted here yesterday.

Continued improvement last week in almost all lines of economic activity carried the level of business in the Pittsburgh district to a new high level in the recovery period, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. is anticipating a near-record crowd in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night when Henry Armstrong, world welterweight and lightweight champion, defends his 147-pound crown against the powerful-hitting Filipino challenger, Ceferino Garcia.

The Hempstead Methodist Episcopal Church was the scene of the marriage tonight of Miss Marjorie Jeannette Walters, daughter of Mrs. Marjorie D. Walters of this place and A. Vernon Walters of New York, to B. Raymond Hansen of Baldwin.
Continuing rains today caused a new 400foot avalanche at the deserted scene of landslides of the past two days that have taken a heavy toll of life.

Maxwell S. Stewart, national chairman of the American Friends of the Chinese People and associate editor of The Nation, made public yesterday a statement declaring that none of the activities of the American Friends of the Chinese People is in any way connected with domestic political issues and that "I know of no Communists among its membership."

Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in making final arrangements today for his departure for the Pan-American conference at Lima, Peru, expressed confidence that it would result in tangible and intangible benefits.

Phil Ross of Montreal, Canada, the medalist, and a trio of Duke University students-Guy Berner, Buffalo, N. Y.; Tom Perry, Tampa, Fla., and Henry Russell, Miami, Fla.came through successfully in the first round of match play in the twenty-third annual Carolina golf tournament on the Pinehurst No. 2 course today.

The French liner Normandie is due to arrive today from Europe. Among her passengers are: S. E. Ricardo Olivera, Argentine Ambassador to Mexico; Leon J. Garcey, Charles Renaud, Swiss banker; Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, William Nelson Cromwell, Mrs.

In order to collect the 1,000,000,000-mark fine imposed on the Jews as a "money atonement" for the murder of Ernst vom Rath, German Embassy secretary in Paris, the government today decreed a 20 per cent capital levy on the property of all German and stateless Jews possessing more than 5,000 marks. Foreign Jews were specifically exempted.

William G. Barry, formerly assistant vice president of the Ohio Bell Telephone Company, with headquarters in Cleveland, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home on Nassau Point Road, Peconic, L. I. His age was 61.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies was informed this week that the Canadian Minister of Finance has decided to waive penalties "in the absence of fraud," levied recently against agencies and advertisers here,
Cornell against Pennsylvania for the Ivy League championship and Southern California against U. C. L. A. for a share in the Pacific Coast title and possibly the Rose Bowl nomination.

In an unexpected announcement from his Pine Mountain cottage late tonight, President Roosevelt expressed gratification with the information "reported here" that the number of Jews allowed to enter Palestine would be increased.

A hawk was discovered eating a white and gray pigeon on the twenty-fourth floor roof of the Times Building yesterday at 10:15 A. M. by Charles Summers, head porter, who was making a round of inspection. The hawk flew away at his approach.

The method of payment to New Jersey citizens of unemployment compensation Insurance benefits, beginning next January, will be outlined in a motion picture, it was announced today by Harold G. Hoffman, executive director of the Unemployment Compensation Commission. Mr. Hoffman said

The City Council today dropped its plan to pass a flat 2 per cent wage tax and moved to substitute the 1 1/2 per cent tax on wages, salaries, fees, commissions and the net profits of businesses advocated by Mayor Wilson.

School authorities of Elizabeth, N. J., reported yesterday that 91 of the 235 pupils in the Victor Mravlag grade school had been stricken with an intestinal disorder since Monday, apparently the same type of disease that has affected 413 students in White Plains, N. Y., schools.

A series of decrees issued today included a half dozen dealing with "safeguarding the interests of the republic." Workers' general strikes, employers' lockouts, peasant strikes and other attempts to hinder the supply of foodstuffs to the towns will make participants liable to five years' imprisonment.

The Middle Atlantic States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools and four associated organizations will open their annual conference here at Chalfonte Haddon Hall tomorrow to continue through Saturday.

The ancient steam packet Nancy Brooks was plunging her rusty nose into angry mid-Atlantic seas, that blustery Thanksgiving Day ten years ago, and all hands not engaged below were huddled on deck, gravely contemplating sullen skies and mountainous waves.

Before 4,500 shivering spectators, St. John's Prep brought its football campaign to a successful conclusion at Boys High Field yesterday morning with a 6-to-2 victory over its annual Thanksgiving Day foe, Brooklyn Prep.

Mme. Francisca Benavides, wife of the President of Peru, arrived yesterday on the Normandie accompanied by her 17-year-old niece, Malvina Malkowsky, en route to her home after placing two of her children in European schools.

Miss Edith L. Milliken, daughter of Carl E. Milliken, former Governor of Maine, and Mrs. Milliken, was married here tonight in the First Congregational Church to William Ernest Wade Jr. of Rutherford, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. L. McCorison Jr.

Stephen F. Chadwick, national commander of the American Legion, addressed a letter yesterday to Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, challenging her explanation in her recent communication to him of the causes for her delay in bringing about deportation hearings in the case of Harry Bridges, West Coast C. I. O. leader and alleged Communist instigator of strikes and disturbances in the shipping industry.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is inconceivable that the La Guardia Administration will not provide money for the construction of much-needed schools in this city.

Southern California crushed the hapless Bruins of the University of California at Los Angeles under a 42-to-7 score today and immediately set up a clamor for the nomination as the Far West's representative in the Rose Bowl's football game.

Former President Eduard Benes, co-founder with Thomas G. Masaryk of the democratic Republie of Czechoslovakia, has been publicly disowned by the government of what is now called in all the newspapers "the second republic."

Miss Agnes Mary Funke, daughter of Joseph A. Funke of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Funke, was married to Captain Eugene M. Cunningham, also of Brooklyn, commanding officer of the Howitzer Company, 106th Infantry, yesterday morning in St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church. Brooklyn.
Six hundred needy residents of Jersey City's Second Ward received a Thanksgiving dinner today as guests of Freeholder John V. Kenny, the ward leader.
The clergy and the parishioners of many denominations in Westchester County joined today in conducting union services in observance of Thanksgiving Day.
French press comment on the agreed FrancoGerman declaration is sharply divided, but not along the usual political lines.
North Carolina's Tar Heels overpowered the University of Virginia, 20 to 0, today as these two old rivals wrote another chapter in Dixie's oldest continuous football rivalry.

Dr. Alcan Hirsch, a chemical engineer with offices at 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, died here today at the New Rochelle Hospital at the age of 53. Dr. Hirsch suffered a heart attack while horseback riding two weeks ago and since had been in the hospital.

The Republican State executive committee, meeting Monday in Albany, will ignore demands from the more conservative element within the party for the cancellation of the election of Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County chairman, as a member of the National Committee if it follows the plans of party leaders, it became known yesterday.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday details of the sale of $40,000,000 of New York City bonds, to be held on Tuesday, consisting of $25,000,000 of serial bonds I and $15,000,000 of assessment bonds, all to be dated Dec. 1, 1938.
James A. Dunlap, president of the Dunlap Printing Company, died of a heart attack today at his home in West Philadelphia. He was 68 years old.

The expectation here, based on buzzings in the White House inner circle, is that the bulk of the President's message to the next Congress will dwell on the new program of national security, or hemisphere defense, which in this space has previously been referred to as "the Fourth New Deal."
Coach Earl Blaik of Dartmouth expressed apprehension today over a spell of warm-weather. He said it wouldn't do his football players any good Saturday against Stanford, if it kept up.

In the heart of a husky West Virginia youth there was little or no thankfulness Thanksgivi Day, a year ago, for he was stranded in Fort Worth, Texas, with no place to go and two dimes in the one good pocket of his coat. He had lost a quarter through a hole in a trousers pocket.
Some 500 of the 1,300 volunteers who fought a winning battle two months ago against the flooding Connecticut River by sandbagging dikes here apparently want no pay for their strenuous efforts.

Two of Switzerland's most prominent skiers, Arthur Schlatter and Karl Acker, arrived yesterday aboard the Normandie of the French Line. The former will serve as coach of Middlebury College's ski team this Winter,
Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita and German Ambassador Eugen Ott signed the Japanese-German cultural agreement this morning.

Miss Margaret Mary Burke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Burke of South Orange, and Harry Wilson Angevine Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Angevine of Glen Ridge, were married this evening in the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lambert Dunn.

Pennsylvania business stands ready to provide employment for at least 16,000 persons "as soon as readjustment of excessive State taxation on business makes this possible," according to results of a survey made public today by the Emergency Council of State Associations.

Bail securities offered by bondsmen for Leo Bochner, Toronto broker held by police here for New York authorities in connection with an alleged $250,000 nickel "swindle" in 1936, were refused by Judge Daniel O'Connell today. The judge said the securities offered were "not sufficiently substantial."

In the perfect city no pedestrian will ever be hurt or killed crossing the street. No automobile driver will swing around a corner and bag him when the lights are green. He will not cross in the middle of the block or when the lights are red.
Virginia State College spoiled the sixyear undefeated record of Morgan College, Baltimore, with a 15-0 triumph today. Morgan had a string of fifty-four consecutive victories.
Officials of the State Department of Public Works rushed plans today for one of their largest undertakings in recent years-construction of $25,000,000 worth of public buildings.

Ian McIver, through Culver, Hollyday Co, in 530 E 88th St; Huber Hoge, through Morgenthau-Seixas Co, in 103 E 84th St; Winslow P. Hubbard, through Duff Conger, in 19 E 65th St: Betty Fitzgerald, in 435 E 57th St; Hildred Badger, through Brett Wyckoff, in 39 E 78th St; James W. Clancy, in 15 W 11th St; John Gordon, in 236 W 70th St; Byrne Bowman, brokers.
Three interesting old properties in Greenwich Village and on the East Side of Manhattan have just changed hands after having been held in undisturbed ownership for many years.
The Polish Government will not guarantee the new frontiers of Czechoslovakia as long as the Ruthenian question remains unsettled.
A storm of sleet and snow greeted the players as the 1938 national women's field hockey tournament opened at the Merion Cricket Club today.

The British Government is considering making a large increase in immigration figures for Palestine in an effort to cope with the refugee problem, Colonial Secretary Malcolm MacDonald told the House of Commons today.

It would be a fortunate thing for all concerned if the long-continued controversy between public and private enterprise in the Tennessee Valley area could be settled promptly, on terms which would protect the government's interest and at the same time give the utility industry reason to believe that it can go ahead with its plans for expansion without fear of subsidized competition.
Harry C. Abell, who, until his retirement a few years ago, had been an officer in several large public utilities and holding companies, died here today after a week's illness. He was 69 years old.

Miss Annette Manderson Stahl, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. B. Franklin Stahl of White House, Haverford, was married at noon today to Dr. Joseph F. McClughan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William McClughan of Newburgh, N. Y.
Ignazio Silone, whose new book, "The School for Dictators," was published by Harper last Wednesday, reports that he is now at work on a sequel to "Bread and Wine."
Putting trivial matters to one side for the moment, Clifford Odets is writing about love in "Rocket to the Moon," which the Group Theatre put on at the Belasco last evening.

A. J. County, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in charge of finance and corporate relations, will retire on Nov. 30 from active duty after forty-eight years in the company's service, under the pension rules of the railroad.

The Jewish National Fund, the Zionists' land-purchasing agency, is preparing to place at the disposal of German-Jewish refugees sufficient land in Palestine to accommodate 25,000 families, according to Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the fund and co-chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, who returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie.

The prefabricated steel farmhouses and other buildings which are to be erected by the Farm Security Administration on selected sites in Alabama, Georgia and South Carolina are by no means the first of their kind.

Before a crowd of 11,500, East Orange High defeated the Barringer High football team in their forty-second annual game today, 13 to 6. In the long series, started in 1897, Barringer has won twenty games and East Orange eighteen. Four games resulted in ties.
The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on Nov. 19, according to figures of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which were made public today.

Mr. and Mrs. Archer Harmon of Concord, N. H., formerly of Short Hills, gave a reception this afternoon at The Close here to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Adele Harmon. Autumn flowers and foliage decorated the home.

Registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of 1,000,000 shares of beneficial interest in the Knickerbocker Fund for the Diversification, Supervision and Safe-Keeping of Investment, has become effective, it was announced yesterday by Pettit, Bryan Kalbach, Inc., sponsors and administrators of the fund.

The Dolomite 4, an all-welded, 300-foot freighter, constructed with a removable deck house, docked at Jersey City yesterday after her crew had the unusual experience of passing the vessel's deck house on the voyage from Wyandotte, Mich., by way of the barge canal.

The Japanese have decided to mop up Chinese troops along the entire Canton-Kowloon Railway Line and have notified the Hong Kong Government that Japanese troops will shortly operate near the British border.

The Treasury Department is conducting a study of the problem of pier visitors in New York harbor and may decide after conferences with shipping representatives to curtail the number of visitors permitted to meet incoming liners, it became known yesterday.

The Rev. Jonathan Goodhue Sherman, who since 1935 had charge of St. Thomas's Protesant Episcopal Church, Farmingdale, took up his duties this morning as rector of St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, Commonwealth Boulevard and Superior Road, here.

The Lions defeated the Bears, 14 to 7, today and advanced to within a single victory of a tie with Green Bay for the Westerln Division title of the National Football League. The Packers have completed their regular schedule and Detroit needs a victory over Philadelphia here a week from Sunday to force a playoff.

Plans for the construction here of a $132,000 public library, which would be designed to resemble a private home "in order to have greater influence on the lives and reading habits of residents," received new impetus today with the announcement of a $700 gift to the library for the purchase of books dealing with the history of the Jews, according to Ernest E. Quantrell, president of the library board.

The intensive campaign of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, roll-call ended yesterday. However, according to Mrs. David Challinor, roll-call director of the organization, many group chairmen have received more time in which to complete their lists.
The Detroit Red Wings scored their first home victory of the National Hockey League season by routing the Chicago Black Hawks, Stanley Cup champions, 4 to 2, tonight before 10,000.

At every performance thus far in the current Metropolitan Opera season, Edward Johnson has presented new singers. They have been of varying merits, but they have provided welcome new elements of interest in the casts, and last night's debuts were the most interesting thus far of the season.

Wake Forest's ripening sophomores, concluding their first year of varsity play, gave promise of better things to come as they swamped Davidson, 21 to 0, today. Playing before 6,500 fans in a cold rain, the Deacons won as they pleased, racking up touchdowns in each of the first three periods.

The New York University footbail squad concluded practice at Ohio Field yesterday, with the players communicating their optimism over the result of the Fordham game tomorrow even to the usually solemn trainers and campus caretakers.

Headed by Captain Al Caruso, quarterback, seven Manhattan College varsity players have accepted invitations to join the Metropolitan All-Star squad which will meet the Brooklyn Dodgers on Dec. 3 at Ebbets Field, it was announced yesterday. The contest is being held for the benefit of Catholic, Jewish and Protestant refugees.
It is not at all hard to understand Berlin's feelings about Mr. Ridder and the Staats-Zeitung. In the eyes of the German press Mr.

A dinner dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. George Sergei Piroumoff of 1,160 Park Avenue last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to introduce Mrs. Piroumoff's daughter, Miss Margaret Gilbert Higgins.

More than 20,000 WPA workers in this city face dismissal next Thursday, it was learned last night. Mayor La Guardia said at City Hall that 15,000 were in danger of discharge because the State Board of Social Welfare would not contribute $180,000 a month toward their continued employment.
The Brewster Aeronautical Corporation is now engaged in moving into its new building to provide for expansion of its operations in 1939, James Work, president, announced yesterday.
The Manhattan of the United States Lines is due to arrive today from the Channel ports. The passenger list includes Hugh R. Wilson, United States Ambassador to Germany; G. L. Burke,

Miss Thelma Wharton, concert pianist, formerly of Chicago, died in Freeport, Ill., last night. Until recently she was head of the piano department at the Frances Shimer Junior College at Mount Carroll.

The senior promenade of the class of 1939 of City College will be held tonight in the Hotel Astor Belvedere Room. Audrey Christie, featured in "I Married an Angel," has been selected as prom queen and Charles Walters, who plays opposite Miss Christie, has been named prom king.

Trapped on the second floor of their home at 233 Tomlin Avenue, here, early today when fire on the stairway cut off their escape, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Tissot and their five children all jumped from a second-floor window twenty feet to the ground into the arms of neighbors. None was injured,
A survey of the forest fires in several counties showed the situation tonight as follows:

The defeat of Mikhail Botwinnik of Moscow by Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam was the outstanding result recorded in the twelfth round of the A. V. R. O. international chess masters tournament contested here tonight.

All resident Americans and many of their friends celebrated Thanksgiving dinner today in Lima's luxurious American-constructed Country Club. The honorary president of the Society of Resident Americans, Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt, said in an address:
The Mexican Government has ordered the seizure of an additional 2,014,000 acres (more than 3,100 square miles) of undeveloped American oil land in Northeastern Mexico.
A plucky band of University of Tulsa football players held the favored Univeristy of Arkansas Razorbacks to a 6-6 tie today in the fifteenth test of their inter-Conference Thanksgiving Day rivalry.

A violent editorial in Komsomolskaya Pravda dispelled any doubt that the removal and' almost certain arrest of Alexander V. Kosaryeff and other high officials of the Young Communist League is the opening barrage in a new severe purge ,of this organization, upon which the Soviet regime largely depends for a reservoir of future leaders.
William F. Gates, who rose from a job as laborer to president and general manager of the Prairie Pipe Line Company in 1915, died here today at the age of 71.

Company officials are taking a much more active part in the shaping of advertising programs, reflecting the growing realization of advertising's importance as a sales tool, according to the results of a survey of important advertisers announced by Sales Management.

After an address tonight by Miss Nell Ziff, national president of Junior Hadassah, in which she exhorted Jewish youth "not merely to talk but to act in the present Jewish crisis," 500 delegates to the annual convention of the organization adopted budgets totaling $77,285 for its projects in Palestine, including an item of $9,000 for the mains tenance in Palestine of twenty-five Jewish refugee children of Rumania for two years.

A complete reorganization of the business administration of the WPA Federal Theatre Project, intended to put the project on a par with the commercial theatre in terms of operating efficiency, was announced yesterday by Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the five WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city, and George Kondolf, local director of the theatre project.
Marian Anderson, the Negro contralto, returned yesterday from Europe on the French liner Normandie to start her Winter concert tour at Buffalo on Tuesday.
A decree was issued today dissolving Freemasonry in Poland. Its properties were confiscated and the proceeds from the sale will be handed over to charity.
Santa Claus dipped to a perfect three-point landing on Floyd Bennett Airport, Brooklyn, yesterday morning at 10:30 o'clock after a flight of unknown length.

The special Senate committee studying profit sharing in industry has invited Gerard Swope, president of General Electric Company, and Alfred P. Sloan, chairman of General Motors Corporation, to testify next week.

Miss Dorothy Aylesworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Hall Aylesworth of 812 Park Avenue, and Robert G. Knott, son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Knott of 43 Fifth Avenue, will have eighteen attendants at their marriage on Jan. 4.
A sweeping Congressional investigation of radio broadcasting policies was proposed today by Senator White of Maine, who said he had received indications of Democratio support.

Talking at Memphis before cotton growers and handlers, Oscar Johnston, chairman of the National Cotton Council and former manager of the United states Cotton Pool, summed up the present situation in cotton in three sentences:

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Perrotty of Yonkers, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Therese Perrotty, to Anthony Del Balso, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Del Balso of Riverdale and Wappingers Falls, N. Y.

Miss Beatrice Lipman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lipman of 680 West End Avenue, was married to Harry David Haber, son of Municipal Court Justice and Mrs. Isidore I. Haber, yesterday afternoon in Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street.

The Brookhattan soccer team defeated the New York Americans, 3-0, before a crowd of 3,000 yesterday at Starlight Park. The Brooks outplayed their local rivals throughout. After twentyfive minutes, a pass from Joe Boyle to Jannette gave the Brooks a 1-0 lead which they held at half-time.

Vic Hanson, former head football coach at Syracuse University and onetime All-America end, returned to the gridiron wars today to direct an all-Onondaga County high school team against Manlius where Hanson starred as a schoolboy.

The Giants found snow, sleet and the Dodgers equally annoying yesterday, but finally compromised with the elements and Brooklyn on a 7-7 tie at Ebbets Field before 17,400 frozen spectators. A touchdown pass with those two old reliables, Ed Danowski and Dale Burnett operating, rescued the pupils of Stout Steve Owen from defeat 1 minute 45 seconds from the end.

Stipulations to discontinue false and misleading advertising have been entered into with the Federal Trade Commission by three dealers engaged, respectively, in the sale of knitting yarns, a cleansing powder and a beauty culture booklet, the commission announced today.

A letter containing sixty-five signatures was addressed to President Roosevelt yesterday urging him not to lift the embargo against Loyalist Spain. The letter criticized ninety-four persons who recently urged the President to lift the embargo. It said:

The high-riding Tartans of Carnegie Tech pulled touchdown plays twice today, one for a 27-yard gain and the other for 38 yards, and marked up a 14-to-0 victory over a tough and inspired North Carolina State eleven.

Harold M. Sawyer, vice president of the American ?? and Electric Company; Fletcher W. Rockwell, vice president, National Lead Company; Fred A. Hubbard, vice president, Hanover Fire Insurance Company; Gilbert Hudson Wehmann,

Carmen Bova, captain of the Seton Hall Prep School team, won the thirteenth annual national interscholastic cross-country meet over the Branch Brook Park course today. Bova, with a strong finish, ran the two and a half miles in 12 minutes 55.2 seconds, 1.4 slower than the record set last year by Les MacMitchell of George Washington High.

" Ragamuffins' Day," a New York tradition, is perceptibly vanishing. It was the custom of former years for streets to be filled with youngsters, garbed in flimsy but multicolored attire, braving the cold and asking, "Anything for Thanksgiving, Mister?"
West Virginia's Mountaineers played an alert, hard-driving football game today to defeat the George Washington Colonials, 7 to 6.

A Christmas season exhibit of scientific toys will open next Thursday at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center with the cooperation of the Toy Manufacturers of the United States of America.

Edgar Hanover, a yearling bay colt by Calumet Chuck and out of Hanover's Bertha, was the bright star of the second and final day of the forty-fourth annual Old Glory horse auction, concluded yesterday in the Squadron A Armory.
Rabbi Samuel A. Friedman stood today in the pulpit of the Church of the Pilgrimage, hard by the hill where the Pilgrim Fathers are buried, and gave thanks for the "peace in our land."
The 1938 navigation season here will close early next month, officials of-lake shipping companies said today. They are making preparations to end one of the busiest seasons in many years.
Jimmy Hines of the Lakeville Club, Great Neck, L. I., fired an eightunder-par 63 practice round today at the Ridgewood Golf Club, where tomorrow the $5,000 Columbia open will start.
The Viennese Roof of the St. Re gis was the setting last night for Miss Amanda Alston Cecil's coming-out party, a small supper dance given for her by her father, James McC. Cecil.

In a cold, wintry setting an aroused underdog Pennsylvania team added one more chapter to the history of Cornell's frustration on Franklin Field today as the teams fought to a scoreless draw before a crowd of 70,000 spectators.

Out of the ashes of eight straight defeats rose the University of Texas players in full gallantry today-gallantry that submerged Texas A. M., 7-6, and stunned 36,000 who came out to see them trampled into victoryless season.
In hail and rain Howard University defeated the Lincoln University eleven today, 6-0, before a crowd of 4,000 fans in the thirty-third game of the annual classic.

In anticipation of increased patronage during the World's Fair, the new owners of the Hotel Winthrop, at the corner of Lexington Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, announced yesterday that they would make extensive improvements in the seventeen-story hostelry.

The marriage of Miss Margaretta Nelson, daughter of Francis A. Nelson of this place, to Donald Merrill Clayton, son of Mrs. Thomas R. Clayton of Providence, took place tonight in St. James Episcopal Church here.

Following is the text of the pastoral letter of Dennis Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishops and Bishops to the Catholics of the United States announcing a plain for the study of democracy by Catholic schools:
Racing under the most adverse weather conditions remembered here in years, three horses hit the wire heads apart in the Thomas K. Lynch Memorial Handicap today.
Twenty additional fellowships and scholarships have been awarded in the Graduate School of Brown University for the current academic year. The recipients include:

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and his Foreign Secretary, Viscount Halifax, made a diversion from their consultations with French statesmen when they called this evening on the Duke and Duchess of Windsor.

Guy Berner of Buffalo, the Empire State junior champion, scored an easy victory in the semi-final round of the twenty-third annual Carolina golf tournament today, beating Phil Ross of Montreal, winner of the medal, by 6 and 5.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $8,852,596.

Eastchester High School defeated Tuckahoe High, 14 to 0, before 4,500 fans at Eastchester High stadium today to win the scholastic gridiron championship of Tuckahoe and complete its season as the only undefeated, untied schoolboy team in Westchester County.

Austrian refugees in France were notified by the police today that they must leave the Paris region before the end of this month. They received a list of Departments in which they will not be allowed to take up residence.

Hayden Eames, industrialist and a former officer in both the United States Army and Navy, died today at the age of 74. He entered the United States Naval Academy at the age of 15, and rose to a lieutenancy in charge of ordnance at Eastern navy yards.

Edward Benedict Cobb, retired lawyer of Washington, D. C., whose family for many years was prominently identified with Tarrytown, N. Y., died today at the Hotel Wendell, where he made his home for eighteen months. His age was 89.

Another American country-the republic of Colombia - followed the United States in calling away the head of its diplomatic mission here when Rafael Jaramillo, newly-appointed Minister, left for Paris tonight without presenting his credentials to Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Army's football team completed its preparations for the Navy game with a signal practice in the field house this afternoon before entraining for the trip to Philadelphia this evening. As the squad rolled away in its big bus toward the West Point station, the entire corps of cadets turned out despite the snowstorm to cheer the players on their way.

Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, chairman of the Temporary National Economic Committee which is investigating monopoly, will head the speakers at the thirtieth annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., to be held next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in the WaldorfAstoria, according to announcement issued for publication today by Paul S. Willis, president of the association.

An increase of $2,339,000 in Dominion Government deposits is revealed in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended on Wednesday. Deposits of chartered banks also were up by $1,607,000 while notes in circulation showed a drop of $3,366,000.

A program designed to encourage the marketing of this season's record orange and grapefruit crops through lowering of packing and handling charges and prices, formulated at a meeting here of representatives of retailers, wholesalers, shippers and growers, was made public today.

Displaying their "streamlined" game at its best, the New York Rangers subdued the Toronto Maple Leafs in the rivals' first clash of the National Hockey League season at Madison Square Garden last night. Lester Patrick's charges placed constant stress on aggressiveness, attacked at every turn, and their willingness to carry the play brought them a 6-to-2 triumph and first place in the circuit.
Winter weather beset most of the nation yesterday and marred New York's Thanksgiving Day celebration. Freezing temperatures and a sleet storm played havoc with land, water and air transportation.

Opening a library in his native town the other day, Poet Laureate Masefield enlarged upon the familiar assumption that motor cars have diminished reading. He praised the grandfathers and great-grandfathers who read so much more than their descendants.
Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, president of Boston University, and Mrs. Arline Woodford McCormick were married today in the Smithfield Avenue Methodist Church, where he was once pastor.

Nebraska tossed into reverse the mightiest challenge Kansas State could muster, on the 6-inch line midway in the final period, and the Cornhuskers came out of their Big Six Conference football game today a 14-to-7 victor.

Seton Hall Prep ended a nine-year touchdown famine by defeating St. Benedict's Prep, 12-0, today in a same that practically assured the South Orange eleven of the North Jersey Group 4 prep school title. It was Seton Hall's first victory and first score against St. Benedict's since 1929.
According to The Daily Telegraph's Johannesburg correspondent, Jews were attacked in Johannesburg tonight after Fascists. had broken up an anti-Fascist demonstration.
The forty Civilian Conservation Corps camps in New England will be used the next six or eight months on fire hazard reduction work in timbered areas which were swept by the hurricane.
To celebrate the holiday, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli's direction, gave one of its most effective concerts of the season at Carnegie Hall last night.
President Roosevelt tonight again implied nis abhorrence of Nazi policies by reading a Hollywood telegram contrasting the state of affairs on Thanksgiving Day in this country and Central Europe.

The strike movement against the decree laws lengthening the forty-hourweek took on large proportions in the North and in the Paris region yesterday and for the first time since 1936 met with forceful measures by the government.
Cotton-mill activity rose last week, countering a seasonal easing, and the adjusted index advanced to 122.2, a "high" since the week ended Sept. 25, 1937.
Bernhard Freiberg, for many years a leader in the distilling industry in the United States, died at his home today. He was 88 years old. Mr.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cornell Dunlap of Elizabeth of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Dunlap, to John Carnes Weeks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Weeks, also of this city.

The new six-story apartment building at 155-65 West Twentieth Street, corner of Seventh Avenue, owned by the Horace Realty Company and containing 120 apartments and seven stores, is now fully rented, according to H. Stanley Hillyer, Inc., agents.

Raw gusts and prickling hail from a gray and stormy sky pelted the fourteenth annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade yesterday afternoon as it beat its way down Central Park West and Broadway, from 106th Street to Herald Square, through a threemile lane of numbed but delighted children and adults.

The 49-year-old Henry Rust, twenty-year veteran of the heel-and-toe wars, yesterday won the twentyeighth annual walk over the ten and one-half mile course from City Hall to Coney Island. The runnerup was Alex Moutsis of the GreekAmerican Hermes A. C., with two St. Anselm's men, George Holland and George La Torre, taking the next two places. Sidney Abramowitz of the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A., last year's winner, finished fifteenth.

A perfect field goal, booted by Charley Burin from the 15-yard line late in the second quarter, enabled Muhlenberg to nose out the fighting Albright Lions, 3 to 0, in today's eighteenth renewal of their Thanksgiving Day classic.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn F. Westervelt, daughter of Mrs. Harry F. Westervelt of Maplewood, formerly of Newark, and the late Mr. Westervelt, to Nelson William Hoff of Boston, son of Mrs. Bertha Hoff of Newark, took place this afternoon in the Clinton Hill Baptist Church, Newark.

Henry Herbert McClure, former general manager of Associated Newspapers, died of heart failure at midnight yesterday in his apartment in the Whist Club, 9 East Sixty-second Street, of which he had been secretary and manager for the last year. He was 64 years old.
More than 12,000 spectators saw West, Orange High School defeat Columbia High School of South Orange and Maplewood today. The score was 6-0.

The Triangular League, composed of Hackley, Riverdale, and Storm King Schools, yesterday announced its annual All-League football team for 1938. Riverdale, circuit champion, placed five of its men, Hackley and Storm King each getting three.

In return for a cheap turkey dinner yesterday, Joseph Burke, 30 years old, told a story to Detective Charles Byrnes of the Ralph Avenue station that landed Burke in jail and may result in his return to a Florida chain gang.
Mrs. Sophia Listemann, art patroness and widow of the violinist, Bernhard Listemann, died today in her home here. She was 86 years old.

Baron Silvercruys, Belgian Minister to Canada, will arrive from Washington today and will be at the Ambassador before returning to Ottawa. Mr. and Mrs. Winston Guest have come from their home in Oyster Bay, L. I., to the Pierre.

More than 2,000 delegates and guests, representing labor unions and other organizations with a membership of 500,000, will attend the opening session of the fourteenth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine at the Hotel Pennsylvania tonight.

With Marty Kalishman's touchdown on a 10-yard pass from Mario Bertucci into the end zone in the second period giving an early lead, the John Adams High School varsity football team blanked an Alumni eleven, 20 to 0, in the annual game played before 4,000 at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.
Miss Alma Homer Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Albert Davis of this city, was married this evening to Robert Glenn Struble of Lratrobe, Pa., son of Mrs. Priscilla Struble.
" Beaten but not disgraced" briefly describes what happened to Columbia in today's football game with Brown, last of the season for both teams and ninth in their series. The score was 36-27.

Presenting more than 18,000 "Thanksgiving greetings," signed individually by workers, to George F. Johnson, chairman of the board of the Endicott-Johnson Corporation, yesterday and announcing that there were "more to come," Charles F. Murphy, chairman of the workers' committee, said:
Lewis Morris, County Attorney, said tonight he did not believe unlawful the activities of a high-school blackshirt organization which, its leaders said, planned a "bloodlessN revolution."
" Gloriana," which under the title of "Elizabeth von England" has been seen abroad, opens tonight at the Little with Blanche Yurka in the role of Queen Elizabeth.
Characters and scenes in children's story books were paraded this morning in Orange, East Orange and Newark before an estimated crowd of 250,000 persons.

The Duchess of Atholl, one of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's bitterest critics in the Conservative party, resigned today as a Member of Parliament for the Kinross and West Perth division of Scotland where she had been repudiated by the local Conservative association last Saturday.

A suit of great interest to Panama Canal employes handling ships has been entered in the District Court by the Compagne Generale Transatlantique against George V. Tawes, the pilot in charge of the freighter Wisconsin when she grounded in the canal in 1935.

In a Thanksgiving Day gesture, Magistrate Myles A. Paige, sitting in West Side Court yesterday, permitted Fred Styles, 55 years old and homeless, to impose his own sentence for vagrancy. Styles, with a glance at the cold, gray skies outdoors, elected to serve ninety days in the workhouse.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Katherine Dove Hoffmeir, daughter of Mrs. Harry J. Hoffmeir of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Mr. Hoffmeir, to Hubert Victor Chain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Hubert Chain of Stockton, Calif.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:
Secretary Morgenthau invited today bids on the Treasury's weekly offering of approximately $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills to be sold on the usual discount basis to the highest bidders.

The present status of the naval armament race between the great maritime nations was disclosed in a series of tables based on ofifcial information and completed within the last week by the Intelligence Division, Office of Naval Operations, of which Rear Admiral Ralston S. Holmes, U. S. N., is the chief.

It is not Vincent de Moro-Giafferi, fiery Corsican barrister, hero of a thousand legal fights, who will defend Herschel Grynszpan for the slaying of Ernst vom Rath, secretary of the German Legation The rumor that M. Giafferi accepted the case is inaccurate.
Princeton's 150-pound football players stepped out in the second half to score four touchdowns and defeat their Rutgers rivals, 27-0, in the league championship game on University Field today.

National seaport facilities on the Canadian Atlantic coast are so inadequate they doubtless were a factor in the Munich accord between Prime Minister Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler, the New Brunswick Government suggested today in a supplementary submission to the Royal Commission on Dominion-Provincial Relations.

Union Hill High School's eleven tied St. Michael's for first place in the North Hudson scholastic football race today by defeating Emerson in their twentieth annual game, 12-0, before a crowd of 10,000.

Several afternoon receptions were given for debutantes yesterday, the holiday being marked also by a number of evening parties, rounding out a gay and festive Thanksgiving Day program of entertaining for the young women who are being introduced to society this season.
In twenty-three hours last night and today there were eleven Rebel air raids on Barcelona, and tonight again at 7 o'clock there was another.

The team of James Cagney and Pat O'Brien, currently appearing on the screens of 375 theatres throughout the country in "Angels With Dirty Faces," will next appear under the Warner Brothers' auspices in "The Battle of City Hall."

Led by Bob Cooke, who tallied three times and assisted in the making of two other goals, the St. Nicholas Hockey Club registered a 7-to-3 triumph over the Boston Olympic Juniors at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The victory was the third in as many starts for the St. Nicks. Cliff Thompson shone for the Boston contingent, making two goals and helping Arra with the other.

Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Henry Armstrong vs. Ceferino Garcia, fifteen rounds, welterweight championship. First bout.8:15 P. M. Broadway Arena, Halsey Street near Broadway, Brooklyn. Amateur bouts.8:30 P. M.

Heavy snow forced cancellation today of the annual holiday football game between Marshall College and West Virginia Wesleyan. Wesleyan returned tonight to Buckhannon. The annual ball was held with Miss Beatrice Hardwick of Huntington, Marshall College senior, the queen.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. announced last night during a radio broadcast that he intended to seek the enactment of legislation at the next session of Congress "to prohibit the arming and drilling of Nazi bands by the German-American Bund."

Arthur G. Mitten, member of a family long prominent in this area, and vice president of the Indiana Historical Society, died at his home last night after a long illness. He was 72 years old, and a native of Brighton, England.

Richard Friedmann, 24 years old, a leather salesman, of 1,911 West Venango Street, Philadelphia, who, according to police, shot and killed his wife, Ruth Myers Friedmann, 24, last Sunday and then shot himself, died today in Atlantic City Hospital.

A driving snowstorm smothered both Virginia MilitaryInstitute and Virginia Tech today in the annual clash that closed the season. A crowd of 16,000 saw the rival elevens count automatic safeties in the first period for a 2-2 tie.

Shipments of pneumatic casings during October are estimated at 4,285,233 units by the Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc. The total represents the largest figure since August, 1937, and a gain of 8.7 per cent over September, this year.

Henry Armstrong, holder of the lightweight and welterweight championships of the world, is prepared to defend his heavier title against the onslaught of Ceferino Garcia of San Francisoo in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Led by Secretary Hull, a delegation representing our Government will sail from New York today to attend the Pan-American Conference at Lima. A year or two ago this might have seemed to be a somewhat cut-and-dried affair. Now, after Munich, after China,

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson has confirmed the foreclosure sale of the Sixth Avenue elevated line on Oct. 13 to a committee of Manhattan Railway bondholders for $12,500,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

Spot cotton was in limited demand here today with prices 3 to 18 points lower. American, strict good middling, was 5.88d; good middling, 5.53d; strict middling, 5.33d; middling, 5.18d; strict low middling, 4.93d; low middling, 4.43d;
Ray Vacca, Manhattan College track star, today won the two-andone-half-mile invitation A. A. U. run, defeating a field of twenty other starters in freezing weather and snow.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's approval of the proposed FrancoGerman peace declaration was seen tonight in the announcement that Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop probably would start "within the next few days for Paris" to sign the agreement.

DeWitt Clinton High's football team had too much manpower for its old foe, the High School of Com.lerce, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. The Red and -Black gridmen humbled the wearers of the Orange and Blue, 18-0, in the thirty-fifth struggle between the schools in a series inaugurated in 1904.
Thomas Jefferson High School, concluding its football season today, came from behind to defeat Gonzaga Higlt School of Washington, D. C., by 32 to 19.

At first glance it might look as if Mayor La Guardia was asking the President and Harry Hopkins for special treatment for New York City with regard to relief. The Mayor believes that this city should be exempted from the nation-wide reduction of WPA rolls which the Administration is now undertaking.

Mrs. Genevieve Macaulay, wife of William J. Babington Macaulay, the Irish Minister to the Holy See, and formerly Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady of Long Island, died this afternoon as the result of a tooth infection. She was 53 years old.

A six-room house on a plot 50 by 100 feet on Wagner Avenue, New Rochelle, N. Y., was bought by Clemens Zucks from Costantino Lerza, the builder, through Edward B. Fernschild, broker, who also sold a five-room house on a plot 50 by 100 feet on the same avenue for Mr. Lerza to William Pekrul.

Mayor La Guardia's explanation of why Park Commissioner Robert Moses's housing conference last Tuesday night was not broadcast over WNYC will be sifted by the City Council committee investigating the city station, according to a statement last night by Robert Daru, committee counsel.

Attorneys for Tom Mooney, convicted of the 1916 San Francisco preparedness day parade bombing, said today that they would apply for an original writ of habeas corpus 'before the Federal Supreme Court in a few days.

The marriage of Mrs. Joan Sanford Brewster of Douglaston, L. I., daughter of Mrs. William H. 'Sanford of Litchfield, to James Bennett Barlow, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John Barlow of Freeport, L. I., formerly of Brooklyn, took place here today at the home of the bride's mother.

West Side High of Newark defeated Irvington High, 12 to 6, in the thirteenth annual game between the teams today before a crowd of 8,000. With the score tied in the third period, Dice intercepted an Irvington pass and ran 15 yards for the deciding touchdown.

A young Sepoy, who was believed to have gone crazy after his month-long fast during the Moslem Ramadan, ran amuk in a hill station at Kanwali early this morning and shot and killed four of his British officers and two Indian officers before he was eventually killed.

Steps to protect private hospitals from the financial burden of carrying patients stricken while visiting the World's Fair next year have been taken by officials of the United Hospital Fund, it became known yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy of New York and Southampton, L. I., gave a large reception with music yesterday afternoon at their home, 24 East Seventy-third Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Cuddihy, to older friends of the family.

Playing in four inches of snow, St. Vincent's College and Western Maryland fought to a scoreless tie in the final football game of the season for both today. A crowd of about 400 saw the contest played in a swirling snowstorm.

The good fortune of Americans to be living in a land still free was stressed in sermons from the city's pulpits yesterday as thousands of New Yorkers gathered for religious services on the 317th anniversary of the first Thanksgiving Day at Plymouth.

A design depicting a section of the globe, with the World's Fair familiar symbols, the trylon and the perisphere in the background, has been selected as the winning poster in a competition conducted by the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.
Hector Bolitho, English biographer, arrived last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. to make a three-month lecture tour on the history of England during the last hundred years.
EIsa Melamet, mezzo-soprano of the Baltimore Opera Society, died today at her home in Mount Washington at the age of 40.

New York feasted yesterday on the traditional Thanksgiving turkey of the Pilgrims. Elaborate dinners were served in homes and restaurants throughout the city, while governmental, social and charitable agencies fed the poor, the ailing and the criminal in welfare institutions, hospitals and jails.

Catomar, a field horse, gained an easy victory over nine other horses in the $2,000 added Thanksgiving Handicap that featured the opening of the racing season at the Fair Grounds today. Mrs. C. C. Winters's 4-year-old filly finished two and a half lengths in front of the favorite,
The following Zist includes the catalogue number, the horse soZd, its color, sex, year foaled, breeding, the purchaser and the price paid:

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., has advised holders of Colombian dollar bonds that on Nov. 11 the Colombian Ambassador to the United States informed the council that his government was prepared to resume negotiations with the council in regard to the dollar debt, and a conference was duly held on Nov. 18 before the departure of the Ambassador for the Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru.

With both sides in the C. I. O. strike at the stock yards looking toward a conference arranged by Federal conciliators for 10 A. M. Saturday, pickets of Stock Handlers Union No. 567 remained at the entrance of the Livestock Exchange and two other corners, but the day passed peacefully.
Taxable gasoline sales in California in October showed an increase of 5.36 per cent over the same month last year and a gain of 6.14 per cent over September.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England, issued today, showed the following changes in pounds sterling:
Higher prices and increased demand for high-grade coffee make the prospects for Costa Rica's harvest hopeful, regardless of the reduced production.

The orange-jerseyed White Plains High School football team added further glory to its record by capturing the intersectional contest with Washington High of South Bend, Ind., 20-0, before 9,000 chilled fans today.
Formation of an advisory council for the Women's Committee for the Jewish Palestine Pavilion at the World's Fair was announced yesterday by Mrs. Israel Goldstein, chairman of the committee.

Kenneth Foster Muldoon, at 540 Prospect Ave. from Trust Company of Larchmont; Stanley Montanye. at 8 Heathcote Ave. from Richard Glennon; Paul Gierasch, at 33 Travers Ave, from Mrs. Tillie Lipowsky, Mamaroneck, N. Y., rentals by Peter C. Doern, Inc. broker.

Responsive to the appeal of Pope Plus XI for the defense of democratic government, leaders of the Catholic Church in the United States announced today a plan for devoting Catholic educational resources to training youth in the principles of democracy and citizenship.

United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy praised democracies' respect for the rights of their minorities tonight and declared that the failure to recognize those rights led "to internal decay, external weakness and discontent and perhaps to civil conflict."

The Adler Shoe Company, which plans to expand its business by adding six to ten stores to its chain during the coming year, has leased a large suite of offices on the tenth floor of the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street.

Yesterday's sensation of the announced intention of the French Government to sign at once with Germany a reciprocal "no war" declaration fell back into its appropriate place today when the British and French Premiers and Foreign Ministers sat down at the Quai d'Orsay to discuss for most of five hours "the preservation and consolidation of peace."

The University of Iowa officially announced the release of the football coach, Irl Tubbs, today as various State papers said Dr. Eddie Anderson of Holy Cross had been signed to replace the former Miami (Fla.) University coach.
Field Marshal Hermann Goering today told thirty-six Nazi district leaders that he would hold them personally responsible for any extra-legal action against Jews.
The namecalling feud between former Governor Eugene Talmadge and Secretary Ickes revived again today. The PWA Administrator recently referred to the Georgian as "the eneciable Mr. Talmadge,"

When the Italian motorship Vulcania arrived yesterday from Mediterranean ports with 705 passengers, Joe Adt, the chief steward, who writes French novels in his spare time, was informed that he had been made Knight of the Crown of Italy.

WE are reviewing thirteen books this morning. Or, rather, a book by thirteen men. The occasion is the appearance of "We Saw It Happen,"* a fine garland--or shall we say mixed grill-of newspaper reminiscences and revelations.
The stock markets here continued quiet today, but the undertone was firm in many groups. This was held to indicate a marking of time until the international situation was clarified.
Prince Johann-Georg of Saxony, brother of the last Saxon King, the late Friederich August III, died last night while visiting his brother-in-law, Duke Albrecht von Wuerttemberg.

The Rev. Katherine Ball, widow of the Rev. Dwight A. Ball, died at her home here late yesterday at the age of 78. She was for a time pastor of the Winter Hill Universalist Church in Somerville, serving in 1926 after her husband's death.
THE DAY OF THE LIBERALS IN SPAIN, by Rhea Marsh Smith. (University of Pennsylvania Press, $3.50.) A study of the evolution of the Constitution of 1931.

Iona School, finishing the football season with six victories and two defeats, turned back Georgetown Prep of Washington, D. C., 26-7, at Haag Field before 3,500 today. Iona has now won seven and tied two games with Georgetown teams.

Governor Lehman and the State of New York were pledged yesterday by Charles Poletti, Lieutenant Governor-elect, to do everything possible to make savings bank life insurance successful when it becomes operative on a State-wide basis on Jan. 3.

Threatened with closing because of financial difficulties, the Talmud Torah of the Sisterhood of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue will be aided tomorrow night by a supper dance at the Hotel WadorfAstoria.

Marlene Dietrich, the film actress, returned on the French liner Normandie yesterday after an absence of six months to do a picture for Columbia and receive final papers granting her American citizenship. She filed first papers nearly five years ago and expects to become a citizen in March.
With an eye on the forthcoming Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, German propaganda continued today to hammer away at the United States.

Charley Boswell warmed the hearts of a shivering, partisan Alabama crowd of 25,000 today by blasting through the Vanderbilt line for vital gains in the Crimson Tide's 7-0 victory in their traditional Thanksgiving Day battle.

Trapshooters of the New York A. C. were handicapped by hail and a high wind at Travers Island yesterday. Considering the conditions, the 91 out of 100 that won the highover-all cup for A. L. Cornwell was excellent.

King Leopold of the Belgians concluded his visit to the Netherlands this afternoon. Immediately after his departure a communique announced Queen Wilhelmina's intention to return the visit early next year.
An alert Miami football team picked up an easy first-quarter touchdown, hurled back two Bucknell challenges and surged on to a 19-0 intersectional victory before a crowd of 12.648 today.

Arthur (Buzzer) Jones, sophomore back, gave the University of Richmond a 10-7 victory over William and Mary today. With the score tied at 7-7 in the second period, Jones kicked a placement from the 22 in the fourth quarter.

Baroness Eugene de Rothschild, the wife of a member of the Viennese banking family, arrived from Paris yesterday on the Normandie. Although born in Philadelphia, the Baroness has not been in this country for more than twenty years. She was formerly Miss Catherine Woolf.
The eleven-car streamlined Gilt Edge Express, New York-Boston flier of the New Haven Railroad, was pulled apart tonight by a sleepy passenger.

Mayor La Guardia disclaimed yesterday any immediate ambition for the Presidency when he made public a letter he had written to Mrs. J. W. Rowe of Millerton, N. Y., who wrote him recently and brought up the question.
To seven Americans, including four university professors and one lawyer, were awarded the merit cross of the Order of the German Eagle today by Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Miss Marion Lesher Everett and Miss Marjorie Vose White were introduced to society together last night at a dinner dance given in the ballroom of the Pierre by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. F. Dewey Everett of Rye, N. Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vose White of this city and Philadelphia.

Villanova's football squad defeated Manhattan yesterday and came to the end of its season's trail in the frozen setting of the Polo Grounds still undefeated to extend a string that started in 1936. The victory, by a margin of 20 to 0, was scored over a game team as well as wind, hail and a smattering of snow.

Edward M. Lane of 25 East 177th Street, the Bronx, a Columbia University law student, received an unexpected Thanksgiving present yesterday when his automobile became the 16,000,000 car to pass over the Henry Hudson Bridge spanning the Harlem River.

Mrs. Katharine A. Evarts of 530 East Eighty-sixth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Evarts, to Peter B. Greenough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry V. Greenough of Brookline, Mass.
Following is the statistical comparison of the Bureau of Labor's statement of October employment and payrolls. The employment index compares

Two field goals kicked from placement by Jimmy Joyce in the last period gave Curtis a surprising 6-6 tie with Ferris High School of Jersey City, N. J., yesterday morning before a crowd of 3,500 at Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S. I. Ferris, heavily favored to win, scored in the second period, Johnny Dzitko throwing a 25-yard touchdown pass to Fred Hencken.

A study of 1,889 parolees by the State Parole Board has revealed that 73 per cent did not go beyond the eighth grade in school and that 55.2 per cent left school before the age of 16, it was reported yesterday by Joseph J. Canavan, chairman of the board.

The annual reports of the Chiefs of the Bureaus of Aeronautics and Engineering of the Navy Department, published today, as well as the report of the Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, published yesterday, show the extreme caution with which naval officials are now releasing information to the public.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Platt Daniels of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Daniels, to William Pierrepont White Jr., son of Mrs. William Pierrepont White of Utica, N. Y., and the late Mr. White.

Pete Olexy of Lansford, Pa., former Penn State luminary and now coach of freshman track, used his long legs to advantage today to annex the twenty-ninth renewal of the Berwick marathon by five yards over Lou Gregory, veteran of the Millrose A. A.
Beer drinkers in this city of 125,000 inhabitants will have only four places to quench their thirst after FebruEY.

The Official Gazette printed today a facsimile of the ballot to be used in supplementary elections Dec. 4, in which newly annexed Sudetenland will vote on parliamentary representatives. The ballot reads:

Trading in wool goods markets this week slowed down as buyers and sellers weighed the possible effects of the numerous reductions on imports of piece goods and semimanufactures effected through the consummation of the Anglo-Ameril can trade pact, according to the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Hillson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Hillson Of Waterville, Me., to Dr. Roy M. Seideman, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. H. Seideman of Sunnyside, Queens, took place here this noon at the Copley Plaza Hotel.
A Congressional committee investigating the nation's phosphate resources heard today that phosphate deposits in the United States are sufficient to last 2,100 years at the present rate of production.

WITH the Armstrong-Garcia bout coming up and the middleweight muddle still on, a kind friend sent along a clipping from a Paris newspaper (Action Frangaise) dealing with these affairs in a delightful way. If those who understand French will kindly close their eyes or at least refrain from shrieking in horror, the following somewhat free translation will be spread on the minutes:
The name-calling contest was resumed today by Representatives Dies of Texas, chairman of the Committee Investigating un-American Activities.
Miss Georgia Anna Ver Planck of White Plains, N. Y., and Richard Duane Humphreys of this place were married at noon here today in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

A shuffled line-up brought the Montreal Canadians their first point of the National Hockey League season tonight as they wobbled, after a brilliant start, to a 2-all overtime draw with the New York Americans.

Mount St. Michael turned back All Hallows, 7 to 6, yesterday on the victor's gridiron as Steve Murphy showed the way. The flashy left halfback heaved a 50-yard aerial to Tom Costello, who galloped ten yards for a touchdown in the opening quarter.

Lieutenant Governor-elect Charles Poletti, himself the object of attack on racial and religious grounds during the last political campaign, urged last night in an address that Americans be militant in defense of civil and religious liberties of all our citizens lest foreign ideals gain a foothold in the United States.

The stock market here was in a dormant state today, this being ascribed largely to the holiday in New York. Only about 210,000 shares were traded, a record low turnover for a full session in recent years.
Harry H. Clutia, president of the Northern Insurance Company of New York, died here today of a heart attack at his home. He was 59 years old.
Bank clearings rose sharply in the week ended on Wednesday, compared with the previous week, which, however, was only five days. The current weekly aggregate is larger than correspondingly in 1937.

The College Point Football Club and the Fort Totten army eleven struggled to a scoreless tie yesterday on the latter's gridiron in Queens in the thirty-fourth meeting between the two old North Shore rivals.
In the snow and slush of a cold Thanksgiving Day, Tennessee's Volunteers flashed a spectacular attack today to overwhelm Kentucky's Wildcats and ascend to the Southeastern Conference championship.
Light sales of wheat for export; estimated at 200,000 bushels, was the only feature in one of the dullest sessions in months in the Winnipeg wheat market.

The League of Red Cross Societies, representing the Red Cross of sixtyone nations, adopted in Paris today a recommendation by Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, that studies be conducted to see what emergency assistance to German refugees might come within the scope of the Red Cross.

Evidence of a growing public desire to see Congress reassert direct control over how and where the Administration spends money for relief and recovery is revealed in a national survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

A contract for the construction of a building to provide ventilation for the Queens Midtown Tunnel has been awarded to the Caulcwell-Wingate Company, which submitted a low bid of $547,400 for the project, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner William H. Friedman of the New York City Tunnel Authority.

Each year, with the approach of the open deer season in the Catskills, hunters seem to feel that they have used their old rifles long enough and that the time has arrived for a new one. Then the letters begin to come in, requesting information on this or that caliber, its muzzle velocity, trajectory, and all the other details.

The old Halsey farm at Remsenburg, L. I., with the old homestead and ninety acres, including a frontage of about 1,000 feet on the Montauk Highway, has been sold through Rensselaer B. Dayton of the firm of Talbot J. Taylor Jr., who is associated with Butler Baldwin, Inc.

Police Headquarters had an unusual visitor yesterday, and he left the police and the reporters who "cover" the building a bit baffled. The visitor deposited a bouquet with the startled patrolman at the information desk and then backed away, bowing.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. James P. Soper Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Stevens Soper, to William Benedict Westcott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Westcott of Barneveld and Utica, N. Y.

Bidding by transatlantic telephone was introduced into the stamp world today when a unique mint block of the 24-cent issue of 1869 with the center inverted was sold to the Y. Souren Company, New York dealers, for the record-breaking price of [Pound]2,500.

An extension of the $400,000 mortgage on Southwick Arms, apartment building at E 187th St and Marion Ave, In the Bronx, has been arranged by the Keevily Corp. The new loan is for five years at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent interest.

Although fresh outbreaks were reported on a 100-mile-long mountain front, Southern California's biggest and most costly forest fires in years were virtually under control tonight, after taxing the resources of authorities of five counties and drawing on the services of 2,000 or more CCC and WPA workers.

One-pound lead sinkers tucked away in Thanksgiving turkeys' heads were among the short-weight violations discovered when food shopping for Thanksgiving dinners was at its height by inspectors of the Bureau of Weights and Measures, Alex Pisciotta, director, said yesterday.
St. Mary's Episcopal Church, 521 West 126th Street, yesterday celebrated the 115th anniversary of the founding of the parish, which claims to be the first in this city to have free pews.

Sewanhaka High School's football team today completed an undefeated season, although tied twice, when it defeated Norwich (N. Y.) High, 13-6, before a shivering crowd of 3,500. It was the first loss for the Norwich Purple Wave in its last fifteen starts over three seasons of play.

Work is being pushed by the Brazilian Government on a big new military barracks at Blumenau, the most predominantly Germanic city in the State of Santa Catharina, one of the two States of Brazil where Germans are strongest.

The Segre bridgehead, about thirty miles north of the Ebro front, has been abandoned by the Spanish Segr Government, which has withdrawn its men and materiel in safety and leisure, the government announced today.

Johnny Adams piloted Routine, 13to-10 favorite in the field of six, home first in the Thanksgiving Handicap, feature at Tanforan today. The winner was timed in 1:44 3-5 for the mile and a sixteenth over a fast track.

The marriage of Miss Adair Diane Abrams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Abrams of 241 Central Park West, formerly of Chicago, to Arnold Herbert Golding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Golding, also of New York, took place last night in the Jade and Basildon Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The sturdy Orioles humiliated the Rovers with a shut-out yesterday afternoon in an Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. A goal by Norman Calladine, spare forward for the visitors crashed into the New York net early in the second period, and the tally was sufficient to enable the Orioles to skate off with a 1-to-O triumph over the primary class of the New York Rangers' hockey development school.

Diplomatic relations between Bolivia and Paraguay will be formally resumed tomorrow when their new Ministers simultaneously present their credentials here and at Asuncion in the presence of the diplomatic representatives of the six American nations that acted as mediators at the Chaco peace conference.

More than 645,000 nunting, fiahing and trapping licenses for 1939 have been shipped to County Clerks throughout the State, the Conservation Department announced today. The licenses will be placed on sale Dec. 1, but may not be used until after Jan. 1. 1939.

In protest against the decree laws of the Daladier government, the administrative commission of the French General Confederation of Labor this evening called a general strike for next Wednesday to last twenty-four hours.
THE snow shovels have been busy clearing the terrain, but it may come on to rain, sleet or snow again and, weather or no, the football games will go on just the same today.

Battle-worn but still defiant, Pittsburgh brought the high tide of football into the Southland today when the Panthers ran through their last workout before tomorrow's engagement with Duke University's undefeated, untied and unscored-on forces.
An unofficial poll of sports editors who report football doings in the farflung Pacific Coast Conference showed today that Southern California was favored to represent the Far West in the Rose Bowl.

Miss Jessie E. Sampter, author and for many years a Zionist worker of international reputation, died yesterday at Givat Brenner, a cooperative agricultural colony in Palestine, of which she was a leading spirit, according to word received here. She was 55 years old.

The secondary schools should provide the child with knowledge and understanding of the world he is entering, and his relationship to others and to the world, Dr. Edmund E. Day, president of Cornell University, told 800 delegates to the fifty-second annual convention of the Middle States' Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here today.
The Chicago Black Hawks announced tonight the outright purchase of Bob Gracie, left wing and center, from' the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League. The price was not disclosed.

Retired Lieutenant Thomas Sullivan Jr., formerly a member of Engine 265, residing at 405 Beach 130th St., Belle Harbor, Queens. died Nov. 24. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 9:30 A. M., Monday, Nov. 28. Interment at St. Mary's Cemetery. Lawrence, L. I. The Deputy Chief of the 13th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

The Federal Reserve Board tonight reported that industrial production continued to increase "sharply" in October and in the first three weeks of November, and reflected principally the larger output of steel and automobiles. Wholesale commodity prices showed little change in this period, the board added, while volume of. employment and national income increased in October.

The Cabinet announced today the postponement of the designation of a new capital for New Guinea pending consideration of the amalgamation of the administrations of Papua, Australian territory and mandated New Guinea.
Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas were down 12 per cent in October as compared with October, 1937, the Commerce Department reported today.

A supper dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm last night at the Pierre for Mrs. Chisholm's niece, Miss Elizabeth K. Hardenbergh, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Hardenbergh Jr.

Reinstatement in jobs with payment of lost compensation for about sixteen months to about 187 employes of the Hamilton-Brown Shoe Company of St. Louis was ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board in decision on one of the major cases brought before it.

W. W. Adam's Pay Rack easily captured the feature event at the Fair Grounds today from a field of ten claimers over a mile and seventy yards. Pay Rack was coupled with Mrs. W. T. Westrope's Miney and Mrs. J, Corozzo's Portunus as the field entry.

Interest in skiing, which had waned the past two years because of mild Winters, was revived yesterday as the recent snowstorm left in its wake sufficient white coverage to provide from fair to excellent ski running in many sections of the East.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Abeel of Hackensack, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Forster Abeel, to Benn Wainwright Jesser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Jesser, also of Hackensack.
A rarity in figure-skating will be one of the features of the Ice Follies Carnival to be presented on the Madison Square Garden ice next Tuesday night and again on the following Saturday.

The worst blizzard in years roared over Canada's Maritime Provinces today, wrecked the imperiled shipping, entirely cut off one Province from ordinary communication with the outside world and left behind a trail of damage and destruction.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday that 7,000 WPA workers would be dropped Thursday on orders from Washington and that a further cut of "many more than 15,000" would have to be made if the city reduced its appropriation for WPA materials and equipment by $400,000 a month.

The report of the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank, made public today, showed a further upturn in Seventh District industrial activity in October and early November. Employment expanded, while trade activities were spotty.
Spanish war fronts were relatively quiet today while government and Insurgent commanders prepared for the next offensive.

Stormy weather and the Chicago live stock handlers' strike had the effects of shortening up the slaughter of most classes in local markets yesterday. Trading was none too active early but salesmen advanced prices sharply on most classes regardless.
The four-story rooming house at 30 West Ninety-sixth Street has been sold by Nellie G. Taylor to James H. Cruikshank, through the Wood, Dolson Company, Inc., brokers.

The $370,000,000 Engineers Public Service Company has filed a plan of integration with the Securities and Exchange Commission in compliance with the requirements of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, it was learned yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. George Wilshire of this city gave a dance preceded by a reception tonight at the New Haven Lawn Club to introduce to society their twin daughters, the Misses Renze and Marjory Wilshire.

Contracts for residential construction in Manhattan during October amounted to $7,611,000, or 345 per cent more than the total for the same month of last year, and 542 per cent more than the September figure, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

John Brannan, 8-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Brannan of 3909 Forty-sixth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, was killed by a Long Island Railroad train while waiting his turn to ride his sled down the embankment along Barnett Avenue east of Forty-eighth Street, Sunnyside, about noon yesterday.

Miss Helen Louise Walker of Pleasantville, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. O. B. Walker, was married to J. Edward Schipper Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Schipper, also of this place, here tonight in the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward J. O'Toole.
A funeral Children of the Americ mass for Mrs. William J. B. Macaulay, American wife of the Irish Minister to the Holy See, has been set for tomorrow.
