The pace of holiday trade here quickened during the week, with lower temperatures spurring the demand for cold weather apparel. Shopping yesterday was brisk and a heavy turnover is expected today.

Because of Thursday's snowstorm, the football game scheduled to have been played today between unbeaten Alexander Hamilton High School and Abraham Lincoln High, Brooklyn rivals, on the latter's gridiron, has been postponed until Monday afternoon at 2:30, it was announced yesterday by Abe Plaut, Lincoln coach.
Park Row, 203-5, 50.6xl17.1xirreg: 205 Park Row Corp to Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn; p m mtg, due Nov. 29, 1943, 4 1/2 per cent; $37,500.

Steady liquidation of holders of December wheat contracts on the Board of Trade here carried prices into new low ground for the movement, and at the low point the December sold within 1/8 cent a bushel of the inside figure of the season.
James H. Jourdan, former president and chairman of the board of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, died yesterday in his apartment-at the Drake Hotel, 440 Park Avenue, at the age of 74.

In order to extend its program of fostering higher quality of construction work in the suburban residential field, the New Jersey division of the Federal Housing Administration is planning to sponsor the organization of "better-building" committees throughout the State.

The Vienna edition of the Deutscher Beobachter reveals today the sentence at Salzburg Monday of two officers of the former Austrian Army. Major Gen. Josef Stochmal was sentenced to eight years at hard labor and Captain Franz Rosenkrans to six years. Lieut. Col. Ferdinand Celar was acquitted.

Guards at the Esterwegen concentration camp in Germany have been instructed to be ruthless to prisoners "whenever it is in theinterest of the Fatherland" and to grab "political and intellectual demagogues by the throat" and silence them, according to Miss Carol King, attorney for the-American Committee for the Protection of the Foreign Born.

Guy Berner of Buffalo, N. Y., empire State junior champion, lost in the final of the twenty-third annual Carolina golf tournament on the Pinehurst No. 2 course today. He bowed to Henry Russell of Miami, former Florida titleholder and winner of the event last year, 5 and 3.

Bronxdale Ave (15-4123), n e cor of Morris Park Ave. 75x101: also Morris Park Ave, n w cor of Fowler Ave. 50x100; Irving Trust Co. trustee, to Henry F. Kroger, 321 E 240th St. Gun Hill Rd (16-4638), s e cor of Hone Ave. 53x138; Hilda B. Fulton to Marcella A. Sheehan, 811 Walton Ave.

Business has improved steadily from June through the first three weeks of November, according to a survey made public yesterday by the statistical division of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Practically speaking, a nation is free in proportion to the intelligence and information possessed by its people. A democracy under a perpetual censorship, or a democracy in which most of the future voters did not go to school, would not long be a democracy.

Protestant and Catholic pastors as well as rabbis will preach sermons tomorrow in behalf of "justice for the Jews," and as on last Sunday there will be special prayers "on behalf of victims of racial and religious persecution."

In line with the penalty measures against German Jews, the Retch-student-leader today ordered that all Jews who during the past years have received special loans or school funds should pay them within two weeks.
The ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton was the setting last night for a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. William Samuel Fairchild to present their daughter, Miss Elvira Gould Fairchild.

The National Park Service estimated today that tourists spent $5,003??,500,000 in the United States last year. New York's share, $846,800,000, was the largest State total, the service reported. California, with $416,800,000 was next, and Pennsylvania, where tourists spent $327,850,000, was third.

Due to the drain which the World's Fair and other functions are and will be putting on the numerical strength of the police, Commissioner Valentine has issued a confidential order, effective Jan. 1. which will transfer all ablebodied men who can be spared from clerical positions to active police duty. it was learned yesterday.

Depositors in savings banks in New York State will share in almost $1,700,000 more Christmas Club distributions this year than they did a year ago, with the total amount for 1938 placed at $23,510,599 for 600,731 members, according to the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Maynard Drury gave a supper dance last night at the Colony Club for their debutante daughter, Miss Innes Kane Drury, who was introduced to older friends of the family at a reception given Nov. 18 by her parents at their home, 969 Fifth Avenue.
Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Foss of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Foss, to James W. Hull, son of Mrs. Edward Boltwood Hull and the late Mr. Hull.

If there was any doubt that Henry Armstrong Is a great little fighting man it was dissipated last night in Madison Square Garden, where the tireless, amazing Negro from California retailed his world welterweight championship by winning a decision against Ceferino Garcia of Los Angeles in fifteen rounds of grueling, furious fighting.

Judge Joseph A. Murphy, one of the nation's best-known turf officials, resigned today as director of racing at the Detroit Fair Grounds, a position he has held since pari-mutuel betting on the horses was legalized in Michigan in 1933.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week aggregates $60,005,701, to be represented by 114 municipalities, cornpared with the revised total of $46,944,542 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $24,898,247.

Miss Mary Pitt Mason, daughter of Mrs. Paul Debevoise. was introduced to society today at a reception at their home here. Mrs. Debevoise and Miss Mason were assisted in receiving by Mrs. Joseph Andrews, mother of Mrs. Debevoise, and by Mrs. George Lewis Schenck of Tenafly, the former Miss Jane Debevoise.

Michael J. Brennan of Louisville, Ky., died ln a local hospital this morning after an emergency operation at the age of 61. He was the recognized Democratic boss of his city. Two days ago he induced his friend, Senator Alben W. Barkley, to come to Hot Springs for a rest before a busy Congressional session.

After a careful analysis of the available statistics, Mr. D. H. Killefer, a New York chemical engineer, reports in Industrial and Engineering Chemistry that within a decade pulp and paper will be removed "from a leading position among the imports to one of far less prominence among the 'also rans.' "

The second round of the 1938 women's field hockey tournament being played on the field of the Merion Cricket Club got under way late this afternoon with only two of the scheduled matches taking place.

William R. White, Superintendent of Banks of New York State, announced yesterday that dividend checks aggregating $3,288,194 were being mailed to 230,000 depositors and creditors of the defunct Bank of United States.

An old hunting companion of ours once remarked, after we had urged a pointing dog forward: "When your nose is as sharp as that dog's you won't need to depend on him; you can scent out your own birds." This pearl of wisdom was brought home to us forcibly bright and early Thanksgiving morning.

Industrial activity in the United Kingdom in the third quarter of this year was 4.3 per cent less than in the second quarter and 10.5 per cent less than in the third quarter of 1937, the Board of Trade announced here today.

After inspecting the academy for the study of aerial warfare at Gatow, near Berlin, Oswald Pirow, South African Defense Minister, drove to the military training camp of Doebertz where he witnessed military exercises carried out by detachments of infantry in combination with other services.

Bishop William T. Manning will dedicate tomorrow morning the recently completed new parish house which has been erected on the site of the former parish house of St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

The major broadcasting organizations moved today a step further toward self-regulation when the National Association of Broadcasters established a committee to study the question and prepare recommendations for presentation to the directors of the association at the next meeting here, Dec. 12-13.

Investigation of the Southern Conference for Human. Welfare by the Dies Committee on un-American activities was sought today by Alabama citizens who demanded that the financial sponsors of the conference be disclosed.

Regent Nicholas Horthy today saw leaders of opposition parties and of Premier Bela Imredy's party but he had not announced his decision late tonight. It was generally believed he would entrust the task of forming a new Cabinet to Mr. Imredy, despite considerable opposition.

Intolerance and the destruction of churches abroad were deplored by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as he hailed the practice of tolerance and church building in this country at ceremonies incident to the laying of the cornerstone of the new Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

Mrs. Clara Cowie Fitzpatrick, active in patriotic societies and in charge of the distribution of good citizenship medals to CCC camps in New Jersey, died yesterday in the Presbyterian Hospital, Newark.

Without comment, the Appellate Division affirmed unanimously yesterday a ruling of Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler holding that investors in 151 issues of Lawyers Mortgage Company guaranteed mortgage certificates are entitled to the full 5 1/2 per cent interest guaranteed to them despite reorganization of the mortgages to provide a lower rate of return to the company, now in liquidation.

Miss Carmen Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Lewis of Houston, Texas, and John Ludlow Gould, son of Mrs. John Warren Du Bois Gould of 145 East Forty-ninth Street, were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church by the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, the rector.

The skiing and skating at Bear Mountain are better now than they have been for at least three years, it was announced yesterday by Major W. A. Welch, chief engineer and general manager of the Palisades Park Commission.

This writer has reason to believe that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain intends to go to Rome to. visit Premier Mussolini early next January. A. surprising fact is that yesterday he did not mention it to the French Ministers during his visit here.
No changes occurred among the leaders in the A. V. R. 0. international chess masters' tournament as a result of tonight's play in the thirteenth and semi-final round.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,088,000 bales, against 1,077,000 a week ago, 1,098,000 two weeks ago, 1,109,000 three weeks ago and 866,000 a year ago; of which American 528,000 bales, against 521,000 a week ago, 534,000 two weeks ago, 536,000 three weeks ago and 434,000 a year ago.
A sitdown strike at the Chevrolet gear and axle plant No. 1, a General Motors Corporation unit, halted operations there and at Plant No. 2 tonight.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation has sold to John Gaines for occupancy the one-family residence at 109 Clinton Avenue, Jersey City, .N. J. This is a seven-room house, on the southwest corner or Sackett Street, with a two-car garage at the rear of the plot.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Flled-By ISAAC CANDIB, salesman, 1,839 Bathgate Ave.-Liabilities, $19,300; no assets except insurance. He formerly conducted business as Candib's Remnant Store and Candib's Outlet Store.

King Saxon, one of America's better-known thoroughbreds, died today. The 7-year-old son of Saxon-Poltova, winner on practically every American track, contracted car fever while being shipped from Tanforan early this week. The fever developed into pneumonia.
President Roosevelt expressed his satisfaction today with business conditions and the re-employment of 900,000 industrial workers since March, as estimated in a report by the Labor. Department.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, total bills discounted and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.
The Rev. Dr. John McElmoyle, a retired Presbyterian minister, died yester- 1911 t day while reading in his home at Wayne. He was 82 years old.

Every member of the New York Stock Exchange, member firm and general partner of a member firm must submit a report before Dec. 10 to that institution covering loans of $2,500 given or received, and outstanding, on Dec. 1.

Premier Angus L. Macdonald of Nova Scotia hailed the reciprocal trade agreements recently made by the United States with Canada and Great Britain as a major stride toward world peace in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Ambassador.

The French liner Normandle is due to sail today for Havre via Southampton. Passengers are Myron C. Taylor, Marcel Bloch, Andre Chapelon, Major Keith Trevor, Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Humphrey, E. P. Taylor, W. T. Baird Jr., Miss Antonie Strassman, Philippe Cotnareanu, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brundage. M. L. Stynan.

The government today issued an ordinance ordering the complete elimination and liquidation of all Jewish retail stores, mail order enterprises, commission houses and handicraft shops by a process analogous to bankruptcy proceedings, which leaves little hope of the former owners having much above their liabilities.

The University of Georgia donned its giddiest garb today to receive its favorite football foe when the vaNguard of the alumni army surged into town to warm up for heavy cheering duty at tomorrow's TechGeorgia game.
The blizzard of Thanksgiving Day arrived in time to prevent the demonstration Winter-wheat field at the New York World's Fair of 1939 from maturing prematurely as a result of the recent mild weather.

The Bank of Montreal in its annual statement, issued yesterday, reported total assets on Oct. 31 of $874,255,828, the largest since 1929. This compared with $829,633,950 a year before. Deposits totaled $763,156.945. an increase of $45,357,839.

The husky members of Emergen cy Squad 8, attached to the Ryer Avenue police station, the Bronx,. cheerfully neglected their gleaming truck yesterday to work on thousands of toys which have been collected by police and firemen in the borough and stored in the chilly garage of the emergency squad.

Lotte Lehmann, the Metropolitan soprano, whose song records were banned last month by Austrian authorities after she applied here for American citizenship, saying she wanted to forget "everything I know about Germany and the rest of Europe," appeared yesterday at the Naturalization Bureau, 641 Washington Street, and received her first papers.

Returning from his visit to the United States this afternoon to receive the warmest welcome ever accorded a Cuban official, Colonel Fulgencio Batista, army Chief of Staff, declared tonight that the reciprocity treaty between Cuba and the United States would be modified in favor of certain Cuban products.

The Maritime Commission announced today that three shipyards had submitted bids for the construction of Diesel-propelled cargo vessels. The vessels, which will have a speed of 16 1/2 knots, will be built to a design known officially as the C-3.

Mrs. Raimund von Hofmannsthal will arrive here from Europe on Thursday and will be at the Gladstone for the Winter. Prince and Princess Alexandre de Caraman-Chimay, who have been at the Pierre, will sail today on the Normandie for St. Jean, Cap Ferrat, France, where they will spend the Winter.

During the week ended Nov. 23 member bank reserve balances increased $91,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $70,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $4,000,000 in Treasury cash,
Luther D. Garrett, president of the National Property Owners League, with offices at 551 Fifth Avenue, New York, died of a heart attack here yesterday at his home. He was 72 years old.
On London's market, where the price of gold measured in British currency is habitually quoted, the price rose yesterday to 149 shillings 101/2 pence per ounce. It was the highest ever reached.
New uncertainties in international affairs, in a world already racked with economic difficulty and the fear of disaster, have added greatly to the problems which require adjustment.
The Bolivian Government proclaimed today a nation-wide state of siege, a form of martial law, after announcing the suppression of a revolt attributed to Leftist agitators.

Recent widespread rumors that leading department stores planned to dismiss a certain number of their employee and give their jobs to Jewish refugees from Germany drew emphatic denials yesterday from leaders in the department store field.

A year ago, at any time during the past ten years, in fact, an announcement that Germany and France had agreed to sign a joint declaration guaranteeing the present frontiers and agreeing to settle future disputes by peaceful consultation would have been hailed as the most sensational piece of news since the armistice.

Mr. Roosevelt's "family" Thanksgiving at the Warm Springs Foundation must be the happiest function of his year. It commemorates not only his own gratitude for recovery from a crippling disease but his constant effort to 'help other sufferers and to stimulate research that will bare the secret of this mysterious malady.
National Interfraternity conference, Hotel Commodere, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: Francis C. Pray, Fred H. Turner, Rolf Haugen, George Tuttle, Professor J. J. Davis.

The marriage of Miss Stephanie Wilder Plum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Haines Plum 2d of this place, to Edward Austin Guthrie Jr., son of Mrs. Guthrie, also of Madison, and the late Mr. Guthrie, took place here today in Grace Episcopal Church.

Holding that the hope for "favors" had nothing to do with the award of an $850,000 insurance account to a firm with which James Roosevelt was connected, a court-appointed auditor today found that a rival insurance broker had not been "wrongfullydeprived" of his commission on the policy.

Sixty men with shovels and brooms worked overtime today at Forbes Field, trying to clear away six inches of snow to make possible the playing tomorrow of the football game between Duquesne and Niagara universities.

The Independent Citizens Committee for the election of Governor Lehman and Charles Poletti reported to the Secretary of State today receipts of $73,242.68 for the November campaign and disbursements of $72,296.15. In addition, commitments of $1,235 were reported, which would leave the committee with a deficit of $288.47.

New bond financing, which was open to participation by the general public,' was restricted to the taxexempt field this week with eleven issues of State and municipal bonds placed on the market for a total of $29,382,735. This compares with a total of $50,839,750 in bonds offered last week, including $40,000,000 Dominion of Canada 3s, and with only $3,315,000 marketed -during this week last year.

Grading in the bond market was highly selective yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Except for a few individual issues, including the local tractions, and some of the foreign dollar loans, which responded to a good demand,

The State Board of Mediation admitted yesterday its inability to settle the lockout or strike of building service employes of the San Remo Apartments, 145 Central Park West. The board intervened at the request of Governor Lehman.

The sixth annual series of Advent "talks" to be given weekdays at noon in historic Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, arranged by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, the rector of Trinity Parish, will begin Monday.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Hospitals Commissioner, said yesterday that the medical boards of various city hospitals had agreed on certain basic requirements that would govern the selection of some 800 internes each year.

" Glorious Morning," Norman MacOwan's play on the conflict between the desire for spirtual freedom and the government in a totalitarian state, opens tonight at the Mansfield under the auspices of Oscar hammerstein, in association with Michael Hillman.

Father Charles E. Coughlin will be unable to comply with Station WMCA's request that he submit advance copies of his Sunday addresses forty-eight hours before the broadcasts, it was reported yesterday at Detroit by his associates.

Miss Mary Talbot Earle, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Pitman Earle Jr. of Brooklyn, was the guest of honor last night at a supper dance given here by her parents in the Persian Room of the Plaza.

Fumes from a furnace entering an unventilated bedroom caused the death here today of Otto C. Nichol, 74, a retired railroad engineer of McKees Rocks, Pa., Dr. Charles E. Long, Erie County medical examiner, said.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has officially advised S. L. Davis, president of Hupp Motor Car Corporation, that a loan of $900,000, the full amount requested, has been formally approved.
Wholesale houses recorded larger individual orders and an increase in the number received for the second successive week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

A request that the public reserve judgment on a complaint against the Transamerica Corporation by the Securities and Exchange Commission because "the motive behind this complaint is one calculated definitely to prejudice Transamerica Corporation in the eyes of the public" was made jointly by A.

The New York City Housing Authority _iled yesterday plans for a unit in the Queensbridge low-rent housing development in Long Island City. The plans provide for four buildings of six stories each, with standards. accommodations for a total of 540 families. The cost was estimated at $1,940,000.

Colonel and Mrs. Nicholas Biddle of Springhead, Jenkintown, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanna Wharton Biddle, to Lewis Johnson, son of Eads Johnson of Morristown, N. J., formerly of New Orleans, and the late Mrs. Alice McClellan Johnson.
Miss Mary A. Hunt, a teacher in the public schools in Yorkville for forty-seven years, died yesterday at her home, 732 Rosedale Avenue, the Bronx, after a month's illness.
Sad evidence that the Westward movement in America has fallen on evil days may be found in an. appeal of the California Citizens Association to stop the drift of penniless families into that State.

Associate Justice Owen D. Roberts of the United States Supreme Court announced here today that legislation was being drafted to take the budget of the Federal courts out of control of the Department of Justice.

Bernard Klein, an assistant deputy United States marshal, who lived at 1,060 Forest Avenue, the Bronx, died. yesterday when he suffered a heart attack on the sidewalk a short distance from his home. He was 54 years old.

Dartmouth and Stanford will meet tomorrow in an intersectional battle which is expected to attract some 25,000 fans. The game will pit a team representative of the finest football in the East against a squad which lost six contests this season. Dartmouth's only defeat in two years was at the hands of Cornell two weeks ago.

Miss Daphne Richardson and Miss Evelyn Lovett were introduced to society together last night at a dinner dance given in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin S. Richardson and Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lovett.

Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 19 were 5 per cent lower than for the same week a year ago and for the four weeks ended Nov. 19 also were 5 per cent below those for the same period in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Harry F. Wolf, national cham'pion, captured the final of the Princeton Club's annual invitation squash tennis tournament by defeating a club'annual, Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A. C., in four games yesterday at the Princeton Club courts.
President Albert Lebrun was greatly interested in the American exhibits at the aviation exhibition that opened here today, with eleven countries represented.

The Rev. and Mrs. John Wells Rahill of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Marion Louise Rahill, to Donald Greame Kelley of this city, which took place on Thanksgiving afternoon in the Church in the Gardens, Forest Hills, of which the bride's father is minister.

Seven lawyers were present to advise Herschel Grynszpan and an eighth excused himself because of another engagement when the 17-year-old youth who shot Ernst vom Rath, Germandiplomat, on Nov. 7 was interrogated in court today.

The thirty-ninth edition of the ArmyNavy football extravaganza will be staged in the huge Municipal Stadium tomorrow amid Wintry scenic effects. Philadelphia tonight was still shoveling itself out of the worst November snowfall in forty years,

Dr. Patrick Watson-Williams, pioneer in rhinolaryngology, died today in Bristol at the age of 77. He was one of the first British physicians to specialize in diseases of the nose and throat and collaborated in this field with the late Sir Felix Samon.

Japan's new "closed door" policy in China has been instrumental in establishing record levels for exports of Japanese beer, the Department of Commerce was informed today by the United States commercial attach in Tokyo.
Saul Baizerman will give a public demonstration of the technique of working in hammered copper in the main entrance hall of the Brooklyn Museum this afternoon at 4 o'clock.

Eugene Fritz McKinley, educator, charter expert, transit company attorney and senior partner here in the law firm of McKinley McKinley, died Wednesday night at the White Plains Hospital at the age of 72. On Oct. 14 he was struck by an

John Ryland, the last original employe of the Empire Theatre, who, during nearly half a century as Negro doorman and later as the unofficial superintendent of the famous Broadway landmark, became acquainted with more glittering stars of the theatrical firmament than the average person can name, died in his sleep early yesterday morning.

Three national veterans' organizations soon will begin a campaign to amend the postal and naturalization laws and obtain passage locally of uniform statutes to combat the propaganda and organizational activities of un-American groups, it was disclosed last night by Roy P. Monahan, past commander of the Disabled War Veterans of America and chairman of the its Americanism Committee, who has been active in the prosecution of the GermanAmerican Bund.
An attempt was made today to assassinate FuHsiao-en, puppet Chinese Mayor of the Japanese-dominated areas of Shanghai. The attack was attributed to local political rivalries.

Members of the American Federation of Labor Livestock Handlers Union voted today to return to work in the Chicago stockyards, which have been tied up for five days by a strike of members of the Congress for Industrial Organization.

Republicans will join with conservative Democrats in the next Congress to amend and revise the farm, labor and social security laws, and greatly curtail expenditures, Charles L. McNary, minority leader in the Senate, predicted today.

With the weather furnishing the chief interest for those who are to play the game and those who are to watch Fordham and New York University finished preparations yesterday for the climax of their football season, the twentieth battle between the pair.

Almost all of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, Madison Avenue between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets, was plunged into darkness about 6:30 o'clock last night as the result of a small fire in a fuse of a maintenance switchboard in the subbasement engine room but there was no excitement. among early arrivals at receptions for three debutantes, diners or guests in the hotel's 300 rooms.

With the winner practically assured of a lucrative post-season bid, unbeaten Boston College and high-ranking Holy Cross, ancient Jesuit rivals who have much in common this season, will wage their thirty-sixth football battle at Fenway Park tomorrow before an expected capacity crowd of 40,000.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the Potash Export Association, Inc., had filed papers with the commission under the Export Trade Act for exporting potash.

The name of one of the saints (St. Genevieve, patroness of Paris) was given to the daughter of Patrick Garvin and Mary Carroll. They could not have dreamed that she would in her maturity have become one of the great patronesses of girlhood in America.

Great Britain's pound sterling again was hammered down yesterday in the foreign exchange market by the pressure of capital in flight from London. It fell to $4.63 5/8 and closed there, off 2 5/8 cents from the previous day.
United States foreign trade in October gained over September, but was well below the figures for October, 1937, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce showed in a survey made public today.

Although Washington officials of the WPA Federal Theatre Project admitted yesterday that the planned presentation in Chicago of Emmet Lavery's play, "Ex-President," had been canceled, Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national head of the project, denied at her home in Poughkeepsie that the script had been on the Chicago division's production schedule.
Record high figures for excess bank reserves both for the country as a whole and for New York City were reported in the Weekly Federal Reserve statements, issued yesterday.

An expedition into a section of Northeastern Burma which never before has been entered by a scientific group, in search of the legendary black barking deer, seen only once by a white man, will leave on the Normandie today under the auspices of the American Museum of Natural History.

The formal recognition by the signatories of the Munich four-power accord of the definitive frontiers of the Czechoslovak State is now assured following the final diplomatic intervention by the Reich and Italy in a socalled Carpatho-Ukraine incident.

The second of the series of triumphs which gave Reuben Fine the record score of 5 1/2 points out of 6 in the early part of the A. V. R. O. international chess tournament was at the expense of Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, who outranked Fine in the last National Chess Federation tournament at Rockefeller Center.

Warner Dare Huntington of New York, head of several large chemical manufacturing plants and widely known for his methods of chemical soil treatments, died at a Stanford hospital today of a brain tumor. His age was 65.
A number of full-floor rentals for business use were reported yesterday by brokers and agents.

A guard of honor from the First King's Regiment mounted Government House today when Rear Admiral Henry E. Lackey on the United States cruiser Omaha called on the Governor General, Sir Edmund Ironside, who later returned the call.

Five German fliers were reported today to be planning to take off Monday on an attempted 9,300-mile non-stop flight from Berlin to Tokyo. Air Ministry officials admitted that preparations were being made for such a flight, but said that the date had not yet been set.

The class of 1939 of City College held its Senior Promenade last night in the Belvedere Room of the Astor. Audrey Christie, featured in "1 Married an Angel," and Charles Walters, who plays opposite Miss Christie, reigned as Prom King and Queen.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota said today that he thought it inadvisable for this country to admit large numbers of Jewish refugees from Germany, regardless of how much Americans sympathize with them.

Ambassador Hugh R. Wilson, who was suddenly recalled from his post in Berlin to report to Secretary of State Cordell Hull and President Roosevelt on the recent excesses in Germany, and perhaps to remain absent from his post for an indefinite time, was closely guarded when he arrived here yesterday on the liner Manhattan.
One jump from an unbeaten season and a possible Rose Bowl invitation, Texas Christian comes to town tomorrow in its same old "just-another-game" mood to play dangerous Southern Methodist.

An insurance broker informed the Westchester County District Attorney's office this afternoon that Eugene Y. Burckhalter, president of the Southern Chemical Corporation, planned less than twenty-four hours before he died to change his $10,000 life insurance policy to include double indemnity in case of death by accident.
Former Governor' Edward C. Stokes, 77. was reported by his physician to be in "fine condition" after undergoing an operation for hernia today at Mercer Hospital.

Of interest to society both in this city and the shore colony of Northern New Jersey was the comingout party shared by Miss Alice Noel Rutgers and Miss Nancy Gill Wylie yesterday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.
The Veterans Administration announced today the transfer of Dr. Herbert Caldwell, chief medical officer at its Batavia (N. Y.) facility, to the Veterans Hospital at Aspinwall, Pa.
France, and Britain will each offer hospitality in their colonies to 10,000 Jewish refugees, it was decided during the French-British conversations here, it was announced tonight.
Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Waite Handy gave a tea dance yesterday in the clubhouse of the Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for their debutante daughter. Miss MarJorie Sloane Handy.
The Public Service Company of Colorado, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Power and Light Company of the Cities Service Company system,

Fire started in Hold 2 of the United States liner Uruguay in the harbor here today but was extinguished by the crew within an hour. Some of the ship's officers said the blaze probably had resulted from carelessly tossed cigarette.

Residential parcels in scattered sections of Brooklyn were traded in the realty transactions reported yesterday. J. Golden, an investor, bought from the Williamsburgh Savings Bank the four-story apartment house on the southwest corner of Nostrand Avenue and Lincoln Road.

Coach Carl Snavely of Cornell has been selected by Coach Van Lynn Waldorf of Northwestern as his aide in tutoring Northern representatives for a "Blue and Gray" all-star football game here Jan. 2, Mayor W. A. Gunter announced today.
Fire, fanned by a strong wind, threatened an entire block of stores and cabarets here today. The flames broke out in the rear of a cafe.
The Pennsylvania Supreme Court today held unconstitutional subpoenas duces tecum issued by the Moomaw legislative commission for M. L. Annenberg, publisher of The Philadelplhia Inuirer. and his son.

The Harvest Frolics, held yesterday afternoon for the third year at the Puppet Center of the Works Progress Administration at 78 Fifth Avenue, drew more than 100 children from various recreational agencies. Several children's groups presented entertainment of different kinds.

The Continental Oil Company has filed an amendment to its registration statement covering issue and sale of $21,071,600 ten-year 2 3/4 per cent convertible debentures, giving the offering price at 100.

An offering of 60,000 shares of $4.50 convertible cumulative preferred stock of the National Gypsum Company will be made on Monday at $100 a share, according to an announcement made yesterday by W. E. Hutton Co. on behalf of the offering group.

The Thanksgiving Day blizzard that blanketed sections of the Eastern United States with snow left a trail of death, damage and discomfort that was as far-reaching as the storm was unexpected and unseasonal, reports indicated yesterday.
The Binghamton Press today carried an authorized announcement of Representative James W. Wadsworth's candidacy for the post of House minority leader.

President Roosevelt issued a proclamation today setting the effective dates of the reciprocal trade agreements signed on Nov. 17 with the United Kingdom, Newfoundland and Britain's colonial empire and with Canada, in accordance with the terms of the agreements.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market this week has been more or less stalled by the British trade treaty, with manufacturers endeavoring to determine their position under the new situation.

Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Nov. 19 exceeded purchases by 27,780 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The value of purchases, however, was $1,100,146 greater than the value of sales.

Trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad Company challenged today the authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission to require certain consideration for labor in proposed railway mergers.

Leaders of Republican and Democratic parties in the Legislature were appointed today a committee to confer with railroad representatives on the question of possible compromise of long-fought tax litigation.
The General Foods Corporation is spending about $15,000,000 on an expansion program now under way, C. M. Chester, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Ino., and its subsidiaries showed an operating profit of $1,929,721, after provision for Federal income taxes, including surtax on undistributed earnings, and after deducting all other charges,
The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today dated Nov. 22:

The Interstate Commerce Commission reopened today the reorganization proceedings for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company and set Dec. 4 for oral argument on a proposal for consolidation of it and the Chicago North Western Railway, made by a protective committee of stockholders of the two roads.

To offset the rising cost of relief to the taxpayers of this city the governing board of the old Emergency Relief Bureau recommended yesterday that the State pay half of all home relief expenditures here.

Mrs. Sally Forrest, 52 years old, and Mrs. S. A. Abel, 50, both of 79 Roxbury Road, Garden City, L. I., escaped injury early tonight when their automobile crashed through a guard rail on Brunswick Pike and landed on its side in the old Delaware and Raritan Canal near here.

Garcia sent a straight left to face. Garcia hooked a right uppercut to the jaw. Garcia drove a long right to the head and held when Armstrong closed in. Armstrong hooked a left to the body. Garcia drove a left and right to the head and Armstrong, seeking to evade the blows, almost slipped to the canvas.

As a result of further weakening of the pound sterling against the dollar, the price of gold rose today 8 1/2d to 149s 10 1/2d, a new official high record, the previous record having been made on March 6, 1935, when the price reached 149s 4d.

Hoch Berg Hiller of Berlin has announced here the engagement of his daughter, Miss Johanna-Louise Hochberg Hiller of this city, to John F. C. Moore, son of William E. F. Moore of Summit, N. J., and the late Mrs. Moore.
An attempt to restore the former cordial relations between Turkey and Russia is believed to be the object of a series of conversations between President Ismet Inonu and V. P. Potemkin,

Brig. Gen. Edward P. Meany, one of the organizers of the American Bell Telephone Company, died here last night. He was 84 years old. General Meany, who had lived here for three years, was counsel for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for many years. He formerly lived in New York.

With horse vans halted in snowdrifts along the roadside and exhibitors far behind their schedule of arrival, it became necessary today to postpone for twenty-four hours the opening of the eighth annual Peekskill horse. show.
A secret ballot among employes of the Star Woolen Company of Cohoes to determine employee representation was ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board.
Distinguished lawyers will pay tribute to the life and achievements of Justice Cardozo at a memorial service to be held tomorrow by the Bar Association of the Supreme Court in the court chamber.
The Candy and Confectionery Workers Union, Local 452, A. F. of L., announced yesterday that it had signed a contract with Loft, Inc.,

Only 5,000 bales of cotton out of a total certificated stock of 45,000 were rendered on first notice day for the December delivery, with an equal amount being similarly turned over in New Orleans, and prices on both exchanges were maintained within a limited range yesterday.

In a three-cornered broadcast celebrating the second anniversary of the signing of the anti-Communist International pact and the first anniversary of Italy's inclusion in the treaty, Joachim von Ribbentrop, Foreign Minister of Germany, scored "the new wave of hate and agitation against Germany in America" as the work of "Jewish-Bolshevist decomposition propaganda" emanating from the Comintern.

Palestine is in a position to receive and assimilate a large number of Jewish refugees from Central and Eastern Europe, according to speakers at the opening session of the fourteenth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine, in the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Robert Downie Kent of 11 Kent Court, prominent in the metropolitan banking field for more than fifty years, died tonight in the Passaic General Hospital at the age of 83. Mr. Kent was stricken by a heart attack last night.
Lord Glanely's Trafalgar tonight was made joint favorite with G. F. Hartigan's Pappageno II at 100 to 9 in the final callover of odds for tomorrow's Manchester November Handicap.
The modern woman paints herself in 1,400 different colors, officials of the Food- and Drug Administration have learned with some amazement.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Claire Sackett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Armstrong Sackett of Richmond Hill, Queens, to Frederick S. Burroughs Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Burroughs of South Orange, N. J., took place last night in the Union Congregational Church, Richmond Hill.

BREWSTER, JAMES N. S. (Nov. 13). Estate. more than $10,000. To Margaret Hoge Brewster, widow. executrix, $5,000, household, personal effects and life estate in residue; Margaret H. Brewster, daughter, 25 5th Ave., $5,000 and remainder in residue.

The 'Coast Guard announced today the following changes in assignments for the week ended Nov. 23: CHIEF WARRANT OFFICERS Chief Bosn. J. A. Johanson, detached the Kimball, effective when directed by commandant the depot: to the Manhattan as commanding officer.

Colonel William H. Rankin, head of William H. Rankin Company, New York advertising agency, has received an award of membership in the Order of Honor and Merit of the Cuban Red Cross, with the degree of officer.
Japan will offer two scholarships each to five Central American republics, according to an announcement by Yoriyoshita Saito, Charge d'Affaires here.

To take effect 8 A.M., Nov. 26. PATROLMEN--Carl Byland, from 7th Preceinct to 20th Precinct; Joseph F. McCarthy from 39th Precinct to 18th Division, designated as third grade detective. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANTS--From commands indicated to 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector, for 15 days, from 8 A. M. Dec. 1: T. P. Bronw .... 46J, J. Fox .....5 Div.
A sudden and violent attack of cardinal asthma caused Pope Pius to faint this morning just as he was about to descend from his private to his official apartments.

Debouncing the "brutalities" in Germany as "a war upon humanity," Mayor F. H. La Guardia of New York called upon Americans today "not merely to voice their abhorrence but volunteer their support to a program for thne rescue of the victims of Nazi oppression."

With the onset of snow and cold weather, the Greater New York Safety Council warned automobile drivers yesterday to guard against carbon monoxide poisoning by "periodical inspection and proper maintenance" of their cars. These are the only mean of prevention, it was said.

ALTMAN, GEORGE J. (Sept. 27. 1937). Gross assets. $126,541; net. $93.698. To Hungarian Society of New York and Eliabeth Deak. $500 each; brother, David Altman, $3,000; wife, Jane Altman, $3,000 and life income from residuary estate; sons, Jerome and Jack Altman, and daughter, Beatrice A. Simon, $3,000 each and one-third remainder interest each in residuary estate.
The New York Americans will hold forth in Madison Square Garden tonight when they oppose the world champion Chicago Black Hawks ina National Hockey League game.

Fires in the Santa Monica and San Bernardino Mountains continued as serious menaces to property today after having caused possibly $5,000,000 damage already in destruction of homes and watershed protective growth.

The Postoffice Department's income from first-day philatelic sales of the thirty-two stamps of the "Presidential," or new regular series begun in April, will probably exceed $600,000 before the Philatelic Agency and the Washington Postoffice close their windows on Dec. 8, the date for release of the final two denominations.

THE Battle of Munich was lost upon the playing fields of Eton. European democracy has suffered a setback it is not enormously likely to recover under the leadership of M. Daladier and the Man With the Umbrella.

Lindley G. Beckworth, 25-year-old Texan, will be the youngest House member in recent years. The election of Mr. Beckworth and several other relatively youthful newcomers in both Houses emphasized what veteran capital employes called a trend toward younger members in Congress.

Hester St, 58-62, Margod Realty Corp to Moe Shastock, 286 South 2d St, Brooklynt mtg $33,500. Park Row, 203-205, Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn to 205 Park Row Corp, 205 Park Row; purchase money mtg $37,500 ($45).

As a prelude to the traditional N. Y. U.-Fordham football game this afternoon, 2,000 students, guests, university administrators, faculty members and alumni of New York University attended the third annual all-university frolic held last night at the WaldorfAstoria.

Mayor La Guardia's first consideration with yesterday's snowstorm was the fear that it was the forerunner of others that would delay the opening of the New York World's Fair beyond the scheduled date of April 30, 1939.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn will be decorated with the Commenda of the Royal Order of the Crown of Italy, conferred by King Victor Emmanuel, at a dinner in honor of the Bishop at 7 o'clock Sunday night, Dec. 11, at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
Auburn and Florida, two Southeastern Conference football Teams which have reached top shape after in-and-out seasons, clash here tomorrow.
In order that they might recover from the bruises and shock of their 7-7 battle with the Dodgers on Thanksgiving Day, Coach Steve Owen yesterday decreed a three-day rest period for his Giants.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Concerning John Egan's recent communication explaining Pitt's defeat by Carnegie, may I point out that he was guilty of a fundamental error in causality when he attributed the loss not to Carnegie but to the great warriors of Fordham, who, he claimed, made Pitt a very tired ball club.

Racing over a snow-covered racing strip that looked more like a plowed field, D. A. Wood's heavily backed Infidox scored a popular triumph in the mile and a sixteenth of the Mayor Howard W. Jackson Purse today.
November retail linage figures will show a sharp improvement over those for October as a result of the cold snap and will come very close to those of last year, according to estimates here yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Elliott Brown, Professor of Practical Theology and Human Relations at Oberlin College and brother-in-law of Dr. Robert A. Millikan, president of the California Institute of Technology, died here today after four weeks' illness of a coronary thrombosis. Dr. Brown . would have been 65 years old on Dec. 17.

The marriage of Miss Janet Weed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Spencer Weed of Morristown, to Charles Goetz of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Goetz of Racine, Wis., took place this afternoon in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Short Hills.
The Mendham-Chester Tribune, local weekly, appeared on the streets more than three hours late this afternoon, and many of its readers who had been grumbling about the delay wished they hadn't.

Ward's Automotive Reports today estimated the current week's output of the automobile factories at 84,930 cars and trucks, explaining the drop from last week's 96,735 units as due to the Thanksgiving Day holiday, which put most of the industry on a four-day basis.

The volume of awards for engineering construction this week is $49,970,000, or 31 per cent lower than in the corresponding week of last year, when $72,481,000 was reported, the Engineering News-Record reports.
The Foreign Office spokesman said today that Japan did not contemplate a second communication to the United States on the American protest of Oct. 6 against discrimination in China.

A special meeting of stockholders of the National City Bank of Cleveland will be held this morning at 10 o'clock, at Cleveland, to vote on a proposed increase in the institution's capital through the sale, at $20 each, of 75,000 shares to stockholders.
Five talented skiers from Ostmark, the Austrian section of Germany, are due to arrive here today aboard the S. S. Deutschland of the Hamburg-American Line.

Buyers showed unexpected interest in Confederate provisional stamps at the third day's sale of the Crocker collection at the Harmer Rooke Co. auction rooms today, with the result that the total mounted to [Pound]26,000.
With the publication of a royal proclamation in tonight's London Gazette releasing the last of the naval and air force reservists called up, the September crisis is now officially ended.

Miss Margaret Lewis Byrd of Winchester, Va., was introduced to Richmond society at a ball at the Commonwealth Club here tonight by her father, Thomas Bolling Byrd, and her grandmother, Mrs. Richard Evelyn Byrd.

Miss Virginia Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guthrie Shaw of Three Gardens, Rye, N. Y., and Eau Gallie, Fla., was introduced to society last night at a Tyrolean dinner dance given for her by her parents in the Turn Verein Hall at 152 East Eighty-fifth Street.

Miss Helen Holmes, educator, vice president of the Smith College alumnae and former hostess at the International House, Geneva, Switzerland died here yesterday, Her age was 73, Services will be held tomorrow at the First Parish Church.
Stuart Chase has written a foreword for "America Begins Again," by Katherine Glover, which Whittlesey House will publish in January.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson was accused today by the special October grand jury of having borrowed personally over a twenty-six-month period a total of $53,750 from persons "who might be interested in having him pull his punches."

For the eighth consecutive -year the scholastic standing of fraternity men throughout the country has been higher than that of non-fraternity men, it was reported yesterday at the thirtieth annual session of the National Interfraternity Conference at the Hotel Commodore.
The United States delegation to the eighth Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, headed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull, sailed late yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Clara.

Seven Fordham players and three from City College have agreed to participate in the benefit game at Ebbets Field on Dec. 3 between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Metropolitan All-Stars, the Dodgers' office announced last night. These, with seven from Manhattan who already had signified their willing. ness to play, brings the All-Star, squad total to seventeen.

Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., a member of America's Ryder Cup team, and Ben Hogan, sensational 26-year-old newcomer to the pro ranks, paced the field today in the opening round of the $5,000 Columbia-Ridgewood open golf tourna ment, each carding a sizzling 67 over the par-71 layout.

Cornelius M. Daily, vice president of the Missouri Engineering Company of St. Louis, in charge of the local water works improvement project, died here today of a heart attack at the home of his son, Austin. His age was 62.

Paramount will launch its jitterbug epic, "Some Like It Hot," with Gene Krupa, within the next two weeks. Today Bob Hope and Shirley Ross were assigned to the picture to care for its romantic implications. Kurt Neumann will direct, with the screen play by Lewis Fos ter.

Cleaveland Putnam's 3-year-old colt Wing and Wing finished in front of Pala Chief and Triplane in an allowance race for 3-year-olds and upward at Tanforan today. The winner, a 4-to-1 shot, negotiated the mile and seventy yards in 1:434-5 over a fast track.

Louisiana State and Tulane meet here tomorrow in the thirtysixth renewal of their traditional rivalry. Tulane's Green Wave is the favorite to down the Bayou Bengals and avenge the victories L. S. U. has won in the last three games of the series.
The State Banking Department approved today a move of the branch office of the Bank Polska Opieki, Spolka Akcyjna, Warsaw, Poland,
For the last seven years Ferdinand Bruckner's "Elizabeth von England" has been popping up here and there throughout the Western world and promising to perch In New York at any moment.
Neville Chamberlain's appeasement policies are broad enough to embrace Europe and Asia and modest enough to take in the

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have noted with great interest the attention given to the trade agreements with Great Britain and Canada, and I could not but be reminded of the scriptural phrase, "that which was sown in weakness."
Each of the following regular army officers, on duty at the station listed above their names, is designated as a member of the corps of instructors for the command and general staff extension course:
The government's plan for RFC loans to finance the power part of the proposed national defense program is acceptable to Wendell L. Willkie personally, but is being opposed by leading banks,

" Our whole political machinery," wrote Lord Balfour, "presupposes a people so fundamentally at one that they can safely afford to bicker." The remark was true not only of the British Government of which it was made but of democracy everywhere.

The opera was Italian, and the principals were American. With Helen Jepson, Richard Crooks and Lawrence Tibbett as the headline singers, the Metropolitan Opera had a homebred cast in "Traviata" last night.

Today's eents: "Orfeo ed Euridice" (revival), 2 P. M., and "Lohengrin," 8 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House; "Hansel and Gretel," Charlotte Lund Opera Company, Heckscher Theatre, 11 A. M.; Myra Hess, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Mychajlo Holynskij, Ukrainian tenor, Town Hall, 8:15 P. M.; third Annual Music Festival of the National Labor Committee for Palestine, Carnegie Hall, 8:15 P. M.
Charles Kaiser, operator, has purchased from the Harlem Savings Bank the four-story apartment house at 1,112 Simpson Street, on the southeast corner of 169th Street, the Bronx.

Plans of the Intergovernmental Committee for Political Refugees for settlement of Jewish and other racial and religious groups wishing to leave Germany because of persecution, do not contemplate a change in existing immigration laws, Myron C. Taylor, vice chairman of the committee, said last night in a radio broadcast on the eve of sailing for London to attend a meeting of the committee's officers.
The Reichsbank's. statement as of Nov. 24 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The delegation of the United States sails to take part in the eighth International Conference of American States at Lima at a time when a friendly and dispassionate approach to international problems is essential.

Joseph R. Embery, a retired attorney, died today at his home here at the age of 70. He was born in this city and was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Law School. After an association with E. Spencer Miller he became a member of the law firm of Embery, .Outterson Fuges, retiring from practice three years ago.

Miss Gail Francisco, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Wellington P. Francisco of Orange, was married this evening in Central Brick Presbyterian Church, East Orange, to Alan Condit Hood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred R. Hood of East Orange. The bride's father, associate pastor of the church, escorted his daughter and performed the ceremony.

George E. Nostrand, member of an old Brooklyn family, died on Thursday at his home, 1,831 Eightysecond Street. His age was 77. He was a lifelong resident of the New Utrecht section and a grandson of John Englebert Lott, owner of the old Lott homestead in New Utrecht.
Realty activity in Queens was featured yesterday by sales and leases of business properties and the purchase of a plot In Woodmere for a new residence.
Former Crown Prince Wilhelm of Germany arrived here today for a Hohenzollern family dinner on the birthday of the former Kaiser's youngest stepdaughter, Henrietta.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn will order liquidation of New York Investors, Inc., a holding company with forty-two subsidiaries, unless a plan of reorganization is submitted to the court by next Friday, he announced yesterday. Interests close to the company and its creditors said it was "very remote" that a plan of reorganization would be offered.

American professors on whom Adolf Hitler conferred decorations were asked by telegraph by THE NEW YORK TIMES whether they would accept. The following reply is from Professor Geiser, retired from the faculty of Oberlin College:

A special meeting of Loblaw Groceterias, Inc., has been called for Dec. 14 at Buffalo, N. Y., to consider plans of reorganization, under which a new company of similar name will be formed with an authorized capital of 400,000 shares of $6 par value. Of the total, 327,489 shares will be offered in exchange for present preferred and common shares.

The United States Embassy in Berlin was instructed by the State Department today to send another note to the German Foreign Office insisting upon assumption by the German Government of Austrian Government obligations to this country.

The annual obest fund drive at Swarthmore College is being held earlier this year in order to use some of the funds collected in collaboration with the drive to finance refugee students at Swarthmore or other colleges in this country.
Harry C. Kent, president of the Kent Plumbing Supply Corporation here, dealer in wholesale building materials, died last night in the New Rochelle Hospital at the age of 60.
Lumber production increased last week, countering a nominal seasonal easing, and the adjusted index rose to 70.4 from 65.8. The figure was 65.2 for the week ended Nov. 20, 1937.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today called a hearing for Jan, 16 to determine whether the $2-parvalue capital stock of the Transamerica Corporation, West Coast investment and holding company,' should be suspended for not to exceed twelve months or withdrawn from registration on the New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco Stock Exchanges.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, issued in the form of a general press release today a second letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, reiterating his denial that he had ever at any time said, in any form:
A new record in excess bank reserves, after having failed to appear when it was most expected a month ago, popped up rather unexpectedly in the Federal Reserve statement this week.

The press here, commenting on the withdrawal of Rafael Garamillo, the Colombian Minister, from Berlin before he had presented his credentials, declares diplomatic guarantees and privileges work both ways. However,

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Fifty executives of Butler Brothers, from its distributing points in seven cities, will attend a four-day conference beginning Monday in Chicago to work out details of a program to afford increased profits to independent grocery retailers who cooperate with Butler Brothers.

A well-informed source gave information today that the Greek Government had issued an order to the newspapers that they were not to publish any further news regarding the anti-Jewish activities in Germany unless it came from German sourers.

A selected squad of metropolitan college football stars will meet the Brooklyn Dodgers professional eleven at Ebbets Field next Saturday in a post-season benefit game sponsored by the sports committee for Catholic. Jewish and Protestant refugees from Germany, Austria and Czechoslovakia.

Miss Rosita Perez of San Juan, P. R., who has been speaking English for less than ten years, surprised the College of New Rochelle, here, by spelling down the rest of her class and thereby winning a place on the junior spelling team.
The Stoneleigh Playhouse, now in the final stages of construction, will be opened by Stoneleigh College next week-end with a student program Saturday evening and a guest program Sunday evening.

Membership in the Economic Club of New York this year is the largest since the depression set in, Robert E. Ely, director of the club, announced yesterday when invitations to the 126th dinner, to be held in the Hotel Astor on Dec. 12, were sent to members.

Several promotions have just been made in the Hudson-Harlem Valley Title and Mortgage Company of White Plains by the board of directors. Archie E. Prout, formerly assistant secretary and treasurer, has been advanced to the office of secretary.

FROM 10 in the morning till 5 in the afternoon (with the usual French respite from 12 to 2 for rest and refreshment) a thin and. intermittent trickle of people can be seen these days entering the sumptuous pile of the Opera from a side portal on the Rue Halevy.

THE last frontier of the United States has been located in many places. Mr. Neuberger places it in the Pacific Northwest and borrows his title from a phrase used by President Roosevelt in his speech at the Grand Coulee Dam.

REPEAL RECORD: Barring a few days, five years have passed since the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. That stocks of whisky are now catching up with demand after the long drought the Bureau of Internal Revenue indicated last week.

Acting on its promise to increase France's military air strength, the Daladier government proposed today for Parliamentary approval a 1939 air force budget higher by 766,000,000 francs (about $19,992,600) than that of last year.

The Chicago Black Hawks, holders of the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world that goes with it, will cross sticks with the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today amendment of its rules governing the filing and approval of surety bonds in the case of motor carriers to exclude surety bonds with individual sureties. As amended the regulation reads:

ABRAHAMS-STICH-Mr. and Mrs. Morris Stich, Forest Hills, announce engagement of daughter, Stella, to Norman S. Abrahams, son Mrs. Laura Abrahams of Brooklyn. APPEL-KOZINN-Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Kozinn of 1,490 Jesup Ave., New York, announce the engagement of their daughter, Gladys, to Mr. Robert J. Appel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph 0. Appel of West Brighton, S. I.

MR. BODLEY, author of an excellent biography of George Rogers Clark, has here presented another segment from his extensive researches into the history of the early West, and one by no means as ambitious as its title would seem to indicate.

Fresh winds off the Pacific, tonight whipped new brush fires over the crest of the Santa Monica Mountains across Mulholland Highway to endanger the Encino area of San Fernando Valley, where many motion-picture notables reside.

MICHAEL CURTIZ, who probably has committed more Goldwynisms than Mr. Goldwyn himself, including the famous command "Bring on the empty horses!" when he wanted some unsaddled steeds for an Indian skirmish scene, was being quoted again last week.

St. Anselm College authorities today let it be understood they would be favorable to a poet season football game for the undefeated Hawks. The team won six games and tied one, a score less deadlock with Boston College last week.
Colonel John Stoughton Dennis, former head of the department of colonization and immigration of the Canadian Pacific Railway, died here today after an illness of several weeks. His age was 82.

IT is the occasion to speak of an event which may have more to do with the artistic future of America than any one of the activities of those leading singers, virtuosi and conductors whose doings delight the public and customarily burnish material for a column or two of Sunday commentary.

Merchandising trends, producers relations with consumers and with wholesalers and retailers, and the probable trends of Federal and State legislation will be considered at the thirtieth annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, opening tomorrow for three days at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

THE fear that in trying to cure our economic ills we may be applying remedies the effect of which is to make full recovery impossible has come to disturb the peace of mind of the specialist who considers economic problems from the longrun point of view.

ALTHOUGH the public generally is under the impression that the government, through its air-mail payments to airlines, is heavily subsidizing commercial aviation in this country, it is only necessary to read the accounting statements of the air carriers and hear their arguments against the methods heretofore employed in fixing air-mail rates to suspect that some of the air-transport companies, rather than Uncle Sam, have been playing Santa Claus.

Financing for improvements to small dwellings and for new structures has formed the bulk of the Finsurance on property repair loans by the Federal Housing Administration under Title 1 of the National Housing Act, according to Stewart McDonald administrator. On Nov.

THREE events make for divisions in the dance audience this evening when Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their company make their first apeparance of the season at the Guild Theatre, Angna Enters bows in at the Alvin, and Martha Graham gives a solo recital at the Y. M. H. A.

A large volume of orders for holiday merchandise arrived in the New York wholesale market last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. "Gifts and toiletries were in great demand," the report continues. "Housewares departments purchased goods for January sales. Formal apparel and gift lingerie sold well.
One person was killed and a number wounded tonight as an estimated 20,000 persons joined in demonstrations for the return of Bulgarian territory ceded by a post-war pact to Yugoslavia and Rumania.

The engagement of Miss Virginia Mary Dunne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Dunne of Yonkers and Long Beach, L. I., to Raymond James Ruckel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Ruckel of this city, has been announced by her parents.

Southeastward from the Nazi's mecca of Munich, by way of Austria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Rumania, is the Russian Ukraine--the ultimate goal of German Imperialism. The name has leaped out of the news of the Czechoslovak settlement,
Having attained a position of power in which it feels able to defy world opinion, the National Socialist regime has embarked on what it considers its "final and decisive battle with world Jewry."
The University of Manitoba will open a series of intercollegiate hockey contests with Canadian and United States colleges here Dec. 10, opposing Gonzaga University of Spokane, Wash.

As if to show contempt for grocery store package knots, the Port Washington Y. C. is setting about to teach all hands, men, women and children, how to fashion some nautical hitches. Beginning on Saturday evening at 7 o'clock there will be a weekly series of talks on seamanship. Club members may even bring landluber friends.
STIRRING events have been taking place in Turkey-that crossroads between Europe and Asia which seems bound to play a strategic part in the economic and political future of two continents.
Almost without exception Canadian newspapers and other mouthpieces of public opinion have either praised the new Canadian-American trade treaty or reserved judgment on it.
THREE of the nation's major airlines have just signed tenyear leases with New York City for hangar space at North Beach Municipal Airport, which WPA workers have been building for the past year.

IN 1857 New York was, in the stern words of Harper's Weekly, "a huge, semi-barbarous metropolis, simply not governed at all"; the Territorial Capitol of Kansas was a six-room log house, exposed to blizzards as to the turmoil of the slavery question, and the hoop skirt was fighting the battle for fashion's favor which it was soon to win.

With the city still struggling to clear away the Thanksgiving Day blizzard, another snowstorm began late last night and raged early this morning, threatening New York with as deep a fall as the one on Thursday night, eight inches.

Plans for expanding the Middlebury College Playhouse as a center for cultural and educational activities as well as dramatic entertainment were announced this week by Professor V. Spencer Goodreds, head of the Department of Drama and Speech.

Jewish young people of America must pool their energies in a "fight for democracy" and promote Zionism as part of that program, four speakers agreed during a panel discussion here today at the annual convention of Junior Hadassah, the young women's Zionist organization of America.
For many years the Newark Kennel Club held its annual exhibition the day following Westminster's big show in Madison Square Garden.

More than $500,000,000 of the $3,100,000,000 loaned by the Home Owners Loan Corporation from June, 1933, to June, 1936, to nearly 1,000,000 persons without private credit who faced the loss of their homes will have been repaid as of Dec. 1, Charles A. Jones, general manager of the corporation, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Olga Sanderson Dietz of New York, Palm Beach and Greenwich, widow of John E. Dietz of the R. E. Dietz Lantern Company, died here suddenly early today. She had been a Summer resident here for twentyfive years and had planned to leave Tuesday to spend the Winter at Palm Beach, as had been her custom.

Dr. Henry Schultz, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago, his wife and their two small daughters were killed in a spectacular automobile accident sixty miles east of here late today. The daughters were Ruth, 15 years old, and Jean, 12. Professor Schultz was about 45, and his wife a few years younger.

APECULIAR manifestation of the longing for badges of gentility was the craze for Literary Annuals which reigned in England with such virulence for some thirty years and spread across the Atlantic to the United States.

A suggestion that each executive of combed cotton mills accept a 50 per cent salary cut, to be restored if and when the individual mills begin to show a profit, was offered last week by a cotton goods trader as a means of bringing combed goods prices back to profit levels.

Twenty-two games have been listed for the Waynesburg College basketball team, which will open its season against Carnegie Tech at Pittsburgh Dec. 3 and close with Geneva March 8. The schedule calls for twelve games at home.
THE term, "finance capitalism" has rather suddenly become almost a household expression, but books on the subject are few and far between.
Campaign expenditures were reported to the Secretary of State today by several groups that worked for the election of candidates in the elections early this month.

THAT Professor Ely, in writing this book, has been "a man to double purpose bound" is sufficiently apparent from its title and subtitle; but the rest of the Shakespeare quotation does not apply, for he does ample justice to both his purposes.
OSCAR WILDE. By Leslie and Sewell Stokes. 150 pages. New York: Random House. $2. Text of the drama now on view at the Fulton Theatre.

A STRANGER CAME TO PORT. By Max Miller. 210 pp. New York: Reynal Hitchcock. $2. MAX MILLER'S gntle and melancholy fables--"I Cover the Waterfront," "He Went Away for a While." "The Beginning of a Mortal." "Mexico Around Me"--are said to be great favorites among men of both the cynical and the hard-boiled varieties who carry te wistful small boy somewhere inside them.

The National Republican Club adopted a resolution yesterday condemning the "relapse into barbarism of the present rulers in Germany." "In common with American citizens of every class and race," the resolution said, "the National Republican Club condemns in the strongest possible terms the relapse into barbarism of the present rulers of Germany.
