Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman is honorary chairman of the annual sale of articles made by the blind, opening tomorrow at 601 Fifth Avenue and continuing to Christmas Eve. Churchwomen of various faiths will be in charge of the shop, with Catholic women directing sales tomorrow under the supervision of Miss Ada Clarke.

A suit for $5,000,000 damages under the Securities Exchange Act alleging misrepresentation in sale of stocks and securities of the Alleghany Corporation-the former Van Sweringen railway empire-was filed in United States District Court here today against George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., glass manufacturer and financier.

ALEXANDER--Mr. and Mrs. Murray Alexander (nee Hermine Goldman) joyfully announce the arrival of Jerrold's sister, Nona Elise, at Bensonhurst Maternity Hospital, Nov. 23. ALTMANN--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph, announce birth of a daughter, Nov. 25, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital.

Taxpayers of Westchester County are protesting with such vigor that the Board of County Supervisors has decided to conduct its budget hearing on Monday night in the Little Theatre of the County Center, seating 800 persons, instead of the Supervisors' chambers in the County Office Building, which seat 200 persons.

TWO celebrated exiles in this country, Professor Albert Einstein and Dr. Thomas Mann, have written prefaces to the program of the impending Book Auction Dinner to be held the evening of Dec. 8 at the Hotel Plaza for the benefit of the Joint Distribution Committee and the American Committee for German Christian refugees.

The Associated Dailies of Florida, an organization of newspaper editors and publishers, voted today to ask the Legislature to enact a press confidence law which would protect reporters from punishment for declining to reveal the source of their news.

Ramon Suero, head of Suero y Cia. of Havana, has announced the formation of a -new steamship company to operate ships to New York from Havana and Cuban outports. The line will be called the Cia. de Navigatione de Cuba.

So much has changed in the situation of Europe and the world since the last time any British Prime Minister came to Paris that it was almost impossible this week, looking back to recognize it as the same place it was when David Lloyd George used to come popping back and forward across the Channel to conferences.

HERE at last is a study of William Blake which has the dignity of presenting his philosophy without reference to his personal life. It is made on the basis of the HellenisticChristian mystical tradition, but covers the psychology of man under the aspect of a universal humanity--identical for Blake with the cosmos.

ON New Year's Eve, 1896, David Fairchild, a young botanist, was sitting in a cabin of a ship off the island of Penang listening to an older man, Barbour Lathrop, who was laying before him his ideas of what a botanist could do

Establishment of a board by the Department of Agriculture to advise makers of food, drugs and cosmetics on proper labels and labeling, and permission for producers to file guarantees covering representations made about their products with the department in Washington, were urged yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association in a brief filed with the department in connection with proposed regulations under the provisions of the new Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.

Julius Henry Cohen, general counsel of the Port of New York Authority, will be guest of honor and speaker at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York on next Thursday noon.

The lowest annual death rate for the millions of industrial policy holders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in the United States and Canada will occur in 1938, unless some widespread epidemic or unexpected catastrophe should intervene between now and the end of the year, statisticians of the company predicted yesterday.
Turning a switch this evening, the Minister of Government, General Antonio Rodriguez, provided Lima with 100 per cent automatic telephone service with all its suburbs.
Mrs. Mary Amanda Knapp, oldest member of the North Greenwich Congregational Church and widow of Charles E. Knapp, died here today at the home of her sister, Mrs.

AS a matter of fact there isn't a pearl in every oyster in the Frank Sullivan collection, at least not a pearl of the first water. For you're bound to find favorites in the group with a wicked luster which strike fire from your own particular sense of humor.

Fifteen undergraduates reported to Coach Ed Bullock this week for initial practice for Williams' sixmatch wrestling campaign. Along with Captain Spud Jones, lightweight star, four regulars from last year's team, Wheelock, Potter, Dalzell and Morse, probably will gain berths again this year.

Of the representative works by composers of four nations, played by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night at Radio City, Martucci's First symphony and Liszt's symphonic poem "Orpheus" were of special interest, since they rarely come to performance hereabouts.
Hugh R. Wilson, American Ambassador to Germany, will remain in Washington indefinitely as consultant on relations between the two countries, Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, announced today.

Miss Irene van Feggelen, crack Dutch girl swimmer, bettered the world 100-meter back-stroke record today for the third time in two weeks. Her time was 1:12.9, a tenth of a second better than the mark she established last Sunday.
Preliminary figures of the leading wholesale dry goods houses here indicate that October and November sales exceeded a year ago, considerably in unit sales and moderately in dollar volume.

AUGUSTA, Ga.-Augusta's 1939 Winter golf season will begin here Friday, Dec. 2, first day of the Augusta open tournament, sponsored by the Junior Chamber of Commerce. The $,,000 event is expected to attract virtually all leading professional stars and a number of outstanding amateurs.
Maybe men get less fun out of owning small possessions than women do. At any rate, they are the problem people on most Christmas lists.

Fifteen games will be played by the Drew University basketball team, which will open its season on Friday at Madison, N. J., against Webb. The final game will also be at home with Bard providing the opposition on March 4.

A proposal that administration of relief be turned over to bi-partisan State boards came from a group of Democratic Senators today amid reports that President Roosevelt might ask changes in the present relief machinery.

The Washington Huskies crushed the Washingtbn State College Cougars, 26 to 0, before 17,000 fans today. The annual "big game" between the two old State rivals closed a hit-and-miss season for Washington and left Washington State undisputed cellar champion of the Pacific Coast Conference.
Ben A. Kennan, executive director of the Jewish Sanitarium and Hospital for Chronic Diseases, died at that institution yesterday following a brief illness of pneumonia. He was 34 years old.
ONCE again a Taft will be in Washington. When Congress convenes in January Robert A. Taft, son of a former President, will take his seat at the Capitol as United States Senator from Ohio.

Miss Ellen Irma McGeehan, daughter of Mrs. Edward A. McGeehan of Montclair and the late Mr. McGeehan, was married here this morning in the Immaculate Conception Church to James Richard Phelan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Patrick Pheian of Caldwell. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Edward M. Farrell, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

North Carolina is sponsoring an experimental innovation in vocational education through the planned early opening of the Robin Hood Farms, near Pinehurst, where boys and girls from every county in the State will receive free training in practical farming and domestic science in an effort to give worthy but underprivileged youths an opportunity to become self-supporting citizens.
Charles E. (Bucky) Miller, who recently succeeded Jack Ogden as head coach of the University of Baltimore basketball team, will lead the squad through a twenty-three game schedule this season.
Albert Emile Sorel, author of more than twenty novels and histories, including "Charlotte Corday" and "Louis de Prusse," died today in his Paris home. He was 6Z years old.

Sixteen selected senior engineers are devoting a fourth of their study to social relations as the first step in a program which will ultimately require every student in Carnegie Institute of Technology's College of Engineering to include a broad scope of social sciences in his study list.

The immovable object turned the tables on the irresistible force today as Duke's unbeaten, untied and unscored on team defeated the Pittsburgh Panthers, 7-0, on the snowcovered gridiron of Duke Stadium before the largest crowd in Dixie's football history.

Fully half of the program of the thirty-second annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents, to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday and Friday, will be devoted to points of view from outside the life insurance sphere, according to the final roster of speakers announced yesterday by the association.

Stuart Taylor Danforth, formerly professor of zoology at the University of Puerto Rico for twelve years, died today at the Congregational parsonage. Illness compelled Professor Danforth to take a leave of absence.

A naval airplane crashed soon atter its take-off from Biggs Field army airport at Fort Bliss today, killing two men and slightly injuring a third. The dead are Aviation Cadet L. T. Rowe, the pilot, of San Diego, and Machinist's Mate C. K. Wise of San Diego.

The extent to which the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation has carried forward its principal function of strengthening the confidence of the public in savings and loan associations is set forth in a statement issued yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, quoting statistics announced by Nugent Fallon, general manager of the corporation.

Through a lively last-period scoring barrage the New York Rovers yesterday continued their mastery over the Hershey Cubs, bagging a 3-to-2 verdict in the main attraction of a matinee amateur hockey double-header in Madison Square Garden.

CHINESE civilization, Mrs. Lewis reminds her readers in the introduction to one of her charming story-portraits, has been built through most of its history "on the social structure of four main classes:
Franklin and Marshall College, announces a plan to finance four major social affairs for the student body by means of a fee of $2.50, to be collected with the payment of other fees and tuition.
The first state to enact an unemployment compensation law was Wisconsin, in 1932. New York followed in April, 1935, with its New York Unemployment Insurance Law. In August, 1935,

Criticizing the personnel and methods of the Probation Department of the Kings County Court as inadequate and inefficient, the Division of Probation of the State Deapartment of Correction, in a report made public yesterday, recommended a general reorganization and a house-cleaning.

The departure of the American delegation to the Pan-American Conference at Lima lacked drama. Secretary Hull, former Governor Landon and the other members of the party are not going to Lima to change the map or to stave off a war.

Twenty-two Williams varsity hockey candidates reported to Coach Snively this week for earlyseason workouts in preparation for the four-day Lake Placid practice trip which will open the 1938-39 Purple season Dec. 26.
Fordham won the annual Battle of the Bronx yesterday by a convincing margin but the yearly struggle among rival students to abduct the other school's mascot again resulted in a Mexican standoff.

Miss Rebeca Trucco, daughter of Don Manuel Trucco, Chilean Ambassador, was married this afternoon to Robert Almy Knowlton, son of Mrs. Richard C. Burles on of Honolulu Hawaii, and the late Frank W. Knowlton, in a ceremony at the Chilean Embassy.
Field Marshal August von Mackensen, according to well informed circles, has petitioned Chancellor Hitler requesting the speedy release of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, held in a concentration camp.
ODD stories of native life in the Australian territory of Papua, which is the southeastern part of New Guinea, are contained in the latest report of Lieut. Gov. Sir Hubert Murray.

Holding that the recent elections indicate clearly that the majority of Americans deem the New Deal's planned economy a failure, the National Republican Club called upon the Republican party yesterday to stand for a program of action based on common sense and equal justice and to develop a leader capable of expounding such a program.

The Wage and Hour Law has been in effect for one month. A considerable degree of progress has been achieved in its application, though nothing definitive can yet be said about its possible future workings.

To keep pace with the needs of its pupils the New York City public school system must drastically reorganize the secondary education program and substitute vocational and industrial schools for the existing academic courses, Associate Superintendent Edward Mandel said yesterday. He proposed a 75-25 ratio in favor of vocational schools.

Demands by New York and possibly other cities that the State shoulder a greater share of the local relief burden may provide a major conflict between Democratic Governor Lehman and the Republicancontrolled 1939 Legislature.

Henry Armstrong, who successfully defended his welterweight championship of the world against Ceferino Garcia in Madison Square Garden on Friday night, visited the New York Hippodrome yesterday with his manager, Eddie Mead, and pocketed a check for $25,423 for his battle against the Filipino challenger.

A survey in New York State of thirty-five high schools and eighteen colleges, selected for the most part because of their interest in guidance, reveals that there is a great variety in the kind of activity pursued in both types of institutions, according to Dean Edward S. Jones of the University of Buffalo.
Ernest R. Nichols, former president of the Kansas State College at Manhattan, Kan., died today of injuries suffered on Sept. 12 when he fell from chair. He was 80 years old.
A large new restaurant, to be known as White Turkey Town House, will be opened tomorrow in 1 University Place, twenty-onestory apartment building.

AS a prelude to the annual Winter tournament of the American Contract Bridge League which opens at Cleveland on Tuesday, Oswald Jacoby and Charles Lochridge of New York will play an exhibition match against three strong Cleveland players.

The second annual bazaar in aid of the Memorial House of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square, will be held at the church next Thursday and Friday. Mrs. Charles S. McVeigh and Mrs. Reginald Auchincloss are co-chairmen of the general committee for the benefit and Mrs. Ingersoll Townsend is executive secretary.

FUNDAMENTALLY-although Agnes Sligh Turnbull may have reasons of her own for taking exception to this-"Remember the End" is a success story. It is, indeed, that perennial success story which has always seemed part of the traditional American way of life.

There are no ten easy rules for a happy married life, Dr. Janet Nelson believes to the great disappointment of the students in her classes on home relationships at the Y. W. C. A. However, once they have accepted this fact, she finds that the young business girls with
The basketball five of the New York Stock Exchange last night defeated Columbus Council of the Knights of Columbus, 44 to 38, on the latter's court. At half time the winners were ahead by 20 to 15.
Oklahoma's Sooners, unbeaten champions of the Big Six, traveled the air lanes when their ground attack bogged down and vanquished the Oklahoma Aggies, 19 to 0, before 9,000 fans today.
THE PROTESTANT CRUSADE. 18001860. By Ray Allen Billington. 8vo. New York: The Macmillan Company. A study of the origins of American nativism.

Tulane's fast football team trounced Louisiana State today, 14 to 0, before 40,000 fans in a rough game that caused general fighting among fans and players. The Tigers could do nothing to stop Tulane's shifty halfbacks, Bob Kellog and Fred Cassibry, who scored a touchdown apiece.

C. M. Chester, general chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, announced last night a total of $777,126 had been raised to date in the sixtieth annual appeal in behalf of ninety-two voluntary hospitals and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn.

Temporary convertible 3 per cent debentures of the Phillips Petroleum Company, due on Sept. 1, 1948, may be exchanged for definitive debentures at the Manufacturers Trust Company, trustee, 45 Beaver Street.

The "consumer approach to quality control" of products will be demonstrated at a luncheon to be held under the auspices of the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, Inc., at its new warehouse at 135 Kent Street on Wednesday.

Censorship of student publications is no problem at Syracuse University, which next week observes its first "Publications Week," also marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of The Daily Orange, undergraduate newspaper.

Two meetings that will command the attention of the skiing world are slated to be held next week-end. The National Ski Association will hold its annual convention at Milwaukee, Wis., Saturday and Sunday with many important items due for discussion and legislation.
Members of the Junior Guild of the Church of the Heavenly Rest will give a bridge party and tea on Tuesday afternoon at the church to augment the rector's discretionary fund.

Here are some needles in the haystack of 102,000 football fans at the Army-Navy game: Hardiest Rooter-Daniel W. Armstrong, former Naval Academy man from New York and Hampton, Va., braved freezing weather without hat or overcoat and in silk socks and a medium-weight suit.

More than 125 undergraduates are active staff members on the eleven student periodicals published at Fordham College. This number will be increased materially before the year is out, as several of the annuals are not in full gear yet and more staff members will be added as deadlines approach.
Poetically inclined students of Smith College have an opportunity to express their talent through an organization which has been in existence on the campus since the Fall of 1933.

Immediate must be the aid for German Jewish refugees and immediate in effect must be the programs of resettlement, so "that the concentration camps do not become the tomb of thousands of innocent and helpless captives," said Rabbi Louis I. Newman to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eightythird Street, yesterday.
A new pavilion on Bailey's Beach to take the place of the one wrecked by the hurricane of Sept. 21 will be ready for the opening of the bathing season next Summer.

Retail volume in the Ninth District last week was definitely better than the previous week and showed increases running up to 10 per cent over 1937. Snow flurries, colder weather and promotion merchandising were responsible. Christmas shopping was definitely under way, with department stores reporting interest in gift goods starting before the Thanksgiving holiday.

A gale that sometimes reached a velocity of seventy miles an hour struck the British Isles today. Two cyclists were killed when blasts of wind sent them crashing into motor cars. A thousand sheep were drowned at Rockliffe, a Cumberland seaside village, when a tidal wave in Solway Firth flooded their pasture.

GARDINER. Mont. - Long noted as popular headquarters for big-game hunters, this little town at the northern entrance to Yellowstone Park is looking forward to playing host this Winter to an equally large number of tourists bent on stalking game with cameras.

Only seventeen gunners reported at Travers Island yesterday for the weekly shoot of the New York A. C. Cold weather and a high wind provided difficult conditions. The best work was done by Roger Fawcett, who won the high-over-all-scratch cup with 93 out of a possible 100.

The Brooklyn College five scored an easy victory over its alumni team last night, winning by a score of 41 to 12. The Kingsmen ran up a 21-to-1 lead at half-time. Ender at center topped the scorers with 7 points.
One in four of the 1,000 students at Colgate University has scholarship help of some kind. During the last year $57,280 was disbursed for scholarships or prizes.

Democratic control of extra-curricular activities at Hunter College is exercised by ninety-four class officers, recently elected at the college, according to an announcement by Jean Goodman, president of the student council.

Christmas packages seem scarcely in the Yuletide spirit unless they bear the familiar Christmas seals issued to finance the war on tuberculosis. For thirty-two years the double-barred red cross has had its place on Christmas mail as well as on home deliveries made direct by Santa Claus.

The following Foreign Service changes since Nov. 4 were announced by the State Department today: Cecil Wayne Gray of Bristol, Tenn., now serving in Department of State, designated second secretary of embassy at Lima.

An English laboratory is a feature of the revised system of instruction in English at St. Lawrence University. Started this Fall, the laboratory is proving successful in aiding stundents in writing, especially in the field of essays.

When Georgia emphatically rejected President Roosevelt's "purge" plea of last August and returned Walter F. George to the Senate, it was common talk among politicians that the State and the Administration of Governor E. D. Rivers would quickly feel the effects of White House displeasure. TAKE the B. M. T. Brighton Beach express to Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn; change there for a local train to Avenue M, descend at that point and you will find yourself within a stone's throw of a little bit of Hollywood.

Charges that the Japanese are sponsoring the narcotics traffic in Nanking were made today by Dr. M. S. Bates, American educator connected with the University of Nanking, in a report supplied to the local press.

WHEN Andre Maurois chose Francois-Rene de Chateaubriand as his latest subject for biographical portrayal, he was thinking not only of Chateaubriand but also of Byron, who "was so often a copy" of the French original;

When President Roosevelt began his two-week stay at his "other home" atop Pine Mountain here with the statement that he had come back to the Infantile Paralysis Foundation "to play," he meant exactly what he said.

The Maritime Commission stated today that it had investigated reports of a fire in a hold of the United States liner.Uruguay while in port at Portof-Spain, Trinidad, and had found that no such fire had occurred.
The Duquesne Dukes brightened a disappointing football season today by defeating favored Niagara University, 15-6. The game closed the season for both schools.
The 3-year-old Cherokee colt, Mrs: J. A. Nix's Woodsaw, raced to a hardearned victory in the Dixie Handicap, feature of the Fair Grounds program, today before a crowd of 10,000.

THE second week of the opera season will feature the debuts of Erich Witte, German lyric tenor, and Alessio De Paolis, Italian lyric tenor. The first "opera concert" of the season will take place tonight, at which time Leonard Warren will make his Metropolitan debut.

Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, headed the group, largely composed of persons active in magazine and newspaper syndicate work, which served as pallbearers yesterday at the funeral of Henry Herbert McClure, former general manager of Associated Newspapers.

Miss Martha Turner Healy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Scott Healy of Garden City, was married here this afternoon in St. Joseph's Church to Byron King Callan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Callan, also of this place. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward C. McManus.
The markets last week were far more concerned with the shadow of Europe's troubled state of affairs than with the substance of the business improvement in the United States.

Rushed through the City Council by a vote of 19 to 2, an ordinance levying a 11/2 per cent tax on all incomes in excess of $1,000 earned in Phliadelphia was signed today by Mayor S. Davis Wilson to help balance the 1939 city budget. The Mayor, its original sponsor, declared it was an "equitable levy" favoring the small wage earner.

Transit unification negotiations with the B. M. T. interests are much nearer to completion than those with representatives of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company, according to a statement issued yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.
Some 102,000 involuntary Eskimos left the warmth and comfort of their igloos and submitted to the Arctic breezes that swept across the refrigerated Municipal Stadium today.

With strong teams from the New York A. C., the Millrose A. A. and Manhattan College and a small but select coterie of individual stars in the field, the forty-second annual National A. A. U. senior crosscountry championship will be held today in Newark's Branch Brook Park under the auspices of the Good Counsel Holy Name Soclety.

ONE of the most important exhibitions of the year will open on Dec. 2 at 4 P. M., in the Academy Room of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fiftyseventh Street, when the Oval Table Soiety will present the pictorial section of the eighty-third annual international exhibition of the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain.

A study of South American educational institutions will be made by the Rev. John F. O'Hara, president of the University of Notre Dame, who is a member of the American delegation to the inter-American congress opening in Lima, Peru, Dec. 9.

Joe Wiener and Stanley Galowin, the defending champions, came through the opening round of the fourth annual pro-amateur squash racquets doubles at the Heights Casino yesterday by winning in straight games from James Reid Jr. and Horatio Gray of the Crescent A. C.

The program just announced by the Catholic hierarchy to educate 3,000,000 parochial students in "enlightened American citizenship" was suggested today by the Most Rev. John T. McNicholas, Archbishop of Cincinnati, as an example by which other religious denominations might unite "in concrete action against a common enemy, subversiveness."

Liquidation developed again today in December wheat on the Board of Trade here, and while the selling was orderly, the near-by future declined 1/2 cent at the extreme and sold at 61 cents a bushel, a new low level for the season. The price, in fact,

Surrogate James A. Foley granted yesterday a fee allowance of $40,000 to Max D. Steuer, as counsel for Mrs. Rosalie Bloomingdale, first wife of Irving I. Bloomingdale, New York merchant, and her son, Donald Bloomingdale, in litigation over the settlement of her interest in the estate of her former husband, who died in London in October, 1929.

Manuel Quezon, starting the last half of his six-year term as President of the Philippine Commonwealth, told his revamped Cabinet at its first meeting today that he was "determined more than ever to give the Philippines not only an efficient government, but a government that will be just to all and one, which will promote rapidly and soundly the enduring interests of our nation."

President Roosevelt was selected as their "ideal man" by boys and girls of the Junior Inspectors Club of the Department of Sanitation, according to answers to a questionnaire submitted to several hundred older members of the organization. The results were made public yesterday by Matthew Napear, organizer and commander-in-chief.

FIRST NIGHT: Backstage at the Metropolitan Opera House last Monday evening stood General Manager Edward Johnson. In the auditorium, where the seats and boxes were slowly filling with New York society, the women dressed in ermine and satin, diamonds glittering in many an upswept hairdo, the lights had been dimmed.

Plans for extensive research over a five-year period to determine broad, long-range principles of public housing in relation to city planning have been started at Massachusetts Institute of Technology by the department of City Planning.

Influenced by further weakness in the pound sterling, by disturbing developments in France and by an easiness in the stock market, the Cotton Exchange tended to softness during most of yesterday's session, leaving the list with net changes ranging from a gain of 1 to a loss of 2 points.

The volume of bonds called last week for redemption before maturity was smaller than in the preceding week. Except for one industrial prepayment and several lots of Kentucky bridge bonds, the announcements were mostly for miscellaneous small refundings. Payment dates of the new redemptions were about equally divided for December and January.

Chapter advisers are needed in campus fraternities to inspire and guide the undergraduates, speakers at the closing session of the thirtieth annual National Interfraternity Conference at the Hotel Commodore declared yesterday.

One of the largest charity parties of the early Winter will be the annual Miami-Biltmore Fashion Show and Ball, which will take place on Dec. 16 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Sponsored by Colonel Henry L. Doherty, the event is given annually in behalf of the Goddard Neighborhood Center to assist that settlement in raising its yearly budget for the maintenance of its extensive program of welfare, health and educational work.

The Works Progress Administration stated today that employment on projects declined 14,043 during the week ending Saturday. Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator, said the reduction was accomplished primarily by not replacing those who left WPA employment.

The races at Bowie were called off today for the first time in fourteen years because of the frozen condition of the racing strip, and the Union Station here became a rendezvous for racing fans and horsemen headed toward and away from the race track. Trains from New York.
Department store sales in Boston for the week ended Nov. 19 were 7 per cent over the corresponding week of last year. More seasonable weather caused a substantially larger movement in Winter apparel.
The Interstate Commerce Commission has issued an order fixing $22,966, for the time being, as a maximum allowance to be made by the Federal judge out of the estate of the Old Colony Railroad Company,

The final selection of the complete student east for "The Knight of the Burning Pestle," the Fall production of Wigs and Cues, Barnard College dramatic society, was announced yesterday by Gertrude Smith, president of the club.

Florida's football team struck today with all the fury stored up through a disappointing season and downed Auburn, 9 to 7, in a major upset. A blocked punt, converted into a fourth-period safety, offset Auburn's superior offensive showing. The 'Gators held a defensive edge throughout.

Spurning Hollywood's four-figure weekly pay checks, five top-flight American dramatists pooled their talents last Spring to "do something about the American theatre." Confounding Broadway skeptics, the Playwrights' Producing Company already has scored two of the biggest successes of the new season, with three. more plays in preparation.

In this article a writer who has spent many years in Germany and has been a keen observer of events there attempts to explain recent occurrences in the Reich. For obvious reasons it is published anonymously.

FASTER schectules, new trains and the inauguration by one road of all electric power on its crack train will feature New York to Florida service this Winter. Full of optimism for the coming season, the Seaboard, Atlantic Coast Line and Florida East Coast have made careful plans for handling a large volume of traffic to the "American Riviera."
Every year college enrollment figures show that more and more young people are going in for higher education. With their increase in numbers they become more nearly a cross section of the population.

THE reason for speaking about this volume to the layman is that, although it is written in a language which is very specialized, the layman ought to know something about it. Its subject matter is importtant-a defense of theory in medicine. Medicine and its progress is every one's concern.

Despite the repercussions likely to result from the seizure by the Mexican Government of foreign-owned Oil properties, the international oil situation, which for years has been in a more or less unsettled State because of the large volume of oil from. Russia seeking an outlet and the resulting sporadic price wars, appears to have reached a period of reasonable stability.
Clarke G. Dailey, chairman of the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards, expressed yesterday both praise and criticism of Park Commissioner Moses's housing program as outlined last week.
Holy Cross toppled Boston College from the ranks of the unbeaten Eastern football teams in a setting of snow at Fenway Park before 35,000 today.
More than five Americans in every ten spent money in at least one game of chance this year, and most of them freely admit they have come out on the losing end.
The first group of home owners in the University Manor development at Union Turnpike and Utopia Parkway, Jamaica, L. I., moved into their new dwellings last week.
A final-hour flurry of selling which few groups were able to resist brought about yesterday the sharpest reaction that the market has experienced in the present movement.

Edward Kelly, 18-year-old senior at the Irvington High School who was injured Thanksgiving Day in a football game between his school team and the West Side High School eleven of Newark, died tonight at the Presbyterian Hospital, Newark, after an emergency operation.

Ideal weather prevailed throughout the Pacific Coast and pre-Thanksgiving sales were higher than last year. In San Francisco a number of independent stores reported volume as much as 30 per cent over a year ago. Special sales contributed to these figures in some instances.

An increasing attention to mental aspects of disease in general medical practice has resulted in a rapid growth in the number of patients in the city's general hospitals transferred to the Bellevue Hospital psychiatric division,

Italian press today set about the task of creating the "racial consciousness of the Italian people." It took its cue from Achille Starace, secretary general of the Fascist party, who in a speech to a group of Fascist officials urged that no compassion

Early Christmas promotions and seasonable weather boosted retail trade above both last week and a year ago. On a day-to-day basis, retail sales were about 10 per cent above a week earlier, but on account of the Thankgiving holiday, the week's total was off about 10 per cent.

Members of the D. A. R. chapters of Greater New York will hold a joint meeting tomorrow at 11 A. M. at the Museum of the City of New York to hear reports of some of the seventeen schools supported by the organization.
DROP your eyes for a moment and up pops a drama critic with a new book. It is literary magic. Only a month or two ago Burns Mantle was squiring two obese volumes about this and that in the drama.
Bond prices drifted irregularly lower in a listless week-end trading session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with little interest being shown in the day's proceedings.

Stanford's red Indians, defeated six Aimes and favored to take another picking, provided a stunning climax to their otherwise dull football season today with a 23-to-13 victory never the green-jerseyed warriors-of Dartmouth.

An auction sale of English and French furniture, rugs, chinaware, and other art objects held yesterday and Friday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 742 Fifth Avenue, brought a total of $32,166 for the 460 items offered, officials of the gallery announced.

Miss Margaret M. Hanna, one of the few women in the Foreign Service and a veteran official of the State Deapartment, will retire on Dec. 31, it was announced today. She has been serving as consul at Geneva since July 14, 1937.

Retail sales in this district last week showed a decrease of 6 per cent from last year, little more than the difference in prices. More seasonable weather, increased employment and larger payrolls are being reflected in local retail circles.

William J. Monaghan, vice president of the Pioneer Ice Cream Division of the Borden Company and former president of the Association of Ice Cream Manufacturers of New York State, died yesterday morning in his home, 70-10 Seminole Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, after a long illness. He was 41 years old.
Pensioned On his own application, to take effect Midnight, Nov. 23: PATROLMAN--Francis Farrelly, Borough Headquarters Squad Manhattan, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 28, 1903.

Miss Julia Berwind, one of the founders of the Lisa Day Nursery, is taking an active part in the arrangements for the forthcoming benefit in the interest of the nursery. Proceeds from a demonstration of the game jai-alai, to be held on Wednesday evening at the Hippodrome, will aid the work of the beneficiary in caring for children whose mothers are employed.

The House Investigating Committee expects to complete its inquiry into graft and corruption charges against the Earle Administration with a report to -the lower branch of the Legislature Tuesday or Wednesday night.

The William Randolph Hearst colelection, part three, comprising books in fine bindings, autograph manuscripts and letters, and original drawings, will be offered at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

The spectacle of a large band of Washington women massed before the White House singing Joyce Kilmer's "Trees," and of a few of the same band chained to trees in Potomac Park, in what appears to have been a futile protest against the proposed Thomas Jefferson Memorial, engaged the startled attention of Washington during the past week.

The decision of the Finnish Government to dissolve the Fascist party has been carried out without any disturbance. It has received strong support in Parliament and from public opinion since Minister of the Interior Urho Kekkonen exposed the party's activities against the democratic regime.
WITH the completion of the Volcan Highway route, now under construction, sight-seers in Mexico will be able to penetrate historic country hitherto lacking good roads.

THE picture at the top of this page, showing an artist's con ception of the new $10,000,000 airport now being built 'in Washington, must seem like a dream to pilots who have flown into and out of the nation's capital. Such an airport has been needed for years.
The Philadelphia Maritime Exchange was notified today by the S. Gate Nelson Corporation that it would use this city as a "preferred" grainloading port for the Oriole Lines.

The Social Security Board offered today to consider resuming grants to Ohio for old-age pensions if the officials of that State would cooperate with the board's representative in preparing a "factual statement" describing the present operation of the State's pension plan.

A stone Colonial residence of ten rooms and three baths at the northwest corner of Ogden Road and Brite Avenue, Fox Meadow, Scarsdale, has been sold by the Estates of Cotswold, Inc., M. S. Severino, president, to John B. Glenn, president of the Pan-American Trust Company, according to Fox Meadow Estates.

TELEVISION images are being sprayed across the New York area from the new ?? shaped radiators, the stream lined design of which marks a revolutionary advance in telecasting from the Empire State Building' dome.
THE most arresting aspect of this book is its attempt to reconcile a broadly behavioristic and academic approach to the study of human conflict with psychoanalytic theory.
The Conservatives have held their west Lewisham seat in the latest test in Great Britain's "little general election."

King Carol II of Rumania, whose regime some writers have called a royal dictatorship masked by a cabinet council, has given his nation "a new establishment attuned to the needs of the day, has unshackled the creative powers of the people," Radu Irimescu, Rumanian Minister to the United States, declared last night.
Most important of all questions before property owners and wage earners is that of economy in government, declares A. Pearson Hoover, president of the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation.

The Maryland State Tax Commission approved yesterday an agreement among the Carroll County Water Company, the Bel Air Water Light Company and the Ellicott City Water Company to be merged Into the Maryland Water Works Company, according to an announcement made here by the Associated Gas and Electric Company.
AT the moment Metro is displaying considerable courage. Whether this bravery will last until the preview of "Idiot's Delight" is something no one yet knows.
THOMAS T. K. FRELINGHUYSEN, who is exhibiting sculpture this week at Marie Sternher's, has obviously enjoyed his work. He has experimented boldly with form and color in the figures and portraits.

New Yorker, n. An inhabitant of New York City; distinguished for skill in crossing streets against traffic without injury. The average New Yorker fits this definition. He likes to jay-walk and does. The red or green light makes little difference.

The tenth anniversary of the Rensselaer Players, a unique organization at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in which dramatics and engineering have joined in a- common cause, is being observed this year.
Gwyn R. Tompkins, trainer for Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable at Warrenton, Va., died here last night from injuries suffered in a fall on the ice. His age was 77.

A NEW stir is moving through the aircraft factories of the Pacific coast, the feeling of tremendous events about to happen. Even with the developments of the past two years in mind, nothing quite so evident of the awakening of public opinion to the overshadowing influence of air power can be found as in these shops, where everything from private ships and transports to fighting craft and bombers of enormous size are under construction.

Continuing anti-Semitic demonstrations indicate a tendency on the part of students to transform the Cabinet crisis into a Jewish one. They have smashed and looted Jewish-owned stores and a synagogue. Thirty-five arrests have been made.

The Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, announced last night the settlement of a strike at the Frederick Loeser department store in Brooklyn and the return to work of 800 employes.

Japanese troops in South China were reported tonight to be making rapid progress toward the border of the British-leased territory of Kowloon. The Japanese vanguard was said to be only half a mile from the frontier as the invaders swept aside what they termed Chinese Army "remnants" on the eastern shore of the Pearl River delta.

THE Prix de Rome is open again. Although fellowships are intended primarily for unmarried men not more than 30 years of age, the right is now reserved to invite the competition of men of unusual ability who do not meet these conditions.

Ten papers on technical marine subjects will be presented before the forty-sixth annual conference of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Thursday and Friday of this week.

Five driving forces are paramount in the daily life of the average college student, one of which is the desire for prestige among his fellow students, Dr. Julian L. Woodward, sociologist at Cornell University, told the tenth annual convention of the Eastern Association of College

Manhattan Estate, more than $20,000. To Annie Berland, widow, 650 West End Ave., $45,000; Harry Berland, son, executor, same address, $20,000; Seymour Berland, son, executor, 710 West End Ave., $40,000; Rose Goldman, daughter, Woodmere, L. I.: Mildred Auerbach, daughter, 595 West End Ave., $20,000 each; two minor bequests. Joseph Levy, executor, 215 W. 101st St.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:
With two contests already played the City College Evening Session varsity basketball team still has thirteen games on its schedule, ten on the home court.

Ninety-one undergraduate students at City College are enrolled in special honors courses in seventeen subjects, according to an announcement yesterday by Dean Morton Gottschall of the College of Liberal Arts and Science.

Secretary of State Hull, with ten other delegates from the United States, set sail last Friday from New York for Lima, Peru, which on Dec. 9 will play host to the International Conference of American States-the eighth in a series that began in 1889 when the first PanAmerican Congress met in Washington.
After two months of preparation, the St. John's University basketball squad will see action for the first time this year when it opposes an alumni five Saturday night in the DeGray gymnasium.

DESPITE protests in other countries against further discussion now of the return to Germany of her lost colonies-protests aroused by the recent wave of lawlessness throughout the Reich-there is little indication here either in the press or in government circles that the external outcry has dampened Adolf Hitler's determination to win back all or a large part of Germany's former possessions overseas.

A turn by Poland away from Germany and toward Soviet Russia was indicated here today when announcement was made that the Warsaw and Moscow governments had renewed their determination to adhere to the non-aggression pact of 1932 and had reached other agreements.

Miss Lyda Elizabeth Palmer was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her mother, Mrs. Lyda Killough Palmer, in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. The debutante received the guests with her mother, wearing a gown of silver 21ace and white net over cloth of silver and carrying pale pink camellias. Mrs. Palmer wore a frock of black net and a corsage of orchids.

LONDON.-The German trade drive in Southeastern Europe has passed through what may be called loosely its commercial phase and reached a stage of "power-politics" full of serious implications for the 69,000,000 people of rump Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Rumania, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Greece.

Last week our Moscow correspondent, Harold Denny, called attention to what is tantamount to a formal repudiation by the present Russian Communist party of the doctrine of Karl Marx, that with the coming of communism the State will "wither away," and society will become an orderly, anarchistic Utopia.

Crochet designs executed by blind women from instruction in Braille are for the first time a part of the exhibit by the country's best crocheters which has been assembled in the National Crochet Contest.

AT the pair of concerts to be given by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra this Thursday and Friday in its home city, Hans Lange, associate conductor, will direct a program consisting of Handel's concerto grosso in D major, No. 5; Sibelius's suite,
WHILE Cornelia Otis Skinner is billowing through the Far West with her monodrama, "Edna His Wife," she is seriously mulling over an idea of reviving and playing "Candida."

The Brooklyn College of Pharmacy outscored the New York University Dental School basketball team on the winners' court, 32 to 30, last night. The Brooklyn five was leading at half time by 19 to 15. Saltzman and Pearl starred for Brooklyn.

AN escaped convict from Devil's Island who reached Trinidad in a native canoe records a sympathetic British official there as remarking that he could not understand two things about the Frenchtheir Foreign Legion and the penal colony in French Guiana.
The War De apartment released the following orders to day, dated Nov. 25: MAJOR GENERAL Blanding, A. H., Chief National Guard Bureau, two days' leave, Nov. 28.
Unbeaten Texas Christian ended its regular season today by routing Southern Methodist, 20-7, to win the Southwest Conference title. T. C. U. now awaits word from Pasadena, the Rose Bowl town.

The Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association has made few changes in its list of officials for this season. Mrs. Alfred W. Paine will lead the association again from the presidential chair, with Miss Helen Stone taking over the duties of vice president in place of Miss Helen Rice.

Wheaton College will be hostess to students of the modern danoe at Mount Holyoke and Connecticut Colleges next Saturday at a dance symposium, which will include the performance of original repertoire numbers, analysis of techniques, and intercollegiate exchange of viewpoints on the modern dance.

MR. HARLING had a very happy idea in compiling this scrapbook, which is just such an animated medley of London life in the nineteenth century as one can imagine resulting if it were possible to throw a gigantic net into that prolific period and draw up a casual, characteristic haul of its teeming vitality.

Miss Magdalena Fialho, goddaughter of Francis R. Mayer of Bronxwood, this place, was married to Samuel S. Tyndall, son of Major Gen. Robert H. Tyndall and Mrs. Tyndall of Indianapolis, this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church here.

IF the film scribes of New York had been asked last week whether any one here had seen Kelly, the reply most certainly would have been a unanimous "And how!" For the formal introduction of 17-year-old Nancy Kelly to the local press was the flamboyant event of the week.

President Roosevelt prepared tonight for a thorough canvassing of relations with Europe's chief dietator countries, Germany and Italy, in a conference tomorrow with Hugh Wilson and William Phillips, Ambassadors to the two authoritarian states.

The Washington announcement that Hugh R. Wilson, though remaining the Ambassador to Germany, would stay in the United States indefinitely, was promptly met in political circles here with the statement that in such case Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador to the United States, would remain in Berlin an equal length of time.

AN ambulance driver in the American Medical Corps which the American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy sent to Spain to assist the Loyalist cause brought back from Barcelona last week three stamps issued by the Catalonian Government.
Sailors in the British merchant marine will obtain help in carrying on educational projects through the newly established College of the Sea.
A tea dance at Sherry's yesterday served as a coming out party for Miss Dorothy Raegener Burns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Burns of 14 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

The establishment of the William N. Cohen music fund of $10,000, the income from which is to be used to enable as many blind persons as possible in New York City to hear good music, was an-nounced yesterday by the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

On its traditional date, the Saturday following Thanksgiving Day, the first of the Knickerbocker Assemblies for the season took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Subsequent dances of the current series will be held on Feb. 18 and April 15.

AS the subtitle states, this book is "a story of the ups and downs of civilization as told by man's earliest known literary relies," and "an authoritative digest of the whole subject of ancient writings."

Fifty members of the Columbia University faculty received honors for scholarly achievement during the last academic year from institutions in the United States and foreign nations, it was made public yesterday in reports from the university's divisions to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president.

AN airline couldn't run without radio," is the way Frank Melville, operator in charge of the Eastern Air Lines station at Newark airport, appraises radio's alliance with aviation. And there is no better place in the world than this busiest of airports to observe the two sciences of speed operating together in accelerating transportation.

These are nights of terror and sleeplessness in Barcelona. Planes from Majorca already have come twice tonight and it is still early. Last night there were four raids, the night before one and Wednesday night eight.

Another reminder of the approach of Christmas came with the announcement yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman of the foreign Christmas mail closings for the coming week. With Christmas drawing near, the Postmaster again urged early mailing.

Industrial purchasing executives were advised to follow conservative policies in regard to forward commitments in the monthly report released yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. Although business activity is increasing steadily, the committee held, "there is nothing in the immediate offing in the way of any upward surge of business or marked quickening in price structures" to warrant purchases ahead.

If the United States Treasury Department insists upon enforcing the regulation requiring goods shipped from Sudetenland after Nov. 10 to be marked "Made in Germany," importers will strive to inform consumers that the merchandise actually was made in Czechoslovakia, according to reports here yesterday.
The University of Mississippi took to the air today to beat Mississippi State College, 19-6, before 15,000 fans and win back the Golden Egg, symbol of their thirtysix-year football rivalry.

The Colonial Realty Corporation has moved to larger quarters at 6,903 Fourth Avenue, corner of Bay Ridge Avenue, Brooklyn. The new offices are air-conditioned. A mortgage of $4,500 at 6 per cent covering the property at 1,227 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Eunice M. Greene to a client of the Frank M. McCurdy Company.
The Federal debt has reached a new high record at $38,584,212,458 on the eve of another huge Treasury borrowing operation.

A demand that Japan be deprived of her status as "one of the most favored nations" in the trade agreement just made between Great Britain and the United States is contained in a letter that the Rhode Island Textile Association has sent to Secretary of State Hull.

The State Commission of Correction today renewed its criticism of the "anomalous situation" on Riker's Island, site of the city's $10,000,000 penitentiary, where the Department of Sanitation has renewed the dumping of refuse.
Toronto blanked the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 0, in a National Hockey League contest which ended in a flurry of fists tonight.

The belief that technological improvement has permanently made full employment impossible keeps making its appearance even in responsible quarters. It was illustrated again in the report to Mayor La Guardia by the former Emergency Relief Bureau, the final installment of which was published yesterday. Re-employment,

Outplayed throughout, but rising to great defensive heights when their goal line was threatened, Georgia's Bulldogs battled Georgia Tech to a tie today for the second straight year, with the odds overwhelmingly against them.
Carried between two flaming torches, the coffin of Queen Maud, wrapped in the Norwegian royal standard, was placed today in a temporary resting place in the church of Castle Akershus.
Under the hammer blows of relentless persecution in Germany the future of Europe's unwanted refugees thrust tself this week Into the forefront of public consciousness in the West?rn democracies.

Harold Redish of Townsend Harris Hall and P. Wolff of Brooklyn Boys High were tied for the lead at 4-1 at the conclusion of play in the fifth round of the high school chess championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

Women of the United States, with control of more than half the wealth of the country and organization which is the envy of world feminists, can achieve any "heart's desire" in making the world a better place in which to live, according to Mrs. Linda Littlejohn, leader of the Australian women's movement.

A hearing has been set for Dec. 12 by the Federal Power Commission on application of the Kentucky Utilities Company and the Lexington Utilities Company for authority to merge all of their facilities, subject to the jurisdiction of the commission, into a consolidated corporation to be known as Kentucky Utilities Company.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 23: REAR ADMIRAL Aossiter, P. S., Medical Corps, Surgeon General of Navy and Chief Bureau of Medicine and Surgery, Navy Department to home. relieved all active duty.

James F. Nathan, assistant to the first vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, will retire Wednesday at the age of 70 after fifty years of service with his company, thirty-four of which were in New York City, according to an announcement yesterday.

An old farm lane, with traces of the weathered stone walls still lining its course, provides the setting for the residence recently completed on Evandale Road, in the Fort Hill Estates section of Greenburgh. Westchester County, for Adam K. Geiger, New York banker.

As a result of numerous radio patrol car accidents, Commissioner Valentine issued a general order yesterday cautioning policemen assigned to these cars: "Better get there a minute later than not get there at all."
The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, whose radio address last Sunday was regarded by some listeners as anti-Semitic, indicated last night through a spokesman over the telephone from Royal Oak, Mich.,

I AM on the WPA. For two years I have been one of the 175,000 members of New York's WPA army, a worker who hasn't had a full-time job in private industry for nearly five years. Just now Colonel Brehon B. Somervell and the other administrators are trying to sell us fellows to private industry-at least, to convince industry that we aren't professional paupers.
KILL a baboon in South Africa, cut off the tail as proof, and the government will pay you from 60 cents to $2.50.
CALIFORNIA has never real grown out of the frontie town spirit which pervade the area during and immdiately after the Gold Rush.

Miss Edith Kingdon Gould, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould, who was introduced to older friends of the family earlier this month, was the guest of honor last night at a supper dance given by her parents for 400 younger members of society.

TODAY American Youth in Music, presented by the High School of Music and Art under auspices of the Music Educators Council. Mayor La Guardia will speak after an introduction by Harold C. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
Under the heading, "We Do Not Want Ties With Nazism," the official publication of the Popular Front publishes a leading article opposing the extension of existing trade agreements with totalitarian
The Union Temple basketball team downed the University of Newark five, 32 to 22, on the courts of the winners last night. Union Temple was in the lead all the way with Bersin the high scorer.
In a team match at chess on five boards today, a powerful quintet representing New York University easily defeated Rutgers, scoring 4 1/2 points out of a possible five.
An editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday under the heading "Continental Solidarity" was reproduced prominently by all the leading newspapers here today.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Inskip Wye and Henry Andrew McCashin, both of this city, took place here yesterday morning in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Charles Franklin Shaw, minister of the First Presbyterian Church of Asbury Park, N. J., officiated.

ALTHOUGH evening reception from Europe now is best on 25 and 31-meter bands, with late evening tuning of Great Britain often good on 49-meter waves, morning beams from the Continent, bringing news of recent events in Germany and along the Czech border, are clearest on 16 and 19-meter channels. London news, broadcast at 8:30 and 11 A. M., Eastern standard time, has come in very clearly of late on the British high-frequency channels.

Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, Calif., needed only one hour today to gain a straight-set victory over his professional tennis rival, Fred Perry of England, 7-5, 6-3, 6-2. A crowd of 3,000 saw the match at Sabina Park.
The price of gold reached today a high official record of 150s a fine ounce; in unofficial dealings the price was 150s 2d for small quantities, which also was a.record.

After more than six decades in a former carpenter shop, the Supreme Court of Canada in a year and a half will be moved to a new $2,550,000 building being constructed west of Parliament Hill on a cliff overlooking the Ottawa River.

The registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Public Service Company of Colorado, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Power and Light Company, covered $40,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds due in 1963, $10,000,000 of sinkingfund debentures due in 1948 and 50,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative first-preferred stock, series of 1938.

A reception and dance will be given for Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commandant of the Second Corps Area, and Mrs. Drum on the afternoon of Dec. 16 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Military Order of the World War.

The report of the Cuba Company, the Compania Cubana and the Consolidated Railroads of Cuba, issued yesterday, shows a loss of $254,803 for the three months ended on Sept. 30, after deducting taxes, interest, depreciation and other charges. In the corresponding quarter of 1937 the loss was $436,642.

THE rebirth of Chinese nationalism has produced a new Chinese theatre movement and three samples of its work will now be offered on the London stage. S. I. Hsiung, whose "Lady Precious Stream" held London for over two years, will produce at the Torch Theatre Dec. 6.

Miss Doris Alliaume, daughter of Curtis Franklin Alliaume, Judge of the Children's Court of Utica, and Mrs. Alliaume, was married to Horace Smart Beattie, son of Dr. William H. Beattie and Mrs. Beattie of this city, in the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes this afternoon.

Premier Daladier seems to be holding his own against the I attacks of French labor and Left leaders on his move to modify legislation adopted by the Front Populaire Government following the elections two years ago. The chief point of attack on the Cabinet relates to the modification of the forty-hour week in certain industries, notably those connected with national defense.
London, which has shared with New York in recent years the distinction of being a leading sanctuary for refugee money, is now witnessing a flight of capital of unusual proportions.
Senator Clark of Missouri, who has been mentioned as a possible Democratic Presidential nominee in 1940, said today that the recent election had prevented a break-up of the
HUMOR and pathos, beauty and something less than beauty, though Mr. Coffin always stops short of the ugly and the sordid, fill these pages.

Prospects are growing brighter for trained women in geology and new opportunities in the field are opening, according to Professor Ida H. Ogilvie, who has been teaching geology at Barnard College for thirty-five years.

The food situation in Loyalist Spain is acute, with the people eating "absurd foods" that were fed to cattle before the war, Enrique Miaja, son of General Jose Miaja, in command of the Republican armies of the center and west, declared yesterday in an interview.
Herman H. Torborg of 85 Glen Street, Brooklyn, a lawyer and former State Senator and Assemblyman, died Friday. He was a native of Manhattan and received his law degree from the Brooklyn Law School.
Vittorio Mussolini, the Premier's eldest son, is worried about what will happen to the Italian motion-picture industry when American films are with drawn from Italy after the first of the year.

Lieutenant Kenneth F. Sullivan, who ended forty-seven years with the New York Fire Department when he retired last year, died Thursday at the age of 69. His home was at 405 Beach 130th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens.

A protest against the plan to help aid German Jews to migrate to the British colony of Tanganyika was put forward last night by Justice William Harman Black, of the New York State Supreme Court, in an address broadcast by Station WMCA.

The Jews are not alone in suffering persecution and others will suffer after them, former Premier Leon Blum gave warning in a broadcast speech at a dinner of the League Against Racism and Anti-Semitism here tonight.

Substantial reorders by toy wholesalers who placed light early business were reported in the toy industry here yesterday. Normally the wholesalers have covered their requirements by this time, but hurry calls for merchandise were received during the last ten days.

THIS rather ancient N. Y. K. liner is plodding toward Yokohama at a steady sixteen knots on what is her last voyage in the Orient-California service before being transferred temporarily to the shuttle service between Kobe and Shanghai.
A solution of the dispute that threatens to result in the withdrawal of foreign banks from Panama is expected in a few days by a government decree exempting banks from the purchase of internal bonds.
A divorce was granted today to Mrs. Charlotte H. Patterson Griffin from Barton B. Griffin of New York on the ground of cruelty. Alimony was waived in Mrs. Griffin's plea.

ONCE again there were reports of improved trade last week, With colder weather cited as the chief stimulant to sales. However, the official figures have disclosed very spotty conditions through the country and some setbacks which were not mentioned previously.

THE most sincerely light-hearted capital of Europe this Autumn has at last found expression for its mood. In a spirit tinged with mischief and irony, Karl-Gerhard has opened his "Autumn Manoeuvres" at the Folkan.

As used in income tax law the term "capital asset" has generally included property employed in the conduct of a trade or business. One class of property which has always been excluded, however, is stock trade, like merchandise or other commodities in which the taxpayer regularly deals, or any property which would be properly included in his inventory, or stock-taking, if on hand at the close of the taxable year.

The recital which the pianist Myra Hess gave yesterday afternoon at Town Hall found her in best vein. That means performances of superb artistic resource and a richly poetic personality-attributes which illuminated the full greatness of the Bach D minor tocata, the Schubert B flat sonata and the Beethoven "Pathetique."
A sharp gain for October in permits for residential building sent the nation's construction projectis for the year ahead of the same period in 1937.

Plans are nearing completion for the bazaar to be held at the Park Central Hotel on Dec. 13 and 14 under the auspices of Ivriah, the women's division of the Jewish Education Association. Furniture, toys, household and other articles will be offered for sale. Mrs. Jacob Friedman is chairman of the benefit committee.
The Winter series of free Saturday afternoon lectures at the New York Botanical Garden opens this week with an address at 3 P. M. by Dr. A. C. Smith, associate curator at the Garden. Dr. Smith,

Sub-freezing temperatures have prevailed over much of the Eleventh Federal Reserve District this week and the coldest weather of the season spurred sales of Winter clothing. Retailers expressed .confidence that the volume of sales for the rest of the year will be well ahead of last year.
Oregon State braced and counted twice in the fourth quarter today and defeated Oregon, 14 to 0, in a football game colored with fortytwo years of tradition.

FIDELITY is so far from being a norm in the human character that there are sober students who insist on classifying it as a strictly canine virtue. Mere man manages to come smiling through once in a long while, however; and this is the miniature legend of a leading member of an acting company whose collective distinction for the eighth year now is their unwavering addiction to a consistently discouraging ideal.

Covering Chilean bonds, the majority of which are held in the United States, the government gave out today details of the new regulations which, henceforth, will govern application of Law 5580 instituted
The three five-story buildings at the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street will be sold at auction Wednesday in the Vesey Street salesrooms by H. Louis Hollander.

Though Puerto Rico has now been under the American flag for thirty nine years, the United States has failed to solve the island's economic problems. This fact warrants careful consideration by Congress of a proposed new plan, which Secretary Ickes has approved in principle, calling for the creation of an agricultural and industrial credit corporation for the benefit of both Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
IN this book Miss Flexner arraigns our foremost dramatists on charges of literary sabotage for reasons ranging "from a heritage of 'artistic detachment' to a philosophy of personal success."

Memorial services for Associate Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo were conducted in the United States Supreme Court chamber today by leading members of the Supreme Court bar in the presence of a distinguished company of government and private attorneys.

The University of New Mex ico was invited today to play in the New Year's Day Sun Bowl foot ball game at El Paso, Texas, are invitation expected to be accepted at a meeting of the athletic council Monday.

In this day of hobbies, few people miss the joy of making a collection, whether it be of stamps, buttons, or old glass. Gardeners, however, absorbed in growing things and creating pleasing effects in their gardens, have given little thought to collecting, aside from the making of heterogeneous rock gardens of odd stones picked up in various sections of the country.
The Townsend Movement in the Pacific Northwest, as a result of its victories stories at the recent election, if demonstrating greatly renewes strength in both membership ans enthusiasm.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-The Vienna Boys' Choir, founded in 1498 by decree of Emperor Maximilian I, twenty members of which are making an American tour, will be heard here next Tuesday evening.

Aided by crisp weather, Chicago retail trade scored another sharp advance in the week just ended. Sales of the larger stores were slightly ahead of 1937, although there was considerable variation in the reports of the individual stores.
YEAR after year New York City's parkway system grows more comprehensive and elaborate, much to the delight of city, suburban and out-oftown automobilists.
Susquehanna University's basketball team will open its campaign Friday against Bucknell Junior College on the home court at Selinsgrove, Pa., in the first of sixteen scheduled games.

Another of the old-time truck garden properties which for more than a century gave the greater part of what is now the Borough of Queens a typical farming atmosphere is being out up into plots for mediumpriced homes.

COLUMNS of red ink in the budgets of the world sum up the incredible balance of man's distrust of his fellow-man. Taxpayers dig deep into pockets, and statesmen preach of peace by preparedness and strive for security through armaments.

New York Stocks, Inc., Jersey City, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 2,000,000 of $1 par value special stocks, twenty-one series,

A request that the La Follette Committee on Civil Liberties investigate the Dies committee, which is investigating un-American activities, was contained in a letter made public yesterday by Norman Thomas as chairman of the Socialist party of America.

Mrs. Aubrey James Field, former wife of Marshall Field 3d of Chicago, announced today that she and Peter Pleydell-Douverie, youngest brother of the Earl of Radnor, were married yesterday. No details of the ceremony were disclosed.

The Christmas bell windows at Lord Taylor, 424 Fifth Avenue, were placed on view yesterday and will be continued until Christmas. The windows are devoid of merchandise and contain only gilded bells swinging in tune with carillon music amplified from phonograph records.

Details of changes in the balance sheet are set forth in a letter calling shareholders of the Illinois Zino Company the their annual meeting in Chicago on Dec. 5. The New York Curb Exchange recently suspended the common stock of the company from dealings pending dissemination of this information.

WHEN a man can afford it, he builds his house on the sightliest spot he can find. He'd like to have a view from every window. Then he hangs on his walls paintings and prints of gas houses, mine tipples, used-car dumps, sharecroppers' cabins, Saturday evenings in the slums and stag nights at Sharkey's.

Mrs. Flora Disney, 70, mother of Walt Disney, was found dead in her home, today, from gas poisoning. The cartoonist's father. Elias Disney, 79, also a victim of carbon monoxide, was revived after Alma Smith, a housemaid, had notified the police. She and Mr. Disney are at the Hollywood Hospital.
Naturally the Nazi and fascist diplomats and their allies, the Franco Spanish and Japanese, have not helped President Roosevelt's good neighbor policy in Latin America.

The Bellarmine Debating Society of St. Peter's College will debate Swarthmore College Sunday, Dec. 4, at 8:30 P. M., at the Collins Memorial Gymnasium here on the subject: "Resolved that the United States Government should cease to use public funds for the purpose of stimulating business."

Two months ago, short of three days, London crowds standing in the rain outside No. 10 Downing Street raised lusty cheers when Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, appearing at a window, thus interpreted the momentous Munich meeting that had averted war. Munich, though ending Czechoslovakia as an international problem, left much unsettled. Peace remained precarious.
Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A son was born at the Columbia Hospital here today to Mr. and Mrs. James B. Alley of 544 East Eighty-sixth Street, New York and Jericho, L. I. Mr. Alley formerly was general counsel of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Although French labor has recognized the futility of France's attempting alone among European countries to keep the forty-hour week, there has been a general outbreak of protests throughout the country this- week against the decree laws revising the working system.
THE U.S.S.R. contributed the bulk of the past week's philatelic news and offerings. Received is the heralded series "in honor of international aviation records achieved by Soviet air men and women."

A schedule of seventeen games has been arranged for the Rider College basketball team of Trenton, N. J., according to an announcement by Frank J. Donlon, director of athletics and coach of the Roughriders.

Committees planning the annual Thanksgiving Eve dance of the Alumnae of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel, which will take place Nov. 23 at the Hampshire House, New York, will hold their final meeting on Sunday evening at an informal supper at the home of Miss Rose Mae McCabe, chairman, 16 West Seventy-seventh Street. New York City.

AMERICA, about to embark on the great experiment of a public television service, may profitably study the expensive lessons the British Broadcasting Corporation has learned after two years of regular television broadcasting from Alexandra Palace.
Governor Sir Hubert Young's five-year plan for the development of Trinidad, involving an expenditure of $14,000,000, today was approved by the Legislature.

Paper production in the South will be quadrupled within a decade, requiring investment of $500,000,000 of capital, according to D. H. Killeffer, chemical engineer, who has just completed a survey of the development of the paper industry in the South.

Heavy municipal taxation, creating a threat for the chains that exceeds the possibilities of the Patman Anti-Chain Bill, is coming before the authorities in a number of Southern cities, it was learned here yesterday. Tomorrow, for example, a public hearing before the City Council of Augusta, Ga., is scheduled to be held on a measure which would apply the principles of the Louisiana chain tax to the chains located in that city.

Oliva Dionne, fatheir of the quintuplets, turned thumbs down today on a plan to exhibit his daughters at the New York World's Fair next year. He said that it looked like "a clear case of exploitation."
Cle tail sales in local department stores last week were 6.3 per cent lower than for the corresponding week of 1937. For the four-week period the drop was 11.2 per cent.

A supper dance marking the 285th anniversary of the Spanish and Portuguese Congregation, now at Central Park West and Seventieth Street, was held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, for the benefit of the religious school founded by the sisterhood of the congregation on Stanton Street forty years ago.

Mrs. William Floyd-Jones will be at Mayfair House for the Winter. Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen has come to the Plaza from Tuxedo Park. Miss Virginia Ehret will give a luncheon tomorrow at La Salle du Bois. On Dec. 5 she and her mother, Mrs. Louis J. Ehret, will leave for Hope Sound, Fla.

President Arnaud C. Marts of Bucknell, following his theory that what is done in college is completely the concern of the student body, has arranged a program for next Saturday, the feature of which will be the answering of students' questions pertaining to the administration of the university.

Nov. 26.-After thirteen completed rounds, and with the final scheduled for tomorrow in this city, Reuben Fine of New York and Paul Keres of Estonia are deadlocked in first place in the A. V. R. 0. international chess masters tournament.

Sales of life insurance over the counter by savings banks in this State, which will be begun on the first business day after Jan. 1, were discussed today by Paul Taylor, Insurance Department deputy in charge of savings bank insurance.
ANNUALLY the world of philately is called upon to support, by purchasing specially is sued semi-postal stamps, numerous charities in lands in virtually all parts of the world.

The second meeting of the special Central Roadside Council of the Westchester County Conservation Association has been called by the council chairman, former State Senator Seabury C. Mastick, for Monday night at the Scarsdale Golf Club. Hartsdale.

Relations between the United States and Colombia, which have been improving noticeably for a considerable time, were strengthened today through arrangements that were announced for this country to send a military aviation mission and a naval mission to the South American republic.

ONCE again the wide range of Musicraft's interests and activities is shown in a couple of unusually contrasted releases. In an album is Mozart's Mass in F (K. 192), sung by the Motet Singers with a string orchestra drawn from the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, under the direction of Paul Boepple;

Much activity in store rentals in the Jackson Heights section of Long Island is reported by the Queensboro Corporation, which yesterday announced several leases. In the Queensboro Corporation Building, on the corner of Eightysecond Street and Thirty-seventh Avenue, the entire second floor was leased to the Shell Union Oil Company, which will use it for operating offices for the Long Island, Westchester and Bronx territories.
