UPON the non-Socialist reader Mr. Arvin's laconic and unqualified title produces one of the strangest possible effects. and to begin with it is rather a jangling than a happy effect. The book is the first single-minded, rigorous, complete examination of Walt Whitman ever made in an attempt to answer the specific question.

Sit-down strikers who had occupied one plant of the Chevrolet Gear and Axle Division of the General Motors Corporation since last night left the plant this morning and the company stated that all employes would return to work on Monday.
Nazi leaders in charge of Wuerttemberg amusement places declared today that swing music may be fit for Negroes and Jews "but not for us Germans."
" Adventures in Preventive Medicine" is the diverting title of the program under which club women have been invited to accept responsibility for exploring their community health resources.

After visiting Vienna, Budapest, Bucharest, Berlin and Warsaw, this writer finds four main factors that will direct the course of events in the coming year. It is a truism nowadays to say that the Munich agreement ranks as a historical landmark of first-class importance, but even yet it is doubtful whether statesmen, business men and other foreign observers are fully aware of the depth and extent of the change that Munich has brought.
In an atmosphere so calm and agreeable as to cause observers immediately to note a contrast, a Senate Finance subcommittee this week started a study of profit-sharing in American industry.

Bequests of $5,000 each were made to the New York Bible Society, 5 East Forty-eighth Street, and Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, by James H. Burnside, retired insurance executive, whose will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court. Mr. Burnside died at the Hotel Ansonia on Nov. 20 at the age of 81.
WHEN Aristotle declared that in ethics we cannot expect so great a degree of accuracy as in other sciences, he could hardly have foreseen the speculative babel that was to spring from his words.
While world attention is focused on Europe, Japan's conquest of China proceeds in a way which vitally affects all the great Powers. With her armed forces in possession of China's key cities,

A. A. U. W. (Monmoutn County, N. J., Branch)-Meeting on Latin America, 3 P. M., Rumson School, Rumson. Athena Club of Freeport-Civics department meeting, 3:30 P. M. Columbia Avenue school. Discussions on village affairs, 2:30 P. M.

Something new in boxing hereabouts will greet followers of the ring sport this week. Captain E. W. Whitwell of the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, will give patrons of his club a fifteen-round battle related to a championship, at prices of from 40 cents to $1.

ASTOR-Marie Antoinette: Norma Shearer.* BELMONT-Wild Innocence and Les Miserables;* Abused Confidence: Danielle Darrieux, opens Wednesday night. CAMEO-Professor Mamlock.* CAPITOL-The Great Waltz: Luise Rainer, Fernand Gravet. CONTINENTAL-The Singing Blacksmith;* Two Sisters: Jennie Goldstein, opens Tuesday.

A tendency is growing in Britain, according to American correspondents abroad, for the Conservative Government to "censor" news by "requesting" publishers to withhold facts considered unfavorable. Several remarkable incidents have occurred.

In recognition of his work for interracial understanding and amity, Father John LaFarge, Jesuit writer and editor, will be guest of honor at a dinner given by the Catholic Inter-racial Council, the Catholic Laymens Union and the Alumni Race Relations Council on Tuesday at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

What the newspaper Kokumin describes as a "strong demand for the recall of Ambassador Cralgie" [Sir Robert Leslie Craigie, British Ambassador] because of a reported tentative British offer to mediate on the basis of the withdrawal of Japanese troops from China bears every evidence of being a trial balloon launched by the Kokumin alone. No other paper mentions the story.

FREQUENT battery inspection during Winter months, when low temperatures may greatly reduce strength of the electric storage unit and, consequently, of motor performance, is advised in a bulletin issued recently by engineers of the B. F. Goodrich Company. Studies have shown,

Argentina had a favorable foreign trade balance of 9,296,180 pesos in October, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. Increased exports and a curtailment of imports accounted for the favorable balance, which, too, was the largest for any one month this year.
Texas Tech's smearing Red Raiders struck with unconquerable ground and aerial power in the first and third periods today to smash Marquette University, 21 to 2.

Debutantes are looking forward with keen interest to the first for this season of the Junior Assemblies, which will be held Friday night at the Ritz-Carlton. The assemblies, the most important of subscription dances in New York, are primarily for debutantes, although membership in the series is for two years.

LAKELAND, Fla.- Adoption of Florida's first Constitution 100 years ago in the now extinct community of St. Joseph, in Northwest Florida, will be noted with a four-day celebration, beginning on Dec. 7 at Port St. Joe, within sight of the "ghost city," with Governor Cone, both of the United States Senators, the five members of the House of Representatives and other State leaders taking part.

Premier Edouard Daladier tonight decreed the military requisition of all the principal railroad lines of France in his fighting campaign to crush in advance the one-day general strike called by French labor for next Wednesday.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported today that authorizations and commitments in October amounted to $70,402,106, while actual disbursements in the same month aggregated $60,866,241 and repayments on loans previously made were $30.920.801.

Established in 1931 "to explore public affairs and stimulate public thinking," the Bronxville Community Forum has grown until it now has 700 members living in twentysix Westchester communities, New York City and Long Island, according to Ignatius D. Taubeneck, the conductor.

A mix-month effort for official sanction of the Williams Flying Club ended this week when college authorities granted the request of the group to receive flight instruction. Dean Halfdan Gregersen officially opened its activity by soaring on a ten-minute hop over Mount Greylock on the maiden flight of the club's plane.

Pope Plus once again gave proof of his unusual vitality by recovering with extraordinary rapidity from yesterday's attack of cardiac asthma. Today, exactly twenty-four hours after the attack, he was sitting up in an armchair, protesting to Dr. Aminta Milani that he felt perfectly capable of receiving the several hundred people gathered in the Vatican, many of whom had come great distances in order to receive an audience.
The government decreed this morning that Dec. 1 will henceforth be observed as "Savings Day." The decree appeals principally to the laboring classes and to school children to cultivate the habit.

Mrs Bridget Stack, 65 years old, died yesterday in a squalid apartment at 427 East Eighty-first Street, described by the police as the "meanest" they had ever seen. The apartment, consisting of a kitchen, closet-size bedroom and a storeroom was without heat.
Winter weather came too late in the week to affect volume greatly. A check on Richmond city stores showed a real spurt on the one business day with seasonal weather.

Today, two months after the four great powers decided in Munich on the partition compact which divided Czechoslovakia among her neighbors, leaving an undefendable rump of Czechs and Slovaks entirely at the mercy of these neighbors, one can begin to see in broad lines the extent of the tragedy.

GENEROUS information regarding Alaska since the days of Russian ownership is contained in this historical and reminiscent volume by Judge Wickersham, pioneer jurist of the Territory. explorer, and Delegate to Congress.
THE author of this remarkable account of air-fighting in Spain and of conditions behind the. Loyalist lines is a young Englishman whose sympathies were not deeply involved in the Government cause,

A plan to further better understanding among college students of different nationalities and religions was announced yesterday by Dr. E. George Payne, acting dean of the New York University School of Education, marking the- establishment of a Cooperative Fellowship House in the Washington Square area.

The name of Kronborg Castle at Elsinore, Denmark, has a warm ring for the ears of all lovers of Shakespeare. For through its chambers trod Hamlet, and to the accompaniment of the waves upon its bastions resounded the hollow voice of his father's ghost.

President George M. Trautman of the American Association said tonight that a tentative agreement had been reached with International League officials to place the little world series on a three-out-offive basis in order to end the playoff between the two baseball loops by Oct. 1.

Julius Warburg, of 14 Lewis Place, Brooklyn, father of J. Robert Warburg, former bridge editor, and Paul E. Warburg, former sports editor of The Brooklyn Eagle, died on Friday in Kings County Hospital of a heart attack.

Charges that the State guides being prepared by the WPA Federal Writers' Protect contained "propaganda and appeals to class hatred" were made today by Representative Dies, chairman of the House committee investigating unAmerican activities.

The community interests' focal exhibit designed for the World's Fair by Gilbert Rohde, industrial designer, will show the phenomenal change in man's group life in the last 150 years and illustrate the opportunities for the more abundant life made possible by technological advances, it was disclosed by the plans for the exhibit made public yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.
The Flatbush and Ridgewood sections of Brooklyn are the scenes of considerable realty activity, according to reports from builders of single-family dwellings and multi-family homes.
Mr. and Mrs. Alfred D. Olena of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Audrey Armour Olena, to James Platt Wilkerson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Wilkerson of Colonia, N. J.
DD. FREDERICK D. KERSHNER, dean of the School of Religion at But ler University, Indianapolis, is deeply disturbed over what he sees as a conscious movement toward medievalism.

Every possessor of a greenhouse, no matter how small a one, got a thrill Friday morning when he stepped into his miniature Eden spot and saw his treasures snug and safe when all outdoors was but a whitened winding sheet after the sudden onslaught of Winter.

The average Canadian cannot understand American criticism of President Roosevelt, for most Canadians look upon the President "as really a great man," Grattan O'Leary, associate editor of The Ottawa Journal, one of the leading independent Conservative newspapers in Canada, said yesterday.

Miss Anne Ailes, daughter of the late Eugene E. Ailes of Scarborough, N. Y., and of Mrs. Ailes, who now resides in Martinsburg, W. Va., was married today by Bishop Robert Strider of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of West Virginia to Ira E. Eyler Jr. of Martinsburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eyler of Baltimore.

Practicability of diving to depths of at least 500 feet has been established as the result of experiments during the past fiscal year, Rear Admiral William G. DuBose, chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair of the Navy Depaitment, states in his annual. report for the fiscal year 1938 made public today.

SOLILOQUY-Tomorrow evening at the Empire Theatre. A play by Victor Victor, with John Beal, Helen Craig, Clarence Derwent, Alexander Lockwood, Ellen E. Lowe, Joan Adair, John Rutherford, Daisy Belmore and Jack Duval in the company.

IN this second English sampling of the work of the famous French critic, Paul Valery, there is a touch of the hemlock, an air of sad departure from the sphere of daily living. In part this is attributable to his esthetic attitude, which, for better or worse, the modern world has generally relinquished.

Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester medical examiner, said tonight that an examination of the stomach of the late Eugene Y. Burckhalter of Hastings - on - Hudson, 43-year-old chemical corporation head, revealed the presence of nothing more lethal than a "moderate" quantity of sleeping potion.
Seventy students at the Pennsylvania State College are participating in an adventure in cooperative living both for the experience they are receiving and because of the saving in living expenses.
Nov. 24, 1938, Edwin, beloved husband of Anna, devoted father of Alma. Services Walter B. Cooke, Inc., Funeral Home, 117 West 72d St., Sunday, 2:30 P. M. Interment Rural Cemetery, Albany, N. Y.
The girl with a definite postcollege goal in mind may cross-cut departments at Mount Holyoke College this year for the first time to assimilate material toward a broadened major subject.

BUT exceeding fine, we are told, do they grind, those mills of the gods. If it took most of the eighteenth century to bring on the French Revolution, it took most of the nineteenth to get over it-or rather (in the realm of art) to digest and carry to an ultimate analysis the terrific implications.

Opponents have been scheduled for the season of the Manhattan College Debating Society, it was announced yesterday by Frank J. Norton, manager of debate. Marquette University, Columbia, St. John's, Randolph-Macon and Dayton University will be met in home contests.

A special committee of Cornell University's board of trustees under Bancroft Gherardi, retired vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has begun an active effort to obtain funds for the $6,000,000 program to strengthen the resources of the College of Engineering, announced this week by President Day.
The admission of forty-two members of the freshman class of Princeton University without examination was reported today by Professor Radcliffe Heermance, director of admissions and dean of freshmen.

Wilson College girls will have a voice in directing their own education from now on. A student committee on academic affairs was organized this week to hear undergraduate suggestions and criticisms concerning the curriculum and pass them on to President Havens.

In the State Armory here the eighth annual Peekskill Horse Show got under way today after a day's postponement because of the storm. There were the scheduled three sessions, all carried over from yesterday and while one or two exhibitors failed to get through from rather distant points there -were large entries and keen competition, especially in the hunter and jumper classes.

Jacob Suritz, the Soviet Ambassador, called on Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet this evening and, it is reported, warned that the Moscow Government would consider dissolution of the Communist party an unfriendly act.

ASHEVILLE, N. C.-The gathering of galax leaves and other evergreens for Christmas decorations is in full swing in the mountains of this area in preparation for the shipment of hundreds of tons of evergreens to all sections of the nation within the next three weeks.

TWENTY-THREE "profiles" from a decade of the New Yorker are here reproduced for a well-deserved permanence. As Clifton Fadiman suggests in his preface, they are not only representations of people who "jut out"-that is what makes them profiles-but they have pertinence and value for what they show of contemporary history.

To the Drama Editor APOLITE (and extremely wellintentioned) suggestion to the gentlemen of the Drama Critics' Circle: At the next opening of a musical show let them forsake their downstairs aisle seats and come up in the balcony with us poor folk.

A lead which at one stage of the proceedings saw them five goals ahead of their rivals enabled the New York Americans to withstand a late surge by the Chicago Black Hawks and register a triumph over the world champions in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Five hundred Sea Cadets from Manhattan and Bronx units, including boys and girls from the age of 7 upward, marched and presented special exhibitions last night at the twenty-eighth annual review of the groups in the 105th Field Artillery Regiment Armory at 166th Street and Franklin Avenue, the Bronx. There were 1,100 spectators.
Protests are mounting over a Presidential decree regulating installment-plan sales. The decree modifies the repossession clause in installment sales contracts. Repossession is possible only when

Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, opponents in the last match for the chess championship of the world which resulted in favor of the former, met again in the third round of the A. V. R. 0. international tournament at Rotterdam and once again the Franco-Russian master was successful.
Moving with glittering plays in a Christmas setting of a field surrounded by snowbanks, Fordham came to the end of another successful football season at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.
The ten municipal golf courses under the jurisdiction of the Department of Parks will be closed Wednesday after a season that showed a large increase in patronage. Up to and including Nov. 25,
Colonel Harry Day, Laborite member of Parliament, plans to ask the government whether it has any information on "tankcarrying aircraft" reported to be in the possession of Russia.

THE performances in the many theatres of the Times Square area exert a perennial fascination for the amateur photographer, and, judging from the results being shown at camera clubs and salons, the lensman is not confining his picture-taking to the action on the stage alone.
Mrs. Herschel Jones, who wrote magazine articles under the name of Inis Weed Jones, died yesterday at the Deaconess Hospital in Spokane, Wash., according to word received here last night.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Larzelere Hofmann of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Hofmann, to William Adams Tolman, son of Mrs. Charles Edward Tolman of Concord, Mass., and the late Mr. Tolman.

The Federal Housing Administration has completed arrangements to insure the $800,000 mortgage on five apartment buildings under construction at Midland and Kimball Avenues in Yonkers, to be known as Fleetwood Acres, Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the FHA, announced yesterday.

In an open letter to Mayor La Guardia yesterday, David Thompson, chairman of the city hospital committee of Local 128 of the State, County and Municipal Workers, a C. I. O. affiliate, accused Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, of having refused to recognize the right of hospital employes to baragin collectively.

Miss Nancy Cardozo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Danforth Cardozo of 340 Park Avenue, was married yesterday at the home of her parents to James D. Egleson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Egleson of Essex Fells, N. J. Municipal Court Justice Keyes Winter performed the ceremony in the presence of the two families.

New improvements in cyclotron technique are enabling scientists to bombard hitherto difficult targets like metallic sodium, Dr. Franz N. D. Kurie of Indiana University told the closing meeting of the American Physical Society here today.
Mayor La Guardia led a group of eleven children, including his son and daughter, Eric and Jean, to the World's Fair grounds yesterday afternoon to celebrate Jean's tenth birthday.

Rutgers University will start a training course for city officials in the fundamentals of municipal finance, it was announced this week by Norman C. Miller, director of the University Extension Division, which will conduct the work.
The Social Service Auxiliary of the Cancer Institute will be the beneficiary of a children's holiday party to be given on the afternoon of Dec. 27 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE television station being built by the General Electric Company at Indian Ladder, in the Helderberg Hills, twelve miles from Schenectady, will be linked with the city's studios by a 1.4-meter ultra-short-wave beam instead of a coaxial cable.

Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue-103d and 104th Streets, 1:15 P. M. "Progress of the New York World's Fair 1939," Selma N. Goldberg. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Spanish and Flemish Painting of the Seventeenth Century" (Survey of Collections), Edith R. Abbot, 2 P. M.; "Cabinet-Making: Victorian Types,"
Officials of the Union Stockyard and Transit Company announced today that the Chicago Stockyards, tied up since Monday by a C. I. O. union strike, would be open for business Monday.
An Orange Free State eleven provided poor opposition for the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team today.

OF the approximately thirty exhibitions which fell to the lot of this reviewer last week three or four stood out gratifyingly above the mill run of gallery attractions. About a third of the new shows may roughly be described as primarily decorative in character.
Dr. De Witt Clinton Greene, for fifty-five years a physician in Buffalo, died last night after a brief illness. He was 81 years old.

The Alumni Council of Amherst College has accepted the responsibility for raising funds for rehabilitation of the campus, devastated by the hurricane of Sept. 21, and has appointed Richardson Pratt, '15, of New York, chairman of a committee to organize the campaign.

The Middlebury College basketball squad, numbering at present about twenty candidates, has started a series of long practice sessions to prepare for the opening game of the season against Hartwick Dec. 10.

Herman E. Mellenthin's Ch. My Own Brucie kept up his recent winning streak by taking best of show in the Dr. Homer Gage Memorial Show, staged by the Worcester County (Mass.) Kennel Club at the Worcester Memorial Auditorium today.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Harold R. Stobie of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mildred Margaret Stobie, to Dr. Arthur Gerard De Voe, son of Colonel Ralph Godwin De Voe, U. S. A., and Mrs. De Voe of Fort Bliss, Texas.

Kent State University at Kent. Ohio, is adapting curricula and methods of teaching to the specific needs of students through changes being made under the direction of the new president, Dr. K. C. Leebrick, former dean of the College of Liberal Arts of Syracuse University. Kent,
A complaint containing new charges of unfair labor practices against the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company was issued yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board.
The New York Hotel Trades Council, composed of six A. F. of L. unions, rejected yesterday a proposed wage and hour agreement drawn up by the Hotel Association of New York City.
DURING the last twenty years the staff of a certain well-known London publishing house has increased by more than 50 per cent, although its output has not appreciably changed.
THE National Broadcasting Company announces that from Nov. 28 to Dec. 2, inclusive, its daily "Between the Book-ends" program will be devoted to a "Book Fair of the Air."

THE hunters are out these days. Woods and marshland echo and re-echo with noise of gunfire, and even in a city like New York, where the wild game experience of most of the seven million is vicariously gleaned from the windows of sporting goods shops, people are aware that the hunting season is open, for it has its gastronomic repercussions on metropolitan bills of fare.

John's College of Annapolis today brought to a close a fifty-five-year gridiron rivalry with Johns Hopkins University, matching that of the teams in the Ivy League, by playing its heavier and much touted rival to a scoreless tie on a snowblanketed field today.

A Federal jury of business men today convicted two young Alcatraz convicts, James C. Lucas and Rufus Franklin, of murdering a guard during an escape attempt, but refused to send them to death in the lethal gas chamber.

REPORTS from all sections of the United States, presented at the recent national conference in New York on roadside improvement, show clearly that unusual progress has been made since 1936 in curbing road signs which disfigure landscapes and make highways less safe.

Miss Elizabeth Branson Ketcham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Stanley Ketcham of T'Other Farm, Whitemarsh, was married this afternoon to R. Montgomery Haines Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haines of Strafford.

Miss Pauline Ethridge Clements, daughter of Mrs. Edwin W. Gould Jr. of Osterville, Cape Cod, Mass., and of W. Wallace Clements of Detroit, was married here this afternoon to David Leventritt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Leventritt of 575 Park Avenue, New York.

The fact that fewer "flunk warnings" than usual were issued to Colby College freshmen this week is believed to be one tangible result of an experiment in personalized education started this Fall by Registrar Elmer C. Warren and carried out by the dean of men, Ernest C. Marriner, and the dean of women, Ninetta M. Runnals, with the cooperation of the faculty.

Edward Algernon Baughan, British critic, died today in his seventy-seventh year. Failing eyesight had caused his retirement in 1936. Most of his long working life had been spent with The Daily News, now merged with The News Chronicle,

Nearly 200 of the University of Maine's 1,700 odd students are engaged in theatrical activities conducted by the Maine Masque, student dramatic organization, Professor Herschel Bricker, executive director, disclosed today.

Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet, in a broadcast to the United States tonight, said that the Franco-British talks concluded this week strengthened the common effort to save Europe from the horrors of war.

Bullet Bill Patterson and the Baylor Bears passed, kicked and ran the Rice Institute Owls ragged, overwhelming them by 21 to 6 today. It was Patterson's final game for Baylor and his fifteenth consecutive sixty-minute performance.

The Vikings of Upsala College, under the direction of Coach Lou Spinelli for the second season, will open a twenty-one-game basketball campaign on Saturday at home against Hofstra College and will close against Albright at East Orange on March 4.
M-DAY-that dreaded "zero hour" when secret mobilization orders herald the beginning of war-is the chief concern of Washington nowadays.

A young woman who is attending Teachers College at Columbia University, through her courage and fleetfootedness, last night caused the capture of an alleged member of a Negro gang that has been committing robberies in the vicinity

Samuel Willett Whitson of this place died at the Greenwich Hospital last night following a short illness. He had been manager of the Washington branch of the Corn Exchange Bank, New York, for the last twenty years. He was 63 years old.

The infatuation of a 52year-old unemployed chemical salesman, estranged for seven years from his wife and seven children, for an attractive, auburn-haired stenographer twenty years his junior, resulted yesterday morning in a murder and suicide in the New York Central Office Building at Forty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.
FOR years there has been a cultural storm gathering in our land. The old and the new are digging up the time-worn battleaxe again. The old was ever venerable-the new ever vulnerable.
Do people in high places smile when they hurl at each other words like eneciable and sansculotte?
THERE is probably no more fascinating if difficult task than an investigation of the obscure processes that form the complex and bewildering phenomena loosely described as revolutions.

American exporters, now budgeting 1939 operations, foresee a year in which volume will top that of 1937, a survey among leading foreign traders disclosed here last week. The exporters have selected 1937 as a basis for their estimates because they believe the world-wide recession has made the present year abnormal from a foreign-trade point of view.
LIMA is feverishly undergoing a final wash and brush-up in readiness for the Pan-American Conference which opens here Dec. 9.

Shares of the Transamerica Corportion and of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, its subsidiary, sold off sharply yesterday on the news of the charge by the Securities and Exchange Commission that "false and misleading statements" had been made in the registration statement of Transamerica filed on Aug. 7, 1937.
THESE drawings and prints represent, in terms of lines on paper, the accumulated emotional experiences of many years and of many pilgrimages among the Gothic monuments of Europe.
IN history books of the future, 1938 may well be remembered as the year in which a moving picture theatre was opened on Park Avenue.

In many Midwestern cities a belief exists that "the definitely improved outlook for general business" will create again a demand for quality homes, states C. T. S. Keep, president of Previews, Inc., who recently returned with three members of his staff from a speaking tour and survey of twenty-two leading cities in the Middle West.
An official of Lufthansa, German air line, reported ten airmen were killed today in the crash of a Lufthansa plane during an experimental flight in Gambia, on the west coast of Africa.

The West of Central Park Association, 1,819 Broadway, announced yesterday it had protested to Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine against the use of Central Park West, from 106th to Fifty-ninth Street, as a route for the R. H. Macy Thanksgiving Day parade.

Syracuse University today announced an eighteen-game basketball schedule for the coming season. Contests with Manhattan and Fordham are on the list. The former will be met Feb. 1 at New York and Fordham here Jan. 14.

Fifteen boys at Mercersburg Academy in Mercersburg, Pa., received the major M for their services with the football team in the past season. Those honored were Captain Libren D. Cox, John Brown, Ted Dingle, John Donaldson, Bronner Dovey, Bill Fallon, Paxson Gifford, Tony Lyon, Mac Magruder, Harry Nevil, Jay Overcash, Jack Stone, George Vary, Jack Watt and Jack Welsh.
The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today an application by the New York Central Railroad Company for permission to abandon a branch line of 5.26 miles from Suspension Bridge to Lewiston, N. Y.

Miss Barbara Session Dodge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Clinton Dodge of Douglaston, Queens, was married last evening to Arthur MacDonald Ferreira, son of Mrs. Arthur Williams Ferreira of Boston and the late Mr. Ferreira, in the Zion Episcopal Church, Douglaston. The Rev. Lester Leake Riley, the rector. officiated.

Walter R. McCornack, Cleveland architect, will become dean of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's School of Architecture when William Emerson retires next Autumn, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the institute, announced today.

Plans to rebuild the Lincolndale School at Lincolndale, in Northern Westchester County, and to expand its curriculum were announced yesterday by Robert L. Hoguet, president of the board of managers of the institution.

Although there has been a reduction in the demand for graduates as compared with two and three years ago, the James Lee Pardee Placement Bureau at Lafayette College is hard pressed to fill the many calls for student help.

BOOK shelves, with their multi-coloredcontents, have become an essential in the well decorated room, as a glance at lately completed interiors will attest. Books no longer cling to the library; they appear in practically every room in the home.

Soccer's major attractionthe fight for the English Cupproved as popular as ever today. Sixty-eight clubs, including twentyseven minor professional and amateur teams, battled in the first round proper of the tournament, providing 300,000 spectators with rousing football and the usual surprising results.
The antlerless deer season of Pennsylvania opens tomorrow morning and, according to all reports, the hunters of that State look forward to plenty of venison for the table.
Louise Sydmeth, a former actress, died yesterday morning in a New York hospital, where she had been under care of the Actors Fund of America. She was 70 years old.

THE midseason collections have again been shown in Paris. They are always valuable in helping fashion experts to get their bearings amid the ebb and flow of passing fashion currents. They confirm and amplify certain trends launched in preceding big showings.

Howard University reports a 34 per cent increase in enrollment in its Graduate School and announces that within a short time a program of instruction will be considered which will make possible the beginning of work leading to the doctorate.
Applications for sabbatical leave beginning Feb. 1, 1939, should be filed by Thursday at 500 Park Avenue, Superintendent of Schools Harold G. Campbell announced yesterday.

Colder weather and Thanksgiving Day served to quicken the pace of retail trade here last week. Gift buying, according to. most accounts, has gotten off to a fair start, although the comparison of dollar volume with a year ago suffers because of the price disparity averaging around 7 per cent under last year.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 19 amounted to 657,477 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The Rev. Joseph E. Joyce, pastor of Holy Trinity Catholic Church of Wallingford, died late last night in the Hospital of St. Raphael. He underwent an operation a week ago.

WE drifted early the other day to the set of "King of Chinatown," mostly to see Anna May Wong and Sidney Toler, that actor of crystalline voice who lobs a whisper into any top gallery so the grateful denizens may hear it above. peanuts and the uproar of late-comers, and we sat in a chair to admire the Barbary Coast fog.

The Earl of Derby emerged tonight as the year's winning horse-race owner in England as the 1938 flat-racing season came to a close with the Manchester November Handicap, won by G. F. Hartigan's Pappageno II.
Stockholders of the National City Bank of Cleveland approved yesterday a plan to increase the bank's authorized capital from $7,00,000 to $9.000.000.

THIS is a book that is peopled, except for one man, entirely by shadows. Planes take off from every page-but there is not much about them; they are vague, numbered things that worked or failed to work. The world turns upside down, shattering the career of the book's one character--and is given a paragraph.

Mrs. William Slark Letchford of Morristown gave a large reception this afternoon to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Caroline Whitney Letchford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Palmer Letchford, also of Morristown.

The National Football League moves into its final eight days of competition with nothing decided as to the winners of Eastern and Western titles. And even those last eight days may not settle things entirely.

WHILE not fictionalized in the least degree, this history of a family through nearly three hundred years is, nevertheless, just such a "saga" as many a novelist has striven to write. There are chapters which for excitement rival "Anthony Adverse." Earthquakes and hurricanes:

The Central Union of German Societies of Rhode Island, representing several hundred people of German birth or extraction, issued tonight through its secretary, Rudolf Iiliansky, a "public declaration" condemning persecution of the Jews in Germany.

Captain John J. Ryle Sr., 84, veteran Long Island Sound pilot and one of the leading oyster growers in Connecticut for more than fifty years, was found dead late today aboard his oyster boat. He had fallen down the companionway, striking his head against the engine, and death was attributed to brain concussion.

Twenty-two Hudson Tube passengers were injured, one seriously, this afternoon at 3:40 o'clock when a six-car train of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, bound from Newark to Cortlandt Street, was sidewiped by a switch engine of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Kearny, one mile east of the old Manhattan Transfer station.

The marriage of Miss Bettie J. Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Morgan of Kingston, to Frederick C. Kirkendall, son of Mrs. Frederick Kirkendall of WilkesBarre, has been announced. The ceremony took place in the Congregational Church at Brookline, Mass.. on Nov. 15.

FOR more than two decades books purporting to deal with Anglo-German relationships have poured from the presses. Many are characterized either by a thinness of knowledge so shallow as to appear completely one-sided, or else resemble the documented posturings typical of bad Ph.D. dissertations.

THIS is one of the occasions on which it is necessary to write rather of what might have been than of what has actually happened. The play in question, "So English!" by A. McLeod, is described as a farcical comedy, and is so complete a failure,

Starting from an idea originating in the Chaplain's Religious Council at the University of Pennsylvania about a year and a half ago, plans have been evolved for a four-day "Christian Embassy" to be held on the campus from Dec. 5 to 8.
King Carol of Rumapia had lunch today with Field Marshal Hermann Goering on the latter's special train at Leipzig. They discussed "the development of economic relations between both countries."

Unless otherwise stated, the resuits of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

An electrifying 79-yard runback of a punt for a touchdown by Charley Long midway in the opening period and an 81-yard drive to a second score, registered by Woody Wilson from the 1-foot line late in the third quarter, gained Army a desperately earned 14-7 victory over Navy today before the record crowd of the football season.
Official disapproval of moral laxity now being voiced here is another reminder of the fact that bit by bit Soviet morals are swinging around to the old-fashioned standards of bourgeois society.

WHITE it still is too early to gain any definite ideas of the public's reaction to automobile shows which have been held during the past few weeks the atmosphere of optimism which obtained here prior to the show openings has not abated.

The engagement of Miss Marcia Stevens Kitchell of this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kitchell, to Irvin Torrence Francis of Caldwell, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John A. Francis, has been announced.

Myron C. Taylor, industrialist and vice chairman of the Intergovernmental Committee for Political Refugees, sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie for London. He will attend a meeting of the committee officers to consider the settlement problem of persecuted Jews.

The sun was bright and the turf looked firm enough for good football as the Navy team came out to warm up for the annual service struggle. But a cool breeze blowing in off the snow-covered fields outside kept the 102,000 spectators clutching at coat collars or pulling blankets a little tighter around the knees.

ABROADWAY "Jeeter Lester" stomped in the filth of a stage "Tobacco Road" for four performances last week in a theatre almost in shoutin' distance of the "real" road, and found himself, quite unexpectedly, the center of a mild and genial ovation.

The cheerful chirping of 600 canaries, every one of them a finely bred bird and many coming from as far away as the Middle West and Canada for the eighteenth Grand National Open Show of the Empire Cage Bird Association, turned the Salle Moderne of the Hotel Pennsylvania into a tuneful aviary yesterday.
A decree published in the Official Gazette today provided that after Dec. 1 any Danzig citizen "indulging in subversive activity abroad against the Free City" may be deprived of citizenship.

Better public relations, greater buyer authority, "constant" wage plans for employes and the possibility of new taxes which may require stores to charge for certain services loom up as major elements which retailers are considering in shaping their tentative program for the coming year, a survey of opinions among executives here indicated yesterday.

IN his preface to this unconventional autobiography the general editor of the Science and Culture Series guarantees that "the book, once taken up, will not be laid aside until its last page has been read."

Dwight Williams Huntington, editor, author and long a leader in the wild-game conservation movement, died today at the Maple Convalescent Home, Oceanside, L. I., at the age of 87. Mr. Huntington had lived here with a son, John C. Huntington.

Dr. Stan Bauch was elected president of the New York Physicians Art Club at the annual dinner of the organization last night at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, South. Other officers elected were Dr. Alfred Braun, vice president; Dr. J. R. Gudger, secretary, and Dr. I. Rosen, treasurer. Dr.

Dr. Ellice M. Alger, ophthalmologist of New York, will receive the Leslie Dana.gold medal for "outstanding achievements in the-prevention of blindness and the conservation of vision" at the annual meeting of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness in the Russell Sage Foundation Building on Thursday.
The Columbia Pharmacy basketball team defeated the Cooper Union quintet, 39 to 31, at the Columbia University gymnasium last night for its second victory in as many starts this season.

After nearly six months of elaborate preparation Washington is about to witness the most extensive governmental investigation of monopoly and the whole American economic scene since the 1912 inquiry under Representative Arsene Pujo into the "money trust" involving New York, Chicago and Boston banking houses.

Trade declined in the Sixth Federal Reserve District last week. Department store sales were 2.8 per cent below a year ago. In Atlanta department store sales were off 2.3 per cent. Warm weather was regarded as the main contributing factor.

IN Washington there is an air of spaciousness and serenity that one does not find in any other American city of its size. The streets are broad; the "gridiron" plan imposed on most of our cities is relieved there by diagonal avenues; the city is alive with trees;

Funeral services for Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, wife of the Irish Minister to the Holy See, were held today at the Church of Jesus before a large congregation, including many church dignitaries and diplomats.

IT may as well be bluntly recorded that most of the new Paintings by Reginald Marsh, at Rehn's, are a keen disappointment. In them a fault (as I see it) that has been in the ascendant for some time now presents grave difficulties.

The Southeast first field hockey team, composed entirely of Philadelphians, was again crowned national champion as a result of its victory, 4 to 3, over the Northeast firsts in a closely contested match at the Merion Cricket Club today.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the following additional applications for registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market from New York City:

Electricity will be used to cook the meals in Olentangy Village, the electrified housing project, occupying a sixty-six-acre tract on the banks of the Olentangy River, approximately four miles from Columbus.

Invitations to the dinner Mrs. Charles D. Dickey, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sloan and Mrs. Richard C. Colt had planned to give at the Ritz-Carlton on Jan. 6 before the Second Junior Assembly, for the Misses Mary Sloan Dickey, Marion Mason Colt and Catherine Sloan Colt, all debutantes of this season, have been recalled owing to a death in the family.
Optimism and better feeling nave replaced the bitterness of preelection weeks in San Francisco's industrial relations, and both employer and union spokesmen are predicting a long period of peace.

NEARLY every child at one time or another has inhabited an imaginary country, island or city. Sometimes they invent their own, sometimes they follow the suggestions offered by their favorite author of the moment, living in a Jules Verne country of scientific marvels or in the underground caverns and the castles of George Macdonald's fairy tales.

Credit managers of men's clothing houses have started to check Spring orders very carefully and in numerous instances have pared down the business being placed, they reported here yesterday. Collections have not improved sufficiently in recent months to warrant blanket approval of the sizable orders which most stores are sending in, it was said.

Women are more proficient than men at driving automobiles, according to a study of pedestrian accidents by the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles. The survey, a digest of which was made public yesterday by Carroll E. Mealey, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, also indicated that women were more careful while walking, since fewer women pedestrians than men were killed by automobiles.

NATIONALIST Spain issued her first coin of metal this year. Although dated 1937 the coin, a 25-centimos piece of nickel alloy, was issued during the Summer. The obverse shows the name "Esparia" to the top left and beneath in smaller type "Vna. Grande Libre" (United, Great, Free).
Quite Frequently, it is pointed out, in the corner of a room wallpaper has a tendency to pucker as if one wall had settled and pulled away from the surface it abuts at the corner.
Combined British ground and air forces today wiped out an Arab band of fifteen in a battle midway between Acre and Safed in Lower Galilee.

The Norwegian Turners F. C. and the Swedish F. C. will revive an old rivalry today when they meet in a National Soccer League game at Bay Ridge oval, Brooklyn. In another match the New York Hakoahs will meet the Gjoa S. C. booters at Commercial Field, Brooklyn.

Milton J. Budlong of Newport, R. I. has purchased the fifteen - acr estate of Burton A. Howe, on Lak Avenue. Tax stamps on the war ranty deed filed in the Town Clerk' office indicate that the transaction involved $65,000.

While listening to a broadcast of the Duke-Pittsburgh football game this afternoon, Dr. Harry Unger, a well-known physician of this town, dropped dead. He had been in ill health for the last eight years. He was 51 years old.

Automobile registration in the New York Region-described as New York City and the adjacent territory roughly within a radius of fifty miles of the City Hall in Manhattan -in 1950 will be 2,878,800 and the population of the area 15,355,000, the Regional Plan Association predicted yesterday.

Mychajlo Holynskyj, Ukranian tenor, who has been heard in several European opera houses, made his first appearance in America last night at Town Hall. His program consisted largely of Ukranian and Slovakian songs, but it also contrained arias from "Aida" and "Andrea Chenier."

An extensive program of Winter sports for students at the University of Vermont has been arranged to take advantage of added facilities for skiing, ice skating, hockey, snowshoeing, and Winter hiking.

WITH five weeks remaining on the 1938 calendar, the radio showmen have started to make the selection of the year's outstanding events for dramatizing as "Twelve Crowded Months." For an hour broadcast at the year end they find so many events on the card that the puzzle is to sift them to fit the sixty minutes.

Changes for two well-known beauty salons were announced yesterday. Donu Edmond, who was beautician for the late Queen Marie of Rumania, has leased the entire building at 8 East Fifty-sixth Street, and Charles of the Ritz has opened improved quarters in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, at Madison Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

The new $300,000 library of Marymount College here will be dedicated on Thursday, Dec. 8, on the occasion of the college's thirty-first anniversary. At the same time, a group of students will be inducted into membership in the Society of the Children of Mary, honor society.
Johnny Revolta, Evansville (Ind.) pro, added a 69 today to his firstround 67 to take a five-stroke lead over the field in the $5,000 Columbia-Ridgewood open golf tournament.

NO substantial effect on the radio industry in the United States is expected to result from the reciprocal trade agreements between this country and Great Britain, according to an analysis by the Radio Manufacturing Association.
ACCORDING to the statement on the publisher's jacket, "Mr. Coyle picks up and carries into the future the story of America precisely where James Truslow Adams in 'The Epic of America,' left off.

Matthew Kane, 42-year-old convict, who is believed by the police to have been the intended victim of the gunmen who killed John F. O'Hara, young credit investigator, at his home in Sunnyside Nov. 18, was returned to Sing Sing Prison yesterday on a charge of violation of parole.

Orders booked by the furniture industry in October increased 19 per cent over October, 1937, the first time since June, 1937, that bookings were greater in dollar amount than in the same month of the year before, according to figures issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.
Department store sales, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table for the various reserve districts, for the latest week and the latest four-week period:
The members of the United Sates first field hockey team, announced tonight, also will make the trip to England for the international matches next Fall.

The first figure-skating show of the season will be presented at Madison Square Garden Tuesday evening with the offering of the Ice Follies of 1939. Performances will be given each evening with a matinee on Saturday.

Due to the limited demand for eight-room apartments, the mulitfamily dwelling at 8 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, formerly containing suites of that size, has been renovated and the apartments changed to units of six and seven rooms.

Mrs. Livingston Fountain gave a small reception yesterday at her home,;1,095 Park Avenue, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marion Decker Fountain, to George Ross McKee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKee of 111 East Eighty-eighth Street. Later Mrs. Fountain gave a dinner for her daughter and Mr. McKee at the Versailles.
Authoritative sources said tonight that an official Anglo-French request for United States help toward solving the problem of Jewish refugees from Germany probably would be made early next week.

Moving ahead almost 3 points, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced to 93.1 for the week ended Nov. 19. This compares with 90.3 for the previous week and 88.6 for the corresponding week last year. The new figure is the highest since the week ended Nov. 6, 1937. Five of the components are now at new "highs" for the year.
Mayor Rolland B. Marvin was nominated today by. his predecessor, Charles G. Hanna, for membership in the "Polar Bears Club."
A gift for talking is an asset in selling insurance, but it stops far short of explaining the success women have achieved in this field, leading women underwriters in the metropolitan area believe.

THE Cabaret TAC doesn't like Herr Hitler, an attitude which can hardly be termed unique. But the startling fact about this hardy band of troupers is that it has arrived once more at the American Music Hall with a topical revue which is imaginative,

The ninth annual Black and White Ball was held tonight at the Mayflower Hotel. The young bachelors of the capital gathered to meet Miss Eleanor Roosevelt, debutante niece and namesake of the First Lady, and several dozen other girls who are "coming out" this season.

Members of the Color Guard of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York and their guests will attend a dinner dance to be held on Wednesday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. In charge of arrangements are John C. Lowe, chairman; Moreau Yeomans, vice chairman; Angus S. McCabe, Ralph A. Sayre and John D. Talmage.
WHAT'S west of the Hudson? Twenty years ago your confirmed and contented New Yorker would have

A tale is going the rounds of the capital, which-though doubtless apocryphal and definitely anonymous-well illustrates the general problem that faces the executive and legislative branches of the Federal Government in preparing and financing the proposed new national defense, or Western Hemisphere security, program.

Bolivia and Paraguay renewed diplomatic relations today after six years of hostility caused by the Chaco war. The resumption of friendly intercourse formally began at 11 A. M. when the new Ministers to Asuncion and La Paz presented their credentials to the respective Presidents at simultaneous ceremonies that were surrounded with unusual pomp and dignity designed to emphasize the solemnity of the occasion.

SIDELIGHTS on Europe's mysterious short-wave station, which has been broadcasting anti-fascist propaganda in German and Italian on unassigned channels for the past eighteen months, flashed over the sea recently during an English news broadcast from the Spanish capital.

ORFEO ED EURIDICE-Opera in Italian in four acts and five scenes. Music by Christoph Willibald, Ritter von Gluck; book by Ranieri de Calzabigi. Conductor, Artur Bodanzky; stage director, Herbert Graf. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The social season at New Jersey College for Women is in full swing. In the last week the students entertained the faculty. After a senior-faculty tea and sophomore hop, the first formal dance of the year, a Thanksgiving dinner was given last Monday night by the student body for faculty and administration members and their husbands and wives.

With the prospective return of Winter days, and the renewal of interest in house plants, the cactus family comes in for serious attention. Demanding but the absolute minimum of care, they lavishly reward the indoor gardener with something of interest at all timeswith their fantastic forms, their air of far places and strange, weird lands, and finally with their exquisite perfect blossoms.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Delia Potofsky, daughter of Mrs. John Margulies and Jacob S. Potofsky, both bf this city, to William Paul Gottlieb, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Gottlieb of Bound Brook, N. J. Miss Potofsky is a senior at Goucher College, Baltimore. Her fiance,
The Villanova Wildcats will open their basketball season at home against Roanoke College Saturday and from then until March 1 will range from Baltimore to Chicago to battle high-caliber opponents.

BECK--ARONSON--Samuel Beck and Florence Aronson were married on Nov. 23. COHEN-EPSTEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Moses P. Epstein announce the marriage of their daughter, Naomi, to Mr. Lawrence B. Cohen, on Nov. 24, 1938.
The Rev. Edgar P. Hill, Presbyterian educator and clergyman, died today following a lengthy illness at his home here. His age was 77.
THE first cemet stabilized" road has been completed in New Jersey. Highway Commissioner Sterner regards it as a test for economy in construction on farm-to-market arteries.

John E. King, former vice president of the National Editorial Association, died today at a San Bernardino hospital. His age was 68. Mr. King had been publisher of The Hemet News since 1912 and after 1933 was receiver for the San Bernardino, Rialto and Victorville national banks.

THIS is not a ghost story, although it has a spooky atmosphere so excellently contrived that one expects a ghost to pop out at any minute. Neither is it a detective story in the ordinary sense of the word: but it is most emphatically a mystery story.

As the Republican party turns toward the 1940 Presidential elections, a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director, reveals that Thomas E. Dewey of New York has become the outstanding choice for the Republican Presidential nomination among the rank and file of his own party.

The overcrowding of Federal prisons, sometimes as much as 50 to 100 per cent, was deplored by James V. Bennett, director of the Bureau of Prisons of the Department of Justice, in an address at a conference of jurists of the Third Federal Judicial District in Chalfonte-Haddon-Hall here today.

Inasmuch as they will be compelled to add more printed information to their labels to comply with the provisions of the new Food, Drug and Cosmetic Law, many manufacturers in the fields affected by the act are taking the opportunity to redesign their labels entirely, reports in the industry indicated yesterday.

Two "powder puff" elevens from Morris Harvey College cavorted between halves of today's football game with Davis-Elkins College. Only the co-eds' lipsticks got smear-ed and there was no score. The girls played the entire game of three-minute quarters within the 40-yard stripes but the fans loved it.

A crowd of 102,000, largest of the season, saw Army defeat Navy in the Municipal Stadium, Philadelphia. After being tied at the half, 7-7, Army marched 81 yards in the third quarter for the winning touchdown, Woody Wilson plunging across from the 1-foot line. New York's big game, bringing together Fordham and N. Y. U., resulted in a one-sided victory for the former.

Senator White of Maine, Republican member of the Campaign Expenditures Committee, called today for discharge of every relief official or relief worker found to have used WPA for political purposes in the last campaign. The committee is scheduled to meet Monday to consider final reports on its campaign investigations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In accordance with a statement appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 23, the United States Chamber of Commerce Conference has announced that it favors the abandonment of a Federal plan of railroad consolidation and the enactment of legislation facilitating voluntary consolidation and the retention of all possible competition.

The National Assembly has been convoked for next Wednesday to elect a new President of Czechoslovakia. Emil Hacha will have the votes of the Czech and Slovak Deputies, excepting the Communist, and the Nazi Deputies have announced an intention of abstaining.

King Gustav of Sweden has conferred the Royal Order of Vasa on the Rev. Dr. Felix V. Hanson, for twenty-eight years pastor of the Lutheran Immanuel Church here. Formal presentation will be made at evening service tomorrow.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.
THIS morning, with the Quirigua idling past the old and obsolete batteries of Morro CastleCuba's West Point-toward her berth at Santa Clara,

Federal Judge Frank Cooper tonight granted a temporary injunction requiring four milk companies to pay to the Market Administrator their pro rata share of the expenses of administering the Federal-State milk marketing agreement regulating sale of milk to New York City dealers.

The fourteenth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine continued at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday with two speakers telling of conditions in the Holy Land, which they represent at the meeting.

The proposed new issue of $21,071,600 of ten-year 2 3/4 per cent convertible debentures of the Continental Oil Company will be offered to stockholders at the rate of $4.50 of debentures for each share of capital stock, according to a letter sent yesterday to stockholders by Dan Moran, president.

Organized WPA workers in this city made plans yesterday to resist cuts in the work relief rolls through piclketing, mass demonstrations, pressure on members of Congress and delegations to Albany and Washington.

With only a week remaining before the inauguration of the basketball season, Coach Clair F. Bee of the Long Island University Blackbirds is still undecided about his starting line-up. The team, which is to meet the alumni Saturday at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium, is hampered by injuries and illness.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation states that an alleged plan to extort $10,000 from Shirley Temple, child film star, was thwarted today with the arrest of Hinton C. Hardison, 22, at Galice, Ore.
The victor and the vanquished today took victory and defeat as one naturally would expect. The Army dressing room was a scene of wild jubilation and delight, the Navy quarters steeped in gloom.

The National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers yesterday told members that in order to avoid conflict with the Wages and Hours Law Administrator on the question of learners they should either pay learners the minimum waga or not employ them until the issue is settled.

The drama season on Morningside Heights will open tomorrow night when the Columbia Theatre Associates, central agency of the university's three dramatic groups, presents "Catherine de Medici," by Warren A. Silver of Centralia, Ill., a second-year student in the Columbia Law School. The play is to run a week.

A nation-wide survey among representative investors to determine the causes impeding the flow of new capital into industry has been undertaken by the National Association of Manufacturers, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles R. Hook, president of the association.

The American Committee for Relief in Czechoslovakia announced yesterday that, contrary to impressions in some quarters, Czechoslovakia has not lost nearly all its industries and will not be relegated to the position of an agricultural nation.
FIVE years ago a radio announcer read into a recording machine a tale by P. G. Wodehouse.
Though much is written these days concerning the old-fashioned gardens of colonial days, attempts to reproduce their charm often fall short of expectations Gardeners,

Miss Margaret Esther Hoover, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alden R. Hoover of this city, became the bride of James Stanley Brooks of Ithaca, N. Y., son of Mrs. Fanny Brooks of Bloomington, Ind., and the late Samuel Brooks, at the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon.
A NEW work by Ernest Bloch is news, and this morning's bulletin may properly begin with word of Mr. Bloch's violin concerto, which will be unveiled, as it were, in Cleveland on Dec. 15.

Parents who own and operate the Windward School here, a private institution which stresses progressive education, have added some classes to the curriculum for themselves this Autumn by establishing an adult education school closely resembling those founded recently in Pelham and Scarsdale.

A plea for the establishment of a graduate school of arts and sciences, a new downtown building, adequate dormitory facilities and an additional endowment of $2,000,000 is made by Chancellor Samuel P. Capen in his annual report to the council of the University of Buffalo.

A new use for crude turpentine, the preparation of quicker starting "antiknock" fuel oil for Diesel engines and motors, is revealed in a patent granted here to Robert C. Moran of Wenonah, and George S. Crandall of Woodbury, N. J.

President Roosevelt sent his wishes for a happy voyage today to Secretary of State Cordell Hull and others in the United States delegation en route to the Pan-American Conference at Lima. The President wirelessed:

Having obtained the approval of Mayor La Guardia, the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement is launching a movement to transform "ugly, unsanitary and little utilized" backyards that are blocked off by old wooden fences into single, attractively planned and equipped block-garden courts occupying three-quarters of an acre, it was announced yesterday.

The separation of Italian-born parents from their 8-year-old son born in this country was halted yesterday, at least temporarily, when Federal Judge Edward A. Conger granted the couple a writ of habeas corpus shortly before they were to be deported on the Italian liner Vulcania.
Longview Gardens, a new residential community in Bergen County, N. J., was formally opened last week and a completely furnished model home was placed on exhibition.

Retail trade lost ground last week as more cities reported losses from a year ago. Colder weather brought a more widespread improvement in apparel sales, but volume in other departments was insufficient to meet last year's figures.

Professor Elia Volpi, internationally known antiquarian and painter, died today at the age of 80. He was a member of the Detroit Academy of Fine Arts. One of his paintings won an award at the of Boston World Exposition of 1880.

Mrs. Amelia Freise Wahl, wife of Fred J. Wahl died last night at the Greenwich Hospital at the age of 64. Mrs. Wahl was born in Poughkeepsie but had made her home in Greenwich for the last thirty-six years. Also surviving are a son, Theodore F. Wahl of Greenwich,

Private dispatches reaching here today said that three persons had been killed and upward of forty injured by a bomb explosion in a theatre at Timisoara, in the Banat region, where there have been political disturbances and anti-Semitio demonstrations recently.

Dr. Kent W. Berry, 50 years old, and three other men were convicted by a jury today of kidnapping and assault in the "jealousy" abduction and torture of Irving Baker, an automobile salesman. The jury recommended life imprisonment for all four.

A syndicate headed by Max M. Hurwitz bought for modernizing the three five-story apartment houses containing twenty-five apartments at 124, 126 and 128 East 123d Street, between Park and Lexington Aveues. The houses, which occupy a combined plot 75 by 100 feet, are

James F. Ross, assistant to the vice president of the Railway Express Agency, has been appointed general manager of the New York City department of the agency, effective on Jan. 1, 1939, according to an announcement yesterday by C. R. Graham, vice president in charge of Eastern operations. Mr.

In a speech winding up the sixth Reich Peasant Congress today, RichardWalther Darre, the German Minister for Agriculture, revealed that in the fifth year of "the drive for increased production" there had been a flight of population from the countryside into towns, notably into the industrial regions.

Athur M. Heard, one of New died today Hampshire's leading bankers, died tonight at the age of 72. Mr. Heard, who came from a family of bankers, was elected president of the Amoskeag National Bank in July, 1905, and served in that capacity until last Jan. 4,

Performing consistently through two days of excellent competition, the chestnut mare Stepaside tonight captured the hunter championship of the eighth annual Peekskill Horse Show, which came to a successful conclusion at the State Armory.

The cornerstone of the $150,000 edifice of St. Agatha's Roman Catholic Church, Forty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, was laid yesterday afternoon after a parade of more than 1,000 persons. The church, of which the Rev. John B. Lyle is pastor, is nearing completion.

A proposal that the immigration laws of Palestine be relaxed in favor of German refugees and that TransJordan be opened to Jewish immigration, and an insistence that the projected British round-table conference with Arabs and Jews bei based only on the Balfour Declaration and the British Mandate, were embodied in resolutions adopted today at the final session of the fifteenth annual convention of Junior Hadassah, the Young Women's Zionist organization of America.

Senator Clark, Democrat- of Missouri, today joined the opposition to a domestic "two-price system," which has been proposed by Secretary Wallace as a possible solution of the farm products surplus problem.

Miss Borghild Marie Christiansen of Annandale, S. I., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry Christiansen, became the bride of William T. Blackwell Jr., son of Mr. Blackwell Q of this place in St. Paul's Episcopal m Church here yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur F. O'Donnell, the rector.

The cooperative campaign to be run next year by the Wine Institute, San Francisco, will result in more than doubling the amount the entire wine industry spent this year. If sectional campaigns are stimulated by the national drive, as appears likely, the sum will be further increased.

Repre sentative Dies, chairman of the House committee investigating unAmerican activities, made "urgent request" to Secretary of State Hull Ad today to instruct the Department of Justice or some other agency to Mi prosecute certain Communist and Nazi organizations in this country for failure to comply with the law requiring registration by agents of foreign principals.

Today's events: "Siegfried," Metropolitan Opera, evening; Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Marjorie Beeby, vocalist, Town Hall, 8:30; Sinsheimer String Quartet, Town Hall Club, 8:15; NewYork Philharmonic-Symphony String Quartet, Lexington Avenue Y. M. H. A., 9; Moriz Rosenthal, pianist, Bagby morning musical, Waldorf-Astoria.

Failure of the new Anglo-American trade treaty to improve the foreign demand for domestic wheat, and continued liquidation by holders of contracts for December delivery of that grain resulted last week in an easier undertone in the market.
Charles H. Turner, formerly conncted with the government mail service and express company, died today at his home here after a long (C illness. His age was 70.

The season's first "grand program" of the Metropolitan Opera, given last night before a large house, presented Leonard Warren, baritone, in his official debut. Mr. Warren, who hails from the Bronx, was one of the winners of last season's Metropolitan air auditions.

THERE they stand: Duke, Tennessee, Texas Christian and Notre Dame, the Big Four of the country-wide campaign on Autumn gridirons. Tennessee still has to play "Ole Miss," and Elmer Layden, the Thin Man of South Bend, will be leaving with his Notre Dame squad this evening for that game with Southern California on the Coast. Nobody should count those chickens

Mis, Elizabeth Margaret Wheatley daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Wheatley of this city, was mar ried this afternoon to Joseph S Wheeler, son of Mrs. Richard Gar rabrant of Bloomfield and the late Harvey E. Wheeler. The Rev. C. W Popham performed the ceremony ir Grace Episcopal Church, Ruther ford.
Prayers for the Pope and for peace were recited by every priest celebrating low mass in the archdiocese of New York yesterday and will continue indefinitely.
Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman opened their season before a large audience at the Guild Theatre last night with a most distinguished program, including two works new to New York.

Miss Evelyn Ch ndler of Brooklyn has been acceded co-star billing with Miss Bess Ehrhardt in the Ice Follies of 1939, the figure skating review which opens in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night and runs through Saturday. A familiar figure on New York's rinks for many years, Miss Chandler returns as an acknowledged leader, whose grace and superb technique is recognized the world over.

Local banks have been instructed by German banks to stabilize the price of aski marks, according to the newspaper Universo, which adds: "The German banks used the most peremptory terms in the latest communication and referred to previous instructions sent several months ago."

Offering will be made today of a new issue of 60,000 shares of $4.50 convertible cumulative. preferred stock of the National Gypsum Company, Buffalo. The stock will be offered by means of a prospectus at $100 a share by a group composed of W.-E. Hutton Co.; Blyth

For her recital yesterday after- I noon in Town Hall, Olga Averino had as usual arranged an unconventional and fascinating program, which in itself evidenced the Russian soprano's scholarly attitude toward her art. The list began with Casella's "Tre canzoni trecentesche."

Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Dotzbleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womnrath's: FICTION All This and Heaven Too, by Rachel Field (Macmillan). Rebecca. by Daphne Du Maurier (Doubleday, Doran). The Yearling, by MarJorie Kinnan Rawlings (Scribner).

Addison V. Foshay Jr., '39, of Brooklyn has been elected varsity wrestling captain at Princeton University to succeed Richard B. Harding, '40, of Brooklyn, who has resigned because of ill health and scholastic difficulties, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, graduate manager of athletics.

Professor Clyde R. Miller of New York, director of the Institute for Propaganda Analysis, said yesterday that America may expect "increasing Nazi propaganda" to justify the persecution of Jews, Catholics and Protestants in Germany."

Determined not to let the Eastern Division championship of the National Football League escape their grasp this year, the New York Giants will start work at full speed today for next Sunday's battle withthe Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds, which will determine the Eastern title-winner and representative for the play-off game with the Western Division victor.

Jens Daugaard-Jensen, director of the Greenland Administration Board, died here today of pneumonia at the age of 67. For more than twentyfive years he was managing director of Denmark's huge Polar colony and was considered the "father" of the Eskimo population because of Maj his work in protecting them from exploitation. During his

Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, Ad- yesterday ministrator for the Archdiocese of followed New York, dedicated and blessed the two new shrines in Holy Cross Church, 333 West Forty-second Street last night. One shrine is Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal and the other to the Sacred Heart.

The forwarding of a petition to President Roosevelt asking him to "intervene personally" for the admittance to this country of John Strachey, British author and I. turer, now on bail pending deportation proceedings, was announced yesterday by, the American Civil Liberties Union.

Human thought began when man acquired the power of separating objects, actions and qualities in his mind and giving them pantomimic symbols. This was the gist of an address delivered by Sir Richard Paget, British scientist, at the Pasteur Institute tonight under the auspices of the General Scientific Institute.

Liquidation developed in lard futures last week, with December and January selling at the lowest levels since 1934. Easiness in cottonseed oil and the lack of aggressive export demand more than offset the livestock handlers' strike in the local stoclkyards.
Thomas W. Head, for many years superintendent of the estate of Mrs. Herbert N. Straus here, died today. He was 73 years old.

Professional interests and ambitions of the average enteringfreshman at City College this year have changed considerably from those indicated by their precedessors who enrolled in September, 1929, at the height of the prosperity period, according to a report to Dr. Nelson P. Mead, .acting president, by Dr. Daniel F. Brophy, director of the college's personnel bureau.

The old-time Methodist preacher, often looked upon as a mild, weak individual, was really hearty and strong-willed, Bishop Francis J. McConnell declared in a sermon yesterday morning celebrating 130th anniversary of the Westchester Methodist Episcopal Church, East Tremont Avenue and Overing Street. the Bronx.
Baptized in a single ceremony, seventeen members of the Clay H. Murray family joined the congregation of the Greenville Lutheran Church today. The Rev. S. D.

Milton O. Loysen, Special Deputy Superintendent of Insurance since 1936, has been appointed executive director of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Labor Department, Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.
Cardinal O'Connell, Archbishop of Boston and dean of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States, today quietly celebrated the twentyseventh anniversary of his elevation to the Cardinalate.

The Cunard White Star liner Samaria is due to arrive today from England and Ireland. her passengers include Graham E. Lyon, J. G. Loiseaux, Dr. D. F. Bergthold, Mrs. A. T. Elsworth, Mrs. R. E. Lowler, Miss W. H. M. Morgan, Mrs. S. E. Cheetham, J. W. Dennison, D. D. Taylor and eight members of Noel Coward's "Words and Music" revue.

The Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, said in his sermon yesterday morning that he respected but could not follow the judgment of those peace-loving people-who say they

The veteran Walter Kinsella and his young partner, Bill Coyle, from Midston House, defeated George Cummings and Fred Alexander Jr. of the University Club in a red-hot five-game match in the fourth annual invitation pro-amateur squash racquets tournament at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Ten new hosiery shades for Spring, 1939, will be shown in the hosiery color card to be issued by the Textile Color Card Association to its members this week. The new tones are closely coordinated with color trends in costumes and accessories. Iron Fireman Manufacturing Company has doubled its production floor space with the purchase of second Cleveland plant. The prop erty purchased is the former Lang Body plant.

Sir Oswald Mosley, head of the British Fascist movement, was married in Munich Dec. 4, 1937, with Chancellor Hitler as one of the witnesses, the Daily Telegraph's Berlin correspondent reported tonight.

Erich Rix, president of the San st Francisco unit of the German- bi American League for Culture, announced today that the group had adopted a declaration condemning the Hitler government for "a regular pogrom against the Jews."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Not only was Abraham Lincoln familiar, as you intimate, with the words of Theodore Parker which he closely paralleled in his Gettysburg Address, but he was also acquainted with various other sayings very similar to his own unforgettable "government of the people, by the people, for the people."

The incumbent officers of the Treasurers Club of America were re-elected Saturday night at an annual meeting held in the Hotel Astor. Those re-elected were Allan J. Schnebbe, president; Saul Abraham, vice president; Harry B. Nelmes, treasurer; Harry A. Benson, financial secretary, and Charles R. Bowman, recording secretary. There was no opposition ticket.

James M. Cain's forthcoming novel, "The Modern Cinderella," has been purchased by Universal as a starring vehicle for Irene Dunne. It will be directed by John M. Stahl following completion of "Bull by the Horns," which will start shortly as a film version of Charles Bonner's story.

Eighteen of the athletes who will play on the Metropolitan All-Star college football team against the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field Saturday in a game for the benefit of Catholic, Jewish and Protestant refugees met Benny Friedman, their coach, at a luncheon at the Park Central Hotel yesterday and discussed plans for practice.

Burbridge, 1,265 Nelson Ave.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Perry Beadleston and their debutante daughter, Miss Margaret McG. Beadleston, will come from Hewlett, L. I., today and will be at the Berkshire for the Winter. Count and Countess Ferdinand Colloredo-Mannsfeld will be at the Savoy-Plaza for the Winter.

Two business and apartment buildings were destroyed early today by R a fire which left nineteen persons g: homeless, drove scores of others L into the streets and threatened for several hours to wipe out the entire business section of the town. Damage was estimated at more than $100.000.
