In a sermon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Sixtieth Street and Columbus Avenue, yesterday morning, the Rev. Thomas A. Fox of the Paulist Faothers declared that "a man's own soul is the primary school of peacemaking," and added:

In the guarded seclusion of the "Little White House" on Pine Mountain here President Roosevelt conferred until a late hour tonight with Hugh R. Wilson and William Phillips, this country's Ambassadors, respectively, to Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy, who arrived just before the dinner hour in response to a summons from the Chief Executive.
Dr. P. T. Schlesinger and S. Bruzza were winners yesterday in the fourth round of the annual championship at the Marshall Chess Club. The former defeated A. C. Cass and Bruzza won from T. A. Dunst.

The engagement is announced of Miss Shirley Rachles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Rachles of this city, to Alvin H. Lipton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Lipton of Paterson. Mr. Lipton was graduated from the Newark College of Engineering.

Dr. William-Miller Ford, surgeon and former president of the medical board of St. Vincent's Hospital, died Saturday night at his home, 55 East Eighty-sixth Street. Ill with a heart ailment since last Spring, Dr. Ford had been

Miss Elizabeth Levins, who for twenty years until her retirement in 1925 was secretary to district superintendents of the Board of Education, died Saturday in the St. John's Greenacre Home in Mamaroneck, N. Y. She was 78 years old.

David I. Bushnell Jr., ethnologist of the Smithsonian Institution, attribute today to Indian sculptors the "humanfootprints" occasionally found in 300,000-year-old rocks which have mystified scientists ti many years.
Sidney L. Goldstein of Baltimore has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Edna Goldstein of New York, to Walter S. Salant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron B. Salant of this city.

Mrs. May S. Mathews, widow of Albert. Henderson Mathews, real estate broker, died yesterday at the Leroy Sanitarium, 40 East Sixtyfirst Street, in her sixty-fifth year. She had lived at Brewster, N. Y.

Mrs. Thomas Wistar Whitall of Acorn Farm, this place, has announced the engagement of her second daughter, Miss A. Lovice Whitall, to John Moffat, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Moffat of Mount Kisco, N. Y. The announcement was made at a reception given here today at White Hall, the home of Miss Whitall's maternal grandmother, Mrs. Edward Livingston Coster.

Governor Earle said tonight that he had commuted the sentence of the youngest of six members of the Bruno family, convicted of the election eve massacre of five persons at Kelayres, Pa., four years ago. The Governor said that no

Prices of cotton moved narrowly and irregularly last week, with the near-by deliveries continuing to work higher, while the distant positions were slightly lower. On the New York Cotton Exchange active future deliveries showed for the week net changes ranging from an advance of 10 points to a decline of 5 points.

APOTHEKER--Yetta, on Nov. 27. Funeral from Jeffer Funeral Home, 452 New York Ave., near Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn, today, 10:30 A. M. Interment Bayside Cemetery. BISHOP-Albert C., in his sixty-eighth year, beloved husband of Ida May Bishop, and father of Jennie M. and Helen R. Reposing at the residence. 690 Academy St., until Wednesday. 7 P. M. Services at the Holy Trinity Chuich, Seaman Ave. and Academy St., Wednesday, 8 P. M. Funeral private.

The engagement of Miss Elise Conant Quinby, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William O'G. Quinby of this city, to Harry W. Harris, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Harris of East Orange, has been announced by her parents. The prospective bride was graduated- from the Dearborn-Morgan School in Orange and last June From Hollins College in Virginia.

Though a few more regularly scheduled games remain to be played, a curtain of falling snow was lowered Saturday on the season for most teams, a season that was one of the most satisfactory intercollegiate football has ever known.

A plan for readjustment of the capital structure of the Dewey Almy Chemical Company through the exchange of new $5 cumulative convertible preferred stock, plus common stock or cash, for the outstanding $7, prior preference, and $7 Class B preferred shares,

Pope Pius awakening this morning felt so well that he decided to serve notice on all and sundry both inside and outside the Vatican that he considered himself completely recovered from his attack of cardiac asthma suffered Friday morning.

Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of the Cuban Army, announced tonight that the reciprocal trade treaty with the United States would be revised, and that an appropriation of $50,000,000 for public works would be made available immediately.

The executive committee of the National Grange made public here tonight its "platform for agriculture," calling for elevation of farm prices to the "reasonable profit" level and revision of Federal farm policies.
Christian F. Weltzin, chief signal inspector for the Independent Subway System, died suddenly from a heart attack at his home, 90-23 149th Street, Jamaica, last night. He was 49 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bacon Rowley of Cleveland and Harwichport, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Jane Rowley, to Ralph Briggs Snow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hiram Snow of Harwichnort.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against BICHLER RETTIG, Inc., fur trimmings, 146 W. 29th St.-By Joseph Rothberg Co., Inc., upward of $250; Domestic Fur Co.. upward of $250; Central Fur Dyeing Corp., upward of $250. JOEL NOVELTY CORP., 241 W. 23d St.By Catalin Corp.. for $165: O. Kuehner Co.. Inc.. $145; Frank Morrow Co., Inc., $155; Novo Findings Co., $95.

One of the largest housing properties in the Bronx to change hands in some time passed to new control when Isaac Sherman sold to an investing client of the Kantor Real Estate Company, Samuel Kantor, president, the six-story elevator apartment building at 1,560 Grand Concourse, at Mount Eden Avenue.
Joseph Rollins of Patchogue, L. I., died today at Capri. He formerly was an interpreter in New York courts. His age was 87.

James Simpson, chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company, reported today that the Edison group of companies may make capital expenditures of $75,000,000 in the next two years to meet the growing demand for services. He said that $14,000,000 of funds now being raised by the sale of new securities had been reserved for construction.
A record holding movement by growers of corn, who are expected to pledge millions of bushels of that grain as collateral for government loans, resulted last week in a higher level of prices.
George B. Preston, banker and former village president of this town, died today at his Broad Street home here after a long illness. was t67 years old.

Sammy Roeder's spectacular feat of scoring 28 points for Franklin and Marshall Thanksgiving Day not only topped last week's offensive football activities in the East but catapulated him into the Eastern individual scoring lead.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Madison C. Bates of Maplewood of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Bates, to Edward L. Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell A. Clark of Pawlet, Vt.

Members of the Medical Society of the County of New York received a letter last week from Dr. Kingsley Roberts, chairman of the Medical Advisory Board of the Cooperative Health Association of New York, calling attention to what he termed the "vicious" possibilities of an "ethical" appendix to the by-laws of the county society, included among a number of other changes to be voted on tonight at the annual meeting.

Joseph B. Boyle, manager of the track, said today there would be no more racing at Bowie until Wednesday because of the frozen condition of the turf. Mr. Boyle inspected the track today and found it "in no condition."

A test to determine the relative strength of the r American Federation- of Labor and p the Congress of Industrial Organinations will be made tomorrow when the Chicago stock yards, closed for a week by a C. I. O. strike, will be reopened with A. F. s of L. stock handlers.

Reduced fares on the railroads will be in effect for the period of h the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday by the Fair officials. The Trunk Line Association of New York and the Central Passenger Association of Chicago already have announced a schedule of reductions on lines in their territories, and it b is expected that similar action will be taken by the Southern, Western, New England and Canadian Associations.

Professor and Mrs. Clarence P. Bill of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Adams Bill, to James Walton Osborn of Cleveland. Miss Bill is a graduate of the Laurel School here and Bryn Mawr College. Her fiance, a graduate of Amherst, is a senior at the Western Reserve University School of Mediine.
The first Latin-American insurance congress was inaugurated this morning at the University of Chile. It is sponsored by the Chilean Reinsurance Bureau.

For the right to work on Federally aided public works costing a total of $2,740,00 unskilled laborers will be forced to pay more than $6,000 to labor unions as Initiation fees, it Yor was learned here today.

The Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, protested yesterday before 3,000 persons at the Church of Our Lady of the Angels, Fourth Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, Brooklyn, "against the inconsistency of those who are attacking racial terrorism in Germany and have been unmoved by the more vicious religious terrorism in Mexico, Russia and Spain."
Breaking 94 out of 100, Harry Thoens won the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday.
The further fall of sterling against the dollar, which entails a decline of the franc, is commented upon in various ways here. It is ascribed to the
Over the snow-packed 10,000-meter course at Branch Brook Park, Don Lash today sped to his fifth consecutive national senior cross-country championship. But his margin at the
Students throughout Cuba commemorated today the sixty-seventh anniversary of the execution of nine Havana University students by the Spanish colonial government.

Frederick J. Waugh, 77-year-old artist fromProvincetown, Mass., today won the popular prize in the 1938 Carnegie International Exhibition with his "Pounding Surf" painting. It was the fifth time in succession that Waugh's marine paintings had received the $200 award.

Although current railway receipts, customs returns and bank clearings in Great Britain show a general decline, reports from industrial centers are not discouraging to business, this being evident from a modest revival in some directions, although probably under the spur of armament orders.

Closer cultural relationships between the Americas will be urged at the Lima conference with the suggestion by United States delegates that Puerto Rico, half way between the continents, be utilized as a center, particularly for the exchange of Spanish-speaking and Englishspeaking scholars. It is a concrete step in the broad plan to link more closely Latin-American countries and the United States.
Six young persons were killed and another was hurt today when their automobile went out of control on a hill five miles southwest of here and hit a tree. The dead are Harold L.
George H. Bartle of Fannettsburg, business manager of Wilson College from 1911 to 1937, and a member of its board of trustees, died here suddenly yesterday. He was 72 years old.

Clarity on the procedure to be followed in determining individual liability in conributions to the billion-mark fine levied on the Jews is established y a decree dated Nov. 21, stipulatng that all Jews of German nationality, whether living in the Reich r domiciled elsewhere and all stateless-but not foreign-Jews living in

An issue of 130,000 shares of Union Electric Company of Missouri $5 preferred stock will be offered to the public today through a prospectus by a banking group headed by Dillon, Read Co. The stock, initially represented by interim receipts, is priced at $106 plus accrued dividends.
Half of the Rose Bowl situation will be cleared tomorrow and the other half-the naming of the team to be invited to the Pasadena gridiron classic-doubtless will be clarified before the week is out.

The report of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $5,860,316 after operating expenses and taxes, but before foreign exchange adjustments.

Ordinarily members of the Supreme Court do not participate in the memorial service conducted by the Bar Association of the court for a justice who has died in office. But the serene and liberal spirit of Justice Cardozo may have crossed the still waters to be present awhile at the services in the court chamber where distinguished lawyers honored his memory on Saturday.
State police received word early today a unit of the rescue forces battling through heavy snow to the relief of 100 isolated hunters and CCC youths near Aurora had reached its objective.

A gain of more than 5 per cent in building construction employment during October, providing jobs for 111,000 additional workers, was reported yesterday by the statistical division of the National Industrial Conference Board. The increase for employment in all industries was 0.6 per cent over September.
Dr. John Henry Wilms, physician and surgeon, died at his home here today after a short illness. He was 59 years old.

The Edward Hines Jr. Memorial Hospital, in the suburb of Maywood, largest veterans' hospital in the world, was placed under quarantine for diphtheria today. Colonel Hugh Scott, manager, said fourteen cases of the disease had been found among the 1,750 patients.

Slingin' Sammy Baugh pitched the Washington Redskins to a 15-to-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today to keep them in the race for the Eastern division championship of the National Football League.

Armed policemen patrolled the Falls Road area of Belfast tonight after having cleared the streets of Republican demonstrators. A meeting of United Ireland sympathizers, advocates of union with the Irish Republic, ended with a stone-throwing attack on the police barracks while the crowd sang the forbidden "Soldiers' Song."

One American industry which increased its importance during a period of general business recession was the salad dressing industry, which with an almost continuous upward climb during recession years, reached the highest output in its history last year, according to a study by the marketing research division of the Department of Commerce, made public today.

The General Council of the annual Northern Baptist Convention will hold its semi-annual meeting for the first time in this city beginning tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock and continuing Wednesday Sessions will be held in the Prince George Hotel. A meeting of the

Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., won the $5,000 Columbia-Ridgewood open golf tournament today, with an even par score of 284 for the four rounds. He was just one stroke ahead of his nearest rivals, Harry Cooper of Chicopee, Mass., and Craig Wood of Mamaroneck, N. Y

The fruits of tan years of labor by missionaries, social workers and the government to build in China a modern and unified State have been all but swept away by the Japanese invasion, and work must start anew, the Rev. Dr. Edwin E. Walline said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue at Ninetv-first Street.

Anselmo Abreau, 40 years old, a WPA carpenter, was held yesterday for shooting Mrs. Marina Rodriquez Barana, also 40, and August Rodriquez, 42, a barber, in a room occupied by the woman at 911 Longwood Avenue, the Bronx. Mrs.

After waiting three years the Staten Island Ski Club finally succeeded in holding a jumping competition on its 300-foot hill yesterday. 'By hard work the club members had the slide in good condition and a large crowd gathered on the slopes of West Brighton to see the riders in action.
Harry A. Stella of Kankakee, Ill., Army's great right tackle, was elected captain of the 1939 football team today as the squad made the journey home from the Navy game in Philadelphia.

The weak tendency prevailing in the securities market here last week continued early this week, but after explicit information about the mode of collection of the Jewish levy, payment of which is to be made in four installments spread over ten months, and when expectations
The Eastern Baseball League unanimously elected Scranton to replace Hazleton today and chose Tommy Richardson of Williamsport for a four-year term as president of the circuit.

Realty deals reported over the week-end in Queens and Nassau indicated a demand for dwellings. Two dwellings at 41-11 Fuller Place, Flushing, L. I., were sold by Mrs. Florence Moran to Arthur Jerome of Flushing through the Halleran Agency, broker.

The new residence containing six rooms and occupying a plot 37 by 100 feet at 768 Hudson Avenue, West New York, N. J., was sold by Malte J. Carlson to William Von Dohlen for occupancy. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

The territorial claims at Versailles of former President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia are severely criticized by David Lloyd George in the second and concluding volume of "The Truth About the Peace Treaties," published today.

The Boston Bruins avenged their only setback of the season by overwhelming the New York Americans, weary from playing three games in four nights, by a top-heavy 8-2 margin tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden tonight. Thus the Bruins gained first place in the league with the Americans and the Chicago Black Hawks.

The Rev. William James Drummond, considered the oldest Presbyterian missionary in China service, died late last night from an illness that followed suffering from the Japanese invasion of China. His age was 74. When the invading

Most of, the new soy bean crop is reported to have left farmers' hands and an effort by shorts last week to cover their sales of futures on the Board of Trade disclosed a lack of pressure. Closing quotations yesterday

A tea, with dancing, was given yesterday at the Versailles under the auspices of the junior committee .of. the Italian Welfare -League. Proceeds will be used to further the work of the league in providing Italian children of poor families with clothing, food and recreational and educational pursuits.
Trade negotiations with Moscow are expected in the near future following yesterday's Polish-Russian declaration reaffirming the non-aggression pact of 1932, as renewed in 1934.

Park Terrace Gardens, Inc., David Rose, president, has obtained from the Equitable Life Assurance Society a loan of $1,800,000 to finance erection of five eight-story and penthouse apartments on the block bounded by Park Terrace East, 215th Street, Park Terrace West and 217th Street. The loan was

Sidney Markman, sought by the Brooklyn police since he was named in an indictment in the slaying of Isidore Frank, wealthy poultry dealer, in a hold-up last January in front of the latter's home at 733 Alabama Avenue, Brooklyn, was returned to Brooklyn yesterday morning in the custody of two deputy sheriffs who brought him to this city from Detroit.
Recently we devoted a good part of this column to the suggested tackle specifications for big-game fishing as proposed by Thomas Aitken, recognized authority on this sport. At the conclusion of our

Departing on Friday for Lima, Peru, where he will act as economic adviser to the American delegation attending the Pan-American Conference there next month, Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, predicted that definite moves binding all American countries to closer ing commercial relationships will result from the meetings.
Continued denunciation of the persecution of minorities abroad was ,heard in church, synagogue and forum throughout the city yesterday.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.5, which compared with 80.4 the week before, 80.5 two weeks before, 80.4 three weeks before and 80.4 four weeks before.

The world today is fighting the greatest war in history, and we can be saved only by a program of "moral rearmament" to produce "new men, new nations, a new world," Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman, founder and leader of the Oxford Group, declared yesterday in a radio address from England. Dr.
On Thursday of this week, after nearly six months of preparation, the Government, through its Temporary National Economic Committee, will begin an investigation of "monopoly."

The award of twelve honor scholarships at Princeton University, including several grants-in-aid established in the last year, was announced today by Professor Robert K. Root, dean of the faculty and chairman of the university committee on scholarships. All the awards are highly remunerative and are given to students with high scholastic standing, most of whom are active in campus affairs.

Creation of a Provisional Council Against Anti-Semitism, consisting of fifty-two distinguished Americans of varied faiths, was announced yesterday by Senatorelect W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey; William Allen White,
Duringg the first week in Decemr the Museum of Modern Art will blish "Bauhaus: 1919-1928," a rvey of the work done during the st decade at the school of design ablished at Weimar by Walter opius.

Ejection if Jewish-tenants from apartment houses, reported by extremist Nazi Drgans to be imminent, apparently will raise knotty problems until existing laws for protecting tenants have been revised. Authorities,
Monty Stratton, Chicago White Sox pitcher, was wounded in the right leg in a hunting accident today and was taken to a Dallas hospital.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 62 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the preceding week but up 1 point from the week before that.
Talk of price advances on Spring lines of furniture was general in the wholesale market here last week, as retailers turned their attention to the merchandise to be shown here in January.

Angna Enters gave her first performance of the season last night at the Alvin Theatre. Her program included four new numbers: "Mr. Mozart Has Breakfast," "Balletomane-Connoisseur," "La Cuisine Francaise" and "Impertinente-Hab

Heber Wallace Peters of Detroit, former vice president of the Packard Motor Company, has been appointed provost of Cornell University, with the primary function of coordinating efforts to increase the university's financial resources, President Edmund E. Day announced today.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin replied to critics who accused him of anti-Semitism by broadcasting yesterday an electrical transcription of the previous Sunday's criticized address and amplifying his charge that Jews helped finance the Communist revolution in Russia.
Almost every day brings new success to the British military authorities in their campaign to wipe out Arab terrorIsts in Palestine. There has been relatively little bloodshed.

The markets here last week generally remained in a dispirited condition. The main factor in the current downward drift of security quotations is the rising international tension occasioned by Germany's treatment of the Jews and the consequent serious setback of the efforts toward European appeasement.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Congregation EmanuEl, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street, voiced a plea yesterday morning for "thought which makes you thankful, even in this hour, for being brought into this world a Jew." He said that the world must be thankful for the fact that out of a little people in Palestine came hopes, visions and enterprises to humanize mankind and moralize humanity.

Ludlow St, 90: Nettie Lazarowitz to Bessie Kurzban, 146 Henry St. 1st St, 7 E: Broadway Savings Bank to Harry Greenberg, 65 2d Ave ($6.50). 10th St. 43-47 E: William R. Bogert. referee. to Thomas G. Greene, 1.320 E 26th St, Brooklyn, trustee, foreclosure ($65). 102d St. 230 E: Robert J. Williams to House Renovating, Inc. 286 E 137th St ($1).
C. E. Weaver, general manager of the Central of Georgia Railway, died at a hospital here early today after a brief illness. His age was 61.
Burr Co., Inc., and Morse Brothers Co., Inc., will offer today $490,000 of Brookfield-North Riverside Water Commission, Ill., 4 per cent water revenue bonds.
Although no change has yet been made in the fiduciary issue of the Bank of England, some increase is by no means improbable before the Christmas pressure for currency arises. Last year the fiduciary

Exports of food products from the United States last month amounted to $33,220,000, which was slightly in excess of the September total of $31,349,000 but about 15 per cent lower than in October, 1937, when the aggregate was $38,849,000, according to the Department of Commerce.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret L. Haynes, daughter of Merritt W. Haynes of Cranford, to Meredith S. Conley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Conley, also of this place.

Commemorating the 103d anniversary of Mark Twain's birth, the Mark Twain Association met in the Hotel Astor yesterday and announced Mrs. A. G. Karl of San Diego, Calif., as winner of the association's twelfth annual quotation contest. Dr. William Lyon Phelps was chairman of the judges for the international contest.

Dr. Willis Sacket Knighton, in 121 E 61st St; Frank J. Welton Co, brokers. Edward W. Sims and Kenneth C. Quencer: National Tie-Ins, Inc, in Graybar Building, 420 Lexington Ave, and additional space in same building to Electric Utilities Exhibit Corp, Ethyl Gasoline Corp and Superior Brands, Inc; Joseph Z. Corey, renting manager.

Ruhr coal production amounted to 10,704,907 tons in October, against 10.351,784 tons in September, both months having had twenty-six working days, while the corresponding figures last year were 11,052,618 and 10,775,094 tons. For the whole Reich, however, coal production in October, 1938, amounted to 15,640,000 tons, against 16,110,000 a year ago.

Convinced that the market for expensive radio sets has been ruined, temporarily at least, by the prospect of television in the Spring of next year, most manufacturers have decided to concentrate on their small table models and on those cabinet sets retailing under $100, they reported yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Augustin Snow Hart of Garden City, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie M. Hart, to Eliot M. Wadsworth of Boston. The prospective bride is the twin sister of Augustin S. Hart Jr. She attended .the Cherry Valley School and Adelphi College in Garden City, and the Art Students League and the French Institute in New York.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Florence Vennema of this city, daughter of the late Rev. and Mrs. Ame Vennema, to the Rev. Lawrence H. French of Red Hook, N. Y.
Possibly some slackening in pace of production occurred last week. At all events, estimated steel output decreased from 621/3 per cent of capacity to 611/2.

A Night of Arts" will be held Wednesday at the Bronxville Womens Club by the literary department to aid the MacDowell Colony of Peterborough, N. H. Mrs. Edward MacDowell, widow of the composer and founder of the colony, will be the guest of honor. Carl Cramer, writer, will be the master of ceremonies.

The office of the German Consulate General announced yesterday that coupons of the American portion of the German Government 51/2 per cent international loan of 1930, known as the Young Loan, which are due on Dec. 1, may sell their coupons against American dollars at a price of $20 per $27.50 face amount of the coupon.

In the climax of her debut on this side of the Atlantic, the Yorkshire terrier bitch, Miss Wynsum, owned by Arthur Mills of Roseland, N. J., last night took the best-in-show laurels at the Progressive Dog Club's sixth annual toy breed event at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Because of the censorship, which cut telephonic communications with foreign countries whenever atempts were made to give details of today's events, it is impossible to give the full facts concerning the present 'situation.

The elaboration of codes to bridge the gaps in civilization must ultimately collapse, the Rev. Dr. man Charles W. Gilkey warned in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riv erside Church. Dr. Gilkey, who is dean of the chapel of the University of Chicago, said it was only
With snow heaped on shore and the houses there appearing like igloos in a polar village, Winter sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club carried on today. In the snow, ice and

A hold-up attempt by an unidentified man armed with two pistols, in the lobby of the fourteen-story apartment house at 14 Washington Church Place, near Greene Street, was foiled at 2:20 o'clock this morning when one of his victims floored the thug while another struck him on the head with one of his own pistols, knocking him unconscious.

The Clare Tree Major Children's Theatre will present Hector Malot's "Nobody's Boy" for its New York premiere at a special matinee performance on Dec 27 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The matinee is sponsored by the Social Service Auxiliary of the Cancer Institute.

WHEN I was young and relatively vigorous, I started out to read a book by Dorothy Richardson called "Pointed Roofs." It wasn't a very long book, but I barely got it finished. Miss Richardson went on and on and on-and onabout a certain Miriam Henderson, describing patiently and minutely what Miriam thought, what Miriam dreamed, what Miriam did, what Miriam said, and this in rather novel though crabbed English. The difficulty was that I couldn't

The East and Middle West were digging out yesterday from under the snows of a second storm as the cold set a new Weather Bureau consecutive November days on which the temperature average was more than 10 degrees below normal.

Youngest of all the eight experts who have been competing for three weeks in the A. V. R. O. international chess tournament, Reuben Fine of New York and Paul Keres of Parnu, Estonia, today finished in a tie for first place, each credited with 8 1/2 points out of a possible 14, against the best talent available in the world at the present time.

As reported by the Federal Reserve Board on Friday, surplus reserves of the member banks, rising $90,000,000 for the week to $3,350,000,000, crossed the previous maximum of $3,304,000,000, reached on Dec. 11. 1935.

King George will be accompanied on his visit to Canada next Spring by Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary, and by the Duke of Devonshire, Under-Secretary for Dominion Affairs, it was reported this morning. It is understood, however, that if these Ministers go with King George they will not make the tour of Canada.
Japanese construction of a vast military base near Woosung, at the mouth of the Whangpoo River, downstream from Shanghai, added today to foreign apprehension over Japan's future plans in China.

The golden jubilee of the Congrenational Church of North New York, East 143d Street near Willis Avenue, the Bronx, was marked at yesterday morning's service. The observance will be continued with a concert by the Carapetyan choir Tuesday evening, a church service Wednesday evening with an address by the Rev. Dr. J. Stanley Durkee, minister of the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Brooklyn, and an anniversary fellowship dinner Thursday night.

The increasing philosophy of despair in the world today is due largely to man's hatred and fear of his fellow-men and to consequent failure to love God, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic Universitv of America at Washing

Workers who obtain temporary or part-time jobs during the Christmas season were advised yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, to obtain social security account numbers. Housewives or

In the presence of Board of Education members, labor leaders and city officials, Mayor La Guardia will lay the cornerstone for the Central Needle Trades High School, first of the "skyscraper schools" to be constructed in this city, at a special ceremony tomorrow morning.
Representative Hamilton Fish of New York appealed today for the election of Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts as Republican floor leader in the next House.

Counsel for the Manhattan Railway Company had under consideration yesterday the bringing of one or more court actions in a further effort to block condemnation and demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated line. The Board of Estimate

Thanksgiving has passed in a whirl of snow, and Christmas, like our old friend Prosdaysperity, is just around the corner. Thanksgiving, handed down to us by the Puritans who faced a hard life and many perils, is essentiallv a festival for grown-ups.

Tribute to the Christian Church for denouncing anti-Semitism "with the tongues of the prophets that have lashed out with furious indignation at social corruption" was paid today by Rabbi Beryl D. Cohon in a sermon at Temple Israel, Boston's largest synagogue.

About 3,000 delegates from organizations numbering 30,000 persons in this area adopted a resolution tonight extending sympathy to "the millions of German people who still cherish the German ideals of freedom. justice and toleration."

Reported persecution of the Ukrainian minority in Poland brought a protest from 3,000 Americans of Ukrainian extraction, many of whom wore the native Ukrainian costume, at a mass meeting today at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Favorable signs in business were not lacking .here last week. For instance, the lowering of the bank rate from 3 to 21/2 per cent was accompanied by further reduction in interest on the defense bonds and Treasury bills.
Guelph Carpet and Worsted Spinning Mills, Ltd. (Canada)-Year to Sept. 30: Net profit after depreciation and taxes, $35,005, compared with $96,629, on the same basis, in preceding year.

The Zacchinis, who shoot each other from cannons to amuse circus-goers, were accused yesterday of disturbing the neighbors by their offstage activities. Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Smith of Bayville, L. I., and St. Petersburg, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor F. Smith, to Arthur L. Jerome, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Jerome of Cleveland.

A complaint against Rogers Imports, Inc., 9-11 East Thirty-eighth Street, New York, has been served by the Federal Trade Commission, charging that it represented Japanese-made ash trays, tobacco jars and other smokers' supplies as domestic products."

A member of James A. Farley's office staff said tonight that the Democratic National Chairman had arranged to meet party leaders from the West and Midwest in Chicago next Tuesday and Wednesday Tuesday and Wednesday.
John Dickinson Palmer, prominent in New Brunswick industry and public life, here today after a long illness. age was 68.

Patronesses prominent in more than ten communities in Northern New Jersey have been announced for the Elizabeth holiday and Assembly subscription dances to be held at Elizabeth Town and Country Club on Dec. 22 and 30 and March 31. Two assemblies for the older groups will take place next Friday and April 1.

Annual convention, Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, 10 A. M. Luncheon 12:30 P. M. Afternoon session, 2;30 P. M. Sessions tomorrow. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Outlook in the Far East," Walter H. Mallory.

Maulana West Virginia Shaukat Ali, one of the leaders of the uncompromising section of Indian Moslems which opposed the with participation of India in the World War because of its respect for the Sultan of Turkey as Caliph of Islam, died today of a heart ailment at the age of 65.

Labels showing compliance with the Wages and Hours Law are not necessary on goods produced under labor standards prescribed by the law, nor are certificates of compliance necessary on invoices, Paul Sifton Deputy Administrator of the Wages and Hours Division, said today.

Anton C. Weiss, publisher and general manager of The Duluth Herald from 1892 to 1921 and long prominent in bank age of 76. Taken ill with pneumonia, he was admitted to a hospital for treatment on Nov. 18.
The Montreal Canadiens scored their first victory of the National Hockey League season by downing the hapless Detroit Red Wings tonight, 3 to 2. The Canadiens had lost seven games and tied one.

Secretary of state corden Hull began a series of conferences today with members of other delegations on projects of mutual interest to be considered at the PanAmerican conference in Lima next month. The Secretary met separately with Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, Mexican Ambassador to Washington and leader of his country's delegation, and Ambassador Miguel Lopez Pumarejo, one of Colombia's representatives.

Notwithstanding the earlier decision of Vincent de Moro-Giafferi, noted Paris lawyer, not to proceed with the defense of Herschel Grynszpan in the slaying of Ernst vom Rath, secretary of the German legation, he has now acceded to the desire of the Jewish boy and will be his principal advocate.

The Japanese Government has no intention of asking the recall of Sir Robert Leslie Craigie, the British Ambassador here, the Foreign Office spokesman said today, adding that the attack of the newspaper Kokumin on the Ambassador represented only the Kokumin' view and not the government's.

The labor committee of the Twentieth Century Fund announced last night that it is now engaged in an impartial survey of labor relations in the United States. Originally appointed in 1934 the committee made a special study of the role of the government in labor relations and its report, "Labor and Government" was published in 1935.
The British Board of Trade is understood to be negotiating with the Russian Government for a new trade treaty, but some time is expected to elapse before agreement is reached.
Bishop William T. Manning dedcated yesterday the newly-built parish house of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Em phasizing the great importance of the Panama Canal to the Navy's defense of the Atlantic and Pacific coasts with a single fleet, Secretary of War Woodring declared in his annual report to the President, made public today, that the canal "must be made impregnable."
The Cabinet crisis apparently will be solved, at the wish of Regent Nicholas Horthy, by a reconciliation between Premier Bela Imredy and dissident members of the Government party.

In "Glorious Morning" Norman Macowan is paving the Mansfield. Theatre with good intentions. He is portraying the tragic plight of a modern Joan of Are who sees religious visions in an anti-religious totalitarian state. At this dark.

Egbert Moxham Jr. won four straight races in the B onedesign class in the Manhasset Bay Frostbite dinghy regatta today for a perfect score, while Allan Clark took three out of four and finished second in the other to win handily in Class D.
A crippled widow perished today in a fire that swept a frame apartment building in this Delaware -County community.

The Nazi persecution of the Jews undoubtedly is the principal factor now dominating the European Bourses insofar as it has almost completely throttled buying interest, and given impetus to a move to have ample liquid funds available.

The engagement of Miss Louise Makepeace McKelvy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Graham McKelvy of Oakhurst, this city, to James Herron Walker Jr. of Bethlehem, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walker of Salina, Kan., has been announced by her parents.

Miss Anne Montrose Sneed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. U. Sneed of this city, became the bride of Kenneth Ian Deane, son of Mrs. Walter S. Orr of New York and Orr's Mills, last evening in St. George's Church here. The Rev. Harold Belshaw of the Yale Divinity School and the Rev. Philip M. Styles, rector of St. George's, performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Noel Armstrong has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Anne Corbin Armstrong, to Francis Brooks of Massachusetts, which took place Saturday noon at Danskammer Farm, the Armstrong home in Newburgh. Owing to the recent death of the bride's father, the late Noel Armstrong, only relatives were present at the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Andrew Van de B. Vos and the Rev. Claude McIntosh, both of Marlborough.

By two effective methods-radio appeals and requisition-Premier Edouard Daladier's Government is fighting the general strike called for Wednesday and, it would seem, is doing so with growing chances of success.

Continuing to manufacture goals at a wholesale clip, the New York Rovers, Eastern Hockey League leaders, swamped the Toronto Goodyears, 9 to 1, in the feature clash of an amateur twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
THE ART OF ENJOYING ART, by A. Philip McMahon. (Whittlesey House, $3.) An examination of sensation, technique and form in art.

Two National Football League records were broken and another was tied today on Wrigley Field's frozen turf as Chicago's Cardinals ran and passed Cleveland's Rams to a 31-to-17 defeat in the closing game of the season here.

Mr. and Mrs. Archibald M. Reid gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 941 Park Avenut, to introduce their daughter, Miss Jean Arnot Reid. Miss Reid wore a frock of pale blue chiffon. Her mother's gown was of gray lace.
It will be proper for Cardinals to be addressed in Germany hereafter as plain "Mr. Cardinal," according to a decree issued today by Hanns Kerrl. Reich Church Minister.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Edgar Schenkman, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the Federal Music Theatre. The program consisted of Beethoven's "Coriolanus" overture, Schubert's symphony in C major, and the Glazunoff violin concerto, with Noah Bielski as soloist.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Bower Saul of Rose Valley, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Saul, to Harry E. Sprogell, son of Mrs. Frank E. Sprogell of Lansdale, Pa.

Supply contracts valued at $6,299,795 were awarded during the the week ended Nov. 19 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Deapartment announced today.

Deep concern is expressed in business circles at the huge increase in the State's financial requirements which are reported in official quarters to be necessary "to carry on the tasks the Reich has undertaken," chief among which are the operations of the four-year plan and immense developments in Austria and Sudetenland.

John L. Lewis, president of the newly created Congress of Industrial Organizations, will head the labor delegation this afternoon when the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. o. member, confers with Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, on a. new wages and hours contract on behalf of the company's 14,000 employes.

The New York State Chamber of Commerce made public yesterday report declaring that, because of the developments in the last ten years, the prospect of the St. Lawrence canal and power project becoming a valuable utility "are less today than at any time since it was first proposed."
John Dembeck, violinist, who made his debut in Town Hall last season, gave his second recital in the same surroundings last night, assisted by Yella Pessl, harpsichordist. The program consisted

Under the pressure of the Polish advance and as a result of the desultory skirmishing between Czechoslovak and Polish troops that has been going on since Friday, Czech troops today evacuated most of the areas which, it had been agreed, should not be handed over to Poland until Thursday.

With Bradley Craig scoring the tying and winning goals, the Crescent Athletic Club downed the New York Sporting Club, 4 to 3, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association test at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. The victory placed the Crescents in a first place tie with St. Nicholas, each team having two victories and no defeats.

A woman who turned a pistol over to the police because of fear that her father might end his life was arraigned in Queens Felony Court yesterday on a charge of illegally possessing the weapop, but Magistrate Joseph De Andrea told her that the arrest was a technicality and "not to worry."

Striking swiftly with a pass and sensational run combining luck and quick thinking, the University of Detroit's Titans defeated Santa Clara's Broncos by 7 to 6 today and delivered a smashing blow to Far Western football prestige.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy yesterday afternoon dedicated and blessed the new school and convent of St. Pascal Baylon Parish at 113th Avenue' and 199th Street, Hollis, Queens. The Rev. Patrick B. Kinsella, pastor of the parish, was master of ceremonies. The Rev. George I. Frey was the guest speaker.

Striking swiftly with a pass and sensational run combining luck and quick thinking, the University of Detroit's Titans defeated Santa Clara's Broncos by 7 to 6 today and delivered a smashing blow to Far Western football prestige.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy yesterday afternoon dedicated and blessed the new school and convent of St. Pascal Baylon Parish at 113th Avenue' and 199th Street, Hollis, Queens. The Rev. Patrick B. Kinsella, pastor of the parish, was master of ceremonies. The Rev. George I. Frey was the guest speaker.

Several prominent clergymen of Manhattan will speak at a mass meeting "to condemn the Nazi government's attack on civilization" to be held at 8 P. M. Wednesday at the Judson Memoral Baptist Church, 55 Washington Square, South. The meeting has been called

At the first meeting held in Vienna of the German National Colonial League, the principal speaker, Wilhelm Ruphaupt, who founded the League of German Colonial Friends here in 1924, denounced today what he termed the oppressive tactics employed in African colonies at present.

The engagement of Miss Bessie Holden Spear, daughter of Mrs. Cameron Spear of Rahway and the late Mr. Spear, to James Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith, also of this place, has been announced by her mother.

The story of an aged Negro who, to maintain his "good name with the white folks," captured his own son and surrendered him to officers to face a murder charge was related here yesterday by Constable E. B. Beasley.

Dr. and Mrs. Winfield A. Peterson of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucille Arlene Peterson, to William T. Holmes, son of Dr. and Mrs. C. A. Holmes of Riverdale. New York.

The Fine Arts Substitutes Association, which has been working for a year on behalf of more than seventy high school substitute art teachers who have not been able to become regular teachers because they got failing marks in drawing examinations, announced yesterday that it was resorting to a new strategy.

Winters are not what they used to be. To go back into a bit of history which has a particular interest here, the establishment of this newspaper was first planned by two men who were walking across the Hudson River opposite Manhattan on the ice.

The Rev. Dr. Andrew Rule Osborn, 63 years old, formerly pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Edmonton, Alberta, has accepted a call to the 127-year-old Spring Street Presbyterian Church, near Varick Street.

Rear Admiral Edward B. Barry, U. S. N., retired, who relinquished his com mand of the Pacific Fleet under the shadow of a scandal, dropped dead today after returning to his home from church services. His age was 89.
The German wholesale price index on Nov. 23 was up to 106.3 from 106.0 a week before.

First definite steps toward the establishment of medical insurance for all Californians on a monthly payment basis were taken here today when a special committee of the State Medical Association announced principles to be recommended for the project.

A slight falling-off in the number of new exhibitions this week-a semi-lull before the pre-Christmas rush begins-leaves, nevertheless, more than a score of attractions on its schedule. Curt Valentin has arranged at the Buchholz Gallery a memorial show of sculpture and drawings by the late Ernst Barlach, one of the most widely known of modern German sculptors, which opens to the public tomorrow.

A quota of $1,000,000 in contributions and investments for Palestine next year was set up yesterday by the National Labor Committee for Palestine at the final session of its convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The meeting, at which H.

An appeal to any one having cans knowledge of the slayers of her hus- next band to communicate with the authorities was made yesterday by Mrs. Margaret Hitter, widow of Thomas J. Hitter, a fireman who was attached to Engine Company 290, at 480 Sheffield Avenue, Brook lyn, who was slain by bandits in front of the fire house on Oct. 31 as he returned from a bank with his company's $3,400 pay-roll.
Expenditures of $23,889.14 were reported yesterday to the Secretary of State by the citizens committee for the reelection of John J. Bennett Jr., and other Democratic candidates.

Miss Jeanne Meierhoffer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles J. Meierhoffer of this city, will be married on Jan. 2 to Anderson Force Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. K. Evans. The ceremony will be performed in the Third Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. William G. Felmeth, the pastor. The bride-elect's

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 69 on Nov. 23, compared with 69.3 a fortnight before, 70 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "the Christian has been initiated by his belief in the Lord, Jesus Christ, into
The recent unabated fall of sterling and the hesitant resistance on the part of the British control have created surprise in The Netherlands.

Chief of Police Harry H. Clayton died at his home here early today following a stroke. He was prominent in State and national police association circles, having served as vice president of the New Jersey Association of Police Chiefs.
Stocks declined to lowest levels of the month in moderately active trading; turnover, 4,321,120 shares. All groups of bonds irregularly lower on the week; transactions, $28,230,400.
Spanish Insurgents indicated today that systematic attacks on strategic government ports would be Generalissimo Francisco Franco's main weapons during the Winter months.

In the Broadway sector, "Soliloquy" opens tonight at the Empire after a Coast try-out. This is Victor Victor's psychological study of a young white collar worker in which a sound track of the character's thoughts is synchronized with his spoken lines.

The Commerce Department was informed today that exports of sugar from Cuba in the first ten months of this year amounted to 2,356,753 long tons, as compared with 2,341,960 long tons in the corresponding period last year.
The Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor, has been engaged to appear at the Golden Gate International Exposition at San Francisco for fifteen weeks, from March 19 to July 2.

Edward L. Waller, 46-year-old brother of Thomas (Fats) Waller, Negro orchestra leader, was. shot twice and seriously wounded and his assailant, Thomas Kehoe, 22, an ex-convict, was badly beaten early yesterday morning in a quarrel that followed a request of two girls for the orchestra leader's autograph.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Sichel of Windymere, this city, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yvonne-Eugnie Sichel, to Richard Cooper Passmore, son of Mr. and airs. Roy Hershey Passmore of Pelham, N. Y.

Mrs. C. Minot Weld of 118 East Fifty-fourth Street has announced the engagement of her stepdaughter, Miss Joya Winthrop Weld, to John Granbery, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Carlton Granbery of Stony Brook, Greenwich. Conn.

Mrs. Adam H. Stiehl of Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Stiehl, to James McPhillips Tonsmeire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Tonsmeire of Port Washington, L. I., formerly of Mobile, Ala.

The return of the Bank of France for Nov. 17 shows changes due to the revaluation of the gold reserve. This metal now is carried at 31,456,000,000 francs, and, with the profit on balances the bank held abroad, has been applied to repayment of temporary loans to the State.
The French weekly wholesale price index on Nov. 19 stood at 653, unchanged from the week before.

The Elgar 'cello concerto, Op. 85, arranged for viola and orchestra "with the sanction of the composer" by the noted English violist, Lionel Tertis, was heard yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall at the- Philharmonic-Symphony concert. Zoltan Kurthy, the orchestra's first violist, was soloist; John Barbirolli conducted.
Dr. Edward N. (Eddie) Anderson, who in six years compiled one of the best football coaching records in the country, resigned tonight as head gridiron coach at Holy Cross College.

Irrespective of whether 'the Germans are merely aiming at economic penetration of Brazil or have deep designs against Brazilian sovereignty, one thing is certain: today they are the most formidable foreign factor in this country.

The railroads reported today that they had made coal work for them more efficiently this year than ever before. The Association of American Railroads announced that in the first nine months of the year the carriers hauled eight and four-fifths
Two young Canadian brothers qualified as champion grain growers today when they moved into the "king row" at the international grain and hay show.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hochstadter of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Hochstadter, to Bennett Godfrey Galef, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques L. Galef of New York and Seabright, N.J.

Last-minute calls for gift merchandise of all types, rush orders for ski apparel and active interest in formal wear characterized activity in the wholesale markets last week. Business was only fair in the dress and coat markets, although there was considerable interest in new promotional groups of dressy coats and cold weather stimulated orders for heavy fleece sports coats. Gloves sold well in

Cooperating with Park Commissioner Robert Moses in his general plan for the improvement of City Hall Park, the Board of Transportation will hold a public hearing Friday afternoon on the draft of a contract for alterations and relocations of subway entrances and exits in the area.
The September hurricane, according to the current issue of the Guaranty Trust Company's house organ, made necessary the use of pants-pressers in getting the water out of securities. Securities

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Florence Mackie, daughter of Mrs. James Barker Mackie of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Mackie, to Warner Stuart Goshorn, son of Mrs. George Goshorn of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Goshorn.

Preliminary arrangements are being made for Prime Minister Neville ChamberlaiN to go to Rome at the end of January for consultations with Premier Benito Mussolini on Mediterranean and African questions, according to The Daily Telegraph.

Operas which will receive their first presentation of the Winter during the third week of the Metropolitan season comprise "Manon," "Pagliacci" and "Salome." That week also will see the initial appearances this season of Hilda Burke and Renee Maison.
The one definite conclusion to be drawn from the Gallup poll of gambling habits in the United States is that Uncle Sam still remains a cheerful optimist. More than half our population

Soccer fields throughout the East were snowbound yesterday, with the result that many scheduled championship matches in the American, National, Metropolitan, Empire State and German-American League had to be postponed.
Mr. and Mrs. William A. Adriance gave a tea yesterday at their home, 17 East Ninety-sixth Street, for Mrs. Charlotte Lindholm and William Rodman, whose engagement was announced recently.

The China Aid Council, 268 Fourth Avenue, issued a statement yesterday denying a charge made on Tuesday before the Dies committee.by Stuart Lillico, American newspaper writer in China for six years, that the council was one of four American organizations for aid of the Chinese that he described [as "Communist fronts."

First public utterance here with any bearing on the fact that the Soviet Union has refrained from joining other countries in offering an asylum to Jews from Germany was made today in a signed article in Trud, the organ of the Central Council of Trade Unions.

The Chicago Cardinals broke two records in completing their season. According to statistics released yesterday by the National Football League, the Cards tried the aerial route 240 times and completed 114 passes.
Officials of this Southern Maryland horse-racing plant today canceled the remainder of the season's program because of the frozen track.

Convicted of fostering labor violence, Harry W. Dail, international vice president of the Teamsters Union, and Dexter L. Lewis, president of the Los Angeles local, today were sentenced to serve eighteen months each in the county jail.

The Imperial Bank of Canada, in its annual financial statement for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31. 1938, showed net profit of $961,343, compared with $967,977 in the preceding year. Deposits by the public amounted to $141,563,277; against $132,198,089, while interestbearing deposits aggregated $95,203,907, an increase of approximately $4,000,000. Non-interest bearing deposits showed a gain of $4,000,000, to $36,084,302.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 23: Increases of $115,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks and $196,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and decreases of $25,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and $154,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
Movements of vessels follow and all dates are Nov, 28, unless specified:

The Spanish Government is sending to Mrs.. Franklin D. Roosevelt one of its most precious artistic accomplishments, it was learned to-. day. It is a complete set-one of five on antique Japanese paper-of the final edition of Goya's etchings.

With allowance for the holiday, the daily average of automobile output increased more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index rose to 96.7 from 95.6. The figure was 77.3 for the week ended Nov. 27. 1937.

Women active in behalf of the annual Bassinet Dinner Dance in aid of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, to be held Friday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis, will meet this afternoon at a tea to be given by Mrs. Samuel A. Thompson at her home, 1,100 Park Avenue, to discuss final plans for the event.

The War Department announced today Federal recognition had been given the following National Guard officers of New York City and that they now were commissioned officers of the National Guard of the United States:

Clark Willy, a seaman on board the American Republics liner Uruguay, which is due tonight from her first voyage to Buenos Aires, distinguished himself in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, by jumping overboard and rescuing a stevedore who had fallen into the water.

Responsible persons everywhere will approve the action of those radio stations that refused to broadcast a speech plainly calculated to stir up religious prejudice and strife. These stations acted, as they were entitled to act, on their own responsibility.

The volume of loans for home mortgages made by the savings and loan associations in New York State in October was about 20 per cent greater than the total in September, according to Zebulon V. Woodard, executive vice president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

Warrants for collection of the 193839 taxes in the ten towns of Suffolk County, affirmed by the County Board of Supervisors today, call for a $9,898,863 levy, or $287,242 more than in the preceding fiscal year.

The Federal Government yesterday lost its suit to collect penalties of $40,900 from the National Biscuit Company for that company's delay of 409 days, covered by the period from Feb. 16, 1936, to March 30, 1937, in answering a questionnaire submitted to it by the Federal Trade Commission.

Mrs. Annie S. Disbrow Wilson, president of the Coleman Business College here, died today at her home here. She was the wife of Bennett A. Wilson. Mrs. Wilson was born at South Amboy, N. J. She came to Newark about ten years ago after having resided in Buffalo, N. Y.

Before our double-header storm draped New York in its wet-white blanket, officials of the Continental Baking Company, which is trying to raise a demonstration field of Winter wheat at the World's Fair, were worried. Their wheat,

In Utah's undefeated drive to the Mountain Big Seven football championship five players paced the charge, game after game, and today all five were rewarded with places on the Associated Press all-conference first team.

The Virginians will hold their annual dinner dance Friday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The guest of honor will be the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, who will speak during the evening.

The Federal Communications Commission, which is conducting an antimonopoly investigation of chain broadcasting, took steps today to break up "something approaching a monopoly" in the legal practice before it.

Trailing 24--16 at the half, the St. Simon Stock basketball team rallied after the intermission to defeat Immaculata High School, 42-30, at the winner's court yesterday. Gordon Hill paced the attack of the victors with five field goals and a foul for a total of eleven points.

Assailing the elimination of commercial piers for land improve ments and other encroachments on the:- waters of the harbor, Eugene S. Moran, -chairman of the rivers and harbors committee of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, warned yesterday that "if we continue to destroy commerce" in the port, "the City of New York will be destroyed with it."
Improvement in business has become general, according to the monthly survey of Banking, the publication of the American Bankers Association.

Samuel Earle Haines, a furniture dealer, died today of a heart ailment in his office. His age was 49. Mr. Haines served in the Military Intelligence Division during the World War and was a founder and for three years commander of Merion Post of the American Legion.
Lester B. Pope, supervisor of the Department of Architecture at Pratt Institute, died yesterday in his home at 175 Emerson Place, Brooklyn at the age of 54.

Princeton's 1939 swimming and wrestling schedules were announed today by R. Kenneth Fairman, graduate manager of athletics. The varsity swimmers, with a nine-meet card, will open here Jan. 7 against Lehigh, and the varsity matmen will start their six-meet program against Harvard at Cambridge Jan. 14.

The directors of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., voted here today to augment the service within sixty days with seven twenty-one-passenger planes and to set aside about $40,000 as a "Christmas appreciation fund" for employes in the lower salary brackets.
The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad to borrow $2,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with which to pay taxes.

Bernard Finkelstein, 30 years old, of 47 St. Mark's Place, was sentenced to six months in the workhouse yesterday by Justices Hofmann, Doyle and Flood in Special Sessions after he had pleaded guilty to cheating one of many persons of small sums under the pretext that he had "influence" and would obtain news stand privileges for them.

Corrections or contradictions of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin came yesterday from Alexander Kerensky, from Leon Trotsky and from the United States Secret Service, as well as from other sources to which he had referred in his Sunday afternoon radio address, when he pronounced the Russian revolution a work of destruction inspired and financed by Jews.

Steel production is scheduled at 60.7 per cent of capacity this week, as compared to 61.9 per cent last week, a decrease of 1.2 points, or 1.9 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, and a decline of 1.9 points, or 3.0 per cent, from the year's high of 62.6 per cent set two weeks ago. One month ago the rate was 56.8 per cent.

Intensifying its drive against corporations which allegedly failed to file personal property tax returns for 1937 and 1938, the City Commission here today authorized complaints against eighty-three more concerns with intangible ratables assessed at $2,484,103,133 for the two years.
The engagement of Miss Patricia Adelia Upton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Upton of Great Neck and Point-o'-Woods, L. I., to Joseph Baxter Roberts has been announced by her parents.

" Lorelei," the much-postponed play of Jacques Deval, opens tonight at the Longacre. Richard Aldrich, Dennis King and Sir Cedric Hardwicke receive star billing as co-producers, while the fourth member of the managerial backfield, Richard Myers, is featured as an associate producer.

The official canvass of the vote cast in New York City for Governor in the recent elections was completed yesterday by the Board of Elections. It gives Governor Lehman a plurality of 681,369 over District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, as against the unofficial figure of 682,665 in the election night count. The recapitulation is as follows:
National Crochet Exhibition at the American Woman's Club, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. Open to Dec. 2, 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

Mr. and Mrs. Ely Jacques Kahn are now at the Carolina Hotel in Pinehurst, N. C., on their wedding trip in the South. They are expected to return here on Monday. Mrs. Kahn before her marriage here on Wednesday was Mrs. Beatrice Josephi Sulzberger, widow of Leo Sulzberger.

Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, will address the convention of the National Association of Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 9, Charles R. Hook, president of the association, announced yesterday after a cabled acceptance from Mr. Eden.

The McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will be aided by a card party and tea this afternoon at the home of Mrs. John D. Ryan, 3 East Seventy-eighth Street. During the afternoon there will be on sale gay wrappings, seals, cards and ribbons for holiday gifts at the Christmas season.

Postmaster Francis J. Sinnott of Brooklyn issued a request yesterday that the mailing of all Christmas packages be done in sufficient time for the articles to reach their destination not later than Dec. 23. Announcing that the Brooklyn Postoffice would be closed both on Sunday, Dec. 25, and Monday, Dec. 26, Mr. Sinnott said that only special-delivery mail would be handled on those dates.
If Coach Buck Shaw of Santa Clara had played football the way Coach Gus Dorais of Detroit wanted to, Santa Clara would have won the football game.

Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, who was named last month as president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, was guest of honor last night at a dinner held at the Unity Club, Bedford Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.

John L. Stoneham, 48 years old, whose home is at 22-64 Forty-first Street, Astoria, was sentenced yesterday to sixty days in the workhouse in the Court of Special Sessions at Jamaica on a conviction of practicing as an attorney illegally.

George Backer, son-in-law of the late Mortimer Schiff and an active campaigner for Jewish philanthropies, was chosen last night by the State Executive Committee of the American Labor party to succeed the late B. Charney Vladeck as a member of the City Council.
Conciliators striving to end a C. I. O. strike that has paralyzed trade at the Chicago Stock Yards reported today that they had made "some progress."

The United States apparently has only a little more than average liability to earthquakes, the Commerce Department announced today in stating that part one of a new publication, "The Earthquake History of the United States," has just been prepared by the Coast and Geodetic Survey. N. H.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has called for redemption on Jan. 1, 1939, through operation of the sinking fund, $1,100,000 aggregate amount of its consolidated-mortgage twenty-five-year 41/4 per cent bonds. Series D, due in 1960.
Joe Tate, the American actor who played in "The Belle of New York" in England over a period of thirty years, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Highgate, at the age of 72.

E. Newton Reser, retired director of art in the New York City schools for twenty-four years, who had crossed the Atlantic fifty-two times, died here today in St. Elizabeth Hospital, where he had been for two years. He was born here seventy-six years ago.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull today appointed Alfred M. Landon, the Republican Presidential nominee of 1936, to a committee charged with studying the problem of strengthening peace machinery at the coming Pan-American Conference in Lima.

An exhibition of pictures by Spanish children was opened yesterday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, under the sponsorship of a committee of architects. The arrangements committee has been headed by Mrs. Joseph Urban.

Establishment of an Institute of Nutrition, financed by grocery manufacturers and conducted under the auspices of some leading university, was proposed to 300 delegates attending the opening of the thirtieth annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday by Charles Wesley Dunn, general counsel to the organization.
Duke University tonight was invited to play the University of Southern California in the Rose Bowl football classic Jan. 2. The invitation was quickly accepted.

More conflicting testimony appeared yesterday in the Securities and Exchange Commission stoporder proceedings against the Reiter-Foster Oil Company. Charles L. Kahn, attorney for the oil concern, under examination by R. T. McElvenny of SEC counsel, and cross-examination by William Biel, representing the registrant, defended the registration statement which he had prepared, and contradicted many remarks by earlier witnesses.

Warmer weather for New York and the entire East was predicted for today, a circumstance that will give substantial aid to hundreds of snow-swept communities in their battle to clear the streets and highways.

The six-meter sloop Lucie, which Briggs S. Cunningham sailed in the British-American Cup match off Oyster Bay in September, and which for seven years has been to the fore in international racing, will be shipped to Lake Ontario for use in the George's Cup competition there next Summer between the Toronto and Rochester sailors.

Three hundred members of the New York Chapter of the League of American Writers, left-wing literary group, adopted last night a resolution to send a telegram to President Roosevelt assuring him of support in his attitude on the German and Pan-American situations and urging him to lift the embargo against Spanish war shipments and to act for the immediate cessation of trade with Germany.

The attempt of a group of up-State Republican leaders to oust Kenneth F. Simpson of New York as National Committeeman was defeated in a protracted session of the Republican State Executive Committee here tonight.

A ring battle that is expected to eliminate one of the contenders for the unclaimed world light heavyweight title is scheduled for tonight at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, when Tiger Jack Fox of Spokane battles Al Gainer of New Haven in the feature bout of fifteen rounds.
The crew of the Newfoundland schooner Marion Rogers, reported to number six, were believed lost in a fierce gale which swept Newfoundland this week-end.
Defeating Orange Free State by an innings and 24 runs today, the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team registered the fourth straight victory of its South African tour.

Mrs. Kate Marshall died yesterday at her home at 235 East Twenty-second Street, aged 67. She was born in Russia and had lived in the neighborhood of her late home for the last forty years. Her husband, Edward Marshall, died last January.

A desperate bandit couple, a gunman and a young woman, were hunted in Chicago tonight. They were believed to be hiding here after outrunning and outfighting police during a dramatic ten-hour flight over highways of Southwestern Michigan and Northern Indiana.

A banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co. won the award yesterday of a new issue of $4,025,000 city of Baltimore, Md., general bonds on a bid of 100.2538 for 1 1/8 per cent obligations. The bonds, to be dated Dec. 1, 1938, and to mature serially on Dec. 1, 1941 to 1945, were reoffered by the bankers at prices to yield from 0.50 to 1.20 per cent, according to maturity.

Challenging the constitutionality of the Massachusetts law requiring school children to salute the flag, William A. Johnson, a member of the Jehovah's Witnesses sect, today petitioned the Federal District Court here to restrain the Deerfield School Committee from barring his three children from the public schools of that town.

Thirty-two committees of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States will gather at the Willard Hotel in Washington on Friday for the opening session of the organization's golden anniversary convention, it was announced yesterday by SecretaryTreasurer Daniel J. Ferris. The convention will be held Saturday and Sunday.

Elimination by 1960 of all special trade preferences between the United States and the presumably independent Philippine Government of the future is proposed in a voluminous report. prepared by the Joint Preparatory Committee on Philippine Affairs and made public tonight.

The national A. A. U. ice hockey championships was be held in the New Haven Arena in late February or early March ?? was announced yesterday by Chairman Frederick W. Rubien through Secretary-Treasurer Daniel J. Ferris.

The bulk of the realty activity in Brooklyn reported by brokers yesterday included both multi-family and single-family dwellings. Among the properties announced as having changed hands was the six-story apartment house on a plot 150 by 150 feet at 700 Ocean Avenue, which was purchased by the 112 Haven Avenue Corporation, I.

The Brooklyn Builders and Real Estate Division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities will hold its second annual subcontractors dinner Thursday at 6:30 P. M., at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. John J. Moran, Superintendent of Buildings for Brooklyn, will be the principal speaker.

As coach of the Metropolitan College All-Stars, who will oppose the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field on Saturday in a game for the benefit of Catholic, Jewish and Protestant refugees, Benny Friedman's task is a tremendous one.
Junior Harrington, 4-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Harrington, rescued the baby of the family from a fire which destroyed their home near here.

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $4,838,554, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with a net of $9,497,778 in the twelve months to Oct. 37, 1937.

The claim that he is the sculptor of a statue of Venus that was discovered in a ts field last year-and that was subsequently examined by experts and classified as a historic monument and property of. the nation-has been made by a former student of the Beaux Arts Academy.
Yesterday's rally in the pound sterling was the largest advance that unhappy exchange has enjoyed since Sept. 29, the day after the announcement of the plan for the Munich meeting.

Senator Gillette asserting that Republican gains in Iowa in the Congressional election did not indicate a "reactionary" trend, said today that the Democratic party would carry the State in the 1940 Presidential election if it nominated "a progressive, liberal candidate, not a tory or radical."
Stocks declined to lowest levels since Oct. 4 and closed down 1 to 2 1/2 points; turnover, 1,237,702 shares. United States Government issues irregular, other bonds lower; transactions, $6,036,000.

The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association last week remained at the same level as in the preceding week. The association's index for the week ended Nov. 26 was 73.2, compared with 72.9 a month ago and 79.2 a year ago.

The strange story of a domestic who, if still alive, 'apparently has forgotten two large savings accounts for more than twenty years came to light yesterday with the publication of a display advertisement in THE NEW YORK TIMES seeking information about Bridget Glennon.

The Scholarship Fund of the Hessian Hills School will be augmented by a performance of "American Landscape," a new play by Elmer Rice the night of Dec. 5 at the Cort Theatre. Proceeds will be used to provide scholarships at the school for refugee children of Germany and Central Europe.

The eight-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100.9 feet at 507 West 113th Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the Bank of New York, as plaintiff, for $121,889.

Strife between the Democratic and coalition members of the City Council ,at today's meeting was forecast last night when it was learned that Newbold Morris, President of the Council, would introduce a local law to extend the highly controversial cigarette tax through the first six months of 1939.

Max Rubenfeld, ace triple-threat back of the undefeated and untied Erasmus Hall High eleven of Brooklyn, captured the Larry MacPhail Trophy, emblematic of the most valuable schoolboy player in Brooklyn, it was announced last night by John F. (Chick) Meehan, general manager of football at Ebbets Field.

The annual football dinner of Peddle School was held in the school social room tonight. Dr. Wilbur E. Saunders, headmaster, who was toastmaster, paid tribute to this year's team, which won two games, lost three and tied two, one of the ties being with Blair Academy's unbeaten eleven in New Jersey's oldest prep school rivalry.
The interstate Commerce Commission was asked today to deny the application of the Railway Express Agency, Inc., for readjustment of its rate structure.

The Mutual Savings Bank group committee on New York. New Haven Hartford Railroad bonds asked today the Interstate Commerce Commission to reopen proceedings for reorganization of the New Haven so that it could file either its own modified plan or modification to the revised plan to be filed by the road.

In consonance with lower stock and commodity markets, cotton again eased yesterday, with final prices at losses of 4 to 6 points. A prominent New Orleans operator released 20,000 December contracts on the Southern Exchange, and it was estimated that a further 25,000 were distributed here for the Bombay and the New Orleans accounts.
