The Treasury sold its weekly bills today at an average interest rate of 0.021 per cent compared with 0.026 per cent for last week's issue, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight. At least one bid at 100 was entered.

The first step in reorganization of the closed Lawyers Mortgage Company was authorized yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in a decision which permits Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to sell all the outstanding stock of the new Lawyers Mortgage Guarantee Corporation to the reorganization managers of the old company for $2,200,000.

The announced assent of the Lehigh Valley Railroad's bondholders, to the company's plan for temporary scalingdown of interest charges, introduces a new and interesting technique in the averting of company insolvency.

The board of directors of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange set forth in its annual report today that te South faced a "readjustment of the first magnitude which vitally affects" the entire nation, if the present plan of crop control continues.

With the assistance of a public address system Victor Victor gives his murder a fancy dress costume in "Soliloquy," which was acted at the Empire last evening. The private thoughts of his murderer rattle out of a loud speaker somewhere in the scenery.

An air of confidence marked the bearing of members of the Republican National Committee arriving here today for a meeting tomorrow. Encouraged by results of the elections, the committeemen looked forward to capture the, Presidency in 1940.

Mr. and Mrs. Crittenden X. Adams of Morristown, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Agnes Claflin Adams, to Nathaniel B. Wales Jr., son of Mrs.. Charles E. Greenough of 1,212 Fifth Avenue and of Nathaniel Brackett Wales of Boston and New York.
Edgar T. Appleby, James Burke, William Viertel and Phillip Meise were the winners in the 18.2 handicap balkline billiard tournament at Lawler's Manhattan Academy yesterday.

Three hundred WPA workers made idle by the snowfalls gathered yesterday in front of the Bronx WPA headquarters, at 260 East 161st Street, to protest because the Department of Sanitation had overlooked the possibility of economizing by hiring them for snow removal work.

Dr. William McDougall, one of the world's foremost psychologists, who had been head of Duke University's Psychology Department since 1927, died here today at the age of 67, after a long illness. His body was cremated this afternoon.
Philip L. Gillett, former member of the staff of International Committee Y. M. C. A., died in Utica on Sunday, according to an announcement by the committee yesterday. He was 66 years old.
John William Fordham Johnson, former Liteutenant Governor of British Columbia, died at his home here today on his seventy-second birthday.

Business is continuing to expand, but business sentiment has failed to respond whole-heartedly to the favorable course of trade, the Guaranty Trust Company says in its publication, The Guaranty Survey, issued yesterday.
Today's session of the first LatinAmerican Insurance Congress was devoted to organization of committees and, speeches by the principal delegates; Pablo Bordenave, head of the Argentine group said:
The refusal of the Assembly to provide an automobile for the Governor has led to an unusual and somewhat strained situation between the Executive and the Assembly.

Hubert Ray Duniway, former president of the Intercoastal Lumber Dealers Association, died yesterday morning at his apartment in the Hotel Robert Fulton, 228 West Seventy-first Street after a three months' illness from a heart disease. He was 79 years old.
The Harvard Club remained unbeaten at the top last night in the Metropolitan League's Class B squash tennis by blanking the City A. C., 5-0, on the latter's courts.

Fordham Rd, 271-85 E (11-3154); K. M. L. Realty Corp. to East River Savings Bank, extends mtgs to Nov. 1, 1943, at 4 1/2 per cent; $210,000. Valentine Ave, 2,685 (12-3304); Paulina Realty Corp. to East River Savings Bank, extends mtg to Nov. 1, 1943, at 4 1/2 per cent: $117.800.

Defense Minister Oswald Pirow of South Africa spent a busy day in Rome seeing successively Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister; the Minister for Foreign Exchange, the UnderSecretary of State for War and Premier Benito Mussolini.

A final accounting of the $37,000,000 estate of Ella V. von E. Wendel, the last of the eccentric Wendel sisters whose gloomy old mansion at Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street gave way to a popular-priced chain store, was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by George F. Warren Jr., attorney for the executors.

An amateur camera man, the husband of the grand national crochet champion, sat in the clubhouse of the American Woman's Association yesterday and told how his photography had been the guide for his wife's needle during the rainy season in California.
The revamped Westchester Imperial Victorias scored an overtime 4-3 victory over the New York Athletic Club in a rough New York Amateur Hockey Association feature at the Imperial Arena tonight.

Growing recognition of the need for specialists public housing management is found in the announcement of the National Association of Housing Offidials that it would create a "professional housing managers division."
Monty Stratton, 25-year-old ace of the White Sox pitching staff, today underwent an operation for amputation of his right leg.

Leading members of the Wagner wing of the Metropolitan Opera Company, who have for several seasons past provided performances which placed the works of the German master in the forefront of the repertory, have seldom acquitted themselves more competently than they did in last night's performance of "Siegfried."

The Shady Side News of Shady Side Academy, Pittsburgh, Pa., won the first 1938-39 preparatory school newspaper contest conducted by The Daily Princetonian, campus news organ, it was announced today by James McC. Clarke, '39, of Manchester, Vt., chairman of The Princetonian.

Mrs. Fannie I. Edgerton, widow of Colonel Wright Edgerton, former Professor of Mathematics at the United States Military Academy at West Point, requested her executor to purchase a saber each year for presentation to the outgoing captain of the Army football team, in her will filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

Jewish quarters said today they had evidence from various parts of Germany that arrests of Jews were continuing. Many who stayed away from home during the big arrest wave that followed the killing of Ernst vom Rath by a young Jew in Paris now are being quietly rounded up, these sources said.

A German naval command publication said today that Japan "probably" is building the largest warships in the world, but added that if the United States remains in the Philippines the Anglo-Saxon position in the Far East could be made "unassailable."

Maxie Berger of Montreal won the decision over Irish Eddie Brink in the eight-round main bout last night at St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of 2,500. Berger weighed 140 3/4 pounds and his opponent 144 1/4.

Efforts to get Wednesday's general strike called off until after Parliament discusses the government's decree laws broke down this evening because Premier Edouard Daladier insisted that the C. G. T.-the General Confederation of Labor-must make the first move and withdraw its strike order.

TWO good scouts were giving the football season something of a general going-over and this observer, tuning in, caught some of the passes, to wit and viz: "Yes, a great season, but a fooler all along the line. Now, you take Minnesota.
Gustavo Ross, defeated Rightist candidate in the Oct. 25 Presidential election, left this morning by plane for Buenos Aires, where he will embark for Paris on Thursday, it is announced.

Adjt. Gen. John A. Wilson, 77 years old, this afternoon was reported in a critical condition at the military hospital of the Sixty-fifth Infantry, where he was taken last Wednesday, suffering supposedly from acute indigestion.
A benefit at the first performance of the Ice Follies at Madison Square Garden tonight will be the second event this Autumn arranged in aid of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

Efforts of a group of about 100 men to break up a meeting of an organization known as the Silver Shirt Legion of America resulted tonight in injury to two men and the arrest of nine others. The league's main tenet is anti-Semitism and it is said to favor nazism.

Long-term advertising contracts are becoming a thing of the past, not so much because of uncertainty among advertisers but because of their increasing desire to keep budgets flexible, to cut down or expand at will and to shift from one medium to another,
A committee of Chicago citizens called on Secretary Ickes today in an effort to "draft" him in a campaign to "smash the Nash-Kelly machine" by running for Mayor of Chicago.

The amazing success in pugilistic affairs of Henry Armstrong has intrigued the sportsmen of Paris. Promoter Jeff Dickson, the Tex Rickard of France, has made an offer of $35,000 for a battle in which Armstrong would defend his welterweight title against Pedro Montanez on Feb. 19.

With 80 per cent of the coat and suit industry opposed to the wool rules proposed by the Federal Trade Commission and with other garment associations and the National Association of Wool Manufacturers also dissatisfied, it became apparent yesterday that the FTC will hear a chorus of objections to its tentative draft of trade practice regulations when it begins hearings on Dec. 14.

A one point increase in its construction costs index bringing it to 182, as compared with the 181 which had prevailed for the previous four months, was reported for October yesterday by the American Appraisal Company. The index covers thirty cities throughout the country.

J. Oakley Radway gave a dinner last night at the Madison. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Hendrick Vanderbilt Duryea, Mr. and Mrs. Arnall P. Hodges, Mrs. John M. Willard, Miss Almy Gilford, Mrs. Julian Van Ness Whipple, Edward E. Porter, Philip F. Metz, and John Wiley.
Mrs. Maud Carillo Leitner, widow of Dr. George A. Leitner, leader in State Democratic politics and well-known surgeon, died today at her home in Piermont at the age of 71. Mrs.

Bernard M. L. Ernst, an attorney and a retired president of the Society of American Magiclans, a skillful legerdemainist in his own right and a battler for the legal rights of professional magicians, died yesterday at his home, 25 Claremont Avenue. Mr. Ernst, who was 59 years old, had been in poor health for several years.

MANHATTAN CRAGIN, HARTWELL R. (Aug. 2). Estate, less than- $5,000. To Leslie Davey Cragin, executrix, 910 West End Ave. CROPLEY, JOSEPH M. M. (Nov. 20). Estate, less than $5,000. To Agda H. Cropley, widow, executrix, 10 W. 74th St.

Expressing the belief that the American people are determined to stay out of foreign wars, Walter H. Mallory, executive director of the Council on Foreign Relations, in a talk yesterday at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, discussed the SinoJapanese hostilities and warned that "events might conspire to make such conflict ours."

Relief funds in the amount of $94,870,853 had been allotted to the Bureau of Yards and Docks of the Navy Department up to Aug. 20 last "to enable the Navy Department to assist in affording employment to relief labor," the annual report of Rear Admiral Ben Moreell, chief of the bureau, made public today, states.

Mayor La Guardia, in a sarcastic reply to criticism of the city's schools by Dr. Luther H. Gulick, director of the recent Regents' inquiry, demanded more authority for New York City from the Board of Regents and the State Department of Education in the selection and dismissal of teachers.
Estimates for the new budget show receipts for the ordinary budget of 66,345,000,000 francs and expenditures of 66,317,000,000 francs, leaving a surplus of 28,000,000 francs.

The two-story factory building on a plot 75 by 120 feet at 31-35 Wilsey Street, Newark, N. J., was purchased by the Cozwll Realty Company from the Colonial Life Insurance Company of America. The building contains more than 10,000 square feet of space and will be occupied shortly by the American Screw Products Company, now located at 38 Littleton Street.
Iffie Rogers, 54 years old, a gardener, shot and killed his estranged wife, Anna, 41, and then killed himself shortly after noon today on South Academy Street, here, according to police.
The independent citizens' committee for the reelection of Senator Wagner reported today to the Secretary of State's office that it had received $29,849 and spent the same amount during the campaign.

No official livestock quotations were available here today, inasmuch as no sales were made through the Livestock Exchange because of the handlers' strike, but unofficial quotations on hogs received direct indicated a prevailing price of around $7.75 a hundred for good and choice medium weights. This was about 25 cents under the prices quotable last week, but was in line with outside markets where enlarged receipts lowered Prices at virtually all points.
Pope Pius was said by a usually well-informed prelate today to have passed a quiet night and to be prepared to continue religious exercises begun yesterday.

A new schedule of automobile insurance rates, designed to reward careful drivers with a saving of from $2,000,000 to $2,500,000 yearly, was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

Overcome by carbon monoxide gas from a leaky exhaust pipe, Clyde Bassette of Harrisville and Milton Rice of Newton Falls were found dead and Edward McMahon of Harrisville was found in a serious condition in Mr. McMahon's automobile on a side road near Harrisville today.

Mrs. Rose Brinsko, 21 years old, mother of a 2-year-old daughter, was slain, with an axe this afternoon In the bedroom of her home at 177 Chauncey Street here. Under arrest charged with murder is her husband, Joseph, 32, who, Police Chief John F. Murray said, had confessed.

There are nearly 1,500 freshmen at the City College of the admirable age of not much over 17. They seem to be older in a sense than the freshmen of a generation or two ago. Of these probably a majority put off the evil day of speculating on their means of livelihood till senior year.

The Congressional TVA investigating committee agreed today to call J. R. McCarl, former Controller General, to the stand for his views on the long-standing controversy over the right of the Controller General to "supervise and control" TVA expenditures.

Kennedy F. Rea, clerk of the Senate Appropriations Committee and an important figure in the two Appropriations Committees of Congress for more than forty-six years, died today at his home in this city.

Although there are still some incidents of sniping and sabotage by terrorists, it may be said that on the whole a comparison of conditions a month ago with the situation now shows considerably easing.

On two occasions Congress has had an opportunity to empower the President to name an aggressor in the event of international war and to enforce a general embargo against that nation while permitting free supply to its adversary or adversaries.
The Japanese military machine, stalled in its drive on this capital of Hunan Province, was declared by a Chinese Army spokesman today to have started digging in for the Winter.

Wreckage of the Imperial Airways flying boat Calpurnia was found partly submerged today in the shallow waters of Lake Hannabiyeh, only fifteen miles from the airport further up the lake. Of her crew of six one was dead, two were injured and three were missing, believed drowned under the wreck.

This country has always regarded foreign trade as a means of exchanging goods on a mutually profitable basis and it has never believed that trade should be a medium of political propaganda, designed to influence the customers' system of government, Richard C. Patterson Jr., assistant secretary of commerce, said today in addressing a conference on Latin-American trade of the Kansas City Chamber of Commerce.
" When issued" rights of the Continental Oil Company have been admitted to dealings on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading will be in variations of one sixty-fourth.
Wholesale commodity prices were irregularly lower last week with The Annalist's index losing onetenth of a point to close at 79.9. A year ago the index was 80.0 per cent of the 1926 base.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4171-Walter T. Ueland, Quong Yuen Shing Co. v. the U. S. Opinion by Judge Garrett. The U. S.
Riggs Stephenson, former star with the Indians and Cubs, was named today to manage the Montgomery Bombers of the Southeastern League. He succeeds M. T. (Bud) Connolly.
The next Series of commercial examinations conducted by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York will be held from Jan. 9 to 20, it was announced yesterday.

Notre Dame didn't play Saturday, but for the third straight week Elmer Layden's greatest eleven tops The Associated Press football poll. Of the ninety writers participating in the final selection, forty-eight chose Notre Dame as the nation's best team and the men from South Bend rolled up a total of 823 points.
The University of Iowa athletic board prepared tonight to meet Iowa's new football coach, Dr. Eddie Anderson, who is scheduled to arrive here at 3 P. M. tomorrow.

The proposed appendix to the by-laws of the Medical, Society of the County of New York curbing "contract medicine" was overwhelmingly defeated last night at the organization's 133d annual meeting in the New York Academy of Medicine, 103d Street and Fifth Avenue.

The feelings of Cecil (Tiny) Thompson, the National Hockey League's all-star goalie, were soothed by a $1,000 bonus today when he learned that he had been sold by the Boston Bruins to the Detroit Red Wings for $15,000 and another player.
Notre Dame's unbeaten football forces, thirty-six strong, entrained today for Los Angeles, where next Saturday they will play Southern California in the final game of their hard campaign.

Merchandise stocks in the hands of department stores in this district at the end of October were 11 per cent under a year ago, while apparel store stocks were about 13.5 per cent lower, according to a report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Collections of accounts outstanding continued slower this year than last in the department stores, but were somewhat better in the apparel shops.

Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, today categorically denied published reports that State Department officials were drafting amendments to the Neutrality Act which would permit the President to apply an embargo against any nation he deemed to be an aggressor.

Professor Stefanescu Goanga, dean of the University of Cluj, was shot today on the street by three students, who succeeded in escaping after they had fired on and killed one of the detectives escorting the dean. Professor Goanga was reported dying tonight.

The board of managers of St. Luke's Hospital, 421 West 113th Street, announced yesterday that Stephen Baker had retired as president of the institution. He has been president since 1921 and a member of the board for thirtyeight years.

Mrs. Francis T. Lyons of Beacon Hill, Port Washington, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Lyons, to H. Tenison Deane Jr., son of Mrs. Hubert Harder of Port Washington and Dr. H. T. Deane of New York.

Proceeds from a bridge party to be held today, under the auspices of the New York State Shut-In Society, at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria will be used to purchase wheel chairs for underprivileged invalids. Mrs. Wilmot B. Allen is chairman of the benefit committee and Miss E. A. Conran, honorary chairman.
Exports of electrical goods from the United States during October showed a decided upturn, the Commerce Department reported today.

Net railway operating income of 137 Class I railroads in the first ten months of this year amounted to $273,709,020, compared with $531,689,942 in the same period last year, a decline of $257,980,922, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Boston Rd. 1,081, 1 and 3 story tenement, 49.10x101.2 irreg: Margaret A. Howard Home against Boston Road Market Corp; due, $31,500; taxes, etc, $3,184; to plaintiff for $15,000.

The Kings County Republican Campaign. Committee received $27,732 and spent $29,418 in the recent election campaign, according to the organization's expense statement filed yesterday with the Board of Elections.

Police vans and radio patrol cars were mustered into "emergency service" today to transport 135 policemen from Bayonne Police Headquarters to the Hudson County Court House here to testify at the Special Sessions trial of George W. Rogers, radio operator of the burned steamship Morro Castle and former Bayonne patrolman, who is charged with attempting to kill his superior officer, Lieutenant Vincent J. Doyle, with a home-made bomb.

An overwhelming stockholders' vote controlled by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York crushed today the single-handed efforts of Robert R. Young, financier-broker, to halt liquidation of the Chesapeake Corporation, middle holding company of the once vast Van Sweringen rail empire.

A meeting of holders of votingtrust certificates of the Middle States Petroleum Corporation has been called for Dec. 28 for a vote on a proposed amendment which would permit the legal declaration out of 1936 and 1937 earnings of dividends of 62 cents a share on the Class A stock and 10 cents on the Class B stock, according to Joseph Glass, president, in a letter to certificate holders.

Work on a $400,000 apartment-house project, to be erected at Main Street and Manor Terrace on a four-acre plot formerly owned by the late John Tilney, is scheduled to start in the Spring, according to Harry A. Taylor of the realty firm of Frank H. Taylor Son and Mayor Ovid C. Bianchi of this city.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today went to Buckingham Palace to tell King George about his meeting with the Duke of Windsor in Paris last Thursday.
A list of 776 contributions to the United Hospital Campaign, headed by a gift of $10,000 from Charles Steele, was made public last night by C. M. Chester, campaign chairman.

Solly Krieger, newly crowned National Boxing Association middleweight champion, dropped a decision in a twelve-round non-title fight tonight to Billy Conn of Pittsburgh, in his first contest since taking the title from Al Hostak in Seattle.
Milan Creighton resigned today as head coach of the Chicago Cardinal professional football team, a position he held since succeeding Paul Schissler in 1935.

The Public Health Service has found that six more species of animals native to this country are susceptible to endemic typhus fever, and therefore possible intermediate reservoirs of infection which may be transmitted by insects to humans, according to an announcement today.

THIS has been a banner year for books of and about pictures. Once more I would like to recommend Robert Taft's "Photography and the American Scene, 1839-89" (Macmillan, $10), not merely for the text, which is doubtless the best history of the subject we have, the most intelligent, scholarly and inclusive, but also for the illustrations, of which there are about 300, including reproductions of rare daguerreotypes, ambrotypes and early examples of the wetplate process.
The world's first regular autogiro roof-top mail service is about to be established in Philadelphia by the United States Postoffice Department.

Just before the recently launched U.S.S. Phoenix sailed today on a shakedown cruise, executives of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn., presented to officers of the ship a reproduction of the fabulous bird, the phoenix, a picture of which has been used in the advertising of the insurance company for many years.
Despite severe government measures yesterday, the nineteenth anniversary of the World War Treaty of Nueilly, revisionist demonstrations broke out in full force here again today.

The Virginia Day Nursery, said to be the oldest institution of its kind in the city, will be the beneficiary of a series of performances of the dance pantomime, "Cinderella." The first will be presented by Annette Van Dyke's Children's Repertory Ballet next Saturday morning at the Ziegfeld Theatre.
In yesterday's commercial leasing report, which included several rentals of large space, a wide area of the city was represented.

Mrs. George Z. Medalie, chairman of the committee for student facilities in the colleges under control of the Board of Higher Education, deplored yesterday the reputation given to the student body at City College because of the activities of a few students.

Baron and Baroness W. H. Thoe Schwartzenberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Mea Charlotte Schwartzenberg to Wilhelm Peter Montyn, consul general of the Netherlands at New York.

The isues for the 1940 elections will be made during the coming session of Congress, Senator Norris of Nebraska predicted today. "If Congress blocks President Roosevelt's program he will be forced to run a third time," Mr. Norris asserted.

From a trustworthy source it is learned that within the last fortnight an extensive purge has taken place in the local ranks of the Nazi party. According to this source, 135 party members were recently shot.

W. H. Auden has written the introduction to the Oxford Book of Light Verse, which will be published on Thursday by the Oxford University Press. The collection begins with the pre-Chaucerian "Song of Lewes" and continues chronologically, ending with John Betjeman.

An unusual chapter in business history was brought to a conclusion today when the Anderson Company, maker of automobile accessories, emerged from a six-year receivership with its creditors paid in full and its original officers still in charge, without any resort to refinancing or reorganization.

Park Terrace East, n w cor of 215th St, 326.3x293.10x Irreg; Thomas Dwyer to Park Terrace Gardens, Inc, 758 Brady Ave; mtg $100,000 and p m mtg $35,000 ($185). 46th St. 444, 25x100.5; Jacob Rudd. ref to Greenwich Savings Bank, foreclosure ($13).

Pierre Clemenceau, grandson of the late Georges Clemenceau, wartime Premier of France, will arrive here tomorrow on the Champlain. On the following day he will depart for New Orleans, where he will marry on Dec. 14 Miss Jane Louise Grunewald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict Moret Grunewald of that city. The ceremony will take place in the Grunewald home.

Miss Jean A. Reid, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald M. Reid, who will be introduced to younger members of society at a reception to be given by her parents on the afternoon of Christmas Day at their home, 941 Park Avenue.

Funeral services for James H. Jourdan, former president and chairman of the board of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, who died last Friday in his apartment at the Drake Hotel, were held yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street, Brooklyn.

Commenting on the case of a Queens woman arrested after she turned over a revolver to police because of fear that her father would end his life, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday, "We do not make the laws, but we all take oath to enforce them."

The early development of a Westchester County water system is imperative if a supply is to- be guaranteed for future generations and the county is to avoid paying excessive prices to the New York City watershed system, according to a report filed today by the Westchester County Water Commission with the Board of Supervisors.

With two Bowl entrants already chosen, Southern California and Duke for the Rose Bowl, various "bowlers" throughout the country were busy yesterday scanning the list of available candidates and weighing them in the balance.

Leonora, Teresa, Nicesia, Manual, Desiderio, Enrique and Pablo Garcia Diaz, brothers and sisters forming a family party, this afternoon swore allegiance to the United States before District Judge Robert A. Cooper in the Federal Court.

Dr. William W. Cook, Venezuela oil company physician, flew 1,500 miles from Maracaibo with his fiancee so he could be married today on American soil. The civil ceremony uniting Dr. Cook, 52, and Miss Erna I. Eichner, 28, was performed at the international Pan-American airport a few minutes after they stepped from the plane. Dr.

The Mighty Mite from Texas Christian, Davey O'Brien, yesterday was picked as the most valuable football player of the year and will receive the John W. Heisman Memorial Trophy at a dinner in the Downtown A. C. next Tuesday. A tribunal of 600 sports editors, writers and radio commentators decided that the 150-pound Horned Frog quarterback was the top man.
Dr. Aloysius J. Blakely, Professor of Pediatrics at Hahnemann Medical College, died last night at Hahnemann Hospital after a month's illness. His age was 40.
The Sunday Independent and the Wilkes-Barre Newspaper Guild today signed a wages and hours contract, ending a strike declared by the Guild on Oct. 1.
Wade Cushing, former judge of the Common Pleas Court and Court of Appeals, died in his home here today at the age of 77.
Peru in modern times must be a much more tolerant place than it was 500 years ago under the Incas. Pictures of Lima today show a memorial
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 25:

Exports of agricultural machinery from the United States totaled $5,016,518 in October, as compared with $6,826,322 in October, 1937, a decline of 27 per cent, the Machinery Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce reported today.
The Yiddish Art Theatre will play a special benefit of Sholem Asch's "Three Cities" Thursday for the Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged.
Dead Calm, Mrs. C. Gregory's 4-year-old gelded son of Grandace, captured the sixth and feature race at the Fair Grounds today.

Virtual completion of the Bayonne Terminal, largest ship-to-rail terminal of its type in the world, was reported yesterday to Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the PWA, by Edmund M. Burke, project engineer.

An alleged "two-gun" robber from Baltimore started to hold up three men early yesterday morning in the lobby of the apartment house at 14 Washington Place, but he got such a beating he dropped his pistols, one of which was discharged, wounding one of his intended victime in the left thigh.

Subscriptions opened today for a new German Government loan of 1,500,000,000 marks ($600,000,000). Redeemable at par from Nov. 1, 1953 to 1958, and bearing interest at the rate of 41/2 per cent, it represents the fourth loan floated by the Reich this year.

Employes are an important part of a company's public and must be dealt with more carefully than the average customer, according to George O. Everett, assistant vice president of the First Citizens Bank and Trust Company of Utica and president of the Financial Advertisers Association, who addressed the New York Financial Advertisers at a luncheon meeting in the Lawyears Club yesterday.

Football's last big week gave the nation's individual scoring stars their most drastic shuffling of the season and moved Leroy Fry of Texas Arts and Industries back into the lead, The Associated Press reports.

Sanford Jacobi, one of the founders of Schenley Distilleries Corporation and active in leading philanthropies here, died yesterday following a six months' illness at his residence in the Essex House, 160 Central Park South. His age was 59.

The motorship Pilsudski is due to sail today for Northern Europe. Her passengers include Dr. Karol Ripa, Polish Consul at Pittsburgh, and Mrs. Ripa; Miss Elizabeth Gorska, J. C. Berthelsen, J. C. Holm, F. W. Baldwin, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Mickelsen, Mr. and Mrs. Olaf Degen, and Richard C. Christiansen.

St Paul's Pl (11-2926), s ?, 141 e of 3d Ave, 94x98; Ethel Morrison to Bernhard Mayer Estate, Inc, 175 Lexington Ave. St Paul's Pl (11-2926). ? s. 53 w of Fulton Ave, 94x98; Ethel Morrison to Bernhard Mayer Estate, Inc, 175 Lexington Ave. Cauldwell Ave (10-2628), e ?, 386 ? of 156th St, 55x107; Ethel Morrison to Bernhard Mayer Estate, Inc, 175 Lexington Ave.

Henry Pape, Inc., food distributors, who bought their distributing depot on East Third Street, Mount Vernon, N. Y., in October, 1937, from a group of mortgage certificate holders, have purchased an adjoining vacant plot of 50 by 100 feet from the Harris estate. Harry D. Cole was the broker. This is the second vacant parcel adjoining the plant which has been acquired by the company.
With the season virtually over, eighteen large and small college football teams remain on the nation's select list of the undefeated and untied compiled by The Associated Press.

Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, returning yesterday on the steamship Santa Elena of the Grace Line from a sixteen-day cruise that included two South American ports, Cartagena, Colombia, and La Guaira, Venezuela, said that the countries of South America were "fundamentally friendly to the United States, but it is a question how much poisoning by German propaganda they can take and remain so."

The problems of Pan-Americanism with regard to the forthcoming Pan-American Conference at Lima will be- discussed by six South American correspondents in New York at a dinner next Friday evening at the Hotel Lombardy under the auspices of the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents. Dorothy Thompson will give the North American viewpoint.
A fast four-motored Focke-Wulf Condor plane took off today for Tokyo with a crew of five and one passenger, to show the Orient, especially Japan, Germany's latest achievements in airplane building.

Sixteen stockholders of the Pathe Film Corporation filed suit in Su preme Court yesterday to restrain directors of the company, which develops and prints motion-picture films, from holding a special stockholders' meeting and from dissolving the corporation and transferring its assets in part to a new company.

Pennsylvania's Amish, their fight won against modern schools, sent their children back today to their own building. Thirty children with Amish bowlshaped haircuts rode in horse-drawn sleds and typical Amish wagons through a deep snow to the opening of the'one-room country school which a special act of the State Legislature gave the "plain people" the right to operate.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway and its security holders are under "an enduring obligation" to provide for issuance of new bonds of the reorganized company to secure a loan of $3,390,000 made to the Frisco by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in 1932, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, wrote to Commissioner B. H. Meyer of the Interstate Commerce Commission on Nov. 2, it was learned today.

A memorial exhibition of sculpture, drawings, lithographs and woodcuts by Ernst Barlach, the great German artist who died in October, opened yesterday at the Buchholz Gallery, 32 East Fiftyseventh Street, to continue until Dec. 20.

An expenditure of more than $3,500,000 is contemplated for new buildings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, according to the plans filed yesterday with the various offices of the Department of Housing and Buildings.

Though a hearing is scheduled for next Monday before the United States Board of Tax Appeals on the government's claim for $750,000 against Ed Wynn, the comedian, and several companies in which he has an interest, efforts are being made to bring about a settlement, it was revealed yesterday.

Definite indication that the Treasury will borrow new money on Dec. 15 was given today by Secretary Morgenthau when he said at his press conference that it would be "reasonable" to borrow at that time.

Miss Linda Littlejohn, feminist leader of Australia and president of the Equal Rights International, declared yesterday in an address at Town Hall that under recent trade agreements with this country, Australia probably would turn its attention to the United States.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's plan to visit Rome next January is merely the latest indication of the persistence of his belief that appeasement by negotiation with the diatators is still possible. Nothing new has happened to prompt it.

October production of men's shirts and pajamas spurted to a level 23 per cent ahead of the like month of last year, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers. The industry operated last month at 9O per cent of capacity, as against 80 per cent in September and 74 per cent in October, 1937.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Nov. 23 aggregated $7,710,000,000, or about the same as the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days, and 4 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Dr. Sarah Poindexter Bent, a medical missionary who was responsible for the establishment of two of the first hospitals in China, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Donald MacKubbin of Carrol Don Farm, near Norristown. Her age was 70.
Joseph W. Tolbert of South Carolina, oldest member of the Republican National Committee, said today that he had never worn a necktie "because it's just too aggravating."

Berlin newspapers reported today that Sudeten Germans living in Italythe number was not disclosed-had voted. 100 per cent for Adolf Hitler and the Nazi party in a special polling Saturday on a German steamer off Genoa.

Robert Irwin, psychopathic slayer of Veronica Gedeon, her mother and a boarder in their home, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to consecutive terms totaling 139 years to insure his segregation from society during the remainder of his life.
Australia is planning to put out official "feelers" soon for a trade agreement with the United States, to fall in line with the United Kingdom and Canada.

Despite increases in traffic accidents, injuries and deaths throughout the country due to the two recent storms, sharp declines were shown last week and week-end in this city as compared with figures covering the corresponding periods. last year, the safety bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday.

Koloman de Kanya resigned from the Foreign Ministry today because of ill health. Premier Bela Imredy assumed the portfolio temporarily. Possible successors who are being mentioned are Count Charles Csaky and Dr. Laszlo de Bardossy.

Assistant Secretary of State A. A. Berle Jr., who is now on his way with the delegates to the Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, will eventually have to pay out of his own pocket thousands of dollars to reimburse New York City for funds stolen by an assistant while he was City Chamberlain.

The wage scale of Interborough Rapid Transit Company subway workers will remain as at present for three months after Jan. 1 with the expectation that the city will buy the line within that time, it was decided yesterday at a conference between Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, and a Transport Workers Union delegation headed by John L. Lewis, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Trading by members of the New York Stock Exchange for their own account in round lots in the week ended on Nov. 5 represented 20.07 per cent of the total volume, compared with 20.36 per cent the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission made known today.

Bond prices declined further yesterday in dull trading on the New York Stock Exchange. That quotations generally were influenced to a considerable degree by weakness in other markets was reflected in the action of the secondary and more speculative issues, which as a group were the most vulnerable obligations on the list.

The Wage-and-Hour Division of the Department of Labor will hold a hearing in Washington on Dec. 9 to consider an amendment to the regulations defining "area of production," affecting Puerto Rican cigar leaf tobacco, the Cigar Manufacturers Association of America, Inc., announced yesterday.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, accompanied by Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, will visit Premier Benito Mussolini in Rome during the first half of January while Parliament is in recess, it was announced tonight.

Johnny Gottselig, the stickhandling magician of the Chicago Black Hawks, is still the top pointgetter of the National Hockey League at the end of three weeks of play, according to the league's official statistics issued tonight.
Spreading operations between the December position and the deferred deliveries again were the feature of trading in the wheat market here today.

Thomas Byrd, brother of United States Senator Harry Flood Byrd and Admiral Richard E. Byrd, will marry Mrs. Elizabeth Miller Mitchell widow of Brig. Gen. William Mitchell, U. S. A., this afternoon at the residence here of Mrs. Mitchell's uncle and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. Adrian Lambert of 168 East Seventyfirst Street.
Those who tire of industrial exhibits and large-scale special events at the World's Fair will have a combination zoo, aquarium and general animal headquarters to visit, it was announced yesterday.
An 82-yard thrust on the first play of the game gave South Carolina a 7-to-0 victory over Catholic University at football today in the mud and slush of Griffith Stadium.

Led by a strong late demand for skating and ski suits, reorders in the wholesale markets here yesterday were substantial. Retailers requested ski costumes for immediate delivery, but the supply available in the markets here was not large and a week will be required for delivery in many instances, resident offices reported.
Plans for an intensive training course for officers of the Correction Department were announced by Mayor La Guardia yesterday after consultation with Austin H. MacCormick, Correction Commissioner.

The second annual dinner of the Yonkers Inner Circle, an organization of newspaper men and former newspaper men, was held here tonight. The dinner was also a testimonial to William F. Bleakley, county executive-elect of Yonkers.

Today's events: Musical Art Quartet, Town Hall, evening; Roger Aubert, pianist, 3 P. M.; Tipica Mexican Orchestra, George Copeland, pianist, Plaza Hotel, 3 P. M.; Gunnar Johansen, pianist, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 4:30 P. M.
Lou Ambers won a ten-round decision from Tommy Cross, Philadelphia Negro, tonight. Ambers, who weighed 138 pounds, went into the bout a 2-to-1 favorite. Cross weighed 136 1/2.

Today's events: Musical Art Quartet, Town Hall, evening; Roger Aubert, pianist, 3 P. M.; Tipica Mexican Orchestra, George Copeland, pianist, Plaza Hotel, 3 P. M.; Gunnar Johansen, pianist, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 4:30 P. M.
Lou Ambers won a ten-round decision from Tommy Cross, Philadelphia Negro, tonight. Ambers, who weighed 138 pounds, went into the bout a 2-to-1 favorite. Cross weighed 136 1/2.

Laurance P. Roberts has been named director of the Brooklyn Museums, it was announced yesterday by the board of trustees of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. The museums are the Brooklyn Museum on- Eastern Parkway and the Brooklyn Children's Museum in Brower-Park, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place.
A fire in a transformer box caused only $100 damage but compelled the power company to shut off current in the downtown district for more than an hour today.

Barcelona children are getting bread to eat and going to school daily, thanks to an American gift of wheat flour. [Wheat for 60,000 barrels of flour was given by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation.

A report made public by the State Chamber of Commerce yesterday proposed four amendments designed to correct what are regarded as the most important defects in the Wagner act creating the National Labor Relations Board.

A twelve-game basketball schedule for the 1938-39 season was announced yesterday for Queens College by Coach William Madden. This is the second year of competition for the newest city institution, which lists only one home game, against the Merchant Marine Academy at the Flushing armory Feb. 15.
The Philippine Constabulary expressed concern today for the safety of Filipino authorities on the Island of Coron, where two Japanese were killed last week in a brush with officers.
Dr. John B. Sutherland, veteran Pitt gridiron coach, today spiked a flurry of rumors that he would resign by asserting that he intended to remain at Pitt.

Roosevelt Field pilots and mechanics were astonished this afternoon to see a pilot land a seaplane on the snow-covered field here using pontoons as skis. It was the first time they ever had witnessed a landing of this nature and the field authorities said it was the first ever made at the field.
William Hester Manly, senior vice president of the Birmingham Trust and Savings Company, died today at his home here at the age of 63.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Gaffney, the former a retired police lieutenant, observed the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage yesterday by attending a mass in St. Raymond's Catholic Church, Tremont and Castlehill Avenues, the Bronx, celebrated by their son, the Rev. Edward R. Gaffney, vice chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York. Later in the day the couple received the Papal Benediction in a message signed by Cardinal Pacelli, which read as follows:

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, told the Senate committee investigating profit-sharing today that he believed the government must adopt some form of incentive taxation if it hoped to induce industry to stabilize employment through an annual wage.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The assembling of delegates in conference from the twenty-one American republics at Lima, Peru, on Dec. 9 for consideration of questions affecting the welfare and security of their respective countries individually and collectively makes timely some discussion of the applicability of the Monroe Doctrine under existing world conditions.

Stockholders of the United States Life Insurance Company will be offered rights to subscribe to seven shares of new common stock at $5 a share for each three shares now held, it was announced yesterday. The offer will expire on Dec. 10.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,974,484,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Guy Maynard Liddell, chief of England's Civil Intelligence Department, filed suit here today for the custody of his four children, whose grandfather was the London financier, the late Lord Revelstoke.

Seventy-one names have been suggested to the present nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange for the seven places on the new nominating committee. Yesterday the committee held the third and last of its three open meetings and received the names of twenty-two candidates.

A determined crowd of 650 Westchester County taxpayers gathered here tonight in the Little Theatre of the County Center and protested against departmental requests, that, if granted by the Board of Supervisors, would give the county a 1939 budget of $20,652,575, an increase of about 22 per cent over this year's budget.

Repercussions of the investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn were disclosed yesterday as John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor, prepared to examine the State Department of Correction's report charging politicall" motives to the Probation Department of the Kings County Court.
Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, made several suggestions today for the conditions under which learners in the textile industry might be employed:
" The Slasher," a phantom assailant described by his victims as having a "horrible" face with a big mouth "full of black teeth," tonight claimed his fifth victim within twenty-four hours.

Joseph Wiener and Stanley Galowin of the 42 Broadway Club, last year's winners, gained the semifinal round of the pro-amateur invitation doubles squash racquets tournament at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, yesterday.

East Side parcels furnished a large share of the activity in city realty reported yesterday. A client of George Weisbrod, attorney, bought from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company the vacant plot at 116-24 East Twenty-fourth Street for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $40,000.
Daniel M. Daniel of The New York World Telegram was elected president of the Football Writers Association for 1939 yesterday at the annual business meeting in Jack Dempsey's Restaurant.
The Ice Follies of 1939, newest figure-skating show to reach New York, will have its formal presentation at Madison Square Garden tonight.
From the most recent foreign trade statement it appears that, in the ten completed months of 1938, excess of merchandise exports over imports, $960,131,000, was the largest since 1921.
Nearly every one would agree that it would be a good thing if economic problems could be subjected to the same dispassionate scrutiny that a scientist gives to, let us say, mutations in fruit flies.

George V. Dix, attorney for Johanna Hofmann, who is on trial for espionage in Federal court with Erich Glaser and Otto Hermann Voss, charged yesterday in his closing argument to the jury that the whole conspiracy case against the defendants was "framed" by Leon G. Turrou, former special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and used as a "red herring to obscure the trial in the RobinsonRubens passport fraud."

The Marine Midland Trust Company, as trustee or fiscal agents for the dollar bonds of the Mortgage Bank of Colombia, Department of Antioquia, Department of Cauca Valley and Department of Tolima, has prepared for distribution a circular letter of interest to the holders of these bonds.

A large gathering of members of society filled the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday when Albert Morris Bagby's 406th Musical Morning was held. The artists were Miss Mafalda Favero, soprano; Richard Crooks, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, and Moriz Rosenthal, pianist.

Joseph P. Kennedy, Ambassador to London, will return to the United States on leave for the Christmas holidays, but his visit will have no official significance, Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, said today.

Catholic, Jewish and Protestant leaders of church, State, education, business and labor joined last night at a dinner of the National Conference of Jews and Christians to plead for a true brotherhood of man in the United States and a repudiation of the doctrine of race and hate they saw practiced in the totalitarian States of Europe.

The United Corporation has filed an application under the Holding Company Act for approval of an investment program involving the investment of approximately $8,000,000 of current funds which the company's officials believe now to be available for that purpose, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The Crown Zellerbach Corpora tion and subsidiaries, engaged in the producing and selling of paper and paper products, reported a net profit of $2,338,608 after all charges for depreciation, depletion, interest and taxes and with allowance for minority stockholders' proportion of the net profit of Pacific Mills, Ltd., according to the report for the six months ended on Oct. 31 and issued today.
Members of the Dies committee heard testimony today that one of their colleagues-to-be in the new House was the head of a Communist front organization.

Lieut. Governor Bray as acting Governor today issued a proclamation urging the citizens of New York State to buy "Christmas Seals" to aid public health funds and the nation-wide program for the control of tuberculosis.

Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Newhouse Jr. will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at her home, 983 Park Avenue, for Miss Patricia Shewan, a debutante of the season, whose engagement to their son, Edgar L. Newhouse 3d, was announced recently.

As pink slips began going out yesterday to about 7,000 WPA workers who are to be dropped here on Dec. 1, in line with recent instructions from Washington, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA administrator, announced that a new committee had been set up to pass on the records and qualifications of all WPA executives and candidates for promotion to executive positions.

The Miles quadruplets today celebrated their third birthday with a festive party attended by neighborhood children. One of the many callers with congratulations was Dr. C. Harrison who attended the birth of Ann, Ernest, Paul and Michael.

Sir Oswald Mosley, leader of British Fascists, today issued a formal statement that neither confirmed nor denied reports that he had been secretly married to Mrs. Diana Guinness, blond, 28-year-old, Nazi-admiring daughter of Lord Redesdale.

Japan's armaments must henceforth be on a scale sufficient for a war on two fronts, against China and against Russia simultaneously, Lieut. Gen. Eiki Tojo, Vice Minister of War, told Japan's assembled munition makers last night.

Six of the greatest horses in training-Seabiscuit, War Admiral, Stagehand, Lawrin, Dauber and Pasteurized-are nominated for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup Handicap at Hialeah Park on March 4, it was announced tonight.

Contracts totaling $10,197,717 were awarded by the War Department today for the Chemical Warfare, Air Corps, Medical Corps, Quartermaster, Ordnance and Engineer arms. Those going to New York concerns included:

Paramount today acquired remake rights to "The Cat and the Canary" from Universal and will film it on their Spring schedule with Bob Hope and Martha Raye in the leads. Arthur Hornblow Jr. will produce and writers will be assigned to prepare an adaptation this week.

David Robert Coker, agriculturist and capitalist, died today in his home here at the age of 68. Known widely as a plant breeder and cotton expert, Mr. Coker was the originator of staple cotton varieties planted widely in the United States and elsewhere.

A suggestion that President Roosevelt still places Germany in a class by herself in the matter of racial and religious oppression and that Italy is to be spared any such scathing attack as he recently aimed at Nazi persecutions came today from a concluding conference at the "Little White House" between Mr. Roosevelt and Ambassadors Hugh R. Wilson and William Phillips on American relations with the two dictatorships.

Thursday morning will find hundreds of hunters taking to the woods and swamps of the Catskills in search of a buck, and with weather conditions such as those now prevailing they stand an excellent chance of having a more successful opening day than did those at the Adirondack opening.

What will be the effect on GermanPolish relations of the new PolishRussian declaration reaffirming the 1934 nonaggression pact and opening possibilities for closer political and economic cooperation. is the main topic discussed in Polish political circles and the press.

Preferred stockholders of Federated Department Stores, Inc., yesterday approved the proposal whereby F. R. Lazarus Company, the Columbus, Ohio, subsidiary, will borrow $3,250,000 from the Equitable Life Assurance Society and issue a first mortgage on the store's property as security for the loan.

The Westchester Board of Supervisors adopted a report from its committee on vocational education today recommending that the county refrain from building vocational schools and from creating a county department of education.
Weakness in the stock market was more pronounced today, with losses in all groups jointly attributed to the French strike situation, Wall Street's week-end reaction and the uncertainty of sterling.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth B. Davis of New York, formerly of Columbus, Ohio, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John B. Davis, to Robert N. Steffens, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Steffens of Kew Gardens, L. I.

That the Mexican nation is being aided largely by relief supplied by Washington and that increased United States silver purchases during the first eight months of 1938 enabled the Mexican Government to carry out expropriation of United States and British oil companies was asserted today by Universal, the most important and most widely circulated newspaper in Mexico.
Judge Curtis Bok in formal communications today to State officials virtually asked for the impeachment of Mayor S. Davis Wilson on the basis of his personal financial transactions.
The large short interest in the pound sterling was driven to cover yesterday as rumors of a possible further devaluation of the dollar were revived abroad.

Mayor La Guardia took a walk across City Hall Park to the Hall of Records yesterday to sit in his capacity of member of the Grand Jury Board in making up the grand jury list for 1939. The Mayor has taken part in these annual meetings every year since he assumed office.

The sixteenth annual Christmas sale of articles made by the blind opened yesterday at 601 Fifth Avenue. The display, sponsored by the New York State Commission for the Blind, includes two floors of furniture, metal work and toys.
State police at Doylestown are investigating the death of Schuyler Van Rensselaer Ungar, who lived at Wismer. Bucks County. His body was found in the woods near his home tonight.

The Miles quadruplets today celebrated their third birthday with a festive party attended by neighborhood children. One of the many callers with congratulations was Dr. C. Harrison who attended the birth of Ann, Ernest, Paul and Michael.

Sir Oswald Mosley, leader of British Fascists, today issued a formal statement that neither confirmed nor denied reports that he had been secretly married to Mrs. Diana Guinness, blond, 28-year-old, Nazi-admiring daughter of Lord Redesdale.

MANHATTAN DONEGAN, JAMES A. (Nov. 17). Estate, more than $10,000. To Lucas J. Donegan, brother, executor, 137 West Walnut St., Long Beach, L. I. HENRY, FRANCIS (March 22). Estate, about $425. To Louisa Wilson Henry, widow, executrix, 71 E. 119th St.

" Redskins 49, Giants 14." In letters and figures a foot high on the blackboard in the Polo Grounds dressing room last year's score is placed in such a conspicuous position that it strikes the eye immediately upon opening the door.

Marking the first lifting by the German authorities of the ban on the payment of interest in dollars to American holders of non-governmental external obligations, Siemens Halske and Siemens-Schuckertwerke, German electrical manufacturers, announced yesterday an offer to resume such payments on their 61/2, per cent twentyfive-year sinking fund debentures, due in 1951.

The Southland Paper Mills, Inc. filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for the sale of stock to the amount of $1,615,000. The stock issue is to help finance the construction of a newsprint plant in Texas.
In a surprise move today the Newark City Commission instructed the Newark Tax Board to add $570,000,000 to personalty assessments for 1937 and 1938 on seventeen corporations maintaining offices here.

At the headquarters of the General Confederation of Labor, where meetings of unions of the different industries were being held last night to decide whether or not to join the strike, it was very evident that Premier Edouard Daladier's action of requisitioning public services had had a big effect.

MANHATTAN ADRIANCE, HENRY M. (May 26, 1938). Gross assets, $20,601; net, $18,946. To Lawrence H. Adriance, nephew. Chief assets: mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $18,672. Frank J. Wheeler, attorney, 1 Liberty St. BOWMAN, GEORGE A, (May 5, 1938). Gross assets, $8,927; net, $7.933. To Emma K. Bowman, widow. Chief assets: jointly owned property. $6.663. Warren Spooner. attorney W. 15th St.

Glenn Frank, chairman of the program committee created by the Republican National Committe to formulate a platform for 1940 and outline party policies, made a progress report to the national committee today. The final program report will probably be made late next year.
Do not grieve For the flower gone, The frozen leaf And the fallen cone. Nor for the seed Sealed in the husk, Nor the sap the root leads Home into dusk,

With the teams selected for the Sugar Bowl football game in New Orleans, Fordham University decided to call its season closed and end any further speculation on post season games. This became known yesterday when Jack Coffey, graduate manager, announced in his office:
The thirty-second annual meeting and dinner of the Traffic Club of New York was held last night in the Hotel Commodore. Officers elected for the coming year were president, Joseph A. Quinlan;

Shoe retailers found manufacturers of slippers and snow boots booked to capacity and unable to take additional orders for pre-Christmas delivery at the monthly shoe fair sponsored by the Shoe Travelers Association of Chicago. The twoday fair closed today.

Transfer and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Dec. 1: PATROLMEN-James H. Shaughnessy, from 61st Precinct, to 18th Division, assigned as chauffeur. Reuben Liebowitz, 18th Division, 12th Detective District, designated as third grade detective, assignment as chauffeur discontinued.

The question whether the Securities and Exchange Commission should order suspended or withdrawn the 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock $100 par value and the $100 par value common stock of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company from registration on the New York Stock Exchange was debated today orally before the commission.

The general death rate for New York City in the week ended last Saturday declined to 8.9 per 1,000 population, lower than ever before at this time of year, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records.

The Chase National Bank yesterday headed a group which purchased $40,000,000 New York City serial and assessment bonds. The group, comprising seventy banks and investment firms, received the award on its all-or-none bid of 100.0191 for $25,000,000 serial bonds, due Dec. 1, 1939 to 1973, as 3s, and $15,000,000 assessment bonds, due Dec. 1, 1940 to 1944, as 2 1/4s, or at a net interest cost to the city of 2.883 pert cent.

Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, who has accepted an invitation to address the convention of the National Association of Manufacturers here on Dec. 9, has also been invited to be guest of honor at a dinner of the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor on Dec. 12.

Joseph Brinsko, 32 years old, of 177 Chauncey Street here, accused of killing his wife, Rose, 21, by striking her on the head with a hatchet last night during a quarrel at their home, was arraigned before Police Recorder Louis F. Sellyer here today on a charge of murder.

Dr. James R. Angell, former president of Yale University, was elected national president of the English Speaking Union of the United States, it was announced yesterday afternoon by Henry J. Fisher, chairman of the union's board of directors, at the close of the board's annual meeting.

Being a normal citizen of the world, Jacques Deval has been privately meditating on Nazi Germany. He calls his reflections "Lorelei," and they were acted at the Longacre last evening. The word "privately" is used advisedly.

Fiscal officials met today preliminary to the scheduled meeting tomorrow of the executive committee of the Federal Reserve Board's open market committee to discuss the Treasury's Dec. 15 financing plans with Secretary Morgenthau.

Warning that the destructive forces of "racism" are increasing in the United States, the Rev. John LaFarge, Catholic writer, said last night that these elements would cause untold harm among the American people if immediate steps are not taken to combat them.

The stock market was improved today, although conditions were generally quiet. Gilt-edged shares recovered after an announcement by the House of Commons that the defense expenditure would be provided by a loan, not necessarily by increased taxation.
The Spanish Government destroyer Jose Luis Diez, now docked for repairs here, will soon be ready to put to sea and will then attempt to reach Valencia or Almeria, according to a reliable source here.

Richard K. Mellon of Pittsburgh has agreed to serve as treasurer of the Sesquicentennial Fund for Christian Education, now being raised by the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.
United States exports of industrial machinery in October fell 10 per cent below the same month last year, but showed a 3 per cent increase over September, the Commerce Deapartment reported today.

While liquidation by holders of December wheat was under way again today on the Board of Trade, the selling met with aggressive buying by cash interests who were changing over hedges into the May future.

President Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago, campaigning for "more athletics and less athleticism" in American colleges and universities, yesterday proposed a four-point program for de-emphasis of college football in an article in the latest issue of The Saturday Evening Post.

Tiger Jack Fox of Spokane, Wash., contender for the world light heavyweight title, gained an unpopular decision over Al Gainer of New Haven, Conn., last night in their fifteen-round battle at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx.

Passenger traffic on the cityowned subway system set a high record yesterday when 1,312,710 passengers passed through the turnstiles. The lines, covering fifty-three miles of track, were opened Sept. 10, 1932. The previous record was established one day during the 1937 American Legion convention when 1,294,696 passengers used the lines.
The decision of the government to call out the army in addition to requisitioning railway and State employes may be the deciding factor in the general strike in the French provinces today.

The Sugar Bowl reached outside the Southeastern Conference for both teams for the first time today when Carnegie Tech and Texas Christian University were named the opponents in the fifth annual football battle here on Jan. 2.
Mrs. Irene Fuhlbruegge disclosed here today that she had resigned in September as director of the WPA Federal Writers Project of New Jersey after a "political bout" with WPA officials in this State.

Passengers leaving tonight on the United States liner Manhattan include an all-star football team under Coach Jim Crowley of Fordham, on the way to France for a series of exhibition games. Among the twenty-two players listed are Ed Franco of. Fordham, Frank Souchak of Pitt, Vic Fusia of Manhattan and Jack White of Princeton.

The President's Joint Preparatory Committee on Philippine Affairs has at last made public its full report. In general its recommendations are in line with those indicated by the President last January and repeated in a forecast of the report last April.

Japanese orders for 170,000 tons of scrap steel have been placed here for shipment in December and January, at an average price of about $15.50 a ton, it was reported in trade circles yesterday. An order for 150,000 tons for immediate shipmeant was placed early this month at a slightly lower price.

Philip F. Scholle, retired postoffice clerk, died on Monday at his home, 326 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, after a four-year illness. His age was 64. Born in Brooklyn, Mr. Scholle served as banking and money order clerk at Station D of the Brooklyn postoffice for twentyeight years, and then In the same capacity at the Long Beach (L.I.) postoffice for ten years.

A dispatch from Washington to The Boston Herald said today that Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. intended to make good on Republican promises of cooperation with the Townsend plan by introducing in the next Congress legislation aimed to raise old-age assistance payments throughout the country from an average lower than $30 a month to a flat rate of $60.

Charges that Hiltz Co., Inc., operated to bring about an artificial rise in the stock of the ReiterFoster Oil Company were made yesterday at the Security and Exchange Commission's stop-order proceedings against the latter concern.

Although the Italian contribution to the string quartet literature is not considerable, the Musical Art Quartet was able to put together an interesting program of Italian origin at the third concert of its series last night at Town Hall. Its interest was not only historical but musical as well.
Stocks eased but closed irregularly higher on the day after moderate gains; turnover, 817,700 shares. United States Government issues steady, other bonds irregular; transactions, $6,491,700.
Another figure-skating show-the Ice Follies of 1939-was presented last night at Madison Square Garden, the first of three that will be staged at the arena before Spring rolls around again.

All efforts at compromise have failed and the French one-day general strike has begun. It began when printers and pressmen of Paris evening newspapers announced yesterday that they would stop work at 5 o'clock last evening and remain out until 5 o'clock this evening.

The defending champions, Joe Wiener and Stanley Galowin of the 42 Broadway Club, came safely through the semi-final round of the fourth annual invitation pro-amateur squash racquets tournament at the Heights Casino last night by eliminating the New York A. C. combination of Rowland Dufton and Basil Maguire in straight games, 15-11, 15-9 and 18-15.

The strike situation in the different trades and professions in the Paris region lined up early today as follows: RAILROADS--The rail federation ordered a strike from 4 A. M. to 7 P. M., but the government requisitioned employes and, holding a corps of specialists in reserve, expected to maintain services fairly completely. The first trains out of Paris after 4 A. M. moved on time.

A daughter, their second, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Irving Woodworth Raymond of 1,435 Lexington Avenue on Saturday at the Misericordia Hospital. Mrs. Raymond is the former Miss Henrietta D. Skinner. The child, who is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Raymond and Mr. and Mrs.

The Democratic State Committee reported to the Secretary of State today campaign receipts of $139,951.84 for the Fall election, while the Republican State Committee reported that it received $230,366.94.

Charles E. Bloomer, a retired actor, who passed fifty years in his profession, died yesterday at his Baldwin, L. I., home after a brief illness. Mr. Bloomer, a native of Philadelphia, was 73 years old.

The eleventh annual Russian Students BalI will be given tonight in the main ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of the Russian Alumni and Student Association. The event will have for its decorative and entertainment theme "A Night With Russian Gypsies," based on the native gypsy entertainments familiar to residents of old St. Petersburg.

Robert R. Young and Allan P. Kirby, members of the syndicate which controls the Alleghany Corportion, top company in the Van Sweringen holding structure, resigned yesterday from the board of the Chesapeake Corporation, an important subholding company, in protest against the policies backed by the Guaranty Trust Company in the dissolution of the Chesapeake Corporation.

The Juilliard School of Music yesterday announced its annual competition for the publication of American orchestral works. The winning works will be published by the school, the composer to receive royalties and fees from sales or performances. He will also control the copyright.

The State Federation of Labor, New Jersey unit of the American Federation of Labor, suggested today to the legislative commission studying a labor relations program that a labor judge, to serve for five years at $7,500 annually, be appointed by the Governor, subject to Senate confirmation.

Robert C. Zuppke, dean of Western Conference football coaches, was "reinstated" as head gridiron mentor at the University of Illinois today, receiving a timely "block" by the university's board of trustees.

Due to the holiday the number of out-of-town buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week. However, the total was ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Ye Olde English Faire, the annual three-day bazaar under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, will be opened formally this afternoon at the Biltmore by Godfrey Haggard, British Consul General here.

Two leading exponents of German art and German music who left Nazi Germany as exiles, adopted the United States yesterday as their new homeland. George Groz, painter and caricaturist, was admitted to citizenship by Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Federal court, Brooklyn, and Emanuel Feuermann, considered one of the world's greatest 'cellists, applied for citizenship papers at the Federal Building in Manhattan.

A few football games remain to be played, but for the most part the annual Autumn football frenzy has subsided. It was a flourishing season. There were many colorful games attended by great crowds. Treasurers of the college athletic associations are smiling happily.

President Roosevelt today classed the board of directors of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange with chambers of commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers, because, he said, it called the farm problem a critical one but proposed no solution.

The liner Uruguay of the American Republics Line docked last night at the end of its maiden trip to South American ports in the government's "Good Neighbor" service. During the voyage, it was reported here that there had been two fires on board, but Captain William B. Oakley, master, said the only fire on the ship started on Nov. 13, while the ship was at sea, sixtyfive miles from Montevideo.

The hotel at 70 West Forty-fifth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, formerly known as the Richmond, has been named the Hotel St. Edward. It is undergoing renovations and new elevators are being installed.

A new issue of $4,000,000 mortgage and collateral trust bonds, Series D, 3 1/2 per cent, of the Blackstone Valley Gas and Electric Company, will be publicly offered today by means of a prospectus at 104 3/4 and accrued interest.

Zionist leaders, meeting last night in the Hotel Astor at the annual assembly of the Jewish National Fund, voted to raise $5,000,000 in America for the purchase of land in Palestine for resettlement of Jewish refugees.

Broadcasting to the Newfoundland people tonight, Commissioner Ewbank announced the conclusion of an agreement with Bowater Lloyd, now owners of the former International Mills at Cornerbrook, for the purchase of 5,000 square miles of timberlands held by the Reid Company on Gander Lake.

Directors of the Utilities Employes Securities Company, an investment unit for employes of the Associated Gas and Electric System, voted yesterday to shift common stock voting control to the system's pension fund.

Mrs. Ada Folsom, who originated the "happiness package" idea, is going to get one of them herself. Mrs. Folsom is postmistress at Winthrop, N. Y. She saw how delighted people were when they received surprise gifts through the mails and suggested Americans should send them to friends and relatives during the observance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the starting of the parcel post system.
The highest livestock award of the International Livestock Exposition was won today by Irene Brown, 14-year-old high school girl, with an Aberdeen-Angus steer she bought in January for $60.

Two of twenty-seven defendants, who include T. Frank Hayes, Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut and Democratic Mayor of Waterbury and other prominent politicians of both major parties, pleaded guilty today as they went on trial in Superior Court here. They are accused of taking part in a conspiracy to defraud Waterbury of more than $1,000,000 and selling influence in the State Legislature.

Despite protests by the United States and other foreign powers, the Yangtze River will not be opened to thirdpower trade as long as fighting continues against Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's forces or even against guerrillas, the Japanese Army and Navy commands warned today.

Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N. C., former national women's golf champion, shot a scintillating 36-39-75, only five strokes above men's par for the Pinehurst No. 3 course, to win the Class A low-gross award in the eighteenth annual Carolina tournament for women today.

Roger Aubert, who comes from Geneva, Switzerland, gave his first New York piano recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. He seemed to be another in the long line of pianists stemming from almost every point of the civilized compass whose fingers can do almost anything with the keyboard except make it talk. His technique is, as the French might say, formidable.

George W. Rogers, former Bayonne patrolman and hero of the Morro Castle disaster, took the witness stand here today and denied he had attempted to take the life of Lieutenant Vincent J. Doyle, in whose hands a bomb exploded at Bayonne police headquarters last March.

Abram and Chana Grynszpan, uncle and aunt of Herschel Grynszpan, slayer of Ernst vom Rath, secretary at the German Embassy here, were sentenced to four months in jail and a 100-franc fine today for having illegally sheltered the youth after he had been ordered to leave France.

Mayor La Guardia, Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. and other city officials will attend ceremonies at 9:15 o'clock tomorrow morning in connection with the opening of the second municipal enclosed market at First Avenue and Tenth Street.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 28: Baker, Maj. Gen. W. C., Chief of the Chemical Warfare Service, one day extension of leave. Davis, Col. J. R., (F. A.). National Guard Bureau, one month and twenty-seven days' leave, Nov. 30. with permission to visit foreign countries.

Charles A. Murtha, a court stenographer and assistant to the chief clerk of the Kings County Court, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 530 Fifth Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Murtha, who was 47 years old, had worked until 9 o'clock Monday night with County Judge George W. Martin.
The Court of Appeals decided today that evidence obtained by use of the pathometer, better known as the "lie detector," was not admissible in New York courts at the present time.
The Court of Appeals ruled that the New York City sales tax must be paid by firms which took orders in New York City for goods shipped from another State to the purchaser in New York City.

In a speech filled with ironic references to the supposedly antiquated pre-war idea dominating the economic and trade policies of the United States, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, declared today that Germany would stand pat on her own regimented economy and bilateral barter policy until the world in general and the United States in particular created conditions enabling her to do otherwise.

Two George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart plays, "The Fabulous Invalid" and "You Can't Take It With You," which were produced by Sam H. Harris, will close Saturday night.
