"The Fabulous Invalid," one of this season's more expensive ventures, will have played sixtyfive performances to an average weekly gross of $14,000 or $15,000, which is good, but not high enough to continue the engagement.

9th St, 744 E, 25x93; Sarah Ziatz to Benj. J. Well, 33 E 48th St. and Louis V. Weil, 42 W 74th St, execrs. and trustees Jonas Well, ' int. Same property; same to Bernhard Mayer Estate, Inc, a corp, 175 Lexington Ave, 1/2 int. 7th Ave, 1989, 20x98; Theresa S. Sommer to 1,989 7th Ave Corp, 115 W 116th St; mtg S14,000 (2).

An investigation by Newark detectives disclosed today that John Fausher, 70 years old, who died here last night of malnutrition and exposure, according to physicians, had accounts in Newark and Philadelphia banks totaling $37,000.

Byron (Whizzer) White of the Pittsburgh Pirates, thanks to a brilliant spurt in his last two games, has moved to the top among the ground-gaining stars of the National Football League, according to statistics released yesterday.

Differences of opinion among conservatives and liberals appeared as the Republican National Committee met here today to lay plans for the Presidential campaign of 1940. All signs pointed to a struggle for control between the Old Guard and the younger group.

Plans were filed yesterday for the construction of two new six-story apartment houses, to cost $250,000 each, on Holland and Cruger Avenues, 100 feet south of Lydig Avenue, the Bronx. The Holland Construction Corporation was shown as the owner, and I. L. Crausman as the architect. The buildings are to occupy plots 150 by 84.4 feet each.

Mayor La Guardia received yesterday a large oil painting called "Morning in the Pampas" as a gift from Luis Boffi, head of the Buenos Aires delegation to the First Congress of Municipalities, which the Mayor addressed recently in Havana. Carlos Quiros, Argentine Consul General, accompanied Mr. Boffi.

Impeachment proceedings against Mayor Wilson were formally suggested to the 1939 State Legislature tonight by the House Judiciary General Committee at Harrisburg, twenty-four hours after Judge Curtis Bok had hinted to Governor Earle and leaders of the Legislature that impeachment action was warranted.

The Egyptian Cabinet today voted [Pound]1,023,000 to create the nucleus of an Egyptian fleet to consist of six mine sweepers, six torpedo boats and one coast guard vessel. These craft will compose the first installment of a fleet of thirty-six units to be built at a cost of [Pound]3,500,000 spread over two years.
Lehman Brothers and associates have received formal approval by the City Council of Kansas City, Mo., of the award of $1,200,000 city of Kansas City 2 1/4 and 2 1/2 per cent water refunding bonds.

Further covering by the heavy short interest in the pound sterling proceeded yesterday and aided materially in the continued rally of the British unit. Bankers expressed the belief that the British Control Fund had determined that the pound was far oversold and again sold American dollars until the shorts Were forced to cover.

The newest type of food stores, operated by younger, chain-trained executives and using the latest selling and advertising methods, are the organizations benefiting most from the current upswing in business, Gene Flack, trade relations counsel of the National Biscuit Company, told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

Tenements and business buildings in scattered sections of the city were traded in the realty deals reported yesterday. The five-story flat at 61 East 118th Street between Madison and Park Avenues, which recently was brought into compliance with the Multiple Dwelling Law, was sold by the Ambrose Realty Company to a client of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., for investment.

Selection of Duke University as the opponent of the University of Southern California in the annual Rose Bowl game drew caustic criticism from Los Angeles sports writers today. The general theme was that while Duke boasts a powerful record, particularly as a defensive club, the general public clamor for Texas Christian was overlooked by the U. S. C. officials.

Cornell and Navy, with four and three players, respectively, dominated an All-Opponent eleven selected by Columbia yesterday. Cornell's captain and center, Al Van Ranst, was an almost unanimous choice for the pivot post, while Carl Spang, Bill McKeever and Sid Roth gained end, tackle and guard positions, respectively.

President Roosevelt announced today the appointment of Representa member of the Securities and Exchange Commission to fill the vacancy created by the transfer of John Hanes to be Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

A sealed indictment charging that Bernard Toplitsky, Hollywood promoter, used the mails to defraud Helen Vinson, actress wife of Fred Perry, the tennis player, of $64,000 by means of a fake annuity insurance scheme, was opened yesterday by John F. Dailey Jr., chief assistant United States Attorney.
The Hershey Cubs broke a deadlock late in the third period to beat the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 2 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight.

Joseph Rosenthal, a Brooklyn contractor who built several links of the Independent Subway System, died yesterday at his apartment in the Granada Hotel, Lafayette Street and Ashland Place, Brooklyn. Mr. Rosenthal, who was active in Jewish philanthropies, was 72 years old.

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, received eight write-in votes for Governor in his home borough, the official canvass of the votes cast in the city disclosed yesterday. Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. received five write-in votes for Governor in the same borough.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson said yesterday that Mrs. Bridget Stack, 65 years old, who died on Saturday in a squalid flat at 427 East Eighty-first Street, and her husband, John, received $40.40 monthly, plus payment of their gas bills, and not $30 a month, as Mr. Stack was quoted as saying.
Lieut. Gen. Otto von Lossow, one of the leaders of the opposition to Adolf Hitler's National Socialist uprising in 1923, died today. He was 70 years old.

James A. Farley, Postmaster General and Democratic national chairman, said here today that his "long experience in politics" had taught him that "the people of any State or city resent any outside interference in their own affairs."

A picture of falling real estate values and continuing rise in welfare and relief taxes against real estate, causing many owners to forfeit their property for tax arrears was painted here today at a regional meeting in the City Hall of the New York State. Conference of Mayors.

The United States Maritime Commission today accepted the low bid of $2,729,800 each submitted by the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of Chester, Pa., for building four Diesel-propelled, single screw, C-3 cargo vessels.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy and their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Jane Cuddihy, will go to Washington on Saturday for a visit with Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Distler, who will give a dance that night for Miss Cuddihy at the Chevy Chase Club. The debutante will be introduced at the Bachelors Cotillion in Baltimore Monday night.

Problems which have vexed the odd-lot business since 1932 are expected to be settled on Jan. 1 as the result of a ruling yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange committee on floor procedure. That body, taking cognizance of complaints from three odd-lot houses, decided yesterday that no odd-lot dealer might grant terms any more advantageous to a customer than any other odd-lot dealer might grant.

Announcement has been made-by Mr. and Mrs. Pincus Glickman of Belle Harbor, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Frances Glickman, to George B. Rabinor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Rabinor of Brooklyn.

The marriage of Harry I. Phillips, New York Sun columnist, to Miss Cecele A. Carney of New Haven, was announced today. The ceremony was performed at St. Aedan's Roman Catholic Church on Saturday morning by the Rev. Charles E. O'Leary. A few close friends were present.

Manufacturers' sales during October declined 12 per cent from October, 1937, the Commerce Department reported today. Total sales of 1,600 reporting manufacturers amounted to $314,000,000 as compared with $358,000,000 in October a year ago and $318,000,000 in September of this year.

J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, reported on the condition of the nation's shipbuilding industry yesterday at a meeting of the bureau's special subcommittee on Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering.

Daredevil automobile stunts, including head-on collisions, will be a part of the exhibit staged at the World's Fair by the B. F. Goodrich Company, which signed a contract yesterday for a plot of 120.150 square feet of space and immediately broke ground for its building.

Turpentine firm, 21 1/4c; sales 19 barrels; receipts 470 barrels; shipments 80 barrels, stock 52,247 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 108; receipts 1.745; shipments 1,383; stock 307,337. Quote: B, D, S3.50; E. $4.05; F, $4.15; G. H, I, K. M, $4.27 1/2; N. $5; WG, $5.60; WW, X, $6.30.

MAX LERNER used to be on the editorial staff of The Nation. He is now Professor of Political Science at Williams College. He has put down certain of his ideas on political science and the nation in a book called "It Is Later Than You Think."*

Pennsylvania crews will participate in four Eastern regattas next season, according to an announcement today by H. Jamison Swarts, director of athletics. They are the Blackwell, Childs, Adams and Wright Cup regattas, all away from home. The Red and Blue, following out the policy of the last few years, will not be represented at Poughkeepsie.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 29 unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Acushnet, Nov. 28; Phoenix. Navy Yard, Mare Island, to San Diego: Dewey, Hull, MacDonough, Phelps, Worden.

Miss Carrie B. Neely, holder of many amateur tennis championships in the early Nineteen Hundreds, died last night in her home here after a brief illness. She was 60 years old. Earlier yesterday she had sent twenty of her tennis trophies to the Chicago Historical Society.

A blue-ribbon jury was chosen yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Erskine C. Rogers for the third trial of Henry G. Singer, former chief assistant United States attorney of Brooklyn, on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case.

The German Condor plane en route from Berlin to Tokyo passed over Calcutta at 8:27 P. M. Greenwich time [3:27 P. M. in New-York] today. [Three hours later the plane had passed Mandalay, Burma, 500 miles farther on, Reuters reported from Berlin.]

By a vote of 35 to-2, representatives of every American Legion post in the Bronx decided to recommend to the Bronx County Legion that the organization cooprate with the WPA adult education program for the Americanization of foreign-born, at a meeting last night at the headquarters of the Williamsbridge Post 1,070, 212th Street and White Plains Avenue, the Bronx.
The six-family apartment house on a plot 40 by 125 feet at 758 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the Brooklyn Trust Company to Reuben Specimer through the Bulkley Horton Company, broker.

Mr. and Mrs. Orion C. Hopper of Richmond Hill, Queens, who are visiting their son, A. Chester Hopper, in Rockville Centre, celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage on Monday. Several parties have been given for the couple, their golden wedding celebration including a ceremony at which they were "remarried" by their eldest son, the Rev. Orion C. Hopper Jr., pastor of the Memorial Presbyterian Church, Newark, N. J.

Some New York City employer will be the first "horrible example" under the Wages and Hours Act, Elmer F. Andrews, administrator, said here today. The administrator declared he is anxious to have a court test of the law as soon as possible. He has no fear that it will be held unconstitutional, he said, but believes a court test will serve to clear up any controversies that might arise.

Democratic officeholders of all persuasions--New Dealers, moderates and conservatives-would be something less than human if they did not attempt to make party capital of the selection today of former Senator Hastings of Delaware as a member of the executive group of the Republican National Committee. In such moments the rules of the game require that professionals lay aside their intra-party disputes and turn on the common enemy.

Improved business conditions for the first quarter of 1939 over the corresponding period this year were forecast yesterday by Arthur Babson, head of the education department of the Babson Statistical Organization, in an address to members of the Lions Club at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

Receipts of $70,192 and expenditures of $68,810 were listed by the New Jersey Republican State Committee in a report covering the past year which was submitted to Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis today by H. Alexander Smith, treasurer of the committee.

The marks of his world welterweight title battle with Ceferino Garcia having practically disappeared, Henry Armstrong is ready for further ring activity. Tomorrow the amazing little fighter who holds the welterweight and lightweight crowns will depart with his manager, Eddie Mead, for Cleveland, where, for the second time within the space of ten days, he will risk his 147-pound crown.

As a result of two transactions which have resulted in the concentration of control of the Blue Ridge Corporation into the hands of Harrison Williams companies and the transfer of the Williams minority interest in the Tri-Continental Corporation indirectly to this corporation, the Williams interests have reduced materially their holdings of North American Company common stock.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 26: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Mahoney, E. C., the West Virginia, to continue treatment Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif. LIEUTENANTS

Two conference champions, Tennessee and Oklahoma, were selected today for the seventh Orange Bowl football game here Jan. 2. Both teams are undefeated and untied, but have one more game of their regular schedules to play, the Sooners meeting Washington State and Tennessee's Vols encountering Mississippi on Saturday.

In an attack on Leni Riefenstahl, publicized as a close friend of Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany, the Hollywood Anti-Nazi League for the Defense of American Democracy called upon the film industry today in full-page advertisements in the motion-picture trade papers to "close its doors to all Nazi agents."

The investigation into the conduct of law enforcement agencies in Brooklyn received another case for scrutiny yesterday as the story of how a defendant received three suspended sentences on three separate charges of policy slip possession under three different aliases during one day in Special Sessions Court was related by a witness in Kings County Court in the trial of a "substitution" case.

The board of governors of the National Hockey League assembled yesterday at the Hotel Commodore to discuss plans for indemnifying players whose careers have been terminated by injuries. The governors voted to insure their athletes, and also voted to establish a fund to provide for the families of players who may become fatally Injured in hockey games.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,260,900 barrels, compared with 3,255,800 in the previous week, an increase of 5,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Kibitzers were as rare as grand slams tonight as the American Contract Bridge League opened the Fall session of its national bridge championships. A Cleveland team topped the twenty-eight women's foursomes at the halfway mark in the women's national team-of-four championship.

The All-Eastern football picture is strongly tinged with the Gold and Blue of Pittsburgh and Cornell's Red and White. Each squad contributed three players to the selections compiled yesterday by The Associated Press.

The estate left by Marlyn Miller, musical star of stage and screen, was estimated yesterday at $47,573 net in the transfer tax appraisal filed by the State Tax Commission. The gross estate amounted to $97,407, but it was reduced by funeral and administration expenses of $17,261 and debts of $32,572, including fees to eleven physicians.

The Very Rev. Michael J. Ripple. co-organizer of the national movement of the Holy Name Society, died here today at the age of 63 in the Johns Hopkins Hospital. Father Ripple was one of the bestknown members of the Dominican order in the United States, both for his work in the order and his long association with the Holy Name Society.

Deaths Announced Retired Fireman William F. Renz, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 151, residing at 166-40 Twenty-fourth Road, Flushing, Queens, died Nov. 27. Funeral will take place from funeral parlor of Martin A. Gleason, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, at 2 P. M., Wednesday, Nov. 30. Interment at St. John's Cemetery Middle Village. Queens.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Moss, daughter of Mrs. James Moss of Newark, N. J., and the late Mr. Moss, to Thomas E. Colleton of East Orange, N. J., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the Rt. Rev. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle.
Jose Ramirez Santibanez has been unanimously elected President of the Liberal party, succeeding the late Senator Antonio R. Barcelo, who led the party for twentytwo years.

Additional contributions of $5,031, bringing the total raised to date in the $205,000 campaign of the Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York to $107,693, were reported yesterday at a campaign luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore. The largest gift reported was one of $500 from the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.
Gertrude Ribla, 21-year-old lyric soprano, made her debut yesterday at the Rafaelo Diaz concert at the Hotel Plaza, under the sponsorship of Mrs. Alfred P. Sloan.

Mrs. Ward C. Belcher gave a luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Among the guests were Mrs. Wesley C. Bowers, Mrs. Eugene W. Leake, Miss Marian Forsyth, Mrs. William C. Cannon, Miss Dorothy Cockshaw, Mrs. Delavan M. Baldwin and Mrs. Herbert. Jones.

Hunts Point Ave. 891-99: 5 story tenement, 65.1x00 irreg; Metropolitan Life Insurance Co against Joseph Spektorsky Realty Corp: due, $89.000: taxes, etc. $1,200; to plaintiff for $50,000. Crotona Ave, 2,004: 3-story dwelling. 25x 100; HOLC against Guiseppe Castellano; due, $12,227; to plaintiff for $500.
Mrs. Elsa Dryfoos Weiskopf obtained a divorce today from James L. Weiskopf, New York broker, on the charge of cruelty. Agreement was made for the custody of their two children.

In the fiercest engagement of the present Palestine campaign, fought last night near the village of Umm Azzinatt, on the southern slopes of Mount Carmel, south of Haifa, forty-three Arabs and two British soldiers were killed. Six other British soldiers were wounded, three of them seriously. Many Arabs were also wounded.

Johanna Hofmann, beauty parlor attendant on the German liner Europa, and Otto Hermann Voss, an airplane mechanic, were convicted last night in Federal court for conspiring to transmit American defense secrets to Germany.

Gifts of more than $75,000 toward the construction of a new $250,000 Community Church building at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street were announced last night a dinner in the Hotel Astor on the fifty-ninth birthday of its minister, John Haynes Holmes.

Mrs. John Edmund MacKenty, widow of the senior surgeon of the Manhattan Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat Hospital, who died in 1931, died yesterday morning in 1931 died yesterday morning in her home, 111 East Sixty-first Street, where she suffered a heart attack. She was in her sixty-seventh year.

Rayonier, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Georgia Timber Company, showed a net profit of $64,895 for the three months ended on Oct. 31, after provision for depreciation, expenses and other charges, according to a report issued yesterday.

Mrs. Philip McKim Garrison of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., and 20 East Sixty-second Street, this city, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lydia Knight Garrison, to Samuel Sloan Auchincloss of Darien, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sloan Auchincloss of New York.

Outskating and outplaying their opponents from the start, the St. Nicks won their fourth straight game and their third in the circuit by defeating the Crescent A. C., 8 to 0, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. They took undisputed possession of first place in the New York Amateur Hockey Association.

Vienna has Just had a week-end of fantastic rumors. It was said that Chancellor Adolf Hitler had come here Saturday and spent the night at Schoenbrunn Palace, returning to Berchtesgaden next day after havying ordered a large number of members of the Nazi party, estimated from 90 to 165, shot.

The Midston S. C. team assumed a clear lead in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Class A tournament yesterday by defeating Bayside, which had been tied with it for first place, by a score of 4 to 1.

Five persons disappeared in a rough sea near Point Reyes, twenty miles north of here, early this morning, when a luxurious United Air Lines transport plane, after wandering helplessly amid a maze of radio signals which confused the pilot, alighted on the Pacific Ocean near a 500-foot cliff.

Two international skiing aces, Jack Miller of St. Margaret's, Canada, and Norwood Cox, Harvard coach, have been signed to compete in' the International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show that starts a five-day run next Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.
The consummation of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's plan for interest deferment will cost about $175,000, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.

Government securities held as investment in trust funds and in accounts of certain governmental corporations and agencies on Oct. 26 totaled $4,519,607,000, compared with $4,452,234,000 on Sept. 28, according to a monthly report issued today by Secretary Morgenthau. The report follows:
Following is a summary of the program of cooperation with Latin America recommended to President Roosevelt. today by the Interdepartmental Committee:

Steel ingot production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 99.6, its highest point in almost fourteen months. The figure was 94.8 for the preceding week, and 47.7 for the week ended Nov. 27, 1937.

Upon receipt of a formal resolution yesterday from the American Labor party naming George Backer as its candidate for the post in the City Council left vacant by the death of B. Charney Vladeck, the Council referred Mr. Backer's name to its committee on privileges and elections.

Germany's standing army has been increased by four corps, the press disclosed today. The Nazi Reich now is generally credited with a peacetime army of approximately 1,000,000 men as compared with 800,000 before the World War. (This is second only to Soviet Russia, which has a peacetime army of 1,300,000.)

The State introduced today a mass of exhibits purporting to detail fees and expenses paid to G. LeRoy Kemp as State land agent for the Merritt Parkway and payments to land owners in fifty-six transactions in which he is accused of conspiring to divide commissions unlawfully with two real estate brokers.

Counsel for Thomas J. Mooney proposed today that the California convict be permitted to come to Washington to testify personally before the Supreme Court in his campaign for freedom. He is serving a life sentence in San Quentin Penitentiary on charges of complicity in the 1916 Preparedness Day parade bombing at San Francisco.

Mr. Joseph W. Tolbert, former Republican boss of South Carolina and senior member of the Republican National Committee, is once more adorning the Washington meeting of that body. His famous gold collar button still symbolizes his sterling attachment to the Federal patronage.

On the eve of beginning the Administration's monopoly investigation, the Federal Trade Commission today urged amendment in the next Congress of the Clayton Act to prevent corporations in interstate commerce from buying physical assets of competing organizations.

A marked improvement in Egypt's relations with Italy since her formal recognition of the conquest of Ethiopia culminated today in a semi-official announcement that friendly conversations between the two governments would take place soon.

Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, in a letter to Mayor La Guardia yesterday asked the Mayor to oppose the proposal, now before the City Council, which would give tax exemption to housing projects undertaken by limited-dividend corporations here.

Broadway, 549-55, 99.1x200.3: Rouss Building, Inc, to S. Blecehman Sons, Inc, 502 Broadway; pr mtg, $210,000; due Dec. 31, 1948, 6%; $30,000. 117th St, 172 E, 17x100.11; Mary Angiulo to City of New York by Board of Child Welfare; given to secure money advanced as and for aid to dependent children; 5 yrs. without int; $1,000.

Trading in most classes of traefer meats was generally slow in local markets yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to higher and the cow and bull markets higher. Other classes were steady to lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb and beef to be about steady: veal and calf lower. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:
Today the eyes of the world are on France. Much more is at stake than the fate of a one-day general strike, or the fate of the forty-hour week, or even the future of the Daladier Government.

Miss Lucy N. Robinson, an early worker in the woman suffrage movement, died yesterday at her home here of a heart attack. She was the daughter of the late Judge Silas Arnold Robinson, who was a justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court.

The Rev. Dr. Alexander Marlowe, authority on the Hebrew language, poet and pastor of the Presbyterian Church here for the last sixteen years, died of heart disease in his home here tonight. He was 58 years old.

A1bert P. Hughes, a real estate dealer, who formerly was author and editor of several publications of the American Baptist Publication Society in this city and St. Louis, died in the Delaware County Hospital yesterday at the age of 59.

IT takes something to raise Old Harry because he is ordinarily a quiet and almost reticent fellow. The reference is to Harry Hillman, the Dartmouth track coach, who long ago gathered Olympic laurels in fragrant bunches. But up in his Hanover haunt Old Harry was moved to sit down and write the following letter:

The five-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 175 feet at 1,250 Boulevard East, West New York, N. J., was sold by the Prudential Insurance Company to David S. Meister, operator. Sale was for cash above a ten-year first mortgage of $72,000.

A warning that American business men might eventually be forced to turn to "some form of disguised fascistic dictatorship" to bring order out of chaos was voiced here today by H. W. Prentis Jr., president of the Armstrong Cork Company of Lancaster.
Harry J. Leland, stage actor, died yesterday at his home at the age of 61. Mr. Leland, a native of Boston, played with the late Robert Edeson, Frank Keenan, May Irwin and other stars.

Al Reid, 128, Bronx, gained a hard-fought eight-round decision over Joey Fontana, 130, Bensonhurst, at the Broadway Arena last night before a capacity house. Reid's strong finish gave him the winning margin.
One of the largest sales of property in Greenwich Village in recent weeks was revealed yesterday with the filing of transfers on a Washington Street blockfront opposite the Gansevoort Market.

With the announcement today of the election of Allen A. Bergner of Kankakee, Ill., as football captain for 1939, it became assured that he would lead Navy against a former team-mate, Harry Stella of the same town, who was named captain of the Army team just after last Saturday's service game in Philadelphia.

Dr. Peter Olof Sundin, obstetrician and gynecologist, who had been present at the birth of more than 10,000 babies, died today in the California Hospital, at the age of 61. Dr. Sundin had been a member of the California Hospital staff since 1908 and was on its executive. medical board and obstetrical committee.

The premiere performance of the Ice Follies last night at Madison Square Garden drew a large attendance of members of society and artistic circles, many of whom had assisted on various committees in the Interests of the Musicians Emergency Fund, beneficiary of the event.

Canadian chartered banks in their monthly reports to Finance Minister Dunning as of Oct. 31 show current deposits about $24,000,000 higher than on Sept. 30 and $70,000,000 greater than Oct. 31, 1937. Corresponding increases in savings accounts were $23,000,000 and $72,000,000.

Thomas J. Fallon, 50 years old, who gave the Delmonico Hotel in Park Avenue as his home address, was found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of commercial bribery in accepting $5,000 in the Spring of 1937 to arrange the sale of the Hotel Dryden, in East Thirty-ninth Street, to David Phillips, operator of the Hotel Elysee, in East Fifty-fourth Street.

Allegations that fraud and misrepresentation were used to obtain a $1,710,000 grant to Kansas City, Kan., for the construction of a railroad produce market were laid before Secretary Ickes, PWA Administrator, today by opponents of the project.

Mrs. Allen S. Hubbard gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 800 Park Avenue, for members of the committee arranging a bridge party, tea and Christmas sale to be held tomorrow at the Junior League clubhouse in behalf of the Peabody Home for aged gentlewomen.

B. E. V. Luty of Northside, writer on steel and one of the best informed persons in the country on the statistics of that industry, died today at the age of 68. He had contributed to the financial pages of local newspapers for more than twentyfive years.

In the recovery of values following the end of the European war scare. the dollar value of- sales on national securities exchanges amounted to $1,740,251,592 in October, an increase of 65.1 per cent over September but 13.4 per cent less than in October, 1937, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, have formally accepted invitations to be guests of honor and principal speakers at the first "stunt dinner" of the New York Financial Writers Association, to be held Dec. 16, at the Hotel Astor.
Maria Caniglia, Italian dramatic soprano, was warmly applauded in her Philadelphia debut tonight with the Metropolitan Opera Association in the title role of Verdi's "Aida."

Raffaele Guarriglia, presenting his credentials to President Albert Lebrun of France, announced himself as Ambassador "of His Majesty the King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia." President Lebrun repeated the phrase in receiving the credentials.

Directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company authorized a dividend of $1 a share on the preferred stock. The last payment was $2.50 on Feb. 1, this year. Borden Company A final dividend of 40 cents for the year was voted by the Borden Company, bringing dividends for 1938 to $1.40 a share, or 20 cents less than 1937 disbursements.

William H. Dunmeyer, 46 years old, of 131 Fulton Street, Atlantic Beach, L. I., former postmaster of that seaside resort, who pleaded guilty on Nov. 21 to an indictment charging misappropriation of $1,230 of postal funds, received a suspended sentence of a year and a day yesterday from Judge Robert A. Inch in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

Business in this country has grown so great that State lines no longer exist, and, therefore, the Federal Government has been fully justified in regulatory measures, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming told the dinner session of the convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.

Three resignations announced today from the Non-Intervention Committee on Spain seem to indicate the organization is breaking up. Paul-Henri Spaak, Belgian Premier and Foreign Minister, declared that in view of the committee's repeated failures there seemed to be no point in Belgium's continuing to be represented on it.

Magistrate Frank Oliver settled a subway traffic controversy yesterday while he was sitting in Bronx Magistrate's Court. It seemed that two persons tried to push a subway turnstile in opposite directions at the same time. One disputant was a member of the police force. The party of the second part found himself haled into court on a charge of disorderly conduct.

Business conditions in Nicaragua have greatly improved in the past six months and the currency is stable. The government has a balanced budget, and its surplus is being spent on the construction of public buildings and highways.

Several leases for quarters in buildings on Park Avenue marked the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday. Among those said to have leased suites was Samuel Leidesdorf, head of the accounting firm bearing his name, who took quarters in 550 Park Avenue through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., broker.

The Chinese reported military successes today north and south of Hankow, the great Yangtze port that fell to the Japanese Oct. 26. To the south, the Chinese counteroffensive along the Canton-Hankow Railway was reported to have advanced within seven miles of Yochow.

E. Phillip Nussbaum, head of the Charter Bus Company of New York, which negotiates the chartering of buses, died of a heart attack this morning while riding in an automobile from his home in Eastchester to the Scarsdale railroad station. His age was 54.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Ormonde Vosburgh of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor S. Vosburgh, to Carlton sinnott Cutbill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Cutbill of White Plains.

Harvard University announced tonight that the Harvard Corporation had voted twenty new scholarships of $500 each for qualified refugee students of any creed from Germany, provided that each scholarship be supplemented by contributions for living expenses to an amount equivalent to $500 raised by the undergraduate committee on refugee students.

The performance tonight of "The Boys From Syracuse," the new Rodgers and Hart show at the Alvin Theatre, will be a benefit for the health project of the Frontier Nursing Service, Inc., in the mountainous regions of Kentucky. The evening's benefit program will be concluded with a supper dance in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria after the performance.
Today's events: "La Boheme," Metropolitan, evening; Rose Bampton, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Alfred Saint-Malo, violinist, Town Hall, 3; New York Civic Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, 8:45;

The British Government will help to meet its swollen armament expenditures in the next few years by additional borrowing, Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced today to the intense relief of the House of. Commons and the country generally.

William L. Ward, president of the Marcus L. Ward Homestead here and formerly a partner in the New York jewelry firm of N. H. White Co., died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital, Newark, after a long illness. Born in Newark, Mr. Ward was a son of the late Aaron Ward, founder of an old Newark grocery firm.

Judge J. A. Valin, member of the board of guardians of the Dionne quintuplets, said today that officials of the New York World's Fair need not make any more offers for exhibition of the famous children, adding: "We don't want to exhibit our babies, now or ever.
German insurance concerns made an international question today of claims for damages, which one broker put as high as 1,300,000,000 marks, in the anti-Jewish violence of Nov. 10.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed last night that he would send a special message to the City Council calling for immediate adoption of the county reorganization bills that have been kept in committee since their introduction by Councilwoman Genevieve B. Earle of Brooklyn last January.

A $185,000 mortgage for 10 years at 5 per cent during construction of the building and 4 1/2 per cent thereafter on the 7-story apartment house under erection on the a w cor of Reservoir Ave and W 195th St, the Bronx. has been arranged for Perfect Holdings, Inc. Nathan Weinstein, president, by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc. brokers.

The purchase of Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" by RKO, who have been negotiating with Jed Harris for some days, will be completed if Mr. Harris and Pandro Berman, the studio production chief, can devise a method of filming the play so that it will be a practical commercial venture and still retain its metaphysical flavor.
The Long Island University varsity basketball team will play a difficult twenty-three-game schedule this season, Clair F. Bee, director of athletics and coach, announced yesterday.

Charles E. Kelly, president of Hagerty Brothers Co., was elected chairman of the Drug, Chemical and Allied Trades Section of the New York Board of Trade at the first meeting of its newly elected executive committee yesterday at the Drug and Chemical Club.

Representative Wolverton, Republican, of New Jersey, charged today that accounting practices of the Tennessee Valley Authority did not give a "true picture" of the Authority's financial transactions. He made the assertion at a hearing of the TVA investigating committee of which he is a member. While criticizing an annual TVA report to Congress, Mr. Wolverton said:

President Roosevelt indicated today that the restoration of complete diplomatic representation for the United States in Germany might depend upon future developments in that country and the course it pursued regarding racial and religious minorities, as well as its response to American demands for equitable treatment with other nations in the commercial field.

The Downtown Athletic Club team, Class B champion in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, received a set-back last night by bowing to the Cornell Club, 3 to 2, on the latter team's courts in a Group II match.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Coptic Art in Egypt," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.; The Egyptian Colplection (General Tour), 2 P. M.; "French and English Cabinetmakers: Queen Anne and Chippendale," Ethelwyn Bradish, 4 P. M.

Sunday night we received a telephone call from a friend who had been shooting ducks on Great South Bay. According to this man, one of the greatest flights of waterfowl he ever saw came into the bay just before dark while he was on his way back to port.

A seventeen-game schedule, featuring six contests in Madison Square Garden against strong local and out-of-town opponents, has been arranged for Manhattan's varsity basketball team, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. issued this afternoon the following statement:

T. B. Wilson was elected chairman of the board and a director of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., at a meeting of the board of directors yesterday. He will fill the vacancy created by the resignation some time ago of Henry Dupont. Mr. Wilson was formerly vice president of the Alaska Steamship Company.
The Interstate Commerce Commission reopened today a proceeding in which it permitted three railroads some years ago to pool their passenger earnings.

The commanding officers of the city's sixteen police divisions were summoned to police headquarters by Commissioner Valentine yesterday afternoon for a conference, the subject of which was reported to be gambling arrests, convictions and dismissals.

The late President Kemal Ataturk's will, amounting to about [pound] 750,000 and written in his own hand last Sept. 5, leaves all personal property and the remainder of his real estate to the Republican People's party. During his lifetime he made over to the nation or the party most of his real estate.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the award of contracts for a total of 351,100 yards of textiles, for shipment by Dec. 15, from bids opened Nov. 22, as follows:

A great step forward was taken here today in the matter of the settlement of Jewish refugees. The initiative for the creation of a Jewish colonization society taken by a small committee of Netherland Jews a fortnight ago has been rapidly developing into a vast action that bids fair to become, before long, of paramount importance for world Jewry.

A Communications Commission examiner heard testimony today concerning operation of radio stations WOV and WBIL in New York, which Arde Bulova proposes to combine with Atlantic City's municipal station WPG.

Activities of the Iron Guard, Fascist organization, which had become more intense in Northern Rumania, reached a climax today with the sending of identical letters to the Governors of Cernauti and Cluj, saving.

Five prizes for fine prints were awarded yesterday at the twenty-' third annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers, which will be opened to the public today at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.

In last Sunday's TIMES L. Marsland Gander, reviewing two years of British television, made it clear that in London topical broadcasts are more popular than short plays and that when drama is presented at all the public wants allstar productions lasting an hour and a half.

A former New York school teacher, whose husband, a Korean, is imprisoned in Russia, charged with being an "economic. spy," arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Samaria to appeal to the State Department for assistance in obtaining her husband's release.

An order requiring the Transit Commission to show cause today why the demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated should not be stayed pending appeal was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Isador Wasservogel.

The investigation into the arrest of Mrs. Gladys Holzinger of 17-35 Murray Street, Flushing, Queens, for turning over a revolver to police for fear her father would commit suicide with it, was still under way yesterday.

The flexible gastroscope, invented in 1932 by Dr. Rudolf Schindler, Associate Professor of Medicine at the University of Chicago, has proved to be a powerful new weapon against cancer of the stomach, the greatest of all cancer killers, it was reported here yesterday by Professor Schindler in a lecture at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, under the auspices of the Herbert Swift Carter Memorial Fund.

A better undertone ruled in most sections of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Substantial recoveries were shown in some of the more speculative groups, including local traction issues, while many convertible loans reflected the improvement in share prices by moving up sharply.

The turning point in the A. V. R. O. international chess masters' tournament, concluded at Amsterdam on dents Sunday, came when Reuben Fine of New York and Paul Keres of Estonia, who divided the first and second prizes, met in the seventh round and Keres won.
The Apawamis Club defeated the Greenwich Field Club, 5 to 2, in the final interclub squash racquets match on the latter's courts yesterday and captured the Westchester championship.

The domestic price of zinc was lowered yesterday 4 cent a pound to 4.50 cents at East St. Louis by the leading producers. A week ago the price was reduced 30 points to meet competition expected from the cut of 35 points, or $7 a ton, in import duty, effective on Jan. 1 as a result of the Anglo American trade treaty.
Good news for the vast army of skiing enthusiasts in the metropolitan area is contained in a message from James V. Mulholland, director of recreation of the Department of Parks of New York City.

We have heard a good deal lately about incentive tax exemption. Now the motorists of New York State are to get incentive insurance rates as a reward for safe driving and an encouragement to continued watchfulness.
Miss Agnes S. Ward, general superintendent of nurses of the DeApartment of Welfare from 1920 to 1926, died yesterday of a heart ailment in her home, 865 Riverside Drive.

Unless the United States "strengthens its whole economy and puts it on a sound basis, it is useless to embark on any rearmament program," Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, declared last .night-at the first annual convention dinner of the Made-in-America Club Inc. at the Hotel McAlpin.

Partly Se as a result of large filings by electric and gas utility companies, chiefly for refunding purposes, new security registrations under the Securities Act of 1933 becoming effective in October, exclusive of those registered for conversion, amounted to $405,063,000, the Secur-ities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Miss Helen Dunn, daughter of Mrs. Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Dunn of 119 West Seventy-first Street, will be married today to Simon Mezerow, sol of Mrs. Rose Mezerow of Los Angeles.

Few members of the trading public will be conscious of the change in New York Stock Exchange oddlot business which will become effective Jan. 1. On that date oddlot dealers will be forbidden to go sharp-shooting for business with the ammunition of absorbed taxes.

In one of the few decisions dealing with patent infringement in the manufacture of jewelry, Federal Judge William Bondy has written an opinion disposing of a suit brought by Cohn Rosenberger, Inc., against the Leading Jewelry Manufacturing Company. Inc.

Mrs. Alice St. John Hunt of 46 West Fifty-fifth Street and Elisha Lee of 139 East Fortieth Street obtained a license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said they would be married on Saturday in Bedford, N. Y. No announcement of their engagement had been made.

A row of old four-story East Side tenements well known to motorists who use the Queensboro Bridge soon will be no more. The blockfront on the west side of Second Avenue from Sixtieth to Sixty-first Street, at the Manhattan end of the bridge, has been sold by Helen L. Sackett to an investing group.

Ernie Nevers, backfield coach at the University of Iowa, who came here with Irl Tubbs two years ago, submitted his resignation, effective June 30, 1939, to Athletic Director E. G. Schroeder today. The former Stanford All-America fullback refused to disclose future plans, but he has been mentioned as a possible successor to Mike Creighton, who' resigned as coach of the Chicago Cardinals yesterday.
Appointment of Dr. Ross T. McIntire, White House physician for five years, as surgeon general of the navy with the rank of rear admiral, was announced today by President Roosevelt.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest the letter to THE TIMES of R. C. O'Brien in regard to faults of the merit system as at present administered. Undoubtedly no merit system is perfect. On the other hand, there are several very important matters which Mr. O'Brien does not consider.

A charge of homicide against Frank Mott, 39 years old, a truck driver, of 869 Seventieth Street, Brooklyn, was dismissed in Homicide Court yesterday by Magistrate Louis Brodsky, who found no culpable negligence on Mott's part in the killing of a man and a woman by a truck on Oct. 31.
After a meeting of the men's committee at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, last night, it was announced that $955,076 had been raised to date in the United Hospital Fund campaign.

Mrs. Kenneth Collins of London Terrace, wife of the vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., died of pneumonia at Doctors Hospital yesterday. She was 40 years old. The former Miss Marta Helen Moe, she was born in Tacoma, Wash., and attended the University of Idaho. She had lived in New York for twelve years.

The 7,000 WPA employes in this city who were to have been dropped from the rolls by tomorrow under a retrenchment order from Washington will retain their jobs as a result of instructions received yesterday from Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA Administrator, countermanding the order.

Magistrate Earl A. Smith, who worked his way through two institutions of higher learning, became an Assemblyman and served as a magistrate for sixteen years, died early Monday night in St. Elizabeth's Hospital after an illness of about two months. His age was 62.

Mrs. Elizabeth Miller Mitchell, widow of Brig. Gen. William L. Mitchell, U. S. A., commander of the United States air forces in France during the World War, was married to Thomas Byrd of Winchester, Va., yesterday afternoon at the home here of the bride's uncle.. and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. Adrian V. S. Lambert of 168 East Seventy-first Street.

The National Labor Relations Board was notified from Philadelphia today that its decision holding that a company dyeing and finishing goods was engaged in interstate commerce if it transported these goods across State lines was upheld by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest the letter to THE TIMES of R. C. O'Brien in regard to faults of the merit system as at present administered. Undoubtedly no merit system is perfect. On the other hand, there are several very important matters which Mr. O'Brien does not consider.

A charge of homicide against Frank Mott, 39 years old, a truck driver, of 869 Seventieth Street, Brooklyn, was dismissed in Homicide Court yesterday by Magistrate Louis Brodsky, who found no culpable negligence on Mott's part in the killing of a man and a woman by a truck on Oct. 31.

There's another undefeated, untied and unscored-on team looking for a post-season game. It's Belmont Abbey Junior College. The college authorities issued a blanket challenge today for a post-season game to decide the national junior college championship.

A funeral service will be held at 2 P. M. today in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, for Sanford Jacobi, a founder of the Schenley Distillers Corporation and a philanthropist, who died on Monday here.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull will be met on his arrival on the steamship Santa Clara tomorrow by Colonel Clarence S. Ridley, Governor of the Panama Canal, and Frank P. Corrigan, United States Minister to Panama.
Any number of little boys and girls will look out of the window of their chromium-plated and thermostated classrooms in the

There has been a highly significant change in the Treasury's approach to tax and budget problems. After theme last years it may sound improbable, but the fact cannot be got around; there is a new inclination to consider taxes from the business man's point of view.

Motorists who live in New Jersey but whose cars are registered in other States in which the tags expire Dec. 31 will be required to obtain 1938 New Jersey registration tags to continue operating after the first of the year, Arthur W. Magee, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced today.

Charles E. McDonald, young elec- t trician, was convicted tonight of assault with a deadly weapon for the shooting Aug. 19 of Mrs. Emita Krueger, wife of Karl Krueger, conductor of the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra. The conviction carries a possible prison term of from one to fourteen years.

Praising new educational facilities in which vocational students can be graduated from schools with culture instead of from "sweatshops," Mayor La Guardia laid the cornerstone yesterday for the new "skyscraper" Central Needle Trades High School on Twenty-fourth Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

Barnes Ave (17-4845), s w cor of 232d St. 37x100; Russell Homes Corp to Cotteret Realty Corp, 119 West 25th St; mtg, $26,000. Southern Boulevard (10-2565), e s. 115 ft n of 136th St, 28x138; also Southern Boulevard South, e s. 86 ft n e of 136th St, 28x102: John C. Fayen to Joseph Reitano Jr., 636 E 224th St.

Albert G. Michelson, a Madison attorney, died today at his home at the age of 62 years. Born at near-by Mount Horeb, he was graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1901. From 1903 to 1906 he served as United States vice consul to Denmark.
Dr. Chester A. Mathewson, chairman of the Biology Department of Jamaica High School, died Monday night in his home at 47-30 157th Street, Flushing, Queens, after a short illness. He was 59 years old.

Thomas R. Mountain, '39, of East Orange, N. J., Princeton football captain, received the John Prentiss Poe '95 Cup'at the eleventh annual dinner for the Nassau varsity, scrub, freshman and 150-pound gridiron forces in the Princeton Inn tonight.

A fighting football team at the University of Iowa next Fall was predicted by Dr. Edward N. Anderson today as he received a rousing welcome from 1,500 persons on his arrival to take over the Hawkeye football coaching position.

Premier John Bracken of Manitoba called today for a definite national policy regarding the world wheat situation. The question vital to the national welfare, he said, was how Canada was to continue to find markets for twothirds of its wheat in the face of steadily shrinking world markets.

Harry Hopkins's suggestion that all relief officials be placed under civil service would meet with the overwhelming approval of American voters, according to a survey made by the American Institute of Public Opinion, ot which Dr. George Gallup is director.

Pettingell Fenton, Inc., and the L. H. Hartman Company, Inc., will merge tomorrow, the combination to be known as Hartman Pettingell, Inc., it was learned yesterday. The merger brings together two agencies in widely diverse fields, Pettingell Fenton accounts being chiefly in the fashion, shoe and cosmetic industries and the Hartman clients mainly in the liquor field.
Robert Boda, Columbus theatre manager, announced today that the world premiere of -the Sinclair Lewis-Fay Wray play, "Angela Is Twenty-two," would be held here on Dec. 30.
Simon Schuster have signed a contract with Dr. Abraham Flexner for the publication of his "Memoirs." Dr. Flexner is director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J.

The State Department made public today the registration of twenty more firms and individuals who reported to the department that they act as American agents or representatives of various foreign organizations.

A broad program of cooperation between the United States and the other American republics to render their relations closer and more effective was recommended to President Roosevelt today by an interdepartmental committee that has been studying the question at his request for six months.

Unusually narrow fluctuations marked yesterday's trading on the Cotton Exchange, prices ending with gains of 1 to 3 points. Following the settlement of December contracts for about 45,000 bales here and in New Orleans on Monday, further liquidation of December reduced the open interest in the spot month- on both Exchanges.

Three matinee programs of five games each for high school basketball teams in the metropolitan district will be played at Madison Square Garden during the coming season, according to an announcement yesterday. The dates listed are Dec. 17, Jan. 7 and Feb. 11, all Saturday.

A public woefully lacking in knowledge of banks and their operation" should be informed by the banks, Philip A. Benson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn and newly elected president of the American Bankers Association, said yesterday at a luncheon in his honor in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

Members of Mayor La Guardia's committee to formulate a housing program for presentation to the Legislature expressed agreement yesterday with Park Commissioner Robert Moses' idea that up to 10 per cent of new housing funds might be used for recreation and purposes allied to housing.

The Board of Estimate, at a special meeting yesterday, voted $1,939,561 in tax notes to pay the cost of snow removal up to 6 o'clock this morning, but as the work cannot be completed for a few days the total cost of the recent storms will be well over $2,000,000.

Porcellus, Mrs. Samuel Orr's 5-year-old mare, made her second start of the Fair Grounds meeting a winning one today when she defeated ten other good sprinters in the feature. She stepped right fast, too, running the six furlongs in 1:12 1-5.
Manufacturers and retailers were prominent among the lessees of new business quarters listed by brokers and agents yesterday. Much of the activity centered in the midtown section.
Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Cuban Chief of Staff, said in an interview today that an oral agreement had been reached for reduction of the tariff on Cuban sugar entering the United States.

The New York University freshman basketball team will play seventeen games during the 1938-39 season, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics. The team is coached by J. Albert Maier, '26.

County Judge L. Barron Hill here today held Mrs. Elizabeth Dobitz, 51 years old, of Farmingville, L. I., in $5,000 bail as a material witness in connection with the death of her husband, William Dobitz, 55, a carpenter and builder, who was shot and fatally wounded on Monday night of last week behind their house in Farmingville.

F. W. Elven, editor of the Cincinnati Freie Presse, German language newspaper, who recently was named by the German Government to receive its second-class Eagle award, said today he had refused. to accept the citation.

After we left Medford, Ore., I stayed awake, looking out the window. Most of the other passengers were asleep, but I couldn't sleep. It was rough and blowing and there was a light streak across the sky to the south as though there were a fog bank.

Jacob Abrams, builder, has obtained from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co-a first mortgage of $115,000, running 10 years with interest at 4 1/2 per cent, on the new 6-story apartment at 3,080- Hull Ave, the Bronx. This replaces the building loan for $100,000 made several months ago by the Sterling National Bank and Trust Co.

The New York Central Railroad will meet the last of its funded-debt obligations to fall due this year with the payment of a $745,000 installment on 41/2 per cent equipment trust certificates, W. F. Place, vice president, announced yesterday.

Two European painters, Mariano Andreu the Spaniard and Andre Girard of Paris, are holding their first one-man shows in New Yorkthe former at the Valentine Gallery, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street (unti Dec. 16), the latter at the Sullivan Gallery, 460 Park Avenue (until Dec. 19).

Emilio Funicello, 36 years old, a life-term convict from Dannemora prison who is considered by the police to be one of the most dangerous criminals in America, took the stand in General Sessions Court yesterday and identified four men in the fatal shooting of Police Sergeant Timothy Murphy Sept. 14, 1931, in the hold-up of a restaurant at 18 East Thirteenth Street.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 29: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Carr, E. J., Inf., Indianapolis, Ind., detailed as a member of the General Staff Corps, May 1, and to duty in the Philippine Dept.; to sail from New York about April 1.

The Works Progress Administration reported today that employment on projects declined 27,985 during the week ended last Saturday. The rolls stood at 3,215,564 on that date, as compared with 3,243,549 on Nov. 19.

A refund of $5,000,000 to domestic users of tinplate will result from a retroactive reduction in the price made by steel companies two weeks ago, but hitherto unrevealed, according to an article in this week's Iron Age.

The blockfront on the south side of 215th Street, running from Seaman Avenue to Park Terrace West, in upper Manhattan, will be improved with two six-story apartment buildings by the new owners of the property, the Oval Building Corporation and the Sea Park building Corporation.

Miss Josephine Munson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Sharp Munson of Merion, was married this afternoon to Morris Clothier Maxwell, son of Mrs. John Rogers Maxwell of Selkirk, Villanova. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard C. Lyford in St. Asaph's Church in Bala-Cynwyd.

A dispatch from Washington to The Boston Herald states that Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. intends to make good on Republican promises of cooperation with the Townsend movement by introducing in the next Congress legislation to raise old-age assistance payments throughout the country from an average of somewhat less than $30 a month to a flat rate of $60.
Specific bequests of $200,000 each were provided for Yale University and the Yale Alumni University Fund Association by Edward Benedict Cobb, retired New York lawyer, in his will filed today.

Jacques Deval, who has the reputation of never getting out of a bedroom farce on the wrong side, has written another slight but engaging bit of animated nonsense in "Say It in French," which was being said in English at the Paramount yesterday.

Society must contribute new items toward the cost of rearing children, just as it already contributes to the cost of their education, the American Eugenics Society was told last night by Frederick Osborn at the annual dinner of the society at the Town Hall Club.
The University of Newark opened its season tonight and defeated a stubborn Princeton Seminary quintet, 51 to 44. Sherman Harmelin led the Newark attack with 16 points.

Stuart B. Tulloss, chief investigator of the accounting office, told Congressional investigators today that so far as he knew there had been "no dishonesty worth investigating" in TVA's large expenditures.

A resolution calling for an appropriation of $295,000 to finance the investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn, ordered six weeks ago by Governor Lehman arid regarded as the most sweeping inquiry of its kind in the history of the State, will be submitted at a meeting of the Board of Estimate today by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, leader of the forbidden anti-Semitic Iron Guard fascist movement, who was serving a ten-year sentence of penal servitude for conspiracy with a foreign power and incitement to revolt, was shot dead by his guards this morning together with thirteen other Iron Guard prisoners being transported from the prison in Rimenescul Sarat to the military prison at Jihlava near Bucharest.
Miss Anna W. Kerr, wartime registrar of nurses at the Washington headquarters of the American Red Cross, died yesterday at her home in Larchmont, after a brief illness.

SOME weeks ago there was printed in this corner a sorrowful chapter entitled: "Never Discuss Amateurism." Quite probably-and that's putting it mildly-it didn't fall under the eye of Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, the comparatively youthful president of Chicago University.

Westchester Ave (10-2689); s e cor of 161st St, 35x172xirreg; Great Northern Apartment Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave, extends mtgs to Oct. 1, 1941, at 4 1/2 per cent; $136,500.
Charles F. Noyes Company has arranged with a savings bank for David Zipkin a building and permanent loan for the construction of a six-story apartment, containing 200 rooms, at 251-9 Seaman Avenue.
Rose Bampton, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, was taken suddenly ill during the first half of her recital at Town Hall last night and was unable to go on with her program after the intermission.

Senator Bankhead today blamed failure to "understand fundamental Southern conditions" for the recent action of the Southern Conference for Human Welfare in condemning racial segregation laws. "It is regrettable," Mr.

A cooperative association of farmers and sportsmen to raise and distribute game and safeguard the interests of land owners was advanced today as a means of meeting hunters' complaints of "plenty of game but no place to hunt."

Former Senator Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware owes his election to the Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee to forces within the party councils friendly to Charles D. Hilles, former national committeeman from New York, younger members of the committee asserted today.

The second performance of the Ice Follies of 1939 was presented at Madison Square Garden last night before a gathering of 8,000. The show will be continued tonight and Three tomorrow, with a matinee on Sat- Bow urday and the concluding performance Saturday night.

To take effect 8 A. M. Dec. 1: SERGEANTS--Isaac Goldstein, from 47th Precinct to 70th Precinct; Philip W. J. Parker, 48th Precinct to 47th Precinct. PATROLMAN--Guglielmo W. Cappadora, from 75th Precinct to Motorcycle Precinct 2, assigned to motorcycle duty.

Jim Crowley, Fordham's football coach and one of the game's Four Horsemen during his undergraduate days at Notre Dame, headed for France as a sports missionary when he sailed on the United States liner Manhattan at midnight.
Mercedes Rivera, 40 years old, the father of eight sons and four daughters, today became the island's first farmer to get United States aid for purchasing farm land under the Bankhead-Jones Act.

Clarence C. Fowler of this place, from 1918 to 1931 special deputy superintendent of the State Insurance Department and chief of its liquidation bureau, died yesterday in Wingdale, N. Y., after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

Herschel Grynszpan, accused of the assassination of Ernst vom Rath, a secretary in the German Embassy here, testified in his preliminary examination today that the diplomat, after having been wounded, had struck his assailant in the face and called him "a dirty Jew."

Payments of cash dividends by the companies of the Standard Oil group for 1938 are estimated at $200,917,805, a decrease of about 27 per cent from the $273,735,561 distributed by the companies in 1937, according to Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.

Part of the metropolitan division of the Shell Union Oil Corporation, involving more than 100 employes, will move today from its present office in Brooklyn to new and larger quarters at 81-20 Thirtyseventh Avenue, Jackson Heights.
John J. McLaughry, son of Brown's head football coach, was elected captain of the Brown varsity football team by the letter men tonight.
The annual meeting of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will be held this morning at the Biltmore Hotel where new officers will be elected and plans for the 1939 season discussed.

The United Wholesale and Warehouse Employes of New York, a C. I. O. affiliate, announced last night that 1,000 workers employed in the storage of WPA clothing in the Bush Terminal in Brooklyn had sent a cablegram to Leon Jouhaux, leader of the French general strike,

Ten countries are sending their Foreign Ministers here to preside over their delegations to the Pan-American Conference here opening Dec. 9. They are Bolivia, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Ecuador, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru and the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The subject of national defense is to the fore at the moment, and as it is a problem of great importance it is well that we give it serious consideration. Unless we take care, we are in danger of getting a very unbalanced program.

The failure of the French general strike plan was hailed here as a victory of law and order and a personal victory for Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet, which will permit continuation of the French-German rapprochement initiated after the "Munich peace."

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in November was on a smaller scale, because of the holidays, and the volume of business for the month was the slowest of any corresponding period since 1934. The largest day's trading was 3,098,780 shares on Nov. 9, and the smallest was 783,950 shares, Nov. 2.

Playing on its own court, Webb Institute's basketball five turned back the Brooklyn Poly Institute jayvees last night by 26 to 19. Led by Donovan, who accounted for 9 points, Webb took the lead early and was ahead at half time, 13 to 8.

Mrs. Mary Landes, 41 years old, wife of William S. Landes, president of the Celluloid Corporation, attempted suicide yesterday, according to the police, by inhaling gas in the kitchen of her home at 30 Fifth Avenue. She was found at 11:45 A. M. and quickly resuscitated.

The Brattleboro Theatre actors, those doughty champions of the drama on the other side of Brooklyn Bridge, have grown soft in their latest production, "If You Get It, Do You Want It?" which opened last night for a two-week engagement at the St. Felix Street Playhouse.

Leases of business space reported yesterday included two contracts for specialty shops on Madison Avenue. Emil, designer and maker- of women's gowns, leased the store at 713 Madison Avenue through Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc., and the Fred F. French Management Company.

The Tax Revision Commission, created by the 1938 Legislature and headed by Senator Edward P. Stout of Hudson County, made public here tonight proposals designed to produce about $60,000,000 a year in levies collected by New Jersey to finance education and relieve real estate of approximately $40,000,000 of its present tax burden.

The Delaware Electric Power Company will redeem on Dec. 31, 1938, at par and accrued interest plus 2 per cent, $240,000 of gold debentures, 51/2 per cent series, due in 1959. Payment will be made on Dec. 31 by the Chase National Bank, trustee.

Two hundred airplanes will soar over the gleaming white pylon atop Kill Devil Hill on Dec. 17 in commemoration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the "birth of aviation." Below them representatives of the Army, the Navy, the Marine Corps and other agencies will lay wreaths upon the base of Wright Monument.
Anthony Eden, former Foreign Secretary, will visit America with the blessing of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's Cabinet, Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary, told the House of Lords today.

Mrs. Elsie B. Wimpfheimer, through J. H. Taylor Construction Co, agents, in 315 E 68th St; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc, brokers. Mrs. Joseph F. Moran, in Ritz Tower Hotel. Park Ave and 57th St: Ruth Putnam Mason, in 125 E 56th St; Axel H. Skjelborg, in 18-20 E 58th St; Mrs. Hattle Thompson. in 20 E 67th St; Hazel Hoecker, in 204 Central Park South; Huberth Huberth, brokers.

Edwin S. Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, told the Massachusetts Conference of Social Work tonight that proposed changes in the Wagner Act were not necessary would work against the interests of organized labor, and would cause serious delays in settling labor disputes.

A testimonial dinner for James F. Nathan, assistant to the first vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, who retired yesterday at the age of 70 after fifty years of service with his company, was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

In a move that surprised both prosecution and defense, Judge Thomas H. Brown called Albert D. Osborne, handwriting and typewriting expert, to testify here today at the Special Sessions trial of George W. Rogers, radio operator aboard the ill-fated liner Morro Castle and for1 er Bayonne patrolman, who is accused of attempting to kill his superior officer, Lieutenant Vincent J. Doyle. with a homemade bomb.

Herbert Murray has been appointed special sales representative of the Hotel New Yorker for the Southern area. The Hooker Electrochemical Company is planning to erect an office and administration building in connection with its main plant at Niagara Falls.

So many security holders of the St. Louis, Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway Company have appeared before the New York Stock Exchange Committee on stock list to protest against the proposal that its common and 5 per cent non-cumulative stock be stricken from the list that the committee has decided to defer recommending delisting tO the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Unparalled, C. C. Cook's 3-year-old filly, came from behind to win the mile-and-seventy-yard West End Purse at the Fair Grounds today. The veteran M. Calvert brought Unparalled from far back in the last half-mile.

The Board of Tax Appeals decided today that John J. Raskob, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, owes the government $886,833, plus eight years' interest, and that Pierre S. du Pont, industrialist, owes $586,369, plus interest.

Failure of a counterfeiter to observe traffic regulations may land him in jail. Ramsey S. Black, assistant postmaster general, cautioned postmasters throughout the country today against accepting newly reported counterfeit $10 bills.
Labor disorders broke out in eight French cities tonight after Premier Edouard Daladier had smashed the nation-wide general strike.

Dr. Ernest A. Bennett, for forty years a Catskill deatist, died here today after a long illness. He was 64 years old. A graduate of Waterville School and New York Dental College, he practiced for a time in Brooklyn before coming to Catskill in 1898.

The season's second "La Boheme," given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, attracted a capacity house that responded with unusual warmth to the performance of a cast identical with that of the first performance.

Each of the following reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 77th Division-2d Lt. John E. Arthur, Inf.Res., in care of United Mutual Fire Ins. Co., 10 E. 40th St., New York, N. Y.; 2d Lt. James W. Fuller, Inf.-Res., 331 IV. 28th St., New York, N. Y.; 2d Lt. Charles L. Meredith, Inf.-Res., Co. "I," 18th Inf., Ft. Wadsworth, N. Y.

The special session of the Legislature, summoned in July by Governor Earle chiefly to enact laws delay the Dauphin County grand jury investigation of graft and corruption charges against his administration, adjourned at 5 P. M. today.
The International Silver Company announced today that it would pay bonuses amounting to $100,000 to employes.
Surrogate James A. Foley will be the guest of honor tonight at the annual dinner of the New York County Lawyers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The new measure to control foreigners entering Brazil will go into effect when the recently enacted immigration law becomes effective on Dec. 22. Foreigners who entered Brazil illegally after 1934, mostly on tourist visas good for six months, received 120 days to legalize their stay.

President Roosevelt issued a proclamation through the White House today inviting Americans and "friends beyond our borders" to attend the New York World's Fair and the Golden Gate International Exposition at San Francisco next year.

A contract signed by Francis J. Gorman, international president of the United Textile Workers of America, in March, 1937, giving control of the union to John L. Lewis, head of the C. I. O., was held invalid today by Judge Charles A. Walsh in Superior Court.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity in November showed a sharp decline from the figure of the previous ??th and aggregated $116,862,000, compared with $217,884,000 in October and $76,172,000 in November, 1937.

Judge George W. Whitehurst today gave Mrs. Pauline Warren Palmer a divorce from Potter d'Orsay Palmer, member of a wealthy Chicago family. Mrs. Palmer charged him with habitual intemperance. They were married in New York on June 1, 1937. Palmer previously had been married and divorced twice.

The following Marine Corps changes, dated Nov. 29, were announced today: Pickett, Lt. Col. H. K., Navy Yard, New York, N. Y., to headquarters, Washington, D. C. Hollett, Capt. G. L., Guan, to Navy Yard, Mare Island, Calif., for duty and treat ment at Naval Hospital, to sail via the Chaumont about Dec. 2.
The State Board of Standards and Appeals reserved decision today, pending submission of briefs and depositions, on a request of the Liberty Legion of America, Inc., for incorporation in New York.

133d St, 502 W, 25x99.11; Besslie Shapiro to Rose Baer, 350 Beechmont Dr, New Rochelle, p m mtg. 6 yrs, 4%; $1,000. Amsterdam Ave, 1,473-5, 50x75; Abraham Shapiro to same, given as security for performance of agreement to repair 502 W 133d St, prior mtg $38,000, due March 1. 1939. int as bond.
The LibbeyOwens-Ford Glass Company today received the National Glass Distributors Association's first award of merit for outstanding industry accomplishment during 1938.

A set of gold-filigreed ornaments which Ruth St. Denis had used in a costume for her Egyptian dances was stolen from her apartment at 215 East Fifty-third Street some time Tuesday night, Miss St. Denis reported yesterday to police of the East Fifty-first Street station.

If traditional American individuality is to be preserved, top management must find new ways of producing more goods at lower prices to spread buying power, maintain wages and shorten hours, William L. Batt, president of SKF Industries and head of the International Management Conference, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Standards Association at the Hotel Astor.

With the big charity game at Ebbets Field Saturday still three days away, the starting line-up of the Metropolitan College All-Stars, who will oppose the Brooklyn Dodgers, was released yesterday by Coach Benny Friedman.

The Trunk Line Association, comprising railroads operating West from New York, announced yesterday that passenger fares in its territory both in coaches and Pullman cars would be reduced from Dec. 15 to Jan. 1. The New England lines are to reduce fares on the same basis.
A purge of the National Socialist party is actually in progress here, although rumors of wholesale executions, which are officially denied, appear fantastic.
Pennsylvania's Fair Practice Act, forbidding merchants to sell goods below cost, was ruled unconstitutional today by Judge Samuel H. Gardner in Quarter Sessions Court.

Captain Bill McCoy, a Palm Beach apartment house owner, said today that he had been asked to supervise the building of a $20,000 mahogany fishing sloop to be presented to President Roosevelt by the Dominican Republic "to show its high regard" for the President.

The A. V. R. O. international chess masters' tournament, concluded at Amsterdam Sunday, furnished more than one surprise. Not only did the world champion, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine, fail to win first prize, as many had predicted he would, but he suffered defeat three times.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Congress 'of Industrial Organizations, called profit-sharing programs a "snare and a delusion" today when he testified before the Senate committee studying the use and possible extension of such systems in American industry.

Delegates to a meeting of the general council of the Northern Baptist Convention, representing a membership of 1,800,000, condemned the "threat to vital religion" manifested by totalitarian governments in a resolution adopted yesterday at the Hotel Prince George, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.

Two persons were killed and eleven gravely wounded as a result of a volley that Yugoslav gendarmes fired into a group of Croat peasants near Sibenik, Dalmatia, last Sunday. The Croats were demonstrating in the course of a campaign for the forthcoming national elections.
