Lack of confidence if the stability of the European political situation is reported to have been a continuing cause of the capital movements to the United States in the past month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York observes in a discussion of the movement of gold here from abroad and-of the weakness of the pound sterling, which is contained in the current monthly review of the bank.

With an attendance of about 800, Ye Olde English Faire, sponsored by the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York to aid the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women at Ossigning, N. Y., was opened yesterday afternoon at the Biltmore Hotel.

Hope that the Lehigh Valley Railroad's plan for a reduction of the interest rates on its bonds and extension of the maturity of the securities would be declared operative tomorrow by the committee appointed in connection with it was voiced here today by D. J. Kerr, president of the railroad, at the conclusion of a meeting of the board of directors.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Beattie of Rumson, N. J., were supper hosts in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis yesterday, their party including Mr. and Mrs. William J. Wendell of Hartford, Conn., Mr. and Mrs. Horace E. Fisher Jr. arid Mr. and Mrs. George Dwight of Rumson.

Despite the fact that a legion of New Yorkers are planning to join in the opening of the deer season in the Catskills another large group of sportsmen seem to be wondering just what the fishing situation is like in the deep South.

One of the longest promotion lists ever approved by a President in time of peace was announced tonight by the Navy Department. Heading the promotions are nine captains who are elevated to rear admirals, and seventy-nine commanders who will become captains.

Harvey Huffman, an attorney and president pro tern of the State Senate, died of a heart attack in his home today at the age of 70. This was the last day of his term, his fourth. He was elected to the Senate in 1910 and re-elected in 1922, 1926 and 1934, becoming president pro tem when the Democrats gained control in 1937.

A new non-stop distance record for light planes was set yesterday afternoon when John M. (Johnny) tribute Jones, 25-year-old Van Nuys (Calif.) flier, landed at Roosevelt Field, L. I., after spanning the continent from West to East in a craft with a lower horsepower rating and operating cost per mile than that of popular-priced automobiles.

The $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company announcedd yesterday that it would file a plan of geographic integration and corporate simplification with the Securities and Exchange Commission in compliance with the requirements of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

The St. Andrew's Society held its 182d annual dinner last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, acting as host to more than 600 members and guests and to delegations from several other organizations dating from the founding of the Republic. The dinner opened with the piping of the haggis pudding, the pipers sounding "Bannocks o' Barley Meal."

The first encouraging sign of an adjustment to the complicated middleweight championship situation involving Solly Krieger and Fred Apostoli came yesterday. Hymie Caplin, manager of Krieger, conferred with Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. over the telephone.

The former home of Richard T Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, at 115 East Seventy-third Street, will be sold at foreclosure auction on Dec. 20 in the Vesey Street salesrooms by Edwin J. McDonald, auctioneer.

Fifty-five minutes late, former Mayor James J. Walker attended a party for sixty children of the Silver Cross Day Nursery, 249 East 117th Street, yesterday afternoon. Late or early, it was all the same to the children, however, for officials of the nursery, who had begun to lose hope that Mr. Walker would arrive, had already begun serving the ice cream and cake.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "Tannhaeuser," Metropolitan Opera, evening; Greenwich Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, 8:45; Municipal Opera Association concert, Carnegie Chamber Hall, 8:30; Alan Bush, lecturer, Metropolitan Music School, 7:30.

The German Government issued a semi-official statement tonight insisting that the Colombian Government's recall of Rafael Jaramillo Arango, its new Minister to Berlin, and the transfer of Rafael Roch Schloss.

Henry W. Stokes, a retired paper manufacturer, died of a heart attack today at his home in Media. He was 71 years old. Graduated from Haverford College in 1887, he was president from 1909 to 1929 of the York Haven Paper Company.

A for German cannon that was placed on the front lawn of the public library here last Armistice Day constitutes "a glorification of war" and should be removed to a resting place on the bottom of the Hudson River, according to complaints today to the village and library trustees.

Consideration will be given to providing additional tariff concessions to Cuba on sugar, tobacco and tobacco products, potatoes and rum in a reciprocal trade agreement supplemental to that of Aug. 24, 1934, according to the State Department.

Presession rumblings heard these days in some quarters on Capitol Hill indicate that the new national defense program may not have all easy sailing in the next Congress, especially if President Roosevelt adopts a suggestion advanced within his advisory staff and asks for a super-Congressional and departmental committee to handle its details.

Trading in bull, cow and fresh pork cute fair, other classes slow in local markets yesterday. The general lamb market was lower, veal and calf weak to lower. fresh pork cuts steady to weak, cow strong to slightly higher; other classes steady.

Summoning in his own behalf all the skill he formerly used in convicting others, Henry G. Singer, former Chief Assistant United States Attorney of Brooklyn, spent three hours yesterday delivering an opening address in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Erskine C. Rogers and a blue ribbon jury, where he is on trial for the third time on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case.

The result of local balloting on prohibition in forty-six towns of twenty-four up-State counties of New York last Nov. 8 made little change in the wet versus dry standing in the State, it was revealed yesterday by a tabulation of the State Liquor Authority.
Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, sitting in the Bronx, granted yesterday the city's application for condemnation of the low Sixth Avenue elevated line and ble signed the necessary order.
New financing in November aggregated $213,790,000, of which $182,843,000 represented fifty-nine bond issues and $30,947,000 five stock issues.

Mrs. Jessie Fox Mack, wife of Judge Julian W. Mack of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, died yesterday afternoon at their apartment in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street. She had been ill for several months.

The Assembly Finance Committee outlined today the reductions of imperial preference necessitated by the United States-British trade pact. Electrical products, hardware, certain canned goods and flour are the principal items affected.

Otto L. Tinklepaugh, Mrs. Virginia Shears's house on Old Well Road, Pine Hill, Purchase; James A. McHugh, at 133 Old Mamaroneck -Road, White Plains; George Friedlander, at 148 Greenridge Ave., White Plains; James W. Scales,. at 180 Evandale Road, Greenburgh; Westchester rentals by Howard L. Auerbach, Inc., broker.

Tunisia is a French protectorate on the northern coast of Africa; with the Mediterranean Sea on the north and east, Italian Libya on the southeast, the Sahara Desert on the south and Algeria on the west.
Mrs. Augustus H. Strong, Rochester philanthropist, traveler and church and society leader, died today in her home here. She had been ill for three years.
The death of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu ends the career of the man who had hoped to become Rumania's Hitler, from whose life and ideas Codreanu drew his inspiration.

The refusal of the River Plate and Brazil Conference to grant membership to the Sprague Steamship Agency, Inc., was chiefly the result of opposition of the United States Government, it became known yesterday.

ACCORDING to Postmaster General Farley, Huey Long was wearing a straw hat with a fancy band when he breezed into the President's office for the last time. Mr. Roosevelt was sitting at his desk, and the Postmaster General, as high chief of patronage, was seated near by. Long was in a hurry to settle the question of jobs for the Louisiana faithful and started talking at top speed.

Commission merchants at the Chicago stockyards, which have been tied up for ten days by a C. I. O. union strike, stated today that they would not receive any more livestock until the controversy was ended.

New York will be the scene this month of a large number of conventions; bringing together representatives of industrial, business, fraternity and educational organizations from all over the country, it was announced yesterday by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau of the Merchants Association.

Charles S. White, formerly with Previews, Inc., has formed the White Realty Counsel, with offices at 12 East Forty-first Street. The firm will offer a buyers' advisory service and sellers' publicity service for country and suburban properties.

Italy's first bid for territories which, though belonging to France, fascism regards as rightfully Italy's for ethnographic and historical reasons, was made this afternoon when the Chamber of Deputies resounded to frenzied shouts calling for the annexation of Tunisia, Corsica, Nice and Savoy.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is carrying to New York and other financial centers its investigation of the "front money" or "advance fee" racket, an ingenious method of capitalizing on certain regulations of the SEC designed to protect investors, it was learned today.

A client of Herbert J. Gebing, broker, has purchased for cash from Thomas Crooks a tract of forty-one acres on Farmers Mills Road, Kent, Putnam County. The parcel adjoins the estate of Loretta Both and the Gypsy Trail County Club, contains a one-acre pond and is situated on high ground.

Modern Age reports that recent events in Germany have tripled the sales of Erika Mann's "School for Barbarians: Education Under the Nazis." Since early October 26,800 copies of the book have been printed.

Listed bonds, led by the Treasury Issues and railroad loans, made substantial headway yesterday in slightly increased trading. Closing prices for United States Government obligations were under the best levels of the day, as these issues reacted slightly after the announcement from Washington that $700,000,000 in new money would be sought during December.

Alfredo Monges of 368 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, was found guilty by a General Sessions jury yesterday of criminal neglect in the operation of his motor truck on the evening of Aug. 2, 1937, when Benjamin Spiegel, 24, of 314 East Seventy-eighth Street was knocked down and fatally injured by the vehicle.
More than 3,000 railroad officials and railroad supply men will attend the sixty-sixth annual dinner of the New York Railroad Club in the Hotel Commodore on next Thursday.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition for Arrangement CLARKE PIECE DYE WORKS, INC., 6777 E. 11th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler act, listing liabilities of $23,208 and assets of $27,840. Settlement of claims in full in six equal installments at intervals of three months is offered.

Ecuador's control board has established a quota of $2,500,000 to cover permits for imports from the United States, according to a dispatch to the newspaper Universo here. This does not includee lard or railway equipment, for which special licenses are granted.

Major Gen. Frederick W. Boschen, Chief of Finance, U. S. A., and Mrs. Boschen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Boschen, to Edgar Morris Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris of this city.

Miss Liliuokalani Kawananakoa, daughter of a Hawaiian Prince, and Clark Lee, Associated Press foreign writer, were married here today under special license granted by Sir Geoffrey A. S. Northcote, Governor of Hong Kong.
A sharp rise in public projects throughout the nation last month sent major engineering construction awards to the highest November volume since the lush days of 1929.
A person who suffers partial loss of hearing is entitled to workmen's compensation benefits even though there is no loss of earning capacity, in the opinion of the Court of Appeals.

The number of Jewish refugees expelled over the Sudeten frontier since the German anti-Semitic outbreak is said by refugee organizations to approximate 1,000. Estimates vary, since refugees are pushed back and forth between Germany and Czecho-Slovakia.
In each of its four phases--the latest one, in the general aspect of a hemisphere security program, is just emerging-the New Deal has included spending as a major activity.

The application of the Greyhound Corporation to acquire the Old Colony Coach Lines, Inc. for 16,667 shares of the former's common stock should be denied, A. Henry Walter, examiner, recommended today to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

For the second day in a row the Giants drilled indoors yesterday on the floor of the 165th Infantry Armory in preparation for Sunday's important game against Washington, when the Eastern Division honors of the National Football League will hang in the balance.

Harry E. Mackenzie and Edward G. Levy, who pleaded guilty here yesterday as participants in an alleged million-dollar graft conspiracy, will testify against twentytwo other Waterbury politicians and city officials now on trial for the same charge, including Mayor T. Frank Hayes, whom the grand jury characterized as the leader of "this small but powerful, ruthless and corrupt group of men."

The discovery of an extensive German espionage organization in Denmark, with reported branches in other northern countries, has attracted considerable attention in Finland as constituting a grave risk to her military security.
The Tennessee Electric Power Company, through John R. Aust, denied today all charges of discrimination in favor of The Chattanooga Free Press and the Home Stores, Inc., of Chattanooga.

Distinguishing Christmas from New Year's Day as a "holy day, a family day and a home day," Dr. Frederick Burnett, New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Commissioner, announced today that there would be no exten ion of the 3 A. M. closing hour for Christmas morning, which will be Sunday.

Instead of directly attacking the A. P. series of advertisements in their own advertising copy, independent grocers have decided to switch emphasis to an institutional theme and to "sell" independent grocers- to the American public, it was learned here yesterday.

Those who think that chess is an old man's game should consider the results of the international tournament at Amsterdam. Tied for first place were Paul Keres of Estonia and Reuben Fine of our own Bronx.

Hundreds of products and systems used in industry and public utilities, from heavy power machinery to precision instruments, will be shown by 'more than 275 concerns in the thirteenth National Exposition of Power and Mechanical Engineering, which will open at the Grand Central Palace on Monday and will continue through Saturday.

Dr. Louis Lerner, lecturer and dental specialist and former president and treasurer of the Eastern Dental Society, collapsed from a heart attack yesterday morning while treating a patient in his office, 11 West Forty-second Street, and died before a physician reached his side. He was 54 years old.
The British Government is to make a frontal attack on cancer, which now causes 70,000 deaths each year, by establishment of a cancer service at an estimated cost of about [Pound]700,000 a year.

2d Ave, 240; to 5-story school; Board of Education, 500 Park Ave, owner; A. Rogers,. engineer; cost, $20,000. 113th St, 338 W; to 6-story tenement and stores; Lorenzo Lagomarsino, 311 W 54th St. owner; Anthony Lombardi, architect; cost. s9.000.

Mrs. Edward Spring Knapp, past president of the Women's Long Island Golf Association and a charter member of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club of Glen Head, L. I., died early yesterday morning at her home, 300 Park Avenue. She was 56 years old.
The vatican most positively denied reports in the German press that Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna, has been removed and replaced by Konrad Count von Preysing, Bishop of Berlin.
Sir John Aird, former president of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, died of a heart attack today in his home. He was 83 years old.

A fast-moving program of varied Winter sports kept a crowd of 6,500 enthusiasts interested throughout as the fourth Annual Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet opened tonight in the Alpine setting of the Boston Garden.

The work of flushing the city's $2,000,000 worth of Thanksgiving snow into the sewers was speeded up yesterday by a record number of hose gangs and was continued through the night. With the temperature well above freezing all day, rising to 47 at 3:10 P. M., Department of Sanitation had 23,000 men on snow removal, including 1,756 hose gangs. Five hundred flushing crews worked last night.
The New York Rovers increased their lead in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight by coming from behind to defeat the second-place Orioles, 2 to 1.

The success of Premier Edouard Daladier of France in putting down the general strike gave a strong new boost to the foreign exchange market. Interpreted as an event that would strengthen the present French Government, the smashing of the strike was looked upon, apparently, as a contribution toward greater stability in the general European political situation.

News of the collapse of the general strike in France yesterday heartened the financial markets. Grains alone of the leading commodities failed to improve. The share market closed strong, with leading stocks up 1 to 3 points and two issues up 4 points.

Yasha Katzenberg, described last year at a League of Nations committee meeting as an "international menace" because of his operation of a $10,000,000 narcotic ring, received a prison sentence of ten years and was fined $10,000 when he pleaded guilty yesterday.
One hundred and forty employes of Harmon P. Elliott, addressing machine manufacturer, will divide $4,375 tomorrow as the first payment of a "share-the-profits" plan.

A resolution permitting New York City school teachers to join any organization they choose without fear of discrimination, and allowing teachers the right to hold meetings in the schools, has been presented to the Board of Education's law committee by Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, Bronx member of the board.
Henry Phelps Case, a former lawyer and traveler, died yesterday at his home, 29 East Sixty-fourth Street, after a brief illness. A member of one of New York's older families, he was 78 years old.
The defense injected the name of Clarence G. Willard, Republican leader, into the conspiracy trial of G. LeRoy Kemp today during a discussion of "fee splitting" on Merritt Parkway land deals.

A New York dentist with a keen interest in American history and an overwhelming belief that the freedom of life in the United States must be cherished, emerged yesterday as the originator and co-author of a graphic tribute to his country called "Pageant of the.States."
Annual meeting, Spciety of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, 9:30 A. M. Sessions tomorrow.

Electric power production on a daily average basis rose slightly more than anticipated on the basis of normal trends last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 98.1 from 98.0. The figure for the week ended Nov. 27, 1937, was 97.4.
Governor Lehman gave $3,250 in campaign contributions during the. election campaign, according to a report filed with the Secretary of State.
The Madison Square Boys' Club was the beneficiary of a preview dinner dance given last night in the Queen Elizabeth Room at the Park Lane. The room will be formally opened tonight for the season.
Mrs. Nellie Pillsbury Smith, wife of Edward H. Smith, headmaster of Stamford High School, died at Lewiston, Me., yesterday after a long illness.

The coffee bill of the United States for the first ten months of 1938 amounted to. $112,137,000, compared with $126,914,000 in the corresponding period last year, a reduction of $14,777,000, or 11.6 per cent, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange pointed out yesterday.

Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. and eight associates of the late Magistrate Earl A. Smith will be honorary pallbearers at funeral services to be held this morning at 10 o'clock in the Boyertown Funeral Chapel, 41 West Sixtieth Street.
Lieutenant Harry (Hank) Hardwick, who has been head coach of Navy football for the past two seasons, announced today that under no circumstances would he continue in that position for another year.

A closed shop agreement covering nearly 3,000 workers employed in the department store and warehouse of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., was signed yesterday by officials of the store and the Department Store Organizing Committee of the C. I. O.

The life insurance business is faced with a challenge to "sell" the concepts of free enterprise to the public, rather than to develop new techniques of selling its product, Holgar J. Johnson, -president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, said yesterday. Mr.

The plot of land known as 39 Beaver Street, long held under lease by the Manufacturers Trust Company, has been acquired by that institution to round out the ownership of the parcel occupied since 1929 by the ten-story Manufacturers Trust Company building.

The Ivy League Sports Editors' Trophy, the first of a series of annual presentations to the champion football team of the mythical "Ivy League," was awarded to Cornell yesterday following a vote of the sports editors of the "Ivy" college newspapers.

Possible settlement of 2,500 Jewish families headed by skilled artisans or agricultural workers on a tract of 10,000 square miles in a Central American country was reported last night at a dinner at the Hotel Pierre given by Max D. Steuer on behalf of the American ORT Federation.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull sees the world at a crossroads today, one road leading to peace and the other to war, according to a statement released to the Panama press on his arrival aboard the liner Santa Clara, en route to the Eighth Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru.

Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Newhouse Jr. gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 983 Park Avenue, for Miss Patricia Shewan of New York and Strathmore, Sodthampton, L. I., a debutante of this season, whose engagement to their son, Edgar L. Newhouse 3d, was announced recently.

The University of Tennessee, undefeated and untied champion of the Southeastern Conference, gained additional honors today by placing three of its performers on the 1938 allstar Conference eleven selected for The Associated Press by coaches and sports writers.

From foreign affairs President Roosevelt turned his attention again today to domestic problems and the legislative program for the coming Congressional session. This program he plans to go over with Speaker Bankhead at the "Little White House" tomorrow.

BAMMAN, FERDINAND C. (Nov. 3). Estate, more than $10,000. To Catherine A. and Norma M. Bamman, both of 205 W. 57th st., Ferdinand D. Bamman, 21 E. 14th st., Arthur P. Bamman, 20 Montgomery Ave., Babylon, L. I. and Charles F. Bamman, 88-24 166th St., Jamaica, L. I.,
The eight-family apartment house at 40-23 Ninety-ninth Street, Corona, Queens, has been sold by the Adoma Holding Corporation, through Hosinger Bode, Inc., in conjunction with J. Rianna.

The National Association of Bedding Manufacturers at the opening session of its annual convention here today approved the details of a general educational and publicity sales drive designed to sell bedding and allied products to housewives whose home equipment is either outmoded, worn out, or both.
The city of Memphis today offered $17,385,000 for the gas and electric business of the Memphis Power and Light Company and called it a "final" bid. An answer was demanded by noon on Saturday.

Although prospects are accumulating that point to a further upward trend in steel buying, not much change may develop until after the first of the year unless there should be a price advance for the First quarter, an unlikely possibility, Iron Age says this week.

Harvard Club 4, Crescent 1 W. K. Rice. Harvard, defeated V. Furno, 18-15, 15-12; J. A. Schwarz, Crescent, defeated R. C. Flack, 15-9, 17-14; E. A. Mays, Harvard, defeated D. Noble, 15-5, 4-15, 18-16; C. J. Mason, Harvard, defeated J. N. DeRaismes, 15-4, 15-8; O. C. Stanton, Harvard, won from W. F. Koch by default.

Bronxdale Ave (15-4257), s w s, at w s Cruger Ave, 125x65; Apediac Realty Corp to Standard National Corp, 285 Madison Ave; mtg $89,500. Fordham Rd. (11-3148J) s s, 65 ft e of Valentine Ave,. 64x92; Valentine Realty Corp to Altschul Realty Corp, 277 Broadway.
Martin Erdmann, a retired banker who formerly was a partner in Speyer Co., left a net estate of $5,170,012 when he died on Jan. 27, 1937, according to a transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday.

American bakers should undertake a national campaign to tell public about the many dietary advantages of bread and baked goods, Dr. James A. Tobey yesterday told members of the New York Bakers Club at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.

The American Gas and Electric Company, a registered holding company in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a formal plan for compliance with the integration and simplification provisions of the Public Utility Company Act of 1935, contained in Section 11 (b) of the act, the SEC announced today.

Streamlined to dispense with extraneous material, the Retailers' Calendar and Promotional Guide for b 1939 was issued yesterday by the b sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, 101 West Thirty-first Street, it was announced by Alan A. Wells, manager of the division.

An application by the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, Inc., of 75 East Forty-fifth Street, for renewal of its private detective agency license, which expired last June 24, was denied yesterday by Abraham S. Wechsler, State Director of Licenses.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, made public today part of a list of membership in an organization to defend democracy and the rights of minorities, plans for the formation of which were announced recently.
Reading, Pa., will be in the market on Dec. 20 with $340,000 of school district bonds. The issue will be dated Jan. 1, 1939, and will be due in 1942 to 1958.

Movenment vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 30 unless specified: At San Diego: Dewey, MacDonough, Phelps, Worden. Asheville, Swatow to Amoy. Arkansas, Norfolk to New York. Arctic. San Diego to Navy Yard, Mare Island.

E. Hamilton Sloan, oil pioneer, died on Monday at Grove City in his ninetyfourth year. Mr. Sloan was well known in Pennsylvania in the early days of the oil business, having engaged in operations in Venango, Butler, Armstrong and Greene Counties.

The strong New York Athletic Club team, headed by national champion Harry Wolf, stepped into a clear lead in the race for Class honors in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night when it won its fifth straight match.

The annual pre-season dinner of the Squadron C Polo Club was held last night at the organization's headquarters. Forty persons attended the affair, which introduces the indoor campaign. Two exhibition games will be played Saturday evening in the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn, it was announced.
Officials of the Public Works Administration said today they could find no reason to halt construction of a railroad produce market in Kansas City, Kan.

Mrs. Lina Livingston Mayo Palen of this city, widow of Frederick P. Palen, was married to John M. Barrett, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Barrett, yesterday noon at the home of the bride, 1,158 Fifth Avenue.

Senator Burke of Nebraska said here today that the National Labor Relations Board must be divested of its judicial powers by the next Congress if the Wagner Act was to serve the interests of both employers and employes.

Due to the emergency that exists during the Christmas holiday season, as a result of overcrowding and the accumulation of rubbish and other combustible materials in department stores, the provisions of the Official Action Guide in relation to fire prevention minor violation orders will be waived during said season, in connection with inspections of department stores, and the following procedure will be observed:

Dr. Emil Hacha, President of the Supreme Court, was elected President of the Czecho-Slovak Republic today by the National Assembly in succession to Dr. Eduard Benes. The election ended a period of fifty-six days during which the nation had been without a titular leader.

A jury that already had convicted Johanna Hofmann and Otto Hermann Voss of espionage returned a verdict of guilty late yesterday afternoon against Erich Glaser, a former private in the United States Army Air Corps at Mitchel Field, but in his case the jurors recommended mercy.
Austin Eugene Kirby, formerly part owner of the Hotel Chatham, died yesterday at his apartment in Mayfair House, 610 Park Avenue. His age was 85.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due today from England and France. Passengers are H. Merle Cochran, First Secretary of the United States Embassy in Paris; Count Roman Michalowski, First Secretary of the Polish Embassy in London;

Sweeping changes in the rules surrounding New York Curb Exchange associate memberships will become effective next month if the membership approves the constitutional amendments passed by the board of governors yesterday.

" Great Lady," recalling the career of Madame Eliza Jumel, who occupied the Jumel Mansion on Washington Heights and won fame here and in France early in the nineteenth century, bows tonight at the Maiestic.
By SIDNEY SOLOMON 23d St. 28 E; 5-story building, 25x98.9; Bank for Savings against Tubees Estates, Inc; due $110,111; taxes, etc, $100; to plaintiff for $35,000.

A veiled attack on the Patman Anti-Chain Bill, which is to be re-introduced at the coming session of Congress, featured resolutions adopted yesterday by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., in the closing session of their three-day convention at the Hotel ofWaldorf-Astoria here.

Funeral services for Sanford Jacobi, one of the founders of Schenley Distillers Corporation and a prominent figure in charitable circles, were held yesterday in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixtyfifth Street. About 1,500 persons, representing many social and civic organizations, attended.

At a meeting yesterday of the board of the Horn Hardart Company, New York, directors voted a year-end dividend of 60 cents to holders of the common stock. Including this payment, dividends for the year will amount to $2 a share, the same as last year's disbursements.

The Home Life Insurance Company has sold the four-story apartment building at 84 Lawrence Avenue, Brooklyn, to Meier Block, operator, for cash above a first mortgage of $85,000 which the insurance company extended for five years.

George Prescott Wells, retired secretary and treasurer of the National Biscuit Company, died here today after several months' illness. He was 68 years old. Services and burial will take place in New York.
The youthful Philippine Commonwealth Government, Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring reported today, is one of the world's most prosperous.

General Ulisse Longo, who is here on a tour of Italian legations in South America as aeronautical and naval attache, declared in an interview in the newspaper Espectador that the opposition to the penetration of fascism in Latin America is North American trickery.

The word employee, " as used in the National Labor Relations Act was defined for the first time today by the National Labor Relations Board as meaning "all employes in the conventional as well as legal sense except those by express provision excluded."

Joe Wiener and Stanley Galowin of the 42 Broadway Club last night won the pro-amateur squash racquets doubles championship for the second straight year when they beat the Rockaway duo of Lief Nordlie and Lee Norris in the final of the fourth annual tourney at the Heights Casino. The scores were 15-13, 11-15, 15-4 and 18-14.
Stocks closed strong on news of failure of French general strike; turnover, 983,000 shares. All groups of bonds higher; transactions, $7,606,350.

The Federal Government will ask for $700,000,000 of "new money" to help finance the current deficit and will offer an exchange issue or issues for the $941,613,750 of 11/2 per cent notes due on March 15, the Treasury announced today.
Lawrence Copley Thaw has purchased from James Stewart a sevenacre estate on Cranberry Lane, in Westport, Conn., through Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc., and David Batchelder, brokers.

Authorization by the Supreme Court to sue 500 stockholders of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company of White Plains for losses suffered by about 20,000 mortgage investors will be sought here on Dec. 12 by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, according to papers filed today before Justice Gerald Nolan.

More marines are needed for assignment to new ships and naval activities and to fill out the fleet marine force, Major Gen. Thomas Holcomb, commandant of the Marine Corps, says today in his annual re-oort for the last fiscal year.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
B. Preston Hasbrouck has been appointed Hudson Valley representative for Van Strum Towne. Inc., investment counsel.
An ordinance issued today by Reinhard Heydrich, chief of the Security Police, prohibits Jews from sojourning in certain public areas and from appearing in public at certain designated hours.

Miss Elise Duggan and Edward Putnam Currier Jr., whose engagement was announced early last month. will be married the afternoon of Dec. 10 in the Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, L. I. Bishop Frank Du Moulin will perform the ceremony.
AUGUST, THOMAS P. (June 12, 1938). Gross assets, $16,144; net, $14,895. To Helen B. August, widow. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $7,782. Moran, Galli McGlinn, attorneys, 55 John St.

United States Navy notified the Puerto Rican Government today that plans for a San Juan naval air base had been approved and that title to the proposed site was desired so preliminary steps for naval use might be taken.

The Rev. Ernest Thompson, a retired Baptist minister, died in his home here at the age of 86 today, after a long illness. Born in Gillette, he was a graduate of Peddie Institute and Colgate University. Ancestors on both aides settled in Elizabethtown, now Elizabeth, before the Revolution.

The younger members of society will act as, ushers at the debutante fashion show entitled "Manhattan Nights," which will be a feature of the Christmas bazaar to be held today at the Pierre in aid of the Art Workers Club for Women.
William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, announced yesterday the appointment of two Brooklyn lawyers to his staff to fill vacancies occasioned by a death and a resignation.

Filippo M. Beccari, a retired New York tourist director, died in Rome yesterday, according to word received here. He was 83 years old. A native of Rome, Mr. Beecari came to New York thirty-nine years ago.

A sharp attack on New York's unemploymentinsurance law was made today at a hearing before a joint legislative committee by Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, who headed the commission appointed by President Roosevelt last Summer to study labor conditions in Sweden and England.
The weekly report of crop conditions was issued yesterday by the United States Weather Bureau as follows:

The Tolentine quintet scored a thrilling 33-to-32 victory over the Power Memorial team yesterday on the Tolentine court. With Power Memorial leading, 32 to 31, in the final seconds, Johnny Dwyer, Tolentine's right guard, scored a field goal.

The standing of the Burland Printing Company of 53 Rose Street as a bidder on city printing was questioned yesterday after Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick had been informed that the company had sublet contracts without official permisison and had used union labels on nonunion work.

Mr. and Mrs. DeLancey Kane Jay of Westbury, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Theodora Moran Jay, to Chauncey Devereux Stillman of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. C. Chauncey Stillman.
Mayor La Guardia is angry with cities which try to attract industry by holding out the promise of cheap labor and low taxes.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries, exclusive of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation, reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a profit of $418,130 after interest and ordinary taxes, but before income taxes and depreciation.

Roy Zachary, who calls himself the field marshal of the Silver Shirts Legion of America, an anti-Semitic organization, forfeited his bond and failed to appear on charges of riot and disorderly conduct growing out of a riot Monday night which broke up a Silver Shirts meeting.

Apparent failure of today's strike in France and further consideration of the statement made yesterday by Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, that the costs of rearmament would be financed by borrowing, gave the stock market a brighter tone today.

Mrs. Donald B. Tansill and Mrs. S. W. Peck of New York and Mrs. Galloway C. Morris and Mrs. Olive Peterson of Philadelphia captured the national women's team-of-four championship at the American Contract Bridge League tournament today.

James Connell Magee, an assessor of the town of Greenburgh for the last eighteen years and a former executive here of the National Conduit and Cable Company, for which he perfected several wiremaking inventions, died last night at his home after an illness of five months. His age was 67.

A suit to restrain the Pathe Film Corporation from disposing of 3,500 shares of common stock of the du Pont Film Manufacturing Company without first offering it to E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. on equal terms for cash was filed yesterday in Federal court.
The freight rates on bituminous coal, which would have expired Dec. 31, will be continued indefinitely, the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today.

John L. Schoenfeld, State Correction Commissioner, recommended today that Kings County authorities be cited to show cause why the county jail "should not be closed due to unsanitary conditions, inadequacy and improper segregation."
Officers of the State Young Republican Clubs will meet here Saturday "to organize for 1940." District Attorney Alfred L. Simon of Saratoga County, president, said:

The New York division of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association continued its interclub team matches yesterday with the Junior League defeating the strong Rockaway Hunting Club players, 4 to 3, on the winners' home court.

Third division soccer teams were successful today in replayed first round English Cup matches against minor league opponents. The elimination of three left nine junior clubs in the second round Dec. 10.
A large industrial plant in Newark, N. J., has been acquired to permit of expansion by a manufacturer of electrical equipment.

Dollar volume of retail financing of new passenger automobiles fell in October to a mark lower than any other for that month since 1932, according to a report made public today by the Department of Commerce.
At a conference with Rabbi Leo M. Franklin of Detroit regarding the conditions of the persecuted Jews of Germany, held today in his office in Dearborn, Henry Ford authorized the following statement:

Mayor La Guardia clashed with Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx yesterday after Mr. Lyons had taxed the Mayor with using "a fine Italian hand" in leading Bronx residents to believe they were to get a $5,000,000 extension of the city subway along Burke Avenue.
The Hon. Ivor Grosvenor Guest and Lady Guest of Wimborne House, London, are arriving on the Queen Mary and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Paramount's third venture to be written, directed and produced by Andrew Stone will be "Wife Under Contract," which will be made next Spring.
The residence at 190 Central Avenue, Rye, Westchester, has been sold by the Rye National Bank to Grace Inglis, through E. V. Siedle, broker.

William W. Kennedy has been admitted to general partnership in Ward, Gruver Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, and William T. Wisner, formerly a general partner, has become a special partner. Mr. Kennedy was a member of the Exchange from 1933 until June this year, when he sold his seat.
The Japanese policy for creating a "new order in the Far East" following her victory in China was formally approved by an Imperial Conference in the presence of Emperor Hirohito today.
Usually reliable sources said today that the Customs Bureau had recommended a twenty-four-hour stopover regulation for American shoppers in Mexico.

Speaking at a luncheon here today Frederick T. Birchall, chief European correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told more than 200 of Detroit's leaders in the automobile industry, advertising executives and heads of newspapers of conditions in Europe.
Turpentine firm, 21c; sales 20 barrels; receipts 240 barrels; shipments 175 barrels; stock 52,312 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 248; receipts 942; shipments 1,975; stock 306,304.

Paring the cost of accounting as the principal task of public utility accountants will be discussed at the joint national accounting conference of the Edison Electric Institute and the American Gas Association in Chicago from Dec. 12 to 14.

A gay and colorful party with an Old World theme took place in the main ballroom of the Plaza last night when the eleventh annual Russian Students Ball was presented as "A Night With Russian Gypsies."
The nominating committee of the National Conference on Government recommended today re-election of all officers of the organization for 1939. It chose Clarence A.

Even those friends of the French people who felt that Premier Daladier took an unnecessary risk in making an issue of a symbolic one-day strike must be reassured today by the Government's almost complete victory.
Robert Carson, banker, civic leader, former member of the New Jersey Assembly and former postmaster, died in his home today after a short illness. He was 84 years old.
Germany was warned today by Robert S. Hudson, secretary of the Department of Overseas Trade, that Britain would "fight you and beat you at your own game" in European markets.

A new and revolutionary method of identifying thoroughbred race horses by means of photographs, which it is hoped will make "ringing," or substituting one horse for another, a thing of the past, will go into effect in 1939. It is expected that within two years all 10,000 thoroughbreds in this country will be included in this gallery of photos, which will be used in the opposite manner to the "Rogues' Gallery" of a Police Department.

8th Ave., 2,817, 8 w cor 150th St.; Sadie Rosenberg to Jacob Schulhofer, 231 E. 68th St. Same property; Jacob Schulhofer to Sadie Rosenberg, Hylda Kaufman and Florence Kaufman, formerly. known as Florence Loeb, all at 140 W. 79th St.

In November, 1,064 companies dedared dividends amounting to $512,837,372. This represents the largest total for any month this year and compares with $190,783,485 for 738 firms in October. In November, 1937, dividends of $713,805,827 were voted by 1,113 companies, or $200,968,455 more than in November this year.

Patrolman John T. Mee, 36 years old, of 899 Eighteenth Avenue, Newark, a member of the Newark Police Emergency Squad, was arraigned today before Acting Judge Thomas Guthrie in the Third Precinct Police Court on charges of grand larceny and attempted petty larceny.

Frederick A. Wyckoff, real estate dealer, asked the City Council Commitee on General Welfare yesterday to report favorably a bill restricting the size of advertising signs and marquees in certain sections of the city.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, second largest utility holding company in the country, has dispatched a tentative plan of integration to the Securities and Exchange Commission under the requirements of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, it was learned last night.
Honorable alike to Corporation, Faculty and undergraduates is the foundation by Harvard of twenty scholarships of $500 for "refugee students of any creed from Germany."

So complete was the failure of the general strike called for today in France that it has turned into a triumph for Premier Edouard Daladier. It has also shown to what extent these French people respect law and authority.

A simplified form of income tax return for small corporations, representing about 85 per cent of the business organizations of the country, was approved today by Secretary Morgenthau and will be distributed during the first week in January.
Miss Sally Clark, daughter of Mrs. F. Haven Clark of Nahant and Boston, has arranged final details for her marriage on Saturday to George Xavier McLanahan of New York and Watch Hill, R. I.

A spokesman for Pitt made plain today the university expected its future gridiron teams to tank with Panther powerhouses of the past decade, d spite the Bowman code putting football on a "strictly amateur" basis.

Doubt that favorable action willbe taken by the Department of Agriculture on the retailers' proposal that a board be set up to pass in advance on labels under the new Food and Drug Act were expressed yesterday by Hugo Mock, counsel for the Toilet Goods Association, in a letter to. Irving C. Fox, counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
A new political party of "race protectionists" and a new organization of Hungarian Germans similar to the former Sudeten German party of Czecho-Slovakia emerged in Hungarian politics today.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation here was asked today to search for Frank Edward Healy Jr., 24-yearold son of a former Deputy Attorney General of Connecticut. Healy Jr. was last seen leaving his rooming house at 61 Lincoln Park, Newark, last Thursday evening to have dinner in New York with his

Alfredo de Saint-Malo, South American violinist, appeared in recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. He has not been heard here for eight years. He has been playing extensively in South America, and last August he was one of a group of artists who appeared in the observation of the 400th anniversary of the founding of Bogota in Colombia.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called for Dec. 8 a hearing on the application filed recently under the Holding Company Act by the United Corporation for approval of an investment program not to exceed $8,000,000 of the company's current funds.

A sharp recovery in the stock market on favorable developments in France brought yesterday rises of from 2 to 4 points in prices on. the Cotton Exchange. Following three days of heavy profit-taking by holders of the December position, during which New Orleans interests were estimated to have released more than 40,000 bales in the two markets, a slowing-up of nearmonth liquidation diminished the supply available for mill pricefixing.

The Trianon Room of the Ambassador was the setting last night for a dinner dance given by the Color Guard of the Sons of the Revolution. Members of the organization are custodians of replicas of the battle flags of the Revolutionary War, which are now on display at Fraunces Tavern, headquarters of the Sons of the Revolution.

The government's plan to form a public corporation to absorb the two principal British air transport companies under Parliamentary authority has been advanced a stage by the appointment of Walter Leslie Runciman, 38-year-old son of Viscount Runciman, to a post with the Imperial Airways, Ltd., and the British Airways, Ltd.

A four-motored German monoplane landed here today after a four-lap, 8,375-mile good-will flight from Berlin. The elapsed time for the flight was 46 hours and 41 minutes. The plane, carrying five in the crew and one passenger, landed at 10:35 P.M.
Announcement has been made by Mrs. Oscar G. Harger of Maplewood of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Doris Anne Harger, to Grant Crichfield Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Crichfield of Summit.

Air Minister Guy La Chambre gave a reassuring report and obtained the approval of the Chamber of Deputies' Aviation Commission tonight for the government's reorganization of air services and aviation construction.
As part of its efforts to reduce the work relief rolls without laying off needy persons, the WPA intensified yesterday its drive to eliminate chiselerss" from the rolls here.

Robert C. Zuppke, more firmly entrenched than ever as head football coach at the University of Illinois, said tonight he would take no retaliatory measures against members of the athletic board who voted to oust him.
Holman R. Wilson retired from Moore, McLean McDermott on Nov. 21. The interest of the late Willis W. Clark in Moors Cabot ceased on Nov. 6.

The corn market was the center of attention on the Board of Trade today. Reports that the Commodity Credit Corporation would dispose of its accumulated stock of grain estimated at 20,000,000 bushels-obtained as a result of defaulted farmer loans on the 1937 crop-led to general selling of futures.

Santouri, 3-year-old brown colt, triumphed over a field of ten to take the feature at Tanforan today. The Le Baron entry, a 9-to-1 shot, covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:50 2-5 over a heavy track. Hilsinger- was second and Ethelmont third.
Butter makers were urged by Professor H. C. Jackson, chairman of the Department of Dairy Industry, University of Wisconsin, to maintain a uniform color for their product throughout the year.
The present Manhattan membership of 2,500 Camp Fire Girls will be increased during the coming year through the benefit, "All Mexican Night," to be held tonight at the World Cinema.

This week Germany nosed out the United States in the race for first place among the nations that export to Brazil. According to reliable figures covering the situation up to a few days ago, our exports to Brazil so far this year have reached a total value of $47,993,221, against German exports for the same period worth $49,823,075.

As the petty, sordid and often faintly humorous drama of Guenther Gustav Rumrich and his accused fellow-spies dragged its Oppenheim way through the Federal court to its denouement yesterday, it became increasingly apparent that, as The Army and Navy Journal stated recently, the spy problem is no real problem at all.
Under the strongest kind of British pressure, the Spanish Insurgent regime has admitted its mistake in detaining two Greek ships carrying Rumanian wheat bought by the British Government.

When, after a violent decline, sterling exchange suddenly and without any definite change in financial or political conditions recovers part of its loss, the usual inference would be that the "bears on sterling" were "covering."

The plaster model of the late George Grey Barnard's Rainbow Arch Memorial is being removed from the former power house at 216th Street and the Harlem River, where the huge work of art has been on exhibition intermittently since 1933.

Dr. Henry C. Christensen of Chicago, secretary of the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy, received the Remington medal of the New York branch of the American Pharmaceutical Association, at a dinner in his honor last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Following British protests against Japanese violations of the frontier Saturday a remarkable change in Japanese commands and tactics has occurred, resulting in the evacuation of the entire border to avoid incidents.

The Maryland Racing Commission revoked the jockey license of Johnny Gilbert today and ruled John Sweet, a groom, off the turf at the conclusion of its investigation into the Bye Bye Will "ringer" case.

The announcement of the Treasury yesterday that its financing on Dec. 15 would aggregate more than $1,600,000,000 and would include $700,000,000 of new money named, amounts slightly larger than government bond circles had expected.
Robert Eugene Lorton, associate publisher of The Tulsa World, died today from a cerebral hemorrhage suffered yesterday. His age was 24.

Thr Official Gazette today carried a decree by President Lazaro Cardenas expropriating 7,230 acres-more than eleven square miles -of grazing lands near the town of Muzquiz, State of Coahuila, belonging to an American widow, Mrs. Lettie W. Weller of San Antonio, Texas.

An original broadside report of the famous Boston tea meeting of 1773, called "for the purpose of consulting, advising, and determining upon the most proper and effectual method to prevent the unloading, receiving or vending the detestable tea sent out by the EastIndia Company,"

A possible monopoly on Rose Bowl football games-through an arrangement which would confine the event to battles between Big Ten and Pacific Coast teams-will be discussed by Western Conference athletic representatives who tomorrow will open their annual December meeting.
A nine-game schedule for Army's football team next season was announced today by Lieut. Col. Louis E. Hibbs, graduate manager of athletics. Only one newcomer, Centre College, is on the list.

BEHIND THE BALLOTS, by James A. Farley. (Harcourt, Brace, $3.) The personal history of a politician. THE COLLECTED POEMS OF LAURA RIDING. (Random House, $4.) Selections from her nine previous volumes, with much hitherto unpublished material.

A proposal for the creation of a giant international relief corporation to train the younger Jews of Central and Eastern Europe in agricultural pursuits and systematically remove them to available lands, at the same time giving economic protection to those whose age and training make them unsuitable to farm life in new countries, is receiving earnest study from Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, it was learned today.

Four days after the birth of their first child, Sir Oswald Mosley, head of the British Fascist movement, announced today his marriage two years ago to Mrs. Diana Guinness, who, like her sister, Unity FreemanMitford, is one of the warmest admirers of Chancellor Adolf Hitler in this country.

A twelve-week training course for cooperative grocery store managers was announced yesterday by the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, at a press luncheon at the wholesale organization's office and warehouse at 135 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn.

Robert Miller, 56 years old, who once a year published a "Democracy Year Book" through which he defrauded business men in the city of varying sums for so-called advertising, was convicted yesterday of second-degree grand larceny by a General Sessions jury. He will be sentenced Dec. 12.

Three seamen, former members of the crew of the steamship Algic, who participated in a sit-down strike while the vessel was in port at Montevideo, Uruguay, on Sept. 10, 1937, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn,

The Normandie on East Fiftythird, near Park, newest of the little cinemas, has everything a theatre needs, except-at the momenta first-class picture. Streamlined, comfortable, in excellent taste, the house is betraying its surface modernity by showing one of those vintage French dramas in which a wife ultimately blackens her reputation in court to save her husband from disgrace.

The fifteen buildings on the Washington Street blockfront, from Gansevoort to Little West Twelfth Streets, sold recently by the Guaranty Trust Company to Dennis P. Kennedy, will be modernized and equipped with refrigeration for wholesale meat and poultry dealers, according to John Avlon, broker in the sale.
Voting trust certificates for Iron Fireman Manufacturing Company stock, which have been extended to Dec. 1, 1948, have been admitted to unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange.

Applied Sugar Laboratories, Inc., chemical research subsidiary of the American Molasses Company and of Sucrest Corporation, announces the development of a small sugar refining unit available for food manufacturing companies which use granulated or liquid sugar.
Mrs. Ida Clarke Adams, widow of Professor George Burton Adams of Yale University, died last night at her home here on her eighty-seventh birthday.

Leonard T. Fitton, 34, of 140-10 Franklin Avenue, Flushing, was killed by a friend in the first fatal hunting accident of the deer season, which opened today. Edward Peterson of 115-43 126th Street, South Ozone Park, was detained by State police for a coroner's inquest to be conducted by Dr. J. Cameron Gain of Jeffersonville.

Several important factors in the news were reflected in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the composite result of which was an irregular price tone to the market at the close. Premier Daladier's success in handling France's labor difficulties imparted a better tone to the market for foreign dollar obligations.
Jack R. Roberts, formerly with the Rosenberg-Murray Company, has formed Roberts Co., with offices in 256 Fifth Avenue.

When the United States stops treating its railroad system as a "problem child" and recognizes it "as the asset of the country that it does constitute," the way will be opened to eliminate the so-called railroad problem, John M. Fitzgerald, vice president of the Eastern Railroads Presidents Conference, said today to delegates to the Transportation

North American wheat markets responded in a vigorous manner today to reports from London that the Federal Surplus Commodity Corporation had sold a large volume of domestic grain to English mills, possibly 20,000,000 bushels.

It takes more than a lot of deer in the woods to make a successful deer hunt, as we discovered today while doing our part in opening the Catskill season in this area. We arrived at Frank King's camp last night, and he was very enthusiastic concerning the possibilities for today.

Wiliam O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said tonight that sixty-four top holing companies in the utility industry, including all the major systems, had given notice of their tentative plans or suggestions for voluntary compliance with the simplification and integration provisions of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, or had indicated the extent to which, in their view, they complied with the requirements.

Secretary of Agriculture Wallace was advised today by the railroads that they would be unable to reduce freight rates on citrus fruits to aid in the plan formulated here T a week ago to dispose of the record crops of oranges and grapefruit.

Two members of the seeded list, Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia University Club and Frank A. Sieverman 3d, Bayside Tennis Club, were among those advancing a notch yesterday as the annual Fall scratch squash tennis tourney started at the Columbia University Club. Forty entrants are in the field.
Two natives of London who are connected with Carnegie Hall let it be known yesterday that they both celebrate their birthdays today, thus earning a mutual birthday party from the management.

At a time when giant multi-engined planes and large, specialized crews symbolize aviation to most people, the non-stop flight of John M. Jones from Los Angeles to New York in a plane of lower horsepower rating and cheaper operating cost per mile than popularpriced automobiles is particularly interesting.

The extent of the power of Vladimir Matchek and his Croat national movement was shown today when M. Matchek succeeded in enforcing non-compliance with an official order to house-owners to fly the Yugoslav flag today, a national holiday commemorating the union of Croatia and Serbia.
Arguments for and against separating the Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana Railroad from the Rock Island system were presented today to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

William J. Hagenah, president of the Public Utility Engineering and Service Corporation, announced yesterday the election of E. D. Uhlendorf as a vice president and director and of M. A. Morrison as secretary.

The United Gas Improvement Company, with investments of approximately $332,000,000, announced yesterday that it had filed a plan of integration with the Securities and Exchange Commission as required by the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

The board of governors of the Investment Counsel Association of America authorized yesterday the appointment of a committee of six members, three of whom are not engaged in the practice of investment counsel, to investigate and report its recommendations as to the qualifications for eligibility to memhership in the association.

Charles Mogull, 40 years old, president of Mogull Brothers, Inc., retail camera and film dealers at 68 West Forty-eighth Street, was sentenced to a penitentiary term up to three years yesterday by Judge Collins in General Sessions.
Herman B. Wells was inaugurated today as president of Indiana University,
Twice beaten but dangerous St. Mary's of California today accepted an invitation to. meet undefeated, untied Texas Tech in the Cotton Bowl football game on Jan. 2.

A spectacle without recent parallel in this country was seen in London's vast Albert Hall tonight when leaders of all the main British faiths and all three principal political parties spoke from the same platform to condemn the persecutions in Germany and other countries.

President Roosevelt welcomed Speaker William B. Bankhead to the "Little White House" on Pine Mountain today and in an hour's conference went over with him the legislative program for the new session which he will address in person on Jan. 3.
William S. Krywicki of WilkesBarre, Pa., was elected captain of the 1939 Fordham varsity football team by the unanimous vote of twenty-five lettermen yesterday.

Robert T. Bowman, president of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, characterized today the increase in personal property assessments levied against corporations and industrial plants in the last two weeks by Jersey City, Newark, Camden, Paterson and other cities as "virtual confiscation of property," and warned that it was an "irresponsible and reckless" policy that 'would "ruin New Jersey as an industrial State."
Herbert Reif, 18, and Johannes Horn, 19, automobile bandits, who were sentenced to death by a special criminal tribunal two days ago, were executed here this morning.

George V. Riley, formerly manager of the Hotel New Yorker, has been named director of sales and advertising of the National Hotel Management Company, Inc., with headquarters at the Hotel New Yorker, Ralph Hitz, president of the group announced yesterday.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was confronted before the Dies committee today by two "off the record" speeches which he made last Summer at the Shrine of the Little Flower in Royal Oak, Mich., and he admitted having taken the lid off communism in his own union and in the C. I. O. on those occasions.

The statement of the Bank wa of Canada for the week ended yes- of terday, issued today, shows the est ratio of net reserve to notes and Lo, deposit liabilities as 54.14 per cent, against 52.92 per cent the week be- 29, fore.
Mrs. Gertrude S. Replogle died today at her home after an illness of two weeks. She was 56 years old and had been active in the Women's Club of Scarsdale.

The Jewish Colonization Committee has been formed here by a group of Jewish leaders, and it issued today a declaration outlining its aims. It will cooperate in the international field with world organizations to meet the needs of Jewish emigration from Poland.
A sixteen-acre site in the Bayway section, south of the Elizabeth River, has been selected for this re city's $2,500,000 low-rent housing project, the Elizabeth Housing Authority announced today.
Charley McCarthy, ventriloquist's dummy, was a popular write-in candidate for Governor, Senator and other offices in the November election in Los Angeles County.

George W. Rogers, who stuck to his key in the radio room of the Morro Castle while that vessel burned off the New Jersey coast four years ago, was convicted yesterday in Special Sessions Court in Jersey City on a charge of attempting to kill Lieutenant Vincent J. Doyle, his superior in the Bayonne Police Department, with a homemade bomb enclosed in a fish-tank heater.
At least twenty-two high school students and the driver of their bus were killed when a fast freight train crashed into the bus in a snow storm at a grade crossing here today.

Miss Shirley Geiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Geiss of 49 East Eighty-sixth Street, was married to Lawrence C. Shire Jr. of 225 Central Park West yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman in his study at Temple Emanu-El. After the ceremony a breakfast was held at the SherryNetherland.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Von Moschzisker of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Kate Von Moschzisker, to Horace C. Disston, son of Mrs. Jacob Disston of Chestnut Hill.
Mrs. Walter H. Koch of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marianne Elizabeth Koch, to Dr. Wolfgang Schmidt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Georg Schmidt of Berlin, Germany.
Imports of gold at New York in November, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank, were $84,104,000, the smallest amount for a month since August.

Since last May 400 additions have been made to the collection of nonobjective paintings of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, it was learned yesterday, when visitors were admitted to the collection at the Plaza Hotel.
The Chemistry Club of Hunter College will hold its semi-annual dinner tonight at the Hotel Woodward, Fifty-fifth Street and Broadway.

Division of the estate of Henry Dexter, which had been devoted for the twenty-eight years since his death to the care of a mentally ill daughter who died in October, began yesterday with a distribution from an aggregate sum of $2,900,000.

City Councilor Edward J. Harrington died at his home today at the age of 41. Mr. Harrington was born here and attended St. Joseph's School and Lynn English High School. He entered the composing room of The Lynn Evening Item as an apprentice and worked there until the United States entered the World War.
The demand for well-located realty in the northern section of Manhattan again was evident yesterday when a large apartment house was acquired in the Dyckman section.

Stockholders of the S. R. Dresser Manufacturing Company, at a special meeting at Bradford, Pa., yesterday approved the recapitalization plan under which the company will consolidate with its wholly owned subsidiary. Clark Bros.

Continuation by the United States Attorney's office of an inquiry, interrupted in. 1937 when Philip De Ronde, promoter, fled to South America at a time when his testimony was wanted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, resulted yesterday in a fifteen-count indictment naming De Ronde, Wallace Groves, chairman of the board of the Phoenix Securities Corpora-1 tion, 44. Wall Street;

The New York Sporting Club skaters gained their first victory in the New York Amateur Hockey Association last night by defeating the Westchester Victorias at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, 3 to 2. All the scoring was in the third period. Pedro, O'Brien and Garrone counted for New York. Votiuba registered twice for the losers.

A number of mills stepped up production of wool goods this week and expected to maintain the increased schedules for the next three weeks at least, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly summary. Demand was spotty, with actual business written considerably below the previous two or three weeks.

The twenty-seven-acre estate of Mrs. Robert H. Gair Jr., in Oyster Bay Cove, near East Norwich, Nassau County, has been bought by Robert D. Pruyn. It fronts on the .south side of Flushing and North Hempstead Turnpike and includes a colonial house, swimming pool, garage, stables and a cottage. Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., were the brokers in the sale.

Willard P. Schenck, vice president and secretary of the Brooklyn Trust Company, completed yesterday his fiftieth year in banking. He entered the employ of the old Long Island Loan and Trust Company on Dec. 1, 1888, as a junior clerk.

The advance of the United States Maritime Commission into government ownership was sharply criticized yesterday by Joseph W. Powell, retiring president of the Socity of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, as indication of a movement toward complete control of shipping with "ultimate disaster" to the American merchant marine.

No sympathy need be wasted upon Corneliu Zalea Codreanu, leader of the Iron Guard Fascist movement in Rumania, and the thirteen other political murderers, more or less connected with the same movement, who were shot dead by their guards Wednesday morning in the course of transit from one prison to another "while attempting to escape."

Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, former president of the National Wholesale Druggists Association, has accepted the position of honorary president of the International Drug Club, it was announced yesterday by Joseph A. Huisking, chairman of the committee for the drug industry's participation in the New York World's Fair.

The Pen and Brush Club announces that the Anne. Morgan prize for painting has been awarded by popular vote to Anne Duer Irving and honorable mentions to Grace Bliss Stewart and Love Porter for their pictures in the annual show of work by members.

Henry Warren Freeman, clerk of the United States District Court for the last two years, died last night of a heart attack at the age of 69. In the afternoon Mr. Freeman had attended the induction ceremonies of his former law partner, District Attornoy Michael L. Igoe, now a Federal judge.

The announcement yesterday by Robert S. Hudson, Secretary of the Department of Overseas Trade, that the government was encouraging British industry to organize itself to fight the dictated foreign trade of Germany for the world market aroused speculation today as to the possibility of some form of government export subsidy in the future.

Iceland today celebrated twenty years of independence. Premier Hermann Jonasson broadcast a jubilee address and sent messages of greeting to Canada and to the United States. It was the largest celebration in Iceland in this century barring the thousand-year jubilee of Parliament in 1930.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Major Charles P. Cullen, Inf., having been detailed for duty with the Organized Reserves, 2d Corps Area, with station at Utica, N. Y., the verbal orders of the commanding general, 2d Corps Area, dated Nov. 15, 1938, assigning him to duty as assistant Instructor,

The Navy Department signed a contract today for the building of a 35,000ton battleship, bringing td six the number of capital ships under construction or contracted for. This is one less than the number build-' ing or appropriated for by Great Britain.

The Hoboken Bank for Savings sold to the Ae Realty Company for a consideration shown as $42,500 the five-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 220-22 Seventh Street, West New York. The bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $38,000.

Sidney Ingram, 39 years old, of Ocean City, who was to have started a ten-year term in State prison at Trenton, tomorrow, escaped from the jail here today. Yesterday Judge Palmer M. Way, in the Court of Common Pleas here,

Carl M. Distler of Baltimore was elected president of the board of social missions of the United Lutheran Church in America at an organization meeting of the board yesterday at the Hotel Prince George. The board was created by action of the recent biennial convention of the church in Baltimore.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that it had received bids on twenty-nine issues of municipal and other public agency bonds as follows, all being 4 per cent bonds unless otherwise indicated:

William B. Sedlis of Boston testified yesterday at a hearing of the Securities and Exchange Commission on affairs of the Reiter-Foster Oil Corporatiorrthat he had bought 8,400 shares of the company's stock on assurance that he would "double or triple" his money.

A reduction of from 10 to 20 per cent in wine prices went into effect in -all Quebec Liquor Commission stores throughout the Province today. The price cut followed a drive to popularize the drinking of wine and cause a smaller consumption of spirits.
The friendly rivalry between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran got on a grim .footing yesterday when the two officials exchanged challenges for a swimming race.
Applications to list seven security issues are pending before the Stock Exchange committee on stock list. They include 92,272 additional shares of Armstrong Cork Company common stock, no-par value;
Stockholders of the Commonwealth Edison Company today approved a new plan to gain 100 per cent ownership of its affiliated companies.

Five field goals in the third overtime session enabled the New York A. C. basketball team to defeat the City College Evening Session quintet, 44 to 36, last night on the City College gymnasium, court.

Aided by automotive show linage, the advertising linage loss of eight New York newspapers last month was cut to 3.2 per cent, with three papers registering gains, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures.

A proposal to build a toll higway for trucks from Eastern Boulevard in the Brorx to the State line at Port Chester, providing a swift traffic artery to New England and relieving congestion on the Boston Post Road, was outlined today by Robert Moses, New York City Park Commissioner and head of the State Council of Parks.

Whereas the November election pushed into top rank several new Presidential possibilities in the publican party-notably Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Robert A. Taft of Ohio-it brought into the limelight virtually no new Democratic candidates with any substantial national following, according to the American Institute of Public Opinion.

The Ministerial crisis threatening Belgium tonight over the question of finances turns in reality much more on Premier Paul-Henri Spaak's decision to recognize the Burgos [Insurgent] regime in Spain and withdraw his Ambassador from Barcelona.
The killing of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu and thirteen other captive Iron Guard leaders yesterday during a transfer between prisons produced no reaction from the Iron Guard itself today.

Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, will leave Monday for Paris, where he will ratify in the name of the Reich the French-German "no-war" pact, which has been the subject of consultations between the two governments for the last six weeks.

Provisional President Manuel Maria Borrero resigned late today, says the newspaper Prensa. His Cabinet ministers also offered their resignations, but he refused them in order to prevent chaos, according to the newspaper.
The first of a series of squash racquets matches between men and women stars resulted in a deadlock as two men and two women each recorded victories yesterday on the courts of the Junior League.

With a schoolmaster's pointer and a dizzying array of charts, Dr. Isador Lubin, Federal Commissioner of Labor Statistics, gave the monopoly committee today a broad picture of the operation of the American economic machine in the past and added this advice as to the future:

Mr. James A. Farley, one of the most prolific of letter writers and a constant spurrer of letter-writing in others for the increase of postal revenues and other purposes, has written a book. His "enemies"---opponents is the better word-will chuckle with him and not at him.

Miss Edna Aug, retired actress, died last night in the near-by artists' colony of Willow. She was 60 years old. Although Edna Aug was one of the most successful character actresses and vaudeville comediennes of her day, she retired almost fifteen years ago to a completely secluded life in a small farmhouse in the Catskills near Woodstock.

Mrs. Clara P. Nomenson, high school teacher whose suit in 1920 against the Hoboken Board of Education established the right of married women to retain positions as teachers in New Jersey, died early today in her home here.

Coroner Andrew Calyer of Orange County gave a suicide verdict today in the death of Private Edward E. Mills, 31, of Poughkeepsie, found fatally wounded last nigth in a parked automobile on the Military Academy grounds.

At the end of the third day of the $1,000,000 Waterbury graft trial, involving more than a score of city and State officials and political leaders, only three jurors had been picked-one the first day, none the second and two today. All are men.

The Rev. Dr. Evald B. Lawson, pastor for the last ten years of the Trinity Lutheran Church of White Plains, N. Y., assumed the presidency of Upsala College today, thirteen years after he was graduated from the institution.

As the Board of Estimate authorized an appropriation of $147.500 yesterday to finance the investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan, who was superseded in the inquiry by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen, charged that persons "motivated by political ambitions" are conducting a campaign to "smear Brooklyn."
Mass strikes in France are not broken by Rightist governments, as we would call them now, but by statesmen on the radical

The noteholders protective committee of the Haytian Corporation of America has asked for a division of its stock in the ratio of 80 per cent for present noteholders to 20 per cent for present stockholders and a reduction in the company's expenses.

Sales of securities in odd lots on the New rork Stock Exchange for the week nded on Nov. 26 exceeded purhases by 37,035 shares, but the alue of the securities that were ought were $945,719 greater than hat of those sold, the Securities nd Exchange Commission reported day.

The Fisheries Bureau said today that scientists on the government boat Pelican had established the country's first important source-of fresh Winter-time shrimp in deep water off the Central Louisiana Coast.

Billy Conn, Pittsburgh boxer who recently outpointed Solly Krieger in an over-the-weight bout, was signed yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs to meet Freddie Apostoli in a tenround match at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 6.

The general level of wholesale prices continued unchanged at the low point of the year in the week ended on Nov. 26. The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today that its index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 77.3, the same as last week, compared with 82.0 on Nov. 27, 1937.
