Lawrence R. Moriarty of Brooklyn has been elected captain of the Manhattan College cross-country squad for 1939, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics.

Dr. J. Allen Jackson, a widely known psychiatrist, who since 1920 had been superintendent of the Danville State Hospital for Mental Diseases, died of leukemia today in Jefferson Hospital after a long illness. He was 54.

Debutantes headed by Miss Martha Michalis have been aiding members of the executive committee of which Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford is chairman in the sale of boxes and seats for the perforinance of "Tristan und Isolde" this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Manhattan School of Music, formerly the Neighborhood Music School.

Lammot du Pont told a Senate committee today that he was opposed to profitsharing systems and believed, instead, in "paying high wages based on efficient performance." The president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. added:

Dr. Solomon Goldman of Chicago, national co-chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, said last night when he arrived on the Queen Mary that $10,000,000 was needed from Jews in the United States to establish "hundreds of thousands of persecuted Jews from Central Europe" in Palestine and other places of refuge.

The $3,000,000,000 Electric Bond and Share Company announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a tentative plan of integration in compliance with Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
Canadian income-tax collections in November totaled $4,436,474, an increase of $1,201,924 over November, 1937, when $3,234,550 was collected, the National Revenue Department reported today.

A collection of Italian art treasures valued at $20,000,000, none of which has ever been shown in the United States before, is being assembled in Florence for shipment to this country, according to Dr. Rudolph Heinemann, European representative of the San Francisco 1939 World's Fair and director of the Art Museum of Lugano, Switzerland.

The Midston House team halted the Seminole Club, 5-0, on the Midston courts last night for its fourth victory in as many starts in the Class B League of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association. In one of the hardest battles, E. Oppenheimer, No. 1 player, defeated S. J. Dicketts, 16-15, 12-15, 10-15, 15--8. 15-8.
A farm of ninety-six acres at Campbell Hall, in Orange County, N. Y., has been sold by Mrs. Margaret Corcoran through F. Tuoti Co., brokers.
M. Andre Frangois-Poncet, the new French Ambassador to Italy, received in Rome on Wednesday something more than the formal greeting usually accorded to the envoy of a neighboring nation.

A rise in the profits of Loew's, Inc., from $3,000,000 in 1924 to $14,700,000 last year was cited yesterday by Joseph M. Proskauer in Supreme Court as full justification for contracts which gave executives a percentage of net profits.

Morgan Ave (16-4387-8), e s, 125 ft s of Waring Ave, 100x100, also Morgan Ave, w s, 78 ft s of Waring Ave, 121x100; Clarence M. Rooney to Anthony Cacalupo, 2,517 Radcliff Ave. Bissel Ave (17-5100), s s, 53 ft e of Seton Ave, 50x100; Albert A. Beregh, referee, to Dollar Savings Bank.

The New England Council's index of general business activity 'stood in October at 86.8 per cent of estimated normal, as compared with the same figure in the same month of 1937 and 80.0 per cent in September, the council announced today.

Pierre Clemenceau, grandson of the war-time Premier of France, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain to be married in New Orleans Dec. 14 to Miss Jane Louise Grunewald,. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict Grunewald of that city.

Italy and Great Britain tomorrow will sign a bilateral agreement whereby Italy formally accepts the limitations on the size and gun power of battleships and other craft laid down in the 1936 London naval treaty. The ceremony will be the first fruit of the Anglo-Italian friendship pact,
Legal experts at the State Department passed along the word today that skippers of small boats need not be alarmed about requirements of the new international labor treaty.

St. Marks PI, 28, 26x120, Central Savings Bank to Rose Teitelbaum, 28 St. Marks P1 ($15). 4th St, 124 E, 25x96.2; Isabella Home, a corporation, to Michar Realty Co, 1,541 E 19th St, Bklyn ($23). 10th St, 335 E. 25x94.9; Wm. C. Baumbach to Pearl Rosen, 717 E 9th St, ano (S7.50).
The Social Security Board announced today resumption of Federal grants to Ohio's 112,000 old age pensioners. The grants were suspended in September and resumed as of November.

Westchester Ave, 578 (10-2616); 1,486 Boulevard Corp to Central Savings Bank; installments, at 4 to 41/2 per cent; $24,500. Simpson St, 1,118 (10-2727); Etta Septoff to Harlem Savings Bank; due as per bond; $21,000.

A committee to represent New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway first mortgage and 5 per cent income bonds, headed by F. W. Walker, vice president of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insulance Company, has announced that it will oppose the plan of reorganization for the company proposed on Oct. 24 by an examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commision.

Tried and tested hands will guide the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association in 1939 as a result of yesterday's election in the annual meeting held at the Hotel Biltmore. Mrs. F. S. Dickinson of Yountakah was re-elected president, Miss Josephine F. Windle of Women's

Two women on their way to a prayer meeting at the Seaville Methodist Church, fifteen miles from here, were killed tonight when struck by an automobile. The accident happened only a few yards from the church.

Winning its fourth match in as many starts, the' Class A squash racquets team of the Harvard Club last night took undisputed possession of first place in the Metropolitan League by virtue of its 5-0 shutout of the visiting Montclair A. C.

Dr. Alvis L. Rhoton, professor emeritus of education of Pennsylvania State College, died in the Potsdam Hospital last night at the age of 71. Before entering the hospital a few days ago he had been ill at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Lee Hunt of Canton, where he had been living.

A net profit of $1,540,269 for the first nine months of this year was reported yesterday by the Diamond Match Company and its subsidiaries, after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Captain William T. MacDonald, a member of the New York Fire Department for the last twenty-one years and a veteran of the World War, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 44 years old and had lived at 463 Kissel Avenue, West New Brighton, S. I.
Mrs. Cameron Spear of Rahway has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Bessie Holden Spear, to James Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith, also of this city.
The nominating committee of the New York Security Dealers Association, of which Frank Y. Cannon is chairman, selected yesterday nominees for governors of the association.

KINGS ALTER, SOLOMON (May 11, 1937). Gross assets, $11,252; net, $9,409. To wife, Chaya M. Alter, one-third of residuary estate; sons, S. Reymart, Abraham and Morris Alter, and daughters, Sadie Diamond, Sophie Weintraub and Nettie Kalter, one-ninth of residuary estate each.

Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, will sail tomorrow on the French liner Normandie for his first visit to the United States, to address the National Association of Manufacturers' annual dinner, it was announced yesterday by Charles R. Hook, president of the association.

Searches by British troops of Arab towns and villages are continuing in all parts of the country with satisfactory results and it may safely be said that terrorism in Palestine is now definitely on the down grade.
The Iraq Government's oil concession to the Basrah Petroleum Company has been passed by the Iraq Senate and approved by King Ghazi, it was announced today.

Duke University's Rose Bowl-bound Blue Devils, who completed their nine-game schedule without a defeat, tie or point recorded against them, won five berths on the 1938 Associated Press all-Southern Conference football team.

Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick, ruling yesterday in the case of fourteen process servers who were discharged by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and their jobs abolished, criticized Mr. Dewey for ousting five war veterans without notice and without examining their qualifications for other positions newly created.

William P. Buckner, 31 years old, of 525 West 238th Street, the Bronx, a broker, said to be related to two high officials of the New York Life Insurance Company, and William J. Gillespie, 37, also a broker, of 542 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, were booked at Police Headquarters at 12:25 A. M. today on charges of using the mails to defraud.
Paul Reynaud, French Finance Minister, declared yesterday in- a broadcast heard in this country that the referendum on the attempted general strike in France had been "a triumph for democracy."
Skidding on ice on the Bronx River Parkway extension near here at 8 A. M. today, an automobile went through the guard rail, hurtled down an embankment and rolled into Mohansic Lake.

The first Junior Assembly for this season will be held tonight in the Ritz-Carlton. Numerous dinners will be given before the dance. Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich will give a reception the afternoon of Dec. 13 at their home, 15 East Seventy-eighth Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Aldrich, to older friends of the family.

C. Alonzo Irigoyen, Argentine Financial Attache, in River House, 435 E 52d St; Philip L. Bondy, in 1,075 Park Ave; How ard K. Brown Jr, in 455 E 57th St; Mrs. J. C. Vance, in 145 E 52d St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

A top-flight group of America's younger golf professionals captained by Horton Smith defeated a team of veterans led by Gene Sarazen, 3 matches to 2, today in a prelude to the $5,000 Augusta open starting tomorrow.

John Stites, churchman, attorney and a leader in finance here for more than half a century, died here today at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Charles W. Karraker at the age of 88. He was the father of Judge James W. Stites of the Kentucky Court of Appeals.

Hugh Wilson, American Ambassador to Germany, who recently returned to this country, and Stanley Reed, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, classmates at Yale and graduates with the class of 1906, will be guests of honor Saturday night at the eighteenth annual Barn party given by the Yale Club of Montclair, it was announced today.

Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, accepted yesterday membership on the fraternal council of the "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign, in a letter to Keith Morgan, chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday. Many other offers of cooperation from prominent officials are arriving at his headquarters, 50 East Fortysecond Street, Mr. Morgan said.

Unless he is deterred by urgent State business Eamon de Valera plans to visit the United States late in April when he hopes to accept the personal invitation of President Roosevelt to open formally Ireland's pavilion at the World's Fair.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain denied before the House of Commons today that the British Government had put pressure on United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy to have critical newsreel commentaries deleted during the European crisis in September.

Once more the inpouring of gold from Europe has been largely responsible for lifting excess bank reserves here to record high levels. Monetary gold stock rose $72,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, covered by yesterday's report, to a high -record of $14,312,000,000.

Following the anti-French demonstration in the Italian Chamber of Deputies yesterday, Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet called the new Italian Ambassador, Raffaele Guariglia, to the Quai d'Orsay today to ask for an explanation. The incident is regarded here as regrettably rather than important.

Compilations of transactions on the Stock Exchange during November make some curious comparisons. Shares which changed hands last month were numerically the smallest for any November since 1934 and, except for that year and the "depression year" 1932, the smallest for the month since 1923.

Eight properties on the lower East Side, some of which have remained in the family of the sellers for about sixty-five years, were disposed of yesterday by the Overbeck Estates, Emma E. M. Overbeck, George H. Overbeck and Frederick W. Overbeck.

Following the completion of the current amateur hockey campaign, the United States Olympie squad will be chosen, it was announced yesterday by John Thomas, former Yale athlete, who is secretary of the committee in charge.
Captain John J. Schoener, retired Newark, N. J., fireman, was found dead in his bed at a local tourist camp today. Police said death was due to a heart attack. He was 69 years old.
A nun for fifty-four years, the Rev. Mother Mary of Calvary died here today at the Ursuline Convent. She was ??8 years old. A native of New York, Mother Mary was the former Mary Jane Rose Williams.

Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, praised yesterday the action of the New Jersey Tax Commission in recommending new taxes on corporations, industries and wholesale and retail business to pay the costs of public education and relieve the tax burden on real estate.

An agreement for a regular yearround steamship service between New York and the Bahamas, beginning next Spring, was announced yesterday by J. H. Jarrett, Colonial Secretary of the islands, who has been here for two weeks conferring with officials of the Cunard White Star Line.
Arthur Wilcox Norton, son of Edwin Norton, founder of the Continental Can Company and a former executive in that concern, died yesterday in his home. His age was 60.

Chester M. Wallace, teacher of dramatics at Carnegie Institute of Technology, who has sent many pupils on to stardom on Broadway and in Hollywood, died early today in Allegheny General Hospital. He was 54 years old.
The annual stag party in connection with the opening of Bonwit Teller's 721 Club for Men, formed toe make Christmas shopping easy for men, was held yesterday afternoon.
Gambling casinos at Nice had to suspend gaming today because the managements refused to reinstate eighty professional croupiers who had Walked out in yesterday's general strike.
William Frederick Peters, composer, died in the Englewood Hospital today at the age of 67, after a long illness. He made his home here.

The little Catalan town where Americans released from the Spanish Loyalist Army are now quartered was in a turmoil this afternoon when this correspondent passed through, for 310 Americans are going out to France tomorrow homeward-bound.

Tenders will be considered on Dec. 15 by officials of the Alabama Polytechnic Institute for $506,000 of building revenue bonds, to be dated Dec. 1, 1938, and maturing Dec. 1, 1941 to 1968. The bonds will bear interest at the rate of 4 per cent.
Skiers here in the East, who enjoyed their first good running in a long time last week-end because of the unusually early snowstorms, will find the situation somewhat different tomorrow and Sunday.

Magistrate's Court here today refused to enforce the government's order of last week dissolving the Finnish Fascist party and suspending eighteen newspapers for preaching alleged anti-democratic doctrines.

TANNHAEUSER, opera in German in three acts. Music and book by Richard Wagner. Conductor, Erich Leinsdorf; chorus master, Konrad Neuger; stage director, Leopold Sachse. At the Metropolitan Opera House.
D. Blythe Hanna, industrialist and first president of the Canadian National Railways, formed in 1918, died today after a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

Jennie Moscowitz, who made her stage debut with Sarah Bernhardt and has appeared since in many Jewish mother roles, and her husband, Max Moscowitz, retired theatrical manager, will celebrate their fiftieth wedding anniversary today.

A prediction that nation-wide opposition by States and municipalities would defeat President Roosevelt's plan to end tax exemption of properties, bonds, revenues and agencies of the States was made yesterday by Julius Henry Cohen, general counsel of the Port of New York Authority, at the monthly meeting of the State Chamber of Commerce.

To Report to Assistant Chief G. L. McKenna The deputy chiefs of the 1st, 2d, 3d, 4th, 10th, 11th, 12th, 13th and 15th Divisions will select eighteen firemen from each of their respective divisions and direct them to report to Assistant Chief of Department George L. McKenna on Montgomery St.,
Mary Brown, 18-year-old- student at a convent school, who was reported to have been kidnapped on a highway in suburban Oxon Hill, Md., yesterday afternoon, was returned to her home tonight.

Edwin C. (Babe) Horrell, former University of California center and since 1930 assistant football coach at the University of California at Los Angeles, was named head coach at U. C. L. A. today to succeed William H. Spaulding.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, today confirmed a report that the executive board had "purged" the union of eight men and women, some of whom were alleged to be adherents of Jay Lovestone, head of the Independent Labor League of America.

Six hundred couples will dance at the Fordham Gymnasium tonight at the first Junior Prom of Fordham College within ten years and the first campus formal since 1926. The gymnasium's entire 200-foot floor will be transformed into an elaborate roof garden with a canopied white ceiling and with candystripe awnings.
Lumber production declined last week. With daily average output off more than seasonally, the index dropped to 64.7 from 70.4. The figure was 58.7 for the week ended Nov. 27, 1937.
Further building activity in the vicinity of the World's Fair was indicated yesterday when plans were filed by architects for two new apartment buildings and twenty small homes.
Ernie Nevers, former Stanford University football star and for the past two seasons an assistant coach at Iowa, was signed today as head coach of the Chicago Cardinals, National Football. League.
A new highway for New England, to cost about $100,000,000, is recommended by the Regional Planning Commission in a report which has the 'approval of the planning boards of the six States.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Shipments of steel office furniture, not including professional, store or beauty-shop equipment, were valued at $1,718,366 in October, as compared with $2,019,677 in the same month a year ago, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, announced today.

The riddle of Britain's "miniature general election" was deepened today by the smashing victory of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's candidate in the Parliamentary by-election in the Fylde Division of Lancashire.

Fresh evidences of the uncertainties in Europe's political outlook provided by Wednesday's demonstration in the Italian Chamber of Deputies against France nipped yesterday sterling's rally in the foreign exchange market.
An eleven-game program was announced today for the 1939 Georgia football team by Dr. W. O. Payne, director of athletics.
Headed by its president, Judge Samuel E. Hoyt of New Haven, Conn., the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States will begin its fiftieth annual convention at the Hotel Willard tomorrow morning.
A wet sponge which fell six stories and struck Mrs. Gladys L. White on the head, resulted in an award of $1,038 to her in Superior Court here today.

The office of County Coroner Frank E. Healy, whose son, Frank, Jr., 24 years old, was listed as a missing person today at Newark, N. J., announced this morning the young man was safe at his parents' home in Windsor Locks, Conn.

Five more names were suggested yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange's retiring nominating committee for inclusion in the successor body, bringing the total to seventy-four, two other nominees having requested that their names be withdrawn.

ARCHIBALD MacLEISH'S "Air Raid"* shows again what he has memorably demonstrated before in "Panic" and "The Fall of the City": that the poetic drama in our day is a matter of the poets, not of the time. It is not enough for a contemporary dramatist to make his characters speak as though they'd just been reading Stephen Phillips, or Gilbert Murray's translations from the Greek, and felt very, very deeply moved by the experience.
A client of William J. Yates, broker, has purchased the nine-acre De Hart estate on Blinn Road in the town of Yorktown, Westchester.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.
Style effects, originating in costumes for colder climates, are adapted for Southern resort wear in a midseason collection shown yesterday at Jay Thorpe.

Wilson C. Flake, United States Trade Commissioner at Sydney, Australia, who has recently returned to this country, will be in this city from Dec. 7 to 13, the Bureaua of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, 90 Church Street, announced yesterday.

Joseph N. Weber, president of the American Federation of Musicians, told officials of Opera-on-Tour, Inc., that he would do "everything possible" to prevent them from giving opera with recorded orchestral accompaniment and that he was able to prevent stage hands from working for the company, Bradford Mills, general manager of the company, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien.

Still unwilling to impose any form of conscription or compulsion in time of peace, the British Government today announced the creation of a gigantic voluntary "national register" in which every man and woman will have a chance of stating what kind of work he or she could do in time of war.

Stephen L. Smith, former Mayor of Meriden and president of the H. T. Smith Express Company of this city, was elected today president of the Eastern Motor Freight Conference, Inc., at the annual meeting in the Hotel Bond in Hartford.

The MacNeil of Barra and Mrs. MacNeil were honored yesterday at a reception given by the New York branch of the English-Speaking Union at its rooms at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The MacNeil of Barra, who is R. L. MacNeil, forty-fifth chief of the Clan MacNeil of Scotland and a member of the British Society of Antiquaries, described "The Clan System" in an address before the 125 guests.

The former Austrian Chancellor, Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg is still a prisoner at the Gestapo [secret police] headquarters. His wife, the former Countess Vera Fugger von Babenhausen, lives in a flat a mile distant and is allowed now to visit him twice a week instead of once.

Harry Bridges, the militant West Coast maritime leader who has been under the fire of patriotic and civic organizations as an "undesirable alien," has come to New York to organize longshoremen under the Congress of Industrial Organizations, according to Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association of the A. F. of L.
Heavy trading in Harlem realty was reported yesterday when brokers announced deals involving numerous apartment houses. In one of the transactions a syndicate acquired five parcels.

One of the few contracts providing for a profit-sharing agreement between star and studio was signed today by RKO with Carole Lombard. She will be starred with Cary Grant in "Memory of Love," which John Cromwell will direct.

Frederic Ashton de Peyster Jr. gave a dinner last night at the Stanhope for Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems, daughter of Princess IrbainKhan Kaplanoff, and his brother, James Abercrombie de Peyster, whose marriage will take place this afternoon in St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church. The host will be best man at the wedding.
The Long Island University basketball team unanimously elected Irving Torgoff, senior, captain for the coming season, it was announced yesterday by Professor Clair F. Bee, director of athletics.

The trustees of Barnard College at their annual meeting yesterday formally established the Kimball Fellowship with a fund of approximately $32,000 received under .the will of the late Miss Lillian Emma Kimball.

Dr. Hiyoshi Kato, Manchukuo Trade Commissioner in Germany, today told the East Asia Society that in future Germany and Italy would have an "exclusive preserve" in China's trade with the Occident. Dr. Kato is a Japanese subject.

Dr. Clarence A. Dykstra declared here tonight that as democracy was losing out in other nations of the world, it might be necessary in the United States to have all educational forces marshaled together to give Americans an understanding of its principles and problems. Dr.
Settlement of December obligations proceeded slowly on the Cotton Exchange yesterday under the lightest volume of business and narrowest fluctuations in some time.
Len Harvey won back the British heavyweight boxing championship tonight when Eddie Phillips, his opponent, was disqualified in the fourth round of their fifteen-round bout at Harrinsay.
Students representing seven up-State colleges adopted early today a "student manifesto" directed against "German persecution of its minorities."

W. L. Batt, president of SKF Industries, Inc., Philadelphia, and W. T. Holliday, president of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio, Cleveland, have been appointed chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the resolutions committee at next week's sessions of
Bankruptcy petitions seeking permission to readjust indebtedness were filed in Federal court here today by the Borough of Fort Lee and by the Fort Lee Board of Education.
The French Academy today elected Jerome Tharaud to succeed the late Joseph Bedier. M. Tharaud obtained 19 votes against 11 for his competitor, Fernand Gregh, and was elected on the first ballot.

Candy manufacturers throughout the country are confident of doing enough holiday business to make up for volume lost during the September storms and the unseasonable warmth of October, members of the Manufacturing Confectioners Board of Trade agreed...

Manufacturers and wholesalers of the coat and suit industry, representing an estimated 95 per cent of the country's total output, voted yesterday to assess themselves $270,000 for nonsectarian aid of political refugees in Europe.

Royal Business, 3-year-old filly, showed the way in the Inaugural Purse, feature of the opening day of the Charles Town Jockey Club meeting today. Last Chase was second and Mon Doit, coupled with Teddy's Star, third.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an order dated Nov. 29 granting the application of the Blackstone Valley Gas and Electric Company, a subsidiary of Eastern Utilities Associates, for exemption from the requirements of filing a declaration in regard to the issue and sale of $4,000,000 of its 32 per cent collateral-trust bonds, series D, due on Dec. 1, 1968.
F. D. MacCulloch of Saskatoon has been appointed provincial leader of a new Western political party named the "Western Secessionist party" at a closed convention held here yesterday.

Rough Diamond, 11-to-10 favorite, carried the colors of Mrs. E. Haughton to victory in the Gretna Purse which topped the Fair Grounds program today, but the day's racing furnished the two biggest upsets of the meeting when two field horses won at better than 40 to 1 each, and the first winners' dead heat of the meeting resulted.
Benjamin Franklin High's tossers, defending city champions, conquered Haaren, 21-17, on the Christ Church court yesterday as competition in the Lower Manhattan Division of the P. S. A. L. began.
A new Chicago industry, the Sun Shoe Manufacturing Company, has begun production of women's shoes at its factory at 617 North Aberdeen Street, officials announced today.

Commodity Credit Corporation loans averted a price debacle in raw wool early this year, members of the National Wool Marketing Corporation were told today by C. J. Fawcett, manager, at the opening of their twoday meeting here.

The State Board of Medical Examiners announced today that seventy-nine candidates passed the recent test for licenses to practice medicine in New Jersey, including thirty-four European refugees. All of the aliens have filed declarations of intention to become American citizens.

Dr. Ellice M. Alger, Professor of Ophthalmology at the New York Post-Graduate Medical School, Columbia University, received yesterday the Leslie Dana Gold Medal, given annually for "outstanding achievements in the prevention of blindness and the conservation of vision."

The Board of Estimate will consider today a resolution fixing the date on which the city will take title to the Sixth Avenue elevated line, condemnation of which has been authorized by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and one of President Roosevelt's most influential advisers on fiscal matters, warned a group of bankers here last night that any attempt to reduce government spending too sharply now would be a "short-sighted" repetition of the "mistake" made in 1937 and would create the risk of another setback to national recovery.
Army orders issued today disclosed the assignment of Brig. Gen. Dan I. Sultan to command the Second Coast Artillery District, with headquarters at New York City.
Stefani, the Italian official news agency, announced today that a "very large group" of Itolian legionnaires had arrived at Genoa, on their way home from Insurgent Spain.
The Alumni Association of New York University's Washington Square College will sponsor a luncheon tomorrow in honor of Dr. Charles Maxwell McConn, recently appointed dean of the college.

Turpentine firm, 211/4c; sales, 7 barrels; receipts, 100 barrels; shipments, 25 barrels; stock, 52,387 barrels. Rosin firm; no sales; receipts, 615; shipments, 380; stock, 306,539. Quote: B, D, $3.55; E, $4.05; F. $4.25; G, H, I, K, M, $4.40; N. $5.25-40; WG, $5.75; WW, X, $6.30.

The new 450-seat newsreel theatre in the Associated Press Building, Rockefeller Center, will be opened to the public this morning. The theatre is the fourth unit in the chain of Newsreel Theatres, Inc., operators of the Embassy, which has been devoted exclusively to newsreels since 1929.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an editorial in THE TIMES of Nov. 28 on excess bank reserves you say that there is no reason to suppose that the trade reaction of 1937 was directly a consequence of the "deflationary" policy of the Federal Reserve Board in increasing the reserve requirements and of the Treasury Department in "sterilizing" imported gold.

Articles and novelties from eighteen countries will be offered for sale as gifts suitable for Christmas at the third annual international bazaar of the international department of the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C. A., which will be held at the "Y" tonight and tomorrow from 11 A. M. until midnight.

John Beck, 3-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. George Beck of Long Island Avenue, Medford, L. I., died this evening in the county infirmary here about thirty hours after police had obtained a court order for his hospitalization in the face of his mother's refusal to permit him to be taken from the home.
The resignation of Judson A. Timm as athletic director and football coach was accepted today by Pennsylvania Military College, effective Dec. 15. A successor will be chosen after Jan. 1.

The Davison Fund, established by John D. Rockefeller Jr., has given $30,000 to th United Hospital Fund, I the drive committee announced yesterday. This gift is included in the $955,075 that the committee announced on Tuesday had been raised to date.
Athletic Director T. P. Heard of Louisiana State University announced tonight the appointment of Ted Cox, former head coach at Tulane and Oklahoma A. and M., as assistant football coach at L. S. U.
A snowball sailed through the air and clipped Slingin' Sammy Baugh kerplunk in the back of the neck. "Hey," grinned Sammy, "I'm supposed to do the throwing around here."

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, will be elected minority House leader, according to Republican leaders, to succeed Representative B. H. Snell of New York, who did not seek re-election.
For the first time yesterday trucks rolling along First Avenue at dawn had the whole street to themselves; the pushcart peddlers were gone.

Eaglets nurtured in dove-cotes, as sometimes happens when the economy of nature goes awry, usually make a meal of their foster-parents and foster-brethren as soon as they grow large enough. Such at any rate is the testimony of certain ornithologists.

Stating that certain foreign schools operating in Brazil in disrespect of Brazilian law are engaged in anti-Brazilian propaganda, the Education Secretariat of Rio Grande do Sul has issued a statement that all such schools will be closed.

The report of the American Gas and Electrio Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended or. Oct. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses and charges of $11,821,879.

Miss Louise A. Boyd, the only American woman explorer of polar wastes, returned on the French liner Champlain yesterday to report to the American Geographical Society on her last expedition to the Arctic.

In an out-of-the-way section of the Bronx, facing Pelham Bay Park, live a number of children far from any New York City public school. Any sort of bus service would be expensive. However, they are not far from a public school operated by the town of Pelham.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 30: MAJOR GENERAL Gibbins, H., the Quartermaster General, I day's leave, Dec. 1. COLONEL

Fred. D. Kaplan and Mrs. Sam Rush, both of New York, won the American Contract Bridge League's national mixed pair championship tonight, finishing more than six points ahead of another New York pair, Mrs. Lottie Zetosch and R. L. Appleyard, their nearest competitors in a field of 122 starting players.

International economic collaboration, even though on the modest scale possible under prevailing circumstances, was urged as the only practical approach to a solution of the world crisis by Paul Van Zeeland, former Belgian Premier, in an address before America's Town a Meeting of the Air in Town Hall last night.
Arthur Mincer was elected president of the New York Buyers Association, composed of commission resident buyers, at the annual meeting of the organization held here last night.

William Harris Jr., inactive since 1935, is returning to the Rialto wars with a new comedy by. Sam and Bella Spewack, who together wrote the book for Cole Porter's current musical, "Leave It to Me!" The work is called "Miss Swan Expects" and Mrs. Spewack acknowledged that its locale was New York. The authors will do the staging.
A heavy volume of public work contracts this week has raised the total for all engineering awards 63 per cent above that for the corresponding week of 1937, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Carroll E. Mealey, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, cautioned motorists today to reduce driving speeds and "avoid Winter smashups." The warning followed what he reported as "a wave of traffic accidents which came hard on the heels of New York State's first unexpected taste of Winter weather."

GREAT LADY, "a biography with music" in two acts Book by Earle Crooker and Lowell Brentano, with an assist by Howard Lindsay. Music by Frederick Loewe. Lyrics by Mr. Crooker. Staged by Bretaigne Windust. Settings by Albert R. Johnson.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses delivered a sharp personal attack yesterday on Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, after Mr. Morris had proposed that funds planned for construction of the Circumferential Highway be used instead for needed school construction in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

Major Abraham Harrison, a pioneer in wireless telegraphy, died in Gulfport, Miss., yesterday. He was 79 years old. Major Harrison, a veteran of the Spanish American War, was at one time in command of Fort Sam Houston, Texas.

Judges Joseph Buffington and J. Whitaker Thompson, retired members of the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, have withdrawn from the "five-judge court" which attorneys for the American Civil Liberties Union and the C. I. O. insinuated was "packed" to favor Mayor Frank Hague in the Jersey City free-speech case.
Movements of vessels follows: all dates are Dec. 1 unless specified: Acushnet, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Navy Yard, Washington, Nov. 30. Arkansas, at New York. Asheville, at Amoy.

G. E. Stechert Co. obtained a loan of $75,000 at 3 per cent on the property at 31-33 East 10th St. through the Charles F. Noyes Co. John R. Davidson, Inc., placed for the estate of John Cyriacks a first mortgage loan of $6,000 on 803 Columbus Avenue, which is to be altered.

Deceptive gift packages of foods will not be in New York City stores to tempt hurried Christmas shoppers this season if a new campaign, conducted by the Bureau of Weights and Measures of the Department of Markets, is successful.

John Sewell,- who forty-two years ago broke ground for the project around which the city of Miami grew, died today of a heart attack at the age of 71. He had been sent here by Henry M. Flagler to clear ground and start construction of the Royal Palm Hotel.

The marriage of Miss Paula A. Mendelsohn, daughter of Mrs. Arthur C. Mendelsohn of 25 East Eighty-sixth Street and the late Mr. Mendelsohn, to Charles B. Moss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Moss of this city and Hewlett, L. I., took place last evening at the Pierre. The Rev. Dr. B.
Raymond C. Black of 67 Adams Street, Stewart Manor, L. I., Eastern division sales director of the California Packing Company, died Wednesday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I., after an operation.

Herbert March, one of the leaders in the strike which has tied up the Chicago stockyards for eleven days, reported to police today that he was fired upon by three men as he was driving in his automobile a few blocks from the yards' main entrance.

Dr. John L. Elliott, senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture and founder of the Hudson Guild, settlement house in the Chelsea district, will be the guest of honor tomorrow on the occasion of his seventieth birthday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor at which Mayor La Guardia will be the principal speaker.

Shipping is again moving on the Yangtze River in China after having been closed for many months, the Commerce Department was informed today by C. C. Concannon, chief of the department's chemical division.

New York Urban League conference on industrial and labor problems, 204 West 136th Street, 10 A. M. and 2 P. M. Sessions tomorrow. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. Address by Mrs. Henry R. Caraway.

Dominion Government, according to an announcement made today by Premier W. C. Aberhart of Alberta, will help him to reduce interest rates on that Province's obligations. Failing to get Federal help yesterday, he had declared that Alberta would have to default $3,500,000 of bonds maturing on Jan. 1 and 15, next.

Clearings for the twenty-two leading cities throughout the country amounted to $4,463,501,000 for the five-day week ended on Wednesday, as against $4,604,181,000 for the similar five-day week of last year, a drop of $140,680,000, according to Dun Bradstreet.
THE BLACK-HEADED PINS, by Constance and Gwenyth Little. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel. DEATH CASTS A LURE, by Madelaine Johnston. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel.

Many Americans make their first appearance among more than 1,000 new names in the 1939 edition of "Who's Who," which is out tomorrow. The American entries, picked at random from more than 40,000 biographies packed into the 3,569 pages,
Robert E. Clement, vice president of the Simmons-Boardman Publishing Company of New York, died last night at his home in Fredon after several months of illness. His age was 54.

Beginning today, two Yiddish shows will alternate at the Hopkinson Theatre in Brooklyn. "A Happy Dream" will be played on weekends and "The Eternal Melody" will be presented from Mondays through Thursdays.

It is now clear beyond question that Germany is conducting an international trade war, not in the usual metaphorical sense of that phrase, but in a pretty real sense. This was almost openly proclaimed the other day by Dr. Schacht himself.

Alpha C. Jarvis, sub-registrar of vital statistics of the Hudson County Board of Health for eighteen years, died suddenly today at his home here. He had returned to his home from Bayonne Hospital Saturday after recovering from pneumonia. His age was 76.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Symington Clark of this city and Amagansett, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Clark, to Hubert Tiernan Willis of Louisville, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Hubert Willis of Ashland, Ky.
The Notre Dame football forces entrained tonight for Los Angeles to meet the University of Southern California Saturday.
The stock market took on a more cheerful tone today, sentiment being helped by the disclosure that the government was helping British industry to organize a strong bid for world trade.

Japan's budget for next year is once more-as has now become habitual-the largest ever presented to her taxpayers. Ordinary expenditures agreed on by the Treasury for submission to the Cabinet today amount to 3,694,000,000 yen compared to 3,514,000,000 last year. [The yen is at present worth about 27 cents].

The work of the New York City Housing Authority in clearing slums and erecting low-cost housing was praised yesterday by Warren Jay Vinton, chief economist and planning officer of the United States Housing Authority, at a meeting of the Architectural League of New York.

Does the phrase "local option" bring to memory that other phrase "beer and light wines"? Does it carry one back to the days when Carrie Nation was smashing bars and the hopes of the Anti-Saloon League were riding high?

MANHATTAN BADE, WILLIAM H. (Nov. 18). Estate, more than $10,000. To Martha Bade, widow, executrix, 2 E. 70th St., entire estate in trust for two months, if living at that time, then principal of trust.

Bryn Mawr College announced today that a campaign to raise funds for scholarships for German refugees had been oversubscribed almost 50 per cent within forty-eight hours after an emergency meeting of faculty and students held two weeks ago, at which campaign plans were announced.

Minister of the Interior Jonn McEwen announced in the House of Representatives today that Australia would receive 15,000 European refugees over a three-year period, including "Aryans," Jews and "non-Aryan" Christians, namely, persons partly or wholly Jewish of Christian faith.

A few hours after a brief stoppage of work by several hundred employes of the Hotel McAlpin, negotiators for the Hotel Trades Council, representing the six A. F. of L. local unions involved, emerged from a conference with the Hotel Association of New York yesterday, apparently confident that agreement on a city-wide contract was near.
For the first time this week the Giants were able to take a real workout out-of-doors yesterday for their important test with the Redskins on Sunday.

The series of six successive declines in commercial loans of local banks was terminated this week with a rise of $16,000,000 in the item, according to the condition statement as of Wednesday of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, which was issued yesterday.

The annual December Ball in aid of Grosvenor Neighborhood House took place last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. It was one of the largest philanthropically conceived dances of the season thus far, with hundreds of guests thronging the main ballroom, Oval Room and Palm Room, which were given over to the event.

More than $100,000 of the $250,000 sought to provide for a Temple of Religion at the World's Fair has been pledged, it was reported yesterday at the second'Women's Committee luncheon at the Hotel Astor. Nearly 300 campaign captains and workers attended. The total is $108,509.

The Union City Board of Commissioners ordered today a ten-day suspension of the liquor license of Willy George Bachofen, whose City Hall Tavern was the scene of a recent riot in which World War veterans demonstrated against Fritz Kuhn, National leader of the German-American Bund.

BASKETBALL Brooklyn Poly vs. Queens College, at 101st Signal Battalion Armory, Dean Street and Washington Avenue, Brooklyn..8:30 P. M. BOXING Broadway Arena, Halsey Street near Broadway, Brooklyn, amateur bouts..8:30 P. M.
The annual meeting of the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York was held yesterday afternoon at its offices, 50 Lafayette Street. Harry F.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, has been elected to honorary membership in the Cobden Club of London, which sponsors free trade, it was announced yesterday at the university.

Representative Wolverton Republican, of New Jersey, a member of the committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority, contended today that the Authority, while seeking additional appropriations, had failed to apprise Congress that it had an unexpended balance of $37,900,000.
An influx into Canada of earmarked gold was disclosed today in a report issued by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. The net increase of earmarked

Trading in bull, cow and fresh pork cuts fair; other classes slow in local markets yesterday. Lamb prices, which reached the nighest levels since July during early trading this week, are now weak to slightly below last week's close.

Eight officials, who have been grouped into pairs, will do most of the officiating in the thirty-sixth tournament of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, it was announced last night at the annual rules interpretation meeting of the organization, which took place in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due to sail today for Southampton via Cherbourg. The passenger list includes Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States; the Earl and Countess of Elgin, Lord and Lady Middleton, the Marquis and Marquise de Talleyrand, Lady Martha Bruce, Lady Seymour-Lloyd, Lady MacRobert, Baroness van der Walde, Mr. and Mrs. Ford Frick, Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Benatzky, Joseph Mayer.

Mrs. Mary Wolfe Dumont, wife of Frederick F. Dumont, retired American consular officer, died on Wednesday at their home, The Anchorage, Lancaster County, Pa. She received an Italian Government decoration for her war services in Florence, where her husband was then stationed.
Navy officials today formally denied that a civilian would coach the Naval Academy's 1939 football team and that Lieutenant Harry (Hank) Hardwick, the middies' present coach, had resigned.

Elliott Morrison, proprietor of the Cedarshore Hotel here, died in his home last night, at the age of 40. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Dorothy Nash Morrison; a son, Webb N. Morrison, and a daughter, Miss Patricia Morrison.

Advertising's greatest job in the next five years will be "to sell business with a capital B to the American public" in order to bring about a return of prosperity, Leonard Dreyfuss, president of the United Advertising Corporation, told members of the Association of Advertising Men at a meeting last night in the Hotel Dryden.
The thirty-fifth edition of "How to Win Friends and Influence People," by Dale Carnegie, has come off the press, bringing the total printings to 893,000 copies.

The following Cost Guard changes for the week ended Nov. 30 were announced today: CHIEF BOATSWAINS Hylton, A. H., the Spencer, to command the Faunce. Gillikin, F. G., Cape Lookout Station, to Fort Macon Station as officer in charge.
A "Declaration of Interdependence" was seen yesterday by Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut in the grouping and cooperation of industries which are building up the New York World's Fair of 1939.
In the aftermath of the general strike that failed yesterday, Premier Edouard Daladier announced today that he would summon Parliament to meet Dec. 8.

Miss Jane Burr Dailey, daughter of Mrs. William J. Dailey of 720 Riverside Drive, was married yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral to Donald Schoeffell Frost of Rochester, N. H. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert E. Woods.
Sales of houses on Davidson Avenue and the purchase of a flat on a Billingsley Terrace corner featured yesterday's real estate activity in the Bronx.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad's plan and agreement for a reduction of the interest rates on its bonds and extension of the maturity of the securities moved yesterday a step nearer to effectiveness.

James M. Mead, United States Senator-elect, visited Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday. He said that in the Senate he would seek appointment to the Postoffice and Roads Committees, the Interstate Commerce Committee and the Committee on Commerce.
TODAY--New England: Clear and continued cold, with freezing temperatures throughout the day over central and north portions; slightly above freezing during the day over the south. New York:
Hungarian Nazis today organized street demonstrations in which a number of demonstrators and policemen were injured. There were many arrests.

Rene Richard, a Radical Socialist Deputy, announced today that he would introduce in Parliament for a second time a resolution for opening of negotiations on France's $545,951,725 World War debt to the United States.

The provisions of the proposed new State insurance law as regards reserves, officers' bonuses and other affairs of mutual fire and casualty insurance companies were discussed yesterday at a public hearing before the Joint Legislative Committee on Revision of the Insurance Code, in the State Office Building.

(Tiny) Thompson's brilliant net minding In his debut as a Red Wing and alert stick work of his mates gave Detroit a 4-to-1 National Hockey League victory over the Black Hawks tonight before 11,506 persons.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 29: COMMANDERS Boone, J. T., Medical Corps, when discharged from treatment Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif., to the Saratoga.

Telling the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers, meeting in convention here, that they, in company with other manufacturers, had a public relations job to do, Mrs. Anna Steele Richardson, director of the consumer division of the Crowell Publishing Company, charged that government "is meddling with every line .of business and demagogues are making hay while the so-called liberal sun shines."
The University of Chicago's plan to "deemphasize" football by lightening its schedule was upset today in the annual Western Conference Winter meeting.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation announced in Pittsburgh late yesterday that it would continue present prices on all steel products for shipment in the first quarter of 1939 for delivery and consumption within the United States.
Dr. Aaron Denenholb, for many years a gynecologist and surgeon in New York, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 1,904 Avenue I, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old.

Police Commissioner Valentine revealed yesterday that charges of violating the rules and regulations of the department had been ordered preferred against the lieutenant who booked Mrs. Gladys Holzinger, a substitute school teacher, who turned a revolver over to the police because she feared her father would kill himself.

The thirteen Amherst College fraternities, facing a levy of $1,700 a year in social security taxes because of their employment of student waiters and house officials, janitors and chefs, were cheered today when John W. Wright, cooperative fraternity business manager, informed them that exemption from the Massachusetts State Unemployment Tax, amounting to 2.7 per cent of the payroll, had been allowed.

48th St, 224-6 E, 27.3x100.5: 1,841 Corp to Tuscany Management Corp, 50 E 42d St, p m mtg, due, etc, as bond; $6,500. 62d St, 135 E, 23.6x100.5; Ethel A. Thacker to New York Catholic Protectory, 415 Broome St, 5 yrs, 4%; $21,000.

Indoors and outdoors, on Long Island, in the Bronx and Manhattan, preparations went ahead yesterday for tomorrow's Refugees' Fund game at Ebbets Field between the Dodgers and the Metropolitan College All-Stars.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Blagden of Willowgate, Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L. I., have sent out invitations for the marriage of his daughter, Miss Sarita S. Blagden, to the Rev. Frederic B. Kellogg, son of Mrs. Frederic R. Kellogg of New York and Morristown, N. J., and the late Mr. Kellogg.

The Treasury today made its usual weekly offering of $100,000,000 in ninety-one-day discount bills, with the provision that bids would be received at the Federal Reserve Banks and their branches until 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Monday, Dec. 5.

Dr. Clinton A. Strong, a teacher at Penn Charter School for the last thirtyfive years and well known as a tennis official, died of pneumonia today at his home in West Philadelphia in his sixty-fifth year.

Dr. Malcolm Goodridge, Professor of Clinical Medicine at the Cornell University Medical School, was elected president of the New York Academy of Medicine for two years beginning on Jan. 1, next, at the annual election of officers last night at the academy's headquarters at 2 East 103d Street.

The auction of part three of the collection of William Randolph Hearst, comprising books in fine bindings, autograph manuscripts and letters, and original drawings, was completed last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, bringing a total at the two sessions of $25,207.

The adjusted index of business activity in the Pittsburgh district moved a. little higher last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. There were signs of a seasonal rounding off in most lines of economic activity, however.
Gabby Hartnett, who lost his given name of Charles Leo to baseball years ago, today received a fine Christmas present, twenty-four days early.

Mrs. Francis H. Brown of Philadelphia, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hazen Chase of Paris, was married this morning to Alexander Coxe Groome of Overbrook, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel William Groome of this city. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank L. Vernon in St. Mark's Church.
A deal involving the export of 20,000,000 bushels of domestic wheat to flour mills in the United Kingdom was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

Today's events: "Tristan und Isolde," 1:45 P. M., and "II Trovatore," 8:30 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, 2:30 P. M., Carnegie Hall; Durieux Chamber Music Ensemble and Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichord, 8:30 P. M., Town Hall.
Dr. Wallace Appleton Beatty, for many years a research chemist, died here last night after a long illness. He was 61 years old, and lived at 406 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:
The Roebling Medal of the Mineralogical Society of America has been awarded for 1938 to Dr. Waldemar Theodore Schaller, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Ellis Thomson, president of the society.

Plans for a cooperative educational advertising campaign, to be sponsored by leading manufacturers of radio receivers and by broadcasting companies, in an effort to dramatize the public service rendered by radio and encourage a more extensive use of radio sets, were outlined here today by representatives of the Radio Manufacturers Association and the National Association of Broadcasters, who met at the Stevens Hotel to consider the project.

Military honors were accorded Christian F. Weltzin, chief signal inspector of the Independent Subway System, at his burial in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, today. Mr. Weltzin died Sunday at his home, 90-23 149th Street. Jamaica, Queens.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange announced yesterday the formation of Higgons Lonsdale, comprising J. A. Higgons Jr. and Whittaker Lonsdale, who will conduct a general sugar business at 40 Wall Street.
Raymond D. Stitzer has been named assistant vice president of the Equitable Securities Corporation.

This first capital of the Confederate States of America has receded from one of its war between the States' claims today. An inscription on a marble post in a downtown building once proclaimed that from there orders were sent to fire on Fort Sumpter, the bombardment which actually started the war.

Gruen Watch Company, Cincinnati, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement cover- Loft ......... ing 150,000 shares of $1 par value common stock to be issued to re- General Mot.. deem Class A and Class B preferred stock, to retire bank loans and for working capital. F. Fiberstadt Co., Inc., was named underwriter.

If the capital goods industries can be brought into the circle of business activity the limit of the current recovery is far from having been reached, the National City Bank says in a discussion of the business situation in its monthly letter, published yesterday.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission announced last night the names of 10,997 persons who had passed its examination for positions as Grade 2 clerks in the Department of Public Welfare. About 42,000 took the examination.
Mrs. Fannie Briggs Houghton Bulkeley, widow of the former Senator and Governor of Connecticut, left an estate valued at $990,148.88, according to a document filed in Probate Court.

Francis E. Miller has been elected president and director of Distilled Liquors Corporation and its subsidiary companies, Distilled Liquors Import Company and Walter H. Hildick Company. Mr. Miller formerly was with Seagram as a sales executive.
Pitt's freshman football players, who have scored once in their contest with the university's front office, kicked off again today by laying down a new list of demands for assistance.
2d Ave, 1,999, s w cor of 103d St: 5-story tenement; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co against Morris Rostenover and others; due, $20,301; taxes, etc., $2,263; to plaintiff for $16,000.

Four changes in the executive personnel of the Erie Railroad, brought about by the recent resignation of J. G. Walsh as secretary-treasurer, were announced today by C. E. Denney, president and trustee..

Economies in building design and construction through standardization of sizes of various materials and reduction in the number and variety of parts going into homes and other structures will be the aim of a project launched yesterday by the American Standards Association with the cooperation of many leading manufacturers, builders, architects and governmental agencies.
The names of the members of the new Czecho-Slovak Cabinet were announced tonight in authoritative form. Signed by President Emil Hacha, the document appointine them began:

Many parties will be given tonight in conjunction with the Bassinet Dinner Dance to be held in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery. Proceeds will be donated to the maintenance of the nursery at 444 West Twenty-second Street, which provides shelter and expert care for destitute infants until suitable homes can be found for them.

A General Sessions jury returned a verdict of guilty of manslaughter in the second degree today against Joseph Werner, 21 years old, a motor-truck driver, in the killing of Alfred Strutt, 25, last Feb. 14, in a fight in the victim's home at 217 East Fortieth Street.

Mrs. Anne Parrish Corliss, novelist and widow of Charles Albert Corliss, was married to Josiah Titzell, writer and composer, at City Hall here this morning. The bride arrived here recently after visiting her brother, Dellwyn Parrish, in Switzerland.
Representative John J. O'Connor of New York, defeated for re-election in November after serving fifteen years in Congress, will continue to be a familiar figure in the capital.

Two young men, James Reynolds and John Kelly, were killed two days ago on the Donegal side of the Irish border immediately preceding border explosions. These men, it is stated in their obituary notices in newspapers, were members of the Irish Republican Army.

The army gave orders today to streamline preparations for production of munitions. Louis Johnson, assistant secretary of war, told more than 200 army procurement specialists that in the event of war the high command did not "want the experiences of 19171918 repeated."
Against the objection of competing operators, the Baltimore Mail Steamship Company sought permission today to start a weekly intercoastal service in the New York-California trade.

Three holders of 5 per cent debenture bonds filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court seeking the reorganization of the 2 East Sixtyfirst Street Corporation, which operates the Hotel Pierre under a ground lease.
Japanese exports of pottery for the first nine months of 1938 declined 40 per cent from the similar period of 1937, the Commerce Department was, informed today from the American consulate at Negova.

As in the case with Reuben Fine of New York, by whom he was defeated, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, found in Paul Keres of Estonia an opponent worthy of his steel in the fifth round of the A. V. R. 0. international tournament, contested at Zwolle in The Netherlands.

Depositors and other creditors of four closed State banks will receive Christmas presents in the form of $195.340 in dividends, Louis V. Reilly, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, announced today.
J. J. Hynes, a labor leader, died of a heart attack last night at the age of 66. His body was sent to his home in Chestnut Hill, Mass., today.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Semler of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Liberty Semler, to Boyd Paterno Brown, son of Lyndon M. Brown of Rye, N. Y., and grandson of Dr. and Mrs. Charles V. Paterno of Greenwich, Conn., with whom he makes his home.

Professor Felix Frankfurter of Harvard Law School has been elected a director of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, who was re-elected president.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as successor trustee, has notified holders of Kansas City Gas Company first mortgage 5 per cent bonds due in 1946 that $17,000 of these bonds have been selected by lot for redemption, out of the unapplied balance of sinking fund moneys, on Feb. 1, 1939, at 102.

Paroles were granted to thirty-three convicts in New Jersey penal institutions by the Court of Pardons here today. The court also granted twenty applications for restoration to citizenship and sixteen applications for full pardon.

Carl Lippman was re-elected president of the Garment Salesmen's Guild at a meeting in the Hotel Piccadilly last night. Other officers elected to serve one year were Arthur M. Scholder, first vice president;
The grand champion steer of the 1938 International Livestock Exposition sold at auction today for $3.35 a pound, $1 a pound more than last year's champion and the highest price since 1929.

Pensioned On Their Own Applications-To take effect 12 midnight, Nov. 30: PATROLMEN Edward A. Gross, 109th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 20, 1913. To take effect 12 midnight, Dec. 4. Jacob Greenberg, 111th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 1, 1913.

THERE was the fellow who knew Bob Zuppke only by sight and there was the fellow who knew him by ear, indicating much greater familiarity with the one and only "Zupp." The late George Foster Sanford was a whirlwind in oratory on football and Hurry-Up Yost yields the floor to no man when there's a gridiron argument in full swing.
Charges of violating the new ticket code were filed last night by the League of New York Theatres against two accredited brokers.
Collision of an automobile today with both side walls of the Sumner Tunnel caused the death of one man, injury to two companions and tied up traffic between Boston and East Boston.
Pope Pius attended spiritual services for the fifth day today while taking treatment to bolster his strength. Members of the Vatican household said that the Pontiff's health seemed improved,

Announcement has been made bY Mr. and Mrs. Moritz Wormser of 440 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Wormser, to Stanley R. Wayne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wayne of Hewlett, L. I.

As is well known, Beethoven wrote a number of different "overtures" to his opera, "Fidelio." The piece which is called the "overture to Fidelio" opened the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Suits asking $50 a bottle for every bottle sold below established price levels will be instituted by organized liquor package store owners against any retailer who cuts prices this month, it was learned here yesterday.

Gilbert Jordan of Enfield, Ill., 43year-old champion male crocheter, was reported missing for about five hours yesterday following his arrival at the Newark Airport on the T. W. A. 11:20 A. M. flight from St. Louis. The trip was the first he had made in an airplane.

Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry reserved decision today on a request for a permanent injunction against picketing of an Asbury Park diner, but commented on what he termed an unequal bargaining relationship between a small businessman and a nationwide labor union.

Employment in the steel industry rose during October for the third consecutive month, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, which reports 436,000 workers employed by the industry during the month, a gain of 5,000 compared to September. In October, 1937, employment was 587,000.

The responsibility of industry to society as visualized by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, was outlined yesterday at the convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Associates on the magistrate's bench, political leaders and representatives of civic and fraternal organizations joined yesterday in tribute to the late Magistrate Earl A. Smith at funeral services held in the Boyertown Funeral Chapel, 41 West Sixtieth Street.

Because a jammed lock on the door of Official Referee Thomas C. T. Crain's chambers in the Supreme Court Building could not be opened until an official requisition for a locksmith had gone through the proper channels, the wheels of justice were thrown out of gear for three hours yesterday morning.

Patronage of American ships by Americans results in a mode widespread distribution of orders for American-made products than could possibly result from any other single industry, Basil Harris, vice president of the United States Lines, told the annual conference of the Transportation Council, Associated Industries of New York, here today.
The Ice Follies of 1939, all-professional figure-skating show, will end with tomorrow night's performance. The Follies also will be presented tonight as well as at a matinee tomorrow.

Plans for participation by Argentina in the Inter-American travel congress to be held next April in connection with the San Francisco Exposition have been tentatively formulated according to a report to the Department of Commerce from the office of the American commercial attache at Buenos Aires.

With expatriate capital returning rapidly to France, the franc for the first time in more than four months appreciated in value today to less than 178 in terms of sterling, improving from last night's 178 13-16 to 177 29-32. The three-month forward discount declined from 1-16 to 7/8. At the same time the United States dollar dropped irregularly to $4.681/4.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 30: COMMANDER Laycock, J. N.. Civil Engineer Corp. Portsmouth, N. H., to Bureau of Yards and Docks, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C.
With settings and costumes reminiscent of ancient China, a group of young Chinese men and women began additional rehearsals yesterday of "An Evening in Cathay."

More than 500 New Jersey boys of high school age participated in the opening session of the Model Legislature conducted as a feature of the fortyfifth State Older Boys Conference, which opened in the State House here today under the auspices of the National Council, Young Men's Christian Associations.
The Interstate Commerce Commission dismissed today a complaint by the city of Philadelphia which sought lower freight rates to and from Western areas in relation to rates fixed for other ports.
The Allied Products Corporation declared a 50-cent dividend on the commonn stock, the first since $1 vas paid on Dec. 24, 1937.

A Federal district court granted an interlocutor injunction today preventing Florida from enforcing a new State law which would require fruit processors to use cans embossed with the word "Florida" in shipment of their goods.

Deparment store sales for the week ended Nov. 26 were 4 per cent lower than for the corresponding week last year and 5 per cent lower for the four weeks ended Nov. 26 than for the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Dr. Irving P. Krick of the California Institute of Technology, who for some time has been telling Hollywood film studios what weather to expect on location a week or more in advance, tried a forecast for November, and is now publishing a December forecast in the coming issue of The American Farm Digest.

(AP).-Benjamin Berk, organizer for the Boot and Shoe Union, announced today that the union would accept terms of Endicott. Johnson Corporation officials for a vote on unionization among the firm's 20,000 employes.

An intensive drive for wider organization in the maritime industry will be started soon, said John L. Lewis today in announcing the formation of a maritime subcommittee along the lines laid down by the recent convention of the C. I. O. at Pittsburgh.

There are certain occasions of music when it is hardly possible for the printed report to convey what actually was accomplished by the interpreters, and the performance of "Tristan und Isolde" at the first Wagner matinee of the season in the Metropolitan Opera House is a case in point.

The attack Robert S. Hudson, head of the British Overseas Trade Department, made on Germany's international trading methods has aroused German official quarters and the press, particularly since it followed Secretary of State Cordell Hull's argument and came right on the heels of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's speech boasting of the success of the German policy.

Three hundred and twenty-seven American volunteers came singing into France this morning several hours ahead of schedule, so they th were able to stand on the station platform here and see five Spanish Rebel Junkers planes crash twenty bombs on railroad tracks they had sa just passed over a few miles inside Spain. They escaped their last peril in Spain's civil war.

Most foreigners in North China and the Yangtze Valley who have hoped against hope for an eventual Chinese victory or collapse of the Japanese campaign are beginning reluctantly to concede that most signs at present point to a clearcut Japanese triumph, probably within the next six months.

Thousands of children in isolated mountain communities in Tennessee are obliged to remain out of school because of lack of clothing, according to a statement yesterday from Save the Children Fund headq rters. 1 Madison Avenue.

Frederick Ellery Pollard, descended from Revolutionary ancestry and a great-grandnephew of Asa Pollard, the first continental soldier to fall in the Battle of Bunker Hill, died on Thursday, at his home, 146 Monroe Street, Brooklyn, in his eighty-sixth year. A native of

A mass effort to curb tuberculosis among poverty-stricken families through X-ray examinations of the 529,000 men, women and children on home relief in this city, was announced yesterday by mayor LaGuardia.

Sixty years of train service on the Sixth Avenue elevated line will end at 11:59 P. M. tomorrow and demolition of the ancient structure will begin the following week, as the result of action taken yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

In marked contrast to the verbal broadside he delivered against Georgia on his arrival here a fortnight ago, President Roosevelt extended the olive branch to Representatives of his adopted State today and indicated that it would not be necessary to cut off further public works allotments to the State as he had first threatened.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, one of the largest independents, reaffirmed today current prices on all products for the first quarter of 1939. The announcement followed a similar one yesterday by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

The first of the Junior Assemblies for this season took place last night in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton. Since their inception decades ago as the Junior Cotillions under the direction of the late Mrs. Arthur Murray Dodge, the assemblies have been the most important of subscription dances for the young women making their debuts each

Reports of a drastic and farreaching shake-up in the Police Department, especially among the higher ranking officers, were widespread yesterday despite a categorical denial by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine that he contemplates changes among officials.
Bruce Hobbs, 17-year-old Americanborn jockey, was said to be doing as well as could be expected today at the Oxford Nursing Home, where he has been bed-ridden since his back was broken a month ago.

Announcement has been made by Captain Albert Miller Penn, U. S. N., of the New York Navy Yard and Mrs. Penn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Smith Penn, to Cadet Robert W. Page Jr. of the United States Military Academy at West Point.
The local weather bureau yesterday issued the following weekend forecast for Winter sport areas:

Senator George, who defeated President Roosevelt's effort to "purge" him from the Senate in the recent Georgia primary, lashed out today at "relief spending to control American elections," urged that the National Labor Relations Board be "entirely re-formed" and called for "a free competitive capitalistic system of taxation" which he said "is needed to bring prosperity back to this country."

A student-faculty committee at the University of Pittsburgh reported today after an investigation that Pitt authorities "had no intention of dealing unfairly". with twentytwo freshman athletes who rebelled against payment of tuition fees and demanded a showdown on their status.
Ellwood H. Deysher, formerly president of the Berks Bar Association and vice president of the Pennsylvania Bar Association many years ago, died here today at the age of 81.

SOME will sit by the fireside and tune in on the Notre Dame-Southern California or the Tennessee-Mississippi game today, and some willl pack a bundle of blankets under each arm and journey to Ebbets Field to watch the Metropolltan College All-Stars play Potsy Clark's Brooklyn Dodgers for the benefit of the Refugees' Fund. That should be a good game, too.

While the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce made plans yesterday for a series of conferences to draft a program to stop "confiscatory" personal property taxation in Jersey City, Newark and other municipalities, Mayor Frank Hague issued a statement defending Jersey City's efforts to tax intangible corporation ratables estimated to total between $6,000,000,000 and $7,000,000000. Jersey City has cited more than 1,000 corporations for their. alleged failure to list personal property for 1937 and 1938.

The State Commission of Correction said today that Queens County authorities should be cited to show cause why the county jail at Long Island City should not be closed. An inspection report approved by the commission fer declared the structure is "absolutely unfit to properly house prisoners."

One of the major problems facing local governments is that of formulating an equitable, permanent program for relief, according to spokesmen of four shades of thought who made reports here today to the National Municipal League. One warned against creation of a "professional pauper class."

Voters of 291 municipalities located in thirty-six States during the month of November approved municipal bond issues aggregating $31,732,124, as compared with $49,920,443 approved in October, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the end of the week to Nov. 19 totaled 271,955,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the ?? with

In an address that at times varied widely from the advance text, Jesse W. Tapp, president of the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation, told members of the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers today that the FSCC has no program at present for the disposal of the 1,500,000 bales of cotton: which it holds.

Various phases of marketing and marketing research will be discussed at the annual convention of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Statler, Detroit, Dec. 28 to 30, it was announced yesterday. Joint sessions will be held with the American Economic Association, the American Statistical Association and the American Accounting Association.

One scholastic football game is listed to be played today in New Jersey when South River High and New Brunswick High close their 1938 campaigns in a regular scheduled contest which will be staged on South River's gridiron.
German Jews generally expect that they will be deprived of radio licenses in future anti-Semitic decrees.

The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the awards of contracts for a total of 36,500 yards of textiles, for shipment by Dec. 10, from bids opened Nov. 25, as follows: 820-T. W.-Broadcloth, white, S. B. Marks Company, 2,000 yards;

Describing the operation of the Federal Barge Line by the Inland Waterways Corporation, a government agency, as "an unsound business enterprise at the taxpayers' expense," James B. Hill, president of the Louisville Nashville Railroad, urges in the company's employe magazine that railroad men insist upon liquidation of the corporation and its accessory facilities, according to The Louisville CourierJournal.

70th St, 317-19 E: Ethel Morrison to Bernhard Mayer Estate, Inc. 175 Lexington Ave. 113th St, 112 E: Ethel Morrison to Benjamin M. Gruenstein, 16 W 77th St. 113th St, 108 E; same to same. Seaman Ave, 245; Lensake Building Corp to Annie Glasgall, 1,725 Morris Ave; mtg $65,305 ($11).

Bankers, business men and industrialists from many parts of the United States gathered here tonight for the twofold purpose of observing the diamond jubilee of the First National. Bank and Trust Company and paying tribute to Charles S. Campbell, the bank's president, on his sixty-fifth birthday.

Miss Emma Delafield, daughter of the late Major Gen. Richard Delafield, died here yesterday in her home, Brecknoch Cottage, at the age of 98. She was the last of her generation of brothers, sisters and cousins.

James F. McNulty, former Alderman and a deputy sheriff of New York County for the last fifteen years, died on Wednesday at his home, 1,944 Madison Avenue, at the age of 59. He was formerly secretary to Sheriff Thomas M. Farley and later was appointed deputy sheriff under John E. Sheey.
