In spite of two stubbornly-fought contests, five of the seeded players came safely through the second round of the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament at the Columbia Club yesterday. Those remaining
The annual exhibition of the New York Society of Painters opened with a varnishing-day reception yesterday afternoon in the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.
William F. Bleakley, county executive-elect of Westchester, announced today his selection of three department heads to serve after Jan. 1, under the new county charter.

To supervise Argentina's commercial treaties and foreign interests, the Argentine Government has appointed a permanent interministerial committee of representatives of the Foreign Office and the Departments of Finance and Agriculture, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

Miniature bonfires blazed in the background as the Giants, clad in varied, multi-colored togs, cavorted yesterday on the frozen Polo Grounds turf preparing for tomorrow's crucial National Football League game with Washington.

The Columbus and Southern Ohio Electrio Company has filed an application under the Holding Company Act for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration in connection with issuance and sale of $2,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, due 1968, to be sold privately to John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.
An unusually heavy volume of tax-exempt borrowing, featured by the offering of $40,000,000 New York City securities, swelled the total new bond financing this week by $59,862,500. This compares with

The biggest achievement of. German espionage agents in this country was to stir the public to resentment against "the government of a great people," Federal Judge John C. Knox said yesterday when he sentenced four spies to prison. The proceeding in his quiet court room contrasted with the grim order for decapitations that would have resulted for like offenses in Germany.

Strife, daughter of Night, rages often enough among our city fathers. Soothing is the interchange of quips between the all-accomplished Robert Moses and Henry Curran, that sturdy ancient in municipal affairs.

Edward Taylor Holway, secretarytreasurer of the Trans-Lux Corporation of New York, operators of stock tickers and newsreel theatres, died here yesterday in his home at the age of 76. He had been ill since Aug. 4.
The United States liner President Harding was thrown against a jetty by a heavy wind as she entered port early- today after a voyage from New York and was put in. dry dock.

Western Conference faculty committeemen and athletic directors informally discussed tonight a proposal to make the annual Rose Bowl football game solely a Big Ten-Pacific Coast Conference affair, but adjourned without saying whether they were for or against it.

Soundings taken by New Deal agents among some of the Senators who have recently come to Washington have indicated a strong desire of President Roosevelt to appoint Frank Murphy to a high post, either in the judiciary or the Cabinet, when his term as Governor of Michigan expires next month.
Proposals have been made for formation of the following New York Stock Exchange firms: Bishop Goldman on Dec. 12, with Allen R. Bishop and Henry Goldman Jr. as parterrn; Du Pasquier Co. on

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Various individual aspects of Commissioner Moses' recent proposals for housing in New York have been adequately attacked in various quarters. But it seems important to subject them as a whole to a searching examination, both because several important public men indorsed them on the evening when

Figured on the oasis of a 5.5-day working week, daily average cotton-mill activity declined less than seasorially last week, and the adjusted index rose to 122.7 from 122.2. The figure was 103.0 for the week ended Nov. 27, 1937. Sales of cotton print cloths this week were estimated at less than ...

In his current article in The Saturday Evening Post President Hutchins of Chicago brings a vigorous sledgehammer to bear on the old and sore subject of intercollegiate football. He proposes to cut admission charges to 10 cents, give academic tenure and responsibility to coaches, get more students into the games, and emphasize

Preliminary estimates by the Department of Agriculture place the cash farm income of the United States in 1938 at approximately $7,625.000.000,

The New York Kindergarten Association, sponsor of eleven kindergartens throughout the congested districts of New York, celebrated its fiftieth anniversary yesterday, along with the second anniversary of its Family Thrift Shop, by holding a fashion show at the association headquarters, 524 West Fortysecond Street.
An old friend of this column turned up day before yesterday in Dr. Lubin's testimony before the Senate monopoly committee at
The Star said here today that the Duke and Duchess of Windsor had arranged to entertain the family of a London workingman on Christmas Day at their chateau at Cap d'Antibes, on the French Riviera.

In line with its policy of dropping from registration such securities as it considers continuing in trading on the board is inadvisable, the New York Stock Exchange has filed application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to delist six issues.

A portrait by Gilbert Stuart of Captain Fredrick Philipse brought $5,000 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the auction of paintings from the estates of Harold W. Hack, Ethel May Goodridge, H. Mabel MacDonald, George E. Chisholm, and others.

County Judge Charles S. Colden of Queens directed Martin Schwaeber, assistant district attorney, yesterday to investigate over the week-end and report Monday the circumstances under which a jury last Tuesday evening failed to reach a verdict in the case of Antonio Gambino, 47 years old, of 109 Wilbur Avenue, Brooklyn, who was tried for assault and illegal possession of a pistol.
Commissioner Lithgow Osborne will preside over a hearing on proposed new ski trails within the forest preserve at the State Office Building in Albany at 9 o'clock this morning. Following the session

Notre Dame's football forces, determined to march on to the nation's 1938 championship, reigned slight favorites over Southern California tonight as a record-breaking crowd for tomorrow's thirteenth annual struggle between these two elevens was indicated.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to spend the Christmas holidays in England. He said he expected to return to his post in Washington in February.

The British Government Is growing anxious over the Italo-French tension that. has followed Wednesday's apparently prearranged shouts of "Tunisia!" "Corsica!" and "Nice!" in the Charnber of Deputies in Rome.

The Transamerica Corporation replied today to the most discussed charge in the Securities and Exchange Commission's complaint of last week-that A. P. Giannini, founder and chairman of the company, got more compensation than the $1 a year as reported. The corporation sent a letter to stockholders,
Major John A. Wilson, engineer and adjutant general of Puerto Rico for twenty years, died this afternoon after an illness of more than a week. He was to have celebrated

Morris S. Tremaine, Controller of the State of New York, will address the mid-Winter conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday and Friday next week.

Trading was mostly fair in yesterday's market. The lamb market was barely steady to weak with Thursday's late decline. Other classes of traefer meats showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats indictated beef to be stronger, veal and salt steady, lamb sharply lower. Conditions as reported by the United States Department
The fall of the Belgian Government was averted tonight by the resignation of Finance Minister Max Leo Gerard after a break with Premier Paul-Henri Spaak over economic policy.

A bullet from a gun discharged accidentally in an adjoining house tore through a wall and killed Agnes Fallat, 17, as she slept early today in this Northern Pennsylvania village. Peter Swateskie, 44. who had

Lee Pressman, general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asked the Social Security Board today to withdraw its approval of Oregon's Unemployment Compensation Act because the State's new curb on labor would compel wage-earners to accept jobs vacated in a strike, lockout or other labor dispute as defined by the Federal law.

Arthur Francis Aveling, 45-yearIld counselor of the British Emassy at Brussels, collapsed yesterlay afternoon while shopping in R. I. Macy Co., Inc. He was rushed o St. Vincent's Hospital, where it as said last night that he would probably be back in good health odav or tomorrow.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems, daughter of Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff of 860 Park Avenue and Southampton, L. I., and of the late Chester P. Siems, to James Abercrombie de Peyster, son of the Countess Bohdan de Castellane of New York and Menton, France, and of Frederic Ashton de

The home of Mr. and Mrs. Earl S. Potter of Locust Valley Road was destroyed by fire this morning. The damage was about $30,000, the police reported and said the blaze was caused by a defective oil burner.
Frank Ray Kimbley, New York stock broker, who had lived in Greenwich for thirty-two years, died today of a stroke in the Greenwich Hospital. His age was 63.

The Mrs. Jerome "Rubber Ball" was held here tonight with guests wearing costumes of rubber to pay tribute at a beauxarts ball to the material that brought Akron fame. The Woman's Art League, sponsor of the ball, had stipulated that only persons in rubber-dominated attire would be admitted to the ballroom.

Thomas N. Cooke, Greenwich real estate broker, told a jury in Superior Court today that G. Leroy Kemp, indicted State land. agent for the Merritt parkway, "tipped him off" in advance on parkway land purchases, and that in nineteen such instances he gave Mr. Kemp half the commissions which he received on the sale of much lands to the State.

Reading of the New Testament from cover to cover in an eighteenhour service was arranged today by the Baptist Temple. The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, pastor of the temple and head of the World Christian Endeavor Union, said

176th St (11-2800); 8 w cor of Monroe Ave, 140x96; A. V. J. Realty Corp to Jeffrey Realty Corp. 293 E 167th St. 172d St (11-2977) s s. 50 e of Minford P1, 50x100; Kapbro Realty Corp to Milbord Realty Corp, 565 5th Ave; mtg, S53,650.

The New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the Bell System, reported yesterday a net gain of 6,316 telephones in operation in November, compared with an increase of 4,019 in November 1937. In the first eleven months

The Pennsylvania Power Company, Sharon, Pa., a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 42,000 shares of $5 no-par value cumulative preferred stock. For purposes of computing the filing fee, the company put the maximum price at which the shares might be offered at $102.50 and the aggregate at $4,305,000.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market continues to drag so far as new business is concerned, although deliveries for current season's goods keep up very well. The problem of the trade at the moment is to discount the more remote future against the new trade treaty rates and the expectation that wool tariff rates, also, will be lowered, probably in the projected treaty with Australia. Domestic wool prices are barely steady.
Physicians and public health workers will have their own Professional Club, an incorporated organization, at the New York World's Fair of 1939, it was announced yesterday by the club's founders.

A proposal for a drastic revision in 1940 in the present bridge scoring system drew mixed approval and comment tonight from expert players at the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament.
Carnegie Tech wants John S. (Wrong Down) Getchell of Minneapolis to officiate in the Sugar Bowl football game at New Orleans next Jan. 2 when the Tartans play Texas Christian University.
The actual rarity of "monopoly" in American business as surveyed by a government economist was emphasized today before the Temporary National Economic Committee.

The Court of Appeals, in a decision that may affect hundreds of court employes, ruled unanimously today that the surrogates of Kings and Queens Counties have full power to fix salaries of their court employes and e the Board of Estimate must approprivate the money requested.

A Japanese Army spokesman announced tonight that the invaders in the Yangtze Valley were arrayed on a curving 150-mile front between the Canton-Hankow and Kiukiang-Nanchang Railways for an impending offensive farther southward into Hunan and Kiangsi Provinces.

More than 300 persons, including members of the staffs of the Second Corps Area and of the First Army, attended a formal reception yesterday in honor of Major General Hugh A. Drum, new corps area commander, and Mrs. Drum. The reception was held at the Officers Club at Governors Island.

Boston Rd, 1,155 (10-2614); Marie Bschorr to Felix A. Muldoon, trustee, 164 Bush St: extends mtgs to Nov. 15, 1943, at 4 per cent; $13,000. Creston Ave, 2,403 (11-3173); 2,403 Creston Ave Realty Corp to Bronx Savings Bank; extends mtg to Dec. 1, 1943, at 41/2 per cent; $70,000.

Mrs. Calypso Baring Liddell, daughter of an American woman and an English Lord, agreed today to return to England with her four children at the demand of her husband whom she had called "an unmitigated snob."

The Committee of Physicians for, the Improvement of Medical Care, backed by 770 of America's leading physicians, issued yesterday a statement challenging the opposition of the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, ruling body of organized medicine, to the principle of compulsory health insurance.

" American Landscape," the third offering of the Playwrights Company to reach Broadway, opens tonight at the Cort. This, of course, is Elmer Rice's play about a Connecticut family, owners of a factory, who are caught in the depression. Also involved are the astral bodies of the captains of three wars. Harriet Beecher Stowe and

The National Blouse Company, tenant in the National Tower Building at 1,372 Broadway, is enlarging its quarters by 35 per cent and soon will occupy about 19,000 square feet as a result of a new lease just arranged by Williams Co., Inc.
A deadly aerial attack which netted two touchdowns in a thrill-filled fourth quarter gave the New Mexico State College Aggies a 20-16 victory over Drake University today.
For years Jerome Tharaud, who has been writing novels in conjunction with his brother for a generation, has been trying to get into the French Academy. At last he has succeeded; and the

A Berlin-Kabul Lufthansa plane crashed on a wooded ridge overlooking Vienna at 4:15 this morning. Two British and two German passengers and three members of the crew escaped by breaking glass, but all were injured. The plane crashed in the treetops and its nose grounded.

The navy has slightly increased the area of its base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, by the acquisition of Military Reservation No. 1 at Cuzco Hills, q according to the annual report of the judge advocate general of the navy, made public today.

Sailors of the liner Normandie defied a government requisition order tonight and joined other crew members in a strike, which French Line officials indicated might delay the vessel's sailing for New York tomorrow.

Henry Honeyman tallied Height field goals for sixteen points as he led the De La Salle Institute quintet to a 35-27 triumph over Immaculata High in a non-league test in the Goddard Gymnasium yesterday. The winners were ahead at the intermission, 20-16.

Mrs. Sara Wetherill Logan, who with her husband, Robert R. Logan, a. retired attorney, established an experimental art colony on their estate, Sarobia, at Eddington, a decade ago, died there today after a brief illness. She was 64 years old.

Today's events: "Otello," 2 P. M and "Rigoletto," 8:30 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House; PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Fritz Kreisler, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Frances Hall and Rudolph Gruen, duo-pianists, Town Hall, 3; Aapo Simila. Finnish kantele player and folk singer, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.
With one mark each in their pockets-all the Germans allowed them to take out-196 refugee children from Germany arrived at Harwich in a misty cold dawn today.

The memory of the late Charles Henry Niehaus, American sculptor, will be honored today when a bronze portrait bust of the artist, the work of Adolph A. Weinmann, is unveiled at 4 P. M. in the New York University Hall of American Artists in the Gould Memorial Library at University Heights.

The Yale Club players scored another victory yesterday in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League Class C tournament by defeating the Harvard Club, 3 to 2. City A. C. downed the Crescent A. C. by the same margin, while the Princeton Club subdued Short Hills, 4 to 1, and the Bayside Tennis Club conquered the New York A. C., 4 to 1.

The unbeaten, untied Tennessee eleven raced through its final practice today and Major Bob Neyland pronounced the Southeastern Conference champion Vols "all ready" for tomorrow's battle with Mississippi.

The first large railroad financing handled in the Middle West in many years was concluded here today when the directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company sold a $30,000,000 issue of refunding and improvement bonds to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., of Chicago, and Otis Co. of Cleveland. The bonds, designated as 3 1/2 per cent, Series F, due on Dec. 1, 1963, were bought at par and accrued interest.

Joseph Clendenin, for nearly sixty years affiliated with the copper industry and formerly copper selling agent for Guggenheim Brothers, vast mining concern, died of pneumonia last night at his home, Kirk Hills, here after a twoday illness. Mr. Clendenin was

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Medieval Sculpture: Sluter and Burgundian Realism," Harry D. M. Grier, 11 A. M.; "Flemish Print Makers," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "France and England: an XVIII Century Contrast" (survey of collections). Roberta M. Fansler, 2 P. M.;

A special meeting of stockholders of Pressed Metals of America, Inc., has been called for Dec. 20 to approve an increase in the authorized stock from $150,000 par value to $500,000, according to reports from Toronto. If the plan is approved,

A rousing reception awaits Davey' O'Brien when the brilliant little Texas Christian University quarterback arrives here by plane Monday to receive the Heisman Trophy, annually presented by the Downtown Athletic Club to the outstanding college football player in the country.

ELDRIDGE, LUCY R. (Nov. 19). Estate, more than $10,000. To the Navy Relief Society, Washington, D. C., one-third residuary estate in trust; St. Thomas Church, $3,000 in trust; Mary Rumsden Cady, Rome, N. Y., one-twenty-fourth residue: Mary L. Skerry, 39 Matthewson Rd., Barrington, R. I., Gordon Bacchus,

The application of the city administration to take to the Court of Appeals its attempt to block the City Council's investigation into Radio Station WNYC was denied yesterday by the Appellate Division.
Major the Honorable Sir John Hubert Ward, whose long career as an equerrY to British sovereigns covered four reigns, died today in his London home, Dudley House. He was 68 years old.

Spring St. 119, 25x100; Mayrose Frocks, Inc, to Spingreen Corp, 221 4th Ave; p m mtg, 5 yrs, 3%; $1,000. 8th Ave. 2,773, 24.11x100: West Rock Holdings, Inc, to 2,743 8th Ave, Inc, 36 W 44th St; p m mtg, pr mtg $32,093, due Jan. 2, 1942, 6%; $3,275.

Gracie Field's next Fox-British production will be "Sally of the Shipyards," which Monty Banks will direct, the studio here announced today. The story centers around the building of the Queen Elizabeth, now under construction, and will be Miss Field's third picture for the Fox-London unit.

City College will open its twentieth basketball season under Coach Nat Holman tonight when it opposes Brooklyn College at the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium in the first contest of a seventeen-game schedule prepared for the Lavender for the 1938-39 campaign. The varsity

Overruling the Board of Education, Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter yesterday gave a decision in favor of a substitute teacher who had been refused a regular teaching license in the New York City public school system because of a cardiac condition.

Dr. Max Morgenstern, 50 years old, an employee in the foreign department of Hallgarten Co., brokers, of 44 Pine Street, was found unconscious at 10:30 A. M. yesterday in room 1,111 of the Beaux-Arts Apartment Hotel, at 310 East Fortyfourth Street.

The Dies Committee investigating unAmerican activities subpoenaed the galley proofs of the WPA guide books for New Jersey and Montana today to compare them with original proofs which are alleged to contain communistic propaganda.
Finland has expanded the program for the 1940 Olympic Games to 132 preliminary and main events, with the track and field championships scheduled for July 21-28.

Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn teams saw action in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament yesterday. Alexander Hamilton High, defending titleholder in the Division 1 race in Brooklyn, halted Bushwick, 45-30, in the Hamilton gymnasium.

The large English-type residence at 105 Mount Tom Road, in the Pelham Manor section of Westchester County, has been sold by the Putnam County Savings Bank to Lillian K. Kress, through Murray B. Parks, broker. The property is assessed for $42,000.

Transfer of a part interest in two business parcels in the "Hub" section of the Bronx featured the realty trading in that borough ported yesterday. The properties consist of the parcel occupied by Hearn's Department Store, a five-story building covering the southerly blockfront from Third to Bergen Avenue in Westchester Avenue, and the three-story and two two-story structures on the north side of 148th Street, from Willis to Bergen Avenues.

Officials of the National Power and Light Company announced yesterday that its subsidiary in Memphis, Tenn., the Memphis Power and Light Company, would deliver a formal answer to the city of Memphis at noon today on the municipality's bid of $17,285,000 for all of the properties of the private utility.

John Gardner Gould, retired investment broker and woolen manufacturer, died at his home in Darien last night of a cerebral hemorrhage. He had .been a resident of Noroton for the last nine years and formerly resided in New York and South Orange, N. J.

Solomon Gelb, described by the government as "America's No. 1 drug addict and drug distributor,' was sentenced to a three-year term in prison and fined $2,500 yesterday by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard following his conviction last Thursday on a charge of having committed perjury in 1935 by swearing to immigration authorities that he was an American citizen.

A requiem mass will be celebrated at 7:30 o'clock this morning at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 42 West Sixteenth Street, for Filippo M. Beccari, retired founder and president of the Beccari Catholic Tours, who died in his native Rome Thursday. Mr. Beccari is survived
Sixteen games, including a dozen Eastern Intercollegiate League contests, have been listed for Columbia's varsity basketball team, it was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletics manager.

The Excelesior Savings Bank has extended the $348,000 mortgage on Manchester House, at 145 W 79th St, through the Keevily Corp. The mortgage carries interest at 41/2 per cent. Two first mortgages of $3,500 each have been obtained by Morris Schneir from an insurance company on the three-story apartment and store property at 1,329-31 Fulton St. Bulkley Horton Co was the broker.

The list of the American Banker of the United States Lines, sailing for Plymouth and London, includes Captain John W. Tiebor, Captain Roland F. Tiebor, Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Rivera, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Bissell, Miss Ann C. Magill and Edward M. O'Brien.

Calvert Magruder, general counsel for the Wage-Hour Administration, expressed the opinion today that the Labor Standards Act applied to janitors, charwomen, and other building employe if their employers produced goods for interstate commerce.
William Peterson, assistant secretary of the Brooklyn Trust Company in its Jamaica office, died yesterday at his home at 103-25 Ninetyseventh Street, Ozone Park, at the age of 63.
We entered the tall timber a few miles from this town early this morning and, according to some of the local men, we would practically have to beat off the bears.

Mrs. Mary Curley Donnelly, daughter of former Governor James M. Curley and wife of Edward C. Donnelly, advertising executive, today was burned on the hands, face and one hip by flames which ignited her negligee as she lighted a kitchen stove in her Boston apartment.
District Attorney Charles F. Kelley of Philadelphia County "knew or should have known that the city was wide open as to gambling" last year, the special grand jury asserted in a presentment today.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $42,087,900, to- be represented by one State and eighty-eight municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $68,471,701 for this week. The weekly average of new

Movements or vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 2, unless specified: Guantanamo to Charleston: Brooklyn, Philadelphia. Guantanamo to Newport: Helm, Mugford, Ralph Talbot. Guantanamo to New York: Savannah, Somers, Warrington.

The University of Miami overcame Jim Fordham's 76-yard touchdown run with two 50-yard marches in the second half to conquer Georgia, 13 to 7, tonight before 23,367 persons, a record football crowd for Florida.

New York's ten municipal golf courses closed this week for the Winter, which seems logical enough. Probably not a great deal of golf has been enjoyed hereabout since Thanksgiving Day, even though the game originated on the ice in Holland.

The opening gun in the hearings of the monopoly committee made a mild and reassuring detonation. Dr. Lubin's testimony contained no indication of a witch hunt. It was a sober statistical survey. The first criticism to be made of that survey, indeed, is the very breadth of it. The chief task before the

Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wilmer Welsh of Lanesend, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alys Virginia Welsh, to John French Wilson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson of Shaker Heights, Cleveland.

Oklahoma's powerful Sooners, with an all-victorious gridiron season just around the corner, a spot in the Orange Bowl reserved, and the Big Six title in their pockets, make their last appearance of 1938 here at 2 P. M. tomorrow against the Cougars of Washington State.

Weakness in the Belgian belga induced by the threat of a Cabinet crisis took the center of attention in the foreign exchange market yesterday. The belga fell 7 points to 16 821/2 cents and closed there. This price was below the level at which gold can be shipped here profitably from Beligum.

Leo Walper, maestro at a Washington driving range but seldom in golf's big money, captured the first-round lead in the $5,000 Augusta open golf tournament today with a 67 that beat par by four strokes.

Although most of the roles in last night's performance of Verdi's "Il Trovatore" at the Metropolitan were assumed by singers heard here in the work before, the Manrico was in new hands. The difficult music of the Troubadour of Aliaferia was entrusted to Jussi Bjoerling, the youthful Swedish

Mrs. Harold M. Lehman, treasurer of Opera-on-Tour, Inc., testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien that $70,000 had been invested in the company for a tour in smaller cities to give opera with recorded orchestral accompaniment. The tour was

Each of the following Reserve officers, re cently promoted, is assigned to unit in Third Military Area, as indicated below: To 37th Infantry (R.A.I.)-Capt. Theodore D. Spritzer, Med.-Res., S. Washington Ave., at Newrmarket Rd., Dunellen. N. J. To 618th Coast Artillery (S.E.P.) Bn. (H.
Sheriff Joseph Vincent said tonight that Robert Bready, 29, had confessed the shooting to death of his father, the Rev. Dr. Russell H. Ready, 62, while in a drunken stupor.
Miss Mary Thompson, daughter of Mrs. Smith Hempstone and granddaughter of Theodore W. Noyes, was presented to society today at a tea given at the home here of Mr. Noyes.

Straffordshire figures, furniture, decorations, Oriental rugs and other lots were sold at auction yesterday for $13,199 at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The sale, which will be concluded this afternoon, comprised property of Mrs. J. Ogden Armour of Chicago, Mrs. Harold C. Mathews of this city and others.

In the fourth day of the $1,000,000 graft trial involving public officials and political leaders, seventeen prospective jurors were examined and only one more was accepted for the panel. He brings the jury up to four men-so far accepted among a total of fifty-seven men and women examined in four days.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday that on Monday it would reduce the retail price of its regular grade of gasoline in this city from 17.5 cents a gallon to 16.4 cents. The cut reflects easiness of the primary markets, due in part to the seasonal decline in consumption of gasoline.

Dr. Maurice J. Sittenfield, radiologist, who for years had conducted research into non-surgical methods for treating cancer, died Thursday night in his home, 7 West Eightyfirst Street, after a long illness. His age was 61.

Major Gen. Sir George Aston, who as an officer of the Royal Marine Artillery served as a soldier and sailor in many actions and also became an author and correspondent of The Times of London, died here today at the age of 77.
The sale of two ten-passenger Lockheed planes to the Republic of Colombia was announced in Burbank, Calif., yesterday by Robert E. Gross, president of the manufacturing company.
The re-engagement of workers who went on strike Wednesday was begun in most private industries of France today after examination of each man's case personally.
ARABIAN ANTICS, by Ladislas Farago. (Sheridan House, $2.50.) A record of adventure around the Red Sea. THE NEW YORKERS, by Smith Hart. (Sheridan House, $2.) A story of a people and their city.

The report of the West Indies Sugar Corporation and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 shows a net profit of $186,779 after interest, depreciation, United States income taxes, excess profits and undistributed profits taxes. After deducting $6,765 preferred dividend requirements of the company's subsidiary, Barahona Sugar Company, the net profit equaled 22 cents each on 822,944 shares of $1-par common stock.
After something of a lull in Arab terrorism in Palestine, there has been a revival.

A warning to small democracies in general and Switzerland in particular to observe "integral neutrality" and curb their press in the treatment of Germany was sounded today in the Voelkischer Boebachter.
Richard O. Wittke, a clock maker with the Seth Thomas Clock Company in New York for forty years before his retirement in 1930, died yesterday at his home here of heart attack. Born in Germany 83

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,075,000 a week ago, against 1,088,000 a week ago, 1,077,000 two weeks ago, 1,098,000 three weeks ago and 964,000 a year ago, of which American 516.000 bales,
Shining Heels. 3-year-old filly owned by Mrs. A. M. Creech, won the Audubon Purse six-furlong dash that topped an excellent program at the Fair Grounds today.

Mr. and Mrs. Russell Charles Veit will give a reception this afternoon at their home, 9 East Seventyfifth Street, for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Amelie Veit. Mrs. Cass Gilbert, Miss Emily Gilbert and Miss Julia Gilbert Post have come from Ridgefield, Conn., and are at 1 East Ninety-fourth Street for the Winter.

A total of $701,435, which is $200,000 above the original goal, has been raised for the relief and rehabilitation of German-Jewish refugees through the local campaign of the Allied Jewish Appeal, it was announced today.

The land for public housing projects should be acquired as far as possible through private or direct negotiation rather than by condemnation, in the opinion of Joseph Milner, former real estate adviser of the New York City Housing
The only matinee of the "Ice Follies" will be staged today in Madison Square Garden. The evening performance that follows it will close the New York run.
An investing client of the Hillcrest Realty Company bought from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company the two-family residence at 30-34 Ninety-second Street, Jackson Heights. Queens.

In a surprise move which struck at the very basis of the law enforcement agencies in Brooklyn, Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's extraordinary grand jury, currently investigating charges of official corruption in that borough, took possession yesterday of the calendar books of the six Magistrates' Courts handling criminal cases in Brooklyn.

A plan by which gold hoarders can buy gold here and have similar amounts earmarked to their credit in South Africa, thereby avoiding possible wartime risks and charges, was disclosed today. It was devised when the European crisis arose.

An announcement that Indalecio Prieto, Spanish Government War Minister and Leftist leader, will arrive here Dec. 24 to attend the inauguration of Pedro Aguirre Cerda as President of Chile, caused a stir in political circles here today.

Opening its basketball season on the home court at the 101st Signal Battalion Armory, Brooklyn Poly last night defeated the Queens College team, 34-31, in a game that was close throughout. Aaron Rabinkoff, Poly left guard, carried off scoring honors with five field goals and one foul shot for eleven points. Kneuer, a substitute left forward, counted nine points for the losers.
Dr. Arthur Horace Gordon, president of the Hahnemann Institutions, Inc., and a practicing physician here for more than fifty years, died today in his home. He was 75 years old.

Dally nearing on the proposed modification of the I Cuban-American reciprocity treaty ( will begin Dec. 5 before an interdepartmental commission in charge of this phase of negotiations, it was announced today.

H. A. Hillman has been named retail sales supervisor of the B. F. Goodrich Company in the New York district. Mr. Hillman, who joined the organization a year ago, formerely was truck and bus tire sales representative.

Mrs. William H. Joers gave a small reception yesterday at her home, 3 East Sixty-ninth Street, at which she announced the engagement of -her daughter, Miss Jean Joers, to F. Newell Childs of New York.

Miss Juliet Earl Jasper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Jasper of this place, was married to Walter T. Absolon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Absolon, also of Bronxville, this morning in St. Joseph's Church here by the Rev. Joseph McCann.

A possible opening for national collective bargaining in the textile industry between management and labor has been created by a projected early meeting of spokesmen for textile manufacturers and labor groups in order to discuss the problem of learners in that industry, as affected by the Wages and Hours Laws.

Mrs. Dirkje C. Sombeek, 49 years old, hanged herself today by wrapping electric wire cord around her neck and attaching the other end to the ceiling of a clothes closet in her home at 619 Cartland Avenue, according to police. She was the wife of George Van B. Sombeek, president of the New York cocoa importing firm of C. J. Van Houten Zoon.

A banking group composed of the Bancamerica - Blair Corporation, Goldman, Sachs Co., Kidder, Peabody Co., MacBride, Miller Co. and Colyer, Robinson Co., Inc., has obtained an issue of funding bonds of Montclair, N. J.

Two men set upon Frank Monaco, lawyer and retiring Assemblyman, in front of the garage adjoining his home at 1,409 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, at 8 o'clock last night and, in the presence of Mr. Monaco's two sons, began beating the 40-year-old man severely.

The Committee for Concerted Peace Efforts, composed of leaders of fifteen national organizations interested in world peace, started a campaign yesterday for an amendment to the United States Neutrality Act so this country can "determine the aggressor and apply embargoes to that State only and not to its innocent victim." The committee's statement,

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for two units in the development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on the old Catholic Protectory grounds in the Bronx. Architects also filed for a $250,000 apartment house in Brooklyn and numerous houses in Queens.

Small, smooth slabs of peat, intended for convenient use in the fireplaces of those in the metropol-itan area who have open fireplaces, are going on the retail market here. This announcement was made yesterday by Mervyn Brown, a representative of the firm which, organized by the late Lord Arthur Balfour, conducted the research that made commercial production of peat possible.

William P. Buckner, 31-year-old financier, whose planned visit to Hollywood was interrupted Thursday night when he was arrested on the liner Queen Mary as that vessel returned from London, and William J. Gillespie, his business associate, were freed in bail of $2,000 corpus each yesterday by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, on charges of mail fraud, which will be investigated by a grand jury.

After voting to include funds for the controversial Circumferential Parkway and the Burke Avenue extension of the Independent City Subway in the Bronx, the Board of Estimate adopted yesterday the city's 1939 capital outlay budget totaling $140,849,618.

A warning against possible Federal supervision of insurance was given by Frank N. Julian, president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, in an address yesterday at the thirty-second annual convention of the Associa the Waldorf-Astoria.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 26 amounted to 562,084 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 95,393 cars, or 14.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 6,322 cars, or 1.1 per cent,
Congressional investigators were told today that the government's development program in the Tennessee River Valley would be a valuable weapon of national defense in time of war.
The Suffolk Alcohol Beverage Control Board denied today the application for a beer and wine license for the restaurant adjoining Camp Siegfried, German-American settlement league Summer camp, here.

With the Commodity Credit Corporation having advanced funds to growers through Dec. 1 on 3,111,000 bales from this year's crop, the aggregate amount of cotton now held by that governmental agency exceeds 10.000.000 bales.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler told 30,000 Sudetenland Germans in a 55-minute campaign speech today that he was not worried about the future of Nazism because "the new generation is growing up, and we are educating it."

Commander Edwards F. Leiper, a retired naval officer and for nineteen years superintendent of the Episcopal Hospital in this city, died in the hospital last night at the age of 80. He had been in ill health about a year.

France and The Netherlands today declared that they were willing to follow Britain's example and re-settle refugees from Germany if possible in the thinly populated portions of their colonial empires.

Andre FrancoisPoncet, the French Ambassador, called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, this evening and protested in the most energetic terms against the anti-French demonstration that took place in the Italian Chamber of Deputies at the end of a speech that Count Ciano delivered Wednesday.

Rehearsal Will Be Given Before Opera Group on Deo. 12 Scenes from the forthcoming Metropolitan production of Verdi's "Falstaff" will be presented before the Metropolitan Opera Guild Monday, Dec. 12, at 1:30 P. M., with a cast headed by Lawrence Tibbett in the title role, Maria Caniglia as Mistress Ford, Irra Petina as Mistress Page, Marisa Morel as Anne,
The navy was notified today of the death yesterday in Honolulu, T. H., of Lieut. Comdr. Louis W. Crane, Supply Corps. His age was 51.

Frederic S. Marsell, former president of the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways and long active in civic affairs on the peninsula, died yesterday in Misericordia Hospital, 531 East Eighty-sixth Street, after a short illness. He was 54
A Federal grand jury interspersed the ordinary phraseology of a true bill with blood-and-thunder passages today as it indicted two men in connection with an extortion plot.

Football of the collegiate variety makes its last appearance of the season in the metropolitan district this afternoon when the Metropolitan College All-Stars clash with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn. Sponsored by the Sports

The marriage of Miss Suzanne Hough Arguimbeau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Charles Arguimbeau of Glenbrook, to William Norris H -bbard Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Hubbard of 515 Park Avenue, New York, took place this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church here.

Col. C. L. Corbin, in 320 Park Ave; Dr. Gilman S. Currier, in 40 E 62d St; Donald J. Tobin, in 142 E 71st St; Brendon Gill, in 21 E 90th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc. brokers. Dave Elman, solarium suite, Raymond McAlister, tower suite, in Century Apartments, 25 Central Park West; Chanin Management, Inc, agents.
A rabid dog roamed through corridors and classrooms on the three floors of the West Orange High School for more than an hour this morning, biting five pupils and snapping at several others.

The executive committee of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Association tonight announced that Garfield High School's eleven had won the North Jersey Group 4 football championship. Garfield won all its games, and under the system by which the teams are rated scored 587 points.

Two husky patrolmen, James St. Jacques and William Leckey of the West Thirtieth Street station, and a sympathetic Negro, Mrs. Sadie Lee, proprietor of a moving van company, played the roles of good samaritans to a family in distress yesterday morning.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $920,574,865 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on Nov. 30 was $32.30, compared with $32.96 on Oct. 31.

In observance of Bible Week which begins tomorrow many ministers will devote sermons to the work of the New York Bible Society which will celebrate its 129th anniversary. In numerous churches tomorrow will be commemorated as Universal Bible Sunday and others will observe a week from tomorrow as that anniversary.

In connection with its December financing program to raise $700,000,000 in cash and exchange new issues for $941,613,750 of 1 1/2 per cent notes which mature on March 15, the Treasury is expected to obtain unusually favorable carrying charges as a result
C. H. Perry, secretary of the American Trotting Association, today reported that a proposal to consolidate with various Eastern trotting organizations was disapproved at the annual meeting yesterday.

Mrs. Arthur Glasgow of London gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Baroness Robert de Foucaucourt. Others in the party included Mrs. Charles H. Sherrill, Mrs. William Starr Miller, Mrs. John B. Trevor, Mrs. Hokan Bjornstrom Steffanson,

Miss Dorothy C. Von Elm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Von Elm of Forest Hills, Queens, was married to John Luther Putnam of Great Neck, L. I., yesterday afternoon in the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

Details of the $3,500,000 shipmodel testing basin that is under construction for the navy near Washington were made public yesterday by Commander Harold E. Saunders, U. S. N., technical director of the project. He described the tank in an address to delegates to the forty-sixth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Charles Franklin Reynolds, the oneman Board of Education and supervisor of the one-room school in District 11 of the Valhalla school system for the last forty-eight years, died suddenly of a heart attack last night at his home. He was 68 years old.

A new disagreement between Deputy Mayor. Henry H. Curran and Park Commissioner Robert Moses arose yesterday over plans for renovating of City Hall Park following the removal of the old Postoffice Building. Mr. Curran wants the park restored to its original appearance before erection of the postoffice. He dislikes the mall and "vast expanses of asphalt" in Mr. Moses's plan, which has already been approved by the Municipal Art Commission.

Chairman Douglas of the Security and Exchange Commission expresses satisfaction that sixty-four public utility companies, comprising all the major systems, have responded to a request that they inform the commission of their tentative plans for compliance with Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.
The Bowls--Rose, Sugar, Cotton, Orange, et al.--are with us again bigger and better than ever and with more "gravy" for all concerned except the football players.

George G. Ortlip, Atlantic City's overseer of the poor, was arrested today on a charge of "refusing" to provide relief to a disabled war veteran with four children. He was released on his own recognizance by Magistrate Edward Nappen pending a hearing next Monday.
Anthony Eden, the former Foreign Secretary of Great Britain, during his visit to the United States, will come to Washington and will be received by President Roosevelt.
Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that economic and social progress in Columbia was "a source of satisfaction and encouragement" throughout the American hemisphere.

As a protest against Nazi Germany's treatment of scholars and students in its universities, it was learned yesterday, the faculty council of the City College has approved a plan to drape in black the flags of German universities which hang in the great hall of the main building.

Nine thousand persons were reported homeless today in the Cagayan Valley of Northern Luzon Island because of flood due to torrential rains. Crop and property damage was widespread. Only one death was reported. Several towns were said to be threatened with famine.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 1: COLONELS Churchill, J. M., Inf., Ft. Wayne, Mich., detailed with the Organized Reserves, Manchester, N. H., about Jan. 15.
William M. Norris, a former Federal judge and counsel for the United States Board of War Claims after the World War, died at his home here today. His age was 92.
Indoor polo starts a new season with the games at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn tonight. Next Saturday night, Squadron A will begin play in Manhattan.

English grain traders placed a bearish construcon early today on the sale of 20,00,000 bushels of American cash heat to mills in that country. pricess in Liverpool declined sharpr early in the session, only to rally Lter and closed 1/4 cent a bushel to cent higher than yesterday.

The rolls were closed today for nominations for the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap, but it will be several days before the names and number of candidates are known.

Twenty but of twenty-eight issues of municipal and other bonds offered for sale yesterday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were Awarded today to the highest bidlers. Bids on eight other issues were rejected as unsatisfactory.

Kaufmann Department Stores, Inc., has notified the New York Stock Exchange of a proposed plan of merger which provides for the absorption of its wholly owned subsidiaries and the Kaufmann Deapartment Stores Securities Corporation.

ZURICH is the place to go if you would learn the modern technique for becoming a Man of Iron. It was there, according to Ignazio Silone, that a power-haunted American politician (known simply as Mr. W) and his fantastic companion (Professor Pickup, exponent of Neo-Sociology) met Thomas the Cynic.

A hydraulic device that eliminates almost completely the need for gear shifting was revealed here yesterday as having been put in use for the first time in an American passenger automobile.

General Emile Adolphe Taufflieb, who was French Senator from Alsace and commander of the Thirtyseventh French Army Corps during the World War, died Thursday night in Paris, according to word received here last night. He was 81 year old.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange increased yesterday under a sudden selling wave which carried the October into new low ground for the season, and left the list with losses of 12 to 17 points.

Two scoring forays in the second period, with Ed Schmidtgall netting the disk each time, last night gave Brooklyn Tech a 2-0 triumph over Boys High in a P. S. A. L. ice hockey championship game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. The victory,

The Department of Agriculture disclosed today that it had agreed to withdraw its offer to subsidize exports of flour to Great Britain because of the sale of 20,000,000 bushels of unprocessed wheat to British millers.
Dutton will publish on Jan. 3 a new novel entitled "Royal Regiment" by Gilbert Frankau, author of one of last Spring's best sellers, "Dangerous Years."
The Associated Press fourteenth annual all-Pacific Coast football team, announced today, combines a big mobile line and a backfield of speed and tremendous power.

Basilio Desti, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and manager of the Italian Cloakmakers Union, Local 48, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., according to word received here last night. He was. 59 years old. He lived in Emerson.

Miss Pauline Stone Foraker, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Francis King Wainwright of Mill Brook Farm, Bryn Mawr, was married this afternoon to Fredarick Warren Marshall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Warren Marshall of Eltonwood, Radnor. The ceremony was performed by Canon Ernest C. Earp, assisted by the Rev. Richard B. Gurley, in the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr.

Wholesale volume gained sharply this week, following an expansion in consumer buying, and the decrease from 1937 narrowed to 3 to 10 per cent, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary. Colder weather and the beginning of holiday consumer buying by many stores were responsible for most gains in trade during the week.

Calm has followed the recent terrorist outbreaks. The authorities are investigating suspects in various bombings. An order issued today called on value turn gendarmes to watch closely persons suspected of belonging to the illegal to Fascist Iron Guard.

Glenn Cunningham's startling feat of running the mile in 4 minutes 4.4 seconds was recommended today for acceptance as an American record by the Record Committee of the National Amateur Athletic Union. Tomorrow or Sunday it will be submitted to the general convention for final approval as the fastest mile ever run by man.

Informed by Mayor La Guardia that $160,000 was being withdrawn this month from the city's appropriation for WPA materials, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday that 12,500 WPA workers would have to be discharged here by New Year's Day.
A disappointed litigant stood up today in the august Court of Appeals and bombarded two bewigged Lord Justices with tomatoes.

Former Representative Edward E. Eicher of Iowa was sworn in today as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. About an hour before he took the oath Mr. Eicher sent his resignation to Governor N. G. Kraschel of Iowa and the Clerk of the House and this action automatically terminated his membership on the monopoly committee.

The Adolph S. Ochs Memorial Post 1,207 of the American Legion will hold its first annual military ball and entertainment in the Hotel Park Central on Sunday, Dec. 11, Harry Frank, chairman of the arrangements committee announced yesterday.
The 1940 Olympic Ski Games Committee today voted to recommend to the National Ski Association that the United States ski team visit St Moritz, Switzerland, for exhibitions

Dr. Nelson P. Mead, acting president of City College, charged yesterday that the German Nazi government had established a new propaganda agency in this country under the guise of the German University Service, 580 Fifth Avenue. Dr. Mead is one of 300 American college and university presidents to whom the new German agency recently sent letters announcing plans for encouraging and extending the exchange of students between this country and Germany.
Secretary Perkins said today that she did not favor amending the National Labor Relations Act.

Thousands of taxpayers who appealed their assessed valuations through writs of certiorari were placed in a quadary yesterday when the Appellate Division upheld the city's contention that the deadline for such appeals was June 30, 1938, under the old charter instead of Oct. 24, 1938, under the new one.

Capt. William T. MacDonald of Eng. Co. 161 died Dec. 1. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 463 Kissel Ave., West Brighton, Richmond, at 2:30 P. M., Sunday, Dec. 4. Florida will pit its strong defense against the razzle-dazzle deception of Temple University in their football game tomorrow.

Simultaneously with the announcement that Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany would come here Tuesday to sign the French-German "no war" declaration, it was announced today in Berlin that Page 699 of Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf" would undergo "a historic correction" Tuesday.

The Rev. Ernest J. Mollenauer, for the last seven years pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church, Syracuse, N. Y., has accepted a call to the pastorate of St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street. He will be installed on New Year's Day. Mr. Mollenauer will succeed

The Manufacturers Safe Deposit Company, 55 Broad Street, New York, received authority today from the State Banking Department to open a branch office at Constitution Mall, Washington Square, on the New York World's Fair grounds.
A formal campaign to have Secretary Ickes run for Mayor of Chicago was started here today. A group of citizens disclosed that it had sent a telegram asking him to enter the contest.

Members' trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Nov. 12 aggregated 18.69 per cent of total volume, compared with 20.07 per cent in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries, excluding those in receivership, for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,504,391 after taxes, retirements, interest charges and other requirements. This compares with a revised net of $5,242,830 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1937.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, the general secretary, completed yesterday the last details for the biennial meeting and thirtieth anniversary celebration of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, which will be held in Buffalo, opening Tuesday morning
Irregular price movements were the rule yesterday in relatively dull trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Postal Telegraph land lines system and the Western Union Telegraph Company appealed today to Elmer F. Andrews, administrator of the Wages and Hours Law, to overrule a decision by Dr. W. M. Leiserson declining to permit employment of messengers at lower than the 25cent-an-hour statutory minimum.

To forestall any possibility of certain payments ordinarily made to the sinking fund being held as taxable income under the Federal income tax laws and the possible payment of substantial income taxes as a result, the New York Majestic Corporation is submitting to holders of its 4 per cent non-cumulative income bonds for their approval proposed amendments to the indenture to prevent the necessity for such payments.

Nearly 10,000 men and women were thrown out of work here this afternoon when officials of Fisher Body- No. 1 plant of the General Motors Corporation were forced to close the factory as the result of a walkout by members of Local 581, United Automobile Workers of America, a C. I. O. unit, in a dispute over the method of paying workers.
President Emil Hacha amnestied all poiitical prisoners today. Soldiers who fled from Czecho-Slovakia before Oct. 7 and spies did not receive amnesty.

After more than forty years in the service of the Federal, State and city governments as an interpreter, Dr. Solomon Lubliner, at present attached to the Bronx Supreme Court, has applied for retirement, he announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2.--The possibility that Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes may be a candidate for Mayor of Chicago next Spring has complicated the political outlook in this city of turbulent politics.

When President Roosevelt speaks at the University of North Carolina tomorrow the Carolina Political Union will share some of the limelight. It boasts that it has one of the freest public forums to be found in America, entirely independent of faculty or administration control.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--Goucher College has completed an analysis of the subjects studied by its freshmen and sophomores, revealing that 160 had chosen to follow, in their first two years, no less than 114 different personal curricula.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 3.--An allegorical Christmas pageant of the Nativity will be presented at Marymount College on Sunday, Dec. 18. Bach's Christmas oratorio will provide a musical background. The pageant will replace the usual Christmas opera.

An exhibition of little-known Santa Clauses of other lands will be. on' view for a week, beginning today, on the fourth floor of the Saks Thirty-fourth Street "department store, H. L. Redman, general director of the store, announced. yesterday.
Two apartment houses will be erected on the estate of Judge Burt J. Humphrey in Jamaica, Queens. The property, known as Beech Haven, has been sold by Judge Humphrey to a Brooklyn builder.

More than 800 Jewish children crossed the frontier today from Germany for new homes in France and England. Most of the children, whose ages ranged from 7 to 14 years, will be cared for by families in the vicinity of Metz, Stralsbourg and Mulhouse. About 100 will go to England.

The New York Membership Enrollment for the Seeing Eye, which has been conducting a drive for 1,500 new members, enlisted 1,595 new members, it is reported by. Mrs. Arthur S. Lord, chairman of the membership committee.

Liquidation developed-in lard futures last week and all deliveries sold at new low levels for the season and since 1934. Fears of large amounts of cash lard being tendered on December contracts had some effect on sentiment. The failure of an active foreign demand to develop also was a factor, as was a small increase in stocks in November at leading Western packing points.

A spokesman for the American Friends Service Committee of the Society of Friends (Quakers) said tonight that three committee members were en route to Germany "to "observe and bring back some idea how we could help alleviate conditions there."

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons and his wife, Dame Enid, broadcast through 116 national and commercial Australian stations tonight an appeal for popular support for the government's effort to-procure 35,000 more militia men. This would make the total strength 70,000.
The congress of Industrial Organizations announced today that it would undertake a nation-wide campaign to halt cuts in the employment rolls of the Works Progress Administration.

Capital issues floated in Great Britain in November amounted to [Pound]12,802;202, compared with [Pound]2,627,853 in- October and with [Pound]12,400,174 in November, 1937, making the eleven-month total [Pound]108,501,656, against [Pound]153,081,567 in 1937, and making this year's showing the lowest for the period since 1930.
Sudetenland voters, casting ballots for thirty Deputies to the German Reichstag, gave Adolf Hitler the expected overwhelming vote of confidence today.
A crowd of 40,000 attended the opening today of Lima's new race track, located two and a half miles from the city. President Benavides officiated at the ceremonies.

The Army basketball team will engage in fifteen games during the coming season, according to the schedule released today, with the opening test listed, for Jan. 4, when the Cadets meet Brown at West Point. Both Yale-and Syracuse, the only quintets to turn back Army last season, are once again included in the card.

The tension and complexity of modern life requires that those who want to live most fully must refuel themselves "from those deep wells" of the soul "where the help of God flows in," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

Television is simply another service and will never supplant radio, Larry E. Gubb, president of Philoe Radio and Television Corporation, said yesterday in discussing the current publicity being given to the projected introduction of television next year.

Nearly 4,500 members of the German-American League for Culture, an anti-Nazi organization, dedicating their annual "German Day" program yesterday to "the ideals of freedom, progress and racial tolerance," cheered Thomas Mann and other speakers who assailed the Hitler government and adopted a resolution calling for an American "embargo against the Nazi regime."

Mrs. Robert C. Ream, president of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work; the board of directors and department chairmen will be hostesses at a Christmas tea Wednesday in the salesrooms of the exchange at 541 Madison Avenue.

Dr. and Mrs. Edward V. L. Brown of this city 'have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Brown, to Clarence Boyd Jones, son of Mrs. Walter Clyde Jones of Evanston and the late Mr. Jones.

A Cleveland team tonight won the open pair championship of the American Contract League, most important title at stake in the league's tournament. The new champions, who ended a long reign by Eastern titleholders, were Mrs. Harry E. Funk, one of Cleveland's leading woman players, and Franke Bubna, a city official, who earned his first important bridge honors.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society will give a gala concert under the auspices of the PhilharmonicSymphony League on Saturday evening, Feb. 11, at Carnegie Hall, Nadia Boulanger, eminent composer and pedagogue, will conduct several selections and John Barbirolli will also appear as conductor.

Guy Jackson Hecker, formerly prominent in baseball, died yesterday at the age of 82. He managed the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1890. He scored seven runs for Louisville on Aug. 15, 1886, a record that still stands. He hit three home runs that day.

Meyer Nebenzahl, owner of a children's wear business in Cedarhurst, died suddenly today of a heart attack at his home, 851 Woodmere Drive, in his forty-sixth year. A graduate of Cornell, class of '15, he had been admitted to the bar, but never practiced.

Arrangements for short-wave radio broadcast to Europe and South America of President Roosevelt's address tomorrow afternoon are interpreted as indicating the speech will be of major importance. But there was no inkling from official sources as to the subject-matter.
After holding steady in the first four days of trading, cotton prices last week developed softness on Friday and the losses were extended further on Saturday.

The thorough purge of the Nazi: party in Austria, threatened by Joseph Buerckel, Nazi commissioner, does not appear to have started. Twelve members of the party, already expulled for stealing from Jews on Nov. 9 and 10, will be sent to prison and subsequently confined in a concentration camp, Herr Buerckel announced when he promised a purge.

Life has begun on Santiago Island for 500 monkeys transferred there from India's jungles. The last leg of the 14,000-mile journey was completed today when the cages were taken ashore from a barge after the animals had been sent by truck from the School of Tropical Medicine at San Juan.

After the superlative playing by Simon Barer at his recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, the immensely gifted Russian pianist must be reckoned among the greatest of all exponents of the keyboard heard here in recent times.

A fr ak automobile accident early yesterday sent a private car bounding down the stairway into the Tremont Avenue station of the Independent Subway System in the Bronx. After skidding along for about forty feet on the upper level of the station the automobile came to a stop with its two occupants only slightly hurt.

A banking group headed by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation and including Goldman, Sachs Co., Kidder, Peabody Co., MacBridge, Miller Co. and Colyer, Robinson Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $949,000 town of Montclair, N. J., 214 per cent funding bonds at prices to yield from 0.60 to 2.25 per cent, according to maturity.

Columbia University will make two to five annual awards, conceived in the light of its Pulitzer Prizes, to publishers, editors or writers in the Western Hemisphere, "who, by their professional achievements, shall advance sympathetic understanding among the peoples of South, Central and North America," it was announced yesterday. The first awards will be made public early next year.

Offering will be made tomorrow by John J. Bergen Co., Ltd., of an issue of $4,000,000 Sunray Oil Corporation 5 per cent interestbearing convertible sinking-fund debenture shares, Series A, dated Nov. 1. 1938. at $25 a a share.

Despite a revival of the foreign demand for American cash corn, prices averaged lower the last week. Liquidation by holders of December contracts and fears that the Commodity Credit Corporation would sell part of its holdings were factors.

Employes of Grate Church and Grace Chapel have entered into an arrangement with the Church Life Insurance Corporation whereby they will receive life annuity upon retirement from active service, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of the church, announced yesterday.

Stephen F. Chadwick of Seattle, national commander of the American Legion, said today that the Legion was "opposed to any move which would make America an asylum for refugees." Mr. Chadwick spoke at the annual mid-winter conference of the Kentucky department.

The Jersey City Giants, champions of the American Professional Football Association, vanquished the Paterson Panthers at Roosevelt Stadium by 17-7 today in an exhibition game before a crowd of 17,643.

Pope Pius XI should be asked to appoint a commission to administer relief in famine-stricken areas of Loyalist Spain under-Ernst Toller's scheme of distributing surplus wheat contributed by the democratic governments, the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, declared yesterday in an Advent address in the

The Spanish Galleon, a- thrift shop, will be opened today at 649 Tenth Avenue under the auspices of the Spanish and Portuguese. Synagogue, New York's' oldest Jewish congregation, now celebrating its 285th anniversary.
Advertising volume last month continued to show a definite upturn, as colder weather helped retail trade, and losses in 'national copy were smaller than in the previous month, according to estimates.

The Cullum Gold Medal for 1938 of the American Geographical Socity has been awarded to Miss Louise A. Boyd, explorer and geographer, in recognition of her achievement in Arctic geographical research, it was announced yesterday. Miss Boyd returned on Nov. 30 from her sixth expedition to the Arctic.

The annual Christmas sale of the Lighthouse Craftshop of The New York Association for the Blind opens today at 115 East Fifty-ninth !Street and will continue there until Christmas. As the shop charges no commission, proceeds of articles sold will be paid directly to the blind.

The Rev. Cornelius Cyprian Clifford, whose tiny church with a medieval atmosphere attracted worshipers here from all over the country, died early this afternoon at his home on Thomas Street after being ill for many months. He was in his eightieth year.

The weather was warm yesterday, but the Giants were warmer. In fact, the New Yorkers were ablaze as they crushed the Washington Redskins, 36 to 0, before the fascinated gaze of a crowd of 58,031 at the Polo Grounds.

Dr. Vladimir Matchek, popular Croat leader and chief of the Opposition coalition that is seeking to overthrow Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch at the general elections next Sunday, said in an interview that the Croats would continue to fight for complete autonomy, no matter what the outcome of the balloting.
The German-American Settlement League, which operates Camp Siegfried, is planning to dispose of the commercial buildings and picnic area of the site, its president, Ernest Mueller, announced today.

Complete review of America's foreign trade policy because of recent international realignments will be urged by the tariff committee of the National Association of Manufacturers in its report to the Congress of American Industry which will be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria from Wednesday through Friday. V. L. Derby,

How TO RAISE A. DOG, by James R. Kinney and Ann Honeycutt. (Simon Schuster, $2.) A practical manual, illustrated by James Thurber. NEW WRITING, FALL, 1938, edited by John Lehmann. (Knopf, $2.75.) The fourth In the series containing work by the younger writers.

The memorial stone to Jacob Leisler, insurrectionist Colonial Governor of New York, which Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran banished from City Hall Park last Summer as the "ugliest stone in the city" and- of dubious historic authenticity, is destined to be returned to the park in a new and fancier setting, it was learned yesterday.

In what was described by some members of the union as the first serious election contest in more than twenty years, two separate slates of candidates for officers in Local 202 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. of L. affiliate, were nominated yesterday at a meeting in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street.

Nobody's heart will be utterly broken by the passing of the Sixth Avenue Elevated Line. One can feel sorry for the El workers, thrown out of their jobs at Christmas time, without feeling sorry for the El.

The New York Rovers continued on their merry way yesterday afternoon as they stretched their winning streak to five straight and stayed far in front in the Eastern Hockey League by overpowering the Hershey (Pa.) Cubs, 7 to 3, in the star game of an amateur doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

Although we rebel against the strenuousness of our time, it always has been in such a time that man has won his great inner victories, the Rev. Elmore McNeill MIcKee, rector of St. George's Episcopal Church, Sixteenth Street and Stuyvesant Square, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

From. sun-kissed and supernal plan Of heavenly engineers, What bridge is this flings out its span 'With neither chains nor piers? Bright-arch, the secret-of whose scheme | The sky withholds forever; (0 vast, 0 visionary dream Of perfect cantilever!).
Vocal quartets, vandal groups, celebrities, revelers and sentimentalists-perhaps 2,000 or more in all--rode north and south last night on the final runs of the Sixth Avenue Elevated Line.
C. S. Wills defeated L. F. Sanman, 25-24, for the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday after a tie at 98.

Of the nations that are suffering from "diseases of the heart" today, the United States is faring best, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Catholic educator, said last night in an address in praise of the McCosker-Hershfield Cardiac Foundation at its second annual dinner at the Hdtel Plaza.

Kayser Stores, stockings, gloves and lingerie, store at 358 5th Ave.; Ermanno Franquinet, importer of fashions, in 9 E. 55th St.; Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers. Lauriul Restaurant Corp., service restaurant, In 13-25 Astor Pl.; Tankoos, Smith Co. and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

Although the world seems mad with brutal inhumanity, it would be much worse if the restraining power of Christ were entirely removed from every heart, the RevCarlos G. Fuller said yesterday at the Featherbed Lane Presbyterian Church, University Avenue and 174th Street, the Bronx.
The naval wireless tonight intercepted an S O S call from the German ship La. Plata, which said she had collided with the Greek steamer Akti, about sixty miles directly south of Quimper.

The General Motors Corporation announced early today the settlement of the strike in the Fisher Body Plant No. 1 at Flint. Negotiators for the corporation and the United Automobile Wbrkers reached the settlement after midnight in a conference which opened at noon yesterday.
Premier Paul-Henri Spaak enlarged and shuffled his Cabinet today, by creating three new Ministries following a government crisis that had threatened to force his resignation last week.

Mrs. M. C. Weeks Stewart of 157 East Seventy-second Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Cooper Stewart, to William Morrison Tingue, son of Mr. and- Mrs. William James Tingue of 340 East Seventy-second Street.

Bullishiness regarding the prospects of the market in the United States has become less pronounced. British capital is still drifting steadily toward the United States, but less on investment account than for other reasons.

Raw cotton imports into Germany in the first nine months of 1938 amounted to 428,000,000 pounds, valued at 145,696,000 marks, compared with 354,000,000 pounds valued at 157,441,000 marks in the same period of 1937, an increase of 20 per cen in quantity. but a decrease of 8 per cent in value, the United States Consulate at Bremen reported to the Department of Commerce.

The average temperature yesterday was 51 degrees, 13 above normal, the Weather Bureau reported. The high was 58 at 1 P. M. and the low 44 at 8 A. M. The forecast for today was for occasional rain. with colder weather tonight.

By virtually taking charge of the air force of El Salvador, and supplying planes and instructors, Italy in the past two months has gone far toward obtaining control of an airbase several hours flight from the Panama Canal.

The eleventh annual solemn pontifical mass under the auspices of the Catholic Students Mission League of the Archdiocese of New York will be celebrated by Bishop Stephan J. Donahue, Administrator of the Archdiocese, at 11 A. M. tomorrow at the Church of the Annunciation, Convent Avenue and 131st Street.

Reorganization of the .Municipal Civil Service Commission is recommended in a report made public yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission. The report, based on a twelvemonth study, praises the present civil service administration as "progrossive, independent and vigorous"

A plan to settle 10,000 British fam'ilies in Canada at a cost of $50,000,00 has been submitted to the British Government by Brig. Gen. Sir Henry Page Croft, M. P., and Mr. R. S. Dalgliesh, Newcastle shipowner, who have been touring British Columbia.

Dr. Hu-Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, said here last night that China expects the democratic countries to stop sending war materials to Japan. He spoke at a dinner held in his honor at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

The new transatlantic liner now being built for the United States Lines in Newport News, Va., is to be called the America, it was announced by John M. Franklin, president of the company. Mr. Franklin said that since the laying of the vessel's keel in August thousands of letters from all parts of the country had come in with suggestions for a name.

Ray Ruddy, whose achievements as a swimmer and water-poloist caused him to be ranked among the outstanding athletes of the world, died at 7 o'clock last night at the age of 27 in Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center from the effects of a fall twenty-four hours earlier.

The Sixth Avenue elevated railway was in its prime in the late Eighties and the early Nineties, when it was used daily by the best people in New York business and social circles. It had what was termed a genteel air that was never attained by any of the other elevated lines in the city.

Making a final appeal for the remaining $32,000 which must be raised before work can be started on the interior of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Bishop William T. Manning predicted 'yesterday afternoon that construction would begin "before the first of the year if funds continue to come in as they have been recently.
The fact that the Government's own experts have been disagreeing with each other at the very opening of the monopoly investigation is a healthy and reassuring sign rather than its opposite.

The Mt. Vernon Apartments, an eighty-four-fanily property in Jackson Heigths, Queens, has been sold by Goetz, Woursell Goetz, the builders, to the Jackson HeightsMt. -Vernon Corporation, a syndicate of investors. ,The building, one of the most recent housing operations in Jackson Heights, is in the Colonial style and occupies the site at 34-31 Eighty-first Street.

R. T. Vanderbilt Company, Inc., New York, and the Standard Mineral Company, Inc., Hemp, N. C., have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with violation of both the Federal Trade Commission and Clayton Acts in the sale of pyrophyllite, an aluminum silicate used in making earthenware, the commission announced today..

The markets generally have made a disappointing response to factors which, normally, should have produced some favorable reaction. Among these encouraging incidents the principal places must be accorded to the triumph of Premier Daladier of France in crushing the strike, and to the recovery of sterling.

Operations of the fleet of the bankrupt Pacific Steamship Lines (Admiral Line) may be resumed on a permanent basis by creditor groups of the Pacific Steamship Company, it was stated tonight by Thomas James, vice president .of the Associated Banning Company, stevedores, who was recently elected president of the new company.

Hitherto the dispute with insurance companies concerning the payment of claims respecting the damage to Jewish property had no perceptible effect on the market, since nothing concrete has yet happened.

Jesus Christ was the greatest moral teacher of all times because He took His standards not from contemporary customs or society but from His Father in Heaven, Dr. William Lyon Phelps declared yesterday morning. Dr. Phelps,

A memorial meeting to honor Rabbi Morris Lichtenstein, founder of the Society of Jewish Science, wil be held tomorrow evening at 8:15 o'clock in the auditorium, where he for years held his Sunday morning services, at 250 West Eighty-fifth Street. Dr. Lichtenstein died Nov. 6.

Two Hackensack youths were drowned in the Hackensack River near Route 4 when their homemade cabin boat capsized yesterday. They were Riehard Palmer, 16 years old, of 35 Johnson Avenue, and Walter Ackerman, 14, of 76 Johnson Avenue.
