Following recent trends toward longer seasons, more homes, clubs and hotels are now open than a year ago. The Bath and Tennis, Seminole, Sea Spray, Beach, Sun and Surf Clubs opened Thursday. The Breakers, Brazilian Court, the Palm Beach Plaza, and the Seaglade Hotels are receiving guests.

HAT a day! What a crowd! What a game! The Redskin rooters milled into the Polo Grounds from Washington with red feathers in their hats, their band playing the famous Marshall music "Hail to the Redskins" and thousands of throats uttering wild war whoops of defiance to the Giants and their local supporters.

WHATEVER else one may say of the Oxford University Press, it is a most dignified institution, turning out among other things reference books, anthologies and collected works in well-bred and conservative blue bindings stamped in good-the "Oxford Book of English Mystical' Verse," the "'Oxford Book of Greek Verse in Translation," the Oxford this, the Oxford that, and so on.

Alfred M. Landon, former Presidential candidate, will not remain in Lima for the duration of the Eighth Pan - American Conference, to which he is a delegate. Mr. Landon has made plans to leave the. conference, it was revealed today, in time to be at home for Christmas.

" The Theatre of Angna Enters" presented its second bill of the season last night at the Alvin Theatre, introducing two new numbers and repeating two which had their prep mitres last week. An evening with Miss Enters is rather like rummaging in the top drawer, where almost anything can turn up.

Bishop Donahue, administrator of the Archdiocese of New York, dedicated the renovated basement of St. Michael's Church, 420 West Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon. The space will be used as a gynmasium and social hall for the church and St. Michael's High School. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle,

PORFIRIA PEREYRA, grocer, 1,841 3d Ave., and 1,663 Madison Ave.-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler act listing liabilities of S5,503. and assets of $1,365.. Payment of 15 per recentt is proposed.

Strong opposition to the increase of "runaway" dress contracting shops from the metropolitan area was expressed here today by delegates at the sixth annual convention of the New Jersey Dress Manufacturers and Contractors Assoclation.

The twoscore mark is threatened again by the new exhibitions opening this week in New York galleries and museums. The usual variety in subject-matter and media is evident and among the exhibitions is the ten-year retrospective show of the work of the Bauhaus, which has been assembled at the Museum of Modern Art.

Allan W. Cuddeback, who had been president of the New York Water Service Corporation since 2931, died yesterday of heart disease at his residence, 51 Fifth Avenue, after an illness of ten days. He was born in Cuddebackville, N. Y., seventy years ago.

Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky criticized the police yesterday for holding forty men and one woman for eight hours in jail after arresting them at a card game at a restaurant and social club at 2,726 Broadway at 2:30 A. M.

County Judge John C. Karel died today at the age of 65. He was a star on the University of Wisconsin's football team in the early Nineties. Judge Karel had presided over one of the two branches of the Probate Court of Milwaukee County since it, was established thirty-one years ago.

Miss Ellen Louisa Burrell, former head of the Department of Pure Mathematics at Wellesley College and the college's oldest alumna, died last night in Roxbury at the New Englarnd Hospital for Women and Children after a short illness. Her age was 88.

J. Armitage Ewing, H. R. Stephenson and J. Colin Kemp, members of the preferred stockholders' protective committee for the 7 per cent and 6 per cent preferred stock of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., have announced termination of the deposit agreement of June 10, 1932.

The eleven-story apartment house at 151 East Eightieth Street, northeast corner of Lexington Avenue, is fully rented, according to Byrne Bowman, Inc., the agents. The contract for altering the building at 135 West Fifty-eighth Street has been awarded by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to the J. C. Lyons Sons Company.

Eight women whose residences are notable examples of artistic interior decoration will open their homes informally this afternoon and tomorrow afternoon under the auspices of the Neighborhood Playhouse Associates. Proceeds from the charge of admission to each of the homes will augment the scholarship fund of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre, 16 West Forty-sixth Street.

Victories by teams representing St. Augustine's High and St. John's Prep of Brooklyn yesterday marked the opening of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association dual meet swimming series conducted annually by the Columbus Council K. of C. in its pool in Brooklyn.

Emma Gramatica, noted Italian actress and protegee of the late Eleanora Duse, arrived yesterday from Rome on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to make her first appearance on the American stage playing at the head-of an American company.

Wilham C. Donnelly of Baltimore, general supervisor of time service for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, died last night at Sinai Hospital here after a brief illness. His age was 69.' Mr. Donnelly had been in charge of watch and clock inspection throughout the B. 0. system since 1922.

The State Liquor Authority said tonight, on the eve of the fifth anniversary of repeal, that a survey disclosed a link existed between poor recreational facilities and "temptation to excessive drinking."

Leaders of the American automobile industry, including heads of the General Motors, Chrysler, Ford and Packard companies, will be among the first witnesses tomorrow as the Temporary.National Economic Committee turns from an abstract consideration of the nation's economy to specific cases.

Boston's powerful Bruins scored four goals in the final period, three in 58 seconds, to shut out the Chicago Black. Hawks, 5 to. O, tonight and take undisputed possession of first place in the National Hockey League.

Back in 1875 Siegfried Samuel Marcus was ordered off the streets of Vienna together with his petroleum carriage. He made too much noise. Some eight years later Daimler and Benz astonished their fellow-Germans with mechanically propelled vehicles and aroused some derision.

There is no position for the on- pies, from long looker in religion's struggle against anything to u its enemies, the Rev. Dr. Albert W. work these mo, Beaven, president of the Colgate- "A man who Rochester Baptist Divinity School, declared yesterday in a sermon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
The writer learned today that Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, who was killed "while trying to escape," has been succeeded as leader of the Iron Guard by a lawyer, Jon Victor Vojen.

Inauguration of the first weekly world commodity price index, based on identical commodities and weights, ever to be offered to the public here was announced in a joint statement issued for publication today by General Motors Corporation and Cornell University.

German cormment on the impending ratification of the Franco-German non-aggression declaration reflects a sense of deep gratification over the attainment of a goal which, says the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, has animated German foreign policy for many years.
The Citizens Housing Council advanced objections yesterday to eight of the major proposals of Park Commissioner Robert Moses for his gigantic slum-clearance program.

Distributing its scoring activities evenly among the three periods, the New York Sporting Club gained a surprise 3 to 0 victory over the New York Athletic Club in a New York Amateur Hockey Association test at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

The first performance of Verdi's "Falstaff" since 1927, the debuts of Rise Stevens, American contralto; John Carter, American tenor, and Galliano Masini, Italian tenor,' will mark next week, the fourth week of the Metropolitan Opera season. Lily Pons and Szio Pinza will return for performances, and "Goetterdaemmerung," "Lucia di Lammermoor" and "Mignon" will enter the repertory of the season.
Negotiations between Germany and Czecho-Slovakia on a proposed currency union will begin in the next fewdays.

Administration farm officials said today that if cotton farmers rejected the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's marketing control program, in the referendum to be conducted next Saturday the government's $475,000,000 investment in cotton would be further im paired.

Two Soviet notables, who appeared to be headed for oblivion, are restablishing themselves. Sergey Eisenstein is again the Soviet's foremost motion picture director and Jacob Yusim; head of the huge Kaganovich ballbearing factory, today was defended by Pravda, official Communist party newspaper, against charges of bungling production.

Charles E. Merritt, lifelong resident of Greenwich, died today at his home at the age of 87. He was with the John Dayton shoe store and newspaper stand for fifty years. When he retired in 1926 he was manager and owner of both.

In announcing the Maria Moors Cabot prizes, a new annual award for the recognition of outstanding journalistic achievement in advancing sympathetic understanding between the peoples of North and South America, Dean Ackerman of the Columbia School of Journalism points out a definite shift

The United States gunboat Luzon left Hankow for Shanghai today, the first foreign warship permitted by Japanese to sail down the Yangtze since they gained control of that stretch of the river. [The Navy Department press office in Washington said yesterday that the movement of the Luzon had no significance as to policy and was a routine movement, either to relieve another ship or to bring missionaries or other civilians down the river.]

Miss Mallory Mixsell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell of 161 East Sixty-fourth Street and Locust Valley, L. I., will be married on the afternoon of Jan. 14 to E. Coe Kerr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kerr of 485 Park Avenue and Mill Neck, L. I. The ceremony will be performed in St. James Church by the rector, the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan.

Mrs. Helen'F. Ryan, 38 years old, who, as Helen Cressman, appeared in the Ziegfeld Follies in 1922, was discovered a suicide yesterday in her apartment at 315 Riverside Drive. She was found by the superintendent at 6 A. M., seated in the kitchen near a gas stove with a jet open.

Annual meeting. American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, 9:30 A. M. Sessions to Friday. Annual meeting, First and Second District Dental Societies, Hotel Pennsylvania, 10 A. M. Sessions to Friday.
Twelve persons were known dead and twenty injured tonight in a fire that de-. stroyed 400 Chinese-owned houses on the western border of the International Settlement.
Byron (Whizzer) White ended his one-season professional football career today with a flash of glory as the Cleveland Rams defeated the Pittsburgh-Pirates, 13 to 7.
Samuel B. Hanson, a Civil War veteran who was captured at the battle of Chickamauga and sent to Libby Prison by the Confederates, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 96.

Mrs. Lydia S. Mitchell Hinchman, a genealogist and writer who was active in charitable and women's club activities, died yesterday at her home here in her ninety-fourth year. She was the widow of Charles S. Hinchman.
One of the hardest things to realize is that, as we grow older, we our-selves become historical' documents.

The American people must be awakened to a realization of the weakness of their air defenses and convinced that they must spend money to strengthen them, Louis Johnson, assistant secretary of war, said in his annual report to Secretary Woodring, made public today.

Shallow living is responsible for much of the unrest and uncertainty which possesses the minds and its hearts of men today, the Rev. Leon Merle Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street,

An autopsy performed by Chief Medical Examiner Thomas A. Gonzales at the Bellevue morgue yesterday disclosed that Dr. Max Morgenstern, foreign exchange expert, had been murdered Dr. Gonzales reported that the economist had been the victim of a "homicidal assault" and had been beaten about the head.
The German wholesale price index on Nov. 30 stood at 106.2, against 106.3 a week before.

Telegraph service in Newfoundland returned to normal today after striking operators ended their two-day walkout. The strike followed representations for recognition of an agreement with the Newfoundland post telegraph division of the Commercial Telegraphers Union regarding wage increases and conditions of unemployment.

" Rose of Washington Square," a musical cavalcade of the years since tlie World War,. will go into production at Twentieth Century-Fox Dec. 19, with Roy Del Ruth directing. Tyrone Power, Alive Faye and Al Jolson will head the cast, and Nunnally Johnson, 'associate producer, is writing the scenario from the magazine story "I Love That Man,"
Production will begin today in a new mill built for the Clifton Paper Board Company at Clifton, N. J., by the Austin Company, engineers and builders. The new structure,

Trading here in stocks was at a low ebb last week because the public still fears that in spite of all precautions the enforced -realization of Jewishowned securities ultimately will depress prices unless the Reich adopts a plan for borrowing against the equities from commercial banks.

A plan for organization of a Class E group of leagues for textile and other mill towns where baseball interest runs high-and a change in the draft rule to permit major league teams to take two players from each team instead of one were classed by early arrivals today as likely bones of contention in the annual convention of the nar tion's thirty-seven minor leagues.

Thurman W. Arnold's :"Folklore of Capitalism" (Yale University Press) was voted first choice among the books 'published from Sept. 1, 1937, to Sept. 1, 1938 in a recent poll of the membership,. national advisory council and editorial committee of the Cooperative Book Club.
A "Citizens Rally Against Oppression," described as "more in the nature of a memorial," was called yesterday by Mayor La Guardia for Carnegie Hall at 8 o'clock Friday night.

A plea for a more legible Bible and for the, inclusion of the books of the Apocrypha in the Bible now used by Protestant churches was made yesterday by the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathe,dral of St. John the Divine, the 11 A. M. sermon at the cathedral.

At the annual reception given by President Charles Seymour of Yale University and Mrs. Seymour in the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts last night, and at a reception at the president's residence on Hillhouse Avenue in the afternoon, their daughter, Miss Sally Seymour, who is a freshman at Vassar, was introduced to society.

Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania came out today for the renomination of President Roosevelt. Declaring the 1940 Presidential campaign would be a history-making struggle between "the liberal democracy of Franklin D. Roosevelt" and "the camouflaged fascism of powerful financial and industrial interests masquerading under the colors of the Republican party," the Administration supporter added:

A series of broadcasts from seventeen nations, comprising a "Salute of Nations" to the World's Fair, will begin on New Year's Day, fair officials announced yesterday. Rulers and statesmen from the various countries will send messages and the weekly half-hour programs on Sundays from 1:30 to 2 P. M. will also carry characteristic music from each nation.
Bishop Shvoy of the Fejervar Diocese has forbade the playing of Wagner's "Lohengrin" and Mendelssohn's "Midsummer Night's Dream" wedding marches in all Catholic churches.

Echo Farm in Chester Township, Morris County, N. J., was bought by the Willmen Company from Dr. Rudolph F. Rabe of New York City. Title will be insured by the New Jersey Realty Title Insurance Company.

An 86-year-old woman, known to her neighbors in Corona, Queens, as "Grandma" because she was the matriarch of the neighborhood, was burned to death at 8 o'clock last night when a fire swept through her three-room apartment in a twostory frame dwelling at 105-03 Fifty-third Avenue.
James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, has entered the motion picture industry as vice president of Samuel Goldwyn, Inc., the producer announced today.

Motion-picture producers may have to show Latin Americans as supermen living under utopian conditions to escape censorship regulations which prohibit the exhibition of pictures that offend these countries.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The National Labor Relations Board, in its recent decision against the Inlan'd Steel Company, once again reads into the Wagner act implications which are not only unexpressed therein, but which are in no sense inferential.

The Anglican Church, of which the Episcopal Church is a living part, has never sacrificed truth to anything, the Rev. Gordon Wadhams, rector of the Episcopal Church of 'the Resurrection, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street, said there yesterday.

John Tierney of 137 Hamilton Place, a well-known trainer and judge of show horses, died Saturday night in Mount Sinai Hospital from the effects of a cerebral embolism. Born in Ireland sixty-seven years ago, he had lived here since early manhood.

James D. Mooney, vice president of General Motors Corporation in charge of overseas operations, returning yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia from a threemonth business trip through five European countries, said a "great" world economic revival depended on practical efforts to trade commercial and financial aid to the "have-not" nations in exchange for peace guarantees.

Representative Martin Dies of Texas, chairman of the House Committee investigating un-American activities, defended the committee and the results of its inquiry at a meeting last night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The meeting was under the auspices of the Rings County Allied War Veterans Association, opening a -drive in Kings County against communism, nazism, fascism and other influences.

After many weeks of pleading by Arab orange growers that their entire crop would be ruined unless shippers were able to transport oranges from groves to harbors in motor trucks, the Arab rebel headquarters has finally capitulated to the government's order requiring every male riding a motor vehicle to have a special military permit with a photograph attached.

The third recital in a series. in aid of the East Side House Settlement and its branch, the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery, -will take place tomorrow night in Carnegie' Hall. Marian Anderson, singer, will be the artist. Mrs. Flagler Matthews and Mrs. Rich Hollaman' are co;chairmen of the committee in charge, and Mrs. Ary, J. Lamme Jr. is president of beneficiary.
Cardinal Innitzer today inducted a new priest in Ottakring parish, in the poorer district of Vienna. The Cardinal was respectfully received by the public. There were no demonstrations.
The French weekly wholesale price index on Nov. 26 stood at 658, against 653 the week before.

General Francisco Franco is carrying out his threat to bomb his long list of towns in Loyalist Spain. Within the last three days seventeen different cities and villages, in both Government zones, have been attacked.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull, on his way with the United States delegation to the Pan-American Conference, pledged himself anew today to efforts to stimulate trade among the American nations. The Secretary said:

Charles F. Smith, chairman of the board of directors of Landers, Frary Clark for the last twenty years and prior to that its president for eighteen years, died today at his home here after a week's illness. His age was 77.

Sales volume and net profits of the Food Machinery Corporation fell sharply for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, but gross revenue from leased machinery processes and royalties rose 14 per cent to a new high, according to the annual report of John D. Crummy, president.

Colonel Philip Leffingwell Spalding, World War veteran, former president of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company and a partner in the banking firm of Estabrook Co., died today at his home in Milton after a six months' illness. His age was 67.

John C. L. Dreier, a stock broker who was formerly United States vice consul at Colon, C. Z., and in several European cities, died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage during his sleep Friday night at his residence, the Hotel Peter Cooper, 130 East Thirty-ninth Street. He was born in Burlington, Iowa, fifty-eight years ago.

beloved wife of Leonhard and mother of Leonard. Services Monday, 8 P. M.. Columbus Circle Chapel, 43 West 60th St. Interment Somerville, Mass. Boston papers please copy. BIGELOW-Suddenly, In Westport, Conn., Dec. 3, 1938, John Lawrence, beloved husband of Audrey Sherman Bigelow. Funeral services will be held at the Church of the Holy Trinity, Westport, on Monday, Dec. 5, at 11 A. M. Interment at convenience of family.
An angry demonstration by 500 French colonists against Italy's apparent campaign for Tunisia, French North African protectorate, caused disorders and bloodshed today.

Twenty-three persons were injured early today when a Miamibound bus from New York, driving through a dense fog, skidded on Roosevelt Boulevard near Cottman Street here, went off the road to -a grass plot and overturned, striking a tree.

Today's events: Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, Carnegie Hall, evening; "Orfeo ed Euridice," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Trio of New York, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Madeleine. Carabo, violinist, Town Hall, 3. Dr. Erich Schwebsch will give the first in a series of three weekly lectures on Wagner and the "Nibelungen Ring" this evening at Steinway Hall.

Capturing eleven of- her twelve bouts, Mrs. Aldo Nadi of the Aldo Nadi Studio-won the annual women's novice foils competition for, the Professor Ricardo Manrique Medal yesterday, at the Salle Santelli. Thirty-seven women fencers took- part in the four-hour program,.

The salty water of Jamnaica Bay rose in full tide with the brine of many tears yesterday as Billy Ray and his companion jokesters of Canarsie mourned over the inexorable fate of those who stand in the way of a new city highway.

Senator-elect Mead of New York said tonight that he would introduce resolutions in the next Congress to have the Labor Department investigate alleged discrimination by both private business and the Federal Government against workers over 40 years old.

The work of getting Madison Square Garden ready for the third annual North American Winter sports show and international ski meet, which opens a five-day stand tomorrow evening, began late last night.

Tames Seipser is in the trading department of Pelz Co. F. M. Mayer has announced that Henry W. Byrne has become associated with him to specialize in foreign securities, foreign moneys and. blocked currencies.

Tossed out of his airplane 1,800 feet in the air and dangling by a single leg strap while the pilotless plane hurtled toward the ground, Daniel Cleveland, 24, of Somerville, today cheated death by a matter of seconds.

The engagement of Miss Marilynn Ruth Munn daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. P. Munn of this place, to John H. Mennie, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. S. Mennie of Montclair, N. J., has been announced by her parents.

Commerce Ave (14-3856), s e cor of Butler P1, 104x84 it; William H. Mallett to George Joseph. 80 Westchester Sq; 5 years, 5 per cent; $10,000. In wood Ave (11-2859), e s, 199 ft n of 172d St, 86x157 ft; Harold R. Tether to Willard L. Tether, 15 De Witt -Ave, Bronxville, N. Y.; 10 years, 5 per cen; $30,000.

This map of Central Berlin indicates changes that will go into effect tomorrow. From the district shown in diagonal shading Jews will be excluded unless they have police permits. Part of the north side of Unter den Linden, where the War Dead Memorial stands, is included. Many government buildings are in this area. Exclusions also extend to sport fields, rinks, amusement places and museums.

Wages and hours legislation in action will be the theme of the thirty-eighth annual meeting of the National Consumers League to be held this Friday at the Hotel Astor. Among those who will discuss the problem are Major Arthur L. Fletcher, assistant administrator in charge of enforcing the Federal Wages and Hours Law. and Frieda S. Miller, New York State Industrial Commissioner.

Reorganization of the Sheriffs' offices of New York and Queens Counties to effect a saving of $155,000 a year and to increase the efficiency of the offices is recommended in a report by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, which Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday.

The President Roosevelt of the United States Lines is due to arrive today from the Channel ports. Her passenger list includes Edward G. Pickett, Dr. E. E. Jelley, M. J. Farrell, Mr. and Mrs. William Douglas Read and. Miss Ethel M. Johnson.

West Houston St, 112; Pioneer Towel ana Linen Service, Inc, to James. F. de La Motte, 6,809 No Ashland Ave, Chicago; mtg $20,500, not to merge in fee. Same property, James F. de La Motte to 112 West Houston St Corp, 160 Lincoln Blvd, Long Beach, N Y; mtg $13,710 ($4.50). Madison St, 176; Gisela Gehben to Cedric Daub, 368 Eastern ,Parkway, Brooklyn; purchase-money mtg .$3,000 ($5),

There is no true inalienable right, for our natural rights "are tied up with our worship of Almighty God," Mhgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at the fourth annual communion breakfast of the Catholic Social Workers (in Civil Service) Guild of the City of New York in the Hotel Astor.

Faced with the necessity of raising $25,000 to restore the beauty of the campus, which was devastated by the September hurricane, Robert I. Laggren of New York, chairman of the Wesleyan University Alumni Council committee on finance, has issued a special appeal for funds to the alumni.

The Commercial Telegraphers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, charged today that the National Labor Relations Board had ignored the legal rights of employes in ordering a nationwide election among employes of the Postal Telegraph Company to determine their collective. bargaining representative.

Tentative assignment". for the 1942 Federa-; tional Internationale de Ski championships,' in the event- they are awarded to the United--States at the congress -in Poland'. next February, were made today by the National Ski. Association in convention.

In the hope of conserving 20,000,000 gallons of water a day,. now lost through underground leaks in the water mains and service lines of this city, the WPA will spend $1,360,000 in the next twelve months on water control surveys here, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

If, in the midst of poverty, we 'still find that "valiant dust that builds on dust" it is only because hope dies so hard in the human heart. But in want itself there is nothing ennobling. It is a dark shadow in which pain and terror multiply.
The Pacific Electric Railway Company's October net revenues from traction operations rose 63.3 per cent to $104,478, compared with $63,985 in the same month a year ago.

Chicago's stock yards strike, called on Noy. 21, is over. Through the mediation of Mayor Edward J. Kelly the striking C. I. O. union gave final acceptance to peace terms this morning. Late in the afternoon workers went back to their jobs and livestock from near-by points began to roll in on trucks.

Leaders of settlement house work in twenty American cities, meeting in New York yesterday as the governing body of the National Federation of Settlements, issued a statement urging positive action by the United States in aiding refugees and curbing the march of the dictatorships.
That the failure of the general strike was expected was evidenced by the firmness of the Bourse from the beginning of the week.
Federation of Labor officials today drafted a proposed new wage agreement which sugar-cane workers hope to have accepted by the sugar producers for the season commencing in January.

Plans for modernizing houses Manhattan were announced over the week-end in connection with latest sales. In Greenwich Village, the fivestory apartment at 44 Perry Street was sold by the 44 Perry Street Corporation to the Quill Realty Corporation. The indicated consideration was $24,000 and the seller took back a purchase-money mortgage of $20,000 for five years.
" The God Who Speaks" was the topic of the sermon delivered yesterday in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, by the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker.

The Detroit Lions lost a chance to tie the Green Bay Packers for the Western Division title in the National Football League when they suffered a stunning 21-to-7 upset at the hands of the Philadelphia Eagles in their final game today.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.4, which compared with 80.5 the week before, 80.4 two weeks before, 80.5 three weeks before and 80.4 four weeks before.
Supply contracts valued at $2,506,842 were awarded during the week ended Nov. 26 by thirteen Federal agencies. under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

The first comprehensive effort by representatives of Federal, State and local governments in New York State -to- "think through" the financing and direction of relief willbe made late this month or early next month .at a conference to be called by the State Department of Social Welfare.

Another in the series of bridge I teas for the West Sixty-third Street Community House will be held this afternoon in its headquarters, 149 West Sixty-third Street. Mrs. M. Frazier Clark is president of the settlement and Mrs. Elwood Horton heads the group in charge of the arrangements.

A wage board composed of repre sentatives of employers, employes and the public was appointed yesterday by Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, to recommend minimum wages and maximum hours for women and minors employed in the cleaning and dyeing industry of New York State.

At his recital last night in Town Hall Jan Smeterlin, Polish pianist, devoted himself entirely to works by Chopin. From the rich store of his compatriot's compositions Mr. Smeterlin had selected as chief offerings the sonata in B minor, the "Polonaise Fantasy," the scherzo in E major and the "Ballade" in A flat major. The list also contained several of the composer's preludes, mazurkas and etudes.

The threatened strike of drivers and matrons on 155 buses of the Children's Bus Service, Inc., scheduled for this morning, was averted yesterday for at least three days through the intervention of Mayor La Guardia.

Discussing the trade situation and outlook in Great Britain, the Midland Bank in its monthly bulletin remarks that business appears now to be running on an even keel at a level substantially below that of 1937.
First-place Brookhattan fell victim to the lowly Brooklyn Hispano in an American Soccer League game before 4,000 at Starlight Park in the Bronx yesterday, 3 to 2. The halftime score was 1-all.

Earl De La Warr, President of the Board of Education, addressed a blunt warning to Germany tonight in- a speech that he as a Cabinet Minister presumably could not have delivered without Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain'S consent.

Among those who believe in the American system, Elmer Rice is one of the most sincere. He defends it with considerable highmindedness in "American Landscape," which the Playwrights Company put on at the Cort on Saturday evening.

Mayor La Guardia praised Acting Commissioner Irving V. A. Huie yesterday for the work of the Department of Public Works in completing a new non-skid concrete roadway on the lower deck of Manhattan Bridge without any interruption in traffic.

With the expenditure of more than $1,500,000 for philanthropic programs, chiefly educational, in the past two years, three-fourths of the Julius Rosenwald Fund's endowment' of $20,000,000 has been disbursed and at the present rate of expenditure the endowment will be consumed within a decade, it was revealed today in the biennial report of Edwin R. Embree, president of the fund.

A witness who told the Dies committee that Briggs Local 212 of the United Automobile Workers "was dominated by radicals" was expelled from the local today for a period "not to exceed ninety-nine years and a day."
The congregation of St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street, in Greenwich Village, celebrated the church's eightieth anniversary yesterday.

Sixty years of passenger service on the Sixth Avenue elevated line ended at 11:26 last night when the crowded "second section" of the last northbound train from Rector Street pulled into the station at Fifty-third Street and Eighth Avenue.
A fight to the finish seems to have begun over yesterday's strike on the French liner Normandie, which was called because of the dismissal of sixty workers.

While we were tramping the snow-covered-ridges in the Catskills after deer, hundreds of impatient quail hunters were following their dogs over the North Carolina fields in search of those feathered gamesters.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Investment buying of houses featured latest realty trading in Brooklyn. Wesleyan University sold the apartment house at 953 President Street in the Park Slope section. The buyer intends to alter the building, according to John F. James Sons, Inc., brokers in the deal.

One of the larger benefit theatre parties of the early Winter will take place at tomorrow evening's performance of "Great Lady" at the Majestic Theatre. Beneficiary of the event will be the Music School Settlement, which, since its founding forty-five years ago, has inspired many similar undertakings in other cities throughout the country.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that he had sent letters to department stores and the Hotel Owners Association warning them of fire hazards in Christmas trees and decorations and in other conditions due to the holiday season..

A meal almost 100 per cent of South Carolina grown products served on a set of china made ini England' more than 100 years ago for. President. James Monroe will be laid before President Roosevelt when he breakfasts here tomorrow morning as the guest of Governor Johnston.

The twenty-seventh annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York began yesterday with ninety. contributions totaling $30,551.97 in hand. As in past years, the appeal on behalf of those unfortunates whose distress is the greatest known to exist throughout the entire. city was anticipated by-many old friends of the Neediest Cases Fund even before the publication of the Hundred

Three French policemen and an Italian marine were wounded in shooting that developed early today when the police sought to quell a barroom brawl between sailors and marines of the two governments' defense units here.

A labor contract calling for an average pay cut of 111/2 per cent was voted yesterday by the Phoenix Hosiery Company, local of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers (C. I. O.), it was announced by Harry Bragarnick, volunteer mediator.

AntiJewish legislation in the form of restrictions for Jews in trade, industry and the professions is being prepared by the Camp of National Unity, which obtained a majority of 70 per cent in the last parliamentary elections.

Officers of trade organizations representing 50,000 manufacturing, processing and other business enterprises throughout the country' will gather at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel today for a two-day executive session of the National Industrial Council.
A daughter was born this morning to the Countess of Paris, wife of the Count of Paris, son of the pretender to the French throne.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Quantrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest E. Quantrell of Bronxville and Eastern Point, Conn., to Harry E. Sloan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sloan of Hartford, Conn.

The Poor Richard Club announced today that David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of 'Amerlca and chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company, would receive its 1938 gold medal of achievement.

262d St (13-3423Q), a e cor of Tyndall Ave, 45x100; George Stevenson to Dennek Building Corp, Mosholu Ave, Broadway. Tiebout Ave (11-3145), w a. 85 ft s of 183d St, 33x87: Jerome Lang to Mary Ziplow, 115 W. 168th St; mtg $271,000. Fenton Ave, 3,335 (16-4347); Sari Eisner to Milton Nussbaum, 128 South Grove St, Freeport, N. Y.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,974,282,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

George Cardinal Mundelein, Archbishop of Chicago, returned yesterday from a visit to Rome. He was taken off the Italian liner Conte di Savoia by the tugboat Eugene F. Moran at Quarantine at 7 A. M. and landed at Pier A, North River.
Hans Borchers, German Consul General in New York, protested yesterday against "the daily presentation of the German character to the world as a mixture of crudeness and arrogance."

In a Summer-like day out on Long Island Sound, thirty sailing dinghies competed today in the regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club and the winners were Bud Moxham, in his Class B boat Stingaree II, and Pete Turnev in his craft Jumbo.

The Ulster Anti-Partition Council today sent to President Roosevelt and the British, Canadian and Australian Prime Ministers a warning that the North Ireland situation was "fraught. with grave dangers."

Latin-American countries are preparing to push hard at the- forthcoming PanAmerican conference to force the United States to put the Good Neighbor policy into a concrete form that will insure. its continuance after the termination of President Roosevelt's administration.

Although steel operations were off 1 or 2 points last. week, at 60 to 61 per cent of capacity, the showing nevertheless was favorable in the respect that this was the fourth successive week in which steel-ingot production ran at the rate of more than 40,000,000 tons a year.

QUEENS Gross assets, $49,548: net, $39,546. To widow Barbara Hafner.. life estate in $10,000 residue to children Elisabeth Zimmersbach, William Hafner, Wilhelmine Calcagno, Olga Riebling. Emma Roegelein and Frank Hafner. Chief assets, modtgages and shares, $39,000. George P. Stier, attorney, 161-19 Jamaica Ave., Jamaica.

The House of Commons today unanimously accepted the report of a select committee mildly criticizing Secretary of State for War Leslie Hore-Belisha and Attorney General Sir Donald Somervell for their handling of the Sandys case. Thus the incident was relegated to the history of parliamentarv liberties.

Uptown Properties, Inc., was the broker in the recent sale of the tenement houses at 112 West Houston Street for James de La Motte, and 526 East Sixteenth Street for Medora G. Cox, to the 112 West Houston Street Corporation; also, 176 Madison Street for Gisela Gehben to Cedric Daub.
Funeral services for William H. Dunstone, a former industrial instructor in Yonkers public schools, who died Friday at his home in Manchester, Conn., were held here today. He was 76 years old.

Dividend Shares, Inc.-Year to Oct. 31: Total assets with securities priced at market quotations were $46,890,696, compared with $35,359,359 on Oct. 31. 1937. Investments carried in the balance sheet as of Oct. 31 last at $34,273,423 had a market value on that date of $36,183,506, compared with $32,973,950 and $31,536,950, respectively, on Oct. 31, 1937.

Agents of the Rome-Berlin axis have begun a determined battle to prevent the formation at the Eighth Pan-American Conference of any Pan-American axis that might strengthen the United States' influence in South and Central America at the cost of German and Italian influence.

G. G. COULTON of Cambridge University has G. spent a scholar's lifetime in study and investigation of the Middle Ages, particularly the English phases, and during the past thirty years has written many books for specialists in the field. Now he offers a synthesis for the general reader--for the "professional. or business man or artisan who has some leisure for quiet thoughtful browsing"--under the title "Medieval Panorama."

The Trio of New York-Carl Friedberg, piano; Daniil Karpilowsky, violin, and Felix Salmond, 'cellowas heard in the third of its series of five concerts last night at Town Hall. The program consisted of three great items of the trio literature: the Brahms C major, Op. 87;

William T. Van Alstyne, an attorney, was elected president of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York for the third consecutive time at the annual meeting in Fraunces Tavern, Broad and Pearl Streets, yesterday afternoon. A hundred members attended.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It may come as a surprise to some Americans to learn that the United States constitutes today the only "international" center in the world in fact and not on paper.

Use of existing parks or open spaces for automobile storage and the prevalence of unsightly motor parking areas throughout the city are condemned by the Civic Design Committee of the New York'Chapter of the American Institute of Architects in its report. on "the motor blight problem," made public yesterday.
Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward, assistant Administrator of the Works Progress Administration, and members of the Dies committee investigating unAmerican activities, disputed frequently today.

The Sixth Avenue elevated structure was sold for $80,000 yesterday at auction on the City Hall steps to George L. Weissbaum, a West Coast scrap metal dealer, who will obtain the 17,000 tons of structural steel and the 2,800 tons of rails if the sale is confirmed today by the Board of Estimate.

Tonight's events: Beniamino Gigli, tenor, Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30; Marian Anderson, contralto, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Gari Shelton, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Harold and Marion Kahn Berkley, sonatas for violin and piano, Steinway Hall, 8:30; Goeta Ljungberg, soprano; Walter Bricht, pianist; Guido Brand, violinist, 13 East Sixty-seventh Street, 8:30; Donald Craig, baritone, Studio Club, 5.

Work is being completed on the extension of a small railway on Vincent Astor's estate, "Ferry Reach," which will bring the exsting system within a few yards of the estate's private stop on the Bermuda Railway.
Edsel Ford, who testified at the Monopoly Committee hearing today, said afterward that he felt business was improving, as indicated by the situation in the automobile industry.

Holding a 15-11 lead at the half, the Boys High quintet opened its N Section 1, Brooklyn P. S. A. L. schedule by downing Thomas Jefferson, 29-25, on the Boys court yesterday. It was the first setback in two tournament starts for Jefferson.

Considerable spottiness has developed in Christmas shopping thus far, with the trend indicating the volume of sales is not keeping pace with the increase in the crowds in the stores and that major attention centers on less expensive merchandise, retail executives here said yesterday.

Foreign Ministers von Ribbentrop and Bonnet will sign the German-French non-aggression accord in Paris today. A sign that Germany also intended important negotiations was seen in the fact that Herr von Ribbentrop will have a staff of ten collaborators.

Individual directors responsible for the management of Loew's, Inc., were accused yesterday of practicing "nepotism" in a supplemental bill of particulars served during the trial of a suit to restrain the corporation from entering employment contracts with a number of officials. The trial is taking place before Supreme Court Justice Valente.

After Jan. 1 a person making a local 5-cent telephone call from a hotel lobby telephone exchange cannot be charged more than 5 cents for it, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday. If the call is made from a guest room, however, the call may cost 10 cents as at present, according to the commission's decision.

Present and former members of the choir of St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, L. I.. are uniting in giving a song program on the afternoon of Dec. 28 at the MacDowell Club to raise funds for the restoration of the church's organ, which was damaged in the recent hurricane.

Madeleine Carabo, a young Amerlcan violinist who studied in Chicago and New York and has played in the Middle West, made her local debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Although she listed a far-ranging program of works by Vitali, Vivaldi-Respighi, Schelling, Lalo and others, it served no better purpose than to reveal her palpable unreadiness for the serious test of a New York debut.

The quarter-final bracket in the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament at the Columbia University Club was filled yesterday as six players joined J. J. Lordi, top-seeded star, and E. G. McLaughlin, ranked fifth, in the round of eight. Lordi and McLaughlin advanced last Saturday.
Fred Mosely of the St. Nicholas Hockey Club led his team to a fourth straight league victory at the expense of the Westchester Victorias at the Imperial Ice Arena tonight, 3--0.

Mr. and Mrs. Ira Barrows gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 860 Park Avenue, for their niece, Miss Anne Rowland, debutante daughter of Mrs. William o. Rowland Jr. of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Rowland. American beauty roses and tea roses were used in the decorations. At the tea table was Mrs. William Copper Dickey.

The United States Court of Appeals sustained today a lower court decision which denied a petition by twentytwo coal companies to enjoin the Coal Commission from making public individual production cost figures.

A man was killed and his wife was injured seriously here this evening when the coupe in which they were riding was in collision with The Broker, a Pennsylvania Rairlroad express train, at the Eighth Avenue crossing.

An issue of 100,000 shares of Michigan Gas and Oil Corporation $10 par value 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock is to be offered today by Keeler, Baker Co., Inc., at a price of $10 a share plus accrued. dividend.

The Yale University Press will publish, in February, the American edition of Lloyd George's "Memoirs of the Peace Conference," which has appeared recently in England under the title "The Truth About the Peace Treaties."

The day is not far away when the National Guard, which automatically becomes units of the regular army in time of war, will be ready to play its full part in a national emergency, Major Gen. Albert H. Blanding chief of the National Guard Bureau, stated in his annual report to the Secretary of War, made publie today.

Treasury financing made public yesterday by Secretary Morgenthau carry the hint that this financing may be the last of the government issues to carry the exemption inducement. Mr. Morgenthau revealed that the offering this month would be the lone opportunity for holders of the maturing notes to exchange them for other interest-bearing obligations.

Rocco Grella, a contractor who built more than 100 miles of cement sidewalks in the North Shore communities, died last night at his home here. He was 57 years old and had lived in Glen Cove for thirty years.
Under pressure from the India Office, a film based on the relief of Lucknow during the Indian mutiny in 185758, whose shooting was begun a week ago, has been abandoned.

Penitentiary terms were imposed yesterday on two men whose arrest last Summer uncovered a racket through which "stand-ins" were being used in Special Sessions by horse-race bookmakers with a record of previous convictions to evade heavy fines or jail terms as repeated offenders.

When a man falls out of the sky and falls back in again what are his reactions? According to Daniel Cleveland of Brookline, Mass., a flier and a camera addict to whom this happened, there aren't any at the time.

The years ahead are years of rising taxes, bringing a period of "profitless prosperity," A. W. Zelomek, economist for the International Statistical Bureau, Inc., and the Fairchild Publications, warned last night at a meeting of the Associated Corset and Brassiere Manufacturers of New York at the Hotel McAlpin.
J. Francis Hayden, Manhattan attorney, was re-elected president of the New York Young Democratic Club at a meeting of the organization held last night in the Hotel Commodore.

The ever-mounting toll of bombed Loyalist towns, the growing intensity of the Rebel air offensive and Rebel preparations for a great attack against Catalonia all combined today to make governmental Spain realize that one of the critical periods of the war had begun.

ADAMS--Dec. 5, at his home, 123 East 80th St., Hugh White, husband of Mary Ostrander, son of the late Hugh White and Caroline B. Adams. Service St. Bartholomew's Chapel, Park Ave. and 51st St., Wednesday, 2 P. M.

Although there were few knockouts, the finals of the third annual New York Journal-American Diamond Belt Boxing Tournament at the Hippodrome last night provided plenty of thrills for the 4,000 spectators.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Richard W. Jones Jr., Engr.-Res., 51 Van Siclen Ave., Brooklyn, Y., is ordered to active duty with the CCC for a period of six months, effective Dec. 5, at headquarters Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady, N. Y., for duty as assistant district quartermaster. Date of rank: Nov. 20, 1933. He will revert to an inactive status June 4, 1939.

Formally accepting Finland's invitation to the 1940 games, the American Olympic Committee took official cognizance for the first time last night that the scene of the international show had been changed from Tokyo to Helsingfors. The meeting of the A. O. C.

R. A. Hohfeler has resigned as controller of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., as well as treasurer of its subsidiary companies, effective Feb. 1, 1939, it was announced yesterday. R. P. Connally, president of the corporation, said yesterday no successor has been appointed.

Chinese military authorities said today that the Japanese were preparing to outflank China's defense forces in the south by an invasion of Kwangsi Province. they said that Japanese warships were massed in the Gulf of Tongking and had started shelling Pakhoi, seventy miles east of the French Indo-China border.

Three torpedo boats--Branlebas, Bouclier and L'Incomprise--arrived off Havre this evening and it is reported that men from their engine rooms and crews will be used if necessary to assure the sailing of the French liner Paris Wednesday despite the shipping strike here.

The seventy-two-family apartment building containing 236 rooms at 1,425-27 Wythe Place, the Bronx, has been sold by the Clarris Realty Corporation to a client of Goodman Mabel, attorneys. It is a sixstory structure on a plot 150 by 100 feet and was sold through Wadsworth Co., Inc., brokers. Isidore Witkind represented the seller.
Mrs. Elizabeth M. Day, active in civic and social affairs for the last twenty-five years and the wife of Winsor B. Day, died today after a brief illness.

Leopold Godowsky, noted composer, pianist and teacher, who died Nov. 21 in his sixty-eighth year, left his estate. in equal shares, to his three children, it was revealed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

Low grades of patent leathers, known as "cattle side patents," were advanced 1/2 cent a foot by leading producers yesterday, following advances of 3 to 3 1/2 cents foot in the last few months. This brought prices just above the levels prevailing a year ago, from which they had dropped during the light trading early this year.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York voted yesterday at a meeting here to seek permissive legislation at the forthcoming session of the Legislature to make possible a central insurance association form of operation of savings banks life insurance in addition to the provisions of the present law. The matter was referred to the committees of the association for further action.
Mrs. Phoebe Abrams, 85-year-old cripple, was burned to death here tonight in the small frame house in which she was born, when an oil stove was overturned and the house burned to the ground.

Chancer lor John G. Bowman, defending his "strictly amateur" athletic policy at the University of Pittsburgh, told 350 alumni and athletes tonight he wanted "a football team above criticism." The -chancellor pleaded with the alumni to go ahead with him "in one direction and find the answer to the-real question," which he defined as:

A $100,000 mortgage loan at 4 1/2 per cent on the taxpayer at 124-30 West 125th Street has been arranged .for Thomas F. Morris, representing the Avonzel Corporatior, owners of the structure. The Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., was the broker.

Members of the New York Southern Society have completed plans for the dinner dance they will give tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the society's fifty-third anniversary. Large reception and floor committees have been organized to assist with details of the event.

Pete Scalzo scored a major upset last night when he knocked out Joey Archibald, recognized by the New York State Athletio Commission as world featherweight champion, in 2:10 of the second round of their scheduled ten-round feature boxing engagement at the St. Nicholas Palace before 4,000 persons.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an order directing the Associated Gas and Electrio Company to file with it, not later than Dec. 17, a statement containing the investments of itself and each of its subsidiaries.

Funeral services were held last night for Henry Valentine Jr., who was a member of the police force from 1896 until his retirement in 1924, at the Nast Chapel, Broadway and Thirty-seventh Street, Astoria, Queens. Mr. Valentine, who was 72 years old, died on Saturday in Port Chester. N. Y.

Little Darvey O'Brien (and he is little), who no more looks like a football player than does one of Singer's Midget, arrived here early last night to receive the John W. Heisman Memorial Trophy at a dinner at the Downtown Athletic Club tonight. The 150-pound, 5-foot 7inch star of Texas Christian

The fact that New York tears down its elevated roads after sixty years and its tall buildings after a much shorter life must not delude us into thinking that everything on Manhattan Island is so transitory.
Steel operations are. scheduled at 59.9 per cent this week, as comPared to 60.7 per cent last week, a decrease of 0.8 point, or 1.3 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

William U. Moyer, controller of the Pennsylvania Hotel, New York, and former assistant to the president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, died at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital here Saturday after an illness of several months. He was 57 years old.

Following is the text of President, Roosevelt's address at the University of North Carolina today: The late Justice Cardozo of the Supreme Court wrote a few years ago: "We live in a world of change. If a body of law were in existence adequate for the civilization of today, it could not meet the demands of tomorrow. Society is inconstant.

Following a three-day steady decline which carried prices on the New York Cotton Exchange off over $2 a bale, the market developed resistance yesterday and a recovery left the list unchanged to 3 points up.

Chess players will never cease to marvel at the contrast between the record made by Reuben Fine of New York in the first six rounds of the recent A. V. R. O. international tournament, in which he won five games and drew one, and his score in the next eight rounds, in which he captured only one more, albeit that was against Dr. Alexandre Alekhine.

Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the second time this season, beginning the third week of the current term. A large audience received the work, which was revived in a new production in the opening week of the season, with enthusiastic applause.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Thomas Kiernan of New York City was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 51-Armstrong Paint and Varnish Works, petr., v. Nu-Enamel Corp., an Illinois corporation, et al. On writ of cert. to the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals. Decree affirmed and cause remanded to the U. S. District for the Northern District of Ill. Opinion by Justice Reed.
New War Department regulations decreed today that the entire army, aside from cavalry and artillery horsemen, must don civilian-type trousers by Feb. 1.

Two hundred persons, including social workers, college professors, tenement dwellers and agriculturists, paid tribute last night to the memory of Dr. Caroline Whitney, chairman of the Milk Consumers Protective Committee, at a meeting at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

Pensioned Fireman First Grade Philip H. Clare, H. and L. Co. 130, is retired on an annual pension of $1,500 per annum. to take effect from 12:01 A. M. Jan. 1, 1939. Fireman Fourth Grade Arthur Sherman Jr., Engine Co. 154, is retired on an annual pension of $666.66 per annum, to take effect from 9 A. M. Jan. 1, 1939.

The Farm Security. Administration an nounced today that during the first year's operation of the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act, 1,885 farm tenants, sharecroppers and laborers obtained funds to. buy farms of their. own, averaging 130 acres. The average loan to finance the farm purchase was $4,890 but the average borrower spent only $4,077 for the farm itself, using an additional $804 for repairs and improvements to the property.

Mrs. Florence Drakeford.returned home from a neighborhood. grocery today just as- firemen were 'carrying the charred bodies of two of her children from the makingg ruins of her four-room cottage near River Road here.

Accepting a strike settlement negotiated by Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, members of Flint Local No. 581 voted by acclamation tonight that the 6,600 employes of Fisher Body Plant No. 1 would return to work tomorrow.

Citing the world's attitude toward refugees as a symptom of its unwillingness to "make substantial sacrifices for peace," Oswald Pirow, South Africa's Minister of Defense, predicted today that Europe would slide into war by next Spring unless present tendencies were checked.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn has awarded $1,378,082 to 415 owners of property taken by the city for the approach in Queens County to the new $18,000,000 Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, the completion of which will provide for motorists a direct express highway connection between the World's Fair in Queens and the parkways of upper New York State and New England.

In an extremely easy money market the Treasury sold its weekly offering of $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day discount bills today at an average price of 99.996, equivalent to a rate of approximately 0.017 per cent, a sizable drop from the average interest rate of 0.021 per cent which was paid on an issue sold last Monday.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 30:

The necessity for new local emer. agency taxes to finance relief if the city's efforts to obtain additional relief funds are unsuccessful was forecast last night when Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick predicted a $7,700,000 deficit in relief financing for the year ending June 30, 1939.

Working quickly and in the line of vision of passers-by, four armed thugs, one 'of whom' carried a machine gun and another a sawedoff shotgun, held seventeen employes at bay yesterday in the Consolidated Edison branch office at Audubon Avenue and West 166th Street, forced one of the employee to open the safe,

Plans for a cooperative promotion next Spring designed to add about $1,000,000 to retail stationers' volume have been adopted and will be also completed this week, it was stated yesterday by H. C. Whittemore, general manager of the Wholesale Stationers Association of the United States, 250 Fifth Avenue, under whose auspices the event will be held.

Fordham football players earned four places on the N. Y. U. all-opponents team as chosen by the Violet squad, it was announced yesterday. Three from North Carolina were named while Ohio State gained two places. The remaining positions went to Lafayette and Colgate performers.

A strike of editorial, commercial and circulation employes of The Chicago Herald and Examiner and The Chicago Evening American of the William Randolph Hearst newspaper chain was called early today by the Chicago local of the American Newspaper Guild, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Funeral services for George C. Tillou of Hyde Park, who died at his home Saturday at the age of 81, were held today. Burial was in East Park Cemetery.
At the annual meeting of the Security Traders Association of New York, Benjamin H. Van Keegan of Frank C. Masterson Co. was elected president of the association for 1939, to succeed Harold B. Smith.

The Harvard Club strengthened its hold on first place in the Metropolitan League Class B squash racquets tournament by conquering the Yale Club, 4 to 1, on the latter's courts last night. The victory was the sixth for the Crimson in as many starts.
The City Council tonight rescinded its recent ordinance providing for a tax on main stores this year and immedi-tely enacted a similar levy to take effect in 1939.

An entertainment entitled the Cinderella Ball, for the benefit of Irvington House in Irvington-onHudson, N. Y., will take place the night of Dec. 29 in the Roof Garden of the St. RegiS. Members of the program committee will meet Friday at the home of Mrs. Peter Lehman to discuss further plans for the entertainment.
The Federal Government's tax policies drew fire from two witnesses who appeared today before the Senate Committee on Profit-Sharing.

At least five persons were dead last night and many others injured as the result of a dense fog that covered most of the eastern coast of the United States yesterday. Occasional heavy rain thinned the mist blanket.
Counsel for Thomas J. Mooney failed today in the Supreme Court in another move designed to free the California convict from San Quentin Penitentiary.

Nine members of the Police Department, including a captain, a lieutenant, a sergeant-and six patrolmen, have been charged with departmental violations growing out of the theft of 7,200 police arrest records from the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn on Oct. 15, it was revealed yesterday.

A public hearing has been called for Saturday by the Securities and Exchange Commission under terms of the Public Utility Holding Company Act on an amended declaration by the Monongahela West Penn Public Service Company for issuance of 200,000 shares of $15-par value common capital stock to the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., of which it is a subsidiary, for $3,000.000.

Early reports indicated today a heavy over-subscription to the Treasury's offering, made this morning, of $400,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent longterm bonds and 1 1/8 per cent fiveyear notes for cash, and Secretary Morgenthau announced late in the day that the books on cash subscriptions had been closed at the close of business today, with the provision that subscriptions placed in the mails before midnight tonight would be received.
War Minister Leslie Hore-Belisha named new officers to four key military jobs today .in the third big turnover since he took control, of Britain's army eighteen months ago.

The Bank of Montreal received a measurable increase in commercial loans this year "despite great uncertainty in respect to the immediate future," Sir Charles Gordon, president, reported at the annual meeting in Montreal yesterday.
The Export-Import Bank at Washington will lend Cuba $50,000,000, Pedro Martinez Fraga, Cuban Ambassador to the United States, said here, tonight.

The commercial building at 2 John Street, corner of Broadway, will be extensively remodeled next Spring as the result of a lease just J negotiated by Tankoos, Smith Co. with the Horn Hardart Company for expansion of the Automat A restaurant at that address.

The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association rose during the week ended Dec. 3. The index, based on the 1926-1928 average, was 73.3 last week, compared with 73.2 for the preceding week, 72.9 a month ago and 78.7 a year ago. Reliable livestock quotations were not available because of the stockvards strike in Chicago.

An attempt was mane yesterday by the Iron Guard to assassinate the head of a military court at Cernauti, Colonel Cristescu. He was shot and wounded in the neck by two youthful students. This court had sentenced seventytwo students to prison.

Dick Powell's abandonment of musical comedy in favor of dramatic films, a point over which the actor and Warners have argued for two years, has been accomplished. Today the studio announced that Powell would be featured in a serious role in "A Young Man's Fancy," an original story by Norman Reilly Raines.

Last night's performance of "Victoria Regina" was canceled because of the illness of its star, Helen Hayes, who was confined to her homes in Nyack with a mild case of ptomaine poisoning. The office of Gilbert Miller, the play's producer, said that Miss Hayes will return for tonight's performance. Last night's tickets were exchanged, or their cost price refunded.

The two-story single-family dwelling at 42-27 248th Street, Little Neck, L. I., was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Mrs. Mary E. Ivers of the Bronx who will occupy it. The RomanCaswell Company, Inc., negotiated the sale.

Associated Breweries of Canada, Ltd., has declared an extra dividend of 45 cents in addition to the regular quarterly of 20 cents on the common stock. Last year an extra of 25 cents was paid on the common.

Roger Butler Williams 2d, a New York broker, died today in Tompkins County Memorial Hospital from a stroke suffered a week ago. A former resident of Ithaca, Mr. Williams was 58 years old. He came here for an operation three weeks ago.

The State Department's wooing of Cuba with possibilities of tariff reductions on sugar, rum and tobacco has caused the wail in Puerto Rico that Washington has hard-heartedly turned against an island family member to stress kindly neighborliness in another direction.

The Supreme Court today rejected that part of a National Labor Relations Board order directing the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and its subsidiaries to abrogate contracts with the International Brotherhood 'of Electrical Workers, an American Federation of Labor affiliate.

The manner in which the automobile industry uses the patent system to advance the arts and sciences, as contemplated by the Constitution, obviously impressed members of the Temporary National Economic Committee today as they turned from a "prologue" of economic abstractions to consider the automobile industry as the first step in the patent phase of the inquiry.

The five-story office structure, known as the National Bank of North Hudson Building, at 147 Summit Avenue, Union City, N. J., has been sold by Robert G. Wienceke, receiver of the National Bank of North Hudson to the Jaclar Realty Company which will hold it for investment.

Favorites lost six of seven races at the Fair Grounds today as most of the winners returned attractive prices. The feature was a six-furlong dash in which R. A. Coward's Waxwing, with A. LoTurco up, set a fast pace and stood a hard drive to win from Mrs. A. M. Creech's Miss Dolphin, who closed ground from a slow start.
The Insular Supreme Court today upheld a ten-year prison sentence against Domingo Saltari Crespo, who attempted to assassinate Resident Commissioner Santiago Igleslas during the 1936 campaign.

Marquis H. Lockwood, patent attorney, with an office at 2 Rector Street, died suddenly early yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 301 West 121st Street. He was born in Marshall County, Kan., sixty-eight years ago.

A meeting of the National Trotting Association, oldest governing body of the American light harness turf, will be held today at the Murray Hill Hotel to vote on the proposal to merge with four other trotting organizations.

A bazaar will be given by Ivriah, the Women's Division of the Jewish Education Association, on Dec. 13 and 14 at the Park Central Hotel, to raise funds to carry on the organization's work of providing scholarships to Hebrew schools for underprivileged children.

Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Wilckes of New York and Katonah, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Wilckes, to John Leighton C. McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leighton McCarthy of Toronto, Canada.

Several debutantes will assist members of the executive committee, of which Mrs. Ridgway B. Knight is chairman, at the card party and tea in behalf of the Home Thrift Association to be held this afternoon at the headquarters of the Women's Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. They are the Misses Elizabeth Hardenbergh, Jeanne and Margaret Burbank, Suzanne Close and Gabriella Davis.
International uncertainties overshadowed the new account in the- London market today and prices fell sharply under selling pressure.

Rigid enforcement of the municipal dog ordinance was ordered today by Public Affairs Director Benjamin P. Laidlaw as a result of the town's latest rabies scare, in which five high school students were bitten by a rabid mongrel last Friday.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the Board of the Consolidated Edison Company, reserved general comment yesterday on the Supreme Court decision in the National Labor Relations Board case against the company.

The Giants were given a day off yesterday. They deserved it. But the holiday will be over today when the New Yorkers begin prepara tions for the National Football League championship play-off with the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. The stunning 36-to-O victory over the Washington Redskins slipped into history, a treasured memory, but a memory nevertheless.

Carnegie Tech is the winner of the August V. Lambert Memorial of the 1938 footTrophy, symbolic of the 1938 football championship of the East. Announcement was made yesterday that the Tartans, early leaders in the balloting, had clinched the honor by a 4-to-1 margin over. Holy Cross, with Pitt in third place.

" Skylines," the public school system's pageant of education, was revived in Brooklyn last night before an audience of 3,000, which included Mayor La Guardia and leading school officials. A thousand-pupils from six high schools participated in the) pageant at the Brooklyn Technical High School, DeKalb Avenue and Fort Greene Place.

The wage board for women and minors in the cleaning and dyeing industry was sworn in yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller at the State Building and received a detailed study of wages, hours and working conditions in the industry.

Mrs. Judith Carrington Stettinius,. widow of Edward R. Stettinius, former partner in J. P. Morgan Co., died of pneumonia at 7 o'clock tonight at her home here, The Shelter, after an illness of several weeks.

Sonja Lewis, a German refugee, and her husband, Hudson Lewis, both 23 years old, were found dead of gas poisoning yesterday in the kitchen of their five-room apartment at 53 East Ninety-seventh Street, ten hours after their daughter Patricia, 3, had left for a visit with her maternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Sears of 1,010 Cookman Street, Asbury Park, N. J.

The complete suppression or the Communist party is demanded by the newspaper Narodni Noviny, which complains over the fact that M. Vrbenski, a Communist Alderman, was allowed to be among those who welcomed Dr. Emil Hacha, the new President, on his visit to City Hall last week.
It seems we left Frank King's camp up in Sullivan County a day or so early, for we received a telegram yesterday that they brought tr in five nice bucks.

Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon said today that he believed that people who are discussing possible changes in the present political independence program for the Philippine Islands "are wasting their time."

James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, is. not quite sure what his motion picture duties will be. In a press conference today Mr. Roosevelt, a. new vice president of Samuel Goldwyn, Inc., was asked what he expected to do.

Harry Dick, an American citizen who is a Jew, on returning from Hamburg yesterday on the steamship President Roosevelt of the United States Lines, charged that he had been wrongfully imprisoned in Germany for six months. He said that the United States Consul in Hamburg had made no real effort to have him released.
Thomas Patrick Tunney, brother of Gene Tunney, former world's heavyweight boxing champion, and Miss Mary T. Cocchiola of this city were. married here last Saturday, it was disclosed today.
Premier Edouard Daladier said today that France was resolved to demand respect for "the absolute integrity" of all. French territory by "every means."

Dr. Frank Pierrepont Graves, president of Phi Beta Kappa, told members of that society tonight that "such obstacles to social welfare" as ignorance, poverty, disease and crime challenge the best efforts of the Phi Beta Kappans."

Minetta Lane, 24, 21.5xlO0xirreg; Alice Valentine to Mary B. Valentine, 24 Minetta Lane, quitclaim, 2/21st part. 16th St, 437 E, 25x92; Charlotte L. Schierenbeck to Beatrice Kahane, 656 E 12th St, quitclaim. 79th St, 422-6 E, 200x102.2; Edmund M. Brennan Corp to City Bank Farmers Trust Co as trustee, mtg $490,000 shall not merge.
William J. Grattan, who had represented Albany County in both houses of the Legislature, died early today after a heart attack. He was 61.

The sole change of any importance in the basketball rules since last season, that permitting a player of the offensive team to stay in the foul circle outside the foul line without the ball, is a popular move among the metropolitan coaches. Nat Holman, C. C. N. Y. mentor, was particularly enthusiastic.

The Golden Bit, annually awarded to the "horse of the year" by the magazine "Horse and Horseman," will go to Battleship, it was announced yesterday. Battleship, owned by Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott, won the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree last Spring and became the first American-bred

Gifts totaling $7,697.73 increased the 1938 Hundred Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to a total of $38,249.70, as 121 contributors gave evidence of their desire to come to the rescue of lonely children, ill and destitute families, forgotten old folk and other unfortunates among those whose lot has been adjudged as the harshest in the city.

A Christmas sale in behalf of seven New York and Brooklyn welfare organizations will open on Saturday at the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop, 705 Second Avenue, and will continue throughout next week. Articles suitable for holiday gifts will be on sale, including embroidered linens, toys, beaded bags and glassware.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Huber of 1,225 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ada Marie Huber, to Leland Allen Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roscoe William Smith of Monroe, N. Y.

Conviction that tax structures will broaden the base of giving for the support of higher education and prevent a drying up of philanthropic funds that otherwise might accompany a decline in large fortunes was expressed tonight by Dr. Ernest Victor Hollis of the School
Hugh White Adams, a retired lawyer, died yesterday at his residence, 123 East Eightieth Street, after a long illness. He was graduated from Columbia in 1900.

The Engineers Public Service Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in a statement covering the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 net income of $3,768,314 after Federal income taxes, interest, amortization, appropriations for retirement reserve, subsidiary preferred dividends, minority interterests and other charges.

Manufacturers of clothing figured in many of the leases of large units of space for business use reported by brokers and agents yesterday. Albert Turner, Inc., makers of men's clothes, took two floors with 20,000 square feet in the building at 149-51 Broadway, running through to 921-25 Broadway, through Tankoos, Smith Co.,

James Cannon Jr., retired Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, failed today to obtain a Supreme Court review of a decision against him in his $500,000 slander suit against Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts.

Following the election in Sudetenland, there was a test of the German Army's artillery today at the former frontier. The heaviest guns were worked out against the former Czech fortifications to show their efficiency in overcoming heavy concrete fortifications.

The only State employee to escape the French Government's new economy axe was 76-year-old Anatole Deibler, France's one and only executioner. Although other functionaries had to take a pay cut he will continue to receive 18,000 francs yearly, plus such expenses as every execution incurs.

George L. Chetwood, 58 years old, operator of several riding stables and a member of an old Elizabeth family, was killed today by illuminating gas that escaped from a radiator heater as he was taking a nap in the saddle room of his stable here.

Latvian orders for British arms were expected to result from the six-day visit here of Foreign Minister Vilhelms Munters. Received today by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, he will see the Foreign Secretary. Viscount Halifax, tomorrow.

A public demand for more efficiency in government was seen yesterday by Charles R. Hook, chairman of the National Industrial Council and president of the National Association of Manufacturers, in an address opening a two-day "prelude" to the Congress of American Industry in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The recipients or ten new scnorars ships endowed at Princeton University during the last fiscal year were announced today by Professor Robert K. Root, dean of the faculty and chairman of the university committee on scholarships. The grants-in-aid are based on gifts ranging from $5,000 to $25,000.

President Roosevelt did not overstate the case when he said yesterday at Chapel Hill that what the United States does or fails to do in the next few years will have a larger influence on the course of history than most of us can now conceive.

J. J. Reynolds of the Union Club, top seeded player, was extended to five games before defeating John Depew of the Apawamis Club, as play in the fifth annual invitation Class B squash racquets tournament started at the Squash Club last night.
Alexander F. Bartley, treasurer of Bartley Brothers Hall, saddlery importers at 52 Warren Street, New York, died here today at his home, 120 Christopher Street, after a week's illness.

The "Gay Thirties" dinner dance, a subscription party that has become a feature among entertainments of the Winter here, will take place Friday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. It will be given again for the benefit of the Boys Club. of New York.
