Wheat futures in North American markets advanced today after a modest decline in the early trading.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railroad Company has filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application for authority to issue and sell at par, and accrued interest, $30,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent refunding and improvement mortgage bonds, Series F. The proceeds would be used to refund $30,000,000 of 5 per cent consolidated first mortgage bonds, at a substantial saving in carrying charges.

The Westchester County Board of Supervisors received notification today from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that the county's application for a $1,800,000 loan for completion of the Cross County Parkway has been approved and that bonds would be sold in Washington next Monday.

The city of Baltimore will enter the market on Dec. 12 with a new issue of $3,524,000 of water, airport and viaduct bonds. Bidders are to name the rate of interest. The bonds, dated Aug. 1, Oct. 1 and Nov. 1, 1938, will be due in 1957 to 1968.

Reports by 141 Class I railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed that in September they earned an aggregate net income of $6,276,573, compared with $16,110,527 correspondingly last year.

Net sales of the Prosperity Company increased 49 per cent in November to $173,117 from $116,427 in October, 1937, according to A. R. Braun, president. In September this year sales amounted to $158,974.

A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy decided he wanted to drive an automobile last night, but neglected to learn how. In less than a mile he crashed into nine parked cars, knocking several of them up on the sidewalk, until the car he was driving finally became locked with the ninth car he hit.

The death of Father Cornelius Cyprian Clifford will bring a sense of personal loss, not only to his church associates and parishioners, but to a wide circle of acquaintance, wholly outside his church.

Business failures in the week ended Dec. 1 numbered 207, as compared with 221 in the same week a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary. This was the third week in succession that the figure was below that of 1937. However, the current figure compares with 191 in the weeK ended Nov. 23.

In reply to a report made by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, recommending' a reduction in staff in the office of the Sheriff of Queens along with other, changes, Sheriff. Maurice E. Fitzgerald declared yesterday that his office was undermanned and was already suffering from the "penurious" attitude of the city.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 4014-Milton Schnaier v. Dexter Farr. Opinion by Judge Lenroot. The Board of Appeals decision affirmed. 4045-Ex part George James Manson. Opinion by Judge Lenroot. The Board of Appeals decision affirmed. 4027--Ex parts Jean Sauvageot. Opinion by Judge Jackson. The Board of Appeals decision affirmed.
In a special sitting tonight the Finance Committee of the Chamber of Deputies approved the 1939 army defense budget of 18,205,000,000 francs.
" Hull 369," as she has been prosaically known in the Newport News shipyards, from now on will be called the America. In the Spring of 1940,

Winthrop Coffin of.Brookline, appointed a Boston elevated trustee in 1919 by Governor Coolidge and a retired member of Coffin Burr, Inc., Boston investment bankers, died on Friday in Winter Park, Fla., it was learned here today.

In a scene reminiscent of the Nineties, about seventy-five debutantes from Baltimore and cities throughout the country, including nearly- a score from New York, made their formal bow to society tonight at the first Bachelors Cotillion of the season at the Lyric.

Today's casualties arising from Arab terrorism are one Jewish supernumerary policeman and three Arabs shot dead--two of the latter by policeand three Jewish supernumeraries and one Arab seriously wounded.

Comparing the recent setbacks of the Chinese forces with the early struggles of the American Conti-mental Army, Dr. Hu Shih, recently appointed Chinese Ambassador to the United States yesterday described the Sino-Japanese conflict as a "revolutionary war."
Columbia's varsity swimming team will compete in ten dual meets and the Eastern intercollegiate championships, it was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletic manager.

A permanent loan of $585,000 at 4 per cent interest for ten years has been arranged by Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc., for the Franmor Equity Corporation, David T. Rusoff, president, on the nineteenstory and penthouse apartment building at 5 West Eighty-sixth Street.

Julia Turek of Woodbridge, N. J., who moved her 20-foot square frame house on which a mortgage had- been foreclosed, received suspended sentence for contempt of, court when she appeared before Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein

Speakers before the fourth annual mass meeting of the Committee on Religious Life in the Nation's capital joined tonight in a denunciation of Germany's persecution of the Jews and in an appeal to American adherents of all faiths to unite to prevent the spread of religious and racial intolerance in this country.

Stockholders of the Evans Products Company at a special meeting on Dec. 23 will vote on the proposed increase in. authorized common stock to 500,000 shares from 300,000 to take care of the conversion provision in the $2,000,000 debenture issue planned.

Philip A. Benson and Henry R. Kinsey were guests of honor last night at a dinner given for them in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York. Nine hundred persons, mostly bankers, attended.

Although the lack of authentic figures makes estimates difficult, it is likely that the current year will see more money spent by advertisers in all types of radio than in national magazines, the first time that radio expenditures have passed magazines, agency men pointed out yesterday.
The CzechoSlovak Legation announced today that Jan Masaryk had resigned after fourteen years' service in London as counselor and as Minister.

The Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help will be aided by a special benefit performance to be given by Cornelia Otis Skinner on the evening of Jan. 6 in the Great Hall of the New York Junior League. Mrs. Leighton Hammond Coleman will give a tea for the benefit committee today at her home, 121 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Two women were haled to the courts yesterday for the possession. of firearms, following their arrest by the police on Sullivan Act charges. One- defendant was discharged and commended in Queens Felony Court.
THESE arguments in the wake of the football season somehow bring to mind the title of one of the current best-sellers in the book marts, to wit: "Listen! the Wind."

The General Sessions trial of James Gibbs, 56 years old, of Garden City, L. I. in the alleged theft of $80,000 from the Excess Insur- be ance Company of America while he on was its president, is expected to go to the jury today.

W. J. O'Neil, vice president, has been elected president and general manager of the Dodge Brothers Corporation to succeed K. T. Keller, president of Chrysler Corporation, who held the office of president of Dodge since its acquisition by Chrysler Corporation in 1928.

Automobile production increased last week, but daily average output showed a contra-seasonal decline, and the adjusted index receded to 92.1 from 96.7. The figure for the week ended Dec. 4, 1937, was 91.9.
Even the most casual investigator of our county offices finds evidence of a leisurely and tranquil existence going on amid the hurlyburly of modern life.

It is improbable that James Roosevelt, the new vice president of Samuel Goldwyn, Inc., has bid farewell to political activities. First, they are the salts of his blood and the stepping-stones of his ambition.
The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision upholding the validity of the New York State Mortgage Moratorium Law of 1933.
Although emigration alone cannot remedy Japan's population problem, the government is pushing ahead with measures that, it hopes, will furnish a valuable safety valve to rural districts.

President Roosevelt today served notice that there was to' be no turning back from his liberal objectives despite New Deal losses in the election last month, and reaffirmed. his faith, in the American way of life.

The second section for the Middle Atlantic area of the Interstate Commerce Commission's hearing on minimum profitable freight rates for the trucking industry throughout the United States began yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker and will continue probably through Friday.

Harlan I. Gustafson of Norristown, club's Spring Pa., was elected captain of the 1939 University of Pennsylvania football team today at a meeting of the lettermen. Gustafson,'a junior, has been the regular left end on the Penn squad for two years. He is 20 years o1d, 6 feet 3 inches tall and weighs 195 pounds. He plays varsity basket ball and is a substitute outfielder ball teams on the baseball team.
The interest rate on short-term Treasury bonds again has been reduced, now to 1 3/4 per cent, according to a government decision, which will be printed in Tuesday's Journal Officiel.
The Rumanian Minister to London Basil de Grigorcea, who was recalled immediately after King Carol's return, has been placed on the list of diplomats "at the disposal of the Foreign Office."
Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, its deposed chairman, combined criticism of the Tennessee Valley Authority today with an appeal that it be saved by adoption of "open and above board methods."

Andrew R. Armstrong, American Labor party Councilman from Brooklyn was chosen yesterday as coalition leader of the City Council as the Council prepared to induct George Backer at today's meeting in place of the late B. Charney Viadeck, the Labor representative who held the minority leadership until his recent death.
Daniel Wolf and his associate promoters of the International Jewish Colonization Society met here last night to discuss aims and methods.
Cabinet officers and labor leaders attended tonight the stage production of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, "Pins and Needles."
President Justice and Mrs. Pel ham St. George Bissell will give a reception Saturday afternoon at their home, 270 Park Avenue, for their debutante daughter, Miss Ruth Mason Bissell.
Though a few coaches still are complaining about the extra point after touchdown, it looks as if the present football rules are here to stay.

The Department of Agriculture and nounced today that sugar deliveries by manufacturers and importers for direct consumption amounted to 5,478,774 short tons, raw value, in the first ten months of this year. This compared with deliveries of 5,728,753 short tons in the same pe? riod in 1937.
AMERICAN HIGHWAYS AND ROADSIDES, by Jac L. Gubbels. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.75.) How safety highways are located, designed and built.

A net profit or $261,913 was reported yesterday by the National Standard Company and its subsidiaries for the year ended on Sept. 30. The profit, which is after deductions for depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other charges, is equivalent to 98 cents each on 268,340 shares of $10-par capital stock. In the preceding fiscal year the net profit amounted to $773,799, or $2.88 a share.
The Court of Appeals heard today a test case on the question of whether a school child can be compelled to salute the flag.

The new Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act was characterized today by the Pure Food and. Drug Administration of the Agriculture Department, in its annual report to the Secretary, as a law which unquestionably will afford greatly increased protection to the public.

A thousand engineers from many parts of the country, the vanguard of 3,000 expected to arrive during the week, attended the opening sessions of the fifty-ninth annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers yesterday at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. The sessions will continue until Friday.

Plans for comprehensive presentation of the nation's shipping industry to World's Fair visitors next year are being completed by the Maritran Corporation, a non-profit organization formed by leaders in the steamship and allied fields, it was announced yesterday.
New Jersey rolls continued a downward trend for the fourth consecutive month during October, a statement by Arthur Mudd, director of the State Financial Assistance Commission, revealed today.

There was a gain of 60,200 telephones in service in the principal telephone subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company included in the Bell System during the month of November. The gain for these companies in November, 1937, was 53.600.
Annual meeting, American Society of Refrigerating Engineers, Hotel Commodore, 10 A. M. Luncheon 1 P. M. Sessions tomorrow and Thursday.

Cloyd. P. Clevenger, New York aviator recently indicted with turnino Cedillo, rebel general of Mexico, pleaded guilty today to a charge of transporting two planes illegally into Mexico. A charge against him of conspiring to violate the United. State Neutrality Act was dismissed.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Nov. 30, which included only five business days, aggregated $6,942,000,000, or 10 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 11 per cent below the total for the corresponding week, which also included only five business days.

Supreme Court Justice McCook took under advisement yesterday a motion submitted on behalf of minority stockholders of the Pathe Film Corporation to restrain the company from holding a meeting on Dec. 13 for the purpose of passing on the dissolution of the corporation and the transfer of most of its assets to a new company.

Whittingehame House, Scottish house of the late Earl Balfour, who gave his name to the declaration that held out hope of a Jewish national home in Palestine, was offered 'today as a hostel for refugee Jewish children from Germany.

With retailers lightly stocked and armed with larger than usual sums of ready cash because of abnormally high rubber footwear sales in the last three weeks, the annual Volume Shoe Show at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday set a new record with more than 650 exhibitors, said to be the largest number of shoe manufacturers ever to exhibit anywhere at one time.

Charles H. Pape of 601 West 164th Street, manager of the Hoguet Real Estate Management Corporation, 415 Lexington Avenue, died Sunday In the Presbyterian Hospital of a coronary thrombosis after a three weeks' illness. He was 58 years old.

Many dinners will be given in connection with the first in the series of Yorkville dinner dances for this season, which will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Association.

Basketball prospects at Columbia as the Lions approach their opening encounter against the alumni on Dec. 13 are neither good, bad nor indifferent, according to Coach Paul Mooney. To some this may come as a surprise, for it is a known fact that four of last season's starting five are back. But the loss of that fifth man causes Mooney to hold his breath.

Secretary Perkins obtained a Supreme Court review today of a decision that Marie Elizabeth Elg of New York in a citizen of the United States. Miss Perkins appealed from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.

The National Labor Relations Board today issued orders disestablishing three alleged "company-dominated" unions, reinstating a total of fifty workers in three plants and amended an order previously issued for an election to be held in two plants.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed today its answer to the "proposed report" of the Federal Communications Commission on the telephone industry asserting, in 280 pages of denial and protest, that - the investigation of A. T. T. operations conducted by Commissioner Paul A. Walker and his subsequent recommendations, were "unfair, incorrect and unsound."

A property on tne East Side required to meet the needs of an expanding business has been purchased by Max Nadler, furniture dealer, who acquired from the Dry Dock Savings Institution the fivestory tenement with store at 141 East Fourth Street, adjoining the northeast corner of First Avenue. The parcel is 25 by 96.2 feet and was bought through James Felt Co., Inc., brokers.

The first in a series of dances, known as the "County Assemblies of Westport," will be held Saturday night at the Red Barn in Westport, Conn. Subsequent dances in the series will take place Dec. 28 and Feb. 18. Miss Margaret Langdon will act as master of ceremonies.

Ice and snow sports on a large scale will be brought indoors tonight when the North American Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet starts- its third annual run in Madison Square Garden. The program, which includes skiing, figure skating, dog sledding, snowshoeing and comedy acts on skis and skates, will run through Saturday night.

Commonwealth Edison Company and Continental Oil Company rights have been admitted to New York Stock Exchange dealings and will be traded in variations of one-sixtyfourth. "When-issued" rights of both companies have been suspended from dealings.

After a stormy public hearing, the Nassau Board of Supervisors adopted today the 1939 budget as recommended by County Executive J. Russell Sprague, calling for governmental outlays of $19,857,149, an increase of $1,107,432 over the 1938 record budget of $18.749.717.

Tolls at the Panama Canal during November increased slightly over November of last year, but for the first eleven months of the year they were about $1,500,000 behind the corresponding period of 1937, the War Department reported today.

In London there is no doubt that a direct connection exists between Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop's visit to Paris, with the object of signing a French-German declaration of non-aggression,. and the recent outburst of anti-French feeling in the Italian Chamber of Deputies, which was accompanied by articles in the same sense in the Italian press.

The pound sterling and currencies linked to it made further recovery in the foreign exchange market yesterday, but word was received here of new large engagements of gold abroad for shipment to this country. A total of $10,500,000 gold engagements was reported to the Federal ReserveBank, of which $5,800,000 was engaged in Japan, $2,700,000 in The Netherlands and $2,000,000 in England.
The Duke of Kent, youngest brother King George VI, flew today to Copenhagen, Denmark, en route to Oslo, Norway, to represent the British royal family at the funeral of Queen Maud.

A distinguished audience attended Albert Morris Bagby's 407th Musical Morning yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Miss Lily Pons and Emanuel List of the Metropolitan Opera, and Miss Guiomar Novaes, pianist. The accompanists were Miss Frances Blaisdell, flutist, and Paul Berl and Frank La Forge, at the piano.
In the Treasury's borrowing program for the December quarterly financing, as announced yesterday, there was nothing that surprised.

Mark Stearman 56 years old, of 461 Thirtieth Street, N. W., Washington, D. C., was found drowned late today in the Croton Reservoir. Dr. Amos 0. Squire, medical examiner of Westchester County, said that Mr. Stearman had committed suicide by leaping from the top of Croton Dam.
More than 150 Long Island Presbyterian and Protestant Episcopal clergymen heard addresses on a proposal to unite the two denominations organically yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Margaret, Brooklyn.
Mayor John Boyd Thacher today told social workers at a conference to study the problem of caring for homeless and transient persons that Albany "should do nothing to make transients welcome."
Michigan's Republican Governor-elect, Frank- D. Fitzgerald, said in an interview today that "neither labor organizations nor. employers will dictate to the government" when he assumes office. Jan. 1.

The successful bidder for construction of Public School 194, with a low bid of $539,771, was the Skolwick Building Corporation, Brown's Letters, Inc., announces. The award for the structural steel went to the Harris Structural Steel Company, for $78,000. Eric Kebbon prepared the plans for the building, which is to go up on West 144th Street, west of Seventh Avenue.

Woodruff Randolph, secretarytreasurer of the International Typographical Union, announced here tonight that members in a referendum on Nov. 23 had rejected, by 31,303 votes to 16,345, a proposal to change union laws pertaining to the work week.

The Federal Communications Commission announced today it would take no action against the Columbia Broadcasting System or the stations which carried the Orson Welles "War of the Worlds" radio program, because in its judgment "steps sufficient to protect the public interest" have been taken by the CBS since the broadcast which panicked the country.

The State Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of Philadelphia's new 14 per cent income tax, enacted by the City Council to provide part of the estimated difference of about $26,000,000 between municipal receipts and expenditures next year.

Mayor La Guardia will be the principal speaker today at dedication exercises for' two new Brooklyn schools, Public School 191 on Park Place between Buffalo- and Ralph Avenues and Public School 253 'on Oceanview Avenue between Bright ton Sixth and Brighton Seventh Streets.

Prosecutor John J. Breslin Jr. today instructed members of the panel from which was selected the jury that convicted Joseph Rupprecht last Friday of participation in a Cliffside Park hold-up to be present in Common Pleas Court Wednesday.
The proverbial red tape which has surrounded governmental realty deals often has seriously delayed or caused the abandonment of prospective transactions in this field.

Pensioned On his own application: To take effect 12 midnight, Dec. 3: PATROLMAN-Joseph A. Beddy, 114th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 20, 1905. Temporary Assignments SERGEANT-James A. Giattini, from 110th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. Office, Queens County, for one day. from 4 P. M., Nov. 30.

Johnny Gottselig of the Black Hawks, at the head of the National Hockey League scoring race almost since the outset of the season, has to share first place with Tommy Anderson of the New York Americans, according to tonight's weekly statistical figures is sued by the league.

The International League will open its 1939 schedule April 20 and close Sept. 10. Bill Manley, secretarytreasurer, announced today after a meeting of the board of directors. The board decided the Governors' Cup series would be played in 1939 as this year except that the pennant winner would meet the fourth place club and the second and third team would play each other.

Every year the reader of the Hundred Neediest Cases has long thoughts. He is plagued by the old inexplorable mysteries, pain, evil, misfortune caused by-no fault of the victim, but by human cruelty, by disease, by the pitiless hand of circumstance.

In a close engagement, Yeshiva College defeated the City College evening quintet, 19 to 16, last night on the losers' court. After a 10-all tie at the half the winners stepped into the lead in the second half and were never headed.

Peter Gigliobianco, a habitual runaway at the age of 7, for whom the police had been conducting a citywide search for twenty-four hours, was found safe in Washington yesterday among the ranks of the Washington Redskins, a professional football team that had been vanquished here Sunday by the New York Giants, and their rooters.

Mayor La Guardia announced last night that religious refugees of all faiths would be aided by a contribution of $1,500 from the Shomrim Society of the Police Department, an organization of its Jewish members.

Hard food, rather than soft, is a cause of tooth decay, at least among by animals, Dr. Theodor Rosebury of the Department of Bacteriology of Columbia University told a general session of the Greater New York on dental meeting, opening a five-day I convention yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The thirteenth National Exposition. of Power and Mechanical Engineering,: which is popularly known as ."the Power Show," was opened yesterday at the - Grand Central Palace, where it will continue through Saturday.

Would-be Newtons and Curies of all ages are evidently in for a bigger treat this Christmas than ever before. Scientific toys, simplifying even the most intricate processes of the physicists, chemists and biologists, went on view yesterday at the Science in Toyland Exhibition at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

The New York University women's basketball team will engage in a ten-game schedule during the 1938-39 season, it was announced yesterday by Miss Frances V. Froatz, director of women's athletics at N. Y. U. The Violet co-eds will open their season on Wednesday evening, Dec. 14, facing the Brooklyn College girls at Brooklyn.
All livestock values declined today with the resumption of normal trading in Chicago after the two weeks tie-up because of a handlers' strike, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty signed an order yesterday permitting Charles J. Jewett as ancillary administrator of the estate of Johanna Whalen McIllveigh and Mary Hughes Whalen to file objections to a final accounting in the estate of John Whalen, banker and lawyer, by Miss Nellie M. Mahaney, sole surviving executor of his estate.

Increased cooperation by employers In the adjustment of disputes was reported yesterday by Mrs. Elinor M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, in a statement presenting an accounting of the activities of her office for the thirty-seven months since establishment of the board.
United States Government obligations supplied the only show of strength in the listed bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as railroad issues gave way as much as three points.

Mr and Mrs. Frederick Johnson gave a dinner tonight at their Winter residence. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton were luncheon hosts after a golf game. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Robe ert Jr. have arrived from Wash ington for a week at Mr. and Mrs, Messmore Kendall's home.
Burleigh Grimes, famous spitball pitcher and more recently manager of the Dodgers, was named manager of the Montreal Royals of the International League today.

With the completion of the regu- were reaffirmed so that athletes lar National Football League sea- who do not stand a chance of soorson and only the Giant-Packer playoff left on the agenda, a study of the final team statistics released Furthermore, officials will be limyesterday reveals that six circuit records were broken during the course of the campaign. Here are Gilbert of the new and powerful the records:

The North Shore Country Club of Glenview Ill., will be the scene of the 1939 national amateur champion, it was announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association through Secretary Frank M. Hardt. The competition will be held Sept. 11-16.

Sentencing of J. Richard (Dixie) Davis and. two. other confessed participants in the policy racket who testified for. the State at the trial of James J. Hines,. Tammany district leader, was deferred yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora until Feb. 27.

In the heaviest trading for any session since July 21, 1933, domestic sugar futures on the New York Cofe fee and Sugar Exchange yesterday closed with net losses of 22 to 24 points. The decline was due to the announcement over the week-end by Secretary of Agricuture Wallace that domestic quotas for 1939 would be 6,832,157 short tons, raw value, compared with 6,780,566 this year.

The decline in British industrial activity, which has been partly checked in recent months, has set in again. The number of unemployed is now greater than at any time this year and is 328,900 more than a year ago.

Frederick Blaschke, sculptor, who had specimens of his work exhibited in the Field Museum in Chicago, was found dead on the floor of the basement in his studio home here yesterday afternoon. He was 57 years old.
Members of the. City Council's Committee on Markets heard arguments for and against the bill-banning peddlers from the streets at a public hearing in City Hall yesterday.
Dr. Oscar Lavine, born in 1906 in Elmira, N. Y., and Michael George Albert, a medical student, born in New York in 1906, will go on trial here tomorrow on charges of having violated cur rency laws.

Senator elect Robert A. Taft of Ohio, eldest son of the late President Taft, said here today that he would-not seek the Republican nomination for President in 1940, as suggested by Representative George H. Bender at the meeting of the Republican National Committee last week.
certainly the gayest snow in town is one that opened yesterday at the Marie Harriman Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street. It is made up of posters and colored lithographs by Toulouse-Lautrec.

Compania Hispano-Americana de Electricidad, S. A., known as Chade, will distribute, beginning on Dec. 12, against coupon No. 35, the sum of 22 Argentine paper pesos, 50 centavos on Series A, B and C shares, and 4 Argentine paper pesos, 50 centavos on Series D and E shares to apply on the dividend for the fiscal year of 1938.
Literature of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., appeared today without the slogan, "The Lindbergh Line." Airline officials met with a blunt "No comment," all questions regarding the deletion.

Mrs. Elma N. Lauer, wife of Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer, and Albert N. Chaperau, who was arrested Oct. 26 for bringing contraband to her apartment at 570 Park Avenue, were indicted yesterday by, a Federal grand jury on charges of smuggling and conspiracy.

Retaliatory tariffs on American goods entering Egypt were suggested in the Chamber of Deputies this evening by an independent, Sayyid Badrawi Pasha. He pointed out that the United States imposes a six-cent tax on Egyptian long staple cotton.

Charles Humphrey Fuller, former legislator and, from 1882 to 1930, an attorney in New York, died here suddenly last night in his home at the age of 79. He was a brother-in-law of the late William C. Redfield, Secretary of Commerce in the Wilson Cabinet.

Auto accidents, fatalities and injuries declined last week, compared with the corresponding period last year, despite sharp increases in parallel figures covering the two weekends, a tabulated report of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department showed yesterday.
Soviet Russia began celebrations today of the second anniversary of the new' Bolshevist Constitution, the foundation stone of her "Red democracy."

Trading was resumed today at the Chicago stock yards. Settlement of a C. I. 0. strike sent 600 handlers back to their jobs after they had been idle for two weeks. The tasks of unloading, weighing and selling animals at the nation's largest livestock market were renewed at a brisk pace.

It is not possible for laymen, or even for lawyers, to say precisely what all the wider implications are, of the decision handed down by the Supreme Court yesterday in the case of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York.
The Divorce Court today granted a conditional divorce to Mrs. Marjorie Barbirolli on grounds of desertion by her husband, John Barbirolli, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
Thomas L. Pryor, head of the income tax department of the Brooklyn Trust Company, 177 Montague Street, died on Sunday night at his home, 441 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 58.
Bethlehem Steel Corporation booked about 23,500 tons in steel shapes and other constructional items last week, the largest order involving 17,600. tons for the Narrows Bridge at Tacoma, Wash.

The German liner La Plata arrived tonight with fifteen survivors of the Greek freighter Akti, which sank with seventeen other members of the crew after being struck by the La Plata yesterday in the English Channel.

Trading was generally slow in local markets yesterday. Fresh pork cuts were steady to lower veal hindsaddles weak to lower, calf weak, other classes of traefer meats about steady with last week's close.

Six hundred Jewish children left Vienna this afternoon for new homes abroad. Arrangements for their departure were completed this morning by Mme. G. Wijsmuller-Meijer of Amsterdam, official representative of the Children's Committee in The Netherlands, which arranged to provide homes for 100 child refugees until they could be placed with families elsewhere, probably in the United States.
Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon disclosed today that the first ship of the Philippine Navy, under construction in England, will be ready for trial runs about Feb. 1.

Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes heads the executive committee for the annual bazaar in behalf of the Cenacle of St. Regis, which will take place today and tomorrow at the convent, 628 West 140th Street. Mrs. Alvin P. Weisker, assisted by Mrs. Charles A. Emise of Englewood, N. J., has charge of the tea room, where tea and dinner will be served on both days of the event.

Henry M. Schiller has joined the New York sales staff of R. H. Johnson Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. The following have become associated with the firm in Philadelphia: John R. Abbott. Harry Bancroft, H. A. Brunswick, Joseph F. Euler, H. E. McLaughlin, A. M. Sanders, J. D. Sheldon and George C. Shelmire.
Despite the anti-French campaign in the Italian press, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons today that he saw no reason to alter his plans for visiting Rome next month.
James H. Sisk, who retired last year as a Justice of the Massachusetts Superior Court, died Saturday night following a heart attack. His age was 80.

Following its ghetto ordinance, the German Government issued today a new decree stripping Jews of further control of their property and mobilizing that property for the benefit of German economy generally and Reich finances in particular.

Henry on Armstrong scored a technical knockout over Al Manfredo of we san Francisco in the third round lie tonight to retain his world welterweight championship before 12,724 fans who attended the thirteenth ou annual Cleveland News Christmas AT charity boxing show. Referee Tony Labranch stopped the bout at 1:45 un hi: of the third round.

Under certain restrictions which it felt were necessary for protection of the investors in this country, the Secur ities and Exchange Commission has granted exemption from various provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act to Southern Utilities Company, Ltd., and Great Northern Gas Company, Ltd., operating respectively in Alberta and Ontario, Canada. Both companies are subsidiaries of North Continent Utilities Corporation, a registered holding company.

About 50,000 Mexican Government employes received the right to organize and strike against constituted authority today when President Lazaro Cardenas promulgated a law passed by the Congress. which is perhaps the most farreaching of its kind in existence.

MANHATTAN ALLEN, MARY W. (Oct. 24). Estate, less than $5,000. To Narcissa A. Denniston, Point Pleasant, N. J., and Clara A. Orr, Westport, Conn., daughters, $900 each; Gladys W. Allen, daughter, executrix, 50 W. 106th St., $1,500. Russell A. Orr, sonin-law. Westnort. executor.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders to day, dated Dec. 2: CAPTAIN Philbrick, M. H., Navy Purchasing Office, New York, N. Y., on Dec. 31 to Navy Yard, Portsmouth, N. H. LIEUTENANTS Burden. H. P., and Lambrecht, J. O., Patrol Squadron 18. to Patrol Squadron 1.
Moderate improvement developed in the commodity markets last week, putting The Annalist Index up three-tenths of a point to 80.2, the highest level since the early part of October.

Yehudi Menuhin made his first New York appearance of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, following two highly important and independent decisions on his part, the one involving a romantic marriage, the other a declaration of his stand as musician when the American Guild of Musical Artists requested the Los Angeles Symphony Orches tra not to permit Mr. Menuhin to appear with that body as soloist unless he joined A G. M. A.

The eighth annual Allaverdy Ball, under the auspices of the Caucasian Society Allaverdy, will take place Friday night at the Plaza and will be patterned after old-fashioned Caucasion fetes. Members of the sponsoring society will attend the ball in their national costumes.

New projects for which building plans were filed yesterday included three six-story apartments, two in the Bronx and one in Brooklyn. One of the Bronx houses will rise on 228th Street, near Lowerre Place, and the other on the southwest corner of 182d Street and the Grand Concourse. The former is estimated to cost $200,000 and the latter $250,000. The site of the Brooklyn building is 1,528-46 Fortyninth Street. Its cost is placed at $189-200.

An investing client of Edward K. Kennedy, attorney, has purchased from the 232 East Fortieth Street Corporation, the builders, the recently completed twentyfour-family apartment house at 248-50 East Seventy-seventh Street, through the Wallace J. Grove Company, brokers.
The State closed its case yesterday against the four men charged with the murder of Sergeant Timothy Murphy in a restaurant hold-up in East Thirteenth Street seven years ago.

Tony Lazzeri received a birthday present from the Chicago Cubs today-a requested one which ended his puzzling one-year connection with the National League Club. The taciturn veteran, 34 years old today, who spent the 1938 season as a Cub utility infielder and pinch hitter after more than a decade of stardom with the New York Yankees, sent Owner P. K. Wrigley the following wire:

Dr. John Douglas, a noted surgeon here, died late Monday night in his home, 116 East Sixty-third Street, after a protracted illness. He was in his sixty-fourth year. For many years Dr. Douglas was a leading authority on cancer.

The Rev. Howard Stone Anderson, pastor of the First Congregational Church here, charged today that James Roosevelt's published income returns for five years listed no contributions- to hurches, and drew a prompt reply from the President's son that he "most certainly did contribute."

On paper the Manhattan College basketball squad looms as a strong one. A quick glance over the roster impresses one, for there may be found such names as Captain Ed Glancy, Dick Cole, Bill Boyle, Jim Sarullo and Fred Gardiner, to say nothing of a highly promising group of sophomores.

Frank Brimsek, Boston's rookie goalie, gained his second shut-out in three nights over Chicago tonight when the Bruins scored a 2-0 victory that strengthened their hold on top place in the National Hockey League.
The address to be delivered by Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, Friday night at the annual dinner of the National

Now that the Japanese have more or less consolidated their position at Canton they are driving to the southwest. They captured Kongmoon after a brief resistance and the entire Chungshan district is expected to be occupied shortly, thus clearing the Pearl River delta, the east side of which recently was cleared.

A string of twenty-six cars carrying 250 miners to work in a coal mine north of here was precipitated downgrade for a mile and a quarter today when the haulage cable snapped, and sixteen of the men were killed.

The Museum of Modern Art, in its temporary quarters at 14 West Forty-ninth Street, opened last evening with a reception and preview, a large exhibition devoted to the German Bauhaus, which was established by Walter Gropius at Weimar in 1919.

In our grim world of today it isconceivable that 20,000 tons of steel from the Sixth Avenue "L" may ultimately take the form of explosive shells raining down from Japanese bombers on a Chinese city. The prospective purchaser of the old elevated structure is a dealer in such things on the Pacific Coast. He is also in the export business.

Dazed after a sentence of six months' imprisonment and a fine of 60,000 marks, imposed this evening in Central Criminal Court here, Dr. Oscar Lavine of Mount Rainier, Md., departed from the court room on his sister's arm. He was scarcely able to walk. If his fine is not paid he will have to serve two more months in jail.

The Court of Appeals ruled today that a section of the Multiple Dwelling Law making assessments for improvements to old-law tenement houses in New York City a prior lien ahead of any mortgage on the property was unconstitutional.
Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra will give concerts in Baltimore and Boston on the evenings of Dec. 27 and Jan. 10 respectively, it was announced yesterday.

Light from the moon was water in the sky, The full moon fountainhead a roof of slate, And lights in light, and blue and citrine lie The swimming star boats, turning back too late Upon their courses through the waters, burnt With leaning on their sea, their colors blent

The world's largest stabbing mill was put into operation yesterday by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, as an addition to the Edgar Thomson Works at Braddock, Pa., it was announced last night.
Paced by the sophomore forwards, Howard Samuels and Fred Herzog, the M. I. T. varsity basketball team opened its season tonight by turning back Harvard, 29 to 24, in an exciting game at the Tech gym.
Lehman Brothers headed the successful banking group yesterday in the purchase of $15,250,000 of Los Angeles (Calif.) Department of Water and Power electric revenue bonds. The group laid 100,

In 1912 the Oldfield committee investigated the patent problem without revealing anything unknown to lawyers, business men or inventors. In 1935 and 1938 we had the prolonged sessions of the Sirovich committee, which likewise revealed nothing essentially new. There have been other explorations.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney of New York County, was designated as the recipient of the medal of merit of the St. Nicholas Society at the 104th annual dinner of the society, attended by 479 persons last night at the Hotel Plaza. Because of Mr. Dewey's absence from the city, the presentation will be made at the "Paas" festival supper of the society in March.

Georgd E. March, from 14th Division to 78th Precinct, assignment to duty in plain clothes discontinued. Additional compensation of $240 per annum revoked. William F. Mackin, from 24th Pct. to 23d Pct.: Frederick J. Smith, from 41st Pct. to 24 Pct.: Walter R. Johnson, from Traf. A to 3d Pet.
After spotting the New York A. C. two goals in the opening period, the Brock Hall Hockey Club of New Haven came on to defeat the Winged Footers, 6-3, on the Brooklyn Ice Palace rink last night.

The elaborate city housing program presented a few days ago by Park Commissioner Robert Moses has occasioned more widespread discussion perhaps than any other city planning or housing proposal of recent years. Various architects and planning
Trade here was thrown into confusion today by the government's announcement of creation of a system of export and import control in defense of the Dominion's "New Deal."

A plan for systematic dental care of children between 2 and 7 years old on an annual basis and at a cost expected to be within the reach of the average wage-earner, was announced yesterday by the Greater New York Bureau for Dental Information.

George Baklanoff, Russian baritone, who formerly sang with the Chicago Opera Association, died here today. He was 56 years old. George Baklanoff gained his reputation in parts like Iago in Verdi's "Otello," which he had sung with the Boston Opera Company and the Chicago Opera Association.

President Roosevelt proposed today that expenditures for the national defense should be placed on a."payas-you-go basis," but warned against the inference that he advocated paying the bill in the year it was incurred, or that new taxes would be proposed in connection with the- Administration's armament expansion program.

The intention of Douglas Fairbanks Sr. to return to active film production after an absence of five years was announced yesterday in a cable from London to United Artists, with which he will be associated.

Like almost every other activity, higher education has suffered during the years of reduced national income. Our great public institutions have felt the pinch of enforced economy, our privately supported colleges and universities have lost in tuition fees, in endowment income and in gifts and grants.

Dr. Clyde Fisher. curator-in-chief of the Hayden Planetarium, spoke last night on "Is There Life on Mars?" as a feature of another in the series of "natural science evenings" being conducted in the interests of the ten-year development plan of the museum. Mr. and Mrs.

A regular luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., called to hear a speech on the Cuban and Puerto Rican markets, developed into a general discussion of ideas for thwarting German barter trade ambitions in the Latin-American markets at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Suggestions offered by members ranged from a proposal for a Western
Trading was slow in local markets yesterday. The lamb and veal markets were weak to lower and fresh pork cuts steady to lower; the bull market was uneven; other classes about steady.

Retired Captain Henry. Volk, formerly a member of Engine Co. 11, residing at 315 E. 69th St., Manhattan, died Dec. 5. Funeral will take place from the Funeral Parlor of Jacob Herrlick Sons, 332 E. 86th St., Manhattan, at 10:30 A M., Thursday, Dec. 8

Larry MacPhail, general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, said today all the team's games would be broadcast. "The Brooklyn Baseball Club will broadcast all games at home and on the road in 1939 and 1940," he said. "The facilities and details of this service to the public will be announced later."
William P. (Hiker) Joy offered his resignation tonight as head football coach of Canisius College. The Rev. Francis J. Geraghty, Canisius College athletic director, said Joy had written:

When Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, was a schoolboy and Edouard Daladier, Premier of France, was a teacher between 1911 and 1913, they lived in the same street in Grenoble, says the Paris Soir Grenoble correspondent, and inevitably passed each other morning and evening an they went to their classes.

Dedication of the pavilion of The Netherlands at the New York World's Fair of 1939 placed emphasis yesterday on the ties that have existed between that country and the United States ever since the arrival of the early settlers of Manhattan Island more than three centuries ago.

Carl J. Wold, treasurer of Thomas N. Cooke, Inc., of Greenwich, testified before a jury in the Criminal Superior Court here this afternoon that he had' paid to G. Leroy Kemp, indicted State land agent, "six or eight times in cash," a share of-his commissions on Merritt Parkway land sales.
The F. W. Woolworth Company reported yesterday for the first time in seven months an increase in its monthly volume of business over the same period last year.
Fed Steers and yearlings cleared at steady to 25 cent lower rates in a slow, draggy trade today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Fat lambs sold slowly to weak to
Te Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 3: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Fellis, J., to continue treatment, Naval Hospital, Newport, R. Y.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation of New York, a holding and investment company, was the central figure today in the opening of a new episode in the legal struggle centering about the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, a local utility holding company once rated as a $400,000,000 concern.

Nationwide emulation of Cleveland's example in encouraging new industries, if backed by Congressional action to remove government-inspired obstacles to such development, might prove the formula for bringing about real prosperity,

Joseph G. Myerson of 754 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, whose son, Robert Isaac Myerson, 18 years old, left Harvard University Thursday night, presumably to look for a job, issued the following statement yesterday:
Edward F. Simms, race-horse owner and oil man, died today in the Johns Hopkins Hospital, which he entered Nov. 7 for blood infection treatment. He was 67 years old.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Dec. 1 decreased in three out of five trade groups as compared with the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Victor Ridder, publisher, will print a statement in today's New Yorker Staats-Zeitung und Herold, for the information of its Germanlanguage readers and to "answer a number of inquiries from societies and individuals who are old friends and true friends, asking why I am going to speak at Carnegie Hall at the [anti-Nazi] protest meeting, Friday night."

Charles F. Kettering, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, told the Temporary National Economic Committee this afternoon that the big problem facing the. nation was how to create new industries to put idle men and money to work.

A marked spirit of optimism prevails for the debut of the first Yale hockey team coached by Murray Murdoch here tomorrow night against the St. Nicks. In fact, it is expected that the Blue will surprise its supporters with one of the best-drilled teams in a long time.
Contributions totaling $11,082.69 came in yesterday for the benefit of the Neediest Cases Fund. These gifts, from-340 donors, brought the total received to date in the 1938 appeal to $49;332.39.

More than 2,000 Persons, headed by Governor-elect Leverett P. Saltonstall of Massachusetts and Eddie Cantor, stage and radio star, gathered in Sanders Theatre here tonight, and successfully inaugurated a campaign of Harvard undergraduates to raise $10,000 for expenses of twenty student refugees from Europe to whom scholarships will be granted.

Toward the close of a protracted meeting held yesterday in the Murray Hill Hotel, the Board of Appeals of the National Trotting Association adopted a resolution committing the organization to the furtherance of the plan for unification of the governing bodies of the light harness turf in the United States.

The makings of a first-class political conflict were seen in the House of Commons tonight when Labor spokesmen expressed deep and unexpected suspicion of the government's plan for a voluntary war register of the British people.

Rather poor prices were obtained today as Sotheby's gallery began the concluding sale of the collection of fine bindings, engravings and French literature formed by the late Mortimer Schiff of New York. The total amount paid for 214 items was ??3,460.

The New England shoe manufacturing States of Massachusetts, Maine and New Hampshire produced a total of 9,185,272 pairs of shoes during October, an increase of 28 per cent over the same period last year, to lead other sections of the country in the month's shoe output, the New England Shoe and Leather Association revealed today.
Texas Christian, which placed two of its stars on The Associated Press All-America team, has gained further fame by winning first place in the season's final poll of sports writers.

Plans were filed yesterday for five eight-story apartment houses costing a total of $2,250,000, to be constructed by Park Terrace Apartments, Inc., of which David Rose is president, on the Inwood block recently acquired from the Dwyer estate.

The advance in the pound sterling was halted for the time being yesterday as renewed anxieties about the European political outlook influenced the foreign exchange market. The gloomy prediction of a European war by next Spring which had been made by Oswald Pirow, South Africa's Minister of Defense, was the chief factor in precipitating a rather sharp sell-off in the pound early yesterday.

The upsets which marked the Fair Grounds racing today reached their peak in the feature, a mile and 70 yard event that resulted in a victory for the second longest priced winner of the meeting. H. D. King's Alan Chicle, paying $86.40 for $2 or more than 42 to 1, made every post a winning one, but probably was lucky to win.

Amateur thespians among members of society, who are associated with the activities of the Amateur Comedy Club, Inc., will be seen in this organization's first production of the season tomorrow, Friday and Saturday at the Heckscher-Theatre, 104th Street and Fifth Avenue.

Jack O'Brien, surveyor for the Byrd Antarctic Expedition of 1928-29, died yesterday in his apartment at 400 East Forty-ninth Street, after an illness of six months. Last Summer friends gave him several blood transfusions. He was born in Duluth, Minn., fortytwo years ago.

The first of the two Yorkville Dinner Dances for this season took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The dances have been given for the last twenty-five years to raise funds for the social center maintained by the Yorkville Community Association at 1,639 York Avenue.
Boyhood friends and neighbors of Vice President John N. Garner started a movement today at his old Red River County home to make him the 1940 Democratic candidate for President.

Frank Gillmore, president of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, yesterday defended the American Guild of Musical Artists, constituent union, against criticism by Yehudi Menuhin, violinist.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,223,650 barrels, compared with 3,260,900 in the previous week, a decrease of 37,250, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
The Italian liner Conte di Savoia, leaving today. for Mediterranean ports, will have among her passengers Mrs. Henry Clews, Mme. Mafalda Favero, Gustavo Pulitzer Final.
National Association of Manufacturers, Forty-third Congress of American Industry, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, 9 A. M. Sessions tomorrow and Friday.

Three of the most highly regarded Giantss of recent years were taken out of the Polo Grounds picture Yesterday when Dick Bartell, Gus Iancuso and Hank Leiber were raded to the Chicago Cubs for Bill urges, Ken O'Dea and Frank Demree.

Mohandas K. Gandhi said today that "if ever there could be a justifiable war in the name of humanity, a war against Germany-to prevent the wanton persecution of a whole racewould be completely justified."

A fairyland of snow was unfolded in Madison Square Garden last night as the third annual North American Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet began a fiveday stand. An unusual and divertting program of snow and ice events provided a crowd of 5,000 with swift action throughout.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Macdonald Mitchell of Old Lyme, Conn., formerely of Flushing, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ethel Crosby Mitchell, to John Danenhower, son of Lieut. Comdr. Sloan Danenhower, U. S. N. R., of this city and Old Lyme.
President Roosevelt said today he was adhering quite closely to his promises of appointing Federal

The British Government announced today that it was considering the granting of export credits to China. The announcement was made in the House of Lords by the Earl of Plymouth, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, who added that Great Britain stood squarely behind treaties upholding the policy

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You recently printed a letter from several distinguished architects, including Carol Aronovici, W. F. R. Ballard, Henry S. Churchill, Carl Feiss, William Lescaze, Albert Mayer, Lewis Mumford, Ralph Walker, on my housing and recreation plan. These gentlemen eliminate from their criticism all references to limited dividend construction.

The International Labor Office treaties, ratified by the Senate last session, do not alter the existing law with respect to yachts and fishing vessels, Secretary Perkins said today in a statement which was intended to halt rumors and published reports that the treaties would destroy or seriously hamper yachting.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered well above the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 601, as against 457 in the previous week and 533 in the same period last year.

Domestic sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange were steady yesterday following their break of 22 to 24 points on Monday as a result of higher quotas for next year fixed by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace.

Nine men who were arrested on vagrancy charges last Wednesday in the Stillwell Gardens, 2,033 Stillwell Avenue, Brooklyn, during a beefsteak dinner, were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Mark Rudich in Coney Island Court. All nine men produced evidence that they had homes and means of support.

Miss Liberty, at the age of 52, has been undergoing a refurbishing process on Bedloes Island. Restoration for the time being is now complete and the statue will be rededicated or, at least, reopened to a liberty-loving public on Dec. 15. Perhaps the process is symbolic of what has been happening to Liberty in every nation where people are still permitted to visit her shrine or invoke her name.

The Merchants Association of New York has been informed that certificates of origin covering shipments to France and French possessions must state clearly the country in which the goods actually originated, that is, the country in which they were grown, mined, produced or transformed by a manufacturing' process.

Leonard Del Genio, 1451/4, Harlem, knocked out Eddie Alzek, 1373/4, Brooklyn, in 37 seconds of the seventh round of a scheduled eightround main event at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 4,000 persons.

Today's events: Jascha Heifetz, violinist, Carnegie Hall, evening; "Lohengrin," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Frank Sheridan, pianist, - Town Hall, 8:30; Composers' Forum-Laboratory, Carnegie Chamber Hall; evening (free concert); Kemp Stillings,

Louis O. Mouquin, formerly proprietor with his brother, Henri Mouquin the younger, of the Mouquin restaurants in this city, died yesterday of heart disease at his home, 590 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of five months. He was born in New York 68 years ago.

Harmon O. Nelson obtained an uncontested divorce today from his actress wife, Bette Davis. Home life with Mrs. Nelson contained little of that close communion between husband and wife, Mr. Nelson's testimony in Superior Court disclosed.

More than 1,500 persons, most of them members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, yesterday attended the funeral of Basillo Desti, a vice president of the union, from the organization's headquarters, 3 West Sixteenth Street.
The two leading lead producers announced yesterday a reduction of 15 points in the price of that metal in the domestic market. This follows a reduction of 10 points made about ten days ago.

The Far Rockaway High School basketball team scored its second straight victory in the Queens Division of the P. S. A. L. yesterday when it defeated the Andrew Jackson five, 31-27, on the losers court. The winners led at the half, 15-13. Captain John Brucato set the pace for Far Rockaway with 18 points.

Milton O. Loysen, new director of the State Unemployment Insurance Division, moved swiftly today toward "permanent and real changes" in the unit assailed by Thomas E. Dewey, unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor.

The surprise bid of $80,000 received by the city for the Sixth Avenue elevated structure on Monday was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate, subject to the ability of the buyer, George L. Weissbaum, a West Coast demolition contractor, to qualify financially. The city had expected to pay some one to tear down the structure, with the scrap metal going to the contractor as part of the arrangement.

Signs that France has begun to turn the corner toward recovery are seen in the Finance Ministry's November trade balance report, showing the deficit reduced by more than 500,000 francs, compared with the average for the ten previous months.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn and his staff attended a requiem mass for John Joseph Kean, Assistant District Attorney of Kings County, at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Name, ...

The decision of officials of the Memphis Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the National Power and Light Company, to reduce electric rates to TVA levels and continue the operation of its electric facilities in the city of Memphis had its repercussions yesterday. Officials of Memphis,
Rider College opened its basketball season with a 73-to-38 triumph over Princeton Seminary at Moose Hall tonight. The half-time score was 35 to 26.

A private collector paid $2,000 for the Westover Papers, Colonel William Byrd's famous manuscript, source history of the dividing line "Betwixt Virginia and North Carolina," "Journey to the Land of Eden" and other papers, at the auction yesterday at the ParkeBernet Galleries, Ino., 742 Fifth Avenue.

D. C. Oelsner of the University Club captured a second-round match in the Class B squash racquets invitation tournament at the Squash Club yesterday, defeating J. L. Tappin of the Princeton Club, 15-12, 15-13, 18-15.

The Federal Government to day indicated General Roberto Flerro, former head of the Mexican Army Air Corps, six other Mexicans, two Americans and a Mexican aviation company for conspiring to violate the Neutrality Act of 1935.
Eugene McKernan of 5,391 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, a retired shipping broker, died on Monday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. His age was 69.

Mrs. R., a widow, had five sons--"five of the finest boys in the world." She took in washing to bring them up decently. One died in the World War. Another returned ill from military service and died a few years later. A third gladdened his mother's heart by becoming a priest; then he, too, died. A fourth is ill with tuberculosis.

Colden Ave (15-4101), w s, 65 ft n of Van Nest Ave, 35x75; I Allian Mambrino to Bertha Shuster, 2,197 Cruger Ave. Clinton Ave (11-2935), e s, 69 ft s of 170th St, 39x111; Malpin Realty Corp to Clinton home Realty Corp, 521 5th Ave; mtg $20,000. Colden Ave. 3,038 (16-4576); Jennie M. Sapienze to Jessie Capuano, 3,038 Colden Ave.

The Federal grand jury that indicted Mrs. Elina N. Lauer, wife of Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer, and Albert N. Chaperau, self-styled commercial attach of the Nicaraguan Consul General, on charges of conspiracy and smuggling will continue its investigation of Chaperau, with emphasis on his activities in Hollywood, it was learned yesterday.

Several Bronx apartment houses were reported yesterday as having passed into new hands, An Investing client of Charles Kelman has purchased from David S. Meister the five-story apartment building at 1,737 Pilgrim Avenue, corner of Westchester Avenue, for cash above mortgages totaling $178,500. H. Foreman was the-broker.
Cambridge University triumphed over Oxford University today in the annual intervarsity rugby match, 8-6. In London Saturday the Light Blues defeated their rivals at soccer, 5-3.

An action to restrain the Civil Service Commission from giving preference to candidates for appointment as patrolmen in the Police Department because of college training or participation in group athletics was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court. The plaintiff in the case is Alfred J. Thomas, who said that he wants to take the proposed examination, but has had no college training or experience in group athletics.
Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie. King said in a statement tonight that his government had been "considering" and would continue to consider Canada's affiliation with the Pan-American Conference.

The Rainbow Arch, George Grey Barnard's': dream and masterpiece on which he labored for eighteen years, may never become a reality. This was learned yesterday when his son, Monroe Barnard of 700 Fort Washington Avenue, an executor of the estate, appealed to Surrogate James A. Foley for advice and construction of his father's will.

Mrs. Lila Courtenay Wetmore Stanley, widow of William Stanley, inventor of the alternating electric current transformer and mother of Harold Stanley of New York, president of Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.. investment house,

J. H. Alldredge, director of the TVA Commerce Department, told a Congressional investigating committee today that development of the Tennessee River as an artery of commerce would stimulate greatly the industrial expansion of the South and that a major portion of the agency's work was directed toward this end.
James Park, senior partner of Park, Potter Co., certified public accountants, at 141 Broadway, New York, died today after a short illness in his South Nyack home.

The campaign against unjust returns of merchandise will be continued on a wider scale and directed at offending retailers and manufacturers, Abraham Rosenthal, president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc., said last night at the annual meeting of the organization in the Hotel New Yorker.

An offering of 375,000 shares of common stock of the North American Company was made yesterday by an underwriting group comprising Dillon, Read Co. and seventy-four investment houses. The shares were priced at $21.25 each, the closing quotation yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Commander Sergius M. Riis, explorer and American shipmaster, whose five-masted schooner Andromeda is now being held by German authorities in Koenigsberg, asked THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday to make his position clear.

While the Franco-German declaration was being signed in Paris today cries of 'Down with France!" were raised in more than one Italian city. But these manifestations, which followed hard on the heels of anti-Italian manifestations in Tunis and Corsica, could by no stretch of the imagination be described as serious, even in Rome, where the French Embassy is situated.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Replogle gave a dinner this evening at Trailside for Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien, Mrs. Margaret Emerson and her guests, Mr. and Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart.

With Eddie Dowling as its producer and leading player, "Here Come the Clowns," Philip Barry's study of vaudevillians in a partly metaphysical setting, arrives tonight at the Booth. It is the story which Mr. Barry also wrote in novel form under the title of "War in Heaven." Others in the cast are Madge Evans, Doris Dudley, Leo Chalzel, Russell Collins, Frank Gaby, Bertram Thorn, Ralph Bunker and Hortense Alden.
Wallace Kenyon of Providence died today at Orlean, near Warrenton, Va., of a heart attack following participation in a point-to-point race of the Old Dominion hounds.

After Democratic members of the City Council had balked yesterday at Mayor La Guardia's request for a special meeting to act on reform of county government, the Mayor called the meeting himself for 1 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

The recent order of the Public Service Commission requiring hotels to reduce their surcharges for certain types of telephone service after Jan. 1-was denounced yesterday as nothing short of confiscation of hotel property" by Charles J. Campbell, counsel for the New York State. Hotel Association and the Hotel Association of'New York City.

By DANIEL GREENWALD 76th St, 14 W. 5-story dwelling, 25x102.2: Guaranty Trust Company of N. Y. against Nathaniel Rue High Moor; due, $48,792; taxes, etc., $2,075; to plaintiff for $30,000. By JEREMIAH O'SULLIVAN 25th St, 410 W 4-story tenement, 25x98.9; Franklin Savings Bank against Maurice Cohen; due. $11,998; taxes. etc., $407; to plaintiff for $9,000.

The present upturn in business has been due largely to the huge government spending program and it will not continue unless men are convinced that they have a reasonable expectation of profit, J. Stewart Baker,

The names of Sid Roth, Cornell's great guard, and Cliff Wilson, 190pound Harvard quarterback, were added today to the roster of the All-East football team which will meet an- All-West eleven on the Pacific Coast Jan. 2.

A new-lit star flames in the Western sky. The astronomer who has watched it spreads the news. The Seventy-sixth Congress must prepare itself for the reception of a prodigy. George W. Gillie, Representative-elect of the Fourth Indiana District, is a worthy longitudinal successor of the Tall Sycamore of the Wabash. He comes from the banks of the Maumee and Eel Creek and he comes high.

Establishment of a sales objective and the providing of incentives for salesmen to meet it are vitally important in successful selling, Carroll D. Evans, vice president and director of sales of the Fidelity Investment Association of Wheeling, W. Va., said yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer granted yesterday a motion made by depositors of the National Bank of Greece for the appointment of a receiver for any assets which the bank may have in New York State. He also denied a motion to dismiss the suit made in behalf of the bank.

A preview opening of "The Road to Mandalay," a new luncheon, dinner and supper rendezvous in the Hotel Delmonico next Wednesday night will be conducted as a benefit for the Emergency Shelter at 69 St. Mark's Place.

Funeral services for Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius will be held tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock at the Shelter, her home here. Mrs. Stettinius, widow of a former J. P. Morgan Co. partner, died last night.

Five hundred and thirty additional gifts to the United Hospital campaign, including one of $5,000 from Mrs. John Schiff, were announced last night by C. W. Chester. chairman of the campaign in behalf of the ninety-two voluntary member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn. The new gifts brought the total number of contributions to date to more than 15,000.

Following is an unofficial translation of the text of the Franco-German declaration signed here today. The text was framed and signed in both the French and German languages. M. GEORGES BONNET, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the French Republic, And M. JOACHIM VON RIBBENTROP, Minister of Foreign Affairs for the German Reich,

The proper address of the two floors leased by Tankoos, Smith Co. to Albert Turner, Inc., manufacturers of men's clothing, is 149-51 Fifth Avenue, running through to 921-25 Broadway. Real Estate Board members interested in contract bridge will hold the first of a series of sessions
Turpentine firm, 211/2c; sales 42 barrels; receipts 328 barrels; shipments 2 barrels; stock '53,105 barrels.

John D. Appleby, division chief of prohibition agents of New York and New Jersey during President Harding's administration, died Sunday. Funeral services will be held here Thursday. During the hip-pocket flask era Mr. Appleby received wide publicity. As "land admiral" of the prohibition navy,

Prominent clergy and laymen of the Roman Catholic Church and leaders in business and finance attended a high mass of requiem yesterday for Peter J. Maloney, a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange.

Governor Lehman of New York, passing through Chicago today, said that he had noted marked improvement in business in Los Angeles, where he spent a three weeks' vacation. He only chuckled when asked about Alfred M. Landon's recent statement "nominating" him as the Democratic candidate for President in 1940. He refused to discuss politics.

The Washington Post said tonight that Cliff Battles, former Washington Redskin backfield star, had disclosed he would confer this week with officials of the Cleveland Rams professional football team on what he believed would be a coaching offer-and that he was willing to take the job.

A plea for greater emphasis on progressivism in education than on new school buildings was voiced yesterday morning by Mayor La Guardia at exercises in Brooklyn marking the dedication of new Public School: 191, Park Place between Buffalo and Ralph Avenues.

By defeating the Short Hills team, 3-2, yesterday in the New Jersey Division of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association interclub matches, the Montclair Athletic Club got revenge for a former defeat, thus bringing it within striking distance of the pace-setting Short Hills players.

Bernie Friedkin of Brooklyn, 134, registered his fourth triumph in as many starts last night at the Broadway Arena. He outpointed Wally Hally, Los Angeles, 1313/4, in the featured eight-round bout. Friedkin took every round. There were no knockdowns, but a barrage of rights and lefts almost spilled Hally in the sixth.

On the eve of the thirty-seventh annual convention of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, traditionally the scene of a flurry of Winter trading, numerous deals affecting players and managers were announced tonight.

" Non-Aryans" were conspicuously absent from a brilliant dinner offered tonight by Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet to Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, his wife and the members of the German delegation that came here for the signing of the Franco-German declaration of friendship.

With the danger of a "war" among wheat-producing countries greater than at any time in recent years, United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy, as chairman of the International Wheat Advisory Committee, today summoned the twenty-one member nations to meet in London Jan. 10.
The stock market was depressed today by the uncertain international outlook and the rise in unemployment. Giltedge stocks all declined and foreign bonds were lower where changed.

When the White House arranged fo a world-wide broadcast of what President would say at the University of North Carolina, natural expectation were aroused which the text of speech did not satisfy. It proved to be calm, good-humored deliverance tha will take no high place in his published writings. Unless, therefore,
The Rev. Charles T. McDaniel, pastor of the Holy Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church, Hoboken, for the last twenty-five years, died late last night at the Christ Hospital here. He was 73 years old.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and his bride, the former Manuela Hudson, have purchased the six-acre waterfront estate known as the Lindens, at Sands Point, L. I., and will occupy the place after making improvements. J. Ralph Bloomer was the broker.
THE ABC OF THE FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM, by Edwin Walter Kemmerer. (Princeton University Press, $2.50.) A new edition.
A children's holiday party will be given on the afternoon of Dec. 27 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to aid the work of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Cancer Institute.

Business is generally getting better, said William S. Knudsen, president of the General Motors Corporation in answer to questions by reporters today when he left the witness stand at the hearing of the Temporary National Economic Committee.

On recommendation of the New York State Tax Commission the Village Board of Valley Stream has agreed to reduce by about $655,000 the assessment on property of the Long Island Railroad within the corporate limits.

Despite the strong opposition of the National Maritime Union to the government's merchant marine training school on Hoffman Island, seamen who are receiving instruction on the island, in lower New York bay, have expressed approval of the system and have issued an appeal to the union for cooperation with the government.
The store and apartment building at 356 Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased for cash by the Gotham Equities Corporation (Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner). The four-family brick house at

Members of the library committee of the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York, of which Mrs. Francis Boardman is chairman, will give their annual reception tomorrow afternoon at the clubhouse of the society, 215 East Seventy-first Street.

Mrs. John Delafield, representing the women's committee of the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens, received first prize for her arrangement of a centerpiece in the table decorations contest of the City Gardens Club at the organization's annual luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Pierre.

Building loans aggregating $310,000 on the .six and seven story apartment -houses under construction on plots 100 by 100 feet each on the southwest corner of Park Terrace West and 215th Street and the southeast corner of Seaman Avenue and 215th Street have been arranged for Alexander and Samuel Grutman, owners, by Jacob and Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers. Other realty financing;

Losing no time in beginning construction of the controversial $28,000,000 Circumferential Parkway in Brooklyn and Queens, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday plans for a ceremony to be held in Whitestone, Queens, at noon Saturday.

The Rumanian Legation filed an informal protest today with the German Government against the violent campaign being conducted in the Reich press against the Rumanian Government and even against King Carol personally because of the shooting of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, Rumanian Fascist Iron Guard leader, and his fellow prisoners.
Aided chiefly by a six-week stretch of near-perfect weather in the East, attendance at college football games for 1938 showed a sharp increase over 1937 figures.

The Seventy-ninth Street transverse road through Central Park was closed to traffic for six hours yesterday when a twenty-inch water main broke soon after 5 A. M. It took more than four hours to find the break, which was about 350 feet west of Fifth Avenue. Repair crews worked speedily and at 11:15 A. M. the police allowed traffic to move through the underpass.

THE avocado, carambola, water chestnut, citron, the cobnut, dasheen, fig and grumichama, the jaboticaba, Khalasa date, litchi nut and mangosteen, the nectarine, Kaffir orange, Siberian pea and papaya, the pistachio, soy bean, flat Venetian squash and Finland turnip-an enormous range of growing things, from edible acorns to zucchini, is covered in David Fairchild's "The World Was My Garden,"* a fascinating book with fine pictures that might have been mentioned here months ago.

Because contracts for the bout were signed before receipt of official notification of Tommy Farr's suspension by the British Board of Boxing Control, the State Athletic Commission, at its meeting yesterday, ruled that the fifteen-round battle between Great Britain's heavyweight and Lou Nova, Californian, on Dec. 16 in Madison Square Garden, will proceed as scheduled.

The Century Club, one of the oldest cultural organizations of this city, will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary tomorrow night with a golden jubilee dinner at the home here of Mrs. Robert Dix Benson.

Robert E. McLear, an attorney in New York since 1910, died here today of a heart attack in his home. His age was 61. Mr. McLear was a partner with his brother, Herbert G. McLear of Manhattan Beach, L. I., in the firm of McLear McLear at 141 Broadway.
A number of tenement houses in scattered sections of the city changed hands in the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday. Savings banks figured as principals in two of the transactions.
