" True religion" alone can overcome the forces bringing shame on civilization, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday afternoon before 800 women at a meeting of the Diocesan Women's Auxiliary of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Big manufacturers of men's clothing are looking forward to a moderately prosperous early 1939 business, investigation showed today. Sales of Spring lines are running currently about 12 to 14 per cent ahead of 1937 in units, although the gain in dollars is less because prices average from 8 to 10 per cent lower.

While thirty pickets representing American Federation of labor unions and the Workers Alliance marched around City Hall today in support of the Federal slum-clearance and low-rent housing program, a new majority in the city commission took steps to abolish the local Housing Authority.

Following Monday's resistance to selling pressure as March approached the 8-cent level, the cotton market here advanced 8 to 11 points yesterday, making an improvement of $1 a bale from the low levels of the week.

Jaime Jaramillo Arango, who with drew from Germany without presenting his credentials as Colombia's Minister after detention by the police when he photographed Nazis wrecking Jewish-owned stores, has been appointed Minister to Denmark.

Henry G. Alsberg, director of the WPA Writers Project, told the Dies committee investigating un-American activities today that the writers' project in New York had experienced difficulties with Communists and that it had taken two years "to clean up the mess."
References to Germany's anti-Jewish drive and Baron Rothschild's appeal on behalf of the Jews has been deleted by the censor from the Paramount newsreel that Is being shown here.

Jack Frye, president of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., said today that the deletion of the slogan "The Lindbergh Line" from the company's current advertising literature was a "routine change."

The Rebels continued to bomb Loyalist towns today with a ferocity that is making this period one of the most horrible of the war. The number of towns bombed since Friday is at least thirty, and the minimum casualties are estimated at 300 killed, with perhaps 1.000 wounded.
Those hunters who went to Quebec this Fall for the moose hunting were extremely successful, according to the records of the fish and game officials of that Province.

Fresh instruotions were sent today to Shigenori Togo, Japanese Ambassador to Russia, directing him to press for completion of the new fishery convention. In a published statement the Foreign Office spokesman warned Russia that "a satisfactory settlement is essential for the preservation of normal relations between Japan and the Soviet Union, consequently for the peace of Eastern Asia."

The general death rate for the city rose sharply last week to 10.5 for 1,000 off population from 8.9 for the preceding week, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Dec. 6 unless specified: Navy Yard, Pear Harbor, to San Diego; Aylwin, Dale, Farragut, Monaghan. At San Diego: Cuyama, Kanawha. At Newport: Hamilton, Helm, Ralph Talbot. Mugford.

The signing of the Franco-German accord in Paris today is greeted by the German press with mildly warm enthusiasm. While reiterating a sentiment often repeated here in recent weeks, that there are no reasons why France and Germany should not live as peaceful, friendly neighbors, editorial comment concentrates more on the importance of the Rome-Berlin axis and the effects it has had on the contemporary scene.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange suspended yesterday dealings in the securities of McKesson Robbins, Inc., on receipt of word that a court in Hartford, Conn., had heard charges of mismanagement and falsification of books and had appointed temporary equity receivers.

The Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation filed an amendment with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday fixing the price of its offering of 150,000 shares of $2.50 prior preference stock at $50 a share, the company announced here. Shares not taken up by the preferred stockholders may be offered to the public by the underwriters at $50 a share plus accrued dividends.
George Anderson Cooke, former Chief Justice of the Illinois Supreme Court, died early today at his home, 233 East Walton Place. He was 69 years old.

Mrs. Harriet J. Robinson, 46-yearold widow, who was arrested last July on a charge of defrauding another woman of $25,000 in gems while awaiting trial on indictments for alleged thefts totaling $250,000 from customers of her brokerage office three years ago, was allowed to plead guilty yesterday in General Sessions to second-degree attempted grand larceny.
The annual Maryknoll opera concert at the Metropolitan Opera House will be held this season the evening of Jan. 8, instead of the first Sunday after Christmas as has previously been the custom.

Alumnae of Colby College have subscribed $75,792 toward the $100,000 necessary to construct a women's union building on the college's new campus at Waterville, Me., it was announced last night at an alumnae dinner at the Prince George Hotel.

Forme Judge Jonah J. Goldstein was re-elected president of the Grand Street Boys Association and former Mayor James J. Walker was re-elected fifth vice president at the annual election held last night at the organization's clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

A teletype alarm designed to locate an unidentified woman who had accepted less than a dollar in change for a $100 bill went out from police headquarters last night after a Negro taxi driver had reported the case to the West Forty-seventh Street police station.

President Roosevelt today laughed off for the second time a press conference question as to whether he would consider a third term. A reporter inquired of the President whether he would accede to the wishes of Senator Guffey, who recently joined the ranks of thirdterm proponents.

Widespread price cutting,. a feature. of the local retail liquor market every December since repeal, began in midtown' and lower Manhattan yesterday and gave consumers an opportunity to purchase holiday stocks of liquor at. prices ranging from a few cent to more than $1 a bottle below regular levels. By nightfall the price slashes had spread to some stores in Brooklyn and Queens.

With the closing of the filing period, applications have been received from seventy-five men and women-a few from out of town-for the five $10,000 positions of assistant superintendent of schools now vacant, Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent in charge of personnel, announced yesterday.

Elizabeth St, 286-8, 46.4X75; Giuseppe Livoti to Bowery Realties, Inc, 288 Elizabeth St; deed dated June 21, 1935. 17th St, 228 W, 25X84; Central Savings Bank to 228 W 17th St Corp, 1,751 Anthony Ave ($18). 29th St, 39-43 E, 63.7X98.9; Dry Dock Savings Institution to 316 W 34th St Corp, 122 E 42d St ($65). 85th St, 36 W, 16X102.2; Wm. R. Bogert, ref, to Metropolitan Life Ins Co; foreclosure ($12).
The State Court of Appeals upheld today the first-degree murder conviction of Simon Elmore for the slaying of Joan Kuleba in New York City on Aug. 12. 1937.
Three thousand Americans yearly may now enter Brazil, the immigration authorities have ruled.

The McLellan Stores Company estimated yesterday that its net profit for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 was $800,609 after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the result was equivalent to 85 cents each on 733,187 shares of $1 par common stock.
Wheat showed a firm undertone throughout the day on the Board of Trade, and while the best prices were not maintained the close showed gains of 1/4 cent a bushel.

A lease of a large unit of space in Fifth Avenue and of quarters for a restaurant enterprise on Gramercy Park North featured the commercial rentals announced yesterday. Coudurier, Fructus Devigne, Inc., silk importers with mills in Lyons and Alsace, France, took the fourth floor in the building at 681

An increase of 25 per cent in the turnover of business in the United States would go "almost the whole way toward curing our unemployment difficulties, paying our debts and accumulating new capital," Floyd L. Carlisle, head of the Consolidated Edison Company, said last night,

IT was just after Lippy Leo Durocher had been signed to manage the Artless Dodgers that Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick, secretary of the Giants, fled the country with both hands held aloft in horror. He went to Italy to get away from it--all and just recently he returned wearing a mustache and uttering strange phrases he picked up in the realm of n Duce. He was encountered yesterday and, giving the Fascist salute, he said:

Nine hundred United States stamps assembled during the last fifteen years by a retired Philadelphia broker described as "Mr. X," were sold yesterday at public auction for between $36,000 and $37,000 by Philip H. Ward Jr. of Philadelphia at the Collectors Club of New York.

A high tide and a sweeping wind piled up heavy seas along the southern Rhode Island coast tonight, cutting a dozen temporary gulfs across beaches that were flat tened in the September hurricane. With the sea rising to its highest level sinnce Sept. 21.
Mrs. Francis Bayard Rives will give a tea next Wednesday at her home, 1,021 Park Avenue, for the Misses Elisabeth L. Godwin and Constance and Beatrix Hoyt, debutantes of the season.

A board of officers is appointed to meet at Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., at the call of the president thereof, to examine such persons as may be properly ordered before it to determine their fitness for appointment or certificate of capacity In the Officers' Reserve Corps.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, appealed to fellow-engineers last night to make the welfare of the workingman one of the principal aims of engineering and to apply their engineering skill toward the creation of an industrial democracy within the framework of a political democracy.

A story of the slaughter of 900 whales in Shark Bay off Western Australia, told by Lieutenant T. R. Midtlyng, a Coast Guard officer, resulted yesterday in the filing of a libel by the government against the oil cargo of the whaler Frango, one of the two remaining "factory ships" that fly the United States flag.

Collections from retailers during November totaled 78 per cent of the amount of outstanding receivables as of Nov. 1, according to the report issued yesterday by the Garment Credit Conference, Inc., based on data from the forty member firms in dress, coat and suit and fur lines. The report is the first of its kind issued by the conference.

The seven-story apartment house on a plot 200 by 125 feet at 17 North Chatsworth Avenue, Larchmont, Westchester County, was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of Samuel Reynolds, attorney.

No country on earth is today so conscious of world movements going on outside its own borders as the United States. Indeed, our people may know more about what is happening within a given nation than its own nationals. For this spread of light the Foreign Policy Association deserves no small share of credit.

Religion faces a double threat from the totalitarian States, Charles P. Taft, chairman of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs, warned today at the opening of the biennial meeting of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America. He said that those States not only tried to weaken the church but also competed with it by using two of its most important characteristics, "the leadership principle and the idea of community."
Preston Delano, controller of the currency, announced today that William Prentiss Jr., chief national bank examiner for the San Francisco district, had resigned.

Bonds worked irregularly higher yesterday in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The bond market, as a whole, seemed to reflect the improvement in the share market, as most groups participated in varying degrees in the upturn.

In the same room at the Quai d'Orsay in which the Pact of Paris was signed ten years ago, the Governments of Germany and France gave their approval yesterday to a declaration of non-aggression. This is the French counterpart of the Anglo-German agreement which Mr. Chamberlain brought home with him from Munich, shortly before Great Britain began to rearm with increased vigor.

Charles King of 31 East Twelfth Street, who retired in 1928 as head of Tams King, yacht brokers, died on Monday in Roosevelt Hospital after an illness of three months. He was born in Morristown, N. J., fifty-two years ago, of distinguished ancestry.
The city of Memphis has notified the Memphis Power and Light Company that it will proceed immediately with construction of its municipal electric distribution system.
The German Consul General at San Francisco, Baron Manfred von Killinger, has been called to berlin by his government to "give a detailed report on the situation on the West Coast."

Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen and his extraordinary grand jury, investigating the conduct of law enforcement agencies in Brooklyn, began yesterday to study evidence in the fur racket case upon which the sweeping inquiry was predicated because of rumors of "official corruption" involving a member of the staff of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan.
Premier Paul-Henri Spaak obtained a vote of confidence, 111 to 49 with 21 abstentions, after a prologned debate in the Chamber of Deputies today, but it is not certain that he will remain in office.

The Herald and Examiner and The Chicago Evening American continued publication today while leaders of the Chicago Newspaper Guild started mass picketing of the Hearst plant and issued statements that the circulation of both papers had been "hard hit" by the strike of Guildsmen called early yesterday morning.

Undaunted by armored cars patrolling the streets and a nightly curfew on all highways throughout the country, Jerusalem's music-loving public tonight enthusiastically greeted Bronislaw Huberman's playing as violin soloist with the Palestine Orchestra conducted by Eugen Szenkar.

Addressing 1,500 persons assembled at the Hotel Astor last night to promote the establishment of a Leon Blum colony in Palestine for the settlement of 1,000 Jewish refugee families, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed to Americans to cling to their ideals and by the force of "thought and example" to return the world to "kindness, goodwill and liberty."

The export trade of the United States held up better with Asia than with any other continent in October, compared with October, 1937, the Department of Commerce disclosed today in a further analysis of exports and imports.
Steel ingot production slackened last week, countering a seasonal rise, and the adjusted index declined to 96.5 from 99.6. The figure was 46.1 for the week ended Dec. 4. 1937.

With latest registration figures indicating that at least three automobile companies are now running ahead of last year, the prospect for 1939 motor advertising lineage has brightened considerably, as expenditures are generally based on unit sales, according to agencies here yesterday.

J. Jerome Hahn, former Associate Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court and a native of Albany, N. Y., died here today. He was 70 years old. He had been retired since January, 1935, when Democrats swept five Supreme Court Justices from office.

An urgent appeal to the world in general and the United States in particular to "open the barriers" to Jewish emigration from Germany was made today by Leo Kreindler, editor of a Jewish news sheet of two pages the only Jewish newspaper permitted in Berlin.

Conferences preliminary to the Congress of American Industry, opening today at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, ended yesterday with the indication that industry was eager to cooperate with all elements in the economic structure-agriculture, labor and government-to reduce unemployment and hasten recovery.

Six members of the household of Jefferson Armstrong, Westchester County Supervisor, were saved from a possible asphyxiation by gas early this morning when a maid surprised a ourglar, who had opened the jets in a kitchen range, and then wakened the family before the gas seeped up to the bedrooms. The burglar escaped with a fur and watch, valued at $1.000.

Miss Dorothy Shepard of this city and her sister, Mrs. B. Devereux Barker of Boston, gave a tea yesterday at the Colony Club for their niece, Miss Madeleine F. Butt, a debutante of this season, and for Mrs. James Parker Vogel.

ACKERT, HELENA V. V. (Nov. 11). Es tate, less than $10,000. To Winfred R Ackert, husband, executor, 352 W. 46f St., residue. ANHALT, SARAH (Dec. 1). Estate, les than $5,000. To Sadie A. Stern, daughter 450 West End Ave., and Jacob Anhalt son, 36 Adelaide Ave., Providence, R. I. half residue each; specific bequest. Henr: Stern, executor. 450 West End Ave.
The touring Marylebone Cricket Club team was held to a draw by Natal today in the fifth match of its South African tour.

Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, administrator of the Archdiocese of New York, in an address yesterday at a pontifical mass in the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation, Convent Avenue and 131st Street, told a thousand young men and women representing the Catholic colleges and universities in the city that they should be grateful they live in a country where freedom of worship is permitted.

Stout Steve Owen stared out the clubhouse window at the Polo Grounds yesterday morning. Rain pattered down and the gridiron was a sea of mud. Stout Steve turned to his New York Giants and shook his head. "No practice today, fellows," he said. "If we went out there they'd have to get a derrick to haul us out of the mud."

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 5: MAJOR GENERALS Wilson, W. H., Boston, Mass., to command of Hawaiian Division, to sail from New York about Feb. 7. Woodruff, J. A., in command of Hawaiian Division, to command of First Corps Area,. Boston. Mass.

Charles H. Swift has been elected honorary president of Swift Internacional, S. A., according to an announcement received here today from Buenos Aires. The post of president, which he had held since 1932, has been filled by the election of Harry McLerie.

Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Lawrence N. Martin, trustees for liquidation of the $28,000,000 issue of mortgage investments known as Series F-1 of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, announced yesterday that a distribution of $818,964 would be made to certificate holders on Dec. 31.
Paul Y. Anderson, a Washington news writer for almost twenty years, died early today at his home here after the second of two apparent attempts to take his own life. He was 45 years of age.

John J. Sullivan, who has had several conflicts with the Fusion administration and the Federal Government over his "watchman" duties at the Wallabout Market, Brooklyn, in the last five years, received a suspended sentence yesterday in Brooklyn Special Sessions

There was great excitement and an audience that packed the Metropolitan Opera House when Beniamino Gigli, the tenor of international fame, who left the Metropolitan Opera Company in the season of 1931-1932, owing to a difference with the former management, reappeared in that historic auditorium.

Five officers of the Bankers Trust Company who have completed a quarter-century of service with the bank and John I. Downey with the bank as a director and officer since 1900 were guests last night at a dinner of the Quarter Century Club of the bank in the University Club. S. Sloan Colt, president of the bank, presented momentos to the new members of the club.

Major Bob Neyland signed a contract today to remain at the University of Tennessee as football coach and athletic director for seven more years. President James D. Hoskins of the university said the contract was,

The adverse reaction of Japanese business sentiment to the government's proposed 'control measures and the prospect of heavier budget expenditures and higher taxes to carry on the war with China featured the Department of Commerce's weekly summary of developments over the world during the week ended Nov. 26.

Nell Colville, Mac Colville, Alex Shibieky, Phil Watson, in 235 W 71st St; Thomas Sidoti, in 214 Riverside Rrive; B. Lynch, in 230 W 76th St; William Westaway, in 46 W 96th St; Maude Sullivan, in 222 W 77th St; Milton Hesse, in 41 W 72d St; Mrs. E. Freudenthal, in 230 W 79th St; Leon Aronson, in 245 W 75th St; Alice H. Blair, in London Terrace; Apartment Leasing Service, broker.

Lively sittings are expected when Parliament resumes its session Thursday afternoon, as decided by the Cabinet this morning. Sixteen interpellations have been tabled by Communist members and a great many others from all parts of the Chamber are awaiting discussion.
Dr. Anne Walter Fearn, a physician in China, has delivered to Harper the manuscript of her autobiography, which is scheduled for early Spring publication.
The Public Service Commission adjourned today until Dec. 21 its investigation into the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation's financial dealings with allegedly affiliated service companies.
Business, as represented by Edsel Ford and a half dozen other employers, told a Senate committee today that lower taxes would go a long way toward promoting industrial recovery.

The 1,389 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $50,301,123,815 par value as of Nov. 30, had a total market value of $45,441,652,321, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. As of Oct. 31,

Joseph M. W. Page, Jerseyville publisher and secretary of the National Press Association from 1887 to 1900, died at his home here last night. He was 93 years old. Known as Uncle Joe throughout State newspaper circles, Mr. Page also had served as secretary of the Illinois Press Association for twentyfive years.
Martha Marek was beheaded here today after her conviction of four poison murders between 1932 and 1936 to obtain insurance money.
Accounting methods employed by Loew's, Inc., to arrive at gross profits for the purpose of computing compensation for its top ranking officials were attacked yesterday in Supreme Court.
Upon completion of "Union .Pacific" at Paramount, Barbara Stanwyck is to return to RKO. Today purchase of "Hearts Unknown," by Frances Parkinson Keyes, was announced as the next vehicle for the star.

Two teams shot one under par 71s today to share top honors in a four-ball best-ball tourney that .gave more than forty veteran golf professionals a chance to tune up for the first round of the seniors' championship starting tomorrow.

Joseph J. Lordi, top-ranking player in the tourney, gained the semi-final round of the Fall scratch squash, tennis tournament at the Columbia University Club courts yesterday by vanquishing E. G. McLaughlin, Columbia, in three games, 6-15,15-6, 15-2.
The annual meeting and election of officers of the National Democratic Club was held last night in the clubhouse at 233 Madison Avenue. The officers elected for the ensuing year were: President,

A strong squad of Scotland Yard detectives saw Prince Paul of Yugoslavia off for home today. A spokesman at Scotland Yard denied flatly, however, that the Regent had cut short his visit in London because of a reported warning that Croatian terrorists were en route from New York to "get" him.

Trunk-line railroads operating in New Jersey proposed today to a special committee of the Legislature here that a compromise of litigated taxes be effected on a basis of two-thirds of the total levy since 1931.

A message of tempered Christmas cheer was delivered to Britain tonight by Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy of the United States only twenty-four hours after the depressing statement by Defense Minister Oswald Pirow of South Africa that envisaged a European war next Spring.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull, who heads the American delegation to the Lima conference opening Friday, received an overwhelming vote of confidence from the American public in a survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today A. Harry Weisman of Brooklyn, N. Y., was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 222-The Washingtonian Publishing Co., Inc., petr., v. Drew Pearson, Robert S. Alien, et al. Argued for both.
The two large six-story apartment houses at 35-53 Eighty-second Street and 35-54 Eighty-third Street, in the heart of Jackson Heights, Queens, have been sold by Sam Minskoff Sons. builders.
Many dinner parties were given before the performance of "Great Lady" last night at the Majestic Theatre, which had been taken over for the benefit of the Music School Settlement.

Manned by a crew of French Navy men and "company personnel," replacing union strikers, the liner Paris left this strike-torn seaport tonight for Cherbourg, where in a calmer atmosphere the vessel is expected to take aboard passengers and sail for New York tomorrow.

France and Germany set their seals yesterday on a joint declaration designed to keep peace between them and promptly began to discus other issues. Regarding Spain, France's view that she still hoped for a moderate government there that would give up no territory to a foreign power was well received by the ...
The government will announce tomorrow that the Passenger Ship Act, barring the use of ships. as hotels in the colony's two harbors, except with special permission, has been approved by King George.

N. H. P. Vesey announced in the Assembly today that he would introduce a message to the Governor pointing out that the recent trade agreement between the United States and Great Britain referred to British colonies as "non-self-governing," and that presumably that classification applies to Bermuda.

Continuing the German press campaign against Rumania, the Essener National Zeitung flatly charges today that Corneliu Zela Codreanu, Iron Guard (Fascist) leader, and his fellowprisoners were shot not while trying to escape but in their cells at the express order of the commander-in-chief of Rumania's gendarmery.

The Department of Agriculture reported today that imports of sugar into the United States during the first eleven months this year totaled 4,568,554 short tons, raw value, and that importation of an additional 198,495 tons this month would exhaust quotas for 1938.

Helen Vinson of the stage and screen filed suit today for divorce from Fred Perry, former world's amateur tennis champion who turned professional. Charging various acts of mental- cruelty, she said that the British net star often became enraged at her without provocation.

Secretary Hull has had to deal with a succession of difficult and ticklish matters. He has practiced no arts of popularity. He has been composed, patient, firm. His natural dignity, his modesty, the soundness of his judgment are no attributes of parade.

After lying dormant for several months, the steel wage situation has again been brought to the fore by a proposal of a group of McKeesport Tin Plate Corporation workers to accept voluntarily a wage cut in exchange for a guarantee for more work.
Mott St, 196-98; Miriam Regenbogen to East River Savings Bank; p m mtg, $45.000. 64th St, 27-31 W; Park-64th St, Inc, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; 4 1/2 per cent: $32,000.

Although playing only ten men throughout the second half, Scotland defeated Hungary, 3-1, in an international soccer match played before 20,000 spectators at Ibrox Park today. The Scots dominated the play all the way and led, 3-0, at half-time.

Mrs. Alice B. Horn, wife of C. Lester Horn, former head of the New York brokerage firm bearing his name and now reorganization manager for the Follansbee Brothers Steel Company of Pittsburgh, died yesterday in Knickerbocker Hospital.
Dick Bartell, fiery National League shortstop, was not particularly excited today about his trade to the Cubs. He said he had no idea the Giants would trade him, but added:

The strong New York Athletic Club, headed by Harry Wolf, national champion, maintained its perfect record in the Class A race among teams of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League- last night, by defeating the Short Hills team with, the loss of only one match, 4-1.

Despite Severe Laborite heckling, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today refused to disavow the speech last Sunday in which Earl De La Warr, Minister of Education, deplored the apparent impossibility of satisfying Germany, and declared, "Only armaments can speak effectively."

" Enlarged buying programs in railroad material and equipment, construction steel, tin plate, automotive equipment and miscellaneous business are definitely in sight," Iron Age says this week. it continues:

The trial of Hans Heinrich Schackow who was arrested with three other Germans on charges of unlawfully obtaining photographs of Panama Canal defenses began in District court here today before Judge Bunk Gardner.

Dr. Hu Shih, the new Chinese Ambassador to the United States, has been resting in the Harkness Pavilion at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center since Monday, it was disclosed yesterday at the office of the Chinese Consulate General.

Announcement that another "world wheat conference" is. summoned to meet at London on Jan. 10, merely recognizes that the surplus-production problem remains to be dealt with. Last July, when the International-Wheat Conference met at London, the situation was troublesome enough; but the conference postponed action.

Joseph Cattarinich of Montreal, part owner of the New Orleans, Collinsville and Aurora (Ill.) race tracks, died in a hospital here today. He had undergone an operation on his eye and died of a heart attack while under the anesthetic. His age was 57.

The James Madison High School house basketball team trounced the Manual quintet, 52 to 28, yesterday on the winners' court for its second straight victory in Section 2 of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. race. Madison led at the half, 22 to 10.

The National Labor Relations Board today removed the name of the Commerc I Telegraphers Union of the A. F. of L. from the ballot in the coming poll of Postal Telegraph Company employes and left on the ballot only the name of the American Communications Associations, a C. I. 0. affiliate. The C. T. U.
Directors of the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., voted yesterday to omit the dividends on the Class A and B common stock, which have been paid continuously since July 1, 1932.
The department of stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has been notified by the Pittston Company of proposed modifications to the plan of readjustment approved by stockholders on Oct. 10.

Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced today a series of field conferences to start the permanent phase of the decentralization program for handling contested tax cases. The conferences so far scheduled are: Chicago. Dec. 12 and 13;

Public offering will be made today by an underwriting group of thirty-five members headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., of $48,000,000 of bonds and debentures of the Central Illinois Public Service Company. The offering consists of $38,000,000 of first mortgage 33/4 per cent Series A bonds due on Dec. 1, 1968, and $10,000,000 of 31/2-4 per cent serial debentures due on Dec. 1, 1939 to 1948.
Walter James (Rabbit) Maranville will be the new manager of the Albany Senators' baseball team of the Eastern League during the 1939 season, officials of the club announced today.

The music committee of the Junior League, with Mrs. Alexander McLanahan as chairman and Mrs. J. T. Johnston Mali, vice chairman; gave a luncheon yesterday for Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist, after his recital at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventyfirst Street.

The movement to advance Vice President Garner as a Democratic candidate for -President was marked today by the issuance of letters by the National Democratic Education Club, which declares it is out to win delegates for the Texan following the action of his neighbors yesterday in Detroit, Texas, in pushing him for 1940's standard bearer.

The last opening until week after next will take place this evening at the Morosco. "Spring Meeting," they name it, a story of Irish life by the novelist who calls herself M. J. Farrell, in collaboration with John Perry. Gladys Cooper, A. E. Matthews, Jean Cadell, Arthur Shields, James Woodburn, Aideen O'Connor and others are in it.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Nov. 26 totaled 270,563,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Contributions of $11,644 to the 1939 budget campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York were reported by workers at a luncheon at the Hotel.Biltmore yesterday. The new gifts brought the total amount raised to $119,360. The quota needed is $205,000.

On the campus at City College, where basketball is, the king of sports, the recent victory over Brooklyn College is not interpreted as a sure sign of success this season, but the unanimous opinion is that the triumph brightened the prospects considerably.

Charles Imatz, generally known as "the district's greatest hotelkeeper," is dead here at the age of 68. M. Imatz, who was a Basque, took pride that during his youth he had served on the kitchen staff of the late King Edward VII.

Roger W. Babson, the statistician, predicted in an address here yesterday that business conditions would be favorable during the next two years, but he said the longterm "trend line" was headed downward and could lead only to "inflation, revolution or a change of heart on the part of the American people."

Returning to Albany today after a vacation in California, Governor Lehman plunged into the work of reducing budget requests from State department heads, who had already sought more than they asked for last year.

Weeks Ave (11-2800), e s, 75 ft n of 175th St, 38x95; Tremont Central Corp to 1,810 Corp, 4,140 Bway; mtg $45,500. Belmont Ave (11-2947), w s, 200 ft s of Tremont Ave, 100x67;. Tippany Realty, Inc, to Gold. Ray Properties, Inc, 51 . Chambers St; mtg $70,466.

Field Marshal Hermann Goering, Air Minister, today extended his compliments to.Lieutenant Hans Christiensen, Who, while flying as an observer on Sept. 15, safely landed a military plane after the pilot had been incapaciated by a wild duck.

Mrs. Cobina Wright, in 277 Park Ave; Miss Leslie Motris, in 960 5th Ave; Francis Keally, in 53 E 66th St; Victor Jacobs, in 136 E 36th St; Walter G. Benton, in 455 E 57th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers.

Jock Hutchison of Golf, Ill., defending titleholder, and Fred McLeod of Washington, D. C., national open champion in 1908, set the pace today with three-over-par 75s in the first round of the thirty-six-hole $2,000 medal play' seniors golf championship at the Augusta National course.

Matt J. Winn, the man responsible for the Kentucky Derby becoming America's best-known horse race, was in town yesterday on his annual visit, which combines business and- pleasure, and confirmed that the 1939 renewal of the Churchill Downs classic would be on May 6.
Senator Smathers, Democrat of New Jersey, said today that he agreed with Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania that the Democratic party should renominate President Roosevelt in 1940.

A-change in the system of distribution of Federal funds for the relief of unemployment, with Congress providing the formula governing that distribution, was urged last night by Senator James F. Byrnes of South Carolina, chairman of the Special Committee to Investigate Unemployment and Relief.
Despite the vigorous opposition of Board of Education officials, a bar has been opened directly beside a high school for girls, it became known yesterday.

No indictments were returned against Joseph Dobish of Wildwood, whose lion escaped at Wildwood in October, killing a Boardwalk auctioneer. The grand jury, however, returned a presentment recommending ordinances that would safeguard the public by requiring inspections of devices used in "thrill" games.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook denied yesterday a motion that would have restrained the Pathe Film Corporation from holding a special meeting Tuesday to consider a plan of dissolution and liquidation.

Confidence in the ability of New 'York City to deal with its financial obligations on a satisfactory basis was expressed yesterday by John S. Linen, second vice president of the Chase National Bank, in an address at the monthly meeting of the New York State Savings Bond Men in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Graduation, injuries and ineligibility have taken a heavy toll of Harvardrs major winter sport squads, With the result that the Crimson, as it took stock of the -situation today, feared that a season of comparative famine is destined to follow--in the wake of the sumptuous repast enjoyed in- basketball, hockey and swimming, during 19371938.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power electric revenue bond issue of $15,250,000, purchased yesterday by an underwriting syndicate, was as good as wholly sold on the reoffering to the public a few hours later.

William Burgess Nesbitt of 71 East Seventy-seventh Street, retired advertising executive who had an important part in developing the Interborough car card, station advertising, newsstand and merchandising business, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 51 years old.

S soon as Professor Moe Berg of the Boston Red Sox Department of Languages and Obscure Sciences can be located, this observer plans to consult him about an obscure item that popped up in the recent baseball news.

Mrs. Byron A. Long, wife of Captain Byron A. Long, U.S.N. (retired), and a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Fairchild, died early yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital after an illness of four weeks. Her age was 52.
Because of protests received at Madison Square Garden, flags other than the Stars and Stripes were removed from the decorations at the annual Winter sports show last night.

Battalions of investigators, representing the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Stock Exchange and private inter ests plunged yesterday into the mystery surrounding the drug business of McKesson Robbins, Inc.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Claude V. Allnutt of this place, formerely of Stamford, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katherine Underwood Allnutt, to Robert Max Schindell, son of Mrs. Philip Meisel Joyce of San Antonio, Texas, and Washington, D. C.

Miss Virginia Margaret Rush, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus T. Rush of Orange, was married this evening to Titus Harry Lang, son of Mrs. Joseph J. Catterall of Maplewood and J. Harry Lang of Chicago. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church, Short Hills, by the Rev. Herbert H. Cooper.

W9XZY, an experimental radio facsimile broadcasting station operated by the St. Louis Post Dispatch, began today the world's first regular broadcast on ultra high frequency of specially prepared facsimile newspapers. The broadcast will continue daily and Sunday at 2 P. M.
A jury that had deliberated twenty-three hours returned a verdict of guilty yesterday in General Sessions against James Gibbs, 56 years old, of 116 Hilton Avenue, Garden City, L. I.

An order prohibiting homework in the artificial flower and feather industry, which was suspended July 14 pending its review by the Board of Standards and Appeals, will become fully operative and binding upon the entire industry in New York State on Dec. 19, it was announced yesterday by Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner.
Heavy weather laid a blanket of low-lying clouds over Eastern Spain today, making bombing virtually impossible. Only Alicante was attacked, according to information available here.

There was filed with the County Registrar at Jersey City yesterday afternoon a mortgage whereby the Stanley Company of America ob- . gained from the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn., a loan of $1,750,000 on its theatres and equipment located day. in New Jersey.

Electric power production increased last week, but less, than anticipated on the basis of normal trends, and the adjusted index declined to 96.8 from 98.1. The figure for the week ended Dec. 4, 1937, was 96.1.
Editorial employes of the Albany Knickerbocker News have voted 28 to 10, against the Tri-City Newspaper Guild as its collective bargaining representative, it was stated today.

EN ROUTE from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, to Buenos Aires, Argentina, Dec. 1.-While the stony headlands of Brazil's rugged coast and the thickly-wooded contours of her mountain ranges fade gradually in the distance, this correspondent is busily trying to bring order into ai maze of impressions collected during a short but highly instructive Brazilian sojourn.

Scribner announces the forthcoming publication in eight volumes of a complete edition of the works of John Keats. Besides Keats's literary works, it will include his letters, a biographical sketch and other material. It will be called the Hempstead Edition.

Manhattan opened its basketball season impressively by defeating Cooper Union, 52 to 21, at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. Johnny Kravetz, one of the two sophomores used by Coach Neil Cohalan in the starting line-up, was high scorer for the Jaspers, registering eleven points.

Archibald R. Watson, Clerk of New York County, announced yesterday the appointment of Timothy J. Sullivan, former acting president of the Board of Aldermen and one of the Democratic leaders of. the Eighteenth Assembly District, as a deputy county clerk at $6,000 a year.

Governor Charles F. Hurley and his family will sail for Ireland in June to visit a forty-acre, $40,000 estate which has been bequeathed to the Governor by his uncle, Timothy, of County Kerry, who died in September.

" THE Birth of the Oil Industry"* is excep tionally interesting history in spite of the title, which is unpromising enough. The book itself makes as good reading as anything we have had in its field all season, and it appears to be at least as carefully done. The author is Paul H. Giddens, Professor of History and Political Science at Allegheny College.
The New York Giants, who have so far snatched the limelight at the convention of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, appeared tonight to be on the verge of another deal or two.

The city's taxicab drivers were installed last night as "good-will ambassadors" of the World's Fair by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, at ceremonies in the fair's Transportation Building.

An explosion, followed by fire, seriously injured three men in the filter plant of the Tidewater Oil Company at Bayonne, N. J., shortly after 2 o'clock this morning, and caused the company to call 1,000 employes from their homes to aid in preventnig the flames from spreading to an adjacent storage yard.

William H. Brown has been appointed secretary of the American Viscose Corporation, effective Jan. 1, Samuel A..Salvage, chairman of the, board of directors, announced yesterday. Frank H. Griffin,' vice. president, was named technical director.

New York City securities command a public interest second to none except, perhaps, United States Government obligations. This is attributed, first, to the huge amount of city bonds outstanding, and second, to the spectacular restorationo of the city's credit since the dark days of 1932 and 1933.

Outstanding news stories of the last century will be broadcast on Christmas Day coincidental with the ninetieth anniversary of the founding of The Associated Press and dedication of the new Associated Press offices in Rockefeller Center.

A General Sessions jury in less than an hour yesterday acquitted Alexander Carter, 36 years old, a Negro, of 169 Edgecombe Avenue, on an indictment that he criminally operated a motor truck last Christmas Eve which struck and killed two women at Liberty and West Streets and injured other persons when they were crossing the street.

MANHATTAN BOTHA, JULIUS (Nov. 9). Estate. $500. , To Mary Slanika, executrix, 430 E. 89th St., $500; ten minor bequests. CALLAGHAN, JOSEPH (Dec. 2). Estate, $4,000. To Mary C. Duff, 329 W. 181st St., Helen Callaghan, same address, daughters, Mary Callaghan and Elizabeth Abbott, executrix,- sisters, Lynbrook, L. I., $1.000 each and residuary interests.

Seventeen undergraduate officers have been elected by the freshmen of Barnard College to head the student government of their class. Joanne McQuiston and Margaret. Whitten, both of New York, were chosen president and vice president.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an order approving with certain conditions an application by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire the issue and sale of 8,737 shares of $5 preferred stock, no-par value and without a fixed stated value a share.
The Federation of Tax Administrators estimated today that taxpayers of the United States paid $15 less a person last year than those in Great Britain.

The vacant plot on the west side of South Third Avenue, between East First and Second Streets, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has been leased to Sol Solomine who will use it for a gasoline filling station and parking lot.

Three young employes of a textile plant, although severely burned in a rapidly spreading blaze, hung from a window ledge on the sixth floor of a loft building at 38 West Eighteenth Street for several minutes late yesterday afternoon until one kicked out a window pane on the floor below and all three made their way inch by inch to safety through the narrow aperture. They then went down the stairs to safety.

Epes Winthrop Sargent, a member of the editorial staff of Variety, the theatrical publication, and known- to hundreds of Broadway actors by his noms de plume, Chicot and Chic, died late Tuesday night of a stomach ailment in his home, 1,466 East. Ninth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 66.

Dr. Stanhope Bayne-Jones, dean of the Yale School of Medicine, and Dr. Charles Sidney Burwell, dean of the Harvard Medical School, were elected members of the board of trustees of the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization at 565 Park Avenue.

Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan were luncheon hosts today at their residence. Mr. and Mrs. John Holliday Perry, who also entertained at home, gave a dinner for Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Replogle. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Robert Jr., Mrs. Harold Fitzgeral and Mrs. Annie F. Breniser.
Attorney General Raymond W. Starr of Michigan argued today before the Supreme Court that a State has "absolute sovereign power to control liquor imports."
William S. Culbertson, former United States Ambassador to Chile, completed today a ten-day visit to Santiago. Speaking this evening before a large audience of members of the diplomatic corps,
King George dined with leading Opposition Members of Parliament tonight at a party arranged privately by Earl Baldwin at his Eaton Square home.

The telephone operating subsidiaries of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation had a net gain of 58,833 telephones in service during the first ten months of 1938, compared with a gain of 48,671 instruments in the corresponding period a year ago, it was announced yesterday.
Students of the Gardner School will hold their annual Christmas bazaar and tea in behalf of their charitable activities and library fund tomorrow afternoon at the school, 154 East Seventieth Street.

A $50,000 mortgage for 5 years at 5 per cent, with $1.000 yearly amortization, on the 5-story apartment house at 32-32 34th St, Astoria, L. I. has been arranged by Herbert L Williams, Inc., representing the Troy Savings, Bank, through George C. Ponter Co. broker.

While the police were gathered yesterday in a room at 3,205 Arlington Avenue, the Bronx,where Ruth Clayton, 27-year-old waitress, had just committed suicide because she had been unable to get employment, a telephone call came from a Yonkers organization to offer her a job.

The Tennessee Public Utilities Commission, declaring The Chattanooga Times had been favored with a preferential electric rate since 1919, ordered its chief engineer today to conduct an investigation looking to a correction of "this discrimination."

The Treasury Proburement Division today announced awards of textile contracts as follows: 821-T-Type A chambray, fancy, Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills, Inc., 26,000 yds.; covert 3.20, coarse yarn, unshrunk, Wade Mafg. Co., 10,000 yds.;

Walter Granville-Smith, painter and illustrator, who was president of the Salmaguindi Club, 1924-26, died yesterday after a nine months' illness, at the home of his daughter, Jessie Smith Abt of 34-44 Eighty-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

The full-page advertisement by the Crowell Publishing Company yesterday, in which it expressed its disapproval of the study of weekly magazine readership by Life Magazine, will have no effect on Life's plans to continue the reports, according to executives of the latter magazine.

The of three-masted expeditionary schooner Wanderthirst, in charge of its owner, Howard Livingstone Sutton, head of the Silver Lake Museum of Natural History, Silver Lake, N.Y., left Bayway terminal in Staten Island Sound here today on the first leg of a trip to explore the jungles along the Orinoco River in Venezuela.

Annual Conference, Society for the Advancement of Management, Hotel New Yorker, 9:30 A. M. Session tomorrow and Saturday. New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, 10 A. M. Eastern Shade Tree Conference. Continues tomorrow.

Selling predominated in transactions by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in equity securities in October, with numerous transactions by corporate holders-- of securities, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Martin Egan, former war correspondent and journalist, for the last twenty-five years with the firm of J. P. Morgan Co., died yesterday of a heart attack at 455 East Fiftyseventh Street, where he had been living. Mr. Egan had been in poor health for five years. His age was 66.

The story of how Poultney Bigelow was swindled of $53.93 was told yesterday to Federal Judge William Bondy, who, after hearing it, sent the swindler. 33-year-old Carl Scheland, to the penitentiary for two and a half years.

A marked trend toward a larger proportion of planned children in the families of professionals was seen yesterday by Dr. John C. Flanagan of Teachers College, Columbia University, in reporting on a survey of 300 professional men and their wives.

Showing an increase for the fifth consecutive month, steel ingot production during November totaled 3.572,000 tons, or 62.05 per cent of capacity, thee best since September, 1937, when the industry operated at 76.3 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Clift B. Keyes, electric al engineer, died in his home here today at the age of 61 after an illness of two months. He was a New York district manager in the transportation department of the General Electric Company. Mr.

Guarded by two dogs and seven cats, Mrs; Mary Morrison, 55 years old, was found dead in bed last night in a three-room flat in which she had lived for twelve years at 232 Ninth Avenue, between Twentyfourth and Twenty-fifth Streets.
Today's session of the sale of the collection of early printed books and fine bindings collected by the late Mortimer Schiff of New York brought a total of [Pound]2,313 at Sotheby's.

Simultaneously, a warm sun and the football Giants came out of temporary retirement yesterday, and to Steve Owen, coach of the young men who on Sunday will attempt to capture the world gridiron championship when they engage the massive Green Bay Packers in the play-off game at the Polo Graunds, it was a signal to get busy.

With Ed Danowski of the Giants showing the way, three new National Football League individual records were established and two marks were tied during the regular 1938 season, according to the final official statistics released yesterday.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company and contracts closed Floyd B. Odlum of New York today buried the hatchet in the court room of Federal Judge William H. Holly. Thus ended a dispute which it was reported was to have brought out sensational charges against Mr. Odium, president of the Atlas Corporation, a huge investment trust.

A $750,000 libel suit was filed against Secretary Ickes today by John D. Glass of Tyler, Texas, lawyer and former chief investigator of Federal Petroleum Agency No. 1. The agency is under Mr. Ickes's jurisdiction.
Architects filed yesterday plans for apartment houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn to cost about $2,500,000.

Mr. and Mrs. John Hartigan gave a dinner last night in their suite at the St. Regis for former President Herbert Hoover. Among the other guests were Admiral and Senora Giuseppe Cantu, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Kelley, Mrs. George Bowen de Long and Edgar Pickard.

The New York Athletic Club will hold its seventieth anniversary dinner at its city clubhouse, 180 Central Park South, tonight at 7:30 o'clock. The occasion will celebrate the founding of the club in 1868 and, commemorate seven decades of leadership in amateur athletics.

A new type of container, to facilitate the handling of packaged quickfrozen foods and of other types of perishables, will be put into general use after the first of the year, the American Railway Express Agency announced yesterday.

Perry Newberry, newspaper man and author of boys' stories, died yesterday. He was 68 years old. His books and stories included "Castaway Island," "The Last Mayor of Las Pasturas" and "The Mystery Woman."
A 195-pound backfield operating behind a 196-pound line-that's the 1938 Little All-America football team compiled yesterday by The Associated EPress.

In token of what happened yesterday when France and Germany. signed a common declaration to avoid resort to war and respect each other's frontiers, Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop this morning laid a laurel wreath bound with ribbons of the Nazi colors and marked with a swastika on the grave of the Unknown Soldier below the Arc de Triomphe.
W. W. Sebald, vice president of the American Rolling Mill Company, has been elected a director to fill the vacancy left by the late J. H. Frantz.

Two hundred persons, many of whom are prominent in financial and social circles of New York, attended funeral services held this afternoon for Mrs. Judith Carrington Stettinius, widow of Edward R. Stettinius, financier, at The Shelter, the Stettinius home here, where she died Sunday night.

Frank Bowcher, sculptor and medalist, died yesterday at the age of 70. An exceptionally versatile and prolific artist, Mr. Bowcher's works included a silver seal for King George V, relief portraits in marble of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth and busts of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught.

Paul Sifton, Deputy Administrator of the Wages and Hours Division of the Department of Labor, stated in an interpretative bulletin today that he did not regard newspapers, banks, building and loan associations, insurance companies, loan companies, telephone companies, radio broadcasting stations, toll bridge companies and a group of other businesses as "service establishments" within the meaning of that section of the Wages and Hours Law which exempts service organizations.

A defense of the Washington Administration's merchant marine policies and denial-of charges that the program would lead to "government ownerships" of the nation's shipping- was expressed yesterday by M. L. Wilcox, director of operations and traffic of the Maritime Commission, in a statement made public at the agency's offices here.
Today's events PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; "Manon," Metropolitan Opera, evening; Frederick Koehler, tenor, Hubert Liverman, pianist, Barbizon-Plaza, 8:30; Lilian Carpenter,
Announcement was made today of the election of the Yale junior promenade committee. The members are: Academic Department--Charles Glover, Washington. D. C.:
The six-story apartment building with stores at 1,711 Morris Avenue, corner of 174th- Street, Bronx, has been sold by the Equitable Life Assurance Society to the Hymar Realty Corporation.

The clubhouse of the National Republican Club. at 54 West Fortieth Street will be sold tomorrow to satisfy a debt owed to the Harlem Savings Bank, it was learned yesterday following a meeting of the club's executive committee.

Gifts as prosaic as hand-trimmed wash cloths and as poetic as reproductions of Della. Robbias angels' heads. were among the selections made yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at the annual sale of handiwork of the,blind in the new salesrooms at 601 Fifth Avenue.

Members of the Southern Society of New York City who listened last night to the speech of Senator James F. Byrnes of South Carolina may not have realized the immense significance of its final paragraphs.

The Public Service Commission today ordered eight groups of public utilities to file before Feb. 1, 1939, a copy of all cost-plus contracts exceeding $25,000 for plant improvements written during 1936, 1937 and 1938.

Sid Luckman, Columbia's brilliant back, yesterday announced his definite decision to call quits to hii football career. The triple-threat star of the Lions, one of the outstanding backs of the year, said that he would not accept any of the invitations he had received to play in various all-star games during the Christmas holidays.
An etching by David Young Cameron, a contemporary Scottish etcher, was sold last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries for $1,100. Kennedy Co. was the purchaser.

Because the "Nazi religion" will not provide the endurance and morale necessary for prolonged sacrifice, Chancellor Hitler could not keep his people at war as long as the Kaiser did, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of New York City told delegates to the biennial meeting of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America today.

Some refinements of the Securities Exchange Act are likely to occur, Harry H. Egly of the Securities and Exchange Commission today told members of the Northern Ohio Group Investment Bankers Association, the Bond Club and the Cleveland Stock Exchange. Mr.

Corn developed independent strength today on the Board of Trade here, and prices advanced 1 cent a bushel at the extreme, going to the highest mark since late in September. The best prices, however, were not maintained, due to selling induced by the easiness in wheat, but 'the close was at net gains of 1/2 to % cent.

The definite improvement in the hide, leather and shoe industries, which has been apparent for several weeks, is not without serious difficulties for each of those industries, it was apparent in trade developments yesterday.

Clendenin J. Ryan Jr. of Mayor La Guardia's secretarial staff was promoted yesterday to serve as assistant to William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, in a list of five promotions made by Mayor la Guardia at City Hall.

The first and sixth seeded contestants in the Class B squash racquets tourney in progress at the Squash Club still were in the running as the quarter-finals ended last night. All other seeded players had been eliminated.

Yale, Harvard and Princeton have agreed to a modified extension of pre-season football practice, Malcolim Farmer, chairman of the Yale Board of Athletic Control, told the University Alumni Association's Hartford Chapter tonight.
Two hundred persons tonight attended a musicale given by the Governor General and Lady Tweedsmuir in the ballroom at Rideau Hall.

ALVAREZ--Dora P., on Dec. 6, 1938, widow of the late Joseph and beloved mother of Mrs. Ethel A. Smyth and Frank H. Alvarez. Funeral services at. Henry I. Bunnell Funeral Home, Broadway, near 204th St., Thursday. Dec. 8. 8 P. M.

The liner Paris, with a crew composed partly of strikebreakers and partly of navy technicians, sailed from Cherbourg today despite the strike, which kept the Normandie and other liners tied up at Havre.

At the great Nottingham congress Jose R. Capablanca of Havana and Mikhail Botwinnik of Moscow divided the first and second prizes, but they did not fare so well in the recent A. V. R. O, international chess masters' tournament in The Netherlands.

The International Copper Committee today ordered production cut to 100 per cent of basic tonnages by Jan. 1. A restriction to 105 per cent will be made effective on Dec. 15. At present the quota is 110 per cent, effective on Jan. 1, with output on an unrestricted basis until that time.

Meeting to be held tomorrow forenoon will determine the attitude of Parliament, which reconvenes in the afternoon to discuss Premier Edouard Daladier's plan for the agenda of the short session that will last until the end of the year.
A strike started at noon today in the world's largest sivler mine, the Real de Monte property at Pachuca, sixty miles north of Mexico City.

Arthur Conners, 14 years old, and Bruce Lawrence, 16, who ran away from their homes here on Sunday because they had smashed a fender on the Conners family automobile while driving it without permission, were in Richmond, Va., last night and "having a fine time," according to letters received today by their parents.

Import restrictions in Argentina and New Zealand and new banking regulations in Panama will cause declines -in American sales to those markets in the coming weeks, export credit men maintained yesterday in a discussion of foreign credit and exchange conditions abroad at the regular monthly round-table. meeting sponsored by the foreign credit interchange bureau of tire National Association of Credit Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania..
Webster Ave, 2,247 .(11-3143); Fanbet Realty Corp to 2,247 Webster Ave. Corp., 250 W. 57th; installments, 5 per cent; $13,500.

Joseph Buerckel, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's deputy in Austria, his expelled Franz Winkler, former Austrian Vice Chancellor, from the Nazi party, an official communique published in this morning's papers announced.

Engineers, by changing the environment in which man lives, also change the physiological reactions of his body, with consequent psychological changes affecting his entire personality, Dr. Howard W. Haggard,

" Dangers" in the proposed Patman "anti-chain-store" tax legislation, the need for revision of realty taxation methods and the prospect of a more active realty market in the coming year were emphasized by speakers at sessions of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Balcom, who returned here a few weeks ago after having passed the last two years in Paris and in Austria, gave a buffet supper and dance last night in the Cottage Suite at Hampshire House. Mrs. Balcom is the daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Rogers and of the late Colonel Henry Huddleston Rogers.

Nearly 1,000 Department of Welfare, clerks met last night at Germania Hall, 160 Third Avenue, and endorsed unanimously plans made by their leaders to wage a legal fight against loss of their jobs because of failure to pass a civil service examination which they contend was given under unfair conditions.

A pre-theatre thrill was provided for Times Square crowds last night when three police radio cars and a detective car sped through the district in answer to a telephone alarm that turned out to have been a call for help sent by a subway guard who tried to chase about a dozen Negro boys from a subway entrance near the southwest corner of Broadway and Forty-second Street.

Unemployment difficulties of the youth of the nation are no more serious than are those of the middle-aged and the older-age groups, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, informed the New York Council of the Girls Service League yesterday at its first Fall meeting at headquarters, 138 East Nineteenth Street.

Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy of the United States was criticized and defended in the House of Commons tonight for the part he had played in the deletion of anti-government parts of a Paramount newsreel during the crisis last September.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company announced yesterday that work would begin tomorrow on removing sixteen submarine cables from the Passaic River about 100 feet south of the new Lincoln Highway Bridge in New Jersey.

A belief that public opinion has shifted its favor from government "control" to "free" enterprise was declared here yesterday in the keynote address opening the annual Congress of American Industry, conducted by the National Association of Manufacturers.
Factory whistles in this footballconscious city blared for five minutes late today as the Green Bay Packers.

Checked on Tuesday in its steady recovery, the pound sterling was depressed yesterday in the foreignexchange market. The confused political situation in Europe, which had halted the advance of a week, was influential again and the British currency moved lower with the French franc.
Shooting down the snow-covered hill built in Madison Square Garden, skiers of international repute took part in the competitions last night before a gathering of 6,000.

Philip Barry has written a play that lies very close to his heart in "Here Come the Clowns," which opened at the Booth last evening. Like "Hotel Universe," which stirred many people years ago, it is an imaginative excursion in search of the truth, and some of it shuffles off this mortal coil. in a glow of haunting beauty.
The purchase by an investor of seven parcels from the Central Savings Bank was announced yesterday, by Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker in the transaction.

Joseph A. Marin, textile buyer for the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, was honored last night by the Retail Associates Group, composed of buyers and sellers in the textile industry, at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria on the occasion of his completion of fifty years as a buyer.
Plans for a world heavyweight boxing match as part of the Golden Gate International Exposition were canceled today.

Prompt representations have been made by the United States Embassy in Berlin regarding the latest decrees of the German Government, confiscating under the guise of trusteeship most of the remaining Jewish wealth in the Reich.
Roscoe Toles, Detroit heavyweight, yesterday concluded train ing at Grupp's Gymnasium for his ten-round battle tomorrow night against Gunnar Barlund, rugged Finnish fighter, in the Hippodrome.
We may expect any day now the announcement of revolutionary discoveries in the automobile field.
Edward A. Byrne of 130 Park Place, Brooklyn, designer of the Triborough Bridge, died last night of a heart attack in the home here of a son, Edward A. Byrne Jr. He was 74 years old.
The executive council of the State Federation of Labor ended a two-day session today, approving eleven proposals in addition to five yesterday, for submission to the next session of the Legislature.
Madeleine Carroll and Fred MacMurray, who have just completed "Cafe Society" at Paramount, will again be teamed by the studio in "Angel in Furs" by W. B. Courtney. The yarn,

After two hours' deliberation today a jury before County Judge Edward A. McGrath here acquitted Mrs. Alice Hoffmeister Whaley of a charge of having caused her 12-year-old stepdaughter, Eleanor Whaley, to be burned on the hips by a radiator in their home in Union, N. J., in April, 1937.

George M. Weiss, vice president of the Newark (N. J.) Club of the International League and head of the New York Yankees' "farm" system, taken to a hospital yesterday with pneumonia, was "doing very well" today.
Raymond Robert Carew, an early columnist and magazine contributor, died yesterday at the Queen of Angeles Hospital. He was 88 years old. Mr. Carew,

Pig iron production last month, according to The Iron Age, gained 14.3 per cent. The month's total was 2,269,983 gross tons, compared with 2,052,284 tons in October. On a daily basis the comparison is 75,666 tons against 66,203 tons in October.
Turpentine firm, 21 1/2c; sales; 40 barries; receipts, 222 barrels; shipments, 25 barrels; stock, 53,302 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 131; receipts, 795; no shipments; stock, 310,887.

Mrs. Robert King Munroe gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for her debutante , daughter, Miss Eleanor Sewall Munroe. The debutante is a granddaughter of the late Henry Smith Munroe, dean of the Columbia University School of Mines and an active member of the Columbia faculty from 1877 to 1915.
John Matovsky, under indictment on eleven arson charges, was elected first assistant chief of the Deal Volunteer Fire Company 2 at the meeting of the organization here last night.

In line with the program of the New York Stock Exchange calling for the removal of securities from trading where the Exchange feels such action is in the public interest, the Securities and Exchange Commission today granted applications of the Exchange to delist the first mortgage fifty-year 51/2 per cent gold bonds due on June 1, 1943,
Papyrus, a famous campaigner on race tracks on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean fifteen years ago, was sold at Newmarket today for about $3,690 in a partnership dissolution.

Helen Wills Moody, having turned down a promoter's offer of "approximately $100,000" to turn professional, today hinted she would gladly start out on another international tennis campaign--if the United States wanted her.

The active cooperation of dress producers in a wide effort to improve the sizing of women's dresses and reduce the waste and expense of altering dresses in retail stores will be sought by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of retail merchandising executives at its offices here.

A uniformly earnest disposition to reach unanimous conclusions and go forward in a spirit of harmonious cooperation was reported by Secretary of State Cordell Hull tonight after he had called on the heads of other delegations to the Pan-American Conference opening here Friday.
In nine days, on Dec. 17 to be exact, the five-day deer season will open in New Jersey, and according to all reports these animals are plentiful in the central and southern areas.

Specified employes of the New York Evening Journal, Inc., of New York, publishers of The Journal and American, will vote by secret ballot within fifteen days for their collective bargaining representatives.

Loot estimated at between $7,000 and $8,000 was obtained today by a gunman who walked into a branch of the Banque Canadienne National in East Catherine Street, held up the teller, alone counting his cash, and escaped down a nearby lane with the currency stuffed in his pockets.
Construction activity will aggregate about $8,800,000,000 this year, due partly to the huge government spending program, the Commerce Department estimated today.

Henry Parkman Jr., Corporation Counsel of Boston, urged city attroneys today to support proposals for taxing income from government bonds. Mr. Parkman, addressing the Institute of Municipal Law Oficers, predcted a fight would be made in Congress this Winter to enact legislation levying taxes on such bonds.

Nu Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national scholastic society, will induct thirty-two Hunter College undergraduates at ceremonies tonight in the college auditorium, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, at. 8:15 P. M. Professor Harry J. Carman of Columbia University, a member of the Board of Higher Education, will speak on "Liberal Arts in Public Education."

One more football trophy was awarded-last night when presentation ceremonies took place with an informal dinner in the Terrace Club at the World's Fair Grounds. The prize this time was the August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy and the recipient the football team of Carnegie Tech.

With the government's final estimate of this year's'cotton crop due today and operators looking for a slight reduction from the forecast of 12,137,000 bales issued last month, prices on the Cotton Exchange here held yesterday within an extremely narrow range and ended with gains of 1 to 3 points.

Mrs. Annie Griffen Baruch, wife of Bernard M. Baruch, financier, left a net estate of $1,045,513 when she died last Jan. 16, according to a transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Barucn and three children are the principal beneficiaries.
The domestic production of zinc in November amounted to 40,343 tons, against 36,740 in October and 49,393 in November, 1937, according to the American Zinc-Institute,

City Hall Park's Christmas tree was erected yesterday by employes of the Park Department, who placed it in the plaza just in front of the Civic Virtue statue. The forty-foot tree rises fifteen feet above the top of the statue.
Compulsory military service will be introduced in Manchukuo in 1940, according to the newspaper Nichi Nichi's Hsingking correspondent.

The first commercial treaty to be negotiated between the United States and Iraq was signed on Saturday at Baghdad by Paul Knabenshue, United States Minister, and Seyyid Tawfik Swaidi, Foreign Minister, the State Department announces. The three-year treaty takes effect thirty days after ratification.

J. A. Krug, chief power planning engineer for the Tennessee Valley Authority, rejected in testimony. today before the Congressional TVA Investigating Committee the proposal by Wendell L. Willkie that the Securities and Exchange Commission be asked to fix a fair price for the purchase of the Tennessee Electric Power Company as a complete system by the TVA.
Acreage and idle plottage in the Flushing section of Queens, used not so long ago for agricultural purposes, are being absorbed rapidly for new residential communities in this World's Fair zone.
The final series of wool auctions closed quietly today with offerings of 7,157 bales, of which 4,542 were sold. Today's turnover was small and rates were easier.

Princeton's basketball team gained an easy victory,33--11, over a visiting Dickinson five in the university gymnasium tonight as both quintets opened their seasons and Frank Cappon made his debut as Tiger varsity coach.

Representatives of twenty-seven civic organizations presented yesterday to Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, a petition urging passage of the county reorganization bills, which will come before the Council today at a special meeting called by Mayor La Guardia.

Wang Ching-wei, deputy leader of the Kuomintang [Nationalist par ty], announced today that the Chi nese Ambassadors to the United States, Britain, France and the So viet Union "at present are ap proaching the countries for a common policy against Japan."

A better tone developed today in the stock market, and prices were higher in many issues, although trading still was on a small scale. Gilt-edge stocks recovered strongly. Among the foreign bonds European issues were dull, but others were steady.
Mrs. Anna Marie Hahn, 32 years old, died tonight in the electric chair at Ohio Penitentiary for one of the four murders of which she was accused.
Jascha Heifetz was in top form at the recital which he gave last night in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism.

Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, said yesterday that he would join the mass meeting called by Mayor La Guardia for tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall to protest against religious persecution in Europe.

MANHATTAN BARUCH, ANNIE GRIFFEN (Jan. 16, 1938). Gross assets, $1,252,902; net, $1,045,513. To Bernard M. Baruch, husband, residue of personal effects and one-half residuary estate; Isabel Wilcox Baruch, Renee B. Samstag, daughters; Bernard M. Baruch Jr., son, specific legacies and one-sixth residue each; Winifred Mann Baruch, daughter-in-law, $2,400; Anna Wipper, $7,500; Minnie B. Draggett, $10,000; Charlotte Macray, $5,000;

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions for Arrangement BERNICE. BREITBARTH, grocer, 2,660 8th Ave.-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of. the Chandler act listing liabilities of $4,476 and- assets of $1,051, exclusive of insurance. A settlement of 15 per cent is proposed.

Toys and dolls enough for 3,500 boys and girls were on display yesterday at the office of the New York Telephone Company, 140 West Street, as gifts of employes to be distributed to sixty child agencies in time for Christmas.

President Nicholas Murray Butler s of Columbia University, Dr. Alexis Carrel of the Rockefeller Institute and leading Catholic clergymen and laymen today attended the funeral of the Rev. Cornelius C. Clifford, rector of Our Lady of Mercy Church, Whippany, and lecturer in philosophy at Columbia University, who died Sunday.

The history of the last fifty years in the buying and selling of merchandise was reviewed last night as Frederick Atkins was honored at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on the occasion of his completion of a half-century as a resident buyer in this city.

Herman Alterman, 50 years old, of 162-05 Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, was killed at about 4:30 P. M. yesterday when, according to witnesses interviewed by the police, he walked into the side of a passing truck at Sixty-sixth Street and. Central Park West.
Dr. Charles Edward Munroe, chemist who invented smokeless powder, died today at his home in suburban Forest Glen, Md. He was 89 years old.

Chief Justice Hughes acclaimed the Red Cross as a unifying influence among the American people today upon its report of a successful roll call. Presiding as vice president at the annual meeting of the Red Cross Board of Incorporators, Justice Hughes also praised Norman H. Davis, national chairman.

Leases of business space reported yesterday included several contracts for quarters in downtown buildings. With its membership increased in less than two years from 2,000 to 12,000, the State, County and Municipal Workers of America took the entire sixth floor in the Temple Court Building, at the southwest corner of Nassau and Beekman Streets.

Grover Petersen, chairman of the Olympic Skating Committee. and president of the Wisconsin Skating Association,' announced today a change in the dates for the Olympic trials to Jan. 18 to 26 at Fowler Lake, Oconomowoc, Wis. The trials originally were scheduled to start four days later.
Colgate came from behind tonight to beat Toronto University, 62 to 43, in the first basketball game for the home team.

Thirtysix producers and shippers of anthracite in Pennsylvania, representing from 60 to 65 per cent of the output in the State, and the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to modify its findings of Nov. 7 which, they held, impliedly increased the freight rates on unprepared anthracite to an amount equivalent to 1.7 cents a ton one the prepared coal.

Miss Virginia Sandford Gibbs, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Philip Gibbs of Huntsville, Texas, was married to Joseph Smyth Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Smyth of Sayville, L. I., in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church yesterday. The rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, performed the ceremony.
