Professor Harold E. Edgerton of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology demonstrated yesterday a new stroboscopic lamp which makes it possible for photographers to make as many as 600 exposures on- a single photographic plate within one second.

Worthington C. Lent, allocation engineer of the National Broadcasting Company, told the Federal Communications Commission at a hearing today that there were about 13,000,000 persons in various parts of the United States who could not receive adequate service from N. B. C. networks under the proposed F. C. C. standards.

Trading continued slow on most classes of locally dressed meats in local markets yesterday. The bull market was strong and other classes of traefer meats mostly weak to lower. Kosher beef opened lower yesterday, veal and calf weak, lamb stronger. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Advance contributions of almost-??500.000 have already been received for "The Earl Baldwin Fund" for refugees, which the former Prime Minister will launch in a nation-wide boradcast tomorrow night..
The Dartmouth basketball team opened its season tonight by defeating Sprigfield College,. 39--31. The visitors put up a strong second-half battle.

This city of reasonably prosperous people expects to have a pleasant Christmas. The clouds of depression have lightened and almost every one is more cheerful. But the individuals listed among THE TIMES Neediest Cases cannot hope for a Christmas such as other people enjoy unless they, too, are remembered in the tide of generosity that sweeps New York at this season of the year.

A first-degree murder indictment was handed up by the New York County grand jury yesterday to Judge Koenig in General Sessions against Eva Kopalchak, 17 years old, former inmate of a State insane asylum,

The Franco-German declaration signed in Paris yesterday is approved here in so far as it accords with the Polish view that bilateral arrangements are the best guarantee of peace without restricting the signatories' relations with third parties..

Mayor La Guardia delivered a scathing attack on the courts yesterday, declaring that they were encroaching upon - the executive branch of the city government to so great an extent that the city was being pushed toward bankruptcy.
D. W. Robinson Jr. was appointed today general counsel of the Federal Power Commission, effective Jan. 1 Clyde L. Seavey, acting chairman, announced.

Although Jimmy Bowen, an apprentice ond from the Canal Zone, took the fea- wir ture race at the Fair Grounds today and, gave Norman Hernandez of New Orleans a double, the limelight was stolen by Eddie Robart and the stable of Weston W. Adams of Boston.

Frank H. Woodruff, a certified public accountant with offices in New York and a director of the Pennsylvania Exchange Bank of New York, died last night in his apartment at the Westchester Country Club after a heart attack. Mr. Woodruff, who was 56 years old, had lived at the club since 1931.
Rental of the recently completed one-story building at 277-85 Front Street, Hempstead, L. I., is now complete, according to Riker Co., Inc.

Contending that he is "still the duly qualified City Clerk," Michael J. Cruise served a show cause order on Joseph D. McGoldrick yesterday in a suit in which Mr. Cruise seeks back pay as City Clerk since Jan. 1.

Royal Business, running with Grumpy as the E. Johnson entry, captured the six-and-a-half-furlong handicap featuring today's program at the Charles Town track. Ocean Roll finished second and Teddy's Star was third.
To put a completely straight face upon the matter, "Pygmalion," which had its premiere at the Astor last night, marks the debut of a promising screen writer, George Bernard Shaw.
Appointment of- James Bentley (Jimmy) Wilson, 42, as bead football coach at Canisius College was announced by the college administration today.
The Baltimore Orioles scored all their goals in a second-period outburst tonight, then held off the New York Rovers' last-period rally to defeat the Eastern Amateur Hockey League leaders, 3 to 2.

The following film programs, to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools:
The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied the application of the Grey Line Motor Tours, Inc., New York City, to acquire control of the Royal Blue Sightseeing Corporation of the same city.
United States Government obligations again were strong in somewhat more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

By virtue of its 7-to-0 victory over the Staten Island Club, the Junior League team took the lead in the New York Division of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association tournament yesterday. The match was played on the victors' courts.

Completion of the plan to readjust the capital of the Dewey Almy Chemical Company was announced yesterday, with formal offers of exchange of shares received from holders of 98 per cent of the prior preference and Class B preferred stocks.
The relief bill of the United States for October reached $266,481,000, an increase of 2 per cent over September, according to tabulations completed today by the Social Security Board.

Eugene McMenamin, business agent for Local 478, Teamsters and Chauffeurs Union, in Newark, was sentenced here today to eighteen months in the State penitentiary on charges arising from an assault on a truck driver during a strike last March of union drivers of the American Stores Company in Orange.

Moderate supplies of cattle cleared in a fairly active market today, steers and yearlings selling as much as 25 cents higher. Hogs sold 15 to 25 cents higher with best lots up to $7.55, while fat lambs turned at steady to strong rates, spots 10 cents higher.

People who visit the Power Show at Grand Central Palace will come away with the impression not so much that we live in an age of power as that we are just at the beginning of one. We are accustomed to think of the industrial revolution as having completed its cycle.

Two-ton Tony Galento, barrel-chested Orange, N. J., heavyweight and recognized No. 1 challenger of Champion Joe Louis, knocked out Otis Thomas, Chicago Negro, in the ninth round of their scheduled twelve-round fight tonight.
Mr. and Mrs. Newcombe C. Baker of Rumson will give a supper dance in the Roof Garden and Lounge of the Pierre on Dec. 22 to introduce their daughter, Miss Barbara Baker.
About 360 Jews have been released from the Dachau concentration camps, and it is reported several hundred will be released from the Buchenwald camp this week.

Concerned lest a defeat in Saturday's referendum on cotton marketing quotas might have repercussions in a Congress which numbers many members who have divergent ideas on farm legislation, officials of the Agricultural Department have led a spirited campaign in the South to carry the day.

Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, who resigned from the Cabinet rather than compromise with the dictators of the Continent, is due here tomorrow evening on the Aquitania to address the closing dinner of the annual Congress of American Industry in the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Central Railroad of New Jersey and the Reading Company have bought fifteen oil-electric switching locomotives, it has been learned.

Dr. Hugh M. Parshall, 40-year-old harness horse owner-trainer-driver of Urbana, stood out today for the tenth straight year as .the nation's pacing and trotting victory king. Parshall's red, white and blue silks flashed across the line in front forty-nine- times during 1938-the greatest number of first places racked up by any driver on the hoof-torn ovals.

Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy is sailing for the United States on the Queen Mary Saturday on a two-month vacation, it was learned tonight. The Ambassador, who received permission from the State Department to take the holiday several days ago, will be accompanied by his son, John.
The $100 bill that was turned in to the police after a Negro taxi driver had accepted it in error as a $1 bill was taken to the office of the property clerk at Police Headquarters yesterday.
The Rev. Howard Stone Anderson today called James Roosevelt "a bad object lesson to the country" for failure to include his church contributions in his income-tax returns.

A comprehensive inquiry into the work of the Department of Welfare is being made by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, on instructions from Mayor La Guardia, it became known yesterday. Mr. Herlands announced that William Hodson,

Washington Ave, w s, 210 a 172d St, 2-story synagogue, 50x150; Mercantile Commerce Bank and Trust Co, trustee, against Congregation and Great House of Learning of Israel of the Bronx; due, $67,877; to plaintiff for $60,000.

Dr. Wallis D-vis, at 231 Nelson Rd, for Amelia B. Crim; Walter A. Mogensen, at 22 Ridgecrest E, for Guranty Trust Co; Frederick H. Simmonds, at 46 Barry Rd, for Bowery Savings Bank; Scarsdale (Westchester County) rentals by Prince Ripley, Inc. broker.

Blyth Co., Inc., headed the successful banking group yesterday in the purchase of $2,500,000 State of Louisiana highway bonds. The group received the award on its bid of 100.08 for $1,052,000, maturing Oct. 1, 1942 to 1955, as 4s, and $1,448,000, due 1956 to 1960, as 33/4s, or at a net interest cost to the State of 3.8256 per cent.

The section of the proposed trade practice rules for the wool industry which would compel a distinction between virgin and reworked wool will be opposed by the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the hearing to be held next Wednesday in Washington by the Federal Trade Commission.
John Ernest Williamson, explorer and originator of undersea motion pictures, is now completing preparations to embark this Winter on a scientific expedition to the coral reefs of the Bahamas.
Ericcson Pt. or Beach St. 36-42. s e corHudson St; Thomas Lenane, individually and as executor of Thomas Lenane, to Beach-Hudson Realty, Inc, 74 Varick St (50c).

This morning, with the decks snow-laden after last night's blizzard, the Wyatt Earp lies idle and wind pressed beside a milewide field of flat ice, one of many such fields scattered in the vast area of Antarctic pack ice which surrounds the polar continent.
The Iowa State Canvassing Board today awarded re-election to Senator Guy M. Gillette by a 2,805-vote margin over his Republican opponent, former Senator L. J. Dickinson.

The nine-story Mohawk building, on the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, known as 160 Fifth Avenue, was bid in at auction yesterday to the Bowery Savings Bank, plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against Edith Darling and others, for $200,000.
Mr. and Mrs. F. Reed Fenton of Scarsdale, N. Y., gave a tea here yesterday in the Junior League clubrooms at the Waldorf-Astoria to in produce to society Mrs. Fenton's daughter, Miss Marnie Wilson.

Four new officers were elected the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at its annual meeting at the Montclair Golf Club today. Mrs. Clifford F. Armitage of Baltusrol was unanimously elected president for a term of two years, with Mrs. Charles L. Morse of Montclair being named treasurer,

Another flat refusal to hand back German colonies was delivered in the House of Commons today by Malcolm MacDonald, Secretary for Colonies, in the firmest statement the British Government has yet made on the subject of German colonial claims.
Without wishing to alarm any one it must be, reported that France was invaded tonight by a number of large individuals of fierce appearance from a far-off land.

Three years ago voters in New York City approved the reform of county government by a three-to-one vote. At the special meeting which he has called for today Mayor La Guardia puts it up to the City Council to act on that mandate.

Government officials, newspaper correspondents and others paid tribute today at his funeral to Paul Y. Anderson, Washington newspaper correspondent, -who died yesterday after taking an overdose of sleeping tablets.

Talk of impeachment proceedings against Secretary Perkins cropped up again today within the House Committee on Un-American Activities when the committee renewed its discussion of the Harry Bridges deportation case.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After reading the reports on the monopoly problem submitted to the TEC one cannot avoid the conclusion that several important facts are being overlooked because all efforts are directed toward the. discovery of some particular feature.

An exhibition of pictures by contemporary Spanish artists was opened yesterday afternoon with a benefit preview at the Arden Gallery, 460 Park Avenue. Proceeds from the opening and from the sale of the pictures will go to the Spanish Child Welfare Association of America and to the American Friends Service Committee.
The theft of $1,093 from the safe of the National Maritime Union at 126 Eleventh Avenue, near Twentieth Street, was discovered yesterday morning by George Hearn, president of the local.

John J. Sullivan, formerly known as the "Czar of Wallabout," the market in Brooklyn where he amassed considerable wealth for "watching" the wagons of farmers with produce for sale, began yesterday to serve a sentence of nine months in prison imposed on him April 19 by Judge Clarence G. Galston in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

Felipe Buencamino, a member of the Philippine National Assembly, was drawn into the Buckner mail fraud case late yesterday when James J. Caffrey, regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission, accused him of soliciting a bribe to sponsor legislation that would result in the redemption of Philippine Railway bonds.

By his will, filed for probate here today, Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the board of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation and of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, who died on Nov. 12, gave to his widow, Anna Case Mackay, $50,000 cash immediately and $2,000,000 in cash or equivalent securities as soon as the estate is settled.

Fascisti paraded today at Naples, Florence and Perugia to shouts of "Long live Italian Tunisia!", continuing clamorous demonstrations of so-called "solidarity with oppressed brothers" in French territory.

The season's second performance of "Lohengrin" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The cast was. headed by Irene Jessner as Elsa, Kerstin Thorborg as Ortrud, Lauritz Melchior as Lohengrin, Hans Hermann Nissen as Telramund, Emanuel List as King Henry and Arnold Gabor as the herald.
The board of directors of the Women's Roosevelt Memorial Association is sponsoring the recital to be given by the Vienna Choir Boys and Anita Zahn's Little Duncan Dancers on the night of Dec. 18

The three-story building containing four stores and two apartments at 233 Jackson Avenue, Jersey City, was sold by the Trust Company of New Jersey to Anna Azzuolo for a consideration shown as $24,000, the bank taking back a purchase money mortgage for $22,000.

The Philco 'Radio and Television Corporation of Philadelphia will shortly enter the electrical refrigeration field, it was learned here yesterday. The company has acquired from Fairbanks, Morse Co., Inc., Chicago, the "Conservador" refrigerator and will begin manufacture of that product.

The Transport Workers - Union, C. I. O. affiliate with a claimed membership of about 50,000 workers on subway, elevated and - surface lines, warned the La Ghardia administration last night that it would insist upon recognition of the closed shop and the principle of "genuine" collective bargaining as- integral parts of any plan for the unification of rapid transit lines.

The Pix Theatre Circuit, Inc., Gary, Ind., operating a motion picture theatre chain, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 50,000 shares, of ??5 par value Class A common stock to be offered at $6 a share.

Mrs. Hortense M. Odium of New York, who as "a novice" assumed the presidency of the Bonwit Teller Fifth Avenue store for women four years ago and built a thriving business on her experience as a customer and her philosophy of life, told some of the secrets of her success on two occasions here today.
The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of United States of America 23/4 per cent Treasury bonds of 1960-65 and 2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1947.

Mrs. Alice M. C. Scherer, widow of the late Rev. Dr. M. G. G. Scherer, first secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America, and mother of the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, pastor of the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Sixtyfifth Street and Central Park West, died yesterday in her home, 3 West Sixty-fifth Street. She was 77 years old.

The Senate profit-sharing committee was told today that almost threequarters of this country's business men would increase employment if this would give them exemption from the undistributed-profits and excess-profits taxes.
Governor Lehman's plurality over Thomas E. Dewey in the November election was put at 64,394 in the report of the State Board of Canvassers, made public today.

Ably abetted by Brig. Gen. Dan I. Sultan, Representative Vinson once more urges the building of the Nicaragua Canal, though the War Department has yet to approve. In the past it was the commercial argument that took precedence over the military.

Alfred T. Cox of New York City has been elected to captain the Lehigh football team next season, it was announced today by Coach Glen Harmeson at the annual Rotary Club gridiron dinner. Cox, a halfback, cane to Lehigh without any football experience in high school.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the application of the Boston Maine Railroad to ask the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a three-year loan of not more than $1,500,000 for maintenance work necessitated by the flood and hurricane in New England in September.

Remonstrances from America have curbed open anti-Semitic violence and plundering by Slovak Hlinka Guards. The Slovak, organ of the Hlinka Guard, declares that a solution of the Jewish problem in Slovakia is the most important today.

The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation was allowed yesterday to list 250,000 additional shares of its common stock on the New York Stock Exchange. Authorization was asked in anticipation of consummation of a deal by which the company will acquire the minority interest in the Universal Credit Corporation, of which it now owns 70 per cent.

Eulace Peacock of Union, N. J., Negro sprinter and jumper, thrice conqueror of Jesse Owens, was used as a- model here today to prove that while most Negroes are congenitally flat-footed, their feet are as serviceable as those of any other race.
President Roosevelt and Governorelect James have been requested to intervene in the strike of the Wilkes-Barre Newspaper Guild, which has left this city without newspapers since Oct. 3.

Rose Bampton, Metropolitan n Opera soprano, who was forced to curtail her recital in the Town Hall endowment series last week in the midst of her program, will give a full program in place of the..canceled one, it was announced yesterday by Kenneth Klein,

Restoration of domestic whisky prices to established levels, additional cuts of 10 cents a bottle on prices of imported liquors and the inclusion of gin in the price competition marked developments yesterday in the city's pre-holiday liquorprice war.

Behind the coincidence between the anti-French manifestations in Rome and the signature of the Franco-German pact, which was arranged a good many weeks ago, there lies some very complicated diplomatic history.

Anticipating by three years the final provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company will begin paying overtime immediately to all salaried non-exempt employes working in excess of forty hours a week,

Irked over the haphazard" methods used by the City Council in renaming streets, Mayor La Guardia withheld. his signatures yesterday from a Council bill changing the name of Horace Harding Boulevard in Queens to World's Fair Boulevard.

Benefactors from every walk of life, united only by a common compassion for their-less fortunate-fellows, added $5,572.50 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, bringing its total three days after the opening of the 1938 appeal to $54,904.89.
The St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York City shattered Yale's defense for four goals late in the opening period of their game tonight to triumph, 4 to 2, and mar the 193839 debut of the Ells.

Letters and telephone calls threatening his life have been received by John Harlan Amen since his appointment as special prosecutor to investigate charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, it was revealed yesterday.

The managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange decided yesterday to close the Exchange for trading on the Saturdays preceding the Christmas and New Year holidays. They also elected Donald M. Mackey of Arnold. Dorr Co;

The Christ marriage of Miss Julia Humphreys, daughter of Marion Humphreys of Warwick Manor, Salisbury, to Frank Charles Wachter 2d of Baltimore, son of Mrs. C. Knapp Wachter of Baltimore and E. J. Wachter of New York, took place here at noon today in St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Mortgage insurance by the Federal Housing Administration in November showed a higher percentage of gain, as compared with November, 1937, than that registered in any other month this year, Stewart McDonald, FHA Administrator, reported today.

Prince Alexis Obolensky, graytempled, broad and tall as befits a former officer of the Czar's Cavalry, confirmed last night that he had resigned a fortnight ago as president of the Russian Nobility Association and yesterday as a member.

We frequently hear it said that what is necessary to restore good times is the creation of some "new industry"the equivalent in our day of the railroad, the automobile and the motionpicture industries in their own respective early periods. Prophets of gloom tell us that without such a "new industry"-and they profess to see none on the horizon--capitalism is doomed.
The New York Southern Society held a gala dinner dance last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in celebration of the society's fifty-third anniversary.

Andy Kerr of Colgate, co-coach of the All-East football team, today' completed selection of his contingent of players when he announced that Walt Shinn, University of Pennsylvania tackle, and Dick Wehler, Temple center, had accepted invitations to play on the Pacific Coast Jan. 2 against the All-West eleven.
William R. Castle, former Under-Secretary of State, in a sharp attack on the Administration's policies toward Latin America, said tonight "the pendulum -has swung from arrogance to supineness."

While wheat futures held within exceptionally narrow limits today, the market had a firm undertone and closed ?? cent higher. Selling of the May at 67 1/2 cents a bushel on resting orders checked the upturn.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today, conditionally, a declaration by the Green Mountain Power Company, a subsidiary of New England Power Association, regarding a reduction of the capital represented by Green Mountain Power's no par value common stock from $2,107,408 to $1,123,951.

Court officials decided today to draw a new panel of veniremen for the trial of Lieutenant Governor Frank Hayes and twenty-one others, charged with conspiracy, after the original panel had been reduced from 172 to 46 and only five jurors chosen during seven days of proceedings.

Operators were active yesterday in the purchase of rows of houses on the East Side near Second Avenue. A deal near the approach to the Queensboro Bridge was announced by Loomis J. Grossman, who bought from the Dry Dock Savings Institution the row of buildings at 305, 307 and 309-11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Clint Smith turned in a spectacular three-goal effort tonight to lead the Rangers to a 6-5 National Hockey League decision over the Canadiens in a game that the Flying Frenchmen almost turned into a victory with a great spurt in the closing minutes.

Forty-five strikes were called in New York State during October but only 2,648 workers were involved, according to the. records of the Bureau of Mediation of the State Labor Department, which made the report public yesterday.

More than $2,000,000 was spent in this year's political campaign which resulted in the ousting of the Democrats from control of the State government after a four-year tenure. Expenditures as filed by the Republican and Dbmocratic State commitees were short of $1,500,000, but the figure was increased to well above $2,000,000 by funds used by county and independent committees.

With much clamor but without any contribution to the clarity of the situation the Chamber of Deputies resumed its session this afternoon and began at once discussing the general policy of the government.

The Nazi treatment of Jews in Germany, against which many American leaders, including President Roosevelt, have lodged strong protest, is disapproved by an overwhelming majority of American voters in every section of the country and of every race and religion, according to the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.
William E. Dodd Sr., former Ambassador to Germany, was charged with hit-and-run driving in a warrant sworn out today by State Trooper Carlisle Johnstone.
Dr. Porter William Shimer, chemist and metallurgist, discoverer of titanium carbide, died at his home in this city last night at the age of 81. He was stricken on Tuesday with paralysis.

With a performance of Massenet's "Manon," French opera finally entered the lists of the current Metropolitan Opera season. It had to wait until the middle of the third week, but when it arrived, it was close to the style that great artists of years ago had taught Metropolitan audiences to expect.

The Department of Agriculture reported today that this year's cotton crop is. estimated at 12,008,000 bales of 500 pounds, gross weight, a cut of 129,000, compared with the 12,137,000 bales that were forecast in the Federal summary a month ago. Last year 18,946,000 bales were produced, and the average production for the ten years, 19271936, was 13,201,000 bales.

The decree of Dec. 3 issued by the German Government covering employment of Jewish capital in the Reich and providing for enforced liquidation of Jewish industrial and real property. contains in its text,
Labor was criticized today before a Senate committee for its attitude toward systems under which business concerns agree to share profits with employes.

Katharine Augusta Carl, internationally known American portrait painter, died in Lenox Hill Hospital Wednesday night of a scalding received while bathing in her studio apartment at 170 East Seventyeighth Street.

The romantic tradition that aspiring young actresses must wade through sorrow to their throne has been loyally, but somewhat melancholically, observed by Luise Rainer and assorted aspirants in Mervyn LeRoy's "Dramatic School," which held its exercises at the Music Hall yesterday.

On some points Mr. Leon Henderson's reasoning before the Temporary National Economic Committee was a little difficult to follow. He complained, for example, that an important factor impeding competition, a factor which, he said, grew out of the large element of fixed costs involved in modern mass production, was "the attempt to break even at a very low-point of production."

The Ponderous Packers from Green Bay, bent on turning the tables on the Giants,- arrived last night for Sunday's play-off for the championship of the National Football League at the Polo Grounds. They seemed hardly able to wait for the opening kick-off so that they could atone for the startling 15-to-3 victory the Maramen scored over them three weeks ago.

With the Crop Reporting Board's estimate of the cotton harvest in line with general expectations, showing a reduction of 129,000 baler from last month's figures to 12,008,000 bales, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday and lost 5 to 10 points.

Mrs. Elizabeth Boynton Patton, a well-known church and welfare worker and wife of Dr. William W. Patton, pastor of the Glen Ridge Congregational Church, died here today at her home here. It was her forty-seventh birthday.

Wholesale baseball trades anticipated for the annual minor league assemblage had failed to materialize today. Rumors were plentiful but lacked confirmation on the second day of the thirty-seventh annual session of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, principal scene of Winter swapping.

A program of tax revision, viewed as essential to recovery, was adopted yesterday by the Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria after presentation of a report by A. G. Spalding, chairman of the committee on government finance of the National Association of Manufacturers. A vital feature of the program is a broader income tax base.

Accused of beating' twenty white children in a school bus at Bucktoe, two miles from here, five Negroes, three of them women, were arrested .tonight on warrants charging atrocious assault and battery and -were held without bail in the county jail for hearing tomorrow.

The insistence of the peoples of the New World on the maintenance of peace will be emphasized to the Pan American Conference by a delegation of the People's Mandate for Peace, which will be completed tomorrow by the arrival of Miss Mabel Vernon and Mrs. Carl Jackson, it was announced by the 'organization's headquarters here today.

A large majority of San Francisco business and industrial groups, as well as individual employers, will operate as a unit in collective bargaining hereafter under the guidance of a newly organized San Francisco employers' council.

The Midston House Squash Club continued unbeaten in five starts as it subdued the New York A. C., 4 to 1, last night on the Midston courts in a Class B match of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association. The hardest test of the evening, however, was won by Vernon Murphy, No. 2 for the losers, who beat Abbott Van Nostrand, 18-17, 17-18, 17-18, 18-17, 15-9.

Senator Byrnes, to illustrate the apparent arbitrariness in the allotment of WPA funds, has cited among other similar examples the fact that, up to April 1, 1938, WPA expenditures in Virginia and North and South Carolina, with a population of 7,300,000, amounted to $94,000,000,

Stealing a march on their professional contemporaries, the young reviewers of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures have announced their selection of the ten best motion pictures produced in Hollywood studios during 1938.

Riggs Distler Co., Inc., 216 N. Calvert Street, Baltimore, air conditioning and construction concern, announced yesterday that it is asking bids on more than $4,000,000 worth of materials, apparatus, refrigeration and electrical equipment in connection with the contracts it has just assumed.

Miss Mary Agnes Hooker, part owner and manager of the American and Foreign Teachers Agency, 19 West Forty-fourth Street, which supplies teachers to private schools, died yesterday at the Leroy Sanitarium after a ten-day illness.

Warlaine, owned by W. W. Adams of Boston and ridden by the clever apprentice, Eddie Robart, added to the winnings of his successful owner and trainer when he romped home with the purse in the Asheville Special, a six-furlong dash that topped the program at the Fair Grounds today.

A funeral service for Martin Egan, war correspondent, journalist and a member of the staff of J. P. Morgan Co., will' be held today at 11 A. M. in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Seventy-first Street and Madison Avenue. Burial will be in Greenwood Cemetery.

Clifton Webb, whose appearances on the dramatic stage have been infrequent of late-the last was in "And Stars Remain" in 1936--will be the star of a revival of "The Importance of Being Earnest," which Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers plan to put into rehearsal on Monday and open the afternoon of Dec. 28.

Condemning the "persecution, plunder and even murder" in certain countries today, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared yesterday there could be no lasting peace in the world until the guilty nations returned to a belief in God.
The Americans and the Red Wings fought to a 1-to-1 deadlock in a National Hockey League game tonight, each team scoring in the overtime period.
Making a sensational comeback in the second half, Harvard's basketball team handed Northeastern University a 31-26 setback in the Crimson's indoor athletic building tonight.

The work of the New York Association for the Blind has encouraged similar endeavors for the slightless in many other nations, Mrs. Winifred Holt Mather, honorary secretary and founder of the association, said yesterday at its annual meeting at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

Five of the six buildings on the east side of the Lexington Avenue blockfront between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, four abutting on properties on Forty-seventh Street and ten abutting on Fortysixth Street, were bought in at auction by the Bowery Savings Bank yesterday for $1,000,000.

In a move seriously curtailing the investigative activities of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, whom he was appointed to supersede in an inquiry into charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor, took over yesterday the rival investigation into irregular bail bond practices recently initiated by Mr. Geoghan.
President Roosevelt took steps today toward reviving his plan for reorganization of the executive branches of the government, which was defeated in the last session- of Congress.

Five million documents, rare Looks and secret reports of World War days comprising the Hoover Library on War, Revolution and Peace are to have a new $600,000 home, President Ray Lyman Wilbur of Stanford University announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Bailey of 21 East Ninety-fourth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Couch Bailey, to Robert Hallowell Shaw, son of Mrs. Carleton A. Shaw of Groton, Mass., and the late Mr. Shaw.

MANHATTAN BRETTELL, WILLIAM L. (Dec. 6). Estate, more than $10,000. To Ada M. Snyder, Jamaica, L. I., $10,000; Clinton Brettell, 87 Kingsbury Rd., New Rochelle, N. Y., $1,000; two specific bequests; Frank W. Haight, executor, 2,313 Creston Ave., Bronx, $2,500; Charles F. Brettell, brother, executor, 2,328 Morris Ave., Bronx. S3.000.

Corneliu Codreanu, leader of the Iron Guard Fascist movement in Rumania, and thirteen other Iron Guard prisoners, all of whom, with the exception of Codreanu, had been convicted of murder, were shot dead by their guards "while attempting to escape."

Despite the apparent plentitude of investment money and the large amount of idle funds, new mortgage financing in Manhattan continues to be slow, and the total for this year seems likely to be well below the 1937 figure.

Taking the lead in the second period, the Crescent A. C. hockey team scored its third victory of the season by turning back the Westchester Victorias, 4 to 3, last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace in a New York Amateur Hockey Association game. It was the fourth setback of the campaign for the losers.

The Anglo-American axis is swinging easily this morning. For "Spring Meeting," which was acted at the Morosco last evening, has escaped from London with a skillful band of comedians, and its sense of humor intact.

More than thirty former buttonhole trimmers, cutters, finishers and other garment workers had tea today at Friendship, the McLean estate where Presidents, Cabinet members and royalty have been guests.

Mayor Oliver G. Frake announced today that an investigation would be opened next Tuesday to determine the circumstances surrounding the death of Charles J. Ericksen, 16 years old, who died early this morning after having been impaled on a rope cleat near the bottom of a fifty-foot flagpole in the yard of the grammar school here.
Increased Franco-Italian tension and the Reich's colonial demands, weakened the stock market today and prices drifted lower after a firm opening. Gilt-edged stocks more than lost their early gains.

Engineering construction awards totaling $64,799,000 are reported for the current week by The Engineering News-Record. This figure represents a gain of 103 per cent over the $31,873,000 awarded in the same week of last year.
Two destroyers, the Mustin and the Russell, slid down the ways at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company today to a join the country's expanding naval forces.

Dr. B. Harold Brod of New Rochelle, a dentist with offices at 375 East Fordham Road, the Bronx, was stricken with a heart attack Wednesday night while walking on Third Avenue near Thirty-seventh Street and died before medical aid could reach him. His age was 45.

The Reich's first airplane carrier was launched here today in the presence of Chancellor Hitler. It was named Graf Zeppelin by the Countess Hella von Brandestein Zeppelin, daughter of the airship inventor.

The outlook next year for sugar grown in Puerto Rico is not encouraging, Frank A. Dillingham, president of the South Porto Rico Sugar Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. He said the effect of the Secretary of Agriculture's quota decision, which was above trade expectations, and proposed reductions in the Cuban tariff will operate against a higher price level in this country next year.
EL GRECO. (Oxford University Press, $3.) Phaidon Press Edition, with more than 200 plates. HERBS FOR URBANS AND SUBURBANS, by Katherine van der Veer. (Loker Raley, $1.25.) Recipes.

Despite a further slowing down in the rate of steel mill operations, business in the Pittsburgh district last week reached a new high level for the year, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The fact that the Hull-Roosevelt Good Neighbor Policy, however nobly conceived, seems at present much too unilateral has been pointed out far too often to need my repeating it. There is, however, one factor which is inherent in the policy as it now works which has not been noted.
Hans von Tschammer and Osten, German sports leader, announced today that Germany was breaking off all sports relations with The Netherlands for an unlimited period.

Norway paid her final tribute to Queen Maud today with a two-minute period of silence throughout the country as the body was taken from the Cathedral of Our Saviour for interment in the Castle of Akershus, which hereafter will be used only as a royal mausoleum.
Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne gave a dinner tonight on their yacht, the Coconut. Captain and Mrs. R. Amcotts Wilson were luncheon hosts at their villa.
Brown defeated the Massachusetts institute of Technology team in a hockey game tonight by 4 to 3. Bunny Fletcher scored the winning goal for Brown less than tree from the end of the game.

Paul V. Bunn, president of the Masonic Club of New York, retired vice president and general manager of the Remington Cash Register Company and former chief clerk of the United States Civil Service Commission, died in the Beth Israel Hospital here today.
The navy announced today that twelve entrants in its design competition for small craft had qualified and had been instructed to prepare plans for the final competition.
Heading the list of improvements in preparation for the legislative session is installation of a "public address" system for the Senate clerk.

The marriage of Miss Uta T. Hagen, daughter of Dr. Oskar F. L. Hagen of Madison, Wis., and the late Mrs. Hagen, to Jose V. Ferrer. son of Rafael Ferrer of 390 West End Avenue and San Juan, Puerto Rico, and the late Mrs. Ferrer, took place yesterday morning in the rectory of the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in West Eighty-second Street.
The 100 sirens installed to warn central London of the approach of enemy bombers were tested out today. The sirens, operated from police stations, give out a fluctuating high-pitched moan.

A vast effort to promote sales as an aid to business recovery was urged yesterday upon delegates at the Congress of Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by C. M. Chester, chairman of the executive committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

The Commonwealth Oil Advisory Committee has reported the existence in Victoria of a bed of eight square miles qf oil sands varying from twenty to forty feet in thickness and having an oil content of not less than 150,000,000 gallons. It is probably capable of commercial exploitation by modern methods.

J. J. Lordi of the New York Athletic Club and F. R, Hanson, home club star, ranked first and second, respectively, came through with noteworthy triumphs yesterday to gain the final round in the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament at the Columbia University Club.
Lumber production showed a contra-seasonal gain last week, raising the adjusted index to 69.4 from 64.7 in the preceding week. The index was 56.8 for the week ended Dec. 4, 1937.

Sales of General Motors cars and trucks totaled 200,256 in November, compared with 195,136 a year ago, the company announced yesterday. The October total was 123,835. An eleven-month figure of 1,119,840 was off nearly 840,000 from the 1,956,453 units gold through November, 1937.

A resolution calling for the establishment of legal service bureaus under bar association auspices, where a limited amount of legal counsel l would be given for a small, fixed fee and the applicant referred to a qualified lawyer if further advice was needed, was adopted last night by a conference of lawyers called by the National Lawyers Guild.

Although Fordham's basketball forces have one victory under their belts and hope to bag their second in Jersey City tonight, Ed Kelleher, who is back at the coaching helm after a four-year lapse, is not overenthusiastic concerning the current quintet's present or potential prowess.
With slight hope left that Amelia Earhart, lost with her plane in the South Seas, early in July, 1937, is still alive, George Palmer Putnam, her husband, filed her will for probate today.

Addressing the American Club today, Jules Henry, former French Charge d'Affaires in Washington and newly appointed Ambassador to Barcelona, who has been a close collaborator of Foreign Minister Georges' Bonnet during the past seven months, said that the signing of the declaration of peace between France and Germany "can and should constitute

Syracuse opened its basketball campaign tonight by overwhelming Toronto, 50 to 17. The all-senior Orange varsity set a fast scoring pace, with Captain Bob Stewart and Sidat-Singh getting 13 and 11 points, respectively. Bill Rogin, with 10 points, was outstanding for the Canadians.

W. Douglas Walker of this city has announced the marriage of his niece, Miss Hazel Elizabeth Stanley, to Francis J. Cahir of this city, which took place on Sept. 23 in Los Angeles at the home of the bride's cousin, Mrs. Norman J. Coudert.

Strictly choice and prime heavy weight steer cuts were scarce and about the only items in which the trade found interest in local markets yesterday. Other grades and weights, as well as most other classes of dressed meats, continued in slow demand. Steer, veal and calf were mostly weak; cow lower; fresh pork cuts somewhat uneven.

THE Pan-American Conference opens in Lima today. A good many issues of considerable importance to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness in this hemisphere will be discussed there--in public sessions or informal conversations--by the delegates of the American republics.
Distribution of Gaumont-British film productions. in this country will be handled by the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, beginning Monday, it was announced yesterday.

As the scales of history tilt down on one side of the country they lift on the other. In Virginia a supposed portrait of Captain John Smith turns out to be a painting of Peter John Potemkin, a Russian Ambassador to the court of the Stuarts, who probably never heard of Pocahontas. That is sad, of course.

Miss Barbara Bainbridge and John Seaman Bainbridge gave a dinner last night at the home of their parents, Dr. and Mrs. William Seaman Bainbridge of 34 Gramercy Park and later took their guests to a theatre.

MANHATTAN ADLERBLUM, DAVID (Dec. 23, 1937). Gross assets, $68,980; net, $64,077. To Henriette Adlerblum, widow, furniture, personal effects and life estate in residue: Rose Cahan, Yetta Adlerblum, Minna Berg, Clara Adlerblum, sisters; Cullen Adlerblum, brother, equal remainders in residue. Chief assets, mortgages, notes. cash and insurance, $44,313. Kurz Kurz. attorneys, 122 E. 42d St.

The total short interest on the New York Stock Exchange .at the close of business on the Nov. 29 settlement date, according to information furnished by members, was 587,314 shares, compared with 669,530 on Oct. 28.

Passenger steamship agents received word yesterday that the tenday cruise, scheduled for Feb. 10, of the liner Washington to Nassau, Kingston and Havana was to be canceled. In its place the management of the United States Lines has arranged that the Washington leave New York on Feb. 11 for a thirty-one-day cruise through the Panama Canal to San Francisco and return.

Three agents of the Internal Revenue Bureau visited the office of the New York Football Giants, Inc., 11 West Forty-second Street, yesterday, and after one of them had purchased eight tickets for the New York Giants-Green Bay Packers game next Sunday at the Polo Grounds, arrested two ticket sellers, Helen Simmons Mara, niece of Tim Mara, treasurer of the corporation, and Charles Chaplin.

The $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company yesterday flatly denied in the Federal District Court here that it is "insolvent" or that the consolidated assets of the Associated system have been "artificially inflated."

D. Frederick Burnett, State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner, had under advisement today an attack on his power to set prices of liquor under the State Price-Fixing Law. The law was attacked yesterday by John J. Quinn, United States District Attorney for the New Jersey district, who appeared as counsel at a hearing for John Gaine, owner of a Neptune City liquor and delicatessen store.

E. A. Mays, member of the Har vard Club, who is seeded No. 1 among the forty-six entries in the annual Fall Class B and C squash tennis tourney at the New York Athletic Club, yesterday won his first match when he defeated J. H. Graham Jr., his Yale Club opponent. The score was 155, 15-7.

Edward Kernan Campbell, former chief justice of the United States Court of Claims, died last night at the age of 80. A native of Abingdon, Va., Judge Campbell came to Washington from Birmingham, Ala., on his appointment as chief justice by President Wilson in 1913.

The Secretary of State's office announced today the official vote on three proposed constitutional amendments defeated in November. The amendments would have realigned legislative, districts, prohibited proportional representation and provided a new judiciary article.
Gifts to the Neediest Cased Fund Yesterday totaled $12,055.50 from 262 contributors, whose offerings brought the aggregate amount received to date in the 1938 appeal to $66,960.39.

Testifying in regard to a proposed investment program involving $8,000,000 by the United Corporation, George Howard, president, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that only securities deemed to be of the-highest character would be acquired and emphasized that the corporation had no intention of acquiring blocks of securities for the purpose of exercising control over the management of any issuer.

Mrs. Nona H. McAdoo Taylor, daughter of Senator McAdoo, has arrived here with the intention of filing a suit for divorce against Francis Taylor of New York. She was married to Ferdinand de Mohrenschildt in 1917.

The United States is nearing the end of nine years of sharply arrested development in its economic life. Never before in our history has so long a period passed without recording a new high point in industrial production and individual well-being.

In the view. of hundreds of passers-by, three holdup men stole the entire showcase stock of Nathan Bernstein, watch repairer and jeweler, and $170 in cash, from his store at 125 Delancey Street at about 5 P. M. yesterday. The stock. according to an estimate furnished by the police, was worth $3,500. It was uninsured.

Disclosures of Philippine Railway bond manipulations involving Assemblyman Felipe Buencamino have assumed the comparative proportions of a Teapot Dome scandal here. Mr. Buencamino is one of the leading Assemblymen and has been vigorously supported for the floor leadership in the Second National Assembly.

Extra compensation of a week's pay will be distributed to about 2,000 employes of the Pratt Whitney Company, operating division of the Niles-Bement-Pond Company at Hartford, Conn., Clayton R. Burt, president, announced yesterday.

Fred H. Hilton was appointed yesterday an assistant secretary of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company. Pierre du Pasquier and L. Stanley Kahn have formed a partnership with offices in 11 Wall Street and 26 Champs-Elysees, Paris, France,

The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended Dec. 7, issued today, shows an increase of $2,298,000 in notes in circulation, but the ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities rose to 54.53 per cent from 54.14 the week before.

For many reasons we like the Bermudans, and not the least because they resemble so much our ancestors of the eighteenth century. Their Assembly loves to pick a quarrel with the Royal Governor. Its recent denial of an automobile to the present one is an amusing instance.

Harry Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, revealed today that he planned to sponsor changes in relief procedure. In the first press conference he had held since last Summer he indicated rather definitely that the changes would meet at least some criticisms leveled at the WPA.

In pursuance of his recent policy of conferring with United States Ambassadors at first hand and in view of growing concern over Japan's course in China, President Roosevelt has summoned home Nelson T. Johnson, Ambassador to China, for consultation.

Two women were slightly burned, an apartment was damaged and residents of an eighty-eight-family house at 36-14 165th Street, Flushing, Queens, were frightened about 6 o'clock last night by an explosion and fire that occurred when one of the women, Mrs. Ada Schad, returned home, opened the door of her gas-filled kitchen and discovered the body of her husband, Carl, 64 years old, a lithographer and advertising man in Manhattan.

The American Academy in Rome announces its annual competitions for fellowships in architecture, landscape architecture, painting, sculpture, musical composition and classical studies. Entries for the competitions will be received until Feb. 1.
The first session of the auction sale of American and eighteenth and nineteenth century furniture

Spreading of orders and production throughout the year is vital to the toy industry if rising costs due to wage and hour and social security legislation are to be met, Herman G. Fisher, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., said yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the organization at the Hotel New Yorker.

Final plans were made last night by Mayor La Guardia for the mass meeting at which he is to preside tonight In Carnegie Hall. It has been designed as an organized protest against the oppression of minority groups in Europe.
Stocks closed lower in less active trading; 739,150 shares traded. Italian and French loans down sharply; United States Government and other bonds irregularly lower; transactions, $7,505,170.

Four persons from Linden, including the city clerk and the police recorder, who were allegedly involved in a transaction through which the city of Linden paid $11,000 for a fire house site, were arraigned this aftternoon before County Judge Edward A. McGrath on indictments resulting from a Supreme Court investigation of Linden's financial affairs.

The pound sterling and its satellite currencies fell further in the foreign exchange market yesterday as new developments in the FrancoItalian situation appeared as a menace to peace in Europe. Sterling declined to $4.66 7/8 and closed down 1 cent at $4.671/8.

An investing client of James C. McCormick, broker, has purchased from the Frissell Realty Corporation the six-story apartment house at 43-15 Forty-fifth Street, Sunnyside, Queens. This is a fifty-twofamily building on a plot 100 by 100 feet, assessed for $150,000.

There is every reason to hope that President Roosevelt will hold fast to his present opinion that the cost of a new armament program should be met out of current revenues rather than financed with more borrowed money.
Seven miners were killed by a rock slide in the Bell Asbestos Mine here two hours after a dynamite blast last night. Three of the bodies have been recovered.

The Liggett Drug Company has leased from the Hotel Times Square, Sydney Claman, president, the large store at the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Fortythird Street, with 65 feet frontage on the street side and 42 feet on the avenue. Louis Tangredi was the broker.

Many dinner parties in honor of delegates to the Junior League Regional Children's Theatre Conference in Montclair were given tonight. Among those entertaining were Miss Katherine Beach, Miss Mary Adele Russell, Mrs. Monroe Dreher, Mrs. Philip E. Nuttle, Miss Lorraine Condit and Miss Rosemary Case at the home of the latter:

Newly acquired Sudeten areas of Germany have been included in the provisions governing land accounts for American companies, according to cabled advices received yesterday by the Board of Trade for GermanAmerican Commerce from Berlin.

Mrs. Evelyn Parsons Hollingsworth, wife of Amor Hollingsworth, pulp and paper manufacturer, died today at her estate, Brushwood, Milton. A member of the Chilton Club of Boston, she was greatly interested in the infants' hospital.

The Board of Estimate appropriated $57,708 yesterday to cover the wages of 160 former employes of the Sixth Avenue elevated line who are to be placed on the city payroll in connection with demolition of the ancient structure.
The New York Athletic Club celebrated the seventieth anniversary of its founding last night at a dinner which drew a capacity attendance to the spacious gymansium in its Fifty-ninth Street home.

" Low cost" insurance will be available in at least three savings banks in this city on Jan. 4, Edward A. Richards, president of the East New York Savings Bank, said yesterday in an address over WNYC.

Seventy-five awards have been made in Fall sports at Manhattan, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. Twenty-nine football and ten in cross-country received major insignia.

John F. Wheeler, 38 years old, arrested on a robbery charge yesterday in the Hotel Knickerbocker at 120 West Forty-fifth Street, is alleged to have told his captors that a desire to obtain funds to finish an -invention to improve a motion picture apparatus led him into crime.

The general level of wholesale prices rose during the week ended on Dec. 3, largely because of higher prices for farm products, the Bureau of LaborStatistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 77.4 last week, compared with 77.3 for the week ended Nov. 26 and 82.0 on Dec. 4, 1937.

The Salle Santelli team, composed of Miss Barbara Cochrane, Miss Mildred Stewart and Mrs. Miguel de Capriles successfully defended the national junior foils team fencing championship at New York University last night.
A trend toward building huge, fast airliners, to carry armies in war and civilian passengers in peace, is noted in the new edition of the British annual, Jane's All the World's Aircraft.

In the course of searching operations yesterday British troops surprised an Arab rebel "court" in session in Attil, a village near Tul Karm. Two "judges," two messengers and a number of litigants from neighboring villages were detained for interrogation.

The garage building on a plot 100 by 100 feet at' 1,028-32 Freeman Street, the Bronx, was sold by the estate of Peter A. Smith to the Fox are Laundry Company, Inc., which has occupied it as a tenant since 1934. J. Arthur Fischer, Inc., was the broker in the deal.

Fairbanks, Morse Co. today completed transactions for sale of manufacturing rights of its "Conservador" refrigerator to Philco Radio and Television Corporation. S. T. Kiddoo, treasurer of Fairbanks, Morse, stated that Philco had also taken over the Fairbanks, Morse refrigerator sales organization, comprising 300 to 350 men.
A typhoon raced across fifteen provinces of the central Philippines today, killed at least nineteen persons, made thousands homeless, and was believed to have caused -much property damage.

The recent rainfall has completely washed away any hopes skiers might have entertained for good running in the East this week-end. Unless the Weatherman, whose vagaries the past two Winters have disappointed thousands of outdoor sports enthusiasts, dispatches plenty of snow today, the opportunity to -cut fancy capers on open slopes and wooded trails tomorrow and Sunday will be nil.

TODAY--NewEngland: Cloudy, probably some scattered snow over northern and central parts; cloudy, probably some scattered rain over south; slightly colder, light freezing temperatures over north; slightly cooler, temperatures continuing above freezing over south. New York State:

After a year's effort by the National Association of Manufacturers, collecting opinions among its 5,000 members, its annual "Programi for American Progress" was adopted here yesterday for the guidance during 1939 of this largest organized employing group in the nation.
A remark by Mr. Ybarra in the last of his dispatches from Brazil makes it seem unlikely that there ever will be a completely peaceful

Letters opposing the proposed Patman anti-chain bill are already being received in large numbers by Congressmen, reports here yesterday indicated. The communications attacking the measure, which Representative Patman plans to introduce at the forthcoming session of Congress, are being received from employes of chain stores and from consumers.

Cyrus E. Woods, lawyer and diplomat, who served as this country's envoy to Portugal, Spain and Japan and who held several high positions in Pennsylvania's government, died in Jefferson Hospital here this morning of Bright's disease at the age of 77.

The total of excess reserves of member banks of the Reserve System continued to advance into record high territory in the last statement week, in spite of a sizable increase in currency circulation. Circulation went up $56,000,000, an amount which would just about correspond to what formerly was considered a normal rise for the first week in December.

Representative Martin Dies of Texas, chairman of the Congressional committee on un-American activities, criticized Cabinet members and newspaper writers for "smearing" his committee, in a speech at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the New York State Economic Council in the Hotel Biltmore.

The War Department issued the following orders today dated Dec. 7. COLONELS Bailey, N. E., Q.M.C., Fort Sam Houston, Texas, to retirement. Fulton, W. S., Inf., Fort Douglas, Utah, detailed in the National Guard Bureau and to duty in office of the Chief National Guard Bureau Washington, D. C.: to sail from San Francisco about Jan. 6. for New York.
Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Edith Adams Greene, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Allen Greene of this city, to Francis Cowles Strickland of Washington. D. C.

A step toward approval of a plan for reorganization of the Syracuse System of the New York State Railways has been taken by the Public Service Commission, according to an announcement by the commission yesterday.

After showing the way at the intermission, 33--14, the St. Francis College basketball team downed Cathedral College, 58--33, in the victors' gymnasium in Brooklyn last night. Carl Malfitano and Frank Hrbek, with 9 points each, led the attack for the winners, but individual scoring honors went to Joe Jackette of the losers, with 17 markers.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest for the year.

Actual figures on stocks and shipments of rayon yarn, hitherto available only in the form of index numbers, were issued yesterday by the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., and revealed that November shipment. of filament yarns to domestic consumers totaled 21,000,000 pounds.

The International Railway Company yesterday announced that it will purchase, for cancellation, its refunding and improvement 5 per cent mortgage bonds to the extent of $850,718 now available for that purpose.

A warning to industry that it brought the Wagner Act on itself and that its continued opposition to it might bring about even more stringent legislation was given last night by Dr. William M. Leiserson, chairman of the National Mediation Board,

What seemed to many persons here the opaque statement of the President last Tuesday on the rearmament-and-tax program appeared to them also to confirm reports that the national defense plan is rapidly being revised downward in the intimate councils.
A serious dispute developed today between the Japanese and Soviet Governments. The dispute revolved about Japanese agitation for extended fishing rights in Siberian waters under Russian control.

Screeno, bingo, banko and other such games of chance that have flourished in the neighborhood movie houses may soon be a memory in, this city, if the warning of License Commissioner Paul Moss is heeded.

Today's events: "Lohengrin," for young people, afternoon, Metropolitan Opera House; double-bill, "Salome" and "Pagliacci," Metropolitan, 8 P. M.; PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Mieczyslaw Munez, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Stanley Hummel, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.
Marlene Dietrich and Columbia today announced settlement of their contract, under which the actress was to have starred in a series of pictures, the first of which was "Chopin."

About half the long-distance trucking in and out of this city was cut off yesterday by a strike of stevedores and checkers employed in truck terminals here. More than 1,000 drivers refused to enter the terminals, although their unions insisted no official sympathy strike had been called and that the unions were living up to their contracts reached in October after the citywide trucking strike.

The fact that one of the jurors who sat in the trial that recently ended in the conviction of three members of the German spy ring is believed to be a Jew was cited yesterday in notice of appeals filed by attorneys in behalf of the defendants, Otto Hermann Voss, Johanna Hofmann and Eric Glaser.

Mrs. Anson B. Moran will give a reception at the clubhouse of the Colonial Dames of America, 421 East Sixty-first Street, on Wednesday for her eldest granddaughter, Miss Gertrude Vander Poel Rose, debutante daughter of Professor and Mrs. Robert Selden Rose of New Haven.

Fed steers and yearling trade was less active today and steady to 25 cents lower, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. The market topped at $12.50, paid for 1,050pound yearlings. Hogs cleared on a fairly active basis at steady rates; top $7.55, most fat lambs sold generally steady, fedlambs reaching $9.50.

A cab driver and two women passengers were killed early yesterday morning when the taxi collided with a truck on Lexington Avenue near 119th Street, went out of control, and crashed into a machine shop. A third passenger, a man, was seriously injured.

Miss Josephine Roche, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was elected president of the National Consumers League yesterday at the league's annual members' meeting in the Allerton House, 130 East Fifty-seventh Street. She succeeds John G. Winant, director in Geneva of the International Labor Organization.
Benny Goodman has written an autobiography which Stackpole will publish in February. It is written in collaboration with Irving Kolodin.

Trade of the United States with Latin America should be built up as something of material benefit to both parties, rather than under the guise of altruism, William K. Jackson, vice president and general counsel of the United Fruit Company, declared in an address fonight before the Inter-American Center of George Washington University.

Increased research and experimentation by industry as a means of developing new avenues to national prosperity and buttressing the economic foundations upon which the nation rests was! urged by speakers at yesterday's session of the Congress of American Industry in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mrs. W. Harold Warnock of Montclair, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Warnock, to Dr. George Carson McEachren, son of Mrs. George McEachren of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. McEachren.

Nations as well as individuals must not forget in their craving for peace that there are things worse than war, the Rev. John F. O'Hara, president of Notre Dame University and member of, the United States delegation to the Eighth Pan-American conference, told a huge congregation in Lima's historic cathedral today.

The Mexican Government today signed an agreement by which $17,000,000 worth of petroleum from expropriated American and British properties will be bartered for German merchandise, machinery and other products during 1939.
The Treasury Procurement Division today telegraphed invitations to bid by wire or letter-on a total of 240,000 yards -of cotton goods for shipment to WPA consignees.

Railway management, labor and shippers by rail united last night in urging legislative relief for the railroads in a symposium issued at the annual dinner of the New York Railroad Club in the Hotel Commodore. The interests of railroad investors also were put forward.

Under pressure of generally lower prices the gasoline "war" is waning in the Chicago area, although by no means ended. Helped by a series of price cuts at wholesale by big oil companies, "regular" stations are selling standard-grade gasoline at 16 1/2 to 17 1/2 cents a gallon, tax paid.

Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, made clear at his press conference today that he did not share apprehensions concerning the Good Neighbor policy voiced in an address here last night by William R. Castle, former Under-Secretary of State.
A regional solution of world problems confronting the American republics is insufficient, declared Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, in a radio address tonight over a NBC program.

The Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics has added rowing to its program, according to an announcement yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive director. The list of sports handled by the agency includes football, track, baseball, basketball, hockey, golf, swimming and fencing.

A Western Hemisphere free of written military pacts but united to repel armed aggression from outside and to ward off political encroachments by non-American nations is what Brazil will strive for at the Lima Pan-American Conference.

The greatest threat to the health of the future generations here is presented by the 70 per cent of the city's children who are without dental care or observation, Dr. Charles Wilkie, president of the Second Dental District of the State of New York, told the Greater New York dental meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Soap-box orators and sponsors of open-air forums who formerly frequented the open spaces of Union Square appear to have found a new haven for their activities in Madison Square Park, and property owners and merchants of that neighborhood are studying possible means of halting use of their area for motley gatherings of this type, it became known yesterday.

Mrs. Sylvester Gruszka, wife of the Polish Consul General at New York, gave a tea yesterday at her home, 149 East Sixty-seventh Street, for ten young matrons serving on the reception committee for the Kosciuszko Foundation's sixth annual Night in Poland Ball to be held Jan. 20 in the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. David Meredith Hare heads the reception committee for the benefit.

A Christmas tea, the first in the series of four traditional senior class receptions for the faculty,. wil be. held at Barnard College today. Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve and members of the administration and faculty will be guests of honor. Miss Elizabeth Jackson, senior class president, and Miss Dorothy Alberta Smith, social chairman, will receive the guests in Barnard Hall on the campus.

The High Court here today or dered immediate confiscation of the Iron Guard organization's property, as had been decreed on its dissolution. The organization owns two houses in Bucharest as well as a considerable quantity of furniture and other property.

To counteract the growth of "hatred and intolerance" that has spread to this country from abroad, the Board of Education's instructional affairs committee, at a meeting yesterday, recommended that courses in tolerance be introduced in the New York City public school system.

Colonel George Montgomery, an expert in the manufacture of small munitions who retired in 1922 from the United States Army after thirty years of service, died yesterday morning in his sleep at his apartment, 790 Riverside Drive.

Pedro Montanez, 139 3/4, Puerto Rico, was credited with a tworound knockout victory over Vincenzo Salvini, 136, Stamford, Conn., last night when Salvini, who had injured his wrist, was unable to answer the bell for the third round of their feature eight-round contest at Prospect Hall.

The fifth week's play in the Class A squash racquets. section of the Metropolitan League produced an upset last night when the hitherto undefeated Harvard Club team bowed to the Squash Club by a 3-2 score on the Crimson's courts. This setback, coupled with the Unlversity Club's 4-1 triumph over Rockaway on the winner's courts, put Harvard and University in a tie for first place with four victories and one defeat each.

Transfer and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Dec. 9; assignment to desk duty continued: LIEUTENANTS Jacob J. Levy, from command 79 Precinct to command 13 Division; William A. G. Smyth, from command 13 Division to command 79 Precinct.

The John Marshall College basketball team of Jersey, City inaugurated its schedule tonight with a 42-26 victory over Brooklyn 'College of Pharmacy. The winners rallied in the second half after trailing at the intermission, 16-15. Rizzi and Hale starred for Marshall, with 7 points apiece, while Miller paced the. visitors.

The dictatorship which attempts conquest by force in the name of race or religion reverts to the law of the jungle and retards the higher evolution of mankind, Sir Richard Gregory declared today in a lecture at the dedication of the new auditorium of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.
Jack J. Spalding, Atlanta attorney and nationally known Catholic lay leader, died in a hotel today after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.
Sidney R. Kent, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, defended yesterday in Supreme Court the practice of permitting film executives to share in the profits.

Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, will be transferred from the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania at quarantine tonight and rushed with a police escort to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where he is to deliver an address before the National Association of Manufacturers.

The little things paid big dividends in football this season. The one, two and three pointers, resulting from tallies after touchdowns, safeties and field goals, brought victory or prevented defeat 236 times throughout the nation.

A somewhat broad reaction yesterday pared bond prices on the New York Stock Exchange, although trading was slower than on Wednesday. All groups appeared to be subjected to selling pressure In varying degrees, with the result that the market, as a whole, closed generallyy lower.

As the years go by the human problems listed among the Hundred Neediest Cases may change their nature. Many of them now arise from ill health, which in turn is often due to malnutrition, overwork and worry.

Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, disagreed yesterday with James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, that the presence of a bar adjoining the Straubenmuller Textile High School Annex at 60 West Thirteenth Street,

Herbert C. Sierck, New York Stock Exchange member and a partner in the brokerage firm of Hornblower Weeks, 40 Wall street, died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage on Wednesday at his home, 31 East Seventy-ninth Street, after a brief illness. His age was 51.

L. M. Giannini of the Transamerica Corporation and two of his associates, William Blauer and Russell Smith, vice presidents of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, conferred today with Preston Delano,

A fresh demand for a world economic conference to solve the fundamental problems which threaten peace was voiced tonight by the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Palmer, president of the Chicago Theological Seminary.

The first step in an expansion program for the manufacture of ethyl cellulose was announced today by officials of Hercules Powder Company. Work will begin at once on the construction of a new ethyl cellulose plant at Hopewell, Va.

Executives of four out-of-town stock exchanges visited the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to attend the first of a series of roundtable discussions of the proposed new. listing policies of the New York body.

Distribution of Christmas Club savings checks and the heavy banking transactions usually incident to the first of the month were largely responsible for the 11.7 per cent increase in bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday over the corresponding week a year

The British Government took another step today in setting up machinery for a trade war against Germany. It introduced a bill in the House of Commons giving the Board of Trade a fund of [Pound]10,000,000 to guarantee British export trade, not on commercial grounds but on the basis of "national interest."

Jackson Day dinners will be held throughout the country on Jan. 7, under the auspices of the Democratic National Committee. Prices will range from $25 to $100 a plate and party leaders hope to raise enough money to wipe out the deficit and provide funds for current expenses.

The Outboard Marine and Manufacturing Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $714,158 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania is due today from Southampton via Cherbourg. Her passengers include Margaret Countess of Suffolk and Berkshire, Viscount and Viscountess Hinchinbrooke, Lady Daphne Straight, Sir Martin Beckett,

Subpoenas were issued by the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission today to compel the appearance of about 1,200 employers delinquent in filing wage-record reports. The law provides penalties for willful failure to make such reports.

Proposals for an entirely new type of aquarium, to give practical illustrations of the life of fish and aquatic animals, are described by Dr. Charles M. Breder Jr. in the current issue of the New York Zoological Society Bulletin, published yesterday.

Amazing but incomplete stories of how upwards of $10,000,000" disappeared from the reported as?? of McKesson Robbins, Inc., were disclosed yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, which released for publication a transcript of testimony given on Wednesday before its stock-list committee by W. L. Cummings, director of the drug concern, and Julian F. Thompson, treasurer and director.

Employes who work overtime without the consent of their employers should be discharged, Elmer F. Andrews asserted today in answer to one question asked at a luncheon meeting of the Trade Association Executives Forum of Chicago.

Discussing German efforts to effect "Aryanization" beyond the Reich's frontiers Foreign Minister Rickard Sandler said today in a speech here that Swedish concerns doing business in Germany had been informed that it was not proper for them to have "nonAryan" staffs.

Miss Anna M. Hunter, older daughter of the late Dr. Thomas Hunter, first president of Hunter College, died on Wednesday at her home, 91 Central Park West. A graduate of Hunter College in 1874, Miss Hunter kept up an interest in the college, particularly in the library and the Associate Alumnae.

A lone robber wearing a handkerchief over his face and brandishing a pistol escaped with $50 early yesterday morning, after holding up two employes of the Pickwick Arms Hotel, 230 East Fifty-first Street, between Second and Third Avenues, about a block from the East Fiftyfirst Street police station.

The United States Housing Authority, for which Congress appropriated $800,000,000, reached the point today, of being "broke, but happy," in the words of Nathan Straus, Administrator, who announced allocation of the last of its funds.

A famous fourvolume edition of Ovid's "Metamorphoses" in Latin and with a French translation by the Abbe Banter sold for [Pound]1,180 to Bernhard Quaritch Co. at a further auction of the Mortimer Schiff book collection at Sotheby's today.
The first mortgage 41/2 per cent bonds of the Industrial Rayon Corporation due in 1948 will be admitted to the list and to dealings on the New York Stock Exchange today.

Both private monopoly and totalitarian control of business by the State are equally 'objectionable to Americans, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, chairman of the Temporary National Economic Committee, told the Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

The memory of a man who had a unique role in football as well as in all college sport was honored last night at the Columbia University Club when the first annual award of the Touchdown Club was made posthumously to Le Roy N. Mills, master of controlled kicking and one of the greatest enthusiasts the sports has ever had.

On the basis of early returns in a vote conducted among students at the New York University downtown center by The Washington Square College Bulletin, official undergraduate newspaper, 95.6 per cent of the voters were in favor of a return to big-time football policies.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today agreed to aid financially in the reorganization of the Chicago Great Western Railroad and Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway. Chairman Jesse H. Jones wrote Patrick H. Joyce, a Great Western trustee, that the RFC was ready to lend $6,500,000 to the reorganized company.

Eight mnembers of the American Newspaper Guild were arrested and blows fell on a dozen heads in a melee today along the picket line at the Hearst Building, where members of the guild are on strike against The Evening American and The
