Mayor La Guardia receivd a threat against his life yesterday morning from an unidentified person who enclosed a loaded cartridge in a letter warning that the Mayor could expect death if he did not stop attacking the Nazis in Germany.

A denial that the National Mari time Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, will attempt to set up on the East Coast a rival union to the International Longshoremen's Association of the American Federation of Labor was issued by the National Council of the Maritime Union, holding its quarterly session here yesterday.

The Princeton University Triangle promenade will be held in the university gymnasium tomorrow from 11 P.M. to 4 A. M. The dance, an innovation this year, is given in honor of the Princeton Triangle Club's fiftieth anniversary and proceeds will go to the sophomore class preident's program drive.

THE way they used to announce the batters at old baseball games in the provinces, the heavyweight line-up of the moment could be announced as follows: Barlund and Toles up, Farr and Nova on deck, Lewis and Louis in the hole!

About a decade ago Anthony Eden was referred to as "that terrible young man who wants peace so much." He had earned a Military Cross in finding out what war was like. As a rising diplomat he strove, against obstacles now fully realized,

Continued absence of stocks of wool piece goods in mill hands caused buyers, in the market this week for fair amounts of spot goods, to turn to jobbers, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly summary of conditions.

Every one. up here seems inclined to blame the foxes for the recent scarcity of game birds; that is, every one except the foxhunters, and they place the blame on the recent hurricane, disease and foraging house cats.

Jack Dempsey, by a vote of almost 2 to 1 over his nearest rival, was named yesterday by the New York Boxing Writers Association as the person who has contributed most to the welfare of boxing through 1938. As a token of his accomplishment, Dempsey will receive the Edward J. Neil Memorial Medal, donated by the association, at a dinner to be held next month.

Hans Heinrich Schackow, the first of four Germans to be tried here for unlawfully photographing Panama Canal defenses, failed to' receive permission to visit Forts Sherman and San Lorenzo the day before his arrest at Fort Randolph, according to Lieutenant W. H. Parr.
Mayor La Guardia turned to the bassinets of Brownsville, Williamsburg and Jamaica for ammunition yesterday in his attack on the Court of Appeals. decision affecting the city's prior lien law.

More than $30,000 was raised last for a contribution by J P. Morgan and original manuscripts at a bookauction dinner conducted by the Joint Distribution Committee and the Committee for Christian German Refugees at the Hotel Plaza.

The prize of $500 for a choral work suitable for high-school voices and dedicated to the World's Fair, which was offered by G. Schirmer, Inc., music publishers of this city, has been awarded to Norman Lockwood, associate professor in the Oberlin Conservatory of Music, Oberlin College, Ohio, for his setting of Walt Whitman's "Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking," it was announced yesterday.
Before a gathering of 6,000 ?? Madison Square Garden last night skiing instruction and competition again were the center of attraction at the Winter Sports Show.

In newspaper advertisements and notices posted in stations and trains, the Erie Railroad announced today that it had applied in Federal court at Cleveland for permission to disaffirm its lease on the Northern Rail. road's tracks from North Bergen, N. J., to Nyack, N. Y. A hearing on the application will be held Dec, 21.
Colonel Latham Reed, a former army officer, accused the Americal Civil Liberties Union today, of defending atheism and the right of an individual to advocate murder, assassination and revolution.
Bill Kelley, sightless but determined University of Pittsburgh high-jumper, worked out today with the will to win a berth on Pitt's freshman track squad.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing the Pacific Public Service Company's new common stock of no par value, in accordance with the company's capital reclassification, and suspended dealings in the old non-voting stock.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, after studying plans for the reorganization of the Standard Commercial Tobacco Company, recommended yesterday partial or complete liquidation of assets as more desirable than reorganization.
Declaring that the Paterson regional office of the WPA "reeks with intrigue" and "mismanagement," Mayor Bernard L. Stafford today demanded a "sweeping investigation" of WPA operations.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
The Congress of American Industry undertook to find out yesterday what the average farmer thought of its current proposal that "industry and agriculture are both partners in production."

Charles Jones, Newark attorney since 1906, who was outstanding in real estate and Chancery Court work, died of a heart attack early today in his home here. He was at his office yesterday and was taken ill after dinner last night. His age was 60.

Gunnar Barlund, Finnish heavyweight contender, will oppose Roscoe Toles of Detroit in the star bout of ten rounds at the New .York Hippodrome tonight. The card headed by these warriors will be the first shown in the Hipp in almost a year and promises to attract a gathering of 3,000 fans.

Business men must cease asking for special privilege of any kind from local, State or national governments, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, said yesterday in an address at the luncheon of the Bond Club of New York held in the Bankers Club.

The longest metropolitan racing season since the revival of the sport in 1913 was projected for 1939 yesterday when the stewards of The Jockey Club recommended a schedule of 175 racing days to the State Racing Commission.

Holding their rivals to 4 points in the second half, after trailing, 14--13, at the intermission, the High School of Commerce five rallied to down Haaren High, 28-18, in a lower Manhattan Division P. S. A. L. battle on the Commerce floor yesterday.

An interesting experiment, one not wholly successful, was undertaken at the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra lest night in Carnegie Hall when John Barbirolli performed a series of excerpts from Debussy's opera, "Pelleaa. et Melisande," joined together in the form of a suite, and thus separated from the dramatic context, presented to a concert audience.

Joseph Meilner, consulting engineer and resident here for thirty-five years, died at his home late yesterday. He was 60 years old. Born in Munich, Germany, he came to this country as a young man and engaged in research work for several large American companies.
Nikolai I. Yezhoff, under whom the purge of the last two years has been conducted, has been released from his duties as Commissar of Internal Affairs [which includes the political Police].

Evidence that advertisers and advertising agencies are becoming increasingly concerned with reader interest in publications has accumulated in recent weeks. While circulation figures and market data continue to be of prime importance, buyers of space are now more anxious to go beyond figures into the question of how thoroughly. a publication is read and by whom, agency men reported yesterday.

The proposal now before the City Council which would again grant tax exemption to limited-dividend housing projects was denounced yesterday by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Smiths Barney Co. today will offer 50,000 shares of Monsanto Chemical Company cumulative $4.50 no-par preferred stock, Series B, at $112.50 a share. Net proceeds from this financing will be added to the cash funds of the company.

The National Relations Board today ordered the Douglas Aircraft Company of Santa Monica, Calif., to stop discouraging membership in a local of the United Automobile Workers of America and to refrain from recognizing the Aircraft Workers Union, Inc., which it held to have been supported and dominated by the company.
Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that more than 97 per cent of the holders of $941,613,750 Treasury notes maturing on next March 15 had accepted new securities in preference to cash.

Jack Medica, the Olympic 400meter free style champion and one of the greatest swimmers of all time, will compete for the New York Athletic Club this season, it was learned-yesterday. The former University of Washington ace is taking a post-graduate course at Columbia and hence is available to the Winged Footers.

The body of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, wife of the Irish Free State Minister to the Vatican and .widow of Nicholas F. Brady, New York financier, will arrive here Sunday on the Italian liner Rex.

Cabinet members and guests at the state dinner at the White House on Dec. 13 will have the opportunity. to see the "Eleanor Walk," a special dance dedicated to the wife of President Roosevelt. Yesterday afternoon Mrs. Roosevelt visited the Hotel McAlpin, where the dance was performed by the team: of Miss Mayris Chaney and Edward Fox and she approved it.

A rise of $116,000,000 in "brokers' loans," reflecting the operations of government security dealers in connection with the new Treasury financing, was reported yesterday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their condition statement for the week ended on Wednesday.

Millions of radio listeners in Britain and the empire heard tonight the once familiar voice of Earl Baldwin, their foremost elder statesman, appealing to them to help the victims of persecution in Germany.
During the week ended Dec. 7 member bank reserve balances increased $90,000,000.

The marriage of Miss Mary Van Praag, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Van Praag of Meadowhill, Chappaqua, N. Y., to Edward Necarsulmer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Necarsulmer of 21 East Eighty-seventh Street, took place yesterday afternoon in the Gold Room at Sherry's. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson of Temple Emanu-El.

Breaking out with renewed vigor late yesterday the pre-holiday liquor price war was again in full swing here last night. Three brands of domestic whiskies were offered at prices as much as 53 cents below normal.
The Tennessee Valley Authority began today the presentation of evidence to justify its"yardstick" rates as an "honest and legitimate" basis of comparison with the rates of private utility companies.

The unusual success of the thirteen-ounce, five-cent loaf of bread, put on sale a month ago by one large chain store and since adopted by several other chains in the city, may result in another reduction in the price of the standard eighteenounce loaf, it was learned yesterday.

While pickets marched around city hall today carrying banners denouncing the recently enacted city income tax and hundreds of angry citizens crowded the corridors of-the building, the City Council left its financial headaches to a Citizens' Emergency Tax Committee of twentythree members.

The committee on admissions of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday transfer of the membership of Charles S. Kelley 3d to Gordon Brooks of J. C. Bradford Co. and that of William L. Meffert to L. Stanley Kahn of du Pasquier Co.

Extension of banking credit to build up business, increase income and reduce unemployment was advocated in an address prepared by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, and read for him yesterday at the midwinter conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Federal Judge William H. Holly approved, today, the settlement of claims of the Atlas Corporation of New York, an investment trust, against the Utilities Power and Light Corporation. About $4,200,000 of Atlas claims are to be settled for $3,200,000.

A train robbery, the first on record in this vicinity in some years, was successfully carried out early this morning by a gang of five or six men who stopped a seventy-one-car Pennsylvania Railroad freight, opened a car and escaped with cigarettes and tobacco estimated to be worth not more than $5,000.
The annual awards of the New York Madrigal Society were announced yesterday by Miss Marguerite Potter, founder of the society.

Dr. Rand Percy Crandall, retired captain of the United States Navy medical corps and a former member of the New York City Board of Health, died yesterday at the United States Naval Hospital in Brooklyn after an illness of several months.

With the United States Fleet scheduled to sail for the Atlantic early in January, the Navy Department acted today to feed the 60,000 enlisted men who will man the battleships, aircraft carriers, cruisers and other craft which will be assembled in the New York waters for the opening of the World's Fair.
Since the Reconstruction Finance Corporation resumed lending in February, this year, it has authorized 4,825 loans aggregating $837,559,609, Jesse H: Jones, chairman, announced today.

Samuel H. Silberman, Stamford real estate broker, who is under indictment for conspiracy on Merritt Parkway land, sales, turned State's evidence today and testified in Superior Court that he split his commissions on parkway land sales with G. Leroy Kemp of Mount Vernon, N. Y., indicted agent of the State Highway Department.
The French administration brought in Mobile Guard reinforcements ordered troops to remain in barracks and posted heavy police patrols tonight to put down rioting, over Fascist claims to Tunisia.

With a Rebel offensive expected to begin at almost any hour, the government is marshaling all its forces. All army commissars have been called to headquarters, all leaves have been canceled and all troops have been warned that a great test is coming.

The three-story business building at 51 East Palisade Avenue, Englewood, N. J., which for many years housed the F. W. Bergendahl restaurant and ice cream and candy enterprises, has been sold by William Bergendahl to a client of the Rothman Realty Co., Inc.

Building projects submitted yesterday were featured by plans for a $250,000 apartment house in the Bronx and two large multi-family structures in Jamaica, Queens, to be erected at a total cost of $945,000. The plans follow:

The Federal Trade Commission announced today It had prohibited four glass companies and two organizations of union glaziers in the St. Louis trade area from "combining to maintain certain monopolistic practices and policies."

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, gave a dinner last night at his home, 60 Morningside Drive, for Dr. Paul van Zeeland, former Belgian Premier. The other guests included Owen D. Young, William Nelson Cromwell, Thomas J. Watson,

Two seeded players will face each other in the final of the Class B squash racquets tournament tonight as a result of the triumphs of J. J. Reynolds of the University Club and F. B. Shaw of the Cornell Club in the semi-finals at the Squash Club last night.

Adoption of the Council bills reorganizing county government moved a short step forward yesterday when the Democratic majority made an agreement with the coalitionists to debate the bills in final form at the meeting on Dec. 20 in City Hall.
Defense Minister Oswald Pirow of South Africa said tonight on the eve of returning home that he was leaving Europe with "a feeling of almost unqualified anxiety."

The naval board of which Rear Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn is the president has completed its survey of the coasts of the United States, Alaska and the insular possessions. It will make a report soon, on the basis of which the next session of Congress is expected to enact legislation vital to the coast defense of the mainland and outlying territory.

Various charitable organizations ministering to the ill and needy will be aided by the Christmas sale at the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop which will open tomorrow at the headquarters of the shop, 705 Second Avenue, and will continue there throughout next week.

A banking group headed by Harris, Hall Co., Inc., submitted yesterday the high bids for $3,600,000 water works extension first mortgage bonds of Toledo, Ohio. Because of the closeness of two bids submitted by the group, both of a which afforded an interest cost to the city of about 2.73 per cent, the City Council deferred the official award until today.

Mixed-price movements ruled throughout the bond market yesterday in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Domestic corporation loans worked irregularly lower under the leadership of public utility bonds, while United States Government obligations maintained a firm undertone both on the Stock Exchange and in the outside market.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Medieval Sculpture: the Gothic Style in England and Germany," Harry D. M.. Frier, 11 A. M.; "Etchings of Rembrandt," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "American Painting of the XIX Century" (survey of collections), Alfred Busselle Jr., 2 P. M.; motion, pictures, 2:30 P. M.;.."The Sculpture From the Athenian Agora," T. Leslie Shear, 4 P. M.

With Mrs. Harry S. Woodring, wife of the Secretary of War, acting as sponsor, a new 493-foot, 10,000-ton passenger liner, described by her designers as "virtually sinkproof," will be launched tomorrow at the Fore River Yard of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation.

Hereafter, Mr. Arita, the Japanese Foreign Minister, says in effect, Japan will do the trading with China-and other countries, including ourselves, will do only such trading as Japan chooses to permit.

The marriage of Miss Virginia B. Felter, daughter of Mrs. Laura Felter of this city and the late Arthur Felter, to Jerome P. White, son of Mrs. Clara M. White, also of Rahway, Stook place last night in the Linden Methodist Episcopal Church, Linden.

A substantial increase in real estate activities in 1939 was predicted by William D. Flanders, president of the Lawyers Title Corporation, in an address yesterday at the midwinter conference of the New York League of Savings and Loan Associations, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Joseph Garber of the Trinity Club was placed first in one-wall singles handball play by the National Handball Committee at the national convention of the A. A. U. in Washington earlier this month, it was announced yesterday.

Ludlow St, 94. 24.6x87.6, Max Silverbush and ano to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; p m mtg, 5 yrs, int per bond; $7,000. Rivington St. 244, 25x100; Jostol Realty Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank: p m mtg, demand, int per bond: $20,069.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, today ordered that about 1,000,000 WTPA workers who ordinarily would be paid on Dec. 26 and Jan. 2 should receive their checks on Christmas and New Year's Eve.

Brig. Gen. Richard C. Moore, commanding the Atlantic sector of the Canal Zone defenses, declared that any information regarding the Galeta Island area would be of advantage ot a foreign nation. General Moore testified at the trial here of Hans Heinrich Schackow for unlawfully photographing a section of Fort Randolph.

Delegates to the biennial meeting of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America sharply answered today charges made earlier in the day before' the Dies Committee investigating un-American activities that the council "meddled incessantly in political affairs" and sponsored radical ideas.
New York's social grievance center has been moving north from Union Square to Madison Square. Public demonstrations

Fresh selling as a result of Germany's colonial claims and events in Tunis drove down the stock markets,here today. Political uncertainties and weakness in sterling depressed gilt-edge securities, which set the tone for most other groups.

Manhattan Alterations Broadway, 1,841: to 11-story and penthouse offices; Mutual Life Insurance Co. 34 Nassau St, owners; C. B. Ferris, enginever; cost, $20,000. Carmine St, 35; to 5-story tenement and stores; Joseph and Katrina Ferlauto, premises, owner: W. J. Minogue, architect; cost, $10,000.

Mervyn LeRoy, producer and director, gets $300,000 yearly from Loew's, Inc., instead of the $3,500 weekly generally believed, it was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court. Louis B. Mayer, in a deposition read in a stockholders' suit against directors of the film company, explained that the $3,500 figure was carried in one contract to be shown other producers so they would not become jealous.
Former President Hoover intends to make a series of speeches in the coming month on economic questions but without any intention of entering the Presidential race in 1940.

Department store sales increased by considerably more than the usual seasonal amount from October to November and the Federal Reserve Board's index adjusted for seasonal variation, was 83 per cent of the 1923-25 average in November, as compared with 84 per cent in the previous month, 86 in September and 91 in November, 1937.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Professional football has taken a strong hold in New York but, if the high-handed manner of the Giant management continues, there may readily be a change of attitude on the part of many fans. At the Redskin game last Sunday, an announcement was made that tickets for the play-off with the Packers would go on sale at 9 A. M. Tuesday.

A letter from President Roosevelt has been received by the American Bible Society, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, congratulating the organization on its translation of the Bible into itd one-thousandth tongue.

As the declared spokesman for 42,000 manufacturers with no fewer than 5,000,000 employes, H. W. Prentis Jr., president of the Armstrong Cork Company, closed the annual Congress of American Industry at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night with a declaration that "many of our former charts are useless."
The Ponderous Packers from Green Bay may not be hardier citizens than the Giants, but the fact remains that the Wisconsin mastadons practiced in the mud and rain yesterday and the Giants did not.

The Rev. Dr. William Seward Wallace, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Whitestone for twenty years until his retirement in June, 1937, died yesterday in his home, 150-47 Thirty-third Avenue, Flushing. His age was 74.

The life of Knute Rockne, long contemplated as a motion picture theme, is to be the basis of Warners' production, "The Fighting Irish." Arrangements have been concluded with Arthur Haley, Notre Dame business manager,

A total of $196,669 has been raised to date in the campaign for $250,000 for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. George B. St. George, chairman of team captains of the women's division of the campaign.

The American Smelting and Refining Company reduced yesterday the price of lead 10 points to 4.75 cents a pound at New York. This is the second reduction made this week, a cut of 15 points having been put into effect on Monday.

In other years platforms adopted by the National Association of Manufacturers have too often been wholly uncompromising in their condemnation of any infringement by either Government or labor on the traditional freedom of our industrial leaders.

Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw gave a dinner last night at her home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, for two debutantes, Miss Willa Blake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luther Lee Blake, and Miss Sheila Curtin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Enos W. Curtin. Later she took her guests to the opera. Others in the party were Mr. and Mrs., Dana C. Backus, de Witt Endicott and Mayo Cabell.
The Treasury announced today that its cash offering of 2 3/4 per cent bonds and 1 1/8 per cent notes made on last Monday had been subscribed, re- the spectively, more than fourteen and twelve times.

Oliver Prescott, a resident here more than forty years, but identified all his life with banking, industrial and philanthropic activities of New Bedford and a legal practice here, died today at St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 70.

John J. Rigley, 54 years old, who had been convicted of practicing medicine illegally in an office he maintained at 134 East Ninety-sixth Street, was sentenced in General Sessions yesterday to serve an indeterminate term in the penitentiary up to three years.

Challenging the legality of the action of Governor Hurley and the Executive Council in rushing through last night a flood control appropriation for $4,700,000, Governor-elect Saltonstall today warned contractors who do business with the State under the appropriation that they may not get their money.

Tomorrow in observance of annual "Universal Bible Sunday," of which the American Bible Society is sponsor, many pastors will preach sermons on the work of that organiza tion in trying to make the Scriptures available to every one. Commissioner Alexander M. Damon of the Salvation Army announced yesterday
Despite the heavy kill of antlerless deer last week, reads the report of the Pennsylvania Game Commission, the State deer herd has not been jeopardized.

Karl Mathie of Wausau died last night in Los Angeles, where he and Mrs. Mathie went ten days ago to spend the Winter. His age was 72. Born here, Mr. Mathie was identified with early activities in the papermaking industry in Wisconsin.

After holding a public hearing yesterday on a local bill designed to give the Markets Department control over retail gasoline stations the general welfare committee of the City Council decided to bring the bill before the Council for action at Tuesday's meeting.

In injunction sought by owners of neighboring property to prevent Frank E. Campbell from erecting a funeral church at Eighty-first Street and Madison Avenue was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente, In his opinion Justice Valente said there was nothing to show that such a structure was barred by City Zoning ordinances.

The induction into office yesterday of Professor Alexander G. Christie of Johns Hopkins University as president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers ended the fifty-ninth annual meeting of the society, which was held throughout the week at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirtyninth Street.

Today's events: "Siegfried," 1:45 P. M., and "In Trovatore," 8:30 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House; Trapp Family Choir and Yella Pessl, harpsichord, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Efrem Zimbalist, violin, and Vladimir Sokoloff, piano, Town Hall, 5:30 P. M.; PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.

The West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association received a larger number of applications for mortgages for new homes and sold more properties during November than in any month for some time, Dr. Herman L. Reis, president, announced yesterday.

109th St, 245-7 W, John King to 1. B. T. Realty Corp, 108 Lexington Ave. quit-claim. 162D ST, 535-7 W. George A. Arlington to 535 W 162d St Realty Corp, 535 W 162d St: mtg $84,500 (50c). 2d Ave. 29, 67 Ludlow St. Inc, to 23 Second Ave, Inc, 23 2d Ave ($16.50).

In a setting reminiscent of an old-fashioned Caucasian fete, the eighth annual Allaverdy Ball was held last night at the Plaza under the auspices of the Caucasian Society Allaverdy. Members of the sponsoring group attended in their national costumes. Princess Paul Chavchavadze was chairman of the event.

The marriage of Miss Jimmey Stupel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abner B. Stupel of 315 East Sixtyeighth Street, to Samuel Richard Stern, son of Mrs. Raye S. May, also of this city, took place yesterday morning in the study of the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise, who performed the ceremony.

Denouncing the Workers Alliance as an instigator of rioting, Kings County Judge John J. Fitzgerald ordered three men convicted yesterday of third-degree assault to post $500 bail each on Monday pending sentence.

Gallus J. Bader, prominent in banking and business activities in Gary, East Chicago, Indiana Harbor and Whiting until his retirement eight years ago, died in Holy Family Hospital today after a week's illness. His age was 73.

There is a widespread sentiment throughout the country for liberalization of the leadership of the Republican party, Kenneth F. Simpson, chairman of the New York County Committee, told members of its executive committee yesterday at a meeting in the National Republican Club.

A memorial exhibition of the work of the late William Glackens (1870--1937) will open at the Whitney Mu seum of American Art on Wednesday. Ninety-two paintings, supplemented by thirty-four drawings in various mediums, have been assembled for the occasion,

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

In one of his poems James Stephens, expressing the desire to free his mind of everything else and wait for the murmur of the winds of song, wants to be as "lonely as a tree." Is a tree lonely? They are sociable in the forests. They can hear each other talk.

The Pan-American Conference in Lima is arousing record interest in Europe, judging by the dispatches to the Rio de Janeiro press. The many foreign observers and correspondents at Lima, especially from totalitarian nations, emphasize this interest.

The allotments announced yesterday by the Treasury Department of 7 per cent and 9 per cent, respectively, on the new 2 3/4 per cent bonds and 1 1/8 per cent notes issued for cash were about in line with what had been expected in trading circles.

A seven-point program to make the streets of New York resemble "the tree-lined boulevards of Paris or Washington" was proposed yesterday by Nelson M. Wells, president of the City Gardens Club, at the closing session of the Eastern Shade Tree Conference at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park.

President Roosevelt gave notice today that he would send a special message to Congress calling for enactment of the government reorganization plan which met defeat during the last session of Congress.

A mass meeting to protest racial and religious persecutions in Europe, called by Mayor La Guardia, in Carnegie Hall last night, became a rally for American liberty as one speaker after another warned that the citizens of this country must be on guard to protect themselves from the forces of group hatreds from any sources.

The annual "Gay Thirties" dinner dance was given last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis as a benefit for the Boys' Club of New York. Arranged as a subscription dance, this party has become a feature of Winter entertainments in this city.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

President Roosevelt warned again today that failure of the Canadian and United States Governments to take advantage of cheap electric power, proposed under the St. Lawrence waterway project, would not only cramp industrial development in the areas affected but force substitution of more costly energy, to the detriment of consumers.

A new' era in industrial management where the plant "efficiency man" and the labor union's delegate will work out jointly new techniques of efficiency based on time and motion studies, with resulting profit to each, was forecast' last night at the annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management at the Hotel. New Yorker.

The White House help watched sadly today as workmen crated the famous "gold" piano which had graced the East Room of the mansion for thirty-six years and around which groups had danced and sung at parties given by Chief Executives.

Children can now see and hear themselves perform in the first. sound film ever made depicting the activities of a New York City public school. As part of their classroom lessons in geography and civics, the fourth grade boys and girls of Public School 170, Brooklyn, have made a talking picture, entitled "Our City."

Premier Edouard Daladier early today received a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies. The vote, 315 to 241, followed a long, and at times Uproarious debate that began at 9:30 A. M. yesterday.

Brooklyn Tech's ice hockey team won its third straight contest in the P. S. A. L. games held last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, defeating Textile, 3-0. In the other two games, Manual won from Boys High, 2-0, and New Utrecht conquered Andrew Jackson, 1-0. The triumph enabled Tech to retain its hold on first place in the standings, while Manual's success lifted it to second place.
Ackerson, Josephine Ahrens, Anna Ames, William G. Arnold, Josephin M. Baldwin, Mary Gould Beitter, Eugen Blumethal, Rose Brod, B. Harold Byrnes, May E.

Alfredo Monges, 29 years old, of 358 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, the first driver to be convicted under the law covering auto fatalities resulting from careless driving, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions to a penitentiary term up to three years.

Roscoe Toles, Detroit heavyweight, arrived with a bang last night as a fistic attraction in New York. He battled his way to a unanimous decision over Gunnar Barlund of Finland in ten rounds of savage fighting at the Hippodrome and made a distinct impression on 5,000 fans, who paid gross receipts of $7,080 to see the Detroiter in his local ring debut.

Mr. and Mrs. Ottavio Prochet gave a large supper dance last night in the Cottage Suite of Hampshire House for Mrs. Armstrong Gwynne of London who has been visiting them for several weeks, and who will go to Palm Beach after the holidays.

Directors of the Fuller Brush Company voted yesterday a special payment of one week's salary to its 1,000 employes. The company anticipates that sales this year will gross about $12,500,000, a gain of about 25 per cent over 1937.

The Court of Appeals, without ruling on the enforceability of union contracts outlawing strikes and lockouts, upheld the validity of the complaint of Nevins, Inc., a Brooklyn restaurant accusing a waiters' and waitresses' union of violating an agreement not to strike.
Cornell University will launch its most ambitious basketball schedule in years tomorrow night against the University of Toronto, with signs pointing toward a "new deal," on the court.
Fred McLeod, 56-year-old Washington (D. C.) professional, carded an eight-over-par 80 today to defeat Otto Hackbarth, Cincinnati, in the eighteen-hole play-off of the annual seniors' golf tournament.

President Roosevelt received today a drafting board, a T-square and an honorary membership card in the Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians, a C. I. O. affiliate convening here.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur King of Plainfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise King, to Bronson Tweedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Leslie Tweedy of London, England.
The Court of Appeals affirmed today a lower court's decision that a utility's fee for reconnection of gas service was a "service charge" outlawed by the Public Service Commission.
After an 8,000-mile trip about the country, stopping in more than a dozen. major cities to discuss the Wage-Hour Act, Elmer F. Andrews, its administrator, declared here yesterday:

The 1938 Neediest Cases Fund was swelled to $78,199.35 yesterday by the gifts of 253 contributors who added $11,238.96 to the sums previously realized for those unfortunates whose misery was first revealed in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday, when the twenty-seventh annual appeal for the Neediest was launched.

Premier John Metaxas will henceforth be in direct charge of education and public worship in Greece. He made an announcement to this effect in a speech to school directors, adding that he was taking the Education portfolio vacated by M. Guropulos, who resigned recently under pressure after a disagreement over the nomination of a new Archbishop of Athens.

Production and tax paid withdrawals of fermented malt liquors fell off respectively 4 per cent and 3 per cent in the fiscal year ended June 30 as compared with the previous fiscal year, the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury reported today.

Directors of the First National Bank of Chicago increased today the annual dividend rate on the bank's shares from $6 to $8. A quarterly dividend of $2 a share was declared payable Jan. 1, 1939, to stockholders of record of Dec. 24.

Miss Lida Rose McCabe, author, newspaper correspondent and art critic, died yesterday morning at the Madison Square Hotel, where she had lived for many years. She had been in ill health for some time and was 73 years old.

Tremont Ave, 420 E, 4-story tenement, 25.3x99.4 by irreg; Bronx Savings Bank against Mary C. Thomas, due, $36,801, taxes, etc, $200; to plaintiff for $30,000. Yates Ave. 1,620, dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Hester M. Buckley, due, $6,848, taxes, etc, $77; to plaintiff for S3,100.

SALOME--Music-drama in German in one act. Music by Richard Strauss; text the play by Oscar Wilde in Hedwig Lachmann's translation. Conductor, Ettore Panizza; stage director, Herbert Graf., Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House:
A truce was proposed tonight by the publishers of Wilkes-Barre's daily newspapers to end the strike of the American Newspaper Guild which forced suspension of publication Oct. 3.

El Chico is firmly established at the top of Jack Campbell's Experimental Handicap, announced yesterday by the Jockey Club, which for several years past has published in the Racing Calendar the veteran official's estimate of the season's juveniles.
Janne Nilsson, Swedish Defense Minister since 1936, died of a cerebral hemorrhage today at the age of 57. He was stricken after leaving a former service men's festival last night.

On Monday, Lord Taylor will open a tray service on the fifth floor of the store where light luncheon and tea will be served The "glorified one-arm lunch" will be in a setting of modern fantasy, store officials said.

Members of the University of Michigan Club of New York and their guests, to the number of 250, added a football tinge to their December dinner, held in the Columbia University Club last night, when Herbert O. (Fritz) Crisler, their football coach, and Professor Ralph H. Aigler,

A throng of younger members of society, many of whom in the past had subscribed to the Junior and Knickerbocker Assemblies, attended last night the first Friday Assembly of this season, which was held in-the' main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

CHICAGO CARDINALS Aldrich, T. C. U., center; Goldberg, Pittsburgh, back; Wolff, Santa Clara, tackle; Stebbins, Pittsburgh, back; Daddio, Pittsburgh, end; G. Faust, Minnesota, back; Dwyer, New Mexico, back; Hinkebein, Kentucky, center; Brown, Notre Dame, end; Crowder, Oklahoma, back; Wyatt, Tennessee, end; Thomas, Oklahoma, guard;

A new rule under the Public Utility Holding Company Act, designated U-12F-1, which provides, with certain exceptions, that no registered holding company or subsidiary shall sell any of its public utility securities or utility assets to any company in the same holding-company system or to any affiliate of a company in such system without having obtained permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission, was promulgated today, effective on Dec. 19.

Dr. Herbert U. Williams, former dean and professor of pathology and bacteriology at the University of Buffalo Medical school, died here late last night after suffering a heart attack in the Saturn Club.

The Dollar Savings Bank of the City of New York, oldest and largest savings bank in the Bronx, will open today its new branch office building on the Grand Concourse at Fordham Road, where its Fordham office will be located, as a new milestone in its forty-eight years of service in the community.

George E. Haw, Richmond attorney, said tonight that a $25 check tendered to Lespinia W. Grimes, mother of the 4-year-old Negro child injured in what State police described as a hit-run accident near Hanover Court House Monday, would be returned to former Ambassador William E. Dodd.

The Brooklyn Trust Company, holder, in a fiduciary capacity, of more than $5,000,000 of bonds, mortgages and mortgage certificates guaranteed by the Prudence Company, Inc., announced yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, that it had withdrawn its objections to a plan of reorganization for the Prudence Company, submitted to the court by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, largest creditor of the Prudence Company.

IT'S always a pleasure to listen to Curly Lambeau, the coach of the Green Bay Monsters of the professional football field., So this observer set out on the trail of the Green Bay Monsters yesterday with the hope of catching up with Curly. They were tracked to their hotel.

The C. C. N. Y. swimming team defeated Fordham, 45 to 30, last night in the former's pool. The meet was the first competition of the season for each team. Last year the Lavender triumphed over the Maroon, 38-33.

With the exception of several dissenting opinions and a decided lack of interest--made apparent by shuffling of the feet and gazing at the ceiling when the singing was a little too, long--an audience of 3,500 youngsters yesterday,afternoon for the most part strongly approved of Wagner's "Lohengrin" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The upward trend in industrial operations in Canada continued in November, but the advance apparently was not so general as in October, A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, said yesterday in the bank's monthly review.
Executive committees of National Cooperatives, Inc., and the Cooperative League met here today to prepare for the operation of joint executive offices here in January.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,091,000 bales, against 1,088,000 a week ago, 1,077,000 two weeks ago, 1,098,000 three weeks ago and 959,000 a year ago, of which American 517,000 bales, against 528,000 a week ago, 521,000 two weeks ago, 534,000 three weeks ago and 538,000 a year ago.
Six young Negroes, buoyed by song and prayer, walked firmly to the electric chair today and died in swift succession for the slaying of three white men and a young mother.

Saratoga mineral water is "stored sun energy" and its constituents represent the "remains of organic life processes of the small and large organisms which inhabited the shallow water of the Cambrian Sea half a billion years ago," said Dr. Oskar Baudisch, research director of the Simon Baruch Institute, Saratoga Springs Reservation, in an address b tonight before Sigma Xi at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
Senator Holt, Democrat, of West Virginia said today he would introduce in the next session of Congress a resolution opposing a third term for President Roosevelt.
A capacity house in Princeton's McCarter Theatre tonight saw the premiere of the Princeton Triangle Club's fiftieth anniversary musical comedy, "Once Over Lightly."

Last night's performance of the annual Winter Sports Show at Madison Square Garden attracted 10,000 spectators, the largest gathering that has attended thus far. The show will officially close tonight after a five-day run. The usual matinee also will be held.

New vistas for the Administration's program of social readjustment were opened tonight by heads of New Deal agencies as they addressed members of the American Public Welfare Association, dining during their annual Round-Table Conference at which State and local officials are considering problems of administering public welfare services.

The annual "Gay Thirties" dinner dance was given last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis as a benefit for the Boys' Club of New York. Arranged as a subscription dance, this party has become a feature of Winter entertainments in this city.

Shipments of oil burners in October by 178 manufacturers amounted to 21,059, as compared with 24,525 in October, 1937, and 26,405 in September, 1938, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, reported today.
An unofficial strike of truck drivers in sympathy with striking freight handlers and checkers continued yesterday to tie up half the long-distance trucking in and out of this city.
Assistant Secretary of State Adolf A. Berle Jr. explained in a radio talk tonight that the United States had no desire to seek military alliances in this or the other hemisphere.

The four-story apartment house at 83-03 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by the Newburgh Savings Bank to an investing client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., brokers, for cash above a first mortgage of $50,000.

The full text of Anthony Eden's address, as transcribed by the Columbia Broadcasting Company, follows: Mr. Hook, ladies and gentlemen. My first sentence must be to try to thank you for your truly wonderful welcome to me this evening. It's really very difficult for an Englishman to find words to express his thanks.
The annual "Food for Gifts" cam paign sponsored by the Massachu setts Retail Grocers Association and supported by manufacturers and distributors, will be launched to morrow in New England newspapers.
Professor James W. Garner, head of the Political Science Department of the University of Illinois, died here today at the age of 67. He was an authority on international law.

Evidence obtained by tapping intrastate telephone wires was deelared by .the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today to be as inadmissible in a Federal court as that obtained by tapping interstate wires.

The appearance of one large public utility loan and an unusually heavy volume of tax-exempt issues swelled the total of new bond offerings this week to $75,897,500, the largest for any. week since that ended Oct. 28 last.

There is just ground for Mayor La Guardia's complaint that it is unfair to compel the city to pay the salaries of court clerks, attendants, stenographers, and so on, without giving the city government some voice in deciding what such salaries shall be.

Ed Wynn, the radio and screen comedian, announced yesterday that he had agreed to pay the Federal Government $174,000 plus interest of $55,000, making a total of $229,000, in settlement of income tax claims for 1932, 1933 and 1934, leaving unsettled, however, claims for 1935, 1936 and 1937, which are still pending.

Reports of unemployment resulting from the operation of the Wages and Hours Law, particularly in the south, have been "grossly exaggerated," Arthur L. Fletcher, assistant administrator of the act, declared yesterday at the thiry-eighth annual. meeting of the National Consumers League at the Hotel Astor.
Carabineros and Assault Guards tvere brought under the Ministry of IN national Defense today through a decree issued by the Spanish Government. The decree covers those units fighting at the front.

Litigation to test the constitutionality of the Federal Wages and Hours Law was started in Gratiot County Circuit Court today in behalf of Mac Myers, 13-year-old newsboy, who alleged that The Lansing State Journal had ended a contract under which he distributes newspapers here.

Aided by a particularly good showing on Thursday, Christmas shopping gained marked headway during the week. Despite lower prices and a smaller average sale, dollar volume of department stores here was estimated as running even with or slightly ahead of the comparative 1937 period.
With a secret ballot taken today among French Line employes, their strike movement seemed to be waning.

Ernest Rudolph, 60-year-old marine broker, was injured fatally last night by an automobile a few doors from his home at 32-52 Thirty-third Street, Astoria, Queens. He died in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, at 8 P. M., two hours after the accident.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 3 amounted to 649,086 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 87,002 cars, or 15.5 per cent, more than for the preceding week, and 28,761 cars, or 4.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year,

Payments on open credit accounts to department stores during October were at a higher rate than for any month since January, the Commerce Department reported today. Collections were much better than in September and were only slightly lower than for October, 1937.

Mrs. Martha Delaney Davis obtained a divorce today from J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, disbarred New York lawyer now awaiting sentence after pleading guilty in the recent Manhattan policy rackets trial. She charged cruelty. Permission was given for her to reassume her maiden name.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 7: CAPTAIN McIntire, R. T., Med. Corps, detached as Physician to the White House, Washington, D. C., to duty as Chief of Bureau of Medicine and Surgery, Navy Department, Washington, D. C.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Cofffin, for twele years president of Union Theological Semiary, will receive the honorary degree of Docteur en Theologie from the Faculte Libre de Theologie Protestante Paris, the Protestant Seminary of the University of Paris.

With his team trailing, 34--35, with thirty seconds to play, Bert Smith tossed in a field goal and a foul to lead the Boys High quintet to a 37-35 victory over Brooklyn Technical in the winner's gymnasium yesterday.

Two young men who, according to the police, already had succeeded in one hold-up and were planning others, were betrayed early yesterday by the clumsiness of one of them who accidentally shot and wounded himself.
Mr. and Mrs. George F. Henshaw of Norwood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Ferris Henshaw, to Walter Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Jones of Teaneck, N. J.

The United States advanced to second place as a supplier of goods to The Netherlands during the nine months ending Sept. 30, the Commerce Department reported. Generally this country is fourth or fifth.

Fordham swept to a 49-37 victory over the St. Peter's College basketball team tonight in Collins Gymnasium before a capacity crowd of 2,500. The Rams, led by Bob Hassmiller, had too much height and speed for the scrappy Peacocks.

Magistrate John D. Mason in Pennsylvania Avenue court, Brooklyn, criticized yesterday those who consider relief "a right instead of a privilege," in reprimanding a man and his wife who pleaded guilty to a charge of disorderly conduct in a home relief office at 285 Powell Street, Brooklyn, Oct. 17.

The Green Mountain Power Corporation has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $7,750,000 of first an refunding mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1963 and $1,375,000 of serial notes due in 1940-53, giving underwriters and amounts underwritten as follows:
Photographic film sensitive to red light is lifting the veil of what lies in the center of the Galaxy, the huge star system of which the earth is a small part.
Herschel Grynzspan, 17-year-old Polish Jew, told an investigating magistrate today that he had acted alone in the assassination of Ernst vom Rath, German Embassy official, here Nov. 7.

Expansion of building activities should make for a business upswing during the first eight months of 1939, Walter von Tresckow, head of Young Ottley, Inc., told the concluding session yesterday of the annual convention of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A. at the Hotel New Yorker.

Cotton mill activity increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 127.6 from 126.6, the revised figure for the previous week. The index was 104.4 for the week ended Dec. 4, 1937.
The five-story dwelling at 322 West Seventy-fifth Street, northeast corner of Riverside Drive, has been leased by A. A. Hageman, broker. to Jessie Denton.
A super-All America football squad was picked yesterday by the keenest judges of gridiron talent, coaches and owners of the ten clubs of the National Football League.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Dec. 14 for a hearing on two revised identical plans for reorganization of the Mountain States Power Company. One plan was filed jointly by the preferred stockholders' committee and the company and the other was offered by the bondholders' committee. The company is a subsidiary of the Standard Gas and Electric Company.

The following forecast for Winter sports areas was issued yesterday by the local Weather Bureau: Maine and East Central New Hampshire - Occasional rain today, mixed in high mountains with snow; probably cloudy with snow flurries tomorrow.

Morris Griner, owned by Mrs. Ivan H. Parke, won the Garnet Purse, which featured the Fair Grounds program today. Coming from behind under a well-timed ride by Delpha Castille, Morris Griner passed Mrs. Ed Haughton's Glasby and won by a neck in a thrilling drive. 0. L. Foster's Casinghead was third. The winner paid $7.40 for $2.

In a move they designated as a "price cut to end all price cuts on Scotch whiskies" proprietors of twenty-four retail liquor stores on Lexington, Madison and Park Avenues, from the midtown section north, entered the city's price war last night by announcing a price of $1.69 a fifth on Scotches which normally sell at $3.39 but have been retailed at $2.59 a bottle since Tuesday.

Police Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan, who has threatened departmental revelations that will "shock New York," is prepared today to post the $25,000 bail in default of which he has been confined to the Brooklyn city prison since Oct. 21 on charges of grand larceny in the theft of 7,200 police arrest records from the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn on Oct. 15.
British steel prices, which have been stabilized throughout the year, are to be reduced on Jan. 1 between 6 and 8 1/4 per cent, according to a decision of the British Iron and Steel Federation.

Two cash deals were included among the transactions involving Brooklyn properties reported yesterday. A client of Herbert E. Mohr bought from the estate of Edo E. Mercelis the three-story apartment and store building at 439 New Lots Avenue, on a plot 25.4 by 144 feet, for cash.
Paced by Frank Reilly, Hofstra scored a decisive 46-24 victory over Queens College today. It was Hofstra's home debut and first victory in two starts.

Lady Grenfell, wife of Sir Wilfred T. Grenfell, Labrador's medical missionary, died today in her hotel here. Yearly she visited Labrador with her husband in the Summer, returning each time with a half dozen boys and girls to educate in the United States and Canada and to give them technical training in nursing, science and teaching.

Representatives of the D. A. R. and the Lutheran Church proposed to the Dies committee today that the United States protect itself from subversive elements by developing its "Americanism" and by throwing the light of publicity on foreign influences.

Mrs. George E. Smith, in 4 E 70th St: Jeanette L. Young, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. in 2 Sutton Pl; James L. Green, through Ruland Benjamin, in 157 E 81st St; Mary Palmer, through Fred F. French Co, in Windsor Towers; Peter Finney, in 84 East End Ave; Edward Greene, in 520 E 86th St; Charles P. Berdell Jr, in 108 E 86th St; Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc, broker.

Stanley Hummel, pianist from Albany, gave his fifth New York recital last night at Town Hall. Mr. Hummel's technical dexterity has reached the virtuoso stage of development and enabled him to accomplish much that was effectively brilliant wherever his list called for bravura playing.

Cattle sold a generally steady prices today, the United States Department of Agriculture reported Nothing strictly good or choice was offered Hogs sold somewhat unevenly, with light as much as 10 cents higher and heavier weights steady to 10 cents lower. An active trade prevailed on fat lambs with the tol at $9.50 steady to 10 cents higher.

The justices of the Brooklyn Supreme Court voted salary increases to sixty clerks and attendants of the court on Nov. 30, to take effect as of Dec. 1, last, it was learned yesterday. The increases were reported to amount to $10,570.

Revived after being hit on the head five times with the butt of a pistol, the Rev. Dr. Guy L. Wallis, rector of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal' Church of Tompkinsville, S. I., led detectives in a successful two-hour search for his assailant yesterday afternoon.

A double bill, composed of Ernst Toch's "The Princess on the Pea" and Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana," will be presented next Thursday and Friday nights at the Federal Music Theatre. Both operas will be given in English.

The Schuyler, a nine-story apartment hotel at 57 to 63 West Fortyfifth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has been bought by John I. McMahon, hotel man and president of the Macmont Hotel Corporation.
A heavy fog was a factor in a head-on automobile collision here early today which snuffed out two lives and sent three Wesleyan University students to the hospital.

Brisk and dapper, Anthony Eden, former Foreign Minister of the British Government, left the liner Aquitania to face a typical New York welcome last night, apparently as pleased as an Eton schoolboy over his first visit to the United States.

Charles Booth, 70 years old, one of the leading British shipowners and chairman of the Booth Steamship Line, died here after a fall from a bedroom window. He was a member of a family that has been identified with shipping and commercial activities in Liverpool since 1767.

Her husband is no longer officially a diplomat, but Mrs. Anthony Eden on her arrival here yesterday was still a diplomat's wife. Up to now all that the American public had known about the wife of the former British Foreign Minister from her public utterances was that she wished he were out of politics because it monopolized his time.

Orders to drop 1,500 of the 8,496 workers employed on the fix WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city were received yesterday from Washington by Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the arts projects here. The cut, which will affect nearly one-quarter of the personnel of the theatre-and writers' projects, is scheduled tentatively for Jan. 1.

With less than a week left to liquidation of the December interest, pressure on the near month and unsettling outside influences caused yesterday losses of 8 to 11 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Dec. 10: SERGEANTS-James W. Light, from 28th Precinct to Emergency Service Division. Alfred J. Williams, from Emergency Service Division to 109th Precinct.

The attitude of the American republics at the present stage of world affairs is one of collaboration, not of rebuke; of help, not of reproach, declared President Oscar R. Benavides of Peru today in opening the eighth International Conference of American States.

Storrow St (15-3929). s w cor of Old Rd. 137x84: Joseph Hollerith Realty Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Ohm Ave (18-5412), e s, 300 ft n Griswold Ave. 50x100; Dorothy Jensen to Ida McCullough, 2,215 St Raymond Ave. Monticello Ave (17-5027), w s, 100 ft n of Jefferson Ave. 50x100; Lucy Curcio to Teresa Yannantuono, 8 South Bond St, Mount Vernon.

Four persons have been arrested here on charges of having tried to work a variation of the "Spanish prisoner" game in connection with a mythical 8,000,000-peseta fortune supposed to have been left by Prince Antoine of Orleans, former King Alfonso's cousin. The Prince died in Paris in December, 1930.
R. V. Fletcher, general counsel of the Association of American Railroads, contended tonight the nation's rail lines must have greater freedom to solve their problems.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry K. Harding entertrained with a dinner today for Mr. and Mrs. William Royster Johnson, Miss Joan White, Miss Carolyn Duffield, W. Ross McCulloch and Henry Post.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Peter Sullivan of 375 Park Avenue, this city, and Bay Shore, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Esther Sullivan, to Joseph A. Meehan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Meehan of New York; Lake Mahopac, N. Y., and Pinehurst, N. C. The announcement was made at a dinner given last night by the prospective bride's parents in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Political tension between France and Italy continued to weigh upon the foreign exchange market yesterday. The pound sterling and-its followers sagged slowly in terms of the dollar, while The Netherlands guilder, which seems recently to have become as sensitive to European politics as the pound, was weak.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $70,000, down $1,000 from the last transaction, on Dec. 7, was reported yesterday. The interest of the late Hamilton Fish Benjamin in Benjamin Ferguson ceased on Oct. 26.

Amendments to the National Labor Relations Act under which the government "could never be put in the position of promoting, encouraging or controlling union organination" were forecast by United States Senator E. R. Burke of Nebraska yesterday before the Congress of American Industry and the annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Miss Gertrude Dowd Conklin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leander Hull Conklin of 49 East Eightysixth Street, this city, and Madison, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church to Andrew Hamilton Ransom, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Sutherland Ransom of Albany.

Equipped with several talented players, -the St. Francis varsity basketball squad has been something of a disappointment in merely breaking even in two games thus far, but the Terriers hope to add an important milestone to their court record tonight.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week shows a substantial decline from this week, totaling $22,488,043, to be represented by 102 individual issues, compared with the revised total of $42,562,900 for this week.

Berkeley W. Henderson, a special assistant to Attorney General Cummings, will succeed John Harlen Amen' in charge of the New York City office of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, Mr. Cummings announced today. The reason for the change, effective Jan. 1, was explained in this way:

The unveiling and presentation of a bust of Mrs Florence Foster Jenkins, founder and president of the Verdi Club, was a feature of the musical and dramatic program of the club in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Plaza yesterday afternoon.

William E. Benswanger, presidenttreasurer of the Pirates, declined today to confirm or deny a rumor at the minor league gathering that the Pittsburgh club had purchased Fred Hutchinson, ace right-handed pitcher, from Seattle of the Pacific Coast League.
Mrs. Darwin R. James Jr. headed the committee for the supper dance last night at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn, which was attended by many members from Long Island, New York and Brooklyn.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following cases were argued:

Colledge Leader, the most successful of the noted Newmarket family of race. horse trainers, died in London today following an operation. His age was 55. His father, Tom Leader, trained George Frederick, which won the Derby sixty-four years ago.

Operations in the wheat market today were restricted. Many brokers gave their attention to corn, owing to activity in that grain. Prices of wheat held within a range of 3/4 cent a bushel, advancing early in sympathy with Liverpool and corn, only to react late in the session and close unchanged to 1/3 cent lower than yesterday.

New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 452,938 shares of National Gypsum Company common stock, of which 352,938 are to be available for exercise of the -conversion rights on the $4.50 convertible preferred and 100,000 shares are to be set aside for issuance under the company's employes' stock purchase plan.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold in the last two years 29,272 of the dwellings it was forced to acquire at foreclosure in the course of its work of assisting distressed property owners, Colonel Harold Lee, deputy general manager of the HOLC in Washington, D. C., said here today.

As a part of the program to build up an effective National Guard air arm, the War Department awarded a contracts today for the construction of seventy-four observation planes and spare parts to North American Aviation, Inc., of Inglewood, Calif.

The Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and a member of its staff for the entire twenty-one years of his priesthood, has been promoted to the office of Administrator of St. Catherine's Church, Pelham, N. Y. Mgr. Francis P. McNichol, the pastor, is ill.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of General Motors, proposed today that government encourage industry to scrap its old machinery.and install new instruments of production by reducing the taxes of companies which do so.
The First Mortgage Corporation of Philadelphia is arranging for John P. Henrie a loan of more than $1,000,000 for a low-cost development of 2,322 single homes to be built in Philadelphia.

Preparations have begun in earnest for George White's next edition of the "Scandals" or another revue, due in March. Its authors are to be Jay Gorney, Edwin Gilbert and Donald Gibbs, with songs by E. Y. Harburg and Mr. Gorney.

Equal rights for employers and employes under labor legislation were .demanded by the Congress of American Industry and the annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers in session yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Miss Amanda Cecil, debutante daughter' of James McC. Cecil, left yesterday for Richmond, where she will be presented at a dinner dance tonight by her aunts, Mrs. Frederic R. Scott and Mrs. John Cecil, at the Commonwealth Club.

The first radio station in Andorra, tiny republic between France and Spain, will send its first broadcast Saturday, following the French Government's relaxing of its ban. In Europe Monaco is now the only country without a broadcasting organization.

Competitors here, who are anxious to benefit at the expense of Czecho-Slovakian exporters, are actively spreading rumors of anti-Semitic activities in Prague and other parts of the country, George Boocheever, chairman of the board of the American - Czecho - Slovakian Chamber of Commerce, charged yesterday.

Miss Anna McGoldrick, principal of Public School 14, Brooklyn, and connected with the school system since 1902, died on Thursday at her home, 95 Clinton Avenue, after a short illness. She was a member of a family long identified with Brooklyn social and church life and was a daughter of the late Lawrence and Mary McGoldrick. She was a niece of Mgr.

More than 700 bankers, opening a two-day study conference here under the auspices of the Michigan Bankers Association and the School of Business of the University of day. Michigan, were told today by Alexander G. Ruthven, president of the university, that "banks should lead the molding of public opinion in their sphere of activity."

A speeding police car gave Miss Elizabeth Belville and John A. Futcher a lift on the road to matrimony. Edgar F. Isaacs, State trooper, dashed sixty miles yesterday to bring them the one marriage license issued in Delaware during the day.

James J. Reynolds Jr. of the University Club last night won the annual Class B squash racquets tournament when he overcame his Cornell Club opponent, Forbes D. Shaw, in a hard-fought five-game battle at the Squash Club. The scores were 11-15, 15-9, 12-15, 15-13 and 15--A.

Drunken driving in New York State decreased 29 per cent for the first eleven months of this year compared with the same period in 1937, it was reported yesterday by Carroll E. Mealey, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today Frank Reiss of New York was admitted to practwice and the following proceedings were had:

" The Knight of the Burning Pestle," by Beaumont and Fletcher, was presented last night by Wigs and Cues, the undergraduate dramatic society of Barnard College, to a capacity audience of more than 400 students and guests in Brinck erhoff Theatre on the campus.
Former President Ramon Grau San Martin, who has been living in exile at Miami, Fla., for four years, returned unannounced by plane today. Only a few friends were at the airport to greet him.

Changes in the plans for Yale's pre-season football training became known yesterday with the visit to the city of Malcolm Farmer, graduate manager of athletics at Yale, for an informal luncheon at the Yale Club at which he and Raymond (Ducky) Pond, head football coach were hosts.

Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien took under consideration yesterday an action brought by Opera-On-Tour, Inc., to restrain the musicians' and stagehands' unions from interfering with its productions of opera using recordings as accompaniment. The suit has been nn trial for mare than a week.
Kirsten Flagstad, Metropolitan Opera soprano, gave a recital here tonight before an audience of 3,500 persons at the County Center. It was the third in the current Mrs. Julian Olney series.

Two seeded players, N. Forster of the home club and J. DeRaismes of the Crescent Club, advanced in the annual Fall Class B and C squash tennis tournament on the courts of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

Farmers in the South, growers of cotton, flue-cured tobacco and rice, will vote today on the question: "Do you favor marketing quotas on the 1939 crop?" If two-thirds of the farmers vote for such quotas, they will be imposed.

The Benenson Building, a twenty-six-story office structure at 165-67 Broadway, will be offered at auction on Dec. 30 in the auction salesroom at 18 Vesey Street. The offering is the result of a foreclosure action by the New York Trust Company, as mortgagee and plaintiff, against the Benenson Building Corporation and others.

The National Power and Light Company announced yesterday that stockholders had been summoned to vote on Dec. 20 on the proposed sale of the West Tennessee Power and Light Company, a subsidiary, to the TVA and municipalities served by the company.
Production of the nation's automobile and truck manufacturers crossed the 100,000 mark this week for the first time in sixteen months, Ward's automotive reports estimated today.

With service at an end on the old Sixth Avenue elevated line and the structure sold for scrap iron, realty interests already are looking forward to a rejuvenation of this important artery after demolition work is carried out.

A Federal grand jury today indicted six Cleveland men for alleged collusive bidding in connection with a $1,486,000 school construction project, partly financed by the Public Works Administration. All of the accused are affiliated with the Plastering Contractors Association of Cleveland.

Leading bankers and industrialists of the city were invited by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to a luncheon in the Bankers Club Dec. 20, when plans will be made for an elaborate program of opera, ballet and symphony music in the city during the period of the World's Fair.

The College of Paterson basketball team defeated C. C. N. Y.'s evening session quintet, 49--36, at the Y. M. C. A. tonight. Nat Naideck tossed in 20 points to gain scoring honors while a Paterson team-mate, Joe Rich, tallied 14.

A protest against the request of of cotton-dress manufacturers for a special wage scale for learners on a basis of 50 per cent of the minimum wage set for experienced help under the Fair Labor Standards Act was made yesterday by Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the Popular-Price Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc.,

More than 450 persons, including leaders of finance, attended yesterday morning a funeral service for Martin Egan, former war correspondent and journalist, who was twenty-five years with the firm of J. P. Morgan Go. Mr. Egan died Wednesday at the age of 66.
A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. obtained yesterday $2,599,000 sewer, general and refunding bonds of Onondaga County, N. Y., on a bid of 100.102 for 1.70s. The bonds, dated Dec. 1,

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 8: Philoon, Col. W. C. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, two days' leave, Dec. 10. Neville, Maj. F. N., Q. M. C., three months' leave. April 18.

Subpoenas calling for the appearance of thirteen Hollywood actors and actresses, including Ronald Colman and Miriam Hopkins, have been sent by air mail to the United States Marshal in Los Angeles for immediate service, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. George Mesta is leaving today for Washington, D. C., where she will be the guest for a week of Rear Admiral Mark L. Bristol, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Bristol. Mr. and Mrs. John P. Hazen Perry have come from Rosebrook Farm, their place in New Canaan, Conn., to the Pierre.

The auction sale of American paintings and prints and Currier Ives lithographs, from the collection of the late Julian H. Youche of Crown Point, Ind., and other properties, brought $5,898 at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., last night.

A use, and a practical one, has been found at night for the fourblock-long building of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at Fifth Avenue from Eightieth to Eightyfourth Street, which by day displays to the public priceless art treasures.

As police and postal authorities sought yesterday to track down the person who mailed a bullet to Mayor La Guardia last Thursday with a death threat unless he stopped his attacks on German Nazis, the Mayor got an unintelligible crank letter which was also sent to the police for investigation.

Dr. Charles H. Thurber of Framingham, educator, author and for many years editor in chief of Ginn Co. of Boston, died last night at the Phillips House. He was 74 years old. After a career as a student and professor in various American colleges, Dr. Thurber came to Ginn Co., publishers of educational books, in 1900. He was made a partner in the firm in 1904.

John J. Woodel, formerly with the Brevoort Savings Bank, has joined the Hy. D. Agar, Inc., organization. Charles W. Griswold, who was associated with George R. Read Co., is now with the brokerage deapartment of William. S. Sussman, Inc.

Having been adjudged insane by three prison psychiatrists, Robert Irwin, slayer of Veronica Gedeon, her mother and a boarder in their New York home in 1937, was taken from Sing Sing Prison this evening and placed on a train for Dannemora, where he will be confined in the Dannemora State Hospital for the criminally insane.

THANKS FOR EVERYTHING, as adapted by Curtis Kenyon and Art Arthur from a story by Gilbert Wright; screen play by Harry Tugend; music and lyrics by Mack Gordon and Harry Revel; directed by William A. Seiter; produced by Darryl F. Zanuck for Twentieth Century-Fox. At the Roxy.

Declaring that England was not "seeking to lure others to pull our chestnuts from the fire," Anthony Eden, former Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Cabinet of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, said last night that the people of his country were as firmly committed to the defense of democratic principles as at the greatest moments of their history.

Frank (Pike) Trigilio dropped a foul shot in the last six seconds of play to break a tie and gave Vermonth a 37-to-36 victory over the Dartmouth basketball team before a capacity crowd of 3,000 at the auditorium tonight. The lead changed constantly and neither team was ever more than 4 points ahead.

The construction Finance Corporation, the Railroad Credit Corporation and a bondholders' protective committee joined today in asking the Interstate Commerce Commission to modify its order of Oct. 10 for reorganization of the Western Pacific Railroad.

The marriage of Sir Herbert Grierson, Lord Rector of Edinburgh University and Research Professor at Smith College, to Miss Margaret Storrs, former Smith Professor of Philosophy, was announced today by the college.

Definite action on whether Zeke Bonura, still the property of the Senators, will play first base at the Polo Grounds for the Giants next Summer will be taken tomorrow morning. This was imparted yesterday by Horace C. Stoneham upon the youthful Giant owner's arrival in New York by airplane from the minor leaguers' convention in New Orleans.

Storm signals affecting the Ukraine are steadily increasing. The arrival of a German military attache in Chust coincides with reports in the Czech press of Polish military concentrations in the Teschen district of which Czecho-Slovakia has just been deprived and the opening, today, in Prague of a campaign in pursuance of the long-expected German schemes for an attack on the Polish and Russian Ukraines.

The-new British export offensive, which follows on the heels of Robert S. Hudson's announced determination of "fighting and beating Germany with her own weapons," is viewed with considerable misgiving in Germany, which is pushing her own exports in order to meet her growing deficit in the foreign trade balance.

Diplomatische Korrespondenz, organ of the Foreign Office, takes President Roosevelt to task for using "the threat of the totalitarian military powers" as an explanation for the United States rearmament plans.
All Catholics at every mass tomorrow will be called upon by the officiating priest to renew their pledge to remain away from movies not approved by the Legion of Decency.

The announcement by Bishop Manning that only,$32,000 more is needed to make possible the completion of the choir and sanctuary of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine is a virtual assurance that the work will now go forward, for the needed response will be made.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The movement of wool in this market and in the West as well this week has been very sluggish. Prices are slightly lower as a general proposition.

Special Notice A supply of "large size" Department of Purchase, Bureau of Stores requisition forms (Nos. 23-BS-2) has been forwarded to division commanders for distribution to the various units in their respective divisions. Three sets for each unit.

A demand by the Workers Allidance that George Kondolf resign as director of the WPA Federal Theatre Project in this city and "make way for some one who will lead the Federal theatre closer to its goal of service to all the American people" brought from Mr. Kondolf yesterday the retort that it was "a waste of time to answer such hysterical and false denunciations" as the alliance used in support of its demand.
Another learned discussion of this good old phrase is going on among our Down East contemporaries. Some of the theories of its origin are a bit too thin-spun for lowbrows.

The Northern Ireland Gov- tionall ernment today banned a meeting Abou planned for Sunday at Londonderry to protest the partition dividing that, Eire and the six northern counties. A Loyalist counter-demonstration for he also was banned.

MANHATTAN BEEBE, GEORGE R. (Nov. 14). Estate, more than $10,000. To William A. Beebe, brother, Littleton, N. H., and Howard Beebe Ross, Scottsdale, Ariz., one-half residue each; Typographical Union No. 6. 24 W. 16th St.,

Fortysix debutantes, many descended from distinguished Colonial families, were presented tonight at the Philadelphia Assembly in the Bellevue-Stratford ballroom. It was a larger number than has been invited to the assembly for several generations. The debutantes included:
