A four-day sale of the final portion of the Mortimer Schiff library ended at Sotheby's today for an aggregate of [Pound]12,843. With the two previous sections sold last season the grand total reached [Pound]51,479. Earlier, in the year Christie's sold Mr. Schiff's pictures. furniture and art objects for a total of [Pound]101,948.

The development for the first time of a successful method for the inoculation of a warm-blooded animal against the type of "blood cancer" known as leukemia was reported to the trustees of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.at their annual meeting here today.

Confronted with a pistol and two nervous bandits, blond, 20-year-old Lillian Rosenberg, equally nervous, routed the pair yesterday afternoon by kicking one in the shin and pushing him down a flight of stairs.

Frank Steinhart, American president of the Havana Electric Railway Company, died this afternoon of bronchial pneumonia after an illness of several weeks. His age was 74. Born in Munich, Germany, he went to the United States at the age of 12 and joined the infantry when he was 18.

Supplementing his testimony yesterday in defense of wholesale rates charged by the TVA, J. A. Krug, chief power planning engineer for the organization, filed with the Congressional investigating committee today financial statements of the fortythree municipalities and nineteen rural cooperatives now selling TVA electricity to residential consumers.

Numerous antiFrench demonstrations, more noisy than dangerous, again took place today in Rome and several other cities. As in all previous demonstrations, the moving spirits were university student and school boys and girls of 15 or 16 and upward. They frequently carried posters reiterating Italy's claims against France, which shows that the manifestations, even. if they are not actually organized, are at least premeditated.
Barclays Bank (Dominion, Colonial and Overseas), London, England,

Howard Coonley, chairman of the Walworth Company, Inc., New York, manufacturer of valves and fittings, was elected yesterday president of the National Association of Manufacturers for the coming year.

L. L. White, formerly head of the Pittston Company, a coal concern controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Erie Railroad, has been elected president of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, which holds the coal properties formerly owned by the Erie but leased to the Pittston Company.

Plans for raising funds to purchase and control the Tome School, Port Deposit, Md., were presented the to members of the alumni last night at a meeting at the Princeton Club, 39. East Thirty-ninth Street. The Alumni Association has signed a contract to buy the institution for $350.000.

An option for the purchase by Jan. 1 of the Canos sugar property, comprising a factory and 6,000 acres, has been taken by the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration, and the property is to become the second government-financed cooperative, it was announced today. The price will be based on an appraisal.

If Mexico proceeds with plans to dispose of oil expropriated from American companies before having made proper compensation, she will find the United States Government taking an active interest and such steps as are considered necessary to meet the situation, according to all indications today.

Mystery continued yesterday to surround the affairs of McKesson Robbins, Inc. In Washington Assistant Attorney General Brien McMahon announced that a Federal grand jury would investigate the matter in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

Governqr Lehman today told members of the Hi-Y model Legislature, comprised of seniors of New York State high schools, that the interest shown by colleges and schools in government "is the most encouraging feature of the effort to extend democracy."

Interstate Commerce Commission granted authority today to the Southern Railway Company to assume liability for $6,000,000 of 4 per cent equipment- trust certificates and at the same time gave the Reconstruction Finance Corporation authority to purchase these certificates at par and accrued interest.

Dentistry must work out a program to meet the social demands confronting the profession or "the dental profession will disappear into the clouds," Dr. Leroy M. S. Miner, dean of the Dental School of Harvard University, yesterday told a luncheon of the Harvard Odontological Society held at the Hotel Pennsylvania in connection with the Greater New York Dental Meeting.
Stressing the importance of the Pan-American Conference in Lima, both Rightist and Leftist publications hail it as the commencement of a new era of better understanding on the American continent.

An eight-man crew from the Bureau of Encumbrances of the Brooklyn Highway Department staged a series of raids late yesterday afternoon on twenty-four produce markets and grocers on Flatbush Avenue, a shopping center of the borough, in a final effort to enforce a zoning law prohibiting the erection of sidewalk stands.

One of Pope Plus's rare messages to an interdenominational body was read at a meeting representing all faiths and political parties, called by the Lord Mayor of London, at the Mansion House today to support the Earl Baldwin Fund for the victims of religious and racial persecution.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania is due to sail today for Cherbourg and Southampton. The passenger list includes Lady Moyne, the Hon. Granoa Guinness, Captain the Hon. Alfred Anson, Mrs. E. B. H. Earl, Mr. and Mrs. Clive Ponsonby-Fane, W. P. Roth, Count Naselli, Major B. W. Noble, William Russell, Mr. and Mrs. P. L. Hunting, Clifford Walker, Richard Graves, Mrs. Dudley Wolfe, Herbert Cox and Mrs. Howard Slade.
The Lehigh University five came from behind today to defeat Upsala, 52 to 51, in the opening game of the season. A crowd of 900 students witnessed the closely fought battle.

Plans for putting money and men back to work and for creating steady jobs were outlined by two industrial ,spokesmen - yesterday before the Congress of American Industry and the annual convention of the National Association of Man ufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Encouraged by the success in concluding a far-reaching trade agreement with Great Britain and enlarging an old one with Canada, officials of the State Department under Secretary Hull are proceeding with renewed vigor in efforts to reopen further the channels of international commerce through the process of reciprocal tariff concessions.

The report of the Italian Superpower Corporation for the three months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $822,104 after taxes, interest paid and accrued on debentures and a loss of $32,688 on the sale of securities.

The Princeton, Crescent, Bayside Tennis and City Athletic Club teams were the winners in the Class C squash tennis matches in the Metropolitan League yesterday. Aided by a defaut by T. V. Barber, No. 1 player on the Columbia team, the Princeton Club squeezed

MANHATTAN COPELAND. HENRY C. (Nov. 16, 1933). Gross assets, $1,000,971; net, $367,883. To Lucy M. C. Adams, Frances C. Gray and Henry F. Copeland Jr., $10,000 and life estates in one-third residue each. Chief assets, real estate, $688,966. Reiley, Harrison Reinhardt, attorneys, 253 Broadway.

Actual denunciation of the Nine-power treaty, already pronounced obsolete by the Japanese press, will be announced by the new Chinese Governments established under Japanese protection, it is understood in Tokyo.
Parliament, after a stormy debate today, voted by small majority to expel six Deputies of the Agrarian party because of subversive activities.

The Bank of America's net income for the first eleven months of this year exceeded its net income for the whole of 1937, according to a statement issued today by John' M. Grant, president of the Transamerica Corporation.

Coordination of all Federal intelligence agencies for a counter-offensive against foreign espionage activities in the United States was announced by President Roosevelt today, with the statement that he would ask Congress for additional appropriations for the undertaking.

The Colombian charge d'affaires in Berlin, Rafael Rocha-Schloss, has arrived at Copenhagen with his family. He had remained in Berlin when the newly appointed Minister, Jaime Jaramillo Arango, left after an affront' from the Berlin police during the anti-Jewish disturbances.

Led by Edward McCabe, who tallied eight field goals and a foul for 17 points, the Power Memorial High School basketball team carried off a 35-19 decision over Holy Trinity High of Brooklyn in one of several non-league games played yesterday.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Dec. 9 unless specified: Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Dec. 8. Asheville, at Amoy. Cormorant, Navy Yard, Washington, D. C., to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Dec. 8.

Reynal Hitchcock report that George Fielding Eliot's survey of American defense needs, "The Ramparts We Watch," has gone into a third printing and has been selling more than 1,000 copies a week since publication on Armistice Day.

Venezuela and Brazil agreed today to a diplomatic gesture to celebrate the anniversary of Simon Bolivar's victory at the battle of Ayacucho, which led to liberation of most of Northern South America from Spanish rule.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many are the social problems confronting mankind today. Search for causes proves baffling and even defies investigations conducted under the best possible conditions by renowned specialists in the fields concerned.

John Leddy, who for sixty-five years has been known about the New York waterfront as Jack, celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday yesterday and if his health continues as it is now, he expects to see the century out. He was born in Park Street, Manhattan, reared in Brooklyn and has never left his native shores.
A scavenger hunt, in which more than 300 couples will search for garments and bric-a-brac to be sold by Thrift House, 7 East Fifty-seventh Street, will be held tonight.

Repression of the Iron Guard continued today with forty-six arrests in Cluj, six in Baia and seven in Cernauti. Most of the prisoners were students. At Cernauti and Cluj teachers were instructed to search their pupils and confiscate any weapons found.

A conflict between the views of a grandfather who clung to the ways of his generation and those of a granddaughter, modern to her cork-tipped cigarettes, was disclosed today when the will of Edmont P. Hains Sr. of 40 North Sixth Street, here, was filed for probate.

Buyers in the local wholesale markets occupied themselves with completion of holiday stocks last week and interest lagged in all merchandise except gift lines, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary. Off-price lots for January promotions were taken quickly, but Spring goods moved in small volume.

Frank S. Wright, lifelong resident of Auburn, one of the oldest members of the Cayuga County Bar Association and former United States Commissioner, died this morning at his home here at the age of 80.

North American Aviation, Inc., expects to end 1938 with a high record sales total of $10,000,000, compared with sales of $3,469,735 in 1937. Deliveries in the three months ending Dec. 31 are expected to approach $4,000,000.

Scoring two fall victories and gaining two decisions, the Columbia University varsity wrestling team vanquished the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, 19--9, as both squads opened their seasons in the losers' gymnasium last night.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The first estimate of the gross value of principal field crops in Canada in 1938 is $527,419,000, a decrease of $30,968,000, or 6 per cent, below the 1937 estimated value, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Announcement has been made to friends here of the engagement of Miss Rosina Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Lawrence of Hollywood, Calif., formerly of Westborough, Canada, to Justice Juvenal P. Marchisio of the Domestic Relations Court, son of Professon and Mrs. Secundo Marchisio of Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. John Holme Ballantine of 943 Lexington Avenue and Ballamor Farm, Southbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Ridgely Ballantine, to Wentworth Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Smith of Lexington and Chatham, Mass.

The auction sale of American and English eighteenth and nineteenth century furniture and decorative objects, the property of Leon David of Boston, drew $14,046 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon.
Tsin Ho Zon of Shanghai, 42year-old Chinese, pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to having attempted to smuggle 5,713 ounces of smoking opium, found by customs agents on Nov. 16 on board
The American delegation this morning began consideration of the position it will take at this convention on the question of equality of women in the Americas.

The American delegation this morning began consideration of the position it will take at this convention on the question of equality of women in the Americas.
The Lehigh University five came from behind today to defeat Upsala, 52 to 51. in the opening game of the season. A crowd of 900 students witnessed the closely fought battle.

" The World's Challenge to the Church" will be the subject of a meeting tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, to be held under the joint auspices of the Greater New York Federation
Following is a translation of the address delivered by President Oscar R. Benavides of Peru in welcoming the delegates to the eighth International Conference of the American States this afternoon:

The New Deal's Crop Control Law faces a severe test tomorrow when the nation's producers of cotton, rice and flue-cured tobacco ballot on proposals of the Agriculture Adjustment Administration that it receive authority to control sales of these crops in 1939.

The New York Section of the Nation Council of Jewish Women will launch a membership drive at P. M. tomorrow at a meeting in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, where Robert Morley and Sophie Tucker, both appearing in current Broadway theatrical successes, will speak on the need for aiding German-Jwish refugees.
BEFORE this review appears Postmaster General Farley will have been kidded, so to speak, by experts,

Two thousand candidates belonging to three parties-the Government party, the United Opposition led by Vladimir Matchek, and the Fascist party, to which is conceded little chance-will present themselves to the voters tomorrow to fill 376 parliamentary seats.

To determine which fraternity contributes most to the college in its broad program of campus activities, the Interfraternity Alumni Council of the Worcester Polytechnic Institute is devising a scientific method. The award of an annual prize of $100 will be based on its recommendations.

According to a survey of student employment made by the Vocational Bureau of Skidmore College, 167 Skidmore students worked during the Summer months. Of these, 126 received remuneration, 41 giving voluntary service. The total earnings for the group, who worked from three to ten weeks, was $9,955.

A free press is the most vital American asset in the almost unanimous opinion of the students of Good Counsel College, a Roman Catholic institution for women here, it was announced today by the college. The students' views of the press were gathered by the college Journalism Club in a survey.

Fifteen mission societies, churches and educational institutions share in the estimated $450,000 estate left by Mrs. Marguerite G. Strong, whose will was filed for probate here today. She was the widow of Dr.

Recent letters published on this page have expressed regret that the religious atmosphere of Christmas should, in greeting cards especially, be overlooked. Perhaps the absence of cards with such associations was somewhat exaggerated; they can certainly be obtained by those who desire them.

TODAY it is both pleasant and thrilling to be taken back to the days before gas stations began to dot the Western plains. But, according to Mr. Rister, the pioneers found it much less pleasant and a great deal more thrilling than it appears now.

In the main ballroom of the Plaza on Wednesday night Sydney R. Montague of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police will give a talk entitled "Under Northern Lights" as a benefit for the National Cathedral in Washington. The event is being sponsored by the National Cathedral Association of New York, of which Mrs. Frederic W. Rhinelander is chairman and Mrs. Ernest R. Adee vice chairman.

Frank Thomas Richardson, retired woolen commission merchant, died in his home here late yesterday. He was 60 years old. Mr. Richardson was formerly with his father in the firm of William J. Richardson Son, 62 Leonard Street, New York.

Agricultural bulletins from the United States Government, a liberal arts diploma and a burning desire for service were the equipment which Mrs. Gordon W. Avison took to Korea thirteen years ago. Out of the conglomeration, her resourcefulness found in the ubiquitous soy bean an instrument for reducing infant mortality in a district where 95 per cent of children were afflicted with malnutrition.
The Blair School swimmers extended their string to thirty-nine consecutive victories today by gaining a 34-to-32 decision over Erasmus High.
Construction contracts awarded during November in the thirtyseven Eastern States totaled $301,679,000, the highest for any November since 1929, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

Nearly 70 per cent of the full-time undergraduate women students enrolled at the University of Pennsylvania are participating in at least one extracurricular activity on the campus, and 38 per cent are taking part in two or more.

Federal reorganization is up again, and already those members of Congress who used it last Spring as a weapon to strike at the swollen powers of the Presidency-and Mr. Roosevelt's political prestige-are exercising their sword-arms. Yet in the comments made this week by Mr. Roosevelt, and the proposals from Senator Byrnes of South Carolina, some room can be found for hope that the plan will be considered on its merits, which are many.

The strengthening of education as a bulwark of democracy by cooperation between educators and leaders in public life will be taken up at the annual Teachers College World Congress on Education of Democracy on Morningside Heights next Aug. 15, 16 and 17.

Twenty seniors and twenty-four juniors have been admitted to the Columbia College Colloquium, twoyear reading course for students of high academic standing, it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes.
EXILE: At 9 Grosvenor Place, London, the Czecho-Slovak Minister to the Court of St. James's was last week winding up a diplomatic career.

Robert Balfour, general manager of the Railway Express Agency in New York City, who is retiring at the end of the month after fifty years of service with the agency, will be tendered a dinner by his associates and officials of the company at the Hotel Commodore on

AS a channel of information about the United States or as a source of American influence, the British schools have made no impression upon any one over the age of 25, except by having taught nothing. For those of more tender years, the schools-and one is tempted to include universities-are only slightly more corrective through efforts made in classes of geography and current events,

The Cooper Union basketball team defeated St. John's College of Pharmacy, 35 to 31, last night at the Christ Church gymnasium. Herb Baum and Herman Long each scored 7 points for the winners. It was Cooper Union's first victory in five engagements.

Economic, as well as health and moral safeguards for visitors to the New York's World Fair of 1939, along lines suggested by various women's groups, are assured in the measure regulating lodging houses, which the Department of Licenses has just sent to the City Council for action. The immediate concern of most of these groups is the protection of very young women.

HAVANA.-- Havana's Winter season will get off to an early start next Saturday with the beginning of the nine-weeks' Sports Festival, during which some of the best amateur and professional talent of North and South America will compete here.

The tenth anniversary of Yeshiva College of New York, a Jewish college of arts and sciences, will be celebrated tonight with a dinner at the Hotel Astor in which leaders of American Jewry and prominent non-Jews will participate.

Decorating one's home to make it look gay and festive on Christmas ought to be more fun than ever this year, there are so many irresistible new things to do it with. Some of these Christmas trimmings are man made, but are done with such a flair one does not miss the touch of nature.

Plans for the adjustment of Jewish refugees to American Jewish life will be discussed by representatives of orthodox. conservative and reform congregations at a meeting to be held this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock in the Community House of Congregation Emanu-El at 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.
The University of California has called contractors' bids on three new buildings, one each on the Los Angeles, Berkeley and Davis campuses, it is announced by President Robert Gordon Sproul.

The Mount Carmel Naval Cadets, marching 500 strong, passed in review yesterday before their new commander in chief, Mayor La Guardia, on the plaza before City Hall. The Mayor accepted with thanks his badge of authority and scroll making him honorary president of the battalion and praised the corps for its training in good citizenship.

A plot 200 by162 feet, on the east side of Yellowstone Boulevard between Sixty-ninth Road and Sixtyninth Avenue, Forest Hills, has been sold by the Cord Meyer Development Company to the 471 East Forty-fifth Street Corporation, Alfred Kaskel, president.

AMONG the busy throngs of Christmas shoppers, distracted by the problem of what on earth they can purchase that will really be welcomed by, and be of some practical use to, the recipient, the gardener finds himself this year in a particularly fortunate position.

" Il Trovatore" was given for the second time this season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Zinka Milanov sang the. role of Leonora, Bruna Castagna that of Azucena. Jussi Bjoerling was the Manrico, Carlo Tagliabue the Count di Luna and John Gurney the Ferrando.
With more than 300 positions to be filled, a shortage of commercial teachers faces the New York City public school system, according to Dr. Louis Marks, chairman of the Board of Examiners.
Mrs. Vanderbilt, wife of Governor-elect William H. Vanderbilt, this afternoon became a member of the Colonel William Barton Chapter, D. A. R., of Portsmouth, being unanimously elected.

ON my recent return to France, after three years spent around Broadway, I became acutely aware of the fact that the shoestring producer is not an indigenously American phenomenon. Stepping, as I did, from the well organized, highly efficient movie making machine as exemplified by Hollywood and its counterpart on Broadway to the often chaotic, frequently haphazard production schedules of most French studios, made me realize this all the more clearly.

MANILA, P. I. SEVEN thousand dots of beauty like vivid emeralds studding an aquamarine sea--such are the Philippine Islands. Towering coconut palms fringe coral beaches--at sunset rainbow-hued seas roll over the protective reefs--while flying fish dart over- the shining surface.

PARIS fashion creators are making festive plans for Spring. Primavera will fate her 1939th birthday to the tune of blues. She will flounce into the limelight while the style orchestra plays the "Rustle of Spring" In swing time. Pink frosting and ices, anniversary-candles and bonbons will cast their rosy hues over her party frocks. She may spurn jewelry and dress up like a Tanagra;

Miss Nancy Russell Prentice, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Fowler Prentice of 100 East Palisade Avenue was married at noon today to Dr. Winton J. White Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Winton J. White of Knickerbocker Road.
Directors of the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of $1 and the regular quarterly of 75 cents. A similar extra was paid on Jan. 3 this year.

In a special match staged at the Yale Club courts a Yale University team registered a 7-to-2 triumph over a Yale Club squash racquets team yesterday. F. D. Rogers captured the No. 1 match for the Yale Club when he defeated M. Muir Jr. in five games, 15--6, 11--15, 15--12, 11--15 and 15--10.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in November amounted to 679,653 tons, an increase of 16,366, compared with October's tonnage of 663,287 and an increase of 92,412, compared to 587,241 tons in November, 1937. Last month's total was the largest since October, 1937, when shipments were 792,310 tons.

The twin problems of "padded" subscriptions and "free rides" which confront the United States Treasury each time it sells new securities received fresh emphasis last week when the Treasury received a record subscription to its Dec. 15 offering and found itself compelled, for the first time, to abandon its practice of giving preference to the "little fellow."

THOMAS JEFFERSON once noted that "the country westward of the Alleghany abounds with springs of common salt." He might well have added "and of sulphur." Mr. Firestone, with a poet's love of running water and an antiquarian's devotion to the past, has sought out these springs and the relics of resorts which once attested the traditions of their curative powers.

WITH Europe shadowed by political clouds, African travel is proving to be more popular than ever this Winter. Forty years ago a Cambridge undergraduate named Ewart Scott Grogan left the Cape to walk to Cairo alone.

The $100,000 brokerage account of Mrs. F. Donald Coster, wife of the president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., was tied up yesterday by order of Supreme Court Justice Arqn Steuer on the complaint of Attorney General Bennett, who alleged that "in all probability" she held funds that might have been derived from fraudulent practices involving the large drug concern and certain affiliates.

Changes in rules under the Securities Act of 1933 that are expected to modify some of the requirements of underwriters of securities are expected to be promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission within a few days.

Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. of Philadelphia, United States Ambassador to Poland, and Count Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador to this country, are expected to attend the sixth annual Night in Poland Ball, which will be held on the night of Jan. 20 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
" Tax avoidance" is generally condemned by taxing authorities. The term has been often used as synonymous with "tax evasion."
SINCE the sesquicentennial anniversary of the birth of Prince Pueckler- Muskau our publishers have been issuing volume upon volume of the letters of this remarkable man, who was not really an author,

DESPITE the sudden and unseasonal Thanksgiving snow storm that usset many holiday plans and rudely interrupted a long stretch of ideal Autumn transplanting weather, there is still-as this is written-no frost in the soil, and planting may still be done.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Set. 30 a net income of $691,381 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, $31,985 surtax on undistributed profits and other charges.

senator Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, today demanded an end to "nine years of fiscal insanity" and declared that he was convinced the Roosevelt Administration could not be looked to for leadership toward economy despite the "tragic failurn" of its spending program.

On a windy strip of farmland near the southern towers of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge yesterday afternoon city officials put aside their divergent opinions about the Circumferential Parkway and gave, instead, a public display of harmony over the $28,000,000, thirtyone-mile project.

Performances of opera continue to be among the most popular media of entertainment chosen by men and women of prominence in society and civic affairs to raise funds for various philanthropic enterprises.

The Glants and Packers held there there was nothing to do but wait for the opening kick-off for their National Football League championship play-off at 2 P. M. today. The ponderous athletes from Green Bay worked in Central Park, but the New Yorkers encountered their difficulties of the last few days in finding a field.

The Pegasus Reds of New York, led by the hard-riding Billy Nichols, overcame a nine-goal handicap to defeat the Essex Troop trio, 21 to 13, in the opening polo program of the season at the Essex Troop Armory tonight.

IN an hour among the most crucial in its long history, the Christian Church would do well to evaluate its resources and to face objectively its present inadequacy. Certainly every honest churchman will welcome an analysis of "the basic social facts about organized religion," such as is here attempted by Mr. Swift.

Dr. John Edwin Dearden. of 114 East Ninetieth Street, a general practitioner in this city for more than forty-five years, died yesterday of pneumonia in the Misericordia Hospital, where he long had been an attending physician. He was 75 years old.

MIAMI, Fla.--At the outset of this Winter season Miami is distinctly air-minded. Throughout the remainder of this month more and more attention is expected to be given to aviation here, as arrangements for the eleventh annual All-American Air Manoeuvres, on Jan. 6, 7 and 8, near completion.
Exeter's basketball team, in defeating Lawrence Academy, 97 to 21, today, set an all-time record for high scoring by an Exeter quintet.

Miss Anne McCall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner T. McCall of Bayberry Lane, Greenwich, was married to Dudley H. Dommerich, son of Mr.- and Mrs. Alexander L. Dommerich of Stanwich Road, Greenwich, this afternoon in the Round Hill Community Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold E. Wilson, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Henry E Cobb of Bronxville. N Y.

BIG things are expected of America's 1938-39 Winter vacation season, already under way. Travel experts and transportation agencies predict that it will, in most cases, equal or surpass the'1937-38 record.

French francs improved today, following the vote of confidence in Premier Edouard Daladier, and closed around 177 7-16 to the pound sterling. The dollar was quoted at 4.67 1/2 to the pound, against 4.66 15-16 yesterday. Belgas, lire and Swiss francs also were lower in sterling value, in sympathy with the dollar.

IN a recent talk before the Grolier Club, Bruce Rogers said the printing of books today had reached the highest level of perfection it had ever attained. As one looked around the room and appreciated the unique quality of the most complete display of his work that has ever been brought together,

Lafayette opened its basketball season tonight with a 36-24 victory over Upsala. Lafayette took a 19-7 lead at halftime, after which Coach Dick Madison injected replacements. Later the varsity was forced to return to the fray.

Machines will be safer and less expensive with the use of "threedimensional photoelasticity," a new process enabling engineers to measure the effects of stress and strain on complex metal structures before they are built, it was predicted yesterday at the eighth semi-annual meeting of the Eastern Photoelasticity Conference at Columbia University.

Warlaine, owned by W. W. Adams of Boston and ridden by Eddie Robart, captured his second race in a row today, finishing first in the Jefferson Park Handicap, the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds.

The most serious of all the problems facing the men charged with the defense of the United States is the matter of lining up American industry so that it can produce whatever the army may need in case of war. For many months officers of the army have been seeking a workable answer to this war-time procurement -demand.

Yacht builders, stock cruiser factories, naval architects and the accessory makers of marine gadgets are moving forward to January's National Motor Boat Show in New York with a cresendo of excitement. This is a month full of secrecy in the boat plants.

Hiram W. Johnson's repudiation of the New Deal and his support of the conservative Republican candidate, Philip Bancroft, for the Senate this Fall will cost him a stiff fight for his own seat in the Senate if, as expected, he chooses to run again in 1940.

PARKING meters soon will be installed in scores of cities throughout New York State because of their recent success in controlling parking in the business centers of a half dozen typical cities, it was forecast by William Capes, executive secretary of the State Conference of Mayors, during a recent conference with Westchester officials.
Mr. and Mrs. Louise Levy of 838 West End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen N. Levy, to Milton B. Seasonwein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Seasonwein of this city.

A threadlike eel, described as "one of the world's queerest and probably rarest fish," has been brought to the Smithsonian Institution by Dr. Paul Bartsch of the United States Museum staff. Obtained in the open sea off Cuba, the new species of eel is like one taken a few years ago in a brook in New Guinea by Dr. A. W. Herre of the Natural History Museum of Stamford University, the Smithsonian scientists said today.

KRYNICA, Poland. IN Poland at its coldest one's face draws up like a bag on a gather ing string. The visitor may see neither sun nor stars for a month. Lungs, throat and bronchial passages have not always the resistance to meet this Polish climate, rather sharp even to one who has known the bitter winds that play about New York's East River and Chicago's lakefront.

Charges that Ukrainians of the Greek Orthodox faith who are Polish subjects are being willfully and maliciously beaten, arrested and imprisoned for no other reason than their ancestry and religion were made in resolutions adopted last week at the annual conference of the clergy of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of America.

With the arrival yesterday morning at the navy yard in Brooklyn of the new light cruiser Brooklyn, the number of men-of-war now in the yard for docking, overhaul and the holiday period was increased to eleven, the largest number simultaneously in the yard for many months.

The Federal Government challenged today the authority of Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone to enter a directed verdict acquitting eleven defendants in the Madison, Wis., oil conspiracy case. They had been convicted by a jury.
Amid the Christmas cheer which pervades the Lafayette campus the undergraduates have not forgotten the underprivileged boys of Easton.

The importance of the merchant marine in times of war as well as in peace was emphasized by Secretary Woodring at the Fore River shipyards today in a speech following the launching of the Ancon, a new cargo-passenger steamer of the Panama Railroad Steamship Line, owned by the government.

WITH the approach of the immediate pre-Christmas period, the trickle of new West End productions has almost dried up. Only the boldest managements risk, opening plays in the two or three weeks that commonly are accounted among the least profitable of the theatrical year.

Major Gen. John Byrne, former chief of coast artillery, received a citation and cross of valor from the Federation of Polish War Veterans, Warsaw, at the fortieth annual dinner of the Naval and Military Order of the Spanish-American War at the Hotel Commodore last night.

Miss Mildred E. MacMillan, daughter of Mrs. Daniel George MacMillan of this city and the late Mr. MacMillan, was married to George F. H. Nelson, son of Mrs. George Nelson of New York City, at the Third Presbyterian Church here today. The Rev. Dr. William G. Felmeth officiated.

THE END: Barricades last week blocked stairways leading to New York's famous Sixth Avenue "L." There was no rumble of trains along the tracks that for sixty years had carried steam and then electric transportation. No turnstiles creaked. Fires were out in the station stoves. The Sixth Avenue "L" had become history. At auction the elevated structure brought a hid of $80,000 for serap.

Territorial claims against France heard in Italy last week and repercussions from France and her colonies created a new internettional situation which moved toward a test of strength. In the following dispatches correspondent s in Paris and Rome discuss the reaction to the agitation in the two capitals.

AFTER eight years in jail for a crime he had not committed, young Gordon Stone goes back to Barranca, Ariz., to square accounts with Lyn Gilbert, the powerful cattle king who had brought about his conviction and imprisonment. Gilbert was a wily and a wary rascal who stole cattle from his neighbors and pushed them to the wall, employed gangs of gunmen to do his dirty work,

IN the twenty years that have gone by since the end of the World War there has been a great shift in interest in foreign affairs among the American people. When the war was over, Americans. weary of the bloodshed and of the selfish haggling at Paris and Versailles, turned their backs to Europe and tried to find their way "back to normalcy."
Development of a new attitude of independence by the next Congress is predicted by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States in its official publication, Washington Review.

Many dinner parties were given tonight in connection with the concert by the University Glee Club of New York sponsored by the New Rochelle League for Service to aid the New Rochelle Hospital. The program was held at the Semor High School.

Miss Muriel A. C. Reid, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Simpson Reid of this place, was married to Lloyd Webster Hyde, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. W. Hyde of Glen Cove, this afternoon in the Methodist Episcopal Church here. The Rev. M. Arthur Workman officiated.
William Baker Day, dean of the University of Illinois College of Pharmacy since 1919, died in his home here today after an illness of two years. He was 67 years old.
WHEN fifty or more pairs or teams enter a national championship contest it is usually possible to pick out a few teams of famous players and be confident that one of them will be the winner.

Smoke was recognized as a major problem in St. Louis as long ago as 1894, when the first abatement ordinance was passed, but not until now has an appreciable advance been made toward its elimination, and even now the goal is far distant.

Jewelry, jade carvings, porcelains, bronzes and Chinese rugs sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries realized $7,970, bringing the total for the entire collection to $13,087. The three principal owners represented were the late Samuel Colman, Princess E. Zalstem-Zalessky and Emil Fischer.

Miss Emmy Lou Ruprecht, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ruprecht of this place, has chosen Jan. 27 for her marriage to Bernard J. Salembier of Englewood. It will take place in the afternoon at Miss Ruprecht's home. The date is the anniversary of the marriage of her parents.

By a six-to-four decision, the Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized railroads to increase freight rates on mahogany and other fine foreign woods by 10 per cent and to raise those on competing domestic woods by 5 per cent.
BRILLIANT poinsettias with flaming red bracts, and some of the beautiful rose-colored variety, are now lending their Christmas holiday spirit to the conservatories of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

AVIATION stocks have soared in a spectacular fashion during the past two months and while there has been some profit-taking in the past two weeks, most issues are near the highs of the year. The stock market as a whole has actually lost ground since mid-October, but the- aviation stocks, particularly the manufacturing units, have risen swiftly on wave after wave of buying.

WHILE nationally managed of age in Central America, of age in Central America there is one republic where it is finding a firm foothold. When the other Central Americas were building miles of tortuous narrow-gauged railway, Honduras was experimenting with wings.

The season's second "Siegfried," given yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, brought a new Mime in the person of Erich Witte, who has already made his technical debut in the small part of Walther in "Tannhaeuser."

Germany, repeating the procedure that followed the Austrian Anschluss, held a plebiscite last week in the annexed parts of Czecho-Slovakia. The questions were: "Do you acknowledge our Fuehrer, Adolf Hitler, the liberator of the Sudetenland, and do you give your vote to the list [of thirty candidates for the German Reichstag, whose functions are purely ceremonial] of the National Socialist German Labor [Nazi] party?"

The German press reaction to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech at Lima, Peru, emphasizes "dollar imperialism," of which the United States is accused here in its relations with LatinAmerican countries and ridicules as "laughable" the possibility of a "threatened invasion."
Using three full teams, Colgate defeated the Arnold College quintet tonight, 61-31. Vie Hazard, home team center, made fourteen points, Carter leading the visitors with eleven.

Before the rise of Stalin, Mussolini and Hitler, Sir Richard Gregory's lecture on the "Cultural Aspects of Science," delivered last week at the Carnegie Institution of Washington, would have been regarded as an interesting, scholarly historical sketch with no obvious relation to life.

Representative Wolverton, New Jersey Republican, insisted on incorporating in the record of the Congressional investigating committee today a report of the Federal Power Commission criticizing the, TVA power accounting system.

Dr. Victor Heiser, author of "An American Doctor's Odyssey," will speak at the final report luncheon of the United Hospital Campaign Tuesday at the Hotel Biltmore, according to an announcement yesterday.

Citing what he called a "growing outcry against our loose and divergent corporation laws," James M. Landis, dean of the Harvard Law School and former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said tonight at a meeting of bankers here that Federal incorporation for interstate businesses was "on the agenda" for action.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation reported yesterday that 44,000 American home owners have paid their accounts in full, amounting to more than $100,000,000, to the corporation and their names have been checked off the list of borrowers.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William M. Rhodes of this city and Lake Mahopac, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Coughlin Rhodes, to Robert John Burrough, son of Mrs. Robert Dudley Burrough, also of New York and Spring Lake, N. J.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Birkett of Needham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanette Birkett, to John Barton Chapman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Chapman of Stamford.
Mayor La Guardia issued a warning yesterday to motorists and pedestrians that December has become "a very dangerous month for our people because of the large number of serious automobile accidents."

A drastic tightening of admission requirements in law schools throughout the country which would tend to eliminate the "misfits" who have "seeped" into the legal profession and Which would ultimately result in the elevating of both the bar and the judiciary was advocated last night by the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president. of Fordham University.

All but two of the twenty-seven ships of the United States Lines and associated services will be at sea or in foreign ports on Christmas Day, the company announced yesterday. The two exceptions are the Manhattan and the American Traveler, which will be in New York.
All but 4 per cent of the students of Pennsylvania College for Women prefer, under ideal conditions, to marry, according to results of a questionnaire answered by the whole student body last week.

In an attempt to cut drastically automobile accidents in the early morning hours, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that all traffic lights throughout the city would henceforth be operated on a twenty-four hour basis.

" A play every Tuesday" is the aim of Fordham College's Experimental Theatre, which presented its first dramatic offering-Lady Gregory's "The Rising of the Moon"-this week before an audience of college and graduate school students and professors in the university Little Theatre.

When William C. De Vane takes office as Dean of Yale College on Jan. 1, one of his first tasks will be dealing with the change in educational policy suggested by President Charles Seymour whereby 20 per cent of the formal courses in the larger departments would be eliminated.

THE clergy of Connecticut, through a representative committee, has started a cooperative plan of bringing the motor vehicle accident problem before the people of the State. Material has been prepared for sermons and discussion before organizations, in church schools and in private conversation, and is being distributed by the Highway Safety Commission.

Delegates and coaches of the United States Intercollegiate La, crosse Association laid the groundwork for today's[ fifty-sixth annual meeting yesterdAy afternoon at the Hotel Lincoln and in the evening paid their respects to three oldtimers,: all 70 years of age or more, at an all-America dinner.
A shakeup was indicated today in Osoaviakhim, the civilian air and chemical defense organization of the Soviet Union.
Paced by Wendel Williams, who scored 11 points, the Paterson State Teachers College basketball team scored a 38 to 35 victory over the Savage quintet on the losers' court yesterday.

A committee of Barnard College faculty members has been organized by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve to study plans for cooperation of the college with the New York World's Fair. Professor Wilhelm Braun, head of the German department, will head the committee, which will consider the contributions Barnard can make to the fair.

The city was swept yesterday by winds that reached a peak velocity of forty-seven miles an hour at 3 P. M. The blasts came from the northwest most of the day and followed a freakish thunder and hail storm at 2 A. M. The thunder, although it pealed only a short time, roused many persons from their sleep.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--Many of the leading women squash players in the East are here for the opening tomorrow of the annual Atlantic coast squash racquets championship for women on the courts at Haddon Hall. Play continues through Wednesday, with Anne Page of Merion. Pa., defending her title.

Tony Canzoneri, 143 1/4, Brooklyn, former holder of the world featherWeight and lightweight titles, won another victory in his comeback drive last night when he outpointed Jimmy Murray, 141, Williamsburg, in the eight-round feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, will speak at Grace Protestant Episcopal Chapel, 415 East Thirteenth Street, this afternoon at 4 o'clock. The occasion will be a celebration of "Loyalty Sunday."

While Mayor Robert S. Tipping, after an informal meeting of the Common Council today, said it was his "guess"that the Northern Valley branch of the Erie Railroad would not cease operating, Justice I. Wakelee of Englewood, nephew of Edmund W. Wakelee, general counsel of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, revealed that he thought "present alarm over discontinuance"
SCHEDULED production in automotive plants during the past week continued the up ward trend of the recent few months, although labor difficulties threatened for a time to halt further increase.

The marriage of Miss Mabel Walker, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Knox of Meadville, Pa., to Arthur G. Marx of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Marx, took place here yesterday at noon in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman.
Muhlenberg defeated the University of Newark quintet tonight in its opening game of the season, 44 to 28.

Religious life on the Princeton University campus has been approached through a threefold program during the past year consisting of a curricular study of religion as a force of history, worship in the university chapel and extracurricular social work, according to the annual report today by Professor Robert R. Wicks, dean of the chapel.

The five-story plant with several one and two story adjoining units, containing approximately 120,000 square feet of space, at Greenpoint and Kingsland Avenues and Newtown Creek, Brooklyn,. has been purchased by the Manhattan Paste and Glue Company, Frank S. Kupfer, president.
John L. Lewis, chairman of the Congress of Industrial Organization, said today that fears for the future of democracy in this country could be forgotten if the workers' basic needs were satisfied.

A steady improvement in the Itnancial condition of industry and trade was revealed last month, as bankruptcy figures dropped to a level only 16 per cent larger than in November of 1937, while the volume of liabilities declined sharply, according to an analysis yesterday of the most recent Dun Bradstreet figures.

JUDGE DOUGLAS has paid tribute to my skill with the dagger. I thank him for that, but I must also admit that he can do more with that weapon than I can. He can keep ten daggers flashing in the air at the same time. Fortunately, he is so good at it that none of the knives ever falls and hurts anybody.

Two veterans and two sophomores paced Cornell's basketball team to a 58-30 victory over Toronto tonight. Captain Walt Foertsch and George Polzer shared honors with the sophomores, Bill Bennett and Dunk Ramsey.

NEW YEAR'S EVE prices this year aresgenerally on a par with last year. Despite a 3 A. M. curfew set because Jan. 1 falls on Sunday, cafe owners are energetically trying to have the deadline raised to 5 A. M. If the present curfew time stands, prices in some places may be revised slightly downward. In a few cases the tariff may be regarded as ten'ative until proprietors discover hat their neighbors are asking.

Increased student comprehension of a foreign language and a closer approach to fluency in that language results from the use of bilingual texts or "ponies," according to the results of a survey conducted by members of the Department of German of the City College.

Old Time Toys. Brooklyn Museum, until Jan. 2. Miniature furniture, doll houses and dolls. Old Silver. Lois Shaw Gallery, 460 Park Avenue, until Dec. 23. English and Irish eighteenth century pieces. Antique Furniture. Harris-Bornemisza Gallery, 58 East Fifty-eighth Street. French and English examples.

Three men charged by the government with mailing glowing reports that an almost forgotten mine assessed at $4,000 was worth $8,600,000 were sentenced to prison yesterday in Federal Court. Another reeived a suspended sentence.

The Pacific Coast Conference football wars came to an end today as the Bruins of the University of California at Los Angeles and Oregon State's Beavers struggled to a 6-to-6 tie before a disappointing crowd of less than 10,000.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Sidney O. Hershman of 118 West Seventy-ninth Street on Friday in the Woman's Hospital. Mrs. Hershman is the former Miss Helene Anker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Anker of 118 West Seventy-ninth Street.
The Rev. A. W. Groundwater of Coupar-Angus, Perthshire, today announced that he will stand as an Independent Labor candidate in the Kinross and Western Perth by-election on Dec. 21.

One hundred and two Westchester civic and taxpayer groups, through their representatives voted here this afternoon to unite with the Westchester County Taxpayers Associations in a campaign for better government and lower taxes.

Women of Czecho-Slovakia have sent products of their handicraft to be sold under the auspices of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women at a Christmas bazaar which will open on Wednesday at 25 West Fortythird Street. It will continue for ten days.

Navy placed its 1939 football hopes today in the knowing hands of Captain Emery E. (Swede) Larson, a marine renowned throughout the service for the good fortune that always has followed his coaching efforts.

The break in domestic sugar prices on last Monday, following announcement over the week-end by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace of quotas for next year in excess of estimated consumption has served to focus attention again on the Sugar Act of 1937, which was enacted only after a bitter Congressional fight.

THERE is a delightful spice of remembered reality in Della T. Lutes' chronicles of Millbrook. Here are the scenes and place, the customs and attitudes, the scandals and loyalties, of a Southern Michigan village during the Eighteen Eighties. Here are dozens of details, habits and turns of speech which most American writers have forgotten, or have not thought attractive as literary material.
THE second largest river of America, a waterway that unlocks 1,400 miles of scenic grandeur, has become the destination of thousands of tourists and sightseers from all over the continent.

ALONG the chain of the Appalachian Mountains in the eastern Atlantic States, for a distance of 704 miles, there has come into existence, with the recent execution of an agreement between the National Forest and Park Services, an area devoted solely to the interests of campers and hikers.

WASRINGTON. THE precision and exactitude on which the National Bureau of Standards prides itself was illustrated in a recent announcement regarding the preparation of materials through which the "knock ratings" of standard fuels, such as gasoline, will be determined.

Declaring that the "amazing increase in the business of the FHA In New York City area" is due largely to the advantages of the 90 per cent mortgage benefits in the purchase of low-cost homes, Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director, said yesterday that the FHA mortgage insurance business for the first eleven months of the current year in the local section has reached a total of more than $96,000,000.

In a serio-comic mood last month Fiorello H. La Guardia predicted that "the Mayor will go to jail one of these days" for refusing to pay judicial salary increases. He was talking about a matter long painful to him-the inability of the city administration to control the pay of county judges and their court emnloyes.

More than 1,500,000 toys manufactured or repaired by WPA workers will be distributed at Christmas among under-privileged children, it was announced today by Ellen S. Woodward, assistant WPA administrator.

A forecast of what is believed to be in store for third Powers in China was revealed yesterday in dispatches from Hsinking, the capital of Manchukuo, declaring that henceforth Manchukuo will discriminate against nations that do not grant it formal recognition.
That practical work in art appreciation can be done without large expenditures- has been proved at Hobart and William Smith Colleges.

" THE Monroe Doctrine and the Golden Rule-these are sufficient basis for America's foreign policy," John Hay is said once to have remarked. It is significant that the placed the Monroe Doctrine first. It is also significant that, speaking at a time when President Theodore Roosevelt was giving it some controversial new interpretations, he did not admit any possibility that the Monroe Doctrine and Golden Rule might conflict.

IN 1932 Amleto Vespa, an Italian-born member of the Chinese Secret Service in Manchuria, was forced by threat of punishment to his family to become a secret agent of Japan. Summoned to the office of the chief of the Japanese Intelligence Service in Manchuria, he was given an outline of Japanese plans and instructions for his own part in carrying them out.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- With twenty-seven skiing areas officially designated by the Berkshire Hills Conference, this region is looking forward to the most active Winter sports season in its history. More than 70,000 acres of State forest lands are open to devotees of the ski, toboggan and snowshoe.

Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A. C., on the inactive list last year, captured the final of the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament at the Columbia University Club courts yesterday in impressive fashion.

Country women will debate "Better Schools for Rural America" at a national public-speaking contest in New Orleans today, opening the fourth annual convention of the Associated Women of the American Farm Bureau Federation.

The cast of the Christmas play, "Holy Night," by Martinez Sierra, to be presented by Masque, the dramatic society of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, the Bronx, on the campus next Wednesday night was announced yesterday by the society. The cast will include the Misses Mary McVey, Eleanor Donohue, Josephine Doody, Sally Haskell, Helen O'Brien, Doris Slater, Claire Solan, Ruth McNamara, Marie Power, Livia Audi and Theresa Mitchell.
WASHINGTON. -- Steel farmhouses and outbuildings are the latest development of the Farm Security Administration in its efforts to devise low-cost methods of farm building construction.
IF the defenders of democracy are seeking an outstanding example of same, it was provided them this week by the movies. A former Polish emigrant and glove-maker hired a son of a President.

The plans and drawings of the three New York architects who were among the winners of the first four prizes in the recent competition to select an architect to plan the new campus of Goucher College in Towson, Md., will be on display at the headquarters of the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, beginning Dec. 19.

EARLY morning finds London broadcasting the first European news of the day from station GSE on 11.86 megacycles at 4:45 o'clock, Eastern standard time. Continental broadcasters on 16 and 19 meter waves pick up in signal strength. Meantime, with the sun's rising, waves from Asia, bringing news from Oriental spots,

Charging that the Chicago management of Press Wireless, Inc., had declined to negotiate an agreement ending "intolerable" conditions, twenty-one employes of the Radio Communications Company were on strike today in San Francisco and Honolulu.

MORE kippered herrings for American Sunday breakfasts and more hickory smoked hams for English sideboards are suggested by the new Anglo-American trade agreement which goes into effect on Jan. 1. However the agreement works out, the list of foods affected makes appetizing reading for the householder.

Revision of Articles 7 and 7A of the New York Tax Law which would bring about fundamental changes in existing procedure in sales of land by county treasurers for unpaid taxes and the foreclosure of liens is suggested by Walter Fairchild, president of the New York Torrens Title League.

A sixty-hour working week for general houseworkers will go into operation this week in homes of a number of members of the Women's City Club in a practical test of standards drawn up by its committee on labor and industry. The regulations, devised after a year's study by the committee under the direction of Mrs. Byrne Marconnier, are being submitted to a sixmonth trial.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark.--Golf. will hold the spotlight of the sports program here this Winter when the Hot Springs Golf and Country Club opens another course this month. Completion of the new course gives the club fifty-four holes with grass greens and tees.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 10, unless specified: Antares, Mare Island .to San Diego, via San Pedro. Asheville, Amoy to Hong Kong. Brooklyn, at New York. Cormorant, Norfolk to Navy Yard, Washington, via Naval Operating Base, Norfolk Dec. 9.

The annual luncheon meeting of the Manhattan Chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards will be held on Tuesday in the Hotel Commodore. Robert H. Armstrong, president of the chapter, reported the following new members: George S. Potter, J.

The National Association of Manufacturers, founded to promote American industry and trade in the depression years following the panic of 1893, has expanded from a few hundred members to 5,000. Today it represents the largest single employing group in the country. Annually it holds a Congress of American Industry and offers a "Program for American Progress." Last week the congress convened in New York.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today that the RFC Mortgage.Company had approved a loan of $5,600,000 to the LaFayette Building Corporation to aid in financing construction of a twelve-story office building here.

Eugene Beitter, secretary and treasurer of Heinrich Franck Sons, Inc., chicory manufacturing firm of Flushing for the last forty-three years, died Friday in his home, 131-35 Avery Avenue, Flushing, after an illness of one month.

THE early arrival of snow, which provided skiing in near-by areas and which still blankets the Laurentians and part of Northern New England, seems to have brought in its wake the largest body of question-askers in the annals of adult recreation. New Yorkers planning their first Northland vacations are busy now trying to discover how to protect life, limb and pocketbook when taking up Winter sports.

AS Professor Stace points out in his brief introduction, there is a "common theme" or "single idea" linking this book to his previous ones on "The Meaning of Beauty" (1929) and on "The Theory of Knowledge and Existence" (1932), thus giving a general view of his philosophic observations and beliefs.

A NEW directional microphone called "the cardioid," because it responds to sound in a heart-shaped area, has been introduced by the Western Electric Company. The device is designed to pick up equally all sounds reaching it from the front, but loses its sensitivity as the source of the sound moves behind it.

The eleven-story home of the National Republican Club, at 54-6 West Fortieth Street, was bid in at auction on Friday in the Vesey Street rooms by the Harlem Savings Bank for $75,000, the only offering made for the property. The bank was plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against the Library Square Realty Company to recover on a judgment of about $427,743 and taxes and other liens of about $1,182. Daniel Greenwaild was the auctioneer.

FROM Hermann E. Sieger of Lorch, Wuerttemberg, come details regarding Germany's "Winterhilfswerk" (Winter relief work) semi-postals mentioned in these columns several weeks ago. Designed by Axster-Heudtlass, a Berlin artist, they are in sheets of fifty and were printed by the heliogravure process on unwatermarked paper. They will be withdrawn from sale at the end of March, but will be valid for postage through June.

Five village officials will be named and four propositions will be voted on Tuesday between noon and 8 P. M. the annual Ossining village elec'ion. All Democratic nominees except one have filed declinations.

OVER the last year the growing abuse of marihuana has been sensationally publicized in newspapers, magazines and on the screen. The public is now conscious of a new narcotic danger, but remains uninformed of its source, its history and its technical considerations.

THERE have been countless collections of "views" of New Orleans published in the last half-century, among them Arnold Genthe's splendid "Impressions of Old New Orleans" (George H. Doran Co., $5), but most of them have been inspired by a desire to please the Chamber of Commerce or to satisfy the photographer's personal idea of the picturesque.

In a church service lasting nineteen hours the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, pastor of Baptist Temple, and seventy-two members of his congregation will read the New Testament from cover to cover tomorrow.

PLANS are under way to organize a Scophony Television Corporation of the United States, separate and distinct from the Scophony Company of England, developers of large-screen television-24-inch square pictures produced by an optical rather than electrical system of scanning.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN was twitted and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer was soundly spanked by a well-known theatrical weekly last week. "It's been a great year for Goldwyn," commented this celebrated institution (pretending to be quoting some anonymous Coast wit).

Dean Thorndike Saville of the New York University College of Engineering defended graduate engineering studies yesterday against the charges that they are taught by "overworked or incompetent teachers" and that the work is "without plan or policy."

TODAY tourist parties are climbing to the lofty Citadel on the island of Haiti where Emperor Henri Christophe is reputed to have marched a company of soldiers off a wall with a 200-foot drop, to show a French general what Haitian legions would do for their King.

After three months of preparation Union College has converted its main biological laboratories into a large biological photographic exhibition this week-end to illustrate that "of all the sciences it would seem that biology stands to profit most from the revolution that is now taking place in photography."
A new season of indoor polo opened in the ring of the Squadron A Armory on Madison Avenue last night with two exhibition games, in both of which Squadron A teams went down to defeat.
Eva Tanguay, famous musical comedy and vaudeville star, was critically ill at her apartment tonight. She received several blood transfusions last week.

The French capital will not have a Rue Chamberlain, at least for a number of years, because the mucapital council today approved a new city ordinance, according to which no street may be named after a person who has been dead less than five years.

De Forest Stull, Professor of Geography at Teachers College, Columbia University, where he has been a member of the faculty since 1920, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 53.

Cornelius Vanderbilt 3d of 35 Ocean Drive, Eltingville, S. I., and Miss Lillian Eccleston of Albany, obtained a marriage license here today. Both Mr. Vanderbilt Jr., and Miss Eccleston gave their ages as 22 years. The latter, a native of Oceola, Ark., described herself as a student.

IT'S a long way from Hamlet to the City Hall. It's a long way to go, but there is a contrast there that has always seemed to me a near-by affair. I suppose that Hamlet possessed many things that are denied to our City Fathers in New York, but Hamlet had none of the sense of humor that saves some situation in City Hall every day in the year-not even one little chuckle of it.

A committee of three mortgagees and five owners of property on a lower East Side block in which it is planned to transform the rear yards into a single play area has been formed and all the owners in the block are being asked to participate in the movement.

High school preparation as one of the basie considerations in planning a college curriculum has been stressed in the reorganization of the Hunter College currieulum, according to the final report of the Curriculum Study Committee made public yesterday by Professor Philip R.V. Curoe, chairman. The committee was appointed in 1933 by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college, to recommend revisions in the course of study.

Finglen Johnnie of Strawberry Hill is the leading English springer spaniel of the 1938 field trial season and has been awarded the Field and Stream Challenge Cup to hold for one year. Mr. and Mrs. Fraser M. Horn of Tbwners, N. Y., his owners, also received a smaller trophy for permanent possession to commemorate the victory.
All the flag officers of the Larchmont Yacht Club were re-elected for another year at the annual meeting held in the clubhouse this afternoon.

Rigid peace structures are unable to overcome human relationships and national consciousness, Alfred M. Landon said in a radio broadcast tonight in praising the piecemeal approach that American repubilcs have made to their problems.

TUNISIA has been in the headlines recently due to agitation for Italian colonial expansion. At present Tunisia is a French protectorate. It is situated in Northern Africa bordering on the Mediterranean Sea and the Gulf of Gabes. Its size is about that of the State of Louisiana and the capital of the colony is Tunis.

The first American football game played in France in many years drew 25,000 spectators to the Pare des Princes-Stadium today and caused French critics to call th sport !% combination of Rugby, soccer ana basketball added to wrestling and bullfighting.

MANHATTAN ROMAN. STEPHANIE (Nov. 10). Estate, less than $5.000. To Ernestine von Nemecsky, Budapest, Hungary. residue. Stephanie Hannon, 179 St. Johns PI., Brooklyn, executor. Letters of Administration Granted by Surrogate James A. Foley on these estates:

Mr. and Mrs. John A. Appleton of Newark gave a dinner last night in the Manhattan Room of the Pennsylvania to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Patricia Appleton. Later they took their guests to a theatre.
Contemporary Club of White Plains--Christmas music program, 4 P. M. United Forum of Italian-American Women--Tea dance, honoring Lieutenant Governor-elect Charles Poletti, St. Moritz Hotel.

John S. Clark, Asseessor of Cook County, Ill., in which Chicago is located, has announced that beginning in 1939 his office will consider the income of property as a factor in establishing value for tax purposes.

Lester Green, a farmer, announced today that he was training his hound dog to run away from foxes, not after them. "In fact, the training has gone so far already that the strategy has brought me in the first fox," Mr. Green said.

On expectations that Southern cotton growers would vote to support the government's 1939 acreage quotas in yesterday's referendum, week-end covering operations on the Cotton Exchange here lifted the October delivery $1 a bale.

The coming Spring season will see store inventories built up to more normal proportions -to take care of an expected sales increase of 5 to 8 per cent over the 1938 figures and to meet production and delivery problems brought about by the' new wares and hours act.

Coming from behind in the final minutes of the game the Benjamin Franklin H. S. basketball team, defending P. S. A. L. champion, defeated Stuyvesant, 26 to 25, yesterday on the De Witt Clinton floor in a Lower Manhattan division game. With the score 25 to 22 in favor of the losers Claude Phillips,

The annual theatre benefit under auspices of the Protestant Big Sisters will be held on Jan. 5. The organization has taken over the entire performance for that evening of Thornton Wilder's farce, "The Merchant of Yonkers," which opens on Dec. 28 at the Guild Theatre.
To assist in the formulation of policies for its Guidance and Placement Service, Upsala College recently called upon its alumni for advice.

PERHAPS the neatest and most fascinating gadget of the month is a new interval timer, for use in connection with any enlarger, which has just been placed on sale. Resembling a telephone dial in general appearance, the timer works upon the dial principle, and, when attached to the electric line of the enlarger, will turn the light on and then at the end of any number of seconds desired turn it off.

Federal authorities disclosed yesterday they would question three members of Congress concerning lobbying alleged to have been conducted by William Buckner, the broker arrested last week on mail fraud charges growing out of the sale of Philippine Railway bonds.

The Federal Housing Administration announced yesterday that sponsors of large scale rental housing developments must hereafter submit plans and specifications and all other details of proposed projects to a lending institution prior to submission to the FHA of an application for mortgage insurance. This rule will become effective next Thursday, Dec. 15.
Relatives of Mme. Emma Nevada, American prima donna, were astonished today to receive condolences on her "death" from friends in the United States.

Stanley Kupstas, president of the local of the American Newspaper Guild, rejected today a truce proposed by publishers of three struck Wilkes-Barre dailies, pending action of the National Labor Relations Board.

St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elise Duggan and Edward Putnam Currier Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Right Rev. Frank Du Moulin in a floral setting predominated by lilies.

RECEIPT of another British order--this time for the Australian Commonwealth--calling for fifty more reconnoissance bombardment airplanes, at a cost of $4,500,000, has again focused attention on the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation of Burbank, Calif., as America's leading exporter of heavy military aerial equipment.
Following is a translation of the address of Jose Maria Cantilo, Foreign Minister of Argentina, -before the PanAmerican Conference this afternoon:

THE Colleges of Engineering and Architecture of Cornell Univerity in Ithaca have combined their specialized facilities in a mutual offering of courses of instruction in highway, freeway and parkway planning, it was announced yesterday.

For the first time in five years, this country will not be represented by a women's ski team in the world championships and other major international competitions in Europe this Winter, it was revealed yesterday by Mrs. Alice Damrosch Wolfe, chairman of the National Ski Association's Women's Ski Committee.
A FLEET of 150,000 automobiles, it is estimated, will "sail" on a boat trip by land this Winter-"sall" 145 miles from Miami to Key West across roads and bridges linked in the Overseas Highway.

MELROSE CAVERNS, Va.--What is doubtless one of the Civil War's most unusual monuments, unique that it bears the names of soldiers of both the Union and Confederate armies, carved by the troops themselves, has of recent years become one of Virginia's tourist meccas.

Retail trade in several districts began to show gains over 1937 as holiday trade moved into full swing, but the gains for the country as a whole were small. Lowerpriced goods still were receiving greatest consumer attention, but apparel and home-furnishings lines attracted appreciable demand in some districts.

Dr. James Pierpont, for forty years a member of the Yale University faculty and, when he retired from active teaching in 1934, holder of the Erastus L. De Forest Professorship in Mathematics, died last night in San Mateo, Calif., according to a telegram received here today. He was 72 years old.

The Southern Conference today liberalized its regulations governing financial aid to athletes, voted down a proposal to abolish Spring football practice and gave its official blessing to Duke's trip to the Rose Bowl.

WHILE reports of reception of television pictures have been reported as far away from Alexandra Palace, London, as 200 miles, the normal range of the British Broadcasting Corporation's transmitter is thirty miles, according to Sir Noel Ashbridge, chief engineer.

The chief fault of the American home is that it wears out too fast and costs too much to operate, declares Randolph Evans, architect and designer of many small houses, in commenting on a recent survey of run-down cities and worn-out houses.

Contractors and operative builders in 1939 will experience one of their best years in a decade, Bernard L. Johnson, editor of The American Builder, predicted yesterday in analyzing general building conditions.
To the 40,000 so-called distinctive automobile license numbers in use throughout the State, the State Motor Vehicle Bureau is adding 14,000 fore for 1939, it was disclosed yesterday.
Indications that even the rump of Czecho-Slovakia may not hold together and that Slovakia, in which German influence is now supreme, may be broken away, are steadily increasing.

Miss Charlotte Travis Ketcham, Phila daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Williams Ketcham of 782 East Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, was married last night in the Flatbush Congregational Church to Herman Jay Smith, son of Mrs. Harry O. Smith, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Smith. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. William E. Dudley, performed the ceremony.

Bonds called last week for :redemption prior to maturity were in smaller volume than in the preceding period. Except for a few fairsized public utility and municipal retirements, the notices were for small parts of outstanding issues and, .as in the previous week, payment dates were mostly for January.

Ten teams, which totaled forty-two victories against nine defeats within the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association this year, gained positions on the All-Star eleven chosen for The Associated Press today by coaches and athletic directors.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that as of Dec. 7 it had issued an order granting exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration by the Central Illinois Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation,

The various aspects of the problem of evolving the best possible plan for protecting the civil population against air attacks in war time were discussed by Sir John Anderson, Minister for Civilian Defenses, in a speech before architects and surveyors last night.

THIRTY-FIVE years ago next Saturday a telegraph key in Dayton tapped out this message from the sand dunes of North Carolina: Received at Dayton, Ohio. 176 C KA CS 33 Paid. Via Norfolk Va Kitty Hawk N C Dec 17 Bishop M Wright 7 Hawthorne St

The Public Works Administration has stepped up its program to the point where 188 contracts are being approved every day in order to get as much pump-priming work as possible started under the deadline set by Congress for Jan. 1.
The home builder, advises an FHA official, should use the same sort of judgment in buying the equipment for his house as would be used in buying materials for a factory.

Assignments To take effect 8 A. M.. Dec. 12. PATROLMAN-Daniel J. Kelleher, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., designated as third grade detective. Assignment to clerical duty in Bureau of Correspondence and Records discontinued. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANTS--From commands indicated to 19th Division, office of the chief inspector, for 16 days, from 8 A. M., Dec. 16:

ABOUT four years ago Elmer Rice retired from the theatre with a loud report. About a week ago he returned to the theatre with a patriotic parable entitled "American Landscape." In any of the learned professions that reversal of direction might require an explanation. But in the theatre.
Edward H. Keith, bank president and former Mayor and State Representative, died suddenly of.. bronchitis and heart disease this morning at his home here. His age was 79.
