Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. Alfred John Miller of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Miriam K. Miller, to Wayne MacLaud, son of Mr. and Mrs. Olin MacLaud of Elmira.

Apparently worried over the success of Mayor La Guardia in the promotion of North Beach Airport as a base for the major airlines and the possibility that the metropolitan air mail terminus may be shifted from Newark to Queens, Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein announced plans tonight for an advertising campaign in behalf of Newark Air-. port.
Sales of seven Brooklyn properties in the Flatbush area are reported by Davies-Flegenheimer, Inc., brokers. All were one-family dwellings.

In what may be the most spectacular game of the football season, the Ponderous Packers from Green Bay, the Western champions, will collide with the New York Giants, the Eastern titleholders, at the Polo Grounds today in professional football's own classic, the Cash Bowl. And more than 50,000 expectant spectators hardly can await the zero hour at 2 P. M.
WINTER vacation tours of the Southwest are starting early this year, according to travel bureaus. In fact, one prominent agency opens its series of eight train-motor journeys next Sunday.

The tie-up of long-distance trucking in and out of this city spread slightly yesterday as drivers, acting without the sanction of their unions, continued to strike in sympathy with freight handlers and checkers, who walked out Thursday.

An interesting exhibit of tiles in which some of the oldest types known to history are graphically contrasted with the latest modern productions is on display in the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration.
Breaking 97 of 100 targets, Rog Fawcett led in a field of ninetee gunners at the Travers Island tra of the New York Athletic Club ye terday.

Two young thugs, armed with pistols, held up two women, one of whom is employed by the Adelphi Laundry, 545 West Fifty-third Street, in front of that building yesterday morning and escaped with a payroll of $1,316 in an automobile.

Twelve juniors at Holy Cross College were named this week to editorial posts on The Tomahawk, weekly newspaper. Among them were Murtha P. Lawrence of Flushing, N. Y., editor-in-chief; Robert F. Pollock of Elmhurst, N. Y., managing editor;
THERE was a blackboard near the gangway when we got off at Puerto Limon. It said: "Ship sails Sunday 6 P. M.; the company positively refuses to entertain any

THE island market has been quite brisk in Britain recently. A person with enough money to buy a good-sized house and grounds has found he can acquire a whole island for the Same amount and thus share with kings the luxury of ruling his own domain. If he does not actually buy an island he can, without difficulty, find one with but a few inhabitants and experience much the same sensation.

The Postmaster General has inaugurated a new mobile automatic telephone exchange. Two years ago the postoffice introduced the first mobile postoffice to afford postal facilities at shows and other outdoor events.

It is unlikely that Dunant's life in Heiden could have been so nice and happy as Mr. Albert Bartholdi writes in his letter in The New York Times Book Review of Oct. 30. In my book "Henri Dunant: The Story of the Red Cross," I speak about the hospice which, no doubt about it, was the place for the poor and crippled of this little village.
The new Hemenway Gymnasium at Harvard University will be opened Monday, the Athletic Association announced today.
Dr. William Moore Guilford, who, as the University of Pennsylvania's oldest living alumnus, continued to practice medicine until a few years ago died of pneumonia today at his home here.

Mr. and Mrs. Edmund M. Flaherty of Wilmington, Del., and Milford, Conn., gave a dinner party last night at the St. Regis at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Agnes Flaherty, to Joseph Francis Savage Jr. of Garden City and Bellport, L. I.

Three additional petitions for modification of the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan for reorganization of the Western Pacific Railroad were filed with the commission late yesterday, it became known today.

A DISMAL old house in a sad state of disrepair is the scene of a Christmas house party whose festivities are enlivened by two sudden deaths, both of which prove to be murders. Each murder is preceded by strange sounds in the attic as of something heavy being dragged

Frank Wallace Knowlton, vice president and general manager of the United Shoe Machinery Company, died last night at the age of 73. Born at Lisbon Falls, Me., Mr. Knowlton was educated in Lewiston, entering the machinery business in Boston in 1882.

ST. FETERSBURG, Fla.--More pleasure yachts in the harbor, increasing crowds in the restaurants and lounges of hotels, heavier automobile traffic on the streets and a daily rush for the beaches, the golf courses, the shuffleboard courts and other centers of recreation are among the signs which show that another Winter season is under way here.
Alfred University is taking steps to determine what the members of its liberal arts faculty think of themselves.

A BIO-BIBLIOGRAHY, covering 1,200 typewritten pages, which will be first publication in a series to be known as the "Guide to the Study of Music in America," will be issued within a few months by the Historical Records Survey, a WPA professional project.

The recent trade experience of the United States with countries with which she has established reciprocal tariff agreements is largely responsible for the present unusual elation over the successful negotiation of a pact with the United Kingdom of Great Britain and the new one with the Dominion of Canada.

AHRENS--Anna (nee Rademacher), on Dec. 8, 1938, in her seventy-seventh year, widow of Herman Ahrens, beloved sister of John M. Rademacher. Services at her home, 129 East 235th St., Sunday, 2:30 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. ARNOLD-Josephine M., in her fortyeighth year, beloved wife of Otto Sr., mother of William and Otto Jr. Services at the Stolzenberger Chapel. 450 East 162d St., Sunday: Dec. 11, at 8 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

Princeton's hockey forces started scoring early and gained momentum as the game progressed to crush Boston University, 11--3, before 400 spectators in Baker Rink today. It was the third straight victory for the Tigers and the first loss in two starts for the Terriers.

A convention to guarantee to the women of the Western Hemisphere full rights to vote and to hold public office, which already exist among 80 per cent of its population. has been recommended to the Pan American Conference by the Inter-American Commission of Women in the first formal report it has presented since the seventh Pan-American Conference at Montevideo five years ago.

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list and dealings Pan American Airways Corporation capital stock, $5 par value. The following securities have been suspended from dealings: Utilities Power and Light Corporation Class A stock, $1 par value, as the New York transfer agency and registry are to be discontinued;

Mrs. harriet Lovell Barker, wife of William P. Barker, of this city, died today in Yonkers General Hospital at the age of 63. Mrs. Barker. whose husband was with the Bank of Manhattan in New York until his retirement, was born in Elbridge, N. Y. She founded Alpha Chapter of Westchester Delphians,

The New York World's Fair and the City of New York were named as co-defendants with the Atlas Lathing Corporation of 815 Broadway, Brooklyn, yesterday in liens filed in the Queens County Clerk's office by the Supro Building Products Company of 48-13 Seventieth Street, Winfield, Oueens.

The marriage of Miss Frances Parson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Parson of Youngstown, Ohio, and Pinehurst to Albert Barker Hunt of Weston, Mass., took place here this afternoon at the Parson residence. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Palfrey Perkins of King's Chapel, Boston.

A hearing on the reorganization plan under which the first-mortgage bondholders are taking over ownership of the forty-two-story Ritz Tower Hotel, formerly owned by William Randolph Hearst and associates, will be held on Wednesday by Supreme Court Justice Church.

Bond trading yesterday on the New York. Stock Exchange was without feature, with leading issues in all groups fluctuating irregularly and within narrow limits. The general trend was reflected in only minor changes in the group price averages.
Following is the text of the statement made by President Roosevelt today in announcing his plans for conserving his records and papers for posterity:
W. F. (Bill) Kern, who has just completed his second year as head coach at Carnegie Tech, received the Jacob Ruppert Award last night for being chosen -"the outstanding football coach of 1938."

WINTER sports under a brilliant Arctic moon in this land of long Winter night is the adventure that will await American Winter sports enthusiasts who are in search of something out of the ordinary when the sun sets here for the last time this year, the middle of December.

An International Federation of Film Archives, With membership open to organizations having as their prime object the conserva tion of films, compilation of film records and projection of films for noncommercial purposes, has been organized.

BEEHIND the presentation of the Bauhaus show at the Museum of Modern Art, which opened last Tuesday evening and will be currentt through January, appears a tWofold incentive on the part of the organizers.
The 1937 Provisional Members of the New York Junior League sponsored a barn dance for their successors, the 1938 Provisional Members, last night at the league's clubhouse.

This week's signature of a treaty between France and Germany recognizing each other's frontiers and promising to consult, if trouble should arise between them, through any third party, is an action which would in normal circumstances have been welcomed by the whole world as the greatest contribution to peace and recovery of mutually profitable international life that has been made since the war ended.

NOW that the season for good resolutions is at hand, this department would like to make a suggestion in all humility to those who perhaps have not been able to think up any piece of personal reformation to undertake in 1939.

Nebraskans this week saw the long-talkedof transfer of the power industry of the State from the field of private enterprise to that of public ownership move appreciably closer. Sale of the Nebraska-Iowa Light and Power Company to the Nebraska Hydro-Electric Districts (the "Little TVA") was agreed upon at a price slightly more than $20,000,000. This is a subsidiary of the United Light and Power and the second largest operating company in the State.

The Mexican Government is supplying the Italian as well as the German Navy with fuel oil. It was learned authoritatively today that a large part of the petroleum that the government is shipping to Houston, Texas, is being reshipped for Italian naval uses.

Reflecting acknowledgmentt of the good work which can be accompolished by credit men in liquidating involved commercial enterprises for the benefit of both creditors and debtors," local credit executives will join In a luncheon to Irving Hertz of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association to be held on Wednesday at the Hotel Astor. Mr.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation adopted yesterday a series of recommendations on banking and security laws which will be submitted to the legislatures of the ten Northeastern States affiliated with the Council of State Governments.

CHANDLE--BRODY-Mr. and Mrs. Max Brody of 812 Avenue N, Brooklyn, announce the marriage of their daughter, Sylvia, to Herbert Chandler, taking place at home, Sunday, Dec. 11. FRANK-GOLBY-Mr. Jacob Cohen of South Orange announces the marriage of his daughter, Hilda Golby, to Allie Frank of New York, Friday, Dec. 9.

Word was received here yesterday of the death on Friday in St. Petersburg, Fla., of Horace Grant Healey, retired assistant in charge of the department of secretarial studies in Evander Childs High School, this city.

The executive committee of the National Association of Real Estate Boards announces that the date for the annual 1939 convention will be during the week of Oct. 23 in Los Angeles. The Los Angeles Realty Board and the California Real Estate Association will act as hosts. A meeting of the board of directors will be held the day preceding the opening of the general sessions of the convention.

John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor, investigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, announced yesterday that he had appointed two legal consultants to his staff. They are Professor I. Maurice Wormser of Fordham Law School and Professor Herbert Wechsler of Columbia Law School.

NUMEROUS stamp dealers in New York have been approached recently by representatives of various organizations with the suggestion that the dealers place a boycott on mint postal paper issued by Germany, as a form of reprisal for Nazi attacks on the Jews in Germany.

H. W. Warley, vice president of the Calmar Steamship Corporation, announced yesterday that the concern had purchased three freighters of 10,000 tons deadweight capacity, bringing Its intercoastal fleet to fourteen ships.

Long Island University's fencing team defeated the Fordham swordsmen, 10 to 7, at the Fordham gymnasium last night. Ralph Leiderman of the Blackbirds was outstanding, winning his seven bouts with foils, epee and saber.

Miss Janet Evans Bardusch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Bardusch of Maplewood, was married tonight at the home of her parents to George Hales Badenoch, son of George Badenoch, also of Maplewood.

Eight years old this year, the Smouse Opportunity School at Des Moines, Iowa, has welcomed in recent months educators from Kansas City, Denver and Los Angeles, who have made pilgrimages to this woods-surrounded institution which brings together all types of handicapped children under a single roof.

A tract of sixteen lots in Fairlawn, Bergen County, east of Paterson, has been purchased by the building firm of Peter Pielaet Sons for immediate improvement with eight single-family homes in the $5,000 to $6,000 price class.

IT is interesting to trace the English tradition back through four centuries of English character. But to say that Wallace Notestein's success in this avowed purpose is not his book's most interesting achievement is to give the book very high praise. "English Folk"

A letter furnishing its member ship list will be sent this week to the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers by the Association of Buying Offices, representing the paid resident buyers here, it was stated yesterday by Milton J. Greenebaum, head of the buyers' group. The fur manufacturers asked for this registration so that the buyers' authority for placing retail orders would be indicated.

MINDFUL of the coming concert of the Negro Fisk Jubilee Singers, a friend of the organization has forwarded a volume, published in 1880, entitled "The Story of the Jubilee Singers," by one J. B. T. Marsh.

Concerted efforts to build up a map collection to be contained in the recently created Schwarz Map Room are being made by members of the mining, geology, metallurgy, civil engineering and other departments at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

With the time for forecasting 1939 business prospects close at hand, conditions prevailing this month will have much to do with determination of the outlook for the first few months, at least, of the new year.

Stricken while on his way to the office of the Colonial Bead Company, 1 East Thirty-third Street, of which he was president, Philip Vetsburg of 1,627 East Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday morning in a taxicab before it reached the Methodist Episcopal Hospital at Sixth Street and Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn.

A proposal to provide a "mutual health service" for low-income groups on a small monthly payment basis was submitted today by the Medical Society of the District of Columbia to its members for approval or rejection.

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW has always preached more revolution than he has practiced. In his preface to the film of "Pygmalion" (which is printed elsewhere in this section) he announced, with typically Shavian modesty, that he was going to show Hollywood how pictures should be made. It sounded terribly threatening.

The growing interest of the public in psychology has resulted in the expansion and development of the psychology department at New Jersey College for Women. In the last academic year 200 students were enrolled in psychology courses as contrasted with twenty-nine in 1918, the first year of the college.

How to develop successful human relations is the biggest problem faced by industry today, speakers at the closing session of the Society for the Advancement of Management's annual conference, held at the Hotel New Yorker, declared yesterday.

AS Autumn colors give way to snow and ice, and skis and snowshoes emerge from Summer storage along with the sleds of small boys and girls, many of our national parks come to the foreground as Winter sport centers. From November to July cold weather sports are in progress in one or another of these Federal playgrounds.

MR. HUDDLESTON'S description of himself as an observer is of more than conventional significance. Early in the World War he came to distrust the kind of news that was distributed from official sources, and what prominent people said for publication, he found, needed more than ever to be accepted with many grains of salt.
A thief, who temporarily threatened part of Bridgeport, Conn., with the loss of its daily bread ration, was sought yesterday by the Queens police.

OWING to a rapid growth in general use, infra-red film is now more widely stocked by small retailers. While there are many scientific uses for infrared, notably in astronomy and medicine, it is the ability of the rays to pierce haze that makes them attractive to the run-of-the-mill camera user.

Tupelo, the nation's first city to install TVA electric power, today announced a cut in rates below the TVA standard. Mayor J. P. Nanney said that the reductions would serve as an answer to the contention of the former TVA chairman, Arthur E. Morgan, that Tupelo was losing money.

A gay and elaborately designed Alpine festival, set in surroundings representing a hamlet amid glistening, moonlight-flooded Swiss Alps, was presented by members of the 107th Infantry Regiment, N. Y. N. G. (Old Seventh), last night in their armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's newspaper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, reported tonight that "at least twenty-five" persons accused of high treason had been sentenced to prison terms at the end of a week's session of the People's Court.

About a year ago, before Viscount Halifax had succeeded Anthony Eden as Foreign Secretary, newspaper editors all over the world used to print photographs showing Mr. Eden knocking at the door of No. 10 Downing Street.

William Thomas J. Middleton, Republican member of the New York State Legislature, and Jane Walsh, screen actress known in private life as Miss Jane Elizabeth Miller, were married here today in a hotel chapel by the Rev. Neal Dodd.

Production by Canadian mines continued in an upward trend in November, with several records for recovery made. Macassa Mines set a third successive peak production mark in the month, while Bidgood Kirkland Gold Mines just failed to reach another high record after establishing seven successive peaks.

HOLIDAY trade picked up speed last week and drew closer to last year's levels or even passed them in many center. However, sales results continued to show rather wide variations. The trend to lower unit sales was still pronounced. More items are being bought and more merchandise moved but dollar increase are sluggish.

BURROWS-Mr. and Mrs. Charles, an, nounce birth of a daughter. Dec. 7, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. CARTER-Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Carter announce birth daughter, Beth Israel Hospital CRONIN-Mr. and Mrs. Michael, announce arrival of a baby girl on Dec. 6 at Park West Hospital.

Practically all radio sets costing more than $100 next year will be phonograph combinations as a result of the steady growth in popuclarity of records, distributors reported here yesterday. Many will also be offered in lower-price brackets.

Many luncheons, at which very young members of society will be the guests, will be given in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 27 before the children's holiday party to be held that afternoon in the hotel's grand ballroom.

THE real culinary geniuses have generally been men of ready wit, philosophic trend and picturesque peculiarities. Careme, Vatel and Ude come immediately to mind, but none possessed these qualities in greater degree than Alexis Soyer and, in one respect at least, he surpassed them all. Many great chefs have been paid pandars to the palates of the very wealthy, but Soyer exercised his talents on behalf of the indigent as well.

As the Dies Committee winds up its investigation of. un-American activities this week after several months of stormy hearings, a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director, indicates that the rank and file of American voters believe the hearings have justified themselves and should be continued.

Mrs. Margaret Reilly Ryan, wife of J. Frank Ryan, chief clerk of the Sixth District Municipal Court in Flushing, died yesterday of a heart attack at her residence, 160-03 Thirty-third Avenue, Flushing, at the age of 54.

The organization by film company art directors and advertising and publicity representatives of the Motion Picture Art Fund for German Refugees has received the endorsement of leading stars, directors, writers and producers in Hollywood, it is announced by Leonard Gavnor spokesman for the group.

Two last-period goals by George Seabury and Dud Humphrey of Yale defeated the Boston Olympic Juniors tonight, 4 to 3. Coming in the final three minutes of bitterlycontested action, the first knotted the count at 3-all, then Dud gave the Elis a well-deserved triumph.

The Bank Street Schools will benefit by the performance on Tuesday evening of Elmer Rice's new play, "American Landscape," at the Cort Theatre. Headed by Mrs. Walter E. Beer Jr., members of a benefit committee are now completing arrangements for the event.

Dickinson College will hold its thirtieth anniversary Doll Show Friday night, when several hundred dolls are exhibited in the Alumni Gymnasium before they are shipped to Mrs. Maud Ballington Booth, head of the Volunteers of America, to be distributed to the children of New York City's prisoners.

Miss Gabriella Kirk Leavitt, daughter of Rufus E. Leavitt and the late Mrs. Leavitt of Summit, formerly of Short Hills, was married this morning in Christ Episcopal Church here to Gordon Wallace Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Osroe Clark of West Orange.
Robert Irwin, convicted slayer of Ronnie Gedeon, her mother and a boarder, became an inmate today of the Dannemora State Hospital. Found "very definitely insane"

Folk dancing, carol singing, other divertissements and the sale of holiday articles suitable for gifts will be among the features of the Christmas Festival to be held on Tuesday afternoon and evening at Grace House of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

A BIG first season is expected at the Marine Studios here, located eighteen miles south of St. Augustine, Fla., on the Atlantic coast. Already throngs of tourists headed for resorts on Florida's east coast are stopping to view the two giant oceanariumss," to look at the big sharks or watch the porpoise eat out of a man's hand.

Anis Fuleihan's second piano concerto, which received its world premiere at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, was the special feature of the generous program arranged by John Barbirolli. The new opus was performed with Eugene List at the keyboard, and he also was the soloist in Franck's "Symphonic Variations."

PROFESSOR EDWARD SAPIR of Yale, in his introduction to this candid and curious document, remarks: "We are in constant rapport with an intelligence in which all experiences, remote and proximate, 'trivial' and 'important,' are held like waving reeds in the sensitive transparency of a brook."

The annual Blue Ridge Ball for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Virginia will be held on Jan. 27 at the Plaza. Mrs. Walter Klingman is executive chairman of the benefit committee and Mrs. Stuart C. Gibboney treasurer. Also assisting are Mrs. George Gordon Battle, Mrs. Armistead C.

Award of the fifth annual national semi-pro baseball tournament for Uhiited States teams to Wichita, Aug. 11 to 23, 1939, and scheduling of the Canadian championship tournament at St. John's, N. B., starting on the same date, were announced by the national semi-pro baseball congress today.

THE season's third offering by Le Theatre des Quatre Saisons playing under the auspices of the French Theatre of New York at the BarbizonPlaza will be made in a fortnight. It should be an attractive, possibly an important, occasion, for, if successful, it is quite likely to arouse prehensile curiosity concerning the scarcely known theatre of a great novelist. The announcement reads simply: " 'Le Faiseur,' by Balzac."

The New Jersey Women's Press Club will be entertained at a dinner Tuesday evening in the private dining room of THE NEW YORK TIMES by Miss Rachel K. McDowell, religious news editor of THE TIMES, one of the founders of the organization. The occasion will be the thirty-fifth anniversary of the club.

If a plan of reorganization of the highway debt structure of Texas under consideration by officials of the State materializes as recommended, Texas is expected to offer In the open market, and in exchange for outstanding issues, some $182,000,000 of highway refunding bonds over the next few years. These bonds would be general obligations of the State and would be secured by specific revenues, according to the plan.

A Chinese party, another in a series of events in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls, will be held on Thursday in the studio of Dario Shindell, 45 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The New Deal scored one victory and an apparent defeat tonight in farmer referenda on proposals that the Federal Government be authorized to regulate sales of the 1939 cotton and flue-cured tobacco crops.
Rector of Black Mountain College Beginning its sixth year, Black Mountain College has grown from nineteen students to fifty and from twelve faculty members to seventeen.

The limelight will be focused this week on squash racquets. For the past three weeks women of the metropolitan district have been playing inter-club team matches but starting tomorrow they will have an opportunity to show their individual ability in the ninth annual Atlantic Coast championship.

Individuals must develop and express desire for public order before abstract movements for peace can be effective, Sir Alfred Zimmern, Professor of International Relations at Oxford University, said yesterday in an address at the twentieth anniversary luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Astor.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today allowed the Railway Labor Executives Association to intervene in the Kansas City Southern Railway's application to acquire control of the Louisiana Arkansas Railway.
The decline in the foreign- exchange market was halted yesterday as covering -of short commitments in advance of the week-end brought a moderate rally in sterling and most other currencies.

A SPECTACLE of music history as it comes nearer to us is one of music renewed from time to time by fresh springs of racial energy. There were the great periods, as the world emerged from the Middle Ages, of the Netherlanders, the Italians, the French and the Germans.

A ten-coach train with 630 happy Jewish children, aged 2 1/2 to 16, left the suburban Huttledorf station tonight for The Netherlands, whence.530 of the children will go to England, the. tohers remaining in Holland.
An end of the cut-price war in the retail liquor trade tomorrow was forecast by spokesmen for the business last night as prices remained practically at the same points reached Thursday and Friday.

Smith students are paying special attention these days to the troubled world situation. They have always been in contact with international affairs through the International Relations Club and the Cosmopolitan Club, which bring together foreign and American students, and through study groups maintained by the Smith College Association for Christian Work and the American Student Union.

VIOLETS in Winter need no longer be a luxury. The home gardener may grow his own by taking a tip from commercial growers by whom the growing of violets outside a greenhouse is considered a simple procedure. Many florists keep the plants exclusively in coldframes, in order to save valuable space in the greenhouse for plants with more exacting requirements.

IDEALS of safety and comfort for passengers rule the construction or remodeling of mod ern steamships, a fact stressed by the launching of the Ancon at Quincy, Mass., yesterday. She and her sister ships, the Panama and the Cristobal, are being put into service on the Canal Zone route. Government-owned, they will be operated next year under the American flag by the Panama Railroad Steamship Line.
College football and its evils have been discussed recently by President Robert Maynard Hutchins of Chicago University, who would like to see football cleansed of commercialism.
The historical Records Survey of the Works Progress Administration will issue within a few months the first section of a huge guide to the literature of music in the United States.

Mrs. Anna Reynolds Morse, widow of Bradish Morse of Denver, Col., and George Henry Garrey, a geologist of Philadelphia, were married here yesterday afternoon at the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Cone of 439 East Fifty-first Street.

MANY years ago a sunk and dejected teacher dragged herself along at the head of a straggle of children in the plaster-cast department of a museum. An odor of death, a death that had never lived, pervaded the room.

The Nassau Gun Club of Princeton handed the newly organized Princeton University Skeet Club its third straight defeat, 205-197, on the Cherry Hill range today. R. J. Belford of the Nassauteam and Gordon Bonnyman of the Tigers tied for high honors with 45 birds apiece.

A special dinner in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center will precede the program to be given by Cornelia Otis Skinner on the night of Jan. 6 in the Great Hall of the New York Junior League for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help.

Pointing out that 4,000 persons die of tuberculosis in this city each year, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, appeals for liberal purchase of Christmas seals of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

THE first great posthumous work to appear under the name of Wilberforce Eames is the "Americana Collection of Herschel V. Jones. A Check-List (1473-1926)." To say that it is an achievement worthy of the compiler is to place it in the front rank of library

Beverly Fowlds, 4 years old, was killed and her mother, Mrs. Mary F. Fowlds, 35, was burned at 8:49 A. M. today in a fire that followed the explosion of fumes of a cleaning fluid in the Fowlds home at 53 Loring Avenue here.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 will have one of the finest collections of statuary ever assembled, according to artists and critics who have seen models of more than sixty pieces, it was disclosed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.
A $6,000,000 group insurance plan which will protect employes of the Balaban Katz Corporation and subsidiaries was announced today by John Balaban, secretary and treasurer.

LONDON. TAMES LAVER'S play at the Gate Theatre, "The Heart Was Not Burned," is a gift to criticism, for Byron, Shelley and Keats appear in it, and whoever is not able and eager to write forever on such a group of human beings should have abandoned his pen long ago. It is, indeed, the first merit of the play that it is about something.

The New York University Glee Club, consisting of the combined university faculty glee club and the Hall of Fame Singers, was heard in its annual concert last night at Town. Hall. - Alfred M. Greenfield conducted.

AN "Australian Stonehenge" has been discovered by a State expedition sent to the Northern Territory and led by Hugh Stuart. The find was made 300 miles from Darwin, Northern Territory, and resulted from pursuing clues collected by Charles Barratt, naturalist of the expedition at Delamere.

After dismissing the Rest of Australia for 215 runs, the Aussie team that recently returned from its English tour hit 220 for two wickets in the second day's play of a four-day match. The contest was arranged in celebration of the centenary of the Melbourne Cricket Club.
President Roosevelt asserted in a letter, to be published in The St. Louis PostDispatch, that a free press was primarily a responsibility of the newspapers.

The first round of the Long Island championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association was completed yesterday at the Jackson Heights Squash Club. The three seeded players, who saw action, F. B. Alexander, University Club; J. J. Reynolds, Columbia U. C., and A. E. Watt of Jackson Heights, all Came through successfully.

Paul Keres, the brilliant young Estonian chess master, who divided the first and second prizes with Reuben Fine of New York in the recent A. V. R. O. international tournament in The Netherlands, was the only one of the eight worldfamous experts who did not lose a game in the fourteen rounds.
The Red Sox led all American League teams in percentage for games won by a single run the past season, a survey by the circuit s service bureau showed today.
Bolton Hall, disciple of Henry George and one of the leading exponents of the single-tax theory, died here at Rosemary Inn this morning in his eighty-fifth year.

STRUMMING on his most melodious guitar, singing and talking in his best Spanish and Portuguese, Uncle Sam now sits at microphones north of the Rio Grande serenading for long hours of the day and night his twenty-one sovereign neighbors in the far south. About a year ago he discovered that he as a friendly neighbor should do the serenading and not leave it entirely to aggressive Europeans.

Interference with business correspondence sent to companies in Czecho-Slovakia was reported by exporters here last week, who said they were mystified over the situation. One export executive pointed out that mail sent by him to an established Czech concern in Prague has been returned since October with the legend "addressee unknown" on the envelope.

Prominent figures in newspaper, political and civic circles attended last night the semi-annual dinner of the Silurians, an organization of veteran New York City-newspaper men, held in the Hotel Lafayette, Ninth Street and University Place.
APRACTICAL means of motor-sightseeing--a sort of grown up game of hare-and-hound--has been evolved in Monterey, California's romantic one-time capital city.

Hearings which will be held beginning Dec. 19 by the Social Security Board will determine whether Oregon employers will be compelled to pay unemployment compensation taxes both to the Federal Government and to the State, aggregating 5.7 per cent instead of the present 3 per cent.
The Toronto Maple Leafs walloped the skidding Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, tonight to go into a tie with the New York Americans for third place in the National Hockey League standing.

The new film "Alexander Nevsky," with which Sergey Eisenstein, famous director, so long under a cloud, has won his way back to favor, is notable as a polished example of a new propaganda technique for molding the minds of Soviet citizens.

FOR more than half a century the plain American saw himself in the looking glass of the lithographic print dispersed all over the land and hanging, framed or unframed, on the walls of all but the most elegant establishments, public or private. And the busiest of all the printmakerss to the American people" who created and supplied the demand were Currier Ives.
Taking the place of his father, who died as he was about to perform an operation in a hospital here today, Dr. William T. Black Jr. operated successfully on the patient.

The Forty-fourth annual luncheon meeting and election of officers of the Bronx Board of Trade will be held at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, on Thursday. William E. Matthews, executive secretary,

Paced by Marty Christensen, an aggressive and well-mounted Clover Leaf team, composed of three Hempstead club players, defeated the Squadron C Blues, 10 to 6, in the main attraction of last night's exhibition polo double-header at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.
Brown University will develop its library program to "make more books more easily, more quickly and more freely available" to all students, under plans mapped by President Henry M. Wriston.

Changes in administrative methods at Russell Sage College, giving to the faculty a decisive voice in the formulating of educational policies in the future, is announced by President James Laurence Meader.

A survey of the museums and art galleries of the British Isles, other than national museums, which is published by the Carnegie United Kingdom Trust, shows that in all there are nearly 800 museums In Great Britain, some of them very small and housed in a single room.

' The United Meat Workers Union, Local 635, affiliated with the C. I. O., voted yesterday afternoon at an overflow meeting in Germania Hall, Third Avenue and Sixteenth Street, to call a strike, effective at midnight tonight, in the wholesale, distributing and processing plants in the city.

Mrs. Anthony Eden combined business and pleasure yesterday. The business part of her program took her, to Saks Fifth Avenue department store where, like almost all Englishwomen here long enough to shop, she bought stockings.

President Roosevelt accepted a new piano for the White House late today and dedicated it to "the advancement of music in every city, town and hamlet in the country." The presentation ceremony was conducted beneath the sparkling chandeliers in the east room of the White House. Mrs. Roosevelt acted as mistress of ceremonies.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, after an extensive study of the 90 per cent mortgage insurance provisions of the National Housing Act, has become convinced that the net return on a given amount of the Federal Housing Administration's insured loans is more satisfactory than the return on good bonds at present market prices, declares Philip A. Benson, president of the bank and newly elected president of the American Bankers Association.

German - Rumanian economic agreement was initialed today after a month of discussions. The most important change in the new agreement is that the Rumanian National Bank after Dec. 15 will pay 40.50 lei for the mark, against 38 hitherto. The Germans originally demanded 55 lei.

An observer who has just inspected the Jewish refugees in the so-called no man's land-actually Czech territory beyond the lines of the Czech frontier guards-informs this correspondent that there are now 150 men, women and children there housed in tents and shelters built out of tree roots, old furniture vans and the like.
Appointment of two new members of the National Advisory Cancer Council for three-year terms was announced today by Dr. Thomas Parran, surgeon general and exofficio chairman of the council.

Mr. and Mrs. John M. Palmer of Larchmont, N. Y., formerly of Tarrytown, have announced the engagement of their daughters, Miss Clotilde Sayre Palmer, to Edward Everett Baker, son of Mrs, Edward E. Baker of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and the late Mr. Baker.
The new basketball season that a has moved at half pace to date will strike out in full stride this week as laggards among local colleges start their campaigns.
President Roosevelt will stick to traditional classifications of Federal expenditures in his budget message to Congress the first Week in January, it was disclosed today.

The New Jersey Department of Conservation and Development has made some interesting wildlife population counts in two of the State forests and the results should be of special interest to the deer hunters.

A supper and dance were given last night in the grill room of the Plaza by members of the recently organized New York alumnae association of Randolph-Macon College in Virginia. Miss Helen Claire, the acrtess, who is a graduate of the college, was the guest of honor.

At the end of the week two eloquent voices were raised in defense of the democratic system. One was the voice of Secretary Hull, delivering yesterday a keynote address before the eighth International Conference of American States at Lima.

IN Philadelphia the twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of the Lambert Fund of the Pennsylvania Academy is being commemorated this year with an exhibition in the galleries of the academy (Broad and Cherry Streets). The exhibition will be current until Jan. 1. On the walls are hung works purchased through the fund, which specifies that acquisitions thus obtained are to represent the work of "younger artists who have not yet made standard reputations."

THE first performance of Verdi's "Falstaff" since 1927, the debuts of three artists new to the Metropolitan, and the return to the company this season of Lily Pons and Ezio Pinza will be features of the fourth week of the Metropolitan Opera season. Complete opera and concert programs for the current week follow:

Robert A. Stone of 35-32 Ninetieth Street, Jackson Heights, died late Friday in the Metropolitan Hospital following an operation. His age was 47. He joined the Queens Sewer Bureau twenty years ago and was formean at his death. Mr. Stone was active in Catholic circles.

Mrs. Mary Gould Baldwin, a resident here since 1870, died at her home yesterday after a week's illness. She was the widow of Clarence W. Baldwin, a Civil War veteran who had been connected with the Astor estate.

A serious outbreak of foot and mouth disease has occurred among cattle in Finland-with Estonia the only European country hitherto spared a devastating epidemic-and a large number of animals have already been slaughtered, while the police have isolated the infested areas.

" The so-called modern woman of today is the ancient woman brought back and given a paradoxical name," the Rev. Daniel A. Lord said yesterday in an address before 750 students at the College of New Rochelle. Father Lord is editor of The Queen's Work, a Catholic weekly, and national director of the Sodalities of Our Lady.

A steady flow of gifts brought in $7,211.50 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and increased the total amount that has been received thus far this year to $85,410.85. Two hundred and fifty-five donors took part in this response to the plea for those whose dire misery has led ten great charitable organizations of the city to attest them as most urgently in need of assistance of all the sufferers known to them.
IN an attempt to answer the questions "What is life?" and "What must we do to be saved?" Miss Stuart zealously examines the data and arguments of both modern psychology and modern Christianity.

THE latest Leacock volume on a long list of light-hearted and alliterative titles has a wider range than its predecessors. Its title is explicitly accurate. It begins with five "Model Memoirs" in frolicsome mood, Leacock at his most lunatic;

Receipts of Cuban public service railroads in the first half of 1938 amounted to $10,518,612, compared with $13,046,024 in the first half of 1937, the Department of Commerce learned today from the United States commercial attache in Havana.

Analysis of the vote of confidence given to the Daladier Ministry in the early hours of this morning marks very clearly the extent to which the Left Popular Front majority of May, 1936, has been broken in two.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- Horse racing will be conducted this year under Bahamian rules published by the Montagu Park Racing Association. Formerly races at this circular mile track were run under American rules, which did not always suit local conditions. The new rules are a combination of American, Can.dian and English rules.

The Consul General of Venezuela has increased the consulate's office quarters 'at 51 West Street by 50 per cent under a lease--negotiated through Cushman Wakefield, Inc. A store in the Trans-Lux Theatre Building at 586-90 Lexington Avenue has been rented by Richardi Candies, Inc.,
Two Balkan rulers who have just visited London-King Carol of Rumania and Prince Paul, Regent of Yugoslavia, have each returned to find their respective countries in political turmoil.
Jewelry, eighteenth and nineteenth century watches and miniatures will be sold at auction on Wednesday at the Parke-Bernet galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue.

The Brooklyn Poly basketball team registered its third straight victory last night when it turned back the Newark College of Engineering five, 39 to 33, at the 101st Signal Battalion Armory in Brooklyn. The winners, paced by Charles Walsh, who scored 12 points, were ahead at the half, 21 to 16. In a preliminary engagement the Brooklyn Poly junior varsity beat the New YorK tate Merchant Marine Academy, 35 to 21.

Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan announced today that he would oppose amending the Neutrality Act in order to give the President discretionary authority to identify an aggressor nation and impose an embargo against it on exports of munitions and other essential war supplies.

United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy said today the major need in solving Europe's refugee problem was "cooperation for an international loan and above all a little cooperation from Hitler." "You can stop worrying about where to put the refugees now,' he said. "That problem will by solved."

Governor Moore protested today to President Roosevelt for the second time against the recent action of the Works Progress Administration in serving summary dismissal notices on persons of 65 and mothers with dependent children.
Jews crowded banks today to deposit their remaining stocks, bonds and other securities to fulfill part of a Nazi order designed to effect the "total Aryanization of German economic life."

The Social Security Advisory Council considered today proposing that Congress write three new principles into the Federal Social Security program. These are: 1. Acceptance of responsibility for the economic welfare of wives and children of workers covered by the Social Security Act.

To the surprise of educational officials, an amazing demand for "dead languages" took place in New York City last year, Gustav A. Stumtpf, director of the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education, announced yesterday.

Six women distinguished in their field will speak at a luncheon tomorrow at the Hotel Weylin, sponsored by the Hospital Occupation Committee of the New York City Visiting Committee. Mrs. Charles M. Richter will preside. The committee is engaged in occupational therapy at Bellevue Hospital, its expenses being met by private donations.

Mr. and Mrs. Jay J. O'Brien were dinner hosts tonight at Villa del Sarmiento. Mr. and Mrs. H. Halpine Smith entertained with a dinner at their residence. Mrs. Frederick R. Hattersley gave a luncheon for Mr. and Mrs. Harry Oakes at the Bath and Tennis Club today.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Channing Frothingham of this city and Nonquitt, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Eliot Frothingham, to Charles Jackson Jr. of Boston and Dover.
Lord North, who as the twelfth baron was head of one of the oldest titled Roman Catholic families in Great Britain, died in Newmarket today at the age of 78.
William J. Chalmers, a retired mining machinery manufacturer and one of Chicago's early philanthropists, died tonight in his home here. He was 86 years old.

The National Council of the National Maritime Union of America, at its quarterly meeting yesterday, recommended to the membership an official endorsement of the government's merchant marine training school program.

Solution of the Palestine question seems as remote today as it was two years ago. Arab and Jewish aspirations in Palestine are so diametrically opposed that apparently neither side can reconcile its aims with the other's. While not doubting for a minute Britain's good intentions for solving the problem at the negotiations in London next month, observers here believe it is highly improbable that the talks will lead to any satisfactory solution.
Democracy must find a technique of self-defense before the onrush of dictatorships, said Rabbi Louis I. Newman to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

ADLER--Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence, 1,074 Union St., Brooklyn, announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Herbert, Saturday, Dec. 17. at Union Temple, Eastern Parkway. Reception at home, Sunday, Dec. 18, from 3-6. No cards. EPPNER-Harry Eppner announces the bar mitzvah of his son, Stephen Edward, at Free Synagogue, 40 West 68th St., Saturday, Dec. 17, 10 A. M.

Lady Diana Straight, who arrived on Friday from London, is at the Ritz-Carlton. Mr. and Mrs. Clarence S. Posteley have come to the Pierre from Grass Valley Ranch, their home at Austin, Nev. Mrs. Burke Roche, who arrived yesterday from Paris, is at the St. Regis.

Leading the way for the steel industry in the attack on the minimum wages ordered by the Secretary of Labor for steel companies eligible to handle public contracts under the Walsh-Healey act, a group of small Eastern steel concerns failed yesterday in efforts to have hearings on the wage standards reopened.
Interest in railroading at Cornell University has produced a new campus group called the Cornell Railroad Enthusiasts, which takes trips to nearby railway yards and is holding regular meetings here.

Reports that refugees from persecution in Europe have been made the prey of a ring that is demanding fees to insure their remaining in this country are being investigated by the United States Attorney's office.

An embargo of totalitarian theories of racial superiority, class differences and other contemporary concepts as unadaptable to the Americas was declared on behalf of the Western Hemisphere today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Jose Maria Cantilo, Argentine Foreign Minister, in keynote addresses at the eighth International Conference of American States.
The editorial office of each daily newspaper in Czecho-Slovakia, beginning next week, will have a censor who will determine what is fit for publication.

With eight of its charter members present and the heads of the national and State organizations as guests of honor, the Anne Hutchinson Chapter of the D. A. R. of Bronxville plans to memorialize its nineteenth anniversary tomorrow at a reception and luncheon to be held at the Siwanoy Country Club.

The Service Club of St. Thomas Church, of which Miss Ruth Belsterling is president, will give a dinner dance Thursday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for the Church Mission of Help and the City Home at Welfare Island. Mrs. R. Hasbrouck Shrady is vice president of the club.

The Kur-Gold Building Corporation, headed by Philip Kurland and Samuel Goldberg, which recently acquired 300 lots in the former Boos farm property at Hollis Court Boulevard and Horace Harding Boulevard, in Queens, expects to develop these lots with singlefamily dwellings.

" HIGH TENSION," a technical term describing the super-lethal voltages on the transmission lines that serve the nation with electric light and power, is also an apt description of the recent relationship between the electric utility industry and the government.

When Akron society paid tribute to its bread and butter with a "Rubber Ball," to which only persons in rubber-dominated costumes were admitted, the sight of an oversized hot water bottle dancing around (upper left) was merely one among many amazing phenomena on the ballroom floor.

Miss Jane Gray Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Carter of Scarborough-on-Hudson, was martried to Abbott Abercrombie, son of Mrs. David T. Abercrombie and the late Colonel Abercrombie, this afternoon in All Saint's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. George Bratt performed the ceremony.

Reports that public libraries in the city are "wretchedly handicapped" in their efforts to supply the needs of readers are being compiled this week by Mrs. Henry S. Pascal, chairman of the department of government and education of the New York City League of Women Voters.

Sir Edwin L. Lutyens, 69, who was the architect and designer of the new British Embassy at Washington and the Whitehall Cenotaph, as well as many famous buildings, was tonight elected the president of the Royal Academy.
The Westchester County Historical Society announced today the opening of a special exhibition, tp continue indefinitely, at the Hammond Historical House, on Grasslands Road Mount Pleasant.

Baseball offered a lifetime job today to Monty Stratton, the White Sox pitcher who recently underwent amputation of his right leg after suffering a gunshot wound. J. Louis Comiskey, White Sox president, notified Stratton that as soon as he was fully recovered he could step into a permanent position with the White Sox office organization.

A YEAR ago there was instituted an important addition to the various literary prizes awarded in recognition of the merits of books already published. The Sunday Times then announced its intention of presenting annually, in connection with the National Book Fair, four gold medals for outstanding books of the year in the categories of biography. belles lettres, travel and fiction. This year these distinctions are given to Winston Churchill for "Marlborough:

The engagement of Miss Phronsie Irene Marsh of Washington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Addison P. Marsh of Lynchburg, Va., to Walter L. Filmer of this city, formerly of Chicago, has been announced by her parents.
CERTAIN traits in common, as well, of course, as very marked divergences, invite a contemplative bracketing of Thomas Rowlandson and Pop Hart, exhibitions of work by both of whom are now on:

This is a faithful transcript of Mr. George- Bernard Shaw's remarks personally expressed by him in a film trailer for the screen version of his "Pygmalion," now showing at the Asto Theatre. OH, my American friends, how do you do? Now, since I've got you all here, might I make a little speech? Right! I will. Do you mind if I sit down? I am very old.

The Supreme Court's decision in the caseof the Consolidated Edison Company vs. the National Labor Relations Board prescribes the procedure the board must follow if it wishes to invalidate contracts made by employers with independent labor organizations. At the same time it widens the board's jurisdiction over employes in interstate commerce.

More money was provided by the savings, building and loan associations in the country for home modernization in October than in any previous month this year and the sum advanced for home construction was the second largest in the first ten months, the United States Building and Loan League announced yesterday.
Lawrenceville's basketball team turned back a fighting McDonogh School quintet by 33-23 today. The game was fast but loosely played.
Tony Lazzeri, who obtained his release from the Chicago Cubs a few days ago, announced today he had accepted terms to play second base for the Brooklyn Dodgers next year.

The flow of mail and passengers to foreign countries for Christmas is now in its final week. InIcluding the Cunarder Aquitania, which sailed yesterday, seven liners will have departed by the end of the week with almost 5,000 passengers and approximately 35,000 sacks of mail.

The New York Rangers will bring hockey back to New York tonight, when they oppose the Boston Bruins in a National League game at Madison Square Garden. Local followers of the ice sport, who have seen only two games here in the past two weeks, have been eagerly awaiting this contest, and plans are being made to handle an overflow crowd.

DIPLOMATIC etiquette. such as that involved in arrangements for next year's visit of the British King and Queen to the American capital, is the field of the division of protocol, one of the busiest branches of the State Department. A former army officer a West Point graduate in the class of 1896, George T. Summerlin, heads the protocol division.

The chances for the success of the President's reorganization bill when it is re-introduced in Congress are not favorable, Representative Bruce Barton said last night at the annual dinner of the Flatbush Republican Club, held at 2,431 Church Avenue, Brooklyn.

ROME'S "Fifth Avenue" is Via Veneto, or Via Vittoria Veneto, to give it its full title, a winding uphill street that stretches from the picturesque Piazza Barberini, where Bernini's famous fountain is situated, to the parks and gardens of Villa Borghese, now Villa Umberto, outside the ancient Porta Pinciana.

Forty members of the women's law class conducted at the New York University Washington Square center by the Division of General Education have received scholarships for the first term of the 193839 academic year, it was announced yesterday by Harold 0. Voorhis, university secretary.

Royce Edward Wright, executive vice president of the Title Guaranty Company of Milwaukee, died suddenly today at the Edgewater Beach Hotel. His age was 53. He left Milwaukee this morning to visit a son, Royce Jr., in Evanston and to spend the day shopping.

Completion of a laboratory for practical training in the technique of model building and a fully equipped materials museum have brought the Department of Architecture in the College of Fine Arts at Syracuse University one step nearer realization of the program outlined in its revised fiveyear curriculum.

EARLY next year the French National Museum of Folk Arts and Popular Traditions, now being created in the new Trocadero Palace, will be inaugurated with a series of picturesque folklore festivals. Georges Henri Riviere, the curator, promises that the new museum will present "a graphic panorama of the people of France,"

TOUSSAINT L'OUVERTURE, leader of the San Domingo revolution, was, says the French "Biographie Universelle," one of the most remarkable men of a period rich in remarkable men. C. L. R. James, English historian, goes further: "The writer believes, and is confident the narrative will prove,"

ASTOR--Pygmalion: Leslie Howard, Wendy Hiller. BELMONT--Abused Confidence: Danielle Darrieux; The Little Flower: Simon Bourday, opens tomorrow. CAMEO--Professor Mamlock.* CAPITOL--Out West With the Hardys: Mickey Rooney.

Speedy reorganization of the bankrupt Utilities Power and Light Corporation and integration of its widespread utility properties appear as distinct possibilities as a result of the settlement effected last week between the Atlas Corporation and Associated Gas and Electric interests.

President Roosevelt announced today that he would preserve intact for posterity all his correspondence, public papers, pamphlets and books, as well as his private collection of books, pamphlets, prints and other valuable source material for historians in a special archives building on the family estate at Hyde Park.

The State Department made public the following text of Secretary Hull's speech today at the Pan-American conference at Lima, Peru: It is a matter of unusual satisfaction to me and my associates to meet and greet the members of the other American delegations, with many of whom I have had the good fortune of being associated at previous inter-American conferences.

MORE than a dozen of the current exhibitions have been designed with special reference to the holiday period, either in the character of the exhibition itself as emphasized in two museum shows, or in the asembling by galleries of works of art specially designed to be attractive in nature and in price for those who seek to find gifts in this field. The museum attractions, which are not of objects for sale,

President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 270 Park Avenue, to introduce their daughter, Miss Ruth Mason Bissell. The debutante will also be the guest of honor at a dinner dance to be given by her parents on Dec. 27 in the Jade and Basildon Suite of the WaldorfAstoria.

UNLESS there should be issued supplementary volumes, "Whale Ships and Whaling" must stand as a unique book. Whaling as carried on by the great New Bedford fleet of sailing ships, many of which stayed out three and four years. belongs to a vanished past. This does not mean that the industry is entirely dead.

Debating has become one of the liveliest arts at the Pennsylvania State College. Two new forms of debate introduced by Professor Joseph F. O'Brien have led audiences of hundreds to gather for forensic contests.
ONE of the most interesting aspects of long distance non stop airplane flights is the remarkable accuracy with which pilots now fly a course between take-off point and ultimate destination.

Mr. and Mrs. G. Alfred Knoche of White Plains, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elinor Elaine Knoche, to David Halsey Baird of Hartford, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Baird of Berea, Ky. The announcement was made at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Knoche last night at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N. Y.

All savings, building and loan associations in the United States which can qualify for share insurance of its savings accounts by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation should be insured, declares Leo T. Crowley,

Playing one of the best matches of his career, Norbert Setzler of New York, American open champion; defeated Kenneth Chantler, professional at the Montreal Racquet Club,.yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club. The score was 17--15, 15--11, 7--15, 15--8, 15--12.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 8. CAPTAINS Kimball, L. F., to Navy Yard, Puget Sound Wash., as Captain of Yard, instead duty 12th Naval Dist. Reifsnider, L.F., the Memphis, to duty as Chief of Naval Mission to Colombia, Bogota, Colombia.

Twenty-six- undergraduate students at City College are active in editorial and business posts on four major publications of the Main Center, 139th Street and Convent Avenue. The publications include The Campus, undergraduate newspaper; The City College Monthly, a literary publication; The Mercury, humor magazine, and The Microcosm, the senior year book.

The answer to the question frequently asked during the September crisis, "Where would the government move in the event of war with Germany" is believed to have been provided by extensive works, including the laying of underground cables, now proceeding in the old cathedral city of Exeter.

LAKE PLACID.--Two dozen workmen are completing the latest addition to Lake Placid's interlocking network of 250 miles of ski trails, a new intermediate downhill run, 2 1/4 miles long, on Wright's Peak, at Adirondack Lodge.

HOW many times has Beethoven's Fifth Symphony been recorded? That ever present help, the Gramophone Shop's Encyclopedia lists but ten versions and adds "etc." The first we remember hearing was that by Arthur Nikisch and the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, just twentyfive years ago.

WASHINGTON. THE nation's capital, long embarrassed by an unlovely and inadequate airport on the Virginia mudflats across the Potomac, is at last going to have a plane terminal in keeping with its position of dignity among the municipalities of the country. It will be the first commercial airport to be built, owned and operated by the Federal Government.
Alexander Rossner, for thirty-five years with the Joseph P. Day organization, has joined James R. Murphy, Inc., as manager of that firm's auction sales and liquidation department.

Paced by George Buttle, center, the Rutgers basketball team downed the Montclair Teachers, 40 to 29, before 2,000 persons in the Rutgers gymnasium tonight. Buttle tallied 14 points to take scoring honors.

BEISER-ZEITLIN-Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Zeitlin, 327 Central Park West, announce the engagement of their daughter, Mildred, to Mr. Abraham B. Beiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Beiser. BERLINER-SIMON-Madeline, daughter of Mr. Louis and the late Mrs. Simon, announces her engagement to Howard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Berliner.

Sharply divided views are being expressed in retail circles regarding the "constant" employment plan which some leaders in the department store field have suggested. The plan, based on that of the Procter Gambie Company, would guarantee year-round employment to graded percentages of employee.

THE new web of parkways and feeder roads developed scientifically by leading engineers to combat traffic congestion of the 1939 New York World's Fair was put to a test last Sunday. More than 40,000 motorists visiting the Brooklyn-Long Island Dealers automobile show were enmeshed in a traffic jam which continued until nightfall.
TRAVELING in the Australian Northwest reveals some curious sides of life there.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--Impelled by the rapidly changing Winter schedules, extended each successive year by earlier openings and later closings of villas, hotels, clubs and shops, Palm Beach has already assumed the aspect of midseason.
Th Stevens Tech varsity basketball team overwhelmed an alumni group, 43-26, in the season's opener in the William Hall Walker gymnasium today.
Members of the English department at Bucknell University will soon have a chance to hear themselves as their students hear them by means of recordings now being made.
Mary English, 63 years old, bespectacled, looking like a quiet, dignified school teacher, was in jail again yesterday, and the police who had to deal with her were wishing she hadn't been caught.
The Internal Revenue Bureau has brought a $200,371 income tax claim against William H. Donner of Philadelphia, former father-in-law of Elliott Roosevelt, the President's son.

ALTHOUGH for many years there has been a tendency to minimize the importance of Alexander Pope and even to deny that he was a poet at all, the passing generations leave the author of "The Rape of the Lock" entrenched in an apparently unshakable position. It is unquestionable that never again will he seem the overtowering giant that he appeared to his worshiping contemporaries;

BEFORE it has finished, this season may yet be known as the year of the musical comedy. In apartments all over town, and at Sneden's Landing and New City, grim realists are clutching at the muses in an unpremeditated search for the usual rhyme for moon. In other apartments, all over town, the faithful of Tin Pan Alley are beating their breasts and black keys, trying to keep dissonances from tripping the leading lady.

Permission has been granted to a group of stage and screen stars to erect Christmas trees at six outstanding locations in the city for the benefit of the Christmas Refugee Aid Campaign, an organization formed to help Jewish, Catholic, German, Spanish and Chinese refugees.

In the field of world policy I would dedicate this Nation to the policy of the good neighbor--the neighbor who resolutely respects himself and, because he does so, respects the rights of others--the neighbor who respects his obligations and respects the sanctity of his agreements in and with a world of neighbors.

A LIST of the pianists selected by the New Friends of Music to perform the six Bach piano concertos which the organization will give in its orchestral series under Fritz Stiedry, beginning Feb. 26 in Carnegie Hall, has just been announced.

St. Paul's Episcopal Church, in the East Chester section, will celebrate at 11 A. M. tomorrow, with a special service, the 150th anniversary of the occupancy of the present edifice. The church organization was founded in 1665. Many British and American patriotic and military organizations will attend.

M.; Motion Pictures, 2:30 P. M.: "Interior Design: Architectural Backgrounds," (Gillender Lecture) Francis H. Lenygon, 3 P. M.; "The Stamp Tax and Boston Port Bill in English Cartoons," R. T. H. Wells College Chorus of forty voices will perform the D Minor Mass of Mozart in the chapel tomorrow under the direction of Nicholas Nabokoff, head of the Department of Music. This particular mass is very rarely presented because preference is generally given to the later work of Mozart.
Miss Faith Bach, daughter of Mrs. Marguerite Bach of Greenwich, won the championship, in the midWinter riding meet of the Rosemary Hall School at the Round Hill Stables today.

FROM Suva, capital of the Fiji Islands, comes official information regarding "new reign" stamps being released by the Gilbert and Ellice Islands, British colony, and British Solomon Islands, a protectorate, both in Oceanica. Each will postally illustrate local views for the first time.

The first buffet dinner of the season under the auspices of the arts and interests and exhibitions committees of the Junior League will be held tomorrow at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The feature of the occasion will be an after-dinner talk by Peter Scott on "A Wild-Goose Chase to the Caspian Sea."

In the midst of all the Christmas excitement, millinery departments are showing really interesting and wearable hats. There are lots of them of which men will not say: "What crazy things those are!" And yet they do not lack the spirit of fun and gayety which gives women such pleasure--puts them in a good humor, gives them in a good humor, gives them a lift when they need it most.

Having completed their preliminary tune-ups while standing on the sidelines during the recent convention of the minors in New Orleans, baseball's major league club owners are advancing. on New York today to stage this week their biggest oratorical display of the year-the annual Winter conclaves of the National and American circuits.

Model shoe, fur and clothing factories, on a miniature scale, are operated by the Board of Education's Central High School of Needle Trades. Boys and girls, unlike the bound apprentices of old, become cobblers, tailors and furriers under scientific tutelage and amid pleasant surroundings.
To the Music Editor: MR. HARRISON KERR offered an interesting and provocative defense of "modern music" in THE TIMES of Dec. 4, but it was based, however, on a number of questionable assumptions.

Laying aside the problems of diplomacy if not the language and manner of the diplomat, Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, started his study of the United States yesterday by seeing the sights of New York.

Since the conclusion of the battle of the Ebro there has been an extensive reorganization of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's army while day after day for nearly three weeks Salamanca's official war communiques have reported "Nothing worth mentioning on any front."

FREDERICK LONSDALE is finishing a new play for Broadway consumption: he said so over the Atlantic phone the other day in talking to Richard Aldrich, who, in association with Richard Myers, is to produce it late next month. Mr. Lonsdale said more, noting that he and the script both will arrive here this Thursday, all ready, both of them, for rehearsals.

Exports of cotton from Peru during October totaled 9,665 metric tons, compared with 7,092 tons during the same month of last year, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from the American Commercial Attache at Lima.

THESE thirteen snapshots of recent history are remarkable in their range, vivacity and interest. The volume is not-as the editors explain in their preface--a newspaper book, full of shop-talk; it is not a chronicle of personal achievement in getting "scoops." It is history in the raw, history seen by trained observers on the spot.

Professional full-time football teams for universities unable to reduce their present scale of competition were suggested today by Dr. Clement C. Williams, president of Lehigh University, in a speech at the annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic Collegiate Athletic Conference.
Mercersburg Academy will hold its annual Christmas carol service tomorrow afternoon in the chapel, which has been decorated with Christmas greens. Only candlelizht will be used.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry Mateland Mills of 259 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabel Mills, to Thomas Saylor Oakwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Oakwood of Milwaukee.

Announcing yesterday that he has sold in the twelve-month period from Dec. 15, 1937, a total of 1,456 properties for a total sum of $15,752,500, David Cronheim, head of the Newark realty firm bearing his name, declared that this volume of sales disproved the view long held by many brokers that real estate activity was regulated to a large extent by seasonal conditions and stock market changes.

Women interested in the philanthropies of Willoughby House Settlement are active in the plans for the entertainment to be known as the Holiday Dinner Dance which will take place Dec. 17 at the Downtown Athletic Club. Proceeds will further the work of the settlement, which carries on an extensive educational and recreational program among adults and children in a crowded district of the city.
President Arthur H. Deute of the National Brewing Company announced today the company's third annual "labor dividend," the amount of which is to be determined later.

THIS way to the big show, folks! Presenting, 1 lad-ees and gentemen, the professional football spectacle of the year. The greatest offensive team against the strongest defensive club. The irresistible force against the immovable object, for the world's champeenship. Hold your tickets and don't shove, and, firemen, hold that line!
The Union Pacifio Railroad announced yesterday that it had bought an oil-electric locomotive of 4,000 horse power from the ElectroMotive Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation.

SOUTHERN PINES, N. C.--In preparation for the opening of the first of the season's equestrian gymkhanas at the new horse show grounds at the Southern Pines Country Club on Friday afternoon the paneling of the ring and the erection of fences on the outside hunter trial course have just been completed.

The establishment of the Arthur T. O'Leary Scholarship by the administrative authorities of Manhattan College was announced yesterday by Brother A. Victor, president of the college. Awarded on the basis of an essay contest, the grant will cover the costs of tuition in courses leading to a bachelor's degree in the School of Liberal Arts, School of Science, School of Business or the School of Engineering.

When Prime Minister Naville Chamberlain sees Premier Benito Mussolini in Rome in January Generalissimo Francisco Franco may be able to offer them a "fait accompli" in the form of an important military victory as a support to the British Prime Minister's policy in international relations, so that both British and French opposition to the recognition of Franco's belligerent rights can finally be swept aside.

EVER since Major Bowes staged his amateur hour on the Sunday night air from 8 to 9 o'clock, after which Charlie McCarthy enlivened the same waves, that sixty minutes have been one of the most highly competitive periods on the air. Veteran performers have shied away from it. They confessed the competition was too keen; Bowes was too much for them, so is McCarthy.
Overcoming a first period lead, the Williams basketball team defeated Clark Unvirsity by 33-24 tonight. Captain Buddington of Williams led in scoring with 13 points.
Developments on the subject during the last few days have indicated the probability of a long continuation of the discussion over a third term for President Roosevelt.
Bids will be received on Tuesday for the general construction of the superstructure of the new Hunter College, according to Brown's Letters. Inc., construction reports.

A 75-mile-an-hour gale crippled Sydney and other cities today and fanned dangerous bush fires in outlying areas. Forty persons were injured in fires which were started in Sydney suburbs and surrounding territory.

Students of art and architecture in the University of Virginia are back at work in Fayerweather Hall, remodeled for the third time since it ceased to be used as a gymnasium fifteen years ago. A State appropriation of $20,000 made possible the enlargement and the renovation according to plans drawn by Edmund S. Campbell, head of the McIntire School of Art and Architecture.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has recorded a nominal advance for the week ended Dec. 3, rising to 93 from 92.9 (revised) for the preceding week, and comparing with 84.8 for the corresponding week a year ago.
Students at the Northfield schools gave 330,000 work hours last year to the schools as part payment of tuition. In 1879,

Lieut. Comdr. R. T. H. Fletcher, Labor Member of Parliament, announced today that he would ask the Labor Minister on Thursday for a statement in the House of Commons on reports that German firms in Great Britain had been ordered by Berlin to discharge all Jewish employes by Dec. 25.

WHAHATEVER the outcome of the present political struggle in France may be, it is accepted here as almost certain that this country will not "go Fascist" or "go Communist," as these terms are understood and practiced in Italy, Germany and Russia. France will remain French. If a name must be given to the system which is most likely to evolve that name is "collectivist."

SYSTEMATIC apprenticeship whereby young persons entering government service can be trained for administrative jobs is under consideration by several Federal agencies. The plan runs contrary to present civil service laws, which prohibit covered agencies from employing any persons except those who have attained the civil service rolls after examination.

When the annual convention of the American Farm Bureau Federation meets in New Orleans next week the last of the three great national farm organizations will have gone on record regarding farm relief policies in the approaching session of Congress.

A plan which is said to enable private capital to build low-rental housing projects profitably has been advanced by Gerard B. Lambert, formerly president of the Lambert Pharmacal Company of St. Louis, who has erected at Princeton, N. J., a profitable $30,000 project which rents at $6.25 per room

In a brilliant ceremony in the flower-decked great hall of the Stockholm Concert House, Mrs. Pearl luck, American writer, tonight formally-received from King Gustaf the 1938 Nobel Prize for Literature.

Camp Edalia, a subsidiary philanthropy of Stuyvesant House, will be aided by a tea dance to be held Dec. 24 at Le Coq Rouge. The beneficiary provides outings in healthful surroundings during the Summer months for underprivileged city children at the headquarters of the organization on Tiorata Lake in upper New York State.
