From the classroom at Mount Holyoke College this year, students are carrying their knowledge of musical theory and composition along devious ways to promote their own self-instruction and entertainment.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland. HERE in thin Swiss resort, 6,000 feet above sea level and sur rounded by majestic peaks and sun-bathed slopes, Christmas marks the first climax of a season which begins in mid-December and lasts well into March. Daily the visitor finds a crowded program of events. The only problem is which to choose.

A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held at 500 Park Avenue Wednesday at 4 P. M. The contract providing for an exchange of pupils between the town of Pelham and New York City will be considered.
The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to admit additional evidence in the proceedings for reorganization of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway.

In a dramatic rescue in a pelting rainstorm a few hours before dawn, seven men were taken off the grounded Boston trawler Andover by breeches buoy today, while a pounding surf threatened to break up the leaking vessel, loaded with 50,000 pounds of fish taken off Georges Bank on a week's cruise out of Boston.
Supreme Court Justice Perskie today released Asbury Park from control by the State Municipal Finance Commission, which has been in charge of the resort's fiscal affairs for the last two years.

BECAUSE it rained that momentous day in Tucson, Ariz., in 1907, the infant motion-picture industry packed up its cameras, actors and directors and moved on farther west to the southland of California. Weather, thus inextricably woven into the early, history of the film business, still has a weighty influence on motion Apicture and studio destinies.
THE WPA Federal Music Project of New York City reveals with satisfaction that 136 of its employes have been absorbed in private employment during the year ending on Nov. 30.

Expatiating on the functions of architecture in the Third Reich at today's inauguration of the second National Exhibition of Architecture, Arts and Crafts, Chancellor Adolf Hitler proposed the building of cathedrals capable of accommodating 100,000 worshipers.

Madison Square Garden's third annual ice and snow extravaganza, the North American Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet, closed with a flourish last night as a capacity crowd of more than 12,000 watched the concluding performance of the five-day stand. Four thousand spectators, many of whom were children, attended the matinee.

An architect offers the suggestion to the prospective home builder that consideration should be given-to the family requirements for a comfortable front porch. It is called one of the characteristic features of American dwellings.
Among the many performances of Metropolitan Opera which have been taken over for charitable purposes within the near future is that of "The Barber of Seville" on the night of Jan. 17.

Theatre day will be observed on Wednesdays--at the annual Christmas sale of articles made by the blind at 601 Fifth Avenue. The committee in charge includes Helen Hayes, Edith Barrett, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Byron,
The Rose Bowl, as might be expected, has been sold out for the DukeSouthern California football battle Jan.2.

Aymar Embury 2d, New York architect, has been engaged as consultant. on the construction of a proposed new international bridge over the Niagara River to replace the fallen "honeymoon" span, the Niagara Falls Bridge Commission said today.

The body of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, wife of the Irish Free State Minister to the Vatican, who died in Rome on Nov. 24, will arrive here on the Italian liner Rex this morning and will be taken to Wernersville, Pa., tomorrow, without delay for a requiem mass here, as previously planned, it was announced yesterday.

Still smarting from the sting of two early setbacks, Brooklyn College's basketball team hit a winning stride last night and defeated a veteran Seton Hall quintet, 42 to 16, before a crowd of 1,100 in the Brooklyn College gymnasium. The Setonians never were in the running as the Kingsmen, paced by Jim Coward, rolled up a 20-7 lead in the first half.

OF all the beautiful flowering plants offered by florists this Christmas season, perhaps none is finer than the early flowering or Christmas-blooming azaleas. In their mass of bloom and range of colors from white, through various tints of pink, to red, they are unrivaled.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marion Rodnick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rodnick of Woodmere, L. I., to Sanford J. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Smith, also of Woodmere.
The autonomous Memel district will hold an election tomorrow and it is attracting international attention far beyond its local importance because of German organizing and propaganda methods.

A manifesto assailing the Nazi conception of science as destructive of genuine scientific thought and progress and summoning scientists to take active part in the defense of democracy as the sole means of preserving intellectual freedom and insuring scientific advance was issued yesterday by a committee of prominent scientists.

An appeal that hospitality in American homes be extended in the Christmas holidays to the 10,000 foreign students in the United States was made yesterday, by Anson Phelps Stokes Jr., chairman of the Committee on Friendly Relations among Foreign Students.

For the first time the WPA school lunch project will serve no hot lunches during Christmas week to the needy children who receive their noon meal regularly from the WPA kitchens, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress administrator, announced yesterday.

Hillcrest, a new school at Salisbury, Conn., has opened this Fall with the purpose of giving girls an experience in living otherwise economically impossible to them. It aims to develop young women as complete personalities, with healthy bodies, controlled emotions, minds capable of thinking accurately and creatively, strong moral character and a spiritual basis of life.

The Oregon initiative petition controlling labor unions was officially proclaimed a law this week and the leaders of American labor prepared to fight the measure on the political, economic and legal fronts. The law sharply limits the definition of a labor dispute to a direct conflict between a company and a majority of its employes over wages, hours and working conditions;

An income distribution of $19,827 and one of $13,492 on principal will be made to holders of $1,369,200 Series D New York Title Mortgage Company certificates on Dec. 31 by the trustee, John C. Van Glahn.

OILS, water-colors and graphic work by contemporary Spanish artists make up an exhibition at the Arden Galleries this month for the benefit of the Spanish Child Welfare Association of America, for the America Friends (Quakers) Service Committee. Claude G. Bowers, U. S. Ambassador to Spain; William Allen White, Fannie Hurst, Walter Pach,
50-Yard Free Style--Won by Stanley Chemerys, Seward Park. Time--0:25. 100 Yard Free Style--Won by Benjamin Lobenberg Seward Park. Time--1:01.8.

The engagement of Miss Beatrice Hirschfeld, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David B. Hirschfeld of 1,212 Fifth Avenue, to Seymour Blumenson, son of Mrs. Isidore Blumenson of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Mr. Blumenson, has been announced by her parents.

A fleet of twenty-two vessels will be constructed by the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company within the next three years. The vessels, now in stages ranging from blueprints to final outfitting in the basin, will assure the company's 4,000 employes of steady work for at least two years.

ONCE more far-flung tropical ports lure Northerners seekrespite from snow, sleet and the common cold. The annual southward parade of cruise ships has already begun. Before Spring comes around again, say travel experts, more than 1,500,000 Americans will have sampled the pleasures of Winter vacations in latitudes far removed from the socalled "Temperate Zone."

TRADY reparation for a gross injustice was made when Bruno Barilli's three-act lyric tragedy "Medusa" had its baptismal production at the local Teatro Donizetti, rechristened the "Teatro delle Novita," inaugurating Bergamo's second Fall season of experimental opera.

John Troy of St. Francis Prep captured the mile run which featured the third annual athletic meet of the Parish Club of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, held at the Second Naval Battalion Armory in Brooklyn yesterday.

Miss Adlumia Dent Sterrett, daughter of William Dent Sterrett of this city and the late Mrs. Sterrett, was married here this afternoon to Christopher Smith Sargent, son of the Rev. Dr. George Paull Torrence Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, and Mrs. Sargent.

St. Francis College accomplished a feat last night that had been seventeen years in' the making. After sixteen consecutive setbacks by C. C. N. Y. in the basketball, rivalry that began In 1921, the Terriers staged a terrific comeback midway through the second half, overcame a 20-to-13 deficit and subsequently carried off a 26-to-24 decision before a hysterical crowd of 1,200 persons at the Beavers' court.

Samuel J. Mason, superintendent of the Perth Amboy Water Department for the last twenty years, died last night at his home in Runyon after a long illness. He was 59 years old and had lived here fiftyone years.

THE winning of women being a matter of importance where women are concerned, the author starts his interesting study of Germany's present-day womanhood with the story of the courtship technique by means of which Hitler and his brownshirted fellow-courtiers won the hearts of the feminine portion of the country.

MRS. ELLIOTT in her books does more than describe the life and adventures of children in other lands. In "Riema Little Brown Girl of Java" and now in "Soomoon. Boy of Bali," she has built up real and convincing backgrounds which give the reader the feeling that he, too, is actually visiting the brilliant sunlit islands of which this author writes and making the acquaintance of their happy, smiling, brown-skinned inhabitants.

The statement of Maicolm MacDonald, Dominions and Colonial Secretary of Britain, in the House of Commons, that the return of colonies is "not an issue in practical politics," is welcomed by responsible opinion in South Africa.

MEXICO CITY.--Two opposed points of view about United StatesMexican relations have developed among Americans resident in Mexico. One, held almost unanimously by American business men, merchants and representatives of produring agencies, is called by its opponents the short view. The other, championed by American diplomats and persons here on edunational, labor or writing projects, is termed, in contrast, the long view.

ANY ONE who tries to keep pace with the flood of musical events hereabouts these days has his work cut out for him. For years--and sometimes with reason--hard things have been said about music in Paris--or rather about the lack of it.
The Internal Revenue Bureau agreed today with executors of the estate of Mrs. Emma Rockefeller McAlpin to reduce to $953,491 a $6,277,681 Federal tax deficiency assessment against the estate.

Mrs. Saidie Orr Dunbar, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, will speak at the annual luncheon of the Essex County Tuberculosis League to be held at the Newark Athletic Club on Tuesday.

Despite indications that unit sales at retail are running well ahead of a year ago, producers in some lines of consumer goods expressed dissatisfaction last week with the failure of retail dollar volume for the country as a whole to equal last year's figures. They asserted that, with business recovery well under way, retail dollar volume should have made a much better showing.

Although its date is some weeks removed, the annual opera benefit for the Grenfell Association of America is enlisting the support and cooperation of many members of society who are holding frequent meetings in the interests of the event.

MEDIEVAL PANORAMA. By G. G. Coulton. Svo. New York: The Macmillan Company. A Cambridge University Press book. $4. The English scene from the Conquest to the Reformation. MY LIFE AND I. By Emma Stoner Douglas. 12mo. Dallas, Texas: Mathis, Van Nort Co. $2.50. An autobiography.

A total of eighty-seven low-priced homes in the development at North Fifth Street and Hillside Avenue, East Floral Park, Nassau County, L. I., has been sold since May, Frank A. Droesch, builder, announced yesterday.

Although its date is some weeks removed, the annual opera benefit for the Grenfell Association of America is enlisting the support and cooperation of many members of society who are holding frequent meetings in the interests of the event.

J. P. Morgan was credited today with being the first electric consumer to demand lower rates. Representative Rankin of Mississippi told the TVA investigating committee this today in a discussion of power.

District Judge Bunk Gardner today denied a motion of the defense for a directed verdict and acquittal after the government had closed its case here against Hans Heinrich Schackow, German shipping clerk, who was arrested on Oct. 16 for Photographing the canal defenses at Fort Randolph.

MRS. ELLIOTT in her books does more than describe the life and adventures of children in other lands. In "Riema Little Brown Girl of Java" and now in "Soomoon. Boy of Bali," she has built up real and convincing backgrounds which give the reader the feeling that he, too, is actually visiting the brilliant sunlit islands of which this author writes and making the acquaintance of their happy, smiling, brown-skinned inhabitants.

The statement of Maicolm MacDonald, Dominions and Colonial Secretary of Britain, in the House of Commons, that the return of colonies is "not an issue in practical politics," is welcomed by responsible opinion in South Africa.

A pageant based on the traditional French romance. "Tristan et Iseult" is in rehearsal at Barnard College under the direction of Marianne Pilenco, president of La Societe Frangaise, the undergraduate French club. It will be presented on Saturday in memory of Joseph Bedier, the late French literary authority, to raise a partial scholarship for a Barnard graduate to study in France next year.

The "Russification" of the Finnish-speaking population of the Soviet Karelian Republic, adjacent to Finland's east frontier, is reported recently to have made rapid progress. It is feared here that those tribes will soon be completely denationalized.

Trading in wheat futures today was in sharply restricted volume, with final quotations lower, in consonance with the trend in Liverpool. Closing prices were at net losses of 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel. Professional operators were disposed to keep to the sidelines, to await further developments in the grain situation.

Staging a garrison finish, Public School 51 of Manhattan beat the defending titleholder, Public School 44 of Brooklyn for the team championship at the annual city P. S. A. L. elementary and vocational high schools indoor track and field games at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, yesterday.
With President Roosevelt's return i to Washington from Georgia last f week the Administration's armaments plans--their exact details still tentative and secret--progressed toward final form.

An intriguing array of choral selections, culled from the music of the last five centuries, and representative works for the early vertical flutes known as recorders, was presented by the Trapp Family Choir at their first New York concert given yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

LARGER crowds are milling in the transportation terminals these days. There are husband, wife and daughter starting their first rail trip West, There's the man who wants to fly to Bali. At the piers they're off for the Caribbean, South America and the Mediterranean. College and school students are buying tickets home. Ski fans are making reservations for the snow trains.

The Bronx Board of Trade announced yesterday that figures received from the Bronx division of the department of housing show an increase of $10,986,979 in new building operations in that branch, for the first eleven months of this year as compared with the similar period last year.

Joseph H. Johnson, former township treasurer, died at his home this afternoon after a year's illness. He was 62 years old. Mr. Johnson resigned as treasurer on June 2, after serving for twenty-six years. He had also been custodian of school funds.

A pageant based on the traditional French romance. "Tristan et Iseult" is in rehearsal at Barnard College under the direction of Marianne Pilenco, president of La Societe Frangaise, the undergraduate French club. It will be presented on Saturday in memory of Joseph Bedier, the late French literary authority, to raise a partial scholarship for a Barnard graduate to study in France next year.

The "Russification" of the Finnish-speaking population of the Soviet Karelian Republic, adjacent to Finland's east frontier, is reported recently to have made rapid progress. It is feared here that those tribes will soon be completely denationalized.

Trading in wheat futures today was in sharply restricted volume, with final quotations lower, in consonance with the trend in Liverpool. Closing prices were at net losses of 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel. Professional operators were disposed to keep to the sidelines, to await further developments in the grain situation.

Staging a garrison finish, Public School 51 of Manhattan beat the defending titleholder, Public School 44 of Brooklyn for the team championship at the annual city P. S. A. L. elementary and vocational high schools indoor track and field games at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, yesterday.
With President Roosevelt's return i to Washington from Georgia last f week the Administration's armaments plans--their exact details still tentative and secret--progressed toward final form.

A "Concerto," new to the concert public of this city, played last night in Radio City by Artur Rodzinsky and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, brought forcibly to mind the fact that music is accelerating in its technical developments as rapidly as our streamlined railroad trains or time-demolishing airships.

As the twelve men known as the Temporary National Economic Committee (Monopoly Committee) questioned witnesses in the first five days of public hearings the immensity and importance of the problems confronting them became evident. Observers grew increasingly curious whether out of the statistical maze to which the nation's economy was reduced there could ever be pieced together a blueprint lending itself to uniformity of interpretation.

Sizable commitments for Spring merchandise were made by buyers visiting the wholesale markets last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company resident buyers.

The enduring nature of the nation's relief problem which, he ventured to say, "only a healthy war" could solve, was emphasized by William Haber, Professor of Economics at the University of Michigan, at today's session of the annual conference of the American Public Welfare Association.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Blum of Port Richmond, S. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Blum, to Abraham Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Baker of Tompkinsville, S. I.

ANTIQUE silver is useful to collect because, little affected by age. it can adorn and serve a dining table or garnish a sideboard with as much grace today as when it was first made. Old silver, too, has the distinction we associate with the great ages of hand craftsmanship of the past.

Swimmers of Textile High School virtually made sure of successfully defending the Manhattan-Bronx senior high school championship of the Public School Athletic League yesterday, when they took the measure of Seward Park, 44 to 27, in the seventh series of dual meets for the title in the DeWitt Clinton pool.

A taxpayer who moves out of his own home with the intention of renting it should not make any repairs until he has obtained a tenant if he desires to get the benefit of the cost of this work on his Federal income tax statement, advises Prentice-Hall, Inc., in its taxation and government news letter.

Work was started last Thursday on the first group of medium-priced homes in the Green Park Estates development on the large tract in Flushing, L. I., formerly owned by the Queens Valley Golf Club. The property was purchased a short time ago by the Taylor-Woodrow Estates, Ltd., of London, builders of more than 10,000 homes in various parts of England.

The walls are grimy and discolored. The uneven floors creak and yield under foot. Staircases and landings are rickety and black. The door of every room is open. Walk along these corridors. Walk into this room. Here is a sickly boy of five, deserted by his mother, underfed, solitary in the awful solitude of starved, neglected childhood.

THE British dynasty is today unique in its documentation and the credit for a great achievement is due mainly to the Prince Consort. He insisted that copies be made by the court of outgoing letters and that royal papers be filed as in a well-organized office.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing on Jan. 4 in Chicago on an application by the Badger Paper Mills, Inc., to withdraw its no-par value common stock from listing on the Chicago Stock Exchange.

Japan obtained not a single license during. November for the shipment of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States, according to the monthly report of the Munitions Control Board issued by the State Department today.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Heinle of Toledo, Ohio, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Welch Heinle of this city, known on stage and screen as Phyllis Welch, to Graeme Kirkpatrick MacDonald, son of Mrs. Alan MacDonald of San Francisco and the late Mr. MacDonald.
French foreign trade for the first eleven months in 1938, in francs, was as follows: Imports: 41,767,000,000,

Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Fleming gave a reception yesterday at their home, 216 Greenway South, Forest Hills, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Lucy Patricia Fleming. Among the guests were many older friends of the family.

A joint committee has been appointed to coordinate the research, teaching, field organization and clinical work of the American Birth Control League and the Birth Control Clinical Research Bureau, it was announced yesterday.

Contradicting the suspicion that Joe Louis knocked him into retirement when he stopped him in 2 minutes 4 seconds of fighting last June at the Yankee Stadium, Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion of the world, is contemplating a resumption of his ring career.

Mrs. Dorothea Crouse McVickar died on Saturday night at her villa in Vence, France, after a short illness, according to word received here yesterday. With her was a son, Edward S. J. McVickar 2d, and his wife. Mrs. McVickar's age was 51.

A. S. Cornhill won the high-overall scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, with 99 out of 100. W. Black defeated A. P. Palmer for Class A handicap honors and E. Hughes scored in Class B after a tie with A. A. Roig and J. Nida.
The first annual Negro Actors Guild benefit, which was held last night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, grossed approximately $8,500, according to Nat Dorfman, representative for the organization.
Mendelssohn Co., Berlin, one of Germany's oldest private banks, founded in 1795, disappeared last week through absorption by the Dautacha Bank.
With an increase in the number of births in the State in October, the death rate that month of 10.4 a 1,000 was the lowest, with one exception, ever recorded, the Department of Health reported today.
The Italian agitation against France appears to have averted any internal political clash in France that might have resulted from Premier Edouard Daladier's economic decrees.

With a four-goal attack in the final period featuring, the St. Nicholas Hockey Club triumphed over the Crescent Athletic Club, 8 to 4, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night to strengthen its hold on first place in the New York Amateur Hockey Association race.
Relief workers reported today that the whole town of Camalig had been buried in volcanic debris washed from the slopes of the famous Mayon Volcano by flood waters in last week's typhoon.

Awards for participation in Fall sports at Harvard University were announced today by the committee on the regulation of athletic sports. The major football H went to twenty-one members of the varsity gridiron squad and the manager, Cliver P. Bolton;

A group of manufacturers of paper, pulp and wooden dishes, of the variety used by groceries, delicatessens, and meat markets as containers for foods, has been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease and desist from price-fixing activities started in 1933 under an NRA code, the commission announced today. Price-fixing was legalized under the codes.
Robert Sellmer, American free-lance journalist, here to observe today's election, was beaten up this morning by Memel irregular policemen.
The European markets in the Winter months are likely not to show either a decidedly firm tone or a pronounced bearish tendency.

Cotton prices fluctuated last week over a fairly wide range. Net changes, however, were mostly small. At the close on Saturday prices of active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to up 13 points for the week, in contrast to declines of 31 to 33 points in the previous week.
Angna Enters gave the third and last of her scheduled recitals of character mimes at the Alvin Theatre last night, assisted by Madeleine Marshall at the piano.

As expected, the fiduciary note issue of the Bank of England was increased last week, but the addition this year, [Pound]30,000,000, against [Pound]20,000,000 a year ago, carries no significance, because this larger increase will cover comfortably the expansion in Christmas currency demands. whereas last year's smaller sum was barely sufficient forthe purpose.

Jewish refugees coming to this country and expecting to carry on their professions as nurses must meet the requirements of the new Nurse Practice Law if they expect to practice in this State, Mrs. Ethel G. Prince, president of the New York State Nurses Association, announced today.
Having himself served a prison term, Sidney Porter, or O. Henry, as the world knew him, understood how to make even the convicted

The fourth annual Vacation Dinner Dance will be held on Jan. 2 at the Plaza. the event is for girls from the ages of 15 to 18 and for boys from 16 to 21, and was organized in 1935 by Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark and Mr. George Eustis Corcoran.

John Weismantel, a retired Brooklyn boxing promoter who owned and managed the Show Boat, a restaurant at 814 Jamaica Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home, 78-71 Eighty-second Street, Brooklyn. He-was 66 years old.

A marked increase in the salary schedules for nearly 600 professional librarians was urged yesterday afternoon by members of the United Staff Associations of the New York, Brooklyn and Queens Public Libraries at a meeting in the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the never-ending development of Manhattan Island, the northward encroachments by the trades have brought about such density of population and land coverage that many of the best residential districts have become potential slums.

Playing before 2,500, the Prague booters of the National League held Brookhattan of the American Soccer League to a 2-2 tie at Starlight Park in the Bronx in the first round for the National Challenge Cup.

The value of total daily retail sales .reported in Great Britain for October was 2 per cent greater than that of October, 1937, according to the monthly trade figures issued here this week by the Bank of England.
Antonia Brico, conductor of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, directed the New York Civic Orchestra in concert last night at the Federal Music Theatre.

The only hope of world peace lies in a world economic conference and an economically satisfied Germany, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Gifts to the 1938 Neediest Cases Fund fell off yesterday to a total of $2,207.10, the smallest amount that has been received in any day since the twenty-seventh annual appeal for the Neediest was launched in THE NEW YORK TIMES a week ago yesterday.
The Montreal Canadiens defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 2, tonight and drew even with the losers for sixth place in the National Hockey League standing.
The marriage of Mrs. Deranda Turner Dragna of Dallas, Texas, to James T. Carter of 967 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in All Soul Church, Brooklyn.
With Governor and Mrs. Lehman as guests of honor, the New York State Jackson Day dinner will be held Saturday evening, Jan. 7, at the Hotel Commodore.

The public has helped the Federal Government finance its deficits of recent years to the extent of about $2,000,000,000 through purchases of United States savings bonds, popularly known as "Baby Bonds," since they were first issued on March 1, 1935.
Basing views on private cablegrams from the United States, London concludes that there is little prospect of any immediate important resurgence of American business.

Declaring that "the foundations of peace are in the souls of men," the Rev. S. E. Gerard Priestly prescribed release of spiritual forces, faith and prayer, conviction and sincerity from which creative peace alone can be born as the paramount requisites of the world today in a sermon yesterday morning to the congregation of the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventysixth Street.

Julius Powers resold for cash over a first mortgage of $8,000 the three-story building containing four apartments and six stores at 439 New Lots Avenue, northeast corner of Vermont Street, Brooklyn. Samuel. Hurwitz -was the broker in the sale of the property, which is 25.4 by 114 feet and is assessed at $28,000. Herbert E. Mohr represented the seller.

Vera Reynolds, former film actress, said today it was all a mistake when she filed suit yesterday for divorce from Robert Ellis Reel, screen writer. Remarking that it was "a woman's privilege to change her mind," Miss Reynolds said that she had instructed her lawyer to dismiss the action tomorrow.
The award of 176 insignia to participants in Cornell varsity and freshman football, soccer, cross-country and rowing was announced today.

Unless the Jews of the world realize that their only salvation is in fighting back before they become refugees they face complete moral and physical destruction in the ghetto, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the International Administrative Committee of the World Jewish Congress, asserted yesterday before the congregation of the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall.
Thirty-seven hundred men and women filled Carnegie Hall last night for a memorial to B. Charney Vladeck, majority leader of the City Council. Mayor La Guardia was the principal speaker.
America's touring football squad cut loose with a barrage of razzle-dazzle plays today and many touchdowns, but no one, apparently, cared-least of all the 6,000 amused French spectators.

Brig. Gen. Alexander E. Anderson, commanding officer of the Ninety-third Brigade of the New York National Guard, reviewed the cadet corps of Xavier High School yesterday afternoon in the 165th Infantry Armory, 68 Lexington Avenue.

On that broad thoroughfare of swirling dust and yelling newsboys and honking, speeding, dangerously careening motor traffic, the Avenida de Mayo, center and focus and heart of the throbbing life of this metropolis of Latin America, the visitor from the United States, strolling along past leisurely coffeesippers lounging at tables in front

After clipping tree tops for a block, an airplane bearing two Denver couples on a pleasure ride lost its motor and landed upside down on Seventeenth Avenue Parkway in an East Denver residential district today.

The United State Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association went on record as favoring affiliation with the Central Office for. Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics at its fifty-sixth annual meeting at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.
The Court of Appeals has ruled that liens imposed to guarantee payment for repairs which would make tenements healthful and safe are "unconstitutional both under the Federal and State Constitutions."
A suit for $100,000 in property filed here disclosed today a dispute between two women representing themselves as the widows of Feodor Chaliapin, the operatic basso.

The hope that Germany's persecutions and her aggressive attitude toward her neighbors would not provoke a conflict involving the United States was expressed yesterday by Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, in a talk before a refugee meeting called by the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society.

Twenty-six members of the varsity squad are among the 105 football players representing four teams at the University of Pennsylvania to receive letters and numerals for the 1938 season, H. Jamison Swarts, director of athletics and chairman of the awards committee, announced today.

The stoning of a Jewish synagogue in Brooklyn, which resulted in damage to several frosted-glass windows costing about $100, was reportted to police of the Stagg Street station yesterday by Rabbi Mordecai Silverman of Congregation Beth Yakov Zvei Zichron. Rabbi Silverman said that similar damage was done in 1935, by persons who were not caught.
Emile Baume, French pianist, who first was heard in this city two seasons ago, gave .his third local recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

In the dinghy sailing races off the New Rochelle Yacht Club today Eugene'C. Mynick's boat Mary captured top honors with 33 points. Janie, owned by Frederick Gade, gained 23 points in the first races of the monthly series, leading the Mary by 2 points in this competition.

The final elimination round in the nation-wide "Great Waltz" contest, sponsored by Metro-GoldwynMayer, will be hell this evening in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria, with twelve couples selected in regional contests throughout the country competing to determine the best amateur waltz team.

P. J. Little, parliamentary private secretary of Eamon de Valera, Premier of Ireland, warned Britain tonight to remember the influence of Irishmen in the United States if she expects cooperation from America.

The Chicago Black Hawks ended a four-game losing streak tonight by defeating the New York Americans, 4 to 0, before 15,118 fans. Previous' to this game the Hawks, slumping badly after a fast start, had scored only two goals in their last four contests in the Stadium.
Supply contracts valued at $3,361,556 were awarded during the week ended Dec. 3 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contract Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Strikers in the metallurgical industry here decided at a meeting this afternoon to return to work Tuesday. Their strike, which has been in progress since the twenty-fourhour general strike of Nov. 30, stopped work on the new battleship Jean Bart and the liner Pasteur.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Otis Co., on behalf of a banking group, today will offer to the public $30,000,000 of Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company refunding and improvement mortgage 31/2 per cent bonds, series F, due on Dec. 1, 1963.
An attack on American commercial policy in respect to Cuba was made public today by Filipo de Hostos, president of the local Chamber of Commerce.

Today's Parliamentary elections appear to have passed without serious clashes, although gendarmes fired on crowds in several Croat villages, wounding a number of persons. Government circles declared that except in Croatia and, Dalmatia the government won between 60 and 70 per cent of the votes.

A universal rededication to the Christian principles of the brotherhood of man, tolerance and a willingness to sacrifice for God and country are necessary to combat the growing, forces of dictatorships, Charles Poletti, Lieutenant Goverernor-elect, declared here this morning.

The Rev. Thomas A. Fox of the Paulist Fathers yesterday characterized the peace of Munich as a "common hold-up" and said that the events abroad in the last few years had been reducing nationalism to a degree of absurdity.

The La Guardia administration was praised for its work in advancing the demolition of the Sixth Avenue Elevated line, by Percy C. Magnus, retiring president of the New York Board of Trade, in his annual report made public yesterday.
Three mixed Anglo-Netherlands committees are preparing to leave for America and South Africa early next week to arrange for the admission of Jewish refugees.

The New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., voted yesterday to abstain from affiliation with the Dancing Masters of America, thus deciding an issu which has aroused intense interest among professional teachers of dancing throughout the city for several months.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs.- Ralph W. Earl of Shalebrook Farm, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edna Frances Earl, to Perry Beattie Haynsworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh C. Haynsworth of Sumter, S. C.
The German wholesale price index last week was unchanged at 106.2.
W. F. Knox, winner of the event in 1936, led the second qualifying round of the Siwanoy Country Club's thirtieth annual Sno Bird golf tournament today.

A charge that in the past few weeks a conspiracy had been under way to force the retirement of Prime Minister Mackenzie King from the national leadership of the Liberal party was made by Norman Rogers, Minister of Labor, and C. D. Howe, Minister of Transport, at a mass meeting here last night.

The most harmful, destructive and devastating word in human speech is "gossip," the Rev. H. W. B. Donegan, rector of St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor must obtain $175,423 to balance its budget, according to an appeal for funds to be sent today to 14,000 members and friends of the organization by Barklie Henry, president.

The strike of the United Meat Workers Union, Local 635, C. I. O. affiliate, voted on Saturday in sixty wholesale distributing and processing plants in the city, began last midnight, but its effectiveness will not be determined until this morning.

Only 32 per cent of the 58,109 persons whose claims for unemployment insurance were certified last month got their checks on time, according to statistics made public yesterday by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

With Senator William H. King of Utah, as the principal speaker, Yeshiva College last night held its tenth annual dinner at the Hotel Astor. Five hundred persons attended, and the proceeds were devoted to scholarships and the refugee emergency fund.
Traditional Christmas celebrations, stressing the language and customs of four countries, will be held this week by the Spanish, German, Italian and French Clubs of Barnard College for the students.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, was 68.4 on Dec. 7, compared with 69 a fortnight before, 69.3 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931 which immediately proceded the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Formal offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. of $2,599,000 of Onondaga County, N. Y., 1.70 per cent bonds dated Dec. 1, 1938, and maturing on Dec. 1, 1939 to 1968. The bonds will be priced to yield from 0.25 to 2.10 per cent, according to maturity.
Albino Manca, Italian artist, who arrived here yesterday on the Italian liner Rex. brought forty of his paintings. He came by special permission of Premier Mussolini to exhibit in New York.

The engagement of Miss Marion Drake Dreher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Dreher Jr. of this place, to George A. Staniar, son of Mrs. George W. Staniar of Belleville and the late Mr. Staniar, has been announced by her parents.

The Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, urged Roman Catholics yesterday to write to Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York objecting to a mural with an "irreligious" inscription by Walt Whitman on a wall of the new postoffice in the Bronx.

A Harlem drug store clerk, who had been caught off guard by holdup mien twice in the last four years, was ready with a loaded revolver within reach when two armed Negro thugs entered the pharmacy at 2,692 Eighth Avenue, at 143d Street, at 7 o'clock last night.
More than 1,400 reservations have been made for the 126th dinner of the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor tonight. Robert Erskine Ely is executive director.

Undercover efforts to achieve from the PanAmerican Conference a positive and unanimous stand against nonAmerican military, political and economic aggression are expected to reach a crucial stage tomorrow.

A tea to prepare for an intensive membership drive will be held this afternoon in the Colonnades of Essex House by members of the New York Women's League of Camp Sussex, of which Mrs. William A. Hyman is president.
Captain Charles T. Stoll of Company C, 107th Regiment, N. Y. N. G. (old Seventh), died early yesterday in the French Hospital, 330 West Thirtieth Street, at the age of 45.

Cardinal Mundelein of Chicago, in a statement broadcast nationally yesterday, declared that the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit priest and radio commentator, was "not authorized to speak for the Catholic Church," and that he did not "represent the doctrine or sentiments of the church."

More than 6,000 general stores throughout the country, with aggregate sales in 1937 of $175,188,000, reported to the Bureau of the Census that their sales during the first half of 1938 were off 11.2 per cent as compared with the same period last year. The first quarter of 1938 showed a loss of 9.8 per cent and the second quarter a loss of 12.4 per cent, compared with the 1937 quarters.

The State Board of Social Welfare is seeking the help of the public before presenting to the Legislature its ideas on revision and codification of the State's laws dealing with relief, public welfare and charities, the board announced yesterday.

Dr. George Burgess Magrath, Suffolk County Medical Examiner for twenty-eight years until his retirement three years ago, and professor-emeritus of legal medicine at Harvard Medical School, died last night at Phillips House of Massachusetts General Hospital, to which he had been taken from the St. Botolph Club, 4 Newbury Street, Back Bay, where he made his home. His age was 68.

Mr. and Mrs. Walker W. Stevenson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gretchen Blancke Stevenson, to Walter Whittlesey Bronson 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Hollister Bronson of New Haven, Conn.
When the famous gold piano is carted from the East Room of the White House to the final silence of the National Museum, many melodious memories will go with it.

Steel ingot operations last week were down about 1 point at 59 to 60 per cent of capacity; this was an insignificant decline when compared with the great recovery which has occured in the last five months.

The time has come for a decision as to the necessity of increasing the capacity of the Panama Canal to meet the demands resulting from the increased sizes of ships, merchant as well as naval and also the expected increase in the volume of traffic, Colonel C. S. Ridley, Governor of the Canal Zone, asserted in his annual report to the Secretary of War, made public today.

At the concert given by the New Friends of Music yesterday afternoon in Town Hall before a large and responsive gathering, the Kolisch Quartet gave the fifth and last of its programs devoted to the complete string quartets of Beethoven.

The Junior League of the Oranges has arranged Christmas parties for the various local organizations in which it takes an active interest. A holiday party, including a program of folk dancing, a Christmas tree and Santa Claus for children of the Day Nursery of Orange, has been arranged by Miss Elizabeth Vanston of South Orange.

Mr. and Mrs. Orra S. Rogers of Plainfield have announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Ruth Adelle Rogers, to Dr. Alfred Edward Whitford. The wedding will take place during the Christmas holidays at the Winter home of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers in Fort Pierce, Fla.

The only party that will be tolerated in -the new Czecho-Slovakia besides the Government party held its constituent assembly this morning when 900 delegates elected the former Czecho-Slovak Social Democratio leader, Antonin Hampl, chairman of the new National Workers party.

In a light westerly breeze today the sailing dinghy team of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich won the three-cornered match in Class B boats with a score of 92 1/4 points, to 841/4 for the Larchmont Club and 70% points for the Manhasset Bay Club.
Residents here are aroused over the report of a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board which, they assert, puts the town in a false light and encourages C. I. O. "agitators."

The December issue of the Federal Reserve Bulletin, made public today, discusses the recent phenomenal increase in money in circulation, and declares that "at such a time as the present, when banks do not need to borrow to get currency," an increase "is not an important development."

The Danish A. C. eleven of the National Soccer League turned in a 3-to-1 victory over the.,-Brooklyn Germans in a second-round match for the United States Amateur Cup at Dana Park in 'Brooklyn yesterday. Eddie Skiba paced the Danish squad with two goals.

Last night's opera concert at the Metropolitan gave opportunity for the debut of John Carter, the young lyric tenor from Brooklyn, who was one of the winners of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air for 1937-38. Mr. Carter was heard first with Marisa Morel in the final scene

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bruce Saunders of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Ives Saunders, to Paul G. King, son of A. Rowden King, also of Glen Ridge, and the late Mrs. King.
The corn market is considered by many in brokers a much more promising speculative medium at the moment than wheat.
Jacob Omansky, business manager of The New York Post, since 1933, died from a heart attack while horseback riding in Central Park yesterday morning.

The "deplorable excesses" against religion, with which Loyalist Spain is charged by Generalissimo Francisco Franco's supporters, have been stamped out by the government since the -early days of the Spanish conflict, Indalecio Prieto, former Loyalist Defense Minister, asserted in an interview here yesterday.

A further tightening of deliveries in a number of wholesale markets was noted last week as stores hastened to obtain goods for holiday selling. Among the items stressed on "rush" orders were ski apparel and accessories, men's and boys' gift furnishings, costume jewelry, negligees and robes, gloves of all types, and scarves.

The election of Robert P. Hazlehurst Jr. of Spotswood, N. J., as chairman of the 1940 board of The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper, was announced today by James McC. Clarke of Manchester, Vt., retiring chairman. Hazlehurst and other new editors will take office Feb. 4.
Giovanni Martinell was the guest of honor last night at the Lotos Club at a dinner attended by 200 persons to celebrate the tenor's twenty-fifth anniversary with the Metropolitan Opera Association.
The franc would have recovered much more last week if the foreign exchange market had been left to its own devices, as offers of foreign currency in large volume were not met.

Mrs. Thomas Ewing Jr. gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 720 Park Avenue. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin, Mr. and Mrs. William F. C. Ewing, Mrs. Morgan Belmont, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Adams, Mr. and Mrs. Donaldson Clark, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Ives, Mr. and Mrs. A. Craig Culbertson, Mr. Mrs. Edouard de Wardener, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Harper and Dr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Lambert Jr.

Yale University, as a teaching organization, spent $7,219,061 during the fiscal year, according to the annual report of the treasurer, made public today. Of this the educational costs totaled $6,083,121 and operation and maintenafice of physical plant $1,135,940.

A protective committee has been formed by the holders of the twenty-year 51/2 per cent convertible debentures, due May 1, 1950, of McKesson Robbins, Inc. The company has filed a voluntary petition for reorganization under Section 10 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull is the undisputed hero of the Eighth PanAmerican Conference. Not only do the delegates admire him and hang on everything he says, but also his name is pronounced with enthusiasm through all strata of society, and almost with reverence among H the lower classes.

The Ukrainian Autonomy Bill will not be considered in the Polish Sejm [Parliament] and the speaker will send it back to its proposers. His ground for that action is that, constitutionally, only the President is entitled to ask Parliament to vote on territorial changes.

Although the Bible continues to be the "best seller" and more copies are being sold every day, civilization is becoming increasingly ignorant of it, the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe declared yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Eightyfifth Street.

Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman head the large group of sponsors for the concert to be given the night of Dec. 26 at Carnegie Hall to raise funds for the relief of German and Austrian refugees. The artists, who will donate their services, will be Hulda Lashanska, Mischa Elman, Emanuel Feuermann and Rudolf Serkin.

Protests by cooks that theirs is a despised calling were taken up seriously today by Trud, the organ of the Central 'Trade Union Council, in what appears to be the beginning of a campaign to lift the calling to dignity and honor:

Jack Prokop made a clean sweep of the three races sailed today in the -Class B section of the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association's weekly regatta, making a perfect score of 12 points with O. H. Chalkley's boat, Popover.

Secretary Wallace declared tonight that results of yesterday's farm referenda, in which cotton growers approved and rice and flue-cured tobacco producers rejected marketing controls, signified permanence for the New Deal's farm program.

R. L. Butler, who resigned the Premiership of South Australia to contest the Wakefield seat in the House of Representatives, appears today to have been defeated by the Labor candidate, S. McHugh, in the elections held yesterday.

It is the duty of American Catholics to -make known their opposition to fascism as well as to communism, William F. Bleakley, county executive-elect of Westchester, told 200 members of the Notre Dame University Club of New York at a communion breakfast in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.
Dr. Harry S. Willard, an eye specialist for many years, died today in his home here after a long illness. He was 62 years old and had lived here fifty-one years.
Italian anti-rench demonstrations so far have had no perceptible effect on market opinion here because, at present, all other considerations are eclipsed by discussions, first,
Philadelphia's squash racquets team today captured the Tri-City Arthur H. Lockett Trophy for 1938 by nipping the defending Boston team, 4 to 3.
Last week's money market was dominated by numerous far-reaching capital movements, including:
Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Segel of Roxbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Segel, to Sidney Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Robinsorn of Rahway.
" Masaryk's name and personality should not be dragged into petty political quarrels," declared Premier Rudolf Beran's Agrarian newspaper Venkov today.

THERE is nothing like respectability. Professional football, once a shabby outcast among sports, has become a dignified and honored member of the American athletic family. It is a far cry from the old Canton and Massillon days to the brilliant show that was staged at the Polo Grounds yesterday when 48,120 excited fans gathered for the Giant-Packer play-off for the professional championship.

What was described as the "largest and most magnificent set of Alaskan moose antlers in any collection in the world"' will be placed on exhibition today in the Seventy-seventh Street entrance of the American Museum of Natural History.
H. R. Mallinson Co., Inc., sold its silk mills on Bergenline Avenue, Union City, to the National Realty Corporation of Paterson, for an indicated consideration of $100,000.
Louis Henry Achilles, secretary of Benedict Brothers, jewelers, 168 Fulton Street, died yesterday after a three-week illness at his home, 212 Manor Road, West New Brighton. S. I.. at the age of 77.
Representative Maas, Republican, of Minnesota, said today the Minnesota Republican delegation favored Representative Joseph W. Martin of Massachusetts for leader of Republicans in the new House.

Ch. Blakeen Jung Frau, white standard poodle bitch owned by the Blakeen Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah, N. Y., and handled in the ring by Mr. Hoyt, last night was awarded the best-in-show title in the final judging at the twenty-fourth allbreed exhibition of the Bronx County Kennel Club held in the 105th Field Artillery Armory, the Bronx.

Such "pagan institutions" as communism and fascism threaten to destroy the dignity that women have won under Christianity, the Rev. Daniel A. Lord of St. Louis and former Governor Alfred E. Smith said last night.

Apart from some fluctuations, the Bourse's tendency was firm last week as far as rentes and French stocks were concerned, while foreign securities were subject to the operations due to a more divided opinion, and Friday's session was marked by a fairly sharp rise.

William H. Jackson, for many years a Federal judge in the Canal Zone and a son of the late United States Supreme Court Justice Howell E. Jackson, committed suicide yesterday in his third-floor suite at the Hotel Brevoort, Eighth Street and Fifth Avenue.

The anniversary of the Escalade of 1602, when the republic city of Geneva had an escape from the army of Savoy, was celebrated yesterday in I'Eglise du Sant-Esprit, 229 East Sixty-first Street. The Rev.
A relatively moderate let-down in steel production before the usual holiday slump is expected this year the magazine Steel says today in its weekly summary of the industry.

The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America is "controlled by political and social radicals" and in no sense represents American Protestants, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, the pastor, said yesterday in his sermon in the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,975,117,350.

Victory in the concluding event gave St. Francis Prep a 40-to-35 triumph over St. John's Prep yesterday in the second of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association dual swimming meets conducted by the Columbus Council, K. of C., in Brooklyn.
Frank Brimsek made his bow tc the New York hockey public last night, but so far as the Rangers were concerned he might just as well have missed the train.

Simple funeral services, followed by cremation, were held today at the Church of Our Saviour for Lady Anne Elizabeth Grenfell, wife of Sir Wilfred Grenfell, noted founder of missions in Labrador and Newfoundland.
Mrs. Mary Agnes Smith, 85 years old, of 224 East Maple Avenue, Wildwood, patient in an ambulance in an accident last night, died today in Atlantic City Hospital of injuries suffered in the-crash.
Dr. Christian L. Lange, former secretary general of the Interparliamentary Union, co-recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize of 1921, died here today at the age of 69.

The ticket of regular candidates for the nine offices of Local 202 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. of L. affiliate, defeated the "New Dealers" ticket yesterday by four to one in a membership vote in the New York Fruit Exchange Building, 66 Harrison Street.
General Francisco Franco is completing the detailed preparations for the mighty offensive that he naturally hopes will at last, but quickly, decide the Spanish war in his favor.
Richard, Collins, retired real estate investor and broker, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 124 East Fifty-fifth Street.

Mrs. Joseph E. Goodbar, president of the National Federation of Press. Women, gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 49 West Forty-fourth Street, in honor of the members of the New Jersey Women's Press Club, which was recently received into the federation.

While quiet prevailed yesterday in the strike that has crippled longdistance trucking in and out of the city, D. L. Sutherland, president of the Highway Transport Association, Inc., -the organization representing long-distance truckers, Issued a statement charging that a "mob" has moved in behind the "smoke screen" of the strike to exact tribute from the-employers and seize control of Teamsters Local 807, with which the strikers are affiliated.
The gustatory delights of English cooking were hailed by members of the Gourmet Society yesterday as a means of: promoting Anglo-American amity.

" more than usual" decline in employment and payrolls in New York State factories during November was attributed in part today by State Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller to enforcement of the Federal Wages and Hours Law.

In a joint statement today, Warner Brothers, Dick Powell and Joan Blondell announced that the contracts of the actors with the studio, both having several months to run, would be torn up at the completion of their current pictures.

The Giants and the Packers delved into the realm of fiction for a storybook football game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. In fact, fiction almost seemed too tame a medium for the thriller that the Eastern and Western champions of the National Football League staged for the world title to the delirious delight of a record play-off crowd of 48,120.

A fiery and truculent man is Henry Bernstein. Already he has fought nine duels with actors, producers and critics who slighted his honor by slighting his plays. Fortunately the Atlantic is broad, and M. Bernstein is on the other side of it.

Use of lottery methods in the sale of candy to consumers is prohibited in an order issued against Sweets. Company of America, Inc., 414 West Fortyfifth Street, New York, by the Federal Trade Commission, according to an announcement today by the commission.

Two thousand persons were pres.ent last night at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore given by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City to the fourteen founders of the Bronx division of the organization. The dinner also marked the fif- A teenth anniversary of the Bronx group.

The A. L. Improvement Company sold the three three-story buildings at 465-89 Bergenline Avenue, near Twenty-third Street, Union City, N. J., to Lillian Cator. The sale was subject to a $21,000 mortgage.

Books of the Princeton University Athletic Association show a $18,367 deficit for the fiscal year 193738, according to an official statement issued today by R. Kenneth Fairman, graduate manager of athletics. The standing deficit of the association is now $96,593.07.
A government monopoly for the sale of petroleum and derivatives for domestic consumption was created by a law passed by Congress yesterday.

The Bureau of Mines reported today that stocks of all oils in October amounted to 570,028,000 barrels. This was a decrease of 5,926,000 from September's 575,954,000 barrels, but an increase of 5,829,000 barrels over October, 1937. The amount was considered to be 151 days' supply.

The New York State Temporary Commission to Formulate a Health Program will open a four-day series of public hearings tomorrow in a move to obtain a cross-section of public opinion on the public health needs in this State.

The Utilities Power and Light Corporation, Ltd., a Canadian subsidiary of the Utilities Power and Light Corportion, a registered holding company incorporated in Virginia, was authorized in a decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission today to use $9,000,000 of a cash fund of $12,000,000 for the purpose of buying debentures of the parent company at 70 per cent of the face value.
Strength in corn had some effect on the lard market last week, but trading in the latter was not active.

Speaking calmly with a pronounced British accent, Mary English, 63 years old, known to the police as English Mary, told Magistrate Cooper in Felony Court yesterday that she would like at least a week to hire counsel when she was arraigned on a charge of grand larceny in the alleged theft of $3 from the purse of a shopper Saturday afternoon.

The findings of Soviet explorers aboard the icebreaker Syedoff, now drifting within 300 miles of the North Pole, together with earlier observations by other investigators, have caused Soviet scientists to conclude that the Arctic region and, indeed, the whole world is growing warmer.
Mrs. Prescott Childs will arrive at the Madison tomorrow from Chicago. She will sail later to join Mr. Childs for Christmas at Barbados, B. W. I., where he is United States Consul.
Because it stretched my breast apart I held in check my growing heart. Because I feared a curbless mind Would leave my ordered ways behind I took no chances with the steed.
John Courtenay Frederick Mill, financial editor of The Times of London from 1920 until his retirement a few months ago because of ill health, died here yesterday at the age of 55.
Sammy Snead, cannonading pro from White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., emerged today as golfdom's alltime money baron with $19,039 in this year's winnings tucked away where he feels it's safest.

Mr. and Mrs. William G. Creamer gave a small tea yesterday at their home, 162 Argyle Road, Brooklyn, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Creamer, to Dr. William Reid Pitts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Noah O. Pitts of Glen Alpine, N. C.

A certain revival of rules is necessary to save modern religion from vagueness and weakness, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday morning at the Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
Dr. John Brown Merritt, who practiced dentistry here for nearly half a century until he was taken ill in September, died at his home Friday night of a heart ailment. His age was 71.

" The World Over: 1938" is the title of the first volume to be issued under the imprint of The Living Age on Feb. 1. The editors are Joseph Hilton Smyth, editor of The Living Age, and Charles Angoff, contributing editor of The North American Review.

For the first time in the city's history traffic lights in all five boroughs were operated on a twenty-four-hour basis yesterday. The continuous operation was ordered Saturday by Police Commissioner Valentine in an attempt to cut down early morning accidents.

Dr. and Mrs. Harold E. B. Pardee of 770 Park Avenue and Lawrence, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Althea Pardee, to William A. Evans Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of Northway, Greenwich, Conn.

A tribute to the effort and man power of the United States during the World War was paid today by Jules Henry in speaking at Clermont-sur-Oise at the dedication of a bronze tablet commemorating the American acceptance of the supreme allied command.

Francis J. O'Reilly, the last survivor of the "Fighting Ninth" Regiment and sole surviving Cambridge member of the Grand Army of the Republic, died today after a short illness. He was born ninety-three years ago in Cambridge, where he lived at 9 Saville Street.
Two seeded entrants, J. J. Reynolds of the Columbia University Club and A. E. Watt of Jackson Heights, gained places in the quarter-final bracket, as another, F. B.
Two Jews were shot dead by unidentified gunmen near Haifa today, but most of Palestine appeared to have been subdued by British military forces.

Contracts for the official -guide, souvenir book and daily program for the World's Fair have been signed, it was announced yesterday by fair officials. All three will be published by Exposition Publications, Inc., 33 West Forty-second Street, of which Thomas R. Gardiner, publisher of medical directories, is president.

Hosiery shipments for October totaled 11,957,372 dozen pairs, compared with 12,440,008 dozen pairs in September and 10,653,009 in October, 1937, according to the monthly statistical bulletin issued yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. The increase over October, 1937, marked the third consecutive month that shipments have been above a year ago.
A leading deal in realty activity in this city over the week-end involved an apartment house on Washington Heights which was sold quickly because the seller was leaving on a trip around the world.

A bronze tablet, erected to the memory of the Rev. John J. McGoldrick, former pastor of St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church here, was unveiled today following a memorial mass. Seven hundred members of the parish attended.

The preliminary recommendations on rent control legislation will be presented for discussion this afternoon at a meeting of the Citizens' Housing Council in the auditorium of the Bar Association, 42 West Forty-fourth Street. George A. Boehm, chairman of the committee on laws and administration, said the recommendations were based on an extensive study of rent control laws in the United States and abroad.

Residents here are aroused over the report of a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board which, they assert, puts the town in a false light and encourages C. I. O. "agitators." The report contains findings against the Newberry. Lumber and Chemical Company, following a hearing, for eight discharged lumber mill workers.

The season's first performances of 'Der Rosenkavalier" and "Tosca" with Rise Stevens as Octavian and Maria Caniglia as Floria Tosca will mark the fifth week, starting on Dec. 19, of the Metropolitan Opera season.

Headed by three exhibitions in well-known New York institutions other than galleries, the mid-week of December brings a very diversified list of some thirty new attractions to the art world. On Wednes.
The French weekly wholesale price index on Dec. 3 stood at 655, compared with 658 a week before.

ACHILLES--Louis Henry, Dec. 11, 1938, in his seventy-eighth year, at 212 Manor Road, West New Brighton, S. I., beloved father of Mrs. Kenneth L. Drescher and Mrs. C. Frank Bush, Mrs. Lila A. Zorn, Mildred Achilles. Arthur B. Achilles, secretary of the jewelry firm of Benedict Brothers.
A sharp increase in the acute infectious disease tularemia or "rabbit fever" confronted a number of States today, arousing concern among some public health officers.

The body of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, wife of the Irish Free State Minister to the Vatican, who died in Rome on Nov. 24, arrived here yesterday on the Italian liner Rex, accompanied by Mr. Macaulay.

Anthony Eden, who spent yesterday with his wife in seclusion at the home of friends in the country, planned to inspect slum-clearance and low-rent housing projects in New York today before leaving late tonight for Washington, where the Edens will be guests of the British Embassy.

Bernard Perlin, in 273 W 10th St; Arthur S. Lukbach, Inc, broker. Lily Cahill, Nathaniel W. Smith Jr., Mrs. Anne Tiffany, John B. English, George D. Forney. in 527 E 72d St; Realty Operating Co, managing agent.

Tonight's events: "Goetterdaemmerung," Metropolitan, 7:30; Beethoven Association, Ravel memorial concert, Town Hall; National Orchestral Association, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; New York Philharmonic-Symphony String Quartet, Lexington Avenue Y. M. H. A.; Dr. Erich, Schwebsch, lecturer, Steinway Hall, 8:30.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marcia Stevens Kitchell of Troy Hills, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kitchell, to Irvin Torrence Francis of Caldwell, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James A. Francis.
Direct censorship of the pulpit was exercised here for the first time today, marking another stage in the Nazi party's conflict with the Catholic Church.
Tax collections in the Township of North Bergen, N. J., showed a sharp increase during November, according to Josiah M. Hewitt, North Bergen bondholders' representative.
Over the week-end Julius Nathanson brought to the National Theas tre on Second Avenue for a limited engagement a musical comedy, "Street Singers," which he played in Brooklyn some seasons back.

Because the Spanish Loyalists and the German Nazis are members of the universal brotherhood of man, they should be considered with charity rather than hate, the Very Rev. Nicholas Higgins, guardian of St. Francis Friary, Providence, R. I., declared yesterday in his third Advent sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Secretary of State Cordell Hull today named Alfred M. Landon to head the United States representation on the Pan-American Conference's most important committee, that on organization of peace.
The second annual nation-wide anti-Nazi week opened yesterday with a mass meeting at the Center Hotel, 108 West Forty-third Street, at which speakers urged the boycott of German merchandise.
Democracy has a permanent advantage over dictatorships in its broad base, Rabbi Israel Goldstein told the congregation of Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street near Broadway, yesterday morning.
A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, has been appointed a director of the bank.
The pace-setting New York Rovers acted none too kindly toward the Atlantic City Sea Gulls at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

A mortgage of $22,000 for five years at 51/4 Per cent has been arranged by Herbert L. Williams, Inc. representing the Troy Savings Bank, on the two 5-story tenements at 2,304th 7th Ave; Leon S. Altmayer, broker.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will hold a four days' celebration in thanksgiving for the recent beatification in St. Peter's, Rome, of Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini, the first citizen of the United States to be so honored.

A hundred rabbis and lay representatives of orthodox, conservative and reform synagogues in this city met yesterday afternoon at the Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street, to adopt a uniform program for Jewish refugees from Germany. A resolution adopted unanimously called for a Synagogue Committee for Refugees in every synagogue.

The church today has a fight on its hands and every Christian must join the battle actively if the program of Jesus is to prevail in this world of cruelty and hate, the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday in his sermon at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.

When Elsie Janis returns to Broadway on Jan. 1 for. a series of Sunday night appearances at the Music Box, the performances will take the form of informal revues patterned after the post-war shows of "Elsie Janis and Her Gang."

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, at a celebration of the eleventh anniversary of the Church Army in the United States at the Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, yesterday morning, placed that organization above any other group of missionaries in the world.

New York City pension funds now may be almost $500,000,000 below actuarial requirements on the basis of unofficial estimates, according to the investment firm of Lazard Freres Co. in a new financial study of the city to be made public today, which points to increasing pension requirements as one of the factors that will result in higher future budget costs for the city.
Mrs. Walter Harvey Close gave a tea yesterday at her home, 131 East Sixty-sixth Street, to introduce her daughter, Miss Suzanne Close, to older friends of the family:
Most of the United States delegates to the Pan-American conference are having a hard time wrestling with their limited Spanish, but they have found the language to their advantage in one respect.

In a desultory market, last week's Stock Exchange prices drifted slowly downward, reaching toward the week-end an average nearly 3 points under the December highest and more than 9 points below the year's best average, scored exactly a month ago.

Governmental operations in the international wheat market continue to dominate the supply-and-demand situation to such a degree that there currently is almost no consistent speculative interest in the Pits.
A disiclination for investment is almost universal on the Boerse as liquidation of Jewish property i9s considered certain ulitmately to depress prices.

Members of the Buick and Chevrolet units of the United Automobile Workers local here voted today for a thirty-two-hour week to replace the prevailing forty hours, necessitating re-employment of 6,000 idle workers.
A Gay Winter sports party, which included moving pictures of skiing at Sun Valley, Idaho, was held at the Greenwich Country Club last night.
The Paterson Panthers defeated the Danbury Trojans today in the deciding game of their pro football series. 32 to 7.

Lenox R. Lohr, president of the National Broadcasting Company, denied yesterday that any desire to avoid a controversial discussion had figured in the refusal of stations' WJZ and WEAF to broadcast statements by Representative Martin Dies of Texas Dec. 3.
Guerrilla forces of China's Communist Eighth Route Army were reported today to have killed 6,000 Japanese in a major setback to the invaders' campaign in Shansi Province.
Thomas. F. Bryce, vice president in charge of sales of the Krueger Brewing Company, has been elected president of the Horton Pilsener Brewing Company, it was announced for publication today. Mr.

Tryouts for parts in the 1939 presentation of- "Veronica's, Veil," which will mark the silver jubilee of the internationally known Passion Play, have begun in the auditorium at Union City, N. J., it was announced yesterday by. Father Conrad, producer.

Eight persons prominent in religion, philosophy, letters, education, politics and public affairs combined yesterday on a coast-to-coast NBC broadcast in an effort to explain the meaning of democracy to a 16year-old girl, a high school sophomore.

The Rev. Francis P. Donnelly, Teacher, critic and author, celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of his entrance into the Jesuit order yesterday afternoon with his fellowJesuits at Fordham University, where he is Professor of Rhetoric.

Virginio Gayda, who often speaks Premier Mussolini's mind, warned France today that in failing to consider Italy's claims on Tunisia, Jibuti and the Suez Canal she was committing "guilty and fateful errors."

The three polar bears that Harold Gillam, Pacific Alaska Airways pilot, announced last week he would give to any person, institution or zoo that would pay the animals' board bill for a year and stand the cost of crating, will go to the New York, Brooklyn and Cleveland Zoos, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Helen Jane Edwardsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Edwardsen of Glen Ridge, was married to William Henry Nix Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Nix of Cadogan, Pa., yesterday afternoon at House of Prayer in Newark by the Rev. William S. Venables.

The steamship Santa Lucia of the Grace Line is due today from Chile, Peru, Ecuador, Colombia and Cuba. Among her passengers are Allison V. Armour and Mrs. Mary A. Whitehouse, uncle and aunt of Norman Armour, United States Ambassador to Chile; Professor William A. Aery, Charles Dodd, British charge d'affaires in Buenos Aires, and Mrs. Dodd; Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Baglin, Mr. and Mrs. Collins, Garrison and Enrique Alfredo Wilson.
WOULD-BE travelers who are compelled this Winter to take their Mediterranean cruises in imagination will find H. V. Morton an able guide and pleasant companion.

New York City pension funds now may be almost $500,000,000 below actuarial requirements on the basis of unofficial estimates, according to the investment firm of Lazard Freres Co. in a new financial study of the city to be made public today, which points to increasing pension requirements as one of the factors that will result in higher future budget costs for the city.

As the end of the year approaches there should be interest in that admirable booklet which was wafted out of City Hall not long ago under the title "Knowing the Tax Department and the Tax Commission."

The financial markets here continue inert, in the heavy condition that has characterized them for the last few weeks. A feeble mid-week effort to rally quickly evaporated under the impact of growing Franco-Italian tension, and Germany's reaction to Great Britain's statement of policy concerning the former German colonies.

Some 150,000 inhabitants of autonomous Memel territory in Lithuania went to the polls today to elect a new Landtag, or Diet. As in the case of the last election three years ago, the result was not in doubt.

In recognition of his services to the Italians in the Brooklyn diocese, Bishop Thomas E. Molloy received last night the insignia of the Royal Order of the Crown of Italy at a dinner given in his honor at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

The General Motors-Cornell World Price Index of forty basic commodities rose 0.1 point for the week ended on Dec. 3, over the preceding week's level of 60.4, which was the lowest number registered in thirty years.

With certain matters still to be adjusted, there seems to be every likelihood that Katharine Cornell will be acting for The Playwrights' Company in S. N. Behrman's "No Time for Comedy," which, at the earliest, could not go into rehearsal until Jan. 9.

There is more than a slight possibility that the Warren County Jail, up at Glens Falls, will have a number of new but willing inmates during the next few days, and, if it does, the blame may be placed on Under-Sheriff Frank C. Sherman.

Henry M. Weltzner, Inc builders; Wil liam Rothlein Co, textiles, In Nelson Tower Building, 450 7th Ave, and additional space- in same building to Tex-Mart Fabric Inc, rayons; I: Pomerantz, rayons; New Jersey Worsted Mills, woolens; Princeton Silk Corp, silks and rayons; Frederic Tipper Co., woolens, and Princeton Knitting Mills, knitted fabrics; Michael E. Lipset Co., renting agents.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 79.8, which compared with 80.4 the week before, 80.5 two weeks before, 80.4 three weeks before and 80.5 four weeks before.

The National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers. reported today that most of the men's apparel merchants throughout the country anticipate a Christmas buying season "very little different from that of twelve months ago."
