Officials considered tonight that the recent labor unrest in Jamaica was over. It was believed that the situation has returned to normal.

In these unprecedented times of WPA and home relief, when an appeal is made for the indigent it is easy to shrug the shoulders and feel we have done our share in the taxes we pay. Surely whoever is up against it need only apply to the proper authority to be taken care of.

An amendment to the Federal Wages and Hours law to provide time-and-a-half pay for all work in excess of four hours on Saturday and eight hours on any other day was demanded today by a Textile Workers Organizing Committee convention.

A general plan for integrating and clarifying administration of public welfare assistance and the relationships among Federal, State and. local agencies dealing with welfare problems was suggested by members of the American Public Welfare Association at today's final session of their annual conference.

A controversy that illustrates one of the difficulties in the way of the return to Britain of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor unless the Duchess first gets royal rank is aired today in The Sunday Dispatch.

New York University has received recent cash gifts and bequests totaling $164,567, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase. The largest gift was $25,000 from the Felix M. and Frieda Schiff Warburg Foundation, to establish the Institute of Fine Arts endowment fund, the income to be used for the support of the division.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange last week, also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

MUNICIPAL OFFICE APPLIANCE OPERATOR-Grade 2 (This list will be certified for various positions in the City service for which the skill and ability necessary to operate the various standard types of office appliances used by the City such as comptometer, addressographing, tabulating, bookkeeping, accounting, billing machines.) Salary:

Expressions of moral indignation by Christians and the Christian Church must be tempered by a desire to change or redeem the person or situation involved rather than to judge or assign guilt, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, the rector, said yesterday morning in his sermon in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twentyfirst Street.

The type of Italian bomber that has been raining death on Barcelona and other Spanish ports can carry more than a ton of bombs each and attain a top speed of 215 miles an hour, according to Jane's All the World's Aircraft, just published.

Columbia's crews will compete in four major regattas next Spring leading up to the Poughkeepsie classic in June, it was announced yesterday by Frederick Holt, undergraduate manager of rowing. A triangular race with Manhattan and Rutgers on the Harlem River, opening the Lions' season April 15, is also being arranged.

It may be Regarded as a fortunate coincidence in these days of almost permanent political interference with the markets, that they are able to develop material power of resistance growing out of the belief that economic recovery in the United States will continue.

1--Fundamentals of a Sound Policy The peace of Munich, the conquest of Ethiopia and the overrunning of China by the armed forces of Japan have demonstrated that we are living in a new age of imperialism.
Mrs. Claude Beddington of London, who is at Hampshire House, entertained at The Cottage there last night with a musical and supper.

Songbirds that are seldom required to sing, delicate creatures possessing the more important details of plumage, conformation and posture, attracted wide interest at the annual show of the Brooklyn Cage Bird Association, Inc., in Acme Hall, Ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, yesterday.

Four first performances of works by living American composers graced the program of the Musical Art Quartet last night at Town Hall. This would certainly seem sufficient to pique public curiosity, but the sad truth is that last night's audience was appreciably smaller than those of the previous concerts of this series, which has thus far offered Italian, French and Slavic music.
Fire raged through the Columbia Novelty and Button Manufacturing Company plant here early today. Eleven fire companies from three municipalities fought the blaze.

British Guiana faces the possibility of a Christmas without telephone, inland telegraph, mail service, coastal steamship, ferry and rail services unless strike decisions of postal and transport workers are withdrawn.
Zeke Bonura, for the last five years one of the American League's hard thumping first basemen, will train his guns on National League pitching in 1939, for he is now a number of the Giants.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Valentine Smith of New York and Ramaqua, Rye, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madeleine Marvin-Smith, to Joseph Janer Almirall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Almirall of this city.
Business and banking circles here describe the Franco-German peace pact as "the turning point in Franco-German economic relations";

Fred Hutchinson, young righthanded pitcher, who was the sensation of the Pacific Coast League last season as a member of the Seattle Club, has become the property of the Tigers, it was announced last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mrs. Clara Sullivan, 42 years old, of 321 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, was fatally injured late yesterday afternoon when the car in which she was riding with her husband, James, 46, overturned in Jacob Riis Park, Rockaway.
The Brooklyn College women's basketball team will play eight games this Winter, according to the schedule announced yesterday by the Women's Athletic Association of the college.

Henry S. Short, 54 years old, of 391 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, was stricken by a heart attack yesterday as he was driving to work in his automobile, and: pulled the car to the curb in front of 233 Ninth Street, Brooklyn, and stopped.

The three-story structure known as the Ambassador Mansions and the two-story building known as the Russian Baths at 3,861-69 Third Avenue, Bronx, have been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York to the 3,861-69 Third Avenue Realty Corporation, Nathan Beecher president.

In the article of Godfrey N. Nelson which appeared in the Financial Section of last Sunday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES under the head "Classes Increase Tax Computation" the word "not" was inadvertently supplied in the second line of the fifth paragraph, reading "The tax on corporations in general-those whose net incomes are not more than $25,000."

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that on Thursday night at 8:30 o'clock he would announce promotions and appointments in the department in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue at Twenty-sixth Street.
A drastic ruling restricting semi-pro baseball clubs to a maximum number of ex-professional players was announced today by George H. Sisler, commissioner of semi-pro baseball.

Santa Claus, according to the dead letter office of the General Postoffice, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, is receiving less mail each year, but there is still plenty of it. This year so far about 500 letters have arrived, most of them addressed to "Santa Claus, North Pole, N. Y."

World stocks of refined copper at P the end of November amounted to 424,537 tons, compared with 424,711 on Oct. 31, a decrease of 74 tons, according to the Copper Institute. b Blister stocks increased 20,818 tons, making the net increase in copper stocks last month 20,644 tons.

The three four-story apartment houses on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1. 3, 5 and 7 Booream Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., were sold by the Hoboken Bank for Savings to Abraham Levy, who will hold them for investment. J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker negotiated the deal.

Basketball followers in the metropolitan district who have been singing the praises of Hank Luisetti, Stanford star who made such a fine impression in the East, will see another Coast sensation on Saturday night when the University of Oregon's team meets C. C. N. Y. at Madison Square Garden.He is Lauren Gale, and if he is half as good as his advance notices, every one will be satisfied.

An 82-year-old library cloakroom attendant at Columbia University, who was earning $65 a month at her death last May, after twentyeight years of service, expressed her gratitude for steady employment in a bequest of $500 to the institution,

The British Charge d'Affaires and the French Ambassador called at the Foreign Office today to express the hopes of their respective governments that Germany would use her influence to assure full observance of the Memel autonomy statute by the National Socialist Memel German party.
A tire salesman from New York told in Federal District Court today of his "disappearance" from Washington in 1934 during a Congressional investigation of War Department purchases.
Twelve men were arrested today on. disorderly conduct charges as the Chicago Newspaper Guild's strike against The Chicago Evening American and The Herald and Examiner entered its second week.

Efrain Buenrostro, Secretary of National Economy, asserted today that the Mexican Government had "ordered immediate payment" for the estates known as Nuevo Italia and Nuevo Lombardia in the State of Michoacan, which were expropriated and divided among peasants several weeks ago personally by President Lazaro Cardenas. The properties were owned by the Italian-Mexican Cusi family.

The New York Giants, exuberantly happy as the result of their sensational 23-to-17 victory over the Green Bay Packers the day before for the professional football championship, gathered for a farewell party yesterday, a late breakfast at the Hotel Whitehall, where most of them were quartered during the season.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. disclosed today that the Treasury, with the approval of the President and the State Department, was "earnestly" studying cooperative effort between it and the Treasuries of South and Central American countries in an effort to make available adequate exchange facilities and otherwise stimulate trade between the countries.

New Yorkers may see something of the coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth through the eyes of the artist who has painted it for the sovereigns themselves. Several paintings of the coronation by Frank O. Salisbury, well-known English artist, are on exhibition temporarily at the gallery of Arthur U. Newton, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Dec. 7, aggregated $8,928,000,000, or 29 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days, and 7 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

More than 700 leaders in the financial and industrial world and representatives of governmental agencies will attend the first annual dinner and entertainment of the New York Stoc Financial Writers Association to be M held on Friday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor.

Rumblings of dissatisfaction with "New York City domination" mingled with avowals of party loyalty today as the State's rural Republican leaders completed plans for their own permanent organization, begun at the State convention in Saratoga Springs last September.

The New York County Democratic Committee, meeting last night in Tammany Hall, unanimously recommended to the City Council the reappointment of S. Howard Cohen, Manhattan Democrat, to membership on the Board of Elections.
The Custon condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in. 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Total Dec. 7:

The National Orchestral Association, directed by Leon Barzin, had the Vienna Choir Boys as guests at last night's Carnegie Hall program. Mr. Barzin took this-opportunity to present Pergolesi's "Stabat Mater"--at least, seven of its thirteen sections.

Coast guardsmen from the cutter Haida sought tonight to reach survivors of the motorship Patterson, who were sighted ashore after this former whaler grounded off Cape Fairweather, Alaska, with one man of a crew of nineteen reported washed overboard.

Canadian dealers bought 128,322 radio sets valued at $10,233,850 in the first nine months of this year, compared with 148,911 sets valued at $12,617.630 in the corresponding months or 1937, the Department of Commerce has been informed by its commercial attache at Ottawa.

Even after the surrender of a group of 10,000 guerrillas west of Soochow, which the Japanese claim, there remain at present 60,000 of these roaming Chinese forces on the Yangtze delta in the limited area between Shanghai, the Kiangyin boom, Lake Tai and Hanchow, according to the Japanese military spokesman.

Two unidentified men fired on an automobile carrying Major Antonio Rexach, an aviator formerly with the Spanish Government forces, and Dr. Jesus Porto Carrero, an attorney, in the midtown section this afternoon, wounding the chauffeur.
Harvard's President Emeritus, Dr. Abbott Lawrence Lowell, today completed the eighty-second year of his life with the same zest and alertness that followed him into "retirement."
Caustic comment is made in the press on the speech of Secretary of State Cordell Hull at the opening of the PanAmerican Conference.

The Republic Steel Corporation, in a thirty-two-page petition to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today, gave six reasons why, it contended, the National Labor Relations Board should be required to reopen the Republic case and permit the company to present additional testimony.

The two three-story flats at 22-24 Clinton Avenue, Jersey City, on a plot 50 by 95 feet, were sold by the Trust Company of New Jersey to the Acme Management Corporation, the bank taking back a purchase money mortgage for $7,300.

Anna Publicer has become a contributor to the fund for THE TIMES Neediest Cases. Anna's gift was not the largest received that day. In fact, it was only 10 cents. Accompanying the dime was a letter written in a childish scrawl, reading:

To develop appreciation of the arts among the American people, a plan for a National Bureau of Fine Arts, to be established by the Federal Government independent of the WPA, was made public here yesterday by Dr. Walter Damrosch, its originator.

Representatives of the automobile industry joined yesterday with city officials in %dedicating the new $1,655,000 building of the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades at 50 Bedford Avenue. Mayor La Guardia was represented by Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll.
A further easing of the Treasury-bill interest rate developed on the weekly offering of about $100,000,000 of discount bills.

Walter.Glensmann, 28-year-old research chemist of the American Cyanamid Company, was killed today in. an explosion of chemicals in a laboratory-of the company on Post Road, West Stamford. Two other chemists were injured.

Chief Inspector Alexander C. Anderson returned to his desk at police headquarters yesterday morning fully recovered from the effects of a stroke he suffered Aug. 16 at his home, 60-53 Sixty-eighth Avenue, Glendale, Queens.
Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King took personal cognizance today of the political warfare in the Liberal party between him and Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario.
The regular fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Nov. 30 showed the following changes, in paper pesos:

Bill Kern, Carnegie Tech football coach, reported to have said Referee John Getchell in calling a wrong down caused his team to lose to Notre Dame on Oct. 22, proposed at the Irish football dinner tonight that Getchell referee the Notre Dame-Carnegie Tech game in Pittsburgh next Fall.

The premature announcement of a great government victory in the elections, which was assiduously spread abroad by official agencies last night, was contradicted today when the official figures were announced.
Pensioned On his own application: to take effect 12 midnight, Dec. 9: PATROLMAN Daniel Mandel, 28th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 22, 1911.

Elmer H. Wene, Democratic Representative from the Second New Jersey Congressional District, has served papers on Walter S. Jeffries, Republican, contesting last month's election fraud, overexpenditures and illegal voting is being charged.

Heavier promotions of white goods will be undertaken by both large and small stores in January, selling agents here said yesterday, and they based their prediction upon the large volume of goods ordered for early January shipments. Emphasis in these sales will be upon price, and, as in the last few years, price promotion will be concentrated largely upon sheets.

Larry Gains,Toronto's veteran Negro boxer, tonight won a decision on points from George James, Welsh heavyweight champion, in a twelve-round bout. Thousands of Welshmen who lined the streets and crowded the fight scene gave the boxers an ovation.
Colonel Alexander Rodgers U. S. A. (retired), who fought in several campaigns, died at his home here last night after a brief illness. His age was 86.

A buoyant tone ruled in some sections of the bond market yesterday in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Strength in United States Government obligations attracted considerable attention as gains of 1-32 of a point pushed several of the Treasury loans to new high levels.

Now that the New Jersey open deer season is only a few days off scores of hunting clubs are sending their scouts to the southern and central areas of the State to locate camp sites and check on the best shooting grounds.

The Automobile Club of New York revealed yesterday that it was asking the General Welfare Committee of the City Council to kill a bill before it which might permit combinations in restraint of trade to fix gasoline prices within city limits.

Attorneys for railroads and labor unions opposed an application of the A. C. Coal Company yesterday before the Interstate Commerce Commission for a certificate to permit the operation of trucks across State lines.

The War Department announced today award of the Soldiers' Medal to Private William R. Bouldin of Fort Shafter, Hawaii, for heroism in rescuing a woman from drowning at New Rochelle, N. Y., on Oct. 13. Private Bouldin was born in Irwin, Pa.
The government backed up its plan for repatriating Italians living abroad today with an appropriation of 10,000,000 lire.

The Herbert Schiff Memorial Trophy, awarded annually to the Naval air squadron or unit with the best record for safety, has been won this year by Patrol Training Squadron 4, commanded by Lieut. Comdr.
Dr. W. J. Sweasey Powers died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack in his office at 666 Madison Avenue. He was 63 years old and lived at Red Squirrel Farm, Greenburgh, near White Plains.
Mrs. Frances Chesterton, widow of Gilbert K. Chesterton, the noted writer, died today at Beaconsfield, where she and her husband made their home in 1908.

There is apparently some fear in the minds of Latin-American statesmen at the Lima Conference that we want from them an exclusive loyalty to the doctrine of Pan-Americanism; that we wish them to turn their backs on the Old World, think only of the New, and sever the ties of trade and culture and tradition which bind them to the democracies of Europe.
" The High Road," by Faith Baldwin, which Farrar Rinehart will bring out on Jan. 5, will be Miss Baldwin's thirteenth published book.

Application by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., for an injunction restraining Pathe Film Corporation from transferring stock of the du Pont Film Manufacturing Company to its own stockholders in line with a planned dissolution of Pathe, was denied yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.
The Assembly passed tonight a bill for a special election on June 20 on a constitutional amendment to permit pari-mutuel betting on horse races.

The most challenging naval question before the United States today is the proposal for a "two-ocean" navy. That proposal has been disavowed by President Roosevelt, but it is certain to meet with powerful support at the next session of Congress.
Turpentine firm, 211/2c; sales, 119 barrels; receipts, 187 barrels; shipments, 826 barrels; stock, 52,914 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 120; receipts 934; shipments 1,109; stock 313,120.

In contrast to the sharp advance in Liverpool, following Saturday's referendum which indicated about 84 per cent growers being in favor of the 1939 acreage-reduction plans, prices on the Cotton Exchange here failed to hold their slight early improvement yesterday, and ended Wool the session with a loss of 5 points to a gain of 7.

Trading opened fair to mostly slow in local markets yesterday. Lamb market was higher; veal weak to lower; cow strong to higher; other classes of traefer meats mostly steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady to higher; lamb strong: veal and calf unchanged.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One greets with enthusiasm the outbursts of indignation and sympathy that have appeared on the campuses of so many colleges and universities during the past week directed to the succoring of refugee students.

After a generally firm opening the stock market became irregular today, as lack of support caused some sections to sag. Gilt-edged stocks were lower. German bonds weakened in the foreign list, with other issues moving within narrow limits.
Harry E. Drevenstedt, .vice pres-. dent of the National Carbon Company, has been elected a director of the Peoples National Bank and. Trust Company of White Plains.

November shipments of stock sash, doors and frames rose sharply against the seasonal trend, and carloadings gained 92 per cent over the corresponding 1937 figure, the National Door Manufacturers Association, Inc., reported today.
In a free scoring session, the Westchester Victorias overwhelmed the New York Sporting Club sextet, 11-3, in a New York Amateur Hockey Association encounter at the Imperial Ice Casino tonight.

One hundred and eighteen plans for construction work on factories, mercantile establishments and places of public assembly in twenty-six counties were submitted to the State Department of Labor last month and were the largest number for any November in the fifteen years in which such plans have been filed with the department, Commissioner Frieda S. Miller reported today.

Royal commissioners this afternoon. sought suggestions for bettering the British West Indies Colonials by observing what the United States, a former British colony, is doing in this West Indies possession to provide better economic and social conditions. It is somewhat similar to the neighboring British islands.

Mrs. Stewart Iglehart of Westbury, L. I., wife of the noted polo player; seeded third, was pressed only in the opening game and easily defeated Mrs. Philip Fowler of Boston, 18--17, 15-9, 15-7, today to reach the second round in the ninth annual- women's - Atlantic Coast squash racquets tournament.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told 1,000 men and women at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night that the success or failure of American democracy depended upon the participation of every one in community problems.

In a year the average income of every person played in Great Britain has increased about $1.25, according to the third annual edition of "The Marketing Survey of the United Kingdom," which will be published here soon.

The Haytian Corporation of America has notified holders of its $3,000,000 debenture bonds, which are due Dec. 31, next, of a new plan, under the Chandler act, which has been substantially agreed upon in principle by the two principal noteholders' committees.

Jacob Siegel, president and chairman of the board of directors of the Eichler Brewing Company, died yesterday at his residence, 21 East Eighty-second Street, of heart disease and a cerebral hemorrhage after an illness of several months. He was born in the Bronx on Nov. 15. 1874.
This former provisional capital of Government Spain, long used to Insurgent air raids, was rocked tonight by two earthquakes.

Once more the Supreme Court has spoken out in defense of equality of human rights. It has held that as long as the State of Missouri chooses to provide training for law students it must not deny to Negroes, as it has done, a privilege that it extends to white law students.
Dr. Willard Clark Sanford, chief of staff at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, 1910-30, died of a heart attack today in his home here.

As a result of a better freight movement than had been expected, combined with higher rates in November, preliminary figures indicate that net operating income of the Class I railroads was up to about $42,000,000, compared with $32,440,920 earned in November, 1937.
More than 200 persons attended the nineteenth anniversary luncheon and reception of Anne Hutchinson Chapter, D. A. R., which was observed at the Siwanoy Country Club here today.
Rejecting Japanese concessions and proposing stiffer conditions than those already existing, the Soviet Government has refused Japan's request to sign a new fisheries treaty.
Centuries by Don Bradman and Stanley McCabe featured the third day's play of the four-day match between the Australian International Cricket team and an eleven representing The Rest of Australia.

Details of the I. B. A. Essay Awards, established by the Investment Bankers Association of Amerca at tits recent convention at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., have been announced by Jean C. Witter of Dean Witter Co., San Francisco, president of the association.

Expulsion from the Senate of Carlo Sforza, former Foreign Minister, now in exile owing to his anti-fascist views, was brought up in the Senate today when Senator Perrone asked Luigi Federzoni, President of the Senate, whether that body "does not feel the absolute necessity of expelling from among its members an individual who systematically insults our country-Carlo Sforza."

Charging cruelty, Mrs. Marjorie Anne Nicholas won an uncontested divorce decree here today from Robert Carter Nicholas 2d of New York City. The court approved a separation agreement dated Oct. 25, 1938.
Lake Mead, the world's largest man-made lake, which stretches more than 100 miles behind Boulder Dam at Boulder City, Nev., may become a huge inland air base for the navy, it was learned here today.
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. "Health Insurance," Martin Brown, 10:30 A. M.; "The Building of a Republican Platform," H. Alexander Smith, 8:30 P. M.
More than [Pound]43,000 has been contributed in four days since Earl Baldwin made his broadcast appeal for the fund for the relief of refugees from Nazi persecution.

Gloomy Gil Doble, taciturn man of the gridiron for more than a quarter of a century, tonight ended all conjecture as to whether he would be dropped as Boston College football coach by announcing he wasn't seeking the job again.
The United States Maritime Commission began investigating today the activities in the Western Hemisphere of two of the largest shipping companies under the Japanese flag.

The incorporation of advertising regulations, similar to those in the Wheeler-Lea law, in the model state drug and food bills now being drawn up, is meeting opposition in some advertising circles on the basis that such a step is both unwise and unnecessary.

A straight fight over Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's foreign policy in the West Perth Parliamentary by-election was assured today when the Rev. A. W. Groundwater, Independent Labor opponent of the Duchess of Atholl, withdrew his candidacy.

The St. John's University track team will engage in nine indoor meets, according to an announcement by the athletic association yesterday. The Redmen are slated to open their campaign in the Columbus Council K. of C. games at the 245th Coast Artillery Armory, Brooklyn, Jan. 7, and will close the season at the New York K. of C. meet in Madison Square Garden on March 11.

By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Patterson Ave, 1,930-1,932, 50x100; Adam Besler against Sarah Pearlman; due, $15,. 569; to plaintiff for $500. By GEORGE J. KEARNS Sound View Ave, 625-629: also Beach Ave, 48.11x74.2 irreg; Benjamin Shapiro against John Kaufman; due, $15,782; to plaintiff for $500.

Confronted by the ever-perplexing problems of radio broadcasting, which promises soon to engulf both the New York clubs as well as the Dodgers, and other important legislative matters such as increasing the player limit to twenty-five and adopting a uniform ball, the major league baseball magnates move into their annual off-season show today fo a spirited three-day session.
Frank Ernest Lyman, former State Commissioner of Public Works, died this morning in his home in Easthampton after a long illness. His age was 72.
Services for the Rev. Joachim Cuniffe, O. F. M., former vice president of St. Bonaventure College, who died Dec. 9 in Denver, Col., will be held here Thursday. His age was 64.

Arrangements for completion of the Cross County Parkway at a cost of $1,800,000 and conversion of it into a toll road were consummated this I afternoon by the Westchester Coun- I ty Board of Supervisors after no word had been received from Albany that State funds would be made available for the project on a non-toll basis.

President Roosevelt conferred today with Secretary Morgenthau and Daniel W. Bell, Acting Director of the Budget, and afterward it was said that the Chief Executive was making progress toward preparation of his annual budget message to Congress, which is to be delivered Jan. 3.
James A. Farley's memoirs would never have made so interesting a book if they had been published a few weeks before Nov. 8
Seven children, orphaned when a drunken driver killed their mother and fatally injured their father, arrived in Chicago today and later left for New York and new homes.

The board of directors of the Pru- yesterday; dential Insurance Company of America. announced yesterday the election of two new vice presidents--George H. Chace, second Greyhound.. vice president in charge of Ordinary Agencies, and Robert M. Green, second vice president. F. Bruce Gerhard, associate actuator, was elected second vice president and associate actuary.
ATTERBURY-At Maldstone Farm, Annapolis, Md., on Dec. 11, Faith Ripley, wife of Howard Estep Atterbury. Services at Maidstone Farm at 2:30 P. M., on Tuesday, Dec. 13.
John White and Abraham Pearlman were fellow pleaders--in that order, fortunately for White--before the bar of Magistrate Nicholas Pinto in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Booklyn, yesterday.
Zelan, a new and durable water repellant fabric finishing agent, will be introduced at a luncheon to the press today at Sherry's.
More than 100,000 persons in the United Kingdom are suffering from cancer, Walter Elliot, Health Minister, said today in moving the second reading of the Cancer Bill in the House of Commons.

The acceptance of Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, president of Bonwit Teller, of the general chairmanship of. the fiftieth anniversary campaign of the Child Study Association. of America, was announced yesterday afternoon at a campaign workers' tea at the home of Mrs. George Marshall at 232 East Sixtyfirst Street.

The possibility of economic reprisals by Germany was indicated in informal discussions by delegates here today to be a leading factor in South American opposition to all proposals before the Pan-American Conference tending to solidify American sentiment or action in a manner that could be interpreted as anti-European.
Eight of the ten Cabinet members aocepted invitations today to hear Anthony Eden's "off-the-record" speech tomorrow at a National Press Club luncheon.
Miss Lucy Carlile Watson, local philanthropist, died at her home today in her eighty-fourth year. She was once named on a list of 100 prominent New York State women.

It is a shock to an American who has just arrived here from Brazil-where the United States and Germany are fighting tooth and nail for first. place, commercially and otherwise, among foreign nations dealing with the Braziliansto remember that, here in Argentina, the principal rival of democratic America is not totalitarian Germany but democratic Great Britain.

Today's events: Philadelphia Orchestra, Fritz Kreisler as soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Marcel Maas, pianist, Alfred Dubois, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30; Gunnar Johansen, pianist, McMillin Theatre, 4:30; Mendelssohn Glee Club, Waldorf-Astoria, evening;

The scholarship fund of the Brooklyn Music School Settlement will be augmented by a concert of sacred, folk and war songs by the Don Cossack Choir the night of Dec. 21 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
A double bill from Moliere was presented last evening at the Barbizon-Plaza by Le Theatre des Quatre Saisons, the Parisian players imported by the French Theatre of New York:

Plays, songs and stock in various enterprises owned in whole or in part by Earl Carroll, the theatrical producer, will be sold at public auction today at 11 .A. M. in the offices of Bankruptcy Referee Robert P. Stephenson in the United States Court House, Foley Square.
Traffic courts throughout the city were jammed yesterday as the police, starting a drive against illegal automobile parking, haled 5,086 persons to. the bar for violations over the week-end.

Albert Carre, under whose direction many operatic successes of the Opera Comique repertoire were produced, died today after an operation at the age of 86. M. Carre for twenty-three years directed the Opera Comique and for a time directed the Comedie Francaise.

The marriage of Miss Anne Elizabeth Kiley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kiley of Oneida, N. Y., to William'Escott Rudel, son of Mrs. Clarence M. Rudel of Montreal, Canada, and Pinehurst, N. C., and the late Mr. Rudel, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square.
Leasing of a large retail store location in the Fifth Avenue shopping district involving an aggregate rental of about $750,000 was reported yesterday.

The New York Americans will be seeking to retain an unbeaten record against the Detroit Red Wings when they engage their rivals from the Automobile City at Madison Square Garden tonight. In two games that have already gone into the record the Detroiters have failed of victory. The first saw the Americans score a 2-to-1 triumph. In the second the teams struggled through a 1-to-1 tie.
Gus Dorazlo, 189, Philadelphia, won the decision from Bob Pastor, 185, New York, in the ten-round windup of a boxing show before 6,000 fans tonight.

James McNeill, Governor General of the Irish Free State from 1928 to 1932 and the first Irish High Commissioner to London, died here today at the age of 69. He was a member of a committee appointed in 1922 to draft a Constitution for the Free State.
The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association dropped last week primarily because of weakness in food prices.

The lowest tax rates in the United States and Canada are levied by cities having the council-manager form of government, according to a survey of tax rates of 294 cities published yesterday in the December issue of the National Municipal Review.

Traffic accidents, fatalities and injuries in the city continued to drop last week and week-end compared with the figures covering the corresponding periods last year, it was announced yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department at headquarters.
It was officially announced tonight that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, would go to London for a "private visit to the governor of the Bank of England."

Certificates of deposit representing the entire funded debt bf the Seiberling Rubber Company will be sold at public auction by Adrian H. Muller Son, 18 Vesey Street, on Dec. 28, on behalf of the Chase National Bank as manager for a group.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 9: CAPTAINS Davis, G. E., the New York, to duty as Chief of Staff and Aide to the Commandant of the 13th Naval Dist., Seattle, Wash.. about Dec. 17.

Several points must be kept in mind in connection with the vote of cotton, tobacco and rice growers regarding the imposition of quotas for their respective crops. In the first place, the referenda do not, as Secretary Wallace seems to think, provide a "clear-cut example of economic democracy."
George Burns of the radio and screen team of Burns and Allen Npleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to two indictments voted and sealed last Friday charging him with smuggling.

Nick Camarata, 133, New Orleans, gained the decision over George Zengaras, 134, East Side, in the exciting feature eight-round fight on the card at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before 3,000 persons.
Sixteen of thirty-seven departments in New York department stores registered advertising gains in November, according to a compilation yesterday, based on Media Records figures.

Whenever, as in the present year, Autumn industrial recovery after a springtime reaction has been substantial, the main question asked is whether the upward movement will continue. On this point, there is always a certain skepticism.
After challenging the good faith of Democratic members of the City Council on their efforts to find jobs for 700 employes of the Sixth Avenue Elevated yesterday, Harry A.

Miss Jeannette D. J. Gordon, daughter of Mrs. David Gordon of this city and the late Mr. Gordon, has chosen Dec. 26 as the date for her marriage to Dr. Maxwell Ehrlich, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Joseph Ehrlich. The wedding will take place at Temple B'nai Israel. A reception will follow at the Gordon home.

Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Sibley Dow were dinner hosts in their home tonight to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, Colonel and Mrs. Wade H. Carpenter, Mrs. William Russell Huntley, Mrs. Edgar W. Ward Jr., Dr. Edmund Leroy Dow and B. Henry Pelzer.
Hiram Cavanagh, general manager of the Hotel Master, 310 Riverside Drive, died yesterday morning in Mount Sinai Hospital following an operation. He was born in P Bayonne, N. J., sixty-twoyears ago.

Frederick A. Ingalls, prominent for many years in Chicago industrial circles, died today at his Pebble Beach home at the age of 82. He formerly was president of the Buda Foundry and Manufacturing Company.
More German child refugees-this time 502 from Austria-arrived here today. Among them were fifty-one "non-Ayran" Christians and fortynine Catholics.

Persons close to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt disclosed today that she intended to pay income taxes on her future radio earnings although the Treasury has ruled them tax exempt because they were given to charity.

Chandler Mason Wood, lawyer, who was formerly prominent in banking and politics in Massachusetts, died here last night of a heart ailment. The late A. J. McQuatters, president of the 0. C. Cady lumber mills, asked Mr. Wood to move to Albuquerque, N. M., as general counselor.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, issued orders today which will send Richard T. Frankensteen and Wyndham Mortimer, recently reinstated vice presidents, to opposite sides of the United States.
Announcement of a $111,177 PWA grant toward construction of a $300,000 enclosed public market in Brooklyn was made yesterday by Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional PWA director.

Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Cutler of Brooklyn and Massapequa, L. I., celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage at a dinner given last night at Oetjen's, Church Avenue, Brooklyn, by their three sons and their daughter, Arthur N., William E. and John M. Cutler and Miss Edna Mathilda Cutler.

The annual report of the Rath Packing Company for the year ended Oct. 30, released yesterday, shows a net income of $1,334,443 after depreciation, obsolescence, Federal and State income taxes and other charges.

The Federal Trade Commission has entered orders to cease and desist from the misrepresentation of the fiber content of women's apparel against three New York City concerns, Gimbel Brothers, Inc., Lipman Brothers and A. De Pinna Company, Inc.
Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell has cabled from Honolulu acceptance of an invitation to become chairman of two American Olympia committees, the American Olymplo Association announced yesterday.
A considerable extension of trade,, but little exchange of free currency, is provided under a new Rumanian - German commercial agreement.

Affording to the newspaper Politiken, Crown Prince Frederik and Crown Princess Ingrid will visit the United States next Spring to see the New York World's Fair and preside at the Denmark Day festivities on June 5.

A card to which a .22 calibre bullet had been attached, warning its recipient to stop his "Jewish campaign," was received here today by August Tyler, district organizer of the Socialist party, at the party's headquarters, 34 Park Place.

Albert W. Pickford, a vice president of the Philadelphia National Bank, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Cynwyd at the age of 68. His banking career, during which he became known as an expert on credits, covered thirty-four years, from the time he became associated with the old Girard National Bank of this city.

A revolt led by City Commissioner Bert Daly of Bayonne threatened today to put a dent- in Mayor Frank Hague's powerful Hudson County Democratic machine that has been regarded by politicians throughout the nation as a model of organization."

The United States liner Washington, which is scheduled to sail tomorrow at noon for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg, is the principal ship taking mail for delivery in European countries before Christmas Day, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

Benjamin Bleiberg, proprietor of a vegetable market here, revealed today that Tyrone Power, the motion picture actor, had sent him a check for $500 to cover a personal debt of Mr. Power's father, Tyrone Power Sr., also an actor, who died in 1931.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, former chess champion of the world, who has accepted an invitation to compete in the annual tournament at Hastings, England, made a strong finish in the recent A. V. R. O. international congress in The Netherlands.
Wheat prices got off to a firm start in the pit here today, but failed to carry through to a good close. Final quostations were 1/8 to 1/4 cent a bushel lower, or about 1 cent under the early top.
Izvestia, the g government newspaper, reported today an alarming shortage of automobile transportation-in the United States.
MANHATTAN DANZIGER, SAMUEL (Nov. 27). Estate, not more than $13,000. To Harry Danziger, son, Northport, L. I., residue in trust. Truly Warner, 1,112 Park Ave., executor.

High school and college students have a keener interest in problems of government than do their elders, Governor Lehman told 550 members and guests of the Williams Club last night in appealing for assistance by colleges and universities in maintaining democracy against threatened dangers of today.

In less than a month after rich gold ore was discovered by Ed Herkelrath in the hills at the head of the main street through Randsburg, the Master Key group of claims, upon which the original strike was made, was acquired by, an Eastern syndicate represented by A. A. Turner, who heads the American Gold and Tungsten Corporation, which operates quartz and placer properties near Atolia.
Smith, Burris Co. of Chicago, New York and Los Angeles are to offer today a new issue of 74,148 nopar preference shares of the Domestic Finance Corporation at $28.50 a share.

During a day that found favorites beaten in the first four races but victorious in the last three, Joe W. Brown's 4-year-old Jewell Dorsett ran a splendid race to win the Kentwood Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

The PanAmerican conference today received a recommendation that it adopt the principle that foreign investors in Latin America are not entitled to diplomatic protection except in cases where justice is denied to them by local courts.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors Corporation, in a letter to stockholders accompanying yesterday's common dividend of 75 cents a share, says "little can be said from a factual standpoint at the time of this writing with regard to the fundamental trend of consumer demand."

Miss Margaret Livingston Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howell G. Lord of this city, will be married on Dec. 29 at the home of her parents to John Griswold Merrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Merrow, also of Newark.

Reorders on Christmas gift merchandise were received in heavy volume in the wholesale markets here t yesterday, representing the latest date in years at which volume business has been placed so close to Christmas.

Representatives of charitable and tenant organizations clashed yesterday with spokesmen for realty firms and savings institutions at a meeting of the Citizens Housing Council in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fifth Street.
A working rehearsal of part of Verdi's "Falstaff," which will be revived Friday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, was held yesterday afternoon for members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
A summary of the principal assets and liabilities of the reporting member banks, together with changes for the week and the year ended Dec. 7, 1938, follows:

Francis P. Clark, H. A. Warren, Mrs. Edward Kerbs, Logan Fulrath, A. J. Kinsman, Mrs. Lee Ellis in 965 5th Ave; Ralph P. Kinder, in 50 E 72d St; Kenneth A. Westervelt, in 225 E 73d St; Frank W. Nesbitt, in 315 E 68th St: Alfred Ely, through Douglas Gibbons Co, in 719 Madison Ave; Mrs. John Sweeney, In 779 Lexington Ave; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, broker.

Most livestock prices were lower today. Steers and yearlings sold at steady to 25 cents lower quotations; hogs were 10 to 25 cents off and fat lambs 15 to 25 cents lower, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. The steer top was $13.25, hog top $7.50 and lamb top $9.35.
The breakdown of solemn agreements and established order in the world was deplored today by Dr. John R. Mott of New York, who is presiding at the opening of the World Missionary Conference here.

Special Orders 156, dated July 7, an orders 2d Lt. Alfred E. Bohnert, Inf.-Res. to active duty with the CCC, effective July 9, and relieving him effective Jan. 8, 1939, is amended so as to order Lt. Bohnert to active duty with the CCC, effective July 9, and relieving him effective Dec. 24, 1938.

Mail orders received here yesterday were again heavy as retailers sought to round out their stocks for the peak holiday selling period directly ahead. Store representatives found in many instances that manufacturers were unable to take new orders and sought substitute goods available for quick delivery.
Judge Raymond MacNeille in Common Pleas Court 3 refused today to authorize the distribution of part of a $101,000 trust fund to claimants in Germany.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mrs. William Howard Taft, diplomats and high officials of the government and music lovers in all ranks of Washington society turned out today for the first of this season's concerts given by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at the Mayflower Hotel.

Mayor La Guardia, accompanied by Mrs. La Guardia, left Pennsylvania Station at 7:30 last evening for New Orleans, where the Mayor is scheduled to speak tomorrow afternoon before the twentieth annual convention of the American Farm Bureau Federation.

The first "Monday" of the Richmond German, this city's outstanding social event, took place tonight at the Commonwealth Club. It was preceded by a dinner at which white candles in tall, silver candelabra and centerpieces of poinsettias and snapdragons decorated the tables.
Thornton Wilder, playwright and author, had his second play and first farce, "The Merchant of Yonkers," starring Jane Cowl, open here tonight.

There is no provision in the law to permit the State Superintendent of Insurance, Louis H.: Pink, to sue the approximately 500 stockholders of the insolvent Westchester Title and Trust Company of this city, to recover $2,000,000, part of the sum due to holders of guaranteed claims against the company, according to argument put forward today by counsel for the stockholders.

The use of school buildings for meetings likely to develop controversies or cause dissension would be denied under a resolution to be presented before the Board of Education at its meeting tomorrow by Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, board member. The resolution follows:

Seward Ave (14-3598), n w cor of Taylor Ave, 125x100; De Sales Realty Co, inc, to Max Smith, 489 E 53d St. Calhoun Ave, 512 (181-5561); Falcon Holding Corp to Mary Reilly, 510 Calhoun Ave. 183d St, 784 E (11-3113); William Mildner to John H. H. Blohme, 6,017 Linden St, Brooklyn. Grote St (11-3100), s s, 100 ft w of Southern Boulevard, 66x114; East River Savings Bank to Achille Mancini, 2,456 Arthur Ave.

Chicago's sharpshooter, Johnny Gotteelig, picked up two assists last week and drew into a clear lead in the race for National Hockey League scoring honors, according to official figures released tonight.
Strong westerly gales and high head seas over the North Atlantic are causing inbound liners to arrive in New York from one to three days late.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain announced in the House of Commons today that the businessman's committee that is to advise the -government on means of speeding up the rearmament program will have direct access to Downing Street in case. of a disagreement between the industrialists and army, navy or air force officials.

King George, vacationing in London, telegraphed his choice for Archbishop of Athens today. It fell on Bishop Chrisanthos, formerly Bishop of Trebizond, who was one of three nominated last week by the Holy Synod on the understanding that the final appointment should have royal approval.

Continuing his systematic examination of each individual point at issue between Italy and France, Virginio Gayda in today's Giornale d'Italia takes up the question of Jibuti, French Somaliland port, and the railroad from that point to Addis Ababa, capital of Ethiopia.
The Dartmouth basketball team coasted to a 41-24 victory over Providence tonight. Dudis set the pace with nineteen points to his credit.
Samuel Weidenfeld, 46 years old, a furrier, ended his life yesterday by hanging himself from a water pipe in his shop on the sixteenth floor at 350 Seventh Avenue, near Twenty-eighth Street.

Four burglaries in this vicinity were reported today in. police teletype alarms. All occurred last night or early today and police said the same burglars probably were responsible. Windows of "dark"' houses were forced open and loot valued at $4,500 was stolen.

The board of directors of the united Fruit Company declared a special dividend of $1 a share. Including the four quarterly dividends of 75 cents each paid this year, declarations for 1938 will amount to $4 a share, the same as last year.

A meeting was held yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. Kenneth P. Budd, 773 Park Avenue, in the interests of the fourth exhibition of Amateur Needlework of Today, which will open on Jan. 11 in the House of Needlework at W. J. Sloane's, Fifth Avenue and Fortyseventh Street, and continue there through Jan. 21.

Jesse Eisen of the Model Brassiere Company has been elected president of the New York Corset Club. Others named were Thomas Reilly, Franco Corset Company, first vice president; Dan Leavitt, Best Form Brassiere Company, second vice president; Harold Schwartz, Venus Foundations, treasurer, and John J. Kearney, Corset and Underwear Review, secretary.
Thanks to America's regard for headline heroes, Douglas Corrigan, the jalopy flier, hardly needs to write to Santa Claus for anything.
There are signs that the pendulum is preparing to swing in the direction of recovery, Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, declared today in addressing the National Union of Manufacturers.
The only occupant of the Vatican's model jail, Mario Politi, went on trial before the Vatican Court today on charges of embezzling 608,000 lire while bookkeeper for the Vatican Library.
Holcombe Ward of New York, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, is slated to head the national organization for the third successive year in 1939.
Wilcox, in charge of the Department of Agriculture's efforts to subsidize the export of 100,000,000 bushels of wheat in this fiscal year, predicted today that the goal would be reached.
The Columbia Grammar quintet registered a 32-to-23 victory over Dwight School at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday. Robert Busto of the losers was high scorer with 12 points.

Under the auspices of its hospitality committee, the annual Christmas party of the Women's National Republican Club will be held the afternoon of Dec. 21 at the organization's headquarters, 3 West Fiftyfirst Street.

The week-end rally in the pound sterling and the French franc, which stemmed the steady decline earlier in the week, proved yesterday to be short-lived as pressure again centered on these two monetary units, both in the foreign exchange markets here and abroad.
Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, hailed today the Anglo-American trade agreement as "the effective reply to the defeatism which appeared in some quarters after the Munich settlement."
Manhattan Alteration Spring St, 312; to 1-story garage and loading station; Chemical Bank Trust Co, trustee, 165 Broadway. owner; A. R. Straker, architect: cost $9,000.

The Community Public Service Company, Fort Worth, Texas, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration. statement under the Securities- Act of 1933 covering 38;821 shares of. $25par common stock.
The Rev. John P. Mealey, rector of St. Gabriel's Catholic Church here, died today of a heart attack in the rectory at the age of 75.

The new constitution of the New York Curb Exchange and an interim amendment to be effective immediately and until the new constitution becomes operative on Feb. 23. were approved yesterday by the membership of the Exchange by a vote of 353 to 2.

Leon Trotsky, exiled Russian revolutionary, interviewed in his guarded villa near Mexico City by William R. Mathews, publisher of The Arizona Daily Star of Tucson, said the New Deal program "represents the culmination of the final contradictions in the decay and fall of capitalism."

The receipt of twelve bids for the fifth contract to be let on the circumferential parkway, which the city is financing with the aid of a $12,000,000 PWA grant, was announced yesterday by Robert Moses. Commissioner of Parks.
Colonel and Mrs. H. MurrayJacoby gave a dinner last night at their home, 1,165 Fifth Avenue, for the French Consul General in New York, Count Charles Ferry de Fontnouvelle.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had: 57--State of Mo., at the relation of Lloyd Gaines, petr., v. S. W. Canada, registrar of the Univ. of Mo. and the curators of the Univ. of Mo. On writ of cert. to the Supreme Court of Mo.

The drawing for a mural panel for the new Bronx postoffice, with a quotation from Walt Whitman that was criticized as irreligious Sunday by the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox of Fordham University, remained yesterday in the studio of the artist, Ben Shahn, at 300 East Eighty-ninth Street, but he did no further work on it, awaiting a visitor from Washington.

Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department, returned today after a transcontinental trip and took charge of preparations for the first test cases against employers alleged to have violated the law.

Rising above the 1937 figures for the first time this year, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in November scored an average gain of 1.4 per cent, according to a compilation yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

This evening from 8 to 11 an invitation preview of the Currier Ives show will be held at the Museum of the City of New York. This exhibition, restricted to "The New York Scene," is sponsored by the women's committee headed by Mrs. H. Casimir de Rham, chairman.

A German, Hans Heinrich Shackow, took the stand today in his own defense at his trial for unlawfully photographing coast defenses of the Panama Canal at Fort Randolph. He was arrested on Oct. 16 with three companions who are now awaiting trial.

Clinging tenaciously to the greased cables of an elevator in the Hotel Piccadilly at 227 West Forty-fifth Street, Dr. Konstantine Kostan slid 126 feet down the open shaft from the seventeenth floor and landed seriously injured on the top of the elevator at 5 A. M. yesterday.

Ruth Etting testified today that Martin Snyder, her husband for seventeen years, "told us this was the end of all three of us" just before Myrl Alderman, radio composer, was wounded at his North Hollywood home Oct. 15. Snyder meant her, Alderman and Snyder's daughter. Edith, the singer added.

To many Americans, no doubt, it will be news that the Presidency of the United States is the "strongest monarchy of our time," that this country's national unity has "long depended upon an elective monarchy of increasing authority (the Presidency)," and that in England, on the contrary, "active monarchy was so completely disappeared that its very nature is forgotten."
The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Inc., for the ten months to Oct. 31, released yesterday, shows a net loss of $1,615,919 after taxes, depreciation, interest charges, etc.
More than 600 meat handlers, members of Local 635 of the Meat Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, went on strike here yesterday for higher wages, recognition of the union and other demands.
The Italian Government today notified Italian newspaper men, estimated to number 200, they must cease serving foreign newspapers by Jan. 1.

Operations of the steel industry this week are scheduled at 57.6 per cent of capacity, compared to 59.9 per cent last week, a decline of 2.3 points, or 3.8 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Although no real political power is yet entrusted to the Supreme Soviet Parliament elected under the Stalin Constitution, its Deputies nevertheless are performing an important function in the State.
A conspiracy- to defraud Buffalo in the delivery of gravel for WPA-financed street projects was charged today by an extraordinary grand jury investigating city affairs.

Persons interested in the work of the Edward MacDowell Association in maintaining the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N. H., for creative artists, have taken over the performance of Thornton Wilder's play "The Merchant of Yonkers" on the night of Dec. 29 at the Guild Theatre to raise funds for the organization.

Offering will be made to the publie by an underwriting group of $7,750,000 first and refunding mortgage bonds 33/4 per cent series due in 1963, and $1,375,000 41/4 per cent serial notes due in 1940 to 1953 of the Green Mountain Power Corporation, a subsidiary of the New England Power Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Auchmuty Tucker gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 136 East Seventy-ninth Street, for two debutantes of the season-their niece, Miss Sarah Alden Derby, and Miss Leila Griswold Webb, a cousin of the host and hostess.

Directors of McKesson Robbins, Inc., demanded yesterday the immediate resignations of F. Donald Coster, president, and George E. Dietrich, assistant vice president and assistant treasurer, under threat of dismissal by next Monday.
Friends of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh said today that he had taken an apartment in Paris and settled down here with his family for the Winter.

Fiscal Fund, Inc., has sent a special notice to holders of Bank Stock Series and Insurance Stock Series St announcing its intention of trying ci to qualify as a "mutual investment fo company" under the Federal Revenue Act of 1938, "in order to obtain the most favorable tax status for its beneficial shares afforded companies of this type."

The Hosiery Dyers and Finishers Association has just issued its standard color card of fifteen shades for the Spring and Summer of 1939. There are two golden-blond tones, Carefree (named after the Astaire-Rogers film) and popcorn.

Coach Howie Stepp of Princeton is not hesitant in announcing that he is optimistic over the Tigers' chances of winning the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League title this season. A wealth of capable material is on hand to inspire his enthusiasm as he prepares the team for its debut early next month.

The Board of Trustees of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company voted yesterday to recommend at the annual stockholders' meeting on Jan. 17, 1939, a reduction in the capital stock from $10,000,000 to $6,000,000 and the reduction of the par value of its shares from $20 to $12.
To take service as American Ambassador to the Court of St. James is to hunt for high human achievement, distinction and trouble, and Joseph P. Kennedy has found them all.

Epidemics were feared today in the Central Philippines as deaths reported from Thursday's typhoon reached 302. The total continued to grow as commuuication systems were restored. Many persons were missing.

After a varied diet of sightseeing that included a survey of low-rent housing and slum-clearance projects in Brooklyn, a glimpse of Wall Street and a stroll through the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, boarded a train early this morning with his party for a three-day visit to Washington.

John Holley Clark, who was principal of the Flushing High School from- 1897 until his retirement in 1920, died last night at his home, 143-16 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Queens, after a five-days' illness due to his age, 88 years.
Suspended Without Pay To take effect from 1 P. M. Dec. 11: Fireman 3d grade Fred Nadell, Engine Co. 245.

Horace B. Holcomb, Essex County Supervisor of Weights and Measures for twenty-five years and in public life in Northern New Jersey for more than forty years, died yesterday at his home here after a week's illness. He was 79 years old.

Calvert Distillers Corporation is moving today in Supreme Court for an order punishing the Wall Street Liquor Corporation, a retailer, for contempt of court for alleged violation of a fair-trade agreement fixing retail liquor prices under the Feld-Crawford act. If any punishment is imposed it will be the first under the act.

The N. Y. U. varsity fencing team, intercollegiate three-weapon champion during five of the past six seasons, will engage in seven dual meets during the 1939 campaign before defending its title late in March, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics.

As N. Y. U. awaits tonight's inaugural basketball game against Upsala, Howard G. Cann, the Violet coach, who answers to the name of Jake, is looking ahead. Not just a few weeks in advance, but an entire season. For the veteran court mentor is not unduly concerned about the team's immediate success. That, according to Cann, will come in time.

The Catholic College Press Association, speaking for 17,000 Catholic college students, has adopted a resolution which says: "In this tragic hour for the Jew in Germany, Catholic students are impelled to express their deep anxiety over the rising tide of antiJewish feeling in the world.
Hans Frost, a tall, lean carpenter took leave of his family as usual early yesterday morning, in his second floor at 6,018 Seventh Avenue, in Brooklyn.

The National Labor Relations Board lost today when the Supreme Court refused to reopen a case by which the board sought to force the reinstatement of 145 seamen after a sit-down strike on two ships of the Peninsular Occidental Steamship Company.

Mrs. C. W. Jones had the unusual experience of hearingher own funeral services at the Methodist Episcopal Church in Moravia yesterday afternoon. The Rev. O. J. Fix of Burlington, former Moravia pastor, had been called to preach at Mr. Jones's funeral.

" Archives," says the author of a manual on their administration, "were not drawn up in the interest or for the information of posterity." That is true of national archives, such as those of the United States.

Peter Fick of the New York A. C. created a new pool record last night as he swam to victory in the 100yard free style event in the A. A. U. meet held under the auspices of the St. George Dragon Club at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
Dr. Edward S. Newell, a physician for many years in New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and the Pelhams, died of coronary thrombosis here today at his home. He was 70 years old.

For his unprecedented achievements on the tennis court, Don Budge remained at the top of the list as the country's foremost athlete of 1938, the first to win that distinction twice since the started in 1931.
James J. O'Connor, 27 years old, of 158 Saratoga Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday in Queens County Court, Long Island City, to a charge of manslaughter in the first degree.
The story of last night's performance of "Goetterdaemmerung" in the Metropolitan Opera House, which is a thrilling one, can be told principally in two words: Wagner and Flagstad. For Mme.

Manhattan's varsity swimming team will engage in nine dual meets this Winter, the junior varsity basketball squad will face seven rivals and the freshman quintet sixteen, according to the schedules announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics.
Carnegie Tech's football warriors pulled on their battle togs again today for a hard week of practice before heading South to the Sugar Bowl and the date with Texas Christian Jan. 2.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates being Dec. 12 unless specified: At San Diego: Tern, Dec. 11: Worden, Dec. 3: Antares, Alwin, Dale, Farragut, Lapwing, Sturgeon.
Thirty-eight Spanish sailors were held prisoners tonight by high waves aboard a sinking Spanish Government oil tanker off the coast of Southern France.

Japan's new Ambassador to the United States, Kensuke Horinouohi, former consul-general in New York, landed in Seattle today with assurances of peaceful relations between the two great powers of the Pacific "for generations to come."

Dr. George Van Ness Dearborn, a neuropsychiatrist who for many years was connected with the Veterans' Administration, died of a heart attack yesterday on the sidewalk in front of 76 Madison Avenue, while walking with his wife. He was 69 years old.

The two four-story apartment houses at 42-12 and 42-18 104th Street, occupying the entire blockfront between Forty-second and Forty-third Avenues, Corona, L. I,. have been sold by the Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association to Cahn Cahn, operators.

Albert Morris Bagby's 408th Musical Morning, held yesterday in the main ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria, attracted the usual large gathering of members of society. The artists were Elisabeth Rethberg and Ezio Pinza of the Metropolitan Opera and Mischa Elman, violinist.

With the competition reduced to the championship stage in seven of the eight classes, amateur boxers from New York shared top honors in the Eastern finals of the all-American tournament tonight at the Boston Garden.

The Philadelphia Record, in a copyrighted story, said tonight that Maurice J. (Clipper) Smith, coach of Villanova's undefeated football team, had rejected a three-year contract as head coach at Holy Cross College and had decided against a similar offer from Boston College.

Gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund from 237 contributors added $5,671.17 to its total yesterday and enabled it to pass a noteworthy milestone in its history. Yesterday's contributions brought the total amount that the Fund has received for its work of mercy in its twenty-seven-year history past the $5,000,000 mark.

Lloyds Bank, Ltd., London, announced yesterday through its New York representative that G. F. Abell, chief general manager, who, on Dec. 31, will retire after fortyfive years' service, had been invited to serve as a member of the board.
Mrs. Charlotte A. West Crane, widow of Thedron I. Crane, a Philadelphia industrialist, died of a heart attack today in her suite at the BellevueStratford Hotel. She was in her d early seventies.

Recommendations of the Federal Bar Association's alcoholic beverage law committee are expected to oppose an increase in taxes on alcoholic drinks, Jacob J. Glasser, committee chairman, announced yesterday.

Loews, Inc., motion-picture company, fails to write off its unused stories and rights as rapidly as good accounting practice suggests, according to testimony submitted yesterday in Supreme Court in connection with a minority stockholders' action for an accounting of the acts of company directors.
The National Council of Palestine Jews in a resolution today asked the Jewish Agency executive in London to reconsider its decision to enter the Arab-Jew round table discussions in London next month.

Business failures in the week ended Dec. 8 numbered 221, a gain over the preceding week's figure of 207, but a decrease from the 244 reported in the corresponding 1937 week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday.

The strike of platform men and checkers employed at long-distance truck freight terminals, which had brought with it the sympathy walkout of 1,000 out-of-town truck drivers and a virtual stoppage of long-distance trucking to and from the city, was settled yesterday as a result of intervention by Mayor La Guardia and the State Mediation Board.

Police Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan, who has threatened to make departmental revelations that will "shock New York," was released yesterday from the Brooklyn city prison after posting $25,000 bail in default of which he had been confined since Oct. 21 on charges of grand larceny in the theft of 7,200 arrest records from the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn on Oct. 15.

In a six-to-two decision, the Supreme Court today ruled in effect that Lloyd Gaines, a St. Louis Negro, must either be admitted to the Law School of the University of Missouri or a school of law must be established at Lincoln University, maintained by Missouri for the higher education of Negroes, to which he can be admitted.

The weather is the dominating military factor in Spain these days. Today again it was heavy along the Segre. The ground was too sodden for tanks, the ceiling too low for airplanes. So once more it was "all quiet on the eastern front."
Eldridge St. 197, 24.6x100x irreg; Dorothy Joseph et al to Bessie Kantrowitz, 226 E 5th St; p m mtg. $2,500 ($4.50).
Style settlements last week fell to 2,307, a decrease of 13.9 per cent from the number for the week before, the Joint Board, Dress and Waistmakers' Union, reported yesterday.

The first in the series of Coffee Dances for this season was held last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. Numerous dinners preceded the event, the hosts and hostesses taking their guests later to the club for coffee and dancing.

A sit-down strike to force adjustment of alleged grievances was started at the Home Relief Bureau station at 116 West Seventeenth Street at 5 P. M. yesterday, soon after the station had closed for the day.
The past few days have shown an unmistakable hardening of British public opinion and what looks at first glance like a stiffening of British Government policy toward Germany, Italy and Japan.

The season's second concert of the Beethoven Association, given last night at Town Hall, honored the memory of Maurice Ravel, who died a year ago. Four works, relatively early and late, made up the program.
Fannie Hurst, who has made a good deal of money from the sale of her novels to the movies, yesterday criticized Hollywood for its influence on literature.

Lou Nova, promising young heavyweight from the Pacific Coast, resumed training yesterday for his bout with Tommy Farr in Madison Square Garden Friday night. For the first time in his career, Nova faces a fifteen-round test, and his handlers have put him through a series of stamina-building exercises.

Count Rene Doynel de SaintQuentin, French Ambassador, opened yesterday afternoon at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street, an outstanding exhibition of French cultural history, comprising original drawings, autograph manuscripts, letters and documents, illuminated manuscripts and armorial bindings, from the time of Charlemagne to that of Napoleon.

Arthur Bliss Lane, United States Minister to Yugoslavia, Mrs. Lane and their daughter, Miss Margaret Lane, will arrive tomorrow on the Nieuw Amsterdam and will be at the Ambassador before going to Washington.

Committee members for the annual Miami-Biltmore Fashion Show and Ball, which will be given Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center, will meet this afternoon at the home- of Mrs. Sherman Post Haight, 64 East Fifty-fourth Street, to complete plans for the event.
Matthew Woll, a vice president of the American Federation of Labor, today pleaded for "unity of all Americans" in opposition to totalitarian rule and Nazi oppression in Germany.

The performance of "Spring Meeting," on Thursday night at the Morosco Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the work of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. Frederic W. Ecker heads the benefit committee.
T. J. Pendergast, Kansas City political leader, received a charter today, as did his son, T. J. Pendergast Jr., and P. H. McCrory, to oporate a distillery in Nelson County, tear Bardstown.
Financial circles, and more especially bankers, have foi some weeks been puzzled over the recent export of gold to Brazil.
At the annual meeting of the congregation of Temple Emanu-EI last night the following officers were elected: Lewis L. Straus, president; Sydney H. Herman and Roger W. Straus, vice presidents;

An overflow crowd of 4,500 persons attended a mass meeting here tonight in the Mosque Theatre, called by the recently formed Committee of 100 for the Defense of Human Rights to protest Nazi persecutions. The committee is made up of Essex County civic and religious leaders.

On April 26-there's a definite date for you-Dennis King says he will be producing on Broadway a new musical show. The authors: Fred F. Finklehoffe and John Monks Jr., who wrote "Brother Rat." The composer: Not yet chosen.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Hawley McLanahan will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League for Miss Elizabeth Gilbert Baldwin, principal of Highland Hall, Hollidaysburg, Pa.

Mr. and Mrs. Leo S. De Pinna of 375 Park Avenue have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Constance Vivian De Pinna, to Emerson Muschamp Bainbridge of Gledfield, Ardgay Rossshire, Scotland, which took place yesterday morning in Harrison, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by a justice of the peace.

With the conviction yesterday in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions of a man charged with violating the policy laws it was revealed that the prisoner had continued to operate what the police called "one of the largest policy banks in the city" while he was out on bail on a similar charge preferred by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

Mrs. Sophie de Voe le Page, a worker in the W. C. T. U. for sixtyone years, died today in her home at the age of 95. She had been president of the Mount Vernon branch of the union for thirty-eight years when she retired five years ago.
Mayor La Guardia administered the oath of office yesterday to four appointees whom he promoted in line with his policy of encouraging career men in city service.
Crossroads Farms, a sixty-acre estate in the town of Greenburgh, Westchester County, has been sold by the estate of Jerome Hanauer to a client of Percy M. Bibas, for occupancy.

Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator, today granted a temporary stay of any lay-offs on the Federal Arts Projects in New York, from which 1,500 out of a total of 8,500 workers were scheduled to be "separated" on Jan. 1.
Wreckers began preparations yesterday to demolish the twelve-story Fitzgerald Building and the George M. Cohan Theatre, on the southeast corner of Broadway and Forty-third Street.

Terming the Munich agreement a "blank sheet" on which either peace or war may be written, Paul van Zeeland, former Premier of Belgium, outlined his proposals for an economic approach to international peace to 1,400 members and guests of the Economic Club of New York last night at a dinner at the Hotel Astor.
Gaston B. Means, oft-time convict widely known for his $104,000 Lindbergh baby ransom hoax, died early today at the United States Medical Center here at the age of 58.
This city of about 850,000 population was threatened with a water famine tonight as a jurisdictional fight between two labor unions forced a shutdown of major pumping stations of the city waterworks.
Commodity prices registered a relatively sharp drop last week with The Annalist Index losing almost a point to close at 79.3 on Dec. 10, compared with 80.2 in the previous week.
The State Department made public today the registrations of twenty-three more firms or individuals who reported that they represented foreign principals in the United States.

Burleigh Brooks, Inc., distributor of photographic materials, announced yesterday that it would pay its employes about $20,000 in cash bonuses for Christmas. Last year the firm distributed $10,000 to its staff.

Burleigh Brooks, Inc., distributor of photographic materials, announced yesterday that it would pay its employes about $20,000 in cash bonuses for Christmas. Last year the firm distributed $10,000 to its staff.
Benjamin Friedman of 1,329 Conaga Avenue, Far Rockaway, an insurance broker, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, at the age of 69, after a threeweeks' illness.

A statement from Jose Maria Cantilo, Foreign Minister of Argentina, explaining why his nation was opposed to the attitude of the United States at the International Conference of American States at Lima, Peru, was broadcast last night over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

The first Junior League dinner dance for this season will take place Friday in the Great Hall of the league clubhouse. 221 East Seventy-first Street. Mrs. E. Bonner Bowring-is chairman of the committee.

Robert Clark, United States marshal, announced tonight he had received subpoenas from New York for thirteen motion-picture figures, ordered to appear at the trial there of William P. Buckner on a charge of using the mails to defraud. He said he would attempt to serve them immediately.
Frederick Hamilton McCormickGoodhart, Washington clubman, died today at his residence here at the age of 52.

Charles Mason Remey gave a dinner and musical tonight at his home here, 2,440 Massachusetts Avenue, for Rear Admiral Alfred W. Johnson, U.S.N., commander of the Atlantic fleet, and Mrs. Johnson. The host was assisted in receiving by Mrs. Gracie Richards.

The Roosevelt Administration was denounced yesterday as "one of the most reactionary in American history" by Dr. William Starr Myers, Professor of Political Science at Princeton University. He spoke at the Women's National Republican Club's School of Politics at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

While former Governor Nathan L. Miller of New York, William Macaulay, the Irish Free State Consul General in New York, who represented President Eamon de Valera, and many other notables looked on, the body of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, wife of the Irish Free State Minister to the Vatican, was entombed today in the chapel of the Jesuit Novitiate of St. Isaac Jogues, at Wernersville, near here.
