THE Giants were playing the Redskins in Washington early this season before the largest crowd ever to see a professional football game in the capital. The youthful Jack Mara, president of the New Yorkers, strolled out on the field before the battle with George Preston Marshall, grand high mogul and panjandrum of the Redskins.

A $45,500 first mortgage on the 6-story apartment house at 1,810 Weeks Ave., Bronx, has been arranged for the Tremont Central Corp., Jack Ferman, president, by Quinlan Leland, brokers. The American Baptist Home Mission Society is the mortgagee.
Paramount today was negotiating with Carole Lombard for her to play the lead in the screen version of "The Light That Failed," which William Wellman will produce and direct, starting about Feb. 1.

Churchgoers were asked in a resolution adopted yesterday by the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States to urge Grover A. Whalen to keep the World's Fair closed on Sunday. The resolution, adopted at the alliance's fiftieth anniversary meeting, also applies to the San Francisco fair.
A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank received yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,524,000 city of Baltimore, Md., water, airport and viaduct bonds on a bid of 100.357 for 21s.

The defeat of A. E. Watt of the Jackson Heights club in yesterday's quarterfinal round left only one seeded player for the semi-finals tomorrow in the Long Island championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association, which is being played at the Jackson Heights Squash Club.

Eldridge St, 197, 24.6x10Oxirreg; Bessle Kantrowitz to Dorothy Joseph, 134 E 24th St, et al; p m mtg, 5 yrs, 4 per cent; $2,500. Norfolk St, 148, 25x100: Grandis Holding Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, p m mtg, demand, int per bond; $17,052.
Automobile output last week increaed more than seasonally and the adjusted index advanced to 94.1 from 92.1. For the week ended Dec. 11, 1937, the index stood at 89.0.

The vote of Southern cotton farmers to retain acreage control and marketing quotas was predicated on experience with three growing seasons, each of which had taken the world's supply of cotton to a new high record. As a result surpluses were piling up, foreign market demands lessening and prices diminishing.

Stockholders of the White Sewing Machine Company at a special meeting in Cleveland yesterday approved the recapitalization plan of March 5 and authorized the direc- Less tors to declare the plan operative upon securing the required number Des of assents from preferred stockholders.

The long fight by Thomas J. Mooney to persuade the Supreme Court to review his sentence of life imprisonment for participation in the Preparedness Day bombings in San Francisco met defeat today when the court once more refused to intervene.
Seabiscuit, conqueror of War Ad- s miral in their famous match race, gained another victory over the son of Man o' War when he was acclaimed the outstanding horse of the year.

The TVA has offered $67,000,000 to be paid by itself and local public agencies in the Tennessee Valley for the electric property of the Tennessee Electric Power Company, and Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, holding company which owns the T. E. P. C., has indicated he wants about $90,000,000, according to testimony before the Congressional investigating committee today by J. A. Krug, TVA chief power planning engineer.
The Cubs will pay the salary of the Brewers' manager under a working agreement unique in baseball between the National League champions and the local American Association club.

The controversy over the merits of the so-called Torrens system of State registration of land titles comes to the fore again with the publication of an exhaustive study of title registration made by Professor Richard R. Powell of the New York Law Society.

The singing of Christmas carols by the uniformed "bobbies" of London Terrace, and the reading at a candlelight ceremony of Clement C. Moore's "A Visit From St. Nicholas" will be features of the ninth annual London Terrace Christmas Eve party which will be held at the development under the auspices of the Chelsea Charities.

R. V. Fletcher, general counsel for the Association of American Railroads, told the Senate profit-sharing committee today that incentive taxation might help to release a tremendous backlog of railroad-equipment purchases that would put 500,000 men to work in the heavy industries.
Because she thought more of an animal's life than her own possessions, Miss Ersilia Giubelei received yesterday the American Humane Association's medal for valor.

Senator Murray of Montana, one of the loyal New Deal Senators, came out today for President Roosevelt for a third term, following in the footsteps of Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania and Smathers of New Jersey.

Secretary Ickes recommended today that the Department of Justice cancel eleven trust funds, aggregating $2,805,000 for the benefit of Oklahoma Indians, set up with the Commerce Trust Company of Kansas City.

Reporters found President Roosevelt in a fun-making mood today. When one correspondent asked him about forthcoming appointments to high office, he replied that they were coming to a head. That, he added, is what happens to a boil.
The Hudson County political battle continued today with the disclosure that Mayor Lucius F. Donohoe of Bayonne would be Appointed tomorrow to the $6,000-a-year post of county physician.

The twenty-ninth annual meeting of the Chase Bank Club, a social organization of employes of the Chase National Bank, was held last night in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman, and H. Donald Campbell, president of the bank, were the guests.

Police Commissioner Valentine denied emphatically yesterday charges made the day before by counsel for Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan, who is accused of the theft of 7,200 arrest records from the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn.

Thomas E. Murray Jr. was elected yesterday a trustee of the Bank of New York. The Pennroad Investors Committee announced yesterday through its chairman, Kenneth S. Guiterman, 120 Broadway, the retention of Daniel 0. Hastings of Delaware, as its counsel in Wilmington, Del.

Maxie Berger, 1412, Montreal, holder of the Canadian lightweight title, registered his fifteenth straight victory by beating Frankie Cavanna, 148, East Side, in eight rounds before 4,500 fans at the Broadway Arena last night.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,245,100 barrels, compared with 3,223,650 in the previous week, an increase of 21,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The Long Island University women's basketball team has arranged a five-game schedule for its first intercollegiate campaign. The team is coached by Mrs. Marie Mueller. Fourteen co-eds make up the squad, which will begin its season

G. LeRoy Kemp, defending himself against a conspiracy charge, testified today that former Highway Commissioner John A. Macdonald ordered him to avoid condemnation proceedings while acting as State land purchasing agent for the Merritt Parkway.

A nation-wide tour undertaken by the violinist, Mischa Elman, has been sponsored by a national committee under the chairmanship of Alfred E. Smith for the purpose of rehabilitating the victims of Nazi persecution.
The Interstate Commerce Commission issued yesterday a compilation of earnings of 141 Class I steam railways in the United States or October and ten months, compared with those of a year before.
Bert Hanson, an attorney long active as a leader of civic reform forces, died yesterday in his home at 925 West End Avenue at the age of 71. He had been ill for several months of a heart ailment.
Organized labor, represented by the Federacion Libre, which is affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, wants the Wages and Hours Law enforced, according to a memorial published today.

Twelve Hunter College undergraduates have been elected to Alpha Chi Alpha, honor fraternity of the social science department of the college, Adelaide Keller, president, announced yesterday. The new members will be initiated tonight at 2 Park Avenue.
Passing along to stockholders profits realized from sales of securities, the State Street Investment Corporation declared, yesterday, a special dividend of $5 a share, payable Dec. 20.
Ruth St. Denis has delivered to Harper the copy for her autobiography, "Ruth St. Denis, an Unfinished Life," scheduled for publication on March 23.
Monroe St. 131, 28x100; Audrey Equities, Inc, to the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; p m mtg. demand, int per bond, $16,063.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway placed orders today for 25,000 tons of steel rails and the Pere Marquette Railroad ordered 3,250 tons for its own Spring program. The orders were placed with the Carnegie-Illinois and Bethlehem Steel Corporations and the Inland Steel Company, the affiliated roads announced.

George Kondolf, director of the WPA Federal Theatre Project in New York, was accused yesterday by a committee representing twenty-five WPA deputies of the Actors Equity Association of ignoring the fundamentals on which the governmental theatre was founded three years ago.
The candy business is good and is improving, members of the Western Confectionery Salesmen's Association agreed unofficially today as they gathered for their twenty-fourth annual convention.

A shortage of workers in many of the more highly technical and specialized shipbuilding trades caused the Navy Department to take special steps today in the face of the need to speed up the great naval program now under way and prepare for the additional construction which the next session of Congress is expected to vote.

Young Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis has been chosen the outstanding woman athlete of the year by forty-five of the sixty-seven sports writers participating in the eighth annual Associated Press poll.

Charles Towner Rooot of 2 West 67th Street, retired publisher of trade periodicals, died yesterday in a private hospital in Brooklyn. He was born in North Reading, Mass., 4ighty-nine years ago, a son of George Frederick Root, who wrote the words and music of "The Battle Cry of Freedom," "Tramp, Tramp, Tramp," and other Civil War songs.
With traders claiming to see a hopeful turn in the international situation, the stock market became more cheerful today with more active trading and improvements in nearly all sections.

A practical demonstration of the handling qualities of the new Chrysler "fluid drive" was given yesterday to automobile editors and special writers at a luncheon meeting at the Travers Island clubhouse of the New York Athletic Club.

Judge Richard Iobst today sentenced Carl Sohlgren, a Swede, to jail for thirty days and declared the Court might have been lenient had the defendant made any move toward becoming a citizen during the six years he has been in the United States.

Rookie Frank Brimsek's stretch of perfect goaltending, which had reached three shut-outs, was snapped tonight while his first-place Boston Bruins were turning back the Canadiens, 3 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before 13,000 at the Boston Garden.

Long-term loans aggregating $15,000,000 for South American expansion have been arranged by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, in the form of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent notes, it was announced yesterday.
Archibald B. Roosevelt Jr., grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt, and six other Harvard undergraduates last night formed a PanAmerican scholarship committee.
Walter Stewart, Connecticut State manager for Schenley Distillers Corporation, has been appointed general field supervisor. He will act as field aide to J. L. Leban, assistant general sales manager.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 10: CAPTAIN Stone, E. S., the Argonne, to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C., Dec. 27.

The Civil Aeronautics Authority will hold a hearing Dec. 21 on a proposed agreement between United Air Lines and Western Air Express to lease equipment from one another to provide through sleeper service between New York and Los Angeles over the two lines in the same manner that the railroads operate pullman cars.

The will of Everett S. Noble, 35-year-old Harvard Law School graduate, who committed suicide Dec. 3, after preparing a diary describing his last moments on earth, leaves his body to the Harvard Medical School.

Paced by Art Jackson, who scored three goals, the New York Americans returned to their winning ways last night at the expense of the Detroit Red Wings. Red Dutton's crew of skaters, last victorious on Nov. 26, seemed to do everything right against the hapless Wings, and skated off with a decisive 5to-1, triumph in Madison Square Garden.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, Miss Margot Lumb of England, Miss Eleonora Sears of Boston and Mrs. Stewart Iglehart of Westbury, L. I., advanced to the semi-finals of the ninth annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championships today.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold through the Bulkley Horton Company, brokers, the following Brooklyn properties:

Mexico today joined forces with the other Latin-American republics that expect the Pan-American Conference to be an instrument of the Good Neighbor Policy by adopting some measure or a set of measures denying diplomatic protection for foreigners' investments.

Seven orphaned children smiled happily yesterday as they sat in a cozy five-room apartment in the Bronx enjoying their first homecooked meal since last Wednesday, when they began a 3,500-mile trip to this city from Oregon in search of foster parents.
Chinese troops reported today that they had recovered virtually all the territory they had lost in Hunan Province since the Japanese occupation of Yochow on Nov. 12.

Competition for the coveted Cartier Trophy, won last year by Salle Santelli, dwindled from sixteen folks teams to four last, night at the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C. A., where the preliminary rounds were held.

The concert, given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, for the benefit of its pension fund last night in Carnegie Hall, was signalized by some fine orchestral performance, but, above all, by a new demonstration of the triumphant and unparalleled art of Fritz Kreisler.

The prediction that business would be definitely better in 1939 than It was in 1938 was made here today by Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, in his annual address on the prospects for the coming year, before the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce.

The doors of the Statue of Liberty will be opened to the public tomorrow morning after having been closed twenty months during repair work. During this period visitors were permitted on Bedloe's Island, but were not allowed to enter the statue.

The four-room second-floor apart ment at 6,018 Seventh Avenue Brooklyn, where Hans Frost and his family had lived was empty and still all day yesterday. The bodies of Mrs. Mary Frost, 26 years old 3-year-old Walter, and Arnold, the baby, lay in a funeral parlor.

A jury in the Federal Court in Brooklyn before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz yesterday returned a verdict of not guilty against three former WPA workers charged with embezzlement in connection with the sale of tickets of the WPA Circus, a unit of the Federal Theatre Project.

A movement to get the American Bar Association and State and local bar associations throughout the country to go on record as protesting against "the continuance of the inhuman treatment by the German Reich of innocent men, women and children" was launched last night by the Association of the Bar of the City of New.York at a closed meeting at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Cornelius J. Hayes, an artist and a member of the printing firm of Malcolm Hayes, died on Monday at his home, 351 Eighty-second Street, Brooklyn. A native of County Cork, Ireland, he had lived in Brooklyn most of his life and as a young man studied art at Adelphi College and worked for Tiffany's as a young artist.
Commercial and industrial failures in the week ended Dec. 8 were lower in four groups and higher in one than in the corresponding week of 1937, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

The plan for dissolution of the Pathe Film Corporation failed of adoption yesterday, with only 55 to 60 per cent of the shares represented in person, or by proxy' at the special meeting at 30 Rockefeller Center. An assent of 80 per cent of the shares was needed to consummate the plan.

Germany and Italy are continuing in radio broadcasts and press dispatches printed here to attack the United States as the Lima conference progresses. They warn that "Yankee imperialism is motivated by mercenary economic considerations."
Cuba has proposed calling a world economic conference in an attempt to find solutions. for world problems by extension to them of the remedies worked out at the Pan-Amierican conference here.

A questionnaire sent to prospective investors throughout the country by the National Association of Manufacturers has shown that a large majority of those reached have funds to invest but are reluctant to buy new securities in private corporations because of the remote prospect of adequate profit under taxation and restrictive legislation, George H. Houston told a meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Statistical Association last night.

Yesterday we reported that news of the success or failure of deer hunters in the southern tier counties had been rather -scarce, but we have just received a few interesting facts from the Conservation Department.

Plans for two apartment houses and a number of small dwellings in Queens were among the projects filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday. One house, to go up in Astoria, is estimated to cost about $825,000 and the other, to be erected in Forest Hills, about $226,600.

The introduction of the anticipated enabling bill in Parliament today and Premier Rudolf Beran's program speech signalized CzechoSlovakia's passing from the ranks of the democratic States to become authoritarian.

The Paramount Fire Insurance Company, New York, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 50,000 shares of $1 par value 25-cent cumulative preferred stock and 2,500 shares of $100 par value common stock and interim receipts for preferred and common.
Mrs. Charles Freeman Shelden gave. a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 270 Park Avenue, for members and friends of the Academy of American Poets.

Since Hitler came into power, 800 organizations have been formed in this country with the dual purpose of spreading anti-Semitism and undermining the democratic form of government, the Rev. L. M. Birkhead, national director of Friends of Democracy, charged yesterday.

In the notice of the graduation and promotion exercises of the Police Department in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday it was said that they would take place tomorrow at 8 P. M. in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue at Twenty-sixth Street.

Suggestions made by leading retailers here for the betterment of relations between the Parisian couturiers and American style houses, including steps dealing with the renting of original models, will be presented to members of the French couture by Raymond Barbas, general manager of the Patou organization.

The Central Bank has removed the official exchange rate of four sucres forty-five centavos for German aski marks and offers to sell at demand prices to unload large holdings of that script, which is usable only for the purchase of German goods.

To date the Brooklyn College basketball team has shown little that might stamp it a threat against any of the metropolitan district powers that be. In fact, Artie Musicant, coach of the Kingsmen, says he is keenly disappointed in the play of his charges, who have won two games and dropped a like number thus far.

Business was generally only fair to slow in locally dressed meats yesterday. Fresh pork cuts showed some weakness. The markets in other classes of traefer meats showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef -to be strong to slightly higher and other. classes about steady with Monday's close.

Mrs. E. Clowes Chorley, wife of the rector of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church, Garrison, N. Y., died yesterday at the rectory after a long illness, according to announcement made here last night. For the last thirty years she had been organist and choir director of the church.

Mrs. Charles Allen Judkins of Clearwater, Fla., formerly of this city, has announced here the marriage of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Judkins, to Richard Glenn Kibbey, which took place on Nov. 16 in Edinburgh, Scotland.
The expropriation of property belonging to Jews throughout Slovakia is foreshadowed in an editorial in the Slovak Government organ, Slovak, written by the government's propaganda chief, Sano Masch.

UNITED STATES The United States Civil Service Commission has announced open competitive examinations for the positions named below. Two closing dates are given: The first date, (a), for applications received from States east of Colorado; the second date, (b), for applications received from Colorado and States westward.

Trustees of the First National Bank of Bradley Beacn announced a dividend of 5 per cent today to depositors of the institution who waived their claims in order to permit reopening of the bank when it closed in 1932.

Today's events: "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 P. M.; People's Chorus of New York, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Muriel Dickson, soprano, Town Hall, 3; Don Cossack Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Benny Goodman and orchestra, and John Erskine, lecturer, Town Hall, 5:30;

Wheat futures held within a narrow range today, although quotations reflected an easier undertone largely in consonance with the trend in foreign markets. Closing quotations on the Board of Trade here were at net losses of 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel.

Dr. Max Baruch, a surgeon who had practiced here since coming from Germany in 1923, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in his office at 122 East Eighty-second Street, where he also resided. He was 54 years old.

A union contract under which employes agree to risk 5 per cent of their wages on the prosperity of their employer during the current fiscal year was announced last night as ending the month-old strike at the plant of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company in Brooklyn.
Aloysius J.Hanley, secretary-treasurer of the Wilcolator Company, a thermostat manufacturing firm of Newark, died at his home here late yesterday. He was born here fortysix years ago.

Declaring that the "New Deal is finished," although it will go on for two more years, Bruce Barton, New York Congressman and chairman of the board of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, declared yesterday that it must be followed by an administration which can unite all factor and expand our economy.
Commenting on Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech at Lima, Peru, the newspaper Asahi describes it as "pouring the old wine of the Monroe Doctrine into new bottles."
The Hershey Cubs defeated the New York Rovers, 5 to 4, In an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight.

Passenger automobile registrations for the first ten months of this year totaled 2,207,145, a gain of 24,069 over the corresponding period of 1937, it was announced yesterday by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau.

In his radio broadcast last night from London Prime Minister Chamberlain sought to dispose of the criticism that his policy of appeasement with the dictatorships of Europe is based in any way on admiration of their methods or a desire to have England follow their example.

Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italy's Foreign Minister, has accepted Regent Nicholas Horthy's invitation to come to Hungary for a hunting party. He is expected to arrive before Christmas. It has not yet been decided whether his wife will accompany him.

While heating and plumbing equipment has maintained the increased volume of business which started about two months ago, activity in the field is not as great as would seem to be called for by new building figures, manufacturers pointed out d yesterday.

Overseas sales of General Motors cars and trucks to dealers declined 11 per cent in November from the same month in 1937, the corporation reported yesterday. Last month's total was 26,050 units. The figures announced included products of the corporation's American, Canadian,

Jacob Felbel, an authority on patents and typewriter inventor, with offices at 40 Worth Street, who formerly was with the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company and with the Remington Typewriter Company and its predecessors, died Monday in his home at 216 West Eighty-ninth Street after an illness of several months.

The Marquess of Londonderry, one of the foremost advocates in this country of "understanding" with Germany and a personal friend of Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, called on Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today to give a specific pledge that "we are not prepared to sacrifice an inch of territory or one individual" to Nazi colonial demands.

Deputy State Commissioner of Education Walter M. May of this city and Mrs. May have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ruth May, to George Christie Monell, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Monell, also of Concord.

Miss Helene Rains, national 500yard free-style champion, and Miss Elizabeth Ryan, metropolitan 100yard free-style titleholder, shared honors in a members' meet in the Women's Swimming Association pool last night.

The French military mission that had been in Czecho-Slovakia ever since the foundation of the republic in 1918 has been dissolved and its chief general, Louis Eugene Faucher, and his staff will leave for Paris within a few days.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Our purpose in commenting recently on Mr. Moses's housing proposals was not to engage in a controversy but to clarify some basic issues. As his reply raises certain new aspects, we feel this further letter is in order.
Exports of sugar from Cuba this year to Dec.*10 amounted to 2,746,050 long tons, raw value, compared with 2,490,725 tons correspondingly last year, according to advices received by Lamborn Co.

Miss Shirley Ruth Foote, debutante daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Merrill N. Foote of 405 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, will be introduced to society at a supper dance to be given by her parents at the Cafe Louis XIV, Rockefeller Center, on Dec. 27.

MANHATTAN TRANSFERS Peck Slip, 10, 21x57.9: Title Guarantee Trust Co and ano, trustees, to Adelaide H. Ford, 2,121 Broadway, San Francisco, Calif. Washington St, 442-8, and Desbrosses St, 32-321/2, 80.2x110.6xirreg; 442 Washington St to Abr. M. Essenfeld, 250 Northern Ave, and Jos. Essenfeld, 825 Gerard Ave ($1).

The University Club Class B squash racquets team turned back the Harvard Club, 3 to 2, last night and took first place in Group I ofthe Metropolitan League. The Harvard Club, previously unbeaten, dropped to second place.

Buddy Hassett, the first-base orphan of the Dodgers, found a home yesterday when Executive Vice President Larry MacPhail and Manager Leo Durocher completed a deal with President Bob Quinn and his pilot, Casey Stengel, that will put the Bronx Thrush in a Boston Bee uniform.

Considerable improvement in curbing the smoke nuisance has been made throughout New York City, but constant vigilance and careful planning over a period of years are needed if the city's atmosphere is to be cleansed of soot, Sol Pincus, deputy commissioner of the Health Department in charge of smoke abatement work, told a meeting of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association yesterday at the Hotel Barclay, 111 East Forty-eighth Street.
Japan's increasing influence in Siam was the subject of some discussion when the Chamber of Deputies today ratified treaties of friendship and trade replacing the old French accord with Siam.

Premier Miron Cristea early this morning called a Cabinet session for late today to devise new regulations for the control of Jews. Rumania apparently was seeking measures half way between the pronounced anti-Semitism of the
Igor Sikorsky, aircraft designer and manufacturer, who has been in Europe for three months studying aviation developments, returned yesterday on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line.

The present drive of the Police Deapartment against overnight parking serves as a useful reminder of a growing evil. It may even put a damper on curbstone garaging in the business sections of the city. But it cannot solve the whole problem.

BEFORE THE WIND, by Wilbert Snow. (Gotham House, $3.50.) A poem depicting village life on the Maine coast a generation ago. Illustrations by Gordon Grant. DEAD RECKONING, by Kenneth Fearing. (Random House, $1.25.) Poems.
The problems involved in maintaining the North American export market for wheat were discussed here today at the Prairie Markets Conference by Canadian and American authorities.

Fifth Avenue stores, in keeping with the plan of the World's Fair to celebrate New Year's as "The Dawn of a New Day," will reveal on Dec. 28 window displays designed on the motif of "The Dawn of a New Day on Fifth Avenue--The City's Greatest Retail Shopping Street."
Dr. and Mrs. Charles J. Meierhoffer of this city have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Meierhoffer, to Anderson Force Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. K. Evans.

The first victory of the Fair Grounds meeting for the Le Mar Stock Farm came in the sixth and feature race today when the gelding Maleman, backed into 13-to-10 favoritism, scored by a neck over Dedication. Chanting was third.

Al Reid of the Bronx outpointed Paul Lee of Indianapolis in the feature eight-round bout at the. New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before a crowd of 3,610. Reid, who weighed 128 pounds, had a safe margin in a well-fought battle. Lee scaled 125.

The Michael Chekov Theatre Studio, through Miss Beatrice Whitney Straight, has leased the grounds and buildings of the former Ridgefield School, Ridgefield, Conn., from Jan. 1 to Sept. 30, 1940. The lease was closed with Roland J. Mulford, trustee and former headmaster of the Ridgefield School.

O. O. McIntyre, whose daily column, ."New..York Day by Day," appeared in 550 newspapers in the United States, Canada and Hawaii, left a gross estate, before deducting debts, funeral and administration expenses, of $94,819, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The net estate was put at $72,456. Mr. McIntyre died Feb. 14.

Considerable gains in the fight against cancer have been made in the last year, Dr. John M. Swan of Rochester, executive secretary of the New York State Committee of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, today told the committee here.

The House of Commons by a vote of 151 to 104 tonight granted Captain A. H. M. Ramsay, Conservative, permission to introduce a bill to make it illegal for shareholders in news agencies, newspapers and periodicals to register behind the screen of agents.

Mrs. Eleanor Smith, 73-year-old mother whose silence for ten years shielded her son from murder charges, interrupted her trial with a guilty plea today and received life imprisonment for the 1928 slaying of James Eugene Bassett.

William F. Bleakley, County Executive-elect of Westchester, announced today his selection of Herbert C. Gerlach of Ossining for appointment Jan. 1 as Commissioner of Finance under the new county charter.

Mrs. Virginia Frazer Boyle, poet laureate of the United States Confederate Veterans and well-known author, died here today at the age of 75. Mrs. Boyle, wife of Thomas R. Boyle, Memphis attorney, had been ill for two weeks.

An echo of the recent sensational race for the American Kennel Club's annual award for the best American-bred was heard yesterday at the meeting of the board of directors of the governing body of dog shows when the rules governing the award were changed greatly.

After being deadlocked for sixteen-and-a-half hours, a General Sessions jury reported yesterday that it could not reach a verdict in the case of four men who had been on trial for three weeks charged with the fatal shooting of Police Sergeant Timothy Murphy on Sept. 14, 1931, in the hold-up of a restaurant at 18 East Thirteenth Street.

Police Captain Thomas F. Farley, commander of the Webster Avenue Station in the Bronx, applied to Commissioner Valentine's office yesterday for retirement because he has passed the age limit of 63 years. The application probably will be acted upon within a few days.

Julius Goldman, a retired lawyer who was a founder of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and for many years chairman of its budget committee, died yesterday at his home, 132 East Seventieth Street. He was born in Philadelphia eightyfive years ago.

Three valuable fish-the only ones of their kind ever brought to this country-that have large brains ranking next to those of human beings and anthropoid apes in proportion to the size of their bodies, have been acquired by the Aquarium, it was announced last night by Dr. Charles M. Breder Jr., acting director.

State and city health officials and private physicians, representing State and county medical societies, opposed compulsory health insurance but endorsed voluntary insurance plans yesterday before the New York State Temporary Commission to Formulate a Health Program at a hearing in the Bar Association Building.

French Line ships resumed normal schedules with the departure of the Champlain from Havre yesterday with its regular civil crew, according to M. Morin de Linclays, resident general manager of the company in the United States and Canada.

Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Dec. 14. LIEUTENANT William G. Murray, Ofrice of the Fifth Deputy Commissioner, Designated as Acting Captain. Temporary Assignments For sixteen days, from 8 A. M., Dec. 16. LIEUTENANT Charles R. Michie, from 5th Division to Emergency Service Division, assignment to desk duty continued. From commands indicated to Juvenile Aid Bureau:

With few exceptions, bans on illegal parking apply to every one, including public officials, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday, pointing out that only cars being used in emergency work by the city or public service corporations were exempt.
The smaller Chicago retailers, particularly in the furniture, fur and jewelry lines, are greatly wrought up over the growing practice of "buying at wholesale,"

C. P. Cooper, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, told a Senate committee today that he believed profitsharing would tend to exaggerate the peaks and valleys of industrial booms and depressions, and that incentive taxation, to encourage profit-sharing, was "unsound" as a national policy.

The unbeaten Newtown and Jamaica High School basketball teams continued to set the pace in the Queens division of the Public Schools Athletic League tournament as both accounted for triumphs yesterday.

G. Walter Kinzley of this city died last night at his home after suffering a stroke. He was 68 years old. Mr. Kinzley was the son of Captain Joseph Kinzley, an authority on Bergen County history. He was a retired employe of the Bell Telephone Company.

The Birmingham Gas Company announced yesterday that 20,884 shares of preferred stock, or 74 per cent of the amount necessary for consummation, had been deposited in favor of the amended plan of recapitalization.
The board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters adopted unanimously a resolution today that liquor advertising be discontinued by all radio stations.
Clark Gable said tonight that his estranged wife, Mrs. Rhea Gable, probably would file suit for divorce as soon as the courts legally interpreted a property settlement made three years ago.

The annual Yuletide tea of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York will be held tomorrow at its headquarters, 65 Liberty Street. Serving on the reception committee will be Mrs. Richard W. Lawrence, Mrs. William J. Graham, Miss Mary Graham, Mrs. Winchester Noyes, Mrs. A. Wellington Taylor, Mrs. H. Boardman Spalding, Mrs. J. Barstow Smull, Mrs. Frederick E. Hasler, Mrs. Charles T. Gwynne and Mrs. LeClanche Moen.

A. O. Stewart of San Francisco, president of the Pacific Coast Mortgage Company, yesterday was elected a director and chairman of the board of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation at a meeting held here.

Metro took cognizance of the rearmament program of the United States when it announced pruchase today of "Thunder Afloat" by Ralph Wheelwright, an executive of the studio's exploitation department, and Commander Harvey Haislip.

A large furnished apartment of twelve rooms and four baths at 4 East Seventy-second Street has been leased to Lynde Seldon, executive vice president and director of the American Express Company, Inc., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers. Details of other apartment rentals follow:
President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave tonight the first official dinner of the season, entertaining seventy-two guests in honor of the members of the Cabinet and their wives.

The Italian liner Rex, leaving today for Mediterranean ports, will have among her passengers William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy; Admiral Giuseppe Cantu, Italian High Commissioner for the World's Fair, and Italo E. Verrando, general manager of the Italian Line in the United States.

Death Announced Retired Fireman William H. Will, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 120, residing at 59-26 Grove St., Ridgewood, died on Dec. 10. Funeral will take place from Blasius' Funeral Parlor, 1,872 Gates Ave., Brooklyn, at 2 P. M., Wednesday, Dec. 14. The deputy chief of the 15th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

Edward T. McLaughlin, a retired lawyer, died yesterday in the Ogden Mills Foundation Home for Incurables, 183d Street and Third Avenue, after three years of invalidism due to a stroke of paralysis. He was born in Jersey City sixtysix years ago.
Edwin S. McIntosh, political writer for The New York Herald Tribune, was unanimously elected president of the Inner Circle at the organization's annual meeting in City Hall yesterday.

Many of the essentials for further economic recovery are present in Canada, S. H. Logan, president of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, said today to stockholders in his address at their annual meeting here.

An investing client of Proskauer, Rose Paskus has bought the five-story apartment house at 37 Woodmere Boulevard, Woodmere, L. I., containing thirty suites, through Walter Samuels, Inc. The brokers arranged for the new owner a first mortgage for ten years at 4 1/2 per cent. The property is assessed at $112,000 and is reported fully rented.

The four-day match between Australia's international cricket team and an eleven representing the rest of Australia ended today in a draw. The contest was played in connection with the celebration of the centenary of the Melbourne Cricket Club.
The Commerce Department announced today that gold imports fell off to $177,782,299 in November from the record influx of $562,381,561 set in October.
Tenement properties on Washington Heights, the lower East Side and on the west side of midtown changed hands in the realty deals announced yesterday.

Lauis Bromfield, the author, who recently returned from Eurvope after living there fifteen years, warned yesterday that the "menace of Hitler and Mussolini is much nearer than we realize" and that, although the center of civilization and culture was moving toward America, all Americans should stand ready to fight for demecracy.

Frederick Holmes Paine, formerly chairman of the history department of the Eastern District High School in Brooklyn with which he had been associated for thirty-five years, died Monday at his home, 185 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 72.
It is the finding of the United States Supreme Court that in the field of professional education there can be no Missouri

The Vienna Choir Boys will give a concert Friday night at the Friends Meeting House, East Fifteenth Street and Rutherford Place, for the benefit of the alumni scholarship fund of the Friends Seminary.

The German Ambassador, Herbert von Dirksen, his embassy staff and all German newspaper correspondents in London tonight boycotted the, fiftieth anniversary dinner of the Foreign Press Association, at which Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain in an otherwise friendly speech criticized the German press for its recent attack on this country.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey returned yesterday on the Monarch of Bermuda after a vacation of a little more than three weeks in Bermuda and Nassau, accompanied by his wife and Paul Lockwood, his executive assistant.

Announcement was today made of the election by the Yale Corporation of the following governing board of The Yale University Press for the following year: Charles Seymour, president of the University; Edgar S. Furniss, provost; Carl A.

Merger of the properties of the Chicago, Lake Shore Eastern Railway Company and the Joliet Blue Island Rail Way Company with those of the Elgin, Joliet Eastern Railway Company was authorized today by Division 4 of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Members of Exhibition Employes Local 17,574 and of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union have been ordered not to work for the German Exposition, which is scheduled to open tomorrow in Grand Central Palace, William Collins, New York representative of the American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday.

A new plan designed to reduce drastically the 1939 production of cotton was outlined to the American Farm Bureau Federation here today by United States Senator John H. Bankhead of Alabama, who said that he would be sponsor also of a bill to coordinate efforts to increase cotton consumption.

Re-electing President Will Herridge to a new term of ten years, the club owners of the American League grappled for more than seven hours with baseball's manifold problems yesterday, paved the way for the introduction of night baseball for the first time into their circuit and indicated that the renowned home-run power of the world champion Yankees is to be curbed to some extent next season with the adoption of a less lively ball.

While results of the experiments E in Ohio putting grocery products under the 'fair trade law are still being. awaited, experiences with the unfair trade practice laws, notably in California, indicate the latter are preferable for the food industry, A. C. Monagle, vice president of Standard Brands,. Inc., said yesterday in a fair trade symposium held c by the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Rugs of Imperial Origin," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.; Collection of Paintings (general tour) 2 P. M.; "French and English Cabinetmakers: Adam Hepplewhite and Sheraton," Ethelwyn Bradish, 4 P. M.

The rights of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness are God-given rights which fascism, nazism and communism seek to destroy, Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, Administrator of the Archdiocese of New York, said last night at a meeting of the Catholic War Veterans of America at the Centre Club, 120 Central Park South.

More "pro-Americanism" and less talk of "anti-communism, anti-fascism and anti-nazism" was urged tonight by Representative Martin Dies, chairman of the House Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities, in a radio address summarizing the findings of his committee.

Economies in 1940 amounting to 20 per cent of. the present budget for League of Nations and International Labor Organization are recommended in the final report of the League's Economies Commission, which had been meeting here since Friday.

Mrs. Alton Farrel of 770 Park Avenue, New York, and the Lindens, Pine Orchard, Conn., formerly of this city, will give a large dance at the New Haven Lawn Club on Friday to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Jean Farrel, a freshman at Smith College.
The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on a total of 3,426,863 yards of textiles, for shipment by Feb. 15, 1939, with the opening of the bids on Dec. 21, as follows:
Mrs. Elise Gautier French Rice, widow of William Low Rice, died yesterday morning of a cardiac ailment in her home at 550 Park Avenue, after being ill for several weeks. Her age was 66.
President Roosevelt said today that he would sell about 1,000 Christmas trees from his farm at Hyde Park this year. Prices were about the same as last year, he added.
Two great rivals, Miss Cecilia Colledge, defending titleholder, and Miss Megan Taylor, the world champion, fought it out tonight for the British figureskating championship.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, yesterday notified stockholders that the board of directors deemed it advisable to change the fiscal year of the company to correspond with the calendar year, instead of Pending on Oct. 31.

The shape of his collar betrayed Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, when he sought to foil reporters by speaking French during the few hours he spent here this afternoon on his way to London.

President Roosevelt today approved an increase of $1,000,000,000 in the capacity of the Federal Housing Administration to insure residential mortgages, thus giving further impetus to a program which has aided toward making 1938 the most prosperous year in home building since 1929.

A break of more than $1 a bale in the spot month unsettled yesterday's cotton market and prices on the Cotton Exchange, ended with losses of 6 to 24 points. Circulation of notices for 1,400 bales disclosed only limited buying power, and the re-delivery of actual cotton taken up on the first notice day for the December appeared to indicate an absence of demand for some of the certificated stock.

Without ruling on the fundamental question of civil liberties involved in the case, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here dissolved today an injunction issued twenty-one months ago by Federal Judge William Clark restraining the Jersey City Police Department from "deporting" or otherwise interfering with labor pickets.

The Republic Steel Corporation said today that it was employing almost 48,000 persons on Dec. 1, in contrast with about 37,000 on June 1. Average weekly employment rose from 25 to 32.8 hours in the six months as steel operations increased from 21 per cent of capacitv to 67 per cent.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Monique Robert-LeBraz, daughter of Mrs. Marius Robert-LeBraz of Paris, France, to David Gelston Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Treadwell Nichols of Garden City and Old Mastic, L. I., which took place on Monday in Paris.

Outside of a moderate quota of strictly choice prime steers and yearlings, which sold steady, most cattle moved today at fully 25 cents lower prices, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs were generally 10 to 20 cents lower, the top resting at $7.40. Lambs suffered another 25cent decline. The best brought $9.10.

The Columbia University basketball team opened its campaign last night on the Morningside Heights floor and turned back the alumni, 23 to 34. The graduates took a 5-to-0 lead, but the varsity rallied and, once in the lead, never was threat3,ned again.
A receivership for the Reo Motor Car Company, pioneer automotive concern, was asked today in a suit filed in Ingham County Circuit Court by a group of stockholders' including several employes.

The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the four months from Aug. 1 to Nov. 30 was 2,094,082 tons, compared with 2,821,058 a year before, and cottonseed on hand at mills on Nov. 30 was 1,559,881 tons, compared with 1,741,876.

The Rev. Paul G. Lindemann, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer and founder and editor of The American Lutheran Magasine, died last night after an operation. His age was 56. He had been president of the English District, Missouri Lutheran Synod, for the last three years.

The search for $18,000,000 apparently missing among the $86,000,000 listed assets of McKesson Robbins, Inc., led here yesterday to a Federal order for the arrest of F. Donald Coster, president, together with George Dietrich, assistant treasurer , and George Vernard, agent in the market operations of :he drug corporation.

Martha Byrne, Register of New York County, announced yesterday that David A. Bridewell of the Central Housing Committee of Washington, D. C., had cooperated with her office and WPA workers by publishing in mimeograph form a report of investigations on cost and procedure in mortgage foreclosures, based on studies made in 1936 in Queens, Kings and New York Counties.

MIKE JACOBS and Lee Shubert went to great expense and effort to import the "fastest game in the world" when it was right here in New York all the time and has been on view for more than half a century.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York distributed $3,830,135 for the "diffusion of knowledge" in the United States and British dominions and colonies during the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, according to the annual report of Frederick P. Keppel, president.

Albert N. Chaperau, film agent, whose supposed smuggling activities have resulted in the indictment of the wife of Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer and of George Burns of the radio and screen team of Burns and Allen, pleaded not guilty yesterday to two indictments to which the comedian had pleaded guilty on Monday.

Following is the text of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's talk in London yesterday at a dinner of the Foreign Press Association as transcribed from the air by the National Broadcasting Company in New York:
Yale's hockey team routed Brown tonight, 13 to 2. Yale smashed into a 6-0 lead in the opening period, added another tally in the second and broke loose again in the third to register six times.

Dr. Constantine Konstan of Elkins, W. Va., who slid fifteen floors down an elevator shaft in the Hotel Piccadilly, 227 West Fort-fifth Street, early Monday morning, was reported improved yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital.

Francis J. Stulgaitis of WilkesBarre, Pa., was elected captain of Columbia's varsity football team for next season at a meeting of the Lion varsity lettermen in John Jay Hall last night. Award of varsity C's to nineteen football players and four cross-country runners was announced at the same time.
The cry "Is there a doctor in the house?" will not get a ripple in either branch of the 1939 Legislature. Not a physician will be seated in either chamber.

Joseph Fleischman, who started his career as a flower peddler on the sidewalks of New York and became a millionaire florist and Turkish-bath owner, died yesterday in his home, 78 Beverly Road, Kew Gardens, Queens, after a two-day illness. His age was 75.

A new rayon staple fiber, produced by Sylvania Industrial Corporation under the brand name "Sylph," was announced yesterday by Wellington, Sears Company's drapery department. Unique properties, including a long-sought permanent crinkle resembling that of wool, are achieved through mechanical innovations, although the chemical content of the fiber is the same as that of staple fibers previously on the market.
Norman Forster of the New York A. C. gained the semi-final round of the Class B and C squash tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club courts yesterday by eliminating E. A. Mays, Harvard Club.
I speak from Lima, beautiful and historic capital of Peru. Here the Eighth International Conference of American States is in session.

Both sales and attendance at the eleventh annual trade show of the National Association of Coin Operated Machine Manufacturers are running sharply ahead of the last year, officials of the association reported today.

The forty-sixth annual Columbia University varsity show will be "Constitutionally Yours," a musical comedy by Isadore A. L. Diamond, sophomore in Columbia College, it was announced yesterday by James M. McHaney, chairman of the Columbia University Players.

ASH-Morris, suddenly beloved brother of George and Philip. Funeral private. AYRES-At 45 Waukena Ave., Oceanside, Dec. 12, Paul, beloved husband of Henrietta Ayres, father of Henrietta L. and Paul Ayres Jr., aged 72 years. Services at Funeral Home of Pettit Brothers, 20 Lincoln Ave., Rockville Center, Wednesday, 8 P. M. Interment Greenfield Cemetery. Hempstead.

Construction of a new railway between Kunming and Burma and Chungking-Kunming, and a line to the French Indo-China border is being pushed, the Commerce Department learned today in reports received from China.
The outline of the form of demonstration of continental solidarity in the face of outside political aggression which the Pan-American conference is likely to make became clearer today.
A total of $1,170,952 has been raised in the United Hospital Campaign, it was announced at the final report luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.
Sponsors of housing projects were warned by the Board of Education's buildings and sites committee
NINETEEN HUNDRED AND THIRTY EIGHT'S march of the 10,000 books is nearly over. Not very many more can turn up in a year that has scarcely a fortnight left to stand on.

The political setback the New Deal received in last month's election brought virtually no change in sentiment for and against a Roosevelt third term, but it did cause a sharp decline in the number of persons who think Roosevelt could win if he ran again in 1940, according to a survey just 'completed by- the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

The appointment today of Eljas Erkko, publisher and editor of Finland's principal liberal newspaper, the Helsingin Sanomat, as Minister of Foreign Affairs to succeed Dr. Rudolf Holsti seems to have been received with general approval. Dr. Holsti was forced out as a result of German pressure.

Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard, celebrated his eighty-second birthday by returning to the university tonight for his annual "treat," the party given in his honor by undergraduates of the college house which bears his name.

Lorelle Simmons, 36 years old, a former school teacher of esthetic bearing who turned Raffles twelve years ago to lead a gang of thieves believed to have robbed hotel guests of nearly $1,000,000 in money and jewelry, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday for a term of seven to fourteen years.

Apparently the plan of the Washington Administration, as revealed on Monday by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, to aid the flow of business between the North and South American continents through loans to the nations south of the Rio Grande, is also to include the advancement of funds to American corporations as well.

Francis J. Gorman, president of the United Textile Workers of America, today announced that he had sent letters "to 700 local unions of the U. T. W." preparing the way for an early convention which will vote on whether or not to seek reaffiliation with the American Federation of Labor, and to end formally all ties with the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

An account of Anthony Eden's New York visit, described as his reception "by twoand-a-half million Jews in the New Jerusalem," was coupled with an attack on prominent American Jews today by the Voelkischer Beobachter, Chancellor Hitler's newspaper.

The sailing of the Queen Mary Friday will be the last opportunity to mail articles to reach European countries near Plymouth and Cherbourg in time for delivery by Christmas Day, Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York announced yesterday.

New York State, into which the Home Owners Loan Corporation several years ago poured more than $400,000,000 in loans to save distressed owners from foreclosure, has turned out to be the major "headache" of the HOLC officials seeking repayment of the Federal money.

With preliminary ceremonies and organization routine out of the way, the Eighth International Conference of American States finally got down to work this morning. Its interest was keenly centered on the committee studying the organization of peace.

William Harrison Freedman, an attorney, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 317 West Eighty-ninth Street. He was 60 years old. He had been a practicing attorney since 1902. He was a graduate of New York University Law School.

One of the eleven known copies of the first edition of Edgar Allan Poe's "Tamerlane and Other Poems" was sold last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries for $4,300. James F. Drake was the purchaser. The copy was discovered recently in Skowhegan, Me.

American Lockheed Type 14 land planes will be used by British Airways, Ltd., to inaugurate a daily service between London and Lisbon, which will be subsidized by the British Government to the maximum extent of [Pound]116.000 yearly.

Reports of "violence" between "farmers and labor organizations" were deplored today by Raymond Cooper of Oswego, N. Y., master of the New York State Grange. In his address opening the group's annual convention here, Mr. Cooper asked appointment of a committee to study the problem.

Federal agents arrested two men on espionage charges today, accusing them of sending documents of the United States Naval Intelligence Bureau to Soviet Russia. One of the suspects, Mikhail Gorman, 34 years old, received permission to telephone the Soviet Ambassador in Washington.

Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn, yesterday told three homeless-- defendants, arraigned on a charge of loitering: "Your only crime is not having sense enough-to have your Christmas dinner at the expense of the city.
The Duchess of Sutherland, who arrived on the Bremen, is at the St. Regis. With her are her niece, the Hon. Elizabeth Leveson-Gower, and Lady Margaret Egerton.

Arthur B. Newhall of Watertown, Mass., was elected yesterday executive vice president in full charge of all producing and sales of the B. F. Goodrich Company, it was announced here after a meeting of directors. He also was appointed a member of the executive committee.

Reports from the front today said government soldiers were taunting Insurgents in the opposite trenches over an alleged delay in the great offensive that Generalissimo Francisco Franco is known to be preparing.

Servel, Inc., manufacturer of refrigerators and air- conditioning equipment, reported yesterday in its annual statement covering the year -ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $1,572,469 after taxes and other charges.

Answering the British and French representations to the German Government yesterday in the Memel question, the newspaper Boersen Zeitung, which often speaks for the Foreign Office, today in effect tells Great Britain and France to keep out of an affair concerning only Germany and Lithuania.
Leases for business quarters in buildings along Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Avenues accounted for a number of the commercial rentals reported yesterday.

True to her custom of years' standing, an unassuming woman stopped in at the business office of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Times Square yesterday and handed a clerk a Christmas gift envelope contraining, a crisp, new $1,000 note for the benefit of New York's Neediest Cases.

Colonel Aurelio Alvarez, one of the leaders of the Cuban Revolutionary party, was slightly wounded during a duel that he fought with Secretary of Education Aurelio Fernandez Conchezo this morning at La Plasencia Farm. just outside Havana.

Some historians have sought to prove that many of humanity's tragedies have arisen from the fact that the heads of the nations involved did not like each other, even in instances where they were personally unacquainted.

Claude H. Sandkam of Mount Vernon, manager of the mailing and circulation departments of the Standard Statistics Company, died yesterday of coronary thrombosis at his New York office, 345 Hudson Street. His age was 58 years.
A new low in electric razor prices was reached this week when a Chicago company brought out a model to retail at $1, it was learned here yesterday. The wholesale quotation was said to be $8 a dozen.

The Seaboard Air Line Railway will start tomorrow the first allelectric rail service offered by any railroad between New York and Florida. The first train, named the East Coast Orange Blossom Special, will leave Pennsylvania Station at 1:25 P. M. for Miami.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday placed the stamp of approval on Tommy Farr, Great Brittain's leading heavyweight, who is to fight his fourth American ring battle, a scheduled fifteen-round bout in Madison Square Garden Friday night against Lou Nova, young heavyweight from California.
David D. Sierson, formerly vice president and general manager of the Morgenthau Corporation at 11 West Forty-second Street, will henceforth operate under his own name at the same address.

The Commodity Club of New York will hold a dinner meeting tomorrow night at the Park Central Hotel. The guest speaker will be Carl H. Wilken of Sioux City, Iowa, editor of. The Progressive Farm News and president of the Progressive Farmers of Iowa.

Turning back a late rally, the St. Simon Stock basketball team, playing on its home court, defeated the St. Francis Prep five, 33 to 30, yesterday. McNaney of the winners was the game's leading point-maker with 12.

The United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries, for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, report a net income of $3,880,179, subject to year-end adjustments and audit and after Federal income taxes, provision for retirements, interest, amortization, subsidiary preferred dividends, minority interest and other obligations.

Princess Doris Farid es Sultaneh, divorced wife of the Iranian Prince Farid of Sadri-Azam, reported to the police of the West Forty-seventh Street station the loss of a diamond ring which she said was valued at $15,000, it was learned last night.

A campaign to raise $200,000 to help refugee intellectuals has been started by a group of 150 Americans who will coordinate their efforts under the auspices of the American Guild for German Cultural Freedom, headquarters of which are at 20 Vesey Street.

Most of the suggestions made by employers for changes in the Wages and Hours Act have dealt with exemption of employes in the higher income brackets, according to Administrator Elmer F. Andrews, who summarized today the results of his cross-country trip from which he returned yesterday.

The probability that the French budget would be voted by the end of the year or at least within the first few days of the new year was virtually assured today when the Chamber of Deputies decided to adopt a somewhat shortened procedure of debate.

Mr. and Mrs. Jonah P. Poysher yesterday celebrated the sixty-seventh anniversary of their marriage. They held a reception in the little farmhouse that has been their home for thirty-six years, and many of their neighbors and friends called to congratulate them as the oldest married couple in this locality. Mr. Poysher is 93 years old and his wife is 87.
Mrs. Marion Clark Madeira, a leader in social welfare work, died at her home in Germantown today after an illness of six months. She was 70 years old.

The first major production of the Dramatic Society of the New York University Washington Square College will be held tonight with the performance of "The Beaux Stratagem," the proceeds of which will be donated to the college's fund to benefit German student refugees, it was announced yesterday.

Harvard's hockey team made an auspicious debut under its new coach, Clark Hodder, when it beat the Boston Junior Olympics, 3 to 1, at the Arena tonight. The Crimson lost Captain Austin Harding with a shoulder injury after five minutes.

J. A. Krug, chief power planning engineer for the Tennessee Valley Authority, admitted before the Congressional investigating committee today that the TVA power business was $1,000,000 "in the red" last fiscal year, figuring interest and depreciation, but predicted that it would make a substantial profit on the same accounting basis this fiscal year.

The St. Nicks hockey team scored its sixth victory in as many starts in the New York Amateur Hockey Association last night when it subdued the New York A. C. combination, 5 to 3, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.
The Midston House team remained undefeated in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association competition by defeating Jackson Heights, 4 to 1, last night, It was the fifth straight triunph for Midston.

The Actors Equity Council yesterday afternoon considered many matters, which may be summed up as follows: (1). The Theatre Guild received permission to rehearse a long play, "Jeremiah," for five weeks, instead of the usual four. The guild asserted the production was in the nature of a spectacle and would employ a company of 150 or more.

What was termed "a transportation crisis of the first magnitude" in which the legal guarantees of the five-cent fare will be swept away on the Manhattan and Bronx elevated lines was predicted yesterday by the city's legal advisers on transit if the United States Circuit Court of Appeals does not reverse the decision of the District Court breaking the lease by which the Interborough Rapid Transit Company operates these lines.
Kirsten Flagstad, noted Wagnerian soprano, will be honored by the Bohemians, a club of men musicians, at a dinner Sunday evening in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Matthew Kane, a tight-lipped thug and hold-up man from New York's West Forties, died in the Sing Sing Prison hospital today, the victim of an underworld vendetta.

The Short Hills Club defeated the Plainfield Country Club team, 3 to 2, on the letters' courts yesterday and took first place in the New Jersey division of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets tournament.
Matthew Kane, a tight-lipped thug and hold-up man from New York's West Forties, died in the Sing Sing Prison hospital today, the victim of an underworld vendetta.

The Short Hills Club defeated the Plainfield Country Club team, 3 to 2, on the letters' courts yesterday and took first place in the New Jersey division of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets tournament.

Official Washington steered a wary course today between the warmth of the unofficial greeting it extended to Anthony Eden and that degree of aloofness which protocol requires for a former member of Neville Chamberlain's Cabinet who is now somewhat at odds with the head of the British Government.

The Securities and Exchange Commission p granted today the application of ti the Penn Western Gas and Electric Company for permission to pay dividends out of capital or unearned surplus. The commission's approval, however, imposed the fol- S lowing conditions:

Disclosures in testimony before the National Temporary Economic Committee that the corporation rather than the individual inventor is usually the developer and principal beneficiary of the patent system led Senator O'Mahoney, chairman of the committee, to suggest today the "desirability of considering whether any regulations should be developed to supervise group patenting as it is now carried on."

Frank E. Speicher, a New York tire salesman, testified in Federal District Court today that a General Motors Corporation official had obtained "thousands of dollars" from G. M. C. for "supposed" payment to three high War Department officials.

The Census Bureau offered proof today of the rise of sports am a major American industry. Figures compiled from the recent biennial census of manufacturers show increases in 1937 over 1935 in the value of sports products, wages paid in sporting goods factories, and the number of employee.
The first junior dinner dance of the season will be held Friday in the Red Room of the Bellevue-Stratford. The two other dates of the series are Jan. 13 and Jan. 27.

Members of the City Council Finance Committee who held a hearing yesterday on the 1939 capital outlay budget of $140,849,618 complained that the budget did not include assessable improvements such as the $28,000,000 Circumferential Parkway, and therefore did not give a true picture of the city's large-scale undertakings.

Another motion by defense counsel for a directed verdict of acquittal for Hans Heinrich Schackow, a German charged with unlawfully taking pictures of the Panama Canal's Atlantic defenses, was denied by District Judge Bunk Gardner after both sides had rested their cases today.
Leaflets and posters issued by the United Opposition in Zagreb today alleged, on the authority of Dr. Vladimir Matchek, Croat leader, that the government had falsified the electoral results.

In the Museum of the City of New York an exhibition of Currier Ives lithographs portraying "The New York Scene" opens today. Nobody who loves these vivid reproductions of an early America can afford to keep away. Mr.
The mystery of the missing dispatch case worried Captain Anthony Eden on his trip from New York to Washington, and for a time threatened to assume the proportions of an international incident.

The State Sinking Fund Commission announced today that it will call d about $2,000,000 of New Jersey's bonds next July 1, to save Interest payments of approximately 41/4 per cent until July, 1953. It is not yet determined what outstanding issues t would be called, according to State C Treasurer Albright.
Five German correspondents at the Pan-American Conference stalked out of a committee session today to show their displeasure over a speech attacking Germany.

Another motion by defense counsel for a directed verdict of acquittal for Hans Heinrich Schackow, a German charged with unlawfully taking pictures of the Panama Canal's Atlantic defenses, was denied by District Judge Bunk Gardner after both sides had rested their cases today.

The adoption by the Assembly at an early hour today, before recessing until next Monday night, of a resolution authorizing an investigation of New Jersey's financial condition brought from Governor Moore this afternoon a charge that the legislators were "stalling" and "dead-ending."

Mrs. Henry B. Plant gave a luncheon for her debutante daughter, Miss Mary Ellen Plant, yesterday at her home, 684 Park Avenue. Mrs. Plant and Mrs. John A. Stewart, grand-aunt of the debutante, received the guests.

The Treasury announced tonight that cel it had allotted an aggregate of Co $731,445,700 of its 23/4 per cent bonds and 11/8 per cent notes in ts recent cash offerings of about $700,000,000 Co of the bonds and notes. Both issues were heavily oversubscribed.
Mrs. Frederic Schenck has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Remsen Schenck, to David Bruce Huxley of London.
Dr. Joseph A. Hill, for more than forty years a statistician with the Bureau of the Census, died late last night at his home here. He was 78 years old.

Miss Marie Reboux, 26 years old, an art student, of 123 West Eighteenth Street, was taken to St. Luke's Hospital last night in a serious condition with face lacerations and a possibly fractured skull as a result of being hit twice by automobiles within fifteen minutes.

That vast American public which has long admired the courage and modesty of Charles A. Lindbergh must be glad to know that it is Paris, not Berlin, that the Lindbergh family have selected for their headquarters this Winter. Colonel Lindbergh has suffered tragically from the public interest in his goings and comings.

Since we all love round numbers it was a pleasure for this newspaper to be able to announce yesterday that the total contributions to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund since its establishment in 1912 had passed $5,000,000. There is abundant evidence that this money has not been spent in vain.
The sale of sixty-seven lots on 232d and 233d Streets, north of Merrick Road, Laurelton, L. I., marked the deals in that section reported yesterday by William Schreiber, Inc., broker.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 12: COLONELS Persons, W. E. (Inf.), National Guard Bureau, to retirement, upon own application. Tucker, A. S. J., Inf., Berkeley, Calif., to retirement.

Frederick Millhouse, former assistant chief of ordnance for the United States Army and later general manager of the Driggs Ordnance Company in New York, died at his home here this afternoon after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

More than 3,000 chain drug stores will participate in a nation-wide promotions of large-size packages to be held for ten days, starting March 10, it was announced yesterday by Chain Store Age, which is sponsoring the event in cooperation with manufacturers.
Mrs. Margaret Emerson entertained tonight with a dinner at her villa and Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Terry were hosts to a company of twelve at their residence.

Mrs. Gladys Scheurer, 33-year-old wife of Gustave Scheurer, gliding instructor and manager of Schley Field, Liberty Corners, near here, died in the United States Veterans Hospital here today of injuries suffered Sunday when a glider she was piloting failed to level off for a landing and crashed on the field.

New steps to regulate the theatres that formerly housed burlesque shows, including deletion of the word "burlesque" from the name of the actors' union and a ban on traveling burlesque shows appearing in New York, have been taken by John F. X. Masterson, Mayor La Guardia's appointee to govern the industry, it was disclosed yesterday.

The return meeting between Seabiscuit and War Admiral will take place at Hialeah Park in February, it became known yesterday following telephone talks between Joseph E. Widener, owner of the Miami racing ground, and Marshall Cassidy, who is handling the negotiations. All that remains is the signing of the articles.

Mrs. Elizabeth Burdick Hammett, widow of Alfred L. HammettNew Rochelle banker, died here last night in her home at the age of 84. She was honorary president of the Pelham branch of the Needlework Guild of America, former director of the New Rochelle

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a report on a plan of recapitalization of Northern States Power Company of Delaware, involving its subsidiaries, the Northern States Power companies of Minnesota and Wisconsin,

Five thousand persons gathered at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning with one common thought--to pay tribute to Blessed Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini. Young and old, rich and poor attended a solemn pontifical mass opening the New York diocesan celebration of the recent beatification of the missionary.

Although the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week, the total was considerably ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
For next Summer, the Stadium concerts committee is planning the most elaborate season of its entire twenty years' history, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenhiemer, chairman.

Frank L. Sealy of 7 Walworth Avenue, Scarsdale, a leading American organist who was warden of the American Guild of Organists from 1922 to 1932, died here yesterday in the Medical Arts Center Hospital, 57 West Fifty-seventh Street, as a result of injuries suffered on Nov. 2 in an automobile accident on the Saw Mill River Parkway. He was 80 years old.

The second day of the strike of meat handlers against plants of the "big four" packing companies and smaller wholesale establishments in this city brought the intervention of the Labor Department in Washington in an effort to settle the dispute, which, if continued, it is feared, may lead to a meat shortage and a rise in prices here.

With the sale of five acres at the southeast corner of Jericho Turnpike and Glen Cove Road, in Westbury, L. I., to M. B. Gault for "investment and future development," the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker, reports that it now has disposed of thirty acres of the Walter Thompson Corporation's eighty-five-acre parcel at that busy intersection.

Mrs. Arthur Fletcher was elected president of the Women's Organization for the American Merchant Marine at the annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Commodore. Mrs. Fletcher succeeds Mrs. C. H. C. Pearsall. Others named to office were Mrs. Robert C. Lee, first vice president;

The housing committee of the National Association of Real Estate Boards has under consideration two counter-propbuals to the government's housing program which, it is hoped, will be submitted to the forthcoming session of Congress, Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the association, revalued yesterday.

The Trea House of Lords, highest court in England, upheld today a Court of Appeal decision requiring the New Brunswick Railway Company of Canada to redeem its bonds issued in 1884 at gold value. Interest payments were exempted.

The ten coaches of the National League football teams, a group of experts among experts, have picked their all-league teams for 1938. Three members of the New York Giants and three from the Green Bay Packers made the first team along with two members of the Chicago Bears, one Chicago Cardinal, one Detroit Lion and one Brooklyn Dodger. The selections were announced yesterday.

The second day of the strike of meat handlers against plants of the "big four" packing companies and smaller wholesale establishments in this city brought the intervention of the Labor Department in Washington in an effort to settle the dispute, which, if continued, it is feared, may lead to a meat shortage and a rise in prices here.

With the sale of five acres at the southeast corner of Jericho Turnpike and Glen Cove Road, in Westbury, L. I., to M. B. Gault for "investment and future development," the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker, reports that it now has disposed of thirty acres of the Walter Thompson Corporation's eighty-five-acre parcel at that busy intersection.

Mrs. Arthur Fletcher was elected president of the Women's Organization for the American Merchant Marine at the annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Commodore. Mrs. Fletcher succeeds Mrs. C. H. C. Pearsall. Others named to office were Mrs. Robert C. Lee, first vice president;

The housing committee of the National Association of Real Estate Boards has under consideration two counter-propbuals to the government's housing program which, it is hoped, will be submitted to the forthcoming session of Congress, Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the association, revalued yesterday.

The Trea House of Lords, highest court in England, upheld today a Court of Appeal decision requiring the New Brunswick Railway Company of Canada to redeem its bonds issued in 1884 at gold value. Interest payments were exempted.
Steel ingot production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 100.4 The figure was 96.5 for the preceding week, and 43.0 for the week ended Dec. 11, 1937.

MANHATTAN BASES, ABRAHAM (Sept. 9, 1937). Gross assets, $115,782; net, $90,551. To Annabel Bases, widow, residue; Krakauer Charity Aid Society, $2,000. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $72,375. Clifford L. Tichenor, attorney, 291 Broadway.

Five thousand persons gathered at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning with one common thought--to pay tribute to Blessed Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini. Young and old, rich and poor attended a solemn pontifical mass opening the New York diocesan celebration of the recent beatification of the missionary.
