After the testimony of F. G. Smith, president of the Hartford-Empire Company, no one can longer doubt the close connection in many cases between patents and the problem of monopoly. The investigations of the Temporary National Economic Committee along this line are not merely relevant but valuable.

New York's week-old liquor price war was off to a fresh start here last night, less than six hours after retail establishments- of the city had restored quotations to normal with the announced intention of keeping them there.

Oscar I. Silverstone, architect, is preparing plans for a six-story apartment house to be erected in the place of the row of six old dwellings at 85-95 Lexington Avenue, between Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Streets.
An amnesty covering common crimes committed up to Oct. 8 was approved tonight by the House of Representatives. The Senate has already passed the bill, which will go to the President for signature.
The government sent Al Capone a bill for $57,692.29 today. It included a $50,000 fine and '$7,692.29 court costs of his income tax evasion case still on the books of the Federal district court herb.

The Rev. Dr. Abraham L. Feinberg, for three years rabbi of Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, has accepted a call to Temple Emanuel, Denver, Col., it was announced yesterday by Ernest Katz, president of Congregation Mount Neboh.

The quintets representing James Madison High and Abraham Lincoln High recorded their third straight successes in Section 2 of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. yesterday and remained in a deadlock for the lead.
Seasonal greetings were exchanged through the air over 5,000 miles when Mrs. Thomas C. Carson talked with her son, Robert Carson, in Suimwkab, Egypt.

Sales of men's furnishings for gift purposes continued to mount this week, but the demand for clothing lagged, according to retail executives yesterday. Mild weather is the chief reason for the poor showing of clothing departments and it is now considered likely that quite a few stores will start clearances within a week or so instead of waiting until after Christmas.

Dartmouth's hockey team opened its season tonight by defeating the Blueway Hockey Club of Springfield, 9 to 2, in a game featured by the work of the Green defense men, Jim Feeley and Mal Cross. Feeley scored three Dartmouth goals and teamed with Cross to stop the Springfield attack repeatedly.

Francis M Biddle, General Counsel to the Congressional Committee Investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority, inproduced into the record at today's hearing a report recommending that TVA employes be placed under the Federal Civil Service.

The Federal National Mortgage Association, the entire stock of which is owned by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will offer on Monday $50,000,000, or thereabouts, of its five-year 1% per cent notes, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC announced today.
Legal technicalities indicate that Clark Gable won't be eligible to marry Carole Lombard until some time in 1940.

The resignation of Dr. Frederick B. Robinson as president of City College, a post he has held for eleven years, was unanimously accepted yesterday by the City College administrative committee of the Board of Higher Education at a meeting in the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
The Merchants Association joined other civic and mercantile organizations yesterday in demanding the enactment of five Council bills designed to reorganize county government by the end of this year.

The press defends in editorials Mexico's right to trade with Germany, Italy and Japan, asserting that the Latin-American nations at the Lima conference have declared against United States as well as European imperialism. It is suggested that the Brazilian minorities plan may make it impossible for the United States to defend her minorities in Latin America.

The Crescent A. C. skaters broke a deadlock in the third period and handed the Princeton freshman hockey sextet its second defeat of the season, 4 to 3, at Baker Rink tonight. It was the fourth victory in six starts for the New York amateurs.

A total of 1,279 stock companies was incorporated in the State during November, or seven more than correspondingly in 1937, the Division of Corporations of the office of the Secretary of State announced today.

DAEMGEN, BERTHA (Dec. 8). Estate, $65,000. To Mary Muller, niece, 41-36 74th St., Jackson Heights, and John F. Muller, executor, same address, residue equally. D'AURENCON, MATHILDE LASSERE (Nov. 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To Edward L. d'Aurencon, stepson, also known as Edward Lassere, of 254 W. 31st St., $3,000;

Tile, terra cotta and concrete torn from the west wall of the Thirty-fourth Street station of the B. M. T. by a blast of dynamite in the new Sixth Avenue subway, under construction, hurtled across the south end of the station at 10:08 A. M. yesterday.
New applications of European refugee professional men seeking license to practice in New York State mounted to about 700 today with the approach of the January professional examinations.

Secretary Swanson received a check today for $189,807.90 from the Electric Boat Company of Groton, Conn., representing a refund to the government on contracts for construction of the submarines Perch, Pickerel and Permit.

An expansion in plant and equipment to cost between $750,000 and $1,000,000 is planned by the AddressographMultigraph Corporation to start in January, it was announced today by Joseph E. Rogers, president.

Concerted action looking to adoption of a new or amended copyright law protecting artists was recommended by speakers at a meeting of commercial artists under the auspieces of the Graphic Arts Forum in the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza last night.

Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, is due to arrive tonight from London on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, accompanied by his son, John. Other passengers are Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Brazil; Mrs. Hiulan Koo, wife of the Chinese Ambassador to France.

G. Le Roy Kemp of Mount Vernon, N. Y., indicted land agent of the State Highway Department, who is on trial for conspiracy in Criminal Superior Court, admitted on the witness stand today that he had shared in commissions of Thomas N. Cooke of Greenwich and Samuel Silberman of Stamford on sales of property to the State for the Merritt Parkway.

Mr. and Mrs. John Louis Zaugg of 450 East Fifty-second Street and Great Chebeague Island, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Zaugg, to Dr. Earl Parsons Lasher Jr., also of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lasher of Yonkers, N. Y., and Sandy Hook, Conn.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your reports of the proceedings of the National Association of Manufacturers there was much echoing of the principle that the State was made for man, not man for the State, contrary to the totalitarian dogma, and of the essential right of free enterprise in a democratic society.

A State-wide conference to consider expansion of public health services as recommended at the National Health Conference in Washington last Summer was proposed yesterday by William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Citizens Union, at a hearing in the Bar Association Building before the New York State Temporary Commission to Formulate a Health Program.

The Delaware Hudson Railroad will move its offices from the downtown area to the Grand Central zone, where the company has. leased about 17,000 square feet in the New York Central Building at 230 Park Avenue.
Midnight tonight is the deadline for the fourth and final installment of Federal income taxes for. 1937. Delinquents must pay 6 per cent interest for any period of delay.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith opened yesterday afternoon a sale of merchandise made by refugees from the Sudeten areas of CzechoSlovakia and being sold here at 25 West Forty-third Street under the auspices of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women.

LUCIA DI LAMMERMOOR, opera in Italian in three acts and four scenes. Music by Gaetano Donizetti; book by Salvatore Cammarano, after Sir Walter Scott's novel. Conductor, Gennaro Papi; stage director. Desire Defrere Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Hans Heinrich Schackow, a German employee of the Hapag-North German Lloyd Steamship agency here, was found guilty as charged today of unlawfully photographing the coast defenses of the Panama Canal. The jury of American employes of the Panama Canal and the Panama Railroad Company deliberated two hours.
Beven was elected today president of the Illinois Central Railroad. He succeeds L. A. Downs, who, in turn, was elected chairman of the board of directors.

The liquor price war, in progress here for more than a week, appeared nearing an end last night after Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer had imposed a $100 fine on the Wall Street Liquor Corporation for selling Calvert Distillers Corporation brands below the prices fixed in fair trade contracts.

Great Britain's exports in November were the highest for any month this year, the Board of Trade disclosed today by the in its monthly report, which set the figure at [Pound]48,030,000 (approximately $224,300,100).

Goldman, Sachs Co. and the Marine Midland Trust Company of Buffalo head a syndicate which won yesterday the award of $3,000,000 tax notes of New York City at an interest rate of 0.44 per cent plus a premium of $44.
Directors of the Central Railroad of New Jersey will discuss this week the payment of interest due on Jan. 1 on the company's general mortgage 5 and 4 per cent bonds.
The Department of Agriculture named today the sites for four "test. tube" laboratories in which it will seek to solve the problem of crop surpluses.

Attorney General David T. Wilentz prepared today his resignation as Democratic State chairman. At his office it was said his letter would reach Charles Quinn of Trenton, secretary of the State committee, tomorrow. Mr. Wilentz announced a month ago he would resign "at the convenience of party leaders," explaining he had taken the chairmanship only for the 1938 election campaign and now wished to devote more time to his private law practice.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has become a director in the insurance firm of her son, Roosevelt Sargent, Inc., of Boston. Stephen T. Early, one of the President's secretaries, stated today that Mrs. Roosevelt was becoming a director to protect the interests of her son, James, who recently became a vice president of Samuel Goldwyn, Inc.

Nearly half of the estate of Mrs. Genevieve Macaulay, wife of William J. Babington Macaulay, Irish Minister to the Holy See, and widow of Nicholas F. Brady, was bequeathed for charitable or religious purposes, it was revealed yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.
By winning last night the Bayside Tennis Club's squash tennis team moved into a tie with the N. Y. A. C. for the league lead in the Class A metropolitan team series.

Cuneo Press, Inc., declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock. Directors also announced the intention to increase the regular dividend rate to 75 cents a share from the 50-cent quarterly rate presently in effect.
The relief rolls of the Works Progress Administration dropped last week by 45,514 persons, the largest decline in any week since cuts were begun on Nov. 5.

The first successful manifestation of the growing status and authority of the Japanese-sponsored local government appeared tonight when Mayor Fu Hsiao-en, the head of the government of Greater Shanghai, was host at a party for more than 400 guests-Japanese, Chinese and foreigners-in the Astor House, on the north bank of Soochow Creek.

Repeating what he had already told Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, during his visit in Paris, Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet said today before the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies that "France will never consent to yield an inch of her territory to Italy, and any attempt to make good any such claim cannot do otherwise than lead to armed conflict."

Basing his action on the city's recent condemnation and sale of the Sixth Avenue elevated line, Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, applied yesterday to Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson for an order directing him to surrender immediately to William Roberts, receiver for the Manhattan Railway Company, all the elevated lines now operated by the Interborough.
The market will lose between $650,000,000 and $700,000,000 of excess reserves today as a consequence of the quarterly tax payments and transactions connected with the Treasury financing.

Grain markets rallied strongly today after a small decline in the early trading. Corn, however, was the leading grain in the pit here, with a buying scramble attributed to professional operators who were reinstating recently sold-out lines.

Serious work started today at the PanAmerican Conference on the drafting of a convention concerning pecuniary claims by American States against other States on behalf of their nationals, with the promise that this would become the most controversial intra-American subject discussed.

Italy's ninetyyear-old parliament today voted itself out of existence and suppressed one of the very few surviving democratic institutions in Italy when it approved by acclamation the creation of the new Chamber of Fasces and Corporations, conforming with the decision of the Fascist Grand Council of last Oct. 7.
City College's varsity swimming team has elected co-captains for this Winter, according to the announcement made yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

Most American business men here favor one or the other of two local schools of thought, which, because of recent developments in American-Argentine commercial relations, have been named the Wheats and the Meats.

Business depends on good-will between the various peoples and is being "murdered" by the actions of Chancellor Hitler and Premier Mussolini, Dudley Field Malone told members of the Drug.C?? Chemical Credit Men's Association

Joseph Lassman and Paul J. Schmidt, former WPA workers assigned as deputy Internal Revenue collectors in the First District of New York, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to an indictment charging them with soliciting a bribe. Judge Grover M.
Columbia College of Pharmacy's basketball team defeated the New College quintet, 45-36, at the Bronx Union Y. M. C. A. gymnasium yesterday.

Because the plane is the most spectacular of all instruments of battle and because it has brought the horrors of war home to civilian populations everywhere, aerial forces have been more dramatized in the interpretation of recent events in Europe than either land forces or sea forces.
Winners of six annual contests at the State's forty-six institutional farms were announced tonight at a meeting of farm supervisors. The winners were: Potato production:

The marine industry is now making definite and progressive strides in the practical application of accident-prevention measures, after many years of "inaction" and "stumbling in the dark," it was declared yesterday by H. W. Warley, vice president of the Calmar Steamship Corporation.

Richard Rothschild of the Downtown A. C. yesterday reached the final of the Long Island championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association, in progress at the Jackson Heights Squash Club, when he defeated A. G. Thacher Jr. of the Rockaway Hunting Club, 15-10. 15-9. 18--3.
Dr. Richard H. Hutchings Jr., assistant superintendent of the Harlem Valley State Hospital here, died tonight at the age of 44.

Harold F. Rogers has been named assistant to Isaac Liberman, president of Arnold Constable Co., and is in charge of the New Rochelle store of the company, according to announcement yesterday by Mr. Liberman.

Seventy-six plots were sold by the city of Hoboken, N. J., in an auction yesterday to satisfy 1937 tax arrears. Sales were closed for the exact amount of delinquencies, with William H. Gilfert, Director of Revenue and Finance in Hoboken, officiating.
Almost on the eve of the official opening of Lake Placid's famed Winter sports season, a new fall of snow has turned local Winter sports fans into a group of optimists.

Continuing their policy of producing short subjects to wombat the double-feature problem, Warners have announced that Pat O'Brien will be starred in a series of tworeelers on "What the Constitution Means to You."

Holding its opponent scoreless from the field for the first fifteen minutes of the game, the St. Francis College basketball team recorded its third straight victory by overpowering the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy tossers, 58 to 26, on the St. Francis floor last night.

The Chicago North Western Railway announced yesterday that it had applied to the Federal court in Chicago for permission to buy two streamlined trains of ten cars each and each driven by oil-electric locomotives of 4,000 horsepower for about $2,320,000.

Delay of codification of the State Public Welfare and Charities Law for at least a year was urged almost unanimously at a hearing today in the State Office Building, called by the State Board of Social Welfare.

As Governor A. Harry Moore renewed his protest yesterday on the dismissal of aged persons from WPA projects, more than 100 men and women in the over-65 category appeared before the Atlantic County Board of Freeholders in Atlantic City to appeal for immediate assistance.
The People's Chorus of New York, now in its twenty-third year, presented its eleventh annual Christmas Song Festival last night at Carnegie Hall before a near-capacity audience.

AMERICAN LABOR, by Herbert Harris. (Yale University Press, $3.75.) A history from Colonial times to the present. ROMANTICISM AND THE GOTHIC REVIVAL, by Agnes Addison. (Smith, $2.50.) The rise and decline of the romantic movement in Europe and America.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Civil Liberties Union will apply to Federal Judge William Clark in Newark for a wider civil rights injunction against Mayor Hague and other Jersey City officials as the result of the decision handed down Tuesday by the Circuit Court of Appeals, it was announced yesterday by Morris L. Ernst, counsel for the labor groups.
Twenty-six States tonight had nominated candidates for election Saturday as Rhodes scholars for 1939. The remaining twenty-two will nominate tomorrow.
An open hearing to decide whether school buildings shall continue to be used by teachers or organizations to hold "controversial" meetings will be held soon, the Board of Education voted yesterday.

Princeton forged ahead midway through the first period to trounce the Lafayette basketball team, 41 to 27, in the university gym tonight. It was the Tigers' second straight victory and the first loss in two games for the visitors.

" A Tight Fix," one of the rarest of all Currier Ives lithographs, was sold last night for $2,300 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries to L. J. Marion, an agent for a private collector. The lithograph, dated 1861, depicts a hand-to-hand contest between a large black bear and a hunter with only his knife for defense.

Ending their separate sessions with a flourish at the WaldorfAstoria yesterday, the club owners of the National and American Leagues moved to adopt a uniform ball, set the opening dates and announced their inaugural games for the 1939 championship season, and concluded the long day with the magnates of the American circuit formally accepting night baseball for the first time.
The importation of detective novels was forbidden today by the Italian Government. Italian writers specializing in this kind of literature are being advised to turn to more uplifting works.

Lord Moyne, head of the West Indies Royal Commission visiting colonies to study social and economic conditions, arrived here today on his yacht Rosaura from Belize. He joined Sir Edward Stubbs, vice chairman of the commission, here.
Twenty-seven years ago that great citizen and philanthropist, Cleveland Dodge, organized a Committee on Friendly Relations Among Foreign Students.

THERE was no warning in either the appearance or the action of the visitor, but there was no hesitation, either. Without preliminary, he began answering his own questions. "Why do you people continue to write about sports that are dead and out of season?"

Holiday spending in establishments selling general merchandise, jewelry and household furnishings, which account for the major portion of Christmas sales, will equal or slightly exceed the 1937 volume in value and be considerably larger in respect to the goods moved because of lower prices, Secretary Roper said today.
About 1,500 Baptist churches in Rumania were closed today by the Baptists themselves as a result of a new public worship law, which requires at least 100 families for a congregation.
The Cabinet at a session attended by King Carol today devised a ten-year program for the gradual reduction of the influence of Jews and foreigners in Rumania.
President Roosevelt today appointed Lieut. Comdr. Francis W. Reichelderfer to be acting chief of the Weather Bureau, succeeding Dr. Willis R. Gregg, who died last September.

Victor Pohjola, 68 years old, a steamship agent and a leader in the Finnish colony in this city, was convicted yesterday at his third General Sessions trial, of the theft of $17,480 from a woman who had asked him to send the money for her to Finland.
The W. A. Shaeffer Pen Company announced today payment of profit-sharing bonuses to more than 1,000 employes amounting to 10 per cent of their wages during the last six months.

Charles H. C. Pearsall, national president of the Propeller Club and former head of the Colombian Steamship Company, has been named vice president of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Lines, it was announced yesterday by V. K. Hull, president.

When the steering committee of the Pan-American Conference decided to close the conference on Dec. 27 Alfred M. Landon gave up his plans to go home for Christmas and will remain with the United States delegation until the end of the conference.

The cooperative homestead idea seems to be spreading. Government sponsorship has helped to create subsistence homesteads and suburban residential communities, which are at least partly self-sustaining, and privately sponsored projects of this type, all associated with the "back-to-the-farm" movement, also have been attracting wider interest.

The City Planning Commission approved a modified drainage plan at its meeting in City Hall yesterday to meet the objections of City Island residents who complained of the inadequate sewage system in their community.
Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that he would appoint 270 eligibles to his department and promote seventy-seven members to new ranks, effective on Jan. 1.

Heretofore George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart have invariably selected a Saturday night to usher in their shows. This also will be the case for their spectacle, "The American Way," due to arrive on the evening of Jan. 21, at the Center Theatre, thereby refuting Broadway reports that the team had become superstitious this season about Saturday night openings.
The stock market today started with a firm carry-over from yesterday's activity, but prices eased as soon as trading slackened, though the undertone remained fairly firm.

CzechoSlovakia's demand for mineral oils is expected to drop 30 per cent from the sales made in 1937, as the result of the loss of parts of its territory to Germany, Hungary and Poland, the Commerce Department reports.

Dartmouth College Athletic Council approved varsity letter awards in football and numerals in freshman football today. Among the twenty-three letter winners were thirteen seniors, a record proportion, while the juniors and sophomores had five representatives each.
New York City policemen may not, in their capacity as policemen, receive gifts from civilians, Commissioner Valentine emphasized yesterday afternoon.
The Federated Sportsmen's Clubs of Cattaraugus County has voted unanimously to ask State Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne for an open deer season in Western New York.

While Federal conciliators here and in Chicago continued their efforts yesterday to settle the walkout of C. I. O. meat handlers employed by the "big four" packing companies and smaller wholesalers in this city, the situation was complicated by the calling of a strike against the Wilson Packing Company by the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. of L. affiliate with a membership of 25,000 in wholesale and retail establishments.

Major Gen. Alejandro Mange, commander of the Veracruz zone, was wounded early today on the outskirts of that city by farm strikers who are trying to starve out Veracruz in protest against what they declare to be ruinous prices.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States last month is estimated at 46,048 long tons, compared with 40,333 in October and 34,025 in November, last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

An appeal for more toys to be distributed to needy children at Christmas time by the Police and Fire Departments is made by Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner John H. Morris, director of the Police Juvenile Aid Bureau.

CharlesFahy, general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board, was subjected to a searching examination by Supreme Court justices as he argued today in the case of the Ford Motor Company against the board.

Father Alois Blass, parish priest at Fuegen, in Tyrol, has been arrested for a pulpit declaration that immorality charges against nine Innsbruck monks had been proved absolutely false. The monks were released soon after their arrest some weeks ago. Part of their monastery has been taken over by the State.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the death on Tuesday in his home in San Francisco of John A. Carlson, vice president in Charge of the Pacific Coast department at San Francisco, of the fire companies of the America Fore Insurance and Indemnity Group.

Arab terroristic activities have again shifted to Northern Palestine, particularly to Haifa, where in the past few days several Jews have been killed and others wounded in daylight in the streets. As a result of this new wave of terrorism, the military authorities have undertaken energetic steps in that district.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain gave another reassurance to France-although a carefully qualified onewhen he told the House of Commons today that Tunisia definitely was covered by the Anglo-Italian agreement pledging maintenance of the status quo in the Mediterranean.

More than 100 business, civic and political leaders and members of the Brooklyn College faculty took part yesterday afternoon in exercises dedicating a memorial plaque to Dr. Adelbert G. Fradenburgh, the college's first dean who died in 1936.

Nazi authorities agreed today to rebuild one of the twenty synagogues destroyed in the outburst against the Jews last month. They said they would restore at their own expense a temple used by Turkish Jews.

The New York Electric and Gas Corporation challenged today the right of the State's Public Service Commission to assess it for expenses incurred in the examination of subsidiary company books. Commissioner Neal Brewster reserved decision after a hearing.

A 25-carat emerald-cut diamond ring was sold yesterday afternoon for $12,000 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. It was bought by a private collector and was part of a onesession sale of 114 lots of jewelry.

The resignation of John F. Dailey Jr., chief assistant on the staff of Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, whose resignation also is pending, was announced yesterday by Mr. Hardy on the eve of his departure for Palm Beach.

Business was affected to some extent in local markets yesterday by strike of luggers and cutters in branch houses distributing Western dressed meats and kosher business practically stopped in one large slaughter house because of picketing by representatives of kosher retail butchers' union.
A suspicious police highway patrol discovered today what was described as a perambulating "stock swindling shop" in an automobile they halted on the State highway at Hudson Boulevard.

The vacant plot 119 by 122 feet, forming the southeast corner of Sutphin Boulevard and Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by the estate of John Palmieri to the Dale Holding Corporation, through Corwith Brothers, Inc., brokers.

Miss Eliza Helen Ashbridge died at her home in Rosemont last night at the age of 83. She was president of the Women's Pennsylvania Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals for seventeen years; a member of the women's board of the Bryn Mawr Hospital and treasurer of the Women's Christian Union of Bryn Mawr.
" Misfortunes never come singly": such is the English version of a saying found in one form or another in half a dozen languages, condensing the experience of immemorial generations.

Cold weather and a soft track kept attendance down at the Fair Grounds today, but there was an excellent program. Several heavily played favorites came home in front, ore of them being A. Barrera's Phalasan, who won the featured sixth race at six furlongs by a nose from Joanny, with Dusky Prince third.

A warning that spies were setting up a "potential sabotage machine" designed to impair the industrial and military efficiency of the United States in the time of war came today from an investigator for the House Committee on Un-American activities.

George Roth, American member of the crew of the Manhattan, was detained here today pending the Investigation of the charge of seditious activities. As far as can be ascertained Roth is reported to have possessed Communist literature which, police suspect, he intended to circulate in Germany.

Nearly $30,000 of the $40,000 that the Long Island Association is seeking for its World's Fair program in cooperation with the New York State World's Fair Commission has already been contributed or pledged, it was reported yesterday at a luncheon meeting.
Court contests over the millions left by Ella V. Von E. Wendel, eccentric spinster who died in New York City March 13, 1931, had a sequel today in a petition filed with the Board of Tax Appeals.

A rally in the last few seconds enabled the Cathedral basketball team to down Wagner. 29 to 26, last night in a game played on the court of the losers. It was the first victory for Cathedral in four games.

After playing a comparatively minor part in the steel business in the last year the railroads are coming to the aid of the steel mills just when business in other lines is affected by the year-end inclination to hold inventories to a minimum, according to Iron Age's summary this week.
Walter Gray Pietsch, president of Gale Pietsch, Inc., a Chicago advertising company, died today after an illness of nine months. He was 63 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Lynde Selden of this city and Greenwich, Conn., gave a dinner last night at their New York home, 4 East Seventy-second Street, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Selden, to John William Hulme Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hulme of Jackson Heights. Queens.

Morris Milgram, secretary of the Workers Defense League of New Jersey, announced today that Herman Matson, Hoboken chairman of the league, and his wife, Mrs. Elizabeth Matson, had each filed suit for $5,000 damages against the city of Hoboken in the Hudson County Circuit Court here.
Miller H. Pontius will represent F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., in Chicago and adjacent territory and on the Pacific Coast.
Harold Vladika, 24 years old, and his wife, Dorothy, 23, were found dead today in a gas-filled room at 23 Seeley Avenue, here, where they had lived about two weeks, according to police.

Employes of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company in Brooklyn who went on strike Nov. 14 in protest against a contemplated wage cut by the company will return to work today, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.
The Dexter Fellows Tent of the Circus Saints and Sinners of America celebrated its ninth anniversary yesterday by moving to a new "lot" on the roof garden of the Hotel Astor.

Harold Johnson, 36 years old, a deckhand out of work, went to the door of his second-floor flat at 5,717 Fourth Avenue, in Brooklyn, just before noon yesterday when somebody knocked. His wife, Elsie, 31, was behind him. On the floor, at play, was Richard, 4, youngest of their four children.

The British Government has refused a request by Palestine Jews for immediate permission to bring in 10,000 child refugees from Germany, Malcolm MacDonald, Secretary for the Dominions and Colonies, announced in the House of Commons today.
Production of copper and nickel in Canada in October was lower than in October, 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Canada's international trade in securities during October was almost 35 per cent larger than in September, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Sales to all countries were $36,717,482, an increase of more than $5,500,000, and purchases from all countries at $36,960,847 were up nearly $13,500,000.
Ernest O. Thompson, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, said here today that he had sighed an order to continue the Saturday and Sunday shut-downs in 1,2 Texas oil fields until March 31, 1939.
A tumble from a horse turned out today to be worth $30,000 to Archie O. Andrews, New York lawyer. The award was made by a jury in Federal Court against the Hershey Estates.

Investors in realty centered their attention yesterday on tenement properties in Harlem, where several transactions were announced by brokers. The Central Savings Bank disposed of three houses. It sold to an investor the two five-story walkup buildings at 251-253 West 114th Street for cash over a mortgage of $43,000.

Belated covering of December obligations before trading in that delivery ceases at noon tomorrow, in conjunction with better sentiment from a strong stock market, gave impetus yesterday to a sharp recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange here. Closing quotations were at net gains of 5 to 22 points.

Holders of Series QNS-GNY mortgage certificates of the Greater New York-Suffolk Title and Guarantee Company of record of Dec. 16 will receive a principal distribution of 21/2 per cent and an income distribution of 1 per cent payable on Dec. 31, according to Hellinger, Reichart Singer.

The government agreed today to accept $4,284,927.22 in settlement of an alleged deficiency of $10,732,916.16 in taxes on the estate of Henry W. Breyer, Philadelphia ice cream manufacturer, who died in Florida in 936.
Hugh McAlevey, Belfast sportsman, today offered to back Al Delaney of Oshawa, Ont., to the extent of [Pound]1,000 ($4,667) for a fight with Len Harvey, British Empire heavyweight champion.

Rallying twice in the first half, the Manhattan College, Staten Island division, basketball team last night triumphed over Webb Institute on the Manhattan court in New Brighton. The final score was 30 to 25.

Lawrenceville's indoor polo team defeated the Princeton junior varsity team, 18-12, today. The Tigers tied the count at 4-4 in the first chukker, but trailed thereafter. Dr. Henderson was high scorer for the Red and Black with nine goals.

Breakfast party, Limited Editions Club, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, noon. Award of gold medal "to the American author of that book, published in the three years previous to the making of the award, which is considered most nearly to attain the stature of a classic."
ASH--Morris. Funeral today, 10 A. M., from Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Funeral services private.
Canada had a credit balance of $218,200,000 in international payments during 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

To compute the amount due to executives of Loew's, Inc., under profit-sharing agreements, the corporation included in gross profits the sums due in Germany and Italy that could not be remitted because of exchange restrictions, it was testified yesterday in Supreme Court.

The American Bridge Company, Baltimore, submitted to the Navy today a low bid of $1,219,000 for two 350ton Hammerhead cranes for use at the Norfolk and New York Navy Yards. The Dravo Corporation, Pittsburgh, bid $1,393,000 and the Wellman Engineering Company, Cleveland, $1,549,750.
Argentina has assumed command of continental defense strategy at the Eighth Pan-American Conference.
Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran struck a blow yesterday in defense of all bald-headed men when he rebuffed an attempt by a Bronx woman to grow new hair on various barren pates in the city.
Miss Mary E. Dousman, who served for forty years as head librarian of the children's division of the public library, died of a heart attack last night at the age of 78.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Phil L. Rodier, Harry G. Grover, Angelo Joseph C Zerbarini and Joseph M. Nugent, all of New York City, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Any lawyer in any country who believes that his profession is a public trust must view "with dismay and abhorrence the ever-increasing and cumulating violations by the Government of the German Reich of rights heretofore regarded as fundamental in Germany itself as in all civilized countries."

Upholding a property right in a business idea, a jury before Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch yesterday awarded Manuel G. Rodriquez of 400 West 128th Street $6,500 in his suit against the Western Union Telegraph Company.

The story of the rise and fall of F. Donald Coster, president of McKesson Robbins, was told on the witness stand in detail here yesterday by Julian F. Thompson, treasurer of the drug corporation, who accepted responsibility for uncovering the $18,000,000 shortage among its $86,000,000 listed assets.

Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek has swung toward the tactics of Chinese Communists in a new program to combat the Japanese. Officers at this South China military headquarters disclosed today that he had summoned a conference in furtherance of the program, which was announced to the military staff three weeks ago.

Automobile owners who receive summonses for Illegal parking have no right to turn traffic court into a "mail order house," asserted Frank Carey, assistant clerk of the Gates Avenue Court, Brooklyn, yesterday. Letters containing the police tag and $2 "tucked in" have descended on the court in a wave 200 per cent greater than might normally be expected, he explained.
A policyholders' advisory council of the State Insurance Fund for the Albany and Eastern New York district was formed at a meeting here today.

Mrs. Hazard Holmes of this city has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Barbara Holmes Reeves, to John S. Drum Jr. The wedding will take place on Tuesday at the home of Mrs. Holmes, 133 East Sixty-fourth Street.
Asserting that "the spirit of chance is in every red-blooded man or woman," Judge Eugene C. Bonniwell in Municipal Court today acquitted two movie operators of charges of violating the lottery laws.

Cattle prices continued to decline today, with losses running to 25 cents, but hogs developed recovery power, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Best steers and yearlings were unchanged, however. Hogs were moderately active,

Sharp criticism of the Administration's foreign policy as calculated to create enemies abroad, without reference to the desire of the American people for peace, was expressed yesterday by Major Gen. Van Horn Moseley, U. S. A., retired, speaking at the sixty-sixth annual meeting of the New York Board of Trade in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Miss Elaine Wilson, daughter of Mrs. Edgar T. Salisbury of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Alexander R. Wilson, was married here yesterday afternoon in the Riverside Church to Alfred Paul Dohm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman R. Dohm of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Carder, associate minister.

A net profit of $456,889 for the year ended on Oct. 31 was reported yesterday by the Florsheim Shoe Company after deductions for depreciation, reserve for bad debts, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed profits.

A special meeting of shareholders of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware has been called for Dec. 27 to vote on a, plan of recapitalization, involving readjustment of inter-company debt and restatement of the value of assets.

Figures compiled by the Census Bureau offer evidence of the rise of sports as a major American industry. Last year manufacturers of athletic goods turned out $44,000,000 worth of equipment, a gain of 27 per cent over the figure for 1935.

Next Sunday Grand Duke Vladimir Cyrilovitch Czar Vladimir II to Russian monarchists--will go to Berlin. There, it is reliably reported, he will negotiate with Chancellor Adolf Hitler over the future status of Ukraine, after which the monarchists hope one day to pattern that of the whole of Russia.

David M. Lenz, former president of the National Retail Furniture Association, died of a heart. attack today in his office at the Stern Co. store, of which he was vice president and secretary. He was 55 years old.
American claimants for losses in the bombing and sinking of the United States gunboat Panay and in the looting of Nanking are becoming highly critical of Washington's attitude toward their claims.

Clyde A. Edwards, wanted by New York police since last Saturday on a complaint alleging forgery of two checks totaling $325, was found dead of carbon-monoxide fumes in his car on a dirt road between Route 22 and King Street here this morning.

The Morrison Prize of $500 "for the best paper on solar and stellar energy" has been awarded to Professor H. A. Bethe, physicist of Cornell University, for his paper "Energy Production in Stars," it vas announced last night at the annual dinner meeting of the New York Academy of Sciences and Affiliated Societies at the Hotel kstor.
In an at tempt to organize the waste materials industry on a more profitable basis, the Waste Trade Foundation of America today opened its first annual convention here.

An emergency operation performed at sea under difficult conditions was described here yesterday when the American Republics liner Argentina returned from her first voyage to South American ports. The patient, Junior Officer George Dietrich, was recovering rapidly and will sail again on Saturday.

Paul List of Rochester, N. Y., a German citizen illegally in this country who has been fighting deportation to Germany, sailed yesterday on the Oriente of the New York Cuba Mail Line for Havana on a trip to re-enter the United States legally.

Mr. and Mrs. Walker Woods Stevenson of Essex Fells, formerly of Roselle, have announced the engagement of their' daughter, Miss Gretchen Blancke Stevenson, to Walter Whittlesey Bronson 2d, son of Mr. and ye Mrs. Hollister Bronson of New Haven, Conn.

Credit men and executives of the salvaged business joined yesterday in a luncheon honoring Irving Hertz of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association for his part in handling the affairs of the Franklin. Millinery of New York, Inc., which resulted in payment of 100 per cent to creditors and in continued operation of the company.

Daniel S. Griffin, shoe buyer in Gimbel Brothers' central buying office, has resigned, effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Griffin, connected with Gimbel Brothers since the inception of the central buying office, has formed a new connection, details of which will be announced later.
Fordham's basketball team, playing on its home floor, trounced the Montclair State Teachers College quintet, 48 to 24, last night for its third straight victory this season.
The Princeton, Harvard and Yale Club teams were victors last night in Group I as play started in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C tourney.

Word has, been received here of the birth of a daughter to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dabney Thomson of Cincinnati on Sunday in that city. Mrs. Thomson is the former Miss Silvia Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould of New York.

The three-family dwelling with thirteen rooms at 6,913 Twelfth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Home Owners\ Loan Corporation to Giuseppe Coco through the Colonial Realty Company, Inc., brokers, who -also report the sale of the three-story house at 203-Avenue T for the Bowery Savings Bank to Lucy Giordano.

The Securities and Exchange Commission asked Federal District Judge Edward J. Moinet in Detroit today to enjoin the Fidelity Investment Association, which has sold more than $600,000,000 in securities to the public, from engaging in allegedly fraudulent practices.
A new staff of officers was elected last night at the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Golf Association, held in the Della Robbia Room of the Vanderbilt Hotel. Henry S.

A fresh panel of 100 veniremen was brought into Superior Court today, necessitated by the lack of headway in the quest of a jury to try Lieutenant Governor Frank Hayes and twenty-one other defendants charged with defrauding this city of more than $1,000,000.
In the Administration's secret councils on the national defense program some ideas more enthusiastic than sound have naturally been advanced.

Ten corporations and thirty-two individuals were indicted yesterday a Federal grand jury in an alleged conspiracy to divert denatured alcohol to bootleg channels. The plot, according to Roger V. N. Powelson, Assistant United States Attorney, resulted in tax losses to the government of more than $750,000.

Politics, foreign and American, per- committee today emitting, this country well could be rates might bri entering on a long rather than a short business upturn, in the opinion of Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, New York, since 1920.

Miss Margot Lumb, Great Britain's attractive contribution to the realm of court games, captured the Atlantic Coast women's squash racquets championship today by defeating the defending champion, Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia. The score was 15-8, 15-8, 15-11.

Solemn high mass was celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning at 10 o'clock as the second service of a four-day celebration of thanksgiving for Blessed Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini, Italian-born American citizen who recently was beatified.

A film-producing alliance between' Herbert Wilcox, British producer and director, and RKO-Radio was announced yesterday at a press luncheon held at' the Ritz-Carlton and attended by Mr. Wilcox, Anna Neagle, the star of his recent pro'ductions of "Victoria the Great" and "Sixty Glorious Years," and several RKO executives.

The Brooklyn Hebrew Orphan Asylum has cared for 1,121 children this year, Mrs. Max C. Meyer, president of the Women's Auxiliary, reported at the sixtieth annual meeting of the auxiliary yesterday at the orphanage, 373 Ralph Avenue, Brooklyn.
Nicholas V. V. Franchot 2d, insurance man and former Assemblyman, died at his home here this morning at the age of 56.

Preliminary tabulation of Sunday's Parliament election indicated today that Germans had gained only one seat from Lithuanians despite a strong "back to the Reich" campaign, which gave voting the flavor of a plebiscite on the question of rejoining Germany.

GARNETT, JUDITH L. C. (June 25, 1938). Non-resident; gross assets, $38,851; net, $37,140. To sisters, Georgia V. and Laura F. Garnett: brother, Robert S. Garnett; niece, Hannah Evans, and nephew, Larkin G. Hundley, in specified shares. Chief assets, real estate, $38,250; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $601. John P. Carroll, attorney, 189 Montague St.

American exporters have every reason to expect to see their business increase now that the trade agreement with England and her colonies has been signed, Godfrey Haggard, British Consul General, told a group of them attending a luncheon tendered at India House yesterday by James A. Farrell Sr., chairman of the board of the National Foreign Trade Council.

As a spokesman for the "American public," Mayor La Guardia of New York called upon the American Farm Bureau Federation today to confer with organized labor on a program for meeting a national emergency which he declared was far greater than that of 1917.

A property on the upper West Side that had not changed hands in more than thirty years was bought by Murray Maran and Samuel Stein, operators. It is the vacant plot 37 1/2 by 100 feet at 163-65 West Ninety-seventh Street, on the north side of the street about 150 feet east of Amsterdam Avenue.

Mrs. Margaret Emerson announced tonight the engagement of her daughter, Miss Gloria Baker, to Henry J. Topping Jr. The marriage will take place Monday at 1 P. M. at the Emerson villa in the presence of relatives and a few friends.

Alabama will grant Christmas paroles, beginning on Saturday, to 602 prisoners, the largest number that it ever has rewarded for good prison conduct. Hamp Draper, State Convict Deapartment chief, announced completion of a list compiled from recommendations by guards and wardens.

Gold in the amount of $1,200,000 was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here, according to reports to the Federal Reserve Bank. Of an the amount, $700,000 was taken in The Netherlands and $500,000 in England. No movements of gold at this port were reported.

So much of paragraph 13, Special Orders 198, dated Aug. 25, 1938, as continues Capt. Alfred J. Homan, Inf.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until March 8, 1939 is amended so as to continue him on active duty until Feb. 12, 1939.

Miss Suzanne Sturgis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Sturgis of 23 East Seventy-fourth Street, was inproduced to society yesterday at a large luncheon given by her mother at the Pierre. Mrs. Sturgis and her daughter were assisted in receiving by Mrs. William Sturgis of Merrick, L. I., grandmother of the debutante.
A sentence of twenty years in prison with hard labor, and ten years' banishment from Paris after the completion of DENIES the term, was passed today on Mme.

Liberally endowed with experienced, sharp-shooting veterans and speedy, efficient sophomores, most of whom are six-footers, Long IsO'Brien. land University's basketball squad Lewis appears the answer to every court coach's dream. But the well-fortified set-up has not satisfied Clair F. Bee lately.
The former Fuller tract of six acres on the south side of School Lane in Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L. I., has been sold by Mrs. Linnie Davidson through Henry A. Rogers of Douglas L. Elliman Co.

The eighth annual Christmas tea of the Savings Bank Women of the metropolitan area will be held this afternoon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Guests of honor include Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Mills Jr., Mrs. Victor A. Lersner,

A $63,916 drop in November liquor tax receipts under collections for the corresponding month a year ago was reported today by the New Jersey Beverage Tax Division. The yield last month was listed at $685,790, compared with $749,706 for November, 1937.
William B. Leaf, a Zionist leader and former newspaper publisher, died of pneumonia today at his home in this city. He was 63 years old.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it has become a party to twelve additional reorganization proceedings under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Participation of the commission in five other cases already has been announced.

George H. Clayton, a broker and promoter, who was one of six persons indicted six months ago in the alleges $4,000,000 looting of the Continental Securities Corporation, was arrested yesterday in Toronto, according to a report received at District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office.

A plea for the Western World to be patient and give time for Japan to work out a program of reconstruction in China without condemning it in advance was made tonight by Yakichiro Suma, counselor of the Japanese embassy, in an address at the University of Maryland at College Park, Md.

Although the gifts of 346 contributors added $7,315.68 to the 1938 Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, the Fund dropped further behind in comparison with its total on the corresponding day of the appeal a year ago.

The enabling bill, which confers authoritarian powers on the government and President, was passed by the Chamber today by a vote of 148 to 16. In the course of the debate the former Interior Minister, Jan. Czerny, said that CzechoSlovakia in the past had failed to recognize the importance of Germany.

Miss Patricia de Suzzara Verdi and Arthur Freeborn Chace Jr., whose engagement was announced last month, will have twenty-three attendants at their marriage, which will take place on Jan. 7 in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
Mrs. Ella Wilson Kramer, widow of Samuel J. Kramer, commission merchant, died here last night at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Whitman C. Haff, at the age of 79.

Father Knickerbocker's second intracity hockey battle is scheduled tonight in Madison Square Gardenwith more than merely victory at stake. The blue-jerseyed Rangers of Les Patrick and the StarSpangled squad of Red Dutton will wage a struggle to determine possession of second place in the National Hockey League standing.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, told students in Columbia College yesterday that they were entering the most difficult world ever faced by graduates, "a world deeply troubled by the lack of common understanding, common convictions, common inspiration and common standards, both intellectual and moral."

Colonel and Mrs. James R. Branch entertained today at Abingdon. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wyckoff Harris, Mr. and Miss Patric Mrs. J. Terry West, Mr. and Mrs. and Arthur Robert Appleton, Prince and Prin- whose engage cess Balthasar Odescalchi, Mr. and last month, Mrs. Jerome D. Gedney,

Victor A. Bonomo of 832 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, president of the Bonomo Candy and Nut Corporation of 649 MorganAvenue, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, for himself and the corporation, to an information filed by United States Attorney Michael F. Walsh charging Bonomo and his corporation with shipping in interstate commerce candy that consisted wholly or in part of "filthy vegetable substance."

King George VI observed his forty-third birthday today with a quiet family celebration. Greetings from his family and from the heads of other nations poured in, but the empire will not hold its official birthday observance until next June 9.

The first of four performances of Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" was presented by the Juilliard Opera School in the Juilliard concert hall last night. Students were in the cast, and another set of singers will alternate with last night's in the remaining performances. The orchestra and chorus were made up of students, and the sets were designed by a stagecraft class.

Senator Alben W. Barkley, the Senate majority leader, talked for two hours at luncheon today with President Roosevelt about the legislative program, going over all phases of the subject as it will be presented to Congress by the President.

Louis Kassman, a professional bondsman in Brooklyn, who recently pleaded guilty to a charge of subornation of perjury in a fraudulent bail-bond transaction, has given information and documentary evidence regarding irregular bail-bond practices to John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor investigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, it became known yesterday.

Edwin Cooper, a WPA deputy of the Actors Equity Association, said yesterday that he was not one of the deputies who subscribed to the demand for the resignation of George Kondolf as director of the WPA Federal Theatre Project in New York.

Herbert S. Olmsted, flour manufacturer, died here early today at the age of 71 after being ill for a few days. He had been owner of the Shelby Mills since 1889, was one of three men who built the original Medina cold storage plant and formerly owned the Orleans Mills.
With trading volume the second heaviest for the year, prices of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange registered yesterday some sizable gains. Second-grade railroad obligations set the pace.

Strong confidence was expressed yesterday by Harry Uviller, impartial chairman of the dress industry, that the new collective agreement for the dress industry will be negotiated without labor trouble.
The police here arrested today an alleged hotel burglar, who relied on his talents as a female impersonator both for approaching his victims and subsequently escaping from them.

Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee (C. I. O.) removed Francis J. Gorman, president of the United Textile Workers of America, from the T. W. O. C. advisory council today.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, arrived in London today on the eve of the debate in the House of Commons on Britain's new trade policy and on the bill providing for a [Pound]10,000,000 fighting fund for a trade war against Germany.
Edmund J. Drummond, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died suddenly here today of a heart attack at his home, Holley Hill. He would have been 63 years old on Christmas Day.

Purchase by the Railway Express Agency, Inc., of the operating rights and property of the Southeastern Express Company was approved tentatively today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The agreed purchase price is $622,037.
Looking back to those stirring days in the Fall of 1938 (wrote the veteran Central European journalist in his memoirs),
A verdict absolving Dr. Arthur G. Schroeder, sued for $10,000 as being responsible for the death of a patient because the wrong type of blood was transfused, was rendered by a jury today.

A proposal to "vote the Brooklyn Board of Education building out of the budget" was made yesterday to members of the City Council attending a luncheon of the West of Central Park Association at the Empire Hotel, Broadway and Sixty-third Street.

The State Bureau of Motor Vehicles appealed today for the return of seventeen sets of automobile license plates for 1939 that were lost from a truck transporting them from Auburn Prison, where the plates are manufactured, to this city last Friday.

Headed by such prominent youngsters as Porter's Mite, Xalapa Clown, Time Alone and other leading 2-year-olds of 1937, 107 nominees were announced today for the fifth running of the $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby next Feb. 22.
Turpentine firm, 21c; sales 9 barrels; receipts 214 barrels; shipments 35 barrels; stock 53,382 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 654: receipts 908; shipments 199; stock 314,501.

The marriage of Miss Jane Louise Grunewald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict Moret Grunewald, to Pierre Benjamin Clemenceau of Paris, grandson of the wartime Premier of France took place today in the home of the bride's parents here. The Rev. Everett Gill Jr. of the St. Charles Avenue Baptist Church officiated.

Operating revenues of ninety-two Class I railroads in November, made public today by the Association of American Railroads, disclosed an increase of one-tenth of 1 per cent over November, last year, and a decrease of 19.4 per cent from November, 1930.

Ten thousand Japanese students who will graduate next Spring have jobs waiting for them. Three thousand have asked for colonial posts in Manchukuo, Formosa and Korea; 7,000 will go to government offices and industrial companies in Japan.

Richard W. Lawrence, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, said yesterday that the government should take steps to end all purchases of both American and foreign silver by the United States Treasury at the earliest possible time.

The resurgence of the Republican party, overwhelmingly beaten in the 1936 Presidential election, is shown by tabulation of the vote for candidates for Representatives at the last election in all of the fortyeight States, compiled by The Associated Press and made public yesterday.

F. Donald Coster was arrested yesterday in connection with the $18,000,000 apparently missing among the assets of McKesson Robbins, of which he is president. He was fingerprinted and the Federal criminal authorities started an investigation of his past business connections.
Dr, and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler gave a dinner last night at their home, 60 Morningside Drive, for the Countess of Listowel of London.

Germany has replied in indefinite terms to the two representations made by the United States Embassy in Berlin against application to United States citizens of the decree of Dec. 3 for liquidation of Jewish-owned property in Germany.

Mayor La Guardia and his staff will occupy the "World's Fair City Hall" in the Arrowbrook Country Club near the fair site during the Spring and Summer of next year, it was learned last night at City Hall.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, despite reports of coolness between him and the White House, has accepted appointment as chairman of the Hudson County committee for President Roosevelt's birthday celebration for the benefit of victims of infantile paralysis, it was announced yesterday.

How the National Ski Patrol, which is expected to play an important part in the healthy growth of skiing in the next few years, will operate in this country's snow centers this Winter was outlined by C. Minot Dole, chairman of the voluntary organization, at an informal gathering of the press yesterday at the Yale Club.

Electric power production increased contra-seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 98.9, a new "high" for the year. This compared with 96.8 for the preceding week and 98.5 for the week ended Dec. 11, 1937.

The longest training period of his career ended yesterday for Tommy Farr, British heavyweight. Last night, at ease in his Pompton Lakes, N. J., quarters, he awaited the summons to the ring tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden, where he is to fight Lou Nova, California's young title threat. The engagement is scheduled for fifteen rounds.
The boom in this city's marriage license business, caused by the new Maryland law requiring forty-eight hours' notice of intention to wed, requires expansion of facilities to meet the rush.
Giving a sparkling performance, Peter Fick of the New York A. C. scored two victories last night on the swimming program in the New York A. C. pool before a capacity gathering.

Sales of 596 service wholesalers engaged in selling electrical goods for the second quarter of 1938 totaled $83,023,000, an Increase of 14.7 per cent over the first quarter, but a decline of 37.9 per cent from the second quarter of 1937, according to figures in a census survey of business just issued by the Department of Commerce.
Joseph Valentine Stripp was enthusiastic about a number of things today, and among them was being reunited with Leo (Lippy) Durocher, who he predicted would make good as manager of the Dodgers.
Stephen J. Speer, president of the Caldwell National Bank, died in his home here today at the age of 68. He had been stricken with coronary thrombosis on Nov. 25 after his wife had died suddenly.

TODAY'S column continues the review of a year's reviews that was begun here yesterday. These are all books that have been discussed--generally on Fridays and Saturdays-since New Year's Day. And again, the order of mention has no particular significance whatever.
The Maritime Commission called for sealed bids today for the purchase or charter of four combination passenger and cargo ships, the American Legion, Pan America, Southern Cross and Western World.

Officials of the Furness-Prince Line reported yesterday a large increase in shipments of freight from Argentina. The demand for freight ships from Buenos Aires to New York had caused assignment of an extra freighter to the run, it was said.

Two deaths from diphtheria in the week ended last Saturday and a sharp rise in the number of new cases reported in the city brought a warning yesterday from Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, for inoculation of every unimmunized child between the ages of 9 months and 5 years.
Christopher J. Lake, father of Simon Lake, the submarine inventor, died here last night after a long illness. His age was 91.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday have, unless otherwise specified, been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools.

Entirely for reasons of health, he declared, Yotaro Sugimura, the Japanese Ambassador, suddenly left Paris today. Accompanied by his wife, his daughter and two private secretaries, he took a train for Marseilles, where he will embark for Japan tomorrow.

Two young women who work as clerks in Bloomingdale's department store divided a $500 reward yesterday for finding a $15,000 diamond ring that the former wife of Prince Farid of Sadri-Azam of Persia had lost on Saturday.

The following fireman first grade is promoted to the position of Pilot, with compensation at the rate of $3,500 per annum, to take effect at 12:01 A. M., Dec. 15, and shall be charged to the code noted below. He will report to the Assistant chief of Department for assignment to duty:

The Tenth Avenue Charm School, which started functioning early this month, threw open its doors to the press yesterday for a demonstration of what it has done to make young girls of its neighborhood charming.

Mayor Lucius F. Donohue of Bayonne was appointed here today by the Hague-controlled Hudson County Board of Freeholders to the $6,000-a-year post of county physician vacated Monday by City Commissioner Bert Daly of Bayonne.

A lease involving the eventual occupancy of about 100,000 square feet of space in South Brooklyn was announced yesterday when John Morgan, Inc., manufacturers of beverages, took the ground floors of six contiguous buildings of the New York Dock Company, at 31314-15-16-17-18 Van Dyke Street and the second floor in the building at 315, through Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., brokers.

Town Hall, stronghold of cultural decorum and the classic muse, finally gave way yesterday afternoon before the irresistible forces of swing. It happened when Benny Goodman and his orchestra took enough time to participate in a lecture-recital sponsored by the Town Hall, Inc.

An intensified Insurgent bombardment of Madrid and air raids along the eastern Spanish coast today were said to indicate that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's long-delayed offensive might be about to get under way.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's plan to select America's first undisputed college basketball champion advanced a step today as H. G. Olsen, Ohio State University's cage coach, named committees for eight districts which will select one entrant each for the post-season title series.

Roscoe H. Hupper, receiver in admiralty, who operated the steamships Pan America, Southern Cross and Western World under appointment of the United States District Court, presented his final report on operations and administration yesterday to the court.
Unusually high quality in turkeys for Christmas dinners was predicted today by the Farm Credit Administration, which credited the warm Fall weather with a delay in the "finishing" of the turkey crop.

The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during November totaled 596,289 bales of lint and 66,822 of linters, compared with 542,778 and 72,109 in October this year and 482,976 and 57,619 in November last year.
The Department of Agriculture reported today that sales of wheat and flour for export between July 1 and Dec. 10 totaled 71,400,000 bushels.

Muriel Dickson, the Scottish soprano, who gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, has not blushed unseen since her arrival here as a member of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company some years ago.

Authority of the Federal Trade Commission to enforce a proposed wool industry trade practice rule requiring fabric makers to specify the presence of used, reworked or reclaimed wool in their products was challenged at a commission hearing on the rules today by Arthur Besse, speaking for the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

A committee of the Twenty-third Street Association which has been studying the Wagner labor act for the last six months will meet in the association's offices tomorrow afternoon to draft its final report, for action by the organization on Dec. 21.

Elizabeth, Lady Cheylesmore, who had been visiting her brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Amos Tuck French, in Tuxedo Park, is at the Madison before sailing for Bermuda, where she has taken a house for the Winter.

Colonel John K. Brown has been re-elected to a third term as president of the Metropolitan Equestrian Club, it -was announced yesterday. Other officers for 1939 are Leigh J. Sessions of Brooklyn, Theodore Seltzer of Weehawken and Richard C. Heather and August N. Montulet of New York, vice presidents;

The following Marine Corps changes since Dec. 13, were announced today: COLONEL Ostermann, E. A., Quantico, Va., to headquarters, Marine Corps, Washington, D. C.; detailed an assistant adjutant and inspector.

The business of advertising needs public relations work and institutional advertising to fight "a growing army of termites" within its structure, William A. Thomson, director of the bureau of advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told the Advertising Club of Cincinnati at a luncheon meeting yesterday.

The past few days have brought many letters from Pennsylvania sportsmen, and if the writers represent anything like a cross-section of public opinion the game commission of that State is in for some exciting days.

Both Yankee and Giant ball players yet may cast their shadows under are light as well as sunlight on the terrain of the Ruppert Stadium and the Polo Grounds if the trend of deliberations about the Larry MacPhail brand of baseball at the current major league meetings means anything-and it does.

A meeting to protest Nazi persecutions and organize assistance for professional persons who are refugees from Germany was held last night at Mecca Temple under the auspices of the Professional Conference Against Nazi Persecutions.

Various phases of natural history and science comprised a program of brief talks given last night in the American Museum of Natural History at another of the "natural science evenings" in the interests of the ten-year development program of the institution.

Five hundred persons, including teachers who served under him, yesterday attended funeral service for Dr. John Holley Clark, principal emeritus of Flushing High School, at the First Congregational Church, Thirty-eighth Avenue and Bowne Street, Flushing. The Rev. George Drew Egbert officiated.

President Aurelio Mosquera Narvaez dissolved the Constituent Assembly last night after it had returned his note declaring unconstitutional its action in restoring the former dictator, Colonel Luis Larrea Alba, to active service with the rank of general.

The executive board of the Trust Company of North America declared yesterday a bonus to all employes of the bank, excluding officers and executive employes, on the basis of one-half month's salary to all employed prior to Jan. 1, 1937;

One hundred and forty-seven years ago today the Bill of Rights became a part of the Constitution of the United States. In these days, when men and women are harried and oppressed in many quarters of a troubled world, it is useful to read again the simple words which guarantee the liberties we cherish:
Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., is redesigning its main floor in preparation for the World's Fair and has engaged Robert Heller to supervise the work. A new candy shop has been completed.

Charges of maladministration in the estate of Irving I. Bloomingdale, vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, made by the merchant's widow, Mrs. Geanne Hughes Bloomingdale Butler, against Richmond J. Reese, attorney and coexecutor with the widow, were withdrawn yesterday by her attorney, Arthur T. O'Leary, in a proceeding before Surrogate James A. Foley.
The Nicaraguan Democratic Union was formed last night by prominent citizens to fight against foreign interference and cults. Its slogan is "Neither fascism, nazism, nor communism, but democracy."

The General Motors Corporation had 389,509 common and preferred stockholders in the fourth quarter of 1938, compared with 399,255 in the third quarter and 375,755 in the fourth quarter of 1937. The peak was 403,282 in the second quarter this year.

The New York Yankees, missing a perfect score by only 9 points, have been selected as the outstanding sports team of the year by an overwhelming margin. The American League baseball champions, who went on to set a new record by beating the Chicago Cubs in four straight games for their third successive world series victory, were named first by sixtyone of the sixty-seven contributing sports editors, with three votes each for second and third.
Sir George Paish, British economist, voiced the need for a world

Ahthony Eden. spent his last day here today discussing--affairs of state with men who help shape the foreign and domestic policies of the United States. He used well his opportunities to achieve the expressed object of his visit and "learn-about America" during his brief sojourn here.
Samuel Jackson Snead will train his golfing guns on the last big prize of the year in the $10,000 Miami open tomorrow, needing less than $1,000 to send his 1938 tourney earnings beyond $20,000.
The State budget for the next fiscal year-July 1, 1939, to June 30, 1940-will close with a deficit of 4,755,000,000 lire, according to estimates approved by the Cabinet this morning.
Piano shipments during November were the second highest of any month since 1929, W. A. Mennia, secretary of the National Piano Manufacturers Association, announced here today.

On their own applications, to take effect at 12 noon, Dec. 16. CAPTAIN-Thomas F. Farley, 52d Precinct, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Oct. 31. 1896. PATROLMAN-Henry H. Russell, 14th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 1, 1907.

Fourteen jurors, two of them alternates, were chosen yesterday for the General Sessions trial of two alleged members of the Ukrainian Hall gang in the kidnapping and suspected murder of Arthur Fried, 32 years old, a Bronx business man; from the vicinity of his White Plains home on Dec. 4, 1937, for $200,000 ransom.

A special train, the "Irvin Works Special," left the Pennsylvania Station at 11:40 o'clock last night conveying ninety officials of United States Steel Corporation, important customers and representatives of the press to Pittsburgh to attend the formal opening today of Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's new Irvin Works near Clairton, Pa.

In accompaniment to the trial in Los Angeles of her former husband, Martin Snyder, for attempted murder, Miss Ruth Etting was married here today to Myrl Alderman, the former pianist whom Synder is accused of shooting.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order exempting the Laclede Gas Light Company, a direct subsidiary of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, from the provisions of Section 6 (a) of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935,

Arrangements have been made for the sale of a large parcel of real estate in the business section of White Plains by the County of Westchester, in one of the largest deals in recent years involving properties in that city.

An ox horn with English silver mounts, known as the "Pusey horn," because it was said to have been given by King Canute to William Pusey, brought the highest figure today at Christie's sale of William R. Hearst's collection of silver from St. Donat's Castle.

An afternoon reception was given yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Sterling Robertson at their home, 1,220 Park Avenue, to introduce Mrs. Robertson's daughter, Miss Mary Ide Hine, to older friends of the family.
The New York University girls basketball team defeated the Brooklyn College girls on the losers' court last night by 18 to 15 after holding the lead from the start.

Congress, in a plenary session this afternoon, proclaimed Pedro Aguirre Cerda as President-elect in the presence of the full house, with the exception of the Conservative party any other non-supporters of the Leftist victor in the recent elections.

The Brazilian naval training ship Almirante Saldanha, which left NewN York last July for Rio de Janeiro and ran aground at the entrance of San Juan .harbor on July 25, started for home today, towed by a naval tug.

A railroad president told a Senate committee today that lower freight rates might bring the railroads out of their financial difficulties, if accompanies by reduced expenses and an increased traffic. He was G. P.

Accompanied by a nurse, a physician and two attorneys, Mrs. Elma N. Lauer, wife of Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer, went yesterday to the United States Court House and entered a plea of not guilty to an indictment charging her with conspiracy and smuggling.
The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $7,289,849.

R. H. Berger and J. P. Leo Jr. of the New York A. C. and R. Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday advanced to the semi-final round of the Fall Class B and C squash tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club.

Charges of maladministration in the estate of Irving I. Bloomingdale, vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, made by the merchant's widow, Mrs. Geanne Hughes Bloomingdale Butler, against Richmond J. Reese, attorney and coexecutor with the widow, were withdrawn yesterday by her attorney, Arthur T. O'Leary, in a proceeding before Surrogate James A. Foley.
The Nicaraguan Democratic Union was formed last night by prominent citizens to fight against foreign interference and cults. Its slogan is "Neither fascism, nazism, nor communism, but democracy."

The General Motors Corporation had 389,509 common and preferred stockholders in the fourth quarter of 1938, compared with 399,255 in the third quarter and 375,755 in the fourth quarter of 1937. The peak was 403,282 in the second quarter this year.
Piling up an early lead, the Lehigh basketball team defeated Stevens tonight, 43 to 19. The victory was the second straight for the Bethlehem Engineers. The line-up:
The Federal Communications Commission set aside radio facilities today to aid the press in reporting news events. Issuing new rules for miscellaneous radio services, the commission said:

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 13, unless specified: Acushet, Norfolk, to Navy Yard, Washington. Antares, at San Pedro, Dec. 14. Arkansas, New York to Norfolk, Dec. 14. Allegheny, Navy Yard, Washington to Philadelphia, Dec. 14. Boise, at Norfolk, Dec. 14.

Tonight's events: PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "The Princess on the Pea, Federal Music Theatre, 8:30; Mischa Elman, violinist, Hotel Plaza, 8:45; Gunnar Johansen, pianist, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University;
