A 74-year-old clerk in a liquor store fought back at a 19-year-old youth who attempted to holm him a up with an iron pipe in a store at 4,214 Third Avenue, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, last night and started a chase that ended with the capture of the hold-up man.

William E. Levis, president of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, largest manufacturers of glass containers in the country, stated today before the Temporary National Economic Committee that "price-leadership" is followed in the industry.

The cruise liner North Star of the Canadian National Steamships fleet has been bought by Clarke Steamships Line. The North Star, formerly the Prince Henry, has been under charter to the Clarke Line for two years.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company has sold privately to a group of insurance companies and an educational institution $6,000,000 first mortgage's per cent bonds due in 1953 and has obtained from the Chase National Bank a loan of $4,000,000 represented by serial notes due over seven years.

The long-awaited revival in private construction work has not yet materialized. Although preliminary estimates on building activity of all types prepared by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce indicate an increase for 1938 for the fifth consecutive year, the figures are not at all encouraging to those who believe that an upsurge in private operations is essential for a wellordered recovery movement.

An authorized government spokesman said today that Nazi authorities were declining to renew leases on Stateowned properties rented to various Catholic monastic orders and that several monasteries thus had reverted to the government.

Charles E. Denney, president of the Erie Railroad, announced yesterday that net results in November had improved since last year, when a deficit of $916,722 was reported for that month. Loadings to date in December are running about 3 per cent ahead of last year and 2 per cent under November. The company's equipment is sufficient to

The Federal Trade Commission has issued a cease-and-desist order prohibiting unlawful price-fixing in connection with the sale of calcium chloride in any form against Columbia Alkali Corporation, Barberton, Ohio; Dow Chemical Company, Midland, Mich.; Michigan Alkali Company, Wyandotte, Mich., and Solvay Sales Corporation, Syracuse.

Lindsay Bradford, president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company of New York, has been appointed chairman of a committee to arrange the twenty-eighth annual dinner of the trust division of the American Bankers Association, to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Feb. 16.
Brooklyn properties involved in the realty transactions announced yesterday consisted largely of residential parcels.
Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute's three-game winning streak was broken tonight when it bowed to the State College for Teachers, 33 to 31, in a nip-andtuck basketball contest.

First mortgages have been obtained by Joseph F. Holecek for various owners as follows: $46,000 on the two 2-family apartments at 28-47 and 28-49 34th St. Astoria, Queens, for Van Grand Realty Corp; $6,000 on the 2-family dwelling on the southwest corner of Main St and 56th Ave. Flushing. for Herman Hoops, and $4,000 for Camilla Cerella on the 2-family house at 35-35 34th St, Astoria.

During the week ended Dec. 14 member bank reserve balances increased $68,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $30,000,000 in Treasury cash and $25.000.000 in non-member deposits

The New York Curb Exchange has been informed that stockholders of the Moore Corporation, Ltd., and the F. N. Burt Company, Ltd., have approved a merger. The "old" non-voting stock of Pacific Public Service Company, which has been reclassified into new common stock, has been stricken from the Curb Exchange list.

A jury in Supreme Court before Justice William T. Collins found unanimously yesterday that William Conway, former general manager of the Brooklyn Salvage Company, had been unjustly dismissed as superintendent of final disposition in the Sanitation Department, clearing the way for a court order directing his reinstatement.

New life insurance written in November was 1.5 per cent less than that of the same month last year, while the total for the first eleven months this year was 20.4 per cent below that for the same part of 1937, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reported yesterday to the United States Department of Commerce.

Seventy persons will have been killed by automobile accidents in this State in the eleven days before Christmas, according to a forecast by Robert J. Maloy, statistician of the State Motor Vehicle Bureaux Last year eightyeight persons died in motor mishaps in the same period before Christmas, Mr. Maloy said, adding that traffic fatalities so far this year were running 20 per cent under 1937.

The possibility of a rate war in the United States-India steamship trade is suggested in notifications being sent out to shipping agents by the Kerr Steamship Company, Inc., reporting the company's failure to gain admission to the United States Atlantic and Gulf-India and Ceylon Conference.
New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred by Herbert H. Wurtzler to Charles M. Bull Jr. of Bull Eldredge, and by Harry Kahn to Harry Kahn Jr.
Colonel Walter J. Crafts, national treasurer of the Volunteers of America, died on Wednesday in his home, 3,605 Avenue I, Brooklyn, of a stroke. He was 73 years old.
Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Brazil, arrived from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

The John B. Stetson Company, Philadelphia hat manufacturer, opened a group of new wholesale showrooms and offices yesterday at 475 Fifth Avenue with a fashion display attended by millinery buyers and fashion writers.
Seven persons were killed in a battle between agrarians in the town of San Salvador Acaete, State of Veracruz, the newspaper Noticias reports today.

An eight-month survey of printed direct mail promotion among 7,000 business and advertising executives just completed by Blanchard Press, Inc., has revealed that 72 per cent of the advertisers participating reported handling their entire volume of direct mail in their own advertising departments.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, will hold a five-day celebration of the seventy-eighth birthday of its founder, Miss Henrietta Szold, beginning tomorrow with gatherings in fortysix States.
We have come to look forward to Secretary Wallace's annual reports as models of what such documents should be. The report published today maintains his previous standard.

The American Farm Bureau Federation today endorsed the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 and urged President Roosevelt to call a meeting of industrial, labor and agricultural representatives to work out a program for economic balance among the groups.

Trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here was at a minimum today. While the undertone was steady yearly, the market started to ease late in the session in sympathy with corn and on a sharp recession in Winnipeg. Closing trades were at net losses of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel.

It is reliably reported here that a shipment of arms was landed at Puerto Cortes for the government of Honduras recently. Although an agreement not to import armsmade by Honduras and Nicaragua in the presence of the commission attempting g to settle the boundary dispute between the two countrieslapsed last Saturday, it is understood Nicaragua has protested to the boundary commission here.

The second in a series of matches between men's and women's teams under the auspices of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets As- Eq Bray sociation resulted in a 3-2 victory for the men on the courts of the Junior League yesterday.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was reported tonight to have flown to Sian, capital of Shensi Province, to inspect defenses on the northwestern Chinese front in anticipation of a Japanese offensive.
About 200 students of Lansingburg High School refused to return to classes after the noon recess today in protest against what they described as "mistreatment of a sophomore by the principal."

The breaking of ground yesterday in Washington for a memorial to Thomas Jefferson must recall for all of us the directions which that great American left behind him (written on the back of an old letter) for a monument to mark a simple grave.

Customers' orders to buy exceeded in se value customers' orders to sell in odd-lot transactions on the New tr York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Dec. 10, but buying orders and shares were smaller in number, the Securities Exchange Commis- G sion announced today.

After a woman had been selected today as the eighth juror in the Waterbury municipal fraud trial, the court stated that tomorrow a third panel of veniremen would be drawn, it having become apparent that a jury could not be obtained from the 272 persons thus far summoned for examination.

Mrs. Kenneth S. Walker, a grandniece of the late Theodore Roosevelt, is chairman of a committee in charge of a benefit to be held on Sunday night at Town Hall to augment the educational fund of Roosevelt House.

Exports of coffee from Guatemala from Oct. 28 to Dec. 1 were 91,502 sacks of sixty kilograms each, compared with 15,824 sacks in October and 67,362 in November, 1937, the Department of Commerce has been informed by its attache in Guatemala.

The Police Department announced here yesterday that F. Donald Coster, president of McKesson Robbins, an $86,000,000 drug corporation, was really an ex-convict who changed his name. His past caught up with him after a week's investigation failed to locate $18,000,000 of the drug corporation's assets.

Charges by a former nurse of overcrowding, incompetent service and lack of nursing personnel in city hospitals aroused members of a State commission yesterday to dispute and challenge the witness and request the recall of Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, or other officials "to counteract this testimony, if they can."

Keepers at the Brooklyn City prison by an error in identity permitted Benjamin Herman, 25 years old, of 654 Hendrix Street, Brooklyn, a prisoner, to saunter freely through the prison door to liberty at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The huge reserve fund for old-age pensions, which according to some estimates would total $47,000,000,000 by 1980, would become unnecessary under recommendations proposed by the Social Security Board's advisory council, reported today.

The sale of rare books and manuscripts at the book auction dinner held at the Hotel Plaza a week ago for the benefit of refugees from Germany and Austria netted more than $30,000, it was announced yesterday.

A third-period goal by Ralph (Cooney) Weiland gave the Boston Bruins a 1-0 victory tonight over the Montreal Canadiens, stretched the Bruins' victory string to five straight, and gave Goalie Frank Brimsek his fourth shut-out in his last five National Hockey League games.
A banking group composed of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, the Northern Trust Company, First National Bank, City National Bank and the American National Bank, all of Chicago,

Building plans submitted yesterday by architects included a project for fifty houses at Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. The buildings will be two stories high and will accommodate from four to twelve families each.

The Public Service Company of Colorado withdrew yesterday registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed issuance of $50,000,000 of mortgage bonds and debentures and 50,000 shares of preferred stock.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler told 3,000 German road workers tonight that Germany had about reached the limit of her food production and the country's consumption would have to be adjusted accordingly.
A Polish night club entertainer pointed proudly to

David W. Cannon Jr., an instructor in psychology at the Junior State College from 1932 to 1936 and for the last two years a student at Columbia University, where he was a candidate for a Ph. D. in Education, died yesterday. His age was 28. He was the son of the Rev. David W. Cannon.
William R. Tracy, vice president of the Hudson Motor Car Company, announced yesterday that domestic retail sales for November were greater than for any other month in the past year.
As had been indicated, the new Charles MacArthur-Ben Hecht comedy, "Ladies and Gentlemen," soon will be produced by Gilbert Miller, who sails tomorrow from England to begin casting.

" Rugged individualism" for the nation's farmers was relegated to limbo by Secretary Wallace as, in his annual report on the Department of Agriculture, he said today that the task of getting agriculture "back on a business footing" demanded "wellconceived national programs."

Superior to last year's varsity in several respects and with experienced cagers on hand, the St. John's University basketball squad appears capable of enjoying a banner campaign even though numerous contests on the schedule would be certain pitfalls for an ordinary team.

The Public Service Commission's investigation into accounting methods of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation will be resumed in New York City on next Wednesday, Neal Brewster, commissioner, said today.

George R. Lawrence, who was called the father of flashlight photography and who took the first aerial photographs ever made by a commercial photographer; died today in his home here. He was 70 years old.
Many parties were given last night in connection with the dinner dance in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador, held under the auspices of the Service Club of St. Thomas Church.

It was learned today that the continuing controversy over the attitude of the Eighth Pan-American Conference on continental solidarity springs from the United States' proposal for an additional protocol to the consultative pact signed at the Buenos Aires [Argentina] conference for the maintenance of peace two years ago.

The Federal grand jury which recently indicted George Burns, radio and motion picture comedian, who promptly pleaded guilty to a smuggling charge, heard the testimony yesterday of Sophie Tucker, Sally Eilers and Jack Pearl.

Robert Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club and Norman Forster of the New York A. C. came through as the finalists yesterday in the Class B and C squash tennis tournament on the courts of the New York Athletic Club.
Today will find the New Jersey woods silent, for the upland game season closed at dusk yesterday, but tomorrow morning will find the brief quiet shattered by the guns of the deer hunters.
Thomas C. Sheehan, retired president of Durham-Duplex Razor Company, who suffered a stroke on Dec. 8, died here yesterday in Mountainside Hospital.

The boundaries of Central European nations change so fast that WPA workers who prepare charts and other objective teaching devices for use in the public schools have been instructed to stop. making maps of Central Europe until the reshuffling of territory slows down a little, the WPA announced yesterday.

Walton Ave (11-2826), s e cor of 176th St, 102x26: Ambon Realty Corp to Jennie Goldklang, 1,755 Clay Ave; mtg 534,562. Davidson Ave (11-3204), w a, 458 ft a of 192d St, 58x100; New York Trust Co, trustee, to Dason Building Corp, 165 Broadway.
Most classes of bonds, except United States Government obligations, extended their broad upward movement yesterday in the heaviest trading on the New York Stock Exchange this year.

The ten-room residence at 129 Walworth Avenue, White Plains, has been purchased by Mae Ullum for her own occupancy. The seller, the Maycol Realty Company, was represented in the deal by Wolf Kohn, and the buyer was represented by John Bakerman.

This city was digging its way out tonight after a freak blizzard had blanketed the country for twentyfive miles around with more than a foot of snow and left one dead and a score injured in highway accidents.

A training school to coach 150 prize cows from American and Canadian farms in their World's Fair paces as they perform daily for fair visitors in the demonstration of an electrical milking device will be started February at the exhibit building of the Borden Company, officials announced yesterday.

Kenneth Mackenzie Murchison, architect and writer, vice president of the Central Savings Bank and one of the organizers of the Beaux Arts Ball, dropped dead at 11:45 o'clock last night near a change booth as he was emerging from the I. R. T. station in Grand Central Terminal. He was in his sixtyseventh year.

Active trading in packer hides developed yesterday, and sales and bookings to packer connections were estimated to have exceeded 100,000 units for the day. This followed a similar active day last week and, with yesterday's prices showing advances of 1/2 cent, packers were so well sold up that they refused further bids and made no further offerings yesterday afternoon.

Joseph Hahn-Korff, a German subject, who described himself as secretary of the New Orleans League for the Restoration of Aryan Supremacy in America, was convicted by a Federal court jury today on a charge of sending "scurrilous" matter through the mails.

Before a distinguished gathering di of educators, churchmen and lay friends of Union Theological Seminary, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, received yesterday the honorary degree of Docteur en Theologie from the Faculte Libre de Theologie Protestante of Paris, the Protestant Seminary of the University of Paris.

Efforts of the Memphis Power and Light Company today to open negotiations with the city of Memphis for purchase of the utility's electric and gas properties, or of its electrical distribution properties alone for $13,500,000,

Perhaps the most useful service of the current report of the Carnegie Corporation will be to diminish the fears that our great educational, scientific and cultural foundations are doomed to slow starvation.
George Roth, member ,of the liner Manhattan's crew who is being detained here charged with seditious activities, will not be brought to trial before the People's Tribunal in Berlin.

Former State senator Reuben L. Gledhill died suddenly in a room in the Central Courts Building in Brooklyn last night, a few minutes after taking part in a debate over parliamentary procedure at a meeting of the Kings County Grand Jurors Association, meeting for its annual election of officers.

King Carol today signed a decree creating the "Front of National Renascence," which will be the sole political organization within the State and will be solely qualified to nominate candidates for election to Parliament and to administrative and professional councils.

Counsel for the Petroleum Dealers' Chamber of Commerce of New York, Inc., and for the Garage and Gasoline Station Operators' Council of Greater New York issued statements yesterday denying that a gasoline dealers' licensing bill, now under consideration by the General Welfare Committee of the City Council, would serve as "an entering wedge" for price-fixing of service-station products within the city, as had been charged by the Automobile Club of New York.

A New York Police captain who was lent to the Philippine Government to help organize its constabulary in Manila has been questioned by Securities and Exchange Commission investigators in their inquiry into the activities of William Bucknet and William J. Gillespie, it was revealed yesterday.

UNITED STATES HOSPITAL ATTENDANT-New York, N. Y. Veterans Administration facility, $1,020 to $1,260 a year (less $372 or $396 for quarters, subsistence and laundry). Public Health Service, $1,080 to $1,200 a year (less $450 for quarters, subsistence and laundry). A person who enters this examination will not be allowed to enter any other examination for which the receipt of applications will close on Dec. 19.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain again dared Nazi displeasure today by drawing a distinction between the rulers and the people of Germany. At the same time he implied a warning of Britain's staying powers in the event of war.
The general level of wholesale prices dropped in the week ended on Dec. 10 to the lowest point since late in December, 1934, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

A Federal jury today acquitted former Brig. Gen. Alexander E. Williams, and Nathan and Joseph Silverman Jr., war goods buyers, of charges that they conspired in 1934 to prevent a witness from testifying before the House Military Committee. The verdict came after three hours.

The Salle Santelli A team, national champion, retained the Cartier Trophy last night when it defeated the Salle d'Armes Vince, 5 to 3, in the finals of the open team foils tournament held on the strips of the Saltus Fencing Club in the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C. A.
The Rev. Frederick Perkins, dean of Southern Tier Presbyterian clergymen in point of service, died this afternoon in a hospital here as the result of a heart ailment. He was 73 years old.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the housing discussion three interested groups seem adequately represented. They are the builders and material men, the architects and engineers, and the publicists and welfare workers.

Members of the Board of Estimate criticized the design of the. new $6,414,000 Hunter College Building at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street yesterday as they approved the granting of a $2,453,000 general construction contract for the project.

MANHATTAN ALDERMESHIAN JOHN (Dec. 9.). Estate $17,000. To Moorad Alder, Son, Homestead, Pa., and Vahan Alder, Son, executor, 34-59 43d St., Astoria, residue equally: ten varying bequests. Tickran Dadourian, 100 Bajart Pl., Yonkers, and Entozag Kazangian, 578 E. 163d St., executors.

William Meade Prince's picture of last Sunday, donated as his contribution to the Hundred Neediest Cases, was titled "Last Straw." Its theme was the simple, familiar, poignant letter to Santa Claus asking for a doll.

Daniel C. Roper, 72-year-old Secretary of Commerce, resigned today the Cabinet post he had held since President Roosevelt's inauguration in 1933. He gave as his reason for retirement a desire "to return to private life," and President Roosevelt accepted the resignation "with very sincere regret."
At the annual stockholders', meeting of the French Line today, its president, Marcel Olivier, drew a bright picture of the company's financial progress during the last three years.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry T. F. Johnson of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Johnson, to Richard Emmett Berlin of 399 Park Avenue, son of Mrs. Richard Berlin of Piedmont, Calif., and the late Mr. Berlin.

Nicholas M. .Schenck, president of Loews, Inc., testified yesterday in Supreme Court that the late Marcus Loew, for many years head of the company, had persuaded him in 1926, against his own inclination, to remain with the firm.
Wigan defeated Barrow, 8-7, in an English Rugby League match at Barrow today. At Dublin, Oxford University downed the Dublin Wanderers, 13-8, in a contest under Rugby Union Rules.
Dr. Lucius Donohue, Mayor of Bayonne, was inducted today as County Physician of Hudson by Common Pleas Judge Robert V. Kinkead in the County Court House here. Dr. Donohue succeeds Dr. Bert J. Daly,

The larger Chicago department stores have definitely given up hope of a holiday sales total in dollars that will be equal to last year. One big house is within striking distance of the 1937 figures and may possibly pass them next week, but the declines with the others run from 5 to 10 per cent.
The Organization of Supply To a large degree the problem of an adequate national defense is an industrial problem rather than a military problem.
A New York power expert told Congressional investigators today that private utilities could make good profits selling electricity at the low rates charged by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Schedules in varsity swimming and fencing and freshman basketball and awards for the Fall season in varsity and freshman football and cross-country at Fordham were announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manger of athletics.

An audience of more than 6,000 persons that jammed the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, last night booed the Federal Communications Commission, President Roosevelt, broadcasting systems and individual stations at a mass meeting of the Committee for the Defense of American Constitutional Rights.

President Roosevelt, praising Thomas Jefferson for his services in estabfishing "the practical operation of the American Government as a democracy and not an autocracy," took part today in ground-breaking ceremonies marking the start of construction of the $3,000,000 Jefferson Memorial.

The St. Nicks hockey team avenged an early season setback when it defeated Princeton University, 6-2, lat night at the Broklyn Ice Palace. Iot was the New Yorkers' ninth victory of the season as against the one setback by the Tiger sextet.
Albert G. Brock, president of the Pacific National Bank here, died in his home today of pneumonia. He was 76 years old.
William Alexander Campbell, for more than twenty-five years editor and publisher of The Helena Daily Independent, died today at a Kirkland, Wash., hospital, members of his family were advised.

Lumber production Increased last week, countering a seasonal decline, and the adjusted index advanced to 72.7 from 69.4. For the week ended Dec. 11, 1937, the figure was 56.5. Shipments and orders declined, according to the reports wired especially to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the various regional associations.

E. Townsend Irvin was elected commodore of the New York Yacht Club last night at the annual meeting at the West Forty-fourth Street clubhouse while George E. Roosevelt moved up from rear commodore to vice commodore and Gerard B. Lambert became rear commodore.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross sent out this week Christmas bags for 4,100 invalid veterans and war nurses, General Robert C. Davis, executive director, announced yesterday. The chapter sent a gift bag to every man and woman known to have enlisted in Manhattan and the Bronx who is now In a-hospital or soldiers' home in the United States. Gifts were sent to veterans in sixty-one institutions.

With a further improvement in Liverpool quotations and another rise in the stock market, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange opened higher yesterday, but the best records were made on the call and the list ended unchanged to 5 points higher than Wednesday.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sails today for Southampton, via Plymouth and Cherbourg. Passengers include Anthony Eden, former Secretary for Foreign Affairs in Great Britain; Mrs. Eden, Ronald Tree, M. P.; Lady Daphne Straight, Sir Martin Beckett,- Viscount and Viscountess Harcourt, Baroness Ravensdale, Countess de Krieth, Countess Cittadine, Countess de Castateni, Sir Keith Price, Sir Samuel Walder, Mrs. E. B. H. Earl,
New York financial writers will stage tonight their first annual satirical revue before an audience of leaders of government, finance and industry in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor.
The stock market did its best yesterday to follow through on Wednesday's sharp advance, and at the high point of the day leading issues were up from fractions to more than 1 point.

The commercial, industrial and Agricultural loans of reporting memer banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City fell $16,000,000 in the reek ended on Wednesday' to ;1,408,000,000, according to the statenent of condition of the banks, isqued yesterday.
Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe yesterday adjourned to Jan. 12 a scheduled hearing on the proposed plan of reorganization for the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation.
How grave the breach between Italy and France is was emphasized today by the Fascist party itself when its Secretary General, Achille Starace,
Costa Rica, sometimes called the most democratic country in Latin America, pays its President less than $300 a month and yet seems to get honest executives who leave the office poor men.

J. Frank Carey, president of t Frederick H. Levey Company, printing ink manufacturing firm, died yesterday in his Montgomery County home at the age of 41. Mr. Carey, a native of New York, recently invented a fast-drying ink for use in color printing.

Military training for the young men in the camps of the Civilian Conservation Corps -- a proposal championed by many advocates of preparedness - is widely approved by the voting public, according to a survey Just completed by the American Institute of Public

For the first eleven months of this year daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas were 7.5 per cent below the corresponding period of 1937, while for November of this year they were about 1 per cent higher than last November, according to estimates of the Department of Commerce, published here today.

Descendants of the Ministers in William E. Gladstone's first Cabinet gathered tonight around a table in the famous Devonshire Club, former stronghold of the Liberal party, to celebrate the seventieth anniversary of the formation of that Cabinet, which was said to have been accomplished within its walls.

Dr. William MacDonald, historian,. journalist and educator, died yesterday in his home at 52 Jane Street after a week's illness. He was 75 years old. Dr. MacDonald was the author of many books on historical and economic subjects. His most recent work, "The Menace of Recovery," published four years ago, criticized the NRA and the Roosevelt program.

Four members of the election board of the Third District in Bayonne's Second Ward were acquitted tonight in Common Pleas Court here after a trial on charges of violating the election laws in the Republican primary of last year.
The Knickerbocker Ice Company sold to the American Ice Company the ice plant, a frame building on a plot 175 by 100, at 19-31 West Fifty-fifth Street, Bayonne, N. J.

The four-story, sixteen-family apartment house at 86-25 162d Street, corner of Eighty-sixth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, has been purchased by an investing client of Sylvester F. atte from Mrs. C. Longabarde.
With some 2,000 persons cramming every inch of available space, the New York University basketball team defeated Colgate last night on the University Heights court.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight their first State reception of the season, entertaining in honor of the diplomatic corps.

Captain Reuben Savidge, marine superintendent of the Cullen Transportation Company and for fifty years well known in the towing business in Atlantic coastal waters, died on Wednesday at his home, 246 Ninetieth Street, Brooklyn, in his seventy-fifth year.
The former Colombian liners Colombia and Haiti, now the Mexico and Puerto Rico, were formally transferred yesterday to their new owners, the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Company.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pratt McKean of Willow Tree Farm, Beverly Farms, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth McKean, to Robert Bennet Forbes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Forbes of this city and Broadfields, Westwood.
Sir Robert McDougall, a member of a famous flour milling faraily, who was known widely for his gifts to the National Trust, which preserves beauty spots in this country, died today at the age of 67.

An indication that Soviet authorities are planning to crack down on workers who are habitually absent without leave, who migrate from job to job or who take improper advantage of social insurance benefits is seen in publication by several leading
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Dec. 3 amounted to 271,065,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines.

A determined band of stick-wielders wearing the livery of the New York Americans sought to square matters with their Gotham rivals, the Rangers, in the second of the season's intracity games at Madison Square Garden last night.
The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today the application of the Washington Railway and Electric Company for exemption as a holding company under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Sales of houses in Flushing and Bayside featured realty trading on Long Island yesterday. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to Mary L. Evans of Johnstown, N. Y., for investment the two dwellings at 32-16 and 32-18 204th Street, Bayside. H.

The boycott against German-made gloves is "100 per cent," according to a statement made here today by A. H. Walker of Julius Kayser Company of New York. Appearing before Merle D. Vincent, chief of the hearings and exemptions section of the Wages and Hours Division of the Department of Labor, Mr. Walker said that the boycott has been extended to those areas of Czechoslovakia annexed by Germany under the Munich pact. added.
Columbia's varsity wrestling team overcame Lafayette, 23 to 11, in the Columbia gymnasium last night, scoring its second victory in as many matches. It was the first contest for Lafayette.
The advance of $40,000,000 in excess reserves of all member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the last week lifted the total to a high record of $3,480,000,000.
The annual German Exposition and Christmas Market at Grand Central Palace, held to "create better understanding and economic friendship between Germany and the United States,"
Dr. Walter B. Weaver, president of Wiedemann Brewing Company of Newport, Ky., and former Hamilton County (Ohio) coroner, died here today of heart attack.
Police Lieutenant William J. Dooley, attached to the 111th Precinct, Griffen Avenue and 214th Place, Bayside, Queens, died of a heart attack about 9 o'clock last night at his home at 89-67 218thb

The index of machine tool orders in November stood at 112.2, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported today. The figure compares with 118.1 in October, 120.9 in August, highest point of the year to date, and 127.7 in November, 1937.

Without fanfare the Statue of Liberty functioned as usual yesterday and climbed to the top. Offitwenty months for repair work. A total of 135 persons visited Miss Liberty on Bedloe's Island yesterday and climbed to her top.

Anthony Eden returned to New York from Washington last night to speak at a private dinner of the Council on Foreign Relations after a visit to the grave of his colonial ancestor, Sir Robert Eden, last Provincial Governor of Maryland, at Annapolrs, and a hasty visit to Baltimore, where he received a warm welcome.
One of the better third basemen of the American League received notice to change his uniform for 1939 when Frank (Pinky) Higgins was traded yesterday by the Red Sox to the Tigers.

In its annual report, submitted today to a Governor Moore, the Civil Service Commission said the State's payroll during the fiscal year ended last June 30 was $22,123,585, compared with $18,548,880 the preceding year, and that the number of employes rose from 11,851 to 12,986.

The Agfa Ansco Corporation of Binghamton, N. Y., manufacturer of cameras and photographic materials, announced yesterday a Christmas bonus of $125,000 to be distribu- t ted this week among about 2,600 employes.
The Holborn Borough Council of London approved in principle tonight the construction of an underground airraid shelter beneath famous Russell Square to house 77,000 persons.
Lady Willison, journalist and writer of books and the widow of Sir John Willison, who at one time held the chief editorship of the former Toronto Globe, died today of a heart attack at her home.
It is more than understandable, it seems inevitable, that William H. (Big Bill) Thompson should be trying for a fourth term as Mayor of Chi-
Topping the list at five pounds over scale, Seabiscuit drew 134 pounds when weights were announced late today for the 107 candidates for the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap March 4, 1939.

Full rights of Spanish citizenship were restored to former King Alfonso by the Spanish Rebel Government under a decree promulgated here tonight. The decree was approved by the Council of Ministers presided over by Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
About 30,000 square feet of space in the basement and ground floor of 200 Madison Avenue has been leased by the Berkey Gay Furniture Company of Grand Rapids, Mich., through the Cross Brown Company.

Four young government scientists, with an aggregate service of fiftythree years in the Agriculture Department, received appointments today as directors of the four new Federal agricultural research laboratories.
Chauncey Devereux Stillman gave a dinner followed by dancing last night at River House for Miss Nathalie Simpkins, debutante daughter of Willard S. Simpkins of Bedford Hills, N. Y., and this city.

A sharp note, which was regarded as a final statement of the position of the Unitdd States, was sent to Berlin yesterday. The fourth American communication on the subject, it demanded that our citizens should not be subJected to anti-Jewish decrees.

The Bank of Canada reported today in its statement for the week ended yesterday that its ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 54.51 per cent, against 54.53 per cent a week before.
Directors of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company approved yesterday the transfer of $5,000,000 rie from the undivided profit account to the surplus fund, increasing the surplus to $50.000.000.

James Starr, assistant secretary-treasurer of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee who has been acting as secretary-treasurer of the United Textile Workers while that organization was being absorbed into the T. W. O. C., declared today that the demand made on him for surrender of the U. T. W.'s books and property by Francis J. Gorman was an "impertinence."
President Roosevelt and Senator Pittman, chairman of the Foreign Relatoins Committee,

Turpentine firm, 211/2c; sales, 102 barrels; receipts, 1171 barrels; shipments, 975 barrels; stock, 52,578 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 455 barrels; receipts, 910 barrels; shipments, 815 barrels; stock, 314,596 barrels.

At a meeting yesterday of the directors of Abraham Straus, Inc., a final dividend for the year of 871/2 cents was authorized to holders of the common stock. This brought dividends for the year to $2 a share, against $3 paid in the 1937 fiscal year.
Erie Boon of Chatteris, Cambridgeshire, won the British lightweight championship tonight by knocking out champion Dave Crowley in the thirteenth round of their fifteen-round bout at Harringay.

The week's engineering construction award volume, with $60,208,000, exceeds the figure in the same week of last year by 69 per cent, both public and private work registering gains over the 1937 totals, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Authorities here were advised today that former Governor James R. Fugate, famous American old-timer noted for his ability amicably to control the Moros and other non-Christian tribes in the Philippines, had been murdered.

Loadings of revenue freight for the ended on Dec. 10 totaled 619,340 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 29,746 cars, or 4.6 per cent, less than for the preceding week, 74 cars, or 0.01 per cent,

Shortwave programs from the United States in the language of the people to whom they are sent exceed in volume, scope and number those of any other country to Latin America, Frank E. Mason, vice president of the National Broadcasting Company, told the Federal Communications Commission at today's hearing.

A total of 221 athletic awards to Princeton undergraduates for intercollegiate competition in three sports this Fall was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, graduate manager of athletics. The list topped last year's total of 199.

Godfrey D. N. Haggard, new British Consul here, and Mrs. Haggard were honored yesterday afternoon at a reception given for them by the directors of the Travelers Aid Society at the organization's headquarters, 144 East Forty-fourth Street.

Miss Katharine Miller Leas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Stewart Leas of Weldon, Haverford, was married this afternoon to Curtis B. Dall of New York, son of Mrs. Charles Austin Dall of New York and of the late Mr. Dall. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Rex S. Clements at Weldon.
Amsterdam Ave, 2,284, 6-story tenement, 100x35; Edward J. Moore, et al, against Irving Gluckman; due, $64.548, taxes, etc, $2,284; to plaintiff for $20,000.

Secretary Ickes formally declared himself today out of the race for Mayor of Chicago. He said in a statement that after long study and consultations with friends, and at President Roosevelt's request, he had decided he could best serve the New Deal by remaining in the national Administration.

United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy, arriving last night for a vacation from his post in London, declared that the British Government's appeasement policy in Europe's muddled political affairs had not brought the expected results, but that the efforts must continue, or give way to chaos or war.
Edward G. B. Hudson of Scarsdale, N. Y., was elected president of the Patchogue Citizens Bank and Trust Company by the directors tonight. Mr. Hudson,

' Due to an injury to his ankle which prevented him from playing, Ray Flske of the Bayside Tennis Club was forced to default to J. J. Reynolds of the Columbia Club last night in the Long Island champion- nis ship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association at the Jackson Heights Squash Club.
Mrs. Alice Blackwell Frost, widow of Francis W. Frost, died last night at her home here. Her husband was a brother of the late Charles Hamilton Frost, a former owner of The Plainfield Courier News.
Robert Balfour, who will retire on Dec. 31 as general manager of the Railway Express Agency in this city, was honored last night by 200 of his associates at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore.

James Coburn Musser, general manager of the Eberhard Faber Pencil Company, has leased an entire floor in 25 Sutton Place, consisting of eleven rooms and five baths, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.
Dr. Alexander Loudon, newly appointed Minister to the United States from The Netherlands, arrived yesterday on the HollandAmerican liner Nieuw Amsterdam, accompanied by his wife,

Light supplies of steers and yearlings cleared fairly active today at 15 to 25 cent higher prices, reports the United States Department of Agriculture. Best medium weight steers sold at $12.25. Hogs ruled unevenly steady to 15 cents lower, top at $7.50 on lightweights. Fat lambs were mostly steady, selling downward from $9.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, In francs:
The Harvard Club and University Club teams remained in a tie for first place in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A championship by scoring victories last night.

Harvey A. Gordon, national camp engineer for the Boy Scouts of America and a member of the American Association of Engineers, died yesterday at his home, 290 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. He was 54 years old.
Republican enrollments in the four cities of Westchester County total 66,396, compared with 40,300 Democratic, the County Board of Elections announced today.

The marriage of Philip M. Plant and Miss Marjorie King took place yesterday at the home of Mr. Plant's mother,' Mrs. William Hayward, at 1,051 Fifth Avenue, with the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner performing the ceremony.

A client of Nehring Bros., Inc., has purchased from the Broadwood Realty Corporation the five-story apartment at 870 West 180th Street. There are eighty-nine rooms in the house, the apartments being of four and five rooms.

The careless right geometry Of trees against a hill of snow Disarms the little math I know, For the angle of branches against the sky Informs the accomplished country eye Of the kind of tree, the kind of fruit, And the length, proportionate, of root.
Money market was quiet, and quotations for all classes of loans remained unchanged.

Death Announced Retired Lieutenant Toby Franks, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 28, residing at 1,810 Loring P1. South, Bronx, died Dec. 14. Funeral will take place from Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan, at 11:30 A. M., Friday, Dec. 16. Interment at Mt. Hebron CemeThe deputy chief of the 4th Division shall detail .one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen, as funeral escort.

Two examples of Chinese block printing, antedating the Gutenberg Bible, are part of an exhibition of more than 200 examples of Oriental manuscripts and art now in progress in the Plimpton, Smith and Dale Libraries at Columbia University.
Toto the Clown died in Union Hospital in the Bronx early yesterday morning. He had entered the hospital two days after Thanksgiving Day to undergo an operation for an intestinal condition.

Coat and suit firms in the popular and medium price field are opening their Spring lines early, according to survey completed yesterday by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board. The report revealed that 84 per cent of these houses are already showing their lines, while the remainder will launch their offerings between now and Jan. 20.
A motion picture film demonstrating methods of fire extinguishing was shown at a luncheon yesterday of the Risk Research Institute, comprising insurance buyers, at the - Hotel Astor yesterday.

Before high government, diplomatic and consular officials President Anastasio Somoza delivered a message today inaugurating the Constitutional Assembly, which will refrom the Constitution of Nicaragua. The President said:
Valery Chkaloff, one of the three Soviet Russian aviators who flew across the North Pole from Moscow to Vancouver, Wash., in 1937, was killed today in a crash while testing a new plane.

Preparations for a third big slum-clearance project in New York to cost $9,323,000 were completed today when the United States Housing Authority contracted to lend to the New York Housing Authority $8,390,000, representing 90 per cent of the cost.

Purchase of rights to the German silent film success, "Variety," was announced today by D. A. Doran and Tim Durant, organizers of an independent producing concern, which will begin preparations for an American version of the picture immediately.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Jeanne Levison, daughter of Mrs. Lois C. Levison of 50 East Seventyseventh Street and- the late Mr. Levison, to Adrian Cremieux Israel, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Cremieux Israel of New York, formerly of New Orleans, took place last evening on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 13: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Hartman, C. C., the Indianapolis, to Bu. reau of Navigation, Washington, D. C., In June.

Bench warrants were issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Pecora for the arrest of Leon Scharf, president of the New York Buyers Association, and Herman Yuran, 686 Crown Street, Brooklyn, who are under indictment with Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro and Louis (Lepke) Buchalter for alleged racketeering in the garment industry.

Plans have been completed by Miss Martha Louise Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Darwin Powers of Chicago, for her marriage to George Edward Larsen of New Rochelle, N. Y., which will take-place on the evening of Dec. 28 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and jimmy Foxx made the greatest comebacks of 1938, with the San Francisco tennis queen earning a slight edge over the slugging first baseman of the Red Sox. So say the seventy sports editors who are voting in the eighth annual Associated Press poll.

Employment for thirty-two additional ball players in the major leagues next Summer was assured yesterday when the sixteen club owners of the National and American circuits, in joint session before Commissioner K. M. Landis at the Hotel Roosevelt, voted to increase their player limit from twenty-three to twenty-five.

Because a "substantial number" of the 100,000 women and minors employed in the manufacture of wearing apparel and novelties in New Jersey receive "unreasonable and oppressive" pay, State Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. appointed today minimum wage boards for those industries.

Keeping its opponents scoreless from the field until three minutes of the third quarter had elapsed, Textile High's basketball team upset the High School of Commerce, 26-21, in a Lower Manhattan Division P. S. A. L. game on the wi ner's court yesterday.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 14: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Bradley, O. N. (Inf.), General Staff Corps,

Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State under Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman, will leave the State's service on Jan. 1. He declined the offer of Governor Lehman to reappoint him for a sixth term, giving his health as the reason.

Members of the Senate profit-sharing committee undertook a doublebarreled attack on the nation's unemployment problem today. At their direction, committee attaches began drafting a formula of profit-sharing designed to stabilize employment and guarantee oldage retirement funds for workers in ten of the nation's largest industries.
The Temple of Religion campaign, to build, equip and maintain a religious center for all faiths at the World's Fair, has passed the halfway mark in its drive for $250,000.
Reorganization of the medical board of the New York City public School system, to permit a greater degree of flexibility and to broaden the scope of the board's activities,

Elizabeth Hawes, the young New York designer-author of "Fashion Is Spinach," will have a new book in the Spring called "Are You Comfortable in That," dealing with men's clothes and fashions. Random House will publish the book.

We all Know street corners around which it is impossible to walk without meeting a bad draft. It is the same in politics. From certain areas evil winds are constantly blowing. That is the case with Germany at the present time. Indeed, the British are surprised if a day passes without something disagreeable descending upon them from across the Rhine.

Today's events: "Falstaff" revival, 2 P. M., and "Orfeo ed Euridice," 8:30 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Schola Cantorum, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.

The story of "Frank Donald Coster," president of the venerable drug firm of McKesson and Robbins, is the story of a man who lived two lives-two complete existences within the span of one. Nothing in local criminal history quite compares with it.

Certain army units have intervened in the controversy between President Aurelio Mosquera Narvaez and Congress over restoring Colonel Larrea Alba to active service with the rank of general, according to reports from Quito in the local press.

Business in local markets yesterday was affected to some extent by strike of luggers and cutters in branch houses distributing Western dressed meats and kosher business practically stopped in one large slaughterhouse because of picketing by representatives of kosher retail butchers' union.

MR. ANTHONY EDEN, the world's No. 1 glamour statesman, stepped down from a British liner last week, and four hours later the elegantly turned-out ex-Foreign Secretary who was ready to go ten fast rounds against any and all threats to the empire's lifeline was paying his respects to American hospitality.
David Lloyd George today buried a historic political feud by supporting the government's proposal to place a statue to the late Earl of Oxford and Asquith in the lobby of the House of Commons.

Although the more exuberant German election predictions have not materialized, complete though still unofficial results of last Sunday's election, nevertheless, show a gain for the National Socialist Memel German party and a loss of the four combined Lithuanian tickets.
For the second consecutive week bank clearings rose above the total for the comparable week of the preceding year.

Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse are giving a supper dance tonight at their home, 4 West Fifty-eighth Street. Baroness von Kettler of Villa Gamberaia, Settignano, Florence, Italy, who is passing the season at the Pierre, will leave today for Grosse Pointe, Mich., where she will pass the holidays with relatives.

There was no chance of mistaking the University of Oregon baskectball squad for anything but what it is when the young men who call themselves Webfoots walked from the train at Pennsylvania Station yesterday.

Following the recent announcement by Earl Herring, trustee for the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, that he had received an offer of $200,000 for the company's assets, it became known today that B. B. Robinson of Reno, Nev., had made the offer.
An exconvict was knocked unconscious during questioning at 7 o'clock, last night in the office of Commissioner of:Investigation William B. Herlands. The witness,

An investigation into possible official corruption involving the building and electrical trades industries in Brooklyn by John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor examining the conduct of law enforcement agencies in that borough, was indicated yesterday.

Mrs. Dorothy Thomen Barto, 38 years old, wife of Everett Wheeler Barto, New York attorney, was found dead this afternoon in her home on Hamilton Road here. Dr. Amos 0. Squire, County Medical Examiner, listed the death as suicide by hanging.

Mayor La Guardia directed yesterday that hot lunches be provided during Christmas week for 55,000 needy children who regularly receive their noon meals through the joint activities of the WPA, the Board of Education and the Welfare Department.
Leading throughout and gaining a half-time advantage of 24-12, Yale tonight defeated Lafayette College, 37 to 27, in opening its basketball season.
Ralph Hornblower, senior partner in the banking firm of Hornblower Weeks, announced today that William R. Rovensky and Harold E. Verrill would be admitted to the firm on Jan. 1.

Santa's pack may be heavier this year, upState business men agree today, but it will take a Frank Merriwell finish to bring the dollar volume up to par. Almost to a man, business leaders in large shopping centers agreed with Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper that, because of lower prices, the Christmas sale of articles is ahead of last year.
Robert M. Newcomb, 58 years old, United States vice consul here, was found dead this afternoon of a bullet wound in the head. A revolver lay beside him.
Baron Gilbert de Knyff, French motion picture producer and author of the screen play "Algiers," arrived yesterday on the French liner Paris.

The United Trotting Association parent body of trotting and pacing activities in several parts of the Middle West, approved "with reservations" today a merger with the country's three other leading har ness-horse organizations.

The Neediest Cases Fund yesterday dropped more than $20,000 behind its total on the corresponding day of the appeal last year. Gifts of $7,012.86 from 378 contributors Increased it yesterday to $117,951.59, but on the same day in 1937 it stood at $138,483.22.

Kaufmann Department Stores, Inc., received yesterday permission of the New York Stock Exchange to list 65,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preference stock and 889,114 shares of common stock in preparation for its absorption of the Kaufmann Department Stores Securities Corporation and three wholly owned subsidiaries, expected to become effective on Dec. 19.
Princeton's jayvee sextet turned back the New York Athletic Club, 6-3, in a loosely played contest in Baker Rink tonight. It was the second straight victory for the Tigers.

Movements of vessles follow, all dates are Dec. 15 unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Sirius, Dec. 13; Arkansas. Acushnet, Navy Yard, Washington, to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, via Quantico. Allegheny, at Philadelphia. Chaumont, Honolulu, to San Francisco. Cormorant, Upper Chesapeake Bay, to Navy, yard, Washington.

In the diplomatic corps of Washington there is no surprise over the news from Lima that Argentina and other Latin-American nations-are unwilling to go as far textually as the United States wants them to go in the message aimed at Berlin, Rome and Tokyo.

A spurt of activity in printcloths, prompted by a widespread belief among buyers that inventory pressure upon sellers had carried prices to "bottom" levels for the season, resulted in movement of about 25,000,000 yards yesterday.

Pedro Montanez of Puerto Rico added another knockout to his string of victories last night when he stopped Jimmy Fantini of the Bronx in 2:51 of the third round of a scheduled eight-round fight at Prospect Hall, Brooklyn. Montanez weighed 139 1/4, Fantani 136 3/4. Hank Makamura, 126 1/2, Japan, defeated Tony Novello, 127 1/4, in six rounds.

Mr. and Mrs. Beverly Waugh Kunkel of Easton, Pa., and West Cornwall, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Treat Kunkel, to Jeremy Felix Bagster-Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elijah William BagsterCollins of Montrose, N. Y.

Fifteen of the forty-one Republican memberselect of the 1939 Assembly refused today. to attend a majority caucus at which the other twenty-six voted to support Herbert J. Pascoe of Union County for Speaker, the position he holds this year. Roscoe P.
TODAY-New England: Clear to partly cloudy, with slight rise in temperature, though continuing below freezing over all sections, possibly excepting southeastern portion. New York State:

A short welcoming ceremony was held yesterday afternoon in Madison Square Park for the 149 members of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade who returned yesterday morning on the liner Paris after having seen action with the Loyalists in Spain.

Dr. Carroll N. Brown, Professor of Classical Languages and Literatures at the College of the City of New York, a leading American authority on the ancient and modern Greek languages and a noted archaeologist, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in his home, Riverdale Avenue and 250th Street, Riverdale, the Bronx, after a brief illness. His age was 69.
Registration on the Chicago Stock Exchange of the 5,359,751 shares of common stock, no par value,

After reaching new high ground for the year early in December business in the Pittsburgh district declined somewhat last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The drop was moderate, however, and it is only the second time since the middle of August that a decline has occurred.
A not guilty plea was entered by Rabbi William Margolies, 28 years old, in General Sessions yesterday on a first-degree grand larceny indictment in the alleged theft of an automobile last Summer.
State Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street, 10:30 A. M. Award of prizes to winners of city-wide annual essay contest of Chamber and Board of Education.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Authorization by the government's Export-Import Bank of $25,000,000 in credits to a New York company to be used in financing the export of American "agricultural and manufactured products" to China was announced today by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today approved $394,500 in fees and expenses as partial payment for services in litigation of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Corporation, defunct Insull investment companies.

At a New England breakfast of codfish cakes, cold baked beans and apple pie served yesterday noon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Van Wyck Brooks, critic and author of "The Flowering of New England," received the second gold medal of the Limited Editions Club awarded periodically to "the author of that book, published in the three years previous to the making of the award, which is considered most likely to attain the .stature of a classic."

Two glass manufacturers expressed surprise at the "monopoly" hearing today over testimony that the patent royalty fees which they had been paying to the Hartford-Empire Company were split with HazelAtlas Glass Company, one of their important competitors.

John Geertsen, a 29-year-old former candymaker from Salt Lake City, took his best shot at fame and fortune in the ten-thousand-dollar Miami open golf tournament today, clipping four strokes off par with a 66 to share the first-round lead with Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester, Mass.

Commander and Mrs. H. H. Evans have announced the marriage of their daughter, Mrs. Jane Evans Brown, to Robert Lacy Smyth. The ceremony took place yesterday in Peiping, where the bridegroom is second secretary of the United States Embassy.

George T. Weissbaum, the West Coast scrap metal dealer who purchased the Sixth Avenue elevated, structure at public auction on Dec. 5, has until the close of business today to pay Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick $80,000 and

Transfer and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Dec. 16: SERGEANT Walter F. O'Neill, from Traf. Pet. I to Traf. Pet. J. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT Harry C. Bilms, from 6th Precinct to 18th Division, for 16 days, from 4 P. M., Dec. 16.

The world premiere of the new concerto for violin and orchestra by Ernest Bloch was presented tonight by the Cleveland Orchestra under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos, guest conductor, at Severance Hall before a capacity audience.
Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. has given $50,000 toward the construction of the new Negro school for Williamsburg and surrounding area. The school will cost about $245,000 equipped.
Barnard College in New York will receive $10,000 under the will of Alma Gluck Zimbalist, opera singer, which has been admitted to probate by Judge Harry Smith in New Hartford.

George Gillespie Raymond, former Mayor of New Rochelle and a designer of the electrical equipment on New York's earliest subways, died of a heart attack today at his residence here. He had been ill a month.

Mrs. C. Douglass Green gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the. Ritz-Carlton. Among her guests were Mrs. Wright Barclay, Mrs. E. Whitney Satterlee, Mrs. William Halsted Vander Poel, Mrs. Ronald Currie Lee, Mrs. du Pignac Thompson, Mrs. Alfred Roelker and Miss Harriette C. Sheldon.

An Important legal victory for the city was announced yesterday by William C. Chanler, Corporation Counsel, who disclosed that the Brooklyn Ash Removal Company had dropped Its $3,000,000 claim against the city and agreed to settle for $400,000.
The first installment of 250,000,000 marks of the 1,000,000,000-mark punitive fine levied on Jewish property in connection with the murder of Ernst vom Rath was due today.

Documents filed with the West Indies royal commission studying economic and social conditions in the West Indies, together with a transcript of hearings, so mounted as to increase their baggage to 500 pounds.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Heller of 151 Central Park West and Lazy Corners, Easton, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Claire Heller, to Alvin Breger Marks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Marks. also of New York.

While Federal and State conciliators here and in Chicago, where the main offices of the big packers are located, were continuing their efforts yesterday to settle the strike of Local 635 of the United Meat Workers Industrial Union, C. I. O. affiliate, in this city, the Amalgamated Meat Cutters, A. F. of L. organization, pressed its boycott activities against the Wilson Packing Company to force a closed shop contract.
The Swiss Parliament today ratified the succession of Dr. Philipp Etter to the Presidency of the Confederation for 1939, succeeding Dr. Johannes Baumann.

A set of forty-eight plates of floral and fruit studies engraved by L. C. Ruotte after J. L. Prevost (Paris, 1805) was sold last night for $550 at the Parke-Barnet Galleries to Kennedy Co., this city.
Receivers of the Wabash Railroad have been authorized by Federal Judge Charles B. Davis to pay $211,895 on delinquent interest coupons of several of the road's bond issues.

The Canadian Car and Foundry Company, Ltd., and wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday in the annual report for the year, ended on Sept. 30. Including a $1,229 profit on investments, total earnings amounted to $1,177,314 after

Plans are being completed for the holding of the New York Millinery Market Week from Jan. 30 to Feb. 4, it was announced yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, which is sponsoring the event.
The Pan-American Union said tonight that exports to Cuba had increased 114 per cent from 1934 to 1937 as a result of the reciprocal trade agreement.
The new trial of James J. Hines, Tammany West Harlem district leader, will start in the Supreme Court Building Jan. 9 it was learned yesterday.
The first session of the auction sale of American, English and Continental furniture and decorations drew $6,347 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

Looking forward to a steady period of good trail and open slope running with the arrival of the Christmas holidays, members of the Eastern skiing army can avail themselves of opportunities to test their snow plows and last "Christies" this week-end for skiing is to be had at several points in New York State, New England and the Canadian Laurentians.

Stockholders of the Chicago North Western Railway and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad told the Interstate Commerce Commission today "tremendous savings" would result from consolidation of the two vast systems.

Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, proclaimed today the dissolution of about 23,250 corporations, they having been "found delinquent" in the filing of franchise tax reports or payment of taxes over a three-year period.

The United States delegation offered the eighth Pan-American conference today its major contribution toward preservation of peace in this hemisphere. The proposal took the form of a new treaty embodying the principles of eight separate pacts now in existence.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull has assured Jose Maria Cantilo, Argentine Foreign Minister, and Dr. Francisco Castilo Naiera, Mexico's Ambassador to Washington, that the United States will subscribe to any offer of the good offices of the Americas to terminate the Spanish conflict to which the other twenty members of the Pan-American Union can agree, it was learned today.
Winning favorites were far between at the Fair Grounds today, but one of the successful choices was W. E. Snyder's colt Fore, who won the six-furlong feature in handy fashion from a small field.

Bankers' dollar acceptance outstanding in the United States- on Nov. 30, '938, showed a gain of $3,765,177 over October, but a loss of $74,699,868 from a year ago, according to the monthly survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Plans are being completed for the holding of the New York Millinery Market Week from Jan. 30 to Feb. 4, it was announced yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, which is sponsoring the event.
The Pan-American Union said tonight that exports to Cuba had increased 114 per cent from 1934 to 1937 as a result of the reciprocal trade agreement.

Injunction proceedings to restrain the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company from complying with a request from Dr. Emil Ulmann of Munich, Germany, for the transfer of funds held for his account to German banks was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court.

Bankers' dollar acceptance outstanding in the United States- on Nov. 30, '938, showed a gain of $3,765,177 over October, but a loss of $74,699,868 from a year ago, according to the monthly survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Injunction proceedings to restrain the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company from complying with a request from Dr. Emil Ulmann of Munich, Germany, for the transfer of funds held for his account to German banks was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court.
Two national a leaders of business and labor advocated revisions in the National Labor Relations Act in speeches tonight to the Economic Club of Chicago.

MANHATTAN BRODERICK, ALICE (June 10, 1937). Gross assets, $16,191; net, $13,409. To Patrick Healy, Anastatia Healy, Lillie Lavelle, Kathe Meehan, Ellen O'Hanlon, Elizabeth Tyrell and Bridget Cummings, nephews and nieces, one-eighth residue each;
Unconfirmed reports today said that Marshal Vassily K. Bluecher, Commander in Chief of the Far Eastern Army-who recently was variously
The Navy Department is soon to begin the construction of a new type of cruiser, vessels of about 6,000 tons displacement and carrying main batteries of 6-inch guns.

Construction work on the South's first newsprint mill, at Lufkin, Texas, will be started early in January, according to an announcement yesterday by E. L. Kurth, president of the new Southland Paper Mills, Inc.
The house at 3 East Sixty-third Street, recently remodeled into thirteen apartments of one and two rooms, is now fully rented, according to Wm. A. White Sons, agents.

Elevator terminals here and at Duluth, Minn., shipped to eastern ports on the Great Lakes 158,752,212, bushels of grain during the navigation season which ended on Dec. 9, an increase of 45,322,000 bushels over 1937, according to a preliminary statement issued by the statistical branch of the Board of Grain Commissioners for Canada.

Scoring in wholesale fashion, the undefeated Long Island University basketball team chalked up its fourth straight success of the season last night by crushing the Princeton Seminary five, 82 to 37, on the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court.

A talk on the history of the Recorded Word was given last night by Elmer Adler before members of The Grolier Club, 47 East Sixtieth Street. The talk was illustrated by colored lantern slides provided by THE NEW YORK TIMES History of the Recorded Word Exhibition, of which Mr. Adler is director.
The stock market was brighter today, with prices advancing in many leading sections, although trading was mainly selective.
The Hungarian-Government made another payment of $9,828.16 on its post-war relief debt to the United States through a deposit in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday,

Robert Murray Smith, retired investment broker, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of one week. He was 54 years old. Born in Troy, N. Y., Mr. Smith was the son of Alexander and Ellen Roberts Smith. He had been a partner for twenty years in the firm of Aldred Co., 40 Wall Street, New York. He retired in 1930.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Captain E. F. Carter of the Sands Point Club at Port Washington, secretary of the Long Island Golf Association for the last two years, today was elected president of that organization at the annual meeting held at the Garden City Hotel.

After a series of delays dating from April, a Dauphin County Grand Jury opened its investigation of graft and corruption charges against the Earle administration today, almost exactly a month before Governor Earle leaves office.

Miss Rosalie Rita Chambers, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Chambers of New York and the late Mr. Chambers, was married to David W. Kaplan of this city last evening at the Jewish Theological Seminary, 122d Street and Broadway, by the Rev. Dr. Louis Finkelstein.

The Medical Society of the State of New York will seek to obtain amendments to the present New York State laws to permit the issuance of medical indemnity insurance for voluntary pre-payment of doctors' bills, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. Peter Irving, secretary of the society, in an address at a luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

Sheikh Mahmoud Ansari, 45 years old, was shot and fatally wounded on a main street of Jerusalem this morning. His assailant escaped. The sheikh was a member of a prominent Arab family that for generations has held the hereditary right for one of its members to serve as curator of the Mosque of Omar.
With another great Rebel offensive ready to start, the government this time moved first and drastically to smash all espionage rings in the rear.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Herbert E. Rosenberg and Sidney William Wattenberg, of New York City, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:
In the quest for something different with which to spice their programs, conductors turn up some strange old ruins, and, on occasion, they restore works of appealing freshness.
The Farm Security Administration reported today that more than 144,000 tenants, share croppers and farm laborers had applied for government loans to purchase farms in the last year.

Over some protests the Chamber of Deputies today adopted a limited schedule that would jam through the 1939 budget next week after sixty-six hours of debate. Under normal conditions the Chamber is accustomed to discuss the annual budget over a period of almost three months.

Directors of the Gannett Company, Inc., newspaper publishers, have voted to distribute 10 per cent of the 1938 profits of the company among employes on a pro rata share of their earnings for five years ending this year. Frank E.
Mrs. Jane Dingley Staples, wife of Arthur G. Staples, editor of The Lewiston Evening Journal, died today at her home here at the age of 70.

Bishop Adna W. Leonard of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Pittsburgh, told the House committee investigating un-Americanism today that he hoped a man would be appointed Secretary of Labor, the only Cabinet post now held by a woman.

Sylvan Stroock, president of S. Stroock Co., Inc., of Newburgh, N. Y., protested today proposed rules for the labeling of the wool content of textiles as "impracticable, permitting of deception and non-enforceable."

The Rev. Albert A. Murray has been appointed spiritual director of the St. Paul's Guild, with headquarters at 117 East Fifty-seventh Street. His selection has been approved by Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, administrator of the Archdiocese of New York.

The engagement of $6,800,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. At the same time $22,727,000 of the metal arrived from Europe-$13,771,000 from England and $8,956,000 from Holland.
The Italian Chamber of Deputies, long an impotent survival, has now formally recorded its death and welcomed its appointive successor, which will be guiltless of secret balloting.

An old realty holding on the northern edge of Greenwich Village will be improved for business as the result of the leasing of a blockfront by the Rhinelander Real Estate Company to a client of Louis J. Witkin, attorney.
The Treasury Department invited tenders today for about $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be sold on a discount basis to the highest bidders.

Canadians returning from foreign countries brought $6,945,080 in dutiable goods under the $100 exemption clause of the customs tariff in the eight months ended on Nov. 30, James Ilsley, Revenue Minister, announced today.

Representatives of employers and employes in the dress industry approved yesterday a program for "prompt and peaceful negotiation" under which none of the elements involved would make demands that could be interpreted as putting upon the industry burdens which it could not assume at the present time.

Steel for next year's automobiles and tin plate for next year's cans rolled cut at speeds attaining twenty miles an hour today as the giant Irvin works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, the last word in the world's steel mills, was dedicated in the presence of 1,600 guests.

FIRST MILITARY AREA Major Percy C. Fleming, Field Artillery, will proceed, on or about Dec. 16, from Utica, N. Y., to Cortland, N. Y., on temporary duty in connection with the training of Organized Reserves, and upon completion of this duty will return to Utica, N. Y.
Franz Rehrl, Governor of Salzburg under the former Austrian regime, was back in jail today after eight days of freedom.

Using twelve-ounce gloves, Tony Galento, heavyweight title challenger from the Orange, N. J., beer gardens, knocked out Dick Daniels of Minneapolis in the third round of a scheduled four-round bout tonight.

Singing Christmas carols all the way, sixty members of the Young People's Fellowship of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, will ride in three open wagons filled with hay and drawn by horses next Friday evening to the Lenox Hill Hospital, in Park Avenue, between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets.

Some of the country's most prominent motion-picture stars and other noted women may have to make the pawn shops of this city a hunting ground for the next few weeks in quest of what was estimated to be a total of about $250,000 in fur coats belonging to them.

Imports of gold into the United States in the week ended on Dec. 9, amounted to $76,625,963, the Department of Commerce reported today. Of this sum. $24,794,369 came from France, $7,866,946 from The Netherlands, $32,032,498 from the United Kingdom, $7,048,742 from Argentina, $2,882,642 from Japan, and $1,016,467 from the Philippines.

Southeastern railroads, acting through the Southeastern Presidents' Conference, voted today at a meeting here to reduce day-coach fares from to 1 1/2 cents a mile. The action was seen in some quarters as an indication that the Eastern roads also might make reductions soon from their 2 1/2-cent rate.

Rowland Campbell, president and general manager of the Reo Motor Car Company, was removed from office and from the company's payroll at a special meeting of directors of the corporation late this afternoon. His brother, Thomas Campbell of New York, who since Nov. 12 has been chairman of the board and chief executive officer, presided at the meeting.

William Woodward, New York banker and sportsman, finally has come up with a favorite for the Derby. It is Foxbrough 2d, champion 2 year-old of the year on the English turf full brother to Woodward's famous Gallant Fox, and now Winter book favorite at odds of 6 to 1 to win the 3-year-old classic at Epsom next June.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week aggregates $30,998,300, to be represented by ninety-nine municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $31,273,543 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at -$26,033,691.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday Thursday For the best names .......3/4% 3/4% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Peak Sales Expected Today With peak sales expected, figures on Christmas trade for the week will depend largely on the results today.

The Inter-American Commission of Women has adopted a second and much weaker resolution on the question of equal rights for women than that it brought to Lima for presentation at the Eighth Pan-American Conference. The second text was agreed upon to meet the wishes of the delegations of the United States and several other nations.

Benjamin Herman, 25 years old, who was erroneously released from the Brooklyn city prison on Thursday night, surrendered yesterday. morning at the office of the Brooklyn District Attorney and was returned to jail. Herman, who is awaiting a new trial on a Sullivan law charge, was absolved of blame' in the "escape." He said he had read of the error in a newspaper.
