The program presented by the Schola Cantorum at the concert of Christmas music last night in Carnegie Hall, which marked the opening of its thirtieth season, bore witness to the erudition and the comprehensive musical interests of Hugh Ross, its conductor.

The monthly statement of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank said today that employment in factories in Delaware showed virtually no change from October to November, but that wage payments increased about 1 per cent.

Departing from the usual procedure of choosing the ten best films of the year from among those made in Hollywood, the Committee on Exceptional Photoplays of the National Board of Review of Motion; Pictures has nominated Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's Britishmade screen version of "The Citadel" as the outstanding Englishlanguage picture of 1938.

Brought here from Fairfield, where he witnessed the discovery of the suicide of his brother, P. Donald Coster or Philip Musica, George E. Dietrich, now identified as George Musica, assistant treasurer of the McKesson Robbins Drug Company,

One week from the day he landed Anthony Eden, former Foreign Minister of England, sailed for home yesterday aboard the Queen Mary with a farewell in which he expressed appreciation not only for the friendliness with which he had been received but for the opportunity that had been afforded him to "listen and learn" about the United States.

Th American President Lines, formed by the Maritime Commission to take over the operation of the defunct Dollar Line, is seeking three former Munson Line vessels for service in the New York-California-Manila trade, it was learned yesterday.

Lester B. Rapp submitted his resignation as Mayor of Rochester today a few minutes after the City Council, by a 5-4 vote, defeated his efforts to have his salary as Mayor increased from $750 to $2,500 a year.

Councilman Albert D. Schanzer of Brooklyn said yesterday that he would introduce a resolution at Tuesday's Council meeting asking the Board of Estimate to increase its clothing appropriations for those on relief from about $49,000 to $500,000 a month.

Miss Helen V. Kiendl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kiendl of 2 East Eighty-eighth Street, entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Miss Marion M. Colt, debutante daughter of Mr. and.Mrs. S. Sloan Colt of Boulder Point, Tuxedo Park, N. Y.

Contracts for the heavyweight bout in which Joe Louis will defend his title against John Henry Lewis at Madison Square Garden were formally signed yesterday at the meeting of the State Athletic Commission.

The Rev. John E. Ryan, A. M., head of the English department of Cathedral College in Brooklyn, died on Thursday in Holy Family Hospital, where he underwent an operation seven months ago. Father Ryan, who was 43 years old, had been a teacher for fourteen years.

The engagement of Miss Helen Levi, daughter of Mrs. Carl Levi of 525 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Levi, to Abbott Simon, son of Mrs. Reuben Simon of New York and the late Mr. Simon, has been announced by her mother.

Representatives of the United and National Trotting Associations and the American Trotting Register Association debated behind closed doors for the second day today details of plans which they hope will lead to a merger of the three harness-horse racing parent bodies.
The Secretary of State's office has mailed out 5,000 invitations to the inauguration of Governor Lehman Jan. 2. The Assembly chamber, where the ceremonies will be held, can hold only about 1,700.

Charges of mayhem and conspiracy against Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt, mother of Ann Cooper Hewitt Gay, principal in a sensational sterilization case, were removed today from the Criminal Court calendar. Removal of the charges,

Bonds worked Irregularly lower yesterday in a sharply contracted trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange. Sales of $8,903,700 compared with $12,654,450 in the preceding day. While prices receded moderately on the average, there were notable exceptions to the trend, particularly among a few public utility loans.

Industry may reasonably look forward to a heavier rather than a lighter tax bill, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, writes in his monthly business review, sent yesterday to the organization's 20,000 banking, manufacturing and wholesaling concerns throughout the country.

The Queen Mary sailed yesterday for Europe with 10,000 sacks of mail, the last major shipment to leave New York for distribution on the Continent of Europe and in Great Britain in time for Christmas. The Post Office Department assigned twenty-three extra clerks to the pier at the foot of West Fiftieth Street to pass the supplementary mail.

Circumstances surrounding the disappearance of Arthur Fried from the vicinity of his White Plains home on the night of Dec. 4, 1937, were related yesterday by his sister, Mrs. Elsa Daniels. Mrs. Daniels was a State witness at the General Sessions trial of Demetrius Gula, 30 years old, and Joseph Sacoda, 27, a Sing Sing convict, on a first-degree Kidnapping indictment as alleged leaders in the socalled Ukrainian Hall gang.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses attacked the Thirty-eighth Street Midtown Tunnel before the finance committee of the Council in City Hall yesterday and offered to make a bet that the tunnel would not get 60 per cent of the traffic expected for it.

The Greek exhibition in the New York World's Fair will include what may be considered the ancestor of Mickey Mouse, it was announced today. It is a copy of an antique statue, the base of which bears humorous representations of animals dressed like human beings.
Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 10 were 2 per cent lower than for the corresponding week in 1937 and for the four weeks ended Dec. 10 were 3 per cent lower
(Played at Hippodrome) INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE LAST NIGHT'S SCORES First Game-Ricardo Mirando and Epifanlo Saenz, Cuba, defeated Jose Munagorri and Jose Mugica, 20 to 17.

RING LARDNER is in the new "Oxford Anthology of American Literature,"* and so is Gertrude Stein, and so are Pound and Eliot, Dreiser and Sinclair Lewis, Allen Tate and Leonie Adams, Faulkner, Cummings and Hemingway, Dos Passos and MacLeish.

Prompted by "the remote contingency" that his son, who is believed to have died in the World War, may still be alive and unable to identify himself, Jacob Felbel, typewriter inventor, made a provision in his will for the son, amounting to onehalf of his estate, should he return.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the membership of Herbert H. Wurzler had been transferred to Charles M. Bull Jr. of Bull Eldredge, and that of Harry Kahn, to Harry Kahn Jr. of Loeb, Alsberg Co.

Mrs. Margaret Emerson entertained with a dinner at her villa today. At Periwinkle Patch, Mrs. Henry K. Harding was hostess for cocktails and Mrs. Jesse Spalding gave a luncheon at the Bath and Tennis Club.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 14: COMMANDER Shadday, A. A., Med. Corps, Minneapolis. Minn., to the Milwaukee, about Dec. 12. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Elliott, W., the Vestal, to continue treatment Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif.
The Public Service Commission notified truck owners. today that the new State Motor Truck Regulation Act did not require .their .membership in any association to obtain authority to operate.

A stately Victorian pageant moved across the main ballroom floor at the Ritz-Carlton last night, re-creating amid glowing settings something of the formal and dignified ceremony characteristic of the procedure at a court ball during the later years of Queen Victoria's reign.

Scores of military and naval officers attended a reception in honor of Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, new commanding officer of the Second Corps Area, and Mrs. Drum yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the Military Order of the World War.

G. Leroy Kemp, former land agent for the State in Merritt Parkway deals, was sentenced to from three to seven years in the State penitentiary today by Superior Court Judge Frank P. McEvoy after a jury, -deliberating less than three hours, returned a conviction on a charge of conspiracy.

Word has been received here of the marriage yesterday in Torrington, Devonshire, England, of Miss Catherine Sidgwick Hodgkinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. A. L. Hodgkinson of Torrington, to Marvin McCord Lowes, son of Mrs. Janet M. Lowes of this' city and the late Clarence M. Lowes.

Directors of the Northern Natural Gas Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of $5 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 27. A similar disbursement was made at the end of 1937. The common stock of the company is owned wholly by the United Light...
A. D. Lewis, brother of John L. Lewis, head of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, tonight broke up the two-day coal mining safety conference called by Secretary Ickes.
The Pirates unwrapped their first Christmas package today and pulled out Ray Mueller, alert young catcher, who batted .237 for the Bees last season.

The Japanese Embassy in Moscow has asked Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff to reply to the Japanese proposal for renewal of last year's fisheries agreement, unchanged, not later than Monday or Tuesday.

Miss Jean Farrel, daughter of Mrs. Alton Farrel of 770 Park Avenue, New York, and The Lindens, Pine Orchard, Conn., was introduced to the younger members of society at a supper dance in the New Haven Lawn Club tonight. More than 400 guests were present.

Distillers Corporation - Seagrams, Ltd., reported yesterday a consolidated net profit of $1,458,254 after taxes and reserves for the three months ended on Oct. 31, compared to $2,369,967 in the same period in 1937, with all accounts expressed In Canadian currency.

President Roosevelt indicated today that he would proceed leisurely in filling the two vacancies in his Cabinet. He said he had made no decisions concerning successors to Homer Cummings as Attorney General and Daniel C. Roper as Secretary of Commerce.

A shy, 16-year-old girl, who wants to become a newspaper or fashion illustrator, won first prize over 300,000 contestants in the high school division of the annual New York State Chamber of Commerce essay contest. She is a senior at Girls Commercial High School, Brooklyn, in the art department.

After tonight's performance, "Victoria Regina," which stretched a four-week "limited engagement" into an eleven-week run, closes at the Martin Beck. Also departing from Broadway this evening after a pre-Broadway tour of less than six weeks and twenty performances locally is "Great Lady," which may be put down as the season's costliest venture with an estimated production cost in excess of $200,000.

Buying of stocks for Christmas gained sharply in wholesale markets this week, disclosing large gaps in retailers' supplies, according to the weekly summary of Dun d Bradstreet, Inc., released yesterday.

The ancient art of curling was the center of interest today at the country's oldest golf club, St. Andrews, and the members of the eighteen teams or rinks who took part in the opening program were here as part of the club's golden jubilee celebration.

The French liner Paris sails today for Havre via Plymouth. The passenger list includes M. and Mme. Pierre Clemenceau, Mrs. Jean Brun, Comte Orlowski, Mrs. Clemence Capdeville, Professor Paul Hazard, George Cahen, Mrs. C. D. Jackson, Jacques Sorbets, Paul Winkler and Marc Bertaux.

Harry E. Mackenzie, for twenty years one of Conneeticut's most powerful political leaders in the heyday of the Roraback machine, whose correspondence with F. Donold Coster, or Philip Musica, is being scrutinized in the McKesson Robbins case,

The strike of luggers and cutters in the branch houses affected the locally dressed markets and lamb carcasses were strong to sharply higher. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to lower; fresh pork cuts steady to slightly higher; other traefer meats showed little price change. Kosher business was sharply curtailed in one of the large slaughter houses where representatives of kosher retail butchers' union continued to picket.

FALSTAF--Opera In Italian in three acts and six scenes. Music by Giuseppe Verdi; book by Arrigo Boito. Conductor, Etlore Panizza; stage director, Herbert Graf; chorus master Fausto Cleva. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The suicide of F. Donald Coster yesterday was followed immediately by the unmasking of his three associates as his brothers in the mystery of the missing $18,000,000 among the assets of McKesson Robbins, of which he was president.

William M. Mitchell, solicitor, was censured today by the disciplinary committee of the Law Society for his part in the controversy that led last Summer to the separation of the former Barbara Hutton and Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow.
Mrs. Mary Carlisle, 73, former star of the "flaming hoop" act in the Ringling Circus, was fatally burned early this morning in her lodging house.

The Bolivian delegation to the Pan-American Conference has proposed the restoration of the ancient Inca highway as part of the Pan-American Highway. They have presented the draft of a resolution that would recommend to the governments of Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Argentina and Chile that the road of the Incas be used from Quito, Ecuador, to Tucuman, Argentina.
An express messenger, clinging desperately with a companion td the side of a blazing car, plunged to his death tonight as the Baltimore Ohio train sped on, its crew unaware of the tragedy.

Organization of the State Senate, which will be Republican-controlled this coming session for the first time since 1932, was informally started yesterday afternoon at a luncheon at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway, which was attended by twenty-five of the twenty-seven Republican Senators.

Dr. John A. Kingsbury, former director of the Milbank Fund, told a State commission yesterday that as a result of "misrepresentation" of the British medical system of insurance in the Journal of the American Medical Association the organized physicians in this country were opposing compulsory health insurance.

A heavy undertone developed today in the wheat market, but prices held within narrow lim s. Closing trades on the Board of Trade here were at losses of 1/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel, the latter on the December position. Reports of scattered rain and snowstorms in parts of the West and Southwest had some effect on sentiment.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Medieval Soulpture: the Pisani and Beinnings of the Renaissance," Harry D. M. Grier, 11 A. M.; "Prints: Other XVII Century Developments," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "French Painting of the XIX Century" (survey of collections), Roberta M. Fansler, 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Sparta," A. J. B. Wace, 4 P. M.
The City College swimming team upset the St. Francis College mermen, 42 to 33, last night in the Beaver pool for the second victory of the season. Last year St. Francis scored 40-36.

ANDROCLES AND THE LION, a play in a prologue and two acts, by George Bernard Shaw. Staged by Samuel Rosen; setting by Manuel Essman; music by George Couvreur; lighted by Byron Webb; costumes by Perry Watkins;

Experimental evidence that vitamin A, present in butter, milk, eggs, liver, cod liver oil and some other food substance, is essential for daylight vision as well as for vision in dim light was presented last night by Professor Selig Hecht, head of the Columbia University biophysics laboratories, before a joint meeting of the Physics Club and the Chemistry Teachers Club of New York at New York University.

Today's events: "Mignon" at 2 P. M. and "Aida" at 8:15 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, young people's concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Robert Virovai, violin, Carnegie Hall, 3 P. M.;

The stock markets here ended the account irregularly-today, moving lower after a generally-firm opening. A sharp setback wiped out early advances in gilt-edge issues. Among foreign bonds, German issues were firm, but Czecho-Slovak obligations eased.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Dec. 13, 1938. upon the eligible list of holders of license, as indicated, in day secondary schools other than junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted license, as indicated:

Kenneth S. Templeton, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, said today that the government-by approving constructive speculation-should aid in rebuilding grain markets that have been crippled by the Federal farm program.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Yonge Walker of 70 East Seventy-seventh Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Walker, to Charles Earl Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl of Kew Gardens, Queens.

Testimony and sworn affidavits declaring that two eye witnesses to a Brooklyn slaying in 1933 were not called to testify at the first-degree murder trial which resulted in the acquittal of the defendant, although they were known at the time to the police and the District Attorney's office, were placed yesterday in the hands of John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor investigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn.

Failure of Congress to protect adequately American developers of new processes from foreign "piracy" made it necessary for the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation to exchange its patent information with foreign interests, the "monopoly"

The National Labor Relations Board today certified the United Meat Workers Local Industril Union 635 (C. I. O.) as sole collective bargaining agency for processing and operative employes of Wilson Co.,

USA247Ft.M.1938 returned to active duty with the army yesterday morning after an odd little ceremony in the backyard of 45 Garnet Street, Brooklyn. Center of interest was a small, gray pigeon from the lofts of Fort Monroe, Oceanport, N. J., which Staff Sergeant Clifford A. Poutre and a handful of men came to claim in the city.
The State of California will be in the market on Jan. 5 with a new issue of $3,000,000 Veterans Welfare 2% per cent bonds. The issue is to mature serially on Feb. 1, 1940 to 1954.

Waging its hardest basketball battle of the season on its home court last night, Fordham turned back a fighting St. Lawrence team in overtime when Jack McGuirk sank a foul shot two minutes from the end for a 40-39 victory.

Democratic enrollment in the city for the last election fell off 80,085 from the 1937 total, while Republican enrollment gained 31,240, according to the official figures made public yesterday by the Board of Elections.

Grand Duke Vladimir Cyrilovitch, self - proclaimed Czar Vladimir II of Russia, arrived here this morning from his estate in Brittany on route to Germany and during the day, using the radio as well as giving interviews personally and through

Everett Bellach, 25-year-old Sing Sing prison convict, was captured here tonight five hours after he had escaped from two guards by jumping from a New York Central train in which he was being taken back to Sing Sing after attending the funeral of his mother in New York.

Turpentine firm, 22c; sales, 10 barrels; receipts, 292 barrels; no shipments; stock, 52,170 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 250 barrels; receipts, 540 barrels; shipments, 370 barrels; stock, 314,766 barrels. Quote: B, $3.70; D, $3.95; E, $4.10; F, $4.25; G, H. I. $4.30; K, M, $4.32 1/2; N, $5.35; WG, $5.80; WW, X, $6.30.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition to Reorganize GOLDEN STAR MINING CO., INC., 19 Rector St--Voluntary proceeding under Chapter X of the Chandler Act living Habilities of $111,524 and assets of $140,180, consisting mainly of mining properties located in Arizona.

Led by Johnny Kravetz, who tallied 16 points, Manhattan College's basketball varsity remained in the undefeated circle last night, downing a scrappy Brooklyn College quintet by 49 to 42 in the Manhattan gymnasium.
Arriving buyers may register in this column by telephoning LAckawanna 4-1000 RETAIL DETROIT - Himelhoch Bros.; Miss F. Ames, coasts; 1,441 Bway (Specialty Stores Assn.).

Mott St, 59; 5-story tenement, 25x100; Citizens Savings Bank against Max Levy; due, $18,743; to plaintiff for $1,000. By H. LOUIS HOLLANDER, Cannon St, 87; 5-story tenement, 25x100.11: Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Rae A. Lilienstern; due, $19,691; taxes, etc, $263; to plaintiff for $1,000.
Frank L. Anthony, last survivor of the group of men that met here after a regatta on Memorial Day, 1880, and founded the Larchmont Yacht Club, died last night in his home at the age of 81.

MANHATTAN BLUM, HARRY (Oct. 18, 1936). Estate, $38,121; net, $35,351. To Florence Blum, widow. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $33,154. Hays, St. John, Abramson Schulman, attorneys, 120 Broadway. DONOHOE, JOSEPH (July 23, 1937). Gross assets, $13,055; net, $12,268. To Ellen F. Donohoe, widow, $11,768; one other bequest. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $8,555. Salvatore T. Gambino, attorney, 1,006 Brdwn St., Peekskill, N. Y.

Mrs. Myron C. Taylor sailed on the Queen Mary to spend the holidays with Mr. Taylor in England. Mr. and Mrs. Carlile Boyd of Villa Madeline, Beaumont, Channel Islands, will- arrive here on Thursday. They will be at the La Salle.

The death two days ago of Dr. Richard Reisch, first president of the Austrian National Bank, was announced today. Dr. Reisch, 72 years old, was Finance Minister of Austria in 1920 and was president of the former republic's National Bank in 1922 when Austrian currency was stabilized with the help of a League of Nations loan.

A goal by Bob Johnson late in the first period gave Brooklyn Tech's hockey team a 1-1 tie with New Utrecht at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night and enabled Tech to hold its first place position in the Public School Athletic League race.

The Princeton Triangle Club's fiftieth anniversary show, "Once Over Lightly," had its first New York performance last night at the Fiftyfirst Street Theatre, where it was enthusiastically applauded by an audience of about 1,000.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr. in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday on whether the use of the words "bum," "gin-mill" and "politician" are of themselves libelous or slanderous as charged in an action brought by William Weidberg against Mayor La Guardia for $100,000 damages.

For the sixth successive day great efforts were made today to bring ashore Principal Keeper William Jordain of Eddystone Lighthouse, who is suffering severe pain from an abdominal illness, but after fighting heavy seas for eleven hours the steamer Satellite returned to Plymouth reporting another failure.

Ward's Automotive Reports, estimating automobile output for the current week at a new 1938 high mark of 102,905 units, said today that "sentiment throughout the industry indicated that the lag in production and sales during the Winter would definitely be of less than normal seasonal proportions."

The older a person grows the more likely he is to understand, at this season of the year, the saying that it is more blessed to give than to receive. Our children, in their happy innocence, can hardly wait for the new sled, the new skates, the new doll.

The Roslyn Nursing Association will be aided by a performance of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" to be given tonight at the Theatre of the Four Seasons in Roslyn, L. I. Proceeds of the event will be used to maintain free nursing in the Roslyn district.

ASTORIA is quite a place. The salmon fishing there is simply wonderful. That virtue is more than George Ulysses Harvey, Borough President of Queens, ever suspected about the town. But this discourse does not concern itself with Astoria, L. I. It is about another Astoria, some 3,000 miles away.

Firemen rescued ten women and ten children who were trapped by dense smoke yesterday afternoon in a five-story tenement at 401 East Nineteenth Street near First Avenue. The smoke, from a stubborn fire in the basement, had enveloped the stairway, cutting off escape. Two firemen were overcome.

The Suez Canal Company announced a moderate cut in canal tolls today but said that the reduction had no connection with the recent Italian press campaign. The fact that the reduction would be made had been privately announced last year at a stockholders' meeting, the statement said.

Buyers invested yesterday in business properties in the. Bronx. A leading deal of this type involved the three-story building at 1,790 Walton Avenue, southeast corner of 176th Street, which was sold by Henry Goelet, operator, to an investing client of Abraham Sobil, attorney.
Representatives Carter of California and Guyer of Kansas pledged the support of their delegations today for Representative. Martin of Massachusetts as House minority leader.

A frightened woman, who barricaded last night behind the doors of the FishKill (N. Y.) farm of Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, where her husband is employed as chief gardener, 'and a mother and daughter who have been living quietly in well-to-do circumstances in Westbury, L. I.,

Edmund Dwight, retired head of an insurance firm, who since 1920 had been president of the Children's Village, a charitable school at Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., for unadjusted children, died of a heart ailment last night in Pasadena, Calif., according to word received here last night.

The eighth Pan-American conference took its first conclusive action today, unanimously adopting a resolution intended to commit the Americas to liberal trade practices in their dealings among themselves and with the rest of the world.

Rosedale Ave. 1.359,. dwelling, 37x99.8: Home Owners Loan Corp against Samuel Feffer, due, $16,502; to plaintiff for $500. By JOHN J. REYNOLDS Eastchester Rd. 2.414, dwelling, 25.2x201.6x irreg; Home Owners Loan Corp against Leonard Brunelli, due, $5,723; to plaintiff for $500.

Schoolboy track and field athletes of the metropolitan sector will see action in their first important meet of the indoor campaign tonight when the forty-first De La Salle Institute games are held at the 102d Engineers Armory. Sixteen events are on the program, which starts at 8:15 o'clock.

Following completion of December operations as trading in the spot month ceased at noon, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday to losses of 10 points at one time, with a partial recovery in late dealings that left the list with losses of 3 to 10 points..

Pre-Christmas sermons will be preached tomorrow which is the Fourth Sunday in Advent. There will be candle-light services, miracle and Nativity plays, yule-tide pageants, and processions of the children to the manger.

Carnegie Tech's 21-10 walloping of Pittsburgh in football and the combination of circumstances that led to the Cubs' National League . pennant victory shared first place among 1938 sports upsets in the opinion of the nation's sports p writers who contributed to the eighth annual Associated Press poll.

The seismograph at Fordham University recorded two distinct earthquake shocks yesterday afternoon. The first and most violent was at 12:40, and was apparently about 10,000 miles distant. The second, at 2:04, was nearer and apparently not so severe, and may have been. off Central America.

A first mortgage of $40,000 has been obtained from an insurance company for the Morland Great Neck Corporation by the Empire Title Guarantee Co on the recently completed one-story taxpayer on the southwest corner of E lst St and S 1st Ave, Mount Vernon, Westchester.

A considerable stir has been caused among German servant girls in this country by the report that they will soon be recalled to their homeland and thousands have sought information at labor registration offices.

A call for all persons to be on guard and to inform against suspected spies was made in every Barcelona newspaper today. The magnitude of the involved series of plots discovered and the unprecedented number of executions and sentences have made a deep impression on the people.

George McKeever of Glenville, Greenwich, automobile dealer, died of heart attack at the wheel of his car at the Greenwich Hospital space last night. He had been visiting his wife who had been seriously ill with pneumonia.
The countless of Mar and Kellie, a close friend and hostess for King George V and Queen Mary, died today at Alloa House, Alloa, Scotland, at the age of 70.

An investor has purchased, through Harold E. Wolf, broker, from the New York Life Insurance Company, the one-story store building at 217-23 North Avenue, New Rochelle, Westchester, for cash above a first mortgage of $40,000 taken back by the seller.

The exhibition of Chinese bronzes, jades and ceramics lent from the Randon collection, which was scheduled to close last Sunday at the Brooklyn Museum, has been extended to Jan. 8. The collection includes a large group of archaic jades, pottery and bronzes.

Despite the cancellation of the offering of $50,000,000 bonds and debentures of Public Service Company of Colorado that had been scheduled for Thursday, total bond financing this week reached a total of $55,039,850 and was represented by the most diversified list of issues marketed in many months.
A Christmas list of fifty books for juveniles, selected by the Cardinal's Literature Committee of the Archdiocese of New York as approved reading, was made public yesterday. The list follows:

Rutgers asserted itself in the closing minutes to regain an early lead and conquer the hitherto undefeated Princeton basketball team, 28-25, in a hard-fought contest in the university gymnasium tonight. The victory left the Scarlet unbeaten in four starts.

Tonypandy Tommy Farr's record of American ring reverses still is intact. Last night in Madison Square Garden, in his fourth fight here, Great Britain's unrecognized heavyweight champion was bammered into his fourth straight defeat in fifteen rounds of dramatic heavyweight fighting by the younger, cruder, unschooled Lou Nova, a husky from Alameda, Calif., who glories in fighting.

WHAT CHURCH PEOPLE THINK ABOUT SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC ISSUES, by Norman L. Trott and Ross W. Sanderson. (Association Press, 75 cents.) A report of an opinion survey made in Baltimore under the Baltimore Rauschenbusch Fellowship of the Council of Church and Christian Education of Maryland and Delaware.
The first division of opinion among the Leftists was revealed today when the composition of the first Cabinet of President-elect Pedro Aguirre made was analyzed by the Popular Front press.

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $6,155,819 after expenses and charges. This was equal to 96 cents a share on 6,399,002 shares of capital stock outstanding.

The engagement of $920,000 gold in Holland for shipment here was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank also reported gold imports for the last two days aggregating $16,969,000.

Several well-known persons appeared as lessees in the lists of apartment rentals submitted yesterday by brokers and agents. Lieut. Comdr. James J. Hughes, who commanded the United States steamship Panay when that vessel was sunk in Chinese waters, has rented a suite in 1 University Place. through Alberti Romano.

The following members having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on date specified, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937, the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:

Employes of the Life Savers Corporation celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of the concern at a Christmas party held yesterday at the company's plant at Port Chester when $65,000 was passed out in the form of bonus checks.

In the atmosphere of a synthetic springtime, next season's fashions last night cast their shadows before, in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, where the largest crowd in the history of the event attended the annual Miami-Biltmore ball for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center.

As part of its larger program for the abatement of the pollution of harbor and other waters of the metropolitan area the regional office of the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works announced yesterday that construction would be begun immediately on a $300,000 sewage treatment plant at Ossining, N. Y., for which the PWA has granted $135,000.
One of the first rail orders for delivery in 1939, about $300,000 worth of materials, was placed today by the Chicago Great Western Railroad with the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

The cattle trade was generally steady today with supplies of all classes limited, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Light hogs were fairly active at steady to 10c lower prices, top $7.50, while heavier weights lost 10c to 15c. Fat lambs rose 15c to 25c, best load lots reaching $9.15.

Urging concerted participation in lemon prorate agreements as the alternative to "disaster" in California's lemon industry, C. C. Teague, president of the California Fruit Growers Exchange, criticized "snipers" in the lemon price field today in the eighth of a series of broadcasts on the subject.

Two intersectional contests will mark the opening of the fifth season for intercollegiate basketball in Madison Square Garden tonight. Starting at 8:15 o'clock City College will face the University of Oregon and in the second game St. John's of Brooklyn will oppose Northwestern University.

The annual Barnard College Christmas dance was held last night in Hewitt Hall on the campus as a part of the college's seasonal celebration, which includes an all-college tea, the serenading of Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve and the traditional broadcast of the Barnard College and Columbia University Glee Clubs.

Thomas Saxe, an Irish-born newsboy who with his brother, John, opened the first nickelodeon in Milwaukee and ran it up to a chain of nearly 100 theatres in Wisconsin and Minnesota, died today at the age of 64. He had been ill for two years and last Saturday underwent on operation.
In a Christmas message to clergymen, Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of

Nikita Talalaeff, 24 years old, and Clarence C. Runyon, 22, both of Manhattan, pleaded guilty today to charges of third-degree burglary and first-degree larceny in connection with the theft of clothing and jewelry valued at $16,000 from the home of Miss Olive Anderson of 100 Wilson Place, Freeport, on Nov. 20.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. applied tonight to the Board of Trustees of North Tarrytown for permission to establish a private burial ground on the 4,000-acre Rockefeller estate in the village of North Tarrytown and Mount Pleasant Township.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced early last night that he would give George T. Weissbaum, the West Coast scrap metal dealer who purchased the Sixth Avenue elevated structure from the city at public auction Dec. 5, until midnight tonight to post a performance bond of $40,000 and make a cash payment of $80,000.

Miss Katherine M. Keyes, principal of Public School 95, Brooklyn, since 1917 and a teacher in the Brooklyn schools for forty-seven years, died yesterday at her home, 50 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, after a short illness.

His mask of respectability ripped away to reveal him as Philip Musica, exconvict and swindler of a quarter-century ago, F. Donald Coster, president of McKesson Robbins, shot and killed himself in his home here today shortly after noon.

The Cabinet, under Premier Benito Mussolini's chairmanship, today decided to create a special board for the purchase, management and resale of property owned by Jews in excess of the maximum allowed under the law approved Nov. 10.

Former Alderman Isaac R. Minnerly, for more than fifty years a printer and linotyper engaged in newspaper work in Yonkers, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 69. He was associated with The Yonkers Herald-Statesman and before that was for many years with the former Yonkers Statesman.

Elizabeth Doran has purchased for cash the one-family dwelling with fifteen rooms and three baths at 199-23 Dunton Avenue, Hollis, Queens. The house is on an irregular plot about 289 by 155 feet and is assessed for $15,000. Samuel Hurwitz was the broker.

Colonel Luang Bipul Songgram, Defense Minister and head of the dominant militarist clique, today was named Premier by the Regency Council. He succeeded Phya Bahol Bolabayuha Sena, and his appointment was expected to bring drastic

Experimental work with a new organism high in vitamin B, which, when administered to rats, doubles their life span, is considered a possible cause of a strange undetermined disease marked by high fever from which Donald H. Cook, biochemist at the School of Tropical Medicine has suffered for the past month.

The refusal of commodity prices to show any sign of strength continues to be the source of concern to many persons who are of the opinion that there cannot be any material improvement in business conditions without some rise in prices of raw materials.

Laconia Ave (16-4580), e s, 100 ft s of Burke Ave, 100x100; Max Llttman to Theresa Unger, 2,048 E 18 St, Brooklyn. Home St (10-2681), n s, 116 ft w of Prospect Ave, 44x171; Sophie Swarts to Frelk Estates, Inc, 922 Hoe Ave; mtg 832,750.

FIRST RACE--Purse $600; claiming; 3-year-olds; six furlongs. Start good; won driving: place same. Went to post 2:59, off 3:00 1/2 Winner, It. b. g., by In Memoriam-Balata. Trainer, D. Hardy. Time-1:13 3/5.

General Louis Eugene Faucher, long head of the French military mission to Czecho-Slovakia, left Prague today after the tragic conclusion of his twenty-year work in building up and training the CzechoSlovak army.

Manhattan Alterations Broadway, 1,437; to 6-story offices and restaurant; estate of Francis L. Kennedy, 22 William St, owner; L. A. Swarthe, architect; cost $25,000. 104th St, 316 and 318 W; to two 4-story tenements: Namrac Realty Corp,
Adding five second places to a clean sweep of the firsts, a wellbalanced Williams swimming team defeated Fordham, 64 to 11, in a dual meet in the Forham pool yesterday.

More than 350 persons, many of them prominent in the field of education in New York, attended funeral services yesterday afternoon for Dr. Carroll N. Brown at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church, Riverdale Avenue and 248th Street. Dr.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
The Atlantic City Sea Gulls registered their first victory in twelve games tonight by defeating the New York Rovers, 3-1, in an Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League match.

Cotton-mill activity declined last week against a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index receded to 123.6 from 130.5, the revised figure for the preceding week. The index was 93.1 for the week ended Dec. 11, 1937.

Confirming preliminary reports of Sunday's election with only slight corrections, the election commission announced today that the German ticket had polled 2,093,466, or 87.3 per cent of the total valid votes while the Lithuanian tickets polled 266,485, or 12.7 per cent.

The auction sale of American, English and Continental furniture and decorations, property of Bruce W. Dennis, and of the estates of the late Edward A. Wylie, Edwin Isham, James F. Hamill and other owners, netted -$10,527 yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.

Bids for the general structural work on the sixteen-story Hunter College building, to rise on Park Avenue between Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth Streets, were opened yesterday by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college, in offices at 2 Park Avenue.

During the recent upland game season we covered a good portion of New England, as well as New York and New Jersey, and among the many bird hunters we met and hunted with the topic of conversation was not so much dogs, as field trials.

Newtown High's tossers, defending champions, registered their fifth straight Queens P. S. A. L. victory and tightened their hold on first place in that loop by turning back Jamaica High, 35-29, at Jamaica yesterday.

The Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association moved today to eliminate "hypocrisy" in its eligibility rules by letting down the bars and placing its chief aim on the maintenance of ideal scholastic standyards.

Renewed attacks on the administration of George Kondolf, local head of the Federal Theatre Project, were made yesterday afternoon at the quarterly meeting of the Actors Equity Association held in the Hotel Astor.

As "William Johnson," F. Donald Coster, or Philip Musica, was a special agent of the Attorney General's office in New York City from 1916 to 1919, engaged principally in investigations of spies and World War draft dodgers, a search of old records showed yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith in Brooklyn approved yesterday, with minor modifications, the reorganization plan submitted by the State Mortgage Commission for the $1,400,000 bond and mortgage on the property of the Lido Club Hotel at Long Beach, L. I. The court stipulated that the modifications must be accepted within ten days for final approval of the plan.

The commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "While the week has found demand for wool still moderate, there has been a better tone development since midweek, which is encouraging.-Sales have been made in moderate manner at rather better prices than were possible a week ago.

The stock market lacked rallying power yesterday. Share prices were irregular in the early trading and moved lower before midday and continued lower through to closing. The volume of trading diminished on the decline and the day's total on the Stock Exchange at 1,147,240 shares compared with 1,798,410 the day before.

The executive committee of the French Federation of Labor declares that it seeks a conference of American British and French workers' unions for a "common labor front to influence public opinion and the governments of the three great democracies."

Two more death sentences were meted out today as the Nazi regime pushed its campaign to stamp out what it calls "gangsterism." Willi Heller, 24, and Hanna Muendel, 21, his woman companion, were convicted of robbing a taxi driver and attempting to kill him.

The anti-third-term resolution which Senator Holt of West Virginia proposes to offer in the coming session of Congress will not be opposed by New Deal Senators, some of them said today. The proposal for a vote is now being accepted by those close to the Administration as desirable.

The Women's University Club has renewed its lease on the quarters it has been occupying in the Hotel Biltmore since Jan. 19 and has taken five additional rooms. Occupying about half of the second floor in the hotel structure, the club's quarters consist of an office,

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Dec. 16, unless specified: Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Brazos, at San Pedro. Cormorant, at Navy Yard, Washington, D. C, Dec. 15. Henderson, at Guam.

Cannon St. 87; Anthony J. Graziano, referee, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; foreclosure ($2). Mott St, 59; John H. Breen, referee, to Citizens Savings Bank; foreclosure ($1). Mulberry St, 139; East River Savings Bank to Seipol Realty Corp, 132 W 43d St ($15). Sheriff St, 97-99, s w cor of Stantnn St;

The labor difficulties that forced the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus to return to Winter quarters last June have been ironed out at a series of conferences between the management and th American Federation of Actors, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday.

Resignation of Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, following that of Homer S. Cummings, Attorney General, draws attention to the rather unusual length of time within which President Roosevelt's Cabinet has been kept intact.

George C. Hughes, founder of the Hughes Printing Company, East Stroudsburg, Pa., died today at Miami, Fla., relatives here were informed. His age was 76. Mr. Hughes, who retired from active management of the company about five years ago, formerly published The Hunterton Journal, at Flemington, N. J.;

The Customs Commissioner reported today that imports of Douglas Fir and Western hemlock under provisions of the Canadian trade agreement totaled 155,905,673 board feet, or 62.4 per cent of the annual quota, between Jan. 1 and Dec. 3. Of the imports, 87,001,122 board feet were straight Douglas fir, 31,253,073

It. Col. Walter P. Davenport, medical Corps having been detailed for duty with the organized Reserves, Second Corps Area, with station at New York, N. Y., is assigned to duty as assistant instructor, Second Military Area, and will report to the executive officer, Second Military Area, for duty. Capt, James M. Tobin, Engr.-Res., 73 Manchester Place, Newark, N. J., (D), 303d

The expectation that New York newspapers this month will equal or surpass linage for the correspending period of 1937 is being realized, according to estimates yesterday. It is now expected that about six of the eight papers here will register a gain for this month, if they continue the increases shown for the first two weeks of December. Sharp declines in two papers,

Six convictions obtained in the restaurant racket by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey as special prosecutor were upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division. On five of the convictions the court Was unanimous.

The Washington Square Association is engaged in a detailed study of the realty needs and the prospective growth of that neighborhood. with a view particularly to fostering and protecting wider use of the section for residential purposes.

W. A. Kingsland, vice president of the central region of the Canadian National Railways, will retire on pension on Dec. 31. F. L. C. Bond, general manager of that region, will become vice president and general manager at Toronto. C. G. Bowker, vice president and general manager of the Grand Trunk Western lines, will retire on pension. F. D. Fitzpatrick, heretofore chief engineer, will become general manager, with office in Detroit.

Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester, Mass., pulled away from the rest of the field in the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament today as he shot his second sub-par score, a 69, for a thirty-six-hole 135.
Properties in Harlem that have been rehabilitated or offer enhanced investment possibilities through modernizing held yesterday the center of interest in realty activity in Manhattan.

Max Schulman, 39-year-old window cleaner, of 154 Hopkins Street, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday morning in an accidental fall from the twelfth floor of a building at 254 Fourth Avenue, at Eighteenth Street, where he was cleaning windows.

South Australia got away to a big start in a Sheffield Shield cricket match against New South Wales today. Led by Don Bradman, the horre team had compiled 353 runs for the loss of three wickets at the close of play.

American dogwood trees are going to outnumber the Japanese cherry trees in Washington. In fact, President Roosevelt at his press conference today laughingly commended a proposal that the dogwoods be planted in the ratio of five to three, reminiscent of the naval strength agreed upon at the Washington arms conference.
Miss Katrina Levan Corbiere, daughter of Mrs. Levan Corbiere of this place, was married today to Cyril Bradford Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley Leverich Martin of Montclair.

The K-2, described as the largest non-rigid dirigible in the world, arrived at the Naval Air Station here today at 11:25 A. M. after a flight of 8 hours and 25 minutes from Akron, Ohio, where the craft was built for the navy by the Goodyear-Zeppelin Corporation.

The Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, who has long been first assistant at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Rosary, Yonkers, N. Y., will on Sunday, Jan. 8, begin his duties as assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, of which Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle is the rector. On the same day the Rev.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, New York, was authorized by the State Banking Department today to open a branch office at Halifax, N. S., upon discontinuance of its branch office at Moncton, N. B., Canada.
This is a summary of the evidence, on the patent situation in the glass container industry as made public today by Chairman O'Mahoney of the Temporary national Economic Committee:

BARRY. HONORA A. (Sept. 23). Estate, $9,500. To George J. Tichenor, nephew, 136 W. Broad St., Burlington, N. J., income from $1,000 bond; Frank A. Tichenor, nephew executor, 431 Rushmore Ave., Mamaroneck, N. Y., residue.
BASKETBALL Intercollegiate double-header, C. C. N. Y. vs. Oregon and St. John's vs. Northwestern, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.....8:15 P. M.

The High School of Music and Art-Mayor La Guardia refers to the school as his special "baby"-last night presented in its,auditorium, 135th Street and Convent Avenue, its sixth semi-annual concert before an audience of about 2,000.

In the last analysis the key to the problem of industrial planning for national defense lies in the organization, the administration and the methods employed by the War and Navy Departments. Manufacturers may do their part; business may support governmental programs wholeheartedly;
The local Weather Bureau yesterday issued the following week-end forecast and report on conditions for Winter sports areas in the East:

Thomas Meloy has been elected president of the Chambon Corporation, Garfield, N. J., maker of rotary printing presses. A. P. Barber, who has been with Valentine Co., Inc., paint and varnish concern,- for twenty-seven years, has been appointed trade sales manager.

Symbolizing the friendly renations between this country and Canada, colored lights to be strung next week on the Thousand Islands International Bridge will spell out the Christmas legend "Peace on earth, good will toward men."

Wall Street and Washington met on friendly terms last night under the auspices of the New York Financial Writers Association. The occasion was the association's first annual dinner and satirical revue, "The Financial Follies of 1938," held in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor.

Mother Mary Mercedes, who was principal of the Blessed Sacrament School here from 1927 until 1934, died here tonight at the Ursuline Convent after a long illness. She was 54 years old. A native of New York, Mother Mary was born Catherine Sullivan.

Visitors to the New York World's Fair of 1939 were assured of a roller coaster yesterday when Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, signed a contract with Harry C. Baker and Harry G. Traver, veteran carnival men, for the erection and operation of a "giant safety coaster" at the exposition.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn unanimously affirmed yesterday a decision of the Brooklyn Supreme Court upholding the right of the judges of the Kings County Court to grant pay increases to members of the tribunal's probation department, recently criticized in a report of the State Department...

Charging many violations of the legislation that it administers, the Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today G. L. Ohrstrom Co., Inc., of New York and Chicago, an investment house, to show cause on Feb. 1 why its registration as an over-the-counter dealer should not be suspended or revoked.

Relying heavily on reserves, Yale tonight scored a 12-to-2 hockey victory over Boston University as Dave Rodd and George Seabury starred. After being held in check for thirteen minutes, Yale's strategy netted three goals in two minutes, Dud Humphrey and Rodd making solo dashes to account for two of the tallies.

Richard Rothschild of the Downtown A. C. yesterday won the Long Island championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association at the Jackson Heights courts. Making his corner shots with greater accuracy than ever, Rothschild turned back J. J. Reynolds, a Columbia man representing the University Club, in the final round, 15-13, 16-15, 15-17.

Clarkson's strong defense kept the Syracuse quintet in check tonight until the last ten minutes, when the Orange broke loose on a scoring spree to gain a 40-to-17 triumph. Mark Haller's nine points helped Syracuse to a 20-to-8 lead at halftime. Captain Bob Stewart also collected nine points.

The Tennessee Valley Authority attacked another agency of the Federal 'Government today, the General Accounting Office. Replying to testimony of accounting office auditors before the Congressional Committee investigating the TVA, E. L. Kohler, the TVA controller, accused the office of incompetency, irresponsibility and inaccuracy.

The government tonight was reported to be in full control of the situation after several days of political unrest. Colonel Luis Larrea Alba and various Radical members of Congress are in hiding and many Socialists have been jailed in Quito. Friends of Dr. Francisco Arizaga Luque, President of the Constitutional Congress, are trying to obtain his release for voluntary exile.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Dec. 15: COLONELS Coburn. H. C. Jr., Med. Corps, Washington, D. C., to Ft. BBragg, N. C., April 16. Koon, G. H., Veterinary Corps, Ft. Sam Houston, Texas, to headquarters, Boston, Mass., and additional duty at the Boston Quartermaster Depot, as Attending Veterinarian, Harvard University, April 1.
President Thomas Lipscomb of the Cleveland Rams started pro football's Winter bartering today by hiring Earl (Dutch) Clark of the Detroit Lions as new head coach.

Thousands of Arabs are planning a monster demonstration Sunday on a hillside south of Hebron to express their loyalty to the King and the British Government and to give a public expression of thanks to the British army for ridding Palestine of lawless elements.

Metropolitan Vocational High has been awarded the Manhattan-Bronx vocational and continuation school swimming championship of the P. S. A. L. instead of Manhattan Aviation, announced as the winner at the conclusion of the title tourney last Saturday.
The marriage of Mrs. Florence Leavitt Schick of Montreal to Captain Giles C. Stedman, master of the liner Washington, which took place on Monday, was announced here yesterday.

The news that the United States Export-Import Bank had granted China a credit of $25,000,O00 was received in Japanese diplomatic and military circles here first with incredulity and then with amazed resentment.

Armando Novello did not die in poverty or of old age. He was in his fiftyfirst year, his death was the unhappy result of an operation, and he was the owner of a comfortable home and of an inn. He belonged, nevertheless, in the grand tradition of clowning.
Joseph P. Kennedy, Ambassador to London, paid a flying visit here today to report to President Roosevelt that he thinks the possibility of war in Europe within a few months is very great.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.

A lien for $4,000, representing a penalty of $50 for each ounce of heroin smuggled ashore from the Italian liner Rex on Oct. 27, has been filed against that vessel by the United States Government, it was learned yesterday..

Frank Donald Coster, whose real name was Philip Musica, came to the end of his incredible trail yesterday. Not in the pages of the "Arabian Nights," of Jules Verne, of Daniel Defoe or of any of our modern mystery writers has there been any imagined figure whose career matches that of this man.

Mrs. Annie Reilly of Canada, charged with having come into the United States six times illegally to see her children, was released from Oneida County jail today when three local citizens signed a $500 bail bond assuring her appearance in Federal court in Albany Jan. 4.
The Giants are going on the air. Horace G. Stoneham, young president of the New York National League club, announced yesterday that all Polo Grounds baseball games would be broadcast.

Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, will arrive on Monday to be the guest of Regent but Nicholas Horthy for some hunting parties. Although this is officially Three pri described as a private four-day visit, it will enable Count Ciano to meet a number of leading Hungarians

Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, will arrive on Monday to be the guest of Regent but Nicholas Horthy for some hunting parties. Although this is officially Three pri described as a private four-day visit, it will enable Count Ciano to meet a number of leading Hungarians

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick was directed yesterday by the Appellate Division, in a unanimous decision, to refund $176,703 in sales taxes paid under protest by the Berwind-White Coal Mining Company and $6,203 paid by A. H. Du Grenier, Inc., manufacturers of vending machines.
Mr. and Mrs. George W. Hubbell of this place have announced the engage- we ment of their daughter, Miss Marian Bellamy Hubbell, to Allan Quimby Mowatt of Swampscott, Mass.
John McKinlay Wight, for many years an attorney in New York, died yesterday at the home of a friend after a brief illness. Mr. Wight, who lived at 65 West Ninety-secbnd Street, was 70 years old.

Francis J. Gorman, president of the I United Textile Workers, advised the 700 locals of his union today to stop their payments to the C. I. O.'s Textile Workers Organizing Committee. Denouncing the C. I. O.'s T. W. O. C., which, he declared, a Rhode Island court decision had dissolved,

A man sentenced to be guillotined for murder was today again led to court to receive a five-year prison term for burglary. Maurice Pilorge, 24, who is a soldier, is soon to die for the murder last Summer of a wealthy Mexican
The $25,000,000 credit extended to China by our Government's Export-Import Bank is plainly no ordinary commercial credit, but something very close to an outright loan by the Government itself.

A Christmas gift of $153, saved in pennies by his fellow-students to enable him to buy a Seeing Eye dog, was presented here this afternoon to John Hamilton Jr., blind freshman at Bergen County Junior College, in the Barn Theatre on the campus.

A German plan for the release of the Jews under a system whereby a "ransom" in the form of foreign exchange would be paid as the price of their evacuation was today before the nations that are taking part in the international effort solve the refugee problem.

The six-story apartment house for fifty-four families at 1,580-4 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Brighton Apartments Corporation to Maplewood Estates, Inc., for $34,200 above X first mortgage of $172,800.

Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loews, Inc., testified yesterday that he regarded the profit-sharing contracts between the company and the chief executives of its filmproducing division as "a very good day's business for Loew's" The contracts are under attack in a minority stockholders' suit for an accounting of the actions of directors now on trial before Justice Louis A. Valente without a jury.

Secretary Perkins announced today that the minimum wages for employee of the airplane industry, as a result of hearings by the Public Contracts Board, was 50 cents an hour, or $20 a week for forty hours.

The House committee to investigate un-American activities will recommend to Congress next month a five-point program designed to control subversive influences in the United States. The committee ended four months of testimony yesterday. Informed persons said today that it would suggest:

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,086,000 bales, against 1,091,000 a week ago, 1,088,000 two weeks ago, 1,077,000 three weeks ago and 982,000 a year ago, of which American 511,000 bales, against 517,000 a week ago, 528,000 two weeks ago, 521,000 three weeks ago and 559,000 a year ago.
A thrilling spurt in the closing minutes enabled the Columbia University basketball team to score a dramatic triumph over the Colgate quintet in the Lions' gym last night.

At the annual general meeting of the Canadian Industrial Alcohol Company, Ltd., here today, Dr. Joseph Kaufmann was elected a director to succeed Thomas H. Gibbons. Other directors were re-elected. Mr. Gibbons, one of the representatives of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, resigned to make a place for Dr. Kaufmann.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had decided, by a vote of 3 to 2, to permit electric companies in New York City to extend the applicability of the rate for charitable institutions to include service to low-cost housing and slum clearance projects operated by governmental agencies under Federal law, by corporations organized under the State Housing Law and by insurance companies operating under the State Insurance Law.

Shoe production in November as totaled 27,500,000 pairs, the Tanners' Council estimated yesterday. This was a less-than-seasonal decline from October, and was 29.2 per cent above the output for November, 1937, which was 21,290,000 pairs.

An order for three more ships, bringing its total to fifty, was placed today by the Maritime Commission. The award went to the Bethlehem Steel Company, Inc., for combination passenger-cargo vessels costing $3,218,000 each, or a total of $9,654,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last Sunday night there was a forum on the radio devoted to a discussion of the chain-store tax proposed by Representative Patman. As a consumer this question is of financial interest to me.
The squash tennis team of the Bayside Tennis Club scored another victory yesterday when it defeated Princeton, 4-1, in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association.
The thirtieth anniversary of the founding of Temple Israel of Lawrence was celebrated at the temple here tonight by a service attended by more than 1,000 persons of all religious faiths.

The appointment of Mgr. William F. Lawlor. superintendent of archdiocesan schools, as archdiocesan consultor, was announced today by the Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Archbishop of Newark. Mgr. Lawlor succeeds the late Mgr. E. P. Carroll.

Peter Charles Swartz, joint owner of Cornfalfa Farms near here, died today after a brief illness at the Milwaukee Sanitarium. His age was 56. Born on the farm in 1882, Mr. Swartz attended Carroll College and the University of Wisconsin.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Scott Stewart of Grenville Farm, Media, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Mary Stewart, to Gordon Inglis Lindsay Jr. of New York.
A new book about Long fellow is being cordially received on all sides. Along with kind kind words for the biography there are all sorts of nice things about the subject thereof.

Adrian P. Burke, trustee for New York Title and Mortgage Company Series C-3 certificates, announced yesterday that he contemplated making on Dec. 31 a distribution of 3% per cent of income and one-half of 1 per cent of principal to holders of record of Dec. 10, the respective amounts to be $19,797 and $2,946.
Irving and Donald McKesson, who now are engaged in the chemical manufacturing business, issued yesterday through The Associated Press the following statement:

Senator Henry Berenger, opening a meeting of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee today, put Georges Bonnet, Foreign Minister, on the spot and asked him to explain in simple words what France's foreign policy is. The Senator cited the complicated series of European pacts to which France is a party and asked which ones hold and which ones France is incapable of maintaining.

The adventure of F. Donald Coster and those now revealed as his brothers in constructing an elaborately documented life pattern that they tried to follow was revealed in part yesterday by officials in Washington, D. C., Connecticut, New York City and elsewhere.

Kartiganer Co., millinery firm, has taken about 25,000 square feet of space, consisting of the store, basement and mezzanine in 43-51 West Thirty-sixth Street, where it will consolidate its various departments which now are scattered in several locations in the city.
J. Frankin Meehan, a landscape architect, died today of pneumonia at the age of 68. He was a member of the landscape gardening firm of J. Franklin Meehan Sons, Germantown.

Member trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange during the week ended Nov. 26 was 19.86 per cent of the total volume, compared with 20.72 per cent for the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The applicability to Puerto Rico of the 1873 United States statute prohibiting in territories the sale, gift or loan of birth-control articles will be tested soon as the result of the indictments today of six directors of the Puerto Rico Maternal and Child Health Association.

The Montclair team of the Women's New Jersey Squash Racquets Association triumphed over Elizabeth yesterday at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club by 4 to 1 for its second victory over its rivals. The losers gained their point through a default.

Thomas E. Otterson, 39 years old, of Stanwood Park, an office employe of the New York Telephone Company, was found dead today of carbon monoxide poisoning in his automobile, which had been parked in the woods near the Mount Kisco Country Club.

Important public documents in the indictments which were returned against the late Philip Musica, more recently known as F. Donald Coster, have disappeared from the files of both the Court of General Sessions and the District Attorney's office, it was revealed yesterday as a sideline of the general investigation into Coster's connection with the McKesson Robbins case.

Mrs. Sadie Monssen, 50-year-old widow of 'a United States Navy hero, finally yielded yesterday morning in her seven-month battle with the Home Owners Loan Corporation to escape eviction from her Brooklyn home. 1,756 West Tenth Street, on which the HOLC held a $7,000 mortgage.
Germany recalled today 200 empty steel bottles-bottles the Nazi had hoped would come home filled with precious helium, the noninflammable gas that might prevent another Hindenburg disaster.

RKO has scheduled "They Made Me a Spy," original screen story by Lionel Houser and George Bricker, for production early in January with Sally Eilers in the lead. Lew Landess will direct and Joe Pagano has been assigned to prepare a scenario.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Nothing has aggravated me as much as the All-America football teams selected thus far. I have reason, to be angry. In scanning these mythical elevens, I note the country's greatest player has not been named on any first team as yet.

The death in an airplane crash yesterday of Valery Chkaloff, Who placed his name among the greatest heroes of aviation last year when he piloted the first Soviet plane over the North Pole to America, has evoked the deepest and most sincere grief of any event in Russia since the destruction of the airplane Maxim Gorky and the death of all fortynine aboard in 1935.

Gifts of $10,752.18 from 343 contributors increased the 1938 Neediest Cases Fund to $128,703.77 yesterday, but nevertheless left it $23,124.55 behind where it stood on the corresponding day of the appeal a year ago.

116th St, 368 W, 25x100.11: Gedar Realty Corp to Myron E. Crawford et al. at New Canaan, Conn.; p m mtg, 7 yrs, 4%; $6,000. 117th St, 17 E, 25x100.11; Dotton Holdings, Inc, to Bank of New York et al., exec'rs Geo. A. Thayer, p m mtg, 6 yrs, 31/2-41/2%; S12.500.

" Skiing in the East," a guide to the 1,500 miles of ski trails in the New England States, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, prepared and written by the WPA Federal Writers Project in New York City, will be published Jan. 10 by Barrows.

11:00-11:15A. M.--"Work of the Postoffice Department," Postmaster KI General Farley; Band and Glee Club-WJZ. 11:00A. M.-12:30P. M.-Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert; Choir of Pope Pius X School of Liturgical Music-WABC. 12:30-1:30 P. M.-Representative Martin Dies Discussing "Un-American Activities" on Farm and Home Hour-WJZ.

Miss Marie New of New York, daughter j of Dr. and Mrs. James E. New of Dublin, Ga., and John Merritt Fisher were married this afternoon in Christ Church, Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Ernest A. De Bordenave.
