M.-Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert; Choir of Pope Pius X School of Liturgical Music-WABC. 12:30-1:30 P. M.-Representative Martin Dies Discussing "Un-American Activities" on Farm and Home Hour-WJZ.

Miss Marie New of New York, daughter j of Dr. and Mrs. James E. New of Dublin, Ga., and John Merritt Fisher were married this afternoon in Christ Church, Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Ernest A. De Bordenave.

An agreement is understood to have been reached between CzechoSlovakia and Germany concerning new tariffs. It is believed that the new agreement will link CzechoSlovakia very closely with the German economic system.

The marriage of Miss A. Marie Louise Bates, daughter of Mrs. Putnam A. Bates of this city and the late Mr. Bates, to Thomas Mercer Emory, son of Mrs. George Bache Emory of Morristown and Cazenovia, N. Y., and the late Dr. Emory, took place here this afternoon in the Church of the Redeemer. The Rev. Thomas W. Attridge performed the ceremony.

The arrest by Nazi authorities in Danzig of a widow, Frau Agnes Schultz, and her ten children for frequenting a Polish school and the arrest of a teacher and a kindergarten nurse for conspiracy to "lure German-born pupils" aroused a strong protest from Warsaw.

Upsets marked the Fair Grounds racing today, the feature race, a six-furlong dash, providing one of the surprises. It was won by a 15-to-1 chance, Lucky Star, as the short-priced favorite, Sadie F., ran last in the field of seven starters.

The Brooklyn College wrestling team last night triumphed over Lafayette at the Brooklyn College gymnasium, 19-11. The winners had a wide lead when the visitors took the heavyweight bout, Frank May pinning H. Schneiderman in 3:25.
Aimed at a better understanding between sources of supply and buyers, the first of a series of informal meetings of the staff buyers of the paid resident offices was held here last week.

Godfrey K. Preiser of East Orange has been re-elected president of the Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood. Other officers are J. Lewis Fiacre of Maplewood, vice president; James G. Word and John D. Munther, vice presidents; Donald W. Willett,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORR TIMES: Your recent editorial on Mr. Kettering's testimony before the Economic Committee, that the big problem facing the nation is how to create new industries to put idle men and money to work, pointed out that certain limiting considerations obtained against the theory that new industries, per se, were always beneficial to employment or that they alone were capable of stimulating industry.
The Nassau Speedwell Society will be the beneficiary of a skating carnival at the Mineola Fair Grounds Roller Skating Rink here on Friday afternoon. An exhibition of fancy skating will be given.

HERE is a book of strange matters. There are some curious monsters here, and many mysteries; heroic conflict, careful nurture, incredible proficiency; now and then the microscope will show astounding complexities in minuscule, like the antennae that smell out the mosquito's prey.

Mme. Jos Maria Sert, a sister of the tragic Georgian Mdivani Princes, died yesterday in a Lausanne hospital after a long illness. The death of Mme. Sert, in her early thirties, became known only today after simple funeral services in a Lausanne church and burial in a near-by provincial Swiss cemetery.

The engagement of Miss Carmen Arguedas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arturo Arguedas of Forest Hills, Queens, to Marvin Chandler, also of Forest Hills, son of Mrs. Thomas E. Chandler of Brookline, Mass., and the late Dr. Chandler, has been announced by her parents.

By the world's material way of measurement, Madame, the executive, is making good in Washington. Cabinet officer, diplomat, director, bureau head, she is moving into positions in government that carry financial reward for heavier responsibilities.

PERU'S series commemorating the Eighth Pan-American Conference, now in progress at Lima, reached New York last week. It comprises six large stamps, three of them for air mail use, and all are inscribed "VIII Conferencia Internacional Americana" and "Lima-Deciembre de 1938." They were printed in London.

The threat of out-of-town markets to the supremacy of production in the dress industry here is becoming greater than in past seasons, with a larger volume of orders going to Chicago, St. Louis, Cleveland and Los Angeles, according to reports in merchandising quarters here last week.

Opposition to the Westchester County Water Commission's proposal to build a $22,343,000 watershed system was expressed today by Putnam County supervisors and members of the Peekskill Water Board. They declared the system,

A proposal to establish a nonprofit theatre with a permanent acting company to further the interests of theatrical art and education was advanced yesterday by Professor Randolph Somerville, chairman of the Dramatic Art Department of the New York University Schonl of Education, in a report to Acting Dean E. George Payne.
World events dominated the most significant news stories of 1938, students in journalism at the University of Pittsburgh decided in their annual ballot.

The marriage of Miss Justine Cutting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting of Wheatley Hills and New York, to Alexander C. Cushing, son of Mrs. James Denison Sawyer and the late Howard G. Cushing, the artist, took place this afternoon at the Episcopal Church of the Advent.

G. Leroy Kemp, convicted Frilay of conspiracy in connection with Merritt Parkway land purchases, was released from the county jail, where he spent last night, after raising $20,000 bail today pending a hearing on his appeal to the Supreme Court of Errors.
Forty per cent of the members of the freshman class at Bryn Mawr College want to participate in dramatics during their college career.

Pierre Etchebaster, world open court tennis champion, probably will defend his crown against James Dear, British professional, in the Spring. It was learned today from Clarence C. Pell, president of the Racquet and Tennis Club of New York,

An interesting and important experiment is to be tried by the International Kennel Club of Chicago on March 31, the day before the opening of that organization's two-day exhibition in the International Amphitheatre in the Union Stock Yards.

Miss Sarita S. Blagden, elder daughter of Edward S. Blagden of Willowgate, Lloyd Harbor, was married this afternoon to the Rev. Frederic B. Kellogg, son of Mrs. Frederic R. Kellogg of New York, in St. John's Episcopal Church of Cold Spring Harbor.

WHERE, oh where has the Mercury gone, where, oh where can it be? Last year it was not hard to find. By following the crowd in Forty-first Street just east of Broadway you were bound to turn up at the Mercury box office, where every one was trying to buy tickets for "Julius Caesar" at once.
AN inner joyousness: that seems the true and abiding, seems the sovereign quality in the work of William Glackens, whose memorial exhibition opened last week at the Whitney Museum.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Edyth Elizabeth Prahl, daughter of Mrs. Betty S. Prahl of 375 Riverside Drive this city, and of Frederick A. Prahl of Toledo, Ohio, to James R. Gaskill, son of Mrs. James R. Gaskill of Grantwood, N. J., formerly of Tarboro, N. C., and the late Mr. Gaskill.

Peter Grimm, former head of the Citizens Budget Commission, has been named chairman of the executive committee of the $250,000 campaign of the Community Church, it was announced yesterday. Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof,
Seton Hall evened matters with the Brooklyn College five by winning, 45-29, at the Orange Armory tonight. The Pirates lost on the Brooklyn court last week. Seton Hall led at the half, 24-16.

Borough President Joseph A. Palma of Staten Island has appealed to Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran for assistance in finding drill and recreation accommodations for the Thirty-third Fleet Division of the Naval Militia, which has been without a home since the old Briarcliff sank at her pier near Stapleton several weeks ago. Mr. Curran has referred the request to John McKenzie, Dock Commissioner.

Mrs. Edward Ehrbar of 30 Sutton Place, this city, and Raquette Lake, N. Y., gave a supper dance last night in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kathryn Loretto Ehrbar, to John J. Glennon Jr. of New Rochelle, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Glennon.

Europe's fevered state of mind after Munich could not have been dramatized more vividly than at the dinner of London's Foreign Press Association this week, when the German Ambassador and all German correspondents here boycotted a speech by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain.

Many exporters in the United States no doubt were highly elated over the indication given this week by Secretary Morgenthau that financial steps were being planned to increase the flow of commerce between the Americas.

The "What Helps Business Helps You" campaign, opened last July to develop greater public understanding and support of private enterprise, will be intensified in 1939, it was announced yesterday by presidents of seven of the city's leading commercial organizations.

WHATEVER may be the final result of the war between Japan and China, its issues are now officially clarified for the first time. In fact, the whole Far Eastern conflict, dating from before 1900, is clarified.
MALESHERBES was not the most powerful or conspicuous Frenchman in public life during the period of the Revolution and the years before it, but he was one of the greatest and the best.

A fast St. Francis College basketball team outclassed the University of Newark tonight, scoring by 52 to 36. Al Lenowicz led the winners with 15 points. Newark held a 2-point margin for most of the first half but trailed at the intermission, 25-17.

Daily grocery chain store sales during November hit a new post-depression high for that month. They exceeded every previous month this year and every other November average since 1930, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce revealed today in its monthly tabulation of this business.
Announcement has just been made that the eighteenth Beaux-Arts Ball will be given under the auspices of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects on April 21 at the Hotel Astor.

Five hundred toys made by the Lexington Homedrafters, a club of forty business and professional men in Lexington, will be delivered to the children of the Eastern Kentucky mountains through facilities afforded by the mountain radio listening center system of the University of Kentucky.

With factory sales of mechanical anthracite stokers up about 45 per cent for the first eleven months of this year over the corresponding period of 1937, the number of manufacturers in the field is increasing steadily and several more will bring out lines early next year, reports here yesterday indicated.

MUCH has been written about the influence of the Negro on American music. Many critics and musicians throughout the country, with the exception of John Powell, have proclaimed hat this nation's most significant contribution to music has been the Negro spiritual, and a few earnest, scattered souls have gone so far as to admit that the Negro blues have had their effect upon serious American composers.

The Chinese army will adopt new tactics, according to General Pai Chung-hsi, vice commander of all China's armies, because positional warfare tactics employed at Shanghai, Hankow and elsewhere have been disastrous against Japan's superior armaments.

THE Pharisees were the antiassimilationist party among the Jews of the immediate centuries before and of the first century of our era. They were the culminating factors in making Israel the people of the Torah.

The autonomous Memel District, which, though it legally belongs to Lithuania, has played a disproportionately large role am a German irredenta along one of Germany's "bleeding borders," has just held an election in which her National Socialists polled 87.1 per cent of the vote under the slogan "Back to the Reich."

The Christmas festivals in New York City will start this week. Father Knickerbocker, through the Park Department, will erect trees in twenty-eight parks in the city and at 5:25 o'clock Tuesday evening Mayor La Guardia will throw the switch to light the tree in City Hall Park, officially starting the city's observance of the Christmas season.

Smaller properties are forming the bulk of open-market realty trading in Manhattan. Although there was a sharp upturn last month in the number of such sales, the dollar volume of trading declined, according to the monthly sales report of the Real Estate Board of New York.

ALMOST as many ingenious schemes for "crashing the movies" have been devised as there are eager lads and lasses ambitious to get before a camera. But to date, it would appear, young David Niven is unique among those who have successfully "crashed." He is the only screen player who got into the movies via a British warship.
Efforts of Chile, Mexico and Argentina to have the Pan-Americann Conference agree that no diplomatic intervention should follow seizure of property of foreigners were defeated at Lima yesterday.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schmidt of Ridgewood, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hazel M. Schmidt, to Curt L. Mahnig of St. Gallen. Switzerland.

With the opening tomorrow of Shell Pile Social Center near Port Norris, N. J., for the benefit of itinerant oyster shuckers, the Council of Women for Home Missions will launch its fiftieth project in a national, long-range experiment for the relief of migratory laborers.
New impetus to the Federal investigation of spy activities in Southern

WASHINGTON.-With the opening next month of the new annex of the Library of Congress, with twice the shelf capacity of the main building, the library, now the world's largest in number of books, manuscripts and other items, will become even more popular as a tourist attraction.
The University of Pittsburgh played in midseason form tonight and defeated the Duke University basketball team, 51 to 37.

The newspaper is the most effective and favorite advertising medium of progressive savings and loan associations throughout the country, the Federal Home Loan Bank Review, official organ of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, stated today.
FLOOR screens, long valued by decorators for their usefulness and versatility, are becoming. in the hands of clever designers, examples of art in themselves.
One week before Christmas the 1938 Neediest Cases Fund stands at $137,473.22, a generous sum, but far, far short of what is needed to relieve the harshest misery known to exist in New York today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-This resort is ablaze with the red and green lights of Christmas, and visitors to the resort during the next two weeks will find the Yuletide spirit in full swing.
More Winter construction, according to reports from many builders and brokers, is under way at the present time in Queens and other sections of Long Island than has been the case for many years.

Coach Charles Benson and a squad of about twenty-two Pompton Lakes High School football players will leave Newark by train Thursday for a game Dec. 26 with Clearwater (Fla.) High School at Clearwater.

IN response to foreign broadcasts on short waves, the British Broadcasting Corporation reports its mail climbing steadily. Since Oct. 1 more than 10,000 postcards have been received, according to The Listener, journal of the organization. Broadcasting of news to foreigners in their own tongue is said to have given stimulus to the mail.

Many indoor horticulturists are finding a zestful hobby these Winter days making lead vessels for their "dish gardens." The process is simple, and requires only a few common tools and no great muscular exertion.

PARIS.--Vienna is going to be the Chicago of Europe. The Nazi plan is to make of it the center of distribution for all produce and commerce passing east or west, north or south, across the Continent. It is, in fact, to be Chicago, Duluth, St. Louis and Kansas City all rolled into one.
Kensuke Horinouchi, the new Japanese Ambassador, arrived in the capital today. He said in an interview he would strive to be a "bridge builder" between his country and the United States.
Acting United States Attorney Gregory F. Noonan announced here yesterday that the government had conclusive proof of an extensive arms traffic masked as the foreign drug trade of McKesson Robbins.

DURING the Spring, Summer and early Fall of next year millions of visitors to New York's World's Fair will view a panorama of the City of Tomorrow, or, to take the alternate titles, the City of Tomorrow Morning, or Democracity.

Mr. and Mrs. Blaine S. Smith of Pelham Manor, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Ann Smith, to Arthur Fenton Hetherington Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Hetherington of Bound Brook, N. J.

Notwithstanding the gains in home construction registered this year, "decent housing facilities in the United States are still grossly inadequate," Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonald declared yesterday.
Coach Wallace Wade announced after a practice session today that he would take a squad of thirtyfive players to Pasadena for the Rose Bowl game with Southern California's Trojans.

In the widespread publicity that has attended Mexico's seizure of United States and British oil fields, it seems to have been forgotten that Bolivia was the first Latin-American government to confiscate a foreignowned petroleum property.

IN these days of much political talk about "prices" it is well to turn to impartial sources to find out what all the talking's about, especially in view of what the Administration at Washington may do about prices.
Paced by Homer Peabody, Harvard's basketball team rallied in the final eight minutes to upset Boston University, 50 to 37, before 1,000 enthusiastic rooters in the Indoor Athletic Building tonight.
Mrs. Winston Churchill will get back ten five-pound notes stolen during her brief stay here as a guest of Lord Moyne, chairman of the West Indies Royal Commission.

Merchants from the city's garment center visited Police Headquarters yesterday to identify goods stolen from them in recent weeks and recovered by detectives who trailed four alleged loft burglars to 20 West Twenty-second Street Friday night.

IS the turnpike coming back? Westchester's Cross - County Parkway will become a toll road when two important improvements-an extension at Dunwoodie, Yonkers, to connect with the Saw Mill River Parkway, and. a new Fleetwood bridge over -the Bronx River valley-are completed.

Engagement of $8,300;000 gold abroad for shipment here-$2,500, 000 in England and $5,800,000 in Japan-was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank also reported the arrival late on Friday of $6,709,000 gold from England and $2,682,000 from Holland.

SHIPS at sea will celebrate the Yuletide in good old-fashioned style. And whether in port at Calcutta, Port Said, or Hongkong, sets of whiskers for Santa Claus, plum puddings, and Christmas trimmings will be hauled out of mysterious storerooms on Dec. 24. The United States Lines,

The suicide of Philip Musica, or F. Donald Coster, indicted head of McKesson Robbins, Inc., was cited by a Congressional critic of TVA today as evidence of the need for "a most complete audit to protect the people's money."

More than 250 students from twelve Catholic colleges of the metropolitan area will convene this afternoon at 2 o'clock for the third meeting of the National Federation of Catholic College Students being held in the new Cardinal Hayes Library at Manhattan College.

The city's annual Christmas pageant-shopping for presents-is reaching its frantic climax with streets and stores jammed with hurried men and women who are trying to fill last-minute gaps in their Christmas lists.

Because new faces are about to appear in the President's Cabinet-the first for years-the personnel, status and record of this government group have come again to public attention, together with deep interest in the identities of the two new members. To some extent this attention and interest stem from historical memory, since, save in a few instances, modern Cabinet members play but minor roles in current affairs.

Some of the younger generation of Republican leaders, among them Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Robert A. Taft of Ohio, were entertained at luncheon today by John D. M. Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee.

TWICE a year many suites of apartments in New York hotels are taken over by California manufacturers, who bring with them tall trunks of the kind used by theatrical companies on the road. When they are opened and their steel rods pulled out, they release a flood of color. There,
AMERICANS who find themselves in strange ports at Christmas time will have their loneliness for home at this time of year abated by the colorful celebrations of various countries.
Today Westwood (N. J.) Woman's Club-Choral group Christmas program, Mrs. Lester C. Brower, chairman, presiding, 4 P. M., Alpine Methodist Church.

IT IS strange that radio drama, so closely allied in its plays and players with the stage and a screen, is not setting the outstanding example of how commercial announcements can be handled without annoying the audience.

Six houses per day are being constructed in the Pennsylvania Housing Corporation's development at Clairton, Allegheny County, Pa., a few miles south of Pittsburgh, points out The Architectural Forum in its current issue, which declares that it is one of the most significant housing projects in the United States.

For the first time in the history of Protestantism a system of accrediting has been established for the theological schools of all denominations of the Protestant faith in the United States and Canada and a list of the accredited institutions drawn up.

TRAPPERS and fur dealers of the Far North are abandoning snowshoes, dog sleds and boats in favor of aerial transportation. Game wardens of the Alaska Game Commission, armed with Congressional permission to purchase, maintain and operate aircraft in the pursuit of their duties, also have wings. Formerly,

Miss Leontine Cary Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orin C. Baker of Englewood, and Mortimer B. Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Thomas of Tenafly, N. J., were married today at a candlelight service in St. Paul's Episcopal Church Chapel by the Rev. James A. Mitchell.

Realty interest in properties in Westchester and Putnam Counties has continued through the Fall and Winter months at a very satisfactory level, and as a result of seveal important deals recently an active building year is predicted by brokers and builders during the coming year.

The National Steel Car Corporation, Ltd., has advised the Montreal Stock Exchange of a special meeting of stockholders to be held in Hamilton, Ont., on Dec. 28 to consider an increase in authorized capital stock from 130,000 to 250,000 no-par shares.

Even the birds-the hardier species that have not flown South for the Winter-will feast well this Christmas, for the Boy Scouts of Nature Study Troop 472 of the Kips Bay Boys Club, 301 East Fifty-second Street, have not forgotten them.

ALTMAN-Rose, beloved mother of Lillian Cymberg, Hyman, Doris and Vivian, sister of Mike and Abe. Funeral from her late residence, 1,507 Morris Ave., Bronx, 1 P. M., Sunday. Burial New Mount Zion Cemetery, Rutherford, N. J. ANNAPOLEN-Isaac, devoted husband of the late Sarah, beloved father of Mollie Engel, Ida Feldman, Leona Goldberg, Bert Tobey, Ethel Neidenberg.

THE trusts, like the poor, are always with us, and the cynic might find a causal connection. They were outlawed by the Sherman Anti Trust Act of 1890, but the verdict was suspended; they were busted by Theodore Roosevelt, but mended again; they were reformed by the Federal Trade Commission and regulated by the Clayton Act, but survived both these outbreaks of morality.

WE had seen the famous view of Vesuvius across the Bay of Naples, towering over the city. And the scene from Capri, with he Isle of Ischia on the left, Naples ahead and Sorrento on the right, all dominated by the imperial Vesuvius, which seems to be the source of these white clouds hanging in the Neapolitan skies.

In the first change of ownership for the property in nearly 170 years, Edward M. Townsend Jr. and Greenough Townsend have sold their large rambling residence on a two-acre plot at Oyster Bay, L. I., with frontage on Oyster Bay Harbor, to John R. Gibb of Glen Head.

Anticipating an exodus of skiing enthusiasts from the metropolitan area each week-end this Winter, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad yesterday announced a comprehensive schedule of snow trains for the Berkshires and the White and Green Mountains of New Hampshire and Vermont.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Thomas Hamlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Sears Hamlin of Summit, to Henry Root Stern Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stern of New York and Manhasset, L. I., took place here this afternoon at Redgate, the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Seth E. Thomas Jr.

The Interstate Commerce Commission received from Frank M. Weaver, one of its examiners, a recommendation for a reduction of about 20 per cent in the all-rail rates on sugar shipments between the Northand the South.
Mrs. Emma J. Fellows, wife of Otis Dwight Fellows of Newton Center and prominent in the affairs of the New Center's Women's Club, died today at the New England Deaconness Hospital at the age of 54.

ONCE again the used-car situation is receiving close attention on the part of both dealers and manufacturers. The condition of dealers with respect to used-car inventory continues to be far better than last year.

One thing is pretty certain to many observers in Kansas, and that is that when Payne H. Ratner, Governor-elect, takes office next month he will have more than a casual knowledge of the State's industrial problems.

E. Roland Harriman of New York, head of the American Trotting Register Association, reported tonight that his organization and two other parent bodies in the harness horse racing sport had reached "virtual agreeiment" on a merger plan after three days of consideration.

Arrangements were completed yesterday for the 1939 appearance of Miss Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue at Madison Square Garden. The Norwegian figureskating star and her supporting cast will give six performances in New York, the visit of the troupe extending from Monday, Jan. 16,

An official of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Fidelity Investment Association was preparing to answer the SEC's charges of fraud in connection with the sale of $600,000,000 securities to the public.

Miss Marcia Stevens Kitchell, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Kitchell, was married in her home here this afternoon to Irvin Torrence Francis of Caldwell, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John A. Francis.

Student participation in musical activity that ranges from the serious consideration of swing music on a phonograph record to organ recitals of the great masterpieces will be increased this week at City College as preparations for two orchestral concerts and Christmas carol singing are made.
A train carrying a determined band of Carnegie Tech football players steamed out of Pittsburgh tonight to New Orleans and the Sugar Bowl.
The first women to obtain diplomas from a co-educational school in Colombia have just been graduated from the National University here.

The need for wholesome recreation among household employes is being stressed in the program of the WPA household training course, being given in Brooklyn and Manhattan Centers, by a recreation committee, headed by Mrs. Emma Shields Penn.

The body of F. Donald Coster, president of McKesson Robbins who killed himself in his home here yesterday, will be sent sometime tonight to Fairchild's Funeral establishment, Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, for burial on Monday or Tuesday.
Virginio Gayda, who fills the double role of managing editor and chief editorial writer of the Giornale d'Italia, probably can claim to be one of the world's most widely quoted journalists.

At a moment when the Pan-American conference at Lima commands attention the conclusion that there is an open door in South America for American cultural and educational leadership is brought home by Dr. Merle E. Frampton, Professor of Education

Paced by George Stanley and Jack Hopkins, who scored 22 points between them, Episcopal Academy defeated Trinity School of New York, 30-27, at Basketball today. Stanley and Hopkins hit the cords for five field goals and a foul apiece, while Bob Nicholson,

LONDON. REHEARSALS began today for the English premiere of Noel Coward's "Design for Living," which is going into the Haymarket in January with Diana Wynyard, Rex Harrison and Anton Walbrook making up the triangle.
Arriving at the same decision independently, the Yankees and Giants disclosed yesterday that they would play no baseball at night anywhere in 1939.

Connie Mack, ranked by some with Billy Penn and Ben Franklin as Philadelphia's all-time leading citizen, will celebrate his seventy-sixth birthday on Friday, two days before Christmas, with the hope Santa Claus will bring him a winning baseball team in 1939.

LIKE the old gray mare, the little cinemas ain't what they used to be. Once they were a fairly reliable font of screen entertainment. Noncompetitive with the Broadway houses, they combed the foreign market for the best pictures produced outside of Hollywood.

The strike of 1,000 C. I. O. meat handlers employed in the plants of the "big four" packing companies in this city was settled yesterday through the efforts of a Federal mediator. The strike began last Monday.

Recent political events in Memel and rumors of impending German offensive in Danzig have aggravated the apprehensions of the Baltic States, especially Latvia and Lithuania but also Estonia, about increased Nazi activities on a wide front in the countries between Germany and Russia.

VALENTINE WILLIAMS, now known as a novelist specializing in romance and mystery, began his writing career as one of Reuter's men, his father before him having worked long years for this famous news-gathering agency. So,

Although the number who obtained jobs prior to graduation this year was unusually small. at least 81 per cent of the 1938 graduates of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn are now gainfully employed, according to a report by the college placement bureau, based on returns from 149 of the 172 students who received degrees in engineering or chemistry last June.
THE next war is now being fought in the research laboratories of the great powers, a fact which air officials of the United States have recently sought to impress upon the public mind.
For the second successive year, Princeton University's Whig-Cliosophic Debating Societies are planning an ambitious program of over forty debates.

The little tin soldier will be covered with rust, the "mamma" doll will squeak no more and the familiar old set of blocks in the nursery will be put aside this Christmas to make way for newer and more complicated toys, for the young folks of modern times are seeking scientific playthings.

Archibald McNeil, former Democratic National Committeeman from Connecticut, who has been subpoenaed as a grand jury witness by Federal authorities in New York City, said today he would be glad of an opportunity to testify. The subpoena has not yet reached him.

The marriage of Miss Vivian Campbell, daughter of Dr. O. S. Campbell of Grafton, W. Va., to John S. Radosta of this city took place yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector, performed the ceremony.

A UNITED STATES postal item obtained recognition as one of philately's most valuable pieces when Esmond Bradley Martin purchased last week for $25,000 the only known used block of the 1869 24-cent purple and green stamp with center inverted.

The A B C of the Federal Reserve System. By Edwin Walter Kemmerer. (Eleventh edition.) A discussion of the conditions leading to the establishment of the Federal Reserve System, a description of the main features of its organization, and a study of its actual operation.
A sudden jingling of sleigh bells caused Ernest Schelling to interrupt the Young People's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall.

A $15,000 contract to erect the Vanderbilt gates and fence at the entrance to the Conservatory Gardens at 105th Street near Fifth Avenue in Central Park was awarded yesterday to Abraham M. Goldsmith, Inc., general contractor.

WITH photographic Christmas cards finished, with the list of photographic gifts checked over for the last time and the final present purchased, the time has come when camera enthusiasts turn their attention to recording the scheduled visit of Santa Claus next Sunday.

The public approves the instructions sent by the government to its delegates at the Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, to aid the United States decisively in lowering trade barriers and adopting a pact of solidarity against threats of force or similar acts by non-American governments.

After almost daily outrages for two weeks, Haifa has enjoyed three days of tranquility. This supports a recent authoritative statement that the attacks were the last fling of the terrorists, who are slowly being rounded up.
ASTRONOMERS are gazing with enhanced interest and Respect these December nights upon the planet Jupiter, which aside from the moon is now the brightest thing in the sky.

College versifiers continue creative efforts long after they have graduated from composition classes, students' magazine staffs and literary clubs. This is the opinion held at Middlebury, where an alumni and Bread Loaf poetry contest closed Thursday.

Miss Jean McVicar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Harrison McVicar, was married tonight to Lieutenant Trevor N. Dupuy, son of Major R. Ernest Dupuy and Mrs. Dupuy of West Point, N. Y., in the McVicar home here. The Rev. Joseph McCann, rector of St. Joseph's Church, performed the ceremony.
The recent alleged German attempt to "Aryanize" Swedish concerns was discussed today at a meeting of the Swedish business men concerned.

Farmers of the nation were warned today by Representative Martin Dies, chairman of the committee investigating un-American activities, to expect efforts by the Communist party within the next two years to organize and "dominate" a National Farmer-Labor party.

JOHN C. WILSON, presumably looking ahead to next season, has emerged as the successful bidder for "Duo," Paul Geraldy's dramatization of the Mme. Colette novel, which is currently on the boards of the Theatre St. Georges, Paris.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.
The Ukrainian Press Service has challenged statements made in a dispatch from G. E. R. Gedye on Dec. 3 dealing with the situation in the Ukraine.

Italian agitation for the annexation of French Tunisia and Corsioa bears directly on Frenoh Somaliland and the port of Jibuti which forms a natural outlet for the oonquered Kingdom of Ethiopia, now Italian East Africa. A correspondent recently in this territory describes below the efforts of the Italians to open up their great domain.

THIS week before Christmas will be, for most of us, a time of kindly thought toward those who make up our circle of friends, and of pleasant assurance of their thought in return. We shall have the double joy of remembering and being remembered.

Many holiday dances will be held this week throughout Westchester County. On Thursday evening the Ardsley Country Club here will be the scene of a supper dance to be given by the Thursday Club to aid St. Faith's House in Tarrytown,

The Cross Brown Company held its 238th monthly dinner last week. More than 200 members of the staff were present. Speakers included Morton B. Cross, president; A. J. Courtney, vice president, who also acted as toastmaster;

The annual Christmas celebration at Marymount College will open today with the presentation of an allegorical Nativity pageant presented by the dramatic society. The program, for which scenery has been designed by the college studio, wi11 include also Bach's Christmas oratorio by members of the Choral Club.

An official of the FHA in calling attention to the fact that every room in the new home should be carefully planned states that too little thought is generally given to proper planning for the dining room, despite the fact that it is frequently used for entertaining and that the family spends some part of every day in that room.

The interest of the delegates to the Eighth Pan-American Conference was concentrated today in a new project circulated by the American delegation for a declaration on continental solidarity to be known as The Declaration of Lima.

Representative Wright Patman, the Robinson-Pathan Anti-Chain Store Act, made speeches under the sponsorship of McKesson Robbins, Inc., the drug concern whose affairs are being investigated by the Federal authorities, according Democrat of Texas, co-author of to an advertisement appearing in Drug Topics, a trade publication, in its issue of Nov. 23, 1936.
Locusts have again destroyed Nicaragua's bean crop, one of the chief foods of Nicaraguans. but have not touched the rice crop, the largest on record.

The heads of the twenty-one delegations to the Pan-American Conference met unexpectedly today in their capacity as steering committee in an endeavor to reconcile conflicting views regarding Pan-American mediation in the Spanish civil war.
The Christmas holiday period will provide many subscription dances for the diversion of juniors in society who will be at home from schools and colleges for the Winter recess.

The cumbersome word circumferential as applied to the $28,000,000 highway project skirting Brooklyn and Queens has been cut down to belt, a designation within the grasp of every one, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday.

Sterling was in demand in the foreign exchange market here today, and as the dollar weakened to $4.67% to the pound the customary sympathetic depreciation of the Swiss and Dutch currencies followed. The franc closed firm at 177 9-16 to the pound.

A great deal has been heard recently about "incentive taxation," particularly in connection with an investigation by a Senate committee to determine whether such taxation should be adopted to encourage profit-sharing plans in business.
Dr. William B. D. Penniman, one of the leading chemists and chemical engineers in the country, died this afternoon in his home, after an illness of several months. He was 72 years old.

Sir (Edwin) Cooper Perry, eminent British physician, died today at the age of 82. Sir Cooper was chairman of the Worthing Hospital, governor of Royal Holloway College, chairman of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and senior consulting physician of Guy's Hospital.
WE sat on the floor and looked at photographs o his buildings - building by Antonin Raymond Architects know Antonin Ray mond; to the layman his is prob ably an unfamiliar name.
Viscountess Astor, speaking in support of camps for children, said today, "Britain does not expect war but we never can tell what will happen, because dictators are like lunatics, at large."

Defeat of flue-cured tobacco marketing quotas in the Dec. 10 referendum in North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia, Georgia, Alabama and Florida is viewed by agricultural leaders as implying not only disapproval of crop-control principles but more particularly dissatisfaction with the administration of the law.

Eight homes have been completed in the Park Acres home community near Westfield, N. J., reports Herbert B. Smith Co., agents for the property. The tract of fifty-two acres was for many years the Fairacres race track and is now being developed with medium priced homes by the Fidelity Construction Company.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Review said today: "The newspaper is the most effective and favorite advertising medium of progressive savings and loan associations throughout the country."
The American Radiator Company has prepared a portfolio of heating and air conditioning systems with complete specifications for eight different types of homes.
Colonel Louis R. Burgess, U.S.A. (retired), a veteran of the Philippine insurrection, the China relief expedition and the World War, died in Walter Reed General Hospital today at the age of 67.

Douglas Fairbanks Jr., arrived here today to spend the week-end as the guest of his friend, Lord Tweedsmuir, at Government House. Mr. Fairbanks explained he met the Governor General several years ago in Scotland when he was making a picture there,

A SHOW of paintings by four artists is current at the Frans Buffa Gallery. Rich-toned landscapes by the late Walter Griffin present an effective contrast to the picturesque Norwegian Winter scenes by William H. Singer.

PRE-CHRISTMAS programs by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will include such features as Josef Hofmann, who will appear as soloist tomorrow in the annual Pension Fund concert of the orchestra; Hortense Month, who will be heard today; the first performance of Haubiel's Passacaglia in A minor, and a special program of Yuletide music with chorus and soloists, to be given Thursday, Friday and next Sunday.

A NEW and complete edition of the works of John Keats is announced by Charles Scribner'sSons. It is called the Hampstead Edition in recognition of the section of London where Keats lived and where during the last half century most of the significant biographical and critical work on the poet was done in the house of Henry Buxton Forman and his son, Maurice Buxton Forman, the editors of this edition.

After weeks of preparation to guard against the contingency of some important news "break," the general offices of The Associated Press, with its 285,000-mile network of leased news wires, was moved last night from 383 Madison Avenue to the new fifteen-story Associted Press Building in Rockefeller Center.

NADIA BOULANGER, eminent French musician and Dedagogue, has been engaged for a series of lectures to be given Thursday afternoons during February and March in the Recital Hall of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music.

Examinations for licenses as teacher of speech improvement in elementary and junior high schools, and for licenses as teacher-in-training in high school shop subjects were announced by the Board of Examiners.

In an informal practice match Princeton University defeated the Army sextet today, 2 to 0. Making their first appearance on the Army rink, the Tigers showed a strong array which the Cadets were unable to score against, their lack of practice being evident.

Reports that manufacturers in some lines operating under fair trade laws were desirous of being relieved of the policing of enforcement of price-maintenance contracts, and that a move for mandatory fair trade legislation would be made, were dismissed in wellinformed quarters yesterday.

Ernie Lombardi, ponderous catcher of the Reds, won the 1938 batting championship of the National League with a mark of .342, according to the official figures released for publication today, and thus became the second backstop to top the senior loop since 1900.
The Williams College Chest Fund drive this week closed with more than $5,200 in contributions to go over the top by $400.
Thomas G. Grace, New York State FHA director, reported yesterday that construction work on the second large unit of Fort Hill Village, Greenburgh, Westchester County, is now under way.

Never headed after the first two minutes of play, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's basketball squad tonight downed Brooklyn Poly, 45 to 31. Rensselaer was paced by Merritt Preston, who accounted for eight field goals.

Mrs. Jack Hollander of New York City has purchased the Anton Tauber farm of fifty acres with a twelve-room house in Colts Neck, near Freehold, Monmouth County, N. J., for occupancy as her home after making alterations to the residence.
The arrest of an unstated number of Baptist clergymen and the closing of some Baptist churches was disclosed today by the Rumanian Ministry of Popular Culture.

A broad program of participation in community life has been developed more than ever this year at Pembroke College, and students have originated several media through which they can render practical service to the community and- to the world in general.

To "make the campus a fortress of democracy" is the purpose of the annual convention of the American Student Union, which will draw 1,000 delegates representing 20,000 members in high schools and colleges all over the country to the Twenty-third Street building of City College from Dec. 26 to 30.

OUTWARD BOUND-Thursday evening at the Playhouse. A revival of Sutton Vane's 14-yearold play with what could be called an all-star cast. The roster includes Laurette Taylor, Florence Reed, Helen Chandler, Alexander Kirkland, Vincent Price, Bramwell Fletcher; Thomas Chalmers, Morgan Farley and Louis Hector.

PANAMA'S series of five postage and five air-mail stamps issued to pay, as an inscription indicates, "Homenaje a la Constitucion de los Estados Unidos de America" (Homage to the Constitution of the United States of America), reached New York last week.
Miss Ann Joan Fennessey of Flushing, L. I., was the bright star among the junior riders competing in the Brooklyn Winter Horse Show held yesterday in the Teevan Riding Academy.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity improved on its gain for the week ended Dec. 10, moving to 94.3, which compared with 93.1 (revised) for the preceding week and 85.0 for the week ended Dec. 11, 1937.

A broker who signs a written brokerage agreement consenting to withhold his commission fees until title has passed on the property for which he has found a willing buyer and seller can no longer claim his commission on the grounds that the agreement is not binding on him because he had earned the commission before he signed the agreement, declares Edward Ross Aranow, attorney for the Walter McMeekan Management Corporation.

All the adventure, mystery and romance of the sea have been brought into the classroom as boys at the Board of Education's Metropolitan Vocational High School learn to become sailors and maritime workers.

ONCE more the problem of the division of the earth's surface and supplies has been raised acutely by Italy's unofficial demand for Tunisia and by Germany's tacit understanding with France and Great Britain that she will not press the colonial issue if she is allowed to assure herself of food supplies by the reorganization of Eastern Europe.
The annual Christmas party of the Junior Dance Club and the Junior Assembly was held here this evening under the direction of Mrs. Clara I. Austin in the Woman's Club.

Robert Moses, chairman of the State Council of Parks and president of the Long Island State Park Commission, will be 50 years old tomorrow and will observe the day with Mrs. Moses and their two daughters, Barbara and Jane Moses. Congratulatory messages are already arriving.

With the finishing touches being placed on its development in Harlem, a syndicate of builders headed by D. Napoli yesterday extended its operations to the Yorkville area. Under the name of the Alna Realty Corporation the group signed contracts to buy 342 to 352 East Seventy-seventh Street.
Adoption of a student guidance program on a permanent basis at the University of Rochester is announced by Dr. Alan Valentine, president.

Philadelphia, the defending team, and New York were eliminated from the annual intercity court tennis doubles tournament for the Payne Whitney Memorial Cup today in the Greentree court of John Hay Whitney.

Henry Albert von Dohln, credit manager of the silk manufacturing firm of Hess, Goldsmith Co., Inc., 1,400 Broadway, New York, died in his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 60 years old.
All favorites came through unscathed as the annual two-day invitation mixed doubles squash racquets tournament moved along to the semi-final round at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

STRANGE as it may seem, there was activity at the Guild Theatre. Actors (among them Jane Cowl) were upon the stage. An author (Thornton Wilder) dashed hither and thither with deletions and additions for the script ("The Merchant of Yonkers").

THAT master of public relations, "Wrong Way" Corrigan, here offers the story of his life, a home-made autobiography that is no more sleek, no more professional, than the crate he flew to Ireland, but that performs its purpose quite as effectively, and, like that flight, provides an emotional jolt.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 15: CAPTAIN Norris, A., Washington, D. C., about March 1, to home, relieved all active duty. COMMANDERS

Lehigh University's quintet won its third straigth game tonight, defeating Wittenberg, 50-40. Led by Al Cox, junior forward, with sixteen points, the Engineers rallied in the last few minutes to gain the honors.

Seymour Weiss, president of the New Orleans Baseball Club of the Southern Association, announced today the signing of Roger Peckinpaugh, former Cleveland skipper, as manager. Weiss did not disclose the terms of the contract, but said Peckinpaugh would act also as vice president and general manager.
Mayor La Guardia will reopen the completely reconstructed upper roadway of the Queensboro Bridge to pleasure cars tomorrow morning. The work began on Oct. 3 with WPA cooperation.
TWO safety mechanisms in particular among many such features on the new Hudsons have brought forth praise from persons driving the cars in demonstrations, it was reported last week by F. D.

John Watson Cochran, for more than half a century a representative and manager of musical artists, died at his home here last night at the age of 79. Until a few months ago he had an office in the Steinway Building, New York, and was engaged in arranging bookings for the Pacific Coast.

LONDON. TO Englishmen who have been there recently the United States is remarkable as a country which has no A. R. P. Here in Britain those tell- tale initials occur in newspapers and on billboards all over the country.
LONDON.--The war settlement commemorated by the names of Versailles, St. Germain, Neuilly, Trianon, Sevres, is rapidly disappearing.
LAKELAND, Fla.-Although the State of Florida has failed to release $78,000 reserved for development of the Everglades National Park, several agencies in the State are working to advance the project.

Perhaps the most striking aspect of Secretary Morgenthau's statement regarding the sale of Government "baby bonds" was the number of subscribers. Since the sale of these small-denomination bonds commenced in March, 1935, some 1,400,000 men and women have invested in them.

Santa Anita Park went ahead today with plans for the opening of its fifth meeting on Dec. 31, when the $10,000 added California Breeders Stakes will be run. The $10,000 added New Year's Handicap is listed Jan. 2.

The St. Nicholas of Tolentine High School basketball team of New York defeated the Concordia Collegiate Institute quintet, 19 to 17, on the loser's court today. The visitors built up a 10-8 advantage in the first half and held this slim margin until the end.

Fall, 1939, prices on men's robes, scheduled to be named late next month or early in February, will probably be unchanged from the levels to which they were recently advanced, according to manufacturers yesterday.

Merger of five North Jersey traction companies with the Consolidated Traction Company of Newark was approved today by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners. Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Corporation, is president and a director of Consolidated Traction.

LAST week two Americans who should know whereof they speak when the conversation deals with things aeronautical returned to the United States after visiting several European countries and viewing the progress of aviation there.

Girls like to see real life in the movies; boys like adventure best. Film versions of classics spur rather than destroy interest in reading for young folks. Love scenes bore the very young. These are some of the conclusions drawn from country-wide reports of the 4-Star Clubs, comprising the Young Reviewers of the National Board of Review of motion pictures. The members,
The Department of Journalism at Temple University has installed a typographical laboratory in a room adjoining that in. which practice copy and headlines are written.
British women civil servants want a share in the higher posts in the three defense departments. At present they are excluded from the administrative and executive classes.
All the major officers of the Bronx Board of Trade were reelected last week at the board's forty-fourth annual meeting.
Dwight H. Green, the Federal prosecutor who put "Al" Capone behind the bars, said today he would seek the office of Mayor of Chicago on the Republican ticket.

William F. Wallace of New York City has been named editor-in-chief of The Quadrangle, student weekly newspaper of Manhattan College, it was announced by Brother Paul Edward, F. S. C., director of publications.

HOLLYWOOD. NEVER has it been recorded that Hollywood suffered in pocket-or very deeply, at least-for making a revue. The formula varies not at all, except in the degree of lunacy. But a revue isn't easy to make.
John C. L. and M. Elizabeth Marshall have purchased a six-room colonial-type residence in the Nordholm and Updike development in the Hendrie Avenue section of Riverside.

A benefit recital by Mme. Kirsten Flagstad, sponsored by the New York Kindergarten Association, will be held the night of Jan. 2 at Carnegie Hall. The event had originally been scheduled for Nov. 15, but had been postponed due to the illness of Mme. Flagstad. Tickets for the earlier date will be accepted on Jan. 2.

The Knickerbocker Greys, junior cadet corps, will hold their annual Christmas drill Tuesday at 4 P. M. at the 107th Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue, according to an announcement yesterday.

Beginning Dec. 26, the Children's Opera Company production of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" will be given nine performances at the Lyceum-Theatre. On Monday, Wednesday and Saturday, performances will begin at 11 A. M. and on other days at 2 P. M.

ISCUSSING the present status of the General Electric Company in television development, W. R. G. Baker, chairman of the radio and television division, reports that bringing telecasts to the public introduces new program and economic problems, the magnitude of which "we do not yet fully grasp and the solution of which is not evident today.

Renewed efforts on behalf of the chronically ill in New Jersey will be made by the Organized Women Legislators of the State, it was announced yesterday with the appointment of Miss May Carty of Jersey City to direct activities of the group in urging allocation of funds for a new State hospital.

Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester, Mass., clung to his dwindling lead in the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament as he rallied after a poor start to score a one-over-par 71 for a fifty-four-hole total of 206.

TWO years ago at the exhibition of "Modern Painters and Sculptors as Illustrators," staged by the Museum of Modern Art, some small colored lithographs, done by Jean Hugo, Victor Hugo's nephew, to illustrate the Princess Bibesco's "Perroguet Vert" (Editions Jeanne Walter, Paris, 1929) were shown.
Mr. and Mrs. Jesse V. Honeycutt of this city gave a tea dance here today at the Saucon Valley Country Club, at which they presented to society their daughter, Miss Josephine Anne Honeycutt.
WASHINGTON. FRIDAY Dec. 23, represents some thing in the nation's capital than the last, but one, shopping day before Christmas.

Surrogate James A. Foley granted yesterday the applications of Donald Bloomingdale and his mother, Mrs. Rosalie Banner Bloomingdale, former wife of the late Irving I. Bloomingdale, New York merchant, for the payment of their legacies for the current year.

Noting the fact that the new building code and the new city charter are about to celebrate their first birthday, H. I. Fellman, New York architect, said yesterday that the experiences of the past year under their operation have been disappointing in many respects to both realty interests and the building industry.

Choate tonight defeated Taft, 3-0, in a rough hockey battle at the Imperial Theatre. The opening period was scoreless as both defenses worked smoothly. Hugh Joyce, hard-playing center, set the style for the first score shortly after the start of the second session. Bill Partridge took the disk from scrimmage and drove to Bob Comfort, who slammed it home at 0:22.
Give the Chicago Cubs a little more time-they may yet get the pitching and hitting strength they've been after since the big league trading season opened.

THERE are signs of a growing uneasiness lest there should spread to this country from the Continent the infection of a censorship which would rob British writers of their inherited freedom in the expression of opinion.

Bonds, except United States Government obligations, eased moderately in fairly active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The two-hour turnover Was $4,655,850, compared with $4,435,000 on the preceding Saturday.

The annual Christmas dinner and carol night processional of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel will end an all-day Christmas celebration at the college on Wednesday, marking the final day of school before the holidays.
American Rhodes scholars for 1939 were elected today by district committees interviewing nominees in eight cities. The Thirty-two scolarselect, with grants valued at about $2,000 a year,
British Celanese, Ltd., and Courtaulds, Ltd., are reported to be discussing a price-maintenance agreement for regulating the price of acetate rayon yarn. Should agreement be reached,

ONE of the most interesting of the numerous recent exhibitions of work by French artists of the last century opened last week, to be current through the holidays. This is a group show at the French Art Galleries, in which are brought together characteristic paintings by Manet, Monet, Pissarro, Renoir, Sisley and Guillaumin, and pastels by Degas.

SECOND MILITARY AREA Each of the following reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 77th Division-2d Lt. Culbreth N. Rice, Inf.-Res., 21-25 78th St., Jackson Heights, N. Y., 2d Lt. Edward J. Rieger, Inf.Res., Lakeview Road, Millwood. N. Y.

FOFTY-SIX new 300-mile-an-hour pursuit planes have been grounded temporarily by the Twentieth Pursuit Group of the Third Wing of the G.H.Q, Air Force at Barksdale Field here pending correction of a fault in their retraotable landing gear which recently caused a pilot to make a "belly" landing.
Ed McCuan's shifty gelding Lostagal showed his heels to eight others in the Pass Christian Handicap at the Fair Grounds today, scoring by a length and a half over Patrol Scout, with Jubilee C. third.

BOSTON. BOSTON was not to be caught napping a second time on Thornton Wilder-even in the fortnight before Christmas. When his new farce, "The Merchant of Yonkers," opened here Monday night, the Colonial was filled and standees were waiting for a glimpse of his latest work.

The Fordham University fencing team scored its first victory of the season yesterday when it turned back the Loyola of Baltimore swordsmen in the Ram's gymnasium, 15 to 12. The winners scored in foils, 6 to 3, and in epee, 5 to 4. In saber the Loyola combination triumphed, 5 to 4.

RADIO ALGER," chief short wave link between France and her North African colonies, has, since the current disturbances along the Tunisian border, flashed frequent news bulletins from the unsettled African area.

AFTER thirty years of teaching and investigation in various departments of medieval history, Dr. Coulton has turned back to produce such a general study as "he would have been glad to find before him" at the outset of his career.

THE remarkable thing about the publishing of the major writings of Thomas Mann is that they underwent virtually no revision. There is no set rule for the evolution of a book but the usual procedure nowadays is for the author to have a typescript made from his original manuscript,

The Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., reported yesterday in a preliminary statement for the year ended on Sept. 30, a net loss of $1,276,990 after depreciation, taxes and other charges. The company ended the preceding fiscal year with a net profit of $473,029, which was equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to 14 cents each on 2,046,229 shares of common stock.
The fact that Poland is about to conclude important trade agreements with two neighbors-Russia and Lithuania-gives a clear indication of the trend of her present foreign policy.
Less than five hours after sentence had passed on him for attempted highway robbery Willi Heller, 24, was executed here at midnight.

Dr. and Mrs. Michael Thomas Reynolds of 191 Arlington Avenue, Brooklyn, gave a dinner at their home last evening at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Alice Reynolds, to Lieutenant Edward S. Miller. U. S. N.

The Rev. Charles Ensor Walters, a Methodist leader and one of the ablest platform speakers in Great Britain, died today at the age of 65. He had visited the United States and Canada as a representative of British Methodists and raised [pound]1,600,000 for building Methodist churches in London.
Produce merchants are complaining that the city's interdiction against street peddlers is ruining the annual Christmas tree business this year. According to L. Larry

Political speculation was keen six years ago as President-elect Roosevelt pondered the make-up of his New Deal Cabinet. Many experts scoffed when the name of Daniel C. Roper of South Carolina was mentioned.

A voluntary change by industry in the disposition of loyalties obtained from patent or licensing arrangements, rather than in the current methods of granting and controlling patents, was considered last week as one of the most likely outcomes of the monopoly investigation by business executives and patent authorities.

Appointment of State Senator C. Tracey Stagg as chairman of the Republican Senate Committee on Legislation, which will meet soon with a similar Assembly committee and representatives of the Republican State Executive Committee to draft the party's legislative program, was announced yesterday by State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Westchester,

LONDON. THE attempt to create in London a company with a continuous policy based upon the work of a group of established actors, which was begun with a production of "The White Guard," has been continued in a performance of "Twelfth Night" under the direction of Michel St. Denis.

Last Monday's Supreme Court ruling upholding a Missouri Negro's right of admission to the State University's Law School reopens the question of the educational system of the South. Possible effects of the decision are discussed in the following dispatches from Richmond and St. Louis.

Ely Jacques Kahn, chairman of the Committee on Allied Arts of the American Institute of Architects, has submitted a report to the institute in which he recommends organization of artists in the manner of the Renaissance guilds.

The Art Workshop of the Rivinton Neighborhood Association, a creative center for leisure time, will be the beneficiary of a preview of "King Henry IV," with Maurie Evans, to be held the evening Jan. 27 at the St. James Theatre The play opens on Jan. 30.

The illfated "purge," through which the administration sought to 'discipline anti-New Deal Democratic members of Congress, was the leading -feature of the Winter dinner of the Gridiron Club before an audience of more than 500 persons including President Roosevelt.

The first husband of Mrs. F. Donald Coster, Edward W. Hubbard, nephew of Elbert Hubbard, the writer, said he first knew Coster by his real name, Philip Musica, in 1915, but did not know of his past and never had any suspicion of him.

Carl B. Zilenziger, former City Architect of Philadelphia, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 73. Mr. Zilenziger, who was born and educated in this city, was an architect in the Department of City Transit for twenty-five years.

Delegatas of the People's Mandate Committee, headed by Miss Mabel Vernon, today informed Foreign Minister Carlos Concha of Peru, as presiding officer of the Pan-American Conference, that they had brought to Lima "an evidence of public opinion against war which is constantly increasing in power and insistence."

The picture of the American republics as a tranquil oasis in a troubled world which the eighth Pan-American Conference hoped to create will be painted in paler colors than Secretary of State Cordell Hull and his colleagues want, but stronger than the Argentinians, Chileans, Brazilians, Uruguayans, Paraguayans and Bolivians originally desired, according to present prospects.

To the Art Editor: IN your review of the Bauhaus exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, you quote the museum's director, Mr. Barr, as saying that "the Bauhaus is not dead: it lives and grows through the men who made it"-and your conclusion is that Mr. Barr is right, that the Bauhaus "has a message for America and for the future."

Kavy Kavovitt, Brooklyn architects, announce that they are preparing plans for multiple-family dwellings to be erected in 1939 in the Kings Highway, Ocean Avenue and Borough Park sections of Brooklyn.

An art laboratory, whose primary objective is to give an opportunity to students to use their leisure time for creative expression and to acquire a better appreciation of the fine arts has become an integral part of the Department of Art of Queens College.
The Williams College swimming team submerged Columbia, making its first start, 47-28, in the Columbia pool yesterday to climax a twoday invasion of this city. Fordham succumbed to Williams on Friday.

A dark period in the life of Ulysses S. Grant, a decade before he rode to the Presidency of the United States on the crest of his post-Civil War popularity, was disclosed for the first time today with the making public of two letters written by General Grant, which have come into the possession of Rutgers University.
NEW passenger car sales during November reached a new high for the twelve months' period with the total estimated between 230,000 and 240,000 units.

The current plans of the Baltfmore Ohia Railroad and the Lehigh Valley Railroad for reductions in their burden of payments of interest on their debts without recourse to bankruptcy reflect not so much conditions peculiar to these two companies as the general situation of the entire railroad system.

To the Music Editor: Would it be permitted to one educated in science and not in music, nor particularly in any of the humanities, to add to the long discussion of the piece by Samuel Barber, without touching upon his duties, musical prospects or future activities? Just to offer the opinion that the piece, as performed by Toscanini and his orchestra, sounded well.

Miss Harriet Wood Colby, daughter of Mrs. Frank Moore Colby of 680 Madison Avenue and the late Mr. Colby, editor and essayist, was married here yesterday afternoon in the chantry of Grace Church to Walter William Beachboard, son of Mrs. Walter William Beachboard of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Beachboard.

With few exceptions, business and financial leaders continue unusually reticent about forecasting business conditions for the early months of the new year. The stock market last week endeavored to do a little forecasting of its own, but did not quite succeed.

THE natural grace of this writer's style grows technically more varied and expert as his substance gets more to the point and becomes more expressible. It is a poetry of individual and romantic beauty threatened by a total, or totalitarian, eclipse. Those who wish to put it on political grounds may do so. It may serve as a text, but that is probably the best way to misunderstand it.

Tax Collector Raymond C. Tower of Livingston died here today in St. Mary's Hospital. He was 38 years old.

The cost of living of wage earners in the United States declined 0.2 per cent from October to November, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday in its regular monthly survey.

For the first time in more than the 150 years of its existence the Phi Beta Kappa honorary scholastic society has voted to investigate the educational status of two of its chapters, Dr. William Allison Shimer, executive secretary, announced.

Scholarship alone is not enough to make a good teacher, Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, declared yesterday in an address before the New York College Teachers Union annual educational forum, at New York University.
The Charles F. Noyes Company has just been appointed managing agent of the New Amsterdam Casualty Company's properties on John and William Streets and Maiden Lane.

The Daniels Homes syndicate, which is developing the Westchester Hills community on Central Park Avenue, near Bronxville, Westchester County, announces the purchase of a large tract in Astoria, Queens, for improvement early in the new year with medium-priced homes.

M., West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120-38 West 76th St., Manhattan.

The foreclosure auction sale of the former residence of Richard Whitney at 115 East Seventy-third Street will be held on Tuesday in the Vesey Street salesrooms by Edwin J. McDonald, in pursuance of an action brought by the United States Trust Company on a mortgage claim of about $116,973.
Federal agents and court officials struck sharply yesterday at rumormongers who have been circulating reports that holders of McKesson Robbins junior securities may be wiped out.

Mrs. Phebe Clark celebrated her 102d birthday here today with a quiet informal party at the home of her daughter, Mrs. W. F. B. Leavitt, with whom she has made her home since her husband, the Rev. A. L. Clark, died twenty-six years ago.

Sale of so-called "double-header" drinks of whisky will be stopped in local bars and grills by Jan. 7 as a result of a cooperative move by distillers and organized tavern owners, John J. Daly, president of the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers of New York State, and of its local affiliate. predicted yesterday.

Miss Dorothy M. McGee heads a junior committee whose members are aiding with plans for a dinner dance to be held on Jan. 6 on the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria. The event, known as a "Red, White and Blue" dinner dance, will benefit the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.
As the time draws near when the Administration must again ask Congress for relief funds it becomes evident that Harry L. Hopkins's WPA is approaching a crossroads in its three years' existence.

Armed with a goodly supply of sleek-looking 15 1/2-ounce racquets bearing his name, a fiery-haired, blue-eyed young man stepped jauntily off the Commodore Vanderbilt as it slid to a stop in the Grand Central Station yesterday morning.
WHILE the rest of the world is happily looking ahead to Christmas (and some what less happily to Christmas bills) the Stadium Concerts Committee is already plotting its Summer activities.

With William Fechter and Robert Mortimer scoring 10 points apiece, the St. Paul's School basketball team turned back the Adelphi Academy quintet, 42 to 32, today on the winners' court. St. Paul's led at the half, 25 to 12. Harold Shoemacher of Adelphi was the game's high scorer with 12 points.

One of the chief philanthropic enterprises of the Vassar Club of New York for seventeen years has been the selection of a special opera matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House for the purpose of augmenting the scholarship fund of the organization.

The Commodity Credit Corporation announced today that Dec. 31 would be the deadline for the granting of government loans to farmers desiring to withhold surplus wheat from market for possible higher prices in the future.

THIS little book is Rudyard Kipling's last piece of prose writing, and it is a story about a dog. It is certain, thus, to have a wide reading. And the first assurance which must come from the reviewer is that it is certain also to be widely enjoyed, and would be if its author's name were quite unknown.

The Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue, will hold its monthly meeting on Wednesday at 2:30 P. M. The lecture by J. J. Levison on "Important Factors in the Planting and Care of Trees" and flower exhibits will be open to the public.
Augustine J. Daly, former Mayor of Cambridge, died today at his home in Cambridge at the age of 77. He served two terms as Mayor in 1902 and 1904.

The successful operation of a definite course in leadership was described last week at the semiannual meeting of the board of directors of The Culver Educational Foundation, by Brig. Gen. L. R. Gignilliat, Superintendent of the Culver Military Academy.

The Elks National Foundation, a philanthropic subsidiary of the Elks, will award $1,500 in prizes to the nation's four "most valuable students," it was announced yesterday by John F. Malley, chairman of the foundation's board of trustees.

Organization of a voluntary committee of business and professional women to cooperate with the National Council of Jewish Women in its drive for an expanded membership was accomplished last week at the home of Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, 1,109 Fifth Avenue.

Plans for a survey of professional nurses' registries in the State, with the object of widening their usefulness in the community and of improving the standards guiding their operation, were adopted last week by the New York State Nurses Association.

Theodore F. Stevens, assistant superintendent of agencies of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, died Friday evening in the New York Hospital, after a brief illness. His home was at 98 Riverside Drive. He was 65 years old.

FAR from advocating equality of the sexes in bridge tournament play, women who hold official positions in the American Contract Bridge League are now agitating for some differential to give women players an opportunity equal to that of the men.

Plans for further replacing cotton, wool and silk textiles by rayon were discussed by Dr. Henry Dreyfus, chairman and joint managing director of British Celanese, Ltd., at the nineteenth annual general meeting of the company here this week.

ONCE again the Christmas season is at hand, and once more this corner jots down the list Lof current shows and a little something about each one of them. It has been easier work this year, for only eighteen items are represented-and those exclusive of Federal Theatre Project works-in comparison with last year when there were twenty-four.
Paced by Danny Smick and Jimmy Rae, the undefeated University of Michigan basketball team gained a last-minute 47-45 victory over a surprisingly strong University of Rochester quintet tonight.

The swimmers of Metropolitan Vocational High School, ManhattanBronx champions of the Public School Athletic League, won the interborough vocational and continuation school league title yesterday by defeating Jamaica Vocational, victor in the Brooklyn-Queens dualmeet pennant series, in the 25-yard De Witt Clinton pool. The score was 30 to 23.

As a small reception given at their home here this afternoon, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sartwell Beardsley announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yvette Beardsley, to William Vernon Platt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Livingston Platt of Ryu N. Y.

Trinity College's favored basketball team had to go into a five-minute overtime period tonight at Billard Hall to defeat the Coast Guard Academy. 39-37.
James S. Watts of East Orange, whose inventions in waterworks equipment are in wide use in the United States and Canada, died in Orange Memorial Hospital here late yesterday. He was 57 years old.

The 113th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York will take place on Jan. 27 in the grand ballroom of the Commodore Colonel Edward Havemeyer Snydes. is commander of the Old Guard the oldest veterans' organization in the country.

Residents of Westchester County have been invited to attend a program of Christmas carols tomorrow afternoon at the County Center here. Edgar. B. Fowiston will lead the assemblage in the singing of the carols.
President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner conferred today for three and a half hours on subjects that neither would divulge publicly.
Dr. M. C. Householder, one of the bestknown surgeons in Eastern Pennsylvania, died of a heart attack today in his home here. He was 74 years old .

Mrs. Dorothy Rosenman, chairman of the housing committee of the United Neighborhood Houses and vice chairman of the committee on old housing of the Citizens Housing Council, will speak on tenement problems tomorrow evening in the weekly forum conducted by the council in cooperation with New York University at 20 Washington Square North.
The United Textile Workers said today that F. J. Gorman had sent registered letters to four international vice presidents of the organization, telling them that their offices were "vacated."

The army's new semi-automatic rifle, the Garand, which shoots eight rounds to a clip and is faster than the Springfield, which it will replace as the common arm of the infantry, will be demonstrated tomorrow night at 7:30 P. M. for the officers of the 165th Infantry, New York National Guard (the old Sixty-ninth).
Activities of the World's Fair centered yesterday on three South American countries-Peru, Chile and Argentina-which will be represented in the exposition.

To augment a scholarship fund, which enables young people to become residents of the George Junior Republic, a theatre benefit will be given the night of Jan. 4. The play chosen is "Everywhere I Roam," the new Mare Connolly and Bela Blau production which opens on Dec. 26 at the National Theatre.
George M. Trautman, president of the American Association, handed unconditional releases today to three members of his umpiring staff and signed another for the 1939 campaign.

Another epic of Arctic exploration is being written day by day as the Soviet icebreaker Syedoff zigzags along the eighty-fifth parallel, moving northward for a time and then slipping southward on an adventure begun by accident, but which may carry it over the Pole itself.

The Junior Guild of New York, members of which are students at the Chapin and Brearley Schools, will give a Christmas tea dance on Dec. 26 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the Speedwell Society.

The Nathan Hale apartment building at 454 Fort Washington Avenue, southeast corner of 181st Street, will be altered under the direction of Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, architects, it was announced yesterday.
Rider College's basketball five returned to the victory column tonight by subduing the Cooper Union quintet, 46-31, at Moose Hall.

WHEN Carl Akeley asked William R. Leigh to go with him to Africa to make studies for the backgrounds of his habitat groups it was understood that the artist's part would be "to paint with perfect fidelity to nature."
