The New Jersey deer hunters turned out in force today for the opening of their five-day season, but from the reported kills in several areas reported to be "excellent" deer country, the great majority of the hunters were disappointed.

The fourth annual Bicycle Breakfast will be held today at La Salle du Bois, 36 East Sixtieth Street, as a benefit for the Children's Welfare Federation, which for twenty-five years has maintained temporary shelters and Summer camps for children and otherwise assisted in their health and vocational training.

Dr. and Mrs. Raphael David Gilady of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Ruth Gilady, to Edward Jackson Brundage Jr., son of Mrs. Brundage of Falls Church, Va., and the late Mr. Brundage.

NO major industry in the United States has plumped more suddenly and completely for the objectives of the Good Neighbor Policy, designed to expand and consolidate our economic, political and cultural ties with the twenty Latin-American republics, than has Hollywood. Elimination of foreign markets for the industry's product, especially in Europe, has been bewilderingly rapid.

The New York Rangers forged into second place alone in the National Hockey League standing tonight when they downed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 2, before a crowd of 11,525 fans. Previous to the game the Rangers were tied with their intracity rivals, the Americans.

Robert M. Hutchins, one of the first three "public representatives" placed on the board of the New York Stock Exchange, resigned yesterday because his colleagues wished to consider the case of Richard Whitney a closed book.

Rallying in the second half, the Hudson College basketball team defeated Manhattan College of Staten Island tonight, 36 to 30, on the winners' floor. The invaders led at the half, 19 to 10. Hudson went ahead early in the final session and held its advantage.

PASADENA, Calif. - What promises to be California's finest tourist season will be ushered in by the fiftieth annual Tournament of Roses at Pasadena on Jan. 2, to be followed by the opening of the Golden Gate International Exposition at San Francisco in February.

Miss Mimi Francis, who has made her debut in St. Louis, was introduced to society here yesterday at a tea dance at the Sherry-Netherland. The party was given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney R. Francis of New York, who formerly resided in St. Louis.
HOLIDAY sales this year will be slightly below the volume of last year, reports seemed to indicate last week, although the physical quantity of merchandise moved will run some 4 per cent larger.

Fatal highway accidents in the city during November showed a decrease of more than 40 per cent as compared with the record for November, 1937, Mayor La Guardia reported yesterday. Fifty-nine persons were killed in highway accidents last month, compared with 101 in the same month in 1937, according to police statistics.

BARNETT-GOLDSTEIN-Mr. and Mrs. I. Goldstein announce the engagement of their daughter, Rose, to Joseph, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Barnett.

Al Davis, Brownsville lightweight, won from Jimmy Lancaster of Wilmington, Del., in the feature bout scheduled for eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove last night before a capacity crowd. Lancaster failed to come out for the sixth. Davis weighed 138 1/2. Lancaster 132.

Mrs. Emma Pomlitz Stillman, widow of Thomas Bliss Stillman, former Professor of Industrial Chemistry at Stevens Institute in Hoboken, died of a cerebral hemorrhage last night at her home here. She was born in Baltimore eighty years ago.

Elmer F. Andrews, administrator of the Wages and Hours Division, announced today that the Cotton-Textile Institute, the National Rayon Weaver's Association and the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., had withdrawn their application for a learner's exemption under the Wages and Hours Law.

Production at Pamour Porcupine Mines in November is estimated at $275,000, virtually the same as in October. Production for the first eleven months of this year is put at $3,077,000 and gross production from the start of milling is around $5,929,818.

The University of Maine, in cooperation with the three largest hospitals in the State, has started a five-year combined course in liberal arts and nursing which leads to a bachelor of arts degree and a hospital diploma.

The appointment of F. Donald Coster as president of McKesson Robbins was dictated by financial interests, J. Mahlon Buck, president of the Smith, Kline French Company, wholesale drug house, said today.
A report recently published abroad that Brazil was negotiating a new barter agreement with Germany was emphatically denied today by Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha.

A double setback was inflicted on Derby County and Everton today in their furious drive for the English Football League championship. Unbeaten home records went by the board when Derby, the pacemaker, lost a 4-1 decision to Middlesbrough and the Lancashire squad bowed to Charlton Athletic, also by 4-1.

ASH-FREUND-Mr. and Mrs. J. D. Freund of New York City announce the marriage of their daughter, Helen Roslyn, to Mr. Arthur L. Ash, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. B. Ash of Brooklyn, this afternoon, at the Essex House.

The army air corps is developing a revolutionary new type of war plane in its race to keep ahead of other countries in aviation. The new plane was described in authoritative sources today as an attack bomber, combining features of existing attack and bombing planes.

But like all seagoing men who come ashore, Mr. S. has tried to surround himself with things nautical and in his new Hollywood he has done everything except to install a pair of Diesel engines below deck.
Dr. and Mrs. Jacob S. Fisher of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Marion Fisher, to David Simeon Edelstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edelstein of this city.

Fred C. Moffatt, president of the New York Curb Exchange, is not a candidate to succeed himself. He has notified the nominating committee that he does not wish his name presented to the membership at the elections in February for a post on the board of governors.
Luang Bipul Songgram, new Nationalist Premier-designate of Siam, sought a Cabinet today to carry out his dream of making the nation into a first-class Southeastern Asiatic power.

Clavel Badcock, young international cricketer, hit 271 runs, not out, out of a total of 600 for eight wickets, declared, made by South Australia against New South Wales in a Sheffield Shield match today.

Elections for the Slovak Diet will be held tomorrow. All citizens over 21 years of age are entitled to vote, but only one list is allowedthat of the government.
Presentation of a sixteenth Miracle Play from the Chester Cycle and the singing of a group of eight carols composed a program of Christmas observance at Hamilton College Thursday evening.

IF the American dance should choose to observe the timehonored custom of taking stock of itself as the old year draws to a close, there is no doubt that it would discover, besides the many items for which it should commend itself heartily, at least one which should cause it a misgiving or two.
MIAMI, Fla.-Miami's season of horse racing, which opens tomorrow at Tropical Park, is declared to differ from those of previous years in point of increased entries and prestige.

The newest entrant in the Metropolitan Indoor League, the Pegasus Polo Club, sent its line-up into action at the Squadron A ring last night and showed a blinding burst of speed that buried the home team under a 17-to-3 score.

Pan-American unity, talked of, dreamed of, since the days of Simon Bolivar the Liberator, has always been blocked by the rivalries of American republics, and, at least for many years, distrust and dislike of the United States-"El Coloso del Norte."

At Oxford the University Exploration Club reports that in the first ten years of its existence fifteen expeditions have been organized, about 100 men have had experience in northern latitudes and about twenty-five have taken part in tropical expeditions.

OF the several chapters in this book, John Crowe Ransom says that some are "papers" in criticism and the others preparation for criticism. Since, obviously, a work of such divided purposes cannot lead to a homogeneous review, a report must be made on each part separately.

The Louisiana Arkansas and the Louisiana Arkansas Texas Railway Companies charged today that the Interstate Commerce Commission is "without power and jurisdiction" to include provisions for the protection of labor in I. C. C. orders.
Wheat futures on the Board of Trade delined 5/8 cent a bushel at the extreme today on selling induced by what was construed as an extraordinarily bearish Argentine crop estimate.

Relatively steady foreign cotton markets, with another advance in Alexandria, imparted an upward impetus on the Exchange here, with the result that gains of 3 to 5 points were registered at the close yesterday.
The burial of Major Gen. George S. Simonds, United States Army, retired, who died on Nov. 1, in San Francisco, took place here this morning in the post cemetery.

The Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, the Feast of Lights, commemorating the delivery of the Jews by the Maccabees from. Syrian-Greek oppression 2,000 years ago was a theme of sermons by rabbis here yesterday.

Directors of the Texas Pacific Railroad declared yesterday a dividend of 1 per cent on the preferred stock, payable on Dec. 27 to stock of record of Dec. 27. All the stock is owned by the Missouri Pacific.
A definite relationship between good scholarship in college and participation in extra-curricular activities is indicated by a study of Phi Beta Kappa students at Colgate University.
The military authorities at Santiago took precautions today to prevent public disorders upon the arrival of the German training ship Schleswig-Holstein, which is expected at that port Monday.
MONTREAL.-A Winter record activity awaits the skier in the Laurentian Mountains, where some fifty separate ski events are scheduled for the next two months. And apart from competitions,
Into the hospital wards where "aggressive" toys are recommended for psychiatric patients; into the cardiac rooms where stuffed animals, soft and cuddly, afford no undue excitement;

More than any other plant, holly is synonymous with Christmas. The holly most typical of Christmas in this country is the native American one, Ilex opaca, whose red berries and glossy evergreen leaves are recognized even by children who can call no other plant by name.

A model State food, drug and cosmetic bill has been drafted by the Association of Food and Drug Officials of the United States, composed of State officials, and has received favorable comment because of its close adherence to the new Federal act, it was reported here yesterday.
William W. Oliver, who, according to his family, was conductor on the first train out of Weehawken on the West Shore Railroad, died at his home here today at the age of 93.

OVERLOOKING the more scabrous and sinister items involving film people in the week's news, we are happy to lend additional currency to the purely frivolous disclosures that James Roosevelt, the new Goldwyn vice president, flunked a screen test for Paramount in 1932 (a few days after his father was elected President) and that Carl Laemmle Sr.,

Making public 355 additional gifts to the United Hospital Campaign, headed by an anonymous contribution of $10,000, C. M. Chester, chairman of the drive, announced yesterday more than $1,170,000 has been raised to date.

The calling of eight large issues of outstanding public utility bonds was the outstanding announcement last week of bonds to be retired before their maturity dates. Numerous issues of Land Bank bonds also were included in the new list of prepayments. Most of the retirements are to be effective in January, although several small redemptions were posted for payment this month.

ALTHOUGH for some it is the beginning only of the Winter of their discontent, December is the most opulent harbinger of all the months. To the young it brings dancing visions of sugar plums, pawing reindeer hoofs on the housetop, and jolly, red-cheeked St. Nick coming down the chimney. To the persevering devotee of Winter sports it brings the mirage of flakepacked hills waiting to give wings on the frosty air to freshly waxed skiis.

In an exhibition of basketball at its best, St. John's made good its early promise by defeating Northwestern, 49 to 41, before 16,386 wildly excited fans in Madison Square Garden last night as the college court double-headers stepped off to a rousing start with a brilliant and spectacular show.

The first units of the Meadowbrook Village garden apartment project under construction in Plainfield, N. J., will be completed and ready for occupancy early in the Spring, Harry A. Taylor, president of the development syndicate, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON. - The Alley Dwelling Authority, the agency now tackling Washington's slum problem, derives its name from the fact that slums here grew out of the thousands of hastily built houses on alloys to care for laborers and the influx of slaves following their emancipation during the Civil War.
MR. STRODE'S excellent anthology had its origin, he tells us, in a longstanding dissatisfaction with Palgrave's famous "Golden Treasury."

New York ranks first among individual yachting centers and ports in Department of Commerce figures showing the year's growth of numbered motor boats. There has been an increase of 3,353 power craft registered here by the Custom House bureau in the first ten months of 1938.

Solly Krieger, 161 1/2 of Brooklyn, recognized by the National Boxing Association as middleweight champion, scored a technical knockout over Red Farmer, 162, of Honolulu in the eighth round of their scheduled ten-round non-title fight last night.

THE Christmas season stirs memories, of other places as well as of other times. Particularly for the foreign-born does the holiday time bring memories of their native feasts; now, of all times in the year, the markets offer exotic foods in abundance.
LESS than two years after announcement of initial plans the new Northern State-Wan tagh Parkway Extension on Long Island was opened yesterday.

Funeral services were held in the Cathedral of the Incarnation here I this afternoon for Kenneth M. Murchison, architect, who died suddenly Thursday in the subway station of the Grand Central Terminal.

Following is the text of the Declaration of Lima, proposed today by the American delegation: Declaration of the Principles of Solidarity of America. Eighth International Conference of American States.

Scholastic basketball on a wholesale scale made its season's debut at Madison Square Garden yesterday and a crowd of 7,500 persons, which came early and stayed late, witnessed a seemingly endless parade of quintets, with five games featuring the six and a half-hour program.

Curlers from the Country Club of Brookline, Mass., captured one of the keenest matches of the golden jubilee bonspiel that the St. Andrew's Club is staging here, when they eliminated the colorful Caledonian Curling Club of New York in the quarter-finals today.

Suggested establishment of a international research laboratory staffed by noted cereal chemists to seek solution of the recurring problem of wheat surplus will be placed on the agenda of the International Wheat Advisory Committee meeting in London on Jan. 10, a cable to the Northw at Grain Dealers Association said today.

Federal Judge Lederle today named A. J. Brandt of Detroit as trustee for the Reo Motor Car Company of Lansing after the company had filed a petition seeking permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the national Bankruptcy Act.
Many persons from New York, Washington and Maryland attended the Headdress Ball held here tonight in the Bellevue-Stratford ballroom for the benefit of the American Oncologic Hospital.
Lectures in medical jurisprudence, to cover a number of medicolegal considerations, have been added to the fourth-year curriculum of the Louisiana State University School of Medicine, New Orleans.

Contracts will be awarded early next month for construction of the new four-story Tremont Health Center and Bronx Borough Office Building at 1,826-38 Arthur Avenue, between East 175th and 176th Streets, in the Bronx, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday.

Charles J. Kraft, one of the assistant directors of health education in the public schools, received the Aldinger Club award last night "for outstanding achievement and meritorious service in the field of health education in the public schools."

Labor union affilates of the A. F. L. joined with C. I. O. organizations yesterday in pledging the support of their local groups to aid the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in its work of rehabilitating former members of the brigade now returning from Loyalist Spain.

A Warmer World? From Moscow last week came the news that Professor N. N. Zupoff of the Soviet Meteorological Institute of the Northern Sea Administration and Professor L. Berg of the Soviet Academy of Sciences conclude that the Arctic, and probably the world, may be growing warmer.
Florida's ninety-six-day chase for racing gold and glory-intensified this year by the advent of a third track--opens Monday at Tropical take Park..

Members of two parishes will give a dinner Thursday at the Commodore Hotel to celebrate the fiftieth year as a priest of Mgr. John B. Roach. Mgr. Roach is pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Spirit, 1,940 University Avenue the Bronx.

Cornell poloists triumphed over the 112th Field Artillery riders of East Orange, N. J., tonight by 17-12. Captain Art Christian and Dave Pollak put Cornell ahead in the second period and the home team went on to score handily.

A long line of automobiles proceeded this afternoon over the new link between the Northern State Parkway and the Wantagh State Parkway leading to Jones Beach, marking the completion of the existing parkway program for Nassau County.

The Rochester Red Wings of the International League announced the outright sale of Catcher Brusie Ogrodowski and Infielder Frank Morehouse to the Sacramento club, of the Pacific Coast League, today. The consideration was not disclosed.

Miss Anne Whitmarsh, a member of the Junior Assemblies and a provisional member of the Junior League, was the guest of honor at a dinner dance given last night on the St. Regis Roof by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Leggett Whitmarsh.

The opening of the Northern and Wantagh State Parkway Extension in Nassau County, L. I., has resulted in an increased interest in real estate in Westbury and its vicinity, reports Harland W. Meistrell, broker.

SOURCE material has seldom, if ever, been presented in so beguiling a fashion as in this handsome edition of Bartholomew Las Casas's abstract of Columbus's log. This edition, designed primarily for young people, contains the record of the seventy-one days of the world's most famous voyage, supplemented by Columbus's account of the first two days on land.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Isabel Rogers Whitman, daughter of Mrs. Homer Whitman of this city and the late Mr. Whitman, to Frederic Stephenson Haggerson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred H. Haggerson of Plandome, L. I.

Life ended at 107 for Charles Wilmott Eldridge today and bronchial pneumonia-not old age-was blamed for his death. Mr. Eldridge, St. Petersburg's oldest resident and a former commander of the Florida Grand Army of the Republic, was active until a fall last week, which resulted in the complication that caused his death.

A fighting Harvard team delighted its followers at the Arena tonight by upsetting the favored Southern California skaters, 6 to 2, before 2,500 fans in the first intersectional hockey contest between an Eastern and a Far Western college hockey team.

Trouble which had been brewing for nearly two years between Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario and Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec on the one hand and Prime Minister Mackenzie King of Canada on the other reached its head this week and the resulting explosion promises to change the whole face of Canadian politics.

Police officials tightened yesterday their embargo on the movement of food to six men and eight women who have been conducting a sit-in strike in the home relief office at 116 West Seventeenth Street since Monday evening.
A late wave of negative votes cast in today fourteen-State farmer referenda apparently defeated Federal marketing restrictions for burley and dark type tobaccos in 1939.

In one of the largest realty transactions of the year in Brooklyn, the Prudential Insurance Company has sold the Adelphi Hall apartment building at 201 Eastern Parkway, northeast corner of Washington Avenue and running through to Lincoln Place, to the Carlton Management Corporation.

Word has been received here of the marriage yesterday in Tampico, Mexico, of Miss Helen Horton Hudson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elisha Stevens Hudson of Tampico, to Richard Finder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Finder of this city. The wedding took place in the Cathedral Concepcion.

Death yesterday ended fifty years of squalor for Mrs. Letitia V. Graham. Today, Tampa learned she left a $350,000 fortune-its source a mystery and its extent a shock to the few who knew the 93-year-old recluse.
THE Japanese Government has recently put out as war issues two new coins, a large copper one-sen piece and a smaller aluminum-bronze five-sen piece.

Coincident with Postmaster Albert Goldman's reminder to the public that there will be no deliveries of mail on Christmas Day, announcement was made yesterday that there is still time for greetings to reach Central and South American places by air mail before Christmas.

In response to inquiries as to possible changes in the customs treatment of goods from former Czecho-Slovak areas now under Polish and Hungarian occupation, the Bureau of Customs has sent a letter to all collectors with directions to communicate it so far as possible to all interested persons. A new Department of Architectural Sciences has been formed in Harvard College, reorganizing the studies of undergraduates preparing for graduate work in architecture, landscape architecture or regional planning.

Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien entertained tonight with a dinner at Villa Del Sarmiento for the Duchess of Sutherland, Lady Margaret Egerton and-the Hon. Elizabeth Leveson Gower, house guests of Captain and Mrs. R. Amcotts Wilson. Milton W. Holden of New York is with Mr. and Mrs. O'Brien before opening his home.

THE outstanding characteristic of these forty new lyrics from the pen of Lindley Williams Hubbell is their carved chastity of line. Almost as monosyllabic as A. E. Housman, Mr. Hubbell is nevertheless no imitator of the Shropshire poet.

A week of uncertainty as to developments at the Lima conference on the question of women's rights has left the five national women's organizations favoring protective legislation studying new strategies as they prepare for the next session of Congress. The picture of conflicting forces manoeuvring at the Peruvian sessions has stirred both sides to the controversy in this country to an unprecedented degree.

DAR-ES-SALAM, Tanganyika.--An economic boycott of British shops and British goods exists here. It is not carried out in a violent or vituperative manner, but it is none the less effective.
Alterations have been started on the old-time five-story residence at 647 Fifth Avenue, which will transform that structure into a dignified but architecturally attractive commercial building.

IT may be remembered that some five years back Victor issued an album containing Stokowski's "symphonic synthesis" of "Tristan und Isolde." Realizing that so much orchestral glory lay between the usual prelude and Liebestod, the enterprising conductor decided that the concert hall might benefit by its use.

THE Prefaces which Miss Glasgow has provided for this collected edition of her work have a threefold value. They are, first of all, an illuminating commentary on the novels they introduce, and on the art of fiction itself;
THE historian of the British laborer has here done a masterly job on the relations of Gladstone to the Irish Home Rule movement. If his book is long, it tells a long story whose roots are deep.

Dr. Ralph L. Watts, dean of the School of Agriculture and director of the agricultural experiment station at the Pennsylvania State College since 1912, will retire on Jan. 1 as dean emeritus of the School of Agriculture.

Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont said in an interview here today that if the Republicans wanted to win the Presidency in 1940 they must push forward during the next two years with a liberal program that would draw labor and farm support.

After more than five years of work, complete data in the form of scale drawings, photographs and historical notes have been assembled in the Library of Congress on thousands of old structures throughout the country and will be preserved there for the enlightenment and inspiration of historians and architects of the future.

Solution of the mystery of the fuel supplying the sun with its enormous and inexhaustible supply of radiant energy, without which life on earth could not go on, was announced here today by Professor Hans Albrecht Bethe of Corrnell University, a leading theoretical physicist.

The Savage School basketball team easily turned back the New College quintet on the former's court last night, 48 to 28. Billino, with 12 points, was high scorer for the winners, who led at the half, 26 to 14.

While his wife and two children were out shopping for Christmas Edward F. Murphy, 40 years old, a WPA clerk, was burned to death early yesterday afternoon in the living-room of his three-room apartment at 1,646 Anthony Avenue, the Bronx, at the intersection of Anthony and Clay Avenues, near 173d Street.

The three-day sale at the ParkeBernet Galleries which ended yesterday afternoon netted $30,764.50, of which nearly half, $13,890.50, was realized at the final session. The sale included American, English and continental furniture and decorations.
Dr. Edith Summerskill, M. P., will arrive here on Thursday from England to appeal for funds for the children's cities to be built in Spain for the care of refugee children and war orphans.
The Roof of the Pierre was the setting last night for a small dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Witherbee Black for Mrs. Black's debutante daughter, Miss Ethelette Tucker.

Scant supplies of many types of desirable merchandise for immediate delivery will face many retailars who are preparing to enter the wholesale markets here for January sales goods after the wind-up of Christmas trade this week, a suryey here yesterday indicted.

Binnie Morison of this place has announced the marriage of his daughter, Miss Cristal Morison, to George Henry Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Baker of Deland, Fla., this morning in Caracas, Venezuela.

A five-day celebration of the seventy-eighth birthday of Henrietta Szold, founder of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization, began yesterday in forty-six States, national headquarters of the group announced here.

The Air Ministry has discovered that an aviation training manual, containing some of the most closely guarded secrets of British aircraft design, has been on public sale at the government's stationery office for several months.

A large list of box and ticket holders has been reported for the theatre benefit to be held the night of Dec. 29 under the auspices of the Edward MacDowell Association. Members of the sponsoring organization have taken over the performance of Thornton Wilder's play,

Family parties in country homes will be a feature of Christmas in North Shore society and, although many estate owners have been absent from their homes for several weeks, they will return for the holidays to be joined by various members of their families.

Edgar R. Patterson of Harrison, N. Y., president of Patterson Fabrics, Inc., of New York, died yesterday in Wickersham Hospital after a brief illness. He was 56 years old.

The passing of the deciduous leaf in Autumn brings on what might be drab days in a dead-looking earth at Christmas if it were not for nature's evergreen cheer leaders which keep the freshness of Spring and Summer glowing.

The very youthful Sons and Daughters of the Rainbow Division had their Christmas party yesterday afternoon in the warm, spacious Father Duffy Chapter Room of the 165th Regiment Armory at Lexington Avenue and Twentysixth Street.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Geneva Leach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic R. Leach of this place, to George A. Lynn of Montclair, son of Mr and Mrs. C. J. Lynn of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

George T. Weissbaum, the West Coast scrap metal dealer who bought the Sixth Avenue elevated structure from the city at public auction on Dec. 5, failed last night to meet Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick's midnight deadline for the payment of $80,000 cash and the posting of a $40,000 performance bond.

The peak of the year's retail trade was reached last week, and it fell short of a year ago in terms of dollar volume because of lower prices now prevailing. It seemed probable that unit volume for the country was ahead, but the emphasis upon gift purchasing in the lower brackets continued to trouble store executives.
Arriving here after an overnight sea journey on a small British coaster, I found Hainan's 13,000 square miles guarded by only 500 regulars and fewer than 20,000 ill-equipped militiamen.

Many women will make a determined attempt at the coming session of the General Court to prevent the passage of any legislation which would prohibit the employment of married women in the service of the State in case their husbands are employed. In the last session a bill of that nature failed, but in November attempts were made to put the voters on record against double employment.

The Stevens Tech basketball team won from Cathedral, 34-22, in a fast game at the William Hall Walker gymnasium today. Stevens broke through Cathedral's zone defense in the second period after trailing, 16--9, at the half, and rolled up 25 points to Cathedral's 6.

With the closing today of State and area offices of the American Re-Cross in New England, officials a regional headquarters here announced that 18,949 families, representing 83,241 individuals, had been assisted in rehabilitating themselves following the hurricane of Sept. 21, and the concurren floods.

The Westchester County penitentiary would require eight additional guards and construction of a new "escape-proof" wing if recommendations made recently by the State Commission of Correction were adopted, Warden Paul R. Brown said today.

The best field that has ever competed in the Ardsley Country Club's invitation tournament produced such sterling squash racquets that, almost invariably, favorites had to come from behind to keep from being toppled as the first round and quarter-final round were completed today.

A last-minute rush of telegraphic reorders last week indicated the usual pre-holiday spurt in retail sales, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. "Merchants expressed satisfaction with sales results,"

If Santa Claus comes around to see the Christmas floral display, at the New York Botanical Garden it is predicted that he will desert his North Pole home at once for a temperate region, just as he has in recent years deserted his reindeer in favor of an airplane.
A five-goal drive in the final period featured Princeton's 12-6 victory over the Essex Troop trio tonight at the Essex Troop Armory.

Worcester Polytechnic Institute will make available forty-five scholarships having a total value of $20,000 to promising students of the next entering class. This conforms strictly with the policy of the college to extend its scholarship asdistance without increasing freshman enrollment, limited several years ago to 180.

John L. Lewis, chairman of Labor's Nonpartisan League, announced today that the league would broaden its program, enter the Democratic Presidential primaries and seek the selection of delegates who would assure the nomination of "progressive candidates for the office of President and Vice President" at the 1940 Democratic National Convention.

Canada's exports to the United States in November amounted to $35,584,371, an increase of $4,295,872 from the $31,288,499 reported for November, 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Exports affected by the trade agreement between the countries amounted to $18,728,475, against $20,663,995 a year before.

Over a mysterious signature of three asterisks the Relazione Internazionale, generally regarded as the favorite magazine of Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, prints an editorial today in which for the first time the possibility is mentioned that war may in the end be appealed to as the supreme arbiter of the differences between Italy and France.

Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania denounced the spending of billions "to make the government all-powerful," and Admiral William H. Standley, U. S. N., retired, linked the British Navy with American defense plans in addresses at the fortieth annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.

The only girl in the College of Engineering at the University of Vermont is Kay Holden of this city. She is a freshman in civil engineering. Among the 126 men in the College of Engineering Miss Holden looks more like a student of home economics.

There are compelling reasons why it is essential at this time to consider an increase in the defensive forces of the United States. We are living in a new age of imperialism and we have our own interests to conserve in a disordered world.

On London's Park Lane, overlooking famous Hyde Park, haven for free speech, stands the modern and exclusive Grosvenor House Hotel. Famous among Londoners as a place to dine and dance, it achieved world prominence last week as the scene of an international incident involving Britain and Germany.
Material for the debate on the farm problem before the next Congress being supplied by the voting now being done by farmers in widely scattered parts of the country.

The cost of Germany's anti-Jewish excesses, not only in the destruction of property goods, of which Germany is already short, but also in the loss of foreign trade, is brought home to the German people by the November trade figures, issued today.

A. outdoor and indoor champion, won the open division team. honors for the second year in a row at the forty-first De La Salle Institute indoor interscholastic track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

PREPARATIONS are in progream in the little known interior of South America for a feast that not only coincides with Christmas but is imbued with much of the Christian spirit, though the people partaking of it are pure pagans.
The four-story garage at 162-174 Christopher Street and 130-142 Barrow Street will be sold on Thursday in the Vesey Street rooms by Henry Brady.

Robert Virovai, the young Hungarian violinist whose recent American debut with the PhilharmonicSymphony was as close to a sensa tion as the season has offered, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

Lou Nova has no intention of taking a long lay-off from boxing, despite the fact that he has ascended to a position of importance in the heavyweight division by virtue of his convincing triumph over Tommy Parr at Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

Members of North Shore society who follow the fox and drag hounds are in the midst of one of the most active seasons in many years, and, except for a few days in November when the snow was too deep in the valleys of the woodland estates, they have hunted three times a week and are continuing the sport through the Christmas holidays when house guests will be added to the field.

A well dressed man carefully deposited 200 stamped and addressed envelopes in the waste paper box in Fountain Square.

William J. Allen Jr. has been elected president of the newly formed Green Acres Civic Association and will serve a term of one year. Elected with Mr. Allen were William MacMullen, vice president; R. E. Palmer, treasurer, and Jack Tartikoff, secretary.

Miss Helen Stewart Higgins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reyburn Alvin Higgins, was married this afternoon at the home here of her parents to William Chastain Shelton, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Shelton of Chevy Chase, D. C.

Mr. and Mrs. Leigh Chandler of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Anne Howard Chandler, to Bruce Duncan Nichols, son of Mrs. E. Remington Nichols of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Nichols.

The opening this Fall of the Nursery School-Parent Education Center at Bennett College in Greensboro, one of two liberal arts colleges exclusively for the education of Negro women in the United States, marked the beginning of scientific training for the Negro pre-school child in North Carolina.

TO those with only a casual interest in the screen the mystery surrounding Selznick-International's inability to find a suitable actress for the role of Scarlett O'Hara in "Gone With the Wind" has been difficult to understand.

Silver and green were the predominating colors in the floral decorations for the coming-out party last night of Miss Elaine Storrs Frueauff. A supper dance was given in the ballroom of the Pierre by the debutante's mother, Mrs. Frank Wheatcroft Frueauff.
It begins to look as though the annual hibernations of Arthur (Turkey) Gehrke, heavyweight 56-year-old tavern keeper, are at an end.

The marriage of Miss Mary Margaret Culbertson, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Means Culbertson of Coconut Grove and the late Mr. Culbertson, to Dr. Preston Watters, son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Watters, also of Coconut Grove, took place in Plymouth Congregational Church this afternoon.

Marina Yurlowa, Russian dancer of Spanish dances, gave a recital at Carnegie Hall last night for the benefit of German refugees. The performance was sponsored by B'nai Brith Lodge No. 1 in association with Bishop William T. Manning as chairman of the AllReligious Committee.

What does the political future hold in store for New York's Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia when his term ends in 1940? The Mayor intimates he hasn't got time to think about it because running New York City is a twenty-fourhour-a-day job.

George Dietrich, brother of F. Donald Coster, president of the McKesson Robbins drug firm, was questioned for several hours today by Thomas J. Dodd, special assistant to the United States Attorney General, and by Arthur J. Gorman of this city, assistant United States attorney for New Haven.

A large attendance of young people, who have returned to their homes in Westchester and Connecticut for the Christmas recess, is expected at the annual Holiday Dance under the direction of Mrs. Graham T. Johnston, which will take place at the Wee Burn Club here on Dec. 28.

Funeral services were held for Armando Novello, famous as "Toto the Clown," at 2:30 P. M. today at the funeral chapel of Gehlert Neslage here in the presence of 100 mourners, including many of his associates on the stage and in the circus.

Announcement has beep made of the engagement of Miss Gertrude M. Eagan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Eagan of Brooklyn, to Dr. Walter Luke Willigan, son of Mrs. Luke Willigan of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Willigan.

Major Generar Sir Frederick Maurice, former president of the British Legion, in a speech at Durham today in which he alluded to the legion's efforts for many years to create good understanding with Germany, declared that recently there had been natural expressions of indignation at the treatment of the Jews in Germany.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Church Tompkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stuart Tompkins of New York, to Douglas Houston Kenyon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan D. Kenyon of Belle Terre. L. I., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

THE Music Teachers National Association will hold its sixtieth convention, Dec. 27-30, at the Hotel Mayflower, Washington, D. C. In connection with the convention, meetings also will be held by the National Association of Schools of Music, the American Musicological Society and the Phi Mu Alfa (Sinfonia).
The British Government was reported tonight to have made a start with its proposals for assisting China to purchase British goods.

In many a garden where the hardy perennials and bulbs are carefully protected for the Winter, shrubs, evergreens and other large plants are left to shift for themselves, even though many of them may actually be in more need of protection than their much smaller relatives.

One of the outstanding industrial developments of 1938 has been the completion of 454 and the commencement of construction of sixtyone by-product coke ovens by the steel industry alone, with prospects that 1939 and ensuing years may witness further additions fully as extensive.

The women's committee recently recommended to the executive board of the United States Golf Association that the yardage for women's par should be changed in order to raise the standard of women's golf for the future.
Two Breton autonomists, Who pleaded guilty to charges of attempting to separate the western peninsula of Brittany from France, were sentenced today to one Year and fined 2,000 francs.

TAKEN from nearly 200 languages, about 26,000 of the world's best and most interesting proverbs are here gathered together in most easily available arrangement by an editor who has been working for more than twenty-five years on his task.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. David Stewart Craven of Salem, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Goodwin Craven, to Julien Jaquelin Mason Jr., son of Mrs. Julien Jaquelin Mason of Washington and the late Mr. Mason.
EARLIER this year THE TIMES had occasion to discuss, and incidentally to oppose, two bills for a Federal bureau of fine arts that were put before Congress.

Although there is little likelihood of any change in the present tax upon undistributed earnings of corporations before the measure terminates by statutory limitation at the close of 1939, public agitation for its annulment is current.

It long has been the boast of the automotive industry's leading executives that their business, while first to feel the effects of any economic disturbance, is also first to recover from it and that it usually "leads the way back to prosperity."
An ill lighthouse keeper, marobned for seven days in a tower off the British coast, was rescued today with the aid of - a breeches buoy.

TWO developments in Southern California aviation last week hastened the day of feeder airlines, profitable short hauls and faster, more economical transportation between hitherto minor mail-passenger cities.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to reconsider its devision of last July establishing an eight-cent fare on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad between Hudson Terminal, New York, and Jersey City and Hoboken.

Hunter College freshmen improve more than 15 per cent in reading ability after a required six months' orientation course, according to a report made by the Educational Guidance Bureau of Hunter yesterday.

SOUTHERN PINES, N. C.--Marking the holidays here, the program of sports for the next two weeks will be the most interesting in years, with golf, hunting, gymkhanas and hunter trials taking the lead in the field of outdoor activities.

Up in the wintry Vermont hills, flanked by the Green Mountains and the Taconic Range, Bennington College faces the annual exodus of its more than 250 girl students for two months of field and reading activities.

The centenary of "the great trek" of Boers from British rule into lands beyond the Orange River culminated at Pretoria yesterday with the laying of the foundation stone of a great national monument to those who, after years of suffering, established themselves on the plains that later became Transvaal Republic and Orange Free State.

The cashier, assistant cashier and a teller of the Ventnor City National Bank of Ventnor, N. J., near here, were arrested at the bank late today on charges that through a conspiracy they embezzled at least $25,000 of the bank's funds during the last three years.
The Yale varsity sextet swamped the Eli alumni tonight before 2,000 spectators, 7 to 2. The battle was close in the early periods, but four goals in the final chapter decided for the varsity.

The Keuka College Biology Department has received a gift of an herbarium of 5,000 specimens from Mrs. G. P. Van Eseltine, widow of the botanist of the-State Agricultural Experimental Station at Geneva.
Mayor La Guardia. returned to the city yesterday from New Orleans, a day ahead of schedule. Arriving at Pennsylvania Station at 9:15 A. M., he went to City Hall and Mrs. La Guardia went home.

When the ship that makes the overnight run from the Hook of Holland to Harwich comes through the smoking mists to her dock nowadays she often carries in addition to the business men who must make that weary trip a pathetic cargo of children.

Paul Copples of Atlantic City and Tony di Tomo of Vineland paired today to give an All-South Jersey high school team a 7 to 6 victory over an All-Philadelphia eleven in a first annual scholastic football game for charity.

The marriage of Miss Jean Hurwitz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter C. Hurwitz of 310 West Eighty-sixth Street, to Maurice Wellner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Wellner, also of this city, will take place this afternoon at the home of the bride-elect's parents. The Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein will perform the ceremony.

As a stimulus to interest of students Dr. Gabriella Bosano, Professor of Italian Literature and chairman of the Department of Italian at Wellesley College, frequently holds her classes in the Plimpton Room of the college library.
BRUSSELS. FROM April 29 to May 14, 1939, the Palais des Beaux Arts, in Brussels, will house an international phonographic exposition.

The question of controlling or greatly reducing the volume of interbank deposits, which has been cropping up recurrently for more than a year whenever banking "reforms" are discussed, came in for new and agitated comment last week.
Hundreds of boys of high school and college ages have set themselves the task of arousing Argentina's 12,000,000 people to "the perils of Yankee imperialism."

Shooting for Christmas turkeys featured the program at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Tracy H. Lewis and Roger Fawcett were the high guns, each breaking 98 out of 100 for the honor of picking the first bird. On a toss, the choice went to Lewis. There were thirty prizes in all.

The Navy Department announced today that the annual fleet manoeuvres which would be held in the Atlantic next year were designed for one major purpose-"to afford the maximum amount of fleet training, training of personnel and tests of material" under all conditions of weather and sea.

Stuyvesant's basketball team defeated the Haaren quintet, 25 to 17, in a Lower Manhattan Division P. S. A. L. contest played on the victors court yesterday. The triumph was the second in three league starts for Stuyvesant,

THERE are few men better fitted by knowledge and experience to discuss the illustrated book than the learned curator of prints of the New York Public Library, Dr. Frank Weitenkampf. He has written much on the graphic arts and has under his thumb the vast resources of one of the greatest of libraries.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gave tonight her sixth "Gridiron Widows Party," entertaining at the White House the wives of members and guests of the Gridiron Club and other women in and out of official life who neither may belong to nor attend the dinners given by that organization of newspaper men.

With the recent opening of the Joseph H. Pratt Diagnostic Hospital of the New England Medical Center, the Tufts Medical School, the teaching base for the center, will extend its facilities to the general practioners of New England by broadening its post graduate program.

Hard-headed business men are finding it increasingly to their advantage to turn to colleges for the solution for their research problems, according to Fred J. Sievers, director of the experiment station at Massachusetts State College.
England, France, Holland and Belgium are the markets in which American importers will concentrate their search for new sources of supply next year, foreign traders agreed yesterday.

THE greater part of the space in this volume is devoted to the political cartoon, and rightly so, for not only have many of the cartoons reproduced here helped to make history, but this form of graphic humor was the first to arrive at maturity in this country.

Indications that the United States Housing Authority, administered by Nathan Straus, plans to continue indefinitely asking Congress for funds to finance slum-clearance and lowcost housing projects received a measure of confirmation today with issuance by the Authority of an eighty-eight-page booklet entitled "What the Housing Act Can Do for Your City."

Frank E. Vitolo, who was with the architectural firm of Robert D. Kohn and Charles Butler of 56 West Forty-fifth Street for the last twenty years, died Friday night in his home, 4,707 Delafield Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. His age was 51.

The New York and Richmond Gas Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration in connection with reduction of the capital represented by the company's 150,000 outstanding shares of no-par common stock from $1,500,000 to $850,000 to make adjustments of accounts to meet requirements of the New York Public Service Commision.
Instructions on how to celebrate Christmas in an acceptable Nazi fashion have gone forth from various cultural departments of the National Socialist regime.

Gerald Shattuck, president of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, operator of Schrafft's stores, announced yesterday that more than $135,000 would be paid as extra compensation to all employes who had been with the company since Jan. 1, 1938, amounting to a full week's pay for each. Other employes will receive candy.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt were invited yesterday, with Governor Lehman, to become the first policyholders of savings bank life insurance in this State. The invitation was extended by Paul R. Taylor,

As a business barometer, the annual Christmas seal sale for the State outside of New York City indicates improvement over 1937, members of the State Charities Aid Association committee on tuberculosis and public health reported at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

The increasingly successful operation of the selective process of admission to the' Columbia University Law School is reflected in the fact that the present first-year class entered with the best academic records of any group since the process was adopted eleven years ago, the school's committee on selection of students reported yesterday to Dean Young B. Smith.

JAMES BRIDIE" of Glasgow is becoming a national institution. "The King of Nowhere" was first produced at the Old Vic in London, stronghold of Shakespeare; this is a unique distinction for a contemporary dramatist.

St. George Henry Rathborne, who, under a variety of pen names, wrote seventy novels and 250 books for boys, died here last night in the Presbyterian Hospital after a year of failing health. On Dec. 26 he would have been 84 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Carney of Boston and Osterville have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Frances Carney, to Lieutenant John H. Theis, U. S. N., son of the late Lieutenant John E. Theis, U. S. N., and the late Mrs. Theis.
The sum of #33,676 was realized by the three-day auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, which closed yesterday afternoon with the last session bringing $16,125.
To one who, like Oliver J. Caldwell, vriting in THE TIMES of Dec. 4, has spent some time in the Orient and has given serious thought to present happenings there, Mr. Caldwell's article is heartening.
A revised edition of Uncle Sam's best seller has recently come off the presses of the Government Printing Office in Washington.

The increasingly successful operation of the selective process of admission to the' Columbia University Law School is reflected in the fact that the present first-year class entered with the best academic records of any group since the process was adopted eleven years ago, the school's committee on selection of students reported yesterday to Dean Young B. Smith.

JAMES BRIDIE" of Glasgow is becoming a national institution. "The King of Nowhere" was first produced at the Old Vic in London, stronghold of Shakespeare; this is a unique distinction for a contemporary dramatist.

St. George Henry Rathborne, who, under a variety of pen names, wrote seventy novels and 250 books for boys, died here last night in the Presbyterian Hospital after a year of failing health. On Dec. 26 he would have been 84 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Carney of Boston and Osterville have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Frances Carney, to Lieutenant John H. Theis, U. S. N., son of the late Lieutenant John E. Theis, U. S. N., and the late Mrs. Theis.
The sum of #33,676 was realized by the three-day auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, which closed yesterday afternoon with the last session bringing $16,125.
To one who, like Oliver J. Caldwell, vriting in THE TIMES of Dec. 4, has spent some time in the Orient and has given serious thought to present happenings there, Mr. Caldwell's article is heartening.
A revised edition of Uncle Sam's best seller has recently come off the presses of the Government Printing Office in Washington.
The broad question of complete equality in civil and political rights for women appeared about to intrude on the Pan-American Conference today, despite strong efforts to keep it out.

RARELY does Hollywood devote itself to a feature length motion picture which has as its hero a holiday. The reasons-distribution and play dates being such important factors in the financial success of a film-are easily discernible.

The Federal Power Commission announced today the receipt of an application for authority to sell practically all of the operating facilities of the Orange Rockland Electric Company of New Jersey to the Rockland Electric Company for $255,877.
Archie Compston has found a man with "the perfect putter." He is Professor A. M. Low, whose putter is fitted with a delicate red light.

The United States is a religious country at heart, said the Rev. Dr. 1 Norman Vincent Peale yesterday in his sermon as pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Twenty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.

There is a good deal of confusion regarding Santa Claus in a city as large as this, and well there might be, with character actors in red suits and false whiskers popping up on every street corner and in every department store.

Spurred by evidence that the unmasking of F. Donald Coster, the ex-convict president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., occurred at a time when he was in the midst of a deal in embargoed arms and ammunition, Federal authorities determined yesterday to concentrate their inquiry on that phase during the coming week.

The Budapest Quartet made its Mu, first appearance in the current series of concerts of the New Friends last of Music late yesterday afternoon, where they were heard in two quartets by Haydn, the Opus 33, No. 2, and the Opus 77, No. 1.

The German wholesale price index on Dec. 14 stood at 106.4, against 106.3 a week before. In the first eleven months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 106.3 on Nov. 23. The lowest was 105.3, in the first two weeks June.

The employment policies of the steel mills have kept on the payrolls about 155,000 more wage-earners than would have been the case if employment in the industry had dropped as sharply as output, according to estimates by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Formation of a special committee of Catholic college students to assist the committee for Catholic refugees from Germany, of which the Rev. Joseph D. Ostermann is chairman, was announced yesterday by the National Federation of Catholic College Students.

Dr. and Mrs. Hubert V. Guile of 37 East Sixty-fourth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Vivian Guile, to Dr. Archer Cornelius Springsted of Garden City, L. I., son of Dr. and Mrs. James W. Springsted of Brooklyn and Port Washington, L. I.

Subscriptions at par and accrued interest for approximately $50,000,000 of Series B 1% per cent notes of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the capital stock of which is owned by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, were invited today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC.
Miss Madeline Ritt, daughter of Lieut. Commander Charles C. Ritt and Mrs. Ritt of the submarine base at Coco Solo was married here yesterday to Aviation Cadet Neil Claibourne Porter, U. S. N. R.,

Pierre and Mme. Joly Brunet of France, erstwhile Olympic and world pair skating champions, gave their first exhibition in New York as a professional team yesterday at a private session of the Skating Club at the Iceland rink atop Madison Square Garden.
The New York Rangers found the Black Hawks red hot tonight and went down before a 5-to-0 barrage of goals at the Chicago Stadium.

The "elections" for the Slovak Diet were held today on the approved fascist model. Only one party-the Hlinka party-was allowed to present candidates and opposition to it could only be expressed by handing in blank ballots. The balloting was secret,

The Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, replied yesterday to John Haynes Holmes, who had criticized his views on the Spanish situation last week In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Those members of the board of directors of the Bank of Spain living in Franco territory held a meeting at Santander today under the presidency of Antonio Giocoechea, and with the permission of the Insurgent Finance Minister, after which it was announced that more than 1,000 shareholders, each representing fifty or more shares, were actually represented at the meeting.

Martha Fleischman, formerly of Kirby, Block Co., has been appointed buyer of jewelry, accessories and neckwear for William M. Van Buren, resident buyer. Walter Johns has joined the rayon women's wear division of Pacific Mills.

Kirsten Flagstad, noted Wagnerian soprano of the Metropolitan E Opera Association, was the guest iof honor last night at a dinner of The Bohemians, a musical organization of men, in honor of the twenty-fifth anniversary of her debut in grand opera.

At memorial services this afternoon in the auditorium of Children's Village, Edmond Dwight, for eighteen years president and fortyeight years a director of the Village, was eulogized for his contributions to humanity and work for poor q children.

Ellen Glasgow, novelist, and Thornton Wilder, novelist and playwright, have been elected members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters to fill the two remaining vacancies in its membership, which is limited to fifty. Only members of the National Institute of Arts and Letters are eligible for membership in the academy.

Miss Dorothy Young, a niece of Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, made her first public address as an evangelist last evening. She wee preached in the Broadway Temple feel Methodist Church at 174th Street and and Broadway, of which the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner is pastor, on "The Quest for Peace."
Secretary. Ickes said tonight he felt that any American who accepted a decoration from a dictator "automatically foreswears his American birthright."
A plot. 100 by 82 feet at the northwest corner of Seventy-sixth Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Mary Walsh to Woodside Estates, Inc., builders.

Admitted assets of the State Insurance Fund are about $50,000,000, the largest in the organization's history and about two and a half times the amount held five years ago, Major Nicholas W. Muller, executive director of the fund, announced yesterday.

The Aetna Fire Insurance Company and its subsidiary, the World Fire and Marine Insurance Company, soon will establish a complete Canadian department at Toronto, according to W. Ross McCain, president.

Voluntary submission to the tax provisions of the State Unemployment Insurance Law by the GreenWood Cemetery, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, will give its 400 employes protection against joblessness, Allan S. Haywood, Regional Director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday.

The Anglo California National Bank announced plans today for increasing its capital stock through the sale to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $8,000,000 in new preferred stock. The bank called a meeting of the stockholders for Dec. 28 to authorize the proposal.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederic C. Pitcher of Ridgewood, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Coramae Pitcher, to Thomas Arner Herbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Herbert of Maplewood, N. J.

Gloom, hell-fire and damnation have no part in true religion, the Very Rev. Nicholas Higgins, Guardian of St. Francis Friary, Providence, R. I., declared yesterday in his final Advent sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Larry Reybine and Eddie Maxwell were models of consistency in the dinghy sailing at the Larchmont Yacht Club today to produce the somewhat unusual result of a tie for first place in the standing.

The engagement of Miss Eleanor Haggerty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Haggerty of Potsdam, to John McGowan Shells, son of Judge William J. Shells, former Surrogate of Westchester County, and Mrs. Shells of New Rochelle and Carmel, has been announced by her parents.

Paris was short of taxicabs this afternoon while the Grand Duke Vladimir received homage as the head of the house of Romanoff from the local Russian colony because all the Russian former Princes and former generals who have been forced to earn their living as taxicab drivers took time out to pay obeisance to "His Majesty Vladimir II, Czar of All the Russias."
Sheikh Said el Khatib, a priest of the Mosque of Omar, was shot dead by Arabs in the Old City of Jerusalem this morning.

The Vienna Choir Boys and Anita words Zahn's 'Little Duncan Dancers titled shared the program last night at Town Hall. It was given under the auspices of the Educational Fund Flags, of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association.

Financial sentiment here appears to be undergoing a slight but definite change for the better. The City has given up clutching at straws and is fastening onto factors of a more concrete nature, or what it considers to be more worthy of consideration.

Three hundred Boy Scouts from the five boroughs will spend the Christmas holidays in camp at Ten Mile River, N. Y., 100 miles above y the city. the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York announced yesterday.
The General Motors-Cornell world price index of forty basic commodities declined 0.1 point for the week ended on Dec. 10, returning again to the thirty-year low of 60.4 set two weeks previously.
Following is the text of the address delivered today at the Pan-American Conference by Alfred M. Landon, member of the United States deleation:

Although no authentic information about Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's London mission is obtainable officially here, its essential aims were indicated clearly in the pronouncements in German publications that customarily voice official opinion.

The United States should prohibit sending dollars from the country in settlement of German estates since Nazi Germany retains inheritances due to heirs abroad and the "only language the Nazis understand is the language of reciprocity," Gerhart Seger, member of the German Reichstag from 1930 to 1933 and now editor of the Neue Volkszeitung of New York, told the Town Hall of Washington tonight.

Aside from the United States Army stores, 'the only sources for such large numbers of rifles as have been mentioned in connection with the investigation of F. Donald Coster, the fictitiously named president of McKesson Robbins, Inc.,

A spirit of thoughfulness and understanding must be behind giving to make Christmas a season of joy, said the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church at Wall Street and Broadway in a sermon yesterday morning. Dr.
The Canadian salmon pack for the season up to Nov. 11, 1938, showed an increase of 14 per cent over the preceding year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Mariana Sarrica, 19-year-old New York pianist, who made her debut at Town Hall two years ago, gave a second recital yesterday afternoon in the same auditorium.
Production of steel in the current month to date generally is less than in November, following the pattern of eleven of the last fifteen years.

As these columns said on Nov. 20, only to be disputed by a Theatre Guild spokesman, the Herman Shumlin production of "The Merchant of Yonkers" will be offered to Guild subscribers on the usual subscription basis.
The Yale Dramatic Association presents at 8:45 this evening and tomorrow a musical satire, "1066And All That," at the Windsor Theatre. It is a dramatization of the book by W. C. Sellar and R. J.

The marriage of Miss Mildred Feinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Feinberg of 910 West End Avenue, to Dr. Samuel Blumgarten of this city took place yesterday at noon in the Feinberg home. The Rev. Dr. Elias L. Solomon performed the ceremony.

Behind, 2-1, entering the final period, the league-leading New York Rovers came up with two goals to down the stubborn Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 2, in an Eastern Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

With the annual Christmas promotion list in the Police Department to be announced tomorrow night at ceremonies at the 165th Regiment Armory, Twenty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue, rumors of other impending changes in high offices were heard at headquarters yesterday.

Huaracha Duchicela, 26, "The Inca of America," according to his own claim, and head of the Inca Monarchist party here, has sent to the Lima conference a program for the restoration of the Inca empire with himself as emperor.

Hunter Lott Jr. of the Kenwood Country Club, Philadelphia, successfully defended his Ardsley Club invitation squash racquets laurels by conquering the national champion, Germain G. Glidden of the Harvard Club, in four desperately fought games, 15-14, 15-11, 10-15, 15-10, as the seventh annual tonurament closed today.
Joseph Fishbach, top-seeded player and defending champion, triumphed as the metropolitan junior indoor tennis singles tournament began on the Hamilton courts at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.

Atheists are working hard to make this the most godless Christmas Soviet Armenians ever have had. The new ??er Communist, published in Erivan, capital of the Armenian Republic, reported with satisfaction today that never has there been a better year for godlessness in that section of Soviet Russia.

One of the largest properties to come under a single agency management in some time will be handled by Byrne Bowman, Inc. They have been appointed managing agents of nineteen buildings on the east side of Lexington Avenue, comprising the block front from Forty-sixth to Forty-seventh Streets.
Princeton oarsmen have petitioned the university council on athletics for permission to enter the Poughkeepsie Regatta on the Hudson, it was announced today.

The importance of religious training for the young and the need for spiritual leadership in the community were stressed last night at the seventeenth annual Hanukkah dinner of the Jewish Education Association, at the Hotel Commodore. Hanukkah, or the Feast of Lights, is observed by Jews everywhere in commemoration of the victory 2,000 years ago of the Maccabees over the oppressor, Antiochus IV, Emperor of Syria.

Field Marshal Hermann Goering, to whom have been entrusted many of Germany's high diplomatic missions, will go to Italy to meet Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Viscount Halifax, British Foreign Secretary, when they visit Premier Benito Mussolini from Jan. 11 to 14, according to an article printed in The Daily Herald this morning.

The State has put a halt to efforts by WVPA workers who are able to complete their monthly working schedule in ten days or two weeks to get unemployment insurance for weeks in which they do not work, it became known yesterday.
Fiscal revenues in October were 5,427,000,000 francs, an increase of 1,177,000,000 compared with the same month in 1937.
Supply contracts valued at $27,404,522 were awarded during the week ended Dec. 10 by eleven-Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

As the culmination of a gradual change in policy since 1927, the Brooklyn Hebrew Orphan Asylum, oldest and largest child-caring agency in the borough, will discontinue institutionalized care for dependent children on Jan. 1, and abandon its building at 373 Ralph Avenue 'next July 1. Henceforth, the institution will specialize in placement of orphaned children in private foster homes.

Mrs. Alfred W. Paine of New York and Archibald G. Thacher Jr. of the Rockaway, Hunting Club today won the annual invitation mixed doubles squash racquets tournament at Sleepy Hollow for the third straight year, defeating Miss Margaret Bostwick and Brainerd H. Whitbeck Jr. of the Bronxville Field Club in a grueling final, 15-10, 12-15, 15-9, 13--15, 15-12.

Close-range destruction of does and fawns as small as forty pounds, I among other violations of the State's hunting code, and twenty arrests occurred in connection with the opening of the deer season in New Jersey, it became known yesterday.

Today's events: "Rosenkavaller," Metropolitan Opera, evening; Philharmonic-Symphony pension concert, Carnegie Hall, evening; Yoicha Hiraoka, xylophonist, Town Hall, evening; Dr. Erich Schwebsch, lecturer, Steinway Hall, 8:30; Don Cossack Chorus, John Wanamaker's, 6 Sam Morgenstern, lecturer,
Miss Elisabeth Mary Heinzelmann and James Lyle Phillips will be marrted here on Jan. 7 in Christ Church by the Rev. Harold F. Hohly.

Brokers on the Board of Trade here who bought corn futures recently in anticipation of a revival in the European demand generally sold out last week when the inquiries failed to broaden materially. This had a depressing effect on the market, as did increased receipts from the country.

The newspaper Excelsior yesterday stressed editorially that the PanAmerican Conference at Lima was showing Europe that many countries were able to maintain good relations without attempts to devour each other.

Prague was told to cease its activities against Poland and warned to stop encouraging anti-Polish activities -by Ukrainian emigres, the press here said today. This, the press asserted, was the purpose of representations made in the Czech capital Friday and announced here today.

Five new marks for the season were established yesterday as St. Francis Prep and St. John's Prep scored victories in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association dual meet swimming series at the Columbus Club pool in Brooklyn.
Henry Spalding, attorney, Union League member and former chairman of the board of governors of the Philadelphia Bar Association, died yesterday in Abington Memorial Hospital. He was 64 years old.
The Nebraska Public Hydro District's first deal for private electric companies in their effort to form a "little TVA" has been announced.

A boycott by Latin America of the German merchant marine is advocated today by the Prensa Libre in an editorial that warns that the entire continent is threatened by economic penetration and armed attack from the totalitarian governments.

Charles R. Rogers, independent producer, has just completed negotiations with the Hull House Association for exclusive rights to utilize their records and photograph their establishment for a film life of Jane Addams.

THE three of them--Bill Terry, Pie Traynor and Casey Stengel--made a strange group as they sat quietly round a table off in a corner, imbibing refreshments after an arduous day pounding the Waldorf lobby during the recent major-league conclaves. For the present they seemed glad to be away from it all, yet they kept right on talking baseball.

Mr. Van Wyck Brooks, with whom so many of us have toured literary New England, has got another medal. Himself a critic, he could face without fear fifty other members of that once rhadamanthine but now benigner tribe.

102d St, 73 W, Central Savings Bank to Solsleg Realty Corp, 872 Columbus Ave ($18). 122d St, 238-40 E, Thomas A. Morrow to Kosower Estates, Inc, 1,450 B'way; purchase money mtg $5,500 ($6.50). 123d St, 123 W, Helen A. Markham to Joseph A. Duross, 158 W 81st St; mtg $4,000, not to merge in fee (50c).

The Comite Pro-Cuba, in accord- ane ance with its custom of celebrat- pea ing "Thanksgiving Day" on the next to the last Sunday of each year, held a semi-military ceremony to yesterday in the Roman Catholic -a] Church of Our Lady of Esperanza, 624 West 156th Street.

Plans are rapidly being completed for the Parade of Progress of Nationally Known Grocery Products, which will be conducted by manufacturers and distributors in 1939, according to Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, which is sponsoring the program.

Executive employes of the Long Island State Park Commission gave an informal party at the administration building today in celebration of the fiftieth birthday of Robert Moses, head of the commission, the State Council of Parks and the New York City Department of Parks.

Inventory reserves accumulated in 1933, 1934 and 1935 permitted Swift Co. to pay dividends of $1.20 a share, or 4.8 per cent, in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 29, according to the annual report signed by John Holmes, president of the company.

The Archbishop of York and the Bishops of Chichester, Bradford and Bristol, together with representative laymen and other clergy of the Church of England, have assured their Jewish fellow-countrymen that they deplore anti-Semitism as "a wicked folly utterly opposed to the spirit and letter of the teaching of our Lord."

Finding of an empty damaged motor boat today caused police to fear that Charles S. Rye, 50, a United States Steel Corporation official from Elmhurst, Ill., and his 6-year-old daughter, Dorothy, had been drowned in Biscayne Bay.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Putnam of Boston and Manchester, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Putnam, to John MacDougall Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelley Graham of this city.

The revival of Beethoven's "Fidelio," with Kirsten Flagstad, and the season's first performances of "Haensel und Gretel" and "Lakme" are features of the sixth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning next Monday. Richard Bonelli will make his first appearance as Iago in "Otello."

Dr. F. T. Schlesinger is leading in the annual competition for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club with a score of 4 1/2 -- 2 1/2 Other leading scorers are S. Bernstein and Milton Hanauer, 4-2; H. Seidman and Matthew Green, 3 1/2 --1 1/2; K. Darby, 3-3; A. E. Santasiere, 3 1/2-3 1/2; F. Reinfeld, 3--4; S. Bruzza, 2-3.

A book "intended to expose the purposes of National Socialist propaganda outside the Reich," published under the sponsorship of a group of prominent citizens, including Nicholas Murray Butler, Felix Frankfurter, Monsignor Ryan and Henry L.
John Exton Thropp, Trenton industrialist and banker, died in his home here last night after a twoyear illness. His age was 56.

Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Ainsworth Eyre will give a dinner in the Persian Room of the Plaza on Wednesday for Miss Hilda Holloway, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Holloway. Miss Holloway made her debut in September at a dance at Foxland, the home of her parents in Old Westbury.
